description: Not ready to let Twitter tip you over into typing rapid-fire thoughts while sucking your brain out? It's O.K. to sign up and just listen. Chances are good many people whose opinions you care about are already on Twitter, so just follow them. And here's a list of others, with an emphasis on those who bring the funny and a caveat that I'm avoiding mentioning people I know personally or who work at The New York Times, a group that includes

title: What to Expect as T.S.A. Tightens Airport Security
description: The best way to prepare for the new security measures at the airport? Pretty much as you did for the old rules, experts say.

title: U.S. Lawyers Knew About Legal Pitfalls in Blackwater Case
description: WASHINGTON  The sudden blow to the case against the former Blackwater security guards over a shooting that killed 17 Iraqis and wounded at least 20 may have come as a surprise to the public in Iraq and the United States, but the legal problem that the judge cited Thursday when he threw out the indictments was obvious to American government lawyers within days of the shooting.

title: James L. Goddard, Crusading F.D.A. Leader, Dies at 86
description: Dr. James L. Goddard, who as a brash, crusading commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration in the 1960s helped revolutionize the federal governments methods of evaluating drugs, died Dec. 18 in Laguna Woods, Calif. He was 86.

title: British House Prices Rose in December
description: British house prices rose for an eighth straight month in December as a scarcity of homes for sale and signs that the economy was emerging from the worst recession on record pushed up prices, the Nationwide Building Society said. The average cost of a home increased 0.4 percent from the previous month, to 162,103 ($260,086), the mortgage lender said Thursday. Prices rose 5.9 percent from a year earlier. Home values are 12.2 percent lower than at their peak in October 2007. The restriction in supply meant that even a relatively modest pickup in demand was able to put upward pressure on house prices, Martin Gahbauer, Nationwides chief economist, said in a statement.

title: Contract Talks at Chilean Copper Mine Break Down
description: Union representatives for Codelcos Chuquicamata copper miners in Chile said that last-minute contract talks broke down, ending an effort to head off a strike set to begin on Monday. Negotiations had resumed on Friday, the last day of the current contract, according to a union official, Miguel Lopez. We are not going to sign today, Mr. Lopez said by telephone. We will just have to carry out the strike. Chuquicamata is part of the state-owned Codelcos Norte unit, which accounted for almost half of the companys copper output of 1.55 million metric tons in 2008. Codelco is one of the largest copper producers in the world. Worldwide production this year is estimated at 18.1 million tons, according to Barclays Capital.

title: U.S. to Investigate Trade Dispute Over LCD TVs
description: The Samsung Electronics Companys latest patent-infringement claims, which seek to block United States imports of LCD TVs made by the Sharp Corporation, will be investigated by a trade agency in Washington. The federal International Trade Commission said this week that it would investigate the complaint, which was filed Dec. 1. The case is part of an escalating two-year legal battle between the two companies over inventions used in liquid-crystal display televisions. The Samsung patents relate to the way LCD screens portray the black and white portion of images. Samsung is seeking to block imports of Sharp Aquos HDTVs made in Mexico. Samsung, based in Suwon, South Korea, won an earlier trade commission order banning Sharp televisions from the United States. That case is on appeal. Sharp continues to import its televisions, saying it has altered the product to avoid using the Samsung invention. Samsung says Sharp is flouting the trade commissions order. A commission judge, Paul Luckern, said he would hear arguments on the dispute in April and release his findings by July 19.

title: South Koreas Exports Surged Last Month
description: South Koreas exports increased in December at the fastest rate in 17 months, adding to signs that the countrys economy is recovering from the global recession. Overseas shipments gained 33.7 percent in December from a year earlier, to $36.2 billion, the Ministry of Knowledge Economy said Friday. That was more than the median 27.9 percent forecast in a Bloomberg News survey of 10 economists. Imports rose 24 percent, to $32.9 billion, for a trade surplus of $3.3 billion. For 2009, the countrys trade surplus reached a record $41 billion as imports dropped 25.8 percent while exports declined 13.8 percent, the ministry said in a statement. Exports to China, the biggest buyer of South Korean goods, surged 74.4 percent in the first 20 days of December, the ministrys report showed. Shipments to the United States rose 8.7 percent and shipments to Europe gained 49.4 percent over the same period. Shipments of semiconductors and display panel exports more than doubled last month, the government said. Petrochemical exports gained 61.1 percent.

title: Singapore Says Its Economy Is Set to Grow This Year
description: Singapores economy is improving after a volatile year in which it shrank for the first time since 2001, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, left, says. Gross domestic product fell 2.1 percent in 2009, Mr. Lee said in his New Year message on Thursday. The figure was in line with the government estimate for a contraction of 2 to 2.5 percent. The trade ministry forecasts that the economy will expand 3 to 5 percent in 2010, an estimate reiterated by Mr. Lee. Singapore joined other Asian nations in emerging from a global economic slump last year after the regions governments unveiled about $1 trillion in stimulus measures to spur growth. Still, a sluggish recovery in overseas demand for goods could moderate growth prospects in the coming months, the government said in November. The economy grew 3.5 percent in the fourth quarter from a year earlier, Mr. Lee said. That compares with the 3.8 percent median forecast of nine economists surveyed by Bloomberg News.

title: 31 Down: Dramatic Break
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Weve had a fair number of tough Saturday crosswords over the last few months, and todays offering does nothing to soften the curve. Robert H. Wolfe presents us with a mix of long entries, sly clues and some challenging vocabulary in a wide-open grid.

title: The Cost of High Anxiety About Flying
description: Everyone knows that flying in a plane is potentially dangerous  just as everyone knows that climbing Mount Everest is dangerous. What goes up must come down; and if you put yourself at a great height, you put yourself at risk of falling, though the odds of perishing in a plane crash are one in ten million, whereas for every ten Everest climbers who reach the peak, one dies ... a far less comfortable margin.

title: The Art of the Deal
description: THE squeeze is on. Museums everywhere are having trouble making ends meet, what with the overblown expansions theyve made, the decline in investment income and the steep drop-off in contributions from foundations and individuals. Many have cut staff, frozen pay, trimmed exhibition schedules and slowed or stopped acquisitions. For some, that may not be enough: the American Folk Art Museum, to cite one example, recently admitted that it isnt making debt payments.

title: Robinson Return Is Electric for Knicks
description: ATLANTA  Nate Robinson was on the court again Friday night, driving, dishing, occasionally bouncing and hooting if the mood struck. Whatever his transgressions were in December, they faded in the light of the new year.

title: To Three Siblings in Need, Opening Home and Heart
description: Lynette Byers was in her early 60s when she became a mother for the second time. She had been married, raised a son to adulthood, worked for years as a private pediatric nurse and lived in her Harlem apartment for decades when a scrawny 9-month-old named Curtis came into her life. He was sickly, and his mother could not care for him. He was not expected to live.

title: Ringing In 2010, Around the World
description: From Beijing to London, revelers around the globe said goodbye to the decade and welcomed in a new year.

title: A New Comptroller, Cheered by Asian-Americans Declaring a New Era
description: At 9:45 on Friday morning, just hours before he was to be sworn in as New York Citys comptroller, John C. Liu stood in the front yard of his house in Flushing, Queens.

title: The DNA Problem in American Spying
description: This time, at least, disaster was averted. But the parallels between Christmas Day and Sept. 11, 2001, were inescapable: a radical Islamist, an airplane, explosives that came close to destroying innocent lives.

title: The Courage to Use the China
description: My new year came ringing in with a bang, or maybe it was more like a crash.

title: A Last New Years Eve Toast for Tavern on the Green
description: It ended as it all began, in a rush of light. But even the brilliance of its mirrored corridors, twinkling trees and shimmering heirloom chandeliers could not avert the bankruptcy blackout of Tavern on the Green.

title: Lottery Numbers
In the Shadows, Day Laborers Left Homeless as Work Vanishes
description: Carlos Ruano was down to his last $50 when his landlord kicked him out in September because he could no longer pay rent. He sent the money to his wife and children in Guatemala and spent the night riding the E train, which has a nickname among his fellow day laborers in Woodside, Queens: hotel ambulante, Spanish for roving hotel.

title: Public Advocate Takes a Challenging Tone, and Thoughts of 2013 Are Near
description: Bill de Blasio began his term as New York Citys public advocate with a teasing question to a shivering crowd outside City Hall.

title: The New Katrina Flood: Hospital Liability
description: Three years before Hurricane Katrina inundated New Orleans, a senior executive at Pendleton Memorial Methodist Hospital assessed its vulnerability to the sort of flooding that had been long feared there.

title: The Family Bible Is a Guest for the Oath, but Not a Participant
description: A few hours before the inauguration on Friday, the mayors aides distributed an exhaustive description of the Bible that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg would use to take the oath of office.

title: In Real Estate Industry, Remembering a Year Worth Forgetting
description: Even the hardiest members of New York Citys real estate industry acknowledge that 2009 was a year of startling casualties. After the steady implosions of 2008, last year was practically a freefall, as the residential market, which had often been inflated by Wall Street bonuses, started to absorb the financial blows when bankers stopped buying up pricey apartments. Troubles have only just begun for developers and skyscraper owners as they struggle to finish projects that were planned in more prosperous times; in some cases, the owners may choose simply to abandon them. A roundup of the highs and lows:

title: Why Didnt They See It?
description: It will take some time before all the facts about the Christmas Day terrorism plot are known and analyzed. One thing is already clear: The government has to urgently improve its ability to use the reams of intelligence it receives every day on suspected terrorists and plots. That was supposed to have been addressed after the infamous failure to connect the dots before the 9/11 attacks. The echoes of the earlier disaster in this near-disaster are chilling.

title: Hands Off the Watershed
description: New York City has now officially registered its ringing opposition to a proposal by state regulators to allow natural gas drilling in the watershed that supplies drinking water to more than eight million city residents. Albany should amend its proposal and put the area permanently off limits to drilling.

title: Canadas Free Press
description: In a welcome move toward increased freedom of expression, the Supreme Court of Canada has issued two rulings that will give reporters a new legal defense for responsible communication.

title: Reason for Hope
description: Two-and-a-half years ago, Michael Ragusa was 13 years old when he was in a car accident that left him with more than two dozen skull fractures. Medically, there is no hope, one doctor warned his mother, Anne Wollman.

title: How Hospitals Care for the Dying
description: To the Editor:

title: Candidate for Sainthood: Pius XIIs Wartime Record
description: To the Editor:

title: Help for Young Researchers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Nation of Do-It-Yourself Lawyers
description: AMERICAS courts are built on a system of rules and procedures that assume that almost everyone who comes to court has a lawyer. Unfortunately, the reality is quite different. An increasing number of civil cases go forward without lawyers. Litigants who cannot afford a lawyer, and either do not qualify for legal aid or are unable to have a lawyer assigned to them because of dwindling budgets, are on their own  pro se. Whats more, theyre often on their own in cases involving life-altering situations like divorce, child custody and loss of shelter.

title: Real Estate in Cape Coral Is Far From a Recovery
description: CAPE CORAL, Fla.

title: Buying a Share of Victory. Or Not.
description: How do you pay for a war? The question re-emerged in Congress last month after President Obama announced he would send 30,000 more troops to Afghanistan, and it is likely to be a major issue as lawmakers return to work in January.

title: Citis Creator, Alone With His Regrets
description: THIS is my final annual meeting as chairman, says Sandy Weill, standing near the window of his office, peering at a grainy photograph of him and his wife on stage at Carnegie Hall more than three years ago. They are smiling broadly, and behind them is a packed house of cheering Citigroup shareholders. A huge banner dangling from the balcony reads Thank You Sandy.

title: Reading File
description: Devil No. 1 Gets a Makeover in China

title: Remember to Share the Stage
description: This interview with Gordon M. Bethune, the former chief executive of Continental Airlines, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Insight by a Thousand Strokes
description: Caricature works wonders at skewering puffed-up demigods, moguls and celebrities by ripping off their false facades. For artists it is both a vent for frustration and a tool of dissent, but being good at it is never easy. Just getting a good likeness is hard enough; making it into a truly smart distortion takes a master manipulator.

title: A Sign of Things to Come at Ohio State?
description: PASADENA, Calif.  The Ohio State sophomore quarterback Terrelle Pryor was nonchalant when asked about his performance Friday that earned him most valuable offensive player of the game honors in eighth-ranked Ohio States 26-17 Rose Bowl victory against No. 7 Oregon.

title: In Tsunamis Wake, an Unexpected Second Chance
description: THANTIRAYANKUPPAM, India  Five years ago, I woke up on a Sunday morning, checked the news online and saw that a tsunami had hit my part of the world. Early reports were sketchy. I read about just a few casualties (in Sri Lanka, as I recall), and I remember thinking that the whole thing sounded exciting.

title: Woman, 19, Held in Stabbing Death
description: A 19-year-old woman was charged with stabbing a 17-year-old acquaintance to death after an argument at a Queens apartment building on Friday.

title: Sweet Finish for Tebow and Gators
description: NEW ORLEANS  In a college football career filled with superlatives, Tim Tebow gave a performance Friday night that epitomized his larger-than-life persona.

title: A Data Explosion Remakes Retailing
description: MOST people think of the grand challenges in computing as big science projects, like simulating nuclear explosions or protein folding. But with the holiday shopping season just ended, consider another: retail marketing.

title: Bearings That Pack a Punch (and Their Own Controls)
description: TRAINS that float on air may be the most famous objects borne by magnetic fields.

title: The Legacy of Tebow
description: NEW ORLEANS  Tim Tebows career at Florida began when he chose the Gators on national television, the culmination of a television documentary about him. Before hed ever started a game in college, he had women following him everywhere.

title: How the Jets Got Here, Set to Music
description: Is the rest of the Jets season going to play out like a Clint Eastwood revenge movie?

title: Pats and Colts Dont Care What You Think
description: Two of the most controversial decisions of the 2009 season occurred in the same stadium, Lucas Oil Field in Indianapolis.

title: The Greatest Story Rarely Told
description: On December 30, I posted the following Twitter riff: Check this diagram of the years news. Find climate? Climategate? Copenhagen? http://j.mp/noCO2news.

title: Warnings not heeded, self-referential edition
description: Hmm. Im preparing for my Monday talk at the economics meetings in Atlanta, which is going to be about the relationship between currency crises and broader financial crises, and ran across a paper I wrote myself in 2001  then largely forgot about.

title: Kristin Reilly, Salvatore DiGiacomo
description: Kristin Ann Reilly, a daughter of Sharon A. Reilly and Thomas F. Reilly of Huntington, N.Y., was married New Years Eve to Salvatore Dominick DiGiacomo, a son of Diana DiGiacomo of Baldwin, N.Y., and John T. DiGiacomo of Grasmere, Staten Island. Msgr. John Martin performed the ceremony at St. Edward the Confessor Roman Catholic Church in Syosset, N.Y., where the brides father is a deacon.

title: Sarah Barlow, Nicholas Huston
description: Sarah Brooks Barlow and Nicholas James Huston were married Saturday evening in Brooklyn. Dr. Christian Isichei, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the restaurant Bubbys Brooklyn.

title: Ugandan Troops Kill a Rebel Leader
description: KAMPALA, Uganda (Agence France-Presse)  Ugandan troops killed a top commander of the Lords Resistance Army rebels in the Central African Republic, a military spokesman said Saturday.

title: Obama Says Al Qaeda in Yemen Planned Bombing Plot, and He Vows Retribution
description: HONOLULU  President Obama declared for the first time on Saturday that a branch of Al Qaeda based in Yemen sponsored the attempted Christmas Day bombing of an American passenger jet, and he vowed that those behind the failed attack will be held to account.

title: Afghans Answering the Call to Fight
description: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan  Bakhtiar Ludin looks like a rogue, with a roughly tied checkered scarf for a turban, a Kalashnikov and a band of similarly tough, armed men for company.

title: 2020 Vision
description: In 10 eventful years, LeBron James will be the celebrated elder statesman of the N.B.A., Alex Rodriguez will be baseballs home run champ and Tiger Woods will be a corporate powerhouse again as the record-holder for golf majors.

title: International Bowl: South Florida (7-5) vs. Northern Illinois (7-5)
description: After the intensity of the Rose and Sugar bowls, its nice to wake up Saturday with the International Bowl, which pits two second-tier teams from the Big East and Mid-American Conference. If its bowl season, we all know where to find South Florida: in a tailspin. Yet again, the Bulls have folded in the second half of the season; after starting 5-0 this fall, U.S.F. has dropped five of seven. This is officially a trend. For Northern Illinois, 2009 served as proof that last seasons bowl trip  which came on the heels of a 2-10 finish in 2007  was not a fluke. The Huskies have already made a one-win improvement over last season and have a shot at winning eight games for the first time since 2004.

title: The Gators Night of Triumph Could Become the Twilight of an Era
description: NEW ORLEANS  If the future of the Florida football program had a Facebook page, its relationship status would read, Its complicated.

title: Risks of Switching Parties Are Clear
description: WASHINGTON  Periods of intense partisanship and turmoil occasionally lead to a smattering of Congressional party-switching. But changing affiliation is no guarantee of political survival. Just ask ex-Representative Michael P. Forbes of New York.

title: Blizzard Conditions Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Wow. Ms. Cox and Mr. Rathvon have outdone themselves with todays acrostic. Its nice, as we saw two weeks ago, when a good smattering of the lettered clues and their answers have connections to the quotation in the grid above. Thats true almost across the board today, in interesting and varied ways, imparting an added richness to the solve.

title: Twice an M.V.P., but Never a Shoo-In
description: Two well-respected slugging outfielders from the 1980s are once more on the Hall of Fame ballot. One has inched ever closer to the required 75 percent approval from voters and is probably eagerly awaiting the announcement of the new class Wednesday. The other is close to being bumped off the ballot for too little support. Andre Dawson, who starred for the Montreal Expos and the Chicago Cubs, hit 438 home runs, winning the 1977 Rookie of the Year award and the 1987 Most Valuable Player award over his 21-season career. He was an eight-time Gold Glover with a golden arm to match. In his first year on the ballot, in 2002, he received 45.3 percent of the votes but he climbed to 67.3 percent last year.

title: Iran Gives West One-Month Ultimatum to Accept Nuclear Counterproposal
description: CAIRO  Irans foreign minister warned the West on Saturday that it had one month to accept Irans counterproposal to a deal brokered by the United Nations aimed at slowing the Iranian nuclear program, or else Iran would begin further enriching its nuclear fuel stockpile on its own.

title: Many Karzai Afghan Cabinet Choices Are Rejected
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In a clear signal to President Hamid Karzai that he cannot count on Parliament for support, lawmakers resoundingly rejected most of his nominees for cabinet posts and expressed discontent with the candidates competence.

title: Cartoonist in Denmark Calls Attack Really Close
description: LONDON  A heavily bandaged 28-year-old Somali man was wheeled into a Danish court on a stretcher on Saturday and was charged with attempting to kill a Danish artist whose 2005 cartoon of the Prophet Muhammad was one of a series that ignited riots across the Muslim world, as well as firebombing attacks on Danish and other Western diplomatic missions.

title: A Man Who Knows How to Lead
description: Few in professional sports had a rsum as diverse as Jerry Colangelos. He was an assistant with the Chicago Bulls who became the first general manager of the expansion Suns, then came to own the Phoenix franchise, as well as the W.N.B.A.s Mercury and baseballs Arizona Diamondbacks. After the United States mens basketball teams uninspiring performances at the 2002 world championships and the 2004 Olympics in Athens, Colangelo was named the programs managing director and charged with returning it to prominence. The sports columnist Dan Bickley shared the story of the United States victory at the 2008 Beijing Olympics in a new book, Return of the Gold: The Journey of Jerry Colangelo and the Redeem Team. Colangelo recently visited the N.B.A. Store in New York to discuss the process. JONATHAN ABRAMS

title: U.S. Sees an Opportunity to Press Iran on Nuclear Fuel
description: WASHINGTON  As President Obama faces pressure to back up his year-end ultimatum for diplomatic progress with Iran, the administration says that domestic unrest and signs of unexpected trouble in Tehrans nuclear program make its leaders particularly vulnerable to strong and immediate new sanctions.

title: Yemens Chaos Aids the Evolution of a Qaeda Cell
description: SANA, Yemen  Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula has rapidly evolved into an expanding and ambitious regional terrorist network thanks in part to a weakened, impoverished and distracted Yemeni government.

title: After a Bout With Injury, Griffin Still Waiting to Contribute to Clippers
description: LOS ANGELES  The shot by Baron Davis didnt even nick the rim, lest it take a typical Clippers bounce and kick out. Instead, it swished right through, a buzzer-beater that upended the Boston Celtics last week and momentarily allowed the Clippers to feel better about a season that will probably end where it often does  at the door to the N.B.A.s draft lottery.

title: Letters to the Editor: Debating What Defined the Decade
description: For the past two weeks, The New York Times has looked back at the decade, highlighting the big games, impact players and overriding trends in various sports. Readers at nytimes.com shared their favorite moments of the past 10 years.

title: Fruitful Decade for Many in the World
description: IT may not feel that way right now, but the last 10 years may go down in world history as a big success. That idea may be hard to accept in the United States. After all, it was the decade of 9/11, the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, and the financial crisis, all dramatic and painful events. But in economic terms, at least, the decade was a remarkably good one for many people around the globe.

title: New Topics for the New Year?
description: The new year is a time to think about issues that deserve more coverage in my column. I tend to think that a column is a bit like a spotlight and has the most impact when it is illuminating something not presently getting enough attention. Thats not always true, of course, but Im always looking for neglected topics that deserve more real estate on the op-ed page. So heres your chance. Tell me what I should think about addressing more in 2010 and where I can learn more about the issue in question.

title: A Holiday for Oregons Offense
description: PASDADENA, Calif.  Oregons 26-17 loss to Ohio State on Friday in the Rose Bowl is sure to especially sting Chip Kelly, the Ducks first-year coach.

title: Giants Have Lots of Time Off Ahead, but the Vikings Are Hoping for a Week
description: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  At the south end of the Minnesota Vikings chilly Winter Park field house Thursday, defensive players broke into position groups to start practice. Quickly, assistants offered telling signs of how the suddenly vulnerable Vikings defense might deal with two critical injuries in Sundays game against the Giants at the Metrodome.

title: Food Stamps, and Nothing Else
description: Food stamp programs in 30 states and the District of Columbia provided data on the number of recipients who had no other cash income.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu: Jan. 3, 2010
description: National security dominates the talk shows on the first Sunday of the new decade after an unsuccessful attack placed the nations counterterrorism operations into a glaring spotlight.

title: Even at Home, Jets Have Felt Like Visitors
description: After the Dodgers left town in 1957, Alan Titan of Brooklyn was a fan without a team. That changed when he and some City College classmates took the subway one Sunday afternoon to see the debut of a new professional football franchise.

title: Harvard Teaching Hospitals Cap Outside Pay
description: The owner of two research hospitals affiliated with the Harvard Medical School has imposed restrictions on outside pay for two dozen senior officials who also sit on the boards of pharmaceutical or biotechnology companies. The limits come in the wake of growing criticism of the ties between industry and academia.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Bruins Win OT Thriller Outside at Fenway
description: Two games on Jan. 1, 2010. One, the outdoor extravaganza at Fenway Park in Boston, the other in Buffalo, where the N.H.L.s Winter Classic got started on a beautiful snowy New Years Day in 2008. Home teams listed first:

title: Cotton Bowl: No. 19 Oklahoma State (9-3) vs. Mississippi (8-4)
description: Mississippi heads to the Cotton Bowl for the second consecutive season, hoping to follow up last Januarys satisfying win over Texas Tech with another upset over a potentially explosive Big 12 opponent. To be fair, Oklahoma State does not have the same firepower as the 2008 Red Raiders  at least this season. However, whatever points the Cowboys have lost on offense has been made up for by a shockingly aggressive, opportunistic defense. Yes, you read that right: Oklahoma State can play some defense. O.S.U. will be tested by the Rebels, whose team speed rivals anything the Cowboys have seen this season.

title: Papajohns.com Bowl: South Carolina (7-5) vs. Connecticut (7-5)
description: The Papajohns.com Bowl has the misfortune of playing next to the Cotton Bowl, clearly the top bowl game of an otherwise forgettable day of college football. Did I say forgettable? For some of you, perhaps; Ill be trying out the old picture-in-picture feature in order to catch what could be a very competitive game, one that stars two teams with contrasting strengths and weaknesses. The Huskies can score (21st nationally with 32.1 points per game)  the Gamecocks, yet again, cannot (96th). While South Carolinas defense ranks in the top 25 in the nation, Connecticuts is reliably mediocre. Each team is riding its own sort of momentum: South Carolina is coming off a win over rival Clemson, while Connecticut has weathered the emotions of the passing of one of its teammates and takes a three-game win streak into bowl play.

title: Before Giants Stadium Closes, Making One Last Fly-By
description: If youve attended a pro football game at Giants Stadium, youve probably noticed the sea gulls riding the wind high above the upper deck, sailing and swooping before diving toward the parking lots for the tailgate leftovers. And with the stadium about to close, whenever Ive looked up to see those sea gulls while covering Giants and Jets games, I remember the afternoon a small plane suddenly appeared.

title: For Sanchez, Comfort Level Has Increased With Games Importance
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  By the middle of last week, Mark Sanchez, the rookie Jets quarterback, had determined that Sundays game against the Cincinnati Bengals would be grander in magnitude than the Rose Bowl. It would be bigger than 10 Rose Bowls, maybe 100, he said.

title: Boy, 9, Fatally Stabbed During Manhattan Visit
description: The police arrested a 25-year-old man and charged him with the murder of a 9-year-old boy who was fatally stabbed early Saturday in Upper Manhattan, the police said.

title: Amateur Video From Tehran Appears to Show Shots Were Fired at Protesters
description: Updated | Sunday 11:45 a.m. As The Los Angeles Times reported on Saturday, amateur video has surfaced online that appears to contradict the Iranian governments claim that its security forces did not shoot at protesters last Sunday during demonstrations that left at least eight people dead.

title: More Wins at Home, but Fewer Fans
description: A team that is better at home than on the road is nothing surprising; through Friday, 27 of the N.B.A.s 30 teams had a better record while playing in their own arenas. But the New Orleans Hornets have set themselves apart by being among the leagues most dominant teams at home and among its worst on the road.

title: The Fumble and the Unreliability of Memory
description: Wrapping up our countdown on the most memorable Giants moments at Giants Stadium.

title: Rival Islamists Fight for Town in Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Shabab rebels, who control most of Somalia with allied Islamist groups, on Saturday attacked a town lost to moderate Islamists about a year ago.

title: Ten for the Next Ten
description: Dublin

title: Living on Nothing but Food Stamps
description: CAPE CORAL, Fla.  After an improbable rise from the Bronx projects to a job selling Gulf Coast homes, Isabel Bermudez lost it all to an epic housing bust  the six-figure income, the house with the pool and the investment property.

title: Looking Back at the Wizards Name Change
description: The Washington Wizards received a lot of attention this week over accusations that guns were involved in an altercation between Gilbert Arenas and Javaris Crittenton. It was a reminder that the team was known as the Bullets from 1963 until 1997.

title: States of Conflict: An Update
description: In 2009, Iraq, Pakistan and Afghanistan dominated American military and foreign policy. Which themes emerged over the last year?

title: Big Crowd for James Is Another Sign of Intrigue
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Before last years all-encompassing rhythmic tribute to New York in Empire State of Mind, the rapper Jay-Z wrote an ode to his home borough, Brooklyn. He ended with this promise: In a couple years, Im a bring you some Nets.

title: The Editor Everyone Should Have Had
description: Deborah Howell, former ombudsman of The Washington Post, Washington bureau chief of the Newhouse newspapers and executive editor of The St. Paul Pioneer Press, died in an accident in New Zealand on Friday. The accident, in which she was struck and killed by a car, happened while she was on a long-planned trip with her husband, C. Peter Magrath, the former president of the University of Minnesota. She was 68 at the time of her death, and while tragic, the fact that she died in the midst of one more adventure on a life-list full of them surprised no one who knew her.

title: No Liquor? No Band-Aids
description: The Jets have chosen to ban alcohol sales during Sunday nights crucial game against Cincinnati, as they did for the 2007 season finale.

title: No Liquor? No Band-Aids
description: The Jets have chosen to ban alcohol sales during Sunday nights crucial game against Cincinnati, as they did for the 2007 season finale.

title: Dangerous Game
description: The National Football League seems finally to have emerged from its cocoon of denial about the devastating long-term effects of concussions on professional football players. In November, it announced that players with concussions could not return to the field without the blessing of an independent brain-injury expert. It has also agreed to support research by its most vocal critics.

title: What Will It Take to Make A.F.C. Playoffs? Start With a Calculator
description: There is such a divide between the best and the worst in the National Football Conference that every playoff spot is clinched going into the final weekend and teams are playing only for seeding. In the American Football Conference, seven teams are alive for the two wild-card spots. If you can figure out these possibilities without help, youre better than us and youre probably a mathematician. Here is what it takes for each team and how Sunday might unfold. Take a few aspirin before you dive in.

title: For Shanghai Fair, Famous Fund-Raiser Delivers
description: WASHINGTON  In the hectic last week before she became secretary of state, Hillary Rodham Clinton squeezed in a Bon Jovi benefit concert in New York, part of a frantic effort to pay off the debt from her presidential campaign. No sooner had she arrived at the State Department than Mrs. Clinton discovered she needed to start raising money all over again.

title: Dennis Brutus Dies at 85; Fought Apartheid With Sports
description: When Dennis Brutus heard the news, he was breaking stones on Robben Island, the notorious prison colony where Nelson Mandela, the freedom fighter and future South African president, occupied the cell next to his.

title: Therese Kolata and Nathan Allison Jr.
description: Therese Bari Kolata, the daughter of Gina Kolata and William G. Kolata of Princeton, N.J., was married Tuesday to Nathan Allison Jr., a son of Yvonne Allison and Mr. Allison Sr. of Burlington, N.J. The Rev. Ellis Holdren, an Episcopal deacon, officiated at the Vitruvian Mansion in Las Vegas.

title: Frontiers, Virtual and Real
description: THREE of my four grandparents immigrated to America from Russia, through Ellis Island, in the early 1920s. My father grew up in Brooklyn, and my mother in Buffalo. I was born in Syracuse, where my father was in medical school. After he graduated, he was drafted into the Air Force, which assigned him first to San Francisco, then to Madrid, where we lived for three years.

title: Getting Back in Shape for the Job Chase
description: THE beginning of this new year  after a very difficult 2009 for job seekers  offers a good opportunity to review and fine-tune every element of an employment search, from rsums to thank-you notes.

title: In Recession, Americans Doing More, Buying Less
description: MIAMI  Rosario and Igor Montoya used to buy, buy, buy for themselves and their two children without a second thought. Expensive sneakers, a new laptop, Legos  they all got what they wanted. But with the recession slashing the Montoyas workload and income by more than half, their priorities have shifted from products to activities.

title: Aviva Androphy and Evan Marlin
description: Aviva Yaffa Androphy, a daughter of Nancy R. Androphy and Rabbi L. Ronald Androphy of East Meadow, N.Y., and Evan Seth Marlin, the son of Bebby Marlin and Dr. Arthur E. Marlin of St. Petersburg, Fla., were married New Years Eve. The brides father, the leader of the East Meadow Jewish Center, performed the ceremony there, with Rabbi Aryeh Scheinberg taking part.

title: Abigail Gaunt and Gabriel Feldman
description: Abigail Ford Gaunt and Gabriel Adam Feldman were married New Years Eve at Cipriani 42nd Street in New York. Judge Denny Chin of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, for whom the bride was a law clerk, officiated.

title: Alexandra Asjes, Jonathan Dudkowski
description: Alexandra Anneke Asjes and Jonathan Lynch Dudkowski were married on New Years Eve in San Francisco. Mark S. Fox, a Universal Life minister, officiated at a Quaker-style ceremony at the Palace Hotel.

title: Caroline Evans, Florent de Gants
description: Caroline McMullan Evans and Florent de Gants were married in New Orleans Tuesday. The Rev. William Gedge Gayle, an Episcopal priest, officiated, and the Rev. Arnold A. Bush, an Episcopal priest, took part in the ceremony at Christ Church Cathedral.

title: Liberty Bowl: Arkansas (7-5) vs. East Carolina (9-4)
description: The two-time defending Conference USA champions earn another shot at a premier opponent after going 0-3 against B.C.S. competition during the regular season. E.C.U. gave West Virginia, North Carolina and Virginia Tech its best shot, losing by two touchdowns or less against each eventual bowl participant. However, the Pirates rolled through conference action for the second consecutive year, losing only one game in the regular season (to S.M.U.) and squeezing past Houston in the conference title game. Arkansas has reached bowl play in its second season under Bobby Petrino, and with a 38-point effort against East Carolina can break the programs single-season record for points.

title: Lauren Deysher and Paul Gojkovich III
description: Lauren Amanda Deysher, a daughter of Cynthia M. Deysher and Bryon G. Deysher of Concord, Mass., was married Saturday to Paul Gojkovich III, the son of Mary W. Gojkovich and Mr. Gojkovich II of Westport, Conn. The Rev. Brian M. Clary, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Middlesex School Memorial Chapel in Concord, Mass. The Rev. Michael A. Bird, an Episcopal priest, participated.

title: Laura OSteen, Jeffrey Boatright
description: Laura Elizabeth OSteen and Jeffrey David Boatright were married Saturday at the Lovely Lane Chapel at Epworth by the Sea, a conference and retreat center in St. Simons Island, Ga. The Rev. Charles Adams, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

title: Erin Roeder, John Spader III
description: Erin Ventre Roeder, a daughter of Kathleen V. Roeder and Alan C. Roeder of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., was married in Detroit on New Years Eve to John Peter Spader III, the son of Christine Spader and Mr. Spader Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y. Mayor Jerry M. Ellis of Farmington Hills, Mich., officiated at the Detroit Athletic Club.

title: Mary White, Paul Means
description: Mary Willis White and Paul Edward Means were married Friday at Bourbon and Branch, a bar in San Francisco. Jeffrey Speckels, a friend of the couple who was named a deputy marriage commissioner by the city and county of San Francisco for the event, officiated.

title: Resurrecting Local Militias
description: In areas like Kunduz, in northern Afghanistan, the American-led coalition and the Afghan government are enlisting local militias in the battle against the Taliban.

title: The Road Brings Out the Worst in the Hornets
description: A team that is better at home than on the road is nothing surprising as 25 of the N.B.A.s 30 teams have a better record while playing in their own arenas. But the New Orleans Hornets have set themselves apart by being among the leagues most dominant teams at home and among its worst on the road.

title: Antique Finish
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Todays theme has been brought to you by the letter H. Tack it on to the end of a noun that ends in ET, and suddenly thou hath a Biblical-sounding verb. For example, BUCKET BRIGADE becomes BUCKETH BRIGADES.

title: Later Payments Are Jamming the Economys Gears
description: Whats one sign of a weak economy? People take longer to pay their bills. As a result, those who await payment have less money to pay their bills, and a cycle of slowness sets in, gumming up the economic works.

title: What the Past Cant Tell Investors
description: A STOCK that builds momentum in one year often carries it over into the next. Might that momentum effect work for the overall stock market?

title: A Writerly Approach to the Financial Crisis
description: ONE of the aftereffects of the financial crisis has been a flood of books promising to explain it. There have been books by economists, journalists, politicians, Wall Street insiders and even a federal judge, Richard Posner, who has produced more than 40 other books, and evidently couldnt resist the temptation to churn out one on this subject.

title: Jean Carroll, 98, Is Dead; Blended Wit and Beauty
description: Jean Carroll, a comedian of the 1940s and 50s whose ready wit, impeccable timing and unorthodox blend of glamour and humor made her one of the first female stars of mainstream stand-up comedy, died at a hospital in White Plains on Jan. 1. She was 98 and lived in Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: Not my actual lecture text
description: Because I dont read speeches. But more or less what Im planning to say.

title: Neediest | The Will to Work
description: Palita Gbalajobi just wants to work. Even though she is 70, she needs two more years of work to qualify for Social Security benefits.

title: Atlanta is ours, and cheaply won
description: I thought I might blog about this WSJ article saying that economists are cheapskates. But then I figured, my time is valuable, Ill let someone with a lower opportunity cost of time do the work.

title: A Womans Desire to Work Is Thwarted by a Body That Strains to Keep Up
description: Palita Gbalajobi wants to work, and she will push her body to the brink to do it.

title: A Year With No New Champs but Plenty of Big Winners
description: Viswanathan Anand of India, the world champion, and Alexandra Kosteniuk of Russia, the womens titleholder, were able to rest on their laurels in 2009. That was because for the first time in six years there was no world championship match or tournament.

title: Robinsons Big Game Raises New Questions for Knicks
description: In the Knicks universe, controversies do not end  they merely morph and adapt as circumstances dictate. So Nate Robinsons electrifying 41-point performance on Friday merely shifted the debate.

title: Arenas Cites Bad Judgment in Gun Case
description: WASHINGTON  Gilbert Arenas stood at his locker with his back to about 20 reporters and cameramen. He smiled as he dressed after the Washington Wizards 97-86 loss to the San Antonio Spurs on Saturday, seemingly amused by the fuss.

title: Soldier Says Pardon Buoys His Hopes for Police Career
description: On the day he was to be deployed for another tour in Afghanistan, a young soldier who was pardoned by Gov. David A. Paterson last week for a gun possession conviction said that Army life remained his priority. But his dream of joining the New York Police Department was never far behind.

title: Atlantic City International Airport
description: FOUNDED 1942, as a naval air station for combat training.

title: Westchester County Airport
description: FOUNDED 1942, as an Air National Guard base.

title: Tweed-New Haven Regional Airport
description: The Tweed-New Haven Regional Airport is not regarded as much of a factor in relieving congestion in regional air traffic. It is used by just one commercial airline  US Airways Express  and oversees a handful of daily flights to only one city, Philadelphia. (In Philadelphia, connections can be made to the rest of the country.)

title: Long Island MacArthur Airport
description: FOUNDED 1942.

title: La Guardia Airport
description: FOUNDED 1939.

title: Snowboarder Pearce Has Long Recovery Ahead of Him
description: The snowboarder Kevin Pearce remained in intensive care, in critical but stable condition, at a Salt Lake City hospital two days after sustaining a severe head injury while training in the halfpipe at Utahs Park City Mountain Resort.

title: New Years Resolutions
description: WASHINGTON

title: Fight Against Asian Carp Threatens Fragile Great Lakes Unity
description: CHICAGO  Asian carp, the voracious, nonnative fish whose arrival near Lake Michigan is threatening to cause havoc in the Great Lakes, are now setting off strife on land as well.

title: Worlds Healthiest Food
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras

title: Connecticut Ends Trying Season With Bowl Victory
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Randy Edsall, the Connecticut football coach, seemed unsettled this week as he watched his team practice for the PapaJohns.com Bowl. The Huskies had been through a trying season, with five defeats by a total of 15 points and a win over Notre Dame in two overtimes. But that was nothing compared to the stabbing death of defensive back Jasper Howard.

title: Alamo Bowl: Michigan State (6-6) vs. Texas Tech (8-4)
description: It will be strange to look at the Texas Tech sideline and not see Mike Leach, the face of the program for the last decade and the winningest coach in program history. Sadder still is the sinking feeling that the Red Raiders are destined for Big 12 and national irrelevance only two years after nearly playing for the national championship. At least Texas Tech will feature the same cast that won eight games  only its coach is missing; Michigan State will be without the use of 10 players due to violations of team rules.

title: Giving a Job a New Perspective
description: Robert Wong began his career at 23 as a correctional officer at San Quentin. Now, 27 years later, he is ending it as the acting warden. He oversees 2,000 employees and 5,200 prisoners, including 680 on death row. Few inmates see the bay view that is his paradise. (His words have been edited and condensed.)

title: To-Do List Grows for Leadership Group
description: The Silicon Valley Leadership Group represents business interests in a region known for being on the leading edge of innovation. But when it comes to politics, the group is decidedly retro, a throwback to the days when there was a viable center in Californias civic affairs.

title: Trainer Faults Treatment of Player at Texas Tech
description: A Texas Tech athletic trainer said he was told by the fired coach Mike Leach to lock wide receiver Adam James in the dark after doctors determined that he had a concussion, according to an affidavit released Saturday by the university.

title: Asking Stars Not Just to Play, but Also to Stay
description: The relationship between the rock stars of classical music and the orchestras and audiences that interact with them can generally be characterized as a series of memorable one-night stands. When the Lang Langs, Joshua Bells and Rene Flemings of the world arrive in town for an evening or two, tickets fly, and standing ovations shake concert halls. But no sooner has the applause died down than the artists are on a plane to the next city.

title: Ambitious Downtown Transit Project Is at Hand
description: In 2010, San Francisco will finally bring out the wrecking balls and cement mixers and embark on a grand overhaul of its downtown. The project could eventually result in a half-dozen new skyscrapers, including a 1,200-foot tower whose gracefully tapered top would add a defining element to the iconography of the upwardly mobile skyline.

title: The Replacements
description: Milwaukee

title: Transit Project Could Transform City and More From the Bay Area Report
description: A Grand Transformation | In 2010, San Francisco will finally begin a grand overhaul of its downtown. The ambitious plan for a new urban neighborhood could be scaled back. But the centerpiece of the project  a $4.2 billion public transit hub  has enough financing to begin construction, and the first dirt could be turned as early as March.

title: Editors Note
description: SUNDAY BUSINESS

title: Scenes From the War on Terrorism in Yemen
description: The evidence that Al Qaedas branch in Yemen had a role in the failed Christmas Day bombing of an American passenger jet has led some to declare that Yemen is the new front in the war against the terrorist organization. But the truth is, Yemen has been a front in that war since at least Oct. 12, 2000, when Al Qaeda blew up the Navy destroyer Cole, killing 17 American sailors, in the port of Aden. The explosives for the bombing were bought in Yemen. And the attackers and their accomplices were predominantly Yemenis. Indeed, after the attack, terrorists in Qaeda camps in Afghanistan would march and chant, We, the Yemenis, destroyed the Cole.

title: Piecing Together Wins at William & Mary
description: On Wednesday, William & Mary Coach Tony Shaver entered the Tribes locker room at the Comcast Center after a victory over Maryland as his players swayed in a circle to the Black Eyed Peas song I Gotta Feeling.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Brazils effort to curb illegal land seizures in the Amazon misstated the amount of land that the leader of a local Amazon residents association said he purchased 15 years ago and was subsequently forced to sell by powerful farmers. It was at least 120 acres, not 20 acres.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the reaction of states to the costs of expanding Medicaid coverage in the Senate health care bill misstated the length of time the federal government would pay the entire cost of the expansion to people who are not already eligible under state coverage. It is three years (2014 through 2016)  not two.

title: For Many People, Holidays Are a Time for Playing
description: The period around the new year has become one of the busiest times for chess players.

title: Times Standards, Staffers or Not
description: Mary Tripsas, an associate professor at the Harvard Business School, has been writing a monthly column in The Times called Prototype, about corporate innovation, her academic specialty. Last Sunday, she highlighted the 3M Companys customer innovation center at its headquarters in St. Paul.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions last Sunday about Charles Gehring, a New York State Library employee who has been translating 17th century Dutch records into English for the past 35 years, referred imprecisely to events in the career of Nelson A. Rockefeller, who pushed to finance the position Mr. Gehring holds. While Rockefeller stepped down as governor and was succeeded by Lt. Gov. Malcolm Wilson, that succession came in December 1973, not after Rockefeller became vice president, in December 1974.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions last Sunday about Urban Meyers announcement that he was resigning as the University of Florida football coach misidentified the university of Houston Nutt, one of the coaches who reacted to the news. It is the University of Mississippi  not the University of Arkansas, which is where he coached from 1998 to 2007. (Meyer later announced he would take an indefinite leave of absence instead of resigning.)

title: Giants at Vikings: What to Watch
description: Matchup to Watch: David Diehl vs. Jared Allen

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Long Island Calendar in some editions last Sunday erroneously included a performance among events being offered at the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor. Performances of Peter and the Wolf, by the Long Island Philharmonic Woodwind Quintet, ended in 2008. (The error first appeared in the listings on Dec. 20.)

title: Shedding Old Rivalries and Pulling Together
description: Abdul Kagdi looked up from his Koran with a stare as frigid as the winter breeze swirling outside his 110-220 Volts Electronics shop. I only have a few minutes, he said, his courtesy overcoming his irritation at being interrupted. Im praying.

title: Avoiding a Japanese Decade
description: Thankfully, 2009 ended better than it began. Economists talk about green shoots of recovery taking hold. Consumer confidence has improved. Equity markets have soared. But for all the progress, the American economy remains extremely vulnerable.

title: The Shinnecocks, Recognized
description: More than 200 years late  31 if you count from the tribes petition  the federal government has acknowledged that the Shinnecocks of Southampton, Long Island, are an Indian tribe. Settling that question raises new ones. The Shinnecocks will almost certainly try to build a casino  they have been lobbying as hard for one as they have for recognition  but how big, and where?

title: Snowing Forward
description: Last week felt like a last chance before winter. The snow melted, dying back until the vole trails became thin green paths through the remains of whiteness. The ice unbound itself from the rim of the horse tanks. One warm morning, a bat fluttered past my head, resting on the clapboards for a moment and then arcing around to the east side of the house. Despite the sense of relenting, the ground was still frozen solid.

title: Not a Total Economic Washout
description: To the Editor:

title: Security and Civil Liberties in the Age of Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: What Dying Patients Need
description: To the Editor:

title: Theres More to Publishing Than Meets the Screen
description: WHAT is an e-book?

title: Coachs Future Is in the Hands of Mama Bear
description: As the 85-year-old owner of the Chicago Bears franchise her father founded 90 years ago, Virginia Halas McCaskey knows National Football League history is once again in her hands.

title: Arenas Plays for Wizards; Pollin Family Reacts to Gun Investigation
description: WASHINGTON  Gilbert Arenas did not speak to reporters before the Wizards game against the San Antonio Spurs on Saturday night at the Verizon Center. He walked through the locker room at one point and noticed the larger-than-usual media contingent.

title: Corrections
description: EDITORS' NOTE

title: Lottery Numbers
Inauguration Day
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg, Comptroller John Liu, and Public Advocate Bill de Blasio were inaugurated on New Years Day.

title: Even Better than Pepperoni Pizza
description: My Sunday column is about how we can keep children healthier  actually, everybody healthier  by paying attention to micronutrients. This is one of those issues that is enormously important but not very sexy, so I hope I havent bored you. But the truth is that once you see kids with holes in their spines or skulls because of insufficient folic acid, its just haunting.

title: Bengals at Jets: What to Watch
description: Matchup to Watch: Jets Running Game vs. Bengals Run Defense

title: A Last New Year's Eve Toast for Tavern on the Green
description: Facing new ownership and perhaps even a new name in 2010, Tavern on the Green was given a festive farewell.

title: Loyola and Northwestern Shine, but DePaul Keeps Struggling
description: The stretch between Christmas and New Years yielded some highs and lows in local college basketball.

title: Hoping Prominent Support Will Translate to Victories
description: Two of Chicagos most prominent reform politicians gave their blessings to candidates last week. The beneficiaries better hope it is not an omen.

title: Vows: Elizabeth & Joe
description: Joe McLaughlin and Elizabeth Cronise met in early 2008 when Joe was working at a restaurant in the West Village. A mysterious bracelet reading "Nemo Nisi Mors" stuck around until their wedding rings bound them together.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Great Homecoming for Langenbrunner and Lemaire
description: Twelve games on Saturday, highlighted by the East-leading New Jersey Devils visit to Minneapolis  their first in two seasons. Thus it would be Jacques Lemaires first trip back since he stepped down as Minnesotas first and only coach last spring. Seems like something dramatic in the offing. Home teams listed first:

title: Readers Suggestions for Late-Season Competitive Integrity
description: As our Judy Battista wrote for Saturdays paper, the N.F.L. recognizes that it may have a problem.

title: Threats Led to Embassy Closings in Yemen, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  The United States and Britain decided to close their embassies in the capital of Yemen because of continuing threats from Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, the terrorist group linked to the attempt to bring down an international flight into Detroit on Christmas.

title: Market Madness
description: Greetings from Atlanta, where Im attending the American Economic Associations annual meetings.

title: The Decade in Musicals
description: Charles Isherwood on significant Broadway musicals of the aughts.

title: Living on Food Stamps
description: About six million Americans receiving food stamps report they have no other income, according to an analysis of state data collected by The New York Times.

title: The Kids Stay in the Picture
description: Laini Fondiller and her Alpine goats at Lazy Lady Farm in Vermont.

title: A Decade of Star Power
description: Ben Brantley on some of the celebrities who helped fuel Broadways box office.

title: Lax Oversight Caused Crisis, Bernanke Says
description: ATLANTA  Regulatory failure, not low interest rates, was responsible for the housing bubble and subsequent financial crisis of the last decade, Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, said in a speech on Sunday.

title: A High-Energy Leader at Army
description: Once, when Army Coach Zach Spiker filed an expense report from his days on the recruiting trail as a Cornell assistant, his receipt from a gas station stop around 3 a.m. was denied. The purchase in question was a pack of Sour Patch Kids.

title: Some Backing for Napolitano in Wake of Remarks
description: Key Republican and independent senators and former members of the Bush administration spoke up Sunday in support of Janet Napolitano, the secretary of homeland security, despite stinging criticism last week of her comments that a Nigerians foiled effort to blow up a Detroit-bound airliner on Christmas Day showed that the system worked really smoothly.

title: Surf, Skin and Jersey. Whats Not to Love?
description: In the United States even the most unrepentant, obviously guilty serial killer or multimillion-dollar defrauder is entitled to a defense. It is in that spirit that this writer, an actual resident of New Jersey, steps forward to defend Jersey Shore, which seems likely to be the consensus choice for most appalling show of 2009.

title: Touring German Car Museums
description: A glimpse of what's on display at the Audi, BMW, Mercedes-Benz and Porsche museums.

title: Fee to Film in New York Municipal Buildings Riles Producers
description: A new fee levied on movie and television production companies filming inside some municipally owned buildings in New York City is drawing complaints from the entertainment industry, which argues that the charge of $3,200 accompanying each permit is excessive and could drive productions elsewhere.

title: Ugly First Half for the Giants in Minnesota
description: MINNEAPOLIS  With nothing to play for, the Giants arent doing much for the job security of Bill Sheridan, their defensive coordinator.

title: Iraq Says Deal Is Near on the Last of 5 Hostages
description: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi government may be close to a deal with those who took five British men hostage in 2007 that will finally clarify the fate of the last of them, a government spokesman said Sunday.

title: Checking Out Cuba's Antique Car Museum
description: At the Depsito del Automvil, the countrys official antique car museum, a century of automotive history is on display.

title: First Comes Love, Then Comes Fear of Marriage
description: Megajumbo is the word Elizabeth Gilbert uses to describe the popularity of Eat, Pray, Love, her mega-chatty account of the midlife globe trot she undertook in the wake of a bitter divorce. Having written a book so user-friendly it made her feel like every readers best pal, Ms. Gilbert found herself stumped. For reasons both personal and commercial, Eat, Pray, Love was a tough act to follow.

title: 2010 Aston Martin DBS Volante
description: The DBS Volante eschews styling gimmicks and relies on the classic formula of beautiful proportions.

title: Sanctions for U.S.C. Basketball
description: Southern California has imposed sanctions on its mens basketball team following an internal investigation that found N.C.A.A. violations relating to the recruitment of the former Trojans star O.J. Mayo.

title: On Human Happiness, and Why Its So Hard to Find
description: How you know that the lazy days from Christmas to New Years are over: PBS puts up a three-night, six-hour special led by a social psychologist at Harvard. Its time, apparently, to put our thinking caps back on.

title: Once-Promising Season Ends With Grim Defeat
description: MINNEAPOLIS  With a lineup depleted by injuries and nothing to play for, the Giants ended a disappointing season with a listless, embarrassing 44-7 loss to Minnesota that made last weeks 32-point blowout by Carolina look competitive by comparison.

title: While Starters Rest, Colts Fans Should Reflect
description: Indianapolis Colts fans are still seething over what they perceive to be a lost chance to achieve glory.

title: American Honda's Corporate Collection
description: The dream of being able to showcase these vehicles is at least a year or two away from becoming reality.

title: Sondheim Makes His Entrance Again, Intimately
description: At 79, with some of the greatest works of American musical theater to his credit, Stephen Sondheim has reached that point in a prolific composers career when major revivals of his shows now number in the double digits. And with revival has come reconception. On Broadway the most evident trend has been toward chamber-style orchestrations like the eight-instrument arrangements for the current revival of A Little Night Music, Mr. Sondheim and Hugh Wheelers story of aging lovers grappling with regrets.

title: When Sondheim Goes Small
description: In Patrick Healys interview with Stephen Sondheim, the composer says he has made a fragile peace with the chamberization of his musicals, like the eight-instrument arrangement for the current Broadway revival of A Little Night Music.

title: Local Stop: Port Authority
description: The bustling commuter hub casts its shadow over tiny cafes, mom-and-pop bakeries and bona fide dive bars that are beauties to its beast.

title: 2 Lost Chances, and 12 Points Toward a Title
description: The winners of the top bracket in the opening-day Compact Knockout Teams at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in New York were Mimi Bieber of Armonk, N.Y.; Barbara Skluth of White Plains; Ruth Stober of Great Neck, N.Y.; and Steven Conrad of Manhasset, N.Y.

title: New CDs
description: FINDLAY BROWN Love Will Find You (Verve Forecast)

title: Meet the Press
description: John Brennan, President Obamas deputy national security adviser, Michael Chertoff, former secretary of Homeland Security and Michael Hayden, former C.I.A. director.

title: There Be Dragons, Among Other Things
description: Can the imagination ever convey as much meaning as experience? Or rather, can exploration of the imagination  the inner life of the mind  itself become a fully developed sort of experience?

title: Soundgarden Rides Again
description: The Seattle grunge band Soundgarden has announced a reunion and possible tour dates this year, Billboard reported. The lead singer, Chris Cornell, second from left above, Tweeted the news on Friday morning, writing: The 12 year break is over and school is back in session. Sign up now. Knights of the Soundtable ride again! and posted a link to a new Web site, soundgardenworld.com. The group  which also includes the guitarist Kim Thayil, second from right; the bassist Ben Shepherd, right; and the drummer Matt Cameron, left  helped to usher in the grunge scene in the late 80s and rose to prominence with its 1994 album, Superunknown, which included radio favorites like Black Hole Sun. The group has not played together since breaking up in 1997, but Billboard sources say Soundgarden has already been offered spots at several festivals in the United States and abroad. Tour dates are also in the works, but must be planned around Mr. Camerons commitments to his current band, Pearl Jam, which is touring in the spring and summer.

title: Judge Rejects Lawsuit Over Circus Elephants
description: In a case involving the treatment of circus elephants, a federal judge has ruled that the Animal Protection Institute does not have the legal standing to sue the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus under the Endangered Species Act, The Associated Press reported. The Animal Protection Institute, along with Tom Rider, a former Ringling animal trainer, had accused the circus of abusing its Asian elephants by using bull hooks  tools with a sharp steel hook at one end used to control the animals during performances  and of leaving the elephants chained for long periods to punish them for bad behavior. During a six-week trial last year in Washington, held without a jury, Feld Entertainment, which owns Ringling Brothers, said that these things didnt hurt the elephants, and that they were necessary measures to control them and ensure public safety. This ruling represents a victory for the elephants and a win for the United States Constitution, said Michelle Pardo, a lawyer representing Feld, because it reinforces that the federal court is no place to entertain a philosophical debate about whether elephants should be in the circus.

title: Avatar on Top Again
description: Critics may be at odds about the meaning of Foxs 3-D science-fiction epic Avatar, but its meaning to the box office is clear: It started the new year at No. 1 in domestic ticket sales. With just over $68 million for the weekend, Avatar, directed by James Cameron, left (in 3-D specs), finished its first 17 days in theaters with $352.1 million, a record for a film in its third week of release, according to Variety. Robert Downey Jr. and Jude Law helped keep Sherlock Holmes (Warner Brothers) at No. 2 with a little more than $38 million, bringing its total to about $140.7 million. Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (Fox) remained at No. 3 in its second week, with $36 million ($157 million, total). Nancy Meyerss romantic comedy Its Complicated (Universal) finished with $18 million, putting it in fourth place with about $60 million total. And though Sandra Bullock was the top box office draw of 2009, The Blind Side (Warner Brothers) drew only a little more than $12 million in its seventh week in theaters. Still, it was enough to tip it over the $200 million mark, with $209 million total.

title: Footnote
description: The playwright and actor Sam Shepard, 65, was arrested on charges of speeding and driving under the influence early Saturday morning in Normal, Ill., with a blood alcohol level twice the legal limit, according to Reuters. Mr. Shepards new play, Ages of the Moon, begins performances this month at the Atlantic Theater Company in Manhattan.

title: Deadliest Catch Crewman Held
description: A former deckhand on a fishing boat featured on Discovery Channels Deadliest Catch, a reality series about the dangerous fishing industry in the Bering Sea near Alaska, is being held in connection with three bank robberies, The Associated Press reported. Police in East Peoria, Ill., said they arrested Joshua Tel Warner, 23, on Thursday after he was pulled over for a routine traffic stop. A check found that he was being sought in conjunction with robberies in Eugene, Ore., one in 2007 and two in 2009. Mr. Warner was being held on $30,000 bail in the Tazewell County Jail in Illinois. Before being fired from the crew of the ship, the Wizard, Mr. Warner was a Dungeness crab fisherman on the Oregon coast and a wild-land firefighter. A second suspect has been identified but would not be named until police got an arrest warrant.

title: In the Wings
description: The White Horse Theater Company will be staging Tennessee Williamss Clothes for a Summer Hotel, which depicts an ethereal meeting between the restless ghosts of F. Scott Fitzgerald and his wife, Zelda. Performances begin Feb. 5 at the Hudson Guild Theater and run through Feb. 21. The Feb. 14 show will be followed by a discussion with Nancy Milford, author of the biography Zelda. ... Theater for the New City will hold its seventh annual Love n Courage Gala on Feb. 22 at the National Arts Club in Manhattan, this year honoring the acting couple Eli Wallach, above right, and Anne Jackson, above left, as well as Martha Coigney, director of the International Theater Institute. The actor and playwright Charles Busch will host the event, which will include appearances by Laura Linney, Romulus Linney, Marian Seldes, Elaine Stritch, Tammy Grimes and F. Murray Abraham, among others.

title: More Paintings Stolen in France
description: Works by Picasso and Rousseau, among others, have been stolen from a collectors villa in the south of France, Reuters reported. A caretaker of the house, in La Cadire dAzur, a village in Provence, reported Thursday that about 30 paintings were missing, French police told Reuters. The works were worth an estimated total of about $1.4 million. The owner of the villa, who had been vacationing in Sweden, returned to France to help with the investigation, by taking inventory to determine what was stolen. Police said there was no evidence linking this case to the theft of a drawing by Degas, worth almost $1.15 million, from the Cantini Museum in Marseille last week. The Degas was gone when the museum opened on Thursday morning. There were no signs of a break-in. According to BBC News, the Cantini will remain closed while the theft is being investigated.

title: Productivity
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Whats in a name? Sometimes immortality and sometimes extinction.

title: Inside the Ducati Museum
description: The museum features significant motorcycles from Ducati's past, including most of its world title winners.

title: Are They Students? Or Customers?
description: A recent article in The Chicago Tribune described a continuing debate in business schools over whether their enrollees should be regarded as customers rather than as traditional students. Should the students have more say over what they are taught and even how they are judged? Whats the risk of the student-consumer approach in M.B.A. programs? And does the issue reflect broader issues in higher education?

title: Polaroid Photographer
description: Louis Mendes has made a living photographing the people of New York City.

title: Live Tracking of the Playoff Picture
description: Update | 11:28 p.m. On the final day of the regular season, seven A.F.C. teams were alive for the two wild-card spots. In the N.F.C. most of the seeds were up for grabs. At the end of the day, the Vikings had a bye, the Cowboys were N.F.C. East champions, and the Ravens and the Jets had the A.F.C. wild cards. The Fifth Down tracked the results and the changing playoff scenarios as the day went on.

title: Firms Selling Apps for Simple Phones
description: Given the craze around the iPhone, Motorola Droid, Palm Pre and Nexus One, it might seem that nearly everyone has a smartphone.

title: Russia-Belarus Oil Dispute Threatens Europes Supply
description: MOSCOW  Russia and Belarus have failed to renew an agreement on crude oil export tariffs that expired on New Years Eve, raising the prospect that yet another otherwise unremarkable energy pricing dispute between Russia and a neighbor could unravel into a midwinter fuel shut-off on the Continent.

title: Watching TV Together, Miles Apart
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For the lonely couch potato, help is on the way.

title: A Black Market Finds a Home in the Webs Back Alleys
description: HAVANA  On one block on the outskirts of the Cuban capital, a mother of two goes door to door selling hair ribbons and other sundries to her neighbors. An old man sells cookies and candies to those who ring the bell at his dilapidated home. A grandmother fills up empty beer cans with low-budget rum, which she sells in the evenings to help make ends meet.

title: Harsh Storm Batters Island Off the Coast of Russia
description: MOSCOW  Five days of blizzards and avalanches have paralyzed the Russian island of Sakhalin, cutting off air and sea links to the mainland, stranding dozens of motorists on highways, and burying a train, along with three railway workers, under snow drifts 10 feet deep.

title: In Allowing Ad Blockers, a Test for Google
description: IN a manifestolike e-mail message sent last month to all Google employees, Jonathan Rosenberg, a senior vice president for product management, told them to commit to greater transparency and open industry standards. Rather than hoard knowledge to exploit it, he wrote in The Meaning of Open, share it and watch Google and the entire Internet prosper.

title: Knut Haugland, Sailor on Kon-Tiki, Dies at 92
description: Knut Haugland, the last surviving member of the six-man crew that sailed on the Kon-Tiki expedition in 1947, and a leader of the Norwegian resistance who helped carry out one of the most daring acts of sabotage of World War II, died in Oslo on Dec. 25. He was 92.

title: A Toast to Advances in Technology
description: Though they never came up with a name for them, an overwhelming number of Americans agree that the last 10 years were almost all for naught  with the exception of most major technological advances.

title: Live Analysis: Jets 37, Bengals 0, final
description: Greg Bishop, Joe Lapointe and William C. Rhoden are at the Meadowlands and Paul Myerberg at The New York Times building in Manhattan providing live analysis of tonights game between the Jets and the Bengals. Use your refresh button to stay current on the updates.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: City Finally Poised to Give Up Lever Voting Machines
description: Say goodbye to the voting booth with its quaint little curtain. Say goodbye to pulling the lever for your candidate.

title: Dallas Carries the N.F.C. East Title and Big Momentum Into the Playoffs
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The Dallas Cowboys erased a reputation of late-season flops and maligned performances Sunday, capturing the National Football Conference East title with a 24-0 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles at Cowboys Stadium.

title: A Savior in the Form of a Tablet
description: Last year about this time, I was talking with an executive from Apple about e-readers and print at a conference we were both attending, much of it in the context of the mainstream medias original sin of giving away content if people happened to be reading it in digital form.

title: Following Venture Capital for Signs of Tech to Come
description: After hibernating for the last year, Silicon Valleys venture capitalists are beginning to stir.

title: Avatar Joins Holiday Movies That Fail an Antismoking Test
description: Some of those who oppose smoking in movies have just seen the future, and they are not happy about it.

title: Legislators Work to Improve Laws on Runaways
description: WASHINGTON  State and federal lawmakers from around the country are pressing a variety of new laws that would make sweeping changes in the way runaways and prostituted children are handled by police officers and social workers.

title: Newspapers Covered Terror Plot Without Home Delivery Edition
description: Covering major news events on Christmas Day is a challenge at any news organization, given low holiday staff levels. But when a flight carrying a suspected terrorist landed at the Detroit airport this Christmas, the two major Detroit newspapers had an additional challenge. Earlier in 2009, they ceased home delivery several days a week, and they had to figure out whether the event was important enough to revise that plan.

title: Four Ugandans, Four Points of View
description: A transgender man, an anti-gay politician, a taxi driver and a gay activist share their perspectives on the gay and transgender issues in their country.

title: Americans Role Seen in Uganda Anti-Gay Push
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  Last March, three American evangelical Christians, whose teachings about curing homosexuals have been widely discredited in the United States, arrived here in Ugandas capital to give a series of talks.

title: Gauging the Dedication of Teacher Corps Grads
description: Teach for America, a corps of recent college graduates who sign up to teach in some of the nations most troubled schools, has become a campus phenomenon, drawing huge numbers of applicants willing to commit two years of their lives.

title: From Broken Boy to T.C.U. Tackler
description: FORT WORTH  The Fiesta Bowl between Boise State and Texas Christian on Monday night is a symbolic affair, a critical apex for two programs trying to join college footballs elite.

title: At Barbies Mansion, Its Time for Yoga With Pro Wrestlers
description: AFTER all these years of marketing Barbie in all her glorious incarnations  and outfits  Mattel is about to gear up to sell a new plastic collectible figure with a different, but still distinctive, look: a 7-foot-tall wrestler named the Big Show.

title: Pearces Parents Thank Supporters
description: The Olympic hopeful Kevin Pearces parents, Simon and Pia, released a statement Sunday night regarding the support they have received in the wake of the serious head injury he sustained while training in the halfpipe last Thursday in Park City, Utah.

title: In Health Bill for Everyone, Provisions for a Few
description: WASHINGTON  Early versions of the Senates far-reaching health care bill said that small businesses with fewer than 50 workers would not be penalized if they failed to provide insurance. That was before labor unions in the construction industry went to work and persuaded Senate leaders to insert five paragraphs.

title: Detective Ahmed Nasser, Yemen
description: Ahmed Nasser

title: Officer Henry Ko, Nigeria
description: Henry Ko

title: Officer Tatyana Ananyeva, Estonia
description: Tatyana Ananyeva
