title: From Around the Globe, Serving New York
description: The New York Police Department has sent its officers to 11 cities around the globe  even once dispatching a husband and wife to Abu Dhabi. But the return from the world has been far greater.

title: Heroes in a Land of Pirates
description: Nairobi, Kenya

title: Lottery Numbers
Program for Children Has Uncertain Future
description: WASHINGTON  As Democratic Congressional leaders work to merge the House and Senate versions of major health care legislation, a big question is what they will do about the Childrens Health Insurance Program, which now provides coverage to more than nine million children and pregnant women and is expected to cover more than 14 million by 2013.

title: It Was All Started by a Mouse (Part 1)
description: There he is, lying in the ruins of a bombed-out apartment building. Mickey Mouse, splayed, limbs akimbo, surrounded not by the denizens of the Magic Castle, but a bleak war-zone landscape of rocks, shards of glass, a dark red truck, a couple of people in the distance, but otherwise devoid of humanity. The caption to the photograph reads:

title: Corrections
description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

title: U.S. Is Said to Consider Easing Informants Term
description: The Justice Department is weighing whether to ask a federal judge to reduce the jail sentence of a former UBS banker who was a main figure in a wide-ranging tax evasion case against wealthy American clients, a person briefed on the matter said.

title: Hazaras Hustle to Head of Class in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  For much of this countrys history, the Hazara were typically servants, cleaners, porters and little else, a largely Shiite minority sidelined for generations, and in some instances massacred, by Pashtun rulers.

title: Patriots in Pain, and the Cowboys in First
description: As important as Sunday was for teams hoping to get into the playoffs, the most critical postseason moment might have come for a team that was already in.

title: James Cameron Responds to Critics of Smoking in Avatar
description: James Cameron, the director of Avatar, is not one to do things halfway. Asked for a response to those who objected to the movies scenes in which the scientist Dr. Grace Augustine, portrayed by Sigourney Weaver, puffed on a cigarette, Mr. Cameron wrote this:

title: U.S. Intensifies Screening for Travelers From 14 Nations
description: Citizens from nations including Pakistan, Saudi Arabia, and Nigeria will face intense screening, but U.S. citizens will no longer face the full range of security imposed after the Christmas Day bomb plot. Read the full story.

title: Arenas Incident and N.B.A.s Image
description: As the N.B.A. closed out a decade that included a brawl involving players and the crowd and a referee betting scandal, a fresh incident threatens the leagues image.

title: News Sites Dabble With a Web Tool for Nudging Local Officials
description: Doug Hardy, an associate editor and Internet supervisor for The Journal Inquirer in Manchester, Conn., wanted to increase page views on its Web site.

title: Flights Out of Newark Airport Halted for Possible Security Breach
description: Flights out of one terminal at Newark Liberty International Airport were temporarily halted Sunday night as officials investigated a possible security breach.

title: Alabama Democrat Toes the G.O.P. Line
description: ANDALUSIA, Ala.  Among the men who gather every morning at 6 oclock at the Churchs Chicken here on Three Notch Street, there is general agreement that the Obama administration is doing a very bad job of running the country. And the stakes are as high, as one coffee drinker put it, as the survival of the countrys culture, economy and way of life.

title: Danish Police Start Inquiry in Cartoonist Attack
description: OSLO  The Danish police have ransacked three apartments in an attempt to determine whether a 28-year-old immigrant from Somalia acted on his own initiative on Friday when he was suspected of trying to kill a newspaper cartoonist whose 2005 drawing of the Prophet Muhammad set off pitched riots among offended Muslims in the Middle East and elsewhere.

title: Another Chance to Dine With Andr
description: Good dinner companions are hard to find, especially in this era of distracted iPhone-texters and constant tweeters. Take a break from the digital age and head to the Walter Reade Theater tonight for a screening of My Dinner With Andre, part of a series devoted to the French director Louis Malle. This 1981 film stars Wallace Shawn (he co-wrote it with Andr Gregory), as Wally, a playwright in an oversize raincoat who takes acting jobs when he can get them to make ends meet. In his original review for The Times, Vincent Canby wrote, My Dinner With Andre is just that, nearly two hours of talk about theater, art, life, electric blankets and Western Civilization, over dinner. Bon apptit.

title: Iranian Filmmakers Keep Focus on the Turmoil
description: CAIRO  Irans government cannot silence the filmmakers.

title: Nuance Communications Buys SpinVox, Which Converts Voice Mail to Text
description: SpinVox, a former high-flying British start-up that developed a system for converting telephone voice-mail messages to text, has been sold to an American software provider for less than a quarter of the valuation it once commanded.

title: Out of the Mouth of Ryan, a Soundtrack of the Jets Ups and Downs
description: In his first season as the Jets coach, Rex Ryan talked. And talked. And talked some more.

title: Billionaires Ex-Wife Hires New Lawyer in Civil Suit
description: Patricia Cohen, the ex-wife of the hedge fund billionaire Steven A. Cohen, has a new lawyer representing her in the civil racketeering lawsuit she filed against Mr. Cohen.

title: Trivial Pursuit
description: Start the New Year off right by exercising your brain as well as your body. Tonight, Le Poisson Rouge is hosting the Big Quiz Thing, a live trivia event that has been running since 2002. Beginning at 7:30, the quizmaster Noah Tarnow will be on hand to present questions onstage and on a video screen while groups of contestants collaborate to produce answers and vie for a chance to win $250. We suggest studying up ahead of time for a special round of Rebus in Peace, which requires contestants to guess the names of celebrities who have died in the past year based on clever clues. Why let that People magazine subscription go to waste?

title: Doing the Wamble Twang
description: Doug Wamble specializes in a rustic Southern sound, from the bluesy cry of his vocals to the quavering twang of his acoustic guitar, writes Nate Chinen. Hes a magnetic performer even by himself; in a working band like the one he leads here, with Rich Hinman on pedal-steel guitar and Jeff Hanley on bass, he can be gripping. Mr. Wamble, who hails from Tennessee, will be at Bar Next Door on Macdougal Street tonight beginning at 8:30 p.m., with another show at 10:30.

title: Limbaugh to Resume Radio Show on Wednesday
description: Rush Limbaugh will return to his talk show on Wednesday, two days later than planned, after a two-day stay at a hospital in Hawaii.

title: Knicks Take Out Pacers, and Suspense, Early
description: There were 3 minutes 26 seconds left in the first quarter Sunday night, the Knicks up by 15 over the Indiana Pacers. Suddenly, the decibel level started to rise at Madison Square Garden. Some fans even stood and clapped. Al Harrington and Nate Robinson were reporting in, and the summer-warm welcome was not for Harrington.

title: Inside the Classroom
description: Teach for America is nearing its 20th anniversary and has 17,000 alumni who committed two years of their lives to teaching in some of the nations most troubled schools. One person currently in the program is David Donaldson, who teaches English at a charter school in Baltimore.

title: Seymour Wittek Dies at 88; World War II Hero at Home
description: Seymour Wittek, a former Coast Guardsman who helped battle a fire that threatened to devastate New York Harbor during World War II, and six decades later gained the recognition he coveted for his units heroism, died Wednesday at a hospital in the Bronx. Mr. Wittek, who lived in Ossining, N.Y., was 88.

title: Media Equation: And a Tablet Will Lead Them
description: In todays Media Equation, David Carr writes:

title: Through Ups and Downs of Illness, Creativity Endures
description: Janet Dennard can still hear the hum of her sewing machine. Late at night, the memory of it lulls her back to sleep.

title: At a Botanica, New Year Means Renewal, and Jinx Removal
description: Cecilia Oliver was having a problem with her lover and needed some help. Hes being resistant, she explained. I want where hes submissive to me at all times.

title: Suffolk County Executive Weighing Primary Challenge to Paterson
description: The first politician to announce a possible primary challenge to Gov. David A. Paterson is a well-financed, conservative Democrat  and his last name is not Cuomo.

title: Authority Seeks Bids for Partner on Tower
description: The central tower at ground zero, designed to rise to 105 stories, has been characterized by some as a symbol of New Yorks resilience, and reviled by others as a white elephant. Now it will pick up a new label: for sale.

title: Unions Money Fueled Lavish Lifestyle, Prosecutors Say
description: In her working hours, Melissa G. King administered benefit funds for the sandhogs union, associating with the muscled and plain-spoken men who blast through earth and darkness to build tunnels beneath the city.

title: Muslim Deli Owners Must Choose Koran or Customers
description: Most of Khairul Kabirs customers at the Madison Deli and Grocery in East Harlem do not realize that his jovial smile masks a lingering sense of shame.

title: Parolee Held in Boys Killing Was Mentally Ill, Mother Says
description: The man accused of fatally stabbing a 9-year-old boy in an Upper Manhattan apartment over the weekend has suffered from schizophrenia for many years and was paroled from prison in May after serving five years for assault, according to family members and the police.

title: Deborah Howell, One of the First Women to Lead a Big U.S. Paper, Dies at 68
description: Deborah Howell, one of the first women to become the top editor of a large American newspaper, died Friday in New Zealand, where she was struck by a car while on foot. She was 68 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Neediest | Looking Ahead
description: Janet Dennard, who has struggled with bipolar disorder and a frayed relationship with her daughter, channels her creative energy into sewing.

title: Next Up on Cable TV, Higher Bill for Consumers
description: The performances on American Idol may be erratic and the plot twists on Lost may be unpredictable, but one facet of television is certain: the costs just keep going up.

title: The Smartphone Makes and Breaks
description: What will the mobile phone devour next? It swallowed up the personal digital assistant, the gadget that defined the beginning of the last decade, and is eating through the landline telephone, digital camera, MP3 player and even the wristwatch. The creative destruction has just begun.

title: Yes, It Was Torture, and Illegal
description: Bush administration officials came up with all kinds of ridiculously offensive rationalizations for torturing prisoners. Its not torture if you dont mean it to be. Its not torture if you dont nearly kill the victim. Its not torture if the president says its not torture.

title: Where the Action Is on Climate
description: Even as many members of Congress resist as too hard or too costly the steps necessary to address global warming, American cities and states  the largest of which have carbon footprints bigger than those of most nations  have quietly been making serious commitments to curb emissions. Instead of finding reasons to do nothing, Congress should build on these actions to fashion a national response to climate change.

title: Prisons and Budgets
description: The United States, which has less than 5 percent of the worlds population, has about one-quarter of its prisoners. But the relentless rise in the nations prison population has suddenly slowed as many states discover that it is simply too expensive to overincarcerate.

title: Really Big Money Politics
description: The nations hard times are proving to be boom times for the lobbying industry in Washington. Lobbyists are expected to easily break their record of $3.3 billion in annual business, raising an inevitable question: How much more in special-interest donations will be bagged by lawmakers as they are furiously lobbied on everything from health care reform to economic regulation?

title: Using Sedation for a Gentler Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Light of a Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: Defending Cadillac Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: That 1937 Feeling
description: Heres whats coming in economic news: The next employment report could show the economy adding jobs for the first time in two years. The next G.D.P. report is likely to show solid growth in late 2009. There will be lots of bullish commentary  and the calls were already hearing for an end to stimulus, for reversing the steps the government and the Federal Reserve took to prop up the economy, will grow even louder.

title: Decline Is Relative
description: Here in the United States, we spent New Years weekend bidding good riddance to the awful, awful aughties  a miserable decade of bubbles and busts, rising health care bills and soaring deficits, domestic terror attacks and overseas quagmires.

title: 4 Afghan War Veterans Look Back, and Ahead
description: WASHINGTON  One of them, an Army Ranger who served three tours in Afghanistan, led a team into a treacherous mountain ravine to recover the remains of 16 American commandos shot down in a helicopter crash. He still remembers how only their boots had been taken off their bodies by the Taliban.

title: Jan. 3: Vikings Beat Giants
description: The Vikings rolled up 487 yards of offense in routing the Giants, 44-7.

title: NBC to Bulk Up Olympic Coverage
description: NBC will augment its multi-network event coverage of next months Winter Olympics in Vancouver with news and studio programming on Universal Sports.

title: Criticized as Too Sedate, Public Advocates Office Intends to Get Louder
description: In a challenge to the administration of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, the citys new public advocate, Bill de Blasio, will unveil a plan on Monday to train aggrieved residents to organize petition drives, demonstrations and civic actions against City Hall.

title: Warm Feelings at Least as Fans Bid Farewell
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Jets and the Giants want the N.F.L. to stage a Super Bowl outdoors in the Meadowlands in February 2014 at the new stadium they will share beginning next season.

title: Bloggingheads: Conservative Fascism?
description: Charles Johnson, left, of Little Green Footballs and Conn Carroll of The Heritage Foundation debate extremism on the right.

title: Fiesta Bowl: Boise State (13-) vs. T.C.U. (12-0)
description: Boise State (13-0)

title: Trying to Add Portability to Movie Files
description: It is easy to take a DVD to a friends house and watch it on his TV. But things are more complicated when digital video downloads are involved. A movie file bought from Blockbuster.com will not work on a Sony HDTV, for example, and videos from iTunes work only on devices with Apple software.

title: Word of the Day | provocative
description: provocative \pr-v-k-tiv\ adjective

title: Jets Rout Bengals and Clinch Playoff Berth
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  On Sunday night, in the bitter cold, the Jets played in the final N.F.L. game of the regular season. They most likely played in the final N.F.L. game at Giants Stadium. But they did not play in the final game of their season, a notion that seemed impossible even to their coach three games ago.

title: Gay in Uganda, and Feeling Hunted
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  Isolation, insults, threats and violence: this is what Ugandas mostly closeted gay community has dealt with for years.

title: Iraqracy
description: BAGHDAD  The old year ended here with mortar shells falling on the heavily fortified Green Zone and with the sounds of scattered gunfire, another reminder of how horrible that past decade had been. The New Year began with an assurance and a continuing mystery.

title: Bernanke Blames Weak Rules for Crisis
description: Regulatory failure, not low interest rates, was responsible for the housing bubble and subsequent financial crisis of the last decade, Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, said in a speech on Sunday, Catherine Rampell writes in The New York Times.

title: Brad Smith Adds Unpredictability to Jets Conservative Game Plan
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Technically, the Jets Brad Smith is a wide receiver, listed as second on the depth chart behind Braylon Edwards.

title: Jets Win and They're In
description: With a 37-0 victory over the Bengals, the Jets clinched a postseason berth in their regular-season finale.

title: U.S. Is Said to Consider Easing Informants Term
description: The Justice Department is weighing whether to ask a federal judge to reduce the jail sentence of a former UBS banker who was a main figure in a wide-ranging tax evasion case against wealthy American clients, a person briefed on the matter said, Lynnley Browning writes in The New York Times.

title: Living With Less and Liking It
description: WHOM do you know whose priorities have shifted from buying products to doing activities with friends and loved ones as a result of the recession?

description: BALTIMORE (wild card, 6th seed) at NEW ENGLAND (East champion, 3rd seed)

title: Yemen Says It Killed Militants as Three More Embassies Shut
description: SANA, Yemen  Yemeni government forces killed two suspected militants with Al Qaeda on Monday and wounded others in a firefight 25 miles north of this capital city, Yemeni officials said, tying the militants to the continuing threats directed against the United States and British Embassies here.

title: South Korea Renews Offer of Liaison Offices
description: SEOUL, South Korea  President Lee Myung-bak renewed a proposal Monday that South and North Korea open liaison offices in each others capitals to facilitate dialogue.

title: An Investment Chief at Third Avenue Is Said to Step Down
description: Martin J. Whitman, Veteran value investor, will relinquish his role as Third Avenue Managements co-chief investment officer, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Leader of Junta Confirms Myanmar Is Planning 2010 Elections
description: HONG KONG  The head of the military junta in Myanmar confirmed Monday that it was planning to hold national elections this year.

title: Has the Financial Center Crown Lost Its Luster?
description: Three years ago, New York authorities worried that London might steal their citys crown as the worlds financial capital. That distinction now looks much less desirable, Reuters Breakingviews says.

title: Obamas War Over Terror
description: The evening before he was sworn into office, Barack Obama stepped out of Blair House, the government residence where he was staying across from the White House, and climbed into an armored limousine for the ride to a bipartisan dinner. Joining him in the back seat were John Brennan, his new counterterrorism adviser, and two foreign-policy advisers, Denis McDonough and Mark Lippert. The three men with the president-elect were out of breath, having rushed more than a mile from transition headquarters on foot after failing to find a taxi in Washingtons preinaugural madness. As the motorcade moved out, they updated Obama on gathering evidence of a major terrorist plot to attack his inauguration. After a weekend of round-the-clock analysis, the nations intelligence agencies were concerned that the threat was real, the men told him. A group of Somali extremists was reported to be coming across the border from Canada to detonate explosives as the new president took the oath of office. With more than a million onlookers viewing the ceremony from the National Mall and hundreds of millions more watching on television around the world, what could be a more devastating target?

title: Bain in $124 Million Deal for Indias Himadri
description: Bain Capital, the American buyout shop, is paying $54.4 million for a 15.6 percent stake in Indian chemical manufacturer Himadri Chemicals.

title: What the Past Cant Tell Investors
description: A stock that builds momentum in one year often carries it over into the next. Might that momentum effect work for the overall stock market?

title: Citis Creator, Alone With His Regrets
description: This is my final annual meeting as chairman, says Sandy Weill, standing near the window of his office, peering at a grainy photograph of him and his wife on stage at Carnegie Hall more than three years ago. They are smiling broadly, and behind them is a packed house of cheering Citigroup shareholders. A huge banner dangling from the balcony reads Thank You Sandy.

title: SpinVox, a Voice-to-Text Converter, Is Bought
description: SpinVox, a former high-flying British start-up that developed a system for converting telephone voice-mail messages to text, has been sold to an American software provider for less than a quarter of the valuation it once commanded, The New York Timess Eric Pfanner reports.

title: Five Tech Themes for 2010
description: From Jenna Wortham at Bits:

title: F.C.C. Chairman Spams Facebook Friends
description: From Brad Stone at Bits:

title: GMAC Gets $3.8 Billion More in Aid
description: The Treasury Department said on Wednesday that it would give $3.8 billion more to GMAC Financial Services and become the auto lenders majority owner because GMAC had been unable to raise sufficient capital on its own.

title: 4 Americans and Briton Killed in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  As a new year began in the war in Afghanistan, coalition casualties continued to mount with four American service members and a British soldier killed over the weekend, according to official announcements Monday.

title: Kraft to Sweeten Cadbury Bid, Report Says
description: Kraft Foods is preparing to sweeten its hostile 10 billion takeover bid for British confectioner Cadbury, The Sunday Times of London reported.

title: Ferrero Said to Discuss Cadbury Bids With P.E. Shops
description: Ferrero, the Italian confectioner, has met with private equity firms, as well as Hershey, to discuss a possible bid for Britains Cadbury, Il Sole 24 Ore reported.

title: Co-Vocabularyear
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared the words that helped define their 2009 for good and ill.

title: JAL Said to Favor Delta Offer
description: The president of Japan Airlines said he is against a bankruptcy proceeding under a state restructuring plan and has no plans to completely withdraw the carrier from overseas flights, The Asahi Shimbun newspaper reported.

title: Novartis to Buy Majority of Alcon From Nestl
description: Novartis, the giant Swiss drugmaker, said Monday that it would take control of the eye-care company Alcon by buying Nestls majority stake for $28.1 billion, raising its own stake to 77 percent, and said it would like to acquire the rest.

title: Watson Wyatt Sews Up $4 Billion Merger With Towers
description: Watson Wyatt Worldwide, the human resources consulting company, completed its merger with rival Towers Perrin Forster & Crosby to form a combined company called Towers Watson that will make its trading debut in the United States on Monday.

title: What Do You Think of the Response to the Foiled Terror Attack?
description: Since the Christmas day terror attempt, airport security has been tightened and questions have been raised about why the U.S. government didnt connect the dots beforehand. What was your reaction to this news story and its aftermath?

title: Tokyo Exchange Starts High-Speed Trading System
description: The Tokyo Stock Exchange will start a new high-speed trading system Monday, scrapping an antiquated, glitch-prone platform for one that is intended to compete with its major global rivals.

title: Rusal I.P.O. Said to Value Shares Cheaper Than Rival
description: United Rusals upcoming initial public offering in Hong Kong could value the worlds largest aluminum producer 16 percent lower than its biggest Chinese competitor, Bloomberg News reported.

title: R.B.S. Says Pakistan Deal Fell Through
description: Royal Bank of Scotland said a deal to sell its Pakistani business had lapsed after failing to get regulatory approval, confirming a statement earlier this month from MCB Bank, the units would-be buyer.

title: The First Speed Read for 2010
description: Highlights from todays media coverage in The New York Times:

title: For the Holiday Season, Paris on Ice
description: Every year during the holiday season (and beyond) a rink appears on the esplanade in front of the majestic splendor of Htel de Ville, Pariss City Hall, set between a pair of brightly-lit old-fashioned carousels.

title: Tippling Point | Natural Wine Bars
description: Kathryn OMara, who last year opened Londons first natural wine bar, Artisan & Vine (126 St. Johns Hill; 44-207-228-4997), grew up drinking wine and works in the wine industry  and yet she had never really liked drinking wine by itself. It tasted funny, she recalled. Like you had to get something plasticky out of your mouth. But after OMara tried natural wine  that is, wine that hasnt been doctored with additives or modern processes of vinification  she had an epiphany. Its a unique fruit-based beverage, she said with a laugh. The shop, in a gorgeous Georgian-era pub in Battersea, sells such bottles as the hypernatural Sicilian vintages from Frank Cornelissen, who uses grapes indigenous to Mount Etna. I wouldnt expect everyone to be as carried away as I was, OMara said. But we have a lot of regulars now who say that they have difficulty going back to ordinary wines. A lot of them say they feel the difference and seek out these natural wines now.

title: Giants Open Thread: What Needs to Be Done?
description: Ernie Palladino has been a Giants beat writer since 1989 and is the only fully credentialed independent blogger covering them. He writes about the team at erniepalladinosgiantsbeat.blogspot.com.

title: U.S. Decline: Do the Numbers Add Up?
description: Todays idea: Americas vital statistics dont add up to long-term decline, a scholar says. In the future, it will have far fewer retirees per capita than other advanced nations while enjoying military prowess and vast resources of energy, agriculture, labor and innovation.

title: Cheerynomics vs. Gloomynomics
Hedge Funds Finish 2009 With a Bang
description: For the global hedge fund industry, 2009 marked one of best years of performance in close to a decade, The Financial Times reported, citing industry data.

title: Equal Taxes for Private Equity?
description: Hedge fund managers and private equity partners are merely beating the system when they pay lower tax rates than their own secretaries and janitors, The Boston Globe says in an editorial.

title: Jets Open Thread: The Beauty of Low Expectations
description: I was lucky enough to be at the Meadowlands last night for the last ride of a roller coaster of a regular season.

title: Delta and Northwest Can Work as Single Carrier
description: Delta Air Lines has received government permission to operate as a single carrier with its Northwest Airlines subsidiary, a Delta executive said Thursday.

title: Stocks Start Year Mixed in Asia, but Up in Europe
description: Global stocks started 2010 on a mostly positive note, rising modestly in Europe after a mixed session in Asia. Wall Street was primed to rise at the start of trading, The New York Timess David Jolly reported.

title: Flights Out of Newark Airport Halted for Possible Security Breach
description: Flights out of one terminal at Newark Liberty International Airport were temporarily halted Sunday night as officials investigated a possible security breach. Read the full story.

title: Sampler: Cliff Crumbles, Owl Eviction, and Mr. April and His Crew
description: Intellectual Heft Goes to Sacramento | Beginning on Monday, 10 scientists and engineers will work with state lawmakers and legislative committees on issues like energy and water as part of a program to bring expertise to Sacramento. The $7 million cost is being picked up by foundations. Each fellow will receive a $45,000 stipend for a one-year term from the California Council on Science and Technology, which oversees the program and has a list of fellows and their assignments. [The San Jose Mercury News]

title: Layoffs in Long Island City, but Growth, Too
description: While Mary Ceruti recognizes that the recession has cast some shadows on Long Island City, Queens, she says the area is still better off than it was eight years ago. Ms. Ceruti, executive director of a nonprofit gallery called the SculptureCenter and a resident who lives there with her husband and 3-year-old daughter, can point to plenty of abandoned development sites and unemployed neighbors. But she is also grateful for the restaurants and boutiques that have cropped up with the opening of so many new condos.

title: Whats a Bailed-Out Banker Really Worth?
description: Last August, as midnight approached on a Friday, two Treasury Department staff members sat in a cramped basement office in the Treasury Building next to the White House and watched as their e-mail in-boxes filled up. The aides worked for Kenneth Feinberg, the governments special master for executive compensation, and they were awaiting submissions from companies that had received (and not yet paid back) billions in what federal regulations call exceptional assistance from the governments Troubled Asset Relief Program, or TARP.

title: The Year in Energy and Climate Policy
description: The American Clean Skies Foundation supports energy independence and a cleaner, low-carbon environment through expanded use of natural gas and renewables. The group also has a news division, Clean Skies News, that endeavors to cover energy and the environment and to inform the public about all forms of energy, objectively and free from bias.

title: Better Ideas? Ford May Have Some
description: Nostradamus Im not.

description: It was billed by the Food Network as The Greatest Night in Culinary History. Mario Batali and Bobby Flay, the celebrity Iron Chefs, traveled to the White House with Emeril Lagasse, the New Orleans restaurateur whom the network calls a Super Chef, to meet up with the White House executive chef, Cristeta Comerford, to receive instructions for an epic Iron Chef smackdown: Mr. Batali and Mr. Lagasse versus Mr. Flay and Ms. Comerford, on the network from 8 to 10 p.m. on Sunday.

title: Goodbye to the Lever, and Hello to the Oval
description: Say goodbye to the voting booth with its quaint little curtain. Say goodbye to pulling the lever for your candidate. And say hello to filling in SAT-style ovals on Election Day.

description: Wall Street ushered in 2010 on Monday with its biggest stock market rally in nearly two months, as signs that manufacturing was strengthening around the world fed hopes that the economy would recover this year.

description: What were reading on Monday morning.

title: After Balmy Hawaii, Chilly Washington
description: HONOLULU  As Air Force One lifted off late Sunday night, President Obama and his family left behind a balmy 77-degree Hawaiian evening. Bearing east, the plane headed toward Washington, where the temperature was a brisk 23 degrees.

title: Obama Faces Full Plate Upon Return
description: President Obama is set to return to the White House shortly before noon, following an 11-day trip to Hawaii. He has no public events listed on his schedule for the rest of the day, but his advisers are bustling through the West Wing to prepare for his arrival  and an even busier year than they anticipated before the holiday break began.

description: For those who missed it over the weekend, we asked readers for suggestions on improving the competitive integrity of late-season games.

title: Cold and Signs of Stronger Economy Drive Oil Above $81
description: HOUSTON  A combination of frigid weather, expectations of an improving economy and new tensions between Russia and Belarus catapulted crude oil prices above $81 a barrel on Monday to the highest close in nearly 15 months.

title: Bernanke in Atlanta
description: Ben Bernanke gave a somewhat odd speech at the American Economic Association meetings. Not a bad speech, and certainly not stupid. But defensive, I think, in the wrong way.

title: A New Year, a New Honor for Hurt Locker
description: Welcome to 2010, a brave new world where film is made of ones and zeros, you can watch them on your phone and yet  wait for it  people are still flocking to the movie theaters. (You and your friends can only play Rock Band for so long.)

title: Biomass Briquette Plant Opens in Cambodia
description: Cambodia opened its first biomass charbriquette factory in Phnom Penh last month, an enterprise that will produce fuel for stoves from waste biomass material.

description: This week, Eric Schofield, the manager at Bicycle Habitat on Lafayette Street in Manhattan, will be responding to readers questions about bicycle maintenance and repair.

title: Eight Steps to a Better Year in 2010
description: Its time to dust ourselves off and get back on the horse. It is a new year with new opportunities  and some old problems. I am not an economist, so perhaps I shouldnt make any predictions about the economy.

title: Credit Suisse Accused of Defrauding Resort Investors
description: Investors at four high-end resorts have filed a class-action lawsuit against Credit Suisse and the real estate services company Cushman & Wakefield, contending that they conspired to inflate the value of the properties so they could take them over, Jim Robbins writes in The New York Times.

title: Blagojevich Will Appear on Celebrity Apprentice
description: Rod R. Blagojevich, the disgraced former governor of Illinois, may never hold an elected office again, but he has at least fulfilled his ancillary goal of getting booked on a reality show. Mr. Blagojevich, who was removed from office last January by the Illinois State Senate after his indictment on federal corruption charges, will be one of 14 contestants competing for the favor of Donald J. Trump on The Celebrity Apprentice, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Blagojevich, who was arrested and charged in December 2008 with conspiring to profit from his authority to appoint a successor for Barack Obama in the United States Senate, was denied in his previous attempt to become a reality television star. In April, a judge rejected his request for permission to travel to Costa Rica for the NBC series Im a Celebrity  Get Me Out of Here!, while he awaits his federal trial. (The judge said at the time that Mr. Blagojevich did not appreciate the position he finds himself in.) Mr. Blagojevichs rivals on The Celebrity Apprentice, which is taped in New York and makes its debut March 14 on NBC, include Darryl Strawberry, Cyndi Lauper and Sharon Osbourne.

title: Intimitations of Decline
description: My column today discusses the possibility of American decline, and how we might avert it. It doesnt venture any bold predictions about the likelihood of our decline, however. For that, I recommend consulting Joel Kotkin (representing the optimists) and Patrick Deneen (speaking for the deep, deep pessimists).

title: Motorsports Links: Death in Dakar Rally
description: Motorsports news from around the Web

title: Monday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appear in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Table 8 Closing, Will Reopen Under Scott Conant
description: As several blogs have speculated, the chef Scott Conant is indeed taking over Table 8, the restaurant in the Cooper Square Hotel, which is closing today for renovations. Although hotel officials had suggested that the name might remain, the restaurant will have a new name and a fresh design by the time it reopens in the coming weeks, said a spokeswoman for the restaurant. Mr. Conant is the chef and an owner of Scarpetta on West 14th Street.

title: Showcase: Disposed Of
description: Japans economic boom once kept the men in the Kamagasaki district of Osaka busy working on buildings and highways. Now they pass the time waiting in free-meal lines and collecting cans.

title: Kenya Seeks to Deport Muslim Cleric to Jamaica
description: LONDON  The Kenyan authorities were reported on Monday to be planning to deport a Jamaican-born Muslim cleric, Abdullah el-Faisal, who may have helped inspire the Nigerian man accused of trying to bomb an American airliner headed to Detroit on Christmas Day.

title: Pioneering Greenhouse Analyst Appraised
description: Global warming has of late felt like a new issue, but its useful once in a while to review the generations-long line of analysis that points to substantial climatic and environmental consequences from rising emissions of greenhouse gases. The basic idea, of course, goes back more than a century, but the real number crunching started in the 1950s, and even drew the attention of the filmmaker Frank Capra, who produced a series of television programs on science (in the post-Sputnik days when science was a high priority), that included The Unchained Goddess, a remarkable 1958 film on weather and climate. It contained a section on greenhouse-driven warming:

title: Total Joins Chesapeake in Gas Joint Venture
description: The French oil giant Total said Monday that it was acquiring a 25 percent stake in tens of thousands of acres of natural gas fields in Texas controlled by Chesapeake Energy in a joint venture deal valued at $2.25 billion.

title: Divergent Views on Signs of Life in the Economy
description: Signs of revival on the factory floor emerged in the United States and Asia on Monday, fueling exultant buying on Wall Street and reinforcing a sense that genuine economic recovery was unfolding.

title: A New Look at High School Students Ambitions
description: The goal of going to college holds broad appeal, regardless of a familys income level, a new survey suggests. And that is true even of students who lack confidence in their own academic preparation.

title: For Law Firms New Chief, Challenges Abound
description: At five-foot-two, H. Rodgin Cohen may not be the tallest lawyer in the room. But his stepping down on Jan. 1 as chairman of Sullivan & Cromwell has left his successor, Joseph C. Shenker, with some big shoes to fill.

title: Secrets Kept Last Week May Lead to Victories This Week
description: Ken Whisenhunt folded up his Arizona Cardinals play card and essentially tucked it in his pocket Sunday. Marvin Lewis rested the Bengals top running back and three defensive starters. The Philadelphia Eagles played a startlingly passive defensive style.

title: A Brief Conversation About Last Nights Iron Chef
description: Ms. Severson barely had her scarf off this morning before she was ranting about last nights Iron Chef America. Mr. Sifton, a little scared by the emotion, suggested moving the conversation to the more impersonal if more easily shared medium of electronic chat. Their conversation follows, for the edification of those interested in such matters and for those who subscribe to Cablevision, which because of a contract dispute, did not broadcastthe event.

title: N.F.L. Playoffs Q. and A. With Judy Battista
description: Judy Battista, who covers the N.F.L. for The Times, answered questions from readers on Monday (in the comment section below). With the playoffs approaching, Judy looks at the rematches that will take place this weekend; three of the four games feature the same matchup as this past Sunday. The Jets and Bengals, Packers and Cardinals, and Cowboys and Eagles square off again. In Mondays Times, Judy took an early look at this weekends games, A.F.C. and N.F.C.

title: Judge Refuses to Delay Prison for UBS Informant
description: A federal judge refused on Monday to delay the prison reporting date for a former Swiss banker-turned-informant who helped start a huge tax evasion investigation.

title: Wake Up, Mr. West: Kanye Says Hes Back in the Studio
description: True to his word, Kanye West let Taylor Swift  and all of 2009  finish before announcing he was back at work on a new record. After a surprise appearance at a Kid Cudi show in Los Angeles just before Christmas (at which Mr. West rapped about begging fashion houses to hire me), Mr. West further baffled fans with a post on his personal blog in which he compared himself with Kobe Bryant, Maya Angelou, Gil Scott-Heron and Nina Simone, The Guardian reported. In the all-caps post at kanyeuniversecity.com, Mr. West thanked his listeners for their constant love and support over these past 6 years, and he said he was working in a studio making new music. He offered few details about his latest effort, saying that he was working with the same dedication that Kobe has on the court, and that his responsibility, like other modern-day poets and artists, is to accurately represent what is happening now, so when the powers that be try to rewrite history you can always look at our works and find truth and sincerity. Mr. West has generally kept a low profile since a September incident in which he interrupted an acceptance speech by Ms. Swift at the MTV Video Music Awards.

title: Group Gives Up Death Penalty Work
description: WASHINGTON

title: Europe Seems Set to Approve Krafts Cadbury Bid
description: Kraft Foods appears likely to win conditional regulatory approval from the European Union this week for its hostile $16 billion takeover bid for the candy maker Cadbury, Reuters reports, citing an unidentified person familiar with the situation.

title: Security Scare at Newark Airport
description: Flights out of one terminal at Newark Liberty International Airport were temporarily halted as officials investigated a possible security breach.
