description: As Michael Cieply reported in The New York Times on Monday, some of those who oppose smoking in movies have just seen the future, and they are not happy about it.

title: Merz to Buy BioForm Medical for $253 Million
description: The Merz Pharma Group of Germany said Monday that it would buy BioForm Medical for $253 million in cash, expanding its aesthetic medicine business.

title: Dissident Chinese Writer Appeals Sentence
description: BEIJING  Liu Xiaobo, the Beijing writer who was given an 11-year prison sentence on subversion charges on Dec. 25 after urging Chinese leaders to embrace democratic reforms, has appealed his conviction to the Beijing Supreme Peoples Court, one of his lawyers said Tuesday.

title: Travel Deals: JetBlue Flights Starting at $29
description: In celebration of the New Year, JetBlue is offering a Shake Up the New Year Sale with one-way tickets starting at $29. The sale ends Jan. 13 and is good for travel through March 24.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Kovalevs Four Goals Sink Flyers
description: Four games on Sunday, highlighted by Alex Kovalevs rare mortarboard trick  thats four goals, named after the hat with four sides  that carried resilient Ottawa past the Flyers, who seemed to have a hangover from New Years Day. Home teams listed first:

title: Levin Is Sorry for Creating AOL Time Warner
description: Jerry Levin, the former Time Warner chief who helped orchestrate the disastrous merger with AOL shares that resulted in the loss of billions of dollars for shareholders, offered a mea culpa Monday during an appearance on CNBC.

title: The Story and the Backstory at the Fiesta Bowl
description: PARADISE VALLEY, Ariz.  Have you ever seen a sports book that sells itself as more than a sports book? Its not just the book about - generic example here - the Red Sox and Yankees one-game playoff in 1978. Its about how that one game epitomized the tension of the rivalry, the essence of a baseball era and helped Americans adjust to life in the post-Vietnam era. Exaggerating a bit here, but you get the idea. The game itself isnt really that important.

title: If Everyone Is in an Honor Society, Has the Honor Been Cheapened?
description: I wanted to make sure that those of you catching up on your newspaper reading after the holidays saw an article by my colleague Winnie Hu on the proliferation of high school honor societies. As youll see below, were hoping this article will jump-start a comment thread on the issue on The Choice.

title: Meet Mr. Gaga | The Stylist Nicola Formichetti
description: Whether or not you know him by name, youll recognize the stylist Nicola Formichetti by his aggressively modern looks (Lady Gagas metal orb, anyone?). When it comes to his personal style, Formichetti attributes his unrestricted creativity to his multicultural upbringing, which was shared between Italy and Japan. Now 32, he lives in New York, London and Tokyo, and keeps himself busy working as the creative director of the London magazine Dazed and Confused, the fashion director of Vogue Hommes Japan and as a stylist for advertising campaigns for Uniqlo, Dolce & Gabbana and Alexander McQueen, to name just a few. Before kicking off Lady Gagas Monster Ball tour in Montreal, T caught up with Formichetti to ask him about his career, inspirations and what its like to work with Gaga.

title: What to Watch Monday: Love and the End of the World
description: Over on the History Channel theyre bringing in the new year on a cheery note: Its Armageddon Week, and Monday night at 8 the real Doctor of Doom, Michel de Nostradamus, gets center stage with a two-hour program called Nostradamus: 2012. These days it seems as if Nostradamus is credited with predicting everything from the world wars to your latest head cold. This program, Historys Web site says, will look at the parallels between the nightmarish daily headlines and the 2012 prophecies from Nostradamus and others.

title: The Morning Skate: Will the Thrashers Trade Kovalchuk?
description: In their always interesting  and sometimes baffling  annual rankings of the 100 most powerful and influential people in the game, The Hockey News ranked the Thrashers star Ilya Kovalchuk at 71. Strange, since it recognizes that his status as a pending unrestricted free agent renders him berinfluential.

title: Are the Oscars Ready for Another Sassy Southerner?
description: Though some bloggers are already lamenting that there is no drama left in the awards season, the Bagger can still find some stuff to get excited about, and thats not even including the fan fiction version of the potentially in-the-works Goonies musical.

title: Chaos and Inquiry Follow Security Breach at Newark Airport
description: A security officer failed to react when a man went through the wrong door at Newark Liberty International Airport on Sunday afternoon, the authorities said on Monday. When a passenger reported the breach, it set off seven hours of chaos, starting with the evacuation of the airports busiest terminal on one of the busiest travel days of the year.

title: School Closed Today. Just Kidding.
description: Students at Brooklyn Technical High School thought they were in for a bonus New Years vacation when they got an e-mail message on Sunday, purportedly from an assistant principal, that the school would be closed until further notice.

title: Bank of Americas Chief Seeks to Rebuild Trust
description: Bank of Americas new chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan, said Monday that the recession was fading and that the bank had finished making its biggest acquisitions, allowing him to focus on rebuilding relationships with customers.

title: A Bizarre Finale
description: Normally, we would be riveted by the finally here N.F.L. playoffs. Wed be parsing matchups and deconstructing the favorites, double-checking the schedule and setting TiVo, then double-checking that. But with such a weird season spinning to a pitch perfect bizarro-world finish, nothing makes sense. Well, nothing other than the Redskins finally firing Jim Zorn, eight weeks after metaphorically decapitating him and interviewing possible successors while he wandered around looking for his head.

title: Correction
description: An earlier version of this column incorrectly identified the elected official from South Carolina who assaulted a senator with a cane in 1856. He was a member of the House of Representatives, not a fellow senator.

title: Is It Live, or Is It iTunes? Apple Store as Recital Space
description: People passing by the new Apple Store on Broadway and 67th Street on Sunday evening noticed something unusual happening inside the spacious salesroom: a pianist playing a grand piano on a makeshift concert platform right next to the towering window wall.

title: Should a Quadriplegic Mom Have Custody?
description: Kaney ONeill and David Trais will be in a Chicago courtroom this week, arguing over their five-month-old son, Aiden. Trais says that ONeill is unfit to have custody of the boy because she is a quadriplegic, having lost all use of her legs and some use of her arms in a fall off a balcony a decade ago.

title: The Stock of the Decade: Think Energy
description: While some stock market commentators are declaring the 00s the lost decade for stock investments, that certainly wouldnt have been the case if you had invested in energy sector stocks.

title: Bay Passes Physical With Mets
description: Outfielder Jason Bay passed his physical with the Mets on Monday and will be introduced at a news conference at 11 a.m. Tuesday at Citi Field. Any concerns the Mets may have had about the long-term condition of his shoulders were apparently satisfied.

title: For the Moment | Michele Caniato
description: Michele Caniato is the president of Culture and Commerce, a design management consultancy, and of Material Connexion, a materials consultancy and library; both companies are based in New York.

title: Spoleto Festival USA Unveils 2010 Season
description: Updated | 2:35 p.m.  One of Americas oldest theaters will show off its newly finished facelift when the Spoleto Festival USA begins its 2010 season in May. Organizers of that classical music and theater festival in Charleston, S.C., said in a news release that it would feature the reopening of the Dock Street Theater, a performance space whose namesake was first opened in 1736 and says it was the first building designed as a theater in America. After a three-year renovation, the theater will reopen during the festival with a production of Flora, an Opera, a British ballad opera that was performed at the theater in the early 1700s. The Spoleto Festival USA, which was spun off from the Festival dei Due Mondi in Spoleto, Italy, will also feature productions of Nol Cowards Present Laughter, presented by Dublins Gate Theater; Giselle, danced by Nina Ananiashvili and the National Ballet of Georgia; and Dance, a work by Lucinda Childs that includes an original score by Philip Glass; and a short film by the artist Sol LeWitt. The festival runs from May 28 through June 13.

title: Pink Tea Cup to Reopen
description: The Pink Tea Cup, the Greenwich Village soul food restaurant that closed Sunday night after 55 years in business, will soon reopen nearby with its same staff, said Lawrence Page, who said he bought the name from the restaurants owner, Lisa Ford, for $400,000.

title: VWs Green Theme at Autostadt
description: In Sundays Automobiles section I write about auto museums in Germany dedicated to preserving the heritage and history of Porsche, BMW, Audi and Mercedes-Benz (Touring the Temples of German Automaking). The trip did not include a visit to Volkswagens Autostadt because I had been there before, and a detour to Wolfsburg  some 250 miles north of Stuttgart  would have added considerable time to the tour.

title: Readers Examine the Wherefores of Whining
description: When Thelma Karro, a retired librarian who is closing in on 80, gets together with her friends, questions of mere politeness or real concern are often met with a litany of woes. So to avoid lengthy  and unnecessary  back stories, she holds back on asking others, How are you?

title: Chinatown Brasseries Chef to Open a Restaurant in the Village
description: With the Chinatown Brasserie space soon to become less Chinese, its chef, Joe Ng, will be opening an American-Asian spot in the West Village with the Chinese food expert and restaurant consultant Ed Schoenfeld.

title: 'Once and For All'
description: A scene from "Once and For All We're Gonna Tell You Who We Are So Shut Up and Listen," part of the Under the Radar Festival. (Video courtesy of the New Victory Theater)

title: Giants Season the Day After: Embarrassment
description: It is one thing to miss the playoffs. It is quite another to close out the season the way the Giants did on Sunday night.

title: Economy Is Down, but Dubai Tower Tops All
description: For all the towers that give shape to Dubais skyline, the city-state still hails the addition of each new one as a reaffirmation of its reach-for-the-skies spirit.

title: Economy Is Down, but Dubai Tower Tops All
description: Even in the midst of a devastating real estate crash, Dubai pulled out all the stops Monday to celebrate the opening of the worlds tallest building: a rocket-shaped edifice that soars 828 meters, or 2,717 feet, with views that can reach 100-kilometers, or 60-miles.

title: The Year of Darwin
description: Steven Shapin has a wonderful essay in the London Review of Books looking at the remarkable outpouring that accompanied Charles Darwins bicentennial last year  the exhibitions and live readings and one-man musicals, the books and essays and scientific pilgrimages, the postage stamps and Facebook groups and Darwin is my Homeboy T-shirts. He writes:

title: Aging: Abdominal Surgery Risk May Rise With Age
description: Common abdominal surgery like removal of the uterus or the gallbladder may pose a greater risk to older patients than generally reported. A new study finds that 5 percent of those 65 and older died within 90 days of surgery and that 17 percent developed complications.

title: Corporate Tax Returns Face Heavier Scrutiny
description: While the recession may be ending across much of the world, its effect on revenue collectors and corporate tax returns will last much longer.

title: Now Sipping | Stumptown Mocha
description: City Bakerys 18th annual Hot Chocolate Month is around the corner, but dont postpone crazy joy. Have a mocha at Stumptown and proceed directly to the next level.

title: Two Killed in Las Vegas Courthouse
description: LAS VEGAS  A man clad in black opened fire in the federal courthouse lobby here on Monday, killing a security officer and wounding a deputy United States marshal before he was fatally shot by federal officers as he fled.

title: Standoff Builds Over Afghan Cabinet
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The tug of war under way between President Hamid Karzai and Parliament over his cabinet picks entered a new phase Monday when the president ordered lawmakers to delay their long-planned winter holiday so he could offer them a new list of nominees.

title: Regimens: Questioning Benefit of Diabetes Test Strips
description: People with Type 2 diabetes are often advised to use blood-glucose test strips to monitor their blood sugar levels, but a Canadian analysis has found that routine self-monitoring is not cost-effective for many patients: the strips can cost almost a dollar each, and they prevent comparatively few complications of diabetes.

title: Chafee Announces Bid for R.I. Governors Seat
description: Lincoln Chafee, the former Republican senator from Rhode Island who lost his seat to a Democrat in 2006, announced Monday that he would run for governor there as an independent.

title: S.F. Sea Lions May Have Gone South. Or North.
description: Update | 3:04 p.m. Some sea lions have returned to their old home, K-Dock at Pier 39. Their return home has pleased the staff at the company that runs the outdoor marketplace and attraction at Fishermans Wharf. Im so happy, said Sue Muzzin, director of public relations at Pier 39.

title: Final Words on Last Nights Iron Chef
description: As comments trickle in responding to our correspondents reactions to the Sunday night edition of Iron Chef America, Kim Severson and Sam Sifton bring an end to their discussion about the contest, which saw the team of Mario Batali and Emeril Lagasse fall prey to that of Bobby Flay and the White House executive chef, Cristeta Comerford, in a kitchen battle that had them using vegetables harvested from the White House garden.

title: Study Says Women With Mate Get Heavier
description: It is widely known that women tend to gain weight after giving birth, but now a large study has found evidence that even among childless women, those who live with a mate put on more pounds than those who live without one.

title: After Holiday Gluttony, a Perfect Time for Entree Salads
description: If the holiday season was one feast after another for you, you may have resolved to eat nothing but salads in January. This can be a diet to look forward to, as there are plenty of ways to make salads interesting and satisfying.

title: Football Culture Keeps Some in the Dark
description: The old football mentality  play through pain or get out of the way  can be dangerous, particularly in the murky area of brain injury.

title: One on One: Jack Dorsey of Twitter and Square
description: I recently sat down for coffee with Jack Dorsey to discuss Twitter, the location-based service Foursquare and his latest venture Square, an on-the-go credit card payment platform. Mr. Dorsey is the co-founder and chairman of Twitter, an angel investor in Foursquare and chief executive of Square.

title: Major Issues: Writing Text-Supported Arguments About the Purpose of College
description: Overview | What is the purpose of a college education? In this lesson, students examine the controversy over restructuring university curriculum to focus more on job-related skill development and less on traditional liberal arts learning. They then develop and practice the skill of supporting an argument with textual evidence by crafting a letter that argues for or against restructuring university curriculum.

title: A Third Party Crasher Is Reported
description: The Salahis, it turns out, apparently were not the only ones who arrived uninvited to President Obamas first state dinner at the White House.

title: Camuss Death and a Rare French Sports Car
description: Monday marks the 50th anniversary of the death of Albert Camus, the existentialist philosopher and novelist  and of the brief moment of notoriety Camuss death brought to the car in which he died, a Facel Vega.

title: A Placard Makes Parking a Breeze
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Spiced Red Lentil Dal
description: Mark Bittman makes spiced red lentil dal, a simple vegetarian dish from India.

title: Judge Excludes Media Reports in Bank of America Case
description: The federal judge overseeing the governments civil lawsuit against Bank of America over its Merrill Lynch deal ruled Monday that media reports about the merger could not be used as supporting evidence.

title: From Davis and White to India, With Love
description: American ice dancers Meryl Davis and Charlie White thought their Indian-themed original dance program could be popular.

title: Newark Airport Delays Cause Ripple Effect
description: Officials were trying to determine on Monday how a man who walked through the wrong door on Sunday turned a busy airport terminal into a human traffic jam. Read the full story.

title: The Nifty 50 | Julian Louie, Designer
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Agency Wont Be on Reality TV Series
description: A reality series in the works at MTV may be big, but it wont be Huge.

title: Event Planners Try to Dodge Slide of Dollar
description: Although it has ticked up a bit recently, the United States dollar did not have a particularly good 2009. Nor was its value against competing currencies like the euro and Japanese yen easy to predict.

title: Elevating Simple Legumes, Just Enough
description: IF the word dal conjures up images of a simple dish of well-flavored lentils, the kind of thing you might see at an Indian lunch buffet, thats not inaccurate. But it is incomplete, because dal is a generic term for bean dishes, and for the beans and lentils used to make them.

title: Tips for Cutting Your Cable Bill
description: A new deal, covered in this New York Times article, between News Corporation and Time Warner Cable doesnt just mean Time Warner will have to pay subscriber fees for the Fox Broadcasting network.

title: Spiced Red Lentil Dal
description: 2 tablespoons peanut oil

title: The Best Vegetable Youve Never Tried
description: FOR weeks, Bill Maxwell of Maxwell Farms in Changewater, N.J., put the rutabaga bug in my ear every Saturday morning at the farmers market.

title: Tharps Sinatra Show Is Broadway Bound
description: Its been nearly 35 years since Frank Sinatra played the Great White Way, but Ol Blue Eyes is back: the singers music and voice will return to Broadway in a Twyla Tharp musical that its producers said on Monday will transfer to the Marquis Theater later this year. The musical, which is conceived, choreographed and directed by Ms. Tharp, was previously titled Come Fly With Me when it was presented at the Alliance Theater in Atlanta last fall, but will be called Come Fly Away for its Broadway run. (The shows press representatives did not immediately offer an explanation for the name change, you dig?) Casting for Come Fly Away was not announced; it is to begin previews at the Marquis on March 1 and open on March 25. Mr. Sinatras only previous Broadway credit, according to ibdb.com, was a 1975 concert performed at the Uris Theater with Ella Fitzgerald and Count Basie. Ms. Tharp (Movin Out) has previously used Mr. Sinatras music in her dance pieces Once More Frank, Nine Sinatra Songs and Sinatra Suite.

title: When Doctors Are Sued (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Managing Manure (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: What I Learned
Of Grief and Bereavement (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Options for Bone Loss, but No Magic Pill
description: A reader recently complained that her elderly mother had faithfully taken the medication prescribed to protect her osteoporotic bones from fracture but still broke her hip as she walked from her bedroom to the bathroom one morning. The older woman recalled that she had felt her hip give way and then fell, not the other way around.

title: Contact Lens, 1930
description: Contact lenses had a long history before they were mentioned in The New York Times.

title: Treating Patients When Language Is Only One of the Barriers
description: A defective heart, a child detained by border guards  Julia Barquero had already had her struggles. But now her physician at Bellevue Hospital Center, Dr. Danielle Ofri, was trying to explain to Ms. Barquero that she could not receive a heart transplant because she was an illegal immigrant.

title: Microbes: Fighting Mosquito-Transmitted Viruses With Bacteria That Infect Many Insects
description: A type of bacteria that infects many insects may make mosquitoes more resistant to viruses that can be dangerous to humans, researchers have found.

title: A Love Affair With Panthers, for the Moment
description: NAPLES, Fla.

title: Suppressing Tinnitus With Music Therapy
description: Subjective tinnitus, the ringing or other noise that often accompanies noise-related hearing loss, is a tough problem to treat. But researchers in Germany have come up with a novel approach, a kind of music therapy in which the music is custom-tailored to the person with tinnitus.

title: Much-Maligned Mother of Many Beloved Wines
description: About a decade ago, researchers had some startling news for wine lovers. Some of their beloved grape varieties, including chardonnay and gamay noir, were the offspring of a third-rate parent, gouais blanc. In fact, the research showed that at least a dozen varieties were a result of crosses, a long time ago, between pinot noir and gouais blanc, which had such a bad reputation that its cultivation was at times outlawed.

title: White Lizards Evolve in New Mexico Dunes
description: The White Sands of New Mexico are a good place to study evolution in progress. One reason is that the terrain, gypsum dunes white as a sheet of paper, is so different from the surrounding area. Another is that the dunes formed only about 6,000 years ago.

title: Congress Examines N.F.L. Concussions
description: DETROIT  Dr. Ira Casson, a symbol of the N.F.L.s reluctance to recognize mounting evidence linking professional football and dementia before his resignation as co-chairman of a league committee on brain injuries, continued to deny the existence of any such relationship while testifying before a House Judiciary Committee hearing Monday.

title: In California, a Scrub Oak Is an Old Pro at Cloning
description: In Southern California, a place where most everything is new, botanists have discovered something very old: a scrub oak that has been cloning itself for at least 13,000 years.

title: The Perfect Marriage: Leek and Potato
description: Leek and potato soup. One of the classics, and a great favorite, hot or (as vichyssoise) cold.

title: Using a Viruss Knack for Mutating to Wipe It Out
description: Evolution is a viruss secret weapon. The virus can rapidly slip on new disguises to evade our immune systems, and it can become resistant to antiviral drugs.

title: A City Ballet Stars Reinventions
description: When Peter Boal retired from New York City Ballet in 2005, he left a gap at the dance barre. As it happens, there just arent enough well-proportioned, innately elegant men with scrupulous line and demeanor to go around.

title: Temperature and Exercise
description: Q. Does a person tend to burn more fat exercising outdoors in colder weather or in hotter weather? I am leaning to the colder weather side, since the body has to work harder to keep the body temperature near normal.

title: Where Did the Time Go? Do Not Ask the Brain
description: That most alarming New Years morning question  Uh-oh, what did I do last night?  can seem benign compared with those that may come later, like Uh, what exactly did I do with the last year?

title: Continental Chief Puts Pay On the Line
description: From Micheline Maynard, a DealBook colleague

title: George Lakoff Tries to Reframe Sacramentos Conversation
description: George Lakoff is known for, among other things, writing books about how the outcome of political debates and campaigns often depends on how the conversation has been framed, who controls the metaphors used. He has spoken to lawmakers in Washington and Sacramento and analyzed conservative spin and why liberals have failed in some of their efforts.

title: Secret Service Investigates Obama Effigy in Carters Hometown
description: According to a report from a television station in Georgia, President Barack Obama may have been hanged in effigy in the hometown of former President Jimmy Carter on Saturday. Plains, Ga. is best-known as the home of Mr. Carter and the effigy was found hanging above a billboard celebrating the former president on Main Street.

title: Medical Care That Transcends Words
description: In the chilly bureaucratic confines of the social services office where I worked before college, few people had it in them to waste energy on politeness. Poverty and dependence tended to take a toll on good manners.

title: Man, 25, Arrested on Rape Charges for Second Time
description: A 25-year-old Upper Manhattan man was arrested on Sunday on rape charges, just a little more than two months after prosecutors dropped similar charges against him, according to the police.

title: Hazards: With This Spider, Wear Safety Goggles
description: When a 29-year-old man went to an eye clinic in Britain complaining of a very sore, watery, bright-red eye, doctors at first suspected a virus.

title: A Guide to the Cosmos, in Words and Images
description: In the universe there is always room for another surprise. Or two. Or a trillion.

title: New Envoys Old Advice for Children: Read More
description: BARRE, Vt.  Katherine Paterson, the childrens novelist who will be appointed the national ambassador for young peoples literature on Tuesday, often assures aspiring writers that she showed little apparent talent as a child.

title: In a Hall of Glass, Performing for an Audience of Shoppers
description: People passing by the new Apple Store at Broadway and 67th Street on Sunday evening noticed something unusual happening inside the spacious salesroom: a pianist playing a grand piano on a makeshift concert platform right next to the towering window wall.

title: The Claim: Diabetes Can Lead to Frozen Shoulder
description: THE FACTS Shoulder problems are not what come to mind when most people think of diabetes.

title: For F.D.R. Sleuths, New Focus on an Odd Spot
description: When President Franklin D. Roosevelt died unexpectedly on April 12, 1945, in Warm Springs, Ga., the White House lost no time announcing a cause of death.

title: Travel Apps 2.0
description: Augmented reality  the hot new thing in smartphone technology  is starting to trickle into travel apps.

title: Lenny Kravitz Says He Did Not Leak Michael Jackson Video
description: Two days after part of an unreleased song featuring Michael Jackson was leaked onto the Internet, Lenny Kravitz has announced, via a video posted to Twitter, that he had recorded it with Mr. Jackson and that the leak was unauthorized.

title: Pictures of the Day: Monday, Jan. 4
description: On Dec. 17, Pictures of the Day published an unusual four-slide series by Scott Olson of Getty Images on the evacuation of an Afghan boy, rigid with tetanus, to an American field hospital in Helmand Province. A number of readers asked what happened to the child. On Monday morning, Lens received a note from Lt. j.g. Nichole Benson, who wrote: I am a U.S. Navy Nurse at the Role 3 Hospital who took care of the young boy for the past three weeks and I am pleased to say that he went home with his father today. His father was very happy for the care they both received.

title: BlogTalk: New Year, Same Battles
description: A new year dawns in Washington, and the critics, pundits and bloggers are already putting in their two-cents worth on the issues that will be taken up by pols returning from vacation. The big topics today include health care, of course, terrorism and the soul of the Republican Party.

title: Readers Photos: Curating a Decade
description: When Times editors began brainstorming about ways to mark the end of the decade, it didnt take us long to settle on a course of action: get readers involved.

title: Bushs Supermajorities
description: Last week, discussing the filibuster, I wrote that the Bush tax cuts, No Child Left Behind, and Medicare Part D all passed with Senate supermajorities. I should have written that the Senate versions of those bills passed with supermajorities (that is, filibuster-proof majorities). The initial Senate vote on the 2001 Bush tax cuts, after some horse-trading with Democrats, was 65-35; the vote on the bill that came back from conference, however, was 58-33. The Senate version of Medicare Part D passed 76-21, but the final version passed 54-44. (Neither bill was filibustered, obviously: The 2001 tax cuts were passed using reconciliation, and in the cloture vote for Medicare Part D, 70 Senators voted yea.)

title: Critics' Picks: 'M'
description: A. O. Scott reviews Fritz Lang's "M," about a serial killer and the city he terrorizes.

title: Packing Tetrahedrons, and Closing In on a Perfect Fit
description: More than 2,300 years ago, Aristotle was wrong.

title: Excerpt: 'Chuck'
description: In the new season of the NBC action comedy, its nerdy hero becomes a more competent spy.

title: Census Working Overtime With Advertising
description: The first year of a new decade brings, for Americans, the decennial census. The census for 2010 will be the subject of what is being called the most elaborate advertising and marketing effort to date from the Commerce Department.

title: Cleveland Orchestra Wrangles Over Proposed Salary Cuts
description: Under a cloud of labor strife, the Cleveland Orchestra planned to begin rehearsals on Tuesday. The players contract with management expired on Aug. 30, but both sides agreed to an extension during negotiations for a new contract. The players union, however, formally terminated the extension agreement, giving them the right to strike, the orchestra management said. Were operating without a contract, said Gary Hanson, the orchestras executive director. That situation represents an unspecified threat to the entire concert schedule.

title: Inside, Outside, All Around the Aesthetics
description: Folk, outsider and other self-taught artists are popularly viewed as exotics, and not without reason. They tend to produce weird, wacky and eccentric objects, and many of them seem to operate on a mental frequency to which few conventional people have access.

title: Pulling Out All the Stops to Rescue a TV Hero
description: BURBANK, Calif.  Remember when Chuck was a show about a helpless newcomer maneuvering ineptly through a world of espionage and danger? Cherish those memories.

title: Attacker in Afghanistan Was a Double Agent
description: This article is by Richard A. Oppel Jr., Mark Mazzetti and Souad Mekhennet.

title: Frank Words About Chuck From Josh Schwartz
description: Back in April, we had either the good fortune or poor timing to speak with Josh Schwartz, the co-creator of Chuck, at a time when he still wasnt sure if that cult NBC series, about a computer nerd with a spy database in his brain, was going to be renewed for a third season.

title: What Theyre Saying About the Debacle in Denver
Giants Make a Change, Still Stinging From Failure
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The dismissal of Bill Sheridan as the Giants defensive coordinator Monday ended an unusual day of public soul-searching for the franchise.

title: A New Sort of Culture War
description: As Avatar continues to dominate the box office, earning more than $1 billion globally in just a few weeks, more critics are weighing in on What It All Means, culturally. The public health perspective aside, the film represents, as the Bagger has noted, the future of movies: a synthetic high-tech saga, worthy of forking over a few extra bucks at the ticket machine. Its likely competitor in the best picture race, Jason Reitmans Up in the Air, meanwhile, feels of-the-moment, handcrafted and indie  even though it stars the worlds slickest movie star in George Clooney, and comes from a writer-director who is himself a product of Hollywood. Their likely matchup has, as Owen Gleiberman put it in Entertainment Weekly, a King Kong vs. Godzilla culture-war vibe, or, as the Bagger likes to think of it, Autotune Kanye vs. Lil Country Star Taylor.

title: Day One Joys
description: The stock market is up today. The S.&P. 500 ended the day with a gain of 1.6 percent.

title: College Report: A Full Denver Cup
description: The holiday season may be over, but college hockeys schedule was full of holiday tournaments this weekend before conference play dominates the second-half race to the finish. While most of the tournaments feature a grab-bag of quality teams and subpar competition, the Denver Cup has traditionally served as a great appetizer for the stretch run. Last season, Boston University took the Cup on its way to a national championship.

title: Skiff and Sprint to Unveil a Reading Device
description: Sprint and a start-up company called Skiff said on Monday that they would preview the first Skiff Reader in Las Vegas this week at the Consumer Electronics Show.

title: Britain Informed U.S. About Nigerian, Official Says
description: LONDON  As officials on both sides of the Atlantic review intelligence lapses in the case of the 23-year-old Nigerian accused of attempting to bomb a Detroit-bound airliner on Christmas Day, a government spokesman said Monday that Britain had passed information about the suspect to American authorities before the bombing attempt.

title: Adu and Altidore Out-Tweet the British Press
description: Soccer players are now scooping the voracious media that cover them. While January is traditionally the time of rampant speculation in tabloids and on Web sites about which player will move where, a couple of American forwards are tweeting themselves to the forefront of the transfer market speculation.

title: Fiesta Bowl: No. 6 Boise State (13-0) vs. No. 4 Texas Christian (12-0)
description: In its infinite wisdom, the B.C.S. opted to match Boise State and T.C.U. against each other rather than give each the chance at unseating one of college footballs big boys. After watching the Sugar Bowl, who wouldnt have loved to see T.C.U. take on the Gators? Or see Cincinnati head out to Tempe to play Boise State in this Fiesta Bowl? Alas, that time has passed. What remains is a rematch of last seasons Poinsettia Bowl, which saw the Horned Frogs outlast the Broncos by a single point. These top teams deserved better, as each could have used a win over a B.C.S. conference opponent to vault into next seasons preseason top five.

title: New Health Rule: Quit Worrying About Your Health
description: Have you had your five to nine servings of vegetables today? Exercised for an hour? Cut back on saturated fat and gotten eight hours of sleep?

title: Music Therapy to Treat Tinnitus
description: German researchers have come up with a form of music therapy that may help quiet the noise of tinnitus, a constant ringing or other sound in the ear. Tinnitus can occur after a noise-related hearing loss and is a particularly frustrating and difficult problem to treat.

title: After Planning the Party of the Year, the First Workday of 2010
description: From deep inside a cubicle on the first official workday of 2010 for the hats-and-noisemakers crowd, a question came to mind: How did the people who worked while the rest of the city partied on New Years Eve spend their Monday? Were they still slaving away, if you can use that word about people who orchestrate ball drops in Times Square and mastermind fireworks displays in Central Park?

title: Arenas Admits to Judgment Error in Gun Incident
description: Gilbert Arenas, the embattled Washington Wizards star, met with federal prosecutors on Monday and afterward issued a statement apologizing for his role in a handgun-related incident in the Wizards locker room.

title: Samurai Shopper | Whos Your Daddy?
description: Its generally a life-changing event when people come out of the closet. For Samurai Shoppers though, going into the closet is equally momentous. You may possess a flawless fashion sense, but mistakes do happen: sweaters stretch, bodies shrink, trends outstay their welcome. A true Samurai probes her closet ruthlessly, banishing yesterdays news and all traces of impulse purchases. Even I have fallen victim to acolytes of Dracula.

title: Iran Professors Ask for End to Violence
description: Risking expulsion and possible arrest, 88 professors at Tehran University signed a letter on Monday calling on Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the countrys supreme religious leader, to end the use of violence against protesters, saying it was a sign of the governments weakness.

title: In Galleon Cases, Timing Could Be Everything
description: Peter J. Henning, a professor at Wayne State Law School, specializes in issues related to white-collar crime and follows them for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: Cold Arctic Pressure Pattern Nearly Off Chart
The Nifty 50 | Heidi Mount, Model
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Eating and Gaining Together
description: Many people gain weight as they age, but a large Australian study shows that women with partners gain more weight than women who are single.

title: Spoleto Festival Usa Unveils 2010 Season
description: One of Americas oldest theaters will show off its newly finished facelift when the Spoleto Festival USA begins its 2010 season in May. Organizers of that classical music and theater festival in Charleston, S.C., said in a news release that it would feature the reopening of the Dock Street Theater, whose namesake was first opened in 1736 and was among the first buildings in the country to be used solely for theatrical performances. After a three-year renovation, the theater will reopen with a production of Flora, an Opera, a British ballad opera that was performed at the theater in the early 1700s. The Spoleto Festival USA, which was spun off from the Festival dei Due Mondi in Spoleto, Italy, will also feature productions of Nol Cowards Present Laughter, presented by Dublins Gate Theater; Giselle, danced by Nina Ananiashvili and the National Ballet of Georgia; Dance, a work by Lucinda Childs that includes an original score by Philip Glass; and a short film by the artist Sol LeWitt. The festival runs from May 28 through June 13.

title: Late Midlife Crisis, Prompted by a Violent Encounter
description: Over the years, in a succession of funny-sad-usually entertaining novels, Anne Tyler has created a male character instantly recognizable as a distinct species despite individual variations: a lost soul or self-proclaimed loser who realizes that his life is stalled and who sinks into a low-grade depression  a sad-sack sort of fellow, basically well meaning but detached and more than a little passive.

title: C.I.A. Is Sharing Data With Climate Scientists
description: The nations top scientists and spies are collaborating on an effort to use the federal governments intelligence assets  including spy satellites and other classified sensors  to assess the hidden complexities of environmental change. They seek insights from natural phenomena like clouds and glaciers, deserts and tropical forests.

title: Kanye West Says Hes Back in the Studio
description: True to his word, Kanye West (below right) let Taylor Swift  and all of 2009  finish before announcing he was back at work on a new record. After a surprise appearance at a Kid Cudi show in Los Angeles just before Christmas (at which Mr. West rapped about begging fashion houses to hire me), he further baffled fans with a post on his personal blog in which he compared himself to Kobe Bryant, Maya Angelou, Gil Scott-Heron and Nina Simone, The Guardian reported. In the all-caps post at kanyeuniversecity.com, Mr. West thanked his listeners for their constant love and support over these past six years, and he said he was working in a studio making new music. He offered few details about his latest effort, saying that he was working with the same dedication that Kobe has on the court and that his responsibility, like other modern-day poets and artists, is to accurately represent what is happening now, so when the powers that be try to rewrite history, you can always look at our works and find truth and sincerity. Mr. West has generally kept a low profile since a September incident in which he interrupted an acceptance speech by Ms. Swift at the MTV Video Music Awards.

title: 14 Queens Libraries to Close on Weekends
description: The Queens Library announced on Monday that beginning next month, 14 library branches in Queens will no longer serve customers on the weekends.

title: Tharps Sinatra Show Is Bound for Broadway
description: It has been nearly 35 years since Frank Sinatra played the Great White Way, but Ol Blue Eyes is back: his voice will return to Broadway in a Twyla Tharp musical that its producers said on Monday would transfer to the Marquis Theater later this year. The musical, conceived, choreographed and directed by Ms. Tharp, was titled Come Fly With Me when it was presented at the Alliance Theater in Atlanta last fall (above, with Keith Roberts and Karine Plantadit) but will be called Come Fly Away for its Broadway run. (The shows press representatives did not immediately offer an explanation for the name change, you dig?) It is to begin previews at the Marquis on March 1 and open on March 25. Casting was not announced. Mr. Sinatras previous Broadway credit, according to ibdb.com, was a 1975 concert at the Uris Theater with Ella Fitzgerald and Count Basie. Ms. Tharp (Movin Out) has used Mr. Sinatras music in her dance pieces Once More Frank, Nine Sinatra Songs and Sinatra Suite.

title: Cleveland Orchestra Without Contract
description: Under a cloud of labor strife, the Cleveland Orchestra planned to begin rehearsals on Tuesday. The players contract with management expired on Aug. 30, but both sides agreed to an extension during negotiations. The players union, however, formally terminated the extension agreement, giving them the right to strike, the orchestra management said. Were operating without a contract, said Gary Hanson, the orchestras executive director. That situation represents an unspecified threat to the entire concert schedule. The orchestra management is seeking cuts in salaries and benefits, said Leonard Di Cosimo, president of Local 4 of the American Federation of Musicians in Cleveland. A negotiating session is scheduled for Wednesday, a day before the years first concert.

title: Celebrity Apprentice Books Rod Blagojevich
description: Rod R. Blagojevich, the disgraced former governor of Illinois, may never hold an elected office again, but he has at least fulfilled his ancillary goal of getting booked on a reality show. Mr. Blagojevich, who was removed from office last January by the Illinois State Senate after his indictment on federal corruption charges, will be one of 14 contestants competing for the favor of Donald J. Trump on The Celebrity Apprentice, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Blagojevich, who was arrested and charged in December 2008 with conspiring to profit from his authority to appoint a successor for Barack Obama in the United States Senate, was denied in his previous attempt to become a reality television star. In April a judge rejected his request for permission to travel to Costa Rica for the NBC series Im a Celebrity ... Get Me Out of Here! while he awaits his federal trial. (The judge said at the time that Mr. Blagojevich did not appreciate the position he finds himself in.) Mr. Blagojevichs rivals on The Celebrity Apprentice, which is taped in New York and makes its debut on March 14 on NBC, include Darryl Strawberry, Cyndi Lauper and Sharon Osbourne.

title: One Monteverdi Work and 400 Years of Debate
description: The classical music world, besotted with anniversaries and now deep into the Romantic age, will celebrate the bicentenaries of Schumann and Chopin this year. In addition the early-music contingent, appropriately, will hark back another two centuries, to a landmark work whose informal name all but announces the anniversary, Monteverdis 1610 Vespers.

title: Democrats Likely to Dispense With Conference Committee
description: House Democratic leaders will meet on Tuesday to begin discussing plans to merge their version of major health care legislation with the bill adopted by the Senate on Christmas Eve. But leadership aides in both chambers say there are no plans for a formal conference committee to reconcile the two measures.

title: A Toxic Workplace, With Ill-Tempered Clients
description: There are more than 700 reasons not to visit Australia, Donald Schultz tells us, in a backhanded sort of way, in the opening episode of Wild Recon on Tuesday night on Animal Planet.

title: Dances With Smurfs
description: For all its box office love, Avatar has also been hailed as Dances with Smurfs (cf. South Park). The pop culture fiends at MTV draw some parallels between James Camerons 3D epic and Kevin Costners Oscar-winning Dances With Wolves, as well as the sci-fi reaches of David Lynchs Dune and the dont-exploit-us sensitivity of Disneys Pocohantas.

title: Critics Picks Video: M
description: This week, A. O. Scott looks back at Fritz Langs 1931 film M, about a serial killer stalking the streets of Berlin. Peter Lorre gives what Mr. Scott calls an unnervingly persuasive performance as the killer.

title: Box Offices Ring in Broadways New Year
description: It was a Happy New Year at most Broadway box offices last week, with Wicked, The Lion King and The Phantom of the Opera setting records even after long runs on the boards, while other shows were winding down their runs on financial high notes.

title: New Health Rule: Quit Worrying About Your Health
description: Have you had your five to nine servings of vegetables today? Exercised for an hour? Cut back on saturated fat and gotten eight hours of sleep?

title: Morgan Freeman Becomes CBS Evening News Announcer
description: CBS News is retiring Walter Cronkites voice, nearly six months after the esteemed anchorman died. Beginning Monday, the actor Morgan Freeman will read the introduction to the CBS Evening News.

title: Intense Screenings for 14 Nations
description: There was harsh reaction from around the world to plans by the U.S. to conduct more thorough screenings of passengers arriving here from 14 countries.

title: Even in G.O.P., Lazios Bid for Governor Is Hard Sell
description: CANANDAIGUA, N.Y.  Rick A. Lazio is on a tear: ripping into corruption and cowardice in Albany, blasting state leaders addiction to spending and taxes, warning that New York is on the verge of losing a generation of job seekers to economic decline.

title: Mara Fumes; Sheridan Is Dismissed
description: The Giants president, John Mara, was scathing in his assessment of his team earlier today. A few hours later, the defensive coordinator Bill Sheridan was dismissed. Heres a transcript of Maras discussion with reporters, via Giants.com:

title: Visa Reigns With Silent Tax
description: The growing use of debit cards has meant big profits for Visa, and there are concerns that the company's market power has led to unnecessarily high fees to merchants.

title: Coaxing an Antique Press to Kiss the Page
description: Stop the presses. Thats what Robert Warner, 53, does every time he takes his foot off the treadle at one of the antique letterpresses at Bowne and Company Stationers at the South Street Seaport Museum. Bowne, founded in 1775 and claiming to be the oldest company in the city still operating under the same name, opened the museum print shop to celebrate its bicentennial. Twenty years later, Mr. Warner, an eyeglasses-maker and artist, wandered in to volunteer. Now he is the master printer there in a former cast iron stove factory from 1835, turning out stationery, social announcements and commemorative items to raise money for the museum and teaching the digital generation of schoolchildren an ancient craft.

title: British Prime Minister Appalled by Protest Plan
description: LONDON  A radical Islamic group planning a protest march through the streets of a town that has achieved iconic status in Britain for honoring the passing hearses of British soldiers killed in Afghanistan ran into a stiff rebuff from the British government on Monday.

title: Take Off Your Shoes, and Is the Parrot Loaded?
description: DOES he bite? the screener at the checkpoint asked warily.

title: Shopping With Alexandra Champalimaud
description: A few carefully selected items is often all it takes to warm up even the most sparsely furnished room.

title: Ex-Senator Runs for Governor in Rhode Island as Independent
description: BOSTON  Lincoln D. Chafee, the former Republican senator from Rhode Island who lost his seat to a Democrat in 2006 despite his familys longtime presence in state politics, announced Monday that he would run for governor there as an independent.

title: Where to Buy Warmth
description: CREATING a feeling of warmth at home is essential this time of year  especially in minimalist interiors, which can sometimes feel cold. And adding a few carefully selected items is often all it takes to warm up even the most sparsely furnished rooms.

title: My Favorite 14 Apps of 2009
description: Looking back on the several hundred apps I have evaluated since the start of Gadgetwise, I thought a Best Of list would an appropriate way to kick off the new year. But how do I determine whats best? Apps that are highest rated? Apps with highest number of downloads? Apps that I personally use most? No method seems really perfect, but what I settled on were the apps that I was most likely to show people when they asked What do I need with a smartphone?

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,362 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: The N.F.L. Seasons Leaders for 2009
description: The final N.F.L. leaders in some prominent categories:

title: Samsung Introduces Hybrid D.S.L.R. Camera
description: Samsung has announced, with limited details, its first interchangeable lens camera. The Samsung NX10 will be displayed at the upcoming CES Show in Las Vegas, so well get more details later in the week.

title: Rising Price of Faith in Frances Shrinking Parishes
description: GEST, France  The soaring steeple, airy flying buttresses and steep slate roof of the 19th-century parish church that dominates this town in western France is  like many other village churches in France  scheduled for demolition, a victim of its size, its condition and, ultimately, municipal budget concerns.

title: Week 17 Quick Hits: A Playoff Format Flaw
description: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com.

title: Morgan Stanley Names New Top Financial Bankers
description: Morgan Stanley named new heads of its financial institutions group last week, the latest reshuffling of its bankers in the wake of changes imposed by its new chief executive, James P. Gorman.

title: A Snowboarders Dream and a Familys Anguish
description: Over breakfast in Copper Mountain, Colo., on Dec. 13, snowboarder Kevin Pearce talked about the wicked crash in the halfpipe that shattered his ankle in June. It kept him off his snowboard until November.

title: Will Profiling Make a Difference?
description: Updated, Jan. 5, 1:10 p.m. |  Philip Baum, a London-based aviation security expert, argues that profiling based on an analysis of the appearance, behavior, itinerary and passport of a passenger can be effective.

title: Third Uninvited Guest at State Dinner
description: WASHINGTON  The saga of President Obamas first state dinner continues.

title: Attempt to Break New Irish Blasphemy Law
description: Last Friday morning in Ireland, about 30 minutes after a new law took effect with the new year that makes blasphemy a crime punishable by a fine of up to $35,000, a group of Irish atheists invited the government to prosecute them by publishing 25 blasphemous statements on an Irish Web site.

title: Pitching a Product, Without Showing It
description: SPECIAL K, the 54-year-old Kellogg brand, has in recent years aimed at women with its Special K Challenge, which recommends replacing two meals daily with cereal and curtailing snacking to lose up to six pounds in two weeks. The popularity of the plan led the brand to expand to nine flavors and develop noncereal products like frozen waffles, protein bars, crackers, shakes and powdered drink mixes that can be substituted for cereal at mealtimes or eaten as the two daily snacks the plan permits.

title: Neediest | Going Back to School
description: Out of work and behind on rent, Denise Wintz got help from the Neediest Cases Fund to get caught up, and went back to school to pursue a new career.

title: Demonstrating Resourcefulness in the Face of Career Challenges
description: Have a problem? Denise Wintz has a Web site for you. Or a book. Or a motivational seminar.

title: Abbott Says Plushenko is Just Another Competitor
description: Jeremy Abbott, the 2009 United States national figure skating champion, isnt intimidated by the Russian skater Yevgeny Plushenko.

title: How Visa, Using Card Fees, Dominates a Market
description: Every day, millions of Americans stand at store checkout counters and make a seemingly random decision: after swiping their debit card, they choose whether to punch in a code, or to sign their name.

title: Tax Enforcers Intensify Focus on Multinationals
description: While the recession may be ending across much of the world, its effect on revenue collectors and corporate tax returns will last much longer.

title: As Zorn Exits, Redskins Talk to Shanahan
description: Finally, two years after he was the surprise hire and after a season in which he was stripped of everything but the headset he wore on the sideline, Jim Zorn was fired by the Washington Redskins early Monday morning.

title: Deciphering Hall Ballot Without Superstar
description: There is no higher level for a baseball player than to be a Hall of Famer, and no ranking or seeding among the chosen few. The plaque for Johnny Evers is the same size as the one for Johnny Bench, no distinguishing between obscure and obvious.

title: Washington Post Discontinues Chess Column
description: The Washington Post has ended its chess column written by Lubomir Kavalek. The final column, which was published Jan. 4, noted that Kavalek covered chess for the newspaper for 23 years. Kavalek said in a telephone interview that the column began in 1995 and that before that he had written about chess events, beginning with the 1986 world championship match between Garry Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov.

title: Credit Suisse Is Accused of Defrauding Investors in 4 Resorts
description: HELENA, Mont.  Investors at four high-end resorts have filed a class-action lawsuit against Credit Suisse and the real estate services company Cushman & Wakefield, contending that they conspired to inflate the value of the properties so they could take them over.

title: In Yemen, U.S. Faces Leader Who Puts Family First
description: SANA, Yemen  The United States is quickly ramping up its aid to Yemen, which Washington sees as a revived new front against Al Qaeda. But one of the most delicate tasks will be managing the relationship with the president of Yemen, Ali Abdullah Saleh, who has filled his government with numerous members of his family and who wants to ensure that his son Ahmed succeeds him, Yemeni officials, analysts and Western diplomats say.

title: In Russia, a Bankrupt Town Keeps Humming
description: BARANCHINSKY, Russia  For a few weeks this winter, this town wobbled on the edge of nonexistence.

title: Court Upholds Conviction in 9/11 Case
description: A federal appeals court on Monday upheld the conviction of the only person who has been tried in a United States court on charges of involvement in the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Roberto Alomar Awaits the Halls Call
description: When he passes a career milestone, Ken Griffey Jr. often says that he never dreamed about it. All he ever wanted, Griffey will say, was to be as good as his father.

title: Novartis to Pay $28 Billion for a Majority Stake in Alcon
description: Novartis, the large Swiss drug maker, said Monday that it would take control of the eye care company Alcon by buying a majority stake from Nestl for $28.1 billion. The move would raise its stake in Alcon to 77 percent, and Novartis said it was interested in acquiring the rest of the shares.

title: The Resurgence of the Hazaras
description: For most of Afghanistans history the Hazara were typically servants, cleaners, porters and little else, an ethnic Shiite minority sidelined for generations.

title: Oil Feud Reflects Growing Rift Between Russia and Belarus, Once Close Allies
description: MOSCOW  The oil price dispute that erupted over the weekend between Russia and Belarus has been depicted as a threat to European energy supplies  a development that has become something of an annual cold weather ritual. The greater threat, however, seems to be to relations between the two countries, often thought of as the closest of allies.

title: Odds Against Gay Marriage Grow With Setback in Trenton
description: With just two weeks before New Jersey changes governors, gay-rights advocates are facing lengthening odds  and they have been long for some time now  of winning approval of a law that would grant legal recognition to same-sex marriages in the state.

title: Dubai Opens a Tower to Beat All
description: Burdened by debt and a devastating real estate crash, Dubai is doing what it does best: doubling down.

title: Outside the Box
description: Wonder Bread plastic bags sliced and weaved into a rug; buttons nailed and wired to a branch; weathered tree trunks transformed into comical demons. All of these unusual creations are part of Toward Abstraction, a thought-provoking exhibition at the American Folk Art Museum, writes Ken Johnson. The show is an example of the trend in mainstreaming self-taught art, and Brooke Davis Anderson, the museums curator of contemporary art, has selected from the permanent collection some 60 works in which formal, material and procedural elements are asserted with particular vigor. Go to see the imaginative designs of those who work outside the professional art box. Get inspired.

title: Spring Ahead
description: Grab an early start on spring fashion today courtesy of the Japanese master craftsman Issey Miyake. The designers TriBeCa flagship has temporarily set up shop uptown with a pop-up store at 807 Madison Avenue, at 68th Street. You have until Jan. 30 to scout out new items for spring/summer 2010 for both men and women as well as pieces from the Cauliflower, Pleats Please and HaaT lines.

title: The Return of Peter Boal
description: Balletomanes should rejoice tonight when  Pacific Northwest Ballet makes its long overdue New York debut under Peter Boals direction at the Joyce Theater. When Mr. Boal retired from New York City Ballet in 2005 he left a gaping hole, writes Gia Kourlas. As it happens, there just arent enough well-proportioned, innately elegant men with scrupulous line and demeanor to go around. This week Mr. Boal returns to the city not as a dancer but as the artistic director of the Seattle-based company. He has brought 21 dancers to present a program of repertory works, including two that were created for the company: Twyla Tharps Opus 111 and Benjamin Millepieds 3 Movements.

title: New Air Security Checks From 14 Nations to U.S. Draw Criticism
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administrations decision to mandate extra scrutiny  including full-body pat downs  for people flying into the United States from 14 mostly Muslim countries provoked criticism from foreign officials and skepticism from some security experts that the measures would be effective.

title: With Death and Taxes, Timing Is All
description: My wife and I decided that our wills needed an update. The old documents were written so long ago that cellphone was a fairly new word suggesting prison slang for convicts calling home.

title: When a Citizen Feels Impelled to Help
description: Just over a year ago, Laura van Straaten, a 41-year-old multimedia executive who had recently joined the ranks of the underemployed, stopped on a slushy street corner on West End Avenue to watch someone administering CPR to an older man who had collapsed. She saw how hard the man giving CPR was working, the sweat that slicked his face in the December cold as he pressed on the strangers chest, pushing him farther down into a small pile of snow with every compression. And she felt some chagrin that neither she nor the other bystanders could help the man who was struggling to keep that failing heart pumping.

title: Big Plans for Old Sugar Refinery Face Review
description: In 2004, the Domino Sugar refinery that occupied five blocks along the Brooklyn waterfront in Williamsburg for more than 150 years shut down, joining the neighboring brick factories as remnants of the areas industrial past.

title: The Tea Party Teens
description: The United States opens this decade in a sour mood. First, Americans are anxious about the future. Sixty-one percent of Americans believe the country is in decline, according to the latest NBC News/Wall Street Journal survey. Only 27 percent feel confident that their childrens generation will be better off than they are.

title: Google Moves to Keep Its Lead as Web Goes Mobile
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google unveiled a rival to Apples iPhone on Tuesday, part of its careful plan to try to do what few other technology companies have done before: retain its leadership as computing shifts from one generation to the next.

title: True Economic Barometer? How About Bowling
description: As New York struggles to resurrect its economy, it needs powerful new engines of growth. Wall Street may look sturdier, but it will never be the old Wall Street again, when $10 routinely became $1 million during your lunch break. Another eruption in real estate prices? Dubious. The new sports stadiums? Not going to get us there.

title: Man Accused of Second Rape on Same Manhattan Rooftop
description: A 25-year-old Upper Manhattan man was arrested Sunday on charges that he raped a woman on a rooftop on New Years Day  the same place where he was accused of raping a teenager three months ago.

title: Mayor Sticking by Tourism Projections Despite Dropoff in 2009
description: With the number of visitors to New York City declining by almost 2 million last year, it might be reasonable to expect that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg would offer a less than rosy view of the decline, or at least express some concern that a continued slump might be in store in 2010.
Stanley Fish is away this week.

title: An Uneasy Feeling
description: Im starting the new year with the sinking feeling that important opportunities are slipping from the nations grasp. Our collective consciousness tends to obsess indiscriminately over one or two issues  the would-be bomber on the flight into Detroit, the Tiger Woods saga  while enormous problems that should be engaged get short shrift.

title: For Cape Cod Wind Farm, New Hurdle Is Spiritual
description: BOSTON  In a new setback for a controversial wind farm proposed off Cape Cod, the National Park Service announced Monday that Nantucket Sound was eligible for listing on the National Register of Historic Places, guaranteeing further delays for the project.

title: With Physical Behind Him, Bay Joins Mets
description: The slugging left fielder Jason Bay officially joined the Mets on Monday when he passed his physical, the only thing delaying completion of his four-year, $66 million contract. Bay was introduced Tuesday at a news conference at Citi Field .

title: A Team That Wins, but Cant Win Respect
description: I am an invisible man. No, I am not a spook like those who haunted Edgar Allan Poe; nor am I one of your Hollywood-movie ectoplasms. I am a man of substance, of flesh and bone, fiber and liquids  and I might even be said to possess a mind. I am invisible, understand, simply because people refuse to see me.

title: Lawmakers Grill Doctor for His Views on Concussions
description: DETROIT  Although the most theatrical moments of a House Judiciary Committee hearing on football brain injuries on Monday involved the grilling of a former N.F.L. doctor, most of the testimony centered on the application of recently strengthened professional rules to amateur levels, from youth leagues to college programs.

title: Wizards Arenas Says Unloaded Guns Were a Misguided Joke
description: Gilbert Arenas, the embattled Washington Wizards star, apologized on Monday for what he called a misguided joke involving unloaded handguns, but he insisted that he never threatened anyone during a locker-room incident Dec. 21.

title: When the Pilot Pulls Out the Flashlight
description: I DONT enjoy flying as I used to. But who does?

title: It Was All Started By a Mouse (Part 2)
description: (This is the second part of a two-part article. Click here for the first part.)

title: Texass Kindle Raises Hopes and Questions
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.  A couple of weeks after Texas won the 2005 national championship, Sergio Kindle arrived on the Longhorns campus. It was an eye-opening experience for Kindle, then an 18-year-old from inner-city Dallas.

title: This Years Housing Crisis
description: The financial crisis and Great Recession have their roots in the housing bust. When it comes, a lasting recovery will be evident in a housing rebound. Unfortunately, housing appears to be weakening anew.

title: Does Visa Play Fair?
description: We just published an article by Andrew Martin that explains how Visa has become the dominant payment network for credit and debit cards. Among other things, the article reports that Visa makes more than twice as much money on a transaction if a consumer signs a debit receipt rather than punching in a four-digit PIN. Mr. Martin also writes:

title: Not Quite Making a Name for Himself at T.C.U.
description: Texas Christian quarterback Andy Dalton only had a couple of options when it came to playing college football.

title: Pent-Up Anger
description: If what I do prove well, it wont advance.Theyll say its stolen, or else it was by chance.  Anne Bradstreet

title: Health Spending Rises in 2008, but at Slower Rate
description: Health spending grew in 2008 at the slowest pace in 48 years as the recession throttled back the explosive growth of health costs, the federal government reported Monday.

title: Union To Put Horrible Newsday Deal To Vote
description: A proposed contract reached between Newsday and its largest union would cut salaries by 10 percent, extend the workweek and eliminate one week of paid vacation per year, among other concessions, employees were told on Monday.

title: Whats Acceptable for Bank Returns?
description: What is an acceptable return on equity for a bank? That question is likely to dominate the debate among executives, investors and regulators in the 2010.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Monday about the playwright and actor Sam Shepard was published in error. His arrest on charges of speeding and driving under the influence of alcohol occurred a year ago, not early Saturday morning. The Times regrets the error.

title: Corrections
description: A picture with the Saturday Profile about Choi Sung-yong, the leader of Abductees Family Union who works to bring home South Koreans believed to have been kidnapped by North Korea, was published in error. The picture showed Choi Wook-il, a man who was smuggled out of the North by the Abductees Family Union; it was not of Choi Sung-yong.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Tuesday about travelers confusion over new security rules at airports misspelled the surname of a college student bound for Pittsburgh, who passed through security in Philadelphia. She is Current DIgnazio, not DIgnazil.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about accusations that an administrator for the union that represents workers who build tunnels embezzled money to pay for a lavish lifestyle misspelled the name of the school in the Bronx where she sent her children. It is Fieldston, not Fieldstone.

title: Corrections
description: A picture credit last Tuesday with an article about the discovery of a two photographs believed to be of the first immigrant to set foot on Ellis Island when it opened in 1892 misstated her married name. She was Annie Moore Schayer, not Shulman.

title: E-Mail Hoax Raises Hopes of a Day Off
description: For one glorious hour Sunday night, it looked as though Brooklyn Technical High Schools 4,900 students would not have to drag themselves out of bed at 7 a.m. for the first day of school after the long winter break. An e-mail message, purportedly from a school administrator, was sent to student government leaders saying that a construction accident had forced the building to close.

title: Lottery Numbers
Paterson Seeks Overhaul to Combat Corruption
description: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson on Wednesday will unveil a set of sweeping proposals to rein in political corruption in state government, including vastly expanded ethics oversight, term limits for all state officeholders and a system of public campaign financing modeled on New York Citys, administration officials said on Monday.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Monday listing the National Football Leagues final leaders in seven categories included, in some editions, outdated statistics for three players, one each in touchdowns, tackles and interceptions; in some copies, it also omitted two quarterbacks from the passing yards list. A corrected chart can be found at nytimes.com/sports.

title: Sales Spur Optimism in Manhattan Real Estate
description: The 2009 Manhattan real estate market ended on a better note than it began, according to fourth-quarter reports that were to be released Tuesday by the citys largest brokerages.

title: Higginss Goal Lifts Rangers at Garden
description: The Eastern Conference is so mediocre that the Rangers are in seventh place after beating the Boston Bruins, 3-2, on Monday at Madison Square Garden.

title: Jets Ryan Is Planning on Four More Games
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Less than 17 hours after the Jets most dominating and important victory of the season, Coach Rex Ryan stepped purposefully onto a platform Monday, grasped the sides of a lectern and said they had merely earned the right to keep playing football.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 22 about new frequent-flier tiers and other perks being provided by some airlines misstated the number of miles needed to achieve Continental Airlines new top category of Presidential Platinum. It is 100,000 miles, not 125,000.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the Pacific Investment Management Companys hiring of Neel T. Kashkari, who ran the Troubled Asset Relief Program in the Bush administration, misstated the location of the cabin in which he decompressed after leaving that job a few months after the Obama administration took office. It was near Lake Tahoe in northeast  not northwest  California.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Gadgetwise column on Thursday about the Mattel Mindflex game misstated the number of batteries required. It is seven (four C batteries and three AAA batteries), not eight.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Thursday about new stamps the United States Postal Service will issue this year misidentified the image on a stamp portraying Katharine Hepburn that is to be issued on May 12. The image is from her movie Woman of the Year, not from the play West Side Waltz. (The margins on sheets of the stamps depict her in West Side Waltz.)

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Dec. 24 about the replacement of a scheduled production of Speed-the-Plow at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles with a revival of The Subject Was Roses erroneously attributed a distinction to Neil Pepe, who directed the 2008-9 revival of Speed-the-Plow on Broadway and will direct The Subject Was Roses. Mr. Pepe was not nominated for a Tony Award for his direction of Speed-the-Plow.

title: Corrections
description: THE ARTS

title: Curtis Allina Dies at 87; He Put the Heads on Pez
description: Curtis Allina, a candy company executive who presided over a powerful innovation in marketing that was less about the candy itself than it was about the container it came in  and who in unintended consequence created a universe of enraptured collectors  died Dec. 15 at his home in Olympia, Wash. Mr. Allina, who helped bring the world the modern Pez dispenser, was 87.

title: Hate Begets Hate
description: Ugandas government, which has a shameful record of discrimination against gay men and lesbians, is now considering legislation that would impose the death sentence for homosexual behavior. The United States and others need to make clear to the Ugandan government that such barbarism is intolerable and will make it an international pariah.

title: Tasers and Liability
description: A federal appeals court in California has sent a strong warning to law enforcement officials that should make them rethink the all-too-common use of Tasers. It ruled last week that a police officer can be held liable for delivering a high-level electric shock to an unarmed person who poses no immediate threat.

title: MoMA and the Coming Flood
description: The Tim Burton exhibit at the Museum of Modern Art was sold out, which is not serious deprivation at a museum that also offers Czannes apples and Matisses goldfish. But what could disappointed fans of the dark vision of Edward Scissorhands or Gothic Batman turn to?

title: Casey Johnson, Daughter of Jets Owner, Dies at 30
description: The Jets announced Monday that Casey Johnson, a daughter of the teams owner, Woody Johnson, had died in Los Angeles. The cause of the death was undetermined. Ms. Johnson was 30.

title: A Venture Integrating Skype Into the Family Room
description: SAN FRANCISCO  There will soon be something new to watch on the living room TV: your relatives and friends in different parts of the world.

title: Home and Away Opponents for 2010 N.F.L. Season
description: As the playoff teams look forward to what lies ahead, the rest of the league is already focused on next season. While the dates and game times have yet to be determined, the home and away opponents for 2010 are set.

description: BAGHDADThis month I received the long-awaited phone call from the International Organization for Migration telling me that they had put me on their schedule to leave Iraq within the next few weeks.

description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  Any casual college football fan who stumbled upon Boise State in the magical Fiesta Bowl three years ago knows that the Broncos can conjure up the most creative of happy endings.

title: Saving the Economy, One Strike at a Time
description: Within the past several years, a spate of upscale bowling alleys have come to New York, with features such as V.I.P. lounges, clubs and dress codes.

title: Rex Ryan, Quipster, and Now Playoff Coach
description: Rex Ryan could charge admission to his news conferences, which are part football briefings and part monologues. Recommended reading: Greg Bishops article on Rexs Greatest Hits.

title: Ihor Sevcenko, Byzantine and Slavic Scholar, Dies at 87
description: Ihor Sevcenko, a leading scholar of Byzantine and Slavic history and literature who as a young man persuaded George Orwell to collaborate with him on a Ukrainian translation of Animal Farm for distribution to refugees, died at his home in Cambridge, Mass., on Dec. 26. He was 87.

description: WHO is Danny MacAskill?

title: News Quiz | January 5, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.
