title: Russian Parliament Weighs Stiffer Penalties for Protesters
description: MOSCOW  Among the draft laws that Russias Parliament will review when it reconvenes next week is a proposal that would increase significantly the punishment for protesters who block traffic or railway tracks, raising fines from 2,500 rubles, or $84, to 100,000 rubles, or $3,340, and increasing maximum prison sentences from 15 days to two years.

title: For the Moment | What Does Design Mean?
description: Michele Caniato is the president of Culture and Commerce, a design management consultancy, and of Material Connexion, a materials consultancy and library; both companies are based in New York.

title: Cycling on Camera, in New York and Beyond
description: There is something cinematic about riding a bicycle through New York traffic with its speed, lights and danger. For the rider, street scenes can open up in flashes between stopped cars, creating a kind of stuttered approximation of film. No wonder, then, that many riders, like Luke Stiles and Chris Thormann, have tried to capture these scenes with a camera.

title: Senator Graham Censured Again
description: Updated, 7 p.m.  For the second time in the last few months, conservative Republicans in one of South Carolinas counties have voted to censure Senator Lindsey Graham for his congressional votes.

title: December a Mixed Month for Auto Sales
description: DETROIT  Automakers ended a miserable year with some less bad sales figures, though the Ford Motor Company was the only one of the three domestic companies to report higher numbers in December.

title: Suspect in Deaths of 5 G.I.s Is Freed, Iraqi Official Says
description: BAGHDAD  An Iraqi accused of being behind the killings in 2007 of five American soldiers has been released by the Iraqi government, according to an Iraqi official.

title: Movies and Vices: Made for Each Other
description: As long as there have been movies, there have been scolds who condemn the movies for glamorizing vice. And the scolds have generally been right: one of the great pleasures of movie watching is that it allows us to witness and vicariously take part in all kinds of behavior we wouldnt dream of (or would only dream of) undertaking in our daily lives.

title: Obama Says Plot Could Have Been Disrupted
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Tuesday that the government had sufficient information to uncover the terror plot to bring down a commercial jetliner on Christmas Day, but that intelligence officials had failed to connect those dots.

title: Iceland Blocks Bank Compensation for Foreigners
description: The president of Iceland blocked a hard-fought $5 billion compensation deal with the British and Dutch governments on Tuesday, upending the precarious finances and politics of the island nation and further jeopardizing already frayed ties with Europe and international lenders.

title: Bishop Yao Liang, 87, Imprisoned in China for Loyalty to the Vatican, Dies
description: BEIJING  Leon Yao Liang, a Roman Catholic bishop who spent 28 years in Chinese prisons during Maos rule for his refusal to renounce his allegiance to the Vatican, died on Dec. 30 in Xiwanzi, a town in north Chinas Hebei Province.

title: Indiana Chosen for Electric-Car Plant
description: Think, the Norwegian electric carmaker, said on Tuesday that it will open its first American assembly plant in Elkhart, Ind.

title: Kirkus Reviews May Survive Yet
description: In December, the publishing industry was shocked by the news that the Nielsen company was shutting down Kirkus Reviews, the venerable journal of pre-publication book reviews used by many buyers as a hint at what might become bestsellers and a source of neglected gems.

title: Kirkus Reviews May Survive Yet
description: In December the publishing industry was shocked by the news that the Nielsen company was shutting down Kirkus Reviews, the venerable journal of prepublication book reviews used by many buyers as a hint at what might become best sellers and a source of neglected gems.

title: A.I.G. Sells Canadian Mortgage Insurance Unit
description: The Canadian mortgage insurance business of the American International Group will be sold to a private investor group headed by the Ontario Teachers Pension Plan, the group said Tuesday. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed, The Associated Press reports.

title: Apples App Store Tops 3 Billion Downloads
description: We hope Apple will stop counting soon, because this is getting repetitive. After announcing in September that more than two billion applications had been downloaded from its App Store for the iPhone and iPod Touch, Apple said on Tuesday that it had surpassed three billion downloads.

title: Some Inspiration to Make 2010 a Success
description: We have never been big on those inspirational posters that uninspiring managers put up on the office walls. You know the ones. They show a picture of a kitten desperately grasping a tree branch with a caption like, Hang in there, baby, or a lone eagle flying above the countryside, with the words Dare to soar.

title: Kenneth Noland, Color Field Artist, Is Dead at 85
description: Kenneth Noland, who painted some of the great emblems of the postwar American abstract style called Color Field painting, died Tuesday at his home in Port Clyde, Me. The cause was cancer, said his wife, Paige Rense, editor in chief of Architectural Digest. He was 85.

title: Doughnut Plant to Open in Chelsea
description: I knew there was only one Doughnut Plant in New York, but did you know there were 27 in Asia? Now, that balance is about to be adjusted a bit.

title: No Tavern in the Park Trademark
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: David P. Murbach, Finder of Rockefeller Center Trees, Dies at 57
description: David P. Murbach, a horticulturist who added an impresarios flair to one of the biggest jobs in the world of trees and gardens, finding the holiday tree for Rockefeller Center, was found dead on Dec. 23 in West Palm Beach, Fla., where he had an apartment. He was 57.

title: 10 Ways to Cut Your Travel Costs This Year
description: LAST year was arguably the year of the travel deal, with resorts and airlines practically begging for bookings, and many travelers finding bargain airfares and hotel rooms as a result. But airlines have cut back capacity, meaning there will be fewer seats going unsold, and resorts may not be as quick to cut rates to attract guests, now that the economy looks as if it might be on a slight rebound. So now is the perfect time to review your booking strategy. Here are 10 simple steps you can take to help cut your travel costs in 2010.

title: The Nifty 50 | Zoe Kazan, Actress
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Concern That Airport Scans May Be Pornographic
description: Updated | 6:56 p.m. According to a report in The Guardian, Britain may be forced to delay the introduction of full-body scans for all airline passengers because of concerns that the images produced may break national laws against the production of pornographic images of children.

title: B.L.M. Expedites Review of Energy Projects
description: Thirtyone proposed renewable energy and power transmission projects have been put on the fast track for approval by the Bureau of Land Management, with the aim of getting them paid for with stimulus funding under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act.

title: Correction: Correction to Year in Pictures
description: An article on Dec. 27 about the death of Edward M. Kennedy in August referred incorrectly to the assassination of his brother President John F. Kennedy, and a correction on Sunday erroneously corrected the length of his tenure in the Senate. The president was assassinated in 1963, the year after Edward Kennedy was elected to the Senate  not the same year. And as the article correctly reported, Senator Kennedy served 46 years  not 47, as the correction said. (The correction also erred in stating that the length of tenure was incorrect in Mr. Kennedy's obituary, in two other articles on Aug. 27 and Aug. 28 and in an editorial on Aug. 28. All four correctly reported the tenure as 46 years.)

title: New Worlds Take On the Old
description: The Directors Guild of America will join its above-the-line buddies in the Producers Guild when its nominations are announced on Thursday, and for those looking for a leg up in Oscar pools, its worth paying attention. The D.G.As members are even better at predicting eventual Oscar winners than the producers, anointing the same filmmakers 55 out of 61 times. Last years winner, Danny Boyle, also went on to win the top Oscar for Slumdog Millionaire, since best director and best picture usually go hand-in-hand, a nifty little equation that is getting squeezed this year, when Kathryn Bigelow is earning accolades outsize to her film, The Hurt Locker.

title: Home Fires: Getting the Word Out
description: My last memory of Iraq was of boarding a transport plane on the flight line at Balad Air Base in late January 2008. It had been raining and we were hoping to get out of the country before MUDCON, or mud conditions, turned every inch of desert not hiding below flight line or rocks into peanut butter.

title: Mesa Air Group Files for Bankruptcy Protection
description: The struggling regional airline operator Mesa Air Group said Tuesday that it had filed for bankruptcy protection in a Manhattan court in a bid to cut its oversize fleet.

title: Playwrights Prize Established in Honor of Horton Foote
description: The name and spirit of Horton Foote, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright and screenwriter, will live on in a playwriting award that will be given out for the first time this fall. The Horton Foote Prize, whose creation was announced Tuesday and was endorsed by Mr. Foote before his death in March, will be awarded every other year to an American playwright who has written an original work of exceptional quality, its organizers said in news release. The competition will invite 65 resident theaters to submit a play by an author who has written at least three original full-length plays that have been produced by professional theaters; selection committees will choose a short list of finalists; and the winner will be determined by a group of four artistic directors Mr. Foote worked with closely: Andre Bishop (of Lincoln Center Theater); James Houghton (Signature Theater Company); Michael Wilson (Hartford Stage Company); and Andrew Leynse (Primary Stages). The $30,000 prize will be supplied by the Greg and Mari Marchbanks Family Foundation of Austin, Tex.; Ms. Marchbanks is also the founder and executive director of the prize committee.

title: Resolving to Open a Restaurant by April 1
description: New Years resolutions are like business plans and leaky boats: make them, swear by them, commit to them and prepare to jettison them at any moment. Here are my restaurant resolutions for 2010, part one:

title: The Courage to Break the China
description: In the Big City column on Saturday, I wrote about my grandmothers Limoges china, which I used with abandon on New Years Eve after it had been neglected for decades. A saucer broke in the process, which at first made me cringe. Then I realized that breaking dishes was part of using dishes. (It helped when I discovered there were more saucers than cups, anyhow.)

title: Whole Foods Republicans
description: Independent, educated and socially-progressive voters who might be persuaded to vote for the G.O.P.

title: Google Introduces Nexus One, Its Rival to the iPhone
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Google stepped up its attack on the smartphone market on Tuesday, introducing a new touch-screen handset called Nexus One that is widely seen as a rival to Apples iPhone.

title: Countries of Interest  A Pakistani Perspective
description: I was 10 when my family left Pakistan. We packed our bags and made the move to Canada on July 4, 1991. It wasnt by choice that we had taken the flight 26 hours earlier from Lahore to come to a country where we barely knew a single soul. Religious extremists in Pakistan had branded us non-Muslim, and our green Pakistani passports indicated our religious status. We are part of a small Muslim sect called Ahmadiyyat that falls outside the Sunni and Shiite majority in Pakistan and were therefore hunted by the authorities. We could not travel freely because to be identified as a non-Muslim in Pakistan could mean death.

title: Citi Field Doesnt Intimidate Bay and Wont Deter Mets
description: The biggest mystery surrounding Jason Bay the free agent was whether he actually wanted to play for the Mets. After slipping into his No. 44 jersey, donning a blue cap and flashing a wide smile while shaking hands with Omar Minaya at an introductory news conference Tuesday, Bay insisted that he wanted the Mets as much as they wanted him.

title: Think, an Electric Car, to Be Built in Indiana
description: Elkhart, Ind., has been dubbed the R.V. Capital of the World because of the concentration of recreational vehicle manufacturers there. That industry has been hard hit by the recession, however, and it is a sign of the times that one former R.V. factory will become the United States home of the Norwegian electric carmaker Think.

title: These Quadruplets Weigh Enrolling as a Foursome at Hartwick College
description: If reading about the Crouch quadruplets of Danbury, Conn., who were admitted en masse to Yale last month, has piqued your interest in the college ambitions of other so-called multiples, I direct you to an article posted several days ago on the Web site of Newsday. (Note: Newsday requires visitors to register for its Web site.)

title: Walter Mosleys First Play to Open in Cincinnati
description: Walter Mosley, the crime novelist best known for his Easy Rawlins mysteries, has adapted his novel The Tempest Tales into his first-ever play, The Fall of Heaven, which will have its world premiere at the Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park from Jan. 23 to Feb. 20.

title: Extended Period of Cold Raises Fears for Florida Crops
description: As a cold spell continued its rigid hold on much of the eastern United States on Tuesday, farmers in central and southern Florida were bracing for freezing temperatures overnight that could damage orange, strawberry and tomato crops.

title: Pairings: Osso Buco Portobello
description: Deciding what to serve with brunello di Montalcino is no small challenge. In any vintage, the bold wines from this elite patch of the Tuscan countryside demand serious food. And grandstanding would not be out of place for the highly regarded 2004s.

title: The Morning Skate: World Junior Clash, Kings Rule and Kovys Dance
description: The United States national junior team faces its Canadian counterpart tonight in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan. for the I.I.H.F. World Under-20 Championship (NHL Network in the U.S. and TSN in Canada at 8 p.m. Eastern). Its the first time these countries junior teams have squared off for the gold medal since the United States won gold in 2004 and for Team Canada, the game represents a chance to win a record sixth consecutive title.

title: Parting the Clouds Over Brunello
description: BRUNELLO di Montalcino has had a couple of nightmarish years, plagued by a scandal that wouldnt go away. But, to honor the new year and in the spirit of fresh starts, lets for the moment set that aside to focus on what is in the glass. That would be red wine, made, by law, entirely of the sangiovese grape.

title: Travel Deals: 30% Off Hotels in Chicago, New York and Washington, D.C.
description: Affinia Hotels, which operates a stylish but affordable collection of hotels, is offering up to 30 percent off rooms at properties in New York, Chicago and Washington, D.C., for stays through April 5.

title: Tasting Report: One Grape, Different Faces
description: Conti Costanti Brunello di Montalcino 2004

title: A New Hurdle for Cape Wind
description: A decision made Monday by the National Park Service may create a new hurdle for developers of a long-disputed proposal to build the nations first offshore wind farm in Nantucket Sound.

title: U.S.O.C. Picks Ex-Leader as Its New One
description: The United States Olympic Committee has hired Scott Blackmun, a Colorado Springs lawyer who previously served as acting chief executive of the organization, as its new leader, according to several people who are familiar with the decision.

title: City Selects Company for New Voting Machines
description: Updated, 5:33 p.m. | The voting levers are officially history.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) Uncertainty over the regulatory future is hampering the recovery, three University of Chicago economists write.

title: Bulgarian Journalist Gunned Down in Sofia
description: LONDON  A prominent radio journalist and author of a book on Bulgarias gangsters was shot and killed Tuesday in the Bulgarian capital, Sofia, the first such murder since a new government was elected last July promising to clamp down on organized crime and corruption.

title: Will New Security Measures Thwart Tourism?
description: The travel industry was already concerned that foreign visitors to the United States faced unfriendly, even hostile, screening from customs and security agents. Now, concern is rising that the latest change, announced Sunday in response to the Christmas Day bombing plot, will deter more visitors.

title: Skadden, Arps Takes Lead as M.&A. Adviser
description: The New York law firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom overtook Linklaters of Britain as the biggest legal adviser on global mergers and acquisitions in 2009, a year that saw a sharp drop in deals, a new study shows.

title: N.C.A.A. Upholds Decision to Vacate as Many as 14 Bowden Wins
description: The N.C.A.A. did not let Bobby Bowdens retirement party last very long before announcing Tuesday that it had upheld its decision to strip the Florida State football team of as many as 14 victories. The decision will leave Bowden as many as 19 behind Joe Paterno of Penn State for most victories among football coaches at major colleges.

title: An Expensive Dip in the Sangiovese Pond
description: My column is on a wine panel tasting of the 2004 brunello di Montalcino. I tried to get past the scandal that has colored the coverage of brunello over the last two years, but it wasnt easy. One cant help mentioning it, and then it requires at least a minimal amount of explanation.

title: Judge Lifts Some Tobacco Ad Limits
description: A federal judge in Kentucky issued a mixed ruling Tuesday in the first significant legal challenge to the new federal law regulating tobacco products.

title: A Sure Sign of Excess: The Worlds Tallest Building
description: There is something about putting up the worlds tallest building that screams financial excess, and warns that a bubble is ready to burst.

title: Do Consumers Really Want 3-D TVs?
description: I have a confession to make. Im a little confused by one of the themes were already seeing from the 2010 Consumer Electronics Show: 3-D Televisions.

title: Green Day Goes Broadway With American Idiot
description: The new musical American Idiot, based on the Grammy Award-winning album of the same name by the band Green Day, will move to the St. James Theater on Broadway this spring, in time to be eligible for the 2010 Tony Awards. With a book by Green Days Billie Joe Armstrong and Michael Mayer, who is also directing, American Idiot is scheduled to begin preview performances on March 24 and open on April 20, according to a statement from the producers on Tuesday.

title: Are Tom Cables Days Numbered as Raiders Coach?
description: After Sundays 21-13 loss to the Baltimore Ravens, the Oakland Raiders season is over  and it looks like Coach Tom Cable might be on the way out, as well.

title: Amid 2009 Gloom, Subaru Had Record Year
description: December sales numbers are rolling in. And in a year of gloom, doom, clunkers and bailouts, Subaru of America had its best year ever.

title: Terrorism Today: Investigating Al Qaedas Presence Around the World
description: Overview | In this lesson, students consider the presence of Al Qaeda in various countries, with particular attention to its recent growth in Yemen. Working in groups, they investigate key people, places and institutions related to Al Qaeda and counterterrorism efforts, and create a maps or diagrams.

title: After a Delay, New Atlantic Terminal Pavilion Is Open
description: For decades, the busiest transportation hub in Brooklyn presented itself as a dark warren of miserable mole tunnels for anyone looking for a subway or Long Island Rail Road train. For years, that experience has been enhanced by the din and clutter of a construction site. Now, finally, the new Atlantic Terminal Pavilion has opened.

title: The Filibuster, Once More
description: Heres Ezra Klein, using the case of the Bush tax cuts, which I cited in an earlier post on this topic, to make a slightly different anti-filibuster, the-Senate-is-broken argument:

title: York Theater Company to Present Yank!
description: Yank!, a musical about a gay relationship between two American servicemen during World War II, will have its Off Broadway premiere next month at the York Theater Company, according to a statement from the theaters artistic director.

title: Disneyfication Finds a New Base in Times Sq.
description: It truly is the Disneyfication of Times Square.

title: The U.S.O.C.s Revolving Door Stops at Blackmun. Again.
description: As The Timess Katie Thomas reports, the United States Olympic Committee has spun its executive wheel again and stopped at a familiar name: Scott Blackmun.

title: Slovak Air Security Test Goes Very Wrong
description: Last Updated | Wednesday | 10:24 a.m. In what no doubt seemed like a good idea at the time, Slovak officials decided to test airport security in Slovakia on Saturday by concealing plastic explosives in eight suitcases and waiting to see what happened next.

title: Do Consumers Really Want 3-D TVs?
description: On our sibling blog, Bits, Nick Bilton reports that device manufacturers including Sony, Panasonic, Toshiba and LG are all announcing 3-D-enabled TVs at C.E.S., and content companies plan to start making movies and TV shows for these 3-D experiences. But the gadget-freak first-adopters arent getting excited about 3-D televisions yet.

title: C-Span Seeks Live Coverage of Democratic Meetings
description: Update | 6:02 p.m.  A spokesman for Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, has just released a statement saying Senate Democrats are committed to transparency in the legislative process. The statement did not specifically agree to C-Spans request to allow the negotiations on health care to be televised.

title: House Hunting in ... Mexico
description: A THREE-BEDROOM THREE-BATH OCEANFRONT HOME IN ROSARITO, MEXICO

title: Gillick on Morris: He Just Found a Way to Win
description: As we consider potential Hall of Famers this week, one background name comes to mind: Pat Gillick. As a general manager, Gillick built a two-time World Series winner in Toronto and oversaw playoff teams in Baltimore and Seattle. Then he helped the Phillies win the 2008 championship. Executives rsums dont get much better than that.

title: Orange Bowl: No. 10 Iowa (10-2) vs. No. 9 Georgia Tech (11-2)
description: Bless your hearts, Georgia Tech. You have disproved the belief that the option cannot work in major college football, and for that you have our thanks. In fact, Georgia Tech has done so well under the second-year coach Paul Johnson that the option may become the new craze in college football, supplanting the spread  which is on borrowed time  as the choice of high school coaches and undersized F.B.S. programs across the nation. However, if there is a flaw with the option offense, it is that given time, opponents can prepare for the multitude of looks it presents. Iowa, for instance, has spent the last month using glasses, water bottles and Gatorade to duplicate Georgia Techs multifaceted attack.

title: Obsessions | OMG, Mom Jeans
description: Can a pair of jeans make you look good, even if you just had a baby and youre entrenched in middle age?

title: First Avatar, Now Bafana Bafana
description: An old technology has been made new again and it could be coming to your living room.

title: The Misfits of Modern Agribusiness
description: In Rhode Island, rare heritage livestock breeds like fainting goats are being protected by a process called cryopreservation.

title: Pombo Loses an Ally in Comeback Bid
description: If Richard W. Pombo manages to make it back to Congress, it wont be with the help of his longtime legislative ally Representative George Radanovich, the California Republican whose seat Mr. Pombo is seeking to fill.

title: In London, River Views at the Right Price
description: LONDON  As an art student at Camberwell College of Arts in the 1990s, Rainer Cole, wanting to own property near the Thames but not having the means for the deposit, got creative. If he couldnt live near the river, then why not on it?

title: House Democrats Seek Changes in Senate Bill
description: House Democratic leaders said on Tuesday that they would insist on changes in the Senates health care legislation to make coverage more affordable for middle-class Americans and to tighten control over the insurance industry. But it remained unclear how much leverage the House would have in coming negotiations, given that Senate Democrats cannot spare a single vote without jeopardizing the bills chances of passing.

title: Public Officials Attack Citys Heroin Pamphlet
description: If youre going to do drugs, do it right, because even drug addicts deserve to have their lives protected.

title: What You Get for ... $250,000
description: NATCHEZ, MISS.

title: Republicans Join Call for Live Coverage of Health Talks
description: After C-Span released a letter earlier on Tuesday seeking to televise Congressional deliberations on merging the health care bills, Republicans have been seizing on the notion throughout the day as a way to criticize what will likely be less-than-public negotiations.

title: Happy Days in 2009
description: The happiest day of 2009 was Easter, according to new survey findings. By contrast, the day filled with the most stress and worry was the day after the House passed the stimulus bill.

title: Switch in Cohen Lawsuit Stuns Lawyer
description: The lawyer who initially represented Patricia Cohen, the ex-wife of Steven A. Cohen who is suing the hedge fund billionaire in a civil racketeering case, said he was blindsided by her decision to switch attorneys shortly after filing the case.

title: In the Company of Misery
description: THE doctors receptionist phoned the other day, looking for my husband.

title: That Old Black Magic, So Hard to Recapture
description: CHICAGO  Among the dozens of cartoons that Charles Addams drew of his devilishly subversive Addams family is one in which Gomez and Morticia; their daughter, Wednesday; son, Pugsley; and manservant, Lurch, are admiring the view from their new picture window. The view is of a cemetery crowded with tombstones.

title: Playwrights Prize Named for Horton Foote
description: The spirit of Horton Foote, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright and screenwriter, will live on in a playwriting award that will be given for the first time this fall. The Horton Foote Prize, whose creation was announced Tuesday and was endorsed by Mr. Foote before his death last March, will be awarded every other year to an American playwright who has written an original work of exceptional quality, its organizers said in a news release. The competition will invite 65 resident theaters to submit a work by an author who has written at least three original full-length plays that have been produced by professional theaters; selection committees will choose a short list of finalists; and the winner will be determined by a group of four artistic directors Mr. Foote closely worked with: Andr Bishop (of Lincoln Center Theater), James Houghton (Signature Theater Company), Michael Wilson (Hartford Stage Company) and Andrew Leynse (Primary Stages). The $30,000 prize will be supplied by the Greg and Mari Marchbanks Family Foundation of Austin, Tex.; Ms. Marchbanks is also the founder and executive director of the prize committee.

title: A Year for Christian Tourism
description: Its shaping up to be an auspicious year for Christian tourism, thanks to two infrequent religious events in Europe.

title: Private High School Coming to Greenwich Village
description: Greenwich Village will soon have a new private high school.

title: Mortgage Modifications Affect Credit Scores
description: Do borrowers taking part in the Obama administrations mortgage modification program deserve a black mark on their credit records?

title: Biopharmaceutical Industry Is Banking on Boston
description: Companies battling for an edge in the biopharmaceutical industry have $2.3 billion in manufacturing plants in development in the Boston area to produce genetically engineered drugs.

title: Apple Buys Quattro, an Ad Firm
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple encroached upon Googles turf on Tuesday with its acquisition of Quattro Wireless, a mobile advertising company.

title: A Mercedes Flagship That Sets the Standard
description: Mercedes-Benz USA is building a flagship dealership in a 333,000-square-foot retail space on 11th Avenue in Manhattan, which it expects to set the style standard for all other Mercedes dealers around the country.

title: Must See: He Kept His Speed Graphic
description: Louis Mendes spent the holidays around Rockefeller Center, photographing the crowds and selling prints to his subjects. Nothing unusual about that. Unlike most photographers cashing in on Christmas spirit, however, he was using a vintage Speed Graphic camera  the type, he says, you normally see in the movies  with a Polaroid back. Writing about Mr. Mendes in Polaroid Photographer, David Gonzalez asked, In an age when digital photography offers instant gratification and cameras come in most phones, who would have thought a decent living could be had taking pictures with a vanishing technology? Mr. Mendes has taken portraits around New York for almost 40 years, and charges up to $20 for his one-of-a-kind images.

title: App of the Week: Make a Resolution Easier
description: Improving your health, getting fit and losing weight never fail to top the list of New Years resolutions. All three are easy to do if you are willing to keep a food diary  which isnt easy to do.

title: Mosleys First Play to Open in Cincinnati
description: Walter Mosley, below, the crime novelist best known for his Easy Rawlins mysteries, has adapted his novel The Tempest Tales into his first play, The Fall of Heaven, which will have its world premiere at the Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park from Jan. 23 to Feb. 20. The play centers on Tempest Landry, described in a playhouse statement as a streetwise young man from Harlem who is accidentally killed and finds himself in a dispute in heaven with St. Peter, who ultimately sends him back to earth in hopes that Tempest will recognize his mistakes in life. If he does not, heaven will collapse and Satan will reign supreme. Marion McClinton is directing the production; he is best known for his direction of plays by August Wilson, including the Broadway production of King Hedley II, for which he was nominated for a Tony Award. David Gallo, who won a Tony in 2006 for best scenic design for the musical Drowsy Chaperone, is designing the set. Leland Gantt will star as Tempest. Mr. Mosley is scheduled to hold a discussion of the play at the theater on Jan. 14.

title: Green Days American Idiot Heads to Broadway
description: The new musical American Idiot, based on the Grammy Award-winning album of the same name by the band Green Day, will move to the St. James Theater on Broadway this spring, in time to be eligible for the 2010 Tony Awards. With a book by Green Days Billie Joe Armstrong and Michael Mayer, who is also directing, American Idiot is scheduled to begin preview performances on March 24 and open on April 20, according to a statement from the producers on Tuesday. The musical, which centers on three young male friends whose lives take decidedly different turns, had a run last fall at Berkeley Repertory Theater, starring John Gallagher Jr., right, who won the Tony Award for best featured actor in a musical in 2007 for Spring Awakening. The Broadway cast was not announced in the statement on Tuesday. The lead producers are Tom Hulce and Ira Pittelman, who, with Mr. Mayer directing, also led the Spring Awakening team.

title: Shumway Sells 8% Stake to Goldman Fund
description: The hedge fund manager Chris Shumway sold an 8 percent stake in his firm to a leveraged-buyout fund run by Goldman Sachs, according to a letter sent to investors on Tuesday.

title: Football Rolls Over Conveyor Belt
description: A pair of reality shows, including one in which male contestants were delivered on a conveyor belt to prospective female mates, delivered decent ratings for ABC on Monday night. That networks season premiere of The Bachelor, in which 25 women are vying for the affection of Jake Pavelka, a commercial pilot, drew an average of 9.5 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. ABC finished the night in third as the Conveyor Belt of Love (yes, that is the title) garnered 6.5 million viewers for its debut. Fox won the night with its live broadcast of the Tostitos Fiesta Bowl. Final figures for that football game were not immediately available, but preliminary estimates were slightly higher than Foxs 2009 broadcast of the Allstate Sugar Bowl, which averaged 13.4 million viewers. CBS ranked second for the night with reruns of its comedy lineup and CSI: Miami (10 million). NBC was fourth with a two-hour installment of Heroes (4.9 million) and The Jay Leno Show (4.8 million).

title: Avatar Commandeers Film Piracy Record
description: As Avatar knocks down box office records, the film has hit another, less estimable milestone: it has become the fastest-pirated movie, according to one tracking firms figures. The Times of London reported that Avatar, starring Zo Saldana, right, was illegally downloaded 500,000 times in the first two days of its release and 980,000 times in the first week, citing figures from the Web site TorrentFreak.com, which tracks usage of the file-sharing tool BitTorrent. In the days leading up to the films release last month, its director, James Cameron, seemed confident that the 3-D effects would essentially make it immune to piracy, telling The Times of London, You can pirate a 3-D movie, but you cant pirate it in 3-D, so you cant bottle that 3-D experience. But the TorrentFreak.com numbers seem to tell a different story: Avatar was illegally downloaded far more often than its closest competitor, the Twilight sequel New Moon, which was downloaded 610,000 times in its first week of release. Still, 20th Century Fox, which released Avatar, seemed unconcerned that piracy would hurt box office grosses, which last weekend surpassed $1 billion in worldwide ticket sales. Bootleg copies are unlikely to have much impact, a studio spokesman told The Times of London. Seeing the movie in 3-D in a cinema offers an experience that cannot be replicated.

title: Kirkus Reviews May Survive Yet
description: In December the publishing industry was shocked when the Nielsen company announced it was shutting down Kirkus Reviews, the venerable journal of prepublication book reviews used by many buyers as a hint at what might become best sellers and a source for finding neglected gems. On Tuesday it appeared that a white knight might be lurking in the wings. Eric Liebetrau, the journals managing editor, said in an e-mail message that Nielsen and Kirkus were in the process of working out an arrangement with an acquiring company to continue the publication of the magazine. He said he had no further details about the identity of the acquiring company, but said news was expected by the end of the month. We will definitely publish a second issue in January, Mr. Liebetrau wrote, and then reassess the situation and hopefully continue publication in February and beyond. Kirkus, a biweekly founded in 1933, published nearly 5,000 reviews a year.

title: Lawmakers React to Patersons Proposal for Reform
description: In a conference call on Tuesday, aides to Gov. David A. Paterson on Tuesday briefed reporters on the governors proposal for ethics reforms that, if enacted, would be the most far-reaching such overhaul in state history.

title: A New Prince, a Little Withholding, in a Puccini With a Modernist Touch
description: The tenor Salvatore Licitra took over the role of Calaf, a routed Tartar prince, in the Metropolitan Operas production of Puccinis Turandot on Monday night. When Mr. Licitra emerged in the late 1990s, he had the potential to be the next great Italian tenor. But over the years he has squandered his talents and sung with dismaying insecurity.

title: Obamas Speech
description: President Obama said that the failed terrorist attack could have been disrupted if intelligence officials had connected the dots, but they failed "to integrate and understand" the information. (Video: MSNBC)

title: The Sviata Vecheria
description: A look at vushka, borscht and other dishes that Veselka serves as part of the traditional Ukrainian 12-dish holiday dinner.

title: Google Shakes but Doesnt Upend the Cellphone Market
description: Google sure does love shaking up the system.

title: Montana Cowboys Lead, Coax and Cajole Their Charges Amid a Chorus of Bleats
description: The tagline for the wonderful documentary Sweetgrass, the first essential movie of this young year, is the last ride of the American cowboy. I suppose the word shepherd, with its pastoral evocations of maidens in pantaloons and lads with flutes, doesnt have the necessary grit or mythic punch. But the quiet and cantankerous men in this movie, mostly in cowboy hats  one of which is charmingly ornamented with a sheep pin on the crown  are keeping and sometimes losing sheep as surely as Little Bo Peep did.

title: Slow Start for Military Corps in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  The militarys effort to build a seasoned corps of expert officers for the Afghan war, one of the highest priorities of top commanders, is off to a slow start, with too few volunteers and a high-level warning to the armed services to steer better candidates into the program, according to some senior officers and participants.

title: Google Will Sell Superphone Direct
description: I have to think that a phone is not as exciting as you want it to be when the big news is the way in which you will sell it, even if you dub it part of a new class of superphones.

title: Death of a Golden Boy Ripples Through a Family
description: Late in Caroline Links film A Year Ago in Winter, the bottled-up anguish of the Richters, a well-to-do family in Munich whose 19-year-old son and golden boy, Alexander (Cyril Sjostrom), shot himself to death, is conjured by a turbulent Peter Gabriel song, Signal to Noise, heard on the soundtrack.

title: Senator Dorgan of North Dakota to Retire
description: Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, announced abruptly on Tuesday that he would not seek re-election this year  a clear sign of the difficulties Democrats will face in defending their large Congressional majorities in the upcoming mid-term elections.

title: Thompson to Run for Mayor in 2013
description: The 2013 race for New York City mayor is on.

title: Popular Drugs May Help Only Severe Depression
description: Some widely prescribed drugs for depression provide relief in extreme cases but are no more effective than placebo pills for most patients, according to a new analysis released Tuesday.

title: Clevelands Incomplete Guide to Winning
description: Chase Stuart, a lawyer, Jets fan and statistical analyst, writes for the Pro-Football-Reference.com blog.

title: The Struggles of Cairos Garbage People, but No Whining
description: Following on the grimy heels of Marina of the Zabbaleen (released here in September) comes Garbage Dreams, a second documentary about a poor community of trash recyclers on the outskirts of Cairo. But in the hands of the director and photographer Mai Iskander, this new film digs deeper into the politics of a life that few would choose but many depend on.

title: The Lap of Sonic Luxury
description: To all of the reasons to be presented at this years Consumer Electronics Show for one to stay planted on the living room couch for extended periods, add this one: the Logitech Speaker Lapdesk.

title: Googles Nexus One: A Roundup of Coverage
description: Its official. As The Timess Miguel Helft reported this morning, Google announced its first phone, the Nexus One. We just posted David Pogues review. Heres a roundup of what the technology blogs are saying about the new phone.

title: A Threesome: Husband, Wife, Shakespeare
description: TWO actors might work all their lives and never receive higher praise. In back-to-back productions of Shakespearean tragedy with Theater for a New Audience last season, Juliet Rylances brave, gracious portrayal of Desdemona was hailed in The New York Times as exquisitely moving and the dark, lean and hungry Hamlet of Christian Camargo as virtually perfect. At the time few knew they were newlyweds; their work was judged independently, on the merits.

title: Oh, Just Answer the Question, Honey
description: LOS ANGELES  Children can exhibit a remarkable ability to obsess about the most detailed subjects: train timetables, species of dinosaurs, the names of 18 different dolls and their imaginary occupations. But should that ability be put to use on national television, with a whole lot of money riding on the memory of a preteen?

title: Rajaratnam Expected to Face Additional Charges
description: Prosecutors have indicated that they plan to bring additional insider trading charges against Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire founder of the Galleon Group, that could increase his potential prison time to a maximum of 15 years if he is convicted.

title: Viola Davis Joins Fences'; Lili Taylor Added to Lips Together
description: Viola Davis, recently seen suffering up a storm in the film adaptation of Doubt (a performance that earned her an Academy Award nomination among other plaudits) will not be getting a reprieve any time soon. The actress is set to join the cast of the coming Broadway revival of Fences, by August Wilson, in which she will play the put-upon spouse of Denzel Washington, its press representatives said on Tuesday. The revival of Fences, which won the Tony Award for best play and the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 1987, is to begin previews at the Cort Theater on April 14 and open on April 26.

title: TBS May Need to Get Creative in Replacing Caray
description: Five weeks since parting ways with Chip Caray as its No. 1 baseball announcer, TBS is still searching for his replacement.

title: Death of a Friendship, Birth of a Play
description: IN 1947, while doing research for a screenplay in the Red Hook neighborhood of Brooklyn, Arthur Miller heard a story that reminded him of the plot of a Greek tragedy. An Italian-American longshoreman had turned in to authorities two illegal immigrants, relatives he had been sheltering in his home, in order to stop one of them from marrying his niece. Having violated an unwritten proscription against informing, he was disgraced and later disappeared  possibly, as rumor had it, murdered by one of the men he had betrayed.

title: A Citys Specialty, Japanese in Name Only
description: Seattle

title: I.O.U.
description: Introduction

title: Laughing All the Way to the Bank
description: If you wanted to try to make sense of the global banking crisis, instead of merely weeping openly at your A.T.M. balance, 2009 was a very good year. Bookstores were filled with volumes that, with expert 20-20 hindsight, explained how capitalism went to hell. The blame was spread around: to politicians (for deregulating financial markets), to bankers (for gambling with exotic derivatives they barely understood) and to the rest of us (for living beyond our means, like insatiate zombie piglets).

title: Should Players Be Responsible for Their Agents?
description: In the realm of N.B.A. discipline, some things are clear-cut. Throw a punch  get suspended. Rip the referees  get fined. The rules are as embedded in player psyches as the three-second violation.

title: Sherlock Holmes, Amorphous Sleuth for Any Era
description: Arthur Conan Doyle grew so to hate his greatest creation, Sherlock Holmes, that in 1893 he tried to kill him off, plunging him over the Reichenbach Falls. He called it justifiable homicide, saying, If I had not killed him, he would certainly have killed me.

title: Indian Official Gets Far on a Few Words
description: NEW DELHI  It seemed an innocent enough question, posed by an Indian on vacation recently in the palace-studded region of Rajasthan. Should the Indian government make it more difficult for tourists to visit the countrys glorious sights by tightening visa requirements in the name of preventing terrorism?

title: Senator Dorgan of North Dakota Will Retire
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, announced abruptly on Tuesday that he would not seek re-election this year  a clear sign of the difficulties Democrats will face in defending their large Congressional majorities in the upcoming mid-term election.

title: International Travelers: Share Your Security Experiences
description: In response to the Christmas Day bombing plot, additional screening has been announced for citizens of 14 nations, including Pakistan, Saudi Arabia and Nigeria, who are flying to the United States. Passengers holding passports from those nations, or taking flights that originated or passed through any of them, will be required to undergo full-body pat downs and will face extra scrutiny of their carry-on bags before they can board planes to the United States.

title: Kenya: Efforts to Deport Cleric Fail
description: The authorities are having trouble deporting a radical Jamaican-born Muslim cleric because international airlines have refused to take him and Tanzania refused Kenyas attempt to send him there, officials said Tuesday. The cleric, Abdullah el-Faisal, who officials say may have inspired the Nigerian man accused of trying to bomb an American airliner last month, had entered Kenya from Tanzania. We have no intention of allowing him to enter into our country, Tanzanias Home Affairs minister, Lawrence Masha, said, saying no formal request had been made.

title: Obama Cites Intelligence Failures
description: Jeff Zeleny of The Times discusses President Obama's speech that cited the intelligence community's lack of understanding and integration of information about the failed attack.

title: Putting Lens on Lives in Suspended Animation in Gaza
description: GAZA  In the year since Israeli fighter jets and troops invaded this coastal Palestinian strip to stop rocket fire, time seems to have stood still. A blockade imposed by both Israel and Egypt to isolate the Hamas government bars the vast majority of goods and people from moving in or out. That means there is no reconstruction of destroyed buildings. Thousands remain homeless. Winter has arrived.

title: Britain Tries to Ease Strain Over Bomb Suspect
description: LONDON  As President Obama and his national security team met at the White House to review the attempted Christmas Day bombing of an American trans-Atlantic airliner, the British government moved Tuesday to reduce strains between London and Washington over intelligence lapses in the case of Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab, the suspect in the failed attack.

title: Rare Breeds, Frozen in Time
description: NEWPORT, R.I.

title: High and Low, With a French Twist
description: Paris

title: Beltre to Play for Red Sox
description: The Boston Red Sox have agreed to terms on a one-year contract with third baseman Adrian Beltre, according to an official familiar with the deal. The official was granted anonymity because Beltre must still pass a physical to make the contract official. The deal guarantees Beltre $10 million.

title: Harold Ford Jr. Weighs a Challenge to Gillibrand
description: Encouraged by a group of influential New York Democrats, Harold Ford Jr., the former congressman from Tennessee, is weighing a bid to unseat Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand in this falls Democratic primary, according to three people who have spoken with him.

title: Chinese Envoy Objects to More Penalties for Iran
description: UNITED NATIONS  Imposing tougher sanctions on Iran over its nuclear program is a poor idea while diplomatic negotiations remain possible, Zhang Yesui, the Chinese ambassador to the United Nations, said Tuesday.

title: A Ukrainian Beacon in the East Village
description: ABOUT 40 years ago, Tom Birchard  a mild young New Jersey man of Pennsylvania Dutch and Midwestern antecedents  showed up at a fraternity party at Rutgers University, and was sucked unwittingly into the rest of his life.

title: Flavors of Mexico, Made Fresh in Manhattan
description: Fresh tamales with chicken in red or green salsa, and vegetarian ones, with chilies, are the draw on Saturdays starting at 9:30 at Las Palomas, a tiny Mexican store. A newer attraction is goat barbacoa, fork-tender, mostly boned, and delicious reheated with a slather of salsa, also sold there.

title: Reviving New York States Grain Belt
description: The Midwest is not the nations only grain belt. There once was another in upstate New York, and it is now being revived and expanded, not with commodity crops, but, to the delight of professional and amateur cooks and bakers, with specialty grains ground locally into flours and meals.

title: Texas-Alabama: Rematch 45 Years in the Making
description: There is only one thing wrong with this national championship game, Pete Lammons says. It is not being held in the Orange Bowl.

title: Ukrainian Christmas Borscht
description: Adapted from The Veselka Cookbook, by Tom Birchard with Natalie Danford (St. Martins Press, 2009)

title: Promise to Trim Deficit Is Growing Harder to Keep
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is making final decisions on his budget for next year and is still promising to outline a path to substantially lower federal deficits. But on nearly every front, that goal has gotten harder since his first budget a year ago.

title: A Mouthful of Rainbow
description: Melissa Bushell, left, who has been serving her bite-size cupcakes from the window of a SoHo coffee shop, has opened her own sleek little glass store. It features her tender half-dollar size cakes topped with bright flavorful icing. There are now nine flavors, expanded from seven; some, like cinnamon, mint chocolate chip and peanut butter cup, have fillings, too.

title: Off the Menu
description: Looking Ahead

title: Dining Calendar
description: Markets Head Indoors

title: Dos Toros Taqueria
description: IF the Dos Toros Taqueria just off Union Square brings to mind the sort of fresh, quick and cheap eating found at Mexican joints in the San Francisco Bay Area, thats by design.

title: Microsoft and H.P. to Reveal Slate PC Ahead of Apple
description: It could be one of Steve Ballmers riskiest trade-show moves in years.

title: New Jersey Governors Brother: Asset and a Risk
description: If he werent the younger brother of New Jerseys newly elected governor, Todd J. Christie might be seen as just another freewheeling, risk-taking, deep-pocketed Wall Street trader.

title: A Once-Defiant U.A.W. Local Now Focuses on G.M.s Success
description: LORDSTOWN, Ohio  For the better part of three decades, the car plant here was a seemingly endless source of trouble for General Motors.

title: Christmas Sales Brought a Move Toward Stability
description: Despite a weak start to the holiday shopping season and snowstorms on historically big spending days, the nations retailers managed to have a better Christmas than in 2008, according to the latest data.

title: David Murbach, Finder of Rockefeller Center Trees, Dies at 57
description: David P. Murbach, a horticulturist who added an impresarios flair to one of the biggest jobs in the world of trees and gardens  finding the holiday tree for Rockefeller Center each year  was found dead on Dec. 23 in West Palm Beach, Fla., where he had a home. He was 57.

title: City Urged to Withdraw Flier on Safer Heroin Use That Some See as How-To Guide
description: If you are going to do drugs, do it right, because even drug addicts deserve to have their lives protected.

title: Voting System to Finally Join Electronic Age
description: The voting machine levers are officially history.

title: Boldly, Boise State Moves the Question
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  The fake punt known as Riddler will join Boise States historical repertory of trickery, alongside Statue Left and Circus from three years ago. Broncos Coach Chris Petersens daring call on fourth-and-9 from his own 33 in the Fiesta Bowl on Monday night was destined to be described as either fearless or insane.

title: Randy Johnson Retires While Holliday Stays Put
description: There were two significant developments in baseball Tuesday, neither especially surprising: The 46-year-old left-hander Randy Johnson announced his retirement, and the free-agent left fielder Matt Holliday returned to the St. Louis Cardinals with a seven-year, $120 million contract.

title: Casa Lever
description: HERE now is a new Italian restaurant of the Manhattan old school, built for socialites and those who finance them, staffed by handsome, rakish men with huge wristwatches. Its the sort of place where in the movie, based on a novel as yet unwritten by Dana Vachon, you might cast Anne Hathaway as the lead and Diane Keaton as her mom. Youre welcome, too. For all this, Casa Lever is a deeply likable restaurant. Its very New York.

title: Planet Earth Is Blue
description: My review this week is of Casa Lever in that Midtown space oddity of a room that used to be Lever House, in Midtown. Its a terrific place  two stars!  staffed by a crew of whip-smart Italians. Its well worth visiting if youre ever in the mood for Manhattan scenemaking amid a crowd of women who look like Anne Hathaway and men who look like the interior designer and wine merchant Marco Pasanella.

title: Fed Missed This Bubble. Will It See a New One?
description: If only wed had more power, we could have kept the financial crisis from getting so bad.

title: U.S. Plans New Charge in Galleon Insider Case
description: Federal prosecutors said Tuesday that they planned to bring additional insider trading charges against Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire founder of the Galleon Group, a move that could increase his possible prison time to more than 15 years if convicted.

title: Gregg Allman on Leaving the Beacon: One Monkey Dont Stop No Show
description: No rock n roll tradition lasts forever. Bob Dylan plugged in his guitar. Kiss (temporarily) washed off its face paint. And now the Allman Brothers Band is leaving the Beacon Theater.

title: The Beacon Is Booked, So Allmans Will Move
description: No rock n roll tradition lasts forever. Bob Dylan plugged in his guitar. Kiss (temporarily) washed off its face paint. And now the Allman Brothers Band is leaving the Beacon Theater.

title: Iran Shielding Its Nuclear Efforts in Maze of Tunnels
description: Last September, when Irans uranium enrichment plant buried inside a mountain near the holy city of Qum was revealed, the episode cast light on a wider pattern: Over the past decade, Iran has quietly hidden an increasingly large part of its atomic complex in networks of tunnels and bunkers across the country.

title: U.S. Saw a Path to Qaeda Chiefs Before Bombing
description: WASHINGTON  Before detonating a suicide bomb in Afghanistan last week, a Jordanian militant was considered by American spy agencies to be the most promising informant in years about the whereabouts of Al Qaedas top leaders, including Ayman al-Zawahri, the terrorist groups second-ranking operative.

title: Under the Radar
description: Expect challenging, exciting and sometimes just plain cockamamie new works at the sixth annual Under the Radar festival which begins tonight at the Public Theater. This years festival, produced by Mark Russell, includes well-established figures like Richard Maxwell and the highly regarded Philadelphia troupe Pig Iron, Charles Isherwood writes. Also check out works from newer contributors, including Silver Stars, a song cycle derived from the experiences of gay men from Dublin to New York, as well as The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle, a multimedia adaptation of the Haruki Murakami novel directed by Stephen Earnhart, and John Cassavetes Husbands, a theatrical adaptation of the 1970 film about middle-age malaise.

title: Elaine Stritch at the Carlyle
description: With every new generation, popular art changes, Stephen Sondheim said in a recent interview. Already theres a generation that thinks the Beatles are old-fashioned, which I find screamingly funny. Theres little doubt of Sondheims staying power today and the same can be said for another artist of his generation  Elaine Stritch. Ms. Stritch, who is almost 85, is presenting At Home at the Carlyle: Elaine Stritch Singin Sondheim ... One Song at a Time an all-Sondheim program with six musicians at the Caf Carlyle beginning this week. Her approach to Sondheim is a dramatic no-holds-barred wrestling match between the singer and the song, in which there is little doubt about the outcome, writes Stephen Holden. Because Ms. Stritch is a ferociously age-defiant theatrical force, Singin doesnt fully evoke the savage, canny dramatic eviscerations one can expect in a show that may well be legendary after its run concludes on Jan. 30.

title: Take a Trip to California
description: Theres nothing like a little taste of the West Coast to warm a cold New Yorker. If the Dos Toros Taqueria just off Union Square brings to mind the sort of fresh, quick and cheap eating found at Mexican joints in the San Francisco Bay Area, thats by design, writes Oliver Strand. It was opened by brothers Leo and Oliver Kremer, two natives of Berkeley, Calif., who worshiped Gordo Taqueria, a local favorite founded in 1977. Dos Toros is something of an homage. There are only three items on the menu: a taco, burrito and quesadilla, with a variety of possible preparations. Hint: say yes to the guacamole. Go for the simple and succulent food, stripped-down cooking served in Spartan conditions. Just like at Gordo, Dos Toros has a short menu, high standards and such satisfying fare you dont mind the hospital lighting. Also look out for other Left Coast details: the biodegradable corn-based utensils, the aggressive composting policy, the disarmingly nice staff. It will make you feel like youre in sunny California, at least until you walk back outside.

title: Optimism Is Fresh Arrival in California Cul-de-Sac
description: MORENO VALLEY, Calif.  Phil Winkler pays a neighborhood kid to mow his lawn, that small-bore transaction of the American suburb, where adults are generally busy and teenagers offer a price thats right. But for Mr. Winkler, the relinquishing of his mower was something remarkable.

title: Television Begins a Push Into the 3rd Dimension
description: Ralph Kramden can finally buy a television.

title: Jets Senior Citizen Weighs In on Sanchez
description: Defensive end Shaun Ellis is one Jet  the only one  who has been there and done that. Drafted by the Jets in 2000, Ellis is the longest-tenured player on the team. He has been through high and lows; he has also seen hotshot quarterbacks come and go.

title: City Ignoring Law on Class Sizes, Suit Says
description: Despite receiving hundreds of millions of dollars to reduce class sizes, the citys Department of Education has ignored state law and allowed classrooms to grow in the last couple of years, the city teachers union and other groups said in a lawsuit filed Tuesday.

title: A Clothing Clearance Where More Than Just the Prices Have Been Slashed
description: In the bitter cold on Monday night, a man and woman picked apart a pyramid of clear trash bags, the discards of the HM clothing store that reigns in blazing plate-glass glory on 34th Street, just east of Sixth Avenue in Manhattan.

title: Reprieve Eases Medical Crisis for Illegal Immigrants
description: ATLANTA  After a largely sleepless night, Cruz Constancia got up Tuesday morning wondering whether this would be the day that she finally stopped receiving dialysis without charge.

title: Asian Computer Makers Move Into Riskier Ventures
description: SUNNYVALE, Calif.  For years, the process remained relatively static: PC makers like Hewlett-Packard and Apple, with well-staffed research labs and design departments, would dream up their next product and then hire a Chinese or Taiwanese fabricator to manufacture the largest number of units at the lowest possible cost.

title: Sourcing of Article Awkward for Paper
description: Facing criticism for publishing the work of a start-up news organization, The Washington Post said Tuesday that it should have disclosed more about the groups financier and his connections, and the papers ombudsman said he was looking into the relationship.

title: A Tale of Two Flagella
description: They are the best of beings; they are the worst of beings. They are animals; they are plants. They are saviors; they are killers. They are predators; they are parasites. They are, in short, dinoflagellates  a large, diverse and eccentric group of (usually) single-celled organisms that are as celebrated as they are feared. And I hereby nominate them for Life-form of the Month: January.

title: Shanahan Gets Job, but Market Is Slow
description: In Washington, the Redskins completed negotiations with Mike Shanahan on Tuesday night and a news conference is expected Wednesday to introduce Shanahan as the new coach. In Cleveland, Mike Holmgren started to talk to Eric Mangini about whether Mangini should remain the coach.

title: Ex-UBS Banker Asks Review of the Handling of His Case
description: Lawyers for Bradley Birkenfeld, the former UBS private banker who is headed to jail for helping wealthy Americans evade taxes through secret offshore accounts, asked the Justice Department on Tuesday to investigate whether prosecutors had mishandled his case.

title: Bay Wanted to Be Wanted, and the Mets Obliged
description: As Jason Bay slipped into his No. 44 jersey, put on a blue cap and pumped the right hand of General Manager Omar Minaya at the opening to his introductory news conference Tuesday at Citi Field, the smile never left his face. Clearly, Bay seemed happy about being a Met. But he had yet to say so.

title: In Packing Up, Morgenthau Unearths Treasures
description: Transferring control of the Manhattan district attorneys office from Robert M. Morgenthau to Cyrus R. Vance Jr. has necessitated various housekeeping measures  replacing veteran prosecutors with new ones, hanging new pictures on the walls and putting new policies into effect.

title: Lottery Numbers
Hidden Treasures From Morgenthau's Office
description: The district attorneys treasures, including a letter from Eleanor Roosevelt and a medallion of Thomas E. Deweys.

title: New Year but No Relief for Strapped States
description: SACRAMENTO  It is one of the bleakest new years that states have seen in over a decade.

title: Icelands Leader Vetoes Bill to Repay 2 Lenders
description: The president of Iceland blocked a $5 billion compensation deal with the British and Dutch governments on Tuesday, upending the precarious finances and politics of the island nation and further jeopardizing already frayed ties with Europe and international lenders.

title: Kraft Bolsters Its Hostile Bid for Cadbury by Raising New Cash
description: Kraft Foods took a big step on Tuesday to shore up its $16 billion hostile bid for Cadbury, the British confectioner, by selling one of its most profitable units to Nestl.

title: Court Backs War Powers Over Rights of Detainees
description: A federal appeals court panel on Tuesday strongly backed the powers of the government to hold Guantnamo detainees and other noncitizens suspected of committing terrorist acts.

title: A Blockbuster That Proved Worthy of the Hall of Fame
description: Before he left the 1990 winter meetings in Chicago, Pat Gillick called his wife, Doris, to tell her he would be home in a few hours. Gillick, then the general manager of the Toronto Blue Jays, also told her he had just traded Fred McGriff and Tony Fernandez to the San Diego Padres for Roberto Alomar and Joe Carter.

title: Like King Solomon
description: Once more unto the breach, dear friends, once more;Or close the wall up with our English dead Follow your spirit, and upon this chargeCry God for Harry, England, and Saint George!

title: House Democrats to Pursue Health Bill Changes
description: WASHINGTON  House Democratic leaders said Tuesday that they would insist on changes to the Senate health care legislation to make coverage more affordable for middle-class Americans and to tighten control over the insurance industry.

title: Nurturing Sanchez Leads Jets to Rely on Him
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Mark Sanchezs rookie season has included a series of upgrades, some more noticeable than others. The latest sat at the foot of his locker Tuesday, propped just so in front of a black loose-leaf notebook.

title: Lawyer Says Third White House Crasher Was Invited
description: WASHINGTON  The mystery man starring in a new movie in town  State Dinner Crashers: The Sequel  has come forward.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 935 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Corrections
description: A capsule summary in some copies on Monday for an article about the attitudes toward improving society on the part Teach for America graduates misstated the surname of a teacher shown in an accompanying picture. The error was repeated in a picture caption with the article. The teacher is David Donaldson, not Johnson.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 26 about hardships faced by construction workers in Fitchburg, Mass., as they settled into winter misstated the name of a national construction industry organization. It is the Associated General Contractors of America, not the Association of General Contractors of America.

title: Smith Bagley, Executive and Democratic Fund-Raiser, Dies at 74
description: Smith W. Bagley, a business executive, philanthropist and major contributor to national Democratic candidates, died Saturday in Bethesda, Md. He was 74 and had homes in Washington, in Nantucket, Mass., and on St. Simons Island, Ga.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column on Monday, about Indianapolis football fans who were disgruntled that the Colts rested key players while their perfect record was still intact, referred incorrectly to the start of the current professional football team in Cincinnati, which, like Indianapolis, watched as other cities were given franchises through the years. Cincinnati got the Bengals in 1968, not in the 1970s. (The Colts moved to Indianapolis from Baltimore in 1984.)

title: Corrections
Corrections
description: A dance review on Dec. 26 about Soledad Barrio and Noche Flamenca, at the Lucille Lortel Theater, misstated a word in a line sung by Manuel Gago. He sang: Ay! Que pena!, not: Ay! Che pena!

title: 2 Policemen Are Wounded as 3rd Officer Fires at Pit Bull
description: Two plainclothes police officers chasing a suspect as part of a drug investigation in the Bronx were injured Tuesday night when a third officer fired at a pit bull that had charged at them and a bullet ricocheted, a Police Department spokesman said.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on Sunday, about e-books, incorrectly described the publishing history of William Styrons Lie Down in Darkness. It was first published in 1951 by Bobbs-Merrill, not Random House.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: As Clout Grows, Working Families Party Faces a Question: Has It Reached Too Far?
description: Bill de Blasio, New York Citys new public advocate, is a lifelong Democrat and a likely future mayoral contender. But ask him to name the most innovative political force in the state, and he points to the Working Families Party.

title: Embattled Florida G.O.P. Chairman to Quit
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  Under fire from Republicans upset with everything from his fund-raising efforts to his support for Gov. Charlie Crist in an increasingly bitter United States Senate primary, the chairman of Floridas Republican Party announced his resignation on Tuesday.

title: Immigrations New Year
description: The quest for overhauling immigration received two very welcome lifts on New Years Day.

title: Microsoft and H.P. to Reveal Slate PC Ahead of Apple
description: On our sister blog, Bits, Ashlee Vance offers a preview of what Microsofts chief executive, Steve Ballmer, will unveil during his Wednesday evening keynote at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.

title: PGA Tour's Focus on the Future Obscured by Present Problem: Woods
description: KAPALUA, Hawaii  When he arrived for his first news conference of 2010 on Tuesday, PGA Tour Commissioner Tim Finchem displayed a mood that pretty much matched the laid-back elegance of the Kapalua Resort. Wearing a white golf shirt, plaid slacks and a relaxed demeanor, Finchem talked in glowing terms about the new title sponsor, SBS, which has signed on for the next 10 years, and how Kapalua is a golf course the tour is very fond of and how the tournament is a great way to start the year.

title: Juvenile Injustice
description: Gladys Carrin, New Yorks reform-minded commissioner of the Office of Children and Family Services, has been calling on the state to close many of its remote, prison-style juvenile facilities and shift resources and children to therapeutic programs located in their communities. Her efforts have met fierce and predictably self-interested resistance from the unions representing workers in juvenile prisons and their allies in Albany.

title: In From the Cold
description: Ten years after NATO went to war with Slobodan Milosevic over Kosovo, a democratically transformed Serbia has applied to join the European Union. That process is likely to take five years or more, but this is an apt moment to celebrate the turnaround in Serbian policies and attitudes under President Boris Tadic.

title: The Peak of Something
description: On Monday, Dubai celebrated the completion of what is now, and is likely to remain for some time, the tallest building on the planet and its last-second name change. What was supposed to be called Burj Dubai (burj means tower in Arabic) rises to 2,717 feet above a series of rounded, bronzed setbacks. It took five years to complete and cost $1.5 billion. At the opening, it was renamed Burj Khalifa, in honor of Sheik Khalifa bin Zayed al-Nahyan, the emir of Abu Dhabi, which gave Dubai a $10 billion loan a few weeks ago to help head off the countrys financial collapse.

title: Y2K and Warming: Alarm or Realism?
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Father Knows Best
description: Surely, the most important, interesting  and, yes, heroic  figure in the whole Christmas Day Northwest airliner affair was the would-be bombers father, the Nigerian banker Alhaji Umaru Mutallab.

title: How 12/25 Was Like 9/11
description: IN the days since the attempted Christmas Day airplane bombing, many officials, including the White Houses counterterrorism director, John Brennan, have insisted that the Detroit incident was not like 9/11. In many respects, we agree. But the governments handling of the intelligence leading up to the attack was eerily reminiscent of one of the most shocking  and relatively underreported  revelations to come out of the 9/11 commissions hearings.

title: Another Iranian Revolution? Not Likely
description: THE Islamic Republic of Iran is not about to implode. Nevertheless, the misguided idea that it may do so is becoming enshrined as conventional wisdom in Washington.

title: U.S. Job Site Bans Bias Over Gender Identity
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has inserted language into the federal jobs Web site explicitly banning employment discrimination based on gender identity.

title: Randy Johnson: An Appreciation
description: The first time I met Randy Johnson, I was 14 years old and he was playing for the Montreal Expos. I had a field pass for a game at Veterans Stadium in April 1989. I asked him to autograph his baseball card, and he said hed be right back. He never returned.

title: Donal Donnelly, Actor Who Nurtured Irish Roles, Dies at 78
description: Donal Donnelly, an Irish actor who embodied a variety of Irish characters on the American stage and in American movies, notably in the plays of Brian Friel and in John Hustons adaptation of James Joyces short story The Dead, died Monday in Chicago, where he had been living for the past two years. He was 78.

title: Phys Ed: Can You Be Overweight and Still Be Healthy?
description: The idea that people can be overweight and yet still quite healthy began gaining scientific and popular credence some years ago, fueled by the publication of a number of studies showing that men and women who were a few pounds overweight but physically active had less risk of developing cardiac disease than people who were of normal weight but sedentary.

title: Access in the City? Wi-Fi in New York
description: New Years resolutions are made for many reasons  not least of which is so that they can immediately be broken. Last week I resolved first and foremost to put aside my iPhone (and laptop and other electronic devices) and experience destinations more directly. So what do I do this week? Offer tips on how to find free Wi-Fi in New York City, so youll never be without a digital tether.

title: Showcase: Landscapes Under Foot
description: To find new things, take the path you took yesterday.  John Burroughs, naturalist and essayist

title: Kenneth Noland, Abstract Painter of Brilliantly Colored Shapes, Dies at 85
description: Kenneth Noland, whose brilliantly colored concentric circles, chevrons and stripes were among the most recognized and admired signatures of the postwar style of abstraction known as Color Field painting, died Tuesday at his home in Port Clyde, Me. He was 85.

title: Do Chipmunks Outrank Navi?
description: Avatars $1 billion in ticket sales may garner all the headlines for News Corporations 20th Century Fox, which released the sci-fi spectacle. But the studios other holiday film, Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel, may be more valuable to shareholders in Rupert Murdochs media group over the long run.

title: Senator Dodd Will Not Seek Re-election, Democrats Say
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the embattled Connecticut Democrat who was facing an increasingly tough bid for a sixth term in the United States Senate, has decided not to seek re-election this year, Democrats familiar with his plans said Wednesday.
