description: irreverence \i-rev-rnts, i(r)-, -re-v-; -re-vrn(t)s\ noun

title: C.E.S. 2010: What's New in Internet TV
description: Bits Blog lead writer Nick Bilton on the new Internet TV offerings that will premiere at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.

title: Dodd Is Said to Decide Against Re-election Bid
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the embattled Connecticut Democrat who was facing an increasingly tough bid for a sixth term in the United States Senate, has decided not to seek re-election this year, Democrats familiar with his plans said Wednesday.

title: Hold the Phone
description: WHOM do you know who has a smartphone (that is, a cellphone with computer-like capabilities, like the iPhone)?

title: Kraft Bolsters Bid for Cadbury by Raising New Cash
description: Kraft Foods took a big step on Tuesday to shore up its $16 billion hostile bid for Cadbury, the British confectioner, by selling one of its most profitable units to Nestl.

title: Correction
description: The Critics Notebook last Wednesday about the best dishes in New York City restaurants in 2009 referred imprecisely to the Web site of Craft, the restaurant that formerly employed Karen DeMasco, who created one of the selected dishes, the maple budino dessert at Locanda Verde. Although Crafts site still includes her biography, which can be found through a search engine, it no longer prominently features her.

title: News Quiz | January 6, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Colorado Governor Wont Seek Second Term
description: DENVER  Gov. Bill Ritter Jr. of Colorado, a first-term Democrat, and spokesman for a band of upstart Democratic governors in historically Republican strongholds in the West, will not seek a second term in office this fall, a Colorado Democrat with knowledge of the governors plans said Tuesday.

title: Asia Gains Edge Backing Tech Start-Ups
description: For years, the process remained relatively static: PC makers like Hewlett-Packard and Apple, with well-staffed research labs and design departments, would dream up their next product and then hire a Chinese or Taiwanese fabricator to manufacture the largest number of units at the lowest possible cost.

title: If Fed Missed This Bubble, Will It See a New One?
description: If only wed had more power, we could have kept the financial crisis from getting so bad.

title: Apple Buys Quattro, an Ad Firm
description: Apple encroached upon Googles turf on Tuesday with its acquisition of Quattro Wireless, a mobile advertising company.

title: Decision Sets Stage for Pitched Battle
description: Senator Christopher J. Dodds plan to retire from Congress sets the stage for a contentious battle for a seat that Democrats have held for 46 years, with the party hoping to hold out against determined Republican opposition.

title: Ex-UBS Banker Asks Review of Handling of Case
description: Lawyers for Bradley Birkenfeld, the former UBS private banker who is headed to jail for helping wealthy Americans evade taxes through secret offshore accounts, asked the Justice Department on Tuesday to investigate whether prosecutors had mishandled his case, Lynnley Browning writes in The New York Times.

title: Dodd Will Not Seek Re-election, Democrats Say
description: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the embattled Connecticut Democrat who was facing an increasingly tough bid for a sixth term in the United States Senate, has decided not to seek re-election this year, Democrats familiar with his plans said Wednesday.

title: When Have You Been Fooled by a Hoax or Practical Joke?
description: A fake e-mail message sent to the 4,900 students at Brooklyn Technical High School on Sunday night convinced most students if only for an hourthat school was canceled the next day. When have you ever been the victim (or perpetrator) of a hoax or practical joke, large or small?

title: North Korea Started Uranium Program in 1990s, South Says
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea apparently began pursuing a uranium enrichment program in 1996 at the latest, the South Korean foreign minister said Wednesday, bolstering fears that the Norths second route to building a nuclear bomb could be well on its way..

title: U.S. Plans New Charge in Galleon Insider Case
description: Federal prosecutors said Tuesday that they planned to bring additional insider trading charges against Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire founder of the Galleon Group, a move that could increase his possible prison time to more than 15 years if convicted, Zachery Kouwe reported in The New York Times.

title: Wall St. Ends Mixed on Sliding Home Sales
description: Major stock indexes ended mixed Tuesday, a day after the Dow Jones industrials soared more than 150 points on upbeat manufacturing reports in the United States and China. Uncertainty over crucial reports this week on employment and the service industry also kept buyers at bay, The Associated Press reported.

title: Attack in Kashmir Kills 3 Pakistani Soldiers
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  At least four soldiers were killed and 11 were wounded in what the authorities said could have been a suicide attack in the Pakistan-controlled part of the disputed Kashmir region on Wednesday, according to Pakistani officials and news outlets.

title: Drip Pricing
description: A technique of online pricing where the total cost is revealed only at the end of the purchasing process, after a series of (compulsory/hidden) charges have been added.

title: Schloss Said to Take N.Y. Investment Post
description: Lawrence Schloss, the chairman and chief executive of private equity firm Diamond Castle, has agreed to become the next chief investment officer for New York City, the Web site peHUB reported.

title: Prudential Buys Singapore Banks Insurance Unit
description: United Overseas Bank, Singapores number three banking group, said Wednesday it would sell its Singapore life insurance unit to Prudential P.L.C. of Britain for 428 million Singapore dollars ($307 million), confirming an earlier report.

title: Intuity Medical Gets $64 Million Injection
description: Intuity Medical, which makes blood glucose monitors, has received $64 million in a fourth round of funding, VentureBeat reported, citing a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: GMAC Predicts Further Loss of $5 Billion
description: GMAC Financial Services said on Tuesday that it expected to post a combined fourth-quarter loss of about $5 billion, largely on charges related to its bid to write down or sell risky mortgage assets, Reuters reported.

title: DataSphere Obtains $10.4 Million in Funding
description: DataSphere, a start-up that helps media companies set up hyperlocal and niche news sites, has landed $10.8 million in fresh funding.

title: Calperss New Board Members May Restore Image
description: The California Public Employees Retirement System, the biggest United States public pension fund, said on Tuesday that unofficial election results showed that Kurato Shimada and Joseph Jelincic had won member-at-large seats on its board.

title: I.P.O. Market Remained Dreary in 2009
description: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

title: Yemen Says Its Arrested 3 Qaeda Militants
description: SANA, Yemen  Yemen announced Wednesday that it had arrested three militants from a cell of Al Qaeda suspected of making threats to Western targets here.

title: Milestones: Christopher J. Dodd
description: An interactive timeline of Senator Chris Dodd's life and political career.

title: Reed Elsevier Said to Eye Sale of Magazines
description: Reed Elsevier, the publishing and events group, is in advanced talks to sell some of its loss-making trade magazines and will close other titles during the first half of 2010, Reuters reported, citing an internal memo.

title: Beazer Homes to Offer New Stock and Debt
description: Beazer Homes USA said Tuesday it would begin offerings of new common stock and convertible subordinated debt. The home builders shares tumbled in extended trading, The Associated Press reported.

title: City of London Rents to Rebound, Report Says
description: Rents on the best commercial real estate in the City of London are set to increase 10.5 percent this year, as tenants move upmarket and supply diminishes, according to a report by King Sturge, a real estate consultant.

title: Buyout Shops Chase Siemens Unit
description: Siemens has shortlisted a strategic buyer and five private equity firms as potential buyers of its hearing aid unit, potentially worth more than 2 billion euros ($2.9 billion), Reuters reported, citing several people familiar with the matter.

title: Investors Cheer Departure of Biogen Chief
description: Investors welcomed the upcoming departure of Biogen Idecs chief executive, James Mullen, sending the companys shares higher in early trading on Tuesday, Reuters reported.

title: Kraft Gets 1.52 Percent Acceptance for Cadbury Bid
description: Kraft Foods said it had so far received a 1.52 percent acceptance from Cadbury shareholders for its hostile bid, but most shareholders are expected to wait to see if Kraft raises its bid before making their decisions, Reuters reported.

title: Broadcoms Samueli Resumes Role
description: Broadcoms co-founder, Henry Samueli, has resumed his role as chief technical officer for the chip maker after a federal judge dismissed a criminal charge against him, The Associated Press reported.

title: Goldman Converts Preferred Shares in Sumitomo
description: Goldman Sachs Group agreed to convert its 100 billion yen ($1.09 billion) of preferred shares in Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, Bloomberg News reported.

title: U.S. Exchanges Tout Speed After Tokyo Upgrade
description: A day after the Tokyo Stock Exchange introduced its new high-speed trading system, meant to capture the new need-for-speed in financial markets, United States exchanges were quick to tout how swift their systems are, Reuters reported.

title: Swaying to the Beats of Africa in Prague
description: MC Jah Koko, the owner of Confessions, a Prague bar, is also a Nigerian-born reggae singer who gamely offers to dance with arriving patrons, his swaying invariably reciprocated.

description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

description: Luis DeLoureiro is building a better passer rating, among other statistical pursuits, at NFLStatAnalysis.net:

title: Citis John Havens Earned $9 Million in 2009
description: John Havens, head of Citigroups securities business, earned about $9 million in total compensation in 2009, apparently making him the highest-paid executive at the bank.

title: Global Financial Rules Overhaul Seen in 2010
description: Global financial regulation has changed little since the 2008 banking crisis, but that wont be the case much longer, according to Reuters.

title: U.K. Bonus Tax Has Mixed Results, Report Says
description: It seems that the U.K. governments bank bonus tax has had mixed results.

title: JAL Falls on Report That Agencies Eye Bankruptcy
description: Shares of Japan Airlines fell nearly 7 percent on Wednesday after a newspaper said the carriers main creditor and the finance ministry support bankruptcy as a way to restructure the heavily indebted airline.

title: Anti-Whaling Vessel Damaged in a Collision at Sea
description: HONG KONG  An anti-whaling groups high-speed boat and a Japanese whaler reported colliding at sea on Wednesday, with each blaming the other.

title: The Yanquis Went Home
description: Todays idea: Say adis to the Monroe Doctrine, under which Washington long called the shots in its own backyard. For the first time in centuries, the United States doesnt seem to care much what happens in Latin America.

title: Ex-Perot Employee Returning $8.6 Million
description: A former employee of a Perot Systems affiliate who had been charged with insider trading has agreed to return about $8.6 million in illicit profits, federal regulators said Tuesday.

title: Dal Five Ways
description: I wouldnt say I live on dal, but its become a staple for me  along with about 200 other bean-based dishes  and I love its high flavor and speed of preparation. Read more in this weeks Minimalist column.

title: AQRs Mutual Fund Assets Said to Hit $1 Billion
description: When AQR Capital Management launched its first hedge-fund-style mutual fund in January 2009, the hedge fund was looking for ways to reach out to new investors, even as the industry faced withdrawals.

title: Sampler: Turtle Protections and Lawn-Size Restrictions
description: Autism Clusters Probably Not Linked to Environment | The 10 places in California where there appears to be an uptick in the number of children with autism may be linked to parents ability to get help for their children rather than a specific environmental risk, according to a new study by the University of California, Davis, that was published in The Journal of Autism Research. Among the 10 clusters are the Sunnyvale-Santa Clara area, the San Carlos-Belmont area in San Mateo County and Sacramento. I dont think you have to worry about something in the neighborhood harming children, said Irva Hertz-Picciotto, the projects lead investigator. [The San Jose Mercury News]

title: Was AOL-Time Warner Really the Worst Deal?
description: Gerald Levin, the former Time Warner chief who helped orchestrate the disastrous merger with AOL, said he had presided over the worst deal of the century. But The Telegraph says that Mr. Levin shouldnt be too quick to grab for that tarnished crown.

title: Dodd to Retire, but What About Financial Reform?
description: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the embattled Connecticut Democrat who was facing an increasingly tough bid for a sixth term in the United States Senate, has decided not to seek re-election this year, The New York Timess Adam Nagourney reported Wednesday, citing Democrats familiar with his plans.

title: Block Joins Ford in the World Rally Championship
description: Ken Block, the American rally car driver whose power slides are familiar to millions through some very popular YouTube videos, has signed a deal with Ford to compete in rally racings big leagues, the World Rally Championship.

title: Dodds Decision Sets New Battle for Succession
description: Senator Christopher J. Dodds plan to retire from Congress sets the stage for a contentious battle for a seat that Democrats have held for 46 years, with the party hoping to hold out against determined Republican opposition, The New York Timess Sarah Wheaton reports.

title: Japan Replaces Ailing Finance Minister
description: TOKYO  Dealing another blow to the fledgling government, the Japanese finance minister resigned Wednesday, leaving Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama to appoint a successor with little fiscal experience to grapple with financing an ambitious campaign agenda, a growing public debt and a fading economic recovery.

title: Efficient Lighting, With Fewer Wires
description: At the Fremont, Calif., offices of Redwood Systems, a high-tech start-up, the super-efficient light emitting diode fixtures, or LEDs, that dot the ceiling dim imperceptibly as more natural light comes through the windows.

title: The Early Word: Senate Shake-Up
description: 2010 Election Dispatches The departures of two Democratic Senators, Christopher Dodd of Connecticut and Byron Dorgan of North Dakota, puts the partys precarious hold on the Senate more plainly than ever at risk.

title: Speed Read for Wednesday, Jan. 6
description: Highlights from media coverage in Wednesdays New York Times:

title: Cadbury Shares Slide Toward Kraft Offer
description: Update | 9:52 a.m. Shares in Kraft dropped 2 percent to $28.18 in early morning trading on Wednesday, once again opening up the spread between its bid and Cadburys share price.

title: The Morning Feed
description: More Tangles for Web of Spider-Man: Is the name of Spider-Man now as poisonous to a project as a black widows bite? With plans for a Broadway musical about Marvel Comics best-known (and most lucrative) superhero in flux, The Hollywood Reporter says that a fourth Spider-Man film, planned for 2011, could be delayed by a creative dispute between the director Sam Raimi and the Sony movie studio. Mr. Raimi, who directed the first three Spider-Man movies, wants to pit the wall-crawler against the villainous Vulture, while the studio wants to emphasize a romantic subplot between Spidey and the Black Cat.

title: We Are All Gadget Nerds Now
description: Over the holiday, Decoder was in Lower Manhattan at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Annex and found himself staring at Bo Diddleys guitar. Even, or especially, locked behind glass in an inert state, it is a thing of majestic, mysterious beauty.

title: Will Exchanges Spur Lawsuits? Maybe Not
description: Could a health care overhaul lead to a raft of consumer lawsuits against insurers over medical claims denials?

title: Connecticuts Attorney General Will Seek Dodds Senate Seat
description: Richard Blumenthal, Connecticuts Democratic attorney general, said Wednesday that he would run for the United States Senate seat being vacated by Christopher J. Dodd, who plans to announce his retirement later in the day.

title: Trouble Tempers Working Families Partys Triumph
description: Unabashedly left-leaning, the Working Families Party is the latest in a line of little-known but powerful third parties in New York. The party, whose leaders come from unions and liberal corners of the Democratic Party, rarely runs its own candidates. Leaders recruit and cross-endorse Democrats and put savvy field operatives to work in primaries and general elections.

title: Slovak Air Security Test Goes Very Wrong
description: In what no doubt seemed like a good idea at the time, Slovak officials decided to test security at two airports in Slovakia on Saturday by concealing plastic explosives in eight suitcases and waiting to see what happened next. Read the full post.

title: Senators Said Near Pact to Strip Fed of Some Powers
description: With skepticism over the Federal Reserves role growing by the day, key senators are near an agreement to strip the banking regulator of much of its authority, Reuters reported Wednesday, citing two anonymous sources.

title: Heavy Snow Causes Travel Disruptions in England
description: Unusually heavy snowfall stranded hundreds of motorists, disrupted trains and shut down schools and airports across Britain on Wednesday as the country suffered through its longest cold snap in nearly 30 years.

title: Senior Labour Insiders Want Secret Ballot on Brown
description: LONDON  Months before a national election, two senior leaders in Britains governing Labour Party issued an unusual appeal on Wednesday for a secret ballot on the leadership of Prime Minister Gordon Brown, adding to a catalog of woes ranging from recession at home to criticism of his handling of the war in Afghanistan.

title: Tennis Channel Takes Its Feud With Comcast to the F.C.C.
description: The Tennis Channel filed a complaint with the Federal Communications Commission late Tuesday accusing the cable giant Comcast of keeping it on a digital sports tier while making the Golf Channel and Versus, channels that Comcast owns, more widely available.

title: SXSW Opening-Night Film Is Announced
description: The SXSW Film Conference and Festival in Austin has chosen an opening-night film likely to excite many of the fanboys it often attracts: the fanboy-themed action film Kick-Ass. Based on a comic by Mark Millar and John S. Romita, Jr., the film tells the story of a comic book enthusiast who becomes a superhero. Aaron Johnson stars and Matthew Vaughn (Stardust, Layer Cake) directs. The film will release nationwide on April 16 from Lionsgate.

title: Sherlock Goes Daffy
description: In an analysis of Sherlock Holmes in Wednesdays New York Times, Charles McGrath writes that Arthur Conan Doyles celebrated detective has appeared in countless movies, stage plays and television series, and has inspired a shelf full of literary sequels and knockoffs, as well as some cartoon versions. He has even been played by Daffy Duck.

title: Old Age, New Gizmos
description: When the vast Consumer Electronics Show, underway this week in Las Vegas, adds an exhibition called Silvers Summit, devoted to new products for the aging and their caregivers, brace yourselves. American tech companies, taking notice of the unmistakable demographic trends, have launched a surge.

title: New Life for Solar-Updraft Technology?
description: The solar updraft tower, which uses the greenhouse effect and thermal convection to drive wind turbines and produce electricity, has been hailed as a novel  and promising  approach to renewable energy generation.

title: Wednesday Reading
description: Consumer-focused stories appear in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: The Way We Ate: The Ichthyophagous Club
description: For more than a century and a half, The New York Times has been recording the pleasures and prejudices of the American palate. The Way We Ate is a weekly tasting menu of vintage food writing from The Timess archives.

title: Starting Over at a Lexington Manufacturing Plant
description: It was almost 30 years ago that I led a management buyout of what was then a failing International Harvester factory in Springfield, Mo. As it is now, the economy then was in the tank and capital was next to impossible to come by. I was convinced that our only hope was to open the books and teach every employee how to think like an owner. As I explained in my first post, things have worked out pretty well for the company we created, SRC Holdings.

title: Citing Tough Race, Dodd Steps Aside
description: EAST HADDAM, Conn.  Christopher J. Dodd has been in politics 36 years, including an ill-starred presidential run in 2008 and a record three decades as a United States senator from Connecticut. He can, then, count votes with anyone in Congress. But with his popularity at a nadir, he was not sure he could count enough votes in his home state to assure his election to a sixth term.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Devils and Hawks Stake Claims for Supremacy
description: Ten matches on Tuesday night as the N.H.L. embarks on the second half of the regular season in what will be a January jammed with games. Given that were so far along into the season, wed expect to see a few elite teams establish themselves  and thats exactly what were seeing. On this night its the Devils and Blackhawks, rising to the top alongside the Sharks. If they keep this up, pretty soon theyre going to be on another plane altogether. Home teams listed first:

title: China Admits New Tainted-Milk Case Is Older
description: SHANGHAI  On Dec. 31, Chinese regulators announced that they had arrested three executives and shut down a dairy company here for selling products contaminated with an industrial chemical called melamine.

title: At C.E.S., Cars Take Center Stage
description: Once thought of merely as the repository for thumping subwoofers and multi-disc CD changers, cars and trucks will be a major focus for high-tech gear at the annual Consumer Electronics Show opening this week in Las Vegas.

title: Up Shoots for Academy Upset
description: The Bagger has been enjoying breaking out the sports terminology during this awards season, finding out whos in the pole position or whos pulled off a hat trick. The wild card/dark horse/Cinderella at the dance this week may be Up, which was nominated for best picture by the Producers Guild of America on Tuesday. Pixars hit, about Carl, a 78-year-old widowed grump  played by Ed Asner  who turns his house into a floating bucket list quest, bringing a precociously annoying boy (Jordan Nagai) along for the ride, was hailed by many critics as an adult-worthy animated tale. The first five minutes of the film, which wordlessly captures Carls entire life with his wife, from meet-cute to wedding day to funeral, with images that rifle through cinematic classics, was especially sophisticated. Manohla Dargis called it filmmaking at its purest. Also, it makes everyone cry.

title: City Opera Cedes Dates to City Ballet in Lincoln Center Deal
description: Starting this year the New York City Ballet will be taking over full use of the Lincoln Center theater that it shares with New York City Opera for four weeks in September and October  severely curtailing the opera companys fall season  as part of an agreement that will give the opera some relief from its forthcoming building payments.

title: A Different Kind of Showdown for Bob Barker
description: Though the real-life Bob Barker is better known for his affability and gentleness toward people with no conception of what things cost, a ship named for Mr. Barker, the longtime Price Is Right host, had its first confrontation with whalers on Tuesday, The Associated Press reported. The Bob Barker, a 1,200-ton vessel operated by the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society, the activist group featured on the Animal Planet series Whale Wars, was among the ships that tried to stop a Japanese whaling mission in waters near Antarctica. Mr. Barker, 86, donated the money for his namesake ship after meeting the Sea Shepherd founder Paul Watson through a fellow animal advocate. He said he thought he could put the Japanese whaling fleet out of business if he had $5 million, Mr. Barker told The A.P. I said, I think you do have the skills to do that, and I have $5 million, so lets get it on.' Sea Shepherd describes itself as an anti-poaching organization, and says it enforces the United Nations World Charter for Nature by intervening in whaling missions.

title: We Are All Gadget Nerds Now
description: Its finally happened! We have arrived. When I say we, I mean nerds. We completely bypassed cool and went straight to mainstream. According to David Carr of The Times, writing on the Media Decoder blog, We Are All Gadget Nerds Now. He writes:

title: Council Speaker Tries to Move Out of Mayors Shadow
description: A few weeks before Election Day, Christine C. Quinn, the speaker of the New York City Council, met with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg at a diner in Manhattan.

title: Down is up
description: From Marketwatch:

title: Content in the Service of the Gadget
description: The intersection of culture and technology has always been a rich, mashed-up place, but todays burgeoning army of electronic devices, rather than just serving as a platform for stories, seems to be creating them, David Carr writes on the Media Decoder blog. On the eve of the Consumer Electronics Show, he says, its worth pointing out that content, which weve been told is king, seems increasingly to be serving as software used to animate various devices.

title: Marijuana Trade School Finds a Bigger Home
description: The former home of a charter school at 1600 Broadway in Oakland is the new headquarters for Oaksterdam University, an Oakland-born trade school that teaches adults about the business of all things cannabis.

title: You Would Never Guess
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: Did you hear about the guy that blew up his underpants? People are mad about that. I think its funny. I dont know. Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab. You would never guess hed be mixed up in something like this. Not Abdulmutallab.

title: Graphic Content | Looking a Great Campaign in the Face
description: Steven Heller, a former art director at The New York Times, is a co-chairman of the M.F.A. Design Department at the School of Visual Arts and a blogger and author.

title: What to Watch Wednesday: Friends Forever?
description: Pinch yourselves, its really happening: Lisa Kudrow and Courteney Cox of Friends will be reunited on Wednesday on Ms. Coxs Cougar Town (ABC, 9:30 p.m.). Ms. Kudrow has been just great as a therapist on the improvised Internet series Web Therapy (lstudio.com), but here shes showing her medical versatility: shes a dermatologist. And apparently this dermatologist knows how to cut, with a remark, at least. The episode is called Rhino Skin.

title: Updating the Oval Office
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: President Obama spent the day talking to officials about airline security. One of the things they are doing is adding dozens of names to the no-fly list. Uh, hello, have you tried flying out of Newark? Were all on the no-fly list.

title: Do You Overestimate Your Childs Activity?
description: Compared to adults, children seem to be moving constantly. So its no surprise that most parents who are quizzed about their childs physical activity level describe their children as fairly active.

title: Ideal Next-Door Neighbor
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Tonight Show With Conan OBrien on NBC: A new poll asked Americans who their ideal next-door neighbor would be. The No. 1 answer was the Obama family, mainly because the Obamas are the kind of neighbors who would lend you a cup of sugar or a trillion dollars.

title: A New Look at an Old Quarrel Over Waterfront
description: Some quarrels never seem to fade away, and the anti-Communist battles of the 1940s and 1950s are being fought long after most of the original antagonists are dead.

title: Exploding Underpants
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Late Show With david Letterman on CBS: Cold. Am I right? You know, Rush Limbaugh was ill. And he had to go to the hospital. He had chest pains but hes completely recovered. Hell be back on his job on Wednesday, which is great because the country really can use some hot air now.

title: Bernanke and the bubble
description: Following up on a point I made in Atlanta (along with many others), David Leonhardt takes Ben Bernanke to task for failing to concede that the Fed, himself included, missed the bubble.

title: Iraq in the Future Perfect Tense
description: Simple word choices can tell a lot about a place. In American public conversation, Iraq is slipping into the future perfect tense  away from what is happening now, to what will have happened in the future.

title: The Situation in Yemen
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: The weather here in California is very nice. But its freezing all across the United States. In fact, in D.C., the weather is so bad  this is true  they actually hired convicted criminals to shovel snow at the U.S. Capitol. Isnt that amazing? So its nice to see members of Congress doing something useful for a change.

title: Compared to Other Rich Countries, U.S. Had Big Job Losses
description: Update | 2:45 p.m.

title: Off to the 2010 Races
description: A slow start to the 2010 elections? Not in this political environment.

title: New Features, and Fees, for Checking Accounts
description: As banks look for new revenue sources, they are rolling out new types of credit cards and checking accounts with new fees attached.

title: College Football Q.& A. With Pete Thamel
description: Pete Thamel, who covers college sports for The Times, answered reader questions on Wednesday (in the comment section below) about the Bowl Championship Series final, between Texas and Alabama, and other topics.

title: Ivanhoe Mines Hires Citi to Advise on Strategic Options
description: Ivanhoe Mines may sell shares or debt, sell off a subsidiary or look at other options as it continues to develop its huge gold and copper mine in Mongolia, the company said Wednesday.

title: In Protest, Chinese Films Pulled From Palm Springs Festival
description: Updated | 3:44 p.m. Two Chinese movies have been pulled from the Palm Springs International Film Festival to protest another film about the Dalai Lama and Tibet, Agence France-Presse reported. The Chinese movies Nanjing! Nanjing! (also known as City of Life and Death), about the Japanese occupation of Nanjing in 1937, and Quick Quick Slow, were withdrawn, according to Chinas state-run Beijing Times, because the Palm Springs festival plans to screen a movie called The Sun Behind the Clouds: Tibets Struggle for Freedom. That film, a documentary by Ritu Sarin and Tenzing Sonam, follows the Dalai Lama for a year, and its description in the festivals program said that it chronicled the 2008 protests in Tibet, the long march in India, the Beijing Olympics and the breakdown of talks with China. A representative for Nanjing! Nanjing! said that the films were pulled on the order of Chinas ministry of foreign affairs, its film bureau and the consulate general of China in Los Angeles.

title: Answers From a Bicycle Mechanic
description: Following is the first set of responses from Eric Schofield, the manager at Bicycle Habitat on Lafayette Street in Manhattan, who is responding to readers questions about bicycle maintenance and repair.We are no longer accepting questions for this feature.

title: Hus-been
description: A husband who follows in the wake of his successful wife.

title: Now That the Application Is In, Whats a Parent to Do?
description: Martha C. Merrill is the dean of admission and financial aid at Connecticut College.

title: The Good Wife Watch: New Media Drama
description: This post contains spoilers.

title: Three Views of Violent Clash Over Whaling
description: UPDATE 1/10: There is now a third video viewpoint on the collision between the Sea Shepherd anti-whaling speed boat Ady Gil and the Shonan Maru No. 2, which is described as a security boat in the Japanese whaling fleet. Sea Shepherd contends that this vantage point clearly shows that the Japanese ship was intent on closing with and ramming the protesters. [UPDATE, 2/6: Another collision at sea, this time between a Japanese harpoon vessel and the Bob Barker.]

title: New Director of Cooper-Hewitt Is Named
description: Bill Moggridge, a founder of the design firm IDEO who is widely credited with designing the first laptop computer in 1980, has been named director of the Smithsonians Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum in New York.

title: The Alcon Independent Directors Dilemma
description: Novartiss bid to acquire Alcon is an odd duck of a deal.

title: Drone Strikes Reported in Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  American missiles, presumably fired by drones, struck twice Wednesday in North Waziristan, the Pakistani tribal region that is a stronghold of the Taliban and Al Qaeda.

title: Travel Deals: All-Inclusive Stays Starting at $58
description: Occidental Hotels and Resorts  which operates all-inclusive resorts in Aruba, Costa Rica, the Dominican Republic and Mexico  is offering up to 57 percent off on stays through April 30, with rates starting at $58 a person.

title: Democrats Face Shifting and Perilous Political Environment
description: President Obama awoke on Wednesday to a dispiriting reality: Less than a year after taking office on the strength of a historic Democratic sweep, his party is facing a shifting and perilous political environment that could have big implications for this years midterm elections and his own agenda.

title: Courtney Love to Continue the Hole Story
description: Whether or not, as a timely movie title predicted, 2010 proves to be the year we make contact with intelligent alien life, it has already brought us something equally as improbable: the promise of Holes first shows in 11 years. The Guardian reported that Hole, the vintage-1990s grunge-rock band led by Courtney Love, announced on its Facebook page that it would play three European shows next month, starting with a performance on Feb. 17 at the Shepherds Bush Empire in London. The concert dates are also listed on a Web site for Nobodys Daughter, an album that was once planned as a solo project for Ms. Love but was rebranded as a Hole album last year (and is still without a label or a release date). The Guardian said that the new lineup of Hole would include Ms. Love, the guitarist Micko Larkin, the bassist Shawn Dailey and the drummer Stu Fischer. It was unclear if Ms. Loves former bandmates Eric Erlandson (who has previously declared there is no Hole without me) and Melissa Auf der Maur (who has said of Ms. Love, Shes a nutbag and I really do care about her) would be involved.

title: 3-Ds Quest to Move Beyond Gimmicks
description: THE first Academy Awards banquet, held on May 16, 1929, and honoring films released between Aug. 1, 1927, and July 31, 1928, included a special award to Warner Brothers for producing The Jazz Singer, the pioneering outstanding talking picture, which has revolutionized the industry.

title: Texas and Alabama, Still on the Calendar
description: If youre feeling a bit queasy today, consider it a case of season creep. Sports are throwing off our equilibrium by oozing into the wrong time of year. We should have been able to flip the college football switch on Jan. 1, but no, we still have Mack Brown and Nick Saban yammering at news conferences and they are not talking about their coming spring practices. Baseballs handing-out-fat-contracts season no longer has any end and it feels bizarre talking about Hall of Fame inductions while were still sweeping up the Christmas tree needles. And Redskins-as-circus season, thats a 365-day affair, not just when it gets a new ringleader.

title: Avatar Meets Up in the Air in the Desert
description: By now, it should come as no surprise that The Hurt Locker, the film about bombs over, in and around Baghdad, has been named the years best by Metacritic, the online review aggregator. Kathryn Bigelows gutsy feature has won kudos from nearly every critical group, from New York to Los Angeles to the digital realm, which as we all know, long ago stopped being the domain of pajama-clad mouth-breathers and is now the domain of everyone. Though in the march toward The 10  and the lock step to The One  awards from peer groups are more predictive, professional accolades are helpful, to be sure, if only because they encourage people to actually see the movie. The Hurt Locker, which was released in the summer, has made just over $16 million globally, or about what Avatar took home in an afternoon.

title: Merrill Executive Ford Weighs Challenge to Gillibrand
description: Amid all of the Washington news Wednesday morning, we forgot to flag this bit of news: a Merrill Lynch executive is weighing a bid to unseat Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand in this falls Democratic primary, The New York Timess Michael Barbaro reported, citing three people close to the executive.

title: Flutist to L.A. Philharmonic: Ill Take Chicago
description: Symphony orchestra musicians, in public, at least, rarely cast aspersions on other orchestras. But the principal flutist of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra had some less than complimentary things to say about the Los Angeles Philharmonic, according to a newspaper report. The flutist, Mathieu Dufour, had been on leave and was performing with the Philharmonic temporarily  a fairly common occurrence when first-chair players are considering a move. Mr. Dufour has decided to stay at his Midwestern job, The Chicago Sun-Times reported on Tuesday, quoting him as saying that the Los Angeles Philharmonic has no tradition there  no tradition of sound and no tradition of working together as a dedicated ensemble. Maybe they will have that someday in the future.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) Kiplingers list of public colleges with the best value.

title: Spectacular Dempsey Goal Raises Eyebrows, and His Reputation
description: Clint Dempsey gave England and the world a look at his skill when he scored a stunning goal in Fulhams 3-2 loss at Stoke City in the English Premier League on Tuesday. It was the Cottagers second straight loss following a run of six matches without a loss that had pushed the club to the middle of the pack.

title: The First Senator From the Tea Party?
description: Charlie Crists perma-tanned face bears none of the strain you would expect from the archetype of the embattled Republican. Politicians are supposed to keep up appearances, but Crist is especially convincing, one of the more earnest politicians you will see, whether or not he means it.

title: A Joke Is Deleted, but the Bad Taste Remains
description: The day began with a series of tongue-in-cheek Twitter messages posted by a top Republican official, each imagining the White House chief of staff, Rahm Emanuel, pressuring politically vulnerable Democratic governors from the White House. Included was this tweet:

title: For the Moment | Everyday Design
description: Michele Caniato is the president of Culture and Commerce, a design management consultancy, and of Material Connexion, a materials consultancy and library; both companies are based in New York.

title: Leader of Private School to Step Down
description: The head of the Ethical Culture Fieldston School has decided to leave in June, disappointing many parents, students and staff members who had expected the popular school leader to stay longer.

title: Peacefully Adrift as the Mississippi River Just Rolls Along
description: THE same drifting log had caught up with our kayaks again. It was sometime during our third day on the Mississippi River, or was it the fourth day, or the second or fifth? Id lost myself again in a silent reverie, allowing my kayak to spin lazily along the great rivers western shoreline, like a bright yellow leaf with some kind of exotic beetle in a life vest perched in the middle of it.

title: Alabama Quarterback Found Answers in Season of Self-Doubt
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.  The whispers follow Greg McElroy around. He hears them as he walks across campus, eats at restaurants and even when he takes out-of-state trips.

title: Clean Technology Investing Slips, but Could Be Worse, Report Finds
description: In a flurry of deal making bolstered by government subsidies for renewable energy, venture capitalists invested $5.6 billion in green technology companies worldwide in 2009, according to a preliminary report released Wednesday by the Cleantech Group and Deloitte.

title: Choptank It Shall Be
description: First Bobby Werhane and Joshua Morgan were going to call their Bleecker Street seafood restaurant Cherrystones. But that did not fly (or swim). Then it was Rockfish. Now, when it opens next week, in the space on Bleecker Street that was Bar Q, it will be called Choptank.

title: The Nifty 50 | Bruce High Quality Foundation
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Suicide Bomber Strikes at Police Officers in Caucasus
description: MOSCOW  A suicide car bomber killed six police officers in the capital of the Russian region of Dagestan on Wednesday. It was the deadliest such attack in months in a region where assassinations of police officers is a defining characteristic of the local militant Islamist movement.

title: A Bicycle Death on the Heels of a Memorial Ride
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: What Ails the Mona Lisa?
description: Its not only famous authors whose life-threatening maladies can be diagnosed centuries after their deaths, but a medical expert at the University of Palermo in Italy says that he has also found evidence of medical afflictions in the subjects of some of the worlds most famous paintings, including the Mona Lisa, The Times of London reported. Vito Franco, a professor of pathological anatomy at the university, told The Times that he had spent two years examining people depicted in art masterpieces for evidence of disease and illness. Among his diagnoses, Dr. Franco said that Mona Lisa may have had high cholesterol, possibly evinced by a buildup of fatty acids under her skin, as well as a benign tumor in her right eye. He also said that the 5-year-old Infanta Margarita depicted in Velzquezs painting Las Meninas might have had McCune-Albright syndrome, a genetic disease that affects bones, and the Virgin Mary in Piero della Francescas Madonna del Parto has a goiter on her neck.

title: Theres an Android in My iPhone
description: Heres one of the more curious gadgets youre not going to see on the show floor of the Consumer Electronics Show. Its an iPhone knock-off that may just be better than the iPhone.

title: Senator Dodd Will Not Seek Re-election
description: Democratic Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut announced his decision not to seek re-election for a sixth term. (Video: MSNBC)

title: Can Parenting Be Truly Equal?
description: In the comments about my sleep post yesterday, Stella wrote: I think women need to be more firm in their expectations of their husbands  Theres no reason that women should tolerate anything less than a 50-50 partnership, children or not.

title: Netbook Trio Uses New Intel Chip
description: This Wednesday is press day at the annual Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, when manufacturers line up, one after another, to announce their new products. But press conferences are crowded, the information can be hard to absorb (especially by late afternoon) and lots of details can get lost.

title: Heavy Snow Causes Disruptions in Britain
description: London, a city known for its low tolerance for snow, was buffeted by an unusually thick snowfall on Wednesday, the heaviest in more than 20 years. The snow and ice shut down railroad services, airports and schools across southern England and brought travel nearly to a halt on major highways.

title: A Matter of Time: Conducting Experiments on Perception and Estimations of Time
description: Overview | How good are you at estimating time? Why does time seem to fly when youre having fun? How do our brains perceive or track the passing of time? In this lesson, students estimate time spent on two short activities, one fun and one tedious, and then analyze and discuss their results and experiences. They then devise and conduct their own time-related investigations.

title: Willie Mitchell, Soul Music Producer, Dies at 81
description: Willie Mitchell, who shaped the elegant yet gritty sound of Al Green, Ann Peebles and other stars of soul music as the house producer at Hi Records in the 1960s and 70s, died Tuesday in Memphis, where he lived. He was 81.

title: Gunfire at Gaza Protest Near Egypt
description: JERUSALEM  An anti-Egypt rally in southern Gaza turned deadly on Wednesday when demonstrators rushed the border fence and stoned Egyptian troops on the other side, leading to an exchange of gunfire and the death of an Egyptian soldier. Nine Egyptian soldiers and a dozen Palestinians were wounded from stones and gunfire, witnesses and medics said.

title: Cohen Remains the Wild Card in Womens Skating
description: Nearly four years have gone by since Sasha Cohen, the 2006 Olympic silver medalist, competed in an official figure skating competition. But with the 2010 Vancouver Games about month away, she appears set to break that drought.

title: Passenger Jets Still Carry Unscreened Cargo
description: While a lot of attention has been paid in recent days to the need to find better ways to screen passengers and their luggage, as aviation security officials try to keep terrorists  or Slovak security officials  from smuggling explosives onto passenger jets, it remains an uncomfortable fact that entirely unscreened packages are still routinely loaded into the cargo holds of those same airplanes.

title: How to Sell Your Business
description: You only sell your business once.

title: Iranian Panel Calls Official in Charge of Prison the Main Culprit in Detainee Deaths
description: A parliamentary panel in Iran on Wednesday implicated a senior official and ally of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad in the deaths of at least three detainees arrested in June during antigovernment demonstrations, the Alef Web site reported.

title: As Levy Mulls Bid for Governor, Hispanic Lawmakers Protest
description: ALBANY  His candidacy is not even official, and his announcement that he is considering running for governor is barely three days old.

title: Canon Adds Four Budget Shooters
description: Canon unleashed a quartet of affordable PowerShot models at C.E.S. on Wednesday, setting a decidedly modest tone for the first camera announcement of the show.

title: Has the Economy Closed Your Exit Door?
description: In a recent post on Youre the Boss, the editors asked readers to share their stories of businesses that did not survive 2009. One reader  Joan Donofrio of Concord, Calif.  posted the following comment about her experience as the owner of four Curves franchise locations:

title: The Concierge | Outerborough Adventures
description: Christine Muhlke, T Magazines food editor and de facto concierge, is at your service. Have a dining or imbibing quandary for her? Leave your question in the comments section below.Dear Concierge:What were your top outerborough food adventures last year?  BF

title: Cold Snap Across the United States
description: NBC's Janet Samlien reports on the cold weather plaguing much of the nation. (Video: NBC)

title: AT&T Jumps on the Android Bandwagon
description: Sprint has the HTC Hero. Verizon has the Droid. T-Mobile has the Nexus One, among others.

title: Two Democrats Will Not Seek Re-election
description: Senators Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut and Byron L. Dorgan of North Dakota, both Democrats, will not be seeking re-election in November.

title: Travel Planning Sites Team Up
description: Two prominent Web sites for travel planning have formed a canny partnership.

title: Interior Chief Vows Scrutiny of Oil and Gas Leases
description: WASHINGTON  The interior secretary, Ken Salazar, said Wednesday that his department would conduct more rigorous reviews of oil and gas leasing on public lands, declaring that the agency would no longer be a candy store for the petroleum industry, as he said it had been during the Bush administration.

title: Following Long Wait, Dawson Enters Hall Alone
description: Andre Dawson studied the voting from last years Hall of Fame election, and two figures stood out: 67 percent and 63 percent. The first was his percentage of votes, and the second was Bert Blylevens. Dawson predicted that this time, they would clear the 75 percent threshold needed for election.

title: More Ballet, Less Opera at the State Theater: Win-Win?
description: The New York City Ballet has always wanted a fall repertory season at the theater it shares with New York City Opera at Lincoln Center. Now, the ballets wish is coming true, because of the economic needs of the opera. This September, the ballet will perform for four weeks in advance of its usual Nutcracker run, which starts in late November. The opera, in turn, will get $9 million in relief from its building payments, part of the $100 million gift given by the oil magnate David H. Koch toward the renovation of the theater, which was named after him and was completed in November. Read more about the arrangement.

title: How Many Monkeys Do It Take to Stop the Show?
description: Here at ArtsBeat and its surrounding territories, we got a good laugh from Gregg Allmans evocative explanation for why he wasnt completely bummed about moving the Allman Brothers Bands annual residency to the United Palace from the Beacon Theater: One monkey dont stop no show, he said.

title: A New Video About Video
description: One of the overarching themes of C.E.S. this year (as it was, in fact, last year) is the ways in which TV programming is migrating to the Internet and how the Internet is migrating to television sets. In a new video, Bits blogger Nick Bilton takes a look at how were going to be watching television in the very near future.

title: Essay: The Least of These My Brethren
description: In the winter of 1983, I interviewed and photographed dozens of Americans who had migrated to Florida from the Northeast and Midwest. They left because national unemployment was hovering around 10 percent, while in Florida it was 7.8 percent  and much warmer.

title: Some at Fed See a Need to Do More for Housing
description: Despite extensive government intervention in the housing market, some policy makers at the Federal Reserve are worried that even more might need to be done.

title: Avatar and the Suspense-Free Shortlist
description: None too shockingly, Avatar is still in the running for best visual effects Oscar, as became clear on Wednesday when the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences whittled down the original list of 15 movies to seven. The likely vanquished competitors are District 9, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, Star Trek, Terminator Salvation, Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen and 2012.

title: OLED TV: Still Waiting in the Wings
description: With all the buzz at the Consumer Electronics Show focused on 3D televisionwith companies like Sony, Samsung and Panasonic announcing plans to sell 3D TVs to consumers this yearnews about another potential video breakthough, a full-size OLED TV, is so far a no-show at C.E.S. 2010. So far.

title: A Mixed Forecast for Financial Stocks
description: Investing in financial stocks will be boring this year compared with the charged atmosphere of 2009, analysts at FBR Capital Markets said in a report to clients on Wednesday. But they warned that residential loan losses and the weak economy would continue to clip the earning power of banks.

title: Treat Me, but No Tricks Please
description: I RECEIVED an e-mail message recently from an angry doctor. Hed torn his hamstring running on a beach and spent eight weeks  a total of 20 hours  in physical therapy. Then his insurer said the physical therapy was not covered.

title: Resolved
description: Here it is 2010 and Paper Cuts is waking up slowly, still waiting for that second cup of coffee to hit. Soon well be back into the swing of things, with playlists and stray questions and bookish observations, but in the meantime weve been surfing through various reading resolutions for the New Year, and we wonder if youd care to suggest any of your own. Forget Moby-Dick, though  we finally finished that one last year.

title: AT&T Wants to Smarten Up Its Dumb Phones
description: As I reported on Monday, companies and entrepreneurs are bringing the app frenzy to feature phones  the simpler, less sophisticated cousins to shiny smartphones like the iPhone and Motorola Droid.

title: Discovery to Show Pyramids, Great Wall in 3-D
description: One of Discovery Communications first 3-D productions, ATLAS 4D, will feature three-dimensional views of the Pyramids and the Great Wall of China. The program will be produced in 3-D and will be used for several purposes, a Discovery spokeswoman said Wednesday.

title: Unauthorized Times Square Obama Ad Draws Attention
description: A New York garment company known for publicity stunts is getting one noticed by the Obama administration.

title: Fed Minutes Show Division on Emergency Steps
description: Members of the Federal Reserve continued to grapple with uncertainties facing the economy at their most recent meeting, with some members suggesting that the central bank might have to expand measures to help the mortgage markets if the recovery stumbles, The New York Timess Jack Healy reports.

title: Debating Social Democracy
description: Responding to Jim Manzi (and myself) on the subject of Europes falling share of global G.D.P., Jon Chait points out that the gap between Americas economic performance and Europes over the last 30 years narrows dramatically if you look at G.D.P per capita, rather than just at overall economic growth. In other words, much of the widening gap between the U.S. and European shares of global G.D.P. can be chalked up to Americas population growth since the 1970s, rather than increasing per person wealth.

title: Queens Principal Accused of Seeking Sex From Students
description: A high school principal in Ozone Park, Queens, inappropriately touched or solicited sex from at least four male students at the High School for Construction Trades, Engineering and Architecture, where he had served as principal since 2006, according a report by Richard Condon, the special commissioner of investigation for the citys Department of Education.

title: Top Scams Targeted Recession Victims
description: On Wednesday, the Council of Better Business Bureaus released a list of what it considered the top scams of the 2009.

title: Justice Said to Weigh Opposing Ticketmaster-Live Nation Deal
description: The Justice Department has a team of litigators prepared to oppose the merger of ticketing giant Ticketmaster and concert promoter Live Nation and could decide to take the deal to court, Reuters reported Wednesday, citing anonymous antitrust sources.

title: Morgan Stanley Wins Lawsuit Against Discover
description: Morgan Stanley won a legal battle with its former subsidiary, Discover Financial Services, over nearly $800 million that Morgan Stanley says it was owed by the credit card company.

title: Sondheims Wisdom, With Wistful Fragility
description: One reason any singing actor with a modicum of talent cant go wrong interpreting the songs of Stephen Sondheim is that they make whoever sings them sound like a genius and a sage. In a fusion of sensibilities, the composers complicated thoughts become the singers, so that the performers best possible self  a more intuitive, smarter self (Mr. Sondheim doesnt do stupid)  comes to the fore.

title: Opposites Onstage, Opening a Season
description: In the current vogue of ballet programs arranged by theme (All Tchaikovsky! Love stories! Leotard ballets!) its easy to pine for the old days, when works with seemingly little in common lent a certain hot-and-cold balance to a night at Lincoln Center. On Tuesday evening the New York City Ballet opened its winter repertory season with such a disparate double-header: Peter Martinss Nave and Sentimental Music, followed by George Balanchines Who Cares? from 1970.

title: City Says 9/11 Trials Will Cost $200 Million a Year
description: The Bloomberg administration has placed the price for security operations for the trials of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and other terrorism suspects connected to the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, at more than $200 million a year, which would make it by far the costliest security operation for a single event in the city in recent memory.

title: Paterson Says Legislators Put State in Danger
description: ALBANY  In a strikingly blunt State of the State address, Gov. David A. Paterson chastised the lawmakers seated before him on Wednesday, saying they had spent the state into near-ruin and stood by as a plague of political corruption destroyed New Yorkers trust in their government.

title: Orphans Home Cycle Aims for Broadway for the Fall Season
description: A consortium of theater producers plans to transfer the Off Broadway production of Horton Footes Orphans Home Cycle to Broadway in the fall, rather than rush the show to Broadway this spring as had been discussed in recent weeks, two theater executives involved in the decision said on Wednesday.

title: Spam E-Mail Appeals to Young, Overweight
description: Chances are youve seen those e-mail spam ads that tout the latest herbal remedy that promises dramatic weight loss. If youre like most people, you just delete them.

title: J. W. von Brunn, Accused Museum Gunman, Dies at 89
description: James W. von Brunn, who was accused of fatally shooting a security guard at the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington in June, died on Wednesday at a hospital in North Carolina, near the federal prison where he was being held. He was 89.

title: Officers Released From Hospital After Pit Bull Attack
description: When police officers in New York have reason to fire their weapons at dogs, they often hit their mark.

title: Pictures of the Day: Wednesday, Jan. 6
description: Could you just stand over there, for scale? Most of us have  at one time or another  made such a request of a friend or family member, or been asked by a photographer to jump into the frame and serve as a human yardstick. It may not be personally flattering, but its certainly an effective device, as two pictures in todays show, Slide 8 and Slide 10, quite dazzlingly reveal.

title: Schwarzenegger: California Needs a Sweetheart Deal, Too
description: Update | 5:42 p.m.  Congressional Democratic leaders, including the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, who represents San Francisco, are taking issue with Gov. Arnold Schwarzeneggers criticism of the major health care legislation.

title: Writers Groups Oppose Google Settlement
description: A trio of writers groups has sent an open letter to members of Congress who are also authors, objecting to the Google book settlement that seeks to create a vast digital library of mostly out-of-print books.

title: At C.E.S., Cars Take Center Stage
description: Over on Wheels, John R. Quain writes about the car-tech showcasing at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. Among the highlights: Internet-connected cars, advanced navigation systems and a Safe Driver TechZone. Sales of in-car technologies are expected to top $9.3 billion for 2009.

title: Florida Lawyer to Plead Guilty in Ponzi Scheme
description: Bernard L. Madoff may have company soon. A disbarred South Florida lawyer agreed in federal court on Wednesday to plead guilty later this month to charges accusing him of running Ponzi scheme that cheated thousands of investors out of $1.2 billion. The lawyer, Scott Rothstein, could be sentenced to life in prison.

title: Desert bubbles
description: Some commenters on my Bernanke-bubble post wondered how the story I told back in 2005 can account for Phoenix and Las Vegas.

title: Dispatch | Barcelona
description: The best way to beat a case of recession whiplash just might be a trip to Barcelona. Not only is Catalonias largest city a contagiously happy, optimistic sort of place, but it also just keeps getting better and better. Why? Recession or not  Spains economy is in bad shape, too  the locals honestly believe their city will be more beautiful, ecological, socially harmonious and culturally vibrant in the future, and theyre probably right.

title: Adu Joins Greek Club Aris
description: Freddy Adu is going Greek. The United States midfielder/forward ended speculation about his immediate future Wednesday when he agreed to join Aris on an 18-month loan. Adu is contracted to Benfica, in Portugal, and he had fueled speculation  in his Twitter feed that  he could join Jozy Altidore at Hull City in England.

title: Namath Has His Own Memories of 65
description: No doubt about it, Joe Namath said Wednesday, he crossed the goal line with the ball on that fateful New Years Day of 1965.

title: Colorado Governor Will Not Run Again
description: DENVER  Gov. Bill Ritter Jr. of Colorado, a Democrat who was elected in 2006 and hailed as a leader of what his party called a new strategy in the Rocky Mountain West, a region long dominated by Republicans, said on Wednesday that he would not seek a second term.

title: Justice Department to Review Comcast-NBC Deal
description: The Justice Department said Wednesday that it would review Comcasts proposed acquisition of NBC Universals broadcast network, cable channels and movie studios.

title: Putting the i in Apple
description: In among all the speculation about the tablet that seems to be forthcoming from Apple and whether it will be a boon or a gallows for MSM, the name is getting a pretty good work-out. Some have noted that Apple seems to have its leopard paws on iSlate, but reader Patrick J. Shields is underwhelmed and suggested iTab had a nice ring to it. Maybe its time to help Apple and see if we can come up with a name. A few suggestions:

title: U.S.O.C. Introduces Blackmun as New Chief
description: The United States Olympic Committee formally announced the selection of Scott Blackmun as its chief executive at a news conference Wednesday in Colorado Springs.

title: Honda and Toyota Go Small at New Delhi Auto Expo
description: The 2010 auto show season has officially started, though not in the a place you might expect  India.

title: N.B.A. Suspends Gilbert Arenas
description: As Gilbert Arenas prepared to play the Philadelphia 76ers on Tuesday night, he entered a circle of his Washington Wizards teammates, cocked his fingers into a gun and playfully shot them.

title: Lou Reed and Friends to Play Benefit for Tuli Kupferberg
description: Lou Reed, John Zorn, Sonic Youth and others will play a benefit concert for Tuli Kupferberg (left), the Beat poet and original member of the Fugs, at St. Anns Warehouse in Brooklyn on Jan. 22. Mr. Kupferberg, 86, has had two strokes over the last year, which have left him blind  although he still manages to regularly post video jokes to YouTube  and the tickets for the concert, which is being produced by Hal Willner, will help pay his medical expenses. Among the others performers are the singer John Kruth; Ed Sanders, Mr. Kupferbergs fellow Fug; and Peter Stampfel of the Holy Modal Rounders (who also played on early Fugs albums). Tickets are $75 to $125 and are available at stannswarehouse.org or (718) 254.8779.

title: An Oceanfront Home in Mexico
description: This 20-year-old house in a gated community in Rosarito is on the market for $895,000.

title: Whats the Outlook for Democrats?
description: Updated, Jan. 7, 12:15 p.m. |  John Aldrich of Duke University joins the discussion. He says the Democrats will lose Congressional seats as turnout shrinks in 2010.

title: Galleon Insider Inquiry Is Extended Again
description: Eight people charged in the wide-ranging insider trading investigation involving the Galleon Group have agreed with prosecutors on Wednesday to extend the inquiry for at least 21 days for a possible resolution of their criminal cases.

title: Mobile Phones Eliminate Single-Serving Devices
description: As chips and sensors become smaller and more advanced, mobile phones are beginning to swallow and adopt any number of new functions. As a result, they are quickly replacing other single-serving devices, including GPS units and cameras.

title: End of Road Nears for BBDO and Chrysler
description: As the long-running contract between the Chrysler Group and BBDO Worldwide nears its expiration at the end of January, the automaker is completing its line-up of replacement agencies.

title: A Houseboat on the Thames
description: What started off as student quarters has turned into a permanent home.

title: Preview: 'Brace for Impact'
description: The TLC program looks back at the crash landing in the Hudson River of US Airways Flight 1549.

title: At Preview of Tavern Auction, Plenty of Oohs and Ahhs
description: They kicked the tires. Grandly. For the first time, dozens of potential bidders for 25,000 orphaned treasures from Tavern on the Green were admitted to the shuttered and bankrupt landmark restaurant in Central Park on Wednesday. They previewed next weeks three-day auction of 1,000 lots of items that have been valued at $100 to $1.2 million.

title: The Pilot Navigates Fame
description: Watch Capt. Chesley B. Sullenberger III on a red carpet, and at any given moment three or four hands are on him. There are taps on his arms, hands outstretched and palms on his back from fans. People want to reach him, touch him, thank him, take the measure of a media legend.

title: Properties for $250,000
description: Homes for sale in Mississippi, Arizona and Atlanta.

title: Correction: The Week Ahead: Jan. 3  Jan. 9
description: An article last Sunday misspelled the last name of the director of "The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle." He is Stephen Earnhart, not Earnheart.

title: Kaleidoscopic Adventures, Creating a Range of Dramas Big and Small
description: No sooner does Twyla Tharps Opus 111 begin than her architectural command of stage space becomes handsomely evident. She created this work in 2008 for Pacific Northwest Ballet, and, as the company performed the piece at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, other pleasures are soon part of the experience: the individuality and maturity of the 12 dancers; the attractive costumes by Mark Zappone; the Brahms String Quintet No. 2 in G thats the accompaniment (and from which it takes its title). But the ways in which Ms. Tharp dramatizes space are constantly striking here. You can easily imagine how much better it would look on the larger stage of the companys home theater, the Marion Oliver McCaw Hall, in Seattle; but the limited Joyce space cannot wreck it.

title: Vudu Expands Its Service to More TV Makers
description: For the last two years Ive been following Vudu, the Santa Clara, Calif., based start-up entirely focused on bringing a large on-demand catalog of movies from the Web into the living room. The company started out in the tough business of selling its own set-top box, then gradually began integrating its well-reviewed service into televisions and Blu-ray players.

title: Hillary Clinton on Development Issues
description: Sec. Clinton gave an excellent speech on development today. She has a longtime interest in poverty issues, and President Obamas mother was a pioneer in microfinance, yet so far the Obama administration hasnt been particularly engaged in global poverty issues. It took forever, after all, to get an administrator for USAID, the aid agency. In contrast, President Bush never seemed very interested in global poverty, but he left a quite impressive legacy there  with Pepfar, the AIDS effort; the Presidents Malaria Initiative; and his Millennium Challenge Corporation directing aid to countries with good governance.

title: All Clear at the Fed
description: Harry Truman once asked for a one-armed economist, so he would not hear, On the one hand . . .  What would he have thought of a committee filled with economists?

title: Photo of the Week
description: Cars zip through Mauritanias desert in the 11-day Africa Eco Race, which ends in Dakar, Senegal.

title: New Year, Same Ratings
description: New episodes of NCIS and NCIS: Los Angeles helped lift CBS above its rivals on Tuesday night, even against the FedEx Orange Bowl on Fox and the season premiere of The Biggest Loser on NBC. According to Nielsens estimates, 21.3 million viewers tuned in to NCIS, and 18 million viewers watched its spinoff, NCIS: Los Angeles. Fox was likely to place second with its live football broadcast, for which final ratings were not immediately available, but NBC appeared to be in a close race with Fox. NBC earned an average of 11.7 million viewers for The Biggest Loser: Couples, nearly matching the series highest rated debut a year ago (11.9 million).

title: Flutist to Los Angeles: Ill Take Chicago
description: Symphony orchestra musicians, in public at least, rarely cast aspersions on other orchestras. But the principal flutist of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra had some less than complimentary things to say about the Los Angeles Philharmonic, according to a newspaper report. The flutist, Mathieu Dufour, had been on leave and was performing with the Philharmonic temporarily  a fairly common occurrence when first-chair players are considering a move. Mr. Dufour has decided to stay at his Midwestern job, The Chicago Sun-Times reported on Tuesday, quoting him as saying that the Los Angeles Philharmonic has no tradition there  no tradition of sound and no tradition of working together as a dedicated ensemble. He added, Maybe they will have that someday in the future. Los Angeles has fine musicians, he said. But we have achieved a very strong common purpose and set of aims in Chicago that they do not have or do not yet have there. Deborah F. Rutter, the Chicago orchestras president, called Mr. Dufours decision great news. A spokesman for the Philharmonic, Sophie Jefferies, said: Were very sorry to see him go and wish him all the best. He is an amazing player.

title: Chinese Films Pulled From Festival in Protest
description: Two Chinese movies have been pulled from the Palm Springs International Film Festival in California to protest another film about the Dalai Lama and Tibet, Agence France-Presse reported. The Chinese movies Nanjing! Nanjing! (also known as City of Life and Death), about the Japanese occupation of Nanjing in 1937, and Quick Quick Slow Slow, a short film, were withdrawn, according to Chinas state-run Beijing Times, because the festival plans to screen a movie called The Sun Behind the Clouds: Tibets Struggle for Freedom. That film, a documentary by Ritu Sarin and Tenzing Sonam, follows the Dalai Lama for a year, and its description in the festivals program said that it chronicled the 2008 protests in Tibet, the long march in India, the Beijing Olympics and the breakdown of talks with China. The Beijing Times called the movie a Tibetan independence film. A representative for Nanjing! Nanjing! said that the films were pulled on the order of Chinas ministry of foreign affairs, its film bureau and the consulate general of China in Los Angeles.

title: Fences and lips Add Cast Members
description: Viola Davis, below, recently seen suffering up a storm in the film adaptation of Doubt (a performance that earned her an Academy Award nomination, among other plaudits), will not be getting a reprieve any time soon. She will join the cast of the coming Broadway revival of Fences, by August Wilson, in which she will play the put-upon spouse of Denzel Washington, the shows press representatives said on Tuesday. The revival of Fences, which won the Tony Award for best play and the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 1987, is to begin previews at the Cort Theater on April 14 and open on April 26. ... Press representatives for the Roundabout Theater Companys coming production of Terrence McNallys Lips Together, Teeth Apart, said that Lili Taylor (of Six Feet Under and I Shot Andy Warhol) had joined the cast, which also includes Patton Oswalt (Big Fan) and Megan Mullally (Will and Grace). The production, directed by Joe Mantello, begins previews at the American Airlines Theater on April 9 and opens April 29.

title: Courtney Love and Hole to Play European Shows
description: Whether or not, as a timely movie title predicted, 2010 proves to be the year we make contact with intelligent alien life, it has already brought us something equally improbable: the promise of Holes first shows in 11 years. The Guardian reported that Hole, the vintage-1990s grunge-rock band led by Courtney Love, above, said on its Facebook page that it would play three European shows next month, starting with a performance on Feb. 17 at the Shepherds Bush Empire in London. The concert dates, including ones in Milan and Amsterdam, are also listed on nobodysdaughter.com, a Web site for Nobodys Daughter, an album that was once planned as a solo project for Ms. Love but was rebranded as a Hole album last year. (It is still without a label or a release date.) The Guardian said that Holes lineup would include Ms. Love, the guitarist Micko Larkin, the bassist Shawn Dailey and the drummer Stu Fischer. It was unclear if Ms. Loves former bandmates Eric Erlandson and Melissa Auf der Maur would be involved.

title: Bob Barker, Whale Pal
description: Though Bob Barker, below, is known for his affability and gentleness toward people with no conception of what things cost, a ship named for Mr. Barker, the former Price Is Right host, had its first confrontation with whalers on Tuesday, The Associated Press reported. The Bob Barker, a 1,200-ton vessel operated by the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society, the group featured on the Animal Planet series Whale Wars, was among the ships that tried to stop a Japanese whaling mission in waters near Antarctica. Mr. Barker, 86, donated the money for his namesake ship after meeting the Sea Shepherd founder Paul Watson through a fellow animal advocate. He said he thought he could put the Japanese whaling fleet out of business if he had $5 million, Mr. Barker told The A.P. I said, I think you do have the skills to do that, and I have $5 million, so lets get it on.

title: Broadway Move Delayed for Orphans
description: A consortium of producers plans to transfer the Off Broadway production of The Orphans Home Cycle by Horton Foote to Broadway in the fall, rather than rush the show to Broadway this spring as had been discussed in recent weeks, two theater executives involved in the decision said on Wednesday. The producers had an opportunity to move into the Neil Simon Theater this spring for a limited run, but decided they needed more time to prepare the transfer, said the executives, James Houghton and Michael Wilson, who are the respective artistic directors of the Signature Theater Company and Hartford Stage. The play, a co-production now running at Signature through March, was the last work by Foote before he died last year, and is based on the lives of his parents and relatives in Texas in the early 1900s; the intention is to transfer the full cast, including Bill Heck and Maggie Lacey, above. Daryl Roth, a lead member of the consortium planning the Broadway transfer, said that the producers wanted more time to lock in group ticket sales, scale the production from the 160-seat Signature space to a larger theater, and develop a marketing plan for Orphans, which is a three-part play that runs nine hours and lacks star actors.

title: Inspecting the Goods at Tavern on the Greens Auction
description: On City Room, Glenn Collins joins the tire-kicking crowds at Tavern on the Green at the preview of the items to be put up for sale at next weeks auction. Among the 1,000 lots of items are candelabras, samovars, weather vanes, sculptures, murals, prints, lighting fixtures, silver and china place settings.

title: Trying to Grow Up While Collecting Saliva and Fidgeting Off Chairs
description: With the attitude-laden title of Once and for All Were Gonna Tell You Who We Are So Shut Up and Listen, a theatrical piece that has its New York premiere on Thursday, a little history is in order.

title: Albums by Swift and Boyle Top 2009 Charts, as Sales Continue Plunge
description: The music industry rounded out a difficult decade with a difficult year.

title: Young Pianist Thrust Into Elite Group
description: Odd, the pianist Kirill Gerstein thought. A music critic from Houston was coming to interview him in Jacksonville, Fla. Mr. Gersteins manager had arranged the meeting, at the Omni Hotels J bar, to coincide with a run of concerts last November. Might as well meet the writer, the pianist thought.

title: Susan Boyle Still Tops the Weekly Chart
description: Susan Boyle  prevailed in the final week of music sales for 2009, holding at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart for a sixth week. Her I Dreamed a Dream (Syco Music/Columbia) sold 137,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Its 3.1 million sales gave Taylor Swifts Fearless (Big Machine) a run for its money as the best-selling album of the year, but in the end Ms. Swift prevailed. Fearless holds at No. 5 on the latest weekly chart with 60,000 sales, but her total for the year was 3.2 million. ( An article about album sales for the year is here.)

title: Alabamas McClain Sick, but Improving
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.  After missing media day Wednesday with a stomach virus, Alabama linebacker Rolando McClain is improving and expected to play in Thursdays Bowl Championship Series title game against Texas.

title: U.S. Players in Training for Training Camp
description: It is good to be an elite soccer player in Southern California. The weather  70 degrees and sunny on Wednesday  is great. The commute to the United States national team training camp, which convened this week at Home Depot Center in Carson, is pretty easy. And there are always other players around for pickup games and FIFA 10 tournaments on PlayStation.
