title: Tastes of Mariachi and Alabama
description: Usher

title: Righting the Bodys Clock Through Chemicals
description: While Cephalons drug Nuvigil seeks to keep people awake when the bodys internal clock calls for sleep, experts say there are ways to make that clock adjust faster to a new time zone, thereby speeding resolution of jet lag.

title: A Drugs Second Act: Battling Jet Lag
description: It seemed like the offer of a lifetime  earn $2,500 by flying to France aboard a private luxury jet.

title: The Obamas and Their Outerwear
description: A New York clothing company has gotten some extra unauthorized mileage out of President Obamas coat choice for his visit to the Great Wall of China.

title: Rebound Expected After Drop in Law Firm Mergers
description: The number of law firm mergers in the United States fell 24 percent in 2009 from the prior year, but that downturn is expected to be reversed this year as law firms look to join forces to increase profits and gain access to new markets, according to Altman Weil, a legal management consulting firm.

title: Boulezs Gentler Roar
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland

title: Ill Have a Low-Fat Muffin With My Frappuccino
description: A Stanford University study has found that customers at New York City Starbucks restaurants bought items with 6 percent fewer calories after the city began requiring chain fast food restaurants to post calorie counts in April 2008.

title: Breaking Up in a Digital Fishbowl
description: THERE is a scene in the movie Hes Just Not That Into You in which Mary, played by Drew Barrymore, laments the numerous technological ways she is being rebuffed by a potential beau. E-mail. Text messages. MySpace. Its exhausting, she complains.

title: Cadbury Stock Price Draws Closer to Krafts Bid
description: Shares in Cadbury fell again on Wednesday, edging closer to the level of Krafts $16 billion hostile takeover offer.

title: Spoon: Still Independent, Still Cool
description: BOSTON

title: A Pillow-Talk Portrait of a Hollywood Survivor
description: In writing his exhaustingly detailed biography of Warren Beatty, Peter Biskind relied on strange rules of decorum. He decided that Mr. Beattys relationship with his wife, Annette Bening, was off limits, because I didnt want to be in the position of writing anything that might embarrass them or their four children. He chose to respect the privacy of the Beatty household. Less sacrosanct: Mr. Beattys pants.

title: GMAC Bowl: Central Michigan (11-2) vs. Troy (9-3)
description: Perhaps no other bowl this season will send more people scrambling for a roster. You might know of Dan LeFevour, the Central Michigan quarterback, but are you familiar with Troys Jerrel Jernigan? How about Frank Zombo? Nick Lewis? Cameron Sheffield? Do you know which of the last four names was made up by me and plays for neither team?

title: The Light Alston Touch: 40 Years of Casual Grace
description: London

title: No Award for You, Mr. Hornby
description: All day Wednesday, the Twitterverse has been buzzing  if thats the sound retweeting makes; the Bagger thinks of it as more of a low hum  with the news that Nick Hornby, the novelist, screenwriter and music lover, was deemed ineligible for a Writers Guild of America nomination for his script for An Education. Not that Mr. Hornby needs to sweat his reputation  dude has more accolades in more media than the RZA  but he is in good company: Quentin Tarantinos Inglourious Basterds, Tom Ford and David Scearces A Single Man and Joe Penhalls The Road, are also ineligible, reports Indiewire, because they are not guild-affiliated.

title: Steady Drip of Leaks Corrodes the Core of the Iranian Regime
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  Beatings, arrests, show trials and even killings have failed to discourage Iranians from taking to the streets in protest. But those same tactics may be taking a toll on the government itself, eating away at its legitimacy even among its core of insiders, Iran experts are saying. The evidence? Leaks.

title: Restructuring of Simmons Is Approved
description: The Simmons Bedding Company says a bankruptcy judge has approved its plan to be taken over by a group that owns its rival Serta. Simmons plans to emerge from bankruptcy around Jan. 20, Reuters reports.

title: Southern Schools Mark Two Majorities
description: ATLANTA  The South has become the first region in the country where more than half of public school students are poor and more than half are members of minorities, according to a new report.

title: Moods Conducive to Dying and Dancing
description: Up on the screen above the Glasslands Gallery stage on Tuesday night, a car was being swallowed whole by flames. Beneath it the Chicago-born band Salem was suggesting what it might sound like to die.

title: Out of the Blue, Prestige and Riches
description: EVERY diamond is a story as old as the earth and will outlast us all. Diamonds are, indeed, forever, but they are not forever in view.

title: UBS Client Sentenced to 5 Years Probation
description: A New Jersey client of the international banking giant UBS has been sentenced to five years probation after pleading guilty to concealing more than $6 million in assets in Swiss bank accounts, The Associated Press reports.

title: Cooper-Hewitt Picks Director, First Designer in Job
description: Bill Moggridge, a founder of the design firm IDEO who is widely credited with designing the look of the first commercial laptop, has been named director of the Smithsonian Institutions Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum in New York.

title: H & M Says It Will Stop Destroying Unworn Clothing
description: The clothing retailer H & M promised on Wednesday that it would stop the practice of destroying new, unworn clothing that it could not sell at its store in Herald Square, and would instead donate the garments to charities.

title: A Presidential Pat on the Back for Teachers
description: President Obama honored more than 100 math and science teachers at the White House on Wednesday. But the awards, he joked, came with a catch.

title: 8,870 Pairs at the Table and Charity on the Agenda
description: ECatsBridge in England, under the guidance of Anna Gudge and Mark Newton, ran its eighth Children in Need simultaneous pairs last month. There were 490 heats over five nights in Botswana, Croatia, Cyprus, England and Spain, with 8,870 pairs competing. Nearly $95,000 was raised for the charity.

title: With Dawson in Hall, Red Sox Evans Looks a Lot Better
description: Youve got to be happy for the new Hall of Famer, Andre Dawson, a class act and a phenomenally talented player. On his conference call, he actually apologized to writers for taking so much time to come to his locker after games. He was in the trainers room, of course, getting treatment on his ravaged knees.

title: A Yooper in the Abortion Fight
description: Representative Bart Stupak, who is used to bearing the freezing temperatures of Michigans Upper Peninsula, is now enduring hatred from fellow Democrats over his anti-abortion amendment.

title: Cheap Mobile Calls, Even Overseas
description: Recently, my parents returned from Italy with a few bottles of Chianti and $750 in AT&T calling charges. Buon giorno!

title: Viewing Facebook via Roku
description: Viewing Facebook

title: Men on Television: A Look at West Wing
description: To the Editor:

title: Decade in Dance: Complexity and Emotion
description: To the Editor:

title: Celebrities Onstage: The Cost of Stars
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: Men With a Message: Help Wanted
description: An article last Sunday about the depiction of men on television over the past decade misidentified the cable channel that runs the show in which Mary McCormack stars. The show, In Plain Sight, is on USA, not on TNT.

title: AT&T to Sell Smartphones Using the Android System
description: LAS VEGAS  AT&T said on Wednesday that it planned to sell smartphones running the Android mobile operating system by the second half of the year, including Dells first smartphone.

title: Jets, at 50-1, Are Right Where They Want to Be
description: Those who followed the Jets  playoff projections in the last few weeks of the regular season know how steep their odds were to get this far.

title: Coat Maker Transforms Obama Photo Into Ad
description: A garment company in New York known for publicity stunts has seized the attention of the Obama administration.

title: A Faster Route From Camera to Web
description: When the first Eye-Fi SD cards came out, they were impressive (wirelessly uploading photos from your camera to your PC and online photo sites) but deadly slow. The new $150 Eye-Fi Pro card adds some welcome improvements.

title: Tributes to a Father of Modern Harlem
description: They filed one after another into Riverside Church, mayors and governors and renowned preachers and musicians, all come to pay their respects to that most unusual product of our nations history, a man who became father to modern Harlem and godfather to generations of black politicians.

title: Another Compact Camera Offers Changeable Lenses
description: Samsung has announced its first camera with interchangeable lenses, the NX10, which is being shown at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas this week.

title: Smartphones and Tablets Could Doom Netbooks
description: Stuck between the still-evolving smartphone and the emerging tablet computer, the netbook computer would seem to be doomed.

title: App of the Week: Recording Your Daily Bread
description: Improving your health, getting fit and losing weight never fail to top the list of New Years resolutions. All three would be easier if only you could keep a food diary.

title: Prettier With Every Sip?
description: THE notion that beauty comes from within is taken seriously in certain Asian countries. In Singapore, at the restaurant Imperial Herbal, diners with skin conditions consult with an herbalist, who concocts treatments that are mixed into the dishes. Nescaf has found an avid market there for coffee with collagen, a protein found in connective tissues, on the theory that ingesting it will improve skin. In Japan, collagen is added to yogurt drinks, dried fruits and other foods.

title: Scent Trails Start at the Top
description: HAIR scent may be the new fragrance frontier. In recent months, several new products with exotic fragrances are challenging popular hair-care scents like coconut, citrus and rosemary.

title: On the Trail of a Diamond
description: Visitors to the Smithsonian who will soon have the rare opportunity to share in the Wittelsbachs tale will also be venturing into the midst of a controversy about the gem.

title: Using Beauty to Do Good
description: THE theme of About Face, the 240-page coffee table book that features 20 dramatic makeovers and goes on sale this month ($25), is that beauty should be used for purpose instead of for vanitys sake, said its author, Scott Barnes, in a recent interview.

title: Look Out for the SEC
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.  Get ready for more talk of SEC domination if Alabama wins Thursday nights Bowl Championship Series title game against Texas.

title: Fighting Trend, China Is Luring Scientists Home
description: BEIJING  Scientists in the United States were not overly surprised in 2008 when the prestigious Howard Hughes Medical Institute in Maryland awarded a $10 million research grant to a Princeton University molecular biologist, Shi Yigong.

title: Cleveland Orchestra Talks Break Down
description: Talks between the players and management of the Cleveland Orchestra broke down on Wednesday, and the musicians threatened to go on strike on Jan. 18. That is the day before the orchestra is to leave for a residency in Miami. That tour is in question, Jeffrey Rathbun, the orchestras assistant principal oboist and the musicians chief negotiator, said in a statement.

title: Carpetbaggers and New Yorks Economy
description: Former Representative Harold Ford Jr., Democrat of Tennessee, is thinking of running for the Senate. From New York.

title: Antitrust Case Has Implications Far Beyond N.F.L.
description: Is the National Football League a single entity, or a collection of 32 teams that compete against one another every week?

title: Defense Ranks No. 1, but Jets Miss Jenkins
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  A large man, even by N.F.L. standards, moved alone through the Jets practice complex Wednesday, wearing a T-shirt, gym shorts and running shoes instead of a green jersey, pads and a helmet.

title: Saban Is Seeking His Statue of Liberation
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.

title: Security for Terrorism Trials Estimated at $200 Million a Year
description: Providing security for the trials of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and other terrorism suspects connected with the Sept. 11 attacks will cost more than $200 million a year, according to the Bloomberg administration, making it one of the most expensive security operations ever taken on by the city.

title: Jets as Favorites? In Ryans World
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  When asked Wednesday how it felt to be labeled as the biggest long shot of the 12 playoff teams, Jets Coach Rex Ryan replied: I wasnt aware of that. To me, we should be the favorites.

title: Brady and Patriots Ready for Life Without Welker
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Tom Brady won the N.F.L.s Comeback Player of the Year award Wednesday a few hours before Wes Welker went on injured reserve. The intersection of their injuries may determine how far the Patriots go in the playoffs.

title: Cone Leaves YES Network
description: David Cone, who joined the YES Network as a Yankees analyst in 2008, is not coming back.

title: Schwarzenegger Seeks Shift From Prisons to Schools
description: SACRAMENTO  With his state strapped and his legacy looming, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger proposed on Wednesday to greatly reduce the amount of money California spends on its prisons and to funnel that sum to the states higher education system instead.

title: An Early Assessment of the 2010 Senate Races
description: A glum atmosphere for Democrats, highlighted by the retirement of two senators, could jeopardize the partys chances to retain the majority needed to block a filibuster.

title: Clothing Retailer Says It Will No Longer Destroy Unworn Garments
description: The clothing retailer H & M promised on Wednesday to stop destroying new, unworn clothing that it cannot sell at its store in Herald Square, and would instead donate the garments to charities.

title: Scripps Reports Progress in Food Network Fight
description: For almost a week now, about three million Cablevision households in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have been affected by a high-profile argument between the cable provider and Scripps Networks over how much they should pay for the Food Network and HGTV.

title: Chief Says G.M. Is on Road to Profits
description: DETROIT  The new chief executive of General Motors, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., sought to assure the public on Wednesday that the automaker was on track to be profitable in the wake of its bankruptcy last summer.

title: American Needle: From Green Celluloid Visors to Caps of All Kinds
description: American Needle has become famous in sports law circles thanks to the Supreme Court, which will hear the companys petition against the N.F.L. next week. But in the sports apparel business, American Needle has been a big player for decades.

title: A Third Child for Orszag
description: Peter R. Orszag, President Obamas budget director who recently announced his engagement, on Wednesday released a statement confirming that his previous girlfriend had a baby in November.

title: Clark Clinches Vancouver Spot; Pearce Shows Improvement
description: Kelly Clark, the 2002 Olympic gold medalist in the halfpipe, became the first snowboarder to snare a spot on the 2010 United States halfpipe team by winning the United States Snowboarding Grand Prix at Mammoth Mountain, Calif. It is the third consecutive Olympic berth for Clark, who finished fourth at the 2006 Winter Games in Torino, Italy.

title: Travel Planning Sites Team Up
description: On the In Transit blog, Dan Saltzstein reports that two prominent Web sites for travel planning have formed a canny partnership. Yapta, a site that allows users to track airfares and hotel prices, said that Tripit members can now receive automatic alerts on airline refunds or credits based on itineraries they create.

title: Smackdown for the Senate Takes a Twist
description: Linda E. McMahon would recognize the scene.

title: Tour Resumes Without Its Usual Sure Thing
description: KAPALUA, Hawaii  During most of the past decade, the opening of another successful year for the PGA Tour has been as close to a sure thing as a 2-foot putt.

title: Diet Drug Maker Glaxo to Pay for a Film on Eating
description: LOS ANGELES  GlaxoSmithKline is getting into the movie business, pursuing an unusual and most likely controversial strategy to increase interest in a weight-loss drug.

title: SEC Should Come Out on Top, Again
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.  A week of posturing, lecturing and pontificating will end Thursday night with the Bowl Championship Series title game, and a college football season whose hallmark was conventional results should end in predictable fashion.

title: Nigerian Indicted in Terrorist Plot
description: WASHINGTON  The indictment of a Nigerian man on Wednesday for the attempt to blow up a plane bound for Detroit on Christmas Day has rekindled a debate over whether such terrorism suspects should be treated as criminals or as enemy detainees.

title: DirecTV Outlines 3-D Programming Push
description: DirecTV announced Wednesday that it would debut several 3-D channel services later this year.

title: Danes Study Immigrants After Cartoonist Attack
description: COPENHAGEN  As part of the prolonged national headache caused by a Danish newspapers decision to publish 12 caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad in 2005, last weekends attack on one of the cartoonists responsible had a certain awful inevitability about it.

title: Suit Says 2 Chinese Firms Stole Web-Blocking Code
description: BEIJING  A software company in California has sued two Chinese technology firms, charging that they stole its computer code to make an Internet-monitoring program that Chinas government sought to install on every computer in the country last year before backing down.

title: Where Is the Next War Zone?
description: In the wake of the Christmas Day attempt to blow up a Detroit-bound Northwest Airlines flight by a young Nigerian man, Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab, Yemen is now in Americas focus.

title: New Routine for Airports: Contradictions, Delays
description: CHICAGO  As he arrived at OHare International airport here on Wednesday, Dennis Weyrauch, a passenger, described two hours of waiting and scrutiny at the airport in Amsterdam before his plane took off: as happened to all passengers on his flight, his carry-on bag was searched methodically by hand, the insides of bottles in his toilet kit studied and his body patted down.

title: In a Clash Over Cable, Consumers Lose
description: Chris Birckhead came home Tuesday night hoping that his TiVo had recorded Chopped, his favorite show on the Food Network. Instead, it had recorded a looped commercial from Cablevision, his cable provider, saying the networks owner, Scripps, had taken his show away.

title: Taking It to the Street
description: After its debut in August, the Asphalt Orchestra, a brain-child of Bang on a Can, was described by Anthony Tommasini as part parade spectacle, part halftime show and part cutting-edge contemporary-music concert. If you missed hearing this radical 12-member band the first time, then youre in luck tonight, because they are performing a free show at the David Rubenstein Atrium at Lincoln Center beginning at 8:30 p.m. Listen out for an eclectic mix of songs by Bjrk, Zappa, Mingus and others.

title: Back to School
description: The question of what makes a good teacher has been a subject of hot debate in recent weeks. For evidence look no further than the divided reaction to a study Teach for America released about its participants and Amanda Ripleys article in this months issue of The Atlantic. Tonight Cabinet, the art magazine based in Brooklyn, is presenting a more creative take on the issue with Darcy Lange: The Art of Teaching. The program will include a viewing and a discussion of a current exhibition of video work by Mr. Lange. In the 1970s, this New Zealand artist took his camera into schools in Britain to record daily events in the classroom. After the screening, a discussion about pedagogy and art will be led by panelists including Kelly Baum of the Princeton University Art Museum, Simon Critchley, a philosophy professor at the New School and Jeff Dolven, an English professor at Princeton. Drinks will be served.

title: The Living Room as Art
description: For those of you who found the London apartment in An Education swoon-inducing or the Los Angeles bungalow in A Single Man as enticing as the very chic clothes, then head to Greenwich Houses newest exhibition, Studio Pottery and Mid Century Style, at 6 p.m. tonight. The show features a meticulous recreation of an American living room around 1960. The exhibition will include ceramics from the late 1950s and early to mid-1960s by Peter Voulkos, Gertrude and Otto Natzler as well as furniture by Florence Knoll, Eero Saarinen, Eames and others, not to mention textiles and lighting. To kick off the event, guests are invited to dress up in their own Mad Men-inspired frocks and nibble on period food and drink while they take in the stylish scene.

title: At Dover, More Comfort for Mourning Families
description: DOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Del.  So many families of the nations war dead came here in the last year to witness what the military calls the dignified transfer of the remains of their loved ones that sometimes, as on a night this past June, the small waiting area grew crowded and tense.

title: Suicide Bombing Puts a Rare Face on C.I.A.s Work
description: WASHINGTON  In the fall of 2001, as an anguished nation came to grips with the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, a slender, soft-spoken economics major named Elizabeth Hanson set out to write her senior thesis at Colby College in Maine. Her question was a timely one: How do the worlds three major faith traditions apply economic principles?

title: Forum on Football Brain Injuries Set for Houston
description: After one hearing that prompted the N.F.L. to reshape several policies toward concussion management and another on Monday, the House Judiciary Committee announced Wednesday afternoon that a third discussion on football brain injuries would be held Feb. 1 in Houston.

title: Jordanian Bombers Path Remains a Mystery to His Family
description: AMMAN, Jordan  The telephone rang at 7 a.m. on New Years Eve, and then the heavily accented voice of a stranger  possibly an Afghan  told the man who answered what had happened to one of his sons who disappeared a year ago.

title: Changing of the Guard for Emilys List
description: The founder and president of Emilys List, a powerful fundraising network dedicated to electing Democratic women who support abortion rights, is handing the reins to a rising political star.

title: Editors Note: In Light and Heat, Gadgets Claim to Fight Acne
description: The Skin Deep column last Thursday, about electronic home-treatment devices that supposedly alleviate acne, included a qualified endorsement of such products by Dr. Neil Sadick, a Manhattan dermatologist. Dr. Sadick has been an adviser to Radiancy, the maker of No!No! Skin products for acne removal, which were mentioned in the article. Although Dr. Sadick was not commenting directly on the No!No! device, the article should have either mentioned his connections to the company or omitted his comments.

title: Democrats Wary as Two Senators Decide to Retire
description: WASHINGTON  The sudden decision by two senior Democratic senators to retire shook the partys leaders on Wednesday and signaled that President Obama is facing a perilous political environment that could hold major implications for this years midterm elections and his own agenda.

title: A Matter of Toughness
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.  There has been plenty of questioning about the toughness of Texas in advance of Thursdays Bowl Championship Series title game.

title: Health Cares Biggest Hypocrite  Or Hero
description: For Democrats who see their political prospects this year as a tossup between catastrophic and merely horrible, there is hope on the horizon from a most unlikely source. No, not Rush Limbaugh, who recently praised his medical experience in the government-mandated, heavily unionized health care system of Hawaii. Mahalo to him.

title: U.N. Envoy to Afghanistan Warns of Peril of Emphasizing Security Over Social Issues
description: UNITED NATIONS  Kai Eide, the departing United Nations envoy to Afghanistan, warned the Security Council on Wednesday that an emphasis on security matters over social issues would doom international efforts to stabilize the country.

title: F.D.A. Plans Safety Check of 3 Drugs for Anemia
description: The Food and Drug Administration said Wednesday that it would review of the safety of the widely used anemia drugs sold by Amgen and Johnson & Johnson after another clinical trial suggested that high doses of one of the drugs might cause strokes.

title: U.S. Juniors Top Canada
description: John Carlson scored his second goal of the game 4 minutes 21 seconds into overtime as the United States beat Canada, 6-5, in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, to capture its second gold medal at the World Junior Hockey Championship. The loss was Canadas first in the tournament since losing to the Americans in 2004 in Finland.

title: Connecticut Attorney General Says Hell Seek Senate Seat, and Is Quickly Embraced
description: Richard Blumenthal, the popular Connecticut attorney general, announced on Wednesday that he would seek the United States Senate seat being vacated by Christopher J. Dodd, suddenly altering the dynamic of an already volatile race.

title: Deadly Explosion Arouses New Afghan Anger at U.S.
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  American forces inspecting an engineering project in eastern Afghanistan paused to toss candies to a clutch of curious Afghan children on Wednesday when a large explosion tore through the crowd.

title: Abortion Foe Defies Party on Health Care Bill
description: MENOMINEE, Mich.  Representative Bart Stupak often endures things others find unbearable. He crisscrosses a Congressional district so vast that some constituents live eight hours apart and so cold that the beer at his beloved football games sometimes freezes. Years ago, as a state trooper, he blew out his knee chasing a suspect, and he has since had so many operations that he now returns to work the same day, toting crutches and ice.

title: A Public Company Defends Staying Silent About a Legal Snarl
description: For years, Fidelity National Financial, the nations largest title insurance company, did not tell investors about dozens of lawsuits accusing two units and several employees of playing a role in an elaborate mortgage fraud scheme in San Diego.

title: Heebie-Jeebies
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Its time to discuss the Gdel Incompleteness Theorem, or at least the crossword equivalent. What do you do when you exhaust your skill and memory and still end up with a blank square or two, the emptiness mocking you, the sense of accomplishment, of completion, denied? Can you love a puzzle you cant complete?

title: From Bare to Refined
description: An American in Afghanistan looked forward to returning home and moving into his new apartment in New York, which the designer Richard Mishaan transformed on a budget of $10,000.

title: Tsutomu Yamaguchi, Survivor of 2 Atomic Blasts, Dies at 93
description: Tsutomu Yamaguchi, the only official survivor of both atomic blasts to hit Japan in World War II, died Monday in Nagasaki, Japan. He was 93.

title: Pearces Condition Upgraded
description: The snowboarder Kevin Pearce was upgraded from critical to serious condition and had his breathing tube removed as he slowly began to regain consciousness. Pearce, a 22-year-old widely expected to earn a spot on the United States Olympic halfpipe team, sustained a severe brain injury when he fell while training last Thursday. In a statement, Dr. Holly Ledyard of the University of Utah Hospital in Salt Lake City said that Pearce, who remained in intensive care, was beginning to follow commands. While were pleased that hes improving faster than anticipated, he still has a long recovery ahead of him, she said.

title: Bloggingheads:  Bamboozled by Obama?
description: Michelle Goldberg, left, of The American Prospect and Dayo Olopade of The Root debate whether liberals should be disappointed by President Obama's first year.

title: Mayor Agrees to Step Down in Baltimore in Theft Case
description: Mayor Sheila Dixon of Baltimore, who was convicted of embezzlement last month, said Wednesday that she would resign from office in early February as part of a deal negotiated with prosecutors.

title: Senate Subpoenaed for Records on Espada
description: ALBANY  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo subpoenaed the New York Senate on Wednesday for a broad range of e-mail messages and other records concerning Senator Pedro Espada Jr., the Bronx Democrat who led a monthlong coup that brought state government to a standstill this summer, Mr. Espada said.

title: New York to Create Global Insurance Exchange to Cover Complex Risks
description: In a bid to create jobs and bolster New Yorks position as a financial center, Gov. David A. Paterson announced plans on Wednesday to create an international insurance exchange, modeled after Lloyds of London.

title: Do Try This at Home
description: If your first thought on seeing one-of-a-kind lamps is Interesting, but is it so amateurishly wired it will conflagrate, setting my home afire, destroying all my belongings, including my irreplaceable collection of back issues of the New York Times Home section? then your fears will be assuaged by the knowledge that a creator of these particular lamps, Tom Blake, right, is a licensed New York City electrician who has worked on the Chrysler and Empire State Buildings.

title: Hawks Find Their Touch, and Nets Pay
description: CLEVELAND  DeShawn Stevenson, one of numerous Washington Wizards who laughed at Gilbert Arenas when he cocked his fingers into a gun and playfully shot them as they stood in a circle before a game against the 76ers on Tuesday night, said that neither he nor his teammates should have reacted the way they did.

title: Courts Seek More Lawyers to Help the Poor
description: The recession has swelled the number of people showing up in New York State courts who cannot afford lawyers to 2.1 million annually, often turning eviction, foreclosure, debt collection and other civil cases into lopsided battles that raise questions about the fairness of the legal system.

title: Avery Comes Alive Against the Stars, His Ex-Team
description: People say a lot of things about Sean Avery, but no one can say he lacks a sense of the moment.

title: The Next Steps for Arenas and the League
description: Agent Zero is finding out the hard way that hes not Agent 007. When Gilbert Arenas followed up his unloaded guns in the locker room with some pretend gun play before Tuesdays game, a result was an indefinite suspension.

title: Recalling I.D., a Beacon in Design
description: IT was by and large a jovial crowd that filled the back rooms of the Half King bar in Chelsea on Tuesday night, as a crush of former staff members, contributors and friends of I.D. magazine, the 56-year-old design bible that folded last month, gathered, ostensibly to mourn its passing. Though the evening was billed as a wake  its invitation was composed, appropriately, in a font called Requiem  the gestalt was more like a class reunion, a gaggle of bright former students who all seemed to like one another very much.

title: Is Punditry a Prelude to a Race in New York?
description: Robert F. Kennedy possessed the biggest brand name in American politics. Hillary Rodham Clinton boasted eight years in the White House.

title: Cone Says No to Yes
description: David Cone, who joined the YES Network as a Yankees analyst in 2008, is not coming back. He said his contract had expired and he wanted to spend more time with his family. If I do return to broadcasting, YES would be my first choice, Cone said.

title: Asian Antiques That Outgrew Santa Fe
description: Shibui, the Asian antiques gallery, recently moved to Brooklyn from Santa Fe, N.M. In his new store in Dumbo, above, Dane Owen, Shibuis owner, is selling Japanese Tansu chests from the 18th and 19th centuries, as well as vintage textiles, ceramics, glass and folk art  all of which he transported, with his staff, from Santa Fe.

title: Ex-Official in Yonkers Faces Charges of Corruption
description: WHITE PLAINS  A former Yonkers city councilwoman was indicted Wednesday on federal charges of accepting nearly $167,000 in cash and gifts in exchange for dropping her opposition to two contentious developments, including a $630 million project that is the citys largest private undertaking.

title: A Program Helps Sharpen the Business Acumen of Those on the Rise
description: BOSTON  Taza Chocolate, whose stone-ground organic chocolate bars are made in a factory near here, in Somerville, Mass., was growing. The next step, according to its co-founder, Alex Whitmore, was to hire a marketing manager, preferably someone with many years of experience.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a third uninvited guest to President Obamas first state dinner described incorrectly the vehicle that transported the guest, Carlos Allen, to the White House. It was a private van carrying guests to the event under Secret Service escort; it was not a State Department van.

title: Men Who Jump the Picket Fence
description: THE house was an ordinary house: It bore him no malice. Alan Berks knows that now. But back in the spring of 2005, when Mr. Berks, a playwright, and his wife bought the three-bedroom home for $214,000, it often seemed that it was trying to ruin his life.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Dec. 18 about the New York City Housing Authoritys decision to stop issuing new federal rent subsidy vouchers to low-income New Yorkers because of budget cuts and increasing demand misstated the agencys annual voucher allotment. It is 99,000, not 91,000.

title: Lottery Numbers
Winter Clearance for New and Old
description: Buck House, on the Upper East Side, is discounting its antique and vintage furnishings by 30 percent until Jan. 31 (two 1920s Austrian benches, originally $4,800, are $3,360); 1318 Madison Avenue (93rd Street), (212) 828-3123 or buckhouse.biz.

title: Treasures of the Tavern
description: Potential bidders are previewing a three-day auction of thousands of items from Tavern on the Green, the landmark restaurant in Central Park.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the opening of the worlds tallest building, the Burj Khalifa in Dubai, misstated the position of Sheik Khalifa bin Zayed al-Nahyan, for whom the tower is named. He is president of the United Arab Emirates, not of Abu Dhabi. (He is emir of Abu Dhabi.) The error also appeared in a picture caption accompanying the article and was repeated in an editorial on Wednesday. The editorial also misstated the beneficiary of a $10 billion loan from Abu Dhabi. It was the emirate of Dubai, not the United Arab Emirates.

title: Obama Urges Excise Tax on High-Cost Insurance
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama told House Democratic leaders at a meeting on Wednesday that they should include a tax on high-priced insurance policies favored by the Senate in the final version of far-reaching health care legislation, aides said.

title: The Buzz on Twitter: Short and (Maybe) Sweet
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bridge, Naturally
description: THE renovation problem that faced Nili Malach and Robert Poynter of San Francisco is not uncommon among those in an architecturally mixed marriage. Ms. Malach, a lawyer, is a modernist; her husband, who owns an advertising firm, is a traditionalist.

title: Infomercial Products Take One on the Chin
description: IT may come as no surprise that in the February issue of Consumer Reports, where the product-testing magazine rates 15 infomercial products like the Snuggie (The blanket with sleeves!) and the ShamWow (Youll say wow every time!), nearly all are found to be lacking.

title: Corrections
description: A Looking Ahead report on Friday about the Under the Radar theater festival in Manhattan, which began on Wednesday and runs through Jan. 17, misstated the title of a work by Andrew Dawson, a British director and performer. It is Space Panorama  not Invisible Atom, another work in the festival.

title: Fireplace Without the Smoke?
description: The Lighthouse, a portable indoor-outdoor fireplace, is the newest model from Planika, a Polish company. According to the manufacturer, it doesnt produce smoke or odor  and doesnt require ventilation. What makes it burn so cleanly, Planika says, is Fanola, a liquid bioethanol fuel made from potatoes that the company developed and sells with its fireplaces.

title: Law School Admissions Lag Among Minorities
description: While law schools added about 3,000 seats for first-year students from 1993 to 2008, both the percentage and the number of black and Mexican-American law students declined in that period, according to a study by a Columbia Law School professor.

title: Terra Cotta Love
description: To the Editor:

title: In Cold Snap, Floridians Shiver, and Pray for the Strawberries
description: DOVER, Fla.  Icicles hang from the thermometer: 25 degrees, at dawn, and the strawberries that should be on cereal sit suspended beneath hard ice, shiny and clear as lacquer.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of credits on Dec. 18 with a film review of Avatar misstated the given name of the character portrayed by Giovanni Ribisi. He is Parker Selfridge, not Carter.

title: Taxpayer Advocate Faults I.R.S. on Collecting Delinquent Taxes
description: The Internal Revenue Services collection of delinquent taxes from 2005 to 2007 was substantially less than initially reported, an agency watchdog said Wednesday.

title: Peace, Yes; Yurt, No
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about the abstract artist Kenneth Noland misstated the surname of an art critic who wrote a monograph on him. She is Karen Wilkin, not Wilkins.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Some Honesty in Albany
description: Long before Gov. David Paterson delivered his annual report on New Yorks condition on Wednesday, everyone knew that the state of the state was desperate. New York is crippled by a mounting budget crisis and saddled with a Legislature that is incompetent in its governance and corrupt in its behavior.

title: Will the Real Chris Dodd Stand Up?
description: Senator Christopher Dodds decision to not seek re-election in November could be a fatal blow to meaningful financial regulatory reform  or a desperately needed boost. It depends on what he does now.

title: Less Than Two Weeks
description: After weeks of maneuvering and delay, the New Jersey State Senate will finally vote on Thursday on whether to legalize same-sex marriage. The Senate needs to approve the bill, and the General Assembly needs to follow  quickly. Gov. Jon Corzine has pledged to sign the legislation into law; his soon-to-be-successor, Gov.-elect Christopher Christie, has vowed to veto it. The transfer of power takes place in less than two weeks on Jan. 19.

title: Message of the Tea Party Movement
description: To the Editor:

title: As the U.N. Chief Ponders His Choice for Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: At Tavern Auction Preview, a Hunt for Antiques and Nostalgia
description: They kicked the tires. Grandly.

title: Sundown Towns, Past and Present
description: To the Editor:

title: Oh, Byron, We Hardly Knew Ye
description: Senator Byron Dorgan is retiring! I know this comes as a shock to you, people. Also Senator Chris Dodd! We are only one week into the new year, and the political world is in turmoil. Its a wonder we can continue on with our regular duties.

title: The Happiest People
description: SAN JOS, Costa Rica

title: An Alliance Larger Than One Issue
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: The Year the Senate Fell
description: Washington

title: The Rocky Road Home
description: FOR more than 25 years, Michael Logozzo, a native of Brooklyn, lived overseas, working various jobs  as a chef in Venice and in Rome, as a magazine editor in Paris and as a television host and fund-raiser in Warsaw. In 2003, he moved into a guarded compound in Kabul, Afghanistan, overseeing the acquisition of property for Roshan, a telecommunications company, and helping run a charitable program to feed Afghan children.

title: Art Bartlett, Founder of Century 21 Real Estate, Dies at 76
description: Art Bartlett, a founder of Century 21, the real estate franchising giant whose brand name eventually appeared on For Sale signs on lawns throughout the country and even abroad, died on Dec. 31 at his home in Coronado, Calif. He was 76. The cause was complications of Alzheimers disease, his daughter, Stacy Bartlett Renshaw, said.

title: Tough Cancer Is Gone, but Not the Bills
description: When Susan Rabinowitz learned she had lymphoma in May, the cancer was so advanced that her oncologist kept back his initial assessment until she was out of danger.

title: Hospitals Could Stop Infections by Tackling Bacteria Patients Bring In, Studies Find
description: Hundreds of thousands of patients each year suffer from infections after surgery, and experts say more than half of those infections stem from bacteria the patients themselves are carrying in their nose or on their skin. Otherwise harmless bacteria can enter the body through surgical incisions and cause infections that can require expensive treatment, slow recovery or even cause death.

title: A Kennedy Endorsement in Massachusetts
description: Victoria Reggie Kennedy, the widow of Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, will endorse Martha Coakley, the Democratic candidate for his seat, on Thursday, according to the Coakley campaign.

title: Polanski Urges Judge to Sentence Him in Absentia
description: LOS ANGELES  The Oscar-winning director Roman Polanski asked a Los Angeles Superior Court judge on Wednesday to proceed with his sentencing in a 1977 sex case even though he remains under house arrest in Switzerland.

title: Doctor Indicted in Attack on Medical Board Chairman
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  A doctor who had been repeatedly penalized by the Arkansas Medical Board was charged in federal court here on Wednesday with planting a bomb that critically injured the board chairman as he left his home for a meeting of the panel last February.

title: Despite Risks, Internet Creeps Onto Car Dashboards
description: LAS VEGAS  To the dismay of safety advocates already worried about driver distraction, automakers and high-tech companies have found a new place to put sophisticated Internet-connected computers: the front seat.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Delinquent Avery Beats Dallas With 4 Points
description: Six games on Wednesday night, highlighted by the tabloid clash between the Rangers and Stars, the first time those teams have met since Dallas dropped Sean Avery last season for his vulgar remarks about two of his ex-girlfriends dating other N.H.L. players. Home teams listed first:

title: Hospital Infections Increase
description: The Times's Pam Belluck on the increasing number of patients who are getting infections in hospitals.

title: Defenses Start to Catch Up
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.  In this seasons college football preview, Pete Thamel and I wrote an article that detailed defenses efforts to try to stop the increasingly popular spread offense.

title: Behind the Scenes in Costa Rica
description: I actually hadnt intended to write todays column; it was a bit of an accident. Originally when I booked my Central America trip I thought I would travel through Honduras, Nicaragua and Costa Rica, and my plan in Costa Rica was to write something narrowly about its success in health care. But then I chose to spend a bit more time in Honduras and Nicaragua, and everybody seemed to be out of Costa Rica for holiday travel. Since my return flight was from Costa Rica, I went anyway but figured I probably wouldnt be able to write. (And, frankly, my daughter had come along for the trip in part because of the promise of going to Costa Rica; I didnt want to be the one to tell her that she would get the Honduran slums and impoverished Nicaraguan villages, but no Costa Rican beach or jungle.)Then a Times researcher, Hilary Howard, sent me the Happy Planet Index report, which I read while driving around the country. The report got me thinking about Costa Rica and happiness. So I poked around, perused the data, and the column took shape. Originally, I thought I would frame the column more in terms of Latin and Caribbean countries doing unusually well in happiness surveys; I was fascinated by the idea that this reflected a cultural emphasis on building social capital as opposed to financial capital. But although its an interesting theory, I never found much evidence for it, and so I focused on Costa Rica and the gains it made in education after abolishing its army.

title: Mary Daly, a Leader in Feminist Theology, Dies at 81
description: Mary Daly, a prominent feminist theologian who made worldwide headlines a decade ago after she retired from Boston College rather than admit men to some of her classes, died on Sunday in Gardner, Mass. She was 81 and had lived for many years in Newton Centre, Mass.

title: Corrections
description: The 36 Hours column on Dec. 27, about San Miguel de Allende, misspelled the surname of a playwright and filmmaker and referred incorrectly to his house near Parque Jurez. He is Michael Cristofer, not Cristopher, and he owns the house in that neighborhood, he does not rent it.

title: Strawberries on Ice
description: A cold snap has brought freezing temperatures that are threatening Florida's $375-million-a-year strawberry industry.

title: Showcase: New Faces in an Old Gallery
description: It is a season for homecomings at Casa Aboy in San Juan. Thirty years after up-and-coming photographers exhibited their works at this gallery, they have returned  this time as masters.

title: Many Ex-Detainees Said to Be Engaged in Terror
description: WASHINGTON  Administration officials said Wednesday that a classified Pentagon report concludes that of some 560 detainees transferred abroad from the military prison at Guantnamo Bay, about one in five has engaged in, or is suspected of engaging in, terrorism or militant activity.

title: Resuming the Advertising Battle
description: After a brief hiatus, the television advertising wars over health care have resumed.

title: Correction
description: An essay in the special Lives They Lived issue on Dec. 27 about the actor Karl Malden and the film writer Budd Schulberg misstated Maldens position at the time he urged the motion-picture academy to give Elia Kazan an honorary Oscar. Malden was a member of the board and a former president of the academy; he was not the incumbent president.

title: Correction
description: An essay in the special Lives They Lived issue on Dec. 27 about the actress Betsy Blair misstated the source of a song she sang over and over at the end of her life. Love Is Here to Stay is from the 1938 movie The Goldwyn Follies, not from a Broadway show.

title: Flu Shot Study
description: Flu shots do not protect arthritis patients who are being treated with the intravenous drug rituximab, according to a new study by Dutch researchers. Because people with rheumatoid arthritis have depressed immune systems, flu vaccinations are recommended for them. But the study found that in patients vaccinated close to the time they get rituximab, the drug does not promote the formation of antibodies to protect against the flu. Researchers recommended giving the shots well before the rituximab treatment. The study began long before swine flu emerged, but the effects on that vaccine are expected to be similar. Rituximab is sold under the names Rituxan and MabThera.

title: Massachusetts: Immigrant Arrests
description: Federal immigration agents stopped 58 immigrants in Foxborough, southwest of Boston, in an operation they said was to capture fugitives with criminal records. Of the immigrants, who were traveling in four vans, nine were arrested as criminal suspects and 49 were released but ordered to report to Immigration and Customs Enforcement for questioning, a spokesman for the agency said. Most of the immigrants were janitorial workers, many from Guatemala, who were on their way to clean the parking lot of Gillette Stadium, a lawyer for the Guatemalan Consulate said.

title: Hedge Funds Tell Part of Results
description: Only foolhardy parents would allow their children to provide only the grades on their report cards that they were happy with. Yet hedge funds are given this luxury in reporting their performance to compilers of sectorwide performance indexes. A result is that while a single funds track record is clear enough, hedge fund index returns still flatter the average fund in the industry. Investors would be smart to call for a cleanup.

title: France: Task Force on Genocide Planned
description: Justice Minister Michle Alliot-Marie and Foreign Minister Bernard Kouchner said France planned to create a permanent judicial task force to try cases of genocide and crimes against humanity. The task force, part of a bill to be put before Parliament this year, would examine cases in which there is a French perpetrator, a French victim, or suspects who took refuge in France, a Justice Ministry spokesman said. About 15 cases against Rwandans living in France and suspected of involvement in the 1994 Rwanda genocide are being investigated.

title: Word of the Day | provident
description: provident \pr-v-dn(t), -den(t)\ adjective

title: Cuba: Official Says American Was a Spy
description: A Cuban official said Wednesday that an American contractor detained last month in Havana for distributing communications equipment to community groups worked for the American secret services. The official, Ricardo Alarcn, president of the Cuban National Assembly, offered no evidence for his claim, which was disputed by Development Alternatives Inc., a company based outside Washington. It said it employed the American for a pro-democracy contract provided by the United States Agency for International Development.

title: The View From Cincinnati on the Jets
description: Not everyone is impressed with the Jets No. 1 defense, or their No. 1 running game, or their dominating performance against the Bengals. In a nutshell, Who Dey?

title: Damaged and Discarded, Not Donated
description: WHO recently salvaged discarded clothes they found on the street near New York city retailers?

title: McElroy the Decision Maker
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.  Alabama quarterback Greg McElroy is well aware of the pressure on him entering Thursday nights Bowl Championship Series title game against Texas.

title: News Quiz | January 7, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Citi Said to Face Legal Action Over Severance Pay
description: A former senior executive at Citigroup has decided to take legal action against the company to force it to resume paying his multi-million-dollar severance package, which has been frozen for six months, The Financial Times said, citing people close to the situation.

title: Microsoft and H.P. Are Slate Mates
description: Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard sitting in a tree  K-I-S-S-I-N-G.

title: New York to Create Global Insurance Exchange
description: In a bid to create jobs and bolster New Yorks position as a financial center, Gov. David A. Paterson announced plans on Wednesday to create an international insurance exchange, modeled after Lloyds of London.

title: Kelly Clark Makes Olympics Again
description: Kelly Clark, the 2002 Olympic gold medalist in the womens halfpipe, became the first snowboarder to snare a spot on the 2010 United States halfpipe team by winning the United States Snowboarding Grand Prix at Mammoth Mountain, Calif. It is the third consecutive Olympic berth for Clark, who finished fourth at the 2006 Winter Games in Turin, Italy.

title: Some at Fed See a Need to Do More for Housing
description: Despite extensive government intervention in the housing market, some policy makers at the Federal Reserve are worried that even more might need to be done, David Streitfeld and Jack Healy write in The New York Times.

title: C.E.S. 2010: The Internet in Your Car
description: A look at how automakers are building Internet connectivity and services into their newest models.

title: Brown Survives Attempt to Unseat Him
description: LONDON  Months before a national election, Prime Minister Gordon Brown appeared Thursday to have survived an attempt to unseat him by two senior figures in the governing Labour Party who issued an unusual appeal for a secret ballot on his leadership.

title: Should Children Be Allowed to Compete on TV?
description: A new Fox game show will test the knowledge of child geniuses aged 6-12, with the potential to win up to $500,000. Does this seem like a good way to showcase academic knowledge, as the shows creator says, or does it put unhealthy pressure on the children?

title: Wall Street Shows Little Change
description: Stocks ended little changed but modest gains pushed the Standard & Poors 500-stock index to a new 15-month high. The cautious tone came as investors awaited the governments monthly employment report on Friday, The Associated Press reported.

title: Longhorns Can Play, but Can They Spell?
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.  Texas Coach Mack Brown preaches to his team about being fast and physical, and having fun.

title: CDC, a Chinese Software Maker, Bids for Chordiant
description: CDC Software, a Chinese business software developer, said Wednesday it had offered to buy all the outstanding shares of Chordiant Software for $105.1 million, The Associated Press reported.

title: Iceland Pinched by Pressures at Home and Abroad
description: Icelands government says it sees no immediate political solution to contain the fallout of President Olafur R. Grimssons decision to veto a depositor bill that had sought to repair diplomatic relations with Britain and the Netherlands, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Astra Settles Nexium Dispute With Teva
description: AstraZeneca settled a United States patent dispute over Nexium with Israels Teva Pharmaceuticals on Thursday, protecting the Anglo-Swedish drugmakers top-selling heartburn drug from immediate generic competition.

title: Divorcing, Wynn and Wife Split Casino Stock
description: Steve Wynn, the casino billionaire, agreed Wednesday to transfer control of $741 million worth of his stock in Wynn Resorts, where he serves as chief executive, to his wife, Elaine, as part of a divorce settlement, The Associated Press reported.

title: Investors Like the Looks of Stylesight
description: Stylesight, the fashion content aggregator and trend forecaster, has raised a $5 million tranche in a $10 million second round of financing, PaidContent reported, citing a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: Perot Firm Invests in San Bernardino Warehouses
description: A real estate development firm owned by the Perot family has agreed to a $20 million deal to buy more than one million square feet of vacant new warehouse space in California from BlackRock.

title: Wesleyan Sues Former C.I.O. for Fraud
description: Wesleyan University has sued its former chief investment officer, Thomas Kannam, for fraud and breach of contract, accusing him of using his post and resources at the university to promote his own business ventures, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Former A.I.G. Chief Said to Return to P.E. Role
description: After his tumultuous time at the helm of the American International Group, Edward Liddys next job is going to be a lot less public.

title: Animal Spirits
description: A term used to describe stock market optimism.

title: Do Hedge Fund Indexes Tell Only Part of Story?
description: Only foolhardy parents would allow their children to provide only the grades on their report cards that they were happy with. Yet hedge funds are given this luxury in reporting their performance to compilers of sectorwide performance indexes, Breakingviews says.

title: 4 Dead After 20-Hour Gun Battle in Kashmir
description: NEW DELHI  A 20-hour gun battle prompted by a deadly militant attack on a police outpost in Kashmirs summer capital ended Thursday at a hotel after the police killed two militants, including one Pakistani national, Indian police officials said.

title: Antitrust Case Has Implications Far Beyond N.F.L.
description: Is the National Football League a single entity, or a collection of 32 teams that compete against one another every week?

title: How to Sell Your Small Business
description: You only sell your business once.

title: Canadian Police Seek Chinese Warren Buffett
description: Canadian police have issued an arrest warrant for a Toronto-based hedge fund manager who dubbed himself a Chinese Warren Buffett and is accused of masterminding a Ponzi scheme that has left millions of dollars unaccounted for, The Associated Press reported.

title: Helping Business Acumen of Those on the Rise
description: Taza Chocolate, whose stone-ground organic chocolate bars are made in a factory near here, in Somerville, Mass., was growing. The next step, according to its co-founder, Alex Whitmore, was to hire a marketing manager, preferably someone with many years of experience.

title: G.M., Not Hopeful on Saab, Proceeds With Closure
description: General Motorss chief executive, Edward E. Whitacre, said on Wednesday he was not hopeful a breakthrough deal could be reached to save Saab and said G.M. was proceeding with the wind-down of the Swedish brand.

title: Symetra Sets I.P.O. Terms, Buffett to Keep Shares
description: Symetra Financial, the life insurance company, set the terms of its initial public offering on Wednesday, lowering the overall value of the deal from its October filing and signaling that it was likely to price soon.

title: F.D.I.C. to Weigh In on Bank Pay Next Week
description: The board of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation will meet on Jan. 12 to consider proposing rules on compensation for bank employees, the agency said on Wednesday.

title: Is Ivanhoe Mining for a Deal?
description: Colorful dealmaker Robert Friedland, who made a fortune selling an undeveloped Canadian nickel deposit, is seeking new options for his current venture, Ivanhoe Mines, as it starts building a copper-gold mine near Mongolias border with resource-hungry China.

title: Stanford Daughter Fights for $1.3 Million Condo
description: The daughter of jailed Texas businessman R. Allen Stanford must appear in federal court to show why she should not be held in contempt for fighting the sale of her $1.3 million Houston condominium, a judge ruled Wednesday.

title: Global Travel Group Opposes Delta-JAL Tie-Up
description: A group representing business travelers is opposing the proposed tie up between Delta Air Lines and money-losing Japan Airlines, saying it would be bad for competition.

title: Near Hong Kong, Where the Birds Are
description: Winter in Hong Kong brings a flutter of migratory wings. The wetlands at the Mai Po Marshes Reserve in the extreme northwest corner of the territory are the best place to catch a glimpse of the phenomenon  more than 60,000 birds winter at the reserve, coming from northern China, Korea, Russia and Mongolia.

title: N.Y. Fed Told A.I.G. Not to Disclose Swap Details
description: Update | 12:13 p.m. Starting in November 2008, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York under Timothy Geithner began urging American International Group, the huge insurer that the government had bailed out, to limit disclosure on payments made to banks at the height of the financial crisis, e-mail messages obtained by DealBook show.

description: TOKYO  Seiji Ozawa, the Japanese conductor, said Thursday that he has esophageal cancer and will cancel his concerts for the next six months to focus on treatment.

description: PARIS  Eurostar service between Britain and the Continent was again facing significant disruptions on Thursday, just weeks after a breakdown stranded thousands of travelers at the start of the holiday season.

title: Sampler: Oakland Police Mistakes and Sully Navigates the Lingering Spotlight
description: Governor Proposes New Budget Priorities | In his final annual address to state lawmakers in Sacramento, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger proposed a constitutional amendment that would ensure no less than 10 percent of the states general fund be allotted for higher education and no more than 7 percent for the state prison system. Education leaders hailed the proposal, while some questioned the governors plan to cut prison costs by privatizing prison services. It has been five years since the state provided more money to public universities than prisons, and the plan faces obstacles. If it fails in Sacramento, watch for it to become part of a ballot initiative. [The New York Times, The Los Angeles Times]

title: Yemen Says Bomb Suspect Met With Qaeda Figures
description: SANA, Yemen  A senior official here said Thursday that the young Nigerian man accused of trying to bring down an airliner as it was approaching Detroit on Dec. 25 had met with operatives of Al Qaeda and probably with Anwar al-Awlaki, a radical American-born Internet preacher, in Yemen before setting out on his journey.

title: Detroit Auto Show: Design Preview

description: President Obamas top counterterrorism adviser, John O. Brennan, will release the unclassified version of his investigation of intelligence and screening failures that led to a Nigerian mans attempt to blow up an airplane on Christmas Day. The report will be disclosed at about 1 p.m. as Mr. Obama delivers remarks from the White House State Room on the failed attack.

But on the Internet, she has a slightly different identity. She is the Wheel of Fortune contestant who, when offering her solution to a puzzle that seemed to scream out for the answer self-portrait, instead uttered the memorable answer self-potato.

description: Wall Street traders set aside worries about looming interest rate increases on Thursday and focused on stronger-than-expected holiday sales, helping cement modest gains for stocks.

title: The Shrinking American Car Fleet
description: The auto fleet in the United States shrank by an estimated 2 percent in 2009, as 14 million cars were scrapped and only 10 million new cars were sold, according to a new report by the Earth Policy Institute, an environmental research organization in Washington.

title: Travel Deals: Air Canada World Wide Sale
description: Air Canada is having a New Years Sale, with flights throughout Canada, the United States, Europe, Asia and elsewhere, starting at 50 Canadian dollars one way.

title: At Mayors Breakfast, Interfaith Means Atheists, Too

But the coterie did not draw attention because of unusual garb; this group included the first nonbelievers invited to the breakfast in the eight years that Mr. Bloomberg has held it.

title: Gone Fishin!
description: Dont tell anyone, but as of yesterday, I have completely unplugged myself from my business and will continue for an unprecedented 22 days. This is a huge step for me. I have never done anything like this in my many years as an owner and chief executive.

description: This week: Ben Sisario moderates the second part of our year-end retrospective with a look at the best songs of 2009. Joining him are the pop and jazz critics Jon Pareles, Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica. Sia Michel is the host.

title: Jets as Favorites? In Ryans World
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  When asked Wednesday how it felt to be labeled as the biggest long shot of the 12 playoff teams, Jets Coach Rex Ryan replied: I wasnt aware of that. To me, we should be the favorites.

title: Reform of New Yorks Courts Stalls
description: The most ambitious efforts in decades to reform New York States vast network of small-town courts  where sessions can be held in a garage, and where more than 1,450 judges who are not lawyers conduct trials  have stalled in Albany. Even a seemingly modest compromise, one that would allow a defendant to request that the judge be a lawyer, seems doomed, its sponsor says.

title: Carbon Market Grew as Prices Fell in 2009
description: In spite of the global economic slowdown, the market for trading carbon dioxide jumped by 68 percent last year compared with the previous year, but the value of the market remained roughly unchanged after carbon prices fell.

title: Thursday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: What to Watch: Game On
description: The collegiate national championship is decided Thursday night in the Rose Bowl, with ABCs coverage beginning at 8 p.m. Its Texas versus Alabama, and if you didnt already know that, youll probably be looking for something else to watch. Itll be a difficult search.

title: Becoming an Uncle
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: Congratulations to President Obama on becoming an uncle. His brother-in-law, Craig Robinson, and his wife just had a son in Oregon. Or so they claim. Lou Dobbs is demanding to see the birth certificate.

title: Attack Leaves 10 Dead in Southeast Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber attacking a pro-government militia commander detonated his bomb-laden vest in a southeastern provincial capital, Gardez, on Thursday, and witnesses said he killed 10 people and wounded 27, most of them civilians. Also on Thursday, the governor of a neighboring province survived a bomb attack.

title: More Than 80 Teachers
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on The Tonight Show With Conan OBrien on NBC: Today, President Obama honored more than 80 teachers for excellence in math and science. Then he begged them to leave China and come teach here in the United States.

title: A Cruel Parent
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: Anybody make New Years resolutions? I have to find something to do. Im going to crash a White House state dinner.

title: The 31 Places to Go in 2010
description: 1. Sri Lanka For a quarter century, Sri Lanka seems to have been plagued by misfortune, including a brutal civil war between the Sinhalese-dominated government and a separatist Tamil group. But the conflict finally ended last May, ushering in a more peaceful era for this teardrop-shaped island off Indias coast, rich in natural beauty and cultural splendors.

title: Quite a Matchup
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: Today, Senator Chris Dodd unveiled his plan to reduce corruption in the Senate. Hes retiring.

description: Updated | 10:21 a.m.

title: Kenya Deports Muslim Cleric Said to Be Linked to Terrorists
description: A Jamaican-born Muslim cleric whose online sermons drew the attention of a Nigerian man accused of trying to bring down an American airliner was deported Thursday from Kenya, where he had been arrested, according to news reports. He was sent to Gambia, where he was expected to stay briefly before returning to Jamaica.

title: Small British Company Bets on Tidal Power
description: A British company with a device that creates energy from tidal movement announced late last month that it had received $5.6 million in financing that it hopes will help it reach larger commercial production within two years.

title: British Oscars Double Down on An Education
description: An Education leads the long list of nominees released Thursday morning for the Orange British Academy Film Awards, better known as the BAFTAs, or the stiff upper lip version of the Oscars. Lone Scherfigs film about a British schoolgirl, played by Carey Mulligan with an adorable pixie-worthy haircut, and her dashing older lover, played by Peter Sarsgaard with a gleam in his eye, earned 17 spots, including best picture, best director and six acting nods, which account for basically its entire cast.

title: Scent Notes | 1872 for Men by Clive Christian
description: According to Guinness World Records, the worlds most expensive perfume is the designer Clive Christians limited edition No. 1, at $250,000 for a 50-milliliter bottle. Thats fine, but all that really matters is whether his scents are any good. Set aside No. 1 Imperial Majesty ($215,000 for 500 milliliters) and Monogram ($14,500 for 30 milliliters), and were left with three Clive Christian masculines, all of which are slightly offbeat and rather good.X For Men, created by the talented avant-garde perfumer Geza Schoen under Christians direction and launched in 2001, has one of the strangest drydowns Ive ever experienced. It starts out as a delightful retro, channeling the aftershave used decades ago in Italian barbershops  delicious, aromatic pine with bark of burnished cinnamon. About five hours later, after that burns off, the scent that remains is neutral human breath, warm and strange  and incredibly, almost upsettingly intimate. The barber is inches away, squinting as he trims your sideburns. If you find that hes a bit too close, simply reapply after a few hours and the 50s-era pine will return and endure.

title: Hurry Up and Wait for Title Game
description: For everything unlikable about professional sports  and frankly, we can sum much of that up with one picture of Gilbert Arenas as idiotic gunslinger  they do generally get the playoffs thing right, as in, they hold them immediately after a regular season. Forget for a minute that college football does not have an actual playoff, but perhaps even more ridiculously, their faux championship falls roughly three epochs after Texas or Alabama last played a game. The players should be wearing nametags to avoid embarrassing moments in the locker room like: Uh, yeah, Joe, right? Youre our starting strong safety?

title: Struggling Pound Livens Up the London Housing Market
description: LONDON  A three-bedroom, 2,300-square-foot apartment recently went on the market in Londons fashionable Eaton Square and an Italian buyer immediately snapped it up for 5.65 million  a surprisingly quick sale in what has been a flat market.

title: New Analysis of China's Real Estate Market Shows 'Dramatic' Growth
description: HONG KONG  No wonder the Chinese government is trying to extend its winter chill to the residential market. Average home prices in Shanghai leapt 68 percent last year, according to new research, while Beijing shot up 66 percent and Shenzhen, 51 percent.

title: Chinese Looking in America, but Not Buying
description: When Angel Calzadilla, a Florida real estate agent, received an e-mail a few weeks ago from a man who said he was a Chinese executive and wanted to buy a house, he suspected a scam.

title: Swiss Say Decision on Polanski Extradition Expected Soon
description: The justice ministry of Switzerland said Thursday it would probably decide this month or next whether it will grant a request by the United States to extradite Roman Polanski, Agence France-Presse reported. The ministrys spokesman, Folco Galli, told Agence France-Presse: We are preparing our decision. It could be January, it could also be in February. I am not going to be more precise. Mr. Polanski, who fled the United States in 1978 after pleading guilty to having sex with a 13-year-old girl, was apprehended in Switzerland in September. He spent several months in a jail near Zurich before posting $4.5 million bail in December, and is now under house arrest in his chalet in Gstaad. On Wednesday, a written request from Mr. Polanski to be sentenced in absentia was presented to a Los Angeles County Superior Court judge. The judge, Peter P. Espinoza, has scheduled a hearing on Jan. 22 to consider the request.

title: Buick Regal GS Concept Tipped as the Next Gran Sport
description: Over the Internet, General Motors is gradually revealing the cars it plans to unveil at the Detroit auto show. Earlier this week, it was the Cadillac CTS-V Coupe. On Thursday, G.M. revealed the Buick Regal GS.

title: Gunman Kills 3 Co-Workers in St. Louis Factory and Then Himself
description: A factory worker who was suing his employer opened fire Thursday morning at an electrical equipment plant in North St. Louis, killing three co-workers before apparently taking his own life, St. Louis fire and police officials said. Five other people were injured.

title: Lettermans Finishing Game
description: After getting his turn in the tabloids for having an affair, David Letterman seems pretty much back to his old self in spite of the perils that some observers predicted. But even as others have moved on, Mr. Letterman, ever the rueful observer of self, has not forgotten.

description: The Red Bulls are taking on a definite Nordic personality.

title: Why Does Anyone Have Children?
description: A reader, Bailey, has a question. Its a request for advice, but only in the broadest sense. Mostly its a philosophical inquiry, a why, rather than a how, of parenting. Shes 24, working in finance and reading Motherlode in anticipation of a day when she herself is a mom. All her reading makes her wonder, though, WHY people have children. She writes:

description: Here at Diners Journal, where we are hyper-perceptive about all things food, we noticed that take-out orders are pouring into the lobby at an unprecedented rate. The reason? Our beloved New York Times cafeteria is closed today because several staffers reported that vague but scary ailment, gastro-intestinal distress.

The man proposed a price of 4,000 pesos. The woman insisted she could not afford that much. How about 2,500?

title: More M.&A. Seen in Asset Management Industry
description: The global asset management business witnessed a record-setting flurry of big deals last year, and more deals are expected this year, although probably not quite as large as those in 2009, analysts at the investment bank Jefferies & Company said Thursday.

title: 36 Hours in New York City
description: URBAN renewal. The phrase conjures up government-backed megaprojects from the 70s, but its organic to New York, where someone is always getting off the bus, train or plane. In the last year, the city has opened a hot new park, Lincoln Center celebrated its 50th anniversary with a major face-lift that includes a new fountain with 353 custom-made, computer-controlled nozzles, and the center of cool shifted innumerable times (but its probably still somewhere in Brooklyn).

title: Literature After Taboo
description: In a long essay in last Sundays Book Review, Katie Roiphe defends the Great Male Novelists of yore  the Roths and Updikes, Mailers and Bellows  against their more stringent feminist critics, while contrasting them favorably with their less overtly chauvinist, narcissistic, and sex obsessed male heirs (think Jonathan Franzen or Jonathan Safran Foer or the late David Foster Wallace). It has become popular to denounce those authors, Roiphe writes of the GMNs, and more particularly to deride the sex scenes in their novels. But their abiding interest in the sexual connection, she argues, contrasts favorably with the style of their successors:

title: Festival Replaces Films Pulled in Protest

description: Google is a search engine, an advertising company and now a cellphone maker. But a green energy company? That too, said Bill Weihl, Googles so-called green energy czar, in an interview with Jeffrey Marlow of The Times on the Green Inc. blog. He said:

title: Leftover Campaign Cash Is Ruled Eligible for Matching Funds
description: The 2009 mayoral election may still be fresh in everyones minds, but when it comes to money, the 2013 campaign has already begun.

title: Kodak Unveils a Waterproof Camcorder
description: Kodak is all about sharing, and the company put photo sharing center stage at its Consumer Electronics Show announcement of four EasyShare shooters as well as a svelte touchscreen camera and a very cool and affordable update of its Zi8 pocket camcorder.

title: A Writerly Nook of Brooklyn
description: Books have been born all over Brooklyns Fort Greene. Richard Wright labored over Native Son here while sitting on a hill in Fort Greene Park; a bench there now bears his name. He lived nearby, as did Marianne Moore, and several contemporary writers have roots in the neighborhood, including Colson Whitehead, Jhumpa Lahiri and Nelson George. For a tour of this literary hub (or to take the free workshops the New York Writers Coalition holds here to help people find their inner author), hop the subway to DeKalb Avenue or a nearby station. Bring pen and paper, in case the muse strikes.

title: The Morning Skate: A Local Winter Classic? An Unsavory Night
description: Were contending with some serious computer issues this week and working off a laptop that moves as fast as some of the aging guys in our regular Tuesday night skate (this writer included), but this is hockey and you have to play hurt. So here we go.

title: Next-Gen USB 3.0 Arrives at C.E.S.
description: The next, speedier generation of the USB interconnect technology  version 3.0  took a step closer to consumers this week with the introduction of Western Digitals MyBook 3.0.

title: But Crashing Airport Security Was So Cute in Love Actually

title: A Day of Heroism and Horror
description: A GRUESOME fire and collapse before horrified crowds, people leaping out of windows, others dropping back inside into the flames, their bodies mangled into fragments or reduced to dust in the rubble  that was the Windsor Hotel fire of 1899.

title: Walk Away From Your Mortgage!
description: John Courson, president and C.E.O. of the Mortgage Bankers Association, recently told The Wall Street Journal that homeowners who default on their mortgages should think about the message they will send to their family and their kids and their friends. Courson was implying that homeowners  record numbers of whom continue to default  have a responsibility to make good. He wasnt referring to the people who have no choice, who cant afford their payments. He was speaking about the rising number of folks who are voluntarily choosing not to pay.

title: Reality Series Takes Football Recruit on Surreal Ride
description: It sounds like a fairy tale.

title: NBC Denies Rumor of Leno Cancellation
description: Update: NBC May Be Considering Reinstating Leno on Tonight Show

title: Directors Give Basterds Some Oscar Hope
