description: Tea leaves alert: The Directors Guild of America, an uncanny prognosticator of eventual best picture Oscar winners, released its list of nominees on Thursday, one filled with the usual suspects and one big surprise. Kathryn Bigelow (The Hurt Locker), James Cameron (Avatar), Lee Daniels (Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire) and Jason Reitman (Up in the Air) received nominations as expected, but Quentin Tarantino and Inglourious Basterds have elbowed their way into the party.

title: 6 Cited in Honduran Leaders Ouster
description: MEXICO CITY  Six military officers involved in the ouster of Manuel Zelaya from the Honduran presidency last year were charged this week with abuse of power, but the charges are expected to be dropped as part of a deal to ease tensions in the country, officials said.

title: Salazar Wont Leave Cabinet for Gov.s Race
description: Interior Secretary Ken Salazar said today that he would not leave the Cabinet to run for governor of Colorado, and he urged John Hickenlooper, the mayor of Denver, to enter the race as a Democratic candidate.

title: Scientists Reject Mountaintop Mining Methods
Olympus Brings HD Video to Rugged Camera Model
description: Olympus unwrapped at the Consumer Electronics Show an affordable rugged camera that can capture high-definition video, as well as new budget and higher-end pocket shooters that all sport new creative tricks.

title: Apple Patent Application Could Presage Thinner Devices
description: An Apple patent application surfaced on Thursday that points to a new type of multitouch screen technology.

title: Jayson Williams Is Arraigned
description: More than an hour and a half after cutting across four lanes of oncoming traffic on Avenue C and crashing into a tree, Jayson Williams, the former New Jersey Nets basketball player, told a police officer, Im sorry for causing trouble, according to a Criminal Court complaint and statements made by a prosecutor in court on Thursday.

title: Top Service Problem at I.R.S.: Not Picking Up the Phone
description: The most serious problem with the Internal Revenue Service for taxpayers: getting someone at the agency to answer phone calls.

title: Samsung Adds Two Dual-LCD Cameras
description: Samsung added two new models to its DualView line of cameras with enhancements that make it easier to shoot video using the front LCD. Other than that, theres not much new under the hood, and a lack of pricing makes it difficult to judge their value.

title: In Other Words: Writing Gently Humorous Essays About Stereotypes
description: Overview | How do stereotypes inform our ideas about others? How can we go beyond these misconceptions for a truer look at an other? In this lesson, students read a gently humorous essay examining British stereotypes about Americans, consider stereotypes and misconceptions of people in various groups and write lighthearted personal essays.

title: Guilty Plea in Galleon Insider Trading Case
description: Update | 5:00 p.m. Anil Kumar, a former director at McKinsey & Company accused of leaking information to Raj Rajaratnam in the Galleon Group insider trading case, pleaded guilty on Thursday afternoon and agreed to cooperate with prosecutors in the widening investigation.

title: Iran Accuses Five of Warring Against God
description: At least five protesters arrested in Iran last week during antigovernment demonstrations will be tried on charges of warring against God, which carries an automatic death sentence if they are found guilty, Irans judiciary said Thursday.

title: A Drugs Second Act: Battling Jet Lag
description: A new drug, Nuvigil from Cephalon, could become the first medicine specifically approved by the Food and Drug Administration to combat jet lag.

title: BMW Roundel: Not Born From Planes
description: For decades, the spin on BMWs signature roundel  the automakers logo, which looks like a propeller blade set against a blue sky  was that it represented a propeller blade set against a blue sky. The design was supposedly a tribute to the roots of Bayerische Motoren Werke (or Bavarian Motor Works in English) in the early 20th century, when the company built aircraft engines.

title: Are Doctors Ready for Virtual Visits?
description: For over a decade now, health care experts have been promoting telemedicine, or the use of satellite technology, video conferencing and data transfer through phones and the Internet, to connect doctors to patients in far-flung locales. But are doctors ready for this form of technology?

title: Boston.com: Charles Pierce on Gilbert Arenas
description: I am extremely disappointed in my friends over at the National Rifle Association. David Stern has severely restricted the Second Amendment rights of one Gilbert Arenas, writes Charles P. Pierce on Boston.com. Read the rest of his thoughts on the arms race in the Wizards locker room.

title: What Counts Toward the Cadillac Tax
description: President Obama apparently has embraced the so-called Cadillac tax, an excise tax on high-priced health insurance plans, urging its inclusion in the final health care legislation to be hammered out between Democratic leaders in the House and Senate.

title: J. Paul Getty Museum Director to Step Down
description: The J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles announced Thursday that Michael Brand, who took over as its director at the end of 2005, would be stepping down. The museum did not explain why Mr. Brand was leaving or whether he was moving to another institution.

title: Stern Talks of Langes Absence
description: With considerable reluctance, Howard Stern discussed on air the absence of Artie Lange, the comedian and frequent contributor to The Howard Stern Show who has been on an indefinite hiatus from the program since December. On Thursday mornings broadcast of his Sirius XM show, Mr. Stern said at first that he felt uneasy and weird discussing a report about Mr. Lange that appeared Thursday in the Page Six column of The New York Post. Arties demons run deeper than I ever knew, Mr. Stern said, praising Mr. Langes contributions to the show before saying, Arties alive, by the way  it was a suicide attempt. Mr. Lange, who also appeared on the television series Mad TV and in films like Dirty Work, has discussed his illegal drug use in his standup comedy and a book, Too Fat to Fish. After several of his standup shows were canceled, including a performance scheduled for New Years Eve, his representatives said earlier this month that he had been hospitalized. A representative for Mr. Stern did not reply to a request for further comment.

title: Jason Reitman Plays Video Journalist
description: Any journalist who has been shuffled down a hotel room corridor to a press junket can relate to Jason Reitmans clever video, Lost in the Air, about his adventures on the media tour for his film Up in the Air. In fact, many of those journalists may find themselves in this very video.

title: The Doctor Will See You NowOn Video
description: New technologies allow doctors and patients to interact at far-flung locales.In todays Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline Chen writes about the promise and the disappointment of telemedicine, which is the use of video conferencing, the Internet and other technology to connect physicians, health workers and patients around the world.

title: Saying Goodbye to Bryant Park Christmas Tree, Decades After Climbing It
description: A tree only survives so long severed from its roots. The sad reminders of this are now plentiful in the city. Sweet-smelling needles adorn the floors of countless living rooms. Brittle, rust-colored skeletons of wood decorate curbside trash piles. At some city parks this weekend the dead or dying Christmas trees will be ground into mulch.

title: Seeing Things | Johnston Marklee and Walead Beshty
description: Seeing Things is a biweekly design column by Brooke Hodge, a design writer and curator based in Los Angeles.

title: Iranian TV Sees Conspiracy in Neda Video
description: Updated | 6:04 p.m. On Tuesday, Irans state-run Press TV aired a report on a new documentary made for Iranian television seeking to prove that the graphic, widely-seen amateur video of a female protester named Neda Agha-Soltan bleeding to death on a Tehran street last June was fake.

title: Landscaping as a Seductive First Step
description: ON a quiet inlet of the Queens waterfront, where Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed putting up athletes for the 2012 Olympics, land is being cleared for a series of parks that will be the front lawn for a large midpriced housing development.

title: Listings and More, Just a Touch Away
description: THERE are over 100,000 iPhone apps available on iTunes. Some help you find a restaurant, others let you find Waldo. There is also a growing selection of real estate apps that will help you look for a home, but not all of them are designed for the New York City market.

title: Contrarian Investor Sees Economic Crash in China
description: SHANGHAI  James S. Chanos built one of the largest fortunes on Wall Street by foreseeing the collapse of Enron and other highflying companies whose stories were too good to be true.

title: The Way We Ate: Postscript
description: Last week, we published the story of Angelo Sferrazza, the talented boy chef from Manhattan who won an audience with Mussolini and a tentative job offer from the Waldorf-Astoria. Some readers wanted to know if he ended up at the hotel, or perhaps at some other kitchen.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1) Two economists at the Brookings Institution give President Obama a grade of B for his fiscal and tax policy over the last year. The content of their assessment seems a little more critical than the overall grade, though.

title: New Housing, After a Court Order
description: VOICING compliance with a federal court order, the administration of Rob Astorino, the new county executive, pledged last week that Westchester would shift direction and create affordable housing in predominantly white towns and villages rather than in localities with high concentrations of blacks and Hispanics.

title: What Cute Little Germs
description: A senior co-worker brings his sick children to work, rather than leave them at home with a sitter or his wife, or taking the day off. Recently, he brought them in with plastic caps on their heads. You guessed it: head lice! I dont want to be infected, but I also dont want to alienate my colleague, who will probably be my supervisor someday. We dont have a human resources department, and the principals of our firm dont seem to care. What should I do?

title: Rethinking Vacation Homes
description: IN the heart of the winter, many homeowners may be romanticizing about a vacation home in warmer climes.

title: An Embattled Zardari Hits Back
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Increasingly described as embattled, beleaguered and isolated, President Asif Ali Zardari is fighting back. His latest speeches have been defiant and hard-hitting. He smells a conspiracy to force him to resign and warns his enemies of a tough fight. Predictions of his imminent departure from the presidential palace regularly make the rounds here, although they seem to be inevitable in a society rife with rumors and speculations.

title: Ex-Bear C.F.O. Said to Advise on Deal for Pali Capital
description: Samuel Molinaro, the chief financial officer of Bear Stearns at the time of the investment banks collapse in 2008, is apparently back in the finance game.

title: A Place With a Certain Something
description: IT wasnt just that Sally Ardreys home of 21 years stood along the path of the new Second Avenue subway line. Her building was on the main corner of Second Avenue and 72nd Street, the location of a future subway station.

title: Sonys Green Laptop (Literally)
description: At the Consumer Electronics Show, Stan Glasgow, the head of Sony Electronics in the United States, alluded to the arrival, in a not-too-distant future, of a laptop capable of rendering three-dimensional video. As it was, though, he settled for four new Vaio notebooks, each with its own personality. Heres a brief look at each of them:

title: The Tenor Sax Leads the Fusion
description: The tenor saxophonist Chris Potter puts enormous force into his sound, and an even greater measure of control. His tone, all over the extended range of the horn, is dry and dark, often brusque: he doesnt purr or warble, and he treats vibrato as a special indulgence, like a dusting of shaved truffles. Hes fond of thwarted symmetry and surprising digressions. He knows how to build pressure in a solo, and he does this with such extraordinary technical command that his exertions can feel both heroic and routine.

title: The Nano Is Coming  to Detroit
description: The Tata Nano, also known as the $2,500 car, has been a subject of curiosity and concern for auto industry executives since it was unveiled last year.

title: Pictures of the Day: Thursday, Jan. 7
description: Spencer Platt of Getty Images, newly arrived in Afghanistan (Slide 2), is the product of what turns out to have been one of the more impressive breeding grounds for contemporary photojournalists in America: Staples High School in Westport, Conn. He graduated in 1989. Two other notable alumni are Tyler Hicks, a staff photographer at The Times, and Lynsey Addario, based in Istanbul, whose work appears in The Times and National Geographic. (The high school, it should be noted, did not sign a promotional deal with a certain big-box office supply empire. It is named for its founder, Horace Staples.)

title: What Were the Most Popular Times Articles in 2009?
description: What do you think the top five most-viewed articles on NYTimes.com in 2009 were about? President Obamas inauguration? The plane that landed in the Hudson? Balloon Boy? Michael Jacksons death?

title: Delay of Game at the White House?
description: President Obama was scheduled to speak at 1 p.m. about the governments report detailing the missteps and intelligence failures with the Christmas Day terrorism plot on a flight from Amsterdam to Detroit.

title: The Wizards Without Arenas
description: Jon Nichols writes at basketball-statistics.com and is a graduate student at Harvard, where he is pursuing a masters degree in information technology.

title: Bike Lanes and Other Things Bike to Proliferate in Bay Area Cities
description: With combined state, federal and stimulus funding, and a little help from the courts, 2010 just might be the year of the bike in the Bay Area. Berkeley, Oakland and San Francisco plan on paving and/or striping at least 18.4 miles of new bike lanes and pedestrian pathways. Will bicyclists follow?

title: Yours for Under $1 Million
description: TWO years ago, unemployment was around 5 percent, the average price paid for an apartment in Manhattan was nearing $1.7 million, and Eliot Spitzer had a good shot at becoming president.

title: Peperonata
description: 8 gypsy peppers, or mixture of red, yellow and orange peppers, about 21/2 pounds total

title: Bruschette With Ricotta and Peperonata
description: Extra-virgin olive oil

title: New Years Toast
description: Putting your apartment up for sale these days is like going back to seventh grade. The combination of a major buyers market and the fun world of real estate blogs means a trip through the spanking machine of public mockery. You get to read all about what bad taste you have, how youre not half as good as you think you are, why nobodys going to like you, ever.

title: Enron Finds Its Jeffrey Skilling
description: The Tony Award-winning actor Norbert Leo Butz (Dirty Rotten Scoundrels, Thou Shalt Not) has been cast in the role of Jeffrey Skilling, the disgraced former president of Enron Corp., in the upcoming Broadway production of Lucy Prebbles play Enron.

title: Forbes Sells Building to N.Y.U.
description: Forbes Media is about to announce that it has reached an agreement to sell its building on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan to New York University. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but Forbes will continue to occupy the building under a five-year lease back arrangement.

title: Saab Delays Board Meeting for Late Bidding
description: Saab Automobile, the Swedish automaker being wound down by General Motors, postponed a board meeting on Thursday as bidders including Spyker Cars of the Netherlands made last-ditch efforts to buy the company.

title: Video Shows Newark Security Breach: A Kiss Before Flying
description: In an effort to identify the man who caused a security breach at Newark Liberty International Airport, video footage of the security gaffe was released on Thursday by Senator Frank R. Lautenberg.

title: Lessons From the Katrina Cottages
description: LAST June, Nell Bard, a former social worker, was flipping through a Lowes catalog, comparing its plans for diminutive Katrina cottages with her own 780-square-foot converted summer cottage in the hamlet of Brookhaven.

title: Twitter Land Likes Bama
description: PASADENA, Calif.  Four years ago when Vince Young and Texas de-railed the Southern California dynasty here, we didnt have a college sports blog at The New York Times and Twitter was just a twinkle in some computer geeks eye.

title: Optimism About the New Year
description: SO is it over? The three-year period of unrelenting home price declines: has it stopped? And is it possible that sales prices will go the other way in 2010?

title: Where People Stay, and Play Musical Houses
description: IF youre contemplating buying a home in Douglas Manor, a peninsula on Little Neck Bay in northeast Queens, be advised: your neighbors may not think of your house as yours right away. On paper it belongs to you, but in their minds it may take years until you truly succeed its old owners.

title: Nelson to Fight for All States
description: Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, has been under fire in recent days for winning some plum provisions for his home state in exchange for voting for his partys big health care legislation. But in a statement on Thursday, Mr. Nelson said he would fight for all states to get the same benefits as Nebraska  a move that some Senate colleagues had predicted as inevitable.

title: The Leader of the Cheers
description: GOWANUS HOUSES, a complex of 14 red-brick buildings that sits not far from its namesake canal in Brooklyn, opened on a June day in 1949, flush with the optimism that wreathed new housing developments for low-income New Yorkers. Among the 1,100-plus original families was a young couple named Leslie and Victoria Baskett Flowers.

title: A Hatchback for High Rollers
description: LOOKING over the BMW 5 Series Gran Turismo is like waiting in an alley outside the hottest club in town. The view gets better inside.

title: Free Agent Market: Best of the Rest
description: If the current list of remaining free agents had been available just a few years ago, we would be looking at one of the stronger classes in recent memory. But while age and injury have taken a toll on Vladimir Guerrero, Pedro Martinez, Miguel Tejada and Johnny Damon, they lead a long list of unsigned talent that can still help a team make a playoff push in 2010.

title: John Oliver Would Like You to Watch His New Show (if Thats O.K. With You)
description: How exemplary a Briton is John Oliver? We cant speak to his dietary habits or his oral hygiene, but we did learn in a recent telephone conversation with him that he simply cannot pay himself a compliment without immediately putting himself down. (Sometimes the putdowns arent even preceded by compliments.)

title: ABC and Koppel in Talks for This Week
description: Ted Koppel may make a homecoming to ABC News.

title: A Booming Economy in China
description: Signs of China's expanding prosperity are everywhere: construction cranes and bulldozers,  luxury-car showrooms, busy shops, long lines for ski lifts. But some fear the country's economy may be overheating, and headed for a collapse.

title: Egyptian Christians Clash With Police
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  Thousands of enraged Christians clashed with the police in Egypt on Thursday in response to a drive-by shooting the night before that left six Christians dead and nine wounded.

title: Feel-Better Earbuds
description: Take two earbuds and call me in the morning.

title: Time for a Repair Job and a Reality Check
description: DETROIT is shorthand for the American automobile industry in the way that Hollywood is a catch-all term for movies and television. Just as the studios dont make many films in Hollywood anymore, automakers dont build many cars in Detroit. Yet like its Tinseltown counterpart, the Motor City remains a beacon, even if the glow has dimmed.

title: Talks Break Down at Cleveland Orchestra
description: Talks between the players and management of the Cleveland Orchestra broke down on Wednesday, and the musicians threatened to go on strike on Jan. 18. That is the day before the orchestra is to leave for a residency in Miami. That tour is in question, Jeffrey Rathbun, the orchestras assistant principal oboist and the musicians chief negotiator, said in a statement. The players contract expired at the end of August, but they have agreed to continue rehearsing and performing. Management, citing salary cuts among staff members and the music director, Franz Welser-Mst, above, offered a three-year contract calling for a 5 percent cut in the first year, a restoration of that amount in the second and a 2.5 percent increase in the third. We need the union to recognize the shared sacrifice throughout the institution and respond in kind, Gary Hanson, the orchestras executive director, said in a statement. The players offered a salary freeze for this year. A spokesman for the players, Howard C. Landau, said they had made concessions in the past, which is why we keep slipping in the rankings in relation to salaries at other orchestras. We just cant keep slipping any further, he added. Theres no way we can stay competitive. Our musicians are going to leave for greener pastures.

title: Peoples Choice Wins
description: The Peoples Choice Awards, with Queen Latifah as host, attracted its largest audience in three years on Wednesday as 10.7 million viewers tuned in to the two-hour broadcast on CBS, according to Nielsens estimates. The 36th annual installment of the awards show helped lift CBS to No. 1 in the nights ratings, as did CBSs 8 p.m. special I Get That a Lot (8.5 million), in which celebrities pulled pranks. NBC ranked second on the night. Although its medical drama Mercy garnered a modest 7.3 million viewers at 8, Law & Order: SVU led the 9 p.m. hour with 10.8 million viewers. At 10 the Jay Leno Show drew 5.2 million viewers, edging past ABCs Ugly Betty (5.1 million). ABC finished close behind NBC in third place with two episodes of The Middle at 8 (7.5 million) and 8:30 (8.2 million) followed by Modern Family at 9 (10.2 million) and Cougar Town at 9:30 (7.9 million). Fox was fourth with repeats of Glee at 8 and 9, both averaging 3.4 million viewers.

title: Swiss Preparing Decision on Polanski
description: The justice ministry of Switzerland said Thursday that it may decide soon whether to grant a request by the United States to extradite Roman Polanski, Agence France-Presse reported. The ministrys spokesman, Folco Galli, told Agence France-Presse: We are preparing our decision. It could be January, it could also be in February. I am not going to be more precise. Mr. Polanski, who fled the United States in 1978 after pleading guilty to having sex with a 13-year-old girl, was apprehended in Switzerland in September. He spent several months in a jail near Zurich before posting $4.5 million bail in December and is now under house arrest in his chalet in Gstaad. On Wednesday a written request from Mr. Polanski to be sentenced in absentia was presented to a Los Angeles County Superior Court judge. The judge, Peter P. Espinoza, has scheduled a hearing on Jan. 22 to consider it.

title: Festival Replaces Films Pulled in Protest
description: The Palm Springs International Film Festival confirmed that two Chinese movies had been pulled from its lineup and would be replaced. The films, City of Life and Death (also called Nanjing! Nanjing!) and Quick, Quick, Slow, were withdrawn from the festival by Chinas foreign affairs ministry and its film bureau in protest of another film, The Sun Behind the Clouds: Tibets Struggle for Freedom. That film, a documentary, chronicles a year in the life of the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan leader. In a statement Darryl Macdonald, the director of the festival, said the films were withdrawn when the festival did not comply with a request from the Chinese to cancel screenings of The Sun Behind the Clouds. He added: We cannot allow the concerns of one country or community to dictate what films we should or should not play, based on their own cultural or political perspective. The festival said City of Life and Death, with Liu Ye, above, in a scene from the film, would be replaced with screenings of For a Moment, Freedom, an Austrian and French film about Middle Eastern refugees seeking European visas; and Sticky Fingers, a Canadian, French and Spanish comedy about inept gangsters. A replacement for Quick, Quick, Slow has not yet been announced.

title: An Addition to Enron
description: The Tony Award-winning actor Norbert Leo Butz (below, in Dirty Rotten Scoundrels) has been cast in the role of Jeffrey Skilling, the disgraced former president of Enron Corporation, in the coming Broadway production of Lucy Prebbles play Enron. Mr. Butz was last seen on Broadway as Bobby Gould in the 2008-9 revival of David Mamets Speed-the-Plow. Enron, which has been running to acclaim in London, was inspired by the financial collapse of the energy company whose name has become synonymous with corporate fraud. Many of the characters  like Mr. Skilling and Kenneth Lay  are based on former employees of Enron. (Mr. Lay was its chairman.) Directed by Rupert Goold, Enron is scheduled to begin previews at the Broadhurst Theater April 8 and open April 27.

title: Boyle Remains No. 1
description: Susan Boyle prevailed in the final week of music sales for 2009, holding at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart for a sixth week. Her I Dreamed a Dream (Syco Music/Columbia) sold 137,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Its total year sales of 3.1 million gave Taylor Swifts Fearless (Big Machine) a run for its money as the best-selling album of the year; Fearless holds at No. 5 on the latest weekly chart with 60,000 sales, bringing its total for the year to 3.2 million. With no major new releases, Lady Gagas The Fame (Interscope) sold 82,000 last week to reach No. 2, Alicia Keyss Element of Freedom (J) is third with 80,000, and Mary J. Bliges Stronger (Geffen) is No. 4 with 62,000. Justin Biebers My World (Island) is No. 6 with 52,000 sales and the soundtrack to Alvin & the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (Rhino) is No. 7 with 51,000.

title: On Health Care Bill, Nelson to Fight for All States
description: Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, has been under fire in recent days over his success in winning some plum provisions for his home state in exchange for his commitment to vote for the Democrats big health care legislation. But in a statement on Thursday, Mr. Nelson said he would fight for all states to get the same benefits as Nebraska  a move that some of his Senate colleagues had predicted as inevitable.

title: Ex-Chief of C.I.A. Is Leaving Citis Board
description: John M. Deutch, a former director of the Central Intelligence Agency, is stepping down from Citigroups board, the bank disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday. Mr. Deutch, 70, who has been a Citigroup director for 12 years, told the board on Monday that he would not stand for re-election at the banks next annual meeting, scheduled for April 20.

title: Obama: We Are at War
description: President Obama on Thursday ordered a series of steps to improve the governments ability to collect, share, analyze and act on intelligence of terrorist threats, saying the findings of a government review of the attempted airline bombing on Christmas Day revealed significant shortcomings in national security.

title: In Focus | Diane Arbus and William Eggleston
description: New Yorks Cheim & Read gallery opens its 2010 season on Thursday night with a blockbuster show featuring the work of two stars of the photography world: Diane Arbus and William Eggleston. In the Absence of Others shows rarely seen Arbus images of empty interiors and artificial landscapes. (The Moment was lucky to get one of her images, shown below.) She shoots the spaces with the same candid, documentary style she used in her images of people. In the Eggleston show, 21st Century, viewers quickly fall in love with his color and composition and simultaneously feel a pang for the quietness of each image, whether its a doorway or a roll of printed fabric. From Cuba to Kentucky, California to Paris, Egglestons eye is unwavering, and his bold strokes of captured color light up the pigment print like fire. This is American photography at its best.

title: Sudan Clashes Seen as Threat to Peace Treaty
description: At least 140 people were killed in clashes in recent days in a remote corner of southern Sudan, a United Nations official said Thursday, deepening worries that the American-backed peace deal ending decades of war there could collapse amid spasms of ethnically motivated violence.

title: Reader Responses to Review of Googles Nexus One
description: I think I may have accidentally unearthed a whole new untapped population online: the Android Army.

title: In Winter Gardens, a Marriage of Botany and Stark Beauty
description: UNLIKE the tragic hero of Franz Schuberts song cycle Winter Journey (Tearless I must face the cold/Through the bitter weather), multitudes of New Yorkers joyously headed for Central Park to experience in bright sunlight the seasons first pristine snowfall on a preholiday Sunday. And in late-afternoon dusk, under the glow of lamplight, the glistening field of white seemed etched by circuitous paths marked in the distance by streams of brightly clad walkers and the shadowy silhouettes of fences. Invigorating crisp, clean air was the motto of the day.

title: Easy Rider, Part II: The Self-Balance Years
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  For my daughter Ali, who is 11, the highlight of the movie Paul Blart: Mall Cop last year was the way the title character patrolled his indoor beat: atop a Segway, one of those big-wheeled electric scooters that appear to be lifted from the old Jetsons cartoons.

title: NBC May Be Considering Reinstating Leno on Tonight Show
description: NBC executives held discussions with both Jay Leno and Conan OBrien Thursday about the future of the networks late-night lineup. And while executives said that no final decision has been made, they did not deny that the network was considering moves that could include returning Mr. Leno to his old job as host of The Tonight Show.

title: Whittakers at Pender Harbour
description: WHAT Small waterfront second-home community.

title: TV on the Go  Once Again
description: Digital television gave, but it also took away. Digital TV brought us high-definition TV, and if you can get a signal, perfect reception. But one of the things that the switch to digital TV removed is the ability to watch TV while youre on the move.

title: At Ground Level, Taking Jazzs Pulse
description: A lot of people at the Winter Jazzfest this weekend will be ticking off names on a mental checklist, or filing them away for later. This two-day festival, now in its sixth year, is expressly made for them: the prowlers and perusers, many seeking talent for hire. But tickets are also available to the public, at $25 a night or $30 for both, which gives the Winter Jazzfest another, more fascinating purpose. It is for the moment the only real mainstream jazz festival in New York, and its lineup amounts to a temperature reading of the scene at ground level, where its most vibrant and volatile.

title: Tougher Smog Standards, but What About Tailpipes?
description: Environmental groups were full of praise on Thursday when the Environmental Protection Agency proposed the strictest standards to date for smog. Although automobile tailpipes have traditionally been a major source of the smog problem, the auto industry said that it had largely dealt with that issue. Ground-level ozone reductions, the carmakers said, were more likely to come from stationary sources like power plants.

title: Batsheva From and Michael Altman
description: AS a prosecutor in the narcotics division of the Bronx district attorneys office, Batsheva From relishes the challenge and drama of the courtroom. She spends many hours preparing a case, all too aware that improvisation may also be required to win over judge and jury.

title: A Writerly Nook of Brooklyn
description: Books have been born all over Brooklyns Fort Greene. Richard Wright labored over Native Son here while sitting on a hill in Fort Greene Park; a bench there now bears his name. He lived nearby, as did Marianne Moore, and several contemporary writers have roots in the neighborhood, including Colson Whitehead, Jhumpa Lahiri and Nelson George. For a tour of this literary hub (or to take the free workshops the New York Writers Coalition holds here to help people find their inner author), hop the subway to DeKalb Avenue or a nearby station. Bring pen and paper, in case the muse strikes.

title: Of Explosions and Catharsis
description: There were at least two surprises in the Directors Guild of America nominations announced on Thursday: the inclusion of Quentin Tarantino over, say, Clint Eastwood, whom the guild has favored in the past (though Mr. Tarantino was included for Pulp Fiction), and the nod for Lee Daniels, who becomes the first black director nominated by the guild and certainly the first openly gay black director. Perhaps this will ease Mr. Danielss, or his boyfriends, agita about awards season.

title: Hes in Love; Excuse His French
description: In the sweet and slight and often charming coming-of-age tale Youth in Revolt, Michael Cera plays a teenager with rampaging hormones and, when the film opens at least, no obvious romantic prospects. On the face of it, this seems preposterous: Mr. Cera, who turns 22 in June, is a professional cutie-pie and very appealing to both the on screen characters (he usually gets the girl) and, to gauge from his popularity, the audience. After the movie I ran into a friend who was initially worried about this film because Mr. Cera always does the same thing, only to realize that what he does is exceptionally winning. Exactly.

title: Enron Finds Its Jeffrey Skilling
description: From Patrick Healy at ArtsBeat:

title: Trial Pending, Suspects Cars Will Soon Be Freed
description: DENVER  The trial of Jeffrey L. Mowen, accused of defrauding investors in an $18 million Ponzi scheme in Utah and then trying to hire a hit man to kill four witnesses against him, is expected to be lurid at the least.

title: Sonys Memory Stick: Bowing to Reality
description: Deep within the speech by Stan Glasgow, president of the American arm of Sony Electronics, at the Consumer Electronics Show on Wednesday was this little tidbit: the company that pioneered the Memory Stick flash memory format would now accept the rival SD and SDHD memory card format in a number of its new camcorders and digital still cameras.

title: Thinking vs. Feeling
description: Thats from a summary of a recent paper on the language used for marketing and persuasion. The paper is by Nicole D. Mayer, of the University of Illinois at Chicago, and Zakary L. Tormala, of the Stanford Graduate School of Business.

title: House Democrats Push Back on Cadillac Tax
description: Several House Democrats on Thursday chafed at President Obamas insistence that the final version of major health care legislation include a Senate proposal for a new tax on high-cost, employer-sponsored insurance policies.

title: New Rules Proposed for Smog Pollutants
description: If adopted, the proposal will impose large costs on industry and local governments, but will also bring substantial health benefits to millions of Americans.

title: A Safety Net That Tangles Investors
description: In the wake of a series of Ponzi schemes  the most notable being the Bernard Madoff fraud  the Securities and Exchange Commission voted last month to tighten the rules and make it much harder for money managers to misappropriate client funds.

title: Coming to AT&T: Smartbooks, Toys and You Name It
description: Glenn Lurie, the president of emerging devices at AT&T, has what some people may consider a fantastic job.

title: Inside the List
description: THINK PINK: Daniel H. Pink enters the extended hardcover nonfiction list at No. 16 with Drive: The Surprising Truth About What Motivates Us. Pink (inset) achieved full guru status with A Whole New Mind (2005), a paean to right-brain thinking that spent more than 29 weeks on the paperback nonfiction list, thanks in part to a nod from Oprah Winfrey. (She distributed copies to Stanfords graduating class after her 2008 commencement speech.) In The Adventures of Johnny Bunko (2008), billed as Americas first business book in the Japanese comic format known as manga, Pink reached out to the youth crowd with the story of a frustrated desk monkey who conjures up a tough-talking career counselor goddess by snapping open a pair of magic chopsticks.

title: An Extroverts Brisk Dance Through Bachs Arpeggios, in an East River Hall
description: The Well-Tempered Clavier was once the preserve of specialists, among both performers and listeners, but these days one or both of Bachs collections of preludes and fugues in every key can be heard in live performance several times a year. The readings come in every flavor: on harpsichord, clavichord or piano; in accounts steeped in musicological detail or in freewheeling interpretations; and in grandly scaled traversals in halls as large as Carnegie or more intimate performances in chamber spaces.

title: The Best French Toast
description: From diner breakfast to hotel brunch, challah seems to be the bread of choice for making French toast. This is a good idea in principle, but  like nearly all 21st-century bagels  most of the nations challah is the merest shadow of the beautiful eggy bread that Jews used to reserve for special occasions: a recurrent image in Isaac Bashevis Singers stories is the family so wealthy that it eats challah during the week rather than just on the sabbath.

title: The Three Magi of the Meltdown
description: Just because hindsight is 20/20 doesnt mean we shouldnt occasionally avail ourselves of it. The upcoming second-year anniversary of the collapse of Bear Stearns provides just such an opportunity to look back with a degree of analytical wisdom not available at the time of the firms shocking demise in March 2008.

title: Under the Radar: Five Questions About John Cassavetes Husbands
description: Translating the films of the director John Cassavetes for the stage is a novel concept, but not a new one. In 2008, Ivo van Hoves tech-heavy staging of Cassavetess 1977 film, Opening Night, turned a stage at the Brooklyn Academy of Music into an ersatz film set.

title: Getty Museum Director to Leave Post This Month
description: The J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles said on Thursday that Michael Brand, who took over as its director at the end of 2005, is stepping down at the end of the month.

title: Contrarian Investor Predicts Crash in China
description: James S. Chanos built one of the largest fortunes on Wall Street by foreseeing the collapse of Enron and other highflying companies whose stories were too good to be true. Now Mr. Chanos, a wealthy hedge fund investor, is working to bust the myth of the biggest conglomerate of all: China Inc.

title: More on desert bubbles
description: Ed Glaeser emails to say that, contrary to my suggestion, he doesnt believe there were significant supply restrictions in Phoenix or Las Vegas. He directs me to a paper which says, if I understand it, that even in Flatland there may be sufficient short-run price inelasticity of supply to allow brief bubbles.

title: Crankier Than Thou, but Open to New Love
description: Ben Singer (Matthew Broderick), the misanthropic protagonist of Josh Goldins film Wonderful World, voices many of the frustrations nagging at those who harbor suspicion that the world is going to hell. Ben is a divorced, semi-retired childrens musician and pothead who was once near the top of his field. His career went abruptly into decline when his record company encouraged him to make a solo album, then failed to promote it. Now he toils miserably as a proofreader at a law firm.

title: To Sign or Not to Sign in Making Debit Purchases: Part 1
description: The New York Times article How Visa, Using Card Fees, Dominates a Market on Tuesday detailed the behind-the-scenes struggle between banks and retailers on whether to encourage customers to sign or punch in their PIN when making debit card purchases because of the higher fees that stores pay banks for signatures.

title: CRE-ative destruction
description: For some reason I havent seen this: a comparison of commercial real estate prices from Moodys/MIT with housing prices from Standard and Poors/Case-Shiller. Here it is:

title: Eddie the Eagle Returns to Canada
description: Michael Edwards  the hopelessly unskilled and undertrained British ski jumper better known as Eddie the Eagle, who provided humorous relief at the 1988 Winter Olympics in Calgary  returned to Canada on Thursday in preparation for the Vancouver Games. But Edwards, a drywaller by trade, did not come back as an athlete.

title: Obamas Remarks on the Terror Plot Review
description: Following is the text of President Obamas remarks on Thursday in which he addresses the results of a government review of the attempted airline bombing on Christmas Day, as released by the White House:

title: 3 Irish Women Bound by Blood and Behavior
description: Little Gem, a new play by Elaine Murphy that arrives at the Flea Theater trailing accolades from Dublin and Edinburgh, lives up to its title, although if it were trimmed, this jewel would definitely gleam more brightly. Intimately told and beautifully acted, Ms. Murphys play unfolds in alternating monologues, as three generations of Irish women greet lifes travails with strength, humor and the occasional vodka and Diet Coke or night of abandon on the salsa dance floor.

title: Unscarred, Berlusconi Appears in Public
description: Less than four weeks after he was struck in the face following a rally in Milan, Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi appeared for the first time without bandages on Wednesday, during a shopping trip in France.

title: Life as a Runway
description: Susan Sarandon talks about the crowd at Spin New York, a table tennis and social club in New York City, where the clientele is as studiedly understated as the sprawling gray and green interior.

title: An Ancestor Takes Pride in a Taller Descendant
description: The Empire State Building has a message for the Burj Khalifa, the slightly-more-than-twice-as-tall tower that opened in Dubai on Monday: Welcome to the club.

title: This is the way the Chicago School ends
description: Not with a bang, but with a cackle.

title: Columbias Last 3-Point Specialist Is a Pro in Japan
description: Noruwa Agho has filled the net with 3-pointers for Columbia University at a higher rate than anyone else in Division I mens basketball this season, hitting at 59 percent, as I wrote in Fridays New York Times. But he is not the only Lions guard in recent years who had the touch from long range.

title: A Fresh Makeover for Familiar Faces
description: Color changes everything. It has, anyway, in the East Gallery of the Frick Collection, where walls covered with brown velvet since the Johnson administration now glow a beautiful shade of coral.

title: B.C.S. National Championship Game: No. 2 Texas (13-0) vs. No. 1 Alabama (13-0)
description: Its funny just how quickly 126 days can pass, especially with college footballs propensity for scheduling games two, three, even four nights a week. Yet as we stand on the doorstep of the B.C.S. National Championship Game, that is how long it has been  a few days past four months  since Sept. 3, when South Carolina edged North Carolina State, 7-3, in the seasons first prime-time game. Perhaps it takes 126 days for the cream to rise to the top, as tonights title game pits the clear Nos. 1 and 2 in the F.B.S.: Texas, winners of the Big 12, and Alabama, the SEC champs.

title: Fox Drops Little Genius Premiere
description: The premiere of Our Little Genius, a new quiz show that was scheduled to be broadcast on Fox next week after American Idol, has been canceled, Fox announced Thursday, over what appears to be concerns that contestants were given information about the topics on which they would be quizzed.

title: Coffee for Me, Worms for Her
description: Thomas S. Kaplan, the president of the board of directors of the 92nd Street Y, made a fortune in silver, platinum, oil, natural gas and gold. That is good news for the planets big cats and their habitats: their preservation is the mission of Panthera, a foundation that is a major philanthropic focus of his. Mr. Kaplan, 47, who is chairman of the Electrum Group, which mines gold, lives in Chelsea with his wife, Daphne Recanati Kaplan, and their son, Leonardo, 7, and daughter, Orianne, 9. ROBIN FINN

title: Pearls, Fish and Devils Unbound at the Morgan
description: In the next two weeks the Morgan Library & Museum will hang framed 15th-century pages that staff members tore out of old books.

title: Spirals of Self-Reflection, Made by Methods Mysterious
description: Acute  some might say neurotic  self-consciousness is one of modern arts salient features. Before the art world went nuts in the 1960s, this meant focusing on the basic processes, materials and actions by which works were made, as in Abstract Expressionist painting, for example. Now cerebrally ambitious artists like to reflect on all the conditions impinging on art: on the gallery and museum system; on the ideological prejudices and blind spots of art history and criticism; on publications by which information and rumors about art are disseminated; and so on.

title: In Los Angeles, an Urge to Purge
description: For two years the Los Angeles County Museum of Art has been quietly buying paintings and publicly selling them. Readers of Sothebys latest auction catalog may have noticed a group of old master paintings coming up for sale on Jan. 28. It isnt the first time the museum has sold works from its permanent collection. Last year, in January and June, Sothebys auctioned paintings by Joshua Reynolds, Lucas Cranach the Elder, Pieter de Hooch and others, raising more than $6 million for the museum.

title: Fox Drops Our Little Genius Premiere
description: The premiere of Our Little Genius, a new quiz show that was scheduled to be broadcast on Fox next week following American Idol, has been canceled, Fox announced Thursday, over what appears to be concerns that contestants were given information about the topics on which they would be quizzed.

title: The Harvard Psychedelic Club
description: Andy Weil and Ronnie Winston were friends and dorm mates in Claverly Hall. They were both incoming Harvard freshmen when they walked into Leary's office on Divinity Lane and volunteered to be research subjects in his psychedelic research project. Weil had grown up in a middle-class family. Winston was the son of Harry Winston, the wealthy diamond and jewelry manufacturer whose creations hung around the necks of trophy wives and Hollywood starlets from coast to coast. Neither of them would officially take part in the project, but they would both play an important, little-known role in the rise and fall of Richard Alpert and Timothy Leary.

title: Tune In, Turn On, Turn Page
description: In the winter of 1960-61, when their lives began to overlap in Cambridge, Mass., Timothy Leary, Richard Alpert, Andrew Weil and Huston Smith resembled tweedy extras from Mad Men. These future psychedelic pioneers were still buttoned-down intellectuals and careerists, men who leaned more toward martinis than marijuana.

title: Three Decades on, Reunited With a High School Sweetheart
description: BATH, N.H.

title: An Interview With Rep. Steny Hoyer
description: John Harwood of CNBC and The New York Times interviews Representative Steny Hoyer, House majority leader and Democrat of Maryland.

title: Batsheva From and Michael Altman Wed
description: The couple exchanged vows on Dec. 30, in front of Rabbi Hershel Billet and nearly 400 guests at the Great Neck Synagogue in Great Neck, N.Y.

title: Film Excerpt: 'Nostalgia'
description: An excerpt from Omer Fast's 2009 film, now showing at the Whitney Museum.

title: Should the Fine You Pay Be Based on How Rich You Are?
Brown Is Happy at Texas and as a Coach
description: PASADENA, Calif.  Ever since Texas named the defensive coordinator Will Muschamp its designated head coach-in-waiting last season, there has been speculation about when Longhorns Coach Mack Brown will retire.

title: Ireland in February, With Romance in the Air, Manure on the Ground
description: A few weeks ago I resolved, in the spirit of the season, to adopt a more positive outlook in the new year. In particular I vowed to break the habit of seizing on every bad movie as a sign that civilization was collapsing. There is already so much doomsaying and apocalypse mongering going around. Why add to it?

title: China Turns Drug Rehab Into a Punishing Ordeal
description: BEIJING  Fu Lixin, emotionally exhausted from caring for her sick mother, needed a little pick-me-up. A friend offered her a special cigarette  one laced with methamphetamine  and Ms. Fu happily inhaled.

title: Eat, Pray, Marry
description: When exactly was it that Eat, Pray, Love, Elizabeth Gilberts 2006 memoir about her divorce and subsequent year of travel in Italy, India and Indonesia, crossed from mere best seller  published in more than 30 languages, feted by Oprah  to cultural phenomenon? The film adaptation is due out later this year, with Gilbert played by (but of course) Julia Roberts; some of the people Gilbert wrote about, including her ex-husband, are now working on books of their own; and Gilberts second appearance on The Oprah Winfrey Show featured such admiring readers as a woman who had actually retraced much of Gilberts around-the-world journey. Perhaps most impressive of all, in a sign of what a widely understood reference point the book has become, it inspired a headline in The Onion: Copy of Eat, Pray, Love Left on Elliptical.

title: The Twisted Trail of the Khost Bomber
description: Stephen Farrell of The Times interviews the mother of Humam Khalil Abu-Mulal al-Balawi, the Jordanian suicide bomber  who killed 7 CIA officers in Khost, Afghanistan.

title: Ah, Homer, It Seems Just Like Yesterday
description: The Simpsons has been on the air longer than Gunsmoke, but thats not a reason to watch the shows 20th-anniversary special on Fox this Sunday night. Tributes to even the best shows can smother them in pomposity. The Simpsons 20th Anniversary Special: In 3-D! On Ice! is worth a look because  as the self-mocking title suggests  it doesnt make too big a deal of one of the most innovative, influential and irresistibly irreverent shows in the history of television.

title: January Thaw for the Arts
description: These are the festivals mentioned in the article.

title: Festivals to Enliven the Dead of Winter
description: ONCE upon a time, the first half of January was considered a slow, even dead, stretch for the performing arts in New York. Not anymore.

title: Total Recall: A Journey From Vienna to Brooklyn and the Center of the Brain
description: Its not often that you are invited to spend an hour or two in the presence of a Nobel Prize winner, and In Search of Memory: The Neuroscientist Eric Kandel, Petra Seegers new documentary, offers an especially gratifying opportunity. The films subject won the 2000 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for his research into the workings of the brain. He is particularly interested in how, at the cellular level, the mind stores and sorts various stimuli and turns them into long- and short-term memory.

title: Is It Reality or Fantasy? The Boundaries Are Blurred
description: Omer Fast, who has a powerful, discomforting solo show at the Whitney Museum of American Art, and another opening at Postmasters gallery in Chelsea on Saturday, was born in Jerusalem in 1972 and now lives in Berlin. But he studied art in New York City, and anyone who saw his graduate project in the 2000 Hunter College M.F.A. exhibition will remember it.

title: New Jersey Senate Defeats Gay Marriage Bill
description: TRENTON  The State Senate on Thursday rejected a proposal that would have made New Jersey the sixth state in the nation to allow marriages involving same-sex couples. The vote was the latest in a succession of setbacks for advocates of gay marriage across the country.

title: Theater Listings: Jan. 8  14
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

title: Footage of Breach at Newark Is Released
description: In an effort to identify the man who caused a security breach at Newark Liberty International Airport, video footage of the episode was released on Thursday by Senator Frank R. Lautenberg.

title: The Iron Horse Stalks a Sentimental Village
description: The railroad snakes ever closer in Return to Cranford, a sequel to Cranford, the five-hanky Victorian tearjerker and paean to preindustrial village life that collected eight Emmy nominations for PBS in 2008. Despite its tendency to maim and kill them, the fearsome machine is cautiously welcomed by the townspeople, some of whom recognize an economic lifeline when they see one.

title: Excerpt: 'Human Target'
description: The new Fox action series, based on a comic book, stars Mark Valley as a resourceful private eye.

title: Mika Brzezinski: Her Way
description: When did you first become aware of Mika Brzezinski, the co-host of MSNBCs daily news discussion program Morning Joe? For the Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping, it was in the 1970s, when she spilled a plate of caviar on his lap. For me, it was a December morning in 2007, as I listened to the Carter-era statesman Zbigniew Brzezinski discussing Benazir Bhuttos assassination. The anchorwoman addressed him as Daddy. Daddy? I looked up from my pancakes.

title: Reliance Said to Sweeten Lyondell Bid
description: Reliance Industries of India has bolstered its offer to take a controlling stake in LyondellBasell Industries when the chemical maker exits bankruptcy, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing unidentified people familiar with the matter. But Lyondell seemed unlikely to accept the new terms and instead go ahead with a previous deal to turn itself over to its senior lenders.

title: Futuristic World Where Vampires Rule
description: Among the many pleasures of Daybreakers is its reminder that vampire movies can function as more than just metaphors for teenage celibacy. Written and directed by Peter and Michael Spierig (the Australian twins who brought us the ebullient 2003 zombie caper Undead), this impressively styled thriller envisions a world where vampires rule, and humans run. Those who dont are likely to find themselves transformed into Ready Meals and stored in a giant corporate larder: a futuristic Costco with only one product.

title: Casting Identities in Light
description: IN the lexicon of automakers design studios, two abbreviations  D.R.G., for down the road graphic, and D.L.O., for the daylight opening area of the windows  crop up frequently. Together, they refer to the characteristic form of a car that makes it instantly recognizable, the profile that quickly tells a viewer whether the vehicle is a Fusion or a Forester, an Eclipse or an Elantra.

title: Study Raises Cost Estimate for Electric Cars
description: DETROIT  As General Motors began assembling batteries for the coming Chevrolet Volt on Thursday, a new study cast doubt on the likelihood that electric cars will be widely popular in the near future.

title: Apocalyptic Beliefs of American Evangelicals
description: Who knew that one of this years first horror movies would arrive not from Japan or the mind of Eli Roth but from three inquisitive nonfiction filmmakers? Turning their camera on the apocalyptic beliefs of American evangelicals (estimated in the film at more than 50 million), Kate Davis, Franco Sacchi and David Heilbroner illuminate a worldview marked by absolute certainty and chilling finality.

title: Helen Gahagan Douglas, Hollywood Liberal
description: Sally Dentons new biography of Helen Gahagan Douglas, the actress turned New Deal politician, starts on a lyrical note  Her life would begin and end in sun-filled rooms  and never really calms down. Despite its concision, a rare and usually admirable thing in biography, the book doesnt achieve the tonal or interpretive modesty that might give Douglas her due without inflating claims for her significance and her victimization at the hands of Richard Nixon, who defeated her in their 1950 California Senate race. Douglass life was more richly and judiciously presented by Ingrid Winther Scobie less than 20 years ago, in a biography called Center Stage.

title: Obama Details New Policies in Response to Terror Threat
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday ordered intelligence agencies to take a series of steps to streamline how terrorism threats are pursued and analyzed, saying the government had to respond aggressively to the failures that allowed a Nigerian man to ignite an explosive mixture on a commercial jetliner on Christmas Day.

title: Blackhawks Flourish Under Tough Coach
description: If the Blackhawks were a Western movie, Joel Quenneville would be cast as a United States marshal, wise and worldly, so firmly in charge theres no need to flaunt his power or ego. As a hockey team, the Hawks are thriving like a gold-rush boomtown under Quennevilles sharp-eyed, self-assured leadership.

title: Update: NBC Plan Would Move Leno Back to Late Nights
description: Pressed by affiliates and shrinking ratings, NBC has a plan in the works to radically alter its late-night television lineup, restoring Jay Leno to his old spot at 11:35 each weeknight, while pushing the man who replaced him, Conan OBrien, to a starting time of 12:05 a.m.

title: Former Blackwater Guards Charged With Murder
description: WASHINGTON  Two former Blackwater security guards were arrested Thursday on murder charges stemming from a shooting in Afghanistan last May that left two Afghans dead and a third wounded, the Justice Department said.

title: Italy Puts Swiss Haven From Taxes Under Siege
description: LUGANO, Switzerland  Italy and Switzerland have been waging a quiet border war lately, and this picturesque town on the shores of an Alpine lake is caught in the cross-fire.

title: A One-Man Version of First Blood
description: Zachary Oberzan says he spent less than $96 to make Flooding With Love for the Kid, his one-man version of First Blood, but thats disingenuous. Mr. Oberzan, who in addition to being the lone actor was also director, designer, cinematographer, editor and everything else for this odd project, apparently didnt pay himself.

title: Finding Happiness in Helping Those Who Have Less
description: Six years ago, Sheila Salmon, a retired educator and librarian, picked up The New York Times and read a Neediest Cases article about a retired bank executive who volunteered at a senior center.

title: Film Series and Movie Listings
description: Film Series

title: Jobs Report Preview
description: The long-awaited December jobs report comes out Friday, and what it will say is anybodys guess.

title: Partners Near Default on Stuyvesant Town
description: The owners of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, the sprawling sister complexes overlooking the East River in Manhattan, will miss a $16 million loan payment on Friday, which would put them in technical default on their mortgages, and the 20,000 residents in limbo.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Live Analysis: Alabama 37, Texas 21, Final
description: 12:15 p.m. | Use the comment section below to leave your thoughts on the game, even if all you have to say is, Roll Tide Roll. Congratulations to the Tide for its national championship and congratulations to Texas for another fine season. Stay with The Times and the Quad blog for more from Pasadena. And before we all get teary-eyed, remember that were only 239 days away from kickoff of the 2010 college football season.

title: When Running for Office, Be Careful What You Wish For
description: The only thing missing in the most notable television ad in the Illinois governors race is Englebert Humperdink singing, Release Me.

title: Holmgren and Browns Decide to Retain Mangini
description: Back in November, with his team reeling, his players grumbling, the fans booing, it was hard to imagine that Eric Mangini would make it until the end of the season. Instead, he will make it at least two. On Thursday, the Browns new president, Mike Holmgren, announced that Mangini would return for his second season, shocking many around the N.F.L. who assumed Holmgren would clean house.

title: A Campaign Linking Clean Clothes With Stylish Living
description: PROCTER & GAMBLE is taking a nontraditional tack to help Tide, the best-selling detergent in America, fend off challenges from lower-priced rivals as strapped consumers continue to ponder practically every purchase.

title: Democrats Anxious Over a Once-Safe Seat
description: BOSTON  Martha M. Coakley, the Democrat running for Senator Edward M. Kennedys seat in Massachusetts, had seemed so certain of winning the special election on Jan. 19 that she barely campaigned last month.

title: Koppel Said to Be Talking With ABC About This Week
description: Ted Koppel, the former anchor of Nightline, may make a homecoming to ABC News.

title: Princeton Players Are Divided by Heritage, United by Basketball
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  When asked about their political views, cultures and backgrounds and whether they create problems for them on or off the basketball court, Niveen Rasheed and Lauren Polansky laugh simultaneously.

title: Google Applies to Become Power Marketer
description: Google is stepping up its forays into the energy world.

title: Britains Central Bank Leaves Key Rate and Stimulus Unchanged
description: The Bank of England left its benchmark interest rate and economic support programs unchanged Thursday, opting to wait for stronger recovery signals before following other major central banks in starting to dismantle stimulus measures.

title: Hospital Cuts Dialysis Care for the Poor in Miami
description: To chip away at an overwhelming budget deficit, Miamis public hospital system stopped paying for kidney dialysis for the indigent this week, officials said, leaving some patients to rely on emergency rooms for their life-sustaining treatments.

title: Lhasa de Sela, Singer Who Crossed Borders, Dies at 37
description: Lhasa de Sela, a Mexican-American singer and songwriter who became an international star after moving to Canada, died on Jan. 1 at her home in Montreal. She was 37.

title: An Unusual Duo Tests Conventional Song Forms
description: Creative friction that playfully undercuts conventional song forms in a search of greater expressive latitude might describe the collaboration of Michael Winther, a theater singer of impeccable taste and polish, and the jazz pianist Dan Tepfer in their show, Songs and Variations, at the Metropolitan Room on Monday evening.

title: Mad Family Day
description: Cutting, shredding, slashing and burning are usually processes associated with destruction. But on Saturday the Museum of Arts and Design will show children 5 and older how all that clipping and ripping can also play a role in creation.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Peers Hail Dawson, Hall of Famer and Expo Great
description: When Andre Dawson signed with the Chicago Cubs in 1987, submitting a blank-check contract during the height of collusion and working for less than half his salary from the year before, the Wrigley Field fans bowed to him from the bleachers.

title: A Jazz Singer Saunters Through Old and New
description: Giacomo Gates approaches jazz singing with a showmans poise and an aficionados zeal. Holding court on Wednesday night in the mezzanine lounge of the Kitano New York Hotel, he was solicitous but cool. He wanted to let his listeners in on a secret, bring them into his confidence. With his deep, cognac baritone and his vintage-hipster lexicon, he seemed an appreciative throwback, eager to share credit with his precursors while mindful of keeping a little for himself.

title: Murky Trail for Loner in Attack on C.I.A.
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Another blog posting appeared Thursday under the name of Abu Dujana al-Khorasani, eight days after the man who used that pseudonym blew himself up at a secret C.I.A. outpost in eastern Afghanistan. The headline: When will my words drink my blood?

title: With Little Fanfare, the Los Angeles Kings Are in the Playoff Chase
description: LOS ANGELES  When Anze Kopitar arrived in Edmonton for a game this season, he was leading the N.H.L. in scoring. So after the doors to the visiting locker room swung open, he got the royal treatment. Kopitar, a center for the Los Angeles Kings, quickly found himself at the center of about 25 cameramen and reporters  for a morning skate.

title: Repairs May Add to J.F.K.s Delays
description: The average delay at Kennedy International Airport lasts more than an hour; one in every five flights left late last year; and its performance ranks in the bottom third of major American airports.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Thunkless in the Name of Progress
description: This is hard to prove, but the betting here is that many New Yorkers will miss the thunk.

title: Further Slide Seen in Commercial Real Estate
description: There are 920 football fields of available office space in Manhattan. More than 180 major buildings totaling $12.5 billion in value  from Columbus Tower at 1775 Broadway to the office tower 400 Madison Avenue  are in trouble, meaning in many cases they face foreclosure or bankruptcy, or have had problems making mortgage payments. Rents for commercial office space fell faster over the past two years than in any such period in the last half century.

title: Seeking Grants, Paterson Urges Education Changes
description: Gov. David A. Paterson on Thursday proposed a host of changes in state education law, including eliminating the cap on the number of charter schools, which he said would make the state more likely to receive $700 million in federal grant money.

title: Charles Kleibacker, Fashion Designer, Dies at 88
description: Charles Kleibacker, a former fashion designer whose taste for intricately constructed gowns gave him the nickname Master of the Bias in the 1960s, died Sunday in Columbus, Ohio. He was 88.

title: The Loose Cannon in the Locker Room for the N.B.A.
description: Los Angeles

title: Fed Advice to A.I.G. Scrutinized
description: New revelations that the government stopped the American International Group from revealing information about its bailout had securities lawyers and policy makers buzzing on Thursday about whether the information had to be disclosed under federal securities law, and if so, what to do about the lack of compliance.

title: Finding Tender Humanity Among Those Forest Fairies
description: There are stretches in the first act of George Balanchines Midsummer Nights Dream when it grows hard to care for its bumbling human characters, all so blind to the woodland magic enveloping them in the darkness. Far better to root for the fairies, except that Shakespeare wrote a comedy, not a farce, and we must be made to feel for these frail mortals if the ballet is to touch on the plays rich depths.

title: Ex-Consultant Pleads Guilty in Galleon Insider Case
description: Anil, you are a hero.

title: Mother and Son, Inverting and Exploring Standards
description: In a competitive musical climate in which most performers shout to grab attention, the cabaret singer Sandy Stewart embodies an oracular calm. Pondering standards in a quiet, confiding alto with a rolling, sensual vibrato, she turns lyrics into intimate overheard streams of consciousness. As she sang a program of standards accompanied on piano by her son, the brilliant jazz pianist Bill Charlap, at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel on Wednesday evening, their concert offered a master class in subtle musical communication and interpretation.

title: Integrity Concerns Force Fox to Postpone Child Quiz Show
description: LOS ANGELES  The premiere of Our Little Genius, a new quiz show featuring child contestants that was scheduled to be broadcast on Fox next week after American Idol, has been postponed and possibly canceled, Fox announced Thursday, over concerns about the integrity of the show.

title: Sensible Rules to Regulate Risk
description: Sheila C. Bair looks to be leading the regulatory race to the top. The agency she oversees, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, recently unveiled a handful of clever ideas to contain risky bank behavior and protect the nations deposit insurance fund. Rival watchdogs fighting for turf will find it difficult to ignore the F.D.I.C.s latest tactics.

title: Home Fires: I Wanted to Be a Hero
description: Not too many weeks ago, I was honorably discharged from the Army. There was no fanfare, no hail and farewell party, no speeches. I finished out my eight-year enlistment with the Reserves quietly, simply having done my part, including a year-long combat tour in Iraq in 2003 and 2004.

title: Art in Review
description: THE PERPETUAL DIALOGUE

title: Still a Renegade After All These Years
description: It helps to think of time as cyclical, or at least non-Western and nonlinear, when encountering Joan Jonass Mirage at the Museum of Modern Art. The latest installation of a piece conceived in 1976, it suggests that Ms. Jonass art has a longer-than-usual lifespan because its constantly being reborn.

title: Despite Aiding U.S., Iraqi Is Denied a Green Card
description: CHICAGO  Nada Alkhaddar spends her days at the Muslim Women Resource Center helping refugees and immigrants deal with government and commercial bureaucracies that can make life in the United States seem about as easy as computing the Alternative Minimum Tax.

title: Cuba: American Not a Spy, U.S. Says
description: An unidentified American contractor arrested last month in Cuba for distributing communications equipment on the island was aiding a religious and cultural group and was not engaged in espionage activity, his employer, Development Alternatives Inc., said Thursday. A State Department spokesman, Philip J. Crowley, also denied Cuban claims that the man was a spy, Reuters reported.

title: NBC Wants Leno Back in Old Slot
description: Faced with the failure of the biggest recent gamble in television, NBC is shuffling its late-night deck one more time.

title: Kashmir: Gun Battle Kills 4
description: A 20-hour gun battle prompted by a deadly militant attack on a police outpost in Srinagar, in Indian-controlled Kashmir, ended Thursday after the police killed two militants, including a Pakistani citizen, Indian police officials said. A policeman and a civilian were killed, and 10 people were wounded. Kuldeep Khoda, the police chief of Jammu and Kashmir, said both militants belonged to Lashkar-e-Taiba, the terrorist group based in Pakistan that has been blamed for the 2008 attacks on Mumbai.

title: Potential Ford Senate Bid Sets Off Scramble
description: The New York political world reacted swiftly and strongly to the possibility of Harold Ford Jr.s candidacy for the United States Senate, with top Senate leaders trying to squash the bid and close advisers to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg meeting with Mr. Ford on Thursday to plot strategy for a campaign.

title: Seeking Greener Pastures
description: PERRI CESARELLI gets up at 5:30 a.m., takes the dog out, eats breakfast, showers, dresses, then, at 7:05 walks the 12 minutes to the train station in Little Neck, N.Y., leaving herself a five-minute buffer before catching the 7:22 into Manhattan.

title: F.B.I. Seizes Passport of Queens Man Scrutinized in Plot
description: F.B.I. agents on Thursday seized the passport of a Queens man who came under intense scrutiny last year during the investigation of an airport shuttle bus driver who was charged in a Qaeda bomb plot, law enforcement officials and the mans lawyer said.

title: Meet the Dude
description: Would the Dude be the Dude if not for Jeff Bridges? Its a question academics in the burgeoning field of Lebowski studies should ponder and one you can pose to Mr. Bridges himself this Saturday at the Film Society of Lincoln Center. Mr. Bridges, whose performance in Crazy Heart is being touted this year for an Oscar, will be on hand to discuss his long career, including his portrayal of the Dude in The Big Lebowski (1998) and his breakout in The Last Picture Show. That 1971 Peter Bogdanovich movie will be screened following the discussion.

title: Binge on Jazz
description: Winter Jazzfest, Nate Chinen writes, is for the moment the only real mainstream jazz festival in New York, and its lineup amounts to a temperature reading of the scene at ground level, where its most vibrant and volatile. At five Greenwich Village clubs this weekend you can hear how the aesthetic center of the music has broadened and loosened, yielding to many different strategies of rhythm, harmony and texture. Check out the new wave of hybrid acts like Vijay Iyer, who will appear with his trio and whose Historicity was the consensus pick among critics for best jazz album of 2009 as well as Darcy James Argues Secret Society, an ultramodern big band, the violinist Jenny Scheinman, the Claudia Quintet and more.

title: Thats Bull
description: It may come as a surprise, but P.B.R. doesnt just stand for a brand of beer beloved by hipsters; its also the initials of the Professional Bull Riders. Fans of either, or both, should head this weekend to the 2010 bull-riding invitational at Madison Square Garden. Converging on the Garden floor Friday through Sunday: 700 tons of dirt, the top 45 bull riders in the country and 2,000-pound bulls. Grab your cowboy hat and boots; ironic stance is optional. Tickets start at $10.

title: Arenas Image Is Pulled; Questions Are Raised
description: As professional sports leagues have moved deeper into the information media business  starting blogs, Web sites and television networks  they have taken on the look and feel of outlets run by fans and private news media outlets.

title: Lottery Numbers
Gambling Concerns Prompt an N.B.A. Team to Act
description: Before the Washington Wizards had a gun problem, they had a gambling problem  a high-stakes card game that ended in acrimony, threats and ultimately a locker-room showdown that has thrust the franchise into chaos.

title: Seeing Old Age as a Never-Ending Adventure
description: OCALA, Fla.  Ilse Telesmanich, 90, sprained her ankle hiking in South Africa last August. She tried to keep going on the three-week trip, she said, hobbled as she was.

title: Weak Heart
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Friday and Saturday crosswords are not for the weak of heart, but if youre not working through them yet, youll get there in time. Theyre satisfying in a different way than the themed puzzles that appear Monday through Thursday. Like a good single-malt scotch, perhaps, its an acquired taste that you gradually grow into and then get to feel smug and sophisticated. With crosswords, there is little definitive evidence of a link to liver problems, but please solve responsibly.

title: Deal Made to Monitor Brooklyn Hospital
description: New York City, the Justice Department and lawyers representing mentally ill patients at Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn, where a 49-year-old woman died in 2008 while waiting for treatment, said on Thursday that they had reached an agreement allowingthe Department of Justice and the suit's plaintiffs to monitor conditions at the hospital.

title: Timeline: 3-D Cinema
description: A look at some of the milestones in 3-D film over the years.

title: Half of States See Dip in Under-18 Population
description: Maine, Michigan, North Dakota and Vermont had net losses of about one in 10 of their young people from 2000 to 2009, as the populations of Northeastern and Midwestern states continued to age faster than those in the Sun Belt, according to new Census Bureau data.

title: Meters Bring Hardship, Washington Cabbies Say
description: WASHINGTON  A year and a half after meters were installed in taxis here, cabdrivers have seen their income drop 30 percent or more, representatives from the drivers associations said Thursday at a City Council hearing.

title: Top 3-Point Shooter From Downtown Plays in Upper Manhattan
description: There was a garbage can playing the part of a defender along the right part of the 3-point stripe. Noruwa Agho crouched over, the basketball in his hands. He made a quick dart to his left and released a rainbow from beyond the arc that swished through the net.

title: 2nd Chief Pleads Guilty in Surrogate Case
description: ST. CLAIRSVILLE, Ohio  An Ohio police chief pleaded guilty Thursday to a reduced charge in a case in which another chief was convicted of stealing items from the home of a surrogate mother for the movie stars Matthew Broderick and Sarah Jessica Parker.

title: Eight Years Later
description: President Obama was right to take responsibility for the near-catastrophic Christmas Day terrorist plot. The buck, as always, must stop with the president. And it was a relief to hear him candidly acknowledge widespread failures in the vast and vastly expensive intelligence and homeland security system and insist that his administration do better. It must.

title: The Work of War, at a Fever Pitch
description: LOVE is a drug, and so too is war in Kathryn Bigelows visceral and morally urgent Hurt Locker. A story about men and battle and the murderous highs of violence, the film is set in the Iraq of 2004, the year that the torture photographs from Abu Ghraib were revealed to the world, the year that four American contractors were murdered in Falluja, the year that the American military death toll reached 1,000. Written by a journalist, Mark Boal, who based the story on his experiences covering Iraq, it centers on a crew of technicians who spend their dusty days and eerie nights in and around Baghdad disarming bombs.

title: Inspired by Bird, Gallinari Boosts the Knicks
description: A few days ago Donnie Walsh handed Danilo Gallinari, the Knicks promising young forward, a DVD that could alter the trajectory of his career.
