Walsh, the Knicks president, gave Gallinari a collection of Larry Bird highlights, a captivating 30-minute compilation highlighting many of Birds best moves, passes, post-ups and rebounds.

title: Executives New Studio Teams Up With Yahoo
description: The former NBC entertainment co-chairman Ben Silverman has lined up his first distributor, Yahoo, for his new studio, which he says will specialize in creating shows in concert with advertisers.

title: Boy and Beasts, Human and Not
description: MOST of the action in Where the Wild Things Are takes place on an island of monsters, who roar their terrible roars and gnash their terrible teeth and, above all, try to work out their terrible emotional issues in the presence of a young boy named Max.

title: Selig Says He Is Open to Considering a U.S.-Japan World Series
description: For decades, the Japanese have been clamoring for a real World Series that pits the best team in Major League Baseball against the best team in Japan.

title: Mary Gardiner Jones, Consumer Advocate, Dies at 89
description: Mary Gardiner Jones, a prominent consumer advocate who as a member of the Federal Trade Commission in the 1960s and early 70s helped expand its purview to ensure that the stuff of American life  from clothing to cereal to cigarettes  was safer, less expensive and more truthfully advertised, died on Dec. 23 at her home in Washington. She was 89.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a possible bid by Harold Ford Jr., a former congressman from Tennessee, for the Senate seat held by Kirsten E. Gillibrand misstated, in some editions, the amount of money Ms. Gillibrand had raised as of Oct. 1, the amount Mr. Ford raised during his run for a Senate seat in Tennessee in 2006, and the percentage of Mr. Fords total that came from New York. Ms. Gillibrand had raised $5.5 million as of Oct. 1, not $4 million; Mr. Ford raised $15 million in 2006, not $20 million; and a fifth, not a quarter, of that total came from New York. The article also referred incorrectly to the election of Hillary Rodham Clinton, who held the Senate seat before Ms. Gillibrand. Mrs. Clinton was elected 10 months after she moved to New York, not two years, and she moved to New York from Washington, not from Arkansas.

title: The News Is Bad, the Bearers Stoic
description: It is a lazy summer day in a quiet New Jersey neighborhood decorated with yellow ribbons and American flags in Oren Movermans The Messenger. At an adjacent Army post Capt. Tony Stone (Woody Harrelson) and Sgt. Will Montgomery (Ben Foster) work as a team for the Armys casualty notification service, bringing the news to families when a loved one has died in Iraq.

title: Corrections
description: The Experience Necessary feature in some editions on Tuesday, about the master printer at Bowne & Company Stationers at the South Street Seaport Museum, misstated his surname in a passage in which he pointed out that his name is an anagram for Barrow Renter, and that he rents an apartment on Barrow Street. As the introduction to the article noted, he is Robert Warner, not Warren.

title: President Is Said to Decide to Renominate Six Choices
description: President Obama will renominate Dawn Johnsen to lead the Justice Departments powerful Office of Legal Counsel, along with his choices for five other jobs that the Senate did not act on last year, a White House official said Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 2 about Shaya Boymelgreen, a star of the New York real estate boom who has fallen on hard times, misstated part of the address of one of his apartment projects, in Brooklyns Dumbo neighborhood. It is at 42 Main Street, not 402. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message this week.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column on Thursday, about Consumer Reports review of 15 infomercial products, erroneously attributed a distinction to the PedEgg, a foot callous remover that the magazine recommended. PedEgg was one of two items recommended  not the only item that passed muster. (The Magic Jack, a phone device using voice over Internet protocol, was the other.)

title: After Super Bowl Catch, Tyree Is Just Hanging On
description: OWINGS MILLS, Md.  Kelley Washington was at the Baltimore Ravens training facility the day the man with the Velcro helmet walked in. This could have been an awkward moment. After all, Washington was standing on the New England sideline two years ago, the night that man, David Tyree, wedged the football against his helmet to extend the Giants winning drive in Super Bowl XLII and ruin the Patriots bid for a perfect season.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about SeeClickFix.com, a Web site that lets residents communicate with local government officials, misstated its use in The Local blogs at NYTimes.com. Only the blogs that cover communities in New Jersey use SeeClickFix; The Local blogs in Brooklyn do not use it.

title: Corrections
description: A Sports of The Times column on Thursday, about Nick Sabans place in history alongside Alabamas past football coaches, misstated, in some editions, the circumstances under which Coach Gene Stallings left the program after the 1996 season. He resigned; he was not fired.

title: Arrest of a Pediatrician Followed Years of Complaints
description: The Delaware pediatrician who prosecutors say may have molested more than 100 patients showed a pattern of inappropriate touching that led to multiple complaints from patients and co-workers, according to court documents released this week.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column on Wednesday, about the 1965 Orange Bowl game, between Alabama and Texas, the same teams that played in the Bowl Championship Series title game on Thursday night, misstated the given name of a tackle who helped stop Alabamas Joe Namath at the goal line on the games pivotal play. He is Diron Talbert, who played at Texas from 1964 to 1966  not Don, his brother, who played there from 1959 to 1961. The error was repeated on Thursday in a Sports of The Times column about Namaths memories of the game.

title: Arenas Suspension Has Limited Benefit to Wizards
description: The recent news surrounding Gilbert Arenas has generated a lot of questions.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review on Thursday about Pacific Northwest Ballet, at the Joyce Theater, misidentified the work described as too conscious of its effectiveness, too short of inner life while at the same time its skill of construction, all sharply timed to the Reich score, is something rare today. That work is 3 Movements by Benjamin Millepied  not Opus 111 by Twyla Tharp, another work on the program.

title: The Official Word to All, Get a Swine Flu Vaccination Now
description: Citing mistakes made in the 1957 flu pandemic, federal officials on Thursday urged hesitant Americans to get vaccinated now against swine flu to prevent any possibility of another wave of illness and deaths.

title: Jets Are Riding an Arctic Blast to Cincinnati
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Behind the Jets locker room at their practice facility is a room filled with equipment, and behind that is a storage room that on Thursday was stacked with bags, boxes and crates that were about to be loaded on a leased 26-foot truck bound for Cincinnati.

title: Corrections
description: An appraisal on Dec. 31 about David Levine, the caricaturist for The New York Review of Books who died on Dec. 29, may have left the incorrect impression that the Russian writer Aleksandr Pushkin, the subject of one of Mr. Levines drawings, was homosexual. The description of Pushkin as a gay man was a reference to his demeanor, not his sexual orientation.

title: Corrections
description: NEW YORK

title: A Push for Cleaner Air
description: Between them, the Obama administration and the federal courts have reversed most of the Bush administrations wrongheaded environmental regulations. But a few bad rules linger on the books, among them an inadequate health standard governing harmful ozone, which most people call smog.

title: Spineless in California
description: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California was on the mark when he said this week that the state needed to change policies that spend more money on prisons than on the states once-vaunted higher education systems, which are being bled to death in budget cuts. But Mr. Schwarzenegger was way off the mark when he suggested that the answer was to privatize prison services or to pass yet another constitutional amendment, this time to limit prison spending.

title: Avatars Dont Smoke
description: Somewhere in the afterlifes screening room, Will Hays, architect of Hollywoods old Production Code, and the stern Catholic bishops of the Legion of Decency are probably sharing a chuckle, maybe over Scotch and cigarettes. Why? The recent fuss over Avatar, the James Cameron film in which the latest in cinematic technology meets the oldest argument in the movies: whether vice on screen encourages vice in real life.

title: When Museums Sell Art to Raise Cash
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Democrats, a Struggle to Hold Seats
description: To the Editor:

title: As the Senate Turns
description: To the Editor:

title: Term Limits on the New York State Legislature
description: To the Editor:

title: Bubbles and the Banks
description: Health care reform is almost (knock on wood) a done deal. Next up: fixing the financial system. Ill be writing a lot about financial reform in the weeks ahead. Let me begin by asking a basic question: What should reformers try to accomplish?

title: The Messiah Complex
description: Readers intending to watch the movie Avatar should know that major events in the plot are revealed.

title: The Not-So-Secrets of the Temple
description: Pittsburgh

title: Give These Donors a Bone
description: EVERY year, more than 100,000 Americans discover that they have often life-threatening blood and bone-marrow diseases like leukemia. For many, the only hope is a transplant of blood-producing marrow cells.

title: Montreal Expos, Forgotten by Many, Are Reuniting in Cooperstown
description: There is an episode of Newhart, the 1980s sitcom set at a lodge in Vermont, in which George the handyman considers which baseball team to root for. The Montreal Expos were somewhat local, but they would not do.

title: New Standards for Rail Cars
description: Passenger trains must be manufactured to better withstand collisions under a federal rule to take effect in March that follows fatal accidents in New Jersey, Indiana and Maryland. Manufacturers like Bombardier Inc. must meet the new standards for trains sold to Amtrak and American commuter railroads. The rule requires stronger front-end frames on new passenger railcars and some locomotives to help prevent their collapsing or telescoping on impact.

title: A Cultural Bounty
description: The first half of January has become a time for a bountiful array of theater, music and dance festivals in New York City.

title: And on Your Left ... Never You Mind
description: WASHINGTON  Security rules imposed after the Christmas Day bombing attempt may diminish another one of the gee-whiz aspects of flying, the moments when the captain plays tour guide, pointing out landmarks to the passengers.

title: Scathing Report on the Killing of 4 Officers
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In an often-blistering report of a shootout last March that left four police officers in nearby Oakland dead, an independent board there has found that commanding officers made a series of hasty and ill-advised decisions that may have contributed to the death toll.

title: In Cubas Time Capsule, an Automotive Legacy
description: An article last Sunday about the Depsito del Automvil, Cubas antique auto museum, referred incorrectly to a car in the collection. It is a replica of a Maserati racecar driven by Juan Manuel Fangio, the five-time world champion, in 1957, not 1960.

title: A Special Visa Program Benefits Abused Illegal Immigrants
description: She was 14 when her mother smuggled her into Los Angeles. She met her future husband, a legal resident, two years later.

title: A Foreclosure Crisis Rooted, the Family Says, in Predatory Lending
description: Giuseppa Bagnarol, 82, was in her final hours in August, dying at home surrounded by the large family she presided over as matriarch.

title: Word of the Day | cerebration
description: cerebration \ser--bra-shn\ noun

title: Robert M. White Jr.
description: Mr. White, 45, is the founder and president of Real Capital Analytics, a Manhattan-based market research company that tracks commercial real estate sales and trends globally.

title: Corrections
description: A caption last Friday with an article about Argonne National Laboratorys shift from radioactivity to supercomputers referred incorrectly to the Experimental Boiling Water Reactor at the laboratory. The reactor was dismantled and its components removed almost 14 years ago; it is not scheduled to be dismantled.

title: For Those Who Want to Play the Field
description: Included on my list of New Years resolutions was an old favorite: a commitment to drink less  particularly on weeknights, particularly wine.

title: Alabama and Texas Battle for the National Title
description: A hard-hitting defense, an injured quarterback and an inconsistent freshman add up to a Crimson Tide championship.

title: Sorting Out Legislation
description: The California State Legislature convened this week to begin dealing with a projected $19.9 billion budget deficit over the next 18 months, a situation Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger described as our Katrina. Beyond the budget, state legislators have other issues to contend with, including these three legislative proposals, all of which arise from local concerns or incidents.

title: Way-Too-Early Top 10 for 2010
description: The celebration hasnt even ended here at the Rose Bowl and were already thinking about next year. And we do realize that these rankings could change considering many teams have crucial players needing to decide their N.F.L. futures. So feel free to mock us, but heres a way-too-early top 10 for 2010.

title: Alabama Returns to the Top
description: PASADENA, Calif.  Texas and Alabama played a teeth-gnashing, bloody-knuckles game that fit the style of their forefathers, Alabamas Bear Bryant and Texas Darrell Royal.

title: Shivering Strawberries
description: WHO have been working all night to save their strawberry crops?

title: A Texas Quarterback Story Line Takes a Decisive Plot Twist
description: PASADENA, Calif.  The Bowl Championship Series national title game Thursday night started with a story line of two Texas quarterbacks facing each other.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Wings Win on 51 Saves and a Last-Minute Goal
description: Ten games on Thursday, highlighted by a classic cliffhanger in Los Angeles, where the Red Wings won in a performance out of a move script. Home teams listed first:

title: Under the Radar 2010
description: Images from some of the shows in the annual performing arts festival.

title: News Quiz | January 8, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Arizona Concert Promoter Accused in Ponzi Scheme
description: A suburban Phoenix concert promoter has been accused of running a Ponzi scheme that bilked about 140 investors out of $25 million, federal authorities said Thursday.

title: A Special Visa Program and Highlights from Fridays Bay Area Report
description: Special Visa Benefits Abused Immigrants | Victims of domestic violence are often deeply reluctant to press charges, fearing retaliation or simply hoping their abusers will change. The risk of deportation only escalates the aversion to go to the police. One San Francisco woman endured such abuse, but now she legally lives in the country, thanks to what is known as a U visa  a humanitarian island of niceness, as one advocate called it, in a sea of restrictive United States immigration laws.

title: A Star Returns and So Do the Cheers
description: All apparently is forgiven for Jon Scheyer, the local basketball star. One of the most decorated prep players in Illinois history from 2003 to 2006, Scheyer was often booed during his senior year at Glenbrook North High School after announcing he would attend Duke University instead of the University of Illinois.

title: Lawyer Wants Oversight for Hiring
description: The lawyer responsible for federal oversight of hiring by the City of Chicago and Cook County now wants an independent monitor to patrol the personnel decisions of state government, too.

title: How Has the Digital Fishbowl Complicated Your Love Life?
description: Does Facebook make breaking up harder to do? Have you ever had an awkward moment in a relationship because of a text, e-mail or shared photo? A Style article this week looks at how services like these that connect us also make breaking up more difficult. Do you think thats true? Tell us about your experiences.

title: Big Bonuses at BofA, but Overall Pool Stays Level
description: Bank of America, the biggest lender in the United States, expects to pay record bonuses to some investment bankers while keeping the overall cost of incentive compensation below previous years, a company spokesman said, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Seeking Support in the Wrong Place
description: Gov. Patrick J. Quinn may impress some Hispanic voters by nominating Manuel Flores, above, the First Ward alderman, as chairman of the Illinois Commerce Commission. But the move did not go over well with Hispanic state legislators who have repelled challengers financed by the young, ambitious alderman.

title: Talks With Ferrero Over Cadbury Said to Fade
description: Already seen as a long-shot bidder, Italian chocolate maker Ferreros interest in Cadbury has cooled as the hurdles of getting financing and finding suitable partners before the deadline becomes increasingly daunting, sources familiar with the situation told Reuters.

title: Putting World Into Series?
description: For decades, the Japanese have been clamoring for a real world series that pits the best team in Major League Baseball against the best team in Japan.

title: The Agony of Colt McCoy
description: PASADENA, Calif.  Colt McCoy will end his time at Texas as the career leader for victories in college football by a quarterback, with 45. But any look at his career will always have a haunting, What if?

title: SocGen Sues Gundlach for Breach of Duty at TCW
description: TCW Group, the Los Angeles-based unit of Socit Gnrale, sued the former investment chief Jeffrey Gundlach and three former employees after more than half of its fixed-income professionals joined his new firm, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Ex-Consultant Pleads Guilty in Galleon Insider Case
description: Anil, you are a hero.

title: Fed Advice to A.I.G. Scrutinized
description: New revelations that the government stopped the American International Group from revealing information about its bailout had securities lawyers and policy makers buzzing on Thursday about whether the information had to be disclosed under federal securities law, and if so, what to do about the lack of compliance, Mary Williams Walsh writes in The New York Times.

title: Bernie Ecclestone to Buy Saab?
description: The car manufacturers may be drifting out of Formula One  or should I say flooding?  but Bernie Ecclestone, the chief executive of Formula One management, has not finished with car manufacturers yet. Hes making a bid to buy Saab in a joint deal with Genni Capital, which, by the way, is the company that bought into the Renault team.

title: Judge Tells Perelman to Pay Barkin Firm
description: In yet another chapter in the bitter divorce of Ron Perelman and the actress Ellen Barkin, a New York judge has ordered the billionaire financier to pay more than $4 million to a film development company he co-founded with his ex-wife.

title: Twitter Jail
description: Term used to describe the account suspension of overly loquacious Twitterers.

title: P.E. Fund-Raising Down 68% in 2009
description: Last year was miserable for private equity fund-raising in the United States. Hitting its lowest point since 2003, private equity fund-raising fell 68 percent to $95.8 billion across 331 funds, down from $300 billion across 508 funds in 2008, according to Dow Jones LP Source. No category of funds escaped the slowdown, except for secondary funds  a major outlier that saw a more than 50 percent increase in fund-raising, VentureBeat writes.

title: Even in Bad Year, Firms Register for I.P.O.s
description: Despite the grim numbers on venture-capital-backed initial public offerings this last year, PeHub, the forum for the private equity community, says that there are 28 companies registered to price their I.P.O.s in the United States.

title: British Banks Said to Buy Back Talent
description: Londons investment banks are luring back traders and analysts they lost to brokerage firms during the credit crisis, compensating for lower bonuses by as much as doubling base salaries, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Former Homestore Chief to Admit Fraud Conspiracy
description: The former chairman and chief executive of Homestore.com on Thursday agreed to plead guilty to conspiring to commit securities fraud in a scheme to inflate the companys revenue to win over Wall Street analysts.

title: Geely Mulls How to Build Volvos in China
description: Now that Geely Automotive has won the bidding for Swedens Volvo carmaker, Chinas No. 1 private automaker is making plans to set up a local production base, sources familiar with the company told Reuters.

title: Sensible Rules to Regulate Risk?
description: Sheila C. Bair looks to be leading the regulatory race to the top, Breakingviews says. The agency she oversees, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, recently unveiled a handful of clever ideas to contain risky bank behavior and protect the nations deposit insurance fund. Rival watchdogs fighting for turf will find it difficult to ignore the F.D.I.C.s latest tactics, the publication argues.

title: Janus Taps Pimco Executive as New Chief
description: Janus Capital Group has picked a Pacific Investment Management veteran as its chief executive, ending a months-long search for a new leader at the Denver-based stocks mutual fund firm.

title: Change in Japan a Tough Task for Finance Minister
description: TOKYO  It sounds like a script written for Hollywood: an idealistic reformer put in charge of cleaning up his nations most powerful center of entrenched bureaucratic influence.

title: Myanmar Is Reported to Sentence 2 to Death
description: BANGKOK  A court in Myanmar has sentenced a retired military officer and a Foreign Ministry official to death for leaking details of a secret trip to North Korea by top government officials, according to news reports that cited lawyers in the country.

title: Virgin Money Gets Its Bank at Last
description: Virgin Money finally found a way into retail banking, announcing Friday that it had reached an agreement to buy Church House Trust in a deal that values the regional bank at 12.3 million ($19.7 million).

title: Further Slide Seen in N.Y. Commercial Real Estate
description: There are 920 football fields of available office space in Manhattan. More than 180 major buildings totaling $12.5 billion in value  from Columbus Tower at 1775 Broadway to the office tower 400 Madison Avenue  are in trouble, meaning in many cases they face foreclosure or bankruptcy, or have had problems making mortgage payments.

title: For the Moment | The Future
description: Michele Caniato is the president of Culture and Commerce, a design management consultancy, and of Material Connexion, a materials consultancy and library; both companies are based in New York.

title: Shares End Mostly Higher, Helped by Retail Data
description: Wall Street traders set aside worries about looming interest rate increases on Thursday and focused on stronger-than-expected holiday sales, helping cement modest gains for stocks.

title: Saturdays N.F.L. Wild-Card Matchups
description: Jets at BengalsSaturday, 4:30 p.m. (NBC)Line: Bengals by 2 1/2

title: In Rome, Sinful Cantucci and Other Delights
description: In Tuscany, a small chocolatier rolls out pieces of dark chocolate by hand onto slabs of marble to protect its rich aroma from heat, then molds them into half-moon-shaped cookies and bakes them in a wood-fired oven. The chocolate cantucci  a sinful take on the traditional almond biscotti  are available in central Rome, where they can be sampled, along with other regional specialties, at Paciotti Salumeria (Via Marcantonio Bragadin, 51/53; www.paciottisalumeria.it; 39-06-3973-3646), a delicatessen near the Vatican. The cantucci, which are specially baked for the Paciotti family, have some claim to being the most delicious chocolate biscuits in Rome.

title: Sundays N.F.L. Wild-Card Matchups
description: Ravens at PatriotsSunday, 1 p.m. (CBS)Line: Patriots by 3 1/2

title: Italy Puts Swiss Tax Haven Under Siege
description: Italy and Switzerland have been waging a quiet border war lately, and the picturesque town of Lugano, Switzerland, on the shores of an Alpine lake, is caught in the cross-fire, The New York Timess John Tagliabue writes.

title: Executives New Studio Teams Up With Yahoo
description: The former NBC entertainment co-chairman Ben Silverman has lined up his first distributor, Yahoo, for his new studio, which he says will specialize in creating shows in concert with advertisers, The New York Timess Brian Stelter reported.

title: A Safety Net That Tangles Investors
description: In the wake of a series of Ponzi schemes  the most notable being the Bernard Madoff fraud  the Securities and Exchange Commission voted last month to tighten the rules and make it much harder for money managers to misappropriate client funds, The New York Timess Floyd Norris writes in his latest High & Low Finance column.

title: Partners Near Default on Stuyvesant Town
description: The owners of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, the sprawling sister complexes overlooking the East River in Manhattan, will miss a $16 million loan payment on Friday, which would put them in technical default on their mortgages, and the 20,000 residents in limbo, The New York Timess Charles V. Bagli reported.

title: Take 5: Cultural Doings Around the Bay
description: Wondering what to do this weekend? Weve got you covered.

title: New Bids Emerge for G.M.s Saab Unit
description: Saabs prospects for survival hung in the balance Friday as its owner, General Motors, weighed new offers for its Swedish unit, including one backed by the billionaire Formula One racing chief Bernie Ecclestone, The New York Timess Jack Ewing reports.

title: Goldman Sued by Pension Fund Over Bonus Plans
description: If Goldman Sachs was hoping that furor over its bonus payouts was subsiding, the bank might be disappointed by the latest development.

title: Homer Simpson vs. Mickey Mouse
description: Todays idea: Disneys animated classics are primarily visual, but The Simpsons are meant to be heard, says an essay parsing the distinctions between two celebrated opposites of animation.

title: Ammunition Explodes at a House in Pakistan, Killing 7
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A house in Karachi where militants appeared to have been storing ammunition for terrorist strikes was destroyed in a deadly explosion early Friday morning, police officials said.

title: American Said to Lift JAL Offer to $1.4 Billion
description: In the battle for control of Japan Airlines, American Airlines has apparently raised the stakes.

title: R.B.S. Sells Fund Operations to Aberdeen
description: Royal Bank of Scotland said Friday it had agreed to sell part of its asset management businesses to Aberdeen Asset Management in its latest effort to recovery from the financial crisis.

title: The Making of the Militarys Standard Arms
description: In a pair of posts late last year (Part 1, Part 2), this blog covered several arguments surrounding the American militarys primary rifles, the M-16 and M-4, which are also widely used by police departments, counterterrorism units and other federal agencies. (Among those using M-4 rifles are the C.I.A., the State Department and the New York Police Department.)

title: How the World Balances Health Care Risk
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

title: Redstone Sells Russian Theaters to Daughter
description: National Amusements, the holding company controlled by Sumner Redsone, is selling its Russian theater chain to Mr. Redstones daughter and other investors in a further move to reduce its debt, The Associated Press reports.

title: Behind the Warner Bros. and Netflix Accord
description: Earlier this week, Netflix cut a deal with Warner Bros. that will delay the availability of new Warner movies to Netflix subscribers by almost a month but expand the number of older Warner films available for digital streaming.

title: Lawson Buys Healthvision for $160 Million Cash
description: Lawson Software, a maker of business software, said Friday that it had agreed to acquire the privately held Healthvision Solutions for $160 million.

title: Sampler: Bankruptcies Up, Parking Tickets Down, Deadheads Milling in Mill Valley
description: Stricter Air Standards Proposed | The Bay Area and other urban regions would be forced to do more to reduce pollution from cars and industries if health standards for smog proposed by the Environmental Protection Agency on Thursday become final. For the Bay Area, this would mean more Spare the Air days and other measures. We are going to have to work harder at cleaning the air, said Lisa Fasano, a spokeswoman for the nine-county Bay Area Air Quality Management District. Failure to meet federal standards can result in loss of federal highway funds. [The Contra Costa Times, The New York Times]

title: The Newark Airport Security Breach
description: Footage of the security breach at Newark Liberty Airport on January 3.

title: After Months of Scrutiny in Zazi Terrorism Case, Two Arrests Came as a Surprise
description: For nearly four months, since the terrorism investigation focused on a Denver airport shuttle bus driver burst into public view and he was charged in what the authorities say was an Al Qaeda bomb plot, investigators have kept close tabs on two men from his old neighborhood in Flushing, Queens.

title: A Family Property at Risk
description: Fridays Barbary Coast column is about a Redwood City family on the verge of losing its homestead. The property looks like a slice of Positano in Silicon Valley, peppered with three homes on a steep countryside hill. Eight people live on the grounds.

title: Churches Attacked in Malaysian Allah Dispute
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Three Christian churches were attacked with firebombs Friday as tensions rose in a dispute over whether Christians could use the word Allah in this largely Muslim nation.

title: Speed Read for Friday, Jan. 8
description: Highlights from media coverage in todays New York Times:

title: Reflections on Chinas Oil Sands Bid
description: State-owned companies like PetroChina are probably going to be in the market for more energy deals in Canada due to that countrys high dollar, said the former Clinton administration trade official Patrick Mulloy, a member of the United States-China Economic and Security Review Commission.

title: U.S. Job Losses in December Dim Hopes for Quick Upswing
description: The nation lost 85,000 jobs from the economy in December, the Labor Department reported Friday, as hopes for a vigorous recovery ran headlong into the prospect that paychecks could remain painfully scarce into next year.

title: Detroit Auto Show: A Green Preview
description: The auto industry is still in austerity mode when it comes to car shows. The North American International Auto Show in Detroit begins press previews on Monday, and according to Jim Henry, reporter for CBS Interactive, The list of 19 brands holding a press conference is shorter than the list of 26 that arent.

title: The Early Word: Unemployment at 10%
description: With the Obama administration signaling that it intends to shift focus toward jobs and the economy, the newest unemployment figures  released this Friday morning for December  show the rate holding steady at 10 percent.

title: Lost Decade: Reason to Expect Better?
description: At the end of 1999, the Labor Department counted 110 million private sector jobs. The figure for the end of 2009, announced today and subject to numerous revisions before we get a final figure, was 108.4 million.

title: Court Says Swiss Order on UBS Data Broke Law
description: Update | 10:36 a.m. A Swiss court said Friday that the countrys financial regulator had broken the law when it ordered UBS to hand over data on nearly 300 clients suspected of tax evasion to United States authorities last February.

title: C.E.S. 2010: Explosion of E-Book Readers
description: Brad Stone on the proliferation of e-book readers at this year's Consumer Electronics Show.

title: A Conversation With Elizabeth Gilbert
description: Elizabeth Gilbert, the author of Eat, Pray, Love, sits down with Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, to talk about what led her to write her latest book, "Committed."

title: The Morning Feed
description: What were reading on Friday morning.

title: New Yorks Big Buildings Command Small Prices
description: There are 920 football fields of available office space in Manhattan. More than 180 major buildings totaling $12.5 billion in value  from Columbus Tower at 1775 Broadway to the office tower 400 Madison Avenue  are in trouble, meaning in many cases they face foreclosure or bankruptcy, or have had problems making mortgage payments. Rents for commercial office space fell faster over the past two years than in any other such period in the last half-century.

title: The Nifty 50 | Geoff Johns, Comic Book Writer
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

description: Another former employee at Steven A. Cohens SAC Capital has reportedly been caught up in an insider trading probe.

title: Formula One Boss in New Bid for Saab
description: From our colleagues at DealBook:

title: Late-Night Hosts Joke About Latest Late-Night Chaos
description: Once again, the lives of the late-night comedians provided them with plenty of fodder for their topical monologues  and for once, the focus wasnt on David Letterman. As news broke on Thursday that NBC was planning to remove Jay Leno from his 10 p.m. time slot and return him to an 11:35 p.m. show, at least a couple of the performers affected by this move couldnt resist joking about it in their Thursday-night acts.

title: O Tannen-boom
description: Video | A post-holiday recycling idea:

title: A Double Dip?
description: The American economy lost 85,000 nonfarm payroll jobs in December, according to a government report released today. This was far worse than the median forecast  which had payrolls staying flat  put out Thursday.

title: Shares Post Small Gains Despite Weak Jobs Report
description: A grimmer-than-expected report on employment rattled Wall Street on Friday, but a late rally in industrial and energy shares helped the major indexes end the first week of 2010 in positive territory.

title: Comparing This Recession to Previous Ones: Job Losses
description: The economy lost 85,000 jobs in December, worse than most forecasters had expected.

title: Me, Campaign? Just Go to the Film
description: ATLANTA

title: The Labor Picture in December
description: The jobs report in December was far worse than expected.

title: In Europe and U.S., Data Shows Murky Job Outlook
description: PARIS  The euro area has joined the United States in reaching a 10 percent unemployment rate as the American economy lost more jobs than expected in December, according to statistics released Friday.

title: Graphic Books Best-Seller List
description: The first volume of Marvels Dark Avengers series, written by Brian Michael Bendis and illustrated by Mike Deodato, enters our paperback list at No. 6 this week. This new team emerged from Secret Invasion, an event mini-series that pitted Marvels heroes against a race of alien of shapeshifters up to no good. The final blow to the alien threat was delivered by Norman Osborn, the former Green Goblin, who became admired through out the world. Alas, his bad behavior was not behind him. He assembled a team of Avengers who looked familiar  Wolverine! Spider-Man! Ms. Marvel!  but are actually super-villains. This collection, Assemble, chronicles their story.

title: Asked & Answered | Charlie Le Mindu
description: Wigs will never be the same after Charlie Le Mindu. Le Mindu, a 23-year-old designer known not just for his towering wigs but also for making clothes and accessories out of human hair, has set off a craze for avant-garde hair confections in London and around the world. Recently, Lady Gaga has been turning up in Le Mindu wigs. A native of Bordeaux, France, Le Mindu also has the distinction of being the only designer at London fashion week  or any fashion week, for that matter  to put on a show focused entirely on wigs. The Moment dropped by Le Mindus East London loft for a chat over tea.

title: Bad, but Still Getting Better
description: This mornings jobs report was certainly disappointing.

title: Michael Pollan Offers 64 Ways to Eat Food
description: How did your great grandparents ever figure out what to eat? Long before nutrition scientists began studying food, long before marketers began advertising food and long before the author Michael Pollan started writing about food, people, somehow, managed to eat more healthfully than they do now.

title: Friday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Being Clooney: Not as Easy as It Looks
description: THERES no mystery, none at all, about why George Clooney is a movie star. Guys who are extremely handsome, move well, can project intelligence and humor, appear to enjoy the company of women and possess soft, deep masculine voices have historically done pretty nicely for themselves on the silver screen.

title: Stray Questions for: Martha McPhee
description: Martha McPhee is the author of three novels, most recently LAmerica. Her fourth, Dear Money, will be published this spring.

title: Estonian TV News Meets The Simpsons
description: According to the viral video charts on Mag.ma  set up by the video news blog pioneers behind Rocketboom  this note-perfect Estonian television ad for an evening news show, which reimagines the opening of The Simpsons set in rural Estonia, is a cult hit on YouTube:

title: A 14-Day Restaurant Week
description: John Deermount, chairman of the volunteer committee that put together the 2010 Montclair Restaurant Week, to be held Jan. 25 to Feb. 7, remembers last years inaugural event very well.

title: As More Go Hungry, The Neediest Cases Offers Help
description: A growing number of families in the United States are having trouble putting food on the table. According to federal data, in 2009, 49 million people lacked consistent access to adequate nutrition, an increase of 13 million from 2008. Short of cash, parents are forced to make difficult decisions. To make their money stretch farther, they may buy cheaper, less nutritious foods, cut back on meals or skip meals altogether so another member of the family can eat instead. More people are relying on food stamps, but they do not always cover a family's needs. This year, safety nets like food pantries and soup kitchens have had less resources and have faced increasing demand. Below, the seven agencies supported by the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund discuss how the fund helped families not go hungry.

title: Times to Turn Over Local Brooklyn Blog to CUNY J-School
description: The New York Times is turning over day-to-day control of a blog covering parts of Brooklyn to the City University of New York Graduate School of Journalism, in what could be a model for expanding hyper-local coverage to many communities at minimal cost.

title: Maggie, Part 2: An Insiders View of the Indie World
description: Maggie Gyllenhaal is not just a lauded actress and an enthusiastic Brooklynite, she is also something of an expert on how indie movies get sold and marketed, as the Bagger discovered over a recent lunch (at a family-run restaurant in Brooklyn, of course). In Ms. Gyllenhaals latest, Crazy Heart, the directorial debut of Scott Cooper, an actor, she plays the love interest of Jeff Bridgess alcoholic country singer; it also stars Robert Duvall as his old friend and features music by T-Bone Burnett. Yet it very nearly fell to the straight-to-DVD ranks before being scooped up and thrust into the Oscar race late in the year. Now Mr. Bridges is being touted as the best actor front-runner, and, in the year of the 10, the film itself is a dark horse for best picture. (But dont expect the movies good fortune to be reflected in the fortunes of its couple. Jeff always makes this joke, Ms. Gyllenhaal said, like, oh theyre going to get together in the sequel, and its going to be called Crazy Liver. ) Here is Part 2 of our conversation; Part 1, now updated with more answers, is here.

title: Eat Like the King
description: Elvis Presley would have been 75 today, a man in full. He died at Graceland, his Memphis mansion, on August 16, 1977. The Commercial Appeal of Memphis is going wide with the story.

title: Changing of the Guard at City Room
description: Joe Sexton, metropolitan editor of The New York Times, announced a major change for City Room on Friday morning.

title: Modcloth Shows How to Win by Losing
description: Modcloth co-founders Susan Gregg Koger (chief creative officer) and Eric Koger (chief executive) started selling vintage clothing online as undergraduates at Carnegie Mellon University. In 2005, they were too junior to compete in their schools high-tech business plan competition, the McGinnis Venture Competition (which is listed in our guide to business plan competitions). Instead, they pitched at Colorado State Universitys Venture Adventure  and lost.

title: Now Showing | Wieki Somers On Ice
description: Perfectly apropos of the frigid winter that seems to have settled over the United States and parts of Europe, Frozen in Time, by Studio Wieki Somers, opens Jan. 30 at Galerie Kreo in Paris. For this exhibition  which was inspired by a major ice storm in the Netherlands in 1987  Somers, a Dutch designer, and Dylan van den Berg, her collaborator in the studio, took everyday objects  a stool, an architects lamp, a vase  and covered them in UV Topcoat, a liquid resin that hardens, or freezes, when exposed to sunlight, making the objects appear to be covered with a thick glaze of ice. For Somers, the subject was irresistible. The half-transparent ice connected things in a matter-of-fact and extremely poetic way, she explained in the news release for the exhibition. It also added another layer of meaning to familiar objects  an idea that permeates Somerss work, like the Bathboat, a bathtub with the exterior of a rowboat, or the High Tea Pot, which is cast in porcelain from a pigs skull. Frozen in Time runs until March 20.

title: TV Calendar: New Shows in the New Year
description: January marks the midpoint of the traditional television season, a time when networks once introduced a few new shows to replace egregiously bad ones from the fall.

title: Meet the Wheel of Fortune Player Who Didnt Say Self-Potato
description: Update | 2:47 p.m.  In most cases, winning $3,000 on a game show would be a happy occasion. But Michael Newman, who recently accomplished the feat on an episode of Wheel of Fortune, feels a bit conflicted about his windfall: hes the contestant who gave the correct response of self-portrait only after a rival player, Lolita McAuley, buzzed in first and gave the now-famous answer of self-potato.

title: G.M. Hires AlixPartners to Wind Down Saab
description: Update | 2:28 p.m. A delegation from the Swedish government is heading to Detroit on Saturday to plead General Motors for Saabs survival, The Financial Times reports. We still hope there is a chance of a deal but every day that passes makes it harder, Joran Hagglund, Swedens state secretary for industry, told the newspaper, adding that he was surprised by G.M.s hiring of AlixPartners.

title: Brennan and Napolitano Address Changes
description: John O. Brennan, President Obama's chief counterrorism adviser, and Janet Napolitano, the homeland security secretary, discussed security changes in the wake of the attempted airplane bombing on Christmas Day.

title: A Ceremony for Everyone (in Hollywood)
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Endgame
description: I suppose its a kind of solace in these difficult economic times that Norway, the country with, by some measures, the worlds highest per capita income (well, except for Luxembourg), can still produce a novel as unrelentingly without hope as Siamese. It bespeaks a certain clarity of vision.

title: The Man Without the Prosthetic Nose
description: Los Angeles

title: What to Watch This Weekend: John Oliver Stands Up
description: John Oliver, the deadpan dude with the British accent, is the most consistently funny correspondent on The Daily Show With Jon Stewart. On Friday night at 11 p.m. we find out how transferable his comedic skills are as he hosts John Olivers New York Stand-Up Show, a new series. Mr. Oliver brings us some of his favorite comics. Is stand-up comedy dead? Well find out. (Dave Itzkoff interviews Mr. Oliver here.)

title: For Expatriates in China, Creative Lives of Plenty
description: BEIJING

title: Crystalline Affliction
description: In myths and fairy tales, characters frequently shapeshift. Arachne becomes a spider. Midas daughter turns to gold. A frog winds up a prince. These stories speak to a persistent human concern: Our lives as we know them are temporary, subjected to merciless change. Merciless change is on full display in The Girl With Glass Feet, Ali Shaws fantastically imagined first novel. The story is as straightforward as the title suggests: Ida Maclaird, the books protagonist, has feet that are turning to glass.

title: Unraveling the Mystery of Affordable Housing
description: Affordable to whom?

title: Answers About Roth I.R.A. Conversions: Part 1
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks in which youll have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Angels and Hormones
description: Girls, girls, girls. As any observer of playground politics can tell you, the dynamics in groups of girls are awe-inspiring, if not a little frightening. Their social drive can be intense, heady with love and aggression. Add God to the mix and the combustion reverberates through the heavenly choirs.

title: The Google Nexus One Phone
description: David Pogue reviews Google new offering: the Nexus One cellphone.

title: Complaint Box | Packaging
description: Still havent managed to open those blister-packed headphones you got for Christmas? Perhaps youre waiting for the cuts on your fingers to heal before giving it another try. You are not alone.

title: More Perfect
description: Mississippi did not ratify the 13th Amendment, the one that abolished slavery, until 1995.

title: C.E.S. Daily Journal: Day 1
description: Sam Grobart, The Times's personal technology editor, looks at some of the products and spectacle at this year's Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.

title: Love in the Time of Genocide
description: Kim Echlins novel The Disappeared contains many elements that might doom a lesser book: the deaths of multiple characters (among them the narrators baby); an unabashedly effusive love story; a mix of first- and second-person narration; and, as a setting, the bones and ashes of the Cambodian genocide, which claimed approximately 1.7 million lives between 1975 and 1979. Yet the book manages to be spellbinding.

title: BlogTalk: Hitting the Right Note on Responsibility
description: President Obama stood behind a lectern at the White House State Dining Room on Thursday, and said that the buck stops with me when it came to the intelligence lapses that led to the attempted Christmas Day airline bombing.

title: Shots Fired at Iran Opposition Leaders Car, Son Says
description: In yet another sign of escalating tensions in Iran, pro-government demonstrators shot at the armored car of the countrys most outspoken opposition leader, Mehdi Karroubi, his Web site Saham News reported Friday.

title: Payrolls and paradigms
description: Disappointing job number this morning. Still, a month is just a month, right? Well, not quite.

title: Return of the King
description: Maybe theres no need to ask why a biographer of Jenny Uglows caliber and aesthetic interests  George Eliot, William Hogarth and Elizabeth Gaskell are just a few of her fortunate subjects  would take up the oft-told tale of Charles IIs restoration to the British throne. Its a great story: The boy king, in exile after his fathers execution in a populist uprising, grows up to return as monarch, only to face epochal disasters like the plague and the Great Fire of London. Throw in the handsome kings wandering eye (poor barren Queen Catherine had to put up with Charless bankrolling of one mistress after another, as well as the welcoming to court of his illegitimate children); an ABC of conniving ministers (Arlington, Buckingham, Clarendon); and a cluster of brilliant minds (Hobbes and Locke, Milton and Marvell, Newton, Dryden and the inveterate diarist Pepys), and its clear why chronicling this vital era became irresistible. But Uglow does more than narrate the dramatic events of the Restoration, a period known, not coincidentally, for its theater, which often parodied royal affairs.

title: Weekend Competition: Linguistic Fingernails Down a Blackboard
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to share the words they loathe.

title: The Facts About Farming
description: Russ Parsons has long been one of our most thoughtful food writers  the fact that he and I have known one another for 15 years or more and agree on most everything that has to do with food is possibly relevant here  and his short essay about moving forward beyond the black-and-white issues surrounding food and agriculture is both stimulating and important. Read it here.

title: Travel Deals: Virgin America Flight Sale
description: More New Years airline deals, this time from Virgin America, which is offering bubbly low fares starting at $39 one way. Book by Jan. 11 for travel through March 10. Sample fares include:

title: Ford Enters the App Business
description: LAS VEGAS  Were the coolest app of all, Alan Mulally, Fords chief executive, said here Thursday in announcing the automakers foray into the burgeoning computer application business.

title: Houston, We Have a Problem
description: Many books have been published to celebrate the 40th anniversary of the 1969 landing of the first men on the moon. Wayne Biddles Dark Side of the Moon is not celebratory. As the title suggests, it is a deeply skeptical account of the early life and career of Wernher von Braun, who played a key role in the German rocket program before and during World War II. Von Braun was brought to America in 1945 and was later the leader in developing the Saturn V booster rocket that launched the Apollo 11 mission into space. A NASA Web site describes him as without doubt, the greatest rocket scientist in history.

title: Dareuss Big Plays Surprised Even Him
description: Pasadena, Calif.

title: How Other Countries Regulate Premiums
description: Our colleagues at Economix have posted an interesting item by Uwe E. Reinhardt, professor of economics at Princeton University, on the mechanisms used in other nations to equalize premiums for citizens. Writes Dr. Reinhardt:

title: Home Tool
description: I had a revelation recently: a womans place is not in the home; its from the home! The good old home, with its dishes and dust, is, history has shown, not quite satisfying in itself. But maybe its a headquarters! In fact, turn your attention away from the kitchen and the bedrooms to the laptops, the cable, the e-readers, the smartphones, the high-speed triple-play tangle. Tricked out with telecommunications that could have serviced all of I.B.M. in 1950, the bourgeois home has become a womans base of operations. Try it: Hi, boss. Today Im staying home. Staying from home. Im working from home.

title: Deconstructing Dubai: Considering Questions Posed By the New Worlds Tallest Building
description: Overview | On January 4, Dubai officially became the home of the worlds tallest building. What does the Burj Khalifa represent and mean for Dubai? In this lesson, students consider the culture and landscape of Dubai and the significance of the Burj Khalifa. Then, depending on the activities you choose, they further investigate Dubai and its people, or research and critique buildings that are familiar to them, reflecting on their local or national significance.

title: Nuclear Monopolist
description: Early in the morning of Aug. 29, 1949, a mushroom cloud soared up over the Kazakh deserts. The Soviets had detonated their first atomic bomb, a thrilling feat of engineering and physics. The man who had supervised the effort, the pitiless chief of the secret police, Lavrenti Beria, raced to telephone Stalin. But when the leader came on the line he declared that he already knew and hung up.

title: One health care reform, indivisible
description: Jonathan Chait reads Peggy Noonan, so I dont have to:

title: For the New Year, Cost-Effective Options to Stop Smoking
description: LIKE many ex-smokers, Tonya Guess, 33, of Chesapeake, Va., tried just about everything to quit. There were hundreds of nicotine patches, an online support group, a prescription for an antidepressant and another prescription for Chantix, a drug that helps quell nicotine cravings.

title: Health Care, the Unstoppable Force
description: Health care is taking over the economy, especially if you look at the job market.

title: CSI: Trimeris-Arigene
description: Earlier this week, the biopharmaceutical company Trimeris terminated its $85 million sale to Arigene, a South Korean health care manufacturer.

title: Howard Stern Show Says Its Keeping Artie Lange
description: An executive for Sirius XM radio said that the comedian Artie Lange would remain a part of The Howard Stern Show and would be welcomed back to the program when he recovered from a hospitalization. In remarks made Friday on The Howard 100 News, a news broadcast that is played on Sirius XM radio and covers matters related to Mr. Sterns show, Tim Sabean, the senior vice president of the Howard Stern channels said, Artie is very much a part of these channels, and we look forward to Arties fast recovery and we wish him all the best.

title: The Cost of Stop-Smoking Aids
description: Studies show that at least one in three smokers want to kick the habit. Smoking is a powerful addiction, and sometimes the costs associated with smoking cessation can create a psychological barrier to quitting, writes Walecia Konrad in todays Patient Money column.

title: A Muckraking Blogger Focuses on Jews
description: ST. PAUL

title: What Scandal in Bohemia? An Endorsement for Sherlock Holmes
description: Though the new Guy Ritchie film Sherlock Holmes has elicited a range of responses from fans and critics  some loved it, some say it made them want to leap off Reichenbach Falls  the movie has nonetheless received an enthusiastic endorsement from one person connected to Arthur Conan Doyles famous detective.

title: Stung Together
description: Douglas Coupland, zeitgeist chronicler, furniture designer and defender of the Helvetica font, may or may not be interested in saving the world. But in his 11th novel, Generation A, he not only addresses our contemporary spiritual malaise  one brought on in part by information technology, vapid pop culture, environmental disregard and all the trade-offs humans have made in giving up connection for connectivity  he also offers us a form of salvation: the story.

title: Up Front: Curtis Sittenfeld
description: As a 34-year-old woman whos surely in the core demographic of Eat, Pray, Love readers, Ive had literally dozens of conversations about the book, Curtis Sittenfeld wrote in a recent e-mail message.

title: The Perils of Contact Me
description: I opened my e-mail in-box recently and found the following message from someone I did not previously know or know of, asking for my help in adjudicating a dispute in an online forum:

title: Blood Ties
description: Twelve books into a series of mysteries set in England in the aftermath of World War I, the mother and son who team-write under the name of Charles Todd keep finding new ways to gauge the emotional effects of war on the living and the half-dead. The story behind THE RED DOOR (Morrow/HarperCollins, $24.99) is so sad, the book should come with a warning sticker. It begins in Hobson, a village in Lancashire, on the day after the Armistice is signed  at the 11th hour on the 11th day of the 11th month of the year 1918  when Florence Teller hits on a suitable gesture to welcome her husband home from the war, painting the gray front door of their house a vibrant and glorious red.

title: The Americanization of Mental Illness
description: AMERICANS, particularly if they are of a certain leftward-leaning, college-educated type, worry about our countrys blunders into other cultures. In some circles, it is easy to make friends with a rousing rant about the McDonalds near Tiananmen Square, the Nike factory in Malaysia or the latest blowback from our political or military interventions abroad. For all our self-recrimination, however, we may have yet to face one of the most remarkable effects of American-led globalization. We have for many years been busily engaged in a grand project of Americanizing the worlds understanding of mental health and illness. We may indeed be far along in homogenizing the way the world goes mad.

title: Vonn Shakes Off Pain, Regains World Cup Lead
description: American skier Lindsey Vonn is on a major roll, and her painfully bruised left arm isnt getting in the way.

title: Kandinsky Helps Guggenheim Set Record Attendance
description: Having celebrated its 50th anniversary last year in the spiral that Frank Lloyd Wright designed for it, the Guggenheim Museum is now celebrating the numbers it counted during, and after, the celebration: it set new attendance records for 2009.

description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Katy Sparks Out at Bussaco
description: The soap opera continues! Katy Sparks has ended her relationship with Bussaco, Scott Carneys Park Slope restaurant, which she had joined as a partner and chef back at the start of December. Irreconcilable differences, said the restaurants publicist, Steven Hall, in a telephone interview. Katy said white, Scott said black.'

title: Correction
description: An earlier version of this article posted online misstated the country where Vestas, a wind-turbine producer, is based. It is Denmark, not Spain. It also misstated the number of turbines to be built in a project off the British coast and the name of a group that estimated the pace of construction. The project is to total about 6,000 turbines, not 1,000, and the forecast came from Carbon Trust, a group financed by the British government. (Carbon Trust Investments is its venture-capital arm.)

title: Paperback Row
description: LARK AND TERMITE,  by Jayne Anne Phillips (Vintage Contemporaries, $14.95.) A young soldier dies in Korea in 1950 while his wife gives birth back home; nine years later, in West Virginia, their profoundly disabled yet beautiful and calm son is lovingly cared for by his half-sister. In this novel, a 2009 National Book Award finalist, Phillips tells their story from alternating points of view with rich language and deep sympathy. This is the alchemy of great fiction, Kathryn Harrison wrote in the Book Review. The fantastic dream thats created . . . is one the reader enters without ever looking back.

title: Did You Pick an Activity to Impress an Admissions Officer?
description: One of the ways that some students and their parents try to game the admissions process at highly selective colleges is to choose extracurricular activities in hopes of catching the fancy of an admissions officer.

title: Editors Choice

He offered a dollar bill to an official during one game this season and donned a sombrero and a poncho after a touchdown in another. Those stunts cost him $50,000 in fines from the league.

title: With B.C.S. Done, Spring Must Be Near

After more than a month of blather and speculation, of head coach worship and quarterback coronations, of baying at multiple full moons, it makes the Super Bowl look like an instantly conceived pickup game by comparison. So when you hang with all that and still care on Jan. 7 and are handed a complete deflation five Texas snaps into the game, it really makes you want a refund. For something. Your microwave popcorn. Anything.

title: Sci-Fi Films Oscar-Worthy? Discuss
description: One of the (stated) reasons that the Academy moved to 10 best picture nominees this year is to include more populist fare. (The unstated reasons, as Michael Cieply explores in a piece in this weekends special Oscar section, have more to do with boosting the telecasts sagging TV ratings.) Movies like Star Trek, which made both box-office-watchers and critics happy, would seem tailor-made for the 10. And Star Trek did get one of the 10 slots on the Producers Guild of America ballots, alongside another sci-fi favorite, District 9. But, with a few exceptions, like The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring, the Academy has historically shown little love to films that explore the futuristic great beyond, the could-have-been past or the alternate-reality present. Its not quite as strong as those fogies anti-comedy bias, but its there.

Since then, he has quietly built an authentic, grass-roots brand that balances Southern gentility with rock n roll appeal. His well-tailored suits  Reid travels among his seven boutiques to do custom fittings share store space with clothes and accessories that wouldnt be out of place at a duck-hunting weekend or a honky tonk in Muscle Shoals. title: Replacement Costs
description: When I checked into a hotel in California, I was starving, so I ate the $6 box of Oreos from the minibar. Later that day, I walked down the street to a convenience store, bought an identical box for $2.50 and replenished the minibar before the hotel had a chance to restock it. Was this proper? My view is no harm, no foul. In fact, my box was fresher: the Oreos I ate were going to expire three months before the box I replaced them with. DAVID LAT, NEW YORK

title: Semantic Time Travel
description: At a glance, its obvious that the Historical Thesaurus of the Oxford English Dictionary, published in the fall to worldwide lexicographic acclaim, took a lot of work. The two thick blue volumes sort roughly 920,000 words into 797,120 meanings and organize those meanings into 236,400 numbered categories and subcategories. Like Peter Mark Rogets famous thesaurus, first issued in 1852, the H.T.O.E.D. not only lists synonyms but also provides what its editors call a modified folk taxonomy of Englishs meanings  carefully placing deity, for example, among the supernatural elements of the external world, while slotting worship among the manifestations of faith in the social world. It draws on the second edition of the Oxford English Dictionary, as well as a few Old English sources. The task of dicing up the O.E.D. and reassembling it into the H.T.O.E.D. took 44 years, and most of the intellectual labor was performed by humans, working with pencils and slips of paper. A 1978 fire would have proved disastrous if the slips had not been stored in metal drawers in metal filing cabinets.

title: Youth Quake
description: In your new film, Youth in Revolt, you play the sort of charmingly reticent and tongue-tied character we know from your roles in Juno, Superbad and the television series Arrested Development. How does it feel to be the poster boy for awkward adolescence? I dont value it particularly, but, I mean, its nice that people are going and seeing the movies.

title: Going Cyborg
description: On my birthday a few years ago, I taught class, called the guy I was sleeping with and then became a cyborg. I didnt know I was becoming a cyborg. I thought I was just getting a new leg. Ive had 12 artificial legs in my life. The prosthetist said this leg would think 1,000 times per second about the ground. My parents said if I wanted the new leg, I better act fast. I was being released from their insurance. The guy I was sleeping with, Henry, said the new leg sounded hot, like something out of Blade Runner. But I had never seen Blade Runner.

title: Prisoners of Parole
description: IN 2004, STEVEN ALM, a state trial judge in Hawaii, was frustrated with the cases on his docket. Nearly half of the people appearing before him were convicted offenders with drug problems who had been sentenced to probation rather than prison and then repeatedly violated the terms of that probation by missing appointments or testing positive for drugs. Whether out of neglect or leniency, probation officers would tend to overlook a probationers first 5 or 10 violations, giving the offender the impression that he could ignore the rules. But eventually, the officers would get fed up and recommend that Alm revoke probation and send the offender to jail to serve out his sentence. That struck Alm as too harsh, but the alternative  winking at probation violations  struck him as too soft. I thought, This is crazy, this is a crazy way to change peoples behavior, he told me recently.

title: The Right Hand of the Fathers
description: I am writing to clarify the context of a quotation from me in David D. Kirkpatricks excellent article (Dec. 20, 2009) on Robert George. I did call Professor George a Rambo Catholic and an ecclesiastical bully in a post on the Mirror of Justice blog written in the context of the 2004 presidential elections. But not for criticizing pro-choice Catholics, as the article suggests. Instead, I found it objectionable that Professor George cast aspersions on the good faith of pro-life Catholics, like myself, who on occasion vote for pro-choice politicians to prevent other great harms to our nation, not to advance abortion rights.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: When the Persian Gulf war started in 1990, I was working as a volunteer at a refugee shelter in Brownsville, Tex. With only a small stipend for personal expenses, I was unable to even think about going to an antiwar rally in Washington, scheduled for January 1991. Thats where Peg Mullen came in. News traveled around the community that the woman about whom Friendly Fire was written was chartering a bus for anyone who wanted to attend the rally. She filled that bus, at no cost to me and others who wanted to raise their voices in opposition. Before I read Sara Corbetts essay, I had all but forgotten that moment and would not have been able to recall Mullens name. The endless bus trip, the solidarity, the cold and the crowd all come back to me now. It was a small act in a lifetime of actions. Thank you for reminding me of this grieving woman who, bolstered by anger and anguish, did more than her part to bring peace in our time. Holland, Mich.

title: How I Earned My Wings Back
description: I GOT married a few months ago, but my husband  a proud Air Force pilot from a small town in Georgia  doesnt know how we met. Rather, he doesnt know the path that led me to him. By the time he was perched on one knee and presenting an engagement ring, I feared it was too late to tell the love of my life that we had been brought together not by fate but as a result of my nationwide crusade to find a pilot.

title: The B King Takes His Place on the a List
description: WHAT took you so long? was the question posed, semi-rhetorically, by Jonathan Demme to the assembled multitude at the Governors Dinner of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Nov. 14. Mr. Demme was on hand to present a special Oscar to his old mentor, the 83-year-old producer and director Roger Corman, whose prolific career in low-budget exploitation cinema was being recognized, at last, by the industry establishment that for most of his long working life hed had precious little to do with. If you make even the most cursory check of the honorees filmography, the answer to Mr. Demmes question might appear to be blindingly obvious: Directors whose rsums include titles like Attack of the Crab Monsters, Teenage Caveman and The Saga of the Viking Women and Their Voyage to the Waters of the Great Sea Serpent tend to have to wait a while for their Oscar.

title: Comparing the House and Senate Health Care Bills
description: Now that the House and Senate are trying to reconcile their separate health care bills, it seems worthwhile to compare the two bills on the elements most important to small businesses. There are crucial differences between the two. In general, small companies  or at least the most self-interested among them  are likely to prefer the Senate bill, which is more lenient on employers and insurers alike. Employees and those most concerned about the integrity of the reforms  whether theyll actually do what theyre supposed to do  are likely to gravitate toward the House version.

title: Letter: Stendhal and Parma

However, I couldnt believe Mr. Begley never mentioned a book that helped to put Parma on the map for a lot of us  John Grishams Playing for Pizza (2007). It is about a former N.F.L. player who agrees to play football americano in Parma.

description: Wineke Gartzs exhibition at the Westchester Arts Councils Arts Exchange Gallery is among the last of the events organized to commemorate the 400th anniversary of Henry Hudsons first voyage to North America for the Dutch. It is also one of the more theatrical. Ms. Gartz, a 41-year-old Amsterdam-based multimedia artist, has covered the windows, killed the lights and filled the cavernous gallery spaces with video and slide projections. Samplings of rap and rock songs echo throughout the building.
