title: I Dont, I Dont, I Dont, I Dont, I Dont, I Dont . . .
description: Warren Beatty may have notched thousands of bedposts in his bachelor days, if a new biography is to be believed, but only once has it been with the benefit of matrimony. On the other hand, vows are apparently a necessity for an Israeli man who at age 50 has just been granted his 11th divorce. The BBC reports that the man, from Jerusalem, usually divorces after two years and immediately goes out bride hunting. Or perhaps bride reeling. "I send out a hook in all directions, and the fish come on their own," the man, who was not named, said. According to the rabbinical court that announced the divorce, 11 is a record for Jews in Israel. The court praised the man's adherence to religious procedure. Under Jewish law, a man seeking a divorce grants his wife a "get," which declares, "You are hereby permitted to all men."

title: New Afghan Cabinet Picks Still Generate Resistance
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai made a second effort to fill his cabinet on Saturday, nominating 16 new ministers a week after Parliament had rejected most of his first choices.

title: Ragged, Topless, Relieved and Cryptic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Now that registration is open for the 2010 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, youre probably looking forward to meeting and hanging out with fellow enthusiasts. Theres a problem, though. What should you do if you encounter one of those inevitable gaps in conversation? How can you get past that awkward silence and establish your creds as a competitor to be reckoned with at the same time? Dont worry. Wordplay is here to help. Just say, Myself, I prefer cryptic crosswords, of course. Now all you have to do is sit back and watch the ruckus.

title: Jets at Bengals: What to Watch
description: Matchup to Watch: Bengals running back Cedric Benson vs. Jets middle linebacker David Harris

title: From Jihadist Blogger to Suicide Bomber
description: Updated | 4:15 p.m. As my colleague Stephen Farrell reports on Saturday, the Jordanian suicide bomber who killed eight intelligence officers at a C.I.A. base in Afghanistan last month apparently recorded a martyrdom video before his death, in which he said that his attack was an act of revenge for the assassination of the Pakistani Taliban leader Baitullah Mehsud in an American drone strike.

title: Feeling That Cold Wind? Heres Why.
description: A bitter wind has been blowing over parts of North America, Europe and Asia. Some places have been colder than ever, like Melbourne, Fla., which dipped to 28 degrees last Thursday, a record low. Europe has been walloped by snowstorm after snowstorm.

title: The Children of Cyberspace: Old Fogies by Their 20s
description: My 2-year-old daughter surprised me recently with two words: Daddys book. She was holding my Kindle electronic reader.

title: Government Is in Peril as Scandal Rocks Ulster
description: LONDON  The sex scandal that has transfixed Northern Ireland in recent days has a cinematic echo: a 60-year-old Mrs. Robinson who was caught in an affair with a man who was 19 at the time, and is now at the center of a scandal that threatens to bring down the power-sharing government that has steered the province out of 30 years of sectarian bloodshed.

title: In Primary Battles, the G.O.P. Takes On Itself
description: WASHINGTON  In this years midterm elections, Representative Mark Kirk, a moderate Republican from the Chicago suburbs, believes he has a good shot at a plum job: the United States Senate seat once held by President Obama.

title: What Really Happened to Boubacar Bah?
description: An immigrant detainee died in custody under mysterious circumstances.  Now, recently obtained video and documents show that federal immigration authorities withheld information about a dying man.

title: Officials Hid Truth of Immigrant Deaths in Jail
description: Silence has long shrouded the men and women who die in the nations immigration jails. For years, they went uncounted and unnamed in the public record. Even in 2008, when The New York Times obtained and published a federal government list of such deaths, few facts were available about who these people were and how they died.

title: Banks Prepare for Big Bonuses, and Public Wrath
description: Everyone on Wall Street is fixated on The Number.

title: Fords Bet: Its a Small World After All
description: DEARBORN, Mich.

title: Solid Everton Debut for Donovan
description: Landon Donovan started and played 68 minutes in his debut for Everton as the Toffees traveled to cold and snowy London and came away with a 2-2 tie with Arsenal at the Emirates Stadium on Saturday.

title: A Fox Chief at the Pinnacle of Media and Politics
description: In the fall of 2008, Roger Ailes, the head of Fox News, went to his boss, Rupert Murdoch, with two complaints: he had heard that Mr. Murdoch was considering endorsing Barack Obama for president in The New York Post, and he had read a book excerpt in Vanity Fair suggesting that Mr. Murdoch was sometimes embarrassed by the right-leaning Fox News.

title: Multicultural Critical Theory. At B-School?
description: A DECADE ago, Roger Martin, the new dean of the Rotman School of Management at the University of Toronto, had an epiphany. The leadership at his sons elementary school had asked him to meet with its retiring principal to figure out how it could replicate her success.

title: Why All Earnings Are Not Equal
description: AFTER a rip-roaring performance in 2009, the stock market has continued its upward climb. A reason to celebrate? Sure. But also a good time to check whether a company in which you have a stake keeps its books in a way that reflects reality.

title: The Label Factor: Is Obama a Wimp or a Warrior?
description: WASHINGTON  Like every Democratic president since John F. Kennedy, President Obama is battling the perception that hes a wimp on national security.

title: A Great Run, but Where Will We Land?
description: THE rally that brought the stock market back from the brink in 2009 was one of the biggest ever  and maybe one of the most surprising.

title: Hedge Fund Strategies, at Smaller Prices
description: THE lure of hedge funds was always their mix of mystery, complexity and exclusivity. In this post-bear-market, post-Madoff world, though, the cachet belongs to investments that are clear, simple and easy to buy and sell.

title: Queens Man Is Accused of Getting Qaeda Training
description: A 25-year-old Queens College graduate who traveled to Pakistan in 2008 with the Denver airport shuttle bus driver indicted last year in a Qaeda bomb plot was charged on Saturday with conspiring to commit murder in a foreign country and receiving training from the group.

title: The Terrorist Mind: An Update
description: What moves people to kill themselves and innocent bystanders?

title: Father of C.I.A. Attacker Speaks
description: The father of the Jordanian suicide bomber who killed eight people at a C.I.A. outpost in Afghanistan called his son a defender of the oppressed.

title: When Politicians Call It Quits
description: WASHINGTON  There are many ways for a politician to make an exit.

title: A Snowy Skirmish
description: As my wife and I walked our dogs out over the frozen expanse of Catfish Pond, relishing how the brilliant sunshine countered the chilly air in this part of New York state, we spotted some odd marks impressed in the powdery, sparkling snow.

title: The Fox News Architect
description: Bruce Headlam and Tim Arango on Roger Ailes, the head of Fox News whose success has placed him at the pinnacle of power in three corridors of American life: business, media and politics.

title: When Your Country Calls, Spend Wildly
description: IVE been fretting about the double dip.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: How to Gauge the Rush to Emerging Markets
description: IN 2009, emerging markets flew higher than a frigate bird, with the MSCI Emerging Markets Index returning 74.5 percent. Latin America, the top performer among MSCIs developing-market indexes, returned nearly 98 percent.

title: Just How Much Steam Do REITs Have Left?
description: INVESTORS thinking of putting fresh money into real estate investment trusts might easily be dissuaded by unremitting news of distressed commercial property  and predictions that the situation will become even worse.

title: A New TV Show and a New Reality
description: Being John Daly, a reality television series focusing on his latest attempt to put his life and his game back on track, will have its premiere on the Golf Channel on March 2. A fan favorite, Daly has five PGA Tour victories, including two major championships, but drinking, gambling and marriage problems have plagued his career. Daly, 43, lives in Dardanelle, Ark., where he owns the Lions Den Golf Club. He says he has shed 116 pounds, and is expected to begin his comeback this week at the Sony Open in Honolulu. VINCENT M. MALLOZZI Q. What can we expect to learn about you from watching your new show?

title: Beating the Market: Its Still a Tall Order
Detroit Entrepreneurs Opt to Look Up
description: DETROIT  With $6,000 and some Hollywood-style spunk, four friends opened this citys only independent foreign movie house three months ago in an abandoned school auditorium on an unlighted stretch of the Cass Corridor near downtown.

title: In Bonds, a Balance of Risk and Yields
description: MANY Americans have grown up with the mantra that their investment portfolio should hold an increasingly large percentage of bonds as they age. The theory is simple: bonds provide both security and income as people retire and need money to cover their living expenses.

title: Start-Ups Find Space and Support
description: DETROIT  Former auto workers are among the vanguard of those jumping into the small-business trend in Detroit, and one place they are getting help is the sprawling business incubator of Wayne State University.

title: Will a Facade Survive a Visit to Giants Stadium?
description: Im not an actual sports fan, but I impersonated one for more than 25 years.

title: Hauling the Rock: Arizonas Wells Gets a Grip on His Game
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  In his second N.F.L. game, Arizona running back Beanie Wells fumbled twice against the Jaguars, resulting in one turnover. The Cardinals escaped Jacksonville with a victory in September, but Wells was not off the hook. At practice the next week, safety Adrian Wilson scribbled Wellss name on a football and made him tote it around while his teammates tried to strip it from him.

title: In Late-Night Fight, an ABC Salvo (With NBC Cameo)
description: Over at ABC, Jimmy Kimmel couldnt resist commenting Friday on NBCs late-night morass, which could leave his Jimmy Kimmel Live show competing with Conan OBrien, Jimmy Fallon, a test pattern or some hybrid of all three. Weve skipped past Mr. Kimmels extended pumpkin-pie metaphor (but feel free to view it here if you like watching him eat) to the portion that features a cameo from some guy named Carson Daly.

title: Three Paths to Personal Financial Order
description: DO something about our finances probably falls third on the list of New Years resolutions that many of us made 10 days ago  just behind promising to exercise and lose weight, but ahead of getting organized and spending more time with family and friends.

title: Different Paths, Similar Successes
description: AFTER starting with a whimper, 2009 finished with a roar, as a variety of investing approaches yielded double-digit returns in the fourth quarter.

title: Theyre Still the Patriots, but Theyre No Longer Goliath
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Jarvis Green has been around the New England Patriots long enough to remember when their future seemed inviolate. He summoned a moment when, with three Lombardi Trophies already locked away, the Patriots won 10 games in 2005, then lost in the divisional playoff round to the Denver Broncos.

title: OHair Is Trying to Remain a Winner While Not Losing Perspective
description: KAPALUA, Hawaii  The sweeping perspective from the 18th tee at Kapaluas Plantation Course is unmatched on the PGA Tour. At once breathtaking and beguiling, forbidding and inviting, it is a penthouse view that annually greets the fortunate few winners from the previous season to the tours opener on the island of Maui.

title: European decline  a further note
description: Theres been a big to-do in the econoblogsphere over an essay by James Manzi in National Affairs; unfortunately for Manzi, it hasnt been the kind of debate you want. Manzi asserts that having a European-style social democracy is terrible for growth:

title: On a Scale of 1 to 10, How Weird Are You?
description: This interview with Tony Hsieh, the chief executive of Zappos.com, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Live Analysis:  Final, Jets 24, Bengals 14
description: Greg Bishop is in Cincinnati and George Bretherton at The New York Times building in Manhattan provided live analysis of Saturdays game between the Jets and the Bengals.

title: An Unlikely Business Plan
description: From movie theaters to restaurants, young entrepreneurs are opening new businesses in Detroit.

title: Is Sorry the Hardest Word in Health Care?
description: AH, the thorny and seemingly never-ending topic of employee error and corporate misconduct: How does your company handle it? Deny and defend? Disclose and apologize?

title: Failing Like a Buggy Whip Maker? Better Check Your Simile
description: NEED to describe a hand-held mathematical calculator? Try buggy whip. A typewriter? A VCR? Theyve been called buggy whips, too. Even newspapers have received that label. (That one hurts.)

title: Ballot Issues Attest to Anger in California
description: LOS ANGELES  From San Diego to Mount Shasta, voters are expressing mounting disgust over Californias fiscal meltdown and deteriorating services, and they are offering scores of voter initiatives that seek to change the way the state does business.

title: Lee Secures the Perimeter by Perfecting His Jump Shot
description: Sometimes a single play reveals infinitely more than its outcome. On a recent evening at Madison Square Garden, David Lee stood 21 feet from the basket, with the ball in his hands and Tim Duncan, one of the N.B.A.s premier defenders, in front of him. Lee pump-faked, Duncan lurched and Lee darted around him.

title: When Canceling a Contract Is a Workout
description: LETS start with an update. In our last episode, we met Jagoda Walczak, a Polish immigrant who spent $17,600 to become a franchisee with Coverall Cleaning, a janitorial services franchiser based in Boca Raton, Fla. Ms. Walczak said she was unable to earn anything close to the sums she had expected and wanted her money back.

title: Reid Apologizes for Remarks on Obamas Color and Dialect
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Harry Reid, the Democratic majority leader, apologized on Saturday for once predicting that Barack Obama could become the countrys first black president because he was light-skinned and had no Negro dialect, unless he wanted to have one.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Jan. 10, 2010
description: Midterm elections, counterterrorism and the economy are at the heart of this weeks talk shows.

title: A Romantic Now in Trouble Over an Airport Kiss
description: When a man ducked past security at Newark Liberty International Airport last Sunday to kiss his girlfriend goodbye, the breach in security shut down one of the countrys busiest airports, delayed flights through Monday and prompted an intensive manhunt from New Jersey detectives that ended on Friday evening on a street in Piscataway, N.J.

title: Street Corners vs. Cul de Sacs
description: REAL estate agents often chant the mantra location, location, location, which essentially means find a home in a well-kept neighborhood with good schools and a low crime rate.

title: Reid Apologizes for Racial Remarks About Obama
description: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, apologized on Saturday for saying that he believed Barack Obama could become the countrys first black president because he was light-skinned and had the advantage of carrying no Negro dialect, unless he wanted to have one. Read more

title: One-Man Gang for Georgetown, Collective Failure for UConn
description: WASHINGTON  Connecticut Coach Jim Calhoun stood at the dais in the bowels of the Verizon Center, exhaled and tried to explain how his team had let a 17-point second-half lead evaporate against Georgetown.

title: Oops, There Go the Tail Winds
description: IN hindsight, it makes perfect sense that equities started to surge last March.

title: Of Individual Liberty and Cap and Trade
description: SOME people oppose measures to limit greenhouse gases because they believe that global warming is a myth. These denialists may have a little extra spring in their step during the current cold snap, but their influence has been steadily waning.

title: Finding an Answer to Rough Seas
description: THE digital revolution recently snuffed the life out of the print version of the 146-year-old Seattle newspaper for which I wrote a column, and the recession has neatly disposed of most of the rest of my income-producing work. This has not been entirely bad, as it has liberated considerable time for work on the 19-foot sailboat taking shape in my shop.

title: Recession Spurs Interest in Graduate, Law Schools
description: It took longer than some experts expected, but the recession and the resulting shortage of good jobs have spurred a jump in applications to law schools and a growing interest in graduate programs.

title: Lotteries in Any Language
description: I WAS born in Nairobi, part of the Indian migration to Kenya. My grandfather came first, to work on the East African railroad. My father worked as a grocery store clerk and then as a bank cashier until he and my mother moved to England in 1970, hoping for a better life and better education for my sister and me.

title: Cross Words
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Nine pairs of theme answers cross. Cross words.

title: Rangers Revival Seems Right on Schedule
description: BOSTON  Henrik Lundqvist first started mentioning it a couple of weeks ago, the notion that the Rangers were not doing nearly as badly as a lot of people were suggesting. And it turned out he was right.

title: Overhaul Success or Not, Democrats Brace for Losses
description: Democrats have long maintained that they must pass their health care legislation in part because failure to do so would be a political disaster.

title: A Year in Iraq and Afghanistan
description: Its no secret that Afghanistan has replaced Iraq as the central front in Americas struggle against Islamic extremism. Indeed, as illustrated by the chart below (based on data from the Pentagon and icasualties.org, an independent research group), in 2009 there were 498 American and allied deaths in Afghanistan as compared with 141 in Iraq.

title: Obama Urges Quick Action on Health Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Saturday that Americans would see immediate benefits from a landmark overhaul of the nations health insurance system, and he urged Congress to reconcile swiftly differences on the legislation so it could be signed into law in the coming weeks.

title: Eunice Johnson Dies at 93; Gave Ebony Its Name
description: Eunice W. Johnson, the creator of the Ebony Fashion Fair, a celebrated annual tour of nearly 200 cities that has showcased haute couture and ready-to-wear fashion for a mostly African-American audience for more than 50 years, died on Jan. 3 at her home in Chicago. Mrs. Johnson, who was also one of the first entrepreneurs to market cosmetics made particularly for black women, was 93.

title: Togo Pulls Out of African Cup of Nations
description: Update | 5:10 p.m.  It took a call from Togos president to its national team captain, Emmanuel Adebayor, before a final decision was reached, but Togos players and coaches boarded planes and left Angola on the day the African Cup of Nations officially opened.

title: Herbert Spiegel, Doctor Who Popularized Hypnosis, Dies at 95
description: Dr. Herbert Spiegel treated pain, anxiety and addictions by putting people into a trance. Broadway actors sought his help to overcome stage fright, singers to quit smoking, politicians to overcome fear of flying. For years he had a regular table at Elaines, as well as his own place on the national stage.

title: Peyton Manning Is Named League M.V.P. for Record Fourth Time
description: Was it the seven fourth-quarter comeback victories he led? Or his ability to win a game when his team had the ball for just 15 minutes against the Miami Dolphins? Or that he struck such fear in the New England Patriots that Coach Bill Belichick opted for the most controversial play call of the season and went for the first down on fourth-and-2 from his teams 28 rather than punt the ball back to him?

title: Producer Says Sheen Arrest Has Not Affected Two and a Half Men
description: Charlie Sheen on Friday taped his first episode of Two and a Half Men since his Christmas Day arrest in Aspen, Colo., on suspicion of domestic violence, and on Saturday, CBS and the shows producers ended their silence about what effect the incident has had on the show.

title: Clippers Kaman Seeks Respect
description: The Clippers might have felt a little like Cinderella after their 102-91 home victory over the Lakers at Staples Center on Wednesday. Behind 25 points and 10 assists from Baron Davis, the Clippers overcame their far more glamorous and successful hometown rivals and housemates. It was their first victory over the Lakers since April 2007.

title: Calderons Return a Welcome Sight for Raptors Fans
description: Jose Calderon, the Raptors point guard, returned from a long injury absence Wednesday. He must have been a welcome sight for Toronto fans, not just because he is back but because he looked more like the sensation who took over the team at the end of the 2007-8 season than the less efficient version he had become. He had eight assists and one turnover in 25 minutes off the bench.

title: Bomb Goes Off Near Greek Parliament Building
description: ATHENS  An explosive device was detonated outside the Greek Parliament building in the heart of Athens just before 8 p.m. Saturday. The attack caused no injuries and little damage.

title: Make Sure You Get It Rite
description: When youre a major exhibitor at a trade show, you want to make sure that you get everything perfect. Unfortunately, even when you spend upward of seven figures to create your booth, things can go wrong.

title: What About George?
description: George Kramer sat hunched on his stool behind the counter of the small hardware store on Coney Island Avenue, gazing out the window at the passing traffic. He was bundled up in a heavy sweater, a maroon wool cap folded above his ears. Toward the back of the store, beyond Mr. Kramers field of vision, Isaac Abraham was rifling through a cabinet. Mr. Abraham, the stores owner for many years, knows Mr. Kramer about as well as anybody, and he was about to give a demonstration.

title: The Evolution of American Landscape Art
description: So great are the expectations surrounding exhibitions of works from the Metropolitan Museum of Art that it is hard not to be slightly disappointed with the small show of Hudson River paintings at the New Britain Museum of American Art. But in spite of its modest size  a mere seven paintings from the Metropolitan  the overall quality of the works is exceptional.

title: Water Conservation Could Limit Suburban Lawns
description: John Boyle, a 51-year-old venture capitalist in Menlo Park, built a new home on his property more than a decade ago largely to create a big lawn where his children could play football or baseball.

title: Mixing Art and Technology, and Finding Empowerment
description: In March Nazaury Delgado shyly showed his iPod Touch to an art teacher, flicking his finger across the images he had created with Photoshop on his home computer.

title: Texas and Maryland Teams Dominate the College Ranks
description: College athletics are dominated by a relatively small group of schools like Alabama and Texas, which played for the football national championship on Thursday. But as storied as those programs are, they cannot match the dominance of the best collegiate chess teams.

title: Sonoma: A Slow City, but Also a Walled One?
description: The wine country town of Sonoma has long been derided as Slow-noma by bored teenagers looking for something to do at night. Now the adults are trying to make that snail-paced life a virtue.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Afghanistan Parliaments rejection of most Cabinet nominees submitted by President Hamid Karzai misstated the name of his choice for the minister of mines, who was confirmed. He is Wahidullah Shahrani, not Mohammed Sharwani. (There is no one named Mohammed Sharwani among the nominees.)

title: When a Words Look Counted as Much as Its Meaning
description: Typography is ubiquitous. A world without letters, numerals and symbols designed by skillful font makers would consist of boring billboards, pages and street signs. Yet unlike other forms of applied design, typography remains an obscure and little-understood field. When buildings are constructed, they make news. A new font barely registers in the public consciousness.

title: Correction
description: Because of incomplete information supplied by the company, an earlier version of this article published online misstated the overall amount of CanWest's debt and the share owed to senior lenders. The debt is about 1.5 billion Canadian dollars, not 1.3 billion; 950 million Canadian dollars is owed to the senior lenders, not a figure just under 650 million.

title: Freya von Moltke, Part of a Core of Nazi Resistance, Is Dead at 98
description: He put the question to me explicitly  The time is coming when something must be done, Freya von Moltke said. I would like to have a hand in it, but I can only do so if you join in too, and I said, Yes, its worth it.

title: Brawls Cut Short K.H.L. Game
description: You have to go back to the finale of the movie Slap Shot to find a scene as ludicrous as the one in Chekhov, Russia, on Saturday. But there it was, starring Jaromir Jagr and a cast of players and referees from the Kontinental Hockey League.

title: Sunrise to Sunset on the Wharf
description: Lou Marcelli, commodore of the Dolphin Swimming and Boating Club, lives in the cupola atop the club, which was founded in 1877. The club, located at Aquatic Park, has more than 1,000 members today. (His words have been edited and condensed.)

title: Jay Feelys Punting Is a Key to the Jets Playoff Win
description: Cincinnati

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the At the Table feature on Dec. 13, about the Grill Room in Manhattan, misidentified the business with which it is affiliated. It is part of the Four Seasons Restaurant, on East 52nd Street, not the Four Seasons Hotel, on East 57th.

title: Home Fires: Bidding Farewell to Arms
description: For the past year, I could only provide a frustratingly long answer to the simple, frequently asked question, Are you still in the Army?

title: Feeling Like Favorites, the Jets Play Like It
description: CINCINNATI  On Saturday night, the team once ridiculed with the phrase Same Old Jets advanced to the divisional round of the N.F.L. playoffs behind three rookies intent on burying that expression.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption last Sunday about finding the ideal burial spot in New York City misstated the location of St. Raymonds Cemetery and misidentified the borough that includes the neighborhood of Whitestone. St. Raymonds is in Throgs Neck, the Bronx, not in Whitestone, and Whitestone is in Queens, not the Bronx.

title: Chicagos Jazz Scene Grows With Do-It-Yourself Trend
description: Surveying the chaos at 1540 West North Avenue, it is hard to believe this former sports bar will soon be a sleek new jazz club.

title: Letters: The Tax Climate
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters: Foreclosure Bargains
description: To the Editor:

title: University of Chicago, a Bright Spot for the City
description: Mayor Richard M. Daley is surely feeling so beleaguered these days that he could probably use a dose of reaffirmation from Stuart Smalley, the Saturday Night Live self-help talk show host created by Al Franken, the comic-turned-senator from Minnesota.

title: Health Reform, the States and Medicaid
description: The country needs health care reform, and Congress should move quickly to pass legislation. But as House and Senate leaders work to forge a consensus bill for final approval, they should look for ways to lessen the Medicaid burden on hard-pressed state budgets  and ensure that relief is fairly apportioned.

title: More Perils of Ground Meat
description: About eight years ago, a company called Beef Products Inc. had the novel idea of injecting its ground beef with ammonia to kill deadly E. coli and salmonella. The Agriculture Department pronounced the idea effective and exempted Beef Products Inc. from routine tests. The companys beef began appearing regularly in grocery stores, fast food restaurants and school lunch programs. It turned out the beef was not safe.

title: Are They Really?
description: Whats with the apologies? Goldman Sachss Lloyd Blankfein caught his fellow titans by surprise in November, admitting that we participated in things that were clearly wrong and have reason to regret. That came less than two weeks after he infuriated pretty much everyone else by declaring that Goldman was doing Gods work.

title: Other Voices: Freelance Ethics, and Economics
description: To the Public Editor:

title: How to Fill In When the Teacher Is Out
description: To the Editor:

title: So Is That Hamburger Really Safe to Eat?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Benefits of Tribal Gambling
description: To the Editor:

title: Captain Obvious Learns the Limits of Cool
description: Our president came down from the mountaintop.

title: The Other Plot to Wreck America
description: THERE may not be a person in America without a strong opinion about what coulda, shoulda been done to prevent the underwear bomber from boarding that Christmas flight to Detroit. In the years since 9/11, weve all become counterterrorists. But in the 16 months since that other calamity in downtown New York  the crash precipitated by the 9/15 failure of Lehman Brothers  most of us are still ignorant about what Warren Buffett called the financial weapons of mass destruction that wrecked our economy. Fluent as we are in Al Qaeda and body scanners, when it comes to synthetic C.D.O.s and credit-default swaps, not so much.

title: Whos Sleeping Now?
description: Hong Kong

title: Religion and Women
description: Religions derive their power and popularity in part from the ethical compass they offer. So why do so many faiths help perpetuate something that most of us regard as profoundly unethical: the oppression of women?

title: The Spies Who Got Left in the Cold
description: Arlington, Va.

title: White Clinches Trip to Vancouver
description: The snowboarder Shaun White, a gold medalist at the 2006 Winter Games and one of the most recognized athletes working toward Februarys Olympics in Vancouver, earned a spot on the American team by winning Saturdays United States Snowboarding Grand Prix competition at Mammoth Mountain in California.

title: Cold Patches in a Warm World
description: Theres been an unrelenting string of commentary on Dot Earth, and in some other news outlets, from people passionately pointing to the cold conditions around the Northern Hemisphere and crowing about the end of global warming. Following up on my post from last week on the Arctic Oscillation, Ken Chang has written a Week in Review story with a bit more detail on the unusual atmospheric patterns behind the big, but very constrained, chill, and the dominance of warm conditions  just not where a lot of Western media are situated. (As I wrote, it was raining in parts of Greenland about a week ago.) [UPDATE, 1/11: Richard Betts, the head of climate impacts at the Met Office, has written a commentary for the BBC amplifying on the confusion between weather (cold or hot) and climate. Its well worth a read, as is this column by Andrew Freedman at the Capital Weather Gang.]

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday with the Keeping Score column listing baseball players who finished a decade in the top three in home runs and runs batted in gave incorrect information for the 1980s and the 2000s. Mike Schmidts R.B.I. total in the 1980s was 929, not 829. Besides Alex Rodriguez, Albert Pujols was also a top-three finisher in the two categories in the 2000s, with 366 homers and 1,112 R.B.I. And Manny Ramirez, with 348 home runs and 1,106 R.B.I., was erroneously included in the 2000s.

title: Corrections
description: An essay on Page 15 this weekend about underwater mortgages misstates the parties who believe their homes will go up in value quickly. It is the homeowners  not the mortgagees, who issue mortgages.

title: Landscape Controls in View, and Other Highlights of Sundays Bay Area Report
description: The Hissing of Summer Lawns (or Lawn Owners) | When Joni Mitchell wrote her song about summer lawns it was the 1970s and the lawn was still the archetypical suburban landscape, even in dry northern California. But now that a 2006 state law restricting water use for landscaping is finally taking effect, local jurisdictions all over the state must figure out what to do about the issue by Jan. 31. Some are adopting the states model ordinance on landscaping and water conservation; others, like Palo Alto and Menlo Park, are trying to come up with their own. Some of these severely limit the extend of lawns in new or remodeled corporate or residential landscapes. Wary of these possibilities and other more draconian drought-driven restrictions, homeowners in high-end lawn-bedecked suburbs like Atherton and Hillsborough are putting in their own wells as insurance against municipal water cutbacks.Taking It Slow and Easy in Sonoma | An Italian group recently honored Sonoma as a slow city, providing the livability of a time gone by, with few if any chain stores, enough farmers markets and a pedestrian- and bicycle-friendly ambiance. But the corollary of being slow seems to be being white and old and rich, judging by the towns demographics. Which raises some questions: What price is the town paying for its slow lifestyle? Does it mean that many people who work in Sonoma have to drive a long way to get there? Will it mean that the generation growing up in Sonoma will be unlikely to have the money to live there?

title: Corrections
description: An answer to a math problem in the Pop Quiz last Sunday misidentified the system commonly used by credit and A.T.M. cards to identify an erroneous card number. It is not the Codabar. It is the Luhn.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about service learning misstated the surname of a co-author of the book The Unheard Voices: Community Organizations and Service Learning. She is Elizabeth A. Tryon, not Tyron.

title: Documents Reveal Earlier Immigrant Deaths
description: Over the last two years, the news media and Congress have brought attention to many deaths in the immigration detention system that appear to have involved substandard medical care or abuse. But a trove of documents obtained over recent months by The New York Times and the American Civil Liberties Union sheds light on even more fatalities.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Sunday about the comedian Jean Carroll misstated her date of birth. It was Jan. 7, 1911, not Jan. 6. The obituary also erroneously attributed an accomplishment to her. It was another Jean Carroll who wrote for the radio soap opera Our Gal Sunday in the 1940s and 1950s.

title: Failed Olympics Bid Leaves Neighborhood in Flux
description: For much of Shannon Fischers 20 years, community change in her Bronzeville neighborhood has come in the form of a wrecking ball.

title: Case Involving Firefighters Goes to Supreme Court
description: When a federal court found in 2005 that Chicagos 1995 test for aspiring firefighters discriminated against minorities, the city did not disagree.

title: Evanston Considers Cuts to Its Public TV Station
description: A threat by the City of Evanston to sharply cut its contribution to the local community-access television station is making the tiny Evanston Community Media Center the latest front in a fight over money collected as franchise fees.

title: Opposition to Development Near Lincoln Park Hospital
description: Few things anger a developer more than community opposition. Richard Zisook  who with his partner Michael Supera is trying to turn the three-acre site of the shuttered Lincoln Park Hospital into a blend of condominiums, housing for the elderly and retail  is facing it in spades.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Reader Comments on Religion and Women
description: My Sunday column looks at the the ways religions have tended to perpetuate and sanctify the oppression of women, and Im sure readers will be eager to weigh in. Im confident of that because in fact this column originated as a blog item last month. I dashed the blog item off after reading the Jimmy Carter speech, and I was impressed by the breadth and passion of the comments on the blog.

title: Paradox of Plenty
description: Africa has long been a target for plunder. Ian Fisher recounts how fortunes were built off African material riches as it remained the worlds poorest continent.

title: Spitzer Calls Gillibrands Views Wrong and Malleable
description: Former Gov. Eliot Spitzer tore into Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrands performance in the office during an interview with an Albany radio station, and attacked Democratic leaders for protecting her.

title: U.S.C. After Carroll? Recruits Think Twice
description: SAN ANTONIO  For months, Kyle Prater and Dillon Baxter had planned to be roommates at the University of Southern California.

title: Ray Solomonoff, Pioneer in Artificial Intelligence, Dies at 83
description: As a child Ray Solomonoff developed what would become a lifelong passion for mathematical theorems, and as a teenager he became captivated with the idea of creating machines that could learn and ultimately think.

title: The Old Man of the Jets Savors His First Playoff Victory
description: CINCINNATI  Jets fullback Tony Richardson has played in 218 games for three teams over 15 N.F.L. seasons. He has played on contenders and pretenders, played for brash coaches and quiet ones, even served as the feature back one season. Mostly, he has blocked for some of the most productive running backs in league history.

title: In Knicks-Rockets, Landrys Sibling Rivalry Resumes
description: HOUSTON  Some things, no matter how much time has elapsed or how many milestones have been reached, will never change for the N.B.A. brothers Marcus and Carl Landry. Marcus, in his rookie season with the Knicks, is two years younger than Carl, of the Houston Rockets. Marcus will always want to challenge Carl as a barometer of his own maturation. And Marcus will eternally view Carl as a role model, leaning on him in more ways than one.

title: Jets Photo Replay: Jan. 9
description: The Jets rode their youth movement in the chill at Paul Brown Stadium in another triumph, 24-14, over the Bengals.

title: Live Analysis: Final, Cowboys 34, Eagles 14
description: Joe Lapointe was in Dallas and John Woods was in Manhattan providing live analysis of Saturdays game between the Cowboys and the Eagles. Scroll down to track the progress of the game, as it happened. You can follow Joe on Twitter.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about couples who buy homes together before getting married misstated the income limits of the federal first-time home buyer tax credit. For purchases after Nov. 6, 2009, the full credit is available to married couples filing joint returns with modified adjusted gross incomes of up to $225,000, not $150,000; and for individuals with incomes of up to $125,000, not $75,000. (The lower numbers were the limits for purchases before Nov. 6.)

title: Expat Art
description: Artists who have left the United States and Europe for China have discovered a land of vast creative possibility, where scale is virtually limitless and costs are comically low.

title: With Wind Increasing, Kapalua Is No Breeze
description: KAPALUA, Hawaii  After two days of free-swinging, low-scoring golf in placid conditions, the winds came up and so did the scores, turning the third round of the SBS Championship into a Maui version of a survival contest on Saturday.

title: Knicks Revert to Old Ways With Fourth-Quarter Fade
description: HOUSTON  The Knicks have impressed and improved, dusting off their miserable beginning to find themselves a playoff contender. But there are still challenges to overcome.

title: A Redskins Reunion in the Booth Doesnt Quite Click for NBC
description: Last year, with John Madden still at NBC, he analyzed one wild-card playoff game with Al Michaels while Cris Collinsworth did the other with Tom Hammond.

title: Cowboys Put Away Eagles and 13 Years of Frustration
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  On Thursday night, when the Texas Longhorns lost the Bowl Championship Series title game to Alabama, football fans in the Lone Star State were taken down a peg or two.

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 27 about the death of Edward M. Kennedy in August referred incorrectly to the assassination of his brother President John F. Kennedy, and a correction in this space last Sunday erroneously corrected the length of his tenure in the Senate. The president was assassinated in 1963, the year after Edward Kennedy was elected to the Senate  not the same year. And as the article correctly reported, Senator Kennedy served 46 years  not 47 as the correction said. (The correction also erred in stating that the length of tenure was incorrect in Mr. Kennedys obituary, in two other articles on Aug. 27 and Aug. 28 and in an editorial on Aug. 28. All four correctly reported the tenure as 46 years.)

title: Sanchez Pokes Fun at Pete Carroll
description: Right back at ya, Coach.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: When Laws of Time and Physics Are Superseded by N.H.L. Rules
description: Thirteen games on Saturday, highlighted by the triggering of a bizarre rule in the contest at Toronto, while another obscure rule doesnt get triggered in Los Angeles. Home teams listed first:

title: Vows: Haley & Jonathan
description: Haley Mandor and Jonathan Becker met each other on a dating Web site in 2007. After four days of witty banter online, they went out on what was to become their last first date.

title: Open Thread: Should the Jets Care About Whom They Play Next Week?
description: Will it be Indianapolis or San Diego?

title: The Intersection of Dive and Swank
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.

title: What Cute Little Germs
description: A senior co-worker brings his sick children to work, rather than leave them at home with a sitter or his wife, or taking the day off. Recently, he brought them in with plastic caps on their heads. You guessed it: head lice! I dont want to be infected, but I also dont want to alienate my colleague, who will probably be my supervisor someday. We dont have a human resources department, and the principals of our firm dont seem to care. What should I do?

title: Comfort Food for the Family Crowd
description: This cozy local standby  Comfortable Food, its awning says  sits in a tiny storefront at 1310 Cortelyou Road in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, a neighborhood that has been saddled recently with the modifier slowly gentrifying because of its influx of economically unchallenged residents. Serving brunch, burgers and a decent-looking meatloaf, it attracts a family crowd, including two sisters who grew up around the corner on Rugby Road. One of them was accompanied by her 2-year-old daughter.

title: Istanbul Embraces Its Cultural Crown
description: Row after row of twinkling lights, in a pretty shade of European Union blue, already hang high across the crowded Istiklal Caddesi, heralding the arrival of 2010 and the crowning of Istanbul as a European Capital of Culture for 2010. But the yearlong celebration truly kicks into high gear on Saturday, Jan. 16, with a citywide party designed to dazzle spectators and erase any doubts about Istanbuls place as a cultural gem worthy of international attention.

title: At Last, Health Security
description: News Parody | From the Borowitz Report:

title: Philippines Gun Ban Starts Ahead of Vote
description: MANILA  A nationwide gun ban took effect Sunday in the Philippines to stave off any increase in political violence as elections draw closer, officials said.

title: Her Way
description: A look at the career of Mo'Nique.

title: Movie Star, Actor
description: A look at the film career of George Clooney.

title: Sunday Word: The Campaign Book
description: Even before a behind-the-scenes account of the 2008 election campaign hits the stores, Washington has already started writing the epilogue.

title: British Journalist and American Marine Die in Afghan Bomb Explosion
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A British journalist embedded with an American unit in Helmand Province was killed along with a Marine when their vehicle struck a roadside bomb, the British Defense Ministry reported Sunday. It was the second time in two weeks that a Western journalist had been killed on an embedded assignment, underscoring the increased risk on the roads as military operations intensify in Afghanistan.

title: London Theater Journal: Warmth in the Midst of the Big Freeze
description: LONDON  With this city all a-shiver from a crippling cold snap - the big freeze, as the tabloids call it - it only made sense to visit two of the hottest women in town. So on Saturday, my second day here, I made my way through desultory snow flurries to the West End to see the young movie star Keira Knightley playing a young movie star, and then across the Thames to the Menier Chocolate Factory in Southwark, where the seasoned song-and-dance gal Tamzin Outhwaite was portraying a seasoned dance hall hostess.

title: A New Reality for Detroit Autoworkers
description: How the last year has affected the lives of three current and former workers in the automotive industry in Detroit.

title: A Three-Bedroom Home
description: A look at three-bedroom apartments in New York for less than $1 million.

title: Live Analysis: Final, Ravens 33, Patriots 14
description: Judy Battista is in Foxborough, Mass., and will be providing live analysis of Sundays game between the Ravens and the Patriots, along with Andy Benoit, the founder of NFLTouchdown.com, and Connor Ennis, who is at the Times headquarters in Manhattan. Scroll down to track the progress of the game. You can also follow Judy on Twitter.

title: Churches Attacked Amid Furor in Malaysia
description: BANGKOK  An uproar among Muslims in Malaysia over the use of the word Allah by Christians spread over the weekend with the firebombing and vandalizing of several churches, increasing tensions at a time of political turbulence.

title: Yemens President Says Government Is Willing to Talk to Disarmed Qaeda Fighters
description: SANA, Yemen  Yemens government is determined to stand up to the challenges of Al Qaeda, but will be willing to talk to any Qaeda follower who renounces violence and terrorism, said the countrys president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, in an interview broadcast late Saturday night.

title: Bailout Panel Will Question Big Bank Leaders
description: Eight months after Congress established a commission to investigate the causes of the financial crisis, the panel is at last getting its work under way, despite concerns that its report, due on Dec. 15, will arrive too late to influence the debate over regulatory reform, The New York Timess Sewell Chan and Eric Dash report from Washington.

title: Military Is Awash in Data From Drones
description: HAMPTON, Va.  As the military rushes to place more spy drones over Afghanistan, the remote-controlled planes are producing so much video intelligence that analysts are finding it more and more difficult to keep up.

title: NBC Confirms Leno Will Leave Prime Time in February
description: Updated | 2:59 p.m.  The Jay Leno Show will exit prime time on Feb. 11, NBC confirmed on Sunday. But the network does not yet know what its future late-night lineup will look like.

title: Living in Douglas Manor, Queens
description: Douglas Manor, a peninsula on Little Neck Bay in northeast Queens that is a subsection of Douglaston, is a close-knit, family-heavy neighborhood of roughly 2,000.

title: Bank Bonuses, Bigger Than Ever, in the Spotlight
description: Everyone on Wall Street is fixated on The Number.

title: Winter Olympics Probably a TV Money-Loser
description: NBC expects to lose money on its broadcast of the Vancouver Olympics, the first loss on an Olympics broadcast package in the networks history, an NBC executive said Sunday.

title: A Peek Into Netflix Queues
description: Maps can be broken down along well-known lines  income, race, politics, to name a few. And, it turns out, one or two questions about an areas Netflix rental history can draw boundaries just as sharp.

title: Freeze Threatens Floridas Tropical Fish
description: LAKELAND, Fla.  Frosted oranges, strawberries encased in ice: the images of Floridas freezes are familiar, sad and earthy. But just past the crop rows here in the states agricultural core, there swims another sizable industry that has suffered more than any other because of this years unusually long cold snap  tropical fish.

title: A Sense of Sight
description: A look at how John Dugdale, a blind photographer, shot the ad campaign for the Broadway revival of "The Miracle Worker." (Video courtesy of The Miracle Worker/Art Meets Commerce)

title: In a Playpen of Adolescence, Angst Not Included
description: The joyous and miserable chaos of adolescence is distilled into a remarkable hour of theater in Once and for All Were Gonna Tell You Who We Are So Shut Up and Listen, a production from the Belgian Ontroerend Goed company installed at the Duke on 42nd Street as part of the New Victory Theaters season of family-friendly theater.

title: Cumming Says Spider-Man Musical Will Be Delayed
description: The Tony Award-winning actor Alan Cumming (Cabaret) said Saturday that the coming Broadway musical Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark in which he is set to star as the Green Goblin, would be significantly delayed and that producers had hit a financial iceberg last year. Previews were scheduled to begin next month, but speaking at a TimesTalk event, Mr. Cumming said: No ones going to be there that day. Were just waiting. He said the show had hit an iceberg of financial ruin last year when producers could not raise enough money for the show, which is expected to cost upwards of $50 million. He said the producers should have taken down posters in the theater district that suggest the show is opening soon; the musicals Web site still says that previews start Feb. 25. The lead producer, Michael Cohl, who took over in November, has said that the production would take place on Broadway sometime this year. Mr. Cumming said it was a really weird, frustrating thing to be waiting, but added that based on the music (by Bono and the Edge of U2), costumes and sets that he had seen so far, the musical would be a new, very exciting experience for Broadway audiences.

title: 10th Anniversary of the AOL-Time Warner Merger
description: The four executives responsible for the merger reflect on its anniversary about why they did it and why it failed.

title: The Intrigue Over Idol Is Offstage
description: LOS ANGELES  With all of the questions hanging over the new season of American Idol, the least interesting of all might be the oldest: Who will be the next American Idol?

title: 2010 BMW 5 Series Gran Turismo
description: Beneath the sows-ear styling of the 5 Series Gran Turismo is a silk-purse driving experience.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: Properties in Fairfield and Rockland counties.

title: Live Analysis: Final, Cardinals 51, Green Bay 45, Overtime
description: 8:41 p.m. | Richard Sandomir of The Times provides a take on the final moments of the Fox broadcast:

title: Local Stop: Fort Greene
description: A visit to a Brooklyn neighborhood with a decidedly literary leaning.

title: In Game Change, Insight on the 2008 Campaign
description: Why another book on the 2008 campaign, a year after the inauguration of President Obama? What more is there to say about a race that was covered day in and day out by newspapers, magazines, television, radio and bloggers? Is there anything more to learn about the candidates  and does it matter to an American public now focused on unemployment and health care and terrorism?

title: The Windsor Hotel Fire
description: On Friday, March 17, 1899, the Midtown hotel became a heap of smoking rubble.

title: Bringing Torture Home to Chicagos South Side
description: CHICAGO  John Conroy spent 15 years writing investigative news articles about one of the darkest chapters of this citys Police Department, the allegations that some officers on the South Side regularly resorted to suffocation, electric shock and mock Russian roulette in the 1970s and 80s to obtain confessions from suspects.

title: How About the Koob?
description: I just got back from the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. Ive got a bunch of notes and blurbs for you, which Ill be writing up on this blog this week.

title: The Other Plot to Wreck America
description: There may not be a person in America without a strong opinion about what coulda, shoulda been done to prevent the underwear bomber from boarding that Christmas flight to Detroit.

title: With Hours to Fill, NBC Orders More Pilots
description: With five more hours to fill on its broadcast schedule after the cancellation of the primetime version of The Jay Leno Show, NBC announced on Sunday that it had ordered pilot episodes to be shot for an aggressive slate of new drama projects, including new programs from J.J. Abrams, Jerry Bruckheimer, David E. Kelley and David Shore.

title: Jet Makes Emergency Landing at Newark Airport
description: The plane was well into its final descent toward Newark Liberty International Airport on Sunday morning when it began a sudden and unmistakable climb.

title: Lets Put on a Boundary-Crossing Show
description: The video and performance artist Jen DeNike sent a marching band through the Brooklyn Museum in the fall as part of the Performa 09 festival. The piece, Twirl, which also featured a baton-spinning majorette, owed much of its energy to the movement of the musicians, and it anticipated her new work, Scrying, her first foray into the ballet world.

title: Focusing on One French Organ Master
description: The early-20th-century French composer and organist Louis Vierne, who described himself as hypersensitive, wrote much of his music during periods of emotional turbulence. Born nearly blind, he endured crushing professional disappointments, the death of his son and brother in World War I, financial instability, recurring problems with his eyes and various severe illnesses.

title: An Apartment Covered in Memories
description: Renee Flowers, 51, still lives in the Brooklyn apartment where she grew up.

title: Panel Ties Ally of Iran Leader to Protester Deaths
description: An Iranian parliamentary panel said Sunday that Tehrans prosecutor, an ally of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, was responsible for the beating deaths of three imprisoned protesters last summer, state news agencies reported.

title: Catching Late-Night Zzzs: Jazz and Buzz
description: NYC Winter Jazzfest occupied the center of Greenwich Village on Friday and Saturday nights, holding down five clubs in a two-block radius, imposing its thoughtful ruckus on the normal Bleecker Street weekend: Long Island girls in microminis, corner dope dealers, 40-year-old boys taking in the Jets-Bengals game at a sports bar and then communing with Skynyrd covers over at the Back Fence.

title: Did Online Match Offer Years First Intrafinesse?
description: Details of this deal were sent to me by a longtime friend, Al Hollander of Chandler, Ariz. On the first day of the year he watched Nagy Kamel of Plano, Tex. (West), and Jeff Olson of Blaine, Minn. (East), play 48 boards against Billy Miller of Las Vegas (South) and Richard Pavlicek of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. (North), on Bridge Base Online (bridgebase.com).

title: 25 Across: Part of a Mushroom
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  In todays Ask Will, two frequently raised issues are discussed  the breakfast test and difficulty levels.

title: A Clarinetist Who Stacks His Dates
description: As the principal clarinetist at the Metropolitan Opera, Anthony McGill can be heard night after night from the pit, as well as from the Carnegie Hall stage during the Met Orchestras series there. But he is undoubtedly best known for his appearance in the starry quartet  along with the violinist Itzhak Perlman, the cellist Yo-Yo Ma and the pianist Gabriela Montero  that performed at President Obamas inauguration, a year ago.

title: New CDs
description: OMARION Ollusion (Starworld/EMI)

title: A Lady, Not by Leonardo, Retains an Expensive Allure
description: Since the 1920s a debate over the attribution of Portrait of a Woman Called La Belle Ferronnire, has been the stuff of legal dramas and scientific analysis, aesthetic disputes and connoisseurship differences.

title: Hopped-Up Modern Salsa From Havana
description: An audience packed with cheering Cubans greeted David Calzado and his Charanga Habanera at S.O.B.s on Friday night, in a rare and welcome American appearance by one of Cubas top bands  signaling, perhaps, an Obama administration thaw in Cuban-American relations. Formed in 1988 and persisting through multiple personnel changes, Charanga Habanera has made hits in Cuba through the 1990s and 2000s, and its set raced through them in an exultant, nearly nonstop two-hour medley. In songs like Soy Cubano, Soy Popular (I Am Cuban, I Am Popular), the band sang of its own fame and success, and the crowd proved it by shouting along, verse and chorus.

title: The Kids Are All Right (and Flaunting Their Hooks, Taste and Cred)
description: On Thursday night Nick Jonas of the Jonas Brothers made his New York debut as a solo act at the Beacon Theater for around 2,000 shrieking young girls (and a couple of boys) and their chaperones. On Saturday afternoon, in the basement of Cake Shop on the Lower East Side, the all-girl Brooklyn kid-punk outfit Care Bears on Fire hosted a showcase of teen bands for an audience of a couple hundred: plaid-wearing peers, small children, parents scarfing down sandwiches and salads.

title: New Chief to Be Named for Los Angeles Museum
description: There is almost no such thing as a secret in the art world, so when the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles announces its new director at a news conference on Monday morning, the name everyone is expecting to hear is that of Jeffrey Deitch. Neither Mr. Deitch, right, nor officials at the museum returned calls asking for comment, but several experts with knowledge of the search said that Eli Broad, the arts patron who pledged $30 million to save the museum when it was on the brink of financial collapse in 2008, reached out to many unconventional art-world personalities, including Tobias Meyer, head of Sothebys contemporary art department worldwide and Sothebys principal auctioneer, as well as Samuel Keller, the art fair impresario who ran Art Basel and Art Basel Miami Beach until he became director of the Beyeler Foundation in Riehen, Switzerland, in 2006. While the Harvard-educated Mr. Deitch has vast experience working with artists, selling artworks and presenting shows, he has never had a job that involved fund-raising, which is a crucial part of a museum directors portfolio. He has, however, worn many hats. In 1979 he helped start an art advisory service for wealthy clients at Citibank. He has also been a private art dealer, and in 1996 founded Deitch Projects, which now has two spaces in New York; in 1997 Sothebys bought 50 percent of Deitch Projects, a relationship that has since dissolved. Besides running his galleries Mr. Deitch worked at Sothebys managing its 20th-century Art Gallery Program for a few years. Among the artists he has represented are Jeff Koons; the Japanese photographer and performing artist Mariko Mori; Dash Snow; and the British team Tim Noble and Sue Webster.

title: Ground Zero Mural Shifts to Another Wall
description: A planned mural that was to cover part of the construction fence at ground zero has been moved off the site, the New York City Department of Transportation confirmed on Friday. The mural was designed by the architecture firm Sage & Coombe, which was selected in a competition announced last August by the department and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. In the end, though, We didnt think ultimately that any of the submissions was extraordinary enough, given that its the World Trade Center fence, said Stephen Sigmund, a spokesman for the authority. The mural was to have been installed last month on the Church Street fence between Liberty and Vesey Streets, and remain up for about a year. Instead it will be mounted sometime in the spring at Louise Nevelson Plaza on Maiden Lane at William Street. The design has not been made public, but the competition guidelines called for a mural incorporating bold, colorful imagery reflecting the vibrancy of the thriving downtown commercial and residential neighborhood. The principals of Sage & Coombe did not respond to messages seeking comment.

title: End May Be in Sight for Hannah Montana
description: Is Hannah Montana getting ready to give up her microphone? The Disney Channel programming executive Adam Bonnett told MTV News that the fourth season of the series Hannah Montana, which stars Miley Cyrus, right, as a teenager who is secretly a pop star, would be its last. You never know in this business ... but right now, were scheduled to wrap after shooting this new batch of episodes, Mr. Bonnett said in a statement. Rumors of the shows end have been circulating for a while, and the current seasons hourlong finale, Is Miley Saying Goodbye?, scheduled for March, does not look as if it will provide any definite answers. Its one of the things shes been wrestling with for months, Mr. Bonnett said, referring to the shows lead character, whether its time to make a decision to continue being Hannah Montana or just be a regular, ordinary girl. But Ms. Cyrus seems to have already begun to move on, with breaks in production of Season 4 scheduled around the promotion of her new film, The Last Song, in April.

title: Avatar Keeps the Top Spot at Weekend Box Office
description: Aliens, action and animals held the top spots at the weekends box office. Foxs Avatar remained in first place, with domestic ticket sales of $48.5 million, down from $68 million the week before, according to box office tracking services. That puts the domestic cumulative total for Avatar at $429 million. Both Sherlock Holmes (Warner Brothers) and Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (Fox) held their second- and third-place positions, with domestic sales taking a plunge in each films third week: about $16.6 million ($165.2 million total) for Holmes and $16.3 million (just shy of $178.2 million total) for the furry musicians. Vampires lured audiences to Daybreakers (Lionsgate), arrived in fourth place with $15 million in its first week, bumping Nancy Meyerss middle-aged romance Its Complicated, (Universal) to fifth with a little more than $11 million in its third week ($76.3 million total).

title: A Gossip Girl Becomes a Comic Book Heroine
description: The Gossip Girl actress Blake Lively, above right, has been cast opposite Ryan Reynolds, above left,  in a future Warner Brothers film based on the DC Comics character Green Lantern. According to The Hollywood Reporter, Ms. Lively will play Carol Ferris, the Lanterns love interest and daughter of the aerospace company owner who hires the fearless pilot (and secret intergalactic hero) Hal Jordan. The director Martin Campbell (Casino Royale) has yet to cast the villains, Dr. Hector Hammond and the alien Sinestro. Shooting is to begin in Louisiana in March, with an expected release date of June 17, 2011. In the comic books Carol Ferris helps run her fathers company but develops some super skills of her own and eventually battles Green Lantern as Star Sapphire.

title: Obama Plays Down Military Role in Yemen
description: President Obama said he has no intention of sending U.S. boots on the ground to Yemen and Somalia amid mounting concern about terrorist cells in those countries.

title: A Green Goblin Speaks
description: The Tony Award-winning actor Alan Cumming (Cabaret) said Saturday that the coming Broadway musical Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark in which he is set to star as the Green Goblin, would be significantly delayed and that producers had hit a financial iceberg last year. Previews were scheduled to begin next month, but speaking at a TimesTalk event, Mr. Cumming, above right, said: No ones going to be there that day. Were just waiting. He said the show had hit an iceberg of financial ruin last year when producers could not raise enough money for the show, which is expected to cost upwards of $50 million. He said the producers should have taken down posters in the theater district that suggest the show is opening soon; the musicals Web site, spidermanonbroadway.com, still says that previews start Feb. 25. The lead producer, Michael Cohl, who took over in November, has said that the production would take place on Broadway sometime this year. Mr. Cumming said it was a really weird, frustrating thing to be waiting, but added that based on the music (by Bono and the Edge of U2), costumes and sets that he had seen so far, the musical would be a new, very exciting experience for Broadway audiences.

title: A Nation of Hunkered-Down Homebodies
description: The nations mobility rate fell last year to its lowest level since World War II, according to the latest census data. Growth is slowing in Sun Belt states and Northeastern states are holding on to more people. The current recession and lack of jobs  are big factors, but the trend has been gaining force since the 1950s, when nearly one-fifth of all Americans moved every year.

title: Reunited With a Lost Corvair
description: Craig Pursley's search for a car like the one he drove as a teenager led to a surprising discovery.

title: Study Finds That Papers Lead in Providing New Information
description: There are more places to go for local news but less news to find there, and the great majority of actual reporting still comes from newspapers, according to a study of the Baltimore area that is scheduled to be released on Monday.

title: Large Price Jumps Reported for Small but Vital Drugs
description: Prices for a small but growing number of brand-name drugs have risen more than twofold in recent years as drug makers seek to squeeze greater profits out of often small-selling but vital medicines, according to Congressional investigators.

title: Airlines Refuse to Transport Radical Cleric
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The radical Jamaican cleric who was deported to Gambia last week has been returned to Kenya, Kenyan news media reported late on Sunday.

title: Dominating Victory by the Ravens Shakes Up a Dynasty
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Their injured receiver, Wes Welker, watched from a luxury box, his crutches propped nearby providing a fitting reminder of how fragile the New England Patriots grip on success has become. Perhaps, if better days are ahead, the Patriots will look back on this season as a blip in their dynasty, the moments when a young team tasted bitter defeat and grew from it.

title: Optimism Takes Charge at Consumer Electronics Show
description: The mood at last weeks Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas was decidedly more upbeat than at the previous years show. At that exhibition, the chatter on the floor was less about innovation and breakthrough technologies than about how to weather the economic storm that would impede the kind of discretionary spending much of the electronics industry relies on.

title: In Leno Fiasco, a Window to the Midlife Crisis of NBC
description: The syndrome is a familiar one. Men of a certain age  and it is almost always men  wake up one day and find that they are no longer the center of the universe. Women fail to look their way, co-workers dont scurry to fetch them coffee and bosses stop thinking of them as someone on the rise.

title: 6 Years, 3 Teams, 2 Divisions. Finally, a Starring Role.
description: OAKDALE, N.Y.  Defense suddenly turned to offense, and Christie Marrone was off, a 5-foot-6 blur of gold, navy and white, dribbling furiously down the court with the basketball she had just stolen. She finally delivered a nifty no-look pass to complete the two-on-one break.

title: Revelers See a Dimming in a Capitals Night Life
description: PARIS  The neighbors do not like the Zero Zero bar, a graffiti-plastered dive on an otherwise sleepy stretch of Rue Amelot, in the 11th Arrondissement. It is not so much the look of the place, they say, or any particular distaste for its youthful clientele. It is the noise.

title: Two Ideological Foes Unite to Overturn Proposition 8
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The last time David Boies and Theodore B. Olson battled in a courtroom, the presidency hung in the balance as they represented opposite sides arguing the fate of the 2000 election.

title: From Print to Phone to Web. And a Sale?
description: Print may be a flat medium, but that has not stopped magazine publishers from trying to add dimension to their pages. For at least a decade, they have been experimenting with bar codes and icons that could take readers to Web sites, trying to add a bit of Internetlike interactivity to their pages.

title: Photo Replay: Ravens Beat Patriots
description: The Ravens put the Patriots on their heels from the game's first play and never looked back in a convincing A.F.C. wild-card win.

title: Citing Hazard, New York Says Hold the Salt
description: First New York City required restaurants to cut out trans fat. Then it made restaurant chains post calorie counts on their menus. Now it wants to protect people from another health scourge: salt.

title: A Vague Sense of What Makes a Hall of Famer
description: The guidelines for baseballs Hall of Fame voting are condensed to one line: Voting shall be based upon the players record, playing ability, integrity, sportsmanship, character, and contribution to the team(s) on which the player played.

title: In a Series, Nickelodeon Will Focus on Math
description: Nickelodeon, whose preschool shows focus on teaching social skills as much as letters and numbers, will move squarely into the academic realm, with the introduction of Team Umizoomi, which it said is the only preschool series centered entirely on teaching math to children.

title: NBC Confirms Its Late-Night Shake-Up
description: PASADENA, Calif.  NBC confirmed Sunday what the television world already knew  that the network would end Jay Lenos prime-time show in one month and return him to 11:35 p.m., bumping The Tonight Show and its host, Conan OBrien, to 12:05 a.m.

title: Two Killed in Belt Parkway Crash
description: Two young women died when they were thrown from a car that crashed on the Belt Parkway in Brooklyn early Sunday. The cars driver, a 29-year-old man, was charged with vehicular manslaughter, driving while impaired by alcohol and other counts, the police said.

title: In Sour Economy, Biggest Gambler at Foxwoods Is the Casino Itself
description: MASHANTUCKET, Conn.

title: Brooklyn Boy, 15, Charged in Stabbing of 12-Year-Old
description: A 15-year-old Brooklyn boy was charged on Sunday with stabbing a younger friend after they argued in a park where they had gone to smoke marijuana, the police said.

title: Behind the Lens, Continuing a Legacy
description: Spike Lee needed to have his photo taken for a publicity tour a few months before the release of his new movie, Malcolm X, in 1992.

title: Goldman Sachs Considers Charity Requirement
description: As it prepares to pay out big bonuses to employees, Goldman Sachs is considering expanding a program that would require executives and top managers to give a certain percentage of their earnings to charity.

title: Visualizing Parade, Ryan and Jets are Hoping for Real Thing
description: When Coach Rex Ryan gave his Jets their schedule for the postseason last week, it went right through to a Super Bowl parade in February. Nothing like planning ahead. He just wanted to paint a picture in the players minds, wanted them to visualize the tantalizing possibility of winning a championship, because he is an unabashed believer that they can make the confetti-filled picture come to life.

title: In Colorado, Craving Reform of Health Care and Congress
description: DENVER  Donny Seyfer, the manager of an auto repair shop here, had high hopes when President Obama and Congress tackled health care as their top priority early last year.

title: Argentine President and Central Bank in Standoff
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  A disputed plan by President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner of Argentina to use billions of dollars in foreign currency reserves to repay debt has inflamed political tensions in that country, Latin Americas third-largest economy.

title: For Jets, Success Far Beyond One Playoff Victory
description: From his New Jersey basement Sunday afternoon, linebacker Bart Scott multitasked, alternately answering questions about his current team, the Jets, and rooting for his former team, the Baltimore Ravens, in its playoff game against the New England Patriots.

title: Cardinals Beat Packers in Overtime
description: A shootout between quarterbacks -- the highest-scoring playoff game in N.F.L. history -- ended with a score by the defense as the Arizona Cardinals defeated the Green Bay Packers, 51-45.

title: As a Statement, This Beating Could Linger in New England
description: Foxborough, Mass.

title: How the AOL-Time Warner Merger Went So Wrong
description: A decade ago, America Online merged with Time Warner in a deal valued at a stunning $350 billion. It was then, and is now, the largest merger in American business history.

title: Race Riots Grip Italian Town, and Mafia Is Suspected
description: ROME  More than a thousand African workers were put aboard buses and trains in the southern Italian region of Calabria over the weekend and shipped out to immigrant detention centers, following some of the countrys worst riots in years.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Kai Eide, the departing head of the United Nations mission in Afghanistan, misstated the background of Jean-Marie Guhenno, the former head of peacekeeping operations for the United Nations, who is one Mr. Eides possible successors. He is a career diplomat from France, not a general.

title: Train From Sarajevo to Belgrade Revived
description: The famous train line from Sarajevo to Belgrade was disrupted during the Balkan conflict in the 1990s.

title: G.O.P. Attacks Reid Over Comments
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans on Sunday sought to portray racially insensitive remarks attributed to Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, in a new book as similar to comments made in 2002 by Trent Lott, the Republican leader who was forced to step down.

title: U.S. Bankers Are Fed Up With British Regulations
description: LONDON  A tough new requirement by Britains securities regulator that top banking executives and earners must defer 60 percent of their total compensation for a three-year period is pushing some American banks with extensive London operations to say that they just wont take it anymore.

title: Cardinals Defense Ends Shootout With Packers
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  For more than 60 minutes in the desert Sunday, the two gunslinging quarterbacks dueled to a draw, Arizonas Kurt Warner and Green Bays Aaron Rodgers combining for 801 yards through the air and 9 scoring passes.

title: Corrections
description: The Amman Journal article on Dec. 29, about a famed Jordanian sandwich shop, Reem, misstated the number of traffic circles or junctions that form the spine of Amman, the capital. There are eight, not seven. And a reporting credit with the article misidentified the city from which Mona El-Naggar contributed reporting. It was Amman, not Cairo.

title: On Trials Sidelines, Abortion Foes Are Divided
description: When the trial of the man accused of murdering a doctor who performed late-term abortions begins on Monday in Wichita, Kan., Troy Newman, the leader of Operation Rescue, an anti-abortion group with headquarters a few miles from the courthouse, says he will most likely be at his desk, as usual, and certainly nowhere near the courtroom.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the predominance of poverty and minority students in schools in the South misstated the name of a test that measures reading scores among fourth-graders. It is the National Assessment of Educational Progress, not the National Assessment of Economic Progress.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Monday about a new fee levied on movie and television production companies filming in some municipally owned buildings in New York City misstated the title of a television show that has used such buildings and will be subject to the fee, according to a spokesman for the Department of Citywide Administrative Services. It is Gossip Girl, not Gossip Girls.

title: Train Line Across the Balkans Restitches a Region
description: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina  The siege of Sarajevo had just begun the last time Vera Bagur, now 68, took the famous train line from Sarajevo to Belgrade. It was one of the few physical links that bound Muslims, Serbs and Croats.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about the fashion designer and museum curator Charles Kleibacker misidentified the Paris atelier where, Mr. Kleibacker said, in the 1950s he realized he wanted to become a designer. It was Christian Diors  not that of Yves Saint Laurent, who did not start his own atelier until 1962.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Cowboys Are Cruising, but Road Gets Tougher
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Now that the Dallas Cowboys have won a playoff game for the first time in 13 seasons, they can pursue what may be a more difficult objective.

title: Guantnamo Reunion, by Way of BBC
description: New to Facebook, Brandon Neely was searching the site for acquaintances in 2008 when he typed in the names of some of the detainees he had guarded during his tenure as a prison guard at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba.

title: Lights Repaired, and Lightning Finishes Off Devils
description: NEWARK  The Tampa Bay Lightning finally got to go home Sunday night, and not a moment too soon. Minutes after beating the Devils, 4-2, Tampa Bay cleared out of the dressing room, with every bit of equipment jammed into black duffel bags and hustled onto a cart.

title: A Withering Harvest in Florida
