description: In Floridas agricultural core, there swims another harvest that has suffered more than any other because of a long cold snap: tropical fish.

title: Senators War Chest Grows, but So Does Primary Threat
description: As United States Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrands allies have elbowed out her would-be Democratic challengers one by one, they emphasized what was perhaps her most formidable weapon: her fund-raising muscle.

title: NBC Will Televise Major Triple Crown Prep Races
description: Churchill Downs and NBC Sports are expected to announce Monday an agreement to broadcast six major prep races leading to the Kentucky Derby as part of a plan to attract casual fans as well as horseplayers. The move comes as NBC positions itself to win back the three legs of the Triple Crown in 2011.

title: Lawmakers Visits on the First Day of the Detroit Auto Show Seem to Set a Pattern
description: DETROIT  Before opening to the public, the Detroit auto show always begins with a week of preview days, first for the media and then for dealers and others who work in the auto industry.

title: A Higher Price Tag Enters Negotiations
description: As White House and Congressional negotiators work toward an agreement on a final version of sweeping health care legislation, they seem likely to push the 10-year price tag closer to the $1.05 trillion cost of the House-passed bill while relying on new taxes proposed by the Senate, probably including a bigger increase in the Medicare payroll tax than currently proposed.

title: Taking Aim at the Big Names in Animated Film
description: GREENWICH, Conn.  Slumbering in a drab-looking office building here, Blue Sky Studios, the animated-movie division of 20th Century Fox, has long been dismissed as much of a threat. Nobody could catch DreamWorks and Pixar, moviedom figured, especially not a quiet studio that got its start with an animated laxative commercial.

title: A Smaller Player Mounts Must-See Events
description: LAS VEGAS  Ever wonder why electronics stores try so hard to sell audio and video cables made by Monster Cable?

title: Accounts, People & Miscellany
description: Accounts

title: Teaching Green, Beyond Recycling
description: Jose Chirino, a 10th grader in Brooklyn with shoulder-length hair and a thin mustache, says flatly that his high school was his last choice.

title: Aflac Is Leaving Its Agency, and Taking the Duck
description: THE familiar duck is front and center as Aflac expands efforts that began last year to tell consumers more about how its insurance products work. But the relationship between Aflac and the agency that created the character in 1999 is ending.

title: Washingtons Gun Past Affects Arenass Future
description: WASHINGTON  The office of Peter Nickles, the District of Columbias attorney general, is on Pennsylvania Avenue, not far from the White House or the Verizon Center.

title: M.T.A. to Unveil a Makeover of Its Web Home
description: New York Citys mass transit network has become cleaner, faster and more reliable in the past decade. But its Web site remained stuck in the past.

title: NBC Expects Winter Olympics to Lose Money for the Network
description: NBC expects to lose money on its broadcast of the Vancouver Olympics, the first loss on an Olympics broadcast package in the networks history, an NBC executive said Sunday.

title: Lottery Numbers
Action, and Now Reaction
description: The founders built the House of Representatives to act. And throughout President Obamas first year, the House has acted.

title: Is David Lee an All-Star? (And Other Thoughts.)
description: Since the idea of the Knicks David Lee making 20-foot jumpers no longer seems ludicrous, maybe its time to reconsider another once-unthinkable notion: David Lee as an All-Star.

title: Action, and Now Reaction
description: The founders built the House of Representatives to act. And throughout President Obamas first year, the House has acted.

title: N.F.C. Divisional Playoff Matchups
description: Arizona Cardinals at New Orleans SaintsSaturday, 4:30 p.m. EasternTV: Fox

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: When Flood of E-Mail Pitches Recedes
description: Two weeks before Christmas, online retailers blasted out promotional e-mail at a rate 60 percent higher than the yearly median. But in the seven days just before the holiday, the average number of messages fell, according to the online marketing firm Responsys, which tracked e-mail from 104 of the 150 largest online retailers. What gives?

title: A.F.C. Divisional Playoff Matchups
description: Baltimore Ravens at Indianapolis Colts Saturday, 8:15 p.m. EasternTV: CBS

title: Moving Beyond a Childhood Beset by Loss and Illness
description: In the dimly lighted apartment in Flatbush, Brooklyn, Lowanda Hamilton, 23, cares for her bedridden grandmother, Evelyn Dunbar. At times, helping her eat, changing her diapers and managing her mood can be overwhelming for Ms. Hamilton. But the two share an indestructible bond.

title: Hope of Reprieve for Bond Investors
description: Its the slowest train wreck of the financial crisis: Commercial real estate is still screeching roughly two years after lenders jammed on the brakes.

title: Jersey City Officer Shoots Man
description: A man was wounded in a police-involved shooting in Jersey City on Sunday night, a spokesman for the city said.

title: A Meager Existence on Food Stamps
description: To the Editor:

title: Nygard Store Tries to Impose a Press Curb
description: For most companies, store grand openings are about free publicity. But the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation now finds itself the target of a copyright infringement lawsuit after recording the opening of a shop in Manhattan controlled by the designer Peter Nygard.

title: Privatized War, and Its Price
description: A federal judge in Washington, Ricardo Urbina, has provided another compelling argument against the outsourcing of war to gunslingers from the private sector. In throwing out charges against Blackwater agents who killed 17 Iraqis in Baghdads Nisour Square in September 2007, Judge Urbina highlighted the governments inability to hold mercenaries accountable for crimes they commit.

title: The Right to Confront Witnesses
description: Just last June, the Supreme Court decided that when prosecutors rely on lab reports they must call the experts who prepared them to testify. It was an important ruling, based on a defendants right to be confronted with witnesses against him, but the court is about to revisit it. The justices should reaffirm that the Sixth Amendment requires prosecutors to call the lab analysts whose work they rely on.

title: Promises and Facts on Charter Schools
description: Charter schools  which are run with public money but subject to fewer state regulations  have a lot of supporters in Washington. Education Secretary Arne Duncan wants states to close some chronically failing schools and turn them into charters. Congress is so enthusiastic that it has created a $50 million fund and given Mr. Duncan the authority to directly finance charter school operators who want to replicate or expand successful programs.

title: Youngstown Yawns
description: Anyone whos spent time in Youngstown, Ohio, is entitled to nagging affection for the gritty old steeltown that has long struggled with lost jobs and serial political corruption. Bruce Springsteen lyricized its fate: Im sinkin down here Darlin in Youngstown. Theres a touch of fresh hope at word that a collective yawn is greeting the return of former Representative James Traficant, who is on the streets vowing a political comeback after a seven-year prison stretch.

title: A Message to Uganda About a Bill Against Gays
description: To the Editor:

title: Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me
description: To the Editor:

title: The Demands of the Classroom
description: To the Editor:

title: Learning From Europe
description: As health care reform nears the finish line, there is much wailing and rending of garments among conservatives. And Im not just talking about the tea partiers. Even calmer conservatives have been issuing dire warnings that Obamacare will turn America into a European-style social democracy. And everyone knows that Europe has lost all its economic dynamism.

title: Lets Talk About Faith
description: Liberal democracy offers religious believers a bargain. Accept, as a price of citizenship, that you may never impose your convictions on your neighbor, or use state power to compel belief. In return, you will be free to practice your own faith as you see fit  and free, as well, to compete with other believers (and nonbelievers) in the marketplace of ideas.

title: Stacking the Deck Against Proposition 8
description: Washington

title: Mr. Smith Rewrites the Constitution
description: Chicago

title: Using a Pfizer Grant, Courses Aim to Avoid Bias
description: Stanford University on Monday will announce plans to develop new continuing education programs for doctors that will be devoid of the drug industry influence that has often permeated such courses.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Bolts Win Resumption of Newark Power-Failure Game
description: Four games on Sunday, including Chicagos second loss in a row after blowing a 5-1 lead in St. Paul the night before, and the completion of that Devils-Lightning game suspended in Newark on Friday night. Home teams listed first:

title: Strong Finish by Ogilvy in Start to the PGA Season
description: KAPALUA, Hawaii  Geoff Ogilvy came to Maui this year with a different set of golf clubs and a new sponsors name on his cap. But the only significant changes in his performance at the SBS Championship at Kapalua Resort were in his margin of victory and the identity of the runner-up.

title: Word of the Day | sonorous
description: sonorous \s-nor-s, s-n-rs\ adjective

title: Heineken Buys Femsa Beer Unit in $7.6 Billion Deal
description: Update | 6:49 a.m. Heineken said Monday that it would buy the beer operations of Femsa, one of Mexicos biggest brewers, in an all-share transaction that values the business at $7.6 billion. The move further consolidates the beer industry into a few global players, Michael J. de la Merced and Chris V. Nicholson write in The New York Times.

title: Heineken Nears a Deal With Femsa
description: Heineken is close to buying the beer operations of Femsa, one of Mexicos biggest brewers, for $7.5 billion to $8 billion, people briefed on the matter said Sunday. The move would further consolidate the beer industry into a few global players.

title: News Quiz | January 11, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: A.S.P.C.A. Airlift
description: WHO arranged and paid for a Chihuahua airlift in which 15 homeless dogs from San Francisco were flown to New York City?

title: North Korea Calls for Peace Treaty Talks With U.S.
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea on Monday proposed talks with the United States to reach a formal peace treaty that would replace the truce that halted the Korean War 57 years ago, indicating that it would not give up its nuclear weapons until Washington signed such an accord.

title: Goldman Sachs Weighs Requirement for Charity
description: As it prepares to pay out big bonuses to employees, Goldman Sachs is considering expanding a program that would require executives and top managers to give a certain percentage of their earnings to charity, Louise Story writes in The New York Times.

title: Video: Father of C.I.A. Bomber Speaks
description: AMMAN, JordanThe father of the suicide bomber who blew himself up in Afghanistan, killing seven Central Intelligence Agency operatives and his Jordanian supervisor, spoke to The New York Times about his sons attack and what drove him to it.

title: How the AOL-Time Warner Deal Went Wrong
description: A decade ago, America Online merged with Time Warner in a deal valued at a stunning $350 billion. It was then, and is now, the largest merger in American business history.

title: Forte in Talks to Buy Goldmans Shanghai Property
description: Shanghai Forte Land, a Chinese property developer, is in talks to buy a high-end residential property in Shanghai from Goldman Sachs, in a deal worth more than $200 million, Reuters reported, citing two people familiar with the situation.

title: U.S. Bankers Are Fed Up With British Regulations
description: A new requirement by Britains securities regulator that top banking executives and earners must defer 60 percent of their total compensation for a three-year period is pushing some American banks with extensive London operations to say that they just wont take it anymore.

title: Is President Obama a Wimp or a Warrior?
description: Thats the question Helene Cooper asks in a Week in Review article about the labels that presidents and parties get. What is your perception of our president nearly a year after his inauguration? Do you think he needs to toughen up, do you think hes a warrior, or do you think these kinds of caricatures are all just politics and punditry?

title: China Banks Said to Lend $88 Billion in Week
description: Chinese banks made about 600 billion renminbi ($88 billion) in new loans in the first week of 2010, the Economic Information Daily reported on Monday.

title: Art Clokey, Animator Who Created Gumby, Dies at 88
description: Art Clokey, the animator who half a century ago created Gumby, that most pliant of pop-cultural figures, died on Friday at his home in Los Osos, Calif. He was 88.

title: Vagabond Opera
description: They may hail from Portland, Ore., but the six-piece Vagabond Opera has a far more worldly repertory. Paris hot jazz, gut-bucket swing, tangos, Ukrainian folk-punk ballads and klezmer are just a few of the styles the troupe, which was founded in 2002 by Eric Stern, a trained opera singer and composer, mixes together to infuse new life into an Old World art form. The group performs in 11 different languages and sings not only opera but also elements of Weimar cabaret and Arabic and Balkan forms. They promise a burlesque Hula-Hooping fire performer too. Theyll be at the Highline Ballroom on Monday as part of World Music Festival beginning at 7 p.m.

title: Wont You Take Me to Monkey Town?
description: If you havent been to Monkey Town in Williamsburg, now is the time to go. The dining and performance space is, sadly, closing its doors on Jan. 24 because of landlord issues. The multiroom site, which features classic dishes from a country that doesnt exist, offers adventurous cuisine, including braised rabbit ravioli, smoked-cheese stuffed poblano and crispy shrimp tacos, along with even more out there live music, video art and performances. Monday will be a showcase for Swim a group that includes former and current members of Beirut, Rivers, Freetime, Steer and WOOL as well as the ritualistic sounds of Aaron Moore, a member of Volcano the Bear & Amolvacy.

title: The Literary Life
description: Philip Gourevitch, the New Yorker writer and editor of the Paris Review, announced recently that he will be leaving his editors post soon. Catch him tonight at Barnes & Noble, where he will be appearing with the author Richard Price. Hobnob with the literary elite while they discuss Mr. Prices acclaimed novel, Lush Life and also celebrate the publication of The Paris Review Interviews, IV, which includes conversations with Philip Roth, E. B. White, Ezra Pound, Haruki Murakami, Stephen Sondheim, William Styron and more.

title: Blacks Leisure, a British Retailer, Considers Share Issue
description: Blacks Leisure, the British outdoor goods retailer, said it was considering an equity fund-raising of between 15 million and 20 million ($24 million to $32 million), as it posted better sales in the run-up to Christmas, Reuters reported.

title: BofAs Post-Merger Bonuses May Not Be Panacea
description: Bank of Americas crew on Wall Street can breathe a sigh of relief, Reuters Breakingviews says. It looks like the bank is set to hand out 2007-like bonuses to all its investment bankers and traders.

title: Hope of Reprieve for Bond Investors
description: Its the slowest train wreck of the financial crisis: Commercial real estate is still screeching roughly two years after lenders jammed on the brakes, Reuters Breakingviews says.

title: Are They Really Sorry?
description: Whats with the apologies, The New York Timess editorial board wants to know. Goldman Sachss Lloyd Blankfein caught his fellow titans by surprise in November, admitting that we participated in things that were clearly wrong and have reason to regret. That came less than two weeks after he infuriated pretty much everyone else by declaring that Goldman was doing Gods work.

title: Ecclestone and Genii Said to Seek Cash For Saab Bid
description: Formula Ones billionaire promoter, Bernie Ecclestone, and investment company Genii Capital will soon have initial financing to show General Motors that they can finance a purchase of carmaker Saab, Dagens Industri reported.

title: N.Y. Fed Says Geithner Not Involved in A.I.G. Issue
description: Timothy Geithner, the former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, wasnt aware of efforts to limit American International Groups bailout disclosures because the regulators top lawyer didnt think the issue merited his attention, the lawyer told lawmakers, Bloomberg News reports.

title: In Britain, Tate Trustees Pull Out of Hedge Fund Investments
description: It seems that the Tate Gallery, the charitable organization that runs two of Londons best-known museums, is no longer feeling the love for hedge funds.

title: Macquarie Said to Mull $4 Billion Electricity Network Bid
description: Macquarie, the Australian investment bank, has teamed up with the Canadian Pension Plan and the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority to bid for an electricity network in Britain, The Telegraph reported.

title: Hedge Fund Strategies, at Smaller Prices
description: The lure of hedge funds was always their mix of mystery, complexity and exclusivity. In this post-bear-market, post-Madoff world, though, the cachet belongs to investments that are clear, simple and easy to buy and sell, The New York Timess Conrad de Aenlle writes.

title: Virgin Said to Talk to Blackstone on Northern Rock
description: Virgin Money, controlled by the British entrepreneur Richard Branson, has approached the Blackstone Group to seek backing for a new bid for the state-owned British bank Northern Rock, The Telegraph reported.

title: 3i Said to Eye $1.6 Billion Growth Capital Fund
description: 3i Group, the British private equity firm, is planning to raise a 1 billion ($1.6 billion) fund to buy minority stakes in small businesses, in a return to its investment roots, The Sunday Times reported.

title: Future Capital Eyes Biofuels Plant
description: A partnership set up by the investment boutique Future Capital Partners plans to raise 236 million ($380.6 million) for a biofuel plant it will construct in Grimsby, in northern England.

title: Dubais Arabtec May Be in for Big Losses
description: Arabtec Holding, based in Dubai, may need a $1.7 billion investment by Abu Dhabis Aabar Investments to cope with future losses, analysts said on Sunday, as the construction companys shares fell 6.9 percent.

title: You Are Not What Your Record Says You Are
description: The Fifth Down wrote a blog post on Nov. 25 suggesting that the Ravens were the sleeper team of 2009 and that the Jets had more than a pulse.

title: Thats the Ticket, Winfrey Magazine Declares
description: Golden tickets arent just for Willy Wonka anymore. Now Oprah Winfrey is getting into the act.

title: Londons ICA Celebrates the Art of Confusion
description: Londons Institute of Contemporary Art is going esoteric this month with an exhibition called For the blind man in the dark room looking for the black cat that isnt there, a collection of works from more than 20 artists that focuses on the lack of knowledge, unlearning and productive confusion as ways to understand the world.

title: Citis Japan Head Said to Return to N.Y.
description: The head of Citigroup in Japan, Douglas Peterson, is returning to New York after overseeing the sale of assets in Japan to help the banking company repay the government for its bailout during the financial crisis, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing a person familiar with the matter.

title: Chinese Brokers Vie for Trading Program
description: Eleven Chinese brokerages including Citic Securities and Haitong Securities will vie to be included in a pilot program for margin trading and short selling following a nationwide test run in 2008, The China Securities Journal reported, citing an unidentified regulator.

title: Greenberg Blames Goldman for A.I.G.s Collapse
description: Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive at the American International Group, apparently thinks he knows whos responsible for the collapse of the insurance behemoth: Goldman Sachs.

title: Japan Said to Distance JAL From Delta and American
description: A decision on whether Delta Air Lines and American Airlines will be allowed to invest in Japan Airlines will not be made until the struggling carrier has a new management in place, Reuters reported, citing a person familiar with the matter.

title: Moist, Crepuscular, Pullulate, Lugubrious
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared the words that grate on their ears.

title: Urban Creative Class Dismissed
description: Todays idea: Perhaps nurturing a creative class isnt the key to reviving industrial cities after all. An urban guru has second thoughts about his once-hopeful prescription, and now some civic leaders who bought into it arent happy.

title: ESolar Strikes Deal to Build China Plants
description: ESolar, an American solar power company whose investors include Google and Oak Investment Partners, said Saturday it would help build a series of solar thermal power plants in China, as the worlds biggest emitter of greenhouse gases tries to decrease its reliance on coal, imported gas and oil.

title: Was Arizona-Green Bay One for the Ages or Just One for the Record Books?
description: If you ask the Cardinals, Sundays 51-45 shootout victory over Green Bay should be considered one of the greatest games in N.F.L. history.

title: Rumors of an Allianz Bid Drive Up Swiss Life Shares
description: Allianz is preparing a bid for Swiss Life Holding, Switzerlands biggest life insurer, according to a report from the French Web site Wansquare, which cited various Swiss banking sources.

title: Russian Tycoons Said to Plan Big London Listings
description: It appears that Russian oligarchs still have a soft spot for the London Stock Exchange. Several Russian tycoons are preparing for multibillion dollar London listings, The Financial Times reported.

title: Have Women Done It?
Ask About Improv Everywhere
description: Editors note, April 2: a few weeks after this feature appeared, Charlie Todd of Improv Everywhere lied to City Room repeatedly as we questioned him on whether one of his stunts was an April Fools hoax (it was). While the unwritten laws of the Internet prevent us from taking these posts down, we cant vouch for anything he says here.

title: Under Fire Again, Geithner Said to Retain Support
description: Even as he faces renewed criticism for the handling of the American International Groups bailout, Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner still has the support of President Obama and Democratic leaders in Congress, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Submit Your Funny Caption
description: Winter Offensive | Tell us whats going on in the picture above (use the comment link below). Its the latest of the uncaptioned images were posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last weeks funniest captions are at right.

title: Detroit Auto Show: Fords Global Focus
description: DETROIT  Media previews are about to begin. But overnight Ford revealed photos and information of perhaps one of the most important cars that well see at the show  the new Ford Focus.

title: Shares Edge Higher as Investors Await Earnings
description: As companies began releasing fourth-quarter results on Monday, the question on Wall Street was not so much whether businesses turned a profit but how they did so.

title: House Lawmakers Return to Focus on Jobs, Health Care
description: The second session of the 111th Congress opens this week as the House returns to begin what promises to be an intense and partisan year.

title: Thiels Fund Said to Fall 25% in 2009
description: The markets were good to many investors last year. But Peter Thiel apparently wasnt one of them.

title: Sampler: Same-Sex Marriage Goes to Court and Pancho Villas Son Dies in Hayward
description: Same-Sex Marriage Heads to Court | The first federal trial over the issue of same sex marriage begins on Monday in San Francisco. It will address whether the 2008 ballot vote to ban same-sex marriage in the state was unconstitutional. The trial is unusual on several fronts: It will include testimony from two gay couples at the center of the case, video coverage will be available at some point on YouTube and the two lawyers representing the gay couples were courtroom adversaries who argued opposite sides in the battle over the fate of the 2000 presidential election. [The San Francisco Chronicle, The New York Times]

title: Overmedication in the Nursing Home
description: The number jumped out at me as I was reading a newly published study on mental health treatment in nursing homes: 71 percent.

title: Jive Software Grows Up
description: We last looked at Jive Software in April, when the Sequoia Capital portfolio company was learning how to survive during the Great Recession, spurred on by its stark slide show called R.I.P. Good Times.

title: The New Lawyers
description: Because of the economic crisis, new lawyers who thought they were destined for the boardroom have found themselves spending a year defending the poor.

title: The Early Word: Unions on Health Care
description: The fight over how to pay for a overhaul of the health care system breaks out into the open today as top labor leaders head to the White House to criticize a proposal to tax family health insurance policies  the so called Cadillac plans worth more than $23,000  because they fear it would hit many generous union-sponsored health plans.

title: Too big to fail fail?
description: Im puzzled by what David Warsh says about me (not for the first time):

title: Media Equation: NBC Listens to Its Elders
description: In todays Media Equation column, David Carr writes:

title: Detroit Auto Show: Ford Sweeps Car and Truck of the Year
description: DETROIT  The Ford Motor Companys strong showing in 2009 was reaffirmed Monday with a sweep of the North American Car of the Year and North American Truck of the Year Awards.

title: Reaching Consensus on the Klamath
description: The second half of an agreement that parties hope will govern water use and lead to the restoration of the Klamath River, a contentious stretch of water in southern Oregon and northern California, has been reached by some two dozen groups.

title: The Nifty 50 | Jacquelyn Jablonski, Model
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Speed Read for Monday, Jan. 11
description: Highlights from media coverage in The New York Times today:

title: Ninth Church Vandalized in Malaysia as Tensions Rise
description: BANGKOK  A ninth church was vandalized Monday in Malaysia in a series of arson attacks that have raised religious tensions surrounding a dispute over the use of the word Allah by Christians in this mostly Muslim nation.

title: Wars Fury No Longer Pauses for Afghan Winter
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistans high mountains and harsh weather once meant that winter was a respite from much of the wars violence, but as the deaths of six Western soldiers in three separate attacks on Monday show, this winter is proving to be different.

title: In Citi Unit, a Study in Why Size Matters
description: A Citigroup unit called Global Transaction Services, or G.T.S., which converts currencies, helps send payments to American military contractors and processes passport applications, is an example of why Congress will have a hard time breaking up institutions deemed too big to fail, The Wall Street Journal reports.

title: Investor Alwaleed Says Citigroup on Right Path
description: Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, the Saudi billionaire who is the head of Kingdom Holding and a shareholder in Citigroup said the giant American bank had put the worst behind it and was now on the right path, Reuters reported.

title: The Morning Feed
description: What were reading on Monday morning.

title: Detroit Auto Show: Cheerleading From Washington
description: DETROIT  Although he didnt bring pompoms, Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood made a kickoff speech at the North American International Auto Show that was largely an exercise in cheerleading.

title: Another Claim of Prosecutorial Misconduct
description: Peter J. Henning, a professor at Wayne State Law School, specializes in issues related to white-collar crime and follows them for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: Less Salt, Please, the City Asks
description: First New York City required restaurants to cut out trans fat. Then it made restaurant chains post calorie counts on their menus. Now it wants to protect people from another health scourge: salt.

title: Talk to The Times: Micheline Maynard, Aviation Correspondent
description: Micheline Maynard, the senior business correspondent for The New York Times who covers the airline industry and aviation, is answering questions from readers Jan. 11-15, 2010. Questions may be e-mailed to askthetimes@nytimes.com.

title: Vain Glorious | The Body Shop Originals
description: With Vain Glorious, The Moment breaks down the latest spas, salons and products for your aesthetic pleasure.

title: Jonathan Gruber
description: Oy. I sort of missed the controversy over Jon Gruber and his contract with HHS. For those who havent been following this, Gruber  who is one of the three or four top health care economists in the nation  turns out to have a large research grant from the Department of Health and Human Services, for modeling the consequences of various reform plans. This has led some people, mainly Marcy Wheeler at Firedoglake, to question Grubers objectivity.

title: Supreme Court Blocks YouTube Coverage of Same-Sex Marriage Case
description: The United States Supreme Court decided on Monday (.pdf) to block videotaped coverage for the first few days of a federal trial in San Francisco that was supposed to be available on YouTube.

title: What to Watch Monday: Lose the Suit?
description: How I Met Your Mother (CBS, 8 p.m.), in its 100th episode, teases us with the possibility that Barney (Neil Patrick Harris) might give up suits for love. More vexing for some fans was the thought that they had waited five seasons only to find out that Rachel Bilson, who guest stars, was the mother. The rational ones realize that once theres a mother, theres no more show.

title: Detroit Auto Show: 2012 Ford Focus
description: Update | 12:14 p.m.

title: Solar and Biomass Plants to Work in Tandem in China
description: Chinas plans to build 2,000 megawatts of solar thermal power using technology from a California company, eSolar, will also include the construction of biomass power plants to generate electricity when the sun sets.

title: Thrust Temporarily Into Public Service
description: Some law students respond to a higher calling to create justice and serve the common good. Others respond to the call of the money gods, the pedigree and the cerebral challenge. But the economic crisis of 2009 has created an unusual laboratory where some graduating students who thought they were heading for the corner office were thrust into crowded courtrooms.

title: Citis North American Retail Banking Head to Resign
description: The head of Citigroups North American consumer banking business, Teresa A. Dial, has stepped down for personal reasons and will become a senior adviser, the bank said on Monday.

title: The Worst in TV? Its Time for the Bennies
description: The Oscars have their foil in the Golden Raspberry Awards, which have been saluting the worst that Hollywood has to offer since 1981. But what about the small screens most awful? The Emmys have no counterbalance at the moment.

title: Why Did Big Love Change Its Credits? God Only Knows
description: This post might contain spoilers if you consider an opening theme song a narrative element.

title: Europes OK; the euro isnt
description: One addendum to todays column: Europe is OK, but the single currency is having exactly the same problems ugly Americans warned about before it was created.

title: The Logic of Looking Busy
description: Last week, Nate Silver ran the numbers on the odds of experiencing airborne terror, and found that there has been one terrorist incident per 11,569,297,667 miles flown in the last ten years. This means, in turn, that your chances of being on a given departure which is the subject of a terrorist incident have been 1 in 10,408,947.

title: Down in the Trenches
description: In a press kit for Josephus Thimisters first haute couture collection in a decade, in Paris on Jan. 24, I came across an intriguing photograph taken for Vogue by Steven Meisel. A millennial portrait of youngish world-shakers, it included Thimister, Hedi Slimane, Veronique Branquinho, Roberto Menichetti, and Miguel Adrover. In a fairly short time, these designers were to move away from the frontline of fashionMr. Slimane to photography, Mr. Thimister to Charles Jourdanwhile others in the portrait, notably Nicolas Ghesquiere and Hussein Chalayan, were to hold our attention and still others, like Olivier Theyskens, seemed to enter a stage of limbo, between jobs. A number of stars are not included in the portraitno Alber Elbaz, who was then leaving Saint Laurent for Lanvin, no Phoebe Philo, who was at Chlo at the time, and no Christopher Bailey, who perhaps had not yet proven himself at Burberry. Maybe the only thing group portraits tell us is to beware of group portraits. This is a highly unstable business, as weve learned in the last few years.

title: Resting Your Starters, Revisited: Does Belichick Deserve Criticism?
description: The Colts and Coach Jim Caldwell never heard the end of their decision to rest starters in the third quarter of the Indianapolis-Jets game in Week 16.

title: The Desktop: Its Alive!
description: Pity the poor desktop computer.

title: Starting Over in Lexington: The Picnic Lesson
description: When I arrived in Lexington, Ky., to give a speech to the workers at a factory that SRC Holdings had just acquired, I truly felt as if I had gone back in time. I was giving a speech just as I had some 30 years ago to convince a bunch of people that their jobs depended on opening their books and running the place as if they owned it.

title: Monday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Detroit Auto Show: Toyota Promises Affordable Hydrogen Fuel-Cell Vehicle
description: DETROIT  Toyota announced here on Monday that it plans to begin public sales of an affordable, highly fuel-efficient hydrogen fuel-cell vehicle in the United States by 2015  or sooner, if refueling infrastructure becomes available.

title: Detroit Auto Show: Toyota FT-CH
description: Update | 12:41 p.m. More on the Toyota FT-CH:

title: Detroit Auto Show: 18 Degrees Outside, but This Mercedes Seems to Be Melting
description: DETROIT  At 7:45 Monday morning, Mercedes-Benz showed off the lines of its new design language in the form of a sculpture  a two-and-a-half ton silver resin model that appeared to be rising from or sinking into a fabric floor. The slick silver skin, Mercedes said, was supposed to suggest the work of snow or sand or water  or the Terminator films.

title: Ex-Wrigley Chief Joins Greenhill
description: William D. Perez, the former chief executive of the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company and Nike, will join Greenhill & Company as a senior adviser, the boutique investment bank said Monday.

title: New York Ripe for Electric Cars, Study Says
description: New Yorkers, start your electric cars.

title: Video: A Blind Photographer and The Miracle Worker
description: When the coming revival of William Gibsons Miracle Worker, starring Alison Pill as Annie Sullivan and Abigail Breslin as Helen Keller, opens in March, a blind photographer will have helped bring it to Broadway.

title: London Theater Journal: Silence Speaks Volumes
description: Theater people are said to live for applause, and London theatergoers, although slightly less enthusiastic than their New York counterparts, are usually happy to oblige at the drop of a curtain. So it was strange - and oddly refreshing  to experience the loud silence that greeted the end of the first act of Our Class, which I saw over the weekend in one of its final performances at the National Theater, where it opened in September. I was reminded that sometimes the sound of no hands clapping is a greater tribute than the collective clamor of many.

title: Was Simpsons Episode Edited to Spare Seth MacFarlanes Feelings?
description: Update | 2:35 p.m.  Someone get Chief Wiggum on the case! A special 20th anniversary episode of The Simpsons ended with a thank-you message from the shows producers to viewers, but appeared to omit a joke at the expense of their Fox colleague and sometime-rival Seth MacFarlane.

title: Obama Weighs Tax on Banks to Cut Deficit
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will try to recoup for taxpayers as much as $120 billion of the money spent to bail out the financial system, most likely through a tax on large banks, administration and Congressional officials said Monday.

title: Reporting on a Scarcity of Reporting Without Reporting
description: Theres a study from the Project for Excellence in Journalism that uses a small data set from Baltimore to reach some conclusions we all could have guessed at: Much of the news blogging consists of annotating the reporting of others. This post will be no different.

title: Making Art of a Troubled Past
description: The Bagger spent the weekend having a meta-media moment, which is only natural when one writes about oneself in the third person. (Its also handy when youre the director of an acclaimed post-modern film). We had the urge to live-Tweet our own TimesTalk interview with James McAvoy  luckily someone else did it for us  and, like everyone else, checked out our own ZIP code on this nifty interactive Netflix usage map. Whatever, its better than self-Googling.

title: In a Game Like Cardinals-Packers, Why Not Onside Kicks?
description: When two teams are breaching defenses as effortlessly as the Cardinals and the Packers were Sunday, does it make sense to try more onside kicks?

title: Venture Capitalists Eye the Doctors Office
description: In a recent story, I talked with venture capitalists about their technology predictions for 2010 in computers, green technology, the Web and business software. But I left out a big area that tech investors are excited about: health care.

title: Thain Weighs In on Financial Reform
description: John A. Thain, the former chief executive of Merrill Lynch and an architect of its sale to Bank of America during the financial crisis, has lain low since he left the financial industry last year. (And with good reason, given the hail of criticism he has faced.)

title: App to Find Taco Trucks
description: Gourmet food trucks are all the rage, now offering upscale mobile meals of everything from carnitas and crepes to schnitzel and cupcakes. While that might seem like good news to foodies everywhere, there is a problem. Where do you find these trucks?

title: Detroit Auto Show: With Granite, GMC Goes Beyond Countertops
description: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 11: GMC Granite concept

title: Playoffs Q. and A. With Mike Tanier
description: Mike Tanier, an analyst for footballoutsiders.com who writes the game previews each week for The Times, answered readers questions on Monday (in the comment section below) about the N.F.L. playoffs.

title: A Block Where Chase Has the Corners Covered
description: There are blocks in New York that are packed with banks. A Citibank stares across the street at a Capital One here, a Wachovia is steps from an HSBC there.

title: Obama Considers Bank Fee to Help Cut Deficit
description: President Obama is likely to propose a fee on financial institutions to help reduce the federal deficit when he releases his budget plans in February, although the details remain unresolved, according to administration officials.

title: The Surgeon Generals Weight Struggle
description: Given that two of three Americans are overweight, does it matter that the new surgeon general, Dr. Regina M. Benjamin, also struggles with her weight?

title: Under the Radar: Five Questions About Space Panorama
description: In the solo show Space Panorama, playing as part of the Under the Radar festival at the Public Theater, Andrew Dawson recreates the entire Apollo 11 moon landing with nothing more than his hands, a table and Shostakovichs 10th Symphony.

title: A Rogue Homeless Shelter
description: Dan de Vaul houses dozens of homeless men and women on his ranch in central California, but neighbors and the authorities take issue.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1. ) Avatar: Socialist propaganda, or a full-throated defense of property rights?

title: Fonts: Al Gores New Number 1
description: Since words and fonts go together like peas and forks, co-vocabularists may be interested in this delightful tale from the type foundry Typotheque regarding Al Gores involvement in the design of his new book, Our Choice:

title: Answers About Roth I.R.A. Conversions: Part 2
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks in which youll have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Allah  the Word
description: It was 2006 when I sat with a friend, Hikmat Farha, at the foot of a snow-capped Mount Hermon. Our conversation was about politics, as it usually is in Lebanon, and to make a point, he cited Imam Ali, warrior, sage and seventh-century caliph whom Shiite Muslims consider the divinely sanctioned successor to the Prophet Muhammad.

title: In Reids Comments, Hints of Obamas Own Words
description: Senator Harry Reids comments about Barack Obamas race  and its positive implications for his presidential run in 2008  have been well aired by now.

title: A Homemade Homeless Shelter
description: Dan de Vaul has taken in dozens of homeless people by building ramshackle, illegal housing on his ranch in San Luis Obispo, Calif.  Some see him as a good Samaritan, but others consider the ranch to be a dangerous eyesore.

title: Blagojevich Retreats From Race Remarks About Obama
description: CHICAGO  Senator Harry Reid, the Democratic majority leader, is not the only one apologizing for using racially charged language when it comes to President Obama. On Monday, Rod R. Blagojevich, the indicted, ousted former governor of Illinois turned reality television show contestant and Elvis impersonator, had his own apologies to offer.

title: China Sees Avatar (and Criticizes It, Too)
description: While the numerous arguments inspired by James Camerons science-fiction film Avatar have hardly quieted down in its fourth week of release, another group of voices has been added to the debate. On Jan. 2, Avatar opened in China, inspiring bloggers there to race back to their computers and pick apart the messages they are finding in that 3-D blockbuster.

title: Pity the Packers
description: For all but the most die-hard Cardinals fans  and frankly, there may be 12 whose tenure stretches longer than 18 months  it is hard not to feel bad for the Packers. They did, after all, save wild-card weekend from a series of blowouts and Ode to the Patriots Dynasty soliloquies with their frantic comeback in Arizona, only to endure the final crushing indignity of a 51-45 overtime loss.

title: Cuomo Demands Bonus Data From 8 Big Banks
description: Update | 12:52 p.m. Andrew M. Cuomo, New Yorks attorney general, took aim at Wall Streets looming bonuses on Monday, sending letters to eight of the nations biggest banks demanding information on how they structured those payouts.

title: N.C.A.A. Wants the Young Madder About March
description: With this issue, In Advertising returns from its year-end hiatus. And because next Monday is a holiday, look for next weeks issue on Tuesday, Jan. 19.

title: Detroit Auto Show: VW New Compact Coupe Concept
description: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 11: Volkswagen New Compact Coupe concept

title: In New York City, a Chilly Library Has Its Rewards
description: In the pantheon of New York City jobs, many people face rugged extremes. Ironworkers brave fierce winds high on beams. Subway track workers traverse dank tunnels. Firefighters climb through flames.

title: Hoeven Plans Bid for N.D. Senate Seat
description: North Dakota Gov. John Hoeven, a widely popular Republican, will announce that he is running for Senate on Monday evening, according to a state Republican official, a decision that likely increases the G.O.P.s odds of capturing the seat.

title: Warming Imperils Crops in India and China
description: China and India, which constitute about 37 percent of the worlds population, face a future of sharply lower crop yields as a consequence of climate change, leading scientists in both nations warned recently.

title: Monday Puzzle: Moonlighting Triangles
description: With most of the country in a state of deep freeze, lets thaw ourselves mentally by imagining warmer climes. So for our first puzzle of the new year, heres a story about a pair of do-it-yourselfers, Penny and Roger, who have just finished tiling their poolside patio. Do you feel the warm sunshine on your back already? Good!

title: Different Tweets for Different Folks
description: In the new social media order, everyone will broadcast everything about themselves all the time, and generation gaps will be created at lightning speed. Major awards shows are no exception: both Adam Shankman, a producer of the Oscars, and Ricky Gervais, the host of the Golden Globes, have taken to Twitter. But over the weekend, they revealed very differing takes. While Mr. Shankman, also a judge on So You Think You Can Dance, was busy promoting the Academy Award dance auditions, asking his followers what they thought the 10 best picture nominees would be, and, like everyone else, admitting an obsession with Jersey Shore, Mr. Gervais was more reserved.

title: A Fight for the Homeless and Against Authority
description: SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif.  Burly, bearded and gleefully obscene, Dan de Vaul does not look the part of the bleeding-heart homeless advocate, sporting as he does a feather-topped cowboy hat, a large collection of guns and a bushel of hoary wisecracks.

title: Featured Recipe: Farfalle With Gorgonzola, Arugula and Cherry Tomatoes
description: There was a time when pasta dishes dressed with just cheese, cream or milk were popular, at least with me and my family, but today they seem stodgy and fat. Heres a variation on a classic dish, pasta with Gorgonzola, that adds color, acidity and strong flavor without increasing the cooking time a single second. And it increases the shopping and prep times by only about five minutes.

title: Attacking, and Defending, Hard-to-Open Packaging
description: The hard-to-open packaging on Barbie dolls and other gifts underneath the Christmas tree has left many consumers ripping. Yes, these plastic fortresses deter shoplifters and help reduce the wastefulness of bulky cardboard boxes, manufacturers say, but at what cost?

title: Abu Dhabi Royal Acquitted in Torture Trial
description: Updated | 1:38 p.m. A court in Abu Dhabi ruled on Sunday that 45 minutes of video showing a member of the emirates ruling family torturing an Afghan grain merchant  by stuffing his face with sand, firing a machine gun close to his body, hitting him with a whip and an electric cattle prod, cutting his bare buttocks by striking him a nail embedded in a stick and driving over him  did not prove the prosecutions case that the sheik was guilty of a crime.

title: Prize Patrol: Judges Announced for Sundance Film Festival
description: Enter the judges. The Sundance Film Festival, which begins on Jan. 21 in Utah, announced on Monday the members of the five juries awarding prizes. The awards will be presented on Jan. 30 by David Hyde Pierce.

title: YouTube Moment on Hold in Same-Sex Marriage Case in San Francisco
description: The video above appears to be of technical checks at the federal court in San Francisco in preparation for what was supposed to be Mondays YouTube coverage of the same-sex marriage case that opens today. On Monday morning, the United States Supreme Court issued a brief statement barring the videotaped coverage, at least for few days, until it had time to review the issue more thoroughly. The order halted the decision to allow real-time streaming of the trial.

title: Q & A with Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The Advertising Club of New York awarded its 2009 Digital Action Scholarship for academic excellence, which comes with a $5,000 stipend and a one-year club membership, to Yi Qiang Chen, a junior at the City College of New York.

title: Sarah Palin to Contribute to Fox News
description: Former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska has signed on as a contributor to the Fox News Channel.

title: Travel Deals: 20 Percent off Marriott Hotels Worldwide
description: Marriott is offering 20 percent off weekend stays at more than 2,500 hotels around the world. Some Marriott resorts in the Caribbean, Latin America and Hawaii are offering as much as 40 percent off.

description: Enter the judges. The Sundance Film Festival, which kicks off on Jan. 21 in Park City, Utah, announced on Monday the members of the five juries awarding prizes. The awards will be presented on Jan. 30 by David Hyde Pierce.
