title: Counting of Calories Isnt Always Accurate
description: Anyone who counts calories by using the figures on menus in fast-food restaurants or on the packages of frozen meals may want to count again. When researchers tested the food served in 29 chain restaurants and 10 frozen meals sold in supermarkets, they found that their calorie content averaged considerably more than the stated values.

title: Anemic Outlook for Private Equity Fund-Raising
description: The private equity industry had one of its worst years for fund-raising in 2009, and the situation is not expected to get much better this year, Preqin, a private equity data provider, reported in a new study on the industry.

title: A Place on the Web for Outdoor Hobbyists
description: A new Web site called GoFishn gives anglers a place to show off their catches and small fishing businesses a way to find customers.

title: Dispatch | New Orleans
description: Ten to six, Saints  second quarter, our server at Elizabeths said by way of greeting. Ill be right back with your menus. A lady of a certain age, she wore construction boots, cargo shorts and an oversize Saints T-shirt beneath a pixie crop of salt-and-pepper hair.

title: Venture Capitalists Eye the Doctors Office
description: From Claire Cian Miller at Bits:

title: From Toshiba: 3-D 24/7
description: When attending a trade show, one quickly learns not to judge the quality of a product based on what you see on the show floor. At car shows, every vehicle is scratch-free, looks stunning and smells great. And at the Consumer Electronics Show last week, every television produced the most gorgeous picture you have ever seen, with deep blacks and terrific resolution.

title: Burgers Without the Beef
description: Every time I read an article like the one in last months New York Times about the safety of beef, I tell my son, yet again, that I dont want him eating beef at school or anywhere else that we havent agreed upon. Liam loves burgers, but hes seen the movie "Food, Inc.," so he doesnt argue too much. And hes very happy to eat burgers that arent made with beef. I think its not so much the meat as much as the pleasure of eating a browned patty in a bun, with ketchup, that he likes (and that I like too). So I wasnt surprised the other morning when, thinking out loud, I asked What shall I do for Recipes for Health this week? Without missing a beat, he replied, Burgers.

title: Detroit Auto Show: Mercedes-Benz E-Class Cabriolet
description: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 11: Mercedes-Benz E-Class Cabriolet

title: Dont Stop Believin': Glee to Hold Auditions for New Singers
description: For its second season, the Fox musical Glee is holding a nationwide search for three new singers.

title: Chicago Flutist Apologizes to L.A. After Hitting Sour Notes
description: Update | 3:21 p.m. A flutist with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra who briefly took a temporary post with the Los Angeles Philharmonic, only to return to Chicago, apologized for his departure and denied a news report in which he appeared to be critical of the Philharmonic. The flutist, Mathieu Dufour, had been on leave from the Chicago orchestra when he joined the Philharmonic on a one-year trial basis starting in September. But earlier this month he told The Chicago Sun-Times that he had decided not to remain in Los Angeles, telling that newspaper that the Philharmonic has no tradition there  no tradition of sound and no tradition of working together as a dedicated ensemble.

title: Sarah Palin to Contribute to Fox News
description: Former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska has signed on as a contributor to the Fox News Channel.

title: Hybrid Cars Wont Save Much Oil
description: Hybrid cars may be as popular as ever, but they may not have much effect on the nations  or the worlds  oil consumption over the next two decades, according to J. Marshall Adkins and Pavel Molchanov, analysts for the financial services firm Raymond James.

title: Eric Rohmer, New Wave Film Director, Has Died
description: Eric Rohmer, the French critic and filmmaker who was one of the founding figures of the internationally influential movement that became known as the French New Wave, and the director of more than 50 films for theaters and television, including the Oscar-nominated My Night at Mauds (1969), died on Monday. He was 89.

title: Violence in Angola Puts South Africa on the Defensive
description: In the aftermath of Fridays chilling attack on Togos national team, that left three dead, before the start of the African Cup of Nations, South African officials tried to separate the events in Angola from ongoing concerns about security for the World Cup in June.

title: Now Brewing | Starbucks Gets a Makeover
description: In the 1990s, Starbucks was opening one new store per day. Green mermaid logos popped up on retail facades everywhere, sometimes within feet of one another, making the sameness from store to store all the more noticeable. But its not the 90s anymore, and when Starbucks stock began dropping in 2007, the Seattle-based company realized, among other things, that the cookie-cutter approach to store design had fallen out of fashion. Last year, Starbucks announced it would renovate its thousands of company-owned stores, in 52 countries, to be more sustainable and to look, well, less global and more local.

title: What Were Reading
description: Another  salvo is fired against Alice Waters: In The Atlantic, Caitlin Flanagan says Ms. Waterss Edible Schoolyards program shortchanges children educationally.

title: Should Down Syndrome Be Cured?
description: The guest post here on Friday  about the birth of Cash Van Rowe during a blizzard, and the jolting news that he had Down syndrome  led many of you to leave comments for his parents, assuring them that the road ahead was a journey they would cherish.

title: Audio Gear With a British Accent
description: In the theoretical audio cosmos, Mr. Bowers and Mr. Wilkins would get on famously with Dr. Bose.

title: Detroit Auto Show: Lecture by Prof. Marchionne
description: DETROIT  Sergio Marchionne says he was a little unfair to the Congressional delegation, headed by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, that visited the auto show Monday when he led them into a display for a lecture that lasted more than 15 minutes.

title: The Book Review of the Future
description: Last month, when I received my copy of The San Francisco Panorama  also known as McSweeneys No. 33, or the newspaper issue I did the same thing you presumably do when The Sunday Times hits your doorstep: I went right for the book review.

title: Detroit Auto Show: Buick Regal GS Show Car
description: Introduced on Monday: Buick Regal GS concept

title: The Safety Factor When Signing or Punching in a PIN
description: A New York Times article last week, How Visa, Using Card Fees, Dominates a Market, detailed the behind-the-scenes struggle between banks and retailers to encourage customers to sign when making debit card purchases or to punch in their PIN number because of the higher fees that stores pay banks for signatures.

title: White Mans Burden?
description: One of the responses Im getting to my Europe isnt an economic hellhole column is the claim, from conservatives, of course, that Europe is only able to prosper because we Americans are bearing the whole burden of defending freedom.

title: Former CNBC Chief Joins Credit Suisse
description: Credit Suisse said Monday that it had named Pamela Thomas-Graham, a former chief executive of CNBC, to the newly created post of chief talent, branding and communications officer and appointed her to its executive board.

title: Picture This! Building Photo-Based Writing Skills
description: Overview | How can you use the Learning Network feature 6 Qs About the News to build writing, language and news literacy skills? In this lesson, students use photographs to practice writing, vocabulary and skimming skills to develop literacy or prepare for standardized tests.

title: Eric Rohmer, a Leading Filmmaker of the French New Wave, Dies at 89
description: Eric Rohmer, the French critic and filmmaker who was one of the founding figures of the French New Wave and the director of more than 50 films, including the Oscar-nominated My Night at Mauds, died on Monday in Paris. He was 89.

title: Delay in Trial for Abortion Doctor Killing
description: The trial of the man accused of murdering a Kansas doctor nationally known for performing late-term abortions was delayed on Monday, as lawyers disagreed about how far the defense should be permitted to go in presenting opposition to abortion as a reason for the killing.

title: Crazy Like a Fox (Executive)
description: Jon Chait flags the Times report on Roger Ailes, highlighting his apparent paranoia about terrorists:

title: Los Angeles Museum Chooses Deitch
description: We have a winner: as expected, the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles said on Monday that it would name Jeffrey Deitch as its director. Mr. Deitch, the New York gallery owner, has also helped start an art advisory service for clients at Citibank, and founded his Deitch Projects in 1996. Mr. Deitch also managed Sothebys 20th-century Art Gallery Program, and in 1997 Sothebys bought 50 percent of Deitch Projects, a relationship that has since dissolved. Other contenders for the position were believed to include Tobias Meyer, the head of Sothebys contemporary art department worldwide and Sothebys principal auctioneer, and Samuel Keller, the art-fair impresario who ran Art Basel and Art Basel Miami Beach until he became director of the Beyeler Foundation in Riehen, Switzerland.

title: A Spot of Tea vs. a Plea for More Stimulus
description: DETROIT  Undeterred by subfreezing midmorning temperatures, two groups of protesters converged on a snowy street outside Cobo Center at the 2010 North American International Auto Show with varying agendas - ranging from job losses to opposition to government bailouts.

title: Carnism
description: Term given to the psychological disconnect which allows people to eat some animals while remaining resolutely sentimental about others.

title: Listening In After Another Philadelphia Flop
description: Nobody does misery like Philly.

title: The Nifty 50 | David Adamo, Artist
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Cohen Seeks Sanctions Against Ex-Wifes Lawyer
description: Lawyers for the hedge fund manager Steven A. Cohen have asked a federal court judge to sanction the departing lawyer for his former wife after she filed what they called a frivolous lawsuit accusing Mr. Cohen of racketeering.

title: Obama Plans Campaign Stop for Reid in Nevada
description: The White House is about to make another big gesture demonstrating its support for Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader under fire for remarks he made about President Obamas race.

title: Chart: Redshape
description: Redshape is a techno DJ based in Berlin, known for his spare, Detroit-admiring sound (and for always wearing a creepy red mask). The artist Andrew Kuo breaks down Redshapes new album, The Dance Paradox.

title: Ruble Jumps as Russia Returns From Holidays
description: MOSCOW  The ruble had its best day against the dollar in more than a decade on Monday when it rose 3.1 percent.

title: A Cookie Calling Card for Travelers
description: There are few perks left in travel. But fresh-baked chocolate chip cookies may be one.

title: For Toyota, Dealing With Family Business
description: Update | 5:05 p.m. DETROIT  Dont call it a brand, and its certainly not a division. Instead, Toyota says it will be adding a new family in the next few years under the Prius nameplate.

title: Roger Eberts Memory Palace
description: On the heels of Tony Judts moving meditation on living and sleeping with Lou Gehrigs disease, heres Roger Ebert, deprived by surgery of the ability to eat and drink as well speak, writing on his memories of food  and beverages:

title: P.G.A. Tour to Make Asian Debut in 2010
description: The intense growth of golf culture in Asia is paying off: the P.G.A. Tour will make its first visit to the continent when it comes to Malaysia later this year.

title: Prosecutors to Examine Accident Involving Ex-Police Commissioner
description: The Manhattan district attorneys office is investigating an accident last week in which Howard Safir, the former New York City police commissioner, backed his sport utility vehicle into a pregnant woman on the Upper East Side and then drove away, a spokeswoman for the office said Monday.

title: Dragon Breathes Fire Into Touch
description: Remember Dragon Dictation, the free, pretty amazing speech-recognition app for the iPhone?

title: Obama to Attend Funeral for Bidens Mother
description: The White House said today that President Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama will attend the funeral Mass on Tuesday for the mother of Vice President Joseph R. Biden, Jr.

title: Europe, in Grip of Low Temperatures, Faces Flaring Tempers and Disrupted Travel
description: BERLIN  Weeks of wintry weather have left Britons bickering over dwindling salt supplies, Germans worrying over the economic costs of a ferocious start to winter, and residents in the usually warmer corners like Spain and the south of France struggling with rare accumulations of snow.

title: Awareness: To Measure Medicine, Mind the Spoon
description: When the measuring cap that comes with the medicine bottle gets gooey and gummed up, the temptation is to grab a kitchen spoon to guesstimate a teaspoons worth of liquid medicine.

title: Belfast Leader Explains Temporary Leave
description: Peter Robinson, the leader of Northern Irelands local government  in which power is shared by leaders of the provinces two largest communities  announced on Monday that he is taking a six-week leave from his position to deal with a family crisis that has threatened to end his political career.

title: Seahawks Announce Carroll as New Head Coach
description: Update | 3:05 p.m. Pete Carroll, who was announced as the new coach of the Seattle Seahawks on Monday, was scheduled to meet with members of the Southern California football team at 2:30 p.m., Pacific, according to Billy Witz in Los Angeles.

title: Casket Maker Hillenbrand to Diversify With K-Tron
description: At a time when many companies are slimming their offerings down to a few core products, it appears that Hillenbrand, the casket maker and cremation services provider, wants to branch out  into industrial feeders and pneumatic conveyors.

title: The Morning Skate: Strange Things Happen and a Veterans Regret
description: It was a strange weekend in the N.H.L., not the first, and certainly not the last. But we dont often have games spliced in half as the Devils-Tampa Bay contest was on Friday and Sunday. Sundays resumption of the half-completed game, postponed because of a partial power failure, drew about 3,000 fans, wrote Dave Caldwell in The New York Times.

title: Jive Software Grows Up
description: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

title: Ford Adds a 5-Liter V-8 for Mustang Customers Who Must Have One
description: DETROIT  The 5.0 badge on the side of the Mustang on the Ford stand at the North American International Auto show is a symbol of something: the schizophrenic nature of the auto industry, or the range of automotive customers. While Bill Ford, Fords chairman, was at another part of the stand talking about how the company has finally united behind the idea of sustainability and fuel efficiency, Ford was introducing its latest V-8.

title: A Push to Bring the S.S. United States Back Home
description: The S.S. United States, which carried immigrants to America and vacationers to Europe faster than any other ocean liner, has not sailed into New York harbor in 40 years. But some fans of the giant ship are telling city officials that it should come home to Manhattan.

title: It Takes More Than Paper to Raise a Puppy
description: ALL last week, like clockwork, Scout sneaked into our bedroom and licked my face at 3:25 a.m. Precisely. Talk about an unwelcome wake-up call.

title: The Decline of Central Bank Power
description: Deference to central bankers reached a high sometime in the 1990s, fell some after the technology bubble burst, and is now as low as I can remember.

title: Stunning Defeats Raise Serious Doubts
description: The first mention of the future came just 10 questions into Bill Belichicks clipped news conference Sunday afternoon.

title: View From the Bridge Actor Is Down for the Count
description: Even bogus boxing can be hazardous on a Broadway stage. Santino Fontana, who plays the young suitor Rodolpho in the current Broadway production of A View From the Bridge, remains out of the show since sustaining a minor concussion from a boxing scene with Liev Schreibers character during a performance New Years weekend. Mr. Fontana left the show temporarily under doctors orders, according to a statement on Thursday from a publicist for the show, and he was scheduled to still be off for Monday nights performance. It is not clear when he will return. The role of Rodolpho is being played by the understudy, Morgan Spector. Mr. Fontana sustained the concussion during a scene in which Rodolpho is drawn into sparring by Eddie Carbone (Mr. Schreiber), the jealous uncle of Rodolphos love interest, Catherine (Scarlett Johansson). No one from the production was available to comment on Monday about Mr. Fontanas health or whether the boxing scene has been re-choreographed, the publicist said.

title: Avatar, Hangover Crash Writers Guild Party
description: Avatar has been lauded for its technological wizardry and the all-encompassing movie experience it offers. As for the writing: not so much. But that hasnt prevented the Writers Guild of America from nominating James Cameron, the movies writer and director, for best original screenplay. Hell face off against Scott Neustadter and Michael H. Weber for (500) Days of Summer; John Lucas and Scott More for the The Hangover; Mark Boal for The Hurt Locker; and Joel and Ethan Coen for A Serious Man.

title: S.E.C. Seeks New Charge Against Bank of America
description: Update | 7:49 p.m. Judge Jed S. Rakoff ruled on Monday that the S.E.C. cannot amend its complaint against Bank of America a second time, but can file a new complaint. More here.

title: Simon Cowell to Leave American Idol
description: Simon Cowell, the star of the Fox networks biggest show, American Idol, announced Monday that he will leave the show after this season and will start a new singing competition show, The X Factor, on Fox starting in 2011.

title: Commentary: A Plea to Add Consumer Protections to Student Loans
description: Mr. Collinge is the author of The Student Loan Scam: The Most Oppressive Debt in U.S. History  and How We Can Fight Back, and the founder of the Web site studentloanjustice.org.

title: Simon Cowell Confirms Hes Leaving American Idol
description: Simon Cowell, the music impresario and tough-talking American Idol judge you love to hate, will leave American Idol, the Fox reality competition, after the current season, he said on Monday. Mr. Cowell made the announcement during a Fox presentation at the Television Critics Association press tour in California. Though there had been speculation about Mr. Cowells status with the show for several weeks, he said that he had only formally reached an agreement with Fox at half-past-10 this morning to bring another reality series, The X Factor, to the network next year. Mr. Cowell said he would leave American Idol to focus on that show. Bill Carter is at the event and will have updates on Media Decoder.

title: New Jersey Vote Backs Marijuana for Severely Ill
description: TRENTON  The New Jersey Legislature approved a measure on Monday that would make the state the 14th in the nation, but one of the few on the East Coast, to legalize the use of marijuana to help patients with chronic illnesses.

title: James Roday and Michael Weston Join the Cast of Extinction
description: The actors James Roday (Shawn Spencer on the television series Psych) and Michael Weston (Lucas Douglas on televisions House) will star as two friends who face the consequences of a weekend of debauchery in Extinction, a new play by Gabe McKinley, a publicist for the production said on Monday. The production is scheduled to run at Off Broadways Cherry Lane Theater from Feb. 13 to March 14. Directed by Wayne Kasserman, the cast will also include Amanda Detmer and Stefanie E. Frame, who appeared with the two men in a run of the play in Los Angeles last fall.

title: Union Chief Blasts Health Benefits Tax
description: Richard Trumka, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.s new president, issued a stern warning to Democratic leaders on Monday, just hours before he and other labor leaders were to meet with President Obama to protest his support of a tax on employer-sponsored health benefits.

title: Hunting Fossil Viruses in Human DNA
description: The borna virus is at once obscure and grotesque. It can infect mammals and birds, but scientists know little about its effects on its victims. In some species it seems to be harmless, but it can drive horses into wild fits. The horses sometimes kill themselves by smashing in their skulls. In other cases, they starve themselves to death. Some scientists have even claimed that borna viruses alter human behavior, playing a role in schizophrenia and bipolar disorder, although others say there is no solid evidence of a link.

title: Readers Dog Photos
description: Dogs of all breeds and sizes are represented in this album of photos submitted by readers.

title: McGwire Admits That He Used Steroids
description: Mark McGwire, whose inflated statistics and refusal to address his past came to symbolize a synthetic era in baseball history, acknowledged on Monday that he used steroids through the 1990s.

title: F.T.C.: Has Internet Gone Beyond Privacy Policies?
description: Two top Federal Trade Commission officials questioned whether the Internet had evolved past privacy policies, at a meeting with editors and reporters of The New York Times today.

title: The Match Game
description: I dont put a great deal of stock in overly precise efforts to pair food and wine. I understand the desire to get things right  who wants wine and food to blot each other out?  but obsessive efforts, special methods, pairing wheels, etc., hold very little interest for me. I just want to have a good meal, with good wine, and I want to enjoy them both, together. I dont think selecting proper wines is a problem, once you get in the habit of drinking wine with your meals.

title: 2010 Detroit Auto Show
description: Highlights from the North American International Auto Show in Detroit.

title: Thinking About Shrinking
description: Q. Do people really shrink with age? If so, what can be done about it?

title: When Is Grabbing the Face Mask Not a Face-Mask Penalty?
description: To some, the picture speaks 1,000 words and four of them are: the Packers were robbed. The image of Cardinals cornerback Michael Adams with his index finger hooked on Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgerss face mask was captured far and wide, sparking the question of whether it was a penalty and why it did not negate the fumble Adams caused. The question gets louder because the fumble Adams caused turned into the game-winning touchdown in overtime of the N.F.C. wild card playoff game when linebacker Karlos Dansby ran it into the end zone.

title: With Updated Hubble Telescope, Reaching Farther Back in Time
description: Astronaut repairmen had hardly finished tightening the last stubborn bolts on the Hubble Space Telescope last summer when astronomers set the controls on the refurbished telescope to the dim and distant past.

title: Not All Ski Slopes Are Environmentally Equal, Study Concludes
description: Ski resorts are not as fun for the environment as they are for skiers. The damage to forested hills caused by the construction of ski slopes is obvious. Trees are cut down, ground is cleared, and the resulting slopes are maintained as the foundation for a yearly carpet of snow.

title: Paterson Joins the Political Chorus Urging Ford Not to Challenge Gillibrand
description: ALBANY  Add Gov. David A. Paterson to the list of prominent New York Democrats who are less than thrilled with the idea of Harold E. Ford Jr. making a bid to be the states next junior senator.

title: The Madness of Crowds and an Internet Delusion
description: When does the wisdom of crowds give way to the meanness of mobs?

title: Personal Focus as Same-Sex-Marriage Trial Opens in California
description: SAN FRANCISCO  It was not the type of question that one usually hears from lawyers in federal court.

title: The Flowerings of Love Are Not for the Weak
description: At 2 oclock in the morning, no one is to blame, Amy Bloom writes at the start of her beautifully astute new book. Her narrator is Clare, a middle-aged academic speaking in the present tense.

title: Tracking Device Reports a Round-Trip Wonder
description: To reach elite status in many airline frequent-flier programs, you have to log at least 50,000 miles in the air in a year.

title: Warmed by the Sun, Asteroid Changes Shape
description: The main asteroid belt is a cosmic rock tumbler, filled with small bodies that have been shaped and sized through collisions over billions of years. But impact is not the only thing that can affect an asteroids appearance. If a rock is small enough, light can do it, too.

title: Detroit Auto Show: BMW Z4 sDrive35is
description: Introduced on Monday: 2011 BMW Z4 sDrive35is

title: Regimens: Withdrawal Warning on Parkinsons Drugs
description: Some people with Parkinsons disease develop severe withdrawal symptoms when they try to taper off a widely used type of Parkinsons drug, researchers are reporting.

title: Anthrax: In Scotland, Six Heroin Users Die of Anthrax Poisoning
description: Six heroin users in Scotland have died of anthrax poisoning, and more have fallen ill, British health authorities said last week.

title: Under the Radar: Five Questions About Chautauqua!
description: Chautauqua was an educational movement of the late 19th century that invited residents in towns across the country under big tents to hear what teachers, scientists, preachers, musicians and artists had to say.

title: Before You Quit Antidepressants ...
description: Last week, The Journal of the American Medical Association published a study questioning the effectiveness of antidepressant drugs. The drugs are useful in cases of severe depression, it said. But for most patients, those with mild to moderate cases, the most commonly used antidepressants are generally no better than a placebo.

title: Getting the Goods on Your Date
description: Lets say you meet a guy or woman at a bar, and theres a connection. What is the first thing you do?

title: Life Lessons From Big Love
description: Polygamy is wrong. It is illegal. It is a subjugation of women. And yet, as the show Big Love entered its fourth season last night, Michele Gazzolo, an anthropologist and writer who lives in southwest Michigan, is once again taken by the idea of a life with sister-wives to share the daily parenting chores.

title: Detroit Auto Show: For Honda, One More Try at a Sporty Hybrid
description: DETROIT  After showing two concept versions of its CR-Z, most recently at the Tokyo Motor Show last October, Honda finally introduced the real thing here.

title: Now Showing | Andrea Branzi
description: If you happen to be in Paris this week, its your last chance to see Grandi Legni, an exhibition of work by the Italian architect and designer Andrea Branzi at the Azzedine Alaia Gallery. Organized by two well-known Milan galleries  Design Gallery Milano and Nilufar  the exhibition features large-scale, mixed-media works that are the latest in Branzis continuing investigation of the anthropological, animist roots of design. Branzi, who was part of the radical architecture studio Archizoom in the 1960s and was a co-founder of the Domus Academy, feels that in its quest for formal perfection, contemporary design has hit a self-referential brick wall. In these seemingly primitive, totemic pieces, he employs old wood beams (the big woods of the exhibitions title), semiprecious stones, mosaic and a new printing technology from 3M to search for the soul of design between the ancient and the modern.

title: Healthy Aging, With Nary a Supplement
description: The Great Recession, so Im told, has been great for one segment of the economy  the makers of pills and potions that offer the promise of keeping people healthy. A middle-aged woman remarked as she perused the supplement shelves in my local health food store (I was buying bulgur): I cant afford to get sick. I lost my job and I have no health insurance.

title: Hedge Funds Had a Banner Year in 2009
description: December and 2009 year-end results for the nations biggest hedge funds are starting to trickle in, and DealBook has obtained some of the numbers. Hedge Fund Research, which tracks a number of funds, said its index of fund returns gained 1.25 percent in December, bringing last years gains up to 20.04 percent.

title: Pinot Noir With an Umlaut
description: TODAYS word, people, is sptburgunder. Lets say it slowly: SHPAYT-bur-GUHN-der. Thats German for pinot noir, and the time has come to say it out loud.

title: To Treat Bed-Wetting, Healthy Doses of Patience
description: A couple of weeks ago, I saw a 5-year-old girl who was still wetting the bed every night. Its a common complaint: at least 15 percent of healthy 5-year-olds are not reliably dry at night. And bed-wetting is quite common even in older children.

title: High Energy Costs and Dollars Decline Undermine Alcoas Profit
description: Alcoa, the aluminum producer, reported fourth-quarter profit on Monday that trailed analysts estimates as the company faced higher energy and currency costs.

title: When a Child Wets the Bed
description: In this weeks 18 and Under column, Dr. Perri Klass, a pediatrician, explores the challenges of nocturnal enuresis, or bed wetting. While parents often accuse bedwetters of laziness, the problem can stem from a number of physiological causes, writes Dr. Klass:

title: Journeys in Cross-Cultural Drinking, Crimped by Jet Lag
description: IVE become an accidental expert in drinking and traveling. I love my job. I learn about new cultures and I get to party with the locals. Whats not to like?

title: Google Apologizes to Chinese Authors
description: BEIJING  Google has agreed to hand over a list of books by Chinese authors that it has scanned in recent years, company executives said on Monday, in an apparent effort to placate writers who say their works were digitized without their permission.

title: Detroit Auto Show: Audis Second Electric E-Tron
description: DETROIT  Audi introduced a second electric car prototype in Detroit today, and its a family affair. Like the two-seater sports car Audi showed off recently in Frankfurt and Los Angeles, the new concept is also named E-Tron. The automaker is not trying to be confusing, said Michael Dick, a member of Audis Management Board, interviewed in Detroit. Audi says that E-Tron will be the name for a family of electric cars  hopefully to gain the same kind of resonance as quattro and TDI.

title: Amid Scandals, Northern Irelands Leader Takes a Leave
description: LONDON  After days of political turmoil in Northern Ireland over the personal and financial affairs of his wife, the provinces first minister, Peter Robinson, stepped down temporarily on Monday as a co-leader of the power-sharing government that has ruled the province since 2007.

title: Unions Want Obama to Drop Tax on Benefits
description: Union leaders said Monday afternoon that they planned to tell President Obama in a meeting later in the day that it would be a costly political mistake to enact an excise tax on high-priced, employer-sponsored health benefits.

title: Eric Rohmer, in His Own Words
description: In his obituary of Eric Rohmer, the father of the French New Wave, who died on Monday at the age of 89, my colleague Dave Kehr writes:

title: Detroit Auto Show: BMW Concept ActiveE
description: Introduced Monday, Jan. 11: BMW Concept ActiveE

title: A Fantastical Epic Seen Through Gertrude Steins Rose-Colored Glasses
description: The truism that theater is a place for collective make-believe has never seemed more true than at The Myopia, David Greenspans madcap, mind-bending odyssey into the poetics of the stage.

title: Aging Well, Without Pills and Potions
description: In this weeks Personal Health column, Jane Brody writes about the general publics willingness to spend money on supplements for better health. She writes:

title: A New Tax on Banks and Bankers?
description: Updated, Jan. 12, 12:10 p.m. |  Judy Samuelson of the Aspen Institute joins the discussion.

title: Clinton, Starting Trip, Acknowledges Possible Tensions With China
description: HONOLULU  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, embarking on her first diplomatic trip of 2010, will try to ease tensions with Japan, Americas most important Asian ally, over a stalled agreement to relocate a Marine base on the island of Okinawa.

title: Ex-Lehman General Counsel Asked to Join A.I.G.
description: The former general counsel at Lehman Brothers, Thomas A. Russo, has been asked to play that role at the American International Group following the departure of the insurers top in-house lawyer, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Monday.

title: Coal Is Linked to Cancer in China Province
description: Nonsmoking women in an area of Chinas Yunnan province die of lung cancer at a rate 20 times that of their counterparts in other regions of the country  and higher than anywhere else in the world.

title: 'Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf'
description: A. O. Scott takes a look at a very unusual relationship at the heart of Mike Nichols's 1966 film, adapted from Edward Albee's Broadway play.

title: Onstage Boxing Packs a Wallop
description: Even bogus boxing can be hazardous on a Broadway stage. Santino Fontana, below, who plays the young suitor Rodolpho in the current Broadway production of A View From the Bridge, remains out of the show since sustaining a minor concussion from a boxing scene with Liev Schreibers character during a performance on New Years weekend. Mr. Fontana left the show temporarily under doctors orders, according to a statement on Thursday from a publicist for the show, and he was scheduled still to be off for Monday nights performance. It is not clear when he will return. The role of Rodolpho is being played by the understudy, Morgan Spector. Mr. Fontana sustained the concussion during a scene in which Rodolpho is drawn into sparring by Eddie Carbone (Mr. Schreiber), the jealous uncle of Rodolphos love interest, Catherine (Scarlett Johansson). No one from the production was available to comment on Monday about Mr. Fontanas health or whether the boxing scene has been rechoreographed, the publicist said.

title: Chicago Flutist Denies Unkind Sentiments
description: A flutist with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra who briefly took a temporary post with the Los Angeles Philharmonic, only to return to Chicago, apologized for his departure and denied a news report in which he appeared to be critical of the Philharmonic. The flutist, Mathieu Dufour, had been on leave from the Chicago orchestra when he joined the Philharmonic on a one-year trial basis, starting in September. But this month he told The Chicago Sun-Times that he had decided not to remain in Los Angeles, telling that newspaper that the Philharmonic has no tradition there  no tradition of sound and no tradition of working together as a dedicated ensemble. In an e-mail message to the Philharmonics musicians reported by the Culture Monster blog of The Los Angeles Times (latimesblogs.latimes.com/culturemonster), Mr. Dufour wrote that he had returned to Chicago to have shoulder surgery and apologized for having left the season so abruptly. He also wrote that he was grossly misquoted by The Chicago Sun-Times, and added, I sincerely hope that none of you have read it, but if any of you have seen it, I beg you not to pay any attention to it. Andrew Patner, who wrote the report for The Sun-Times, told Culture Monster that he stood behind his reporting.

title: A Big Woo-Hoo for Simpsons
description: A Fox celebration of the 20th-anniversary episode of The Simpsons, above, attracted as many as 20 million viewers on Sunday, according to Nielsens early ratings estimates. Those preliminary audience figures may be somewhat inflated by Foxs overtime coverage of the N.F.C. wildcard football game, which drew more than 30 million viewers to Fox for the start of prime time. But based on the estimates, Fox projected that its anniversary episode of The Simpsons earned the seriess highest ratings since an episode that followed the Super Bowl five years ago. Fox won the night over all, drawing 12.3 million viewers for a documentary special, The Simpsons 20th Anniversary Special: In 3-D! On Ice! ABC placed second, while CBS and NBC ranked third and fourth. NBCs third-season premiere of Chuck averaged 7.4 million viewers.

title: Denmark Leads the Way in Digital Care
description: COPENHAGEN  Jens Danstrup, a 77-year-old retired architect, used to bike all around town. But years of smoking have weakened his lungs, and these days he finds it difficult to walk down his front steps and hail a taxi for a doctors appointment.

title: Glee Sends Out Call for Reinforcements
description: For its second season, the Fox musical Glee is holding a nationwide search for three new singers. The casting calls will begin in February for professionals and amateurs, ages 16 to 26, the Glee executive producer Ryan Murphy announced at a press event on Monday. Anybody and everybody now has a chance to be on a show about talented underdogs, Mr. Murphy said. Meanwhile, Fox confirmed on Monday that Glee would be renewed for a second season. The show has tested its fans patience at times, first with a preview of the first episode in May, four months before its season premiere, and again with another four-month break this winter between the first and second halves of the season.

title: Judges Announced for Sundance Festival
description: Enter the judges. The Sundance Film Festival, above, which begins on Jan. 21 in Utah, announced on Monday the members of the five juries awarding prizes. The awards will be presented on Jan. 30 by David Hyde Pierce. The United States dramatic competition will be evaluated by the author Russell Banks (Cloudsplitter, The Sweet Hereafter); Jason Kliot, producer of 20 films that have been screened at the festival, including Welcome to the Dollhouse; Karyn Kusama, director of Aeon Flux and Jennifers Body, the critically drubbed zombie cheerleader movie; the actress Parker Posey (The House of Yes, Best in Show); and Robert Yeoman, a cinematographer on films like Bottle Rocket and Drugstore Cowboy. Lined up for the United States documentary competition are the producer-director Greg Barker (Sergio); the producer-director Dayna Goldfine (Ballets Russes); Nancy Miller, a senior editor at Wired magazine; the filmmaker Morgan Spurlock (Super Size Me); and Ondi Timoner, the only filmmaker to win the Grand Jury prize at Sundance twice, for Dig! and We Live in Public.

title: Detroit Auto Show: Auto Workers Union Holds Jobs Protest
description: DETROIT  Nearly 100 auto workers and labor activists demonstrated in snowy, blustery conditions near the North American International Auto Show here, calling for a federal jobs recovery bill, a national single-payer health system and a green industrial policy.

title: Facing End-of-Life Talks, Doctors Choose to Wait
description: Its a conversation that most people dread, doctors and patients alike. The cancer is terminal, time is short, and tough decisions loom  about accepting treatment or rejecting it, and choosing where and how to die.

title: A Lifes Labors Lost, but So What?
description: ITS not a good idea to ignore what your computer is trying to tell you when it starts to do that thing where every once in a while the screen freezes like an ice rink and the cursor gets stuck on it, like a stranded skater.

title: New Film May Sway Brazils Vote on President
description: SANTO ANTNIO de JESUS, Brazil  In the opening scenes of a new Brazilian movie, a 7-year-old boy roams barefoot through the parched, cactus-filled dirt of the northeastern town of Caets, collecting water from a creek where cows drink while his mother waits in the one-room house he shares with seven brothers and sisters.

title: States of Suffering
description: The downturn continues to gnaw away at states budgets, a new report shows.

title: Who Owns What at Tavern on the Green?
description: And so, a new front was opened Monday in the enduringly complex court struggle over the assets of the bankrupt Tavern on the Green  the Battle of the Wormy Chestnut Wood.

title: What Idol Will Lose When Simon Cowell Departs
description: Its a little too easy, but it bears saying: in leaving American Idol to produce an American version of his own show The X Factor, Simon Cowell will be taking the Idol X factor along with him.

title: Asked & Answered | Chris Benz
description: With his penchant for classic American sportswear, his gentlemanly manners and his coterie of well-bred friends  Elettra Wiedemann, the model/grad student is his muse  Chris Benz is a designer who evokes a courtlier time. He likes to sift through his grandmothers attic for inspiration and he recently traded in an old photo booth for a digital camera, but as Benz acknowledges with a sigh, its not the same. Even the lipstick color he created for Lancme, the hotly anticipated Chris and Tell, due out next month, is a Mad Men-era peach.

title: Deciphering the Chatter of Monkeys and Chimps
description: Walking through the Tai forest of Ivory Coast, Klaus Zuberbhler could hear the calls of the Diana monkeys, but the babble held no meaning for him.

title: Part 1: A Dose of Knotty Modernism. Part 2: Quaint Nostalgia.
description: As programming approaches go, the one that James Levine ventured in a concert by the Met Chamber Ensemble at Zankel Hall on Sunday evening was a doozy. The first half of the program offered vocal works by Milton Babbitt and Elliott Carter, formidable modernists for whom Mr. Levine has shown a durable affinity; the second, Richard Strausss Brger als Edelmann Suite, quaint, nostalgic music written for a staging of Molires play Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme. Finding offers for midconcert ticket handoffs on Craigslist would have been no surprise.

title: Coat Company Agrees to Pull Obama Billboard
description: Weatherproof Garment Company, which turned heads last week with a Times Square billboard showing President Obama in one of its coats, has agreed to take down the billboard after hearing from the White House.

title: A Call to Rein In Cold or Hot Climate Hype
description: Richard Betts, the head of the climate impacts division at Britains Met Office, has contributed a very useful essay to the BBCs always illuminating Green Room opinion column in which he urges climate scientists to help society avoid misinterpretations or exploitation of climate extremes  either hot or cold. I asked him a few follow-up questions and the answers follow, but first, here are a couple of excerpts from the column.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Simpsons Joke You Didnt See
description: Heres the closing message from the 20th anniversary episode of The Simpsons as it was shown to reporters and critics, with its parting gag about Seth MacFarlane still intact.

title: Another Look at F.D.R. (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:
