title: AOL Begins 1,200 Layoffs
description: AOL announced in November that it planned to cut its work force by about one-third, cutting up to 2,500 positions. On Monday, AOL said that about 1,100 employees accepted a buyout offer, and that this week it would begin laying off an 1,200 more workers.

title: Shopping With Grace Bonney
description: The founder of the blog Design*Sponge scours the sales in January, when many stores offer significant discounts to clear their stock for spring.

title: A World of Fusions: Hot, Cool and Otherwise
description: Some of the oldest-sounding music at the seventh annual Globalfest  a dozen world-music bands performing on Sunday at Webster Hall  was thoroughly up to date.

title: Sweet January
description: WELL-DESIGNED home furnishings arent hard to find, but too often, said Grace Bonney, 28, the founder of the popular blog Design*Sponge, they are priced beyond the reach of people like her.

title: On Our Radar
description: A roundup of electric vehicle news from our friends at the Wheels blog, who are keeping tabs on the Detroit auto show this week:

title: Who Owns What at Tavern on the Green?
description: From Glenn Collins at Diners Journal:

title: Rhythms Bursting With Suspense
description: For the major events of any Noche Flamenca program, no choreographer is cited. Some are pure music anyway, but  as with many but not all other flamenco presentations  the major dance solos apparently have no author save their performers.

title: In Florida, Fresh Talent Takes to the Stage, Along With a Veteran Team
description: MIAMI  At the end of three of the five ballets in Miami City Ballets new program in the Adrienne Arsht Center here, people leapt to their feet at each performance last weekend; after every work there were cheers from all parts of the large auditorium. Yet the ovations stayed brief. And I suspect that relatively few people in South Florida, many of whom are still discovering each of these ballets for the first time, realize just how remarkable this company is.

title: One Ballplayer Heartened by McGwires Admission
description: People who know Mark McGwire tend to love him. For Shelley Duncan, the former Yankee who signed with Cleveland recently, his relationship with McGwire runs deep.

title: Los Angeles Museum Taps Dealer as Director
description: After days of relentless rumors, the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles confirmed on Monday that it had chosen Jeffrey Deitch, a veteran commercial dealer and deal maker, to be its new director, a straddling of the gallery and museum worlds that has few precedents.

title: 1987 Redux?
description: The Standard & Poors 500-stock index has risen each day for the first six trading sessions of the year.

title: A Song of Silicon Valley
description: On Friday night, TechCrunch, GigaOm and VentureBeat held the annual Crunchies Awards for entrepreneurs and the venture capitalists who support them.

title: Mysterious, Low-Tech, Basement Barnum
description: If it were possible to pet a piece of experimental theater, thats what you would want to do to LEffet de Serge, a French poodle of a show that is ingratiating itself with downtown audiences as part of the Public Theaters annual Under the Radar Festival. This mysterious little play reveals an unassuming, modest gentleman named Serge staging low-tech spectacles in his cluttered basement for an audience that could fit inside a bathroom.

title: City Unveils Plan to Trim Food Industrys Use of Salt
description: Depending on your point of view, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is either a crusader for healthy living or a public scold who likes to tell people what they should and (more often) should not eat.

title: Bootstrapping The Messenger
description: Six and a half million dollars. Thats how much The Messenger, the story of two Army men tasked with delivering, as A. O. Scott put it, the grimmest imaginable news to military families, cost to make. A lot in the real world, to be sure, but not very much for moviedom, considering that the cast includes Woody Harrelson, Ben Foster, Samantha Morton and Steve Buscemi. To cut costs, many perks were eliminated: Mr. Harrelson and Mr. Foster shared a trailer, and the shoot was a bone-thin 28 days.

title: In Mass. Senate Race, Candidates Sharpen Their Pitches
description: Update | 9:08 p.m. Martha Coakley, the Democrat running for Senator Edward M. Kennedys seat in Massachusetts, called a news conference Monday to attack her Republican rivals stance on taxes, health care and same-sex marriage amid more signs of Democratic anxiety about the race.

title: Citis Memo on Changes at Consumer Banking Unit
description: Update | 6:25 p.m. The New York Timess Eric Dash provides more details of the management shake-up at Citigroup.

title: Banks Losses May Spell Shake-Up in Germany
description: Even in an era of bad banking deals, the case of Munich-based Bayerische Landesbank stands out, The New York Timess Jack Ewing reports from Frankfurt.

title: In Some Metro Areas, Job Growth
description: Unemployment rates  that is, the percentage of workers who want jobs and cant find them  were higher in November than a year earlier in all 372 of the nations metropolitan areas, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported last week. But in some metro areas, the number of nonfarm payroll jobs actually grew.

title: Letter: Cutting Travel Costs
description: To the Editor: Regarding the Practical Traveler column 10 Ways to Cut Your Travel Costs This Year (Jan. 10), as I read this article, I thought to myself: We are still in a recession. People are spending carefully; discretionary funds are all but extinct. So, why would I go through all this trouble (10 steps) to find a cheap fare. The airlines and hotels want my money. Theyve made a fortune over the past 10 years during the boom; now they have to adjust and offer me deep discounts if they want my money. I will not be running myself ragged trying to get the best deal. Period.

title: Letter: Traveling to Tucson
description: To the Editor: The article 36 Hours Tucson, Ariz. (Jan. 3) gave lots of excellent suggestions about my city. I was surprised, though, that the author recommended flying to Phoenix and driving scenic I-10 to Tucson. This is one of the most unattractive and crowded roads in Arizona, and it can be closed for hours by traffic accidents (once you leave Phoenix, theres no alternate route). Anyone who wants to come to Tucson for just 36 hours  and spend four (or many more) hours on I-10  should instead take a flight to our convenient, uncrowded airport.

title: Corrections
description: The 36 Hours column on Jan. 3 about Tucson, Ariz., misstated the cross street of the location of one cafe and misstated part of the name of a menu item at another cafe. The Epic Cafe is on the corner of University Boulevard, not University Avenue, and the sampler of three dishes chosen by the chef at Cafe Poca Cosa is called El Plato Poca Cosa, not La Plato Poca Cosa.

title: Critics Picks Video: Whos Afraid of Virginia Woolf
description: In this weeks Critics Picks, A. O. Scott looks at the 1966 Mike Nichols film Whos Afraid of Virginia Woolf, adapted from Edward Albees play. The film stars Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton, a real-life married couple at the time, acting out their domestic drama on the screen as the characters George and Martha. About their performances, Mr. Scott says the two probably do more acting per frame of film in this movie than youve ever seen in your life. Please  share your thoughts on the performances in Whos Afraid of Virginia Woolf.

title: Citigroup Replaces Head of Consumer Banking
description: Citigroup announced on Monday that it would replace the head of its consumer banking business  the most troubled part of its financial empire  as the company braces for fresh troubles with home mortgages and credit cards this year.

title: A New Boss, and a Jolt of Real-World Expertise
description: When the going gets desperate, the desperate get creative. On Monday the beleaguered Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles named as its new director Jeffrey Deitch, a prominent New York art dealer. This comes less than a week after Bill Moggridge, a prominent industrial designer and businessman, became the first design practitioner to head the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum in New York  an institution thought by many to lack vision.

title: Landesbank Losses May Bring Change to German Banking
description: FRANKFURT  Even in an era of bad banking deals, the case of Bayerische Landesbank, a bank based in Munich, stands out.

title: Stroller, Diapers, Paperwork
description: THE recent return to the United States of a 9-year-old boy who was at the center of an international abduction and custody dispute once again called attention to the issues that can complicate international travel with children, especially when one parent is staying behind.

title: A Year After a Splashdown, Returning to the Hudson
description: In almost everyones mind, it ranked as one of those where-were-you-when moments: the moment on a waning January afternoon when an airplane landed in the Hudson River.

title: Mood Music and the Times Movie Reviews API
description: Our series of posts about external uses of Times APIs continues. Today were showcasing MovieMusicNow.com, which uses the Times Movie Reviews API.

title: A Backup Sees Plenty of Action Off the Field
description: Surely Blue Mountain State, which officially arrives Tuesday on Spike, is the show that will finally get young heterosexual men to rise up and demand programming that doesnt presume they are sex-obsessed Neanderthals.

title: Detroit Auto Show: My Pet PEEV
description: Introduced on Monday (sort of): 2010 CT&T Parking Enforcement Electric Vehicle

title: Ben Brantley Takes Readers Questions on London Theater
description: Planning a trip to the West End? Need a Shakespeare fix, but not sure what to see? Ben Brantley, chief theater critic for The New York Times, is taking readers questions about the London theater scene  whats hot, whats not and which actors are sizzling  or fizzling  on stage.

title: A Song of Silicon Valley
description: From Damon Darlin at Bits:

title: A Tribute to Her Father, Heavy on Latin Percussion
description: Nattily attired in white tuxedos and black ties, the New Desi Arnaz Orchestra, a 15-member Latin swing band with strings, sent a mild percussive charge from the stage of the Kaufmann Concert Hall at the 92nd Street Y on Saturday evening. It was the first of five performances of an engaging show written and hosted by Lucie Arnaz, in tribute to her father, the Cuban-born bandleader Desi Arnaz.

title: Look Out, Pixar, Here Comes Fantastic Mr. Fox
description: LOS ANGELES  Figuring out which film will win the Academy Award for best animated feature is usually the easiest part of filling out a ballot for your Oscar pool. Go down the list of nominees  often only three, because so few make the cut  and find the one produced by Pixar. Circle it.

title: Sony Switches Spider-Man Plans
description: Spider-Man and Tobey Maguire are parting ways. Mr. Maguire was set to reprise his leading role in Spider-Man 4 in May 2011 with Sam Raimi, who directed the first three installments, returning to the helm. But following disagreements about the creative direction of the film (Hollywood translation: the script wasnt so good and there were conflicting casting strategies), Mr. Raimi opted to move on, according to Deadline.com. Rather than move forward with a different director, Sony decided to push the button on a Spider-Man reboot that it has been simultaneously developing. In a press release Monday afternoon, Sony confirmed that the next Spider-Man movie will take Peter Parker back to high school. The new chapter, written by James Vanderbilt (Zodiac), will have a new cast and director and focus on a teenager dealing with both contemporary human problems and amazing super-human crises, Sony said. The target release date is now summer 2012. Together, the first three Spider-Man movies sold over $1 billion in tickets at North American theaters, according to Box Office Mojo.

title: Scary Ad Fails to Stop Croatia From Going Red
description: On Sunday, Croatians gave Ivo Josipovic a landslide victory in the countrys presidential election despite an ad campaign by his main rival that sought to portray the avant-garde composer and law professor as a Dr. Evil-like figure scheming to return the nation to communism.

title: Perella Hires Tokums Investment Team
description: Perella Weinberg Partners, the boutique investment bank run by Joseph R. Perella, left, has hired Tokum Capital Managements investment team.

title: Side by Side, With the Guilty, After Courts Send Them Home
description: Almost 10 years in the making, My Neighbor My Killer examines the emotional and judicial convulsions of post-genocide Rwanda through the oral testimonies of a handful of traumatized survivors.

title: Ads to Protest Smoking in Avatar
description: Those who oppose smoking in movies aimed at young people planned to step up their assault on the science-fiction epic Avatar on Tuesday with advertisements in Hollywood trade papers that accuse the film of providing the equivalent of $50 million in free tobacco advertising. The full-page ads were scheduled to run in both The Hollywood Reporter and Daily Variety. For every $100 million it earns at the box office, Avatar will deliver an estimated 40 million tobacco impressions to theater audiences, said the ads, referring to scenes involving a cigarette-smoking character played by Sigourney Weaver. That estimate of the films value to tobacco companies included anticipated home video sales. To date, Avatar has taken in more than $1.3 billion at the worldwide box office. In a statement last week, James Cameron, its director, took sharp issue with the notion that the movie advocates smoking simply because it portrays cigarette use. The new advertisements were paid for by Smoke Free Movies, a campaign supervised by Stanton A. Glantz, director of the Center for Tobacco Control Research and Education at the University of California, San Francisco, with backing from the American Legacy Foundation. The foundation was established with money from a 1998 settlement of legal claims between tobacco companies and 46 states.

title: Mr. Deitch Goes to MOCA. How Will the Art World Change?
description: The Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles confirmed on Monday that it had chosen Jeffrey Deitch, a veteran commercial dealer and deal maker, to be its new director, a straddling of the gallery and museum worlds that has few precedents, as Carol Vogel and Randy Kennedy write in an article about the appointment.

title: As China Rises, Fears Grow on Whether Boom Can Endure
description: BEIJING  As much of the world struggles to clamber out of a serious recession, a gradual flow of economic power from West to East has turned into a flood.

title: Midtown Lunchs Founder Leaves Town
description: Zach Brooks, the founder of Midtown Lunch, the great guide to cheap food in central Manhattan, confirmed that hell be moving to Los Angeles at the end of this month, as  Eater reported earlier. His wife, a lawyer, will be taking a job there. But by Thursday or Friday hell be adding Downtown and Philadelphia sections to the blog, which he said will be run, at least temporarily, by a roster of contributors after he leaves.

title: Nomura Taps Lehman Banker as Americas Head
description: Nomura said Monday that it has named former Lehman Brothers banker Glenn H. Schiffman as its head of investment banking for the Americas, as the Japanese investment bank seeks to bolster its international presence.

title: Astors Son to Stay Free During Appeal
description: Brooke Astors son may remain free while his lawyers appeal his conviction on charges of stealing from and defrauding his mother, an appeals court judge has ordered.

title: 5 Convicted in Britain Over Protest at Parade
description: LONDON  A court found five British Muslim men guilty on Monday of harassment and using insulting language during a protest they had staged at a parade welcoming British troops home from Afghanistan. The men had shouted slogans describing the soldiers as murderers, rapists and baby killers.

title: Frigid Temperatures in South Are Putting Pipes and Patience to the Test
description: Unusually cold temperatures caused more than 70 city water mains to break over the past week in Jackson, Miss., prompting Gov. Haley Barbour to declare a state of emergency and close state offices on Monday.

title: Oh, Right, That Attack Under Bush
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani has taken a lot of heat since Friday, and it isnt fair. Of course he knows that George W. Bush was president when the hijacked planes hit the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Lawyers Challenge Ohio on Executions
description: Proper training of prison officials could have prevented a botched execution in Ohio last year that led the state to overhaul its method of execution, lawyers for several death row inmates have argued in court filings.

title: Miep Gies, Protector of Anne Frank, Dies at 100
description: Miep Gies, the last survivor among Anne Franks protectors and the woman who preserved the diary that endures as a testament to the human spirit in the face of unfathomable evil, died Monday night, the Anne Frank Museum in Amsterdam said. She was 100.

title: Working with the Taliban?
description: The Wall Street Journal has a fascinating article today by Yaroslav Trofimov about how the U.N. is working in rural Afghanistan to vaccinate kids against polio  and carrying letters from Mullah Omar to protect them from local militants and fundamentalists. The laissez-passers from Mullah Omar are the only way for health workers to reach the more violent parts of rural Afghanistan in safety. Its obviously embarrassing to have to carry permission slips from the Taliban, but, hey, thats just the only way to work in those areas.I think thats a useful way to think about education in rural parts of Afghanistan as well. Some aid groups are already negotiating with the Taliban about putting schools in certain areas that the Taliban control. The biggest concern for the Taliban has been that boys and girls be separate and that the girls are taught by a woman. Their other big issue is that the school books cant have a photo of President Karzai. With those conditions they have, sometimes, been willing to allow girls and boys education. Thats not going to work everywhere, and the Taliban will be more suspicious of schools than of vaccinations  but I think its worth trying in more areas. If NGOs can get some Taliban approval to work in some areas, that would be a step forward.

title: Humorist for Counterterrorism Czar
description: Updated | 11:33 p.m. Last week The Daily Show recycled this clip from an interview with New Yorker humorist Calvin Trillin in June of 2006, in which he uncannily predicted the threat to the nation that might one day be posed by an underwear bomber.

title: E-Mail? Free. Internet? Thatll Cost You.
description: EVERYBODY wants to be connected, and most major airlines in the United States have made bets that in-flight Wi-Fi Internet service will be a profitable sideline, or at least a worthwhile brand enhancer.

title: Changing Mind-Sets About School, and Hygiene
description: Hoping for a career in television sports news, the Bronx-born Dane Martinez did an about-face after 9/11. After graduating from Syracuse University, he came home and taught under the Teach for America program. Now 29, he is the program manager of school leadership development for the citys Department of Education.

title: Heineken in Deal to Buy a Big Mexican Brewer
description: Heineken said Monday that it would buy the beer operations of Femsa, one of the biggest brewers in Mexico, in an all-share transaction that values the business at $7.6 billion. The move would further consolidate the beer industry into a few global players.

title: Egypt Seeking Redemption at African Cup of Nations
description: Update | 1:00 p.m. On Tuesday, Egypt scored three unanswered goals to defeat Nigeria, 3-1, in each teams opening match in the African Cup of Nations, which was played in Benguela.

title: Emerging Running Backs on Wild-Card Weekend
description: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com.

title: Georgia: Leaders of a Mutiny Receive Prison Sentences
description: The leaders of a brief, botched military rebellion against President Mikheil Saakashvili were sentenced Monday to lengthy prison terms, after a judge concluded that their aim had been to topple the government. The May 2009 mutiny was over after a few hours, when most of the 500-man tank battalion surrendered. Mr. Saakashvili initially suggested that Russia had planned the rebellion in order to force him from office. The three military men accused of masterminding the uprising were sentenced to 29, 28 and 19 years in prison.

title: Future Kenya Port Could Mar Pristine Land
description: LAMU, Kenya  The evening call to prayer here is like a summons, for everyone on the island. As the sun dives toward the ocean, the Muslim residents stream into the mosques, little boys wearing impossibly bright white skullcaps, their mothers in diaphanous, black head-to-toe gowns. The last of the bikini-clad tourists pick themselves up from the beach, dust off the powdery sand and head back to the hotel for a drink.

title: Fox Woos OBrien, but Pact Is a Hurdle
description: PASADENA, Calif.  The dance between the Fox network and NBCs disaffected late-night host, Conan OBrien, got livelier Monday when Kevin Reilly, the president of Fox Entertainment, spelled out in some detail how interested Fox would be in starting a late-night show starring Mr. OBrien  provided he found a way to extricate himself from his NBC contract.

title: With New Member, Supreme Court Takes New Look at Crime Lab Ruling
description: WASHINGTON  Just six months after a narrowly divided Supreme Court announced that crime lab reports may not be used against criminal defendants at trial unless the analysts responsible for them testify, the court heard arguments on Monday about how the new system is working and whether it needs to be refined or rejected.

title: Jobless, Homeless, and Now Known With a Sad Distinction
description: Every year, a handful of homeless people freeze to death in New York City, and in 2010, it appears, that grimmest of lists started early.

title: Joint Effort in Europe Seeks Assets in Distress
description: The fund manager CRG Capital has announced a joint project with the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development to start a fund to buy distressed assets in Central and Eastern Europe.

title: Should You Pay to Read This?
description: Would you be better off paying for online newspapers like this one? Should you feel guilty about downloading free music? Is the Webs information-wants-to-free culture hurting writers, musicians and the rest of the digital peasants, as Jaron Lanier calls us, now providing unpaid content to be exploited by the lords of the clouds like Google?

title: Closer Look at Accident of Ex-Official
description: The Manhattan district attorneys office is investigating an accident last week in which Howard Safir, the former New York City police commissioner, backed his sport utility vehicle into a pregnant woman on the Upper East Side and then drove away, a spokeswoman for the office said Monday.

title: White House Opposes Challenge to Gillibrand
description: WASHINGTON  The White House made it clear on Monday that it opposed the prospect of Harold E. Ford Jr.s running for the United States Senate in New York, even as Mr. Ford, the former Tennessee congressman, showed no signs of being deterred.

title: McDonalds Names U.S. Chief as Its No. 2 Executive
description: McDonalds, the fast-food company, said on Monday that it had promoted Don Thompson, the head of its United States division, to become its No. 2 executive.

title: Al Qaedas Shadowland
description: Washington

title: Justices to Review Plan for Webcasts of a Trial
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court indicated Monday that it might soon have something significant to say about whether and when video coverage of federal trials is appropriate.

title: President Signals Flexibility on Health Plan Tax
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama told union leaders at a private White House meeting on Monday that he remained committed to taxing high-cost insurance policies as a way to drive down health costs. But he also signaled that he was willing to amend the proposal to make this work for working families, a senior administration official said.

title: The Tel Aviv Cluster
description: Jews are a famously accomplished group. They make up 0.2 percent of the world population, but 54 percent of the world chess champions, 27 percent of the Nobel physics laureates and 31 percent of the medicine laureates.

title: Cardinals Timing Is Off on Final Field-Goal Try
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  If not for Arizona receiver Larry Fitzgeralds brain cramp, there would have been no outrage Monday about how his teammate Michael Adams grabbed the face mask of Green Bay quarterback Aaron Rodgers on what turned out to be the Cardinals winning play in overtime of their National Football Conference wild-card thriller on Sunday.

title: As School Exit Tests Prove Tough, States Ease Standards
description: A law adopting statewide high school exams for graduation took effect in Pennsylvania on Saturday, with the goal of ensuring that students leaving high school are prepared for college and the workplace. But critics say the requirement has been so watered down that it is unlikely to have major impact.

title: A Lofty Perch, Sure, but Reasons to Retool
description: THERE is a joke about the enthusiastic disk jockey on a top-40 radio station who liked to introduce the hottest hit record as No. 1, and climbing higher every week. The reason the joke is still being told in an era of downloaded music is that it has always been difficult to drum up interest in an entertainment property that is already successful.

title: At a Mighty 104, Gone While Still Going Strong
description: Joe Rollino once lifted 475 pounds. He used neither his arms nor his legs but, reportedly, his teeth. With just one finger he raised up 635 pounds; with his back he moved 3,200. He bit down on quarters to bend them with his thumb.

title: A Serious Proposal
description: The president of the American Federation of Teachers says she will urge her members to accept a form of teacher evaluation that takes student achievement into account and that the union has commissioned an independent effort to streamline disciplinary processes and make it easier to fire teachers who are guilty of misconduct.

title: Russian Dissidents Passion Endures Despite Tests
description: MOSCOW  You almost feel sorry for the police officer tasked with detaining Lyudmila M. Alexeyeva as she led an unsanctioned protest on New Years Eve. It is not just that at 82 years of age she appears as fragile as a porcelain teacup, or that she was dressed as a Snow Maiden, complete with sparkly hat and adorable fur muff.

title: A Future That Doesnt Guzzle
description: DETROIT  About 98 percent of the vehicles sold in the United States last year were powered by conventional gasoline engines, and hybrids occupied just a tiny niche.

title: Here Comes Doveman
description: When hes not working with indie-bands like Grizzly Bear, Antony and the Johnsons and the National, the pianist and composer Thomas Bartlett performs as Doveman. His solo work is hushed, reverent and mesmerizing, writes Amanda Petrusich. Listen for piano-driven ballads off his 2009 album, The Conformist, at Mercury Lounge Tuesday night, though the engagement also promises friends. Doors open at 7 p.m., with Samamidon and the Poison Tree.

title: Under the Whale
description: Since 2006, PopRally has been a meeting ground for artists and their hipster hangers-on. The events series at the Museum of Modern Art and PS 1 showcases a cross-section of film, music and art. On Tuesday night, the video and performance artist Jen DeNike and the choreographer Melissa Barak combine forces to present a dance installation titled Scrying in the museums atrium under the huge whale skeleton by Gabriel Orozco. Go to listen to the experimental rock group Soft Circle and then watch the short ballet.

title: Kamali Wear
description: Her disco days are decades behind her, Ruth La Ferla wrote of the fashion designer Norma Kamali last year. And, despite an archive that includes studded skirts and bondage-wrapped playwear, she does not harbor a fondness for latex and lace. Look instead for her updated spin on Grecian draped jerseys and sexy fleece activewear, perfect for cold weather dressing, at her store on West 56th Street this week. Until Friday, selected items are 20 to 70 percent off.

title: DePauls Wainwright Is Third Coach to Be Fired
description: Looks like Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim was right.

title: Come Rain or Come Shine
description: And now for my personal 2010 weather forecast.

title: The True Answer and the Right Answer
description: At the beginning of the new year I resolved to leave off writing old grouch columns, columns that chronicle my inability to negotiate modern life. But resolutions rarely stand in the face of provocation, and so here I go again.

title: Lottery Numbers
The How-To of an Admission in the Steroid Era
description: The strategy that Mark McGwire used Monday to lay out his admission to using steroids demonstrated that lessons were learned from other baseball stars who preceded him in making mea culpa about their drug use.

title: Terror Suspects Lawyer Asks for Dismissal of Case
description: A federal judge in Manhattan was asked on Monday to dismiss an indictment against a terror suspect whose lawyer argued that his nearly five-year detention in secret C.I.A. prisons and later at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, was perhaps the most egregious violation in the history of speedy-trial jurisprudence.

title: It Isnt Working for Anyone Else
description: Chinas economic strategy over the past two decades has been remarkably successful. By opening its doors to foreign investment and manipulating currency markets to keep the renminbi from rising against the dollar, it hitched itself to consumers in the industrial world and achieved spectacular growth.

title: What the Financial Crisis Commission Should Ask
description: Questions anyone?

title: U.N. Adopts Bland Home for Gutting of Quarters
description: UNITED NATIONS  Even before Secretary General Ban Ki-moon cut the blue ribbon on Monday to inaugurate the boxy, white, three-story building that will be his temporary headquarters for the coming three years or so, United Nations staff members started debating whether it more closely resembled a Wal-Mart or a maximum-security prison.

title: Robbed, Then Scared; Armed, Then Arrested
description: The night the robbers shoved their way in, Jason Baez lay on the living room floor, terrified. He worried for his children, asleep in their bedroom; for his wife, prostrate next to him; and for himself as two men brandished guns and a third accomplice, a woman, lashed Mr. Baez and his wife with duct tape and electrical cord.

title: 14 Across: Gumbo Vegetable
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Crossword puzzles are good for the brain. They are daily mental workouts that can build new neural connections and keep old ones strong. A puzzle like todays  one thats just plain fun  is also good for the gut. Its like a dose of anti-stress tonic.

title: Extremist Hutu Officials Blamed in 94 Rwanda Assassination
description: Extremist Hutus in Rwandas government in 1994 were responsible for shooting down a plane carrying the Rwandan president, who was also a Hutu, in a premeditated attack that set off a spiral of violence that led to genocide, according to a report released Monday by the current Rwandan government.

title: Bloggingheads: Can Drugs End Depression?
description: John Horgan, left, of the Stevens Center for Science Writings and George Johnson, author of "The Ten Most Beautiful Experiments," debate the effect of medication on depression.

title: Deaths in Fires Last Year Were the Fewest on Record, Bloomberg Says
description: Fewer New Yorkers died in fires in 2009 than in any other year since 1915, when the city began keeping count, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced on Monday. The figures align with an overall pattern of declining fire deaths over the last two decades.

title: Reds Win Bidding for a Potential Ace From Cuba
description: The winning bidder for Aroldis Chapman, a hard-throwing Cuban pitcher, is a midmarket team with nine losing seasons in a row. The Cincinnati Reds, of all teams, took a financial risk Monday for the potential reward of an ace starting pitcher.

title: Cowell Says He Will Leave Idol
description: PASADENA, Calif.  Simon Cowell, the acerbic British music producer whose caustic commentary as a judge on American Idol has guided the program to the top of the television ratings, announced on Monday that he would leave the program after this season to begin producing and judging a new talent competition, The X Factor, for the Fox network in the fall of 2011.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the effects of early winter storms on already strained state and local budgets misstated, in some copies, the current number of state troopers in Iowa, where officials say they do not have enough patrol officers to handle all accidents. It is 379, not 37 (down from 455 about 10 years ago).

title: Canesta's TV Remote Demonstration
description: In this demonstration, gestures are used to control the television and lighting on a Hitachi TV that is equipped with a digital camera that integrated Canesta's 3D-chip.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Thursday about the indictment of a former Yonkers city councilwoman and two other people on federal corruption charges misidentified the position once held by Zehy Jereis, one of those indicted. He is the former chairman of the Yonkers Republican Committee and a former board member of the Westchester County Republican Party; he was not the former leader of the Westchester party.

title: Canesta's Avatar Demonstration
description: In this demonstration, James Spare, the chief executive of Canesta, explains how the company's chip technology would give 3-D vision to electronic devices.  Here, they demonstrate how a camera can see three-dimensional movement and translate that to controlling an avatar character on a computer.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the New Jersey Senates defeat of a bill that would have allowed same-sex marriages misstated, in some editions, the length of time between 1915, the year that New Jersey voters rejected a referendum that would have allowed women the right to vote, and the year that the 19th Amendment was ratified, granting women the vote nationwide. The amendment was ratified five years later, in 1920, not three years later.

title: Corrections
description: The City Room column in some editions on Dec. 31, about a State Senate proposal for referendums asking voters whether New York should be split into two states, misstated, in some copies, the year that the Constitution was ratified. It was 1788, not 1787.

title: Selig Says Steroid Era Is Basically Over
description: Over Bud Seligs 17-year tenure as the head of Major League Baseball, he has made peace with the players union, internationalized the game, introduced interleague play and overseen a solid growth in team revenue.

title: Low Profile for Chrysler After a Year of Change
description: DETROIT  Chrysler always had a showmans flair for grabbing attention at this citys annual auto show. Its stunt highlight reel includes driving a Jeep through the front window of the convention center and dropping a pickup truck from its ceiling.

title: Now, Electronics That Obey Hand Gestures
description: LAS VEGAS  The technology industry is going retro  moving away from remote controls, mice and joysticks to something that arrives without batteries, wires or a user manual.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Friday about the F.B.I.s seizure of a passport belonging to Adis Medunjanin, a Queens man who came under scrutiny during the investigation of what officials have said was a bomb plot by Al Qaeda, misspelled, in some copies, the surname of Mr. Medunjanins lawyer. He is Robert Gottlieb, not Gottleib. (Mr. Medunjanin was arrested on Friday on terrorism charges.)

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Friday about an expected mortgage default by the owners of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, sister apartment complexes in Manhattan, misspelled, in some copies, the given name of a longtime tenant at Peter Cooper who said apartment turnover had increased under the current landlords. She is Soni Fink, not Sonni.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Dec. 22 about criticism of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg by the outgoing and incoming city comptrollers after the Bloomberg administration acknowledged having more than 2,500 unregistered bank accounts misstated the year in which the city received $181 million from unregistered accounts controlled by the office of Robert M. Morgenthau, then the Manhattan district attorney. It was 2009, not 2008.

title: Garment Company Removes Ad Showing Obama in Coat
description: The Weatherproof Garment Company, which turned heads last week with a controversial Times Square billboard showing President Obama in one of its coats, has agreed to take down the billboard after talking with the White House.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Saturday about an accident in which Howard Safir, the citys former police commissioner, backed his car into a pregnant pedestrian in Manhattan included an erroneous address in some copies from the police for the scene of the accident. It took place in front of 1418 Third Avenue, not 1421 Third.

title: The Cowboys Are Confident, but Wary
description: IRVING, Tex.  Dallas linebacker Bobby Carpenter recovered two fumbles in the Cowboys playoff victory over the Philadelphia Eagles, and seemed to be an appropriate spokesman for a dynamic defense that had helped spark a four-game winning streak heading into Sundays National Football Conference divisional game against the Minnesota Vikings at the Metrodome.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the first substantive hearing of a commission established by Congress to investigate the causes of the financial crisis referred incorrectly to a similar investigation in 1932 that sought to learn the causes of the Wall Street crash of 1929. That inquiry was a series of hearings conducted by the Senate Banking Committee; it was not established as a commission. (The investigation has become known as the Pecora hearings, after Ferdinand Pecora, the chief staff investigator.) The error has appeared in other articles written since Congress last year began considering creating a commission to investigate the recent crisis, including articles on March 12, May 6 and July 16 last year and an Op-Ed Page column on Oct. 18.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column on Monday, about a new campaign for Aflac, misidentified the agency behind the new advertising campaign. It is the Zimmerman Agency of Tallahassee, Fla., part of the Omnicom Group  not a Tallahassee office of Zimmerman Advertising, another Omnicom agency.

title: First-Round Pick Has Last Seat on the Bench
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  An undrafted rookie earned minutes in Coach Mike DAntonis rotation ahead of Jordan Hill, whom the Knicks selected with the eighth overall selection in last summers N.B.A. draft.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about Catherine Biden, the mother of Vice President Joseph R. Biden, misstated Mr. Bidens age during his first campaign for the United States Senate. He was 29, not 30. (By the time Mr. Biden was sworn in as a senator in January 1973, he had turned 30, the minimum age required for the office.)

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Bank Is in Talks to Settle State Claims Over Merrill
description: A year after its controversial takeover of Merrill Lynch, Bank of America is discussing settling a troublesome state inquiry into the star-crossed deal and the billions of dollars in bonuses that Merrill hurriedly paid its employees.

title: Looking at Ways to Treat Depression
description: To the Editor:

title: A Favorite Hollywood Theme: The White Savior
description: To the Editor:

title: Terror in Sudan
description: To the Editor:

title: Vonn Motivated by Weight Comment
description: Lindsey Vonn said in a conference call with reporters Monday that a recent article in an Austrian newspaper discussing the size advantage she has against her rivals helped motivate her last weekend when she won three consecutive races.

title: Singing in Conference Play
description: Patrick Behan is a 6-foot-8 senior on the Bucknell basketball team. He is also an English major and an aspiring sportswriter. As he did last season, he will be blogging for The Quad throughout this season.

title: Williams Pleads Guilty in 02 Driver Shooting
description: SOMERVILLE, N.J.  Jayson Williams pleaded guilty to aggravated assault on Monday in the fatal shooting of his limousine driver, bringing toward a close a legal case that began nearly eight years ago.

title: Judicial Security
description: A disgruntled litigant opened fire in a Las Vegas courthouse last week, killing a security officer and wounding a deputy marshal. The same day, the Justice Department released an audit that found that threats against judges and prosecutors have more than doubled since 2003 and warned that their security had critical deficiencies. Both events sound a much-needed alarm.

title: No More Candy Store
description: Ken Salazar promised as the interior secretary to strike a better balance between the need for oil and gas development and the need to protect public lands in the Rocky Mountain West. In the Bush years, it was all about the drilling. The administration aggressively leased out millions of acres of public land and issued more than 50,000 drilling permits, in many cases risking wildlife habitat and ignoring legally mandated environmental reviews.

title: A Real Election, Please
description: Muscling out campaign competition is undemocratic. Yet Democratic Party insiders in Washington have spent the last year trying to scare off potential challengers to Kirsten Gillibrand, the junior senator from New York. The last thing voters of New York State need is a coronation instead of a choice.

title: Should Toronto Pursue Trading Bosh?
description: On Sunday, The New York Post reported that the Lakers were looking to acquire the Raptors Chris Bosh before the Feb. 18 trade deadline. Even though the report was couched in as much tentative language as possible, the Los Angels news media ran with the idea Sunday night. As the Lakers pounced on the Milwaukee Bucks, talk of Bosh filled the press lounge and postgame interviews.

title: Risks Still High for Junk Bonds
description: Investors flocking to junk bonds need to think twice after allowing risk premiums on high-yield investments to get dangerously low. Its good that fewer companies are failing. But high debt prices dont leave room for 2010s biggest financial market risk: the potential fallout when central banks withdraw from markets.

title: Knicks See What Improved Looks Like
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  The Knicks heard rumblings of the Oklahoma City Thunders improvement, but did not have a firsthand account, having not played the club in nearly a year. They can now offer testimony to the Thunders advancement.

title: Challenge Lures Carroll to Seattle
description: LOS ANGELES  When Pete Carroll stood in front of his team for the last time, the man who had given U.S.C. its direction over the last decade was not sure where to go. He knew he was headed to Seattle, where the Seahawks hired him Monday to become their next coach, but he was not quite sure what to say.

title: Showcase: Drained by Rising Waters
description: In all the coverage of the enormous Three Gorges hydroelectric project on the Yangtze River, and the creation of a vast reservoir that has displaced hundreds of thousands of people around his birthplace in Chongqing, the photographer Muge Huang Rong felt the lack of something very important. And personal.

title: New Group Will Fight Cellphone Use by Drivers
description: Safety advocates credit Mothers Against Drunk Driving with helping to change attitudes about getting behind the wheel while intoxicated.

title: Yo Jude: Photo Privacy Settings
description: J.D. Biersdorfer and Sam Grobart on how to manage photo privacy settings online.

title: Focusing on the Future
description: Jerry Garrett surveys a subdued 2010 Detroit Auto Show.

title: Jamie Langenbrunner of Devils Will Captain the U.S. Hockey Team
description: Jamie Langenbrunner, the stoic Devils right wing from Minnesotas Iron Range with the powder-dry wit, was named Monday as the captain of the relatively young United States team for the Winter Olympics in Vancouver.

title: Word of the Day | specious
description: specious \spe-shs\ adjective

title: Corrections
description: An editorial on Sunday mischaracterized the safety record of ground meat produced by Beef Products Inc. The editorial said incorrectly that two 27,000-pound batches of processed beef had been recalled. The contamination of the meat was discovered by the company in its plant before the beef was shipped. No meat produced by Beef Products Inc. has been linked to any illnesses or outbreaks.

title: Giants: From Champion to Onion
description: It took only two years for the Giants to go from Super Bowl winners to the subjects of satire.

title: Consuela Lee, Jazz Pianist and Educator, Dies at 83
description: Consuela Lee, a jazz pianist who fought to establish an arts school for children in rural Alabama on the grounds of a moribund academy founded by her grandfather, died Dec. 26 in Atlanta, where she had lived since 2007. She was 83.

title: Bank Is in Talks to Settle State Claims Over Merrill
description: A year after its controversial takeover of Merrill Lynch, Bank of America is discussing settling a troublesome state inquiry into the star-crossed deal and the billions of dollars in bonuses that Merrill hurriedly paid its employees.

title: News Quiz | January 12, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Shirley Rich, Grand Dame of Casting, Dies at 87
description: Shirley Rich, widely regarded as a star among New York casting directors, who for half a century scoured the country for little-known actors  little-known actors with names like Judd Hirsch, Sean Penn and Tom Cruise  to flesh out a spate of Broadway plays and Hollywood films, died on Dec. 28 in Greenwich, Conn. She was 87 and lived in Rye, N.Y.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: For Burrows, Eight Goals in Three Games and Controversy
description: Four games in the N.H.L. on Monday, but the big story is in Vancouver, where the red-hot Alexandre Burrows scored two more goals. But he was also called on two questionable penalties, which he said afterward were the product of a referees personal animus against him. His contention was supported by Canucks goalie Roberto Luongo and coach Alain Vigneault. Home teams listed first:

title: Coming Clean
description: WHO is Mark McGwire?

title: Fed Said to Have Earned $45 Billion in 2009
description: The U.S. Federal Reserve made record profits in 2009 and will return $45 billion to the U.S. Treasury, after its efforts to prop up the economy created a windfall for the government, The Washington Post reported.

title: JAL Awash With Sell Orders on Possible Delisting
description: Shares of Japan Airlines were flooded with sell orders on Tuesday on growing expectations that the carrier is headed for bankruptcy and delisting from the Tokyo exchange.

title: Fed Fights in Court to Keep Bailout Details Secret
description: The Federal Reserve asked a U.S. appeals court to block a ruling that for the first time would force the central bank to reveal the identities of financial firms that might have collapsed without the largest government bailout in U.S. history, Bloomberg New reported.

title: Joint Effort in Europe Seeks Assets in Distress
description: The fund manager CRG Capital has announced a joint project with the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development to start a fund to buy distressed assets in Central and Eastern Europe, Matthew Saltmarsh reports in The New York Times.

title: Should Harry Reid Resign?
description: A new book about the 2008 presidential campaign quotes the U.S. Senate majority leader, Democrat Harry Reid of Nevada, as saying that the country was ready to embrace a black presidential candidate, especially one such as Obama  a light-skinned African American with no Negro dialect, unless he wanted to have one.  Some have called for Mr. Reid to resign. Should he?

title: Shares Edge Higher as Investors Await Earnings
description: As companies began releasing fourth-quarter results on Monday, the question on Wall Street was not so much whether businesses turned a profit but how they did so.

title: For Heineken, Femsa Deal Is a Beer Balancing Act
description: The Dutch brewer Heineken has managed a delicate balancing act in clinching the auction for the beer business of Femsa of Mexico, Breakingviews says. Despite outbidding SABMiller, the deal is in line with prices paid for growing Latin American markets. Meanwhile, Heinekens all-share offer keeps debt under control while leaving its founding family in charge, the publication remarks.

title: Losses in Manhattan Plague Singapore Fund
description: A butterfly flaps its wings in Manhattan, and Singapore sees a change in the weather. The Government of Singapore Investment Corp., manager of more than $100 billion of the city-states foreign reserves, reported losses from its investment in the boroughs largest residential enclave.

title: Ex-Citi Executive Cut a Controversial Figure
description: Citigroup announced on Monday that it would replace the head of its consumer banking business  the most troubled part of its financial empire  as the company braces for fresh troubles with home mortgages and credit cards this year.

title: Twitgrief
description: Condensed expressions of grief posted on Twitter.

title: Blast Kills Physics Professor in Tehran
description: PARIS  A remote-controlled bomb attached to a motorcycle killed an Iranian physics professor outside his home in north Tehran on Tuesday, state media reported. The reports blamed the United States and Israel for the attack.

title: Death of Accused Financier Ruled a Suicide
description: The death of the California financier Danny Pang was a suicide, Orange County sheriffs officials and coroners investigators said Monday, The Associated Press reported.

title: S. Korea and U.S. Dismiss N. Koreas Peace Talks Proposal
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea and the United States said Tuesday that they would discuss a peace treaty with North Korea only after the North returned to six-nation disarmament talks and began dismantling its nuclear weapons program.

title: What the Financial Crisis Commission Should Ask
description: On the eve of the first hearing of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, which will query the chiefs of the biggest U.S. banks on the causes of the financial crisis, The New York Timess Andrew Ross Sorkin has some questions of his own.

title: A New Tax on Banks and Bankers?
description: The Obama administration is considering a new fee on financial institutions to help recoup the cost of the banking system bailout.

title: Ex-TCW Manager Fires Back After Lawsuit
description: The star bond fund manager Jeffrey Gundlach fired back at his former employer, Trust Company of the West, on Monday, saying the firm had smeared him in a lawsuit it filed last week.

title: BofAs Curl to Lose Risk Post, Report Says
description: Gregory Curl, who lost out to Brian T. Moynihan for the top job at Bank of America, may now find himself demoted.

title: Ford Still Open to Talks on Sale of Volvo Cars
description: Ford Motor remains opens to talks with potential bidders for its Volvo cars unit despite a commercial agreement on a sale with Chinas Zhejiang Geely, a Swedish business daily reported on Tuesday.

title: Deadly Protest in Afghanistan Highlights Tensions
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A volatile town in southern Afghanistan erupted Tuesday as rumors spread that American servicemen had desecrated a Koran and defiled local women in a nearby village. Taliban provocateurs on the scene whipped up a crowd and goaded it to violence, local officials said.

title: The Cubicle: Endangered Species
description: Todays idea: The Great Recession is eliminating not just jobs but work stations as companies reduce their physical space, an article says: Dilberts worldwide are losing their cubicles.

title: Chinas Shanda Games Snaps Up Mochi Media
description: Shanda Games of China has agreed to buy Mochi Media, an American online game company backed by venture firms Accel Partners and Shasta Ventures, for $80 million in cash and stock.

title: Persian Art Sparkles at Istanbul Palace
description: If youve always been interested in Persian history but a trip to Iran is not in the cards right now, a visit to Istanbul might be a good backup choice. Through Feb. 5, the museum at the citys Topkapi Palace  former home of the Ottoman sultans  is hosting Ten Thousand Years of Irans Civilization and Two Thousand Years of Joint Heritage, an exhibition featuring some 150 objects from the National Museum of Iran, as well as pieces from Turkish museums.

title: For Chrysler, a 2011 I.P.O.?
description: Sergio Marchionne, the chief executive of both Fiat and Chrysler, said that the American carmaker might be ready for an initial public offering as soon as next year, The Financial Times reported.

title: Alfa Romeo Not for Sale, Fiat Chief Says
description: The chief executive of Fiat, Sergio Marchionne, said Monday he has no intention of selling the Alfa Romeo brand, but made clear the maker of sporty cars needs to prove its mettle in 2010, The Associated Press reported.

title: GameStop Announces $300 Million Stock Buyback Plan
description: GameStop, the video game retailer, said on Monday it had authorized a $300 million stock buyback plan and planned to spend $200 million on opening new stores and other types of expansion.

title: Orange and T-Mobile Seek Approval on British Merger
description: France Telecom and Deutsche Telekom asked the European Union to approve the proposed merger of their British mobile operations, which will reduce the number of operators in the market to four from five.

title: M-4A1 Firing Test
M-4 Firing Test
Hedge Fund Sues Icahn Over Bond Offering
description: Q Investments is suing Carl C. Icahns Icahn Enterprises over a proposed $2 billion debt offering, as part of an ongoing legal battle between the hedge fund and the billionaire investor.

title: To Curb Loans, China Tells Banks to Increase Reserves
description: BEIJING  Chinese regulators ordered state-owned banks on Tuesday to set aside a larger share of their deposits as a reserve against failed loans, another in a string of indicators that Beijing is concerned about speculation in the nations fast-growing economy.

title: Citadel and Soros Said to Make Galleon Hires
description: It appears that the cherry-picking of Galleon Group employees has begun.

title: Sampler: Marriage Trial Goes Personal and Oakland Airport Is Most Punctual
description: Personal Lives on the Stand | In the first day of the same-sex marriage trial in federal court in San Francisco, Theodore B. Olson asked his client, What does it mean to be a lesbian? Two gay couples testified about their lives and their reactions to the 2008 passage of Proposition 8, the state ballot initiative that changed the states constitution so that gays and lesbians could not marry. Video coverage of the nonjury trial, which addresses the constitutionality of the gay-marriage ban, is not available on YouTube, as had been planned. Hours before the trial began, the United States Supreme halted, for a few days, the plan to show the court proceedings on YouTube until the justices could review the issue of cameras in the court room. [The New York Times]

title: Carlyle Starts China Fund With Beijing
description: The Carlyle Group, following in the footsteps of one of its biggest rivals, announced that it was teaming up with the Beijing government to start a domestic Chinese private equity fund, Bloomberg News reported.

title: The Making of the Militarys Standard Arms, Part II

title: Gone While Still Going Strong at 104
description: Joe Rollino once lifted 475 pounds. He used neither his arms nor his legs but, reportedly, his teeth. With just one finger, he raised 635 pounds; with his back, he moved 3,200. He bit down on quarters to bend them with his thumb.

title: Oil Prices Widen Trade Deficit as Exports Grow Marginally
description: The trade deficit in the United States widened more than expected in November, offering positive signs that American businesses and consumers were growing more confident about spending as the economy slowly improved.

title: And the Powder Puff Goes To
description: As usual, science-fiction and fantasy films dominated the shortlist of the seven films announced by the motion picture academy as finalists for the best makeup Oscar, though two period dramas sneaked in, The Associated Press reports. The finalists are Star Trek, District 9, Night at the Museum: Battle of the Smithsonian, The Road and The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus, as well as The Young Victoria and the Italian political drama Il Divo. Three nominees will be announced along with the other Oscar nominations on Feb. 2.

title: CIT Group Names 3 Directors to New Board
description: CIT Group, the bailed-out commercial lender that emerged from bankruptcy last month, tapped three new directors for its new board on Tuesday.

description: Forget about everyday delusions and the madness of popular crowds. Madison Avenue in the new year continues to be mad for asking the crowds to help create advertising.

title: My Internal Debate: Am I Playing the Recession Right?
description: When I prepared last years budget, the sales projections were based on a month or two of crisis-affected data. There was no way to know for sure whether the economy was going to get worse, stabilize, or start to improve. My approach was to cut some expenses, cut back on hours, add some furlough days, and reduce staff  all based on very little other than the knowledge that sales were evaporating and the hope that things would get better.

title: Q. and A.: Sprechen Sie Elvish, Esperanto, Klingon, Navi?
description: As Navi  the language devised for James Camerons movie Avatar becomes the latest addition to the dictionary of new dictionaries, co-vocabularists are invited to submit questions to two experts in the field of invented languages.

title: Detroit Auto Show: At Chrysler, Placeholders Until the New Products Arrive
description: Skipping the theatrics and staged productions, the Chrysler Group this year built itself a display that brings the sizzle of salesmanship to mind more than it does engineering or technology showmanship.

title: Investors Sell as Japan Airlines Nears a Bankruptcy Filing
description: TOKYO  Investors rushed to sell their shares in Japan Airlines on Tuesday and Wednesday ahead of a bankruptcy filing that could come as early as next week. At the same time, two rival airlines, American and Delta, battled for a stake in JAL, which could still be a strong regional player once restructuring takes place.

title: Housing Hangover in the Sun Belt
description: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.The Census Bureau recently released estimates of state-level population changes, which showed a decline in the growth of some Sun Belt areas.

title: We Waited for This?
description: This post is by Steven M. Davidoff and Peter J. Henning.

title: Letterman Offers His Free Genius TV Advice to NBC
description: David Letterman seems to be happiest when he is at his most cynical, and recent days have given him plenty to be happy about. On Monday night, NBCs late-night quagmire was once again the popular topic among the late-night hosts: Jay Leno continued to joke about his move to the start of NBCs after-hours schedule as if he were getting fired; and Conan OBrien continued to seethe (among his options, he said, was to leave television altogether and work in a classier business with better people, like hard-core porn.)

description: Who is the best acceptance speech giver? someone asked the Bagger on Monday night at the New York Film Critics Circle Awards.

title: A Stolen Kiss Looks Familiar, Though Time Has Gone By
description: There is something oddly compelling, even transfixing, about the time-lapse security video of Haisong Jiang, 28, sneaking into an off-limits area at Newark Liberty Airport to steal a kiss and a few moments with his departing girlfriend. It happened Sunday night, Jan. 3. Here is an intimate moment colliding with the post-9/11 world. All the bittersweet emotions of a long-distance relationship are captured in that embrace.

description: Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.

title: Feeling Like Myself Again After Cancer
description: It has been nearly two years now since I learned I had prostate cancer, and 11 months since my last treatment. The surgical scar on my gut is fading, the radiation and hormones have leached from my body  and my soul  and my post-treatment depression is gradually lifting.

title: Energy Department Awards $187 Million for Development of Efficient Cars and Trucks
description: The United States secretary of Energy, Steven Chu, announced Monday that the government was giving $187 million to nine projects to improve fuel efficiency in heavy duty trucks and passenger vehicles.

title: Waiting for McGwire
description: As morning turned to afternoon on Monday, I willed my cellphone to ring. Baseballs Garbo, Mark McGwire, was supposed to be calling. I was eager to hear what he might say about his past.

description: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 11: Chevrolet Aveo RS

title: Evercores Co-Founder Takes Los Angeles City Post
description: In the latest instance of a finance veteran moving into the political sphere, Austin Beutner, a co-founder of Evercore Partners and former partner of the Blackstone Group, has been tapped by Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa of Los Angeles to guide his effort to attract for more business to the city, The Los Angeles Times reported.

title: God Responded
description: Monologue |  Monday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Listen to this. In his weekly radio and Internet address, President Obama said we are on the verge of guaranteeing Americans health insurance whether they lose their job, change jobs, move or get sick, which means Jay, Conan and I are going to be just fine. So dont worry.

title: Harry Reid Under Fire
description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Tonight Show With Conan OBrien on NBC: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid is under fire for discussing whether or not President Obama has a Negro dialect. Reid is also in trouble for saying Joe Lieberman talks all Moses-y.

title: Tuesday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: With Defense Test, China Shows Displeasure of U.S.
description: BEIJING  China said late Monday that it had successfully tested the nations first land-based missile defense system, announcing the news in a brief dispatch by Xinhua, the official news agency. The test is defensive in nature and is not targeted at any country, the item said.

title: London Theater Journal: Dead Man Talking
description: LONDON  Funny how a dead body in the room can change the way you hear a conversation. That was always a large part of the frisson-generating appeal of Rope, Patrick Hamiltons 1929 drama in which a cocktail buffet is served on a chest that hides a fresh corpse. And it is a perspective exploited to a stylish, poison-tipped hilt in Roger Michells highly satisfying revival at the Almeida Theater, which I caught on an appropriately dark and stormy Monday night.

title: An Over-Emotional Woman
description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: Its a great day for Sarah Palin. She was hired as a commentator for Fox News. She signed a multiyear contract, which means shell probably quit after a year.

title: The Mayor Misspoke
description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: Im tired of being cold. And Im upset with that Al Gore, too. Always shooting his mouth off.

title: Britain Moves to Ban Islamic Group
description: LONDON  Britain said Tuesday it was outlawing a radical Islamic group that had incited outrage by planning a protest march through the streets of a town made famous for its somber ceremonies honoring British soldiers killed in Afghanistan.

title: What Are the Mets Plans for Fernando Martinez?
description: It was just three years ago that the Mets, fresh off a division title and with dreams of a dynasty, envisioned opening Citi Field with an outfield of Carlos Beltran and two prized prospects, Carlos Gomez and Fernando Martinez. As Im sure you noticed, that never happened.

title: Bubble Denial
description: Via Mark Thoma, Economics of Contempt has done [did] a yeoman job [back in 2008] of assembling quotes from pundits/economists who insisted that there was no housing bubble. [At first I failed to note the date of EoCs post; special kudos to Mark for remembering it and providing the link]. Just as a reminder, the facts:

description: Come out, come out, wherever you are.

title: Viewers Might Get Confused
description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: As you may know, our show has been canceled. NBC has some pilots to fill up the 10 p.m. time slot. Theyre talking about bringing back All in the Family, with Harry Reid as Archie Bunker.

title: The Holy See Wishes It Hadnt Seen Avatar
description: Among the things the Vatican approves of: piety, penitence, The Simpsons. Among the things it does not endorse: sinfulness and Avatar. Both the Vatican newspaper and radio station have criticized that James Cameron film, calling it emotionally unengaging and saying that the film tries to replace divinity with nature, The Associated Press reported. The newspaper, LOsservatore Romano, wrote that Avatar gets bogged down by a spiritualism linked to the worship of nature, according to The A.P. Vatican Radio said the movie cleverly winks at all those pseudo-doctrines that turn ecology into the religion of the millennium, adding: Nature is no longer a creation to defend, but a divinity to worship. The newspaper wrote that for all of the stupefying, enchanting technology in the movie, it offers few genuine emotions. But both news media outlets agreed, as the newspaper wrote, that the true accomplishment of Avatar was its extraordinary visual impact. The film is to be released in Italy on Friday.

title: Iranian Cyber Army Strikes Chinese Site
description: Less than a month after a group calling itself the Iranian Cyber Army attacked Twitter, users of Chinas most popular search engine, Baidu, were redirected on Tuesday morning to a Web page displaying a message claiming that the same group had blocked access to that site as well.

title: Detroit Auto Show: Designer Night Party
description: DETROIT  The snow swam in the huge searchlights parked in front of the Bankle Building on Woodward Avenue, site of the  Designers Night 2010 party. It was held, by tradition, in the loft space of Camilo Pardo, a former Ford designer who started the event several years ago. The space is full of Mr. Pardos paintings, on canvas and on old car hoods, as well as his collection of cars, including a racer and an original Mini.

title: Detroit Auto Show: Mini Beachcomber Concept
description: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 11: Mini Beachcomber Concept

title: Fresh Cash for Flurrys Mobile Analytics
description: Flurry, a mobile analytics firm with offices in New York and San Francisco, said Tuesday that it has raised $7 million in a Series B round of financing from venture capital firms InterWest Partners, Draper Fisher Jurvetson, Union Square Ventures and First Round Capital, among others.

title: Dispute Arises Over Lawsuit by Cohens Ex-Wife
description: Update | 1:44 p.m. Just when a lawsuit by Patricia Cohen, the ex-wife of hedge fund magnate Steven A. Cohen, couldnt get any stranger, it did just that on Tuesday.

title: Fresh From the Louvre, and Tasty
description: Last October, days after Roman Polanski was arrested in Switzerland, the culturati gathered in Paris for fashion week, and there was a fresh scandal afoot. Sacr bleu! The Daily News reported, echoing bulletins from around the world. McDonalds invades Mona Lisas lair.

title: How Do You Take Your Avatar?  Well, You Can Take It One of Three Ways
description: With James Camerons Avatar now projected to earn all the money in the known world by spring, I was assigned last week to take a close look at this juggernaut of a film. A ridiculously close look.

title: Balancing Suburban Landscapes and Water Conservation
description: The chart above catches the eye, telling any observer who knows the geography of the Peninsula and South Bay that some of the wealthiest areas in the region  places like Los Altos Hills (1), Hillsborough (2) and Woodside and Portola Valley (3)  consume far more water per capita than neighboring communities. It accompanied an article in Sundays Bay Area report about new moves to cut outdoor water use.

title: Goldman Acknowledges Conflicts With Clients
description: A senior Goldman Sachs executive sent an e-mail message to clients on Tuesday disclosing that the firms Fundamental Strategies Group might have shared investment ideas with the firms proprietary trading group or some clients before sharing them with others.

title: Readers Respond to McGwires Admission
description: Readers had a range of reactions to Mark McGwires admission on Monday that he used steroids in his career, including in his record-breaking season in 1998. Comments reflected anger at McGwire as well as disillusionment with Major League Baseball and the use of performance-enhancing drugs among players. Have a comment? Join the conversation in the comment section below.

title: Encores! Announces Casting For Fanny
description: Encores! has found its Fanny  and its Cesar and its Marius, too. Elena Shaddow, George Hearn and James Snyder will play those characters in New York City Centers coming Encores! production of Fanny, the musical based on Marcel Pagnols trilogy of Marius, Fanny and Csar, its press representatives said on Tuesday. Ms. Shaddow (whose Broadway credits include The Woman in White and Fiddler on the Roof) will play Fanny, the French woman whose illegitimate pregnancy sets off a story of romance and reconciliation. Mr. Snyder (Broadways Cry-Baby) will play Fannys lover, Marius, and Mr. Hearn (a Tony winner for Sunset Boulevard and La Cage aux Folles) will play his father, Cesar. The cast also includes Rondi Reed (a Tony winner for August: Osage County) as Honorine, Fred Applegate (The Producers) as Panisse, David Patrick Kelly as the Admiral and Michael McCormick as Escartifique. Fanny, which is directed by Marc Bruni, choreographed by Lorin Latarro and with music directed by Rob Berman, will run at City Center from Feb. 4 through 7.

title: French Family Values
description: The debate over European economic performance has gone in two directions. One is the usual response of people when they get something very wrong: they start quibbling over minor details (which dataset was Manzi actually using? what about immigration?) to throw up dust clouds. The key thing to remember is that we had a flat assertion that social democracy leads to stagnant economies; that assertion is just wrong.

title: Readers Climb Aboard the Doris Day Bandwagon
description: It turns out that many Times readers are hoping this year that whatever will be, will be an honorary Oscar for Doris Day. A post related to Douglas McGraths article in Sundays New York Times on why Ms. Day is worthy of a special Oscar has inspired more than 100 comments from readers, most of which are supportive of the idea of Ms. Day finally getting an award that has eluded her throughout her career.

title: Top Terror Prosecutor Settles Into a Familiar Role
description: When a federal prosecutor asked a Virginia jury in 2006 to impose the death penalty on Zacarias Moussaoui, the so-called 20th hijacker on Sept. 11, he cited the agonizing calls from victims in the burning World Trade Center towers and on planes, and quoted the defendants own words as he rejoiced in their pain. I wish there would be more pain, Mr. Moussaoui had said.

title: Times Talks: Carrie Fisher
description: Ms. Fisher discussed her life and career, including the legendary Star Wars Holiday Special, with The Times's David Carr as part of the Times Talks series.

title: For Mother and Daughter, the Process Begins in Earnest
description: I cant believe Im actually here. Could it really be that my little girl is about to begin the process?

title: Weiner Wants Scofflaw Diplomats to Pay Up
description: Unlike the streets near the United Nations, most streets in the city are not considered international territory; on those, alternate-side parking rules apply. Still, many foreign diplomats simply park where they please, and they have collectively ignored $18 million worth of the bright orange rectangles stuffed under their windshield wipers.

title: Simpsons Fill-In
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in Alessandra Stanleys review of The Simpsons 20th Anniversary Special, headlined Ah, Homer, It Seems Just Like Yesterday. We have included the first four paragraphs as well as the final paragraph. Use your own words and phrases, or click read more to choose from a scrambled list of the words/phrases that were removed.

title: The Obama Effect on an Indiana Contest
description: President Obamas name is not on the ballot in the November midterm elections, but his policies and his political party certainly will be. So, too, are many Democrats who endorsed his bid for the White House.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) Divorce rates are higher in states with gay marriage bans, Nate Silver writes.

title: Hard to Get, but Great to Find
description: My column this week is on the rise of German sptburgunder, better known to the rest of the world as pinot noir. Many people find it surprising that Germany makes red wines at all. In fact, the popularity of red wine in Germany has probably never been higher, and over the last few decades more and more pinot noir has been planted.

title: Google Lets Users Store More Files Online
description: Google is moving closer to offering something like a Web-based disk drive where users can store any file and access it from anywhere.

title: Travel Deals: Free Resort Nights in St. Maarten
description: The Sonesta Collection in St. Maarten is offering one free night for every night booked, available for travel from Jan. 15 to March. 31.

description: Subarus Hybrid Tourer Concept isnt like any Subaru youve ever seen, which is pretty much the point.

description: Some commenters on my Europe/euro post offer a reductio ad absurdum: if Spain should have its own currency, why not every state/town/family in America?

title: Detroit Auto Show: On Electric Avenue, Coffee Carts and Three-Wheelers
description: DETROIT  Electric Avenue extends for several blocks at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit. The Dow Chemical-sponsored boulevard is colorful, encompassing both Korean-made plug-in coffee carts and three-wheeled E.V.s. The concept seems to be to give some prime-time space (in this case 37,000 square feet) on the shows main floor to small carmakers usually relegated to the basement.

title: Same-Sex Marriage Case, Day 2: History Lessons
description: Update 7:06 p.m. Pacific Time | Speaking to reporters after Professor Cott had left the stand, defense lawyers lashed out at her performance, calling it a disaster and part of a strategy that backfired on the plaintiffs.

title: Iraq Says Raid Uncovered a Plot to Bomb Ministries
description: BAGHDAD  A wide-ranging plot to bomb government ministries and other public places, to be followed by a wave of political assassinations, was uncovered by Iraqi officials, who responded Tuesday by bringing much of Baghdad to a virtual standstill while security forces conducted raids that netted large quantities of explosives, officials said.

title: Race Assumes Central Role in New Orleans Vote
description: NEW ORLEANS  Less than a month before the primary, the race for mayor here is a struggle over who will bring down the soaring murder rate, who will attract badly needed new businesses and who will guide the city in its still dauntingly long road to recovery. But it is also about something else.

title: Spider-Man Musical Will Refund Tickets
description: After weeks of complaints from ticket holders, the producers of the Broadway musical Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark announced on Tuesday morning that they will refund tickets through Ticketmaster for preview performances that had been scheduled to start Feb. 25 but are now, as expected, canceled.

title: Confirming a Diagnosis of Celiac Disease
description: Dr. Sheila Crowe, a professor in the division of gastroenterology and hepatology in the department of medicine at the University of Virginia, recently joined the Consults blog to answer reader questions about celiac disease, an often overlooked digestive disorder that causes damage to the small intestine when gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley and rye, is eaten. In a previous post, Dr. Crowe explained how celiac disease can present not just with digestive complaints, but also anemia and other conditions. Here, Dr. Crowe responds to readers wondering what tests should be requested to confirm a diagnosis of celiac disease.
