title: Port Shut Down Over Explosives Leak
description: An early morning accident at the port in Morehead City spilled as many as five gallons of a highly explosive chemical, prompting officials to close the port and issue a voluntary evacuation for the surrounding area.

title: Big Blues Smarter Marketing Playbook
description: I.B.M. trotted out its smarter planet campaign more than a year ago, starting with a speech by Samuel J. Palmisano, I.B.M.s chief executive, at the Council on Foreign Relations. At the time, the campaign seemed an ambitious, though potentially risky, move. The vision of transportation, health care, cities, retailing, finance and other fields made more intelligent with digital technology  and yes, supplied largely by I.B.M.  could have easily fizzled and been portrayed as big-think puffery, out of step with an economy in a tailspin.

title: Bidens Mother Eulogized
description: WILMINGTON  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. called his mother, Catherine Eugenia Finnegan Biden, a quintessential combination of both optimism and pragmatism who instilled in her four children the ideal that everyone was equal.

title: BlogTalk: Floating a Ford Candidacy in N.Y.
description: The chatter about Harold Ford Jr.s possible challenge to Senator Kirsten Gillibrand continues to swell today, building upon the White Houses decision on Monday to swat away the notion and Mr. Fords own Op-ed promoting the idea in The New York Post.

title: Canadian Broadcasters Hope to Break Even on Games
description: Earlier this week, NBC said that its broadcast of the Winter Games in Vancouver next month will likely be the networks first Olympic money loser. Now it appears that the host broadcaster isnt doing much better.

title: F.D.I.C. Seeks to Link Insurance Fees to Bank Pay
description: Federal banking regulators moved on Tuesday to seek public input on a plan to link the insurance premiums levied on banks to the degree of risk-taking encouraged by their executive pay policies.

title: The Republican Situation
description: I agree with everything Ramesh Ponnuru says in his Time piece on why the G.O.P. shouldnt get overconfident about midterm success. Whats more, I think that all of his warnings will still hold true even if Republicans do make big gains at all levels, as Ponnuru puts it, and head into next year with a larger minority in the Senate, control of more statehouses, and maybe even a slim majority in the House (hey, its possible). This warning, especially:

title: Under the Radar: Five Questions About Chekhov Lizardbrain
description: Dan Rothenberg doesnt hesitate when asked to explain what the show Chekhov Lizardbrain, which he directed for Philadelphias Pig Iron Theater as part of the Under the Radar Festival, is all about.

title: Massachusetts Ad Wars in Senate Race
description: Martha Coakley has released the first negative television ad of the Massachusetts Senate race, reinforcing the perception that Democrats are worried about holding onto Edward M. Kennedys seat.

title: We Have Ways to Make You Pay
description: There have been shame lists. There have been statistics, and corresponding threats of firings.

title: Q&A: To Italy With a Toddler
description: Q.

title: Management Shake-Up Continues at Disney
description: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company continues to slash and burn through the management ranks of its struggling motion picture studio as it works to return the division to profitability.

title: Happy Date = ZIP Code Day, Flatbush
description: Jan. 12 is a very special day in Brooklyn, at least for fans of the Gregorian calendar. In Brooklyn, all ZIP codes begin with 112, so todays date, written numerically, is identical to a ZIP code somewhere in the borough.

title: Woodson Beats Out Jets Revis for Defensive Award
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. - Jets cornerback Darrelle Revis lost the N.F.L.s defensive player of the year award on Tuesday. It went to Charles Woodson of the Packers, the first cornerback to win the award since Deion Sanders in 1994.

title: Coaches Come and Go, Except JoePa
description: Wow. Things sure do happen fast in academia. No sooner did Pete Carroll split from Southern California than Lane Kiffin walked away from Tennessee on Tuesday night.

title: Conan OBrien Says He Wont Host Tonight Show After Leno
The Life of the (Tea) Party: Comparing Social Protest Movements
description: Overview | What drives the current Tea Party movement and its protests? How does it compare with historical social movements? In this lesson, students explore the Tea Party movement, compare it to other social movements in American history and consider their impact.

title: Detroit Auto Show: Tesla Model S Prototype
description: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 12: Tesla Model S prototype

title: Lawmaker Seeks Culprit in A.I.G. Bailout
description: Representative Darrell Issa, the California Republican who is investigating the bailout of the American International Group, said Tuesday that the government must hold someone responsible for how the Federal Reserve Bank of New York dealt with A.I.G.

title: American Idol Preview: 9 Questions on Season 9
description: American Idol begins its ninth season Tuesday at 8 p.m. on Fox. To kick things off, Jon Caramanica will ask nine questions each week about each episode. Share your thoughts and ask your own questions  in the comments area below. But first, a preview:

title: Spanish Solar Firms Model: Build and Sell
description: The OPDE Group, a Spanish developer of solar energy, has received $145 million in financing from a group of Spanish banks, as it expands into other European countries and California.

title: A Potentially Awkward Moment for Gillibrand and Ford
description: It may be slightly awkward for a couple of prominent guests at the Rev. Al Sharptons annual celebration of Dr. Martin Luther King in Harlem on Monday.

title: A Glimpse of a Modern Pioneer
description: The 92nd Street Y commemorated the centenary of Erick Hawkins, a modern-dance pioneer, over the weekend with a three-day symposium featuring discussions, classes and performances, including a rare appearance by the Erick Hawkins Dance Company on Saturday night at the Ys intimate Buttenweiser Hall. Who knew that such a group still existed, even in a small configuration of five members? Since Hawkinss death in 1994, the company has gradually receded from the public eye.

title: Finding a Way to Pay for Green Makeovers
description: Last year, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed four laws and two programs that would have required the owners of New Yorks largest buildings to pay for improvements to make their properties more energy-efficient.

title: Protest in Nigeria Over Absent Leader
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  Hundreds of angry Nigerians marched down this capitals broad avenues on Tuesday to protest the long absence of their president, who has been away for nearly two months getting medical treatment in Saudi Arabia.

title: Judge Denies Rajaratnams Request to Reduce Bail
description: A federal judge on Tuesday afternoon denied Raj Rajaratnams request to reduce his $100 million bail, siding with prosecutors who argued that the billionaire hedge fund manager of the Galleon Group should not get a break on his bail terms.

title: Go for Broke | Akriss Ai Bag
description: Long a staple of ladies who lunch (in Geneva), the Swiss fashion house Akris is expanding its line to include handbags. The horsey Ai Bag coincides with the acquisition of Comtesse, an 80-year-old German firm specializing in the manufacture of woven horse hair. Akris is no stranger to the material: it has been used to structure its coats, and there is even woven horsehair covering the walls of its London boutique. Pony up the hefty $3,990 at Saks Fifth Avenue, Bergdorf Goodman and Akris boutiques.

title: New Tours in 2010
description: With vacationers still wary about spending money in 2010, tour operators are offering travel packages that scale back on amenities like tour guides, while rebranding them as more flexible and independent-minded.

title: A Wifes Betrayal, a Husbands Internal Seething
description: In 1993 the Metropolitan Opera presented its first production of Verdis neglected opera Stiffelio as a vehicle for Plcido Domingo. Without that star tenor in the demanding title role, and without James Levine conducting, the Met would not have taken a risk on the work, which had a dismal reception at its 1850 premiere in Trieste, Italy.

title: Pictures of the Day: Tuesday, Jan. 12
description: Hands held over an oudoor fire for warmth. It is certainly an effective photojournalistic device for conveying  wordlessly  the idea that unusually cold weather is burdening a place that is unaccustomed to it and unequipped for it: India, in this case, from which several hands-over-the-fire pictures have been transmitted in recent weeks. (Todays photo is Slide 10.) But is this a case of visual shorthand so effective it threatens to become clich? A glance at the pictures below reveals subtle variety. Each picture tells a slightly different story. And that never gets tiresome.

title: Frigid Londoners Line Up for Two Blasts of Heat
description: LONDON  With this city all a-shiver from a crippling cold snap  the big freeze, as the tabloids call it  it only made sense to visit two of the hottest women in town. So on Saturday I made my way through desultory snow flurries to the West End to see the young movie star Keira Knightley playing a young movie star, and then across the Thames to the Menier Chocolate Factory in Southwark, where the seasoned song-and-dance gal Tamzin Outhwaite was portraying a seasoned dance hall hostess.

title: Obama to Appear at Democratic, G.O.P. Retreats
description: WILMINGTON  President Obama will appear at separate retreats for both House Republicans and House Democrats within the coming week, White House officials said on Tuesday.

title: 15 Hall of Fame Finalists: Pick Your Five
description: Andy Barall writes about pro football history for The Fifth Down

title: PBS to Announce New Public Affairs Show
description: PBS will air a one-hour public affairs program called Need to Know, to be produced by New Yorks WNET.org, on Friday nights beginning May 7, the organizations plan to announce Wednesday.

title: Magazines Lost  Gulp  58,340 Ad Pages in 09
description: 6:50 p.m. Updated with corrected Meredith & Hachette figures, and more context for the Cond Nast figures.

title: To Get to Paul Castellano Way, Make a Right on Plaxico Terrace
description: It may sound like an echo of the David Bowie song that goes, We can be heroes  just for one day. Seventh Avenue is being renamed Project Runway Avenue  just for one day.

title: Ringo Starr Plans to Be Touring When He Hits (Drumroll Please) 70
description: Ringo Starr released his 16th studio album, Y Not (Hip-O Records) Tuesday, and since he was in town for a run of television appearances to promote the disc, he spent part of the afternoon holding a news conference on the set of Late Night With Jimmy Fallon, on which he will be the only guest Tuesday night. Backed by Ben Harper and the Relentless 7, Mr. Starr performed excerpts from a few songs on the new disc, as well as I Wanna Be Your Man, one his Beatles staples.

title: Hello Creepy: A Spooky Side to Japans Cute Culture
description: There is a surprisingly fine line between nightmarish and cute. Jeremy Wade toes and then smears it in There Is No End to More, a solo for Jared Gradinger that returned for a one-night engagement at Japan Society on Monday.

title: Detroit Auto Show: Nellys Custom Ford Mustang
description: Lawyers for the rapper Nelly will be busy defending speeding tickets if his predictions come true. Nelly and Jim Farley, vice president of marketing for Ford, showed off Nellys custom Mustang GT, which will appear on the cover of his coming album on Tuesday at the 2010 North American International Auto Show.

title: House Panel Subpoenas New York Fed on A.I.G.
description: The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee is demanding that the Federal Reserve Bank of New York turn over its records about the bailout of the American International Group, particularly those involving billions of dollars in payments made to A.I.G.s trading partners.

title: Dropping a Clue or Two About Lost
description: Pasadena, Calif.

title: The Morning Skate: Replay Suspicions, Burrowss Accusations and Dallas Does Rocky
description: The Philadelphia Daily News blogged last night and The Philadelphia Inquirer reported today that the N.H.L. is investigating whether the Fox Sports Pittsburgh television crew, the Penguins local rights-holder, intentionally or accidentally withheld evidence from video replay officials last Thursday of a play that was under review.

title: New York City Ballet News
description: Some of New York City Ballets top dancers will take their final bows this spring season. The company has announced that dates have been set for the farewell performances of long-time principal dancers Yvonne Borree, Albert Evans, Darci Kistler and Philip Neal as well as the principal conductor Maurice Kaplow.

title: New Yorks Roman Empire
description: Dishes from Maialino, Testaccio and Numero 28 Pizzeria Romana, which are among the Roman restaurants that have opened in the last year.

title: Popular Blood Therapy May Not Work
description: The treatment has become so popular that patients with orthopedic injuries are demanding it, willing to pay $1,000 or more out of their own pocket. Its appeal only soared higher when professional athletes like Tiger Woods and the football players Troy Polamalu and Hines Ward reported that it cured them.

title: Award Show Politics, With Sass
description: Sandra Bullock  Sandy to your mom  was a surprise double-Golden Globe nominee, for her comedic work in The Proposal and for the heavy stuff in The Blind Side, and she has a good chance in that category at least.

title: Why the Best Deposit Rates Are Decreasing
description: The best Internet bank rates on money market, certificate of deposit and savings accounts are decreasing, thanks to new Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation rate calculation rules for undercapitalized banks. Those are traditionally the banks that offer the most generous rates to attract depositors.

title: Mystery at the Philharmonic: Who Was That Clarinetist?
description: If the New York Philharmonic had performed Rachmaninoffs Second Symphony last season, the principal clarinetist would probably have been bathed in accolades for his solo stint in the Adagio, one of the most famous clarinet passages in the orchestral literature. For that clarinetist would have been Stanley Drucker, who retired in September after 60 years in the orchestra.

title: A Good Stir-Fry Hides a Lot of Faults
description: A post with two headlines:

title: Investigating Wall Street Compensation
description: Louise Story of The Times discusses the backlash over big bonuses on Wall Street.

title: Mexico Holds Drug Suspect Accused of Grisly Tactics
description: MEXICO CITY  When it comes to gore, Mexicos drug traffickers seem to compete among themselves for the title of most depraved. One will chop off the heads of victims. Another will string dead rivals from bridges or burn their genitals. Recently, hit men removed the face from a dead man and sewed it onto a soccer ball.

title: Students Say Professor Was Government Critic
description: As my colleagues Alan Cowell and Nazila Fathi report, on Tuesday Iranian state television broadcast images shot in the aftermath of an explosion that killed a physics professor outside his home in north Tehran.

title: Baby Einstein Founder Goes to Court
description: A co-founder of the company that created the Baby Einstein videos has asked a judge to order the University of Washington to release records relating to two studies that linked television viewing by young children to attention problems and delayed language development.

title: That Old R&B Tag Team of Love and Lust
description: I need three chairs! Mario shouted as he selected a girl from the crowd to bring onto the Gramercy Theater stage on Friday night. Stools materialized. The too-gentle R&B singer sat his choice down, his guitar player on her other side, and serenaded her with I Choose You. He was tentative. He was sweet. He kept a respectful distance.

title: Article Search API Enhancements
description: The Times Article Search API already had a rich set of data attributes, but we couldnt resist adding a few more. One of our general TimesOpen goals is to ensure that all our APIs interoperate as much as possible. The new fields are part of that effort, and they also offer new ways to search Times content.

title: Case Study | Stocking the Bar
description: Case Study is a bimonthly posting on all things alcoholic by Toby Cecchini, Ts spirits columnist.

title: Detroits Electric Avenue: The Street of Dreams?
description: DETROIT  Which would be a stranger sight: Humphrey Bogart, Marilyn Monroe and James Dean sharing a late snack at an all-night diner, or the filmmaker Chris Paine; Bob Lutz, the General Motors vice chairman; and Elon Musk, chief executive of Tesla Motors, taking a stroll down Electric Avenue at the Detroit auto show?

title: Cline: Color & Play
description: The presentation of Clines early fall collection at Milk Studios had a lets-get-down-to-business quality: a plain white space, clothes hanging from rails, models briskly going through a few changes. Have some coffee? Thank you, I will

title: CBS Comedies Deliver
description: Two and a Half Men and The Big Bang Theory delivered Mondays top ratings by a wide margin. Those CBS comedies drew 17.3 million viewers at 9 for Men and 15.8 million at 9:30 for Theory, according to Nielsens estimates. CBS won the night over all, including the 8 p.m. hour in which the 100th episode of How I Met Your Mother delivered a season-high 9.8 million viewers. Fox and ABC finished in a virtual tie for second place. Fox broadcast House at 8 (12.2 million) and a special episode of Fringe at 9 (7.8 million), while ABCs two-hour installment of The Bachelor averaged 10.5 million viewers from 8 to 10. CBSs CSI: Miami (13.6 million) easily led the 10 p.m. hour ahead of both Castle on ABC (9.5 million) and The Jay Leno Show on NBC (4.8 million). NBC was fourth for the night. On HBO on Sunday, the fourth season premiere of Big Love attracted 1.7 million viewers, a considerable improvement over the first episode of the shows third season last year, which drew 1.2 million.

title: Sony Switches Spider-Man Plans
description: Spider-Man and Tobey Maguire are parting ways. Mr. Maguire was set to reprise his leading role in Spider-Man 4 in May 2011 with Sam Raimi, right, who directed the first three installments, returning to the helm. But after disagreements about the creative direction of the film Mr. Raimi opted to depart, according to Deadline.com. Rather than go forward with a different director, Sony decided on a Spider-Man reboot that it had been simultaneously developing. In a press release on Monday, Sony confirmed that the next Spider-Man movie would take Peter Parker back to high school. The new chapter, written by James Vanderbilt (Zodiac), will have a new cast and director, and focus on a teenager dealing with both contemporary human problems and amazing superhuman crises, Sony said. The target release date is now summer 2012. Together, the first three Spider-Man movies sold over $1 billion in tickets at North American theaters, according to Box Office Mojo.

title: PBS Sets New Shows
description: PBS will broadcast a one-hour public affairs program called Need to Know, to be produced by New Yorks WNET.org, on Friday nights beginning May 7, the organizations plan to announce on Wednesday. The new show, to originate from WNETs soon-to-be-opened studio at Lincoln Center, will blend field reports, features and interviews on topics including the economy, the environment, health, security and culture, and will make extensive use of public input generated online. No anchor or reporters have been announced. Need to Know will replace the public affairs programs Bill Moyers Journal and Now, which end in April. As part of the remake of PBSs news and public affairs lineup, John Wilson, who oversees TV programming, said that PBS also planned to open a Web portal in May that would aggregate all of its news and public affairs content, as well as journalism from local public stations.

title: Five Sites Agree to Stop Flushing Pharmaceutical Waste
description: New York States attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, has reached a settlement under which five hospitals and nursing homes agreed to stop flushing pharmaceutical waste that could potentially contaminate New York Citys water supply.

title: While Spider-Man Musical Offers Refunds
description: After weeks of complaints from ticket holders, the producers of the Broadway musical Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark announced on Tuesday that they would refund tickets through Ticketmaster for preview performances that had been scheduled to start on Feb. 25 but are now, as expected, canceled. The producers did not provide new dates for previews or an opening night, saying only that a revised schedule would be announced shortly and that they still planned to open the show in 2010. With music by U2s Bono and the Edge and direction by Julie Taymor (The Lion King), Spider-Man has been marred by delays after an earlier group of producers was unable to raise the money to produce the show. The production is now expected to cost about $50 million, making it the most expensive in Broadway history.

title: Rathers Appeal Request Rejected by Court
description: Dan Rathers request for an appeal in his lawsuit against CBS was turned down on Tuesday, marking an apparent end to the breach-of-contract case. Mr. Rather, below, the former anchor of CBS Evening News, had appealed to the New York Court of Appeals, the states highest court, after the appellate division of the New York State Supreme Court ruled unanimously in September to dismiss the $70 million lawsuit he brought against the network in 2007. CBS executives say the legal proceedings are now over. In a statement Mr. Rather said he was disappointed. He had been seeking damages in a claim that his contract had been breached by CBS management and his reputation had been unfairly tarnished by the networks handling of an investigation into his report on President George W. Bushs National Guard record.

title: U.S. Selects 18 Cities and 21 Stadiums as Potential World Cup Hosts
description: Chicago is the home of the United States Soccer Federation, but apparently not its kind of town when it comes to potential sites for the 2018 or the 2022 World Cup. And add San Francisco and the rest of Northern California to that list.

title: Vancouvers Winter Games May Lack Some Winter
description: Vancouver may be hosting the upcoming Winter Olympic, but Canadas Pacific coast city often does not get the a typically Canadian winter.

title: Wistful Baroque Moods Echo Through Time
description: There is often a pervasive sense of melancholy in the music of the early Baroque, a gentle wistfulness that underlies both somber and spirited scores, like the selections by Dario Castello and Tarquinio Merula performed in Paul Hall at the Juilliard School on Monday evening. Members of Juilliards new historical-performance program offered works by these two infrequently performed Italian composers to inaugurate the schools ninth annual ChamberFest, a six-day series of chamber music performances by 20 student ensembles, which received intensive coaching by faculty members during the winter break. They were joined by guests from the Royal Academy of Music in London.

title: On Our Radar
description: A roundup of electric vehicle news from our friends at the Wheels blog, who are keeping tabs on the Detroit auto show this week:

title: In Packers Loss, Rule Says No Call Was the Right Call
description: To some, the picture speaks 1,000 words and four of them are: the Packers were robbed. The image of Cardinals cornerback Michael Adamss index finger hooked on Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgerss face mask was seen far and wide, sparking the question of whether it was a penalty, which would have negated the fumble Adams caused.

title: Career Advice From Conan OBrien
description: In light of recent events, now seems like a good time to pull out some of my favorite advice on risk-taking, courtesy of Conan OBrien (from his 2000 Harvard commencement speech):

title: Patersons Son Is Questioned by Police
description: Updated, 6:50 p.m.| Alex Paterson, the 15-year-old son of Gov. David A. Paterson, was questioned on Tuesday in New York after police officers found him and his friends playing dice on the Upper West Side.

title: Aerial Skier Dismisses Conformity, and Gravity
description: DENVER  Each December, the family that launches together builds a rocket for the holidays.

title: Voices of Gay Irishmen, Set to Song
description: Seeing Silver Stars is like taking a very short trip in a time machine. The show, a song cycle stitched together from the stories of older gay Irishmen, sounds like something you might have heard in New York a generation ago, when the act of coming out was by itself enough to hang a theater piece on.

title: On the Web, a Wave of Support for Conan OBrien
description: The Internet has voted, and its supporting Conan OBrien in his struggle against NBC.

title: House Hunting in ... Scotland
description: A FOUR-BEDROOM DUPLEX IN EDINBURGH

title: For All Its Success, Will Avatar Change the Industry?
description: LOS ANGELES  Just five months after Warner Brothers released its talking-picture sensation The Jazz Singer in October 1927, the studio was back in theaters with another talkie, the crime drama Tenderloin.

title: Up-and-Coming Musicians, With a Prominent Backer
description: Orange Mountain Music, Philip Glasss record label, was founded in 2001 as an outlet for Mr. Glasss archival and out-of-print recordings. But the label quickly began releasing Mr. Glasss new works as well, and before long it was releasing discs by musicians in Mr. Glasss ensemble and young composers who had caught his ear.

title: Now Toting | Heritage Man-Bags
description: I hate seeing guys who have a good look going and then crack it open with a Manhattan Portage bag, says the accessories designer Basil Racuk. It drives me crazy. We feel your pain, Basil. Though Jack Spade has made some progress in addressing this all-too common problem, the lines ubiquity (in our non-scientific survey, every second man on the F train was carrying one) has compromised its appeal. Two solutions to the man-purse dilemma: Racuks eponymous collection of made-to-order satchels, and the Madly, a line of mens bags just introduced by Melanie Dizon and Jake Quellman.Racuk, whos based in Northern California, goes for a rustic-yet-refined look  think Berkeley professor crossed with Milanese aesthete  and works with customers on every aspect of a bags design. A good accessory is an exclamation point, he says. You want to get it just right. His designs are distinguished by their trend-proof but not boring classicism  you can order his minimally structured briefcase in bright red if you like.

title: Muzak Wins Approval to Exit Chapter 11
description: The music may not have stopped when Muzak filed for bankruptcy last year, but the company synonymous with the songs piped into elevators and retail stores is playing a happier tune on Tuesday.

title: Bank of America Shuffles Its Top Management
description: Bank of America shuffled its top management on Wednesday afternoon, replacing its chief risk officer and starting a search for a new chief financial officer, as Brian T. Moynihan, the new chief executive, moved to put his team in place.

title: Big Government Health Care
description: The federal government released its latest estimates of health spending last week, and they allow for some telling comparisons. In 2008, the country spent $2.3 trillion on medical care, or 16.2 percent of gross domestic product and $7,681 per person.

title: The Object of Clooneys Affection and Waltz as a Country Boy
description: After George Clooneys wanton kowtowing to the critic Rex Reed at the New York Film Critics Circle Awards on Monday night, the Baguette caught up with Mr. Reed, a longtime writer for The New York Observer, when the party was winding down.

title: Vintage Clothing, Red-Carpet Ready
description: Los Angeles

title: What You Get for ... $500,000
description: SACO, ME.

title: The Breslin Bar and Dining Room
Google Threatens Pullout from China After Cyberattacks on Dissidents
description: In a calm and understated blog post, Google said Tuesday that it had recently come under an unusual cyberattack from China. The Web giant said the attack was very different from previous ones because it was aimed at Chinese dissidents Gmail accounts.

title: Powermat Reconsidered
description: In an article I wrote in October, I essentially trashed the magnetic induction charging products from a company called Powermat. With its expensive charging plate and cellphone adapters, users can charge several devices at once without using any cables.

title: Remembering a Splashdown, Many Flights Later
description: Sheikh Ali remembers standing in the Charlotte-Douglas International Airport, waiting for Matt Kane, a co-worker who had been scheduled to land on a flight from New York. And the flight was late.

title: The Spark That Ignited Rwandas Inferno
description: As followers of the Rwandan governments Twitter feed will already know, a new report on the 1994 assassination of President Juvnal Habyarimana  an event Hutu extremists used as an excuse to begin the massacre of up to one million Tutsi and moderate Hutu that year  was released this week accompanied by a five minute video summarizing an investigative commissions findings.

title: Gaming Goes Lite
description: Gaming computers arent generally known for their subtle physical characteristics. In fact, more than a few gaming friends would like to see desktop boxes that look more like Draculas head.

title: Bar Pleiades and Ardesia Wine Bar
description: Is pedigree destiny? Two sleek new bars from illustrious food families provide clues: Ardesia, descended from Le Bernardin; and Bar Pleiades, from the fecund Daniel Boulud.

title: Going to the Mat With Mind and Body
description: Bertolt Brechts punishing, poetic In the Jungle of Cities follows a deadly philosophical battle between two men, Garga and Szlink, and its devastating effects on Gargas world, set in a mythical Chicago. In the Polish company Teatr Nowys adaptation, Versus, at the Public Theater as part of the Under the Radar Festival, audiences face another epic struggle: between the highly physical action on the stage and Dorothea Sobstels fast-moving, at times wretchedly clunky translation running on a screen overhead.

title: Eating Isnt Rescuing
description: To the Editor:

title: Lassoing Hawaiis Marine Trash
description: When my 8-year-old son first heard about the Texas-size trash patch accumulating in the Pacific Ocean, he asked me a basic question: Why doesnt somebody go pick it up?

title: A Mere Bag of Shells
description: To the Editor:

title: On CBS, Letterman Jokes About NBC
description: Things are getting interesting in late-night television, David Letterman said at the start of his monologue today. (An understatement much?)

title: A Grisly Tale in the Guise of Therapy
description: If youve been eager to spend a truly unpleasant hour in a theater, Jerk at Performance Space 122 is ready to accommodate you. The piece, part of both the Under the Radar Festival and Coil 2010, comes with high expectations, but by its end you may add a few other uns to your assessment as well, like unrewarding and unenlightening.

title: Rohmer the Classicist, Calmly Dissecting Desire
description: Among the films Eric Rohmer directed in the ninth and last decade of his life were The Lady and the Duke, set in the embattled aristocracy of 18th-century France, and The Romance of Astrea and Celadon, based on a 17th-century French literary pastoral. These were not Mr. Rohmers only forays into the past  in the mid-70s he made Perceval and The Marquise of O ...  but period dress was hardly this filmmakers habitual get-up.

title: Fierce Quake Devastates Haitian Capital
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic  A fierce earthquake struck Haiti late Tuesday afternoon, causing a crowded hospital to collapse, leveling countless shantytown dwellings and bringing even more suffering to a nation that was already the hemispheres poorest and most disaster-prone.

title: Even R.B.S. Chiefs Mother Disapproves of His Pay
description: Anyone in charge of the Royal Bank of Scotland at this point in time is bound to take some flak for the British firms bailout by taxpayers. As it turns out, not even the chief executives parents are completely thrilled with his job, according to The Telegraph of London.

title: Saudi and Yemeni Forces Fight Rebels on 2 Fronts
description: CAIRO  Saudi Arabias assistant defense minister, Prince Khaled bin Sultan, said Tuesday that Saudi forces had killed hundreds of Yemeni rebels who had occupied a border village, as fighting between the rebels and Yemens military also intensified nearby in the Yemen city of Sadah.

title: In New York Restaurants, the Rise of Rome
description: YEARS ago, New Yorkers in search of culinary enlightenment did not come back from Italy raving about Roman food. Rome was where your plane landed on the way to that dream trip to Tuscany.

title: Transformed Fort Lauderdale to Host Super Bowl
description: The game will be over in one evening  but for Fort Lauderdale hotels, the after-party could last years.

title: In the Soviet Union, When Food Was Scarce, Hope Could Still Be Nourished
description: The title of Elena Gorokhovas new memoir, A Mountain of Crumbs, about growing up in the Soviet Union in the 1960s and 70s, comes from a game her grandmother invented to hide that she had almost no food to put on the table. Shed break up a slice of black bread and a cube of sugar on a plate and say to the crying child: Look at how much youve got. A whole mountain of crumbs.

title: A Mountain of Crumbs
description: Chapter 1. Ivanovo

title: For Israelis Now, Echoes of Strife Then
description: Personal reminiscence and Israeli history are woven into a dense, occasionally impenetrable cinematic poem in Amos Gitais film Carmel, whose title refers to the mountains near Haifa, Mr. Gitais native city. The film begins with a prologue in which Mr. Gitai, pictured in stills, is shown strolling alone on a beach to the strains of a Mahler symphony. Then it abruptly plunges back in time to a crude re-enactment of the Roman siege of Jerusalem in the first century A.D., when the future emperor Titus and his army destroyed the city and its temple.

title: Google, Citing Attack, Threatens to Exit China
description: This article was reported by Andrew Jacobs, Miguel Helft and John Markoff and written by Mr. Jacobs.

title: Lanvin: Leopard Ladies
description: Amid the sparkly vagabond bits at the Lanvin early fall presentation was an appealing sturdiness, registered in several wool suits, including a slouchy pants number in gray wool, and a very cool olive-drab trench coat.

title: A Fallen Star of French Cuisine, Restored to Its Silver Platter
description: IT was a roasted drumstick that got me thinking about chicken breasts.

title: A Deal With Bank of America Is in Their Prayers
description: Bank of America is facing the power of prayer over foreclosures.

title: Gently Cooked Chicken Breasts With Garlic-Chili-Ginger Sauce
description: Adapted from Zak Pelaccio

title: A Top Cond Nast Executive Is Leaving
description: A top Cond Nast executive, Richard D. Beckman, will leave to become chief executive of e5 Global Media, a new company that owns The Hollywood Reporter, Billboard and Adweek, the two companies said Tuesday.

title: Blair Aide Unapologetic Over Britains Role in Prelude to Iraq War
description: LONDON  A close aide to former Prime Minister Tony Blair made a defiantly unrepentant appearance on Tuesday before the panel investigating Britains involvement in the Iraq war, saying Britain should be really proud of the role that we played in changing Iraq from what it was to what it is now becoming.

title: Acer Notebooks Recalled for Overheating
description: In the laptop computer arena, having the hot hand is not an advantage.

title: Real Estate Comeback? The Phones Ready
description: Is the real estate market making a comeback? I have no idea, but if it is, your phone is ready. Two new real estate apps are being released this week.

title: Is LPD the Next LCD?
description: While covering the development of digital, high-definition television since its inception, Ive been approached by any number of startups that promised The Next Big Thing in displays: rear-projection sets that would cost a small fraction of current technology; a technique to dramatically increase screen contrast and remove all reflective room light that was so promising it was financed by one of the biggest television manufacturers in the world; SED technology demonstrated by Toshiba that put the picture quality of the best plasma TVs to shame. In short, flat panel displays so enticing that makers of other technologies would immediately throw in the towel.

title: Clinton Tries to Defuse Asian Tension
description: HONOLULU  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton kicked off her travels this year, as she did last year, by flying across the Pacific rather than the Atlantic. But this time, her itinerary is more urgent. With tensions rising between the United States and both Japan and China, Asia has emerged as a diplomatic hornets nest, even beyond the perennial threat of North Korea.

title: The Breslin Bar and Dining Room
description: A SNACK to start, scrumpets: shredded lamb, breaded and fried, served with sweet mint vinaigrette. Also a soft-boiled Scotch egg, the orb caked in sausage meat, then breaded and fried.

title: For Some, Kosher Equals Pure
description: THIS year, for the first time, glatt kosher food will be sold at the Super Bowl.

title: Dutch Carmaker Still Pushing to Buy Saab
description: DETROIT  The head of the Dutch carmaker trying to buy Saab said Tuesday that the company had the money to make a deal and that one was still possible even though General Motors had started to shutdown the Swedish carmaker.

title: Deitch at MOCA: The Dealer on Taking Over the Museum
description: In a press conference on Tuesday to introduce Jeffrey Deitch as the new director of the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art, board members and Eli Broad, a founding trustee, praised Mr. Deitch, the New York art dealer, as their unanimous choice after a months-long, global search for new leadership.

title: Ecuador: Foreign Minister Resigns
description: Foreign Minister Fander Falcon resigned after President Rafael Correa criticized his handling of negotiations in connection with a forest-protection project. Ecuador has been seeking aid from rich industrialized nations, in exchange for limiting carbon emissions by preventing oil exploration in the forested area. Mr. Correa had recently said that donor countries in Europe had acted shamefully by seeking to impose some conditions in relation to projects funded by their aid. The talks have been focused on protecting tropical forest in the Yasun region of northeastern Ecuador.

title: Chicago Out in Cold in World Cup Bid
description: Chicago is the home of the United States Soccer Federation, but apparently not its kind of town when it comes to potential sites for the 2018 or the 2022 World Cup. San Francisco and the rest of Northern California are also on that list.

title: Corzine, in Farewell, Admits Failure to Relieve Tax Burden
description: TRENTON  In a farewell address tinged with more wistfulness than Wall Street bravado, Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey acknowledged on Tuesday his inability to solve the states mounting fiscal problems and said he hoped that he would be remembered for his commitment to the states children.

title: People of Earth Respond to Conan
description: Conan OBriens statement about why he will not host The Tonight Show if NBC moves it to 12:05 a.m. sparked a lively and largely pro-Conan response online.

title: Witness Is Revealed in Galleon Case
description: It is one of the biggest mysteries on Wall Street: Who is Tipper X, the secret witness at the center of the biggest insider-trading case in a generation?

title: Kimchi Pancake
description: WHEN Hae Wha Pak and her partners opened Kunjip, a Korean restaurant in Midtown, nine years ago, she and Haksoon Kim, the executive chef, decided to reinvent the traditional savory pancake. The pancake is usually made with wheat flour and filled with scallions and spicy pickled cabbage (kimchi).

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening This Week

title: A Terra Cotta Dish for Earthy Baking
description: Winter sets the appetite for hearty casseroles of beans, grains, sausages and other meats. The cuisines of Italy, India, Mexico and other countries have plenty of dishes to choose from.

title: The Grape Once Again Proves Its Versatility
description: Balsamic is not the only mellow Italian vinegar with a pedigree. Centuries ago, the Este family of Ferrara produced sopraffino. Unlike classic balsamic, it is made from red grapes (not white), which are not cooked but instead concentrated by natural evaporation during aging, similar to Spanish sherry vinegar.

title: The Season for Maine Shrimp Is Extended
description: Tiny, sweet Maine shrimp have a short season, a mere six weeks in winter. But the current harvest is so robust, the state Department of Marine Resources has extended it to May 29.

title: Dining Calendar
description: A Chance of Meatballs

title: Somali Man Is Charged in 2 More Ship Hijackings
description: A Somali man who was brought to New York last year and accused of piracy in the hijacking of an American-flagged cargo ship off Somalia was charged on Tuesday with leading the earlier takeover of two other ships, in which hostages were taken.

title: Feet Dont Fail Us Now
description: My review this week is of The Breslin, a restaurant on the ground floor of the Ace Hotel, on 29th Street of Broadway in Manhattan. The Breslin is the brainchild of Ken Friedman, the scary smart music-head restaurateur behind the Spotted Pig and the late John Dory, and the chef April Bloomfield. Ms. Bloomfield cooks as hearty cuisine at The Breslin as she has at her other restaurants: pigs feet and bellies, lots of fat and lots of flavor. This makes for nice dinners but difficult sleeping, even for those who consume moderately. (Check out the slide show above for a look at her food.)

title: Secret Witness Emerges in Galleon Case
description: It is one of the biggest mysteries on Wall Street: Who is Tipper X, the secret witness at the center of the biggest insider-trading case in a generation?

title: Sidelined From Work, but Always on the Hunt
description: As a nurse case manager, Karen Rashford worked as a liaison between sick foster children and the health care system they were not equipped to navigate by themselves.

title: The Saudis View
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer Offered Clemency for Sex, Woman Testifies
description: They seemed like routine police questions at first, the 26-year-old dog groomer said.

title: In Reversal, Jaguar Habitat Will Be Protected
description: After more than a decade of resistance, the Fish and Wildlife Service said Tuesday that it would reverse previous decisions and protect the habitat of the jaguar.

title: Green Civil War: Projects vs. Preservation
description: Environmentalists are more openly at odds over two goals: the preservation of wide open spaces vs. the use of public lands for renewable energy projects.

title: Monserrate Will Face Sanction Votes
description: ALBANY  A special New York State Senate committee weighing the fate of Senator Hiram Monserrate is set to recommend that the Senate vote on two resolutions to sanction him, including one that would force him from office, people with knowledge of the committees plans said Tuesday.

title: A Higher Authority
description: Yvonne Vizzier Thaxton, one of the sources in my article about the popularity of kosher food among non-Jews, was having coffee one Sunday after Catholic mass with some of her friends in Starkville, Miss.

title: Boy, 4, Chooses Long Locks and Is Suspended From Class
description: HOUSTON  A suburban Dallas school district has suspended a 4-year-old from his prekindergarten class because he wears his hair too long and does not want his parents to cut it.

title: Its Football in January, but Minus the Weather
description: It is that part of the N.F.L. calendar when meteorology collides with muscle and momentum, and the results are condensed to shorthand  the Ice Bowl, the Fog Bowl, the Tuck Rule Game, the Freezer Bowl, the holy-cheese-it-is-cold-here-in-Green-Bay game two years ago. (That conference championship game with the Giants, played below zero, begs for a snappier moniker.)

title: A New Wave of Asian Automakers
description: On display at the 2010 Detroit Auto Show are Asian automakers who are hoping to break into the North American market by introducing electric cars or buying existing automakers.

title: Super Bowl Sales as Economic Indicator
description: THE Federal Reserve Board may want to scrutinize another statistic to gauge the health of the economy: demand for ads during Super Bowls.

title: Magazines Lost a Fourth of Ad Pages in 09
description: Just how bad was 2009 for magazines?

title: Arbitrons Chief Resigns After a False Statement
description: A single imprecise sentence uttered during hours of Congressional testimony prompted the resignation of the chief executive of Arbitron, Michael Skarzynski, on Monday.

title: Mixed Signals on Airport Scanners
description: WASHINGTON  The Transportation Security Administration has promised not to store or transmit nude images of airline passengers made by whole-body scanners, but when it asked manufacturers to submit bids for such machines, it required that the scanners have exactly those capabilities, according to agency documents obtained in a lawsuit.

title: Lack of Medicare Chief Is a Strike Against Reform
description: Almost a year after taking office, President Obama has not yet nominated anybody to run Medicare.

title: Consuela Lee, 83, Pianist and Educator, Dies
description: Consuela Lee, a jazz pianist who fought to establish an arts school for children in rural Alabama on the grounds of a moribund academy founded by her grandfather, died Dec. 26 in Atlanta, where she had lived since 2007. She was 83.

title: As McGwire Moves on, Public Will, Too
description: A hitting coach is probably the least visible person in uniform. He does most of his work in private, in the batting cage under the stands or in the clubhouse video room, long before and sometimes after the games. He appears on the field only during batting practice, studying hitters from the edge of the dirt circle behind the plate.

title: Closing Pipeline to Needy, City Shreds Clothes
description: New York City officials destroyed tons of new, unworn clothing and footwear last year that had been seized in raids on counterfeit label operations, abandoning a practice of giving knockoff garments to groups that help the needy.

title: Clothing Bank for Those in Need
description: A clothing bank in New York allows those who are down on their luck to don much-needed new clothes. (NBC video)

title: Sanchez Stockpiles Points in the Confidence Game
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  When Mark Sanchez looks at the N.F.L. playoffs, he sees the quarterbacks he once idolized, guys like Brett Favre and Peyton Manning, Kurt Warner and Drew Brees.

title: As the Clock Runs, Warner Weighs if Its Time to Go
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  Twelve hours after shepherding the Arizona Cardinals into the National Football Conference divisional playoffs, Kurt Warner was rounding up five of his seven children for school. As others crowned him the king of the postseason after his near-perfect performance against the Green Bay Packers, Warner spent Monday reveling in the commonplace activities of fatherhood.

title: Colts Look for Balance of Rested Versus Rusty
description: INDIANAPOLIS  For two weeks, the Indianapolis Colts have let the Rest Debate rage around them. But quietly, they were working harder than usual.

title: McGwire Portrayed as in Fear in 2005
description: Concerns that Mark McGwire would become ensnared in a federal drug investigation and possibly also become the target of state or local prosecutors led to his decision to dodge questions about his use of steroids at a Congressional hearing in 2005, according to several people with knowledge of the matter.

title: Jewish Film Festival Begins
description: Its hard to sift through all 32 offerings of features and shorts from 13 countries that are part of the 19th annual Jewish Film Festival, which begins tonight. World War II dramas, the story of a Rothschild baroness in postwar New York, and a crime story co-directed by a Palestinian and an Israeli are all on the bill. Two of the stronger films, according to Stephen Holden, depart from the beaten path of historical documentaries and feature films, many of which focus on the Holocaust. One of them is Haim Tabakmans fateful drama Eyes Wide Open, set in contemporary Jerusalem. The film observes the unforgiving response within an ultra-Orthodox enclave to a gay relationship involving one of its own. The other is Adam Elliots claymation feature, Mary and Max, which follows the pen-pal relationship of Mary Dinkle (the voice of Toni Collette), a lonely 8-year-old girl living outside Melbourne, Australia, and Max Horovitz (Philip Seymour Hoffman), an obese 44-year-old Jewish New Yorker with Aspergers syndrome. Go to see those and discover other surprising cinematic gems. The films will be shown at the Walter Reade Theater and the Jewish Museum.

title: A Wonderful, Magical Animal
description: Nowhere in New York right now is the fetish for pork fat and dairy flavor more on display, Sam Sifton writes, then at the Breslin where April Bloomfield, the chef and an owner, is exhausting gall bladders daily. If the thought of shredded lamb, breaded and fried; or a soft-boiled Scotch egg, the orb caked in sausage meat, then breaded and fried; or deep-fried stuffed pigs foot, the size of a toddlers leg, makes your mouth water, then this is your spot. The vaguely British barroom, off the lobby of the Ace Hotel, attracts a bedlam of gastrotourists and scenemakers. But a visit should not be taken lightly, with an offering of 10 colors of fat, excess can become wretched, and fast. Thankfully, at least for your bodys sake, the restaurant doesnt take reservations.

title: Battle of the Internet Stars
description: If the phrases David After Dentist, Lady Gaga Medley and Keyboard Cat make you crack up immediately, or at least giggle, then the YouTube Wars Part I competition is the place to be tonight. Bring youre knowledge of viral videos to the performance space Littlefield in Brooklyn, where contestants can go head to head in a bracket-style tournament. For each round, the two competitors will face-off by playing their two favorite YouTube videos to wow the crowd. Whoever gets the best reaction moves on to the next round. Come armed with a playlist worthy of a belly laugh or at least a hearty guffaw. Organizers recommend choosing your start point wisely; video clips are limited to one minute. There will be prizes and drink specials, too.

title: Jan. 12-13: Updates on Haitis Earthquake
description: Some Haitians and visitors to the country have turned to the Web to share information about the earthquake that struck about 10 miles southwest of the capital of Port-au-Prince on Tuesday evening at a magnitude of 7.0. The Lede is continuing to track online sources on Thursday to supplement reporting by our colleagues. Readers who are in Haiti or are in touch with people there are encouraged to use the comment thread below to share firsthand accounts with us, or to point to them on other Web sites.

title: Thought Experiment #2
description: QUESTION: What is the difference among these three photographs?

title: Sarah Palin Makes Her Debut on Fox
description: Making her debut as a Fox News analyst Tuesday night, Sarah Palin immediately picked up the networks mantra, promising that she would provide fair and balanced commentary.

title: Senate Hopeful in New State Airs Evolving Views
description: In his first extensive interview since he began weighing a run for United States Senate from New York, Harold E. Ford Jr. distanced himself from his previous opposition to same-sex marriage, his description of himself as pro-life and his push to permit local police officers to enforce federal immigration law, and said he would be a fiercer advocate for New York than Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand.

title: Hey Google, Anybody Home?
description: Googles celebrated algorithms may power the Webs most popular search engine, but they have not yet been programmed to answer a call when a customer has a problem.

title: Why Does Health Care Cost So Much?
description: People like to live too much.

title: Baseball to Monitor Marlins Spending
description: The Florida Marlins on Tuesday committed to spend any proceeds from Major League Baseballs revenue-sharing plan on player development and salaries.

title: Manslaughter Defense Remains Open Issue in Doctors Killing
description: WICHITA, Kan.  It remained uncertain on Tuesday whether an abortion opponent accused of murdering a nationally known abortion provider would be permitted to argue that the shooting fell short of first-degree murder because he was trying to save lives.

title: Interview With Harold Ford Jr.
description: Following are edited excerpts from Mondays interview with Harold E. Ford Jr., conducted by Michael Barbaro, a political reporter for The New York Times, at New York Universitys campus in Manhattan:

title: Contractor Jailed in Cuba Was Aiding Religious Groups, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON  The United States contractor detained in Cuba last month and accused of being a spy is a 60-year-old social worker from the Washington suburbs who had gone to Cuba to provide communications equipment to Jewish nonprofit organizations, according to American officials.

title: OBrien Rejects NBC Shift: Hes Set to Say Good Night
description: NBC may control its airwaves, but apparently it does not control Conan OBrien.

title: 58 Down: Folkie Guthrie
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Three famous women have been planted in todays grid, with FLOWER GIRLS hinting at their floral/female connection. IRIS MURDOCH blooms first, followed by DAISY MILLER and finally ROSE KENNEDY.

title: Reid Faces Battles in Washington and at Home
description: HARRY REID WAS HOARSE and hacking, drawn and more stooped than usual on a Sunday morning 12 days before Christmas. It was not yet noon, and Reid was in his second-floor corner office in an empty United States Capitol. He had arrived to bad news. Joseph Lieberman, the independent Connecticut senator, had announced on CBSs Face the Nation that he would not support the Senate health care plan, which meant that Reid did not have the 60 votes he needed. Liebermans announcement, which torpedoed a compromise that Reid helped to midwife, caught the Senate majority leader by surprise. Reid had spoken with Lieberman two days earlier, and one of Liebermans top aides participated in the Saturday-afternoon conference call that Reid orchestrates for Democratic senators who will be appearing on the Sunday talk shows. He double-crossed me, Reid said stiffly, associates later recounted. Lets not do what he wants. Let the bill just go down.

title: Haitis Agony
description: A potent earthquake centered just 10 miles from a city of close to 2 million people, most of whom are deeply impoverished, is a recipe for utter calamity, and initial reports out of Port-au-Prince, Haiti, and nearby communities indicate that is what has unfolded in that unlucky country. It appears that at least one hospital and a school  two of the keystone structures in any community  are among the buildings that collapsed, along with dozens of shanties built on steep slopes.

title: A Year of Terror Plots, Through a Second Prism
description: WASHINGTON  As terrorist plots against the United States have piled up in recent months, politicians and the news media have sounded the alarm with a riveting message for Americans: Be afraid. Al Qaeda is on the march again, targeting the country from within and without, and your hapless government cannot protect you.

title: Wall St. Pay Is a Focus of Many in Washington
description: Everyone in Washington is taking a swing at Wall Street pay.

title: The Biggest Loser
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Is China the Next Enron?
description: Taipei, Taiwan

title: Report Links Vehicle Exhaust to Health Problems
description: Exhaust from cars and trucks exacerbates asthma in children and may cause new cases as well as other respiratory illnesses and heart problems resulting in deaths, an independent institute that focuses on vehicle-related air pollution has concluded.

title: U.S.C. Hires Kiffin as Coach
description: In a bold move that shows that Southern California is unafraid of raising the ire of the N.C.A.A., the Trojans hired Lane Kiffin, the controversial Tennessee coach, on Tuesday to replace Pete Carroll, who was hired as the Seattle Seahawks coach.

title: For Bankers, Saying Sorry Has Its Perils
description: As America recovers from the worst financial crisis since the Depression, some of the nations chief executives are offering that rarest of statements  an apology.

title: Knicks Get Their Look at Iverson
description: PHILADELPHIA  More than a month after briefly entertaining the thought of signing Allen Iverson, the Knicks are set to face him here Wednesday night  provided Iverson plays through knee tendinitis that has kept him in and out of Philadelphias lineup.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with an article about the growing popularity of early-bird dinner specials among younger diners in Florida misidentified, in some copies, the location of the restaurant shown. It is in Miami Beach, not North Miami.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday with an article about a dance installation, Scrying, created for the Museum of Modern Arts PopRally event series, misspelled the surname of a dancer shown rehearsing. She is Grace McLoughlin, not McLaughlin.

title: Union Chief Seeks to Overhaul Teacher Evaluation Process
description: WASHINGTON  Facing criticism that her union makes it too hard to get rid of bad teachers, Randi Weingarten, president of the American Federation of Teachers, on Tuesday announced a union-backed effort to develop a new model for how public school teachers should be evaluated, promoted and removed.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Wednesday about the musical The Addams Family, now playing in Chicago and scheduled to come to Broadway in March, misidentified, in some copies, the maker of the film A Nightmare on Elm Street in citing examples of movies and television shows influenced by Charles Addams. It was made by Wes Craven, not Tim Burton.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review on Tuesday about Miami City Ballet misspelled a dancers surname. He is Michael Sean Breeden, not Breedon.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Friday about Return to Cranford, on PBS, misidentified, at one point, the period in which the story is set. As the review noted elsewhere, it is set in 1844  the mid-19th century, not the mid-18th century.

title: Tax Them Both
description: The White House is talking about levying a tax or fee on large banks to recover the $120 billion it spent to bail out the financial system. That is a good place to start, but it shouldnt stop there. President Obama and Congress should also impose a windfall tax on the huge bonuses that bailed-out bankers plan to pay themselves over the next few weeks.

title: Football and Antitrust
description: On the surface, American Needle Inc. v. National Football League seems to be about hats, shirts and other items with team logos on them. But if the United States Supreme Court issues a broad ruling in favor of the N.F.L., it could help define how far joint ventures can go in stifling competition.

title: Looking Past the Facade of Italian City After Riots
description: ROSARNO, Italy  The official figures show there are 1,600 agricultural workers in this town, all but 36 of them Italians. The reality, exposed by the raw and violent riots here last week, was far different: Some 1,200 foreigners, most of them Africans, earned about $30 a day under the table picking oranges and clementines. Now that the town is largely cleared of foreign labor, the fruit remains on the trees.

title: Compassion in New Jersey
description: It was a rare piece of good news for those suffering from such diseases as cancer, AIDS, Lou Gehrigs disease and muscular dystrophy. The New Jersey Legislature on Monday legalized medically prescribed marijuana, and Gov. Jon Corzine has promised to sign the bill before leaving office next week.

title: Miep Gies
description: I am not a hero, insisted Miep Gies. I was just an ordinary housewife and secretary. It was Mrs. Geiss habit to deflect accolades for defying Nazi occupiers of Amsterdam by helping to hide Anne Frank, her family and three other doomed Jews in a secret annex to the business office of Annes father, Otto Frank.

title: When Religion Oppresses Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: How to Stop Americas Scientific Brain Drain
description: To the Editor:

title: She Hid Anne Frank
description: To the Editor:

title: Poverty in New York City
description: To the Editor:

title: Questions for the Big Bankers
description: Today, the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, which Congress established last year to investigate the causes of the financial crisis, is scheduled to question the heads of four big banks  Lloyd Blankfein of Goldman Sachs, Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase, John Mack of Morgan Stanley and Brian Moynihan of Bank of America. The Op-Ed editors asked eight financial experts to pose questions they would like to hear the bankers answer.

title: Google Would Abandon a Lucrative Market
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google threatened on Tuesday to pull out of China after it learned of immense security attacks and attempts to gain access to the Gmail accounts of Chinese dissidents and human rights activists.

title: Talks to Begin on Creating a Bipartisan Budget Panel
description: WASHINGTON  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will begin talks this week with leading lawmakers about creating a bipartisan budget commission, an idea that has long languished in Congress but could become central to the Obama administrations promise to reduce annual deficits.

title: Kvelling Over a Matriarch of the Yiddish Theater
description: Out came the rugelach. Out came the bagels and lox. Out came the chicken salad. And out came the stories  in Yiddish, of course  about Mina Bern, the great Yiddish actress who died on Sunday, leaving a void in what is left of Yiddish theater in New York.

title: Mina Bern, Versatile Yiddish Actress, Dies at 98
description: Mina Bern, a plucky and versatile actress and singer who was one of the last links to the scrappy world of Yiddish theater in New York, died Sunday in Manhattan. She was 98 and lived on the Lower East Side.

title: Goalies Show Top Form as Devils Edge Rangers
description: It was a game worthy of the nine Olympians on the ice and the two behind the benches, a rugged but cleanly played contest of unrelenting high speed and numerous chances. In the end, however, it was the goaltending that was the most Olympian of all.

title: Insurers Helped Pay for TV Attack Ads
description: Five big health insurance companies funneled millions of dollars to the United States Chamber of Commerce for television commercials attacking Congressional efforts to overhaul the health care system, the National Journal reported Tuesday.

title: Illinois Tries United Front Against Fish and Lawsuit
description: CHICAGO  Federal and state officials from Illinois on Tuesday defended their efforts to ward off Asian carp, a voracious, nonnative fish that could threaten the ecosystem of the Great Lakes, even as they reported new evidence that the fish may be near Lake Michigan.

title: Knox Burger, Agent and Book Editor, Dies at 87
description: As a magazine editor in the 1950s, Knox Burger published Kurt Vonneguts first short story. As a book editor in the 1960s, he asked John D. MacDonald to create a mystery series around a character who eventually turned out to be the detective Travis McGee. And as a literary agent in the 1970s, he took on a novel about a Russian detective by a largely unknown writer  Gorky Park, by Martin Cruz Smith  which in 1980 he sold to Random House for $1 million.

title: Patersons 15-Year-Old Son Is Questioned but Not Charged After Dice Game, Officials Say
description: Alex Paterson, the 15-year-old son of Gov. David A. Paterson, was questioned by the police on Tuesday after officers found him and four friends playing dice on the Upper West Side, people with direct knowledge of the case said.

title: Former Seagate C.E.O. Bill Watkins Joins an LED Start-Up
description: Seagate Technology, the big hard drive company, surprised people last January when the board abruptly fired its outspoken and candid chief executive, Bill Watkins. A year later, Mr. Watkins, as outspoken as ever, has resurfaced as the chief executive of an LED start-up called Bridgelux.

title: Frantic Hunt for News on Haitis Quake
description: As news of the devastation wrought by a powerful earthquake trickled out of Haiti on Tuesday evening, Ricot Dupuy, a station manager at Radio Soleil dHaiti in Brooklyn, sat alone in his radio booth fielding a flurry of phone calls from local listeners.

title: Corrections
description: A recipe with The Minimalist column last Wednesday for French lentils with cashews misstated the amount of dried French green (Le Puy) lentils. It calls for one cup, not a half cup. A corrected recipe can be found at nytimes.com/dining.

title:
At Goldman, E-Mail Message
Lays Bare Conflicts in Trading
description: For years, Wall Street whispered that Goldman Sachs profited handsomely by trading ahead of  or even against  its own clients.

title: Down by the Banks of the River Charles: The American Idol Premiere
description: Let the long period of national mourning begin: the ninth season of American Idol began tonight, and it was two hours of dead-man-walking. With the future stability of the show in doubt, Tuesdays premiere episode, focusing on the Boston auditions, was a reminder of its strengths and weaknesses. Soak in Simon Cowells evident distaste for Kara Dioguardi; ponder the physics of Victoria Beckhams head tilt; let the shock of a contestant saying Randy Jacksons his favorite judge sting anew. Soon, this will all be just a memory.

title: Supreme Court Weighs Authority, Not Legality, of Civil Confinements
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court heard arguments on Tuesday about the controversial practice of keeping sex offenders locked up after they have completed their criminal sentences  but from an unusual angle.

title: Longhorns Look to Stay Unbeaten
description: Kentucky remained unbeaten with its 89-77 victory at Florida on Tuesday. Top-ranked Texas, the other undefeated team in Division I, plays at Iowa State on Wednesday. Texas had never been No. 1.

title: Nobel Winner to Step Down as Chief at Sloan-Kettering
description: Dr. Harold E. Varmus, the Nobel Prize-winning president and chief executive of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, said Tuesday that he would be stepping down after 10 years as the head of the renowned Upper East Side medical institution.

title: Lottery Numbers
California Panel Considers Money From Climate Rules
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Offering an early glimpse of how California might manage a central element of its ambitious greenhouse-gas law, a state committee has recommended that residents receive cash or tax breaks resulting from auctions of emission allowances to industries and other polluters.

title: Deals to Restrain Generic Drugs Face a Ban
description: A group of House lawmakers and the head of the Federal Trade Commission want Congress to include a provision in the health care legislation that they say could save American consumers several billion dollars a year on prescription drugs.

title: An Olympic Plot Line at the Garden
description: At Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night, the Devils cast included the United States captain, Jamie Langenbrunner, who is also their captain, and Zach Parise, an American alternate captain.

title: Obama to Propose Bank Tax to Recoup Bailout Losses
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has decided to seek a tax on big banks to recoup up to $120 billion that the government expects to lose from bailing out the financial system, automakers and some troubled homeowners.

title: Labor Campaigns Against Tax on Health Plans
description: WASHINGTON  Having failed to persuade President Obama to scrap a proposed tax on high-cost health insurance policies, labor leaders took their case Tuesday to Speaker Nancy Pelosi, and they said they received a more favorable response.

title: Fed Is Again Accused of Blocking Release of A.I.G. Bailout Information
description: For the second time in a week, the Federal Reserve was accused by a member of Congress on Tuesday of blocking the public release of information about the bailout of the American International Group.

title: Google Refuses to Kowtow
description: Im quite amazed that Google is showing the guts to announce that it will no longer censor within China (google.cn) and is prepared to pull out of China altogether. Wow! Finally, a company shows some principles and backbone in this area, after Microsoft Bing censored Chinese-language content worldwide (they claim it was a bug) and Yahoo helped the Chinese government sent dissidents to prison.There are no perfect solutions for dealing with a repressive government, and I made my own share of compromises when I lived for five years in China. Im a big believer in engagement as a whole, when foreign engagement amounts to a watchdog and boosts civil society. But instead so many foreign companies have acted as lapdogs and facilitated censorship and surveillance, while refusing to speak up for the values they claim to be committed to.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,364 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 938 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Mixed Signals Complicate European Banks Task
description: FRANKFURT  With signals about European growth mixed and some weaker members of the European Union still in debt crisis, the European Central Bank is in a tough position as it seeks to pull back on measures that helped the euro zone through the recession.

title: GLAAD Award Nominees Include Glee, True Blood, Mad Men and Precious
description: The television shows True Blood, Glee and Mad Men, and the films I Love You, Man and Precious: Based on the Novel Push By Sapphire, are among the nominees for the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamations annual GLAAD Media Awards, the group announced. The winners of the awards, which are for recognizing and honoring media for outstanding images of the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people, the alliance said in a news release, will be chosen from 116 nominees in 24 English-language categories and 36 nominees in eight Spanish-language categories. Precious and I Love You, Man were among the five movies nominated in the outstanding film  wide release category; True Blood and Mad Men were nominated for outstanding drama series, alongside Brothers & Sisters, Greys Anatomy and Skins; and Glee was nominated for outstanding comedy series, as were Modern Family, United States of Tara, Beautiful People and Greek. The actress Cynthia Nixon will receive the groups Vito Russo Award at a ceremony in New York, and the cast of the Broadway revival of Hair will receive a special recognition for its commitment to raising visibility for marriage equality, GLAAD said.

title: Facebook Joins With McAfee to Clean Spam From Site
description: It looks like Facebook has finally gotten fed up with all the viruses and spam that is plaguing the social network and ensnaring and embarrassing its 350 million members.

title: Simon and Garfunkel to Play Jazzfest
description: For a month, fans and potential customers of the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival have been eyeing a big artist TBA on the schedule New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival. That TBA has now been announced by the festival: the surprise act for the first of Jazzfests two weekends, on April 24, will be the reunited Simon and Garfunkel. Its not the first time that Paul Simon has played Jazzfest, but it will be Art Garfunkels first time there, and this is to be Simon and Garfunkels only American appearance in 2010. Simon and Garfunkel fans have been awaiting news of unions shows in the United States since Mr. Garfunkel joined Mr. Simon onstage at the Beacon Theater in New York last February. The festival, now in its 41st year, will also feature, among many others, Lionel Richie, My Morning Jacket, Dr. John, Darius Rucker and Drake in its first weekend (April 23 to 25), and Pearl Jam, Aretha Franklin, Van Morrison, B.B. King, the Neville Brothers and Widespread Panic in its second (April 29 to May 2).

title: North Carolina: Chemical Spill Closes Port
description: An early morning accident at the port in Morehead City spilled as much as five gallons of the highly explosive chemical pentaerythritol tetranitrate, or PETN, prompting officials to close the port and evacuate the surrounding area. Emergency officials made progress containing the spill, and by evening the evacuation was lifted. The accident occurred when a forklift operator punctured a container, putting holes in nine 110-pound drums containing PETN, a Coast Guard spokesman said.

title: Showcase: Pounded Pavement
description: In a typical trip along the sidewalks of Manhattan, a pedestrian peering ahead can quickly take in a variety of expressions. Faces in the crowd inevitably reflect concentration and consternation, amusement and bewilderment, determination and aggravation. But glance down at any point along the way, and you may be surprised to see yet another face returning your gaze, like this one, with its faintly reptilian grin.

title: Rail to the Trails
description: New York City skiers and snowboarders can rarely claim advantages over their brethren out West. Our nearby mountains are small compared with the Rockies and the Tetons. Instead of powder we have ice. And despite the bitter cold, our season is frustratingly short. But we do have one thing Coloradoans dont  a subway to the ski area.

title: Why Do So Many Winter Olympians Have Asthma?
description: Every four years, exercise-induced asthma draws special attention among scientists and the media, in lock step with the Winter Olympics. Thats because when the worlds premier cold-weather sports athletes convene in Vancouver for the 2010 Winter Olympics next month, they will share, as a group, not only exceptional fitness but also a disproportionate tendency to wheeze.

title: Nintendo Wii to Add Netflix Service for Streaming Video
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Owners of the Nintendo Wii can finally stop waving their video game controllers in the air and sink back onto the couch.

description: The news anchor Russ Mitchell will exit The Early Show at the end of the week, leaving a gap in the lineup for the perennially third-place CBS morning show.

title: Battle For Ailing Japan Airlines Continues
description: Investors rushed to sell their shares in Japan Airlines on Tuesday and Wednesday ahead of a bankruptcy filing that could come as early as next week. At the same time, two rival airlines, American Airlines and Delta Air Lines, battled for a stake in JAL, which could still be a strong regional player once restructuring takes place, The New York Timess Hiroko Tabuchi reported.

title: Web Tool Tracks the Flu
description: Googles Flu Trends, a surveillance tool for the United States that tracks flu-related search queries, will measure flu activity in 121 cities. Official flu trend data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, based on how many people with flu symptoms visit doctors, takes a week or more to collect, but the Google data will be updated daily. Google designed the tool in consultation with C.D.C. epidemiologists. Its successful flu shot finder is used by flu.gov and cdc.gov/h1n1flu, the governments chief influenza Web sites.

title: Haiti Lies in Ruins; Grim Search for Untold Dead
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Survivors strained desperately on Wednesday against the chunks of concrete that buried this city along with thousands of its residents, rich and poor, from shantytowns to the presidential palace, in the devastating earthquake that struck late Tuesday afternoon.

title: Citigroup Bonus May Trump Goldmans
description: This bonus season, would you rather be a banker at Goldman Sachs or Citigroup? Goldman has famously set aside more money to reward employees for their efforts last year. But the biggest bonuses will come mostly in stock, and Goldmans shares have surged from the lows of the crisis. Give other banks shares a chance to catch up and bankers paid in the laggards equity could wind up richer on 2009s spoils.

title: Say Formaggio | The Modeling Missonis

Photographed by Juergen Teller, the ads were shot at the family home in Sumirago, Italy, near the companys headquarters and feature three generations of Missonis mugging for the camera. Not that it was hard to coax any of them to say formaggio. For us home and factory have always been very close, explains the labels designer Angela Missoni. It just felt like the right moment to propose something real. And an even better time to cut back on modeling fees.

Huge numbers of people are being injured and killed in this city, said the police chief, Anthony Batts, who supports the idea of a crime summit. Yet I dont hear anybody yelling about it. [The Oakland Tribune]
