title: Today, Were All Haitians
description: After 9/11, the French newspaper Le Monde declared: We Are All Americans. And after yesterdays earthquake: Today, we are all Haitians. No country seems to have had worse luck with misrule, environmental mismanagement, natural disasters and poor governance than Haiti. And now the earthquake.Poverty always hugely magnifies natural disasters. I saw this first in the terrible 1991 cyclone in Bangladesh that killed more than 100,000 people. The poorest people lived in marginal areas, such as flood plains, and in flimsy huts that were immediately washed away. So they were killed. Those who were better off lived on firmer land in sturdier homes, and after the disaster they were able to afford clean water and medical care for their children. Frequently what kills people in these disasters isnt just nature but its interconnection with poverty, and in Haiti its imperative to arrange not only the earthquake response  digging people out of rubble  but also a public health response by controlling disease and assuring access to clean water for survivors.

description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: Sarah Palin is going to be a commentator for Fox News. Well maybe now she can afford to buy some clothes for Levi Johnston.

title: Baucus: Why Health Care Is Expensive
description: To continue the conversation about why health care in America is so expensive and what the legislation emerging in Washington would or would not do about it, the Prescriptions blog asked Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, chairman of the Finance Committee and one of the leading architects of the Senate bill, to answer the same question that we posed earlier to two policy experts of different political persuasions.

title: News Out of New Jersey
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Sarah Palin made her debut as a Fox News contributor tonight on The OReilly Factor. I tried to record it, but my DVR quit halfway through.

title: Avatar as Outlier
description: Just how much of a game-changer is Avatar? The conventional wisdom is that James Camerons blockbuster epic, which has made over $1.3 billion globally, is a turning point in filmmaking on the scale of the switch from silents to sound. But as Michael Cieply reports on Wednesday, the film may not shake up the industry any time soon.

title: Congressional Censure or Worse
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Tonight Show With Conan OBrien on NBC: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, is in the news. Hes still under fire for remarks he made about President Obamas blackness. Sources say he could face Congressional censure or, even worse, be promised The Tonight Show at 11:30.

title: Paterson Does Not Oppose a Ford Senate Bid
description: This is beginning to look a bit familiar.

title: Perella Weinberg Hires Dep. Asset Management Head
description: Perella Weinberg Partners, the boutique investment bank, said Wednesday that it has hired William W. Johnson, a financial services veteran, as a partner and its deputy head of asset management.

title: Getting Old Jobs Back
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: Of course, the really big news is Conan OBrien said in a written statement that he will not do The Tonight Show after Jay Leno. I think. But then he also said he wants to make The Tonight Show the best it can be, which means he didnt quit. I think. I dont know. I have no idea. Im sure the lawyers will figure that out. Actually, I can think of a much better solution than the lawyers. Heres what I think we should do here  government bailout money. It worked with Wall Street. Why doesnt Congress give NBC money to make more late night shows? That would solve everything.

title: NBC Broadcasts Itself as a Punch Line
description: You dont have to watch a lot of broadcast television to know that the brand that is pushed most regularly is the network itself. In spot after spot, one message at a time, networks build their image that their button on the remote is the place to be.

title: Big Week for Giant Announcements
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: A couple of minutes ago, Conan OBrien, who was the host of The Tonight Show over there at NBC, announced that he would not follow Jay Leno at 12:05. If Conan does leave The Tonight Show, then he has to appoint a replacement. Did you know that?

title: A Cement Giant Tackles its CO2 Emissions
description: With cement production accounting for as much as 5 percent of global emissions of carbon dioxide  and the potential for expanded carbon caps looming  Cemex, one of the worlds largest producers of building materials, is angling to bring down its carbon dioxide emissions and perhaps wind up with some credits it can sell.

title: Same-Sex Marriage Case, Day 3: The Defense Pushes Back
description: Update 5:49 p.m. Pacific Time | On Wednesday afternoon, the plaintiffs lawyers changed the subject, focusing again on the issue of marriage. An earlier academic witness, Nancy F. Cott of Harvard University, had recounted the history of racial and other marriage restrictions. When Letitia A. Peplau, a social psychologist at the University of California, Los Angeles, took the stand she talked about marriage in more general terms.

title: Calorie Postings No Match for Holiday Gluttony
description: When a study on New Yorkers eating habits was released last week, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, city health officials and the reports authors focused on what appeared to be a triumph of government policy: After the city began requiring restaurant chains to post calories, customers ordered lighter food.

title: Enchanted Afternoon, Raucous Evening
description: REMEMBER double features? I barely do. They had mostly gone the way of VistaVision and drive-ins by the time I became a movie-mad youth. On a few occasions I created my own, sneaking in to see Grease one more time after paying for another movie. (Apologies, AMC Theaters; the checks in the mail.) Luxuriating in a two-movie afternoon was the closest thing to decadence a 13-year-old can achieve. Or at least should.

title: Really Light-Skinned People
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: Well of course, the big political story, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid got himself in hot water during the election, when he described Barack Obama as a light-skinned African-American with no negro dialect. See, that may explain why Reid was the Senate majority leader and not the Senate minority leader.

title: More Updates on Haiti
description: A note to readers: on Wednesday, The Lede is continuing to add to the post on the earthquake in Haiti we started on Tuesday. Go to the top of the post headlined Updates on Haitis Earthquake, for the latest information gleaned from the Web.

title: A Steak for the Season
description: Tri-tip, the squat, triangular sirloin cut that is perfect in winter (its actually better for roasting than grilling), takes perfectly to a quick little romesco sauce. See todays Minimalist column for more.

title: Is the Military Getting Soft?
description: Rank doesnt matter, nor does it count if your father was a general or a sergeant major: Anyone who reports to his or her unit on Day One in poor physical condition has lost the respect of fellow soldiers.One company commander in my previous unit enjoyed testing his new lieutenants with a five-mile run at a blistering pace the day they arrived, followed by pull-ups, push-ups and a gamut of other calisthenics.

title: The Kiffin Chronicles
description: We interrupt the melee on the University of Tennessee campus to request a moment of silence to mourn the passing of any last semblance of sanity in college sports. Because as peeved as the Volunteers crowd is  and yes, they are burning-mattresses peeved at Lane Kiffin for jumping ship for Southern California  the Trojans crowd may consider being even more ticked off. Because their university seems to be celebrating its wallow in serious N.C.A.A. mire (paging Reggie Bush) by holding its nose and swan-diving into the sewage.

title: Prosecutors in Tokyo Raid the Office of a Political Power Broker
description: TOKYO  Prosecutors in Tokyo raided the office of one of the most powerful figures in Japans governing party on Wednesday, expanding the latest in a series of finance scandals that have sapped support for the new government.

title: The Good Wife Watch: Complications
description: This post contains spoilers.

title: Massive Earthquake Hits Haiti
description: NBC reports on massive earthquake in Haiti. (Video: NBC)

title: Sausalito Says No to Peets
description: Peets Coffee & Tea has spent decades brewing customer loyalty and affection, but that love was not enough to win the hearts of Sausalitos leaders. On Tuesday night, City Council members voted against a zoning change that would have allowed Peets to open its first cafe there.

title: Genetic Testing for Celiac Disease
description: Dr. Sheila Crowe, a professor in the division of gastroenterology and hepatology in the department of medicine at the University of Virginia, recently joined the Consults blog to answer reader questions about celiac disease, an often overlooked digestive disorder that causes damage to the small intestine when gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley and rye, is eaten. In previous posts, Dr. Crowe exploredthe varied symptoms of celiac disease and confirming a diagnosis of celiac disease. Here, Dr. Crowe responds to readers asking about the disease running in families, genetic tests that may help confirm a diagnosis, food allergies and thins that set off the ailment.

title: Basket Cases
description: Video | Whooping hoops tricksters:

title: Reader Rejoinders
description: An occasional assemblage of overheard or underappreciated words  generously proposed by co-vocabularists.

title: Obama to Send Aid to Haiti Quake Victims
description: President Obama says the US will deliver food, water and medicine to Haiti.

title: Detroit Auto Show: A Chrysler Dealer Hangs On
description: It was like old times in the V.I.P. Hospitality Lounge at the 2010 North American International Auto Show on Tuesday afternoon as car dealers and other movers and shakers in the industry greeted one another with jovial back slaps. When Bill Cook, chairman emeritus of the auto show, popped in, several people shouted Hey, Cookie and went to greet him. A father and his two adult sons sat clustered at a small table and reminisced about a childhood spent growing up in the car business, cracking jokes.

title: Text of President Obamas Remarks
description: Here are President Obamas remarks Wednesday morning on the earthquake in Haiti and rescue efforts, as released by the White House.

title: Text of Secretary General Ban Ki-Moons Remarks
description: Following are the remarks made to reporters Wednesday morning by Ban Ki-moon, secretary general of the United Nations, on the earthquake in Haiti, as transcribed by the United Nations press office. The bracketed editorial insertions were supplied with the transcript.

title: Producing Green Natural Gas in Canada?
description: In recent months, American legislators and energy experts have lavished attention on a carbon capture and storage project in Weyburn, Saskatchewan, where millions of tons of carbon dioxide from a North Dakota coal gasification plant are pumped into a large oil field to recover hard-to-reach pockets of fuel.

title: Are We What We Watch? Deconstructing Netflix Queues
description: The New York Times has an interactive map showing by ZIP code what people rent from Netflix for urban areas around the United States, including the San Francisco Bay Area. Netflix, says the caption, provided data on the top 50 rentals in 2009.

title: Travel Deals: AirTran Flights from $39
description: With an arctic blast still freezing much of the country, deals to the Caribbean, Mexico and other warm weather destinations seem especially inviting. AirTran is offering a New Years Resolution sale, with flights to the Caribbean and other destinations nationwide, starting as low as $39 one-way.

title: On Tuesday Night, More Viewers for Leno and OBrien
description: Both Jay Leno and Conan OBrien saw increases in their audience Tuesday night, presumably from TV viewers who wanted to see how the two men would handle NBCs unfolding late-night train wreck.

title: Live-Blogging 4 Top Bankers on Capitol Hill
description: The Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission heard testimony about the financial crisis from four of the nations leading bankers: Lloyd C. Blankfein of Goldman Sachs, Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase, John J. Mack of Morgan Stanley and Brian T. Moynihan of Bank of America. (Watch the live video here, via C-Span 2.) DealBooks Zachery Kouwe live-blogged the hearing, with the most recent entries at the top:

title: Why Merchant Names Go Missing From Debit Card Statements
description: Last weeks article in The New York Times How Visa, Using Card Fees, Dominates a Market detailed the behind-the-scenes struggle between banks and retailers to encourage customers to sign when making debit card purchases or to punch in their PIN because of the higher fees that stores pay banks for signatures.

title: Seeking Your Questions on the Fafsa
description: For many high school seniors and their families, this is the season for tackling the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, a notoriously cumbersome process that the government is attempting to streamline this year.

title: Answers About Improv Everywhere
description: Editors note, April 2: a few weeks after this feature appeared, Charlie Todd of Improv Everywhere lied to City Room repeatedly as we questioned him on whether one of his stunts was an April Fools hoax (it was). While the unwritten laws of the Internet prevent us from taking these posts down, we cant vouch for anything he says here.

title: Final Album in Johnny Cash Series Is Coming
description: The seemingly bottomless supply of songs that Johnny Cash recorded with the producer Rick Rubin before Cashs death in 2003 has yielded enough material for one more album. As youd expect from the musician who called himself the Man in Black, this latest album, American VI: Aint No Grave, is a mix of the mournful and the morbid: in a news release, publicists for Cash said it would include covers of Sheryl Crows Redemption Day, Kris Kristoffersons For the Good Times and Tom Paxtons Can Help But Wonder Where Im Bound as well as Aloha Oe, and an original song called I Corinthians: 15:55. Lost Highway Records, which is releasing the album on Feb. 26 (which would have been Cashs 78th birthday), called it the final installment in Cashs American Recordings series, whose first self-titled release was in 1994. (As with other departed artists, this may not necessarily be Mr. Cashs last posthumous release.) In a statement, Mr. Rubin said the songs on American VI were recorded in the months after Cashs wife, June Carter Cash, died. Johnny said that recording was his main reason for being alive, Mr. Rubin added. I think it was the only thing that kept him going.

title: City as Stage, Audience as Family
description: THE restaurant Veselka, in the East Village, has featured Ukrainian borscht on its menu, individual banana cream pies on its daily specials board, and, in 2008, at the fourth table from the entrance, Etiquette, a performance piece in which the ticket holders were also the actors. Presented by the Foundry Theater and its artistic producer, Melanie Joseph, the work called for two people at a time to play the parts of a young woman and an elderly philosopher, with the dialogue fed to them through headphones.

title: Juggling Full-Time Work and Kids
description: The comments got all philosophical last week when I asked everyone their reasons for having children. Lets get all practical today and discuss how you make your lives work once the children arrive.

title: Skating Tries to Demystify Its Scoring System
description: Its a modern mystery, stumping experts and amateurs alike, since the fall of 2005: What the heck is the International Skating Unions judging system, and how does a skating fan make sense of it?

title: Haitians in New York Eager to Help, but Struggle With How
description: They know how to make the calls. They know what to collect and send. In a city of insular immigrant communities, none has had more experience helping with disasters back home and knowing how to make crucial life-or-death connections than the Haitian communities in Brooklyn and in Cambria Heights, Queens.

title: Artists Prize-Winning Work Is Destroyed. (Its What He Wanted.)
description: Art is long and life is brief, but sometimes art is brief, too. A wall painting by Richard Wright that won him the Turner Prize in December has been erased by workers at the Tate Britain museum  as Mr. Wright intended, The Guardian reported. The painting, a gold-leaf fresco of an abstract design, was sanded and painted over by the museums art handlers last week, after an exhibition on the Turner Prize, the prestigious British art award, was closed. Mr. Wright, 49, who lives in Glasgow, was named the prize winner over the heavily favored installation artist Roger Hiorns. In an Arts Beat post, Roberta Smith described Mr. Wright as a cross between Sol LeWitt and Faberg who creates elaborate works that are meant to exist temporarily. The Guardian said Mr. Wright was not in attendance at this works deletion.

title: Samurai Shopper | Beauty: Youre a Prize
description: Welcome to awards season, when everything unreal and unimportant in showbiz is celebrated, digested and parsed with bloated, brainlessly baroque observations of no import whatsoever. The Samurai Shopper, as usual, is throwing her hat into the fluttering mists of fatuity to honor her own superstars: those beauty products that may or may not grace the faces of telegenic Golden Globers, Grammy-grabbers and the unfortunately named S.A.G. nominees. Ill deploy the same sentimental, indulgent, politically circumspect judgment in awarding my prizes as the Hollywood corps does with theirs.

title: Ke$ha Ends Susan Boyles Dream
description: Susan Boyles six-week run at the top of the Billboard album chart has finally been ended, by a singer who couldnt be more different. Ke$ha, a 22-year-old American whose song TiK ToK is an unabashed celebration of the liquor-fueled party life, opened at No. 1 with Animal (Kemosabe/RCA), which was released last week and sold 152,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Ms. Boyles I Dreamed a Dream (Syco Music/Columbia) fell to No. 2 with 93,000 sales, bringing its seven-week total to just under 3.2 million.

title: France 24 Interviews Haitian Radio DJ
description: French international news channel France 24 interviews Haitian radio DJ, Carel Pedre about the earthquake in Haiti.

title: Fabio Trabocchi Leaves the Four Seasons
description: Fabio Trabocchi has left the Four Seasons, The Feed reports, with a publicist citing philosophical differences.

title: Under the Radar: Five Questions About Ads
description: The trademarks of a Richard Maxwell show are there: the silent pauses, the inflection-less monologues, the minimal set. All thats missing are the actors.

title: Espada May Have Violated Laws, Cuomos Office Says
description: Pedro Espada Jr., the State Senate majority leader, may have violated several laws by using a network of health clinics he controlled as a source of income for his personal and political use, according to court papers filed on Wednesday by the state attorney generals office.

title: Haitis Economy
description: Update | 1:29 p.m.

title: Bankers Face Tough Questions at Crisis Hearing
description: The heads of Wall Streets largest banks faced skeptical questions on Wednesday about executive pay and the failures of regulation from the bipartisan commission established to examine the causes of the biggest downturn since the Depression, The New York Timess Sewell Chan reports from Washington. Tensions flared as commission members retraced the events leading to the near-collapse of the financial system in 2008 and pressed bankers on whether they or their employees had behaved unethically.

title: Paterson Offers New Details on Sons Brush With Police
description: Gov. David A. Paterson offered new details about the incident that led the police to detain his 15-year-old son on Tuesday afternoon, saying that a simple game of dice apparently caused a misunderstanding, and that there is no evidence that his son committed any crime or attempted to use a lost debit card found in his possession.

title: Iraqis on Iraq  Falluja and Tikrit
description: As international attention increasingly shifts from Iraq to Afghanistan  we asked Iraqi journalists working for The New York Times to give a personal view of daily life in the areas where they live. Here, we offer views from Falluja and Tikrit as our colleagues Mohammed Hussein and Timothy Williams report on the escalation of violence in recent weeks and a suicide bombing in Anbar Province Wednesday morning. The names of the Iraqi journalists are withheld because of the continuing threat to their lives.

title: Detroit Auto Show: GMC Granite, Audi A8 Win Design Awards
description: The GMC Granite won the EyesOn Design Award for Best Concept Vehicle at the North American International Auto Show on Tuesday afternoon.

title: Comedic Overachiever Adds Two Books to Rsum
description: Steve Martin has spun his wheel of talents again, and this time it has stopped at author: Grand Central Publishing said in an e-mail message that it had acquired two new books from Mr. Martin, the actor, comedian, bluegrass musician, New Yorker contributor and coming Academy Awards show co-host  one intended for young readers and one for the rest of us. The book for young readers is called Late for School, and is based on a song that also appears on Mr. Martins album The Crow: New Songs for the 5-String Banjo; it will include illustrations by C.F. Payne and a CD of the song (as well as a singalong version) and is to be released in September. The second book, called Woman, One, is a novel that examines the glamour and the subterfuge of the fine art world in New York, the e-mail message said. (Yes, Mr. Martin is an art collector, too.) The book, Mr. Martins first novel since The Pleasure of My Company, is planned for a November release. Both books were acquired by Deb Futter, the editor-in-chief of Grand Central Publishing, an imprint of Hachette Book Group.

title: Forgiving Mark McGwire
description: As Joe Posnanski notes, nobody seems much inclined to do it. And you can understand why. McGwires extended mea culpa comes years after it became clear that he took steroids, years after he stammered his way through a Congressional hearing, years after a public expression of contrition would have counted as brave and morally impressive. Hes been beaten to the admission-and-apology punch by everyone from Alex Rodriguez to Jason Grimsley. And he still doesnt want to acknowledge, for understandable reasons, that the steroids made all his home runs possible, even though saying that they kept him healthy so that he could hit home runs is basically the same thing anyway.

title: Israel and Turkey Patch Up Latest Rift, Over Diplomatic Slight
description: JERUSALEM  Israels deputy foreign minister issued a formal apology to the Turkish ambassador on Wednesday after ostentatiously humiliating him earlier in the week and aggravating strains in a complex and increasingly troubled relationship between Israel and Turkey, its closest Muslim ally.

title: A Landmark, but No Longer a Refuge for the Homeless
description: The West Park Presbyterian Church at Amsterdam Avenue and 86th Street is well known in the city for two reasons: its place as one of New Yorks finest examples of Romanesque Revival religious architecture, and its role for more than 15 years as a haven for homeless people who camp in the buildings doorways at night.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Brodeurs 51-Save Shutout Trumps Lundqvists 45-Save Shutout
description: Nine games in the N.H.L. on Tuesday night. Martin Brodeur made history in one of them, as he so often does. Home teams listed first:

title: The Nifty 50 | Generationals, Musicians
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Hollywood Stagehands Union Comes Out Against Tax on Generous Health Plans
description: The International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, whose 110,000 members work throughout the entertainment industry, is the latest Hollywood union to declare its formal opposition to a proposed excise tax on high-value health plans. In a letter sent to members of Congress on Wednesday, Matthew Loeb, the president of the alliance, said its general executive board had unanimously agreed to oppose any tax on hard-fought benefits and to immediately notify you of this action.

title: Mrs. Obama on Harry Reid and Party Crashers
description: Michelle Obama said on Wednesday that Senator Harry Reid had no need to apologize for his racial comments about her husband. And Mrs. Obama dismissed the fracas over three uninvited guests who crashed her first state dinner as a footnote in an otherwise lovely affair.

title: Wayne, Reed and the Python
description: Indianapolis Colts receiver Reggie Wayne and Baltimore Ravens safety Ed Reed go way back  all the way to their days as roommates at the University of Miami. They will face each other Saturday in a American Football Conference divisional round game. Aside from the fact that Reed could single-handedly doom your offense, he is apparently not the most reliable roommate either.

title: James Hotel to Open in SoHo
description: The real estate market in the New York City may still be in the dumps, but that hasnt slowed the opening of hotels.

title: Cold Still Hurting Floridas Farmers
description: MIAMI  Deep Freeze 2010? Ice Week? No one in Florida knows quite what to call the lengthy cold snap that finally eased on Wednesday, but there is little doubt that its economic and social impact will be memorable and significant.

title: Mayors Critics Sue to Protest Outside His Home
description: A group that opposes charter schools and school closings filed a lawsuit against the city on Tuesday for unconstitutionally and without any legal basis denying its request to protest on the sidewalk outside the Upper East Side town house of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Protecting Data, Ahead of the Curve
description: Network-attached storage, or NAS, may be one of the best-kept secrets in personal technology.

title: Concerns Over Britains Wind Plans
description: On Friday, the British government announced it had awarded licenses for several offshore wind projects with the potential to generate 32 gigawatts of power  or enough electricity to power nearly all the homes in Britain.

title: Haiti Earthquake: Impact on the U.N.
description: U.N. Bureau Chief Neil MacFarquhar reports on impact of the devastating earthquake in Haiti on United Nations facilities and personnel there.

title: Comparing the Bills, Part 2: Insurance Market Reforms
description: Updated | 4:06 p.m.  to note Jonathan Grubers government affiliation.

title: Hummer Production to End
description: General Motors announced on Wednesday that it will stop production of the Hummer next week, according to The Associated Press.

title: A Novel Take on Assisted Living
description: I cant say with assurance that Leslie Larsons Breaking Out of Bedlam is the first novel set in an assisted living facility, so Ill just say its the first one Ive read, and that its a kick.

title: Ben Brantley Answers Readers Questions About London Theater
description: Readers are submitting questions for Ben Brantley, The Timess chief theater critic, who is in London to see several shows.

title: Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard Make a Really Big Deal
description: Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard took the early lead in the unfortunately timed press conferences sweepstakes for 2010.

title: After a Hole Emerged, Greene Hit His Stride
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Even now, two very good years later, Shonn Greene remembers what it was like to work in the warehouse at a furniture store nearly 1,000 miles from home for $8 an hour. It was not exactly hard work, but it was not a lot of fun, either.

title: Well, Maybe Not Doomsday for the M.T.A.
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Less Fitness in the U.S. Military
description: Over on the At War blog, Tim Hsia writes about concerns that an ever-fatter American population has resulted in less-fit recruits to the military.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) Cool map, from the Modern Language association using census data, showing what languages are spoken where in the United States. It says there are more people in the United States who speak Yiddish than speak Thai, which I somehow find hard to believe.

title: Obesity Rates Hit Plateau in U.S., Data Suggest
description: Americans, at least as a group, may have reached their peak of obesity, according to data the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released Wednesday.

title: All About London Theater
description: Over on the ArtsBeat blog, readers are submitting questions for Ben Brantley, The Timess chief theater critic, who is in London to see several shows. First up: what to see in the West End, experimental theater companies and actors to watch.

title: Cedar Fairs Management Entry Ticket
description: The Cedar Fair preliminary proxy filed this week is notable for disclosing that the companys top executives will be staying for Apollo Managements ride.

title: Was There a Commercial Real Estate Bubble?
description: From Casey B. Mulligan at Economix:

title: America vs. Europe
description: David Brooks: Gail, can I draw you into the America versus Europe debate? This is the old argument over which model of capitalism is better, the Anglo-American model or the continental one. It was recently rekindled by two bloggers extraordinaire  Jim Manzi and Jonathan Chait  and then joined by our colleague Paul Krugman.

title: U.S. Regions Show Gains and Softness, Fed Reports
description: Little by little, regional economies in the United States are gaining strength, the Federal Reserve said Wednesday, though several pillars  housing, real estate and the jobs market  remain weak.

title: In Spain, a Delicacy Rooted in Earth and Tradition
description: AS we sauntered up the steep, narrow cobblestone streets of Cceres in western Spain, it wasnt hard to imagine life there in the Middle Ages. Night was falling, and before us were Gothic churches, Roman arches and Moorish towers, glowing in the soft light of lanterns. It was an arresting sight, but our thoughts soon veered elsewhere  to food and the sumptuous meal we were anticipating.

title: Studying the Studies: Evaluating Science and Health News Reports
description: Overview | How are scientific and medical study results reported to the public? How can and should people interpret these reports with an eye to reliability and seek additional information to put the news into scientific context? In this lesson, students reflect on what they look for in science and health news. Then, using any days Science Times and other resources, they evaluate news reports for validity and develop strategies for reading such reports and for developing research and experiment protocols.

title: App Comparison | New iPhone Travel Guides
description: Another day, another iPhone app.While the deluge never seems to stop, there are a few recent apps that cover a somehow previously underaddressed need: travel guides.The new Wallpaper guide essentially brings a version of its existing guide books from page to screen, with 10 different cities at $3.99 a pop.For the most part the guides are smartly organized  theres a 24-hour guide (good for business travelers or if the city is just one stop of many), a section of essential info (which includes the somewhat inessential average price of a bottle of Champagne), an insiders guide compiled by an actual resident and a panoramic photo of the city skyline with architectural highlights labeled and explained. The app also detects where you are in relation to every place in the guide and offers a link to Google maps for directions. Only the listings of restaurants, bars and nightclubs are lacking. Theyre all consolidated into one section called Urban Life, which does have appealing suggestions but also gives short shrift to cities with thousands of places to eat, drink and be merry. The Berlin app is currently available as a free download on the iTunes store for any on-the-fencers out there.

title: Correction
description: An earlier version of this column contained a factual error. The comments made by the Fox News analyst Brit Hume on Tiger Woods's faith were unprompted; he was not asked what advice he would give to Mr. Woods.

title: Road Test: Space Heaters
description: The Times tested 10 portable models to see how well they performed.

title: Haiti Quake Day 2: Devastation
description: Haitian authorities and humanitarian aid organizations are struggling to respond amid devastation wreaked by a 7.0 magnitude earthquake that struck near Port-au-Prince, Haiti, late on Tuesday.

title: Haiti Quake Day 2: A Brooklynite Reacts
description: Donall St. Fleur, the owner of a Haitian pharmacy in Brooklyn, discusses the earthquake back home.

title: Scene Two From the Bankers Lineup
description: Shortly after 11 a.m., Phil Angelides, the financial inquiry commission chairman, called a five-minute break and the CEOs bolted for a back exit en masse, again except for Mr. Mack, who stayed behind at the witness table and entertained questions from a scrum of reporters.

title: Can You Guess Your Homes Walk Score?
description: This weekend, in a story that even we here at Bucks neglected to post in our Best of Times roundup of the best consumer reporting in The Times, the paper ran a story about the Walk Score, which a site of the same name generates.

title: Celebrating Haydn, Even After His Anniversary Has Passed
description: One useful thing commemorations of composers births and deaths should do is remind us that some of the music performed on these occasions, and neglected otherwise, is worth keeping at hand between anniversaries as well. Last year one of the honorees was Haydn, and among the repertory looked at anew was his piano music. Though hardly strangers to the recital stage, Haydns keyboard works are treated like poor relations compared to Beethovens and Mozarts. They should not be: these are rich scores, packed with ideas and technical challenges and brimming over with character.

title: Solar Eclipse in India
description: An exceptionally long eclipse of the Sun will be visible from India this Friday, January 15th, and Jay Pasachoff is there ready to file a Lab report and mark a personal milestone: his 50th solar eclipse. Dr. Pasachoff, a professor of astronomy at Williams College, has been fascinated with eclipses since he was 11. Hes chairman of the working group on solar eclipses of the International Astronomical Union and the co-author, with Leon Golub, of The Solar Corona.

title: Billy Elliot Recoups Original $18 Million Investment
description: The Broadway producers of Billy Elliot: The Musical announced on Wednesday afternoon that they had recouped their original $18 million investment in 14 months of performances, with premium ticket prices helping earn back that capitalization at a faster clip than they initially had expected.

title: Male Chromosome May Evolve Fastest
description: A new look at the human Y chromosome has overturned longstanding ideas about its evolutionary history. Far from being in a state of decay, the Y chromosome is the fastest-changing part of the human genome and is constantly renewing itself.

title: Photo of the Week
description: Revelers parade through the street of Vevcani, Macedonia, for a Carnival celebration, while a child decked out in pink (see Photo 2) looks on.

title: Famous Readers
description: Heres something cool: The blog Whose Voice Is That? has compiled a partial list of the celebrities who read audio books at Audible.com. Highlights include Sean Penn reading Bob Dylans Chronicles: Volume 1 (in the category Narrator as Cool as the Author) and Paul Newman reading The Adventures of Tom Sawyer (A Classic Reads a Classic).

title: Cabaret Garnishes a Chamber Concert
description: Like many other charitable organizations, the America-Israel Cultural Foundation has suffered financial difficulties precipitated by the recession and the collapse of Bernard L. Madoffs Ponzi scheme. William A. Schwartz, the foundations president, shook a noisemaker after mentioning Mr. Madoffs name during a speech at the organizations 70th-anniversary gala concert on Sunday evening at Carnegie Hall.

title: From the Mailbag
description: From the mailbag. Christine D. writes:

title: The Morning Skate: Improving N.H.L. Video Reviews Integrity
description: Two recent incidents have called various aspects of N.H.L. officiating into question.

title: Tennessee Begins Search for a Coach
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  It seemed like a normal campus here Wednesday. Students walked to class. Other students hunted for scarce parking spaces. It all seemed back in order.

title: Moynihan Letters to Be Published
description: Letters, journals and other correspondence written by Daniel Patrick Moynihan over the course of his half-century career in public service will be published in a coming book.

title: In Need of Some Financial Razzle Dazzle
description: Whither the Weinsteins? The fortunes of Harvey and Bob have been much discussed recently, and heading into the Golden Globes this weekend, where their films Inglourious Basterds and Nine picked up the most nominations cumulatively, doesnt mean they get to rest on their substantial laurels. At Deadline Hollywood, Nikki Finke explores the financing of Nine, the star-laden musical which has largely been considered a clunker by audiences and critics, like A.O. Scott.

title: Pictures of the Day: Wednesday, Jan. 13
description: Haiti, of course, leads the report. Elsewhere on Lens is the story of how Tequila Minsky, a New York freelancer, managed get some of the first photographs in Port-au-Prince on Tuesday: There for the Quake.

title: African Bank Jumps Into Carbon Offsets
description: An African bank is hoping that a multimillion-dollar investment in a carbon offset project will help rejuvenate forests and wildlife in rural Kenya.

title: Deaths at Hands of Militants Rise in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The number of Pakistani civilians killed in militant attacks rose by a third in 2009 over the previous year, according to a new research report, a toll that exceeded even the number of civilian deaths in Afghanistan.

title: Small by Choice, Whether Clients Like It or Not
description: Nick Lessins and Lydia Esparza pride themselves on meeting high standards for quality, but not necessarily for catering to the demands of their customers. They are co-owners of Great Lake, a small Chicago pizza shop that has seen the mixed blessing of great reviews.

title: Tricky at Every Turn, the Quad Can Make or Break a Routine
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  The single hardest move in singles figure skating, the quadruple jump, is like an onside kick in football: highly risky, but highly rewarding  if it unfolds as planned.

title: App of the Week: Standing Guard Over a Lost Phone
description: Thoughts of cellphone security often dwell on the danger that hackers pose, but the far more likely threat comes from a phone that is simply lost or stolen. That leaves your personal information, photos and whatever else (you didnt store passwords on your phone, did you?) open to snooping.

title: Rugged, Speedy, Aquatic, Cold-Tolerant. And Not a Seal.
description: Olympus unwrapped its Stylus Tough-3000 camera at the Consumer Electronics Show last week. The Tough-3000 is the first of the companys rugged line to offer HD video capture (720p) and is also the most affordable Tough model at $230. The Stylus Tough-3000 can withstand a five-foot drop, is submersible to 10 feet and works in temperatures as low as 14 degrees. These are basically the same specs as the existing $280 Stylus Tough-6000.

title: U.S. World Cup Bids Independent of 2010 Performance
description: Of all the things hinging on the United States national teams performance in South Africa (pride, glory, the future of the game in America), the countrys bid to host either the 2018 or 2022 World Cup is not one of them.

title: K2: A Trek to Dangers Doorstep
description: ONE day last June, I roped up to a porter and we leaped over crevasses until we reached the side of K2, the second-tallest mountain on earth and one of its deadliest. We scrambled up a few hundred yards to the Gilkey Memorial, a rocky, sandy promontory at K2 Base Camp that commemorates climbers who have died on K2s dangerous slopes.

title: Wes Anderson Acceptance Speech
description: An animated version of Wes Anderson's acceptance speech for his award from the National Board of Review for "Fantastic Mr. Fox."

title: Amtrak Introduces Blue, if Not Corinthian, Leather
description: The popularity of Amtraks Acela Express with the business elite of the Northeast Corridor might as well have earned the train a nickname: Boardroom on Rails.

title: Why Would a Business Say No to Growth?
description: Nick Lessins and Lydia Esparza are the married owners of a Chicago pizza shop, Great Lake, that has received rave reviews, and they made the unconventional business decision not to capitalize on them. In his interview with the owners, Kermit Pattison asked why they choose to have their customers wait for hours rather than hiring more employees and expanding (a decision that has helped spur comparisons to the Soup Nazi on Seinfeld):

title: Quitting Work for Kids
description: Earlier today we spoke about how to structure a return to work. Now lets talk about how to structure a departure.

title: Devastation, Seen From a Ship
description: The commander of the first American ship to reach earthquake-stricken Port-au-Prince, Haiti, described a scene of extraordinary devastation, with collapsed buildings reaching from the port into the hills above.

title: Moynihan Letters to Be Published
description: At our sib-blog, ArtsBeat, Dave Itzkoff reports that letters and papers of the late Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan will be published later this year.

title: Red Bulls Introduce New Coach
description: HARRISON, N.J.  The New York Red Bulls sporting director said that the teams new coach was No. 1 on an extremely short list.

title: Bankers in Their Own Words
description: The first public hearing of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission featured the testimony of four top bank executives.

title: Judge to the LeRoys: Its All Yours, Almost
description: From Glenn Collins at Diners Journal:

title: Can There Be an Awards Show Without Clooney?
description: Bagger poll: Are award shows more or less interesting if youre not watching them in person? On the red carpet for the National Board of Review gala on Tuesday night, J. J. Abrams, the director of the surprisingly potential Oscar bait Star Trek, told the Bagger he prefers to watch the Oscars in bed (remote in hand, presumably). The dream is staying home and being comfy, he said. But he admitted he would probably brave the monkey suit, valet parking and hobnobbing this year, though he added, I truly dont think that Star Trek has a shot of being nominated. Additional Bagger poll: Is it more appealing when Hollywood types forthrightly lobby for attention, or do folks prefer it when they are all demure and self-effacing?

title: Senators Call for Repeal of Insurers Antitrust Exemption
description: Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont and chairman of the Judiciary Committee, and 18 other senators on Wednesday sent a letter to President Obama and Democratic Congressional leaders urging them to repeal the limited exemption for insurers from federal antitrust laws as part of the final version of major health care legislation.

title: Avons Little Sister Is Calling
description: KRISTIAUNA MANGUM, 22, a senior at Ohio State University in Columbus, said she always had a flair for makeup, but never considered it a professional calling. Then she heard about a pilot college program offered by Avons little sister brand, Mark, two years ago. My mother was an Avon Lady, so I thought, huh, maybe becoming a Mark Girl could really be the way to go, she said.

title: Simon and Garfunkel to Play Jazzfest
description: For a month, fans of the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival have been eyeing a big artist TBA on the schedule. That TBA has now been announced: the surprise act for the first of Jazzfests two weekends, on April 24, will be the reunited duo of Simon and Garfunkel, above. Its not the first time that Paul Simon has played Jazzfest, but it will be Art Garfunkels, and this is likely to be Simon and Garfunkels only American appearance in 2010. Simon and Garfunkel fans have been awaiting news of shows in the United States since Mr. Garfunkel joined Mr. Simon onstage at the Beacon Theater in New York last February. The festival, in its 41st year, will also feature, among many others, Lionel Richie, My Morning Jacket, Dr. John, Darius Rucker and Drake in its first weekend (April 23 to 25), and Pearl Jam, Aretha Franklin, Van Morrison, B. B. King, the Neville Brothers and Widespread Panic in its second (April 29 to May 2).

title: Above Paris, and Bourgeois Cares
description: PARIS  If there is a flat surface in Jacques Gourvnecs apartment in the 15th Arrondissement here, it probably has a painting sitting on it. The floor, the bookshelves, the windowsills and even the stairs are all used to display Mr. Gourvnecs paintings  more than 500 of them. (The other 2,500 are stored in his offices in the Bastille neighborhood.)

title: Jay Reatard Has Died
description: Update | 8:48 p.m. Jimmy Lee Lindsey Jr., the Memphis musician better known by his punk-rock stage name Jay Reatard, has died, his record label Goner Records said on Wednesday. In a statement posted at goner-records.com, the label said: It is with great sadness that we report the passing of our good friend Jay Reatard. Jay died in his sleep last night. We will pass along information about funeral arrangements when they are made public.

title: Podesta and Pickens Stump for Natural Gas
description: T. Boone Pickens, the billionaire Texas financier, and John Podesta, President Bill Clintons White House chief of staff, are not exactly political soul mates.

title: No More Free Rides From G.M. for Woods
description: It has been called the most expensive car crash in history. The pro golfer Tiger Woods has so far lost millions of dollars from sponsors who dropped or limited their use of his likeness in their marketing after news of his affairs. Now, he no longer has access to free cars from General Motors.

title: Haiti and the Politics of Disaster
description: As Hurricane Katrina and the Iranian election protests showed, disaster and strife tend to bring out the best of the blogosphere. So its little surprise that the earthquake in Haiti has seen a bipartisan show of concern and support for aid efforts. That said, theres always room for debate.

title: I.R.S. Commissioner Doesnt Do His Own Taxes
description: If youre part of the 60 percent of Americans who hire tax preparers to do their income taxes, youre in good company.

title: The City From the Street
description: On an auspicious day in 1935, the Swiss emigr photographer Rudy Burckhardt and his friend, the poet and dance critic Edwin Denby, moved into a New York apartment next door to Willem de Kooning. I remember walking at night in Chelsea with de Kooning during the Depression, Denby recalled, and his pointing out to me on the pavement the dispersed compositions  spots and cracks and bits of wrappers and reflections of neon light.

title: A Theater and a Jukebox in a Lightweight Package
description: The latest device that AT&T has picked up to sell through partners is the Mobinnova Beam.

title: Boldly Going Where Bose Has Gone Before
description: Bowers & Wilkins  formerly called B&W, but that clashed with BMW  is the highly regarded British sonic innovator and maker of loudspeakers. Think of the company as the British Bose.

title: Pastor Pleads Guilty to Swindling Immigrants in Queens
description: The Ecuadorean pastor in his storefront church in Corona, Queens,  promised the impossible: expedited green cards for illegal immigrants in exchange for several thousand dollars apiece, with few questions asked. And more than 100 people in the New York region, many of them Ecuadorean and desperate to remain in the country legally, took him up on his offer, handing a total of about $940,000.

title: S.E.C. Accuses Radio Iran Host of Fraud
description: The tight-knit Iranian-American Jewish community in Southern California is coming to terms with what could be its own mini-Madoff scandal.

title: Tell Us How You Really Feel, Maureen
description: Maureen Dowd, the New York Times columnist who generally saves her biggest bullets for targets inside the Beltway, made an exception on Wednesday, going after what has been a long-running question for many:

title: In Fiji, Dancing With Sharks
description: THERES a moment when the sheer awe of being arms length from a procession of hungry sharks  so close that you lock eyes with each one as it blitzes by your head  gives way to a sudden burst of clarity, and all your thoughts coalesce into a single edifying idea: Maybe I should duck.

title: 36 Hours in Whistler, British Columbia
description: THERE are good reasons that much of the Winter Olympics is taking place in Whistler next month. Sure, North Americas biggest ski resort looms overhead. But this steep mountain valley is home to something else that makes it particularly welcoming to Olympic athletes: a global citizenry. Walk down the main promenade and see everyone from rich urban castaways and old-school hippies to French-babbling Qubcois and weathered dropouts shouldering skis the size of ironing boards. It makes Whistler feel worldly and cosmopolitan, even when gold medals arent being handed out.

title: Flawed Building Likely a Big Element
description: Engineers and architects who have worked in or visited Haiti say that substandard design, inadequate materials and shoddy construction practices likely contributed to the collapse of many buildings in the earthquake that struck Tuesday.

title: Whos That Man? A Mystery Clarinetist Takes a Bow at Philharmonic
description: When a pinch hitter comes out of the dugout, an announcer intones his name over the public-address system. When an understudy fills in for a Broadway actor, inserts in the program say who it is. A waiter even tells you whats on special.

title: Justices Skeptical of N.F.L.s Court Claim
description: WASHINGTON  Lawyers for the National Football League and an apparel company staked out aggressive positions at a Supreme Court argument Wednesday over whether the league should be treated as a single entity or a collection of 32 independent companies for purposes of the antitrust laws.

title: Report Reveals Role of Immigrants in City
description: Every chemical engineer in New York City was born in a foreign country. Two-fifths of the citys accountants and auditors and more than one-fourth of its chief executives are immigrants. In the three neighborhoods with the highest concentrations of immigrants, Ecuadoreans outnumber residents from any other country.

title: Direct Approach Works for Avon
description: IN the 1880s, David McConnell, a door-to-door book salesman in upstate New York, thought that he might have better luck if he presented potential customers with a gift of perfume. By 1886, McConnell had formed the California Perfume Company, and within 20 years, 10,000 representatives were selling 117 products in 600 styles. In 1939, the company changed its name to Avon Products.

title: S.E.C. Proposes Curbs on High-Speed Trading
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed a new rule on Wednesday that would bar brokers from allowing big clients to trade directly on their platforms with the exchanges, a practice known as unfiltered or naked sponsored access. The practice has been criticized by some market analysts, as it allows traders, especially high-frequency traders, to trade almost instantly at varying market centers without any associated checks on risk.

title: Detroit Auto Show: Chryslers Electric Star, the Gem
description: Its not easy to find Chryslers world-beater plug-in electric vehicle at the Detroit auto show. You have to work your way past the Ferraris, Fiat 500s, Dodges, Chryslers and Jeeps. There, tucked in a corner, youll find Chryslers green transportation star: the Gem. Chrysler has sold more than 40,000 Gems since 1999 and reportedly owns about 70 percent of the neighborhood electric vehicle market.

title: Voice Mail You Can Read: It Saves Time (at the Risk of Meaning)
description: Visual voice mail is great if you want to know who sent a message before you go through the trouble of dialing your voice mail service to hear it.

title: Obamas First Veto Stands
description: President Obamas first veto easily withstood a House attempt to override it on Wednesday.

title: Views on Financial Regulation
description: Clips as four heads of Wall Street's largest banks faced skeptical questions about regulation from the bipartisan commission.

title: Parting Glance: Dennis Stock, 1928-2010
description: Dennis Stock, whose photographs may have done almost as much to create James Deans public persona as the actors own performances, died Monday in Florida. He was 81.

title: Remembering the Jets Great Escape in 2005
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. - Before they beat the Cincinnati Bengals last Saturday, it had been five years since the Jets last won a playoff game. The previous win came in San Diego, at Qualcomm Stadium, the same place the Jets head this Sunday to face the Chargers in a divisional playoff contest.

title: Alone (or Almost) With Michelangelo in Vatican City
description: IT was just after 8 p.m., by now dark outside the walls of Vatican City, and a small group of us were following a guide through the maze that is the Vatican Museums. We had wandered for 40 minutes through galleries crammed with 15th- and 16th-century Italian paintings, courtyards displaying Greek and Roman sculpture, and seemingly endless hallways lined with ancient maps and musty tapestries, before passing through a small doorway I had not noticed on my previous visits here. I glanced up and realized we had arrived in the Sistine Chapel.

title: Art Crops Up in Sarajevos Shuttered Shops
description: ON a recent fall evening in Sarajevo, a crowd of art enthusiasts sipped drinks as one of Bosnias most respected artists and curators, Jusuf Hadzifejzovic, began his remarks at the opening of a new exhibition. Suddenly, the lights went out  but he continued his speech in darkness, unfazed. Minutes later, a cleaning woman calmly pushed her cart laden with mops and detergents through the center of the audience. The speeches went on.

title: Electric Power at the Detroit Auto Show
description: Hybrid-powered and electric vehicles were among the most compelling new cars on display at the North American International Auto Show.

title: Designs on a Boston Hot Spot
description: BACK in 2006, the inhabitants of Fort Point said to be home to New Englands largest concentration of visual artists, met the news of plans for luxury condos with predictable resistance. Goldman Properties, a national real estate development firm, intended to turn the onetime industrial hub on Bostons Inner Harbor into the citys newest hot spot  Bostons SoHo or South Beach. But much to the relief of the many artists, schemes to convert the stout 19th-century masonry buildings that define the neighborhoods architecture havent come to fruition, thanks to the economic downturn.

title: Restaurant Review: Mellilotos in Athens
description: This family-run, weekday-only restaurant specializing in organic dishes opened last July in the lobby of a commercial building just off Syntagma Square. But youll forget about the narrow restaurants meager dcor when you take your first bite of the salmon baked in paper and topped with finely chopped fennel, leek, dill and celery root, in a delicate reduction sauce made from spinach and a tree resin called mastika (12 euros, or about $17 at $1.40 to the euro).

title: His Last Job
description: In recent years, it has appeared that the surest route to a senior government job was to run Goldman Sachs.

title: Heating Your Space
description: The Process

title: Whiplash in the Greenhouse
description: There are a variety of debates under way over the merits or perils of focusing on particular climate (and sea level) findings, or a particular seasons conditions, in discussing human-driven global warming.

title: Praising Virtuosos, Both Here and Gone
description: Accepting his 2010 N.E.A. Jazz Masters Award at the Rose Theater on Tuesday night, the pianist and composer Muhal Richard Abrams was appreciative but brisk. He thanked the past masters, implying both his fellow honorees and jazzs broader pantheon. Then he issued one statement of conviction: This music, jazz music, has a discipline that comes from practice, thats very good for life in itself. Within moments he was at the piano, infusing the evenings first musical performance with a luminous severity.

title: The Dumpster Beautified
description: Despite the plummeting mercury late Friday afternoon, a small crowd had gathered on the Bowery, near the New Museum, where three young women were gamely wallpapering a Dumpster in an elegant blue-and-white floral. A second Dumpster, covered in a green William Morris pattern and stuffed with a Christmas tree, had been finished elsewhere and rolled to the curb next to it.

title: Video: Views on Regulation
description: The scope of the governments involvement in the financial markets is likely to be a hotly debated topic as the Senate is expected to take up legislation on overhauling financial regulation in the next few months. The topic weighed heavily on Wednesday as four executives of the nations largest banks testified before the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, and there were some hints of their views on the subject. They had to walk a fine line between accepting responsibility for past mistakes and pushing back against regulatory reforms they consider too drastic.

title: Furnishings, Marked Down
description: Home Decorators Outlet is offering up to 70 percent off area rugs through Jan. 31 (an eight-foot-round Flokati rug in olive green, originally $349, is $175); (877) 537-8539 or homedecoratorsoutlet.com.

title: Detailed Reflections, Verbal and Visual
description: The soapbox is fully present, in the form of a couple of nondescript wooden blocks, but the speakers are more like specters in Ads, a boundary-pushing curio from the theatrical auteur Richard Maxwell at Performance Space 122, a co-presentation of the Coil festival and the Under the Radar smorgasbord of forward-looking theater.

title: In Quake Aftermath, U.S. Suspends Deportations to Haiti
description: Responding to the devastation from the Haiti earthquake, Obama administration officials on Wednesday temporarily suspended deportations of illegal immigrants from that country.

title: Haiti Quake Day 3: Legacy of Disaster
description: Even before the recent earthquake Haiti's environment teetered on the brink of disaster.  Brent and Craig Renaud report on the country's deforestation problems.

title: High Design in D.C.
description: Is there a market for experimental design in Washington? Craig Appelbaum thinks so. On Jan. 16, Mr. Appelbaum, a lawyer who moonlights as an art dealer, will open Industry Gallery, specializing in the more adventurous reaches of 21st-century design, including new works by Nacho Carbonell, who was named Designer of the Future last month at Design Miami/ Basel, and Tejo Remy, an early member of the Dutch design collective Droog. The first exhibition will show 20 chairs hammered out of stainless steel and aluminum (including  Rendez-vous,  right) by Shlomo Harush, an artist and designer who splits his time between Milan and Brooklyn.

title: A Duplex in Edinburgh
description: This 2,273-square-foot apartment is on the top two floors of a three-story home built around 1870.

title: A Better Life, Starting at $6.99
description: IF you are overweight with a sinus problem and wrinkled clothing, and you wish your children would spend more time with you, and you are so worried about identity theft that you cant sleep at night so you want to go to the kitchen and cook up some chicken, but you are afraid salmonella will get on the paper towels, its a darn shame you didnt make it to the International Home and Housewares Show 2010 sneak preview at the Hilton Hotel in Manhattan last week, where they had all the tools to turn your sorry life around.

title: SpaghettiOs Creator Dies at 83
description: Every once in a while, maybe even when Mom was watching Julia Child, you probably tucked in to a bowl of Franco-American SpaghettiOs. Wednesday afternoon brought the news that their creator, Donald Goerke, died. He also helped introduce Chunky Soup for Campbells.

title: Golden Globes Seek 10% Ratings Rise
description: LOS ANGELES  For months, the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, NBC and Dick Clark Productions have puzzled over a perennial question: How do we prop up the sagging ratings for the Golden Globes?

title: The Unnamed
description: The Feet, Mechanical

title: Compelled to Wander, Nowhere to Go
description: Tim Farnsworth, the unaccountably restless main character in Joshua Ferriss second novel (after his charming but weightless Then We Came to the End), cant stop walking. Nobody knows why, and The Unnamed takes its title from Tims peculiar condition. Is it medical? Is it spiritual? Or is it metaphorical in ways that suggest Mr. Ferriss readers had better beware?

title: What a Block That Was
description: My mother called, reminding me that the name of her First Avenue butcher  where she used to buy tri-tip under a variety of names  was Wertheimers, long since closed. (It couldve been Wortheimers, forgive me.)

title: Revisiting Satanic Deal With Strings
description: Sunday afternoon at La MaMa I was rooting for the devil. Or, rather, I was rooting for his puppet facsimile, Mr. Scratch, who was engaged in a spirited rhetorical debate with a Daniel Webster puppet during the climax of The Devil You Know, an Under the Radar Festival offering from Ping Chong & Company and Phantom Limb.

title: The No Lock People
description: ITS the lore and lure of bucolic small-town living: The community is so safe, people dont even lock their doors. But Joyce Weisshappel, a 63-year-old vice president with the Corcoran Group, a real estate company, does not live in a small town; she lives in Manhattan, in a luxury apartment building. And she doesnt think she has ever locked her door in the 30 years she has lived there  she doesnt even know where the keys are.

title: Wheres the Opera Chief? Look Onstage, or in the Pit
description: Plcido Domingo, conductor, steps into the pit of the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday evening for a performance of Verdis Stiffelio. Four days later Plcido Domingo, singer, steps onto the Met stage to open a run of Verdis Simon Boccanegra.

title: The Triumph of the Size 12s
description: WHEN he met Crystal Renn for the first time last September over lunch at the Royalton in Manhattan, Stephen Gan, the influential creative director of fashion magazines like Harpers Bazaar and Visionaire, had the same reaction as virtually everyone who comes face to face with the industrys reigning plus-size model.

title: The Capitol Hill Twitterverse
description: It may have been sort of a counterintuitive thought at one time, but its become pretty well-established that Republicans on Capitol Hill have embraced Twitter more than Democrats.

title: Dont Forget to Look Out the Windows
description: At Robert, the new restaurant on the ninth floor of the Museum of Arts and Design, the focal point is not necessarily the view of Central Park. Consider the orange acrylic LED lighting by Johanna Grawunder, a designer based in San Francisco and Milan. The rest of the design flowed from there, Ms. Grawunder said, including the palette of orange, purple and vermilion, and the choice of seating. (Vladimir Kagans 1956 Floating Back sofa was altered to keep the legs from jutting out enough to trip the waiters.)

title: You Should Have Seen First Avenue in Those Days
description: On Bitten, Mark Bittman recalls the culinary glories a Jewish boy from Stuyvesant Town could find between 19th and 20th Streets back in the day.

title: When the Gym Isnt Enough
description: OVER the course of a year, Alex Feintuch, a 20-year-old sophomore at the University of South Carolina, spent more than $1,000 on fitness supplements.

title: One on One: Anil Dash of Expert Labs
description: In this installment of One on One, I sit down with Anil Dash, formerly of Six Apart, which created the popular blogging software Movable Type. Mr. Dash is now the director of Expert Labs, a Government 2.0 initiative that aims to connect United States government projects with citizens who want to become more involved in the political discussion.

title: Behind the Scenes: There for the Quake
description: On Tuesday morning, Tequila Minsky enjoyed a reputation in Lower Manhattan as an enterprising freelance photographer.

title: And One-Eyed Offspring Makes Three
description: Parenthood never looked weirder or more terrifying than it does in Smudge, a new play by Rachel Axler at the Julia Miles Theater. Here are some of the things that Colby, a new mother, calls the thing she gave birth to: it, creature, hot dog, freak, smudge, a bunch of entrails in casing.

title: Designer, Salesman, Mannequin
description: TUCKED among the racks of heavy wool navy pinstripe suits of Dries Van Noten, the usual assortment of Gucci and Prada togs for the directional male and some Chanel tweed jackets for men that should, in reality, bear a label that says Karl Lagerfeld Vanity Project, a new label appeared last fall at the Jeffrey New York store in the meatpacking district. It was an unfamiliar name: Devon Scott.

title: Like a College Visit, Minus Kegs
description: JACKIE McMAKIN and her husband, David, are not the least bit apprehensive about moving next month from their home of 33 years in McLean, Va., to a retirement community in Shelburne, Vt. We cant wait, said Ms. McMakin, who is 75 and a retired vocational counselor. It suits our style perfectly  casual and sporty  the L. L. Bean of retirement communities.

title: Idol Creator Plans to Start New Business
description: LOS ANGELES  The offstage turmoil around American Idol continues to grow as Simon Fuller, chief executive of 19 Entertainment and the creator of American Idol, is expected to announce soon that he is starting a new company to pursue film and other entertainment projects separately from 19 Entertainment and its publicly traded parent, CKX.

title: Properties for $500,000
description: Homes for sale in Maine, North Carolina and Texas.

title: In Leno vs. OBrien, Fans Show Allegiance Online
description: Irritated by the proposed shakeup to NBCs late-night schedule, Mike Mitchell, an artist in Los Angeles, sketched a heroic image of Conan OBrien on Monday night, shaded the hair orange, and, recalling one of that talk show hosts nicknames, added the words Im with CoCo.

title: Obama and Democratic Leaders in Marathon Negotiations
description: President Obama and Congressional Democratic leaders have spent much of Wednesday holed up at the White House in a marathon negotiating session aimed at resolving differences between the House and Senate on sweeping health legislation that could cover more than 30 million uninsured Americans.

title: Resetting a Macs Password
description: Q. I have a Mac and want to install system updates, but it keeps asking me for a password. I dont remember it, so what can I do?

title: Letters
description: On Physical Therapy

title: Tavern on the Green Sells Out
description: Everything must go. The champagne flutes, the banana-split dishes, the 1950s Wurlitzer jukebox, the vintage street sign with its weathered prancing deer, the Tiffany glass, the entryway chandelier and even the doormans green frock coat with its fading gold braid and battered buttons.

title: Now Branding | The Next Big Small (Edible) Thing
description: Tuesday night, upstairs at the bistro Ici, in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, a handful of hopefuls pushed snacks upon invitation-only guests and waited for the passing of judgment. One of them would take home the Im a Winner trophy and, more important, win the consulting expertise of the Rooster Design Group. It was the culmination of the companys first The Next Big Small Brand Contest for Culinary Genius.Roosters founders, Fernando Music and Fran Gaitanaros, had canvassed the 140 local applicants and winnowed the field down to the final five. They got all kinds. We had some real head-scratchers, Music mused. Insects as nutritional supplements, positioned as a food that was borderline vegetarian. The insect ingredient would either be ground or mixed into the food product whole to make it more accessible and digestible. We also had a team with a perfectly nice product, good flavor profile, but one of the presenters was drunk  that was pretty dark.

title: Celebrating the Freshest 100-Year-Old Knish
description: The lowly knish, that humblest of pies, has turned 100, or at least the place that sells them has. No one knows for sure, of course, when or where the knish was actually invented. Nor does anyone know the precise date a knish became a knish. But in 1910, Yonah Schimmels opened a knishery on Manhattans Lower East Side.

title: Want It or Not, TV Goes 3-D
description: At the end of each season of The Amazing Race, the host always says something like: Five continents, 14 countries, 21 days, 25,000 miles. You are the official winners of The Amazing Race!

title: Playwrights Nurturing Is the Focus of a Study
description: CHICAGO  When the playwright Tracy Letts handed over his August: Osage County for production in 2007, the board of the Steppenwolf Theater Company here agreed to forgo a balanced budget to finance this 13-character drama and its three-floor set. The bet paid off. The play earned rave reviews, moved to Broadway, won a Pulitzer Prize and a Tony Award, and recouped its investment.

title: House Panel Demands Geithners A.I.G. Records
description: What was Timothy F. Geithner thinking when the American International Group was bailed out? The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee wants to know.

title: Artwork Destroyed as Artist Planned
description: Art is long and life is brief, but sometimes art is brief too. A wall painting by Richard Wright that won him the Turner Prize in December has been erased by workers at the Tate Britain museum  as Mr. Wright, above, intended, The Guardian reported. The painting, a gold-leaf fresco of an abstract design, was sanded and painted over by the museums art handlers last week, after an exhibition on the Turner Prize, the prestigious British art award, was closed. Mr. Wright, 49, who lives in Glasgow, was named the prizewinner over the heavily favored installation artist Roger Hiorns. On the Arts Beats blog on nytimes.com, Roberta Smith described Mr. Wright as a cross between Sol LeWitt and Faberg who creates elaborate works that are meant to exist temporarily. The Guardian said Mr. Wright was not in attendance at this works deletion.

title: Comedic Overachiever Adds to Rsum
description: Steve Martin has spun his wheel of talents again, and this time it has stopped at author. Grand Central Publishing said in an e-mail message that it had acquired two new books from Mr. Martin, the actor, comedian, bluegrass musician, New Yorker contributor and coming Academy Awards show co-host: one intended for young readers and one for the rest of us. The book for young readers, Late for School, is based on a song that also appears on Mr. Martins album The Crow: New Songs for the 5-String Banjo. It will include illustrations by C. F. Payne and a CD of the song (as well as a singalong version) and is to be released in September. The second book, Woman, One, is a novel that examines the glamour and the subterfuge of the fine art world in New York, the e-mail message said. (Yes, Mr. Martin is an art collector too.) The book, Mr. Martins first novel since The Pleasure of My Company, is planned for a November release.

title: Ke$ha Ends Susan Boyles Dream
description: Susan Boyles six-week run at the top of the Billboard album chart has finally been ended, by a singer who couldnt be more different. Ke$ha, below, a 22-year-old American whose song TiK ToK is an unabashed celebration of the liquor-fueled party life, opened at No. 1 with Animal (Kemosabe/RCA), which was released last week and sold 152,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Ms. Boyles I Dreamed a Dream (Syco Music/Columbia) fell to No. 2 with 93,000 sales, bringing its seven-week total to just under 3.2 million. Ke$ha, whose real name is Kesha Sebert, also has a very different audience from Ms. Boyles. I Dreamed a Dream, which retailers said attracted older customers, has been notable for having a very high proportion of its sales in CDs instead of digital downloads: at least 97 percent have been CDs, far above the industry average. But Ke$ha attracted younger and more computer-savvy fans. Seventy-six percent of the sales of Animal were digital, which Billboard said was the most for a No. 1 album. Also on this weeks chart, Lady Gagas Fame (Interscope) fell one spot to No. 3 with 66,000 sales; Alicia Keyss Element of Freedom (J) is No. 4 with 62,000; and Mary J. Bliges Stronger With Each Tear (Geffen) is No. 5 with 47,000.

title: Judge Cites Discrimination in N.Y. Fire Dept.
description: A federal judge ruled on Wednesday that New York City intentionally discriminated against black applicants to the Fire Department by continuing to use an exam that it had been told put them at a disadvantage.

title: Idol Returns to Winning Ways
description: The season premiere of Foxs American Idol commanded almost 30 million viewers on Tuesday, proving that the series, which began in 2002, remains the undisputed ratings leader even if its popularity has waned in recent years. According to Nielsens estimates, 29.8 million viewers tuned in to the two-hour debut of the reality seriess ninth season, its first without Paula Abdul as a judge. Although the premiere audience was down compared to the 30.4 million who watched the first episode last season  not to mention the 33.4 million who watched the start of the seventh and 37.4 million who watched the start of the sixth  Fox easily dominated Tuesdays ratings. The first runner-up, CBS, still drew relatively large audiences for its crime shows NCIS at 8 p.m. (20.7 million) and NCIS: Los Angeles at 9 (15.5 million). CBS also won the 10 p.m. hour following Idol with The Good Wife (13.8 million), which outperformed The Jay Leno Show on NBC (6.2 million) and The Forgotten on ABC (4.4 million). NBC ranked third on the night, averaging 8.1 million for The Biggest Loser from 8 to 10, while ABC finished a distant fourth.

title: Injured View From the Bridge Actor Departs Show
description: The actor Santino Fontana, who had been playing the key role of Rodolpho in the new Broadway revival of A View From the Bridge, said in a statement on Wednesday that he was leaving the show in order to make a full recovery from an onstage injury over New Years weekend that led to a concussion.

title: GLAAD Award Nominees
description: The television shows True Blood, Glee and Mad Men, and films I Love You, Man and Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire, are among the nominees for the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamations annual GLAAD Media Awards, the group announced on Wednesday. The awards recognize and honor media for outstanding images of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people. The alliance said the winners would be chosen from 116 nominees in 24 English-language categories and 36 nominees in eight Spanish-language categories. Precious and I Love You, Man were among the five nominees in the outstanding film (wide release) category; True Blood and Mad Men were nominated for outstanding drama series, along with Brothers & Sisters, Greys Anatomy and Skins; Glee (cast members pictured above) was nominated for outstanding comedy series, as were Modern Family, United States of Tara, Beautiful People and Greek.

title: Vatican Pans Avatar
description: Among the things the Vatican approves of: piety, penitence, The Simpsons. Among the things it does not endorse: sinfulness and Avatar. Both the Vatican newspaper and radio station have criticized that James Cameron film, calling it emotionally unengaging and saying that it tries to replace divinity with nature, The Associated Press reported. The newspaper, LOsservatore Romano, wrote that Avatar, which stars Sam Worthington, right, gets bogged down by a spiritualism linked to the worship of nature, according to The A.P. Vatican Radio said the movie cleverly winks at all those pseudo-doctrines that turn ecology into the religion of the millennium, adding, Nature is no longer a creation to defend, but a divinity to worship. LOsservatore wrote that for all of the stupefying, enchanting technology in the movie, it offers few genuine emotions. But both outlets agreed, as LOsservatore wrote, that the true accomplishment of Avatar was its extraordinary visual impact. The film is to be released in Italy on Friday.

title: $2 Million in Donations for Haiti, via Text Message
description: Update | 12:48 a.m.  The organizers of the mobile donations said on Twitter Thursday night that over $2 million had been raised.

title: Leaps and Bounds (and Boundlessness) in Step-Packed Choreography
description: After the British choreographer Richard Alstons Shuffle It Right (2008)  the work with which his company opened its week on Tuesday night at the Joyce  my American companion said, I want to see it immediately again. Though I had seen it before in London, I felt the same way.

title: After 4 Trials, Government Ends Its Case Against Gotti
description: After four trials, five years of effort and untold amounts of money dedicated to putting John A. Gotti in prison, the federal government has given up.

title: Coast Guard Flyover of Haiti
description: Aerial video by Petty Officer 2nd Class Sondra-Kay Kneen of Port-au-Prince Haiti after a 7.0 magnitude earthquake.

title: Ending Year on High Note, Then Starting on Another
description: The best way to end a bridge year is by winning an event on New Years Eve. The best way to start a bridge year is by winning an event on New Years Day. Judith Bianco, Win Allegaert and Justin Lall of New York and Hemant Lall of Dallas (Justins father) did both of those things at the regional in Myrtle Beach, S.C.

title: Clinton and Gates Returning to D.C. Because of Haiti
