description: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton is cutting short her first diplomatic trip of the year and returning to Washington to oversee the United States response to the Haiti earthquake.

title: Why Blankfeins Job Prospects Are Limited
description: From Floyd Norris at Notions on High and Low Finance:

title: Google Upgrades Security on Gmail
description: Gmail users around the world are getting an important security upgrade.

title: Ed Beach, Host of Just Jazz Radio Show, Dies at 86
description: Ed Beach, the host of a popular jazz radio show in the 1960s and 70s, who attracted listeners in New York and elsewhere with his sonorous voice, eclectic taste, vast erudition and pleasurably irascible temperament, died on Dec. 25 in Eugene, Ore. He was 86 and lived in Eugene.

title: G.O.P. Lawmakers Revisit 1994 Contract
description: Republicans really do think it could be 1994 all over again.

title: Tavern on the Green Sells Out
description: From Glenn Collins at Diners Journal:

title: Eh
description: Some readers were puzzled by my somewhat cryptic remarks about Canada in my optimal currency area post. What did I mean by saying that Canada is closer to the United States than it is to itself? Why is Canada a counterexample to Europeans who insist that a single currency is essential?

title: Islamists Press Jordan to Stop Aiding U.S. Forces in Afghanistan
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Jordan, one of the United States closest allies in the Arab world, came under pressure on Wednesday from Islamists to stop cooperating with American forces in Afghanistan.

title: U.S. Companies Join Race on Iraqi Oil Bonanza
description: BAGHDAD  A wave of American companies have been arriving in Iraq in recent months to pursue what is expected to be a multibillion-dollar bonanza of projects to revive the countrys stagnant petroleum industry, as Iraq seeks to establish itself as a rival to Saudi Arabia as the worlds top oil producer.

title: Im Czar Of The World!
description: Or at least want to be, says Eugene Fama.

title: After China Attacks, Google Makes Gmail More Secure
description: Google is upgrading Gmail to a higher level of security by default.

title: Administration Loosens Purse Strings for Transit Projects
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration will make it easier for cities and states to spend federal money on public transit projects, and particularly on the light-rail systems that have become popular in recent years, Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood said Wednesday.

title: Follow-Up: Roger Ailes on Matthew Freud
description: In a recent front-page profile of Roger Ailes, the head of Fox News, David Carr and Tim Arango quoted Matthew Freud, the son-in-law of Rupert Murdoch, saying this about Mr. Ailes: I am by no means alone within the family or the company in being ashamed and sickened by Roger Ailess horrendous and sustained disregard of the journalistic standards that News Corporation, its founder and every other global media business aspires to.

title: Daschle Handicaps the Final Health Bill
Decision Promised Soon on Cape Cod Wind Farm
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration moved a step closer on Wednesday to ending the nearly decade-long conflict over a major wind power installation off Cape Cod, Mass.

title: Headphones That Vibrate  and Ones That Dont
description: Twist and shout.

title: Sweat Lodge Deaths Not Criminal, Gurus Lawyer Says
description: LOS ANGELES  A lawyer for the New Age guru who led a sweat lodge ceremony in Arizona that left three people dead said Wednesday that the deaths were a tragedy and an accident, but should not be considered a crime.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 941 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans Wednesday:

title: Binghamton President Announces Retirement
description: Lois DeFleur announced her resignation Wednesday as president of Binghamton University. DeFleur said in an e-mail message to the faculty that she was leaving in July because of her mothers fragile health and her plans to be married.

title: Morphine May Help Traumatic Stress
description: Doctors have long hoped to discover a morning-after pill to blunt the often disabling emotional fallout from traumatic experiences. Now it appears that they have had one on hand all along: morphine.

title: Piercing the Sky Amid a Deflating Economy
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  In the first three days after Dubai opened the tallest building in the world, about 10,600 people paid a total of more than $280,000 to ride an elevator to the observation deck on the 124th floor. Outside, day after day, revelers jockeyed for position to be photographed standing before the shimmering tower that reaches 2,717 feet straight up into the steely blue sky.

title: At 6-6, Rockets Chuck Hayes Is the Mite in the Middle
description: HOUSTON  In a position full of giants, the Houston Rockets Chuck Hayes stands out because he stands below them.

title: After a Year of Learning, the First Lady Seeks Out a Legacy
description: WASHINGTON  She has settled her daughters in school  and watched the wonder in their eyes as they met the pope and the queen of England. She has polished her image and driven her poll numbers sky high, with carefully timed interviews and magazine cover shots. She has spotlighted military families, mentored young girls and begun a national conversation on healthy eating by planting the first White House garden since Eleanor Roosevelts day.

title: Lieberman Disputes Reids Account of Health Bill Wrangling
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, the independent Democrat from Connecticut, is taking issue with Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, for feeling double-crossed by Mr. Lieberman during critical negotiations over the health care bill.

title: Essay: No End of Trouble. Ever.
description: As she prepared to depart for Haiti on assignment for The Times, Maggie Steber wrote this reflection on the countrys recent history. Her portfolio shows moments of joy as well as desperation and grief. Aperture published her book, Dancing on Fire: Photographs from Haiti in 1992. She has won top awards from World Press Photo and Pictures of the Year International. Her work appears regularly in National Geographic.

title: Report on Lawyers Death Eases a Political Crisis in Guatemala
description: MEXICO CITY  The story is as convoluted as a film noir plot. A prominent lawyer is murdered after he accuses the president of plotting to kill him. But an international investigation finds that the murder was actually planned by the victim himself and carried out in a way that appeared intended to inflict maximum damage on the government.

title: France: Bill Would Outlaw Harassment by Partners
description: The government has proposed a law that would make psychological abuse within couples a punishable offense. The law, applicable to both sexes, would cover repeated verbal abuse, threats of violence, insults and other forms of harassment. Critics have said such a law would be very difficult to enforce, but the draft has the backing of two main parties and Prime Minister Franois Fillon.

title: Italy: Pope Meets With Woman Who Lunged at Him
description: Pope Benedict XVI on Wednesday met with and forgave the mentally unstable woman who knocked him to the ground at Christmas Eve Mass, the Vatican said in a statement. In a brief private meeting with Benedict on Wednesday, the woman, Susanna Maiolo, a Swiss and Italian citizen, expressed her displeasure at the events, while the pope wanted to show his forgiveness, and his cordial interest and wishes for her health, the Vatican said. Ms. Maiolo, left, has been held at a psychiatric center outside Rome and has not been charged with a crime.

title: Government Ends Case Against Gotti
description: After four trials, five years of effort and untold amounts of money dedicated to putting John A. Gotti in prison, the federal government has given up.

title: Iran: New Law Allows President to Cut Subsidies
description: The Guardian Council, the constitutional watchdog body in Iran, approved a controversial law that gives the green light to President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad to cut government subsidies on energy and food, the IRNA news agency reported Wednesday. Analysts and opponents in Parliament had warned that the measure would lead to a sharp increase in prices.

title: Russia Offers a Hand With Toilet Clog in Space
description: Russia has offered its astronauts help in unclogging a high-tech toilet on the International Space Station that is reportedly backed up because of excess calcium in astronauts urine. Aleksandr Vorobyov, a spokesman for Roscosmos, the Russian space agency, said a Russian crew member had helped repair a toilet in the American sector of the space station six months ago, so they have some experience in this line of work. The comments came in response to an article in the British newspaper The Daily Telegraph, which quoted the stations flight director, David Korth, as saying, Weve learned a lot more about urine than we ever needed or wanted to know. The problematic toilet was designed to purify urine into drinkable water.

title: Agony Sets In as Medics Focus on the Survivors
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  I just want my wifes corpse, said Lionnel Dervil, pleading in vain to bury his wife in his home province.

title: U.S. Mobilizes to Send Assistance to Haiti
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, facing the first large-scale humanitarian crisis of his presidency, moved quickly to send help to Haiti, pledging Wednesday that the Haitians and their devastated island nation would have the unwavering support of the United States.

title: Chinese Executives Held in Construction Site Deaths
description: Three Chinese executives in India have been arrested for possible connections to a chimney collapse at a construction site in Chhattisgarh State in September that killed 41 workers, according to a report on Wednesday in China Daily, an official newspaper. The executives are a project manager and two civil engineers working for a construction company based in Shandong Province, China. It had been given a contract to build a thermal power plant in India and had subcontracted the building of the chimney tower. The arrests come at a time when Indian officials are especially anxious over the influx of Chinese laborers.

title: Obama and Lawmakers Seek Accord on Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  With a growing sense of urgency, President Obama and top Congressional Democrats held a marathon negotiating session on Wednesday in an effort to thrash out agreements on sweeping health care legislation that could provide insurance coverage to more than 30 million Americans.

title: Waiting for Word From Haiti
description: It was only a month ago that Seth Stammler of the Red Bulls was driving through Port-au-Prince, Haiti, and thinking about the fragility of life.

title: S.E.C. Reorganizes in Wake of Madoff Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission named six people on Wednesday to lead new investigative units as the agency reorganizes its enforcement efforts.

title: Lawmakers Offer Ethics Plan, but Paterson Says It Falls Short
description: New Yorks legislative leaders proposed their own ethics overhaul on Wednesday in an effort to restore public confidence in the wake of recent scandals that have exposed political corruption at the highest levels of power in Albany.

title: Justice Dept. Fights Bias in Lending
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department is beginning a major campaign against banks and mortgage brokers suspected of discriminating against minority applicants in lending, opening a new front in the Obama administrations response to the foreclosure crisis.

title: Pirates-Hoyas and Plenty of Wild West Action
description: Seton Hall (10-5, 1-3) at No. 11 Georgetown (12-2, 3-1)The Pirates love to force a fast game that lets them find Jeremy Hazell (23.3 points) in transition. Herb Pope (12.9 points, 11.5 rebounds) is solid inside, but the Pirates need consistent play from their guards. The senior Eugene Harvey, who played only seven minutes in a loss to Connecticut, lost his starting spot to Keon Lawrence. Lawrence and Jordan Theodore, the third point guard, are still trying to establish themselves.

title: Haiti Quake Day 2: Praying for News
description: Haitians living in the United States do not know if their loved ones are dead or alive, but are desperate to help.

title: Country Without a Net
description: THOSE who know a little of Haitis history might have watched the news last night and thought, as I did for a moment: An earthquake? What next? Poor Haiti is cursed.

title: Haitis Angry God
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti

title: U.N. Workers Struggle as Co-Workers Are Unaccounted For
description: UNITED NATIONS  Throughout the day, both at the United Nations headquarters and in Haiti itself, staff members struggled on Wednesday to concentrate on organizing a immense relief effort and not to focus on their friends and colleagues still buried under the rubble.

title: Baidus Gain from Departure Could Be Chinas Loss
description: SHANGHAI  If Google pulls out of China because of concerns over government controls, this country could be left with just one major Internet search engine: Baidu.com.

title: In Queens, Haitian Voices
description: New Yorkers of Haitian descent in Cambria Heights, Queens, shared their concerns and hopes in the wake of the earthquake.

title: Earthquake Hits Haiti
description: A powerful earthquake struck Haiti, causing widespread damage and panic in the impoverished country.

title: Kiffins Departure Leaves Resentment and Uncertainty
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  The charred remains of a Lane Kiffin orange T-shirt lay in the gutter outside the Tennessee football complex. The crowd that had gathered here Tuesday night to taunt the former Volunteers coach was long gone by Wednesday.

title: Are You a Gadget?
description: What does information want? Not so long ago Jaron Lanier would have answered a hot fudge sundae  and to be free, of course. Never mind the sundae, that was just us, but in the 1990s, John Tierney writes, Mr. Lanier was one of the digital pioneers hailing the wonderful possibilities that would be realized once the Internet allowed musicians, artists, scientists and engineers around the world to instantly share their work. Now, however, he has changed his answer. His new book, You Are Not a Gadget, is a manifesto against hive thinking and digital Maoism, by which he means the glorification of open-source software, free information and collective work at the expense of individual creativity. Whether you side with his current camp or not, head to the 92nd St. Y tonight where Mr. Lanier will discuss the book and the wild terrains of the Internets.

title: The Hardest-Working Man in Publishing
description: Dave Eggers makes other writers feel lazy. When hes not spinning out great narrative nonfiction in the form of Zeitoun, his chronicle of a man and his family brought down by Hurricane Katrina, hes writing scripts, see Where the Wild Things Are and Away We Go, in between overseeing a one-time only, Sunday-edition-size newspaper: McSweeneys No. 33: The San Francisco Panorama with full-color comics from Chris Ware, Dan Clowes and Art Spiegelman. Tell him to slow down at The Strand today where hell be appearing at 12. p.m.

title: Mr. Sunshine
description: Julian Casablancas was once the savior of debauched New York City rock n roll. But those heady days when he and the Strokes were the leaders of the downtown guitar scene are long gone and, at the dawn of this decade, Mr. Casablancas is instead busy being a family man, eating healthy and relaxing in the Los Angeles sun. Tonight you can see the changed man in action when he performs at Terminal 5. Hell be playing songs off his solo debut record, Phrazes for the Young, an oddly hopeful record.

title: Proposals Clash on States Role in Health Plans
description: Should someone in Idaho or Nevada have significantly different health care coverage from someone in Massachusetts?

title: Socit Gnrale to Write Off More Debt
description: PARIS  The French bank Socit Gnrale said Wednesday that it would write off another 1.4 billion euros in troubled American mortgage assets in the fourth quarter of 2009, but that it would still manage a slight profit.

title: Meet Mikey, 8: U.S. Has Him on Watch List
description: The Transportation Security Administration, under scrutiny after last months bombing attempt, has on its Web site a mythbuster that tries to reassure the public.

title: Democrats Fight to Hold Crucial Seat: Kennedys
description: BOSTON  Martha Coakley stepped briskly through a community center here Tuesday, issuing clipped greetings and appealing for votes in a race she was once thought to have sewn up. Always a bit stiff, she laughed politely when one man shouted his support, murmuring, We all need to make some noise right now.

title: Wall St. Ethos Under Scrutiny at Hearing
description: The 10 members of the panel, brows furrowed and some furiously taking notes, squared off against the Wall Street chiefs in Washington over the billions in bonuses, and who was really to blame for bringing the financial system to its knees.

title: In Miami, the Lack of Word Fuels Concern
description: MIAMI  Yvose Casimir slumped forward in a pew at the Notre Dame DHaiti Roman Catholic church, her head resting on the next pew, deep in fervent and desperate prayer, while a lay leader intoned a prayer in Creole. There was not much more she could do, she said. She had been on the telephone with her sister in Port-au-Prince when the earthquake struck.

title: A Cardinal Redeems Himself in a Big Way
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  In his Louisiana home, Rickey Bustle yelled at his television as if his voice might carry all the way to Arizona. One of Bustles former Louisiana-Lafayette players, Cardinals cornerback Michael Adams, was getting embarrassed by Green Bay quarterback Aaron Rodgers on Sunday in a National Football Conference wild-card playoff game.

title: Arnolds Last Yodel
description: SACRAMENTO, Ca.  He was never as empty-headed as his enemies imagined, nor the cartoon character he sometimes portrayed. A Reagan Republican who married into the royalty of Americas Democratic dynasty, Arnold Schwarzenegger had everything going for him  no ties to party leaders, interest groups or the past.

title: Surgery for Beltran Means Hes Likely Out Until May
description: The 2010 spring training is only a month away, but for the Mets it still seems like their injury-ravaged 2009. The team announced Wednesday night that center fielder Carlos Beltran, who missed 10 weeks last season with an ailing right knee, had arthroscopic surgery, making him unlikely to play in April.

title: On Future Performance
description: Composing is what I love to do most. It is what best combines my various skills and interests  imagination, reflection, organization and the desire to communicate my thoughts and emotions to anyone who will listen. I also love solitude: I do my creative work in an 18th-century barn on our farm near Boston, where I can pursue my ideas without the need to explain or translate until all is ripe and ready. So it may seem like a paradox that another large chunk of my life is spent in one of the worlds most futuristic, collaborative and intensive centers of technological invention  the The Massachusetts Institute of Technology Media Lab. But the attractions and complexities of merging these worlds are central to how and why I work, and grow from seeds planted when I was very young.My mom is a Juilliard-trained pianist and a remarkable pedagogue and my dad is one of the pioneers of computer graphics, but it actually took me a while to start combining these fields. I grew up as a cellist, first playing solo Bach, then chamber music (I never particularly enjoyed playing in orchestras), and then, by high school, original composed or improvised music using a wired (or is that weird?) transformed rock cello that I created by placing large headphones around the cello for amplification, then sending the sound through tape recorder loops and analog transformation processes.

title: Art Rust Jr., Pioneer in Sports Talk Radio, Dies at 82
description: Art Rust Jr., a pioneering figure in New York radio sports talk shows and a sports historian whose books focused on the interplay of race and athletics, died Tuesday at a hospital in Manhattan. He was 82.

title: To Lead Schools, Christie Picks Voucher Advocate
description: TRENTON  The man once described by teachers union leaders as the antithesis of everything we hold sacred about public education was chosen to serve as state education commissioner by Governor-elect Christopher J. Christie on Wednesday.

title: OBrien Keeps Tapping His Saga for Jokes
description: Conan OBrien kept up his drumbeat of jokes about his tense situation with his network Wednesday night  and even made a pointed reference to losing out on his show because Jay Leno wanted it, too.

title: In Rebuke of China, Focus Falls on Cybersecurity
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Even before Google threatened to pull out of China in response to an attack on its computer systems, the company was notifying activists whose e-mail accounts might have been compromised by hackers.

title: Long Island Shantytown Is Destroyed
description: Officials declared make-shift homes unsafe and ordered them leveled.

title: 15 Across: Nazione di Napoli
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Tight. Thats the operative word in describing todays theme. The approach is straightforward enough, that of adding letters to a phrase in order to form a new phrase. However, the degree of difficulty has been upped considerably by using only movie titles. Then comes the really inspired part.

title: Aide to Leave Mayors Staff for a Job at His Charity
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs communications director will soon leave City Hall for a position at the mayors philanthropic foundation, becoming the first senior administration official to leave in Mr. Bloombergs third term.

title: Google Is Not Alone in Discontent, but Its Threat to Leave Stands Out
description: HONG KONG  Google is far from alone among Western companies in its growing unhappiness with Chinese government policies, although it is highly unusual in threatening to pull out of the country entirely in protest.

title: A Mini-Madoff Who Worked the Pews
description: CLIFTON, N.J.

title: Makeshift Homes Are Leveled in Suffolk County
description: HUNTINGTON STATION, N.Y.  It would be easy to miss the narrow trail into the patch of woods that runs along Fifth Street here. Chunks of ice and snow muddy the path; gnarled, bare tree branches leave a passageway only a foot or two wide. Venturing a little farther, one begins to see the remnants of a home crudely made in an inhospitable area: discarded mattresses, rusty pans, artificial flowers, stuffed animals, a picture of Jesus.

title: Gillibrand Responds to Fords Challenge, Calling Him Out of Touch With New York
description: Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand, after days of ignoring the political threat posed by Harold E. Ford Jr., on Wednesday forcefully took him on, suggesting that his views may be right for Tennessee, but are out of step with the voters of New York.

title: Corrections
description: A graphic in some editions on Friday with the continuation of an article about the slumping commercial real estate market in New York, using information from real estate experts, referred imprecisely to 400 Madison Avenue. Although it has been identified as a property with financial problems, the owners are up to date on their loan payments.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Jan. 3 with an article about people whose only income is food stamps misstated, in one instance, data on the number of such people in Florida. There are more than 400,000, one in five of Floridas food stamp recipients  not six million. (That is the number of such people nationwide.)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the National Briefing column last Thursday about a new study on the interaction between the seasonal flu vaccine and the arthritis drug rituximab misstated a finding. The study found that in arthritis patients who receive the vaccine close to the time they take rituximab, the immune system apparently fails to make antibodies to the flu virus  not to arthritis.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Goal soccer roundup on Tuesday about safety concerns for this years World Cup in South Africa in the aftermath of an attack on Togos national team in Angola on Friday misstated the number of players that Arsenal sent to play for Ivory Coast in the African Cup of Nations there. It was one player (Emmanuel Ebou), not two.

title: U.S.C. Welcomes Kiffin, and Deals With Questions
description: LOS ANGELES  When Lane Kiffin left Tennessee, students burned mattresses and threw debris at cars. He received a much more welcoming reception Wednesday when he was introduced as the new coach of Southern California.

title: Corrections
description: The Books of The Times Review on Friday, about The Harvard Psychedelic Club: How Timothy Leary, Ram Dass, Huston Smith and Andrew Weil Killed the Fifties and Ushered In a New Age for America, by Don Lattin, referred incorrectly to the death of Diane Linkletter, daughter of the television and radio personality Art Linkletter. While Mr. Linkletter said his daughter was on LSD when she jumped from a window to her death in 1969 and blamed Mr. Leary, an autopsy found no evidence of the drug in her body. The review also referred imprecisely to the Harvard careers of Mr. Leary and Richard Alpert (later known as Ram Dass). While they taught psychology at Harvard, they were in the department of social relations  not the psychology department, which later absorbed the department of social relations.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the effect some of the technologies used to make the film Avatar might have on future movies, including The Adventures of Tintin: Secret of the Unicorn, erroneously included a studio among those releasing that film. It will be released by Paramount Pictures and Sony Pictures, but not in conjunction with DreamWorks. (Steven Spielberg of DreamWorks is the director.)

title: Lottery Numbers
Corrections
description: A theater review on Tuesday about LEffet de Serge, at 3LD Art & Technology Center in Lower Manhattan, misidentified the star. He is Gatan Vourch  not Philippe Quesne, who is the director and co-creator of the work with Mr. Vourch.

title: Corrections
description: EDITORS' NOTE

title: Knicks Edge the 76ers on Lees Late Basket
description: PHILADELPHIA  David Lees shot bounced and bounced again, apparently not satisfied until it met every part of the rim.

title: Forget Wind. Pickens Turns Focus to Gas.
description: DALLAS  Arabic script is about to appear on television sets across the country, with the Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens helpfully reading an English translation.

title: Help With Her Shyness, Then in Building Her Life
description: Elsa Sanchez greeted a recent visitor with a dimpled smile, a firm handshake and an air of maturity that belies her 18 years. She explained that she learned to project this confidence only a short time ago, at her high school.

title: Donald Goerke, Creator of SpaghettiOs, Dies at 83
description: Donald Goerke, a Campbell Soup Company executive whose nonlinear approach to pasta resulted in SpaghettiOs, died Sunday at his home in Delran, N.J. He was 83.

title: Texas Shuts Door on Millions in Education Grants
description: Texas will not compete for up to $700 million in federal education money, Gov. Rick Perry said on Wednesday, calling the Obama administrations main school improvement grant program an unacceptable intrusion on states control over education.

title: Anxious Moments Before Hearing the Words Im O.K.
description: The call came just after noon on Wednesday, 19 hours after the earthquake hit Haiti. The Rev. Dr. Frank L. Fowler III, the pastor of Trinity United Methodist Church in Hackettstown, N.J., was checking in  from the airport in Port-au-Prince, on a borrowed satellite phone.

title: Sample of Nestl Cookie Dough Has E. Coli Bacteria
description: Nestl USA said Wednesday that two samples of its Toll House refrigerated cookie dough made at a Virginia factory tested positive for E. coli bacteria this week despite rigorous safety measures put in place after a recall of the product last summer.

title: Growth in Germany Neared Zero at End of 09
description: FRANKFURT  Growth in Germany was near zero at the end of 2009, the government said Wednesday, as the nation struggled to climb out of its worst recession since World War II.

title: Red Storm Ruins Stephensons Homecoming
description: The P.A. announcer at Madison Square Garden introduced the final starter for the Cincinnati Bearcats: At guard, a 6-5 freshman from Brooklyn, New York, No. 33, Lance Stephenson. And the boos flowed out of the stands.

title: A Census Campaign That Speaks in Many Tongues
description: A campaign to encourage participation in the 2010 census reflects many of the major changes since the last census in the population that is to be counted.

title: New Official Named With Portfolio to Unite Agencies and Improve Food Safety
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, moving to address the nations fractured food safety system, on Wednesday appointed Michael R. Taylor, a veteran food expert, as deputy commissioner for foods at the Food and Drug Administration. The newly created position is the first to oversee all the agencys many food and nutrition programs.

title: Some in Canada Say Strike Shows Risk of Foreign Control
description: SUDBURY, Ontario  Last July, the 3,300 unionized workers who normally work deep below this city in the vast nickel mines owned by Vale Inco did something unusual: they went on strike even though they had already been laid off temporarily.

title: Few Burns for Four Bankers on the Hot Seat
description: WASHINGTON  The four bankers of the apocalypse strode into the Congressional hearing room and formed a crooked line. They raised their hands haltingly, looking at one another as if to see whether the other guys were going to do it, too. It was one of the more indecisive swearings-in you will ever see on Capitol Hill.

title: Ruling Blocks Broadcasting of a Trial on Same-Sex Marriage
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Wednesday effectively eliminated the possibility that any part of the trial of a constitutional challenge to a ban on same-sex marriage now under way in San Francisco would be broadcast before it concludes.

title: Year of the Tiger, Not Easily Tamed
description: A month before China ushers in the year of the tiger, its central bank has begun to address the effects of its roaring liquidity boom. It is encouraging that the authorities in Beijing are alert to the threat of an overheating financial system. But with so many countervailing forces, the liquidity tiger will not be tamed so easily.

title: Ohio: Police Chief Sentenced in Break-In
description: The police chief of Bridgeport will spend 50 days in home confinement for his role in last years break-in of the home of a surrogate mother carrying twins for the movie stars Sarah Jessica Parker and Matthew Broderick. The chief, Chad M. Dojack, pleaded guilty last week to a reduced charge of dereliction of duty for not reporting the crime. A chief in a neighboring town, Barry P. Carpenter, 40, was sentenced to 32 months in prison for going into the surrogates home and taking items. Mr. Dojack, 29, said he only failed to report the crime once he realized what had happened. Mr. Carpenter has resigned. Whether Mr. Dojack remains chief will be determined by the towns mayor, who is the grandfather of Mr. Dojacks wife.

title: U.S.C.s Orgeron Says Hes Following Recruiting Rules
description: After Lane Kiffins introductory news conference Wednesday night, Ed Orgeron, less than 24 hours after returning as Southern Californias defensive line coach and recruiting coordinator, found himself backed into a corner by a group of reporters.

title: Bloggingheads:  The Curse of Power
description: Mark Schmitt, left, of The American Prospect and Byron York of The Washington Examiner debate partisanship and health care reform.

title: Haiti
description: Once again, the world weeps with Haiti. The earthquake that struck on Tuesday did damage on a scale that scarcely could have been imagined had we all not seen the photos and videos and read the survivors agonizing accounts  of the sudden crumbling of mountainside slums, schools, hospitals, even the Parliament building and presidential palace.

title: Google in China
description: Google has taken a bold stand by saying that it would stop cooperating with Chinas online censorship and may pull out of the country entirely. Google had many reasons to reconsider its presence, but the discovery that it was a victim of a cyberattack aimed at Chinese human rights activists added a powerful one. There are limits to the price an American company should be willing to pay for access to 300 million Web users.

title: Discrimination on Trial, but Not on TV
description: The trial that started on Monday in San Francisco over the constitutionality of Californias voter-approved ban on same-sex marriage could have been a moment for the entire nation to witness a calm, deliberative debate on a vitally important issue in the era of instant communications. Instead, the United States Supreme Court made it a sad example of the quashing of public discourse by blocking the televising of the nonjury trial.

title: More Than a Scandal in Belfast
description: The struggle for power sharing  and lasting peace  in Northern Ireland has been long and bloody. Political leaders now must make sure that a sordid crisis does not threaten the agreement or the provinces future.

title: Reaching Out to a Devastated Haiti
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Worlds News Media Enter Port-au-Prince
description: The worlds news media scrambled to enter Port-au-Prince, Haiti on Wednesday, hours after a 7.0-magnitude earthquake decimated the capital city.

title: The 10 Percent Rules
description: If Massachusetts was the Department of Homeland Security, the special election to fill Ted Kennedys senate seat would have the Democrats about four-fifths of the way up the terror alert code.

title: Google Takes a Stand
description: It has been dispiriting to see Americas banks apparently stand for nothing more lofty than plunder. It has been demoralizing to see President Obama hiding from the Dalai Lama rather than offend Chinas rulers.

title: Word of the Day | dupe
description: dupe \dp also dyp\ noun and verb

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 31, about the debate over the value of optimism, misspelled the surname of a woman who says the life of her terminally ill husband was prolonged a few weeks by a doctors encouragement. She is Ruth Rosoff, not Rossoff. The article also referred incorrectly to the price of LiveHappy, which is advertised as a mobile happiness boosting program. The $9.99 cost is one time only, not monthly.

title: Braylon Edwards, Enigma
description: Steve Politi of The Star-Ledger with a nice get:

title: Slim Aims to Unite 3 Telecom Firms
description: Amrica Mvil, the telecommunications company controlled by Carlos Slim Hel, on Wednesday started a $21 billion offer for the Mexican telephone companies Telmex and Telmex Internacional, Reuters reported.

title: News Quiz | January 14, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Helping Haiti
description: WHO were killed by the worst earthquake in Haiti in 200 years?

title: Hershey Is Said to Be Still Working on Cadbury Bid
description: Hershey, the American chocolate maker, is still working on a bid for Cadbury that would top Krafts $17 billion hostile takeover offer, a source familiar with the matter told Reuters on Wednesday.

title: William J. Lederer, Co-Author of The Ugly American, Dies at 97
description: William J. Lederer, a writer and career naval officer who, with Eugene Burdick, wrote The Ugly American, a novel that was among the first books to deal with American involvement in Southeast Asia and that barely veiled a blistering critique of the nations foreign policy there, died on Dec. 5 in Baltimore. He was 97.

title: Pickens Focuses on National Security
description: Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens is turning up the volume and changing the pitch on his efforts to persuade Americans to embrace his energy plan.

title: Few Burns for Four Bankers on the Hot Seat
description: The four bankers of the apocalypse strode into the Congressional hearing room and formed a crooked line. They raised their hands haltingly, looking at one another as if to see whether the other guys were going to do it, too. It was one of the more indecisive swearings-in you will ever see on Capitol Hill.

title: Voices That Dominate Wall Street Take Meeker Tone
description: Summoned to Capitol Hill to explain their companies roles in the worst economic downturn since the Depression, leaders of four big Wall Street banks offered a largely clinical take on the financial crisis on Wednesday, pointing to lapses in risk management and government regulation but offering little sense of the turmoils human toll, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

title: How Are You Responding to the Disaster in Haiti?
description: People all over the world are reacting and responding to news of the disaster in Haiti  some by donating money and supplies, others by volunteering to go there to provide medical care and other aid. But the situation may be difficult to fathom. What kinds of information are helping you comprehend the devastation? And how are you responding to the news?

title: China Backs Overseas Acquisitions by Airlines
description: China Southern Airlines led gains by air carriers in Hong Kong markets on Thursday, after an aviation regulator expressed support for consolidation and overseas acquisitions, Bloomberg News reported.

title: MGM Said to Draw Interest From 12 Firms
description: Time Warner, Lions Gate Entertainment, as well as private equity firms, are among those weighing potential offers for the debt-ridden Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, though no bids have come in for the movie studio yet, Reuters reported, citing several sources familiar with the matter.

title: Rusal I.P.O. Said to Be Fully Subscribed in Hong Kong
description: The initial public offering of Russias UC Rusal was fully subscribed by institutional investors on the third day of its bookbuilding process, people familiar with the matter told Reuters on Thursday, in a positive indication of demand for Hong Kongs first-ever primary offering from a non-Asian company.

title: Haiti Relief Effort Faces Major Challenge
description: A host of logistical problems snarled traffic at the Port-au-Prince airport on Thursday, forcing the airport to turn planes away, stranding relief workers for hours and threatening to delay the relief supplies that Haiti so desperately needs.

title: Lotte Considers Acquiring Rival Korean Retail Chain
description: Lotte Group, which operates South Koreas second-largest retailer Lotte Shopping, said it was considering buying GS Retails department store and discount store operations in a deal that may be worth more than $1 billion.

title: Open Space in Paris
description: This apartment, which has 14-foot ceilings, is on the top floor of a Beaux-Arts building in the 15th Arrondissement.

title: Visible Technologies Raises $22 Million
description: Visible Technologies, a start-up that monitors digital and social media for brands, has landed $22 million in a fourth round of funding that VentureBeat says suggests renewed spending by big companies and brands.

title: Get Satisfaction Gets $2.3 Million
description: Get Satisfaction, a start-up that hosts online customer service communities, has raised $2.3 million in a fresh round of financing, PaidContent reported.

title: American Idol 9 on 9: The Atlanta Auditions
description: Tonight in Atlanta, it was American Idol at its finest: the gifted, the deluded, the earnest, the contrived. Kara still looked grim, but Simon smiled, and apparently no one told guest judge Mary J. Blige shed have to sit through bad auditions as well as good ones. Tonights 9 questions:

title: Geriaddicts
description: Elderly drug addicts.(Geriatric + addict.)

title: RealNetworks Founder Steps Down as Chief
description: RealNetworks, the digital entertainment company, said on Wednesday that its founder, Rob Glaser, had stepped down as chief executive but would remain chairman.

title: Justices Skeptical of N.F.L.s Court Claim
description: Lawyers for the National Football League and an apparel company staked out aggressive positions at a Supreme Court argument Wednesday over whether the league should be treated as a single entity or a collection of 32 independent companies for purposes of the antitrust laws, The New York Timess Adam Liptak reported.

title: Should Kraft Hold the Line?
description: Kraft Foods should not budge  at least not much, Reuters Breakingviews says. Its reluctant British takeover target, Cadbury, has disclosed some impressive, if unsurprising, results and high expectations.

title: Christmas Could Boost Matalan Sale Talks
description: A surge in Christmas sales at the British discount fashion retailer Matalan could reinvigorate a sale process that has run slowly since private equity houses first expressed an interest in the chain in October.

title: Tensions Mount in Devastated Capital as Nations Step Up Aid Pledges to Haiti
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  The distance between life and death narrowed in this flattened city on Thursday, with survival two days after the huge earthquake struck depending increasingly on the luck of being freed from under rubble, on treating the thousands of wounded and on speeding the halting flow of emergency food and water.

title: Wall Street Closes Higher After Bankers Testify
description: The stock market closed higher on Wednesday, following the lead of financial shares as the heads of several big banks testified in Washington about the financial crisis.

title: Tough Confirmation for E.U.s Ex-Antitrust Chief
description: With her aggressive antitrust prosecutions, Neelie Kroes, the European Unions former competition commissioner, should be one of the last officeholders on the Continent who needed to prove her pro-consumer credentials.

title: Follow the Law, China Tells Internet Companies
description: BEIJING  Two days after Google announced that it would quit China unless the nations censors eased their grip, the Chinese government offered an indirect but unambiguous response: Companies that do business in China must follow the laws of the land.

title: Idol Creator Plans to Start New Business
description: The offstage turmoil around American Idol continues to grow as Simon Fuller, chief executive of 19 Entertainment and the creator of American Idol, is expected to announce soon that he is starting a new company to pursue film and other entertainment projects separately from 19 Entertainment and its publicly traded parent, CKX, The New York Timess Edward Wyatt reported.

title: Hedge Funds Lose Staff to S.E.C., Survey Finds
description: Findings in a new report that United States hedge funds lost staff to endowments and sovereign wealth funds may not raise many eyebrows, but one of the employers found to be siphoning off hedge fund managers may come as a surprise: the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Forget Wind. Pickens Turns Focus to Gas.
description: Arabic script is about to appear on television sets across the country, with the Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens helpfully reading an English translation, Clifford Strauss writes in The New York Times.

title: Wilbur Ross Sees Slow U.S. Auto Sales Rebound
description: Wilbur Ross, the billionaire investor, said on Wednesday that the United States economy was nowhere near a full recovery and forecast 2010 as a year of moderate growth for American automotive industry sales.

title: Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard Make a Really Big Deal
description: From Ashlee Vance at Bits:

title: Wynns Complete Divorce in Las Vegas
description: Steve Wynn, the billionaire chief executive of casino operator Wynn Resorts, is officially divorced for the second time from his wife, Elaine.

title: Markets Nominee Seeks to Reassure Britains Finance Sector
description: The Frenchman nominated to oversee the European Unions internal market told his critics Wednesday that he would regulate to strengthen supervision of financial services but would not seek to undermine the City of Londons dominance of the sector in Europe, The New York Timess Stephen Castle reported.

title: VMware Gently Nudges Microsoft With a Zimbra
description: From Ashlee Vance at Bits:

title: JPMorgan May Report Profit Leap on Banking Fees
description: JPMorgan Chase, the first of the largest U.S. banks to report fourth-quarter results, may say profit more than tripled from the depths of the financial crisis in 2008 on a rebound in investment-banking fees.

title: Britains Mandelson Warns Bidders Seeking Quick Profit
description: The U.K. business secretary, Peter Mandelson, has warned directors of predatory companies they should expect to run the gantlet of criticism if they ignored local and work force interests.

title: Taxing Banks for the Bailout
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama laid down his proposal for a new tax on the nations largest financial institutions on Thursday, saying he wanted to recover every single dime the American people are owed for bailing out the economy.

title: Barclays Gobbles Up LaBranches N.Y.S.E. Unit
description: Barclays, the British bank, has signed a deal to buy LaBranche & Companys New York Stock Exchange specialist business for $25 million (15.3 million) in cash, underscoring the difficulties standalone market makers face in a shrinking industry.

title: Argentinas Talented Angel
description: The only things that might outpace the talent of Argentinas forwards at the World Cup this summer are the expectations facing Diego Maradonas team in South Africa.

title: Reading English-Language Books in Paris
description: Generations of English-speaking literary expats in Paris have left a legacy of bookstores on both sides of the Seine. Many Anglophone readers swear by the much beloved Shakespeare and Company, or the Paris branch of the British chain W.H. Smith. But for those willing to hunt, there are several gems to discover: small, well-maintained stores crammed with new and used English-language titles  and plenty of character. Here is a selection; share your favorites below.

title: Win Probabilities, and the Importance of Playoff Run Defense
description: (Brian Burke, a former Navy pilot who has taken up the less dangerous hobby of N.F.L. statistical analysis, operates Advanced NFL Stats, a blog about football, math and human behavior.)

title: U.S. Approves Training to Expand Afghan Army
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Pentagon has authorized a substantial increase in the number of Afghan security forces it plans to train by next year, in time for President Obamas deadline for United States combat forces to begin withdrawing from the country, military officials said Thursday.

title: G.M. to Halt Hummer Production Pending Sale
description: General Motors will halt Hummer production next week at its Louisiana plant until sale of the brand to a Chinese company is completed, The Associated Press reported.

title: 3 Executives, Including C.E.O., Leave Zale
description: Zale, the struggling jewelry chain, said on Wednesday that its chief executive officer and other top executives had left the company in a management shake-up aimed at helping to return the company to profitability.

title: Treasury Needs Plan for TARP Assets, Panel Says
description: The Treasury Department will own billions of dollars worth of financial assets when a taxpayer-financed bailout program is over and has not set clear principles for disposing them, a government watchdog agency said on Thursday.

title: Soros Fund Eyes Hong Kong Office, Report Says
description: George Soross Soros Fund Management is planning to plant its flag in Hong Kong, Bloomberg News reported, citing a person with knowledge of the matter.

title: Wall St. Ethos Under Scrutiny at Hearing
description: During the first days hearing of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission in Washington on Wednesday, an essential truth about the Wall Street ethos was laid bare: if theres a buyer  no matter how sophisticated  theres always a seller, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest column in The New York Times.

title: Changing the Rules, Not the Tax Bill
Obama Plan: A 10-Year Bank Tax to Recoup Bailout
description: Update | 12:28 p.m.  President Obama on Thursday proposed taxing about 50 big banks and major financial institutions for at least the next decade to recover every single dime from the bailout of Wall Street, The New York Timess Jackie Calmes reports from Washington.

title: Environmentalism as Religion, Redux
description: Todays idea: Environmental hectoring and guilt illustrate the way religious impulses live on in secular society, an essay says.

title: Taliban Leader May Have Been Target of Drone Strike
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  At least 10 people were killed in an American drone strike in northwest Pakistan on Thursday morning that was aimed at the leader of the Pakistani Taliban, according to Pakistani security officials.

title: BMWs ActiveE Foreshadows the Megacity Car
description: DETROIT  BMW is approaching the electrification of the automobile through what it calls Project i. And although its cars  including the battery-powered Mini E and the Concept ActiveE, which is an electric version of the BMW 1 Series Coupe the company introduced in Detroit this week  have made a splash, Project i has generally flown under the radar. But, even in stealth mode (there isnt even a Web site), the research initiative could be influential on BMWs future products.

title: Jan. 14: Updates on the Rescue Effort in Haiti
description: As we did on Tuesday and Wednesday, The Lede is continuing to follow news of the rescue effort in Haiti, where a 7.0 magnitude earthquake has caused death and destruction that has been difficult for Haitians and observers outside the country to assess, because of severe damage to the local communications infrastructure. To supplement the work of our colleagues  including Simon Romeros reporting from Haiti  The Lede is tracking news coverage on the Web. We are also looking for personal accounts posted online and are asking readers to help draw our attention to any news and first-hand accounts they come across. Our Times Topics team has produced an overview of the weeks events so far.

title: Sampler: No Video of Marriage Trial and Palo Altos Egg War Continues
description: Same-Sex Marriage Trial Not Coming to a Screen Near You | The Supreme Court said Wednesday that it would extend Mondays temporary stay blocking distribution of video images of the federal trial in San Francisco over same-sex marriage. In a 5-to-4 ruling, the court said that the decision to allow video distribution was made in haste, and it blocked broadcasts to courthouses around the country. Its reasoning would apply to Internet broadcasts as well; YouTube distribution had originally been planned. The trial, which enters its fourth day, has had expert testimony over the history of marriage and the effect of laws banning same-sex marriage. [The New York Times]

title: The Early Word: Payback
description: Its payback time for 50 major banks and financial institutions that received support from the federal government during the depths of the economic crisis.

title: Small Firms Slam E.P.A. Clean Air Revisions
description: Small business owners are claiming that the revisedgreenhouse gas regulations proposedrecently by the Environmental Protection Agency to curb emissions would be financially burdensome for them.

title: Uncertainty Grips Haitians in New York
description: They know how to make the calls. They know what to collect and send. In a city of insular immigrant populations, none have had more experience helping with disasters back home and knowing how to make crucial life-or-death connections than the Haitian populations in Brooklyn and in Cambria Heights, Queens.

title: In a Surprise, Retail Sales Fell in December
description: Retail sales fell unexpectedly in December, the government said Thursday, despite earlier scattered signs that the 2009 holiday shopping season was stronger than expected.

title: Cougar Cruise Finds a New Berth
description: Single ladies of a certain age, rest easy: after being dropped by the Carnival line, the Second International Cougar Cruise has found a new host.

title: City Hospital Chief Calls for Coverage of Immigrants
description: The leader of New York Citys massive public hospital system warned this week that the health care bills in Congress would burden safety net hospitals by failing to provide coverage for uninsured immigrants while also reducing federal payments for indigent care.

title: Design Underfoot | BCXSYs Coat Rugs
description: Our favorite Israeli/Japanese, Netherlands-based design duo, Boaz Cohen and Sayaka Yamamoto of BCXSY, are at it again. The high-concept-centric designers, whose light-up swing lamp was on the cover the spring 2008 issue of T Design, came up with their latest project, Re-skinned, while wondering what happens to discarded leather and fur coats. They felt that throwing out the old coats was disrespectful to the animals whose skins made the garments. After some serious thrift-store digging, Cohen and Yamamoto found some likely candidates for their repurposing effort. In their experiments, they found that when the garments were disassembled and laid flat, their backs resembled traditional animal-skin rugs. Each rug is backed with felt and stamped with the BCXSY logo and a serial number for authenticity. At their introduction during Dutch design week in October, some of the rugs were snapped up by Rossana Orlandi for her renowned design store in Milan. And people have already approached Cohen and Yamamoto with their own coats, hoping to take them home again as rugs.

title: Iraq Sentences 11 to Death in Ministry Bombings
description: BAGHDAD  A court in Baghdad sentenced 11 Iraqis to death on Thursday for planning and carrying out two devastating attacks last summer.

title: Good News and Bad News on Food Safety and Health
description: The Food and Drug Administration has appointed the first official to oversee all the agencys food safety programs. The official, Michael R. Taylor, is deputy commissioner for foods. Legislation expected to pass this spring would give even more power to his office to regulate food safety.

title: Technology Helps Lead Shares Higher as Retailers Slip
description: Stocks advanced for a second day as technology shares climbed before Intel reported earnings. In addition, business inventories increased more than forecast, overshadowing an unexpected drop in retail sales.

title: Obama Will Tap Bush and Clinton for Haiti Efforts
description: Updated: President Obama is asking his two immediate predecessors  George W. Bush and Bill Clinton  to come together to lead the nations humanitarian and relief efforts to Haiti in the wake of the earthquake that has ravaged the Caribbean island. The partnership is expected to be announced by the White House in the coming days, after officials have a better handle on the full scope of the devastation. Mr. Obama called Mr. Bush on Wednesday, aides to both men said, and Mr. Bush agreed to do whatever he could to help.

title: When Fear Turns Graphic
description: ZURICH

title: Party in His Pants': American Idol Creates a Viral Hit
description: As far as were concerned, American Idol can end right now, because its winner has already been found. There is no justice if this season is not handed to 63-year-old Larry Platt of Atlanta, who won our hearts, minds and ears Wednesday night with his performance of Pants on the Ground.

title: The Globes Get a Little Dangerous
description: The Bagger has landed in L.A., ready to join the fray with only the barest essentials for the days of parties surrounding the Golden Globes. Meanwhile, our colleague Brooks Barnes takes a look at what the Globes, to be held on Sunday, will be doing differently this year to attract a larger audience. For the first time in 15 years, the broadcast will have a host, Ricky Gervais, whose appeal gibes with the anything-can-happen vibe the show likes to present.

title: A Call for More Regulation at Fiscal Crisis Inquiry
description: The need for tighter federal regulation was the dominant message sent on Thursday to the panel established by Congress to examine the causes of the financial crisis.

title: Can We Change the Webs Culture of Nastiness?
description: Update | 10:52 a.m. Added link to Book Review article.

title: A Pledge to Repeal Health Care Legislation
description: The conservative Club for Growth says it is not sufficient for Congressional Republicans to vote against the Democrats health care legislation  the group also wants elected officials and candidates to promise that they will work to repeal the measure should Democrats succeed in approving it over Republican opposition.

title: Questioning the Impact of Proposed E.P.A. Regulations
description: Our colleagues at Green Inc. have published a post assessing the burden new Environmental Protection Agency regulations would place on small businesses. Sindya N. Bhanoo writes:

title: Chodorow to Open Basque Restaurant in New Kimpton Hotel
description: Next fall, Jeffrey Chodorow will be opening a Basque restaurant with futuristic decor on the second floor of the Eventi, the new Kimpton  hotel on Avenue of the Americas between 29th and 30th Streets. Ed Schoenfeld will be the consultant on Food Parc, a collection of food stands, open to the public, in the building and in an outdoor plaza behind it. One stand will be from RedFarm, the Asian-American restaurant hes opening with Joe Ng from Chinatown Brasserie.

title: Student Crossword | Famous Literary Characters
description: Orphans, detectives, knights, squires, dashing Civil War blockade runners, and, of course, doomed heroines: play our new student crossword to see which famous literary characters you can identify. You can find the answers here.

title: The Help That Haiti Needs
description: Updated, Jan. 15, 9:20 a.m. |  With traffic jammed at Port-au-Prince airport, relief groups are considering moving emergency supplies through the neighboring Dominican Republic and the use of land-sea vessels to unload supplies at the badly damaged port in the Haitian capital.

title: Thursday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Panel Finds Monserrate Unfit to Serve
description: Concluding that State Senator Hiram Monserrate lied about a domestic dispute in 2008 that left his companion with a gash to her face, a special Senate committee has recommended an immediate vote to remove the senator from office.

title: Your Five-Minute Late-Night Feud Wrap-Up
description: On an evening when the late-night hosts expanded their circular firing squad to include Jeff Zucker, the NBC Universal chief executive whos being blamed increasingly for the Jay LenoConan OBrien succession debacle, the single best salvo of the night was fired by Mr. OBrien. In his opening monologue, Mr. OBrien offered this inspirational message: I just want to say to the kids out there watching: You can do anything you want in life. Unless Jay Leno wants to do it, too.

title: The Wealth of Nations
description: No doubt youve followed every twist and turn of the Europe-versus-America debate thats spun out from Jim Manzis Keeping Americas Edge, and Jonathan Chaits critique of Manzi. On the off chance that you havent, though, here are some highlights:

title: After Miracle on Hudson, Many Promises to Keep
description: It is something of an unwritten rule, with the exception of ham-fisted Hollywood scripts, that anyone who walks away from a plane crash is supposed to have made a deal with a higher power in exchange for that walk.

title: Labor Movement Starting an Online College
description: My colleague, Steve Greenhouse, who covers organized labor, reports that the labor movement is creating its own online college. The organizations behind the effort are the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the National Labor College, and the Princeton Review.

title: Haitian Earthquake Spurs Stars to Action
description: The mobile communications company that is working with the pop musician Wyclef Jean to raise money for disaster relief in Haiti said on Thursday that it had raised more than $750,000 in donations since its campaign began on Tuesday. In a news release, Give on the Go, the fund-raising division of the Miami company Red Fish Media, said its goal was to raise more than $1 million per day. The campaign allows the users of mobile devices to make an instant donation of $5 to Mr. Jeans Yle Haiti foundation, a relief charity, by texting Yele to 501501. (The charge appears later on the users telephone bill.) In a statement, Matt McKenna, president of Red Fish Media, said 100 percent of the donations are given directly to the charity. The campaign began at 6 p.m. on Tuesday, and Mr. Jean has tirelessly promoted it on his Twitter account, soon after a 7.0 magnitude earthquake struck Haiti about 10 miles southwest of Port-au-Prince.

title: Do You Have the Right Stuff to Be a Doctor?
description: Not long ago, a friend confessed that her son, who spends much of his free time volunteering at a childrens hospital and who is applying to medical school, has been particularly anxious about his future. His test scores are just O.K., my friend said, the despair in her voice nearly palpable. I know hed be a great doctor, but who he is doesnt seem to matter to medical schools as much as how he does on tests.

title: Vain Glorious | Graceland Brooklyn
description: With Vain Glorious, T Magazine breaks down the latest spas, salons and products for your aesthetic pleasure.

title: Panel Told of F.B.I. Efforts to Fight Financial Crime
description: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. told a panel created to examine the reasons for the financial crisis on Thursday that the Justice Department was working to hold accountable those who had contributed to the near collapse and to deter similar conduct in the future, The New York Timess Sewell Chan reports.

title: Plenty of Good Seats Still Available
description: The Jets are hot, but their fans know the heartbreak of high hopes. A losing tradition has been the backdrop to the teams sales of personal seat licenses at the Jets and Giants new stadium.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Creates Online College for Union Families
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O., the main umbrella group for the nations labor unions, announced on Thursday that it was joining with the National Labor College and the Princeton Review to create an online college for the federations 11.5 million members and their families.

title: Viewing Images From Haiti, and Fearing the Worst
description: The Haitian men sat in the waiting room of Jude Desirs tax preparation office in Brooklyn, combing the television images of the earthquake damage for something that looked familiar: a city, a neighborhood, a street, a face.

title: All the Top Positions
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: A new report says that one year after President Obama took office, 40 percent of top positions in his administration have yet to be filled. George Bush actually filled 62 percent of top positions during his first year, and Bill Clinton filled all the top positions and even some of the weird sideways ones.

title: A Lifelong Dream
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on The Tonight Show With Conan OBrien on NBC: Hosting The Tonight Show has been the fulfillment of a lifelong dream to me. And I want to say to the kids out there watching, you can do anything you want in life unless Jay Leno wants to do it, too.

title: Finally Found a Job
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: Theres a new book out about the most recent U.S. presidential campaign. In the book, it says Sarah Palin was unprepared to be vice president. And I thought, boy, you think you know somebody.

title: Photographing Afghan Girls
description: In the following post, Adam Ferguson recounts his experience photographing Afghan schoolgirls while on a recent assignment for The New York Times.

title: Roosting in a Cozy Chicken Coop (but Eggs Come From the Store)
description: KINGSTON, N.Y.  Tripp Hanson, a former Broadway actor, had a rough year in 2007. He and his longtime partner broke up, a close friend died, and he was starting a second career as an acupuncturist.

title: One Day in California
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: Well, some good news from Afghanistan. Did you hear about this? Critics of the war have stopped referring to it as another Vietnam. The bad news? Theyre now calling it another NBC.

title: Haiti
description: I havent written anything about the disaster, because I have nothing but the obvious to say. Yes, some people are crazy, but thats not news. As far as one can tell, those with the power to help are doing all they can. One can only hope that enough help arrives fast enough to avoid the second-round calamities  deaths due to lack of food and water and/or disease  that can all too easily follow a natural disaster.

title: Steins Law, New Application
description: Steins Law: If something cannot go on forever, it will stop.

title: On Our Radar
description: 1) Prospects are fading for climate legislation in the United States this year.

title: What Retirees Would Have Done Differently
description: Money isnt everything, according to a group of affluent Americans surveyed by Merrill Lynch Wealth Management. Focusing on family and friends, it turns out, gained in importance through the recession.

title: Russians See More Than Expected in Avatar
description: For those of you keeping score at home, the list of people, groups and nations that do not like Avatar include social and political conservatives; anticolonialists; antismoking advocates; the Vatican and China. To that list of detractors you can now add Russian filmgoers, who say the James Cameron movie too closely resembles a literary science-fiction series by the authors Arkady and Boris Strugatsky. The Guardian has reported that the Russian newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda ran an article on Monday comparing Avatar to the Strugatskys Noon Universe books: both take place in the 22nd century on Pandora, and the alien species in Avatar is called the Navi, while Noon Universe chronicles a race called the Nave. In the newspaper Novaya Gazeta, Dmitry Bykov wrote that some elements of Avatar were unequivocally reminiscent of the Noon Universe novels, and told The Guardian that the film is harmful for western civilization. But The Guardian reported that the surviving Strugatsky brother, Boris, had not yet seen Avatar, and that he played down any reports that he was accusing Mr. Cameron of plagiarism.

title: 5 Ways to Teach About Haiti Right Now
description: Yesterday we posted past Learning Network lesson plans that can be adapted for teaching about Haiti, along with links to New York Times resources.

title: Foreclosures Draw Flippers, Study Shows
description: Many New York City residential properties that reach the final phases of foreclosure and are auctioned off are bought by investors who flip them for a profit, rather than by buyers who intend to live in them.

description: The Christmas Day bombing attempt has caused Americans to take a tougher attitude toward national security, according to a new poll conducted by the Quinnipiac University Polling Institute.

title: A Parents Haitian Nightmare
description: Before I had children, my recurring nightmares were about missing a final exam or driving in a blinding snowstorm with faulty wipers. In the years since my sons were born, my worst nights are spent dreaming that they are trapped and hurt, and that I cant reach them. I had that dream last night. Then my alarm radio woke me to the sound of an infant girl wailing in pain in Port-au-Prince, her father helpless in the face of her split scalp and broken legs.

title: Avatards
description: Fervent fans of James Camerons movie Avatar.

title: Travel Deals: Two Nights in a Hotel Near D.C. for $201

title: Jay Reatard, 29, a Force in Punk Rock, Is Dead
description: Jimmy Lee Lindsey Jr., a prolific songwriter who, under the stage name Jay Reatard, was a force in the worlds of punk and garage rock, was found dead in his home in Memphis early on Wednesday. He was 29.

title: New Names and Faces at Southern Cal
description: The college football circus has officially moved to Los Angeles, with Lane Kiffins introduction as Southern Californias football coach, celebrated immediately by the first suspicions of recruiting wrongdoing and the debate over whether the Kiffins really call their 1-year-old son Monte or Knox, as they had so smarmily announced when he was born and the Kiffins were claiming Tennessee allegiance. Things had just about reached the depths of absurdity when a store owner in Knoxville finally injected some perspective, urging angry Tennessee fans to return Kiffin T-shirts so they could be sent with relief supplies to earthquake-stricken Haiti.

title: Sharpton Invites Ford on Trip to Haiti
description: For a noncandidate, Harold E. Ford Jr. is acting an awful lot like a full-fledged contender in New Yorks Senate race.

Under-20 (World Junior) Championship tournament earlier this month in Saskatoon, we spoke with Scott Monaghan, the director of hockey operations for the U.S. Team, which was excerpted in the Slap Shot column in last Sundays Times. Here is the full transcript of that interview.

title: Comments Are Dead! Long Live Comments!
description: Starting with this post, Paper Cuts is using a new commenting system. Readers of other Times blogs may be familiar with the new regime already, as it has quietly annexed many of our brethren. Its also the same interface used for commenting on news articles.

title: Should American Idol Abolish Its Age Limits?
description: Now that weve all had a good laugh at with Larry Platt, the creator and performer of Pants on the Ground, wed like to get serious for a moment. Unless the American Idol producers are feeling especially charitable, or certain Web sites keep promoting Mr. Platt relentlessly, we most likely have seen the sexagenarian superstar on the show for the last time. As commenters like Zaglossus and David have pointed out, Mr. Platt is technically not permitted to compete on American Idol, which allows performers only between the ages of 16 and 28 to participate. At 63, Mr. Platts eligibility ran out in 1975.

title: Democratic Leaders Reach Compromise on Taxing Health Plans
description: The White House and Congressional leaders have reached a tentative deal on a proposed excise tax on high-cost, employer-sponsored insurance plans to be included in the final version of major health care legislation, according to officials familiar with the talks.

title: Black Schools Restored as Landmarks
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Until 1923, the only school in the largely black farm settlement of Pine Grove was the one hand-built by parents, a drafty wooden structure in the churchyard. Anyone who could read and write could serve as teacher. With no desks and paper scarce, teachers used painted wood for a blackboard, and an open fireplace provided flashes of warmth to the lucky students who sat close.

title: 2009: Heavenly Necci
description: By Jody Williams, chef and owner at Gottino in Manhattan.

title: 1987: Heavenly Hots
description: This recipe appeared in The Times in an article by Joanna Pruess. The recipe came from Bridge Creek Restaurant in Berkeley, Calif. A few tips: Dont cook the pancakes all the way through. You want the center to be a pocket of cream. The pancakes are so fragile that it may take a few tries to flip them. I used the thinnest, most flexible spatula I own, wedged it halfway under the pancake, letting the other half hang, then turned my wrist and gently laid it down on the other side. I recommend this over more aggressive flipping, which will tear the pancakes.

title: Recipe Redux: Heavenly Hots, 1987
description: Sometimes the name of a dish is irresistible. Ratatouille. Financiers. Mooncakes. Oysters Rockefeller. Fallen souffl. Anything confited. And my recent favorite, pudding chmeur, which translates to unemployed-person pudding. (Biscuit dough baked in maple syrup and cream, its a delight that Canadians have been keeping to themselves.)

title: Key Prosecutor in Galleon Case to Depart
description: Joshua I. Klein, a key prosecutor in the widening insider trading case involving the Galleon Group and Raj Rajaratnam, is planning to resign as an assistant United States attorney for the Southern District of New York and set up his own criminal defense firm, people close to the case told DealBook.

title: Mets Voice on Beltran Issue Will Not Be Minayas
description: The Mets will address Carlos Beltrans knee injury during a conference call at 2 p.m., Eastern, on Thursday, but General Manager Omar Minaya will not be speaking for the team. Instead it will be the assistant general manager, John Ricco.

description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

description: A drive is under way to restore as landmarks several dozen schools that were built for rural Southern blacks in the early 20th century.

title: LaRoche Signs With Diamondbacks; Sheets to Show Off
description: The remaining free agent market continues to dry up as Adam LaRoche, one of the top offensive options left, has reportedly agreed to terms with the Arizona Diamondbacks. SI.com has the deal at one-year, between $4 million and $5 million.

title: The Bratwursts and Strudels of Yore
description: Few places in New York City would boast about serving sour meat and foamy beer. But in Yorkville, the Upper East Sides easternmost stretch, some establishments proudly serve sauerbraten, a pickled pot roast, while others cultivate pouring sudsy booze. This German fare is a holdover from what was once a thriving ethnic enclave in the 19th century (there was even a German-language movie theater on 86th Street between Second and Third Avenues). The Second Avenue subway will not be finished until 2015 or later, so youll have to walk from the 86th Street stop of the Lexington Avenue line to Second Avenue to visit some of the last few outposts of German Manhattan.

title: China Snaps Up California Solar Market
description: Chinas rise as a major solar module maker has been meteoric, but perhaps nowhere has its ascension been faster than in California, the United States largest solar market.

title: Proposals Clash on States Roles in Health Plans
description: Should someone in Idaho or Nevada have significantly different health care coverage from someone in Massachusetts?

title: Answers About Improv Everywhere, Part 2
description: Editors note, April 2: a few weeks after this feature appeared, Charlie Todd of Improv Everywhere lied to City Room repeatedly as we questioned him on whether one of his stunts was an April Fools hoax (it was). While the unwritten laws of the Internet prevent us from taking these posts down, we cant vouch for anything he says here.

title: The Fine Print Behind Googles Nexus One
description: I really like the Nexus One, Googles first phone. Its got some glitches, as I noted in my review, but in general, its a fast, sleek, powerful app phone. And its cool that Google is trying to bring its shake-things-up approach to the corrupt, calcified cellphone industry.

description: I really like the Nexus One, Google's first phone. It's got some glitches, as I noted in my review, but in general, it's a fast, sleek, powerful app phone. And it's cool that Google is trying to bring its shake-things-up approach to the corrupt, calcified cellphone industry.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Selanne Lost to Ducks, and Maybe Finland, With Jaw Fracture
description: Terrible news for Finland in the game Wednesday at Anaheim. Teemu Selanne, one of the two greatest players in Finnish history, went down with a fractured jaw and is doubtful for the Olympics next month. Speculation in Finland  if Selanne cant go, Carolinas Jussi Jokinen will be elevated to the squad.

description: Pardon me if I fail to squeeze out a tear for Conan OBrien.

title: Senator Grassley Joins the Cost Conversation
description: At the crux of the debate over major health care legislation is the question of why health care in America is so expensive  or to be more precise, why the cost of medical care has been growing far faster than the cost of everything else. It is far outpacing regular inflation and threatening to bust not only the federal budget but the finances of individuals and families as well.

title: And the Winner is  T!
description: To those who claim theres no accounting for taste, we offer the following accounting: nine. Thats the number of recent T Magazine subjects  from the gouge-my-eyes-out-shes-so-freaking-gorgeous Marion Cotillard to Quentin I spell like a third-grader Tarantino  who have been nominated for Golden Globes this year.

title: After a Death, Embracing Lifes Diversity
description: CORINNE BAILEY RAES fans were worried about her. Onstage at the Hiro Ballroom in New York in December, dressed in a slinky Alexander McQueen jumpsuit, this English singer-songwriter was so thin, her baby-blue guitar weighed heavily on her petite frame. Standing 5 feet 2 inches with a wild halo of curly hair, she looked a decade younger than her 30 years. By the time she began to play The Sea, a powerful meditation on grief, it was enough to make the crowd feel protective.
