title: Choreographers Second Chance at a First Time
description: HE is Russian, his name is Alexey, and he is creating a new piece for the New York City Ballet. But his last name is not Ratmansky, as balletomanes might assume. He is Alexey Miroshnichenko, and he has the unusual distinction of having already made an unseen ballet for the company. When Mr. Miroshnichenkos Lady With the Little Dog opens on Wednesday night at the David H. Koch Theater, it will be his second work and first premiere for City Ballet.

title: What a Character! Comparing Literary Adaptations
description: Overview | How do literary characters evolve in various portrayals? How do these variations affect our understanding of the characters? In this lesson, students consider numerous portrayals of the same character to examine what gives characters lasting power and why and how they evolve over time.

description: N.C.A.A. institutions are expected to vote Friday on a measure that could knock sand volleyball  the popular outdoor cousin of indoor volleyball  off a list of emerging sports seeking full championship status.

description: The first New York revival of Angels in America, Tony Kushners landmark play about politics, AIDS and love, will begin preview performances at the Signature Theater Company on Sept. 14 and open in late October with tickets priced at $20, Signatures leaders announced on Thursday afternoon.

title: No Olympic Comeback for Switzerlands Gut
description: The Swiss skier Lara Gut announced Thursday that she had not recovered from a hip injury and would miss the Vancouver Olympics.

title: The D.I.Y. Book Tour
description: I arrived early  Im always early  at a house in Chesterfield, Va., a short drive from Richmond, down the Powhite Parkway. It was the 15th city Id been to promoting my new book, The Adderall Diaries. I had given a reading the night before at a home in a nearby town, and when I mentioned Chesterfield people made sour faces. But I go where Im invited.

This German fare is a holdover from what was once a thriving ethnic enclave in the 19th century (there was even a German-language movie theater on 86th Street between Second and Third Avenues). description: Former Congressman Harold Ford Jr. has yet to make official a primary bid against Senator Kirsten Gillibrand in New York. But by raising his hand and expressing interest, he has unleashed a torrent of opposition among liberal Democrats, bloggers and activists who are mining his every quote. Never mind that the New York media have yet to move into full-blown, old-style tabloid gear, either.

title: Far-Ranging Support for Googles China Move
description: BEIJING  Googles surprising decision this week to abandon cooperation with Chinese government censors  and, possibly, its four-year effort to do business here  is galvanizing an unusually broad coalition of foreigners who hope for a fresh chance to rein in the conduct of an emerging great power.

title: Volcker Defends Fed Role in Financial Oversight
description: The Federal Reserve must have a strong voice and authority on regulatory matters, Paul A. Volcker, an economic adviser to President Obama, said Thursday.

title: Postcard From London: Sucking Blood
description: The adolescent craving to turn into a vampire did not, it seems, originate with the Twilight books. This is made evident by the National Theaters icy revival of Ferdinand Bruckners Pains of Youth, a 1923 play in which some lively young things of Vienna want nothing so much as to be dead. One of them speaks of the ecstasy of being made love to by a man who sucks at her skin as if he wants her blood. This is the same man, a hypnotically handsome chap with bad feet and a rotting liver, who diagnoses his friends futures as a matter of either bourgeois existence or suicide: there are no other choices.

title: The Bay Area Reaches Out to Help Haiti
description: Although the Bay Area has only a small Haitian community (numbering about 3,000 by some counts, according to The Mercury News), the reaction felt by many here has transcended national and regional ties. People want to help.

title: Tight Ends Pose a Bigger Receiving Headache for Defenses
description: INDIANAPOLIS  When Mike Ditka played for the Chicago Bears in the 1960s, he took great pride in blocking for running back Gale Sayers. Tight ends then were used mostly like another tackle. Their primary job was to wall off the edge of the defense for the most important offensive weapon of the time: the runners. But the Bears coach, George Halas, had other ideas. He sometimes put space between Ditka and the offensive line, making Ditka one of the first tight ends to split out a bit and become a receiving threat. As a rookie in 1961, Ditka was the teams leading receiver, catching 56 passes for 1,076 yards. In 1964, he caught 75 passes.

description: The NBC comedy set in a community college returns for its second semester.

title: Is Pentagons Haiti Mission a Model for a New Security Role?

One of the largest vessels, the Carl Vinson, is seen below in Navy footage in its first deployment in nearly five years  to the earthquake zone in Haiti instead of a war zone.

title: Other Voices, Other Selves
description: To write critically in English, Zadie Smith asserts in the opening essay of Changing My Mind, is to aspire to neutrality, to the high style of, say, Lionel Trilling or Edmund Wilson. Praising Zora Neale Hurston, Smith complains that the mandarin critical mode elevates the experiences of white people to the norm while making black women talking about a black book look sectarian. Smiths own way of escaping this narrow assumption is to declare boldly, Fact is, I am a black woman. A writer like Hurston, Smith adds, makes  black woman-ness appear a real, tangible quality, an essence I can almost believe I share, however improbably, with millions of complex individuals. Hurston also allows Smith to say things I wouldnt normally  things like She is my sister and I love her.

title: Regulator Imposes More Limits on Speculative Trading
description: Federal regulators said on Thursday that they would impose hard limits on energy futures contracts held by commodity traders, part of a move to curb excessive speculation and possibly avoid a repeat of the 2008 run-up in oil prices.

title: Team Edward a No-Show at the Oscars?
description: Poor Adam Shankman. The choreographer and Oscar producer is apparently dealing with the unthinkable: the possibility that Robert Pattinson will be unable to attend the ceremony. Scenario: what of, due to scheduling, pats isnt avail? Shall we Go Stewart. And lautner ? Or no twilighters, he posted on Twitter a few hours ago.

title: Israel Raids Polygamist Compound
description: JERUSALEM  An Israeli who lived openly with at least 17 women and fathered dozens of children was ordered into court on Thursday on suspicion of enslavement, sexual abuse and possible rape.

title: Pictures of the Day: Thursday, Jan. 14
description: This is not an easy show to look at. It is not intended to be. The first four photographs out of Haiti, by Damon Winter of The New York Times, chronicle something of the scope of devastation, the depth of grief and the stillness of death. Viewers are cautioned that the fifth slide, by Juan Barreto, is an especially disturbing picture of an injured child.

title: Back to Its Old Brownstone Self
description: WALK down any street of brownstones, and chances are the history you see is fiction, because the typical restoration for old brownstone facades is a nice new coat of stucco. But the case of the old row house at 797 Madison Avenue is one of sedimentary nonfiction, where the usual brownstone repair has been foresworn for, well, brownstone.

title: C.F.T.C. Seeks to Curb Speculative Energy Trading
description: Federal regulators said Thursday that they would impose hard limits on energy futures contracts held by commodity traders, part of a move to curb excessive speculation and avoid a repeat of the 2008 run-up in oil prices, Jad Mouawad of The New York Times reports.

title: More on the Deal to Tax Health Insurance
description: Look, up in the sky! There it is! About to float behind that cloud  its the Democrats big trial balloon on a deal with organized labor leaders over a proposed excise tax on high-cost, employer-sponsored health insurance plans.

title: Weight Issues Around the World
description: Is the United States the only country worried about its collective weight? A new Readers Digest survey has analyzed responses from 16,000 people in 16 countries to find out what people around the world think about weight. Here are some of the findings:

title: Tracking US Airways Flight 1549
description: An animated depiction of the flights path from LaGuardia Airport to its crash landing in the Hudson.

title: OBrien Continues to Book Top Guests for Tonight
description: Conan OBrien may not be keeping The Tonight Show much longer, but he may be getting some good company.

title: A Tax by Any Other Name
description: The Obama administration today released details of its plan to collect a new bank tax.

title: Sam Shepard: The Highwayman
description: For Sam Shepard, the prizewinning playwright and short-story writer (and sometime Hollywood actor) whose work might be characterized as Grass-Roots Gothic, infused as it is with a sense of folksy madness and populist brutality, the American landscape is a sprawling cemetery, a field of bad dreams spread out between two oceans. Its markers, commemorating acts of violence that seem to repeat themselves through the generations in a cruel infinity loop, consist of dark highways stretching to the horizon. Under them lies a dense matrix of remains. The bones of Plains Indians, Confederate soldiers, hard-luck homesteaders and hellbound drunks mix in a democratic necropolis capped by thousands of miles of oily blacktop. These routes, which for some writers promise liberation  an escape into unbounded freedom and possibility  are, for Shepard, roads of no return. Laid out north and south and east and west, they all lead in the same direction: down.

title: Excerpt: '24'
description: The eighth season of the Fox thriller is set in New York.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Report Finds 9 Million Illegal Downloads of E-Books
description: A study by a company that helps track pirated digital books for publishing companies estimates that there were 9 million illegal downloads of copyrighted books in the final months of last year.

title: Film Series and Movie Listings
description: MOVIES

title: Rally Round the Fed
description: It was less than two years ago, in a speech to the Economic Club of New York, that Paul Volcker ruffled feathers by questioning whether the Fed was exceeding its authority in bailouts. Tim Geithner, then the president of the New York Fed, chose to give a speech in reply.

title: Ford Already a Target for Liberal Groups
description: Kate Phillips in The Caucus writes about how liberal groups have started gearing up for a New York Senate race that has yet to even formally begin.

title: The Out-of-Sight Mind
description: Invisible forces that control our behavior have inspired our best storytellers, from Euripides to Steven Spielberg. Whether were yanked around by jealous gods, Oedipal urges or poltergeists, the idea that we feel powerless to direct our own actions has a visceral appeal, one exploited by Shankar Vedantam in The Hidden Brain, his exploration of the unconscious mind.

title: U.S. Embassy Staff Evacuated From Haiti
description: A Coast Guard aircrew evacuated members of the American embassy staff in Haiti from the airport in Port-au-Prince on Thursday.

title: Only Reflect
description: Aspiring fiction writers have been reading E. M. Forsters Aspects of the Novel since it was first published in 1927. I can remember devouring it in 1960 or soon after; here was one of the greatest English novelists of the 20th century, the author of A Passage to India, divulging the secrets of the trade  or rather, expressing strong but always courteous opinions about the rival merits and methods of the important novelists of the past.

title: Bank Tax: A Roundup of Reactions
description: Update | 5:18 p.m.

title: The Mets and Boras Are at Odds on Beltran
description: After experiencing sharp pain in his right knee, Carlos Beltran was examined Tuesday morning in Boulder, Colo., by Dr. Richard Steadman, a top orthopedic surgeon who concluded that Beltran should have arthroscopic surgery to repair an arthritic condition.

title: Hes Back
description: As a boy in Chippawa, Ontario, James Cameron once sent some mice over the edge of Niagara Falls in a small submersible made from old mayonnaise jars, an Erector Set and a paint bucket. Another time, he made a hot-air balloon out of a dry-cleaning bag and some candles, floating it down the street until someone reported it as a U.F.O. and called the Fire Department. Together with the young Steven Spielbergs experiments in civic alarum-raising  locking himself in the bathroom until the Phoenix Fire Department was summoned  Camerons excursions suggest two interlocking propositions: (1) If you want to know who is going to grow up to be a box-office titan, check out the records of your local Fire Department. And (2) nobody should be surprised if Balloon Boy turns into the proud auteur behind Terminator Resurrection: This Time With Feeling.

title: Erika Tarantal and Lucas Nathan
description: AS a reporter and weekend anchor in New York for WNBC-TV, Erika Tarantal goes to bed every Friday and Saturday night at 7 and wakes up at 2:40 a.m. She sleeps in a roomful of alarm clocks, surrounding her like mousetraps.

title: NBC Announces Its 10 p.m. Schedule
description: Even as it faces uncertainty about its plans for late night after the Olympics, NBC announced on Thursday changes to its 10 p.m. hour, which is being vacated by Jay Leno. The changes begin the first week in March

title: Eclipse Day Minus One
description: Jay Pasachoff follows up yesterdays dispatch with another report from India, where he and fellow astronomers are preparing to observe an exceptionally long solar eclipse Friday. Dr. Pasachoff, a professor at Williams College and author of the Peterson Field Guide to Stars and Planets, is in Kanyakumari, at the southern tip of India:

title: CF Withdraws Terra Bid; Agrium Steps Up Efforts
description: Update | 7:12 p.m. CF Industries Holdings announced Thursday afternoon that it had withdrawn its hostile offer to acquire Terra Industries, a rival fertilizer maker, ending this part of a complex, yearlong takeover battle.

title: Updated: Labor Leaders Describe Excise-Tax Deal
description: Facing intense pressure from organized labor, the Obama administration has agreed to major changes in the proposed tax on high-priced employer-sponsored health benefits. One change, according to labor leaders involved in the negotiations, is that workers covered by collective bargaining agreements, as well as state and local employees, will be exempted from the tax until 2018.

title: Election Confidential
description: In July 2006 Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, abruptly summoned Barack Obama, then a freshman senator, for a meeting. Obama, who had a cordial but not warm relationship with Reid, immediately headed for his office, remarking to his press secretary Robert Gibbs, I wonder what we screwed up. Upon Obamas arrival, Reid didnt mince words: Youre not going to go anyplace here, he said. I know that you dont like it, doing what youre doing. After the lecture, when Obama had returned, Gibbs asked if anything was amiss. Not at all, Obama replied. Harry wants me to run for president.

title: New Design Chief Hire May Signal Change for Ferrari
description: Update | 6:13 p.m.

title: The Truth (Serum) About 3-D TV
description: David Pogue tries to get to the bottom of what's driving the new trend of 3-D TVs.

title: Hug Superhero
description: Video | Look! Up in the sky! Its a weird, bearded dude who wants to get very close:

title: Final Health Care Bill to Be Available Online
description: The House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, and the majority leader, Representative Steny H. Hoyer, Democrat of Maryland, said on Thursday that the final version of major health care legislation will be posted on the Internet for 72 hours before the House votes on the measure.

title: The Face of Suffering
description: What is a nonfascist literature? Is this a question we ask ourselves, as writers or as readers, and is it answerable? To put it another way, what is a noncollusive literature? Is there a poem that isnt in negotiation, to some degree, with kings, presidents, generals and the people who hold other peoples heads under water just shy of drowning them? The easy answers are yes and no. In America, where we still jones for innocence and ruin, the intertwining of power and art hasnt generally been a preoccupation of our literature  what a photograph of a meadow might have to do with Guantnamo, whether a play about marriage is connected to the doings of the secretary of state. Joan Didions work might trace the meridians of power through private and public lives, but she is a rare breed. Oddly, despite this being one of the largest participatory democracies in the world, as a culture we are reluctant to engage with, much less obsess over, the demonstrable fact that were born implicated, that our actions and the sufferings of others are inextricably linked.

title: Help for Haiti
description: The restaurant communities in New York, Chicago, Los Angeles and other major cities are moving fast to help raise money for the Haitian earthquake relief effort, and Diners Journal will do its best to keep passing on the word as plans are made.

title: Gritty Scene, Mostly Male and White
description: What would the proverbial alien, beamed into the Grey Art Gallery for a viewing of Downtown Pix: Mining the Fales Archives, 1961-1991, discern about New York toward the end of the last millennium? Maybe this: That it was very gritty, very gay and very Caucasian.

title: Funeral Arrangements Announced for Teddy Pendergrass
description: The soul singer Teddy Pendergrass, who died on Wednesday night, will receive a public viewing in Philadelphia on Jan. 22, his press representatives said. The viewing for Mr. Pendergrass will take place at 10 a.m. at the Enon Tabernacle Baptist Church in Philadelphia. His funeral will be held there on Jan. 23 at 10 a.m., followed by his burial at West Laurel Hill Cemetery in Bala Cynwyd, Pa.

title: Blue Skies
description: America could use a truly Whiggish book right about now. More than a year into the Great Recession, it has become much harder to believe in the idea of inexorable progress. The moment is ripe for a counterintuitive, optimistic perspective that shows, despite appearances to the contrary, that the world is getting better and better every day, in every way. Gregg Easterbrook tries hard to satiate our inner optimist with Sonic Boom.

title: The Bass Art of Nukular Versification
description: Remember nucular, the pronunciation of nuclear that George W. Bush inserted into the national conversation? The ubiquitous jazz bassist and songwriting wag Jay Leonhart offered a facetiously spirited defense of nucular, which he spells Nukular, on Wednesday evening at the Metropolitan Room, where he appeared with Tedd Firth on piano and his son, Michael Leonhart, on trumpet.

title: Utah Ski Resort Offers 30-Year Ski Pass
description: The Canyons Resort in Park City, Utah, is offering a new ski pass that lasts 30 years and is transferable to the owners friends and family. But theres a catch.

title: A Guided Tour in the Palm of Your Hand
description: Design USA: Contemporary Innovation at the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum is less an exhibition than an extra-large design seminar in your head.

title: Bringing Some Whimsy to Construction Sites
description: Although it has been more than eight years since the World Trade Center attack, every day it seems there are more cranes and concrete trucks, scaffolding and chain-link fences as Lower Manhattan struggles to rebuild. According to the Alliance for Downtown New York, a nonprofit business-improvement-district group, an estimated $30 billion worth of construction is going on at 190 sites below Canal Street.

title: A Saxophone Is Her Only Constant
description: Some young jazz musicians find their style and move in lock, stock and barrel, making little refinements over the years but basically keeping their place. Ingrid Laubrock, a German saxophonist who started her career in London and has spent the last 15 years playing there, sounds happily unsettled. On tenor and soprano, shes omnivorous and pointed, slouching and precise, humorous and austere.

title: Governments Go-To Vendors Get it Done
description: GHENT, N.Y.  Here, amid her homemade pickles and jams, Nicole Corey keeps New York City agencies and those of its neighbors supplied with flock-lined latex gloves, safety vests, watches and disposable smocks.

title: The New Taurus at the Top
description: TESTED: 2010 Ford Taurus SHO

title: Theater Listings: Jan. 15  21
description: THEATER

title: Blow, Winds! Deconstruct Thy Text!
description: Certainly the playwright Young Jean Lee does not lack for chutzpah. Last season this talented writer made a heady splash on the downtown scene with The Shipment, a play about black identity politics that was audacious  coming as it did from a Korean-American  but also smart and entertaining. Now Ms. Lee has written and directed a cheeky, freaky modernist gloss on King Lear, which many consider to be Shakespeares greatest play, if not the greatest play written in the English language, if not the greatest play bar none.

title: Shadegg Announces Retirement
description: Representative John Shadegg, a seven-term Republican lawmaker from Arizona, announced today that  he would not seek reelection in 2010, joining 14 other House Republican whove called it quits this session.

title: A Window Opens on Pay for Bosses
description: Is it possible that shareholders will finally get a reliable view of what the bosses are getting paid? And that it will come this spring?

title: Education Chief Criticizes N.B.A. and the N.C.A.A.
description: ATLANTA  Education Secretary Arne Duncan entered some of the most contentious debates in college sports on Thursday when, in a speech at the N.C.A.A. convention, he called for stricter consequences for college teams that do not graduate their athletes and said the N.B.A.s age-minimum policy sets up young athletes for failure.

title: A Rebel in Cyberspace, Fighting Collectivism
description: In 2006, the artist and computer scientist Jaron Lanier published an incisive, groundbreaking and highly controversial essay about digital Maoism  about the downside of online collectivism, and the enshrinement by Web 2.0 enthusiasts of the wisdom of the crowd. In that manifesto Mr. Lanier argued that design (or ratification) by committee often does not result in the best product, and that the new collectivist ethos  embodied by everything from Wikipedia to American Idol to Google searches  diminishes the importance and uniqueness of the individual voice, and that the hive mind can easily lead to mob rule.

title: Celebrating the Tension Between Art and Science
description: The guitarist David Gilmore has a pronounced fondness for metric convolution, jigsaw complexity and a near-mystical spirit of intrigue. So it makes sense that Numerology is the name he has chosen for his new suite, created with a grant from Chamber Music America and presented at the Jazz Standard this week. With its whiffs of occult practice and brow-furrowed calculation, that title could apply to Mr. Gilmores entire body of work.

title: Art in Review
description: PRIMARY ATMOSPHERES

title: Password Unprotected
description: A good friend broke up last year with her longtime boyfriend. While they were dating, she learned the password to his e-mail account and occasionally checked his messages. Now she reads his entire in-box. As a result, she cant get over him. I know she wont stop until he changes his password. Is there any way to discreetly tell him to do so?

title: Exotic Tastes of the Big Island
description: Hilo, Hawaii  CHERIMOYA, calamansi, rainbow papaya. Puna ricotta, poha berries, lilikoi. Lava salsa, dinosaur kale, Hamakua mushrooms. This is the exotic-food litany on the lips of pilgrims who go to the Hilo Farmers Market, held twice a week on the lush eastern side of the Big Island.

title: Social Realism in a Poetic Lens
description: IN Andrea Arnolds new film, Fish Tank, an unsmiling 15-year-old named Mia (Katie Jarvis), who lives in a housing project in Essex, in England, becomes close to the boyfriend of her uncaring mother. The man, an Irish charmer named Connor, played by Michael Fassbender, gives her money and lends her his video camera so that she can tape herself dancing to hip-hop. It soon becomes apparent that the relationship between Mia and Connor is becoming dangerously intimate.

title: Breathtaking Panoramas
description: THE Big Islands Kona-Kohala Coast in Hawaii, a stretch of about 35 miles of northwest shoreline, isnt free of resorts and private communities, but there are far fewer than one might expect. In part this is the result of pressure at both local and state levels to stop the overbuilding that characterized development in places like Honolulu and the island of Maui. The developments here promote their open spaces and low-density building plans as thoughtful efforts to respect the land, noting that these efforts add value to their real estate by limiting inventory and offering breathtaking views.

title: Tea Party Ticket Troubles
description: The planning for headliner guests like Sarah Palin and for media coverage at the Tea Party Nation convention in Nashville next month seems to be in a state of flux these days.

title: Bernanke Defends Feds Oversight Role
description: Facing renewed calls from Washington to limit its authority, the Federal Reserve on Thursday defended its role as one of Wall Streets chief watchdogs and said being able to monitor the health of banks was crucial to setting sound monetary policy.

title: How Do You Get to the Big Apple Circus? Practice, Practice
description: The Big Apple Circus continues through Monday in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center; (888) 541-3750, bigapplecircus.org.

title: Prosecutor in Galleon Case Plans to Set Up His Own Firm
description: Joshua I. Klein, an important prosecutor in the widening insider-trading case involving the Galleon Group and its founder, Raj Rajaratnam, is planning to resign to set up his own criminal defense firm, people close to the case said on Thursday.

title: The Fine Print Behind Googles Nexus One
description: David Pogue says that Google is imposing an early termination fee for people who cancel service with the phone  in addition to any early termination fee that the carrier would impose.

title: A Space Opera in a Proper Galaxy
description: IN 2001 Gotham Chamber Opera opened its doors at the Abrons Arts Center on the Lower East Side of Manhattan with what was billed as the American stage premiere of the teenage Mozarts moral allegory Il Sogno di Scipione, set in the Temple of Heaven. Now, after nine years spent establishing a repertory of rarities from Monteverdi to Piazzolla, the company is preparing its next space adventure. The vehicle this time is Haydns comedy Il Mondo Della Luna (The World on the Moon), to be presented, with unassailable if quixotic logic, in the Hayden Planetarium at the American Museum of Natural History beginning on Tuesday evening.

title: M.P.G. Standards Loom, So Designers Look Afar
description: DETROIT

title: In This World, It Pays to Be a Loner
description: A road warrior of a different sort, the title character played by Denzel Washington in The Book of Eli spends much of the story traveling by foot across an eerie landscape, a long and quick knife at the ready. The brown, dusty environs look familiar and not, dotted with abandoned cars and the occasional corpse. When Eli pauses, the camera settles near his feet, and the sky opens above him like a sheltering hand. With his green jacket and unsmiling mouth, he looks like a veteran of an unknown war, a soldier of misfortune  though, given the fog of religiosity that hangs over the movie, he might be an avenging angel.

title: Gaining a Minute in the Race Against Time
description: We can all relax: were a minute further from doomsday than previously thought, according to a group of engineers, scientists, scholars and security specialists tracking prospects that humans might do themselves in.

title: Ex-U.N. Weapons Inspector Is Charged in Child-Sex Sting
description: A former chief United Nations weapons inspector in Iraq has been charged in Pennsylvania with engaging in online sexual exchanges with a minor.

title: Another Terrorist Plot, Another Very Long Day
description: A lot of secret agents have popped up on television since Jack Bauer first saved the day in 2001. None of them is nearly as intense, of course.

title: The Nifty 50 | Paul Kahan, Chef
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Earthquake in Haiti Spurs Stars to Action
description: The mobile communications company that is working with the musician Wyclef Jean (above, arriving in Port-au-Prince on Wednesday) to raise money for disaster relief in Haiti said on Thursday that it had raised more than $750,000 in donations since its campaign began on Tuesday. In a news release, Give on the Go, the fund-raising division of the Miami company Red Fish Media, said its goal was to raise more than $1 million daily. The campaign allows users of mobile devices to make an instant donation of $5 to Mr. Jeans Yle Haiti foundation, a relief charity, by texting Yele to 501501. (The charge appears on the users phone bill.) In a statement, Matt McKenna, president of Red Fish, said 100 percent of the donations go to the charity. Mr. Jean has tirelessly promoted the campaign on his Twitter account. Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt are among the other notable names who are contributing to relief efforts. In a statement on Wednesday, they said their Jolie-Pitt Foundation would give $1 million to the emergency medical operations of Doctors Without Borders/Mdecins Sans Frontires, which is responding to the devastation in Haiti.

title: Injured Actor Departs View From the Bridge
description: The actor Santino Fontana, below, who had been playing the key role of Rodolpho in previews of the Broadway revival of A View From the Bridge, said he was leaving the show to make a full recovery from an onstage injury that resulted in a concussion. His understudy, Morgan Spector, who has been standing in since Jan. 7, will take over the role. Rodolpho is an Italian immigrant who has entered the United States illegally and draws the ire of Eddie Carbone (played by Liev Schrieber) for courting his niece (Scarlett Johansson). While Mr. Fontana initially was believed to have been injured in a boxing scene between Rodolpho and Eddie, people involved with the production now say that he suffered the injury in another scene over New Years weekend. In the statement, Mr. Fontana said, Knowing that I would not be fully recovered and able to return until after opening, Ive chosen to withdraw with great respect to my fellow actors and to my own health. Gregory Mosher, the director, said in the statement: Santino is a wonderful actor; well miss him, and we are tremendously grateful for his selflessness in this difficult situation. But I have every confidence in Morgan. View is to open Jan. 24.

title: Moynihan Letters to Be Published
description: Letters, journals and other correspondence written by Daniel Patrick Moynihan, below left, over the course of his half-century career in public service will be published this year. On Wednesday, PublicAffairs said it would release a book culled from more than 10,000 pages of letters written by Mr. Moynihan, the former senator from New York, during his time on Capitol Hill and in the administrations of Presidents Kennedy, Johnson, Nixon and Ford. In an e-mail message, PublicAffairs said the letters in the book, which does not yet have a title, would cover the 1950s to Mr. Moynihans death in 2003, and would reveal his thoughts on matters including the civil rights movement, the Vietnam War, health care, urban planning and the United Nations. Among the noteworthy recipients of Mr. Moynihans correspondence were Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, Indira Gandhi, Chaim Herzog, William F. Buckley Jr. and Alexander Solzhenitsyn. The book is to be edited by Steven R. Weisman, a former staff member of The New York Times, who is now the editorial director and public policy fellow at the Peter G. Peterson Institute for International Economics in Washington.

title: For Russians, Avatar Seems a Little Familiar
description: For those of you keeping score at home, the list of people, groups and nations that do not like Avatar include social and political conservatives, anticolonialists, antismoking advocates, the Vatican and China. To that list you can now add Russian filmgoers, who say the James Cameron movie too closely resembles a literary science-fiction series by Arkady and Boris Strugatsky. The Guardian reported that the Russian newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda ran an article on Monday comparing Avatar to the Strugatskys Noon Universe books: both take place in the 22nd century on Pandora, and the alien species in Avatar is called the Navi, while Noon Universe chronicles a race called the Nave. In the newspaper Novaya Gazeta, Dmitry Bykov wrote that some elements of Avatar were unequivocally reminiscent of the Noon Universe novels, and told The Guardian that the film is harmful for western civilization. But The Guardian reported that the surviving Strugatsky brother, Boris, had not yet seen Avatar, and that he played down any reports that he was accusing Mr. Cameron of plagiarism.

title: Win (and Loss) for Idol
description: Night two of American Idol lifted Fox to No. 1 in the ratings by a wide margin on Wednesday. According to Nielsens estimates, the reality show drew an average of 26.3 million viewers, down from the 29.9 million who watched the season premiere on Tuesday. It was followed on Fox by a repeat of the 450th episode of The Simpsons (8.1 million). CBS ranked second, drawing low ratings for its comedies The New Adventures of Old Christine (6.3 million) and Gary Unmarried (5.8 million), but better results for its crime shows Criminal Minds (14 million) and CSI: NY (14.1 million). NBC was third with Mercy (6 million), Law & Order: SVU (7.7 million) and The Jay Leno Show (5.4 million). ABCs lineup of comedies finished the night in fourth place.

title: Voicing Opinion on Next Vols Coach
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  An on-line poll conducted by The Knoxville News-Sentinel asked fans to declare who they would want as the next head coach and it had the usual suspect as the leader: the Texas defensive coordinator Will Muschamp. He had 8,200 votes.

title: Method Walking
description: Ben Foster likes to take walks  long, meandering ones. Theyre how he clears his head and gets into character. Preparing for his role as a still-jumpy Army sergeant charged with delivering news of casualties in The Messenger, he marched around New York, where hes only just moved after many years in California. Id walk for hours and hours for about two months every night, he said, looking at windows and cars, these abandoned cars, and allowing those cars and windows to become threats. So someones in that window and shoots you, you have to be prepared. Its a constant readiness.

title: Union Bolsters Its Roster in M.L.S. Draft
description: There have been 45 55 were 64 players selected in the Major League Soccer SuperDraft  so far over four rounds. (What exactly is so super about it?) The first overall pick by the Philadelphia Union, the leagues newest club, was Danny Mwanga, an 18-year-old forward who scored 14 goals as a sophomore at Oregon State last season.

title: The Destruction in Port-au-Prince
description: View satellite photos that show Port-au-Prince before and after the Jan. 12 earthquake.

title: Defensive Coordinator Is First Casualty in New England Fallout
description: The fallout from the New England Patriots one-and-done postseason has begun: Dean Pees will not return as defensive coordinator after four years on the job.

title: Republicans and Health Insurance
description: In her column today, Gail Collins goes into what she calls a rant.

title: Finally, Some Electricity in the Air
description: DETROIT

title: Iconic Checker Cab Company Shuts Down
description: It has been more than a decade since the last old Checker cab disappeared from the citys taxi ranks and nearly three decades since the last new cab rolled off the production line.

title: A Reckless Teenager, Seeking Solitude Yet Craving Connection
description: Mia, the 15-year-old protagonist of Fish Tank, Andrea Arnolds tough and brilliant second feature, moves with such speed and fury that she seems to be trying to flee not only from her bleak surroundings but also from the movie itself. The narrow, nearly square frame boxes Mia in, and Ms. Arnolds on-the-run hand-held tracking shots increase the sense of panicky claustrophobia. Living in a cramped apartment in a British housing project that stands like a cluster of megaliths in the middle of nowhere, Mia is at once trapped and adrift, unable to contain or to express the feelings seething beneath the blank, sullen mien she usually presents to the world.

title: From a Troubled Past, Into the Line of Fire
description: Human Target, beginning on Sunday night on Fox, has an unusually small set of regular characters. Through the first two episodes there are just three: Chance and Winston (Mark Valley and Chi McBride), partners in an unconventional security firm, and Guerrero (Jackie Earle Haley), the shady figure they employ to hack into corporate and government computer systems.

title: Names Fall Away in Vols Coaching Search
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  The news is being monitored from Kingsport to Memphis. Who is going to be the next Tennessee football coach to replace Lane Kiffin?

title: Can Idol Still Churn Out Stars? Time Will Tell
description: With a rush of publicity over the departure of Simon Cowell, American Idol returned this week for a ninth season, promising once again to introduce the next batch of fresh-faced pop stars.

title: On Vacation and Looking for Wi-Fi
description: FOR several years, our extended family  19 of us  has taken a holiday vacation in the tropics. Typically we go to an all-inclusive resort.

title: Roundup of Reaction to Obamas Bank Tax
description: Over at Economix, Catherine Rampell has a roundup of some of the reaction so far to President Obamas bank tax proposal. Here is a sampling:

title: Teddy Pendergrass, R&B Soul Singer, Dies at 59
description: Teddy Pendergrass, the Philadelphia soul singer whose husky, potent baritone was one definition of R&B seduction in the 1970s but whose career was transformed in 1982 when he was severely paralyzed in an auto accident, died on Wednesday night in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 59.

title: Floridas Deep Freeze
description: A two-week cold spell was the longest in decades.

title: Obama Seeks to Reassure House Democrats
description: Like most political junkies, President Obama said he keeps an eye on the blogs and the cable shows. So, he assured anxious House Democrats on Thursday, he fully understands what they have been going through in the tumultuous health care debate.

title: McAfee Says Microsoft Flaw Was a Factor in Cyberattacks
description: Update | 1/15/10 11:57 a.m.  Clarifying that versions 6, 7, and 8 of Internet Explorer have the security flaw.

title: Gran Turismo 5 Delayed Yet Again
description: For those video gamers who have waited patiently (or not so patiently) for nearly five years for the next installment of the esteemed racing simulation series Gran Turismo for Sony PlayStation, whats another (fill in a number from one to 10  then add months or years)?

title: Waiting for Flexible Displays and Flexible Devices
description: Reports appeared online Friday of a new 19-inch flexible display that LG hopes to start integrating into new devices.

title: For These 3, the Audacity of Nope
description: Here we are on yet another holiday weekend dedicated to celebrating the life and work of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., examining racial progress already made, and reflecting on how much remains to be done.

title: On Stage: Aziz Ansari
description: An excerpt from the the comic's special, "Intimate Moments for a Sensual Moments," which premiered on Comedy Central in January.

title: Senators Urge Fail-Safe Provision in Case Savings Dont Appear
description: Five Democratic senators urged the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, on Thursday to include a fail-safe mechanism in the final version of major health care legislation in order to guarantee the hundreds of billions of dollars in projected government savings that are intended to help pay for the bill.

title: If California Owes You, It Would Like to Pay You
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Somewhere high in the snowy, mountainous wilds of Alpine County, Calif., there is a Californian with a piece of paper worth $1,305.

title: Watch Out for That Disembodied Head, Girls
description: Delirious, deranged, gonzo or just gone, baby, gone  no single adjective or even a pileup does justice to House, a 1977 Japanese haunted-house freakout. Directed by Nobuhiko Obayashi, this energetic exemplar of pulp surrealism began surfacing in the United States last year, playing at events like the New York Asian Film Festival. Now, in advance of the Criterion DVD, which will be released later this year, it is receiving its first, must-see-now domestic theatrical run at the IFC Center in New York. A midnight movie in lysergic spirit and vibe, this was a film made for late-night screening and screaming.

title: Whats That? 50 Degrees Isnt Winter? Tell That to the People Shivering Here
description: NEW DELHI  Behind the counter of J & J Trading Company, an appliance wholesaler in a warren of electrical shops in Old Delhi, Rajinder Singh has no patience for customer service. A man eyeing the Turbo Hot Air asks for a test. Could the small metal heater be plugged in? Buy it first, Mr. Singh demands.

title: Seven Years for a Lawyer
description: Remember Refco? That was a big scandal awhile back. In 2005, we learned that the owner of Refco, the commodities firm, had successfully hidden huge losses for years. The investors who bought the companys public offering were the big losers.

title: Big Brother and the Salt Shaker
description: The Bloomberg administration has announced an initiative to cut salt in packaged and restaurant foods by 25 percent over the next five years. Public health experts say these changes would reduce the incidence of high blood pressure and help prevent some strokes and heart attacks.

title: Wall Street Gives Millions to Haiti Relief Efforts
description: As Haitians continue to reel from the massive earthquake that reduced much of its capital to rubble and killed an estimated tens of thousands of people, Wall Street firms are among those pledging millions of dollars to relief efforts.

title: Time-Traveling With the Muses in Boston
description: BOSTON  You love art. When and where did that start? In school? At home? In books? For me it began when I was a kid in the 1950s and 60s, before and during my teens. The primal scene was divided between two Boston museums where I spent a lot of time. I visited both again last week to check memory against reality and got a surprise: sometimes they match up.

title: Toppled in Ukraine but Nearing a Comeback
description: DNEPRODZERZHINSK, Ukraine  Viktor F. Yanukovich was swept aside five years ago in the Orange Revolution, derided as a barrel-chested party boss and Kremlin stooge whose career was over as Ukraine embraced the West.

title: Moving Through 'Fish Tank'
description: Katie Jarvis is featured in this dance scene from "Fish Tank," written and directed by Andrea Arnold

title: Oscar Mayer Counts on the Joy, Not the Jingles
description: OSCAR MAYER, which has two of the most famous advertising jingles, is pushing them to the side as it introduces its biggest campaign to date.

title: Google Move Gives Hope to Lawmakers
description: A quartet of House Republicans commended Google on Thursday for threatening to pull out of China earlier this week, saying the companys actions could help spark the passage of legislation that aims to loosen the ties between American technology firms and countries that restrict human rights.

title: Newspapers, Wire Services Add Staff in Haiti
description: With very few of their journalists based in Haiti and the countrys main airport closed to most flights after a major earthquake on Tuesday, most Western news organizations were caught out of place by the disaster. They resorted to chartering flights, asking for space on relief flights and even hitching rides with individual motorists. In most cases, they did not reach the devastated areas until the next day.

title: Antitrust Questions for Monsanto
description: The Monsanto Company, the worlds largest seed producer, said on Thursday that the Justice Department had formally requested information on its herbicide-tolerant soybean seed business as part of an investigation into anticompetitive practices.

title: For TV Networks, Haiti Story Brings Huge Mobilization
description: The Fox News correspondent Steve Harrigan is a veteran of the worlds worst calamities, but on television Thursday afternoon, as he stood beside one of the piles of rubble that pockmark Port-au-Prince, Haiti, he broke down.

title: Reader Comments
description: Starting with this post, On the Runway is using a new commenting system. Readers of other Times blogs may be familiar with the new regime already, as it has quietly annexed many of our brethren. Its also the same interface used for commenting on news articles.

title: One Day at a Time
description: Mr. Pfeiffer discusses his morning routine and his role as White House blogger.

title: Shiseido to Buy Bare Escentuals for $1.7 Billion
description: Shiseido said late Thursday that it has agreed to buy Bare Escentuals for $1.7 billion in cash, landing the Japanese cosmetics giant one of the biggest players in the world of mineral makeup.

title: Fighting Illiteracy in Chicago, With Enthusiasm
description: Twice a month, Ava Zeligson stands in front of 55 strangers and, with her infectious enthusiasm, explains why each of them can make a difference in the battle against Chicagos deeply entrenched illiteracy rate.

title: Russian Attitudes Thaw on Rights Court
description: MOSCOW  The Russian Parliament is expected Friday to reverse its longstanding opposition to reforms in the European Court of Human Rights, as part of a new push to smooth over differences with the countrys European partners.

title: Jordan: Israeli Vehicle Attacked
description: An Israeli Embassy vehicle was the target of a roadside bomb in Jordan on Thursday, but the explosion caused no injuries, the Israeli Foreign Ministry said. Several Israeli diplomats were heading in a convoy from Amman toward the border with Israel, Israels Army Radio reported. Jordans public information minister, Nabil Sharif, told Agence France-Presse that the bomb went off near the town of Naur, on the road between Amman and the Jordan Valley. He said an investigation was under way. The Israeli ambassador was not riding in the convoy at the time.

title: Canada: Bomb Plot Leader Apologizes
description: A co-leader of a group that planned to bomb several targets in Ontario repeatedly apologized to Canadians and in particular to fellow Muslims at a sentencing hearing on Thursday. The man, Zakaria Amara, 24, said that his nave and gullible interpretation of Islam led him to help form the group known as the Toronto 18. Mr. Amara, who pleaded guilty in October to terrorism and bombing charges, said that he was glad that he was arrested before causing any harm and that he had been changed by the time he had spent in prison. Prosecutors are seeking a life sentence for Mr. Amara.

title: Directing the Message
description: He intends to maintain pattern of treating Fox News Channel differently.

title: Iran: Zionists Blamed for a Killing
description: The killing of a physicist this week appeared to have been carried out by Zionists, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad said Thursday in his first public comments on the bomb attack. The method of bombing indicates that Zionists did it and that they hate us and dont want us to progress, Mr. Ahmadinejad said, according to the news agency ISNA. The physicist, Masoud Ali Mohammadi, was buried Thursday amid heavy security. The government had blamed the United States and Israel for the killing on Tuesday. Two former presidents, Mohammad Khatami and Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, issued statements calling the assassination an act of terrorism but did not blame Israel or the United States. Mr. Rafsanjani called the assassination a sign of a new era of intrigue.

title: Local Theaters Are Pulling Strings
description: The humble puppet, often crafted from rags, paper or even wire, is having its moment in Chicago theater. Once relegated to puppet-specific stages, the use of marionettes alongside actors in mainstream productions is exploding, said Roell Schmidt, the director of Links Hall performance space.

title: Learning from the Past
description: No flight suits or Mission Accomplished banners, Mr. Pfeiffer says.

title: Shiseido Buys Manufacturer of Cosmetics
description: Shiseido, a Japanese cosmetics company, said Thursday that it had agreed to buy Bare Escentuals, one of the biggest players in the world of mineral makeup, for $1.7 billion.

title: A Spouse Down The Hall
description: The advantages - and disadvantages - of sharing a West Wing workplace with his wife.

title: A Composer Embracing the 12-Tone Technique
description: Continuum, the new-music group that specializes in thematic programming and composer portraits, devoted its Wednesday evening program at Merkin Concert Hall to Ursula Mamlok, a German-born American composer who turns 87 on Feb. 1. Ms. Mamlok remains an eloquent advocate of the 12-tone technique, though in a modified form that pulls her music toward an almost neo-Romantic warmth.

title: Arne Duncan Challenges the N.C.A.A.
description: Education Secretary Arne Duncan has been around the schoolyards and gyms in Chicago, has seen players who could have made more of themselves, in basketball and in life.

title: Judge Orders F.D.A. to Stop Blocking Imports of E-Cigarettes From China
description: A federal judge on Thursday ordered the Food and Drug Administration to stop blocking the importation of electronic cigarettes from China and indicated that the devices should be regulated as tobacco products rather than drug or medical devices.

title: Bank Chief Says Greece Gets No Special Treatment
description: FRANKFURT  Greece should not expect any special favors from the European Central Bank, Jean-Claude Trichet, the banks president, said Thursday. But as Greek leaders presented a plan to drastically lower the countrys debt, Mr. Trichet called speculation that it might have to leave the European monetary union absurd.

title: Filling Shopping Carts, and a Community Need
description: Not long ago it would have seemed inconceivable to Laura Martinez, a councilwoman here, that anyone would come to East Palo Alto to shop for food. Even Ms. Martinez and her family usually left town to do that.

title: Four-Legged Survivors of Hurricane Katrina
description: One from the heart, the documentary Mine relates yet one more wrenching, infuriating story about Hurricane Katrina and the devastation wreaked both by the storm and by human error and indifference. While many victims in the movie will look familiar  whether waving from their New Orleans rooftops after the levees broke in 2005 or talking about their ruined lives and homes afterward  the majority of the victims here have usually been seen only in the background, forlornly howling and wagging their tails.

title: Some Card Fees Waived for Haiti Aid
description: After being criticized for siphoning off up to 3 percent of charitable donations for transaction fees, the nations largest payment networks  Visa, MasterCard, American Express and Discover  announced that they would waive fees for some contributions aimed at aiding Haiti in the wake of a devastating earthquake. So more of the money you donate will find its way to the organizations providing relief.

title: Foster Care Faltering and Other Issues From Fridays Bay Area Report
description: Inadequate Foster Care Support Hits Bay Area Children Hard | In a familiar tale for cash-strapped California, the foster care system has been coming apart as because of inadequate state financing for at least 20 years, officials at the county level said. In the past two months, a succession of court decisions in favor of care providers lifted hopes that the judicial rulings might finally turn things around, but the lawsuits have simultaneously shed light on a system that has been cut to the bone. Jill Duerr Berrick, a professor in the School of Social Welfare at the University of California, Berkeley, said, The supply and demand problem is so pressing that a child services agency is not always capable of finding the type of care that a child needs. The Excell Center outside Turlock is one place that makes the finances work, but at the price of putting San Francisco children 110 miles from their roots.

title: Bankers Without a Clue
description: The official Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission  the group that aims to hold a modern version of the Pecora hearings of the 1930s, whose investigations set the stage for New Deal bank regulation  began taking testimony on Wednesday. In its first panel, the commission grilled four major financial-industry honchos. What did we learn?

title: The Story Behind the Obama Bank Tax
description: From Eric Dash, a DealBook colleague:

title: Financial Difficulties Strain Californias Foster Care System
description: In the summer of 2008, a 13-year-old boy from San Francisco emerged from a government van and scanned his new surroundings. Five handsome houses, a small school and an old gymnasium stood on 11 rural acres in the Central Valley that bordered an almond orchard.

title: Intels Bet on Innovation Pays Off in Faster Chips
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  At about this time last year, Intels board decided to invest $7 billion in new chip plants in Oregon, Arizona and New Mexico.

title: Museums and Lawmakers Mull Sales of Art
description: It was once considered unthinkable: the notion of a museum selling off parts of its collection to pay the bills. But the recession has forced some institutions to do that  or at least consider it  and members of the New York State Legislature have been trying to draft a bill that would regulate such deaccessioning of artworks and artifacts.

title: International Espionage? Kids Are Much Harder
description: The blooper reel that plays alongside the end credits of a Jackie Chan movie  a good-humored flurry of blown stunts and botched lines  is always amusing. In some cases, though, its more fun than what has come before, and in The Spy Next Door the outtakes are not all that great but still better than anything else in the movie.

title: Catholics Gather Courtside to Put Their Faith on Display
description: There was no neutral zone for mere spectators. On one side were thousands decked in green, representing the Fighting Irish of Sacred Heart Cathedral Preparatory. Across the basketball court were an equal number in red and blue for the Wildcats of St. Ignatius College Preparatory.

title: Obama to House Democrats: Buck Up
description: Like most political junkies, President Obama said he keeps an eye on the blogs and the cable shows. So, he assured anxious House Democrats on Thursday, he fully understands what they have been going through in the tumultuous health care debate.

title: U.S. Official Says Talks on Emissions Show Promise
description: Todd Stern, the chief American climate change negotiator, said Thursday that the flawed and incomplete agreement reached last month in Copenhagen could provide significant benefits if countries followed through on its provisions.

title: King Birthday Events
description: Big plans for the long weekend, or has Martin Luther Kings Birthday become more about cleaning the closet or clearing the Netflix queue than about honoring the civil rights leader? How about this: clean and clear on Saturday and Sunday, but leave Monday for Dr. King.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: In Power Push, Movement Sees Base in G.O.P.
description: HOLLAND, Pa.  The Tea Party movement ignited a year ago, fueled by anti-establishment anger. Now, Tea Party activists are trying to take over the establishment, ground up.

title: Yemen: Clerics Oppose U.S. Troops
description: Several dozen Yemeni clerics, including the influential hard-line figure Abdel Majid al-Zindani, above, issued a statement on Thursday saying they would call for jihad, or holy war, if the United States sent troops to fight Al Qaeda in Yemen. President Obama has said he does not plan to send troops to Yemen, although the United States does provide training, intelligence and military hardware to help Yemen fight militants.

title: Iraqi Commission Bars Nearly 500 Candidates
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs independent electoral commission on Thursday barred about 500 candidates from running in parliamentary elections in March, among them an influential Sunni Muslim politician, in a decision that could stoke sectarian tensions here and deprive the vote of crucial legitimacy in the eyes of part of the electorate.

title: Expecting the Big One
description: THOUGH it can offer scant comfort to the victims of the earthquake in Haiti, seismology is making some slight progress in its search for the holy grail of being able to predict dreadful events like that on Tuesday. New studies into ultra-slow-motion events deep underground called nonvolcanic tremors are showing vague but promising signs that the same kind of subterranean danger signals that allow us today to forecast when a volcano is about to erupt may one day offer some warning of the hitherto unpredictable nucleation  the explosive beginning  of an earthquake.

title: Accord Reached on Insurance Tax for Costly Plans
description: WASHINGTON  The White House, Congressional leaders and labor unions said Thursday that they had reached agreement on a proposal to tax high-cost health insurance policies, resolving one of the major differences between the House and the Senate over far-reaching health legislation.

title: A Councilmans Aide Extends a Lifeline All the Way to Haiti
description: For two hours on Thursday morning, Carline Keil tried to help Alex Alexis get a passport. His wife and three children lived in Haiti, and he had heard nothing since the quake struck two days before. There was nothing left to do but go there.

title: Wizards Arenas Is Charged With Felony
description: Gilbert Arenas of the Washington Wizards has been charged with felony gun possession in connection with his recent dispute with a teammate.

title: Demonstrators Press for Haitian Advocates Release
description: Against the backdrop of the earthquake in Haiti, dozens of protesters gathered outside a Greenwich Village detention center on Thursday to demand the release of Jean Montrevil, a Haitian immigrant rights advocate and a community leader in New York who has been detained since December while awaiting deportation.

title: Bonfire of the Bureaucrats
description: When the Berlin Wall unexpectedly fell 20 years ago, a German friend of mine made a sage observation: The Communists opened the wall for the same reason they had raised it 28 years earlier  to keep East Germans from fleeing west. The fact is that the Ossies had been streaming out of East Germany throughout that fall of 1989 through cracks in the Iron Curtain opened by Mikhail Gorbachevs perestroika. Unable any longer to halt this hemorrhage by force, the desperate German leaders gambled that if they let their people visit the West from time to time, they might not wish to flee East Germany at every opportunity. The Politburo official assigned to announce the new rules on Nov. 9, 1989, botched it, giving the impression that the wall had been thrown open. East Berliners rushed to the crossings, a bewildered officer opened the gate, and the rest is  literally  history.

title: For Google, a Threat to China With Little Revenue at Stake
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google has said principle drove its threat to back out of China unless the government there allowed it to run its search engine without censorship.

title: Stark Claustrophobia in the Family Cross-Fire
description: Per Kirkebys striking visual designs for Peter Martinss Romeo + Juliet are neither pretty nor opulent, two things that sadly seem to have become prerequisites for big narrative ballets.

title: A Call for a Monserrate Expulsion Vote, but He Says He Wont Go Quietly
description: The political fate of State Senator Hiram Monserrate, a Queens Democrat convicted of assault in a dispute that left his companion with a gash on her face, grew uncertain on Thursday as a special committee recommended that the Senate vote soon on a motion to expel him.

title: A Passion for Candy
description: Although we have always craved sweets, until the Industrial Revolution many of us made do with candy manufactured by bees, that most industrious of species. Factories and assembly lines made modern candy at once possible and necessary, even though candy contains few nutrients and is bad for our teeth. Now that were all fat and the earth is melting, were supposed to be off candy for good. Ordinary candy is just for Halloween; high-end candy, nestled in luxury boxes, is marketed as a sex substitute. But Alice Tatnall Ziplinsky, the narrator of Katharine Webers new novel, True Confections, knows better. Candy makes people happy.

title: In Miami, Eager Helpers Meet Difficulties
description: MIAMI  The Rev. Reginald Jean-Mary had no time on Thursday to think about his mother, two sisters and a brother still missing somewhere in the ruins of the Haitian capital. He was busy trying to find a shipping container, consoling dozens of parishioners who lost loved ones in the earthquake-ravaged nation and organizing a team of nurses and doctors to send there.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Children Who Changed the World
description: In the winter and early spring of 1965, Alabama schoolchildren and teenagers by the hundreds played a significant role in one of the civil rights movements pivotal victories: the march on Montgomery that crystallized Congressional support for voters rights legislation. In chronicling this episode primarily from the young participants perspective, Elizabeth Partridge takes the past off its pedestal and shows how ordinary people, children among them, can sometimes tip the balance and help determine the outcome of events.

title: Aunt Leaf'
description: AUNT LEAF

title: Seize the Time
description: Mothers. Cant live with them. Cant live without them. Yet 11-year-old Delphine and her younger sisters Vonetta and Fern have done just fine without theirs. Cecile, a poet, walked out on them just after Fern was born. Now, in the summer of 1968, their father, with the reluctant agreement of their grandmother, has decided that the three girls need to leave their Brooklyn home to spend a few weeks with their mother in Oakland, Calif., to get to know her.

title: Dance Away the Heartache
description: A few recent movie performances suggest that a crop of young, first-time actors might be giving professionals a run for their money. There was Gabourey Sidibes turn in Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire, and now there is Katie Jarvis. The teenager  discovered while having a fight with her boyfriend on the street in England  plays Mia, the 15-year old protagonist in Fish Tank, Andrea Arnolds tough and brilliant second feature, A. O. Scott writes. In the movie, Mia moves with such speed and fury that she seems to be trying to flee not only from her bleak surroundings but also from the movie itself. The film offers a harsh brand of realism, a world made familiar by the films of Ken Loach, Mike Leigh and other socially conscious anatomists of British misery. Mia lives with her mother and sister in a cramped apartment in a British housing project that stands like a cluster of megaliths in the middle of nowhere. It also stars Michael Fassbender, recently of Inglourious Basterds, but it is the performance by Ms. Jarvis that makes this movie a diamond-hard reflection on the peril and progress of a fragile soul in a bad situation.

title: Break Into the Vault
description: While youre wandering around Brooklyn this Saturday searching for the perfect brunch spot, duck inside One Hanson Place where the Brooklyn Flea Market has recently set up shop. Below the historic space, which was once home to the Williamsburg Savings Bank and is now a historic landmark, hides a of food court worthy of the boroughs most sophisticated palates. The collection of carefully curated street-food includes Asian hot dogs dressed with kimchi, lobster rolls from Red Hook, fried fish tacos, hot Neapolitan-style pizza and more and can all be savored inside what was once the banks vault. Its a cool setting and whats above isnt so bad either. Vintage clothing and furniture, records and costume jewelry, photographs and other random goods are arranged inside the largest building in Brooklyn, which dates to 1927. Admire the marble and mosaics under the vaulted ceilings while you eat and shop. Its certainly better than waiting an hour for runny eggs.

title: A Goonie Sings
description: Martha Plimpton is an actress who has demonstrated her versatility. The native New Yorker and Goonies alumnus has appeared in musicals like Pal Joey and serious dramas like Cymbeline and The Coast of Utopia, as well as a slew of feature films. On Saturday shell be at Lincoln Center performing a one-night-only concert at Jazz at Lincoln Center as part of its American Songbook series. Expect a night of songs and stories from Ms. Plimptons childhood growing up in the 70s amid show-biz types in Manhattan. There are two shows, one at 8:30 p.m. and another at 10:30 p.m.

title: Arguments at Court
description: Perry v. Schwarzenegger, the case challenging the constitutionality of Proposition 8, unfolded this week in a federal courtroom in San Francisco. The opening statements from dueling legal teams, expert opinions from academics and deeply personal testimonies from four gay plaintiffs were heard by Judge Vaughn R. Walker, but they were not seen by a YouTube audience, after the Supreme Court barred broadcasting the proceedings.

title: Paterson Has More Than $3 Million in War Chest
description: Gov. David A. Patersons campaign reported on Thursday evening that he had more than $3 million on hand, a sharp drop in his available cash from the amount he had in the middle of last year and a development that was likely to increase doubts among Democrats about his political viability.

title: Jersey Girls
description: New Jersey is a teenage state: it looks awkward in places, has questionable ethics from time to time and plays perennial underdog to New York. Perhaps this is why its home to so much good young adult literature, to which we can add Beth Ann Baumans novel, Rosie and Skate. Set on the Jersey Shore after the tourists have gone home, the novel uses the empty storefronts and windy beaches of autumn to explore loss, confusion and love as two sisters struggle with their alcoholic father and try out adult roles they are not quite ready for.

title: Childrens Bookshelf
description: HERE COMES JACK FROST  Written and illustrated by Kazuno Kohara.  Roaring Brook. $12.99.(Ages 3 to 6)

title: Morgue Becomes Mountain of Anguish
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  With chilling regularity, a pickup truck from the Haitian police or a taxi driver with a station wagon pulled up to deliver more bodies to the morgue. Flies buzzed on many of the bodies. Civil servants unloaded the cargo, their expressions hidden by white surgical masks.

title: Ex-Anchor Jailed in Assault of Wife
description: SUFFERN, N.Y.  Dominic Carter, a former political anchor for NY1 accused of beating his wife, was led away in handcuffs on Thursday as he immediately began a 30-day sentence in the Rockland County Jail.

title: Correction: Review of Beneath the Lions Gaze
description: A review on Jan. 3 misstated, at one point, part of the title of the novel by Maaza Mengiste, set during and after the reign of the Ethiopian emperor Haile Selassie. As noted in the review, it is Beneath the Lions Gaze, not Under the Lions Gaze.

title: Planned U.S. Tax Might Hurt Europes Banks Less
description: Europes Edge

title: Indie Rock From Florida, but, Please, No Surfing
description: The Drums and Surfer Blood are bands so deep into the hype-cycle wormhole that they have to spend time denying misperceptions that they themselves have perpetuated. So what they want you to know is this: Theyre not really interested in surfing.

title: For the Jets Weatherford, Metallica Is Off the Playlist
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The heart rate of Steve Weatherford, the Jets punter who loves heavy metal rock and has a huge Carpe Diem tattoo on his left biceps, has returned to normal, but Jay Feely, the Jets place-kicker, is still joking that he is taking no chances.

title: After Googles Stand on China, U.S. Treads Lightly
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  Last month, when Google engineers at their sprawling campus in Silicon Valley began to suspect that Chinese intruders were breaking into private Gmail accounts, the company began a secret counteroffensive.

title: Correction: Review of The Bauhaus Group
description: A review on Dec. 27 about The Bauhaus Group, by Nicholas Fox Weber, misstated the early financial circumstances of Mies van der Rohe, the Bauhauss last director. Though his father, a middle-class stonemason, suffered a financial reverse when Mies was a child, Mies was not born in poverty.

title: Obama Pledges Aid to Haiti
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday promised $100 million along with more American troops for the relief effort in Haiti, vowing that the United States would stand with the impoverished nation as it grappled with the devastation of its capital city.

title: House Music All Night: Stage as a Dance Club
description: Dixon Place isnt a dance club, but the choreographer Niles Ford tried his best to turn it into one on Wednesday night in his energetic homage to nightlife, In Search of the Invisible People. Described in press materials as a danceumentary, the work, a collaboration with the choreographer Nathan Trice, explores house music and the thriving dance scene of the 1970s and 80s.

title: Burst of Mobile Giving Adds Millions in Relief Funds
description: Old-fashioned television telethons can stretch on for hours. But the latest charity appeal is short enough for Twitter: Text HAITI to 90999 to donate $10 to @RedCross relief.

title: Report Says 9 Million Books Pirated Online
description: A study by a company that helps track pirated digital books estimates that there were 9 million illegal downloads of copyrighted books in the final months of last year. Attributor, which works for publishers including Hachette Book Group and John Wiley & Sons, scanned 25 Web sites that offer readers downloadable content, looking for 913 titles across categories ranging from business and investing to fiction. It found, for example, that illegal copies of Freakonomics, by Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner, were downloaded 1,082 times and Angels & Demons, by Dan Brown, 7,951 times. The study did not track any titles published by the companys clients, which would exclude the oft-pirated Twilight series published by Hachette. Rich Pearson, general manager of Attributor, said although not every pirated copy represented a lost sale, the potential loss to the publishing industry could be as high as $3 billion. Some analysts doubted that piracy was as big a problem for the book industry as the study suggested. Mike Shatzkin, chief executive of Idea Logical Company, a book industry consultant, said many people who might illegally download an e-book would never have bought it in the first place.

title: Media Struggle to Convey a Disaster
description: The Fox News correspondent Steve Harrigan is a veteran of the worlds worst calamities, but on television on Thursday afternoon, as he stood beside one of the piles of rubble that pockmark Port-au-Prince, Haiti, he broke down.

title: Shes Got Castanets, So Let Carmen Dance
description: In his overture to Carmen, Bizet introduces a recurring motif that listeners have invariably associated with fate and with the fatal liaison of Carmen and Don Jos. The composer meant it to be played with the curtain lowered. Then, as the stage action proceeds, he develops it powerfully, bringing it back often, in hauntingly different versions: like a flash of lightning, like a slow but tremendous warning, like an irresistible undertow.

title: Pentagon Steps Up Talks on Ending Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon is stepping up internal discussions on how gay men and lesbians might be able to serve openly in the armed services, military officials said on Thursday, in anticipation of fulfilling President Obamas campaign pledge to repeal the dont ask, dont tell law.

title: The Underlying Tragedy
description: On Oct. 17, 1989, a major earthquake with a magnitude of 7.0 struck the Bay Area in Northern California. Sixty-three people were killed. This week, a major earthquake, also measuring a magnitude of 7.0, struck near Port-au-Prince, Haiti. The Red Cross estimates that between 45,000 and 50,000 people have died.

title: Into the Closet
description: Has anyone noticed that now that lesbians and gay men have left the closet to assert their equal rights as citizens, their adversaries seem to be running for a closet of their own?

title: Clooney to Organize a Telethon for Haiti
description: Reached by telephone on Thursday evening, Stan Rosenfield, longtime publicist for George Clooney, confirmed that Mr. Clooney was scrambling to organize a Jan. 22 telethon to benefit victims of the Haiti earthquake.

title: Executive Leaps to Lenos Defense
