title: Could This Be the End of the Celebrity Mobster?
description: Predicting the demise of the Mafia is like predicting the demise of the Rocky franchise: Every time you think you have finally heard the last of it, it rears its ugly head.

title: Immigrants in Detention to Be Sent Out of State
description: Immigration and Customs Enforcement will close a controversial detention center in Greenwich Village next month and transfer the centers roughly 300 detainees to a county jail in New Jersey, federal officials announced on Thursday.

title: 3rd-Party Candidate Named Kennedy Could Tip Senate Race in Massachusetts
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass.  In most elections, a politician calling himself the Tea Party candidate would cheer Democrats, raising hopes that he would siphon votes from Republicans by attracting some of the disaffected anti-Washington, anti-Obama electorate.

title: Labor Panel Is Stalled by Dispute on Nominee
description: A dispute involving Senator John McCain has left the National Labor Relations Board unable to decide its most important cases.

title: Vikings Allen at Top of His Game and Seeking His Next Adventure
description: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  For a guy who can bring down an elk with a spear and a buffalo with a crossbow  check out his YouTube videos  Minnesota Vikings defensive end Jared Allens aim with a Nerf basketball can be shaky. That is the story Vikings linebacker Ben Leber tells, anyway.

title: Possibility of Plots Prompts More Checks for Explosives at Airports
description: WASHINGTON  The Department of Homeland Security moved Thursday to increase random checks for explosives at American airports after officials cited a heightened concern over possible terror plots against the aviation system.

title: Haiti Quake Day 3: Death in the Streets
description: Marc Lacey reports on the scenes of life, death and rescue on Port-au-Prince's streets.

title: Immigrant-Services Groups and Their Founder Are Frauds, Suit Says
description: Over the past 25 years, Edward Juarez-Pagliocco built a reputation as a national expert on immigrant affairs. His work earned him keys to cities in Florida and New Jersey, he had a radio show on WPAT-FM (93.1) in New York, and he wrote an immigration column for El Diario La Prensa, the Spanish-language daily.

title: 52 Across: Set Sail
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  As a rule, the maximum number of answers and black squares in a Times themeless puzzle is 72 and 32 respectively (its 78 and 38 for Monday-to-Thursday puzzles). However, constructors sometimes aim much lower. The record for fewest answers is 52; the record for fewest black squares is 18. Given a choice between the two, my solving preference is for the few-black-squares variety, since the mix of letters and words can still be fairly interesting, whereas a puzzle with few answers will always have a very high common-letter count.

title: A Blind Mother of Two Who Makes Her Own Way
description: Rahkiya Rawlins, legally blind since birth, has found ways of navigating the world.

title: Declaration of Indies: Just Sell It Yourself!
description: LAST November inside a conference room at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles, a film consultant named Peter Broderick was doing his best to foment a revolution. Mr. Broderick, who helps filmmakers find their way into the marketplace, was spreading the word on an Internet-era approach to releasing movies that he believes empowers filmmakers without impoverishing them economically or emotionally. Mr. Broderick divides distribution into the Old World and New, infusing his PowerPoint presentation with insurgent rhetoric. He has written a declaration of independence for filmmakers that  as he did that afternoon  he reads while wearing a tricorn hat.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a lowering of standards for high school exit exams in many states misstated, in some copies, the annual increase in the number of dropouts for which recent studies blame the exams. It ranges from 35,000 to 70,000 nationwide  not per state.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Googles threat to withdraw from China misstated the given name of the White Houses choice for Internet security adviser. He is Howard A. Schmidt, not Robert. The article also misspelled, in some editions, the name of the spiritual leader of the Gelug sect of Tibetan Buddhism, whose computers are suspected of having been attacked by the Chinese government. He is the Dalai Lama, not the Dali Lama.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the end of the worst drought in Texas in 50 years reversed the descriptions of La Nia and El Nio as well as their effect on the drought there. La Nia is the phenomenon that occurs when surface water temperatures along the equator in the Pacific Ocean are below normal, and it was what helped create the drought the past two winters. El Nio is a weather pattern that occurs because of the warming of the Pacific waters, and it was responsible for bringing rain to Texas this winter.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a portrait, once believed by some scholars to be the work of Leonardo da Vinci, that is to be auctioned by Sothebys on Jan. 28, misidentified, at one point, the century in which it was thought to have been painted. It was the 15th century, not the 14th.

title: Conan OBriens Barbs Keep Coming
description: Conan OBrien kept up the patter of jokes related to his late-night contretemps Thursday night:

title: Catherine Deneuve, No Time for Chic
description: PARIS

title: Editors Note
description: Several articles in the past year about the governments plans to overhaul the health care system quoted Jonathan Gruber, identifying him as a professor of economics at M.I.T. On Friday, Professor Gruber confirmed reports that he is also a paid consultant on health care issues for the Department of Health and Human Services. Had editors been aware of his government work, the articles would have disclosed this relationship to readers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a play by the journalist and author John Conroy inspired by his reporting about accusations that some members of the Chicago Police Department tortured suspects in the 1970s and 80s misstated, in some editions, the given name of the playwright who wrote Copenhagen in citing other morality plays. He is Michael Frayn, not Peter.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Art Clokey, the animator who created Gumby, using information from his production company, misstated the year he made the animated film Gumbasia. It was 1953, not 1955. The obituary also misidentified the materials used to make the title characters of the animated series Davey and Goliath, which Mr. Clokey produced with his wife, Ruth. The characters were puppets made of foam and other materials; they were not made of clay.

title: Corrections
description: EDITORS' NOTE

title: Making Darwin the Legend a Man Again
description: PALE, winded, a blanket draped across his twitching knees, a sick, despondent man confides his woes to the minister who has stopped by. Stretching a sympathetic arm around the mans shoulders, the minister murmurs, God moves in mysterious ways.

title: From an Owner to the Quietest Sports Emperor
description: MORA, Mo.  This is not so much a hometown as a home road cut into the corn and bean fields two hours southeast of Kansas City. It is an isolated place  unincorporated, population 25  yet it has produced one of the countrys richest men, the owner of an aspiring global sports empire.

title: Blacks Try to Retain Power as Board Race Splits Community
description: No matter how deep the snow, icy the sidewalks or wicked the wind, nothing was going to keep 76-year-old Mary L. Johnson away from Wallaces Catfish Corner on Friday night.

description: Perry Fewell will replace the dismissed Bill Sheridan as defensive coordinator of the Giants, the team announced Thursday night. Fewell, 47, was the interim coach of the Buffalo Bills for the last seven games after the firing of Dick Jauron.

France, Grudgingly, Imagines Google as a Partner on Digital Media Projects
description: PARIS  As France slowly brings its cultural past and present into digital form, it is realizing that the job will require support from a company often viewed with deep suspicion here: Google.

description: Less than three months after failing in a bid to host the 2016 Summer Olympics, civic leaders took Chicago out of the competition to host World Cup soccer games in 2018 or 2022.

A shocking new study by the Justice Departments Bureau of Justice Statistics surveyed more than 9,000 young people in custody and found that 12 percent reported being sexually abused one or more times, mainly by staff members.

title: Editors Note
description: Articles on Dec. 28, 29 and 30, about the apparent bombing attempt on a flight to Detroit, discussed the use of full-body scanners for airport security. They cited Michael Chertoff, the former secretary of homeland security, as supporting wider use of the scanners. Mr. Chertoff has confirmed in several recent interviews that a manufacturer of the devices is a client of his consulting company. That connection should have been noted in the articles.

title: N. Korea Threatens to Halt All Talks With Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea, denouncing South Korea for drawing up a contingency plan to deal with the potential collapse of the Norths government, warned Friday that it would cut off all dialogue with the South and exclude it from all negotiations concerning the security of the Korean Peninsula. North Korea will also wage a pan-national holy war of retaliation to blow away the South Korean government, said a statement from the Norths highest ruling agency, the National Defense Commission, which is headed by the national leader, Kim Jong-il.

title: Toyota Executive Sees Limits to Electric Cars
description: DETROIT  Although Toyota is the world leader in producing fuel-efficient hybrid cars, and it has plans to introduce a plug-in hybrid and a battery-powered city car (versions of both were on the stand at the auto show here), the company has been outspoken about the limitations of some green-vehicle technologies. Its been particularly vocal about the drawbacks of plug-in hybrids.

title: Sampler: Oakland Child Care Receives a Boost and the Sea Lion Party Will Wait
description: The Economics of Same-Sex Marriage Ban | Legalizing same-sex marriage would be an economic boost to San Francisco, said Edmund A. Egan, the chief economist for the City and County of San Francisco, who testified on Thursday in federal court in San Francisco. On Friday, lawyers for those seeking to overturn Californias ban on same-sex marriage are expected to call William Tam, a proponent in the Proposition 8 campaign. That 2008 ballot initiative, approved by 52 percent of the voters, changed Californias constitution to define marriage as being between a man and a woman. Also, Linda Greenhouse, in the Opinionator, looks at the drama around the Supreme Court ruling on Wednesday to prohibit the broadcasting of trial coverage and the courts consideration of an appeal by same-sex marriage opponents in Washington State who seek to bar the public disclosure of petition signers. [The New York Times, The San Jose Mercury News]

title: The Time for Bonus-Whacking Has Passed
description: While it may feel good to assail Wall Street for the outsize bonuses that will soon be coming down the pike, the usefulness of the practice has long since passed, The Washington Posts Steve Pearlstein argues in his latest column.

title: Celebrating MLK Day
description: Updated: Jan., 2016

title: One Singular Auteur, Through Another
description: STEVEN SODERBERGHS modus operandi is that no film he makes is like anything hes made before. The one exception has been the Ocean series, which from first (Oceans Eleven) to last (Oceans Thirteen) was designed to make money and did. But once Mr. Soderbergh could add that particular genre of moviemaking to his rsum  in Hollywood, the franchise is a genre  he put it aside and returned to being the consummate anti-auteurist auteur, bouncing from the guerrilla epic Che to the coolly soft-core Girlfriend Experience to the comic corporate expos The Informant!

title: Star-Spangled Glamour | Bruce Webers All-American
description: For over three decades, the photographer Bruce Weber has defined contemporary American glamour with his editorial and advertising imagery. Weber has also been a prolific producer of books, including All-American, an annual almanac of the esoterica that he encounters in his travels. But when he sat down last year to plan the next edition, the world appeared to have shifted on its axis, with many around him struggling to find their feet. I wanted to put together a series of stories as eclectic and inspiring as you might hear at a late-night party, Weber says, because the morning after, you feel a reason to continue, even if you dont know all the answers. Fittingly, the ninth volume of All-American (Little Bear Press, $140) is a casserole of conceits, from poetry and photojournalism to profiles on the choreographer Carmen de Lavallade and the doomed beatnik pretty-boy artist Bill Morrow. As ever, nature is never far in Webers search for the sublime: a paean to Big Sur features the strapping landscapes and characters that have made the place as synonymous with muscular naturalism as Weber himself.

title: When Hollywood Learned to Talk, Sing and Dance
description: AS the snowballing box-office success of Avatar suggests a paradigm shift in film, its rewarding to contemplate the last time the movies assumed a new dimension, that of sound.

title: Risk Report Warns on Asset Price Collapse

The trick to avoiding a financial relapse, the authors say, will be a constant watchfulness on the path of recovery.

title: Bartlett on the Beat
description: The New Year started out with a note from John Bartlett. Ive known John since the early, scrappy days of his career and, in fact, our fathers knew each other (I think from the Navy). John has an interesting blog, johnbartlettny.com, that covers all sorts of topics, from design and fashion to literature, and of course I was delighted to see ample reference to his dog Tiny Tim. Toby the Lab says hey.

title: A Miniature Pig for the Red Carpet, Perhaps?
description: The Peeka-bu is the first ergonomically designed and easy to use intimate grooming mirror. It makes maintenance for your most private areas easy and fun! And its one of the many items that celebrities can pick up with this weekend at so-called gifting lounges, otherwise known as swag (or schwag) stops.

title: The Nifty 50 | Patrik Ervell, Designer
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Wee-Hour Health Talks Focus on Costs
description: White House and Congressional officials worked through Thursday night and into the wee hours of Friday as they continued to press for a final accord on far-reaching health care legislation.

title: Bank Profits: Not High Enough?
description: Is almost $12 billion in annual profits enough?

title: Graphic Books Best-Seller List: Casting About
description: A favorite pastime of comic book fans is picking actors they would like to see portray their favorite heroes in big screen films. These days, with so many super-epics being turned out by Hollywood, it seems like only a matter of time before every actor has his shot at a super-costume drama. This week fans learned that Peter Saarsgard would play Hector Hammond in the upcoming Green Lantern film. Mr. Hammond is a bald telepath with a giant head and the hots for the heros girlfriend, Carol Ferris, who it was recently announced will be played by Blake Lively.

title: Movie Misquotations
description: Over the last century or so, movie quotations, like pop-music lyrics, have come to replace Biblical verses and Shakespearean couplets as our cultural lingua franca, our common store of wit and wisdom. Yet many of the most frequently cited motion-picture lines turn out to be misquotations. The speech from Dirty Harry in which Clint Eastwood says, Youve got to ask yourself one question: Do I feel lucky? Well, do ya, punk? is commonly shortened to Do you feel lucky, punk? Michael Douglass Greed, for lack of a better word, is good (Wall Street) is condensed to Greed is good. Expressions of James Cagney like You dirty, yellow-bellied rat (Taxi!) and Dirty, double-crossing rat (Blonde Crazy) are immortalized as the snappier You dirty rat.

title: Terminated Reactor Projects May Be Revived
description: A nuclear reactor project of the federally owned Tennessee Valley Authority  declared officially dead since 2006  have been promoted from terminated status to deferred by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: Chinese Lawyer Declared Missing After Arrest
description: BEIJING  Nearly a year after he was seized by the authorities, the only news of one of Chinas most tenacious civil rights lawyers has been that he went missing after his detention, friends and relatives said Friday.

title: Friday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Mrs. Kennedy: Its the Peoples Seat
description: In the ever-close race now for the Massachusetts Senate seat held for decades by the late Edward M. Kennedy, his widow, Victoria Reggie Kennedy appears in a new ad for the Democratic candidate, Attorney General Martha Coakley.

title: An Exhausted Lady Gaga Cancels Concert
description: Update | 12:24 p.m.  The relentless life of Lady Gaga, with its burdensome headpieces and nonstop costume changes and makeup jobs, has at last gotten to Lady Gaga. On Thursday night that chameleonlike pop singer (whose real name is Stefani Germanotta) canceled a show she planned to perform at Purdue University in West Lafayette, Ind., citing exhaustion, Billboard reported. On her Twitter account, Lady Gaga wrote on Thursday night that she was feeling dizzy and having trouble breathing and that paramedics later came and diagnosed of exhaustion and dehydration. She said her show, which has many coordinated moving parts and mechanical elements, would be too dangerous to perform because, she wrote, she had passed out earlier. Billboard said the Indiana show would be rescheduled for Jan 26; Lady Gagas Monster Ball tour is scheduled to go to Atlantic City on Saturday and play four shows at Radio City Music Hall next week.

title: Pentagon Report on Fort Hood Details Failures
description: WASHINGTON  A Pentagon review released Friday portrayed a systemic breakdown within the military that permitted an Army psychiatrist, now charged with killing 13 people, to advance through the ranks despite concerns from his superiors about his behavior.

title: On Monday Night, He Serves Pasta
description: LAST fall, a job transfer to Brooklyn from the Bronx spurred a series of changes for Briana Fedele. It was not just a good time to move; she also wanted to find a larger place with her boyfriend, Scott Cavagnaro.

title: Erica Hill Joins Early Show
description: Erica Hill, the news anchor for CNNs nightly program Anderson Cooper 360, is moving to the mornings, becoming the newsreader for The Early Show on CBS.

title: Postcard From London: Inside the Financial Inferno
description: LONDON  Oh, what a nightmare I had on Thursday. It had something do with an economic collapse, a closed room that had shed its doorknobs, a feathered man who climbed walls and a tidal wave of multicolored balls. The dream ended around 11:12 p.m. At least I think it did, because I checked the watch on my shivering arm. On the other hand, when I stepped outside to clear my head, I had the uneasy sense that the dream was still going on.

title: Johnson & Johnson Accused of Drug Kickbacks
description: Johnson & Johnson paid kickbacks to the nations largest nursing home pharmacy to increase the number of elderly patients taking the antipsychotic Risperdal and several other medications, according to a complaint filed Friday by the office of the United States attorney in Boston.

title: How to Live Well Beyond Breast Cancer
description: Most books about breast cancer are focused on a womans immediate crisis, helping them learn more about the disease and make urgent treatment decisions. But what happens to women after all the decisions are made, the treatment is finished and life is supposed to go back to normal?

title: A Cupcake of a Cottage
description: Converted from a former industrial chicken coop, this house has plenty of windows to let in sunshine.

title: In Defense of the Edible Schoolyard
description: On the Atlantic food channel, Corby Kummer rises to the defense of Alice Waterss Edible Schoolyard after Caitlin Flanagan wrote that the program, in which children grow food as part of the curriculum, was a waste of educational resources. One of the people that Mr. Kummer spoke to was Tony Recasner, the head of the Samuel J. Green charter school in New Orleans, which is involved in the Edible Schoolyard.

title: Using Music to Fight the School Closings
description: AES Proposed Phase-Out: Shop Classes put to music by Mark Noakes from Save AES CTE HS on Vimeo.

title: The Short of It: Who Was the 2009 Money Player?
description: Heres how award season shapes up so far:Most Valuable Player  Colts QB Peyton ManningOffensive Player of the Year  Titans RB Chris JohnsonDefensive Player of the Year  Packers CB Charles WoodsonComeback Player of the Year  Patriots QB Tom BradyOffensive Rookie of the Year  Vikings WR Percy HarvinDefensive Rookie of the Year  Texans LB Brian CushingCoach of the Year  To Be Announced. You could build a good case for Norv Turner and Rex Ryan, who face each other Sunday.

title: Jets Q. and A. With Greg Bishop
description: Greg Bishop, who covers the Jets for The Times, answered readers questions on Friday in the comments section below. The Jets are preparing to face the Chargers in the divisional round of the playoffs on Sunday.

title: California Adopts Green Building Codes
description: California officials adopted the countrys first mandatory statewide green building code on Tuesday.

title: Keepsakes, Domestic and Dark
description: SEE, you too can do this, the artist Ida Applebroog said, showing a recent visitor to her SoHo studio a box of Crayola Model Magic, the kind of clay that children use, and then opening a glass cabinet filled with what she had made from it: small, doughy white figures that at first glance seemed like grade-school leftovers but upon closer inspection took on the complexity and creepiness of Giacometti by way of Wes Craven.

title: Beatles to Video Gamers: You Never Give Us Your Money
description: Heres some news the Beatles arent used to hearing: they arent selling very well. According to a new report released by a market research company that tracks the video game industry, the heavily promoted (and widely lauded) game The Beatles: Rock Band has not performed as well as other popular music games, and the genre as a whole appears to be on the decline.

title: Elderly Tenants Breaking Leases
description: Q.

title: How Generous Are We to Haiti? 92 Cents Per American Per Year
description: I was delighted that the White House denounced as utterly stupid the Rev. Pat Robertsons suggestion that Haiti had suffered its earthquake because it had made a pact with the devil, and as really stupid the comment by Rush Limbaugh that Americans already donate to Haiti through tax dollars  which many took to mean that he discouraged giving, a suggestion he has strongly denied. In any case, I think those comments may reflect a current that many people think even if they dont articulate, something like this: Those Haitians have screwed up their country, and we already pour money into their economy. We have our troubles at home, we have our needs, so why should our hard-earned dollars go to support Haitians who dont help themselves. Weve already been generous, and it hasnt worked.

title: Sending Residents the Right Signals
description: Q.

title: Pet Friendly to a Point
description: Q.

title: Sex and Gore? Thats Ancient History
description: WHEN the Victorians were feeling gloomy about their prospects they used to compare themselves to the ancient Romans. They read Gibbon, Plutarch and Tacitus and looked for parallels: a society burdened by empire, corrupted by wealth, deficient in manly virtue. Lately we have been doing much the same, only instead of consulting the Latin texts we turn to screen epics like Gladiator, the HBO series Rome, and the 2007 Zack Snyder film 300, which, strictly speaking, was about Spartans, not Romans, but lets not be fussy. The cable channel Starz, as part of an effort to expand its slate of original programming, is extending this classical tradition with Spartacus: Blood and Sand, a 13-part series that starts Friday, and has already taken the unusual step of commissioning a second season before the first one even runs.

title: When Hair Loss Strikes, a Doctor Is a Girls Best Friend
description: A COUPLE of years ago my hair started falling out. Not in clumps, but I noticed more hairs than usual in my comb and in the bath drain.

title: Honda Is Recalling Ridgeline for Electrical Issue
description: Honda is recalling about 76,000 of its 20067 Ridgeline pickups because of the possibility of a fire under the dash.

title: Come Buy With Me
description: To the Editor:

title: All Smiles Now, Recalling a Brief, Grim Flight
description: They began this Jan. 15 by remembering last Jan. 15, the day their plane ditched in the Hudson River.

title: My Mother, My Neighbor
description: To the Editor:

title: Weekend Competition: Workplace Lingo
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to share the words, phrases and abbreviations they use at work.

title: Out and About | Via Tortona, Milan
description: When in 1983 the Italian Vogue art director Flavio Lucchini and the photographer Fabrizio Ferri opened photo studios in a sleepy, warehouse-filled neighborhood southwest of Milans center, their colleagues questioned the move. It was a completely abandoned stretch of Via Tortona, and was considered extremely out of the way, recalls Lucchinis sister-in-law Giulia Borioli, a former director at the complex, called Superstudio 13. People said we were crazy to think that the fashion industry would embrace this neighborhood.

title: City Seeks Volunteers for Homeless Survey
description: The city is calling for volunteers for its annual Homeless Outreach Population Estimate, which seeks to count the number of people living in New Yorks streets.

title: The Futurist: The Life and Films of James Cameron
description: Chapter 1: A Boy and His Brain

title: More TV Time For Surprise Reality Stars
description: Just because youre a reality-show contestant who is technically too old to compete on American Idol doesnt mean you cant continue to appear on television over and over again. Larry Platt, the 63-year-old Atlanta resident who became an unlikely celebrity after performing his original song Pants on the Ground on Idol Wednesday night, has been booked to appear as a guest on The View on Monday morning, USA Today reported. Meanwhile, 48-year-old Susan Boyle, who has nothing to show for her appearances on Britains Got Talent except for millions of sales of her debut album, will appear on The Oprah Winfrey Show on Tuesday, her press representatives said on Friday.

title: A Big Audience for Conan OBriens Tonight
description: Even as negotiations for him to leave NBC moved toward a conclusion, Conan OBrien continued a ratings surge Thursday night, posting huge advantages in early results among young-adult viewers for his Tonight Show on NBC.

title: When Women Lose Their Hair
description: Hereditary hair loss and thinning hair are common concerns in women, but many popular treatments dont do any good, writes Lesley Alderman in todays Patient Money.

title: The Brill Building
description: To the Editor:

title: Realms of Gold
description: Can you examine the moral life of someone without morals? Does someone without morals have a moral life? And is the amoral life worth living?

title: Iraqis on Iraq  Basra and Mosul
description: With international attention shifting from Iraq to Afghanistan  we asked Iraqi journalists working for The New York Times to give a personal view of the areas where they live. Here, our correspondents describe life in Iraqs second- and third-largest cities, which until recently were very dangerous places to live and work. The journalists names are withheld because of the continuing threat to their lives.

title: Travel Deals: Flight Sale to Australia
description: Qantas Airways is offering up to 50 percent off flights between select cities in the United States and Australia.

title: Preaching Power, Jets Callahan Finds Fresh Start
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Jets offensive linemen laugh at the way Bill Callahan approaches football. They find his methods endearing, unusual and effective.

title: Send Photos of Missing Loved Ones
description: The New York Times is collecting photos of missing people submitted by friends, family members and colleagues. Readers who have information can make photo submissions or read comments from others seeking information.

title: N.F.L. Playoffs Come Knocking
description: After a week overflowing with news about steroid confessions, itinerant coaches and felony gun charges, the weekends N.F.L. playoff games will arrive not a moment too soon, although the league has announced that if you have not been obsessing about them all week, as it requires, its people may be paying you a visit. Just a warning.

title: Make Mine a Sully
description: Sure, hes been called a hero. And his act of cool-headed bravery one year ago was nothing short of a miracle. But one honor may have passed Capt. Chesley B. Sullenberger III like a jet floating down the river: a cocktail in his name.

title: Tips for Safe and Efficient Haiti Donations
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has urged Internet users to be cautious and do their research before giving money to help the relief effort in Haiti.

title: NBC's Ann Curry Reports From Haiti
description: As aid pours into Haiti, tension is mounting among the rubble as the search for survivors continues.

title: Guess Who Said It? Late-Night Edition
description: Hey, kids! Heres a fun game to play. Guess who said the following in The New York Times, after recently becoming the host of a popular late-night television program, only to face rumors that he was about to be replaced with another host?

title: Bill Clinton on Devastation in Haiti
description: Former President Bill Clinton encourages Americans to donate money to victims of the earthquake in Haiti.

title: Pictures of the Day: Friday, Jan. 15
description: Haiti continues to demand the worlds attention, but there is no lack of trouble in Kenya, China and India. In one instance, however, the darkness over the land was benign (Slides 9 and 10).

title: Ricky Gervais: Team Leno or Team Coco?
description: Ricky Gervais and the writers of the Golden Globes are likely giving the comedy gods extra thanks this week  they do that by the ritual sacrifice of a Judd Apatow script  because the Jay/Conan dust-up is no doubt giving them reams of easy topical material. From the hosts own jokes to Jimmy Kimmels prosthetic chin to his skewering of Leno directly on Thursday night to the Craigslist listing, it is as surefire comedy gold as making fun of George Clooney. Right? How long do you think it will take until Mr. Gervais, the shows host, makes a reference to the brouhaha on Sunday night? First joke of the monologue? Or after the first commercial break? Will he throw NBC zingers throughout the broadcast, despite (or because of) the fact that the Globes are being broadcast live on NBC? Will he  please, oh gracious, benevolent Mr. Apatow  appear in a Leno fright wig himself? Leave your thoughts in the comments.

title: Up Front: Pankaj Mishra
description: A novelist, literary critic, essayist, travel writer and international journalist, Pankaj Mishra is also, as a recent interviewer in The Believer magazine put it, a maverick scholar. (A label, he joked in a recent e-mail message, that makes him sound like John McCain.)

title: Inside the List
description: AUTHORS HELPERS: Kathryn Stocketts first novel, The Help, finally hits No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list, after 41 weeks of trying. Anne Tylers 18th novel, Noahs Compass, enters at No. 3. Stockett has built her success through word-of-mouth and lots of media interviews and public appearances. Tyler (inset), on the other hand, hasnt done a book tour or given a face-to-face interview since 1977. In a recent e-mail Q. and A. with Writers Digest, she said she doesnt think about the reader until she has a final draft of a book: At that point, I seem to picture my readers as brand-new to me. They have the neuter, faceless quality of people in dreams. It comes as a shock later when a real-life reader writes to me and turns out to be a specific human being.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE GREAT GAMBLE: The Soviet War in Afghanistan,  by Gregory Feifer (Harper Perennial, $15.99.) No one ever actually ordered the invasion of Afghanistan, a Soviet general staff officer told Feifer; it just happened through inertia and confusion. In this readable history of the Soviet war, based heavily on interviews with veterans and spies conducted when he was NPRs Moscow correspondent, Feifer describes the bravery, lack of focus and futility of that effort. What can the United States learn from the Russian experience? Dont shoot up wedding parties, our reviewer, Nicholas Thompson, summarized. And never underestimate fanatics who know the terrain.

title: Editors Choice
description: COMMITTED: A Skeptic Makes Peace With Marriage,  by Elizabeth Gilbert (Viking, $26.95.) Picking up pretty much where Eat, Pray, Love left off, Gilbert describes how her boyfriends unforeseen visa problems enticed her into a most dreaded institution.

title: Naked and Conflicted
description: To the Editor:

title: Dimons Complaint: Bank Tax Isnt Spread Fairly
description: Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan Chases chief executive, says he believes it isnt fair that the big banks will be the only ones forced to pick up the TARP tab under the proposed bank tax, suggesting that other companies that benefited from the government assistance program should pay up as well.

title: Leaving Millions to a School They Embraced as Family
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J.  They were friends and confidantes, surrogate mothers for generations of boys at the Lawrenceville School, an elite boarding school that was once known as a feeder for Princeton University.

title: To Curb Emissions, Port of Los Angeles Tests Hydrogen-Electric Trucks
description: The Port of Los Angeles is buying eight heavy-duty hybrid trucks that are powered by a combination of hydrogen fuel cells and lithium batteries. The trucks come from Vision Industries of Santa Monica and are part of the ports emissions-trimming Clean Truck Program.

title: A Facebook Movement, Against Mom and Dad
description: They feel her pain. At the Spence School and Greenwich High and Fullerton Union High and Nyack High and Narragansett High, teenagers and near-teenagers, hundreds of them, are waving a virtual flag for Tess Chapin, a 15-year-old from Sunnyside, Queens, who has been grounded for five weeks. A few days after founding the Facebook group  1000 to get tess ungrounded  Tess had nearly reached her stated goal, with 806 members by Friday morning; after this column about her quest was posted on nytimes.com, she surpassed it.

title: On Assignment: Prayers in the Dark
description: Damon Winter of The New York Times arrived in Port-au-Prince on Wednesday. He has been traveling through the city in a car shared with Ron Haviv of the VII photo agency and Timothy Fadek, both veteran conflict photographers. James Estrin spoke with Mr. Winter by cellphone at midnight Thursday. Excerpts of their conversation can be heard below.

title: Complaint Box | Baby Barflies
description: As a 5-foot-4, dark-haired Jewish girl in her early 20s, I was never a minority in New York City until I moved to Park Slope, Brooklyn, where I seem to be one of the few childless residents.

title: Correction: New Housing, After a Court Order
description: The In the Region article in Westchester and Connecticut copies last Sunday, about plans and timetables for new affordable housing in Westchester in light of a recent court mandate, misidentified the nonprofit group that is marketing Minerva Place, a 14-unit affordable development in White Plains. It is Community Housing Innovations  not the Housing Action Council, another builder of affordable housing in the area.

title: Teacher Q | How Should Teachers Be Evaluated?
description: In a recent Atlantic Monthly article called What Makes a Great Teacher?, Amanda Ripley writes that the most stunning finding to come out of education research in the past decade is that more than any other variable in educationmore than schools or curriculumteachers matter.

title: Correction: Landscaping as a Seductive First Step
description: A rendering with the Postings column last Sunday about Hunters Point South, a midpriced housing development slated to be built on the Queens waterfront, carried an incomplete credit. The rendering was by Arup/Thomas Balsley Associates/Weiss/Manfredi  not just Weiss/Manfredi.

title: New Grants to Help New Yorkers Buy Foreclosed Homes
description: Home buyers may be given up to $50,000 toward buying a foreclosed home in New York, thanks to a federal fund that has been awarded to the citys housing agency, the Department of Housing Preservation and Development.

title: Correction: On the Market in the Region
description: The On the Market page last Sunday included an erroneous name on the contributors line. It was Elsa Brenner who provided a listing for a 1910 colonial in Upper Grand View in Rockland County. It was not Marcelle S. Fischler.

title: Details of Hope for Haiti Telethon Are Announced
description: Update | 1:16 p.m.  Eleven broadcast and cable networks will show a two-hour telethon next Friday night to benefit the victims of the Haitian earthquake, MTV Networks announced on Friday. The commercial-free telethon, called Hope for Haiti, will be shown starting at 8 p.m., Eastern time, on ABC, BET, CBS, CMT, CNN, CW, FOX, HBO, MTV, NBC and VH1, in addition to the MTV Networks International, CNN International and National Geographic channels, which will show it around the world.

title: Correction: Greenwich, on a More Modest Scale
description: The Living In column on Dec. 27, about Chickahominy, Conn., misspelled the name of a local stone mason who emigrated from Sardinia in the 1902s and was responsible for building various structures in town. He was Sebastiano Bazzoni, not Bozzoni.

title: Madison Avenue Makes Haste to Help Haiti
description: A public service campaign to support relief efforts after the Haitian earthquake is already under way in what the Advertising Council, which oversees pro bono initiatives from Madison Avenue, calls its fastest response to a disaster.

title: Book Review Podcast: Jonathan Dee
description: This week: Jonathan Dee talks about his new novel, The Privileges; Stacy DErasmo guides us though Javier Marass trilogy, Your Face Tomorrow; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Same-Sex Marriage Case, Day 5: Children
description: Update 6:35 p.m. Pacific Time | From the personal to the stiffly academic to the personal again, the trial came full circle by the first weeks end as Danny Chu, a lawyer in the San Francisco City Attorneys office, called Helen Zia to the witness stand.

title: Reaching Out a Valuable Part of Being an Olympian
description: In 2008, the United States Olympic Committee created the Team for Tomorrow program, an effort to involve American Olympic athletes in humanitarian relief programs around the world. They have donated tents to the earthquake-ravaged region in China in 2008 as well as worked with Habitat for Humanity to build homes for people in need. The U.S.O.C. is planning assistance to the Haitian Olympic Committee following that countrys devastating earthquake.

title: Aid Workers on How Not to Help Haiti
description: Stephanie Strom, who covers philanthropy for The Times, pointed me to a blunt and useful post written by Saundra Schimmelpfennig, a leading expert on the recovery efforts after the Asian tsunami of 2004. Ms. Schimmelpfennig has opened her blog to advice from aid workers on the right and wrong ways to donate and help in the coming days and weeks.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week: Jonathan Dee talks about his new novel, The Privileges; Stacy DErasmo guides us though Javier Marass trilogy, Your Face Tomorrow; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Sandras Sources | Matisse for the Masses (Sort Of)
description: T Magazines beauty/style director, Sandra Ballentine, opens up her little black book of tips on where to go, what to buy and whom to know.

title: H-P Ships High-Speed USB Notebook
description: A 15-inch Hewlett-Packard Envy laptop is now available with a USB 3.0 connector, making it among the first computers to be sold with the higher-speed technology.

title: Bill Clinton Urges House Democrats Onward
description: In a 45-minute speech followed by a 45-minute question-and-answer session, former President Bill Clinton exhorted House Democrats to approve major health care legislation, work closely with the White House and to head into their re-election battles in November with eyes wide open.

title: The Reading Life:  Postcards From the Edge
description: Hotel fires. Car crashes. Circus parades. Barn raisings. Offbeat family scenes. The photo postcards reprinted in Luc Santes spooky and engrossing new book, Folk Photography: The American Real-Photo Postcard 1905-1930 (Yeti Books/VerseChorus Press, $24.95), dont provide your usual images of waterfalls or mountain vistas. Theyre examples of real-photo postcards, generally made for personal or local use, not intended for tourists.

title: Answers About Improv Everywhere, Part 3
description: Editors note, April 2: a few weeks after this feature appeared, Charlie Todd of Improv Everywhere lied to City Room repeatedly as we questioned him on whether one of his stunts was an April Fools hoax (it was). While the unwritten laws of the Internet prevent us from taking these posts down, we cant vouch for anything he says here.

title: When I Was Left to Speak for Both of Us
description: This is India red, and thats black galaxy, said the saleswoman, Diane, walking along the aisle of samples. She pointed one row over. And thats Balmoral green.

title: Smart Water Meters Struggle for Foothold
description: With many states projecting that theyll face water shortages in the coming years, smart water meters that provide real-time data on water use can help conserve dwindling supplies.

title: Caring for Both Your Parents and Kids
description: We are the sandwich generation, taking care of aging parents and young children. It is estimated that 25 percent of adults with children under the age of 18 are also responsible for elder care.

title: She Hasnt Seen It
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Theres big news out of Washington today. President Obama announced a plan to recover federal bailout money from banks. I guess that explains why Biden was seen yesterday buying a gun and a ski mask.

title: Golden Globe Crossover
description: One of the many things the Hollywood Foreign Press Association likes to brag about itself  alongside the fact that it has the best party of the season and more stars in one room than a Scientology, Kabbalah and Forum meeting combined  is that the Golden Globe awards are a reliable predictor of Oscar winners. That has been true in the past; since the Globes starting nominating 10 best films, five each in drama and comedy/musical, its choices had twice the chance to line up with the Academys five, and usually the crossover was in the drama category. But in the year of The 10, things are a little hairier, as Variety points out. Not surprisingly, many believe the groups drama nominees will cross over, while the comedies will face a tougher road, writes Glenn Whipp.

title: A Possible Terrorist
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Tonight Show With Conan OBrien on NBC: Its been reported that an 8-year-old boy from New Jersey is on the governments airport watch list because he has the same name as a possible terrorist. So, its been a really bad week for little Skippy bin Laden.

title: For CF Industries, Forever Turns to Never
description: Even the Forever War has to end.

title: Already Making Friends
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: Do you folks know what is going on with NBC and the trouble theyre having with Jay Leno and Conan OBrien? I thought this was nice. President Obama invited Jay and Conan to the White House for a beer.

title: Really Cracking Down
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: Sarah Palin has signed with Fox News to be a correspondent. Well, in a statement today, Fox said if Palin does a good job, theyll sign her to a longtime contract. If she doesnt work out, theyll just blame Leno. Thats what they said.

title: Immediately After Haiti's Earthquake
description: Erik Parker, an American journalist in Haiti, shot this video on his iPhone moments after the earthquake on Tuesday, as he tried to help people trapped in a badly damaged building.

title: More Glamour at Acapulco
description: Acapulco continues go from pass to chic with the arrival of two fashionable hotels.

title: Haiti Quake Day 4: Slow Relief
description: Damien Cave reports on the relief efforts in Port-au-Prince.

title: The iPhone Wins a Touchscreen Test
description: In a test certain to stir debate, technology consulting firm Moto Development Group tested how accurately the touchscreens on four handsets performed and declared the iPhone as the winner.

title: Ravens Lineman Can Create His Own Ending
description: OWINGS MILLS, Md.  Practice had just ended, and the most famous offensive lineman in the N.F.L. was still feeling feisty. Spotting a Baltimore Ravens teammate rolling on an argyle dress sock, Michael Oher nodded his way and asked, Youre not really going to put that on, are you? A reporter wearing a sweatshirt adorned with lacrosse sticks moseyed toward Oher, who laughed and told him, Man, you wouldnt last a day in the hood.

title: Low Rates for Just a Few
description: MORTGAGE borrowers might be forgiven for sometimes feeling like victims of a bait-and-switch scheme.

title: At Years End, Sales Picked Up Pace
description: COMING off one of the worst years ever for the housing market, Connecticut has reason to be hopeful that 2010 will be better  chiefly because it is hard to imagine the economy sliding precipitously enough for sales to fall still further.

title: Hotel Points Can Help Haiti
description: At a loss with how to help earthquake victims in Haiti? In addition to mobile and more traditional forms of donating, hotels are letting members donate their points.

title: The Burger Experience Without the Beef
description: Even the most devoted burger lover may be feeling a bit queasy about eating ground beef these days.

title: School Bake Sales Are Back On, but Only for Haiti
description: The city has taken a number of steps to help Haiti, gathering donations from the public, offering to send rescue workers and city engineers and giving city employees the option to have contributions deducted from their paychecks.

title: Leading Men | Dressing the Part
description: With the Golden Globes kicking off awards season in Hollywood on Sunday, I wanted to offer some red-carpet wardrobe suggestions for our leading men. While a traditional single-breasted tuxedo will always be a handsome look, these options from the coming spring-summer season (just hitting stores now) allow for a bit more individualism. Just make sure to avoid parody  no mandarin collars, please!

title: Dealing With a Tax Burden
description: Mineola

title: Senior Qaeda Figures Killed in Attack, Yemen Says
description: SANA, Yemen  A Yemeni airstrike on Friday afternoon killed at least five senior members of Al Qaedas Arabian branch, Yemeni officials said, including the groups military commander.

title: ArtsBeat: George Clooney Spearheads a Telethon for Haiti
description: George Clooney has successfully spearheaded the creation of a telethon to aid the victims of the earthquake in Haiti. To be shown all over the dial  on ABC, CBS, NBC, FOX, CNN, BET, CW, HBO, MTV, VH1 and CM, in addition to the MTV Networks International, CNN International and National Geographic channel  the telethon will be broadcast next Friday night. Mr. Clooney will host from Los Angeles with Haitian-American musician Wyclef Jean in New York and the CNN anchor Anderson Cooper in Haiti. Read more

title: Wallpaper 2010 Design Awards
description: As completely absorbed as I was by the winner of Wallpapers domestic design award (a slow cooker by Margriet Foolen for Royal VKB), I ought to mention that the best new mens collection award went to Raf Simons and the best new womens to Rei Kawakubo. Last years fashion winners were Junya Watanabe for men and Stefano Pilati of YSL for women.

title: Working Families, Not Working
description: With so many more women in the labor force today, many people who have been laid off in this recession have at least had a spouses income to fall back on.

title: American Red Cross Haiti Spot
description: In a new spot for the American Red Cross, Michelle Obama urges viewers to support relief efforts in Haiti.

title: Making Bigger Bucks Than Ever
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Clothes Encounters
description: Whatever your circadian rhythms, you can satisfy them at the Clean Rite Center, where washers and dryers rumble all day long.

title: CIT Group to Name Interim Chief Next Week
description: The CIT Group, the commercial lender that emerged from bankruptcy last month, plans to name a temporary replacement for its chief executive, Jeffrey M. Peek, after he steps down.

title: Lots for the Family to Love
description: A ROCKLAND County hamlet in Orangetown, several miles southwest of Nyack, Pearl River is not nearly as trendy as its neighbors. It doesnt have Hudson River views or storied estates. Its downtown of unadorned storefronts is a plain Jane next to Nyacks or Piermonts.

title: Obama to Campaign in Massachusetts on Sunday
description: Updated: President Obama will travel to Massachusetts on Sunday to campaign for the Democratic Senate candidate, Martha Coakley, the White House said, a sudden decision in response to growing concern that the party could lose its 60-vote majority in the Senate and a seat that for decades belonged to Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Its Not the Hudson, but Landfill Will Do for Pilot
description: Updated, 3:26 p.m. | It might come to be called the Miracle at the Landfill.

title: What to Watch This Weekend: No More News
description: NOW on PBS (Friday night, check local listings) gets personal: the public affairs and investigative news program, which has been canceled and will go off the air in April, looks at the troubles of the news business. The guests are Bob McChesney and John Nichols, authors of The Death and Life of American Journalism: The Media Revolution That Will Begin the World Again, who advocate government subsidies for noncommercial journalism. Law & Order (NBC, 8 p.m. Friday) tackles the subject of the shrinking news business from a different angle: Lupo (Jeremy Sisto) and Bernard (Anthony Anderson) investigate the murder of a journalist.

title: 24 Hour Cycle
description: At the laundromat, irregular things happen. People square off over washers  mine; no, mine. They sit on the counters where you were planning to fold T-shirts. Women conveniently forget a negligee in a dryer so youll find it and marry them. Street people try to sell utterly unnecessary things. Pesky process servers visit bearing summonses. People stare without mercy.

title: Port of Los Angeles Tests Hydrogen-Electric Trucks
description: From our colleagues at Green Inc.:

title: Vale in Talks to Buy Fertilizer Assets in Brazil
description: Vale S.A. said Friday that it was in talks to buy Bunge Ltd.s fertilizer operations in Brazil for as much as $3.8 billion as that country, the worlds biggest producer of coffee, sugar and orange juice, seeks to cut its dependency on crop-nutrient imports.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Poster Art in Europe, Soderbergh, Spartacus and More
description: Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

title: Talk Is Cheap  And Irrelevant
description: So there appears to be a spreading piece of conventional wisdom saying that instead of trying to pass health care reform, Obama should have focused on the economy. Im with Kevin Drum: I have no idea what this is supposed to mean.

title: Ivy Assets Chief Resigns Amid Restructuring
description: Sean Simon, head of the fund of hedge funds Ivy Asset Management, has left the firm amid a broad restructuring of the fund of funds unit within its corporate parent, the Bank of New York Mellon Corporation.

title: On Health Care, Readers Speak; The Agenda Responds
description: The Agenda is grateful to all the readers who shared their views about the House and Senate health care bills. It is striking to see, at least in the reaction to the second post, that the bills seem to be under even fire from the left and the right. Now, as Democrats in the Senate, House, and White House seem to be wrapping up their negotiations, wed like to pick up on a couple of those points.

title: Lysacek Not Taking It Easy at Nationals
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  Evan Lysacek, the two-time United States national figure skating champion, didnt need the quadruple jump at last years world championships to win the world title.Without the quad, a challenging jump which requires a skater to turn four times in the air, Lysacek also won the Grand Prix final in December.

title: U.S. Mortgage Plan Aided 7 Percent of Borrowers
description: Mortgage payments have been permanently lowered for more than 66,000 borrowers under the Obama administrations $75 billion program to protect homeowners from foreclosure, according to new federal data released on Friday.

title: A Gentle Lift, but a Heavy One
description: How do you move a 14,000-pound marble vase into the Park Avenue Armory at East 67th Street?

title: Aziz Ansari Gets Intimate
description: For a guy who earned his reputation by joking about popular culture, Aziz Ansari has done a pretty good job of insinuating himself into it. From his standup routines about his way-out explorations of Facebook and Craigslist or his love of musicians like R. Kelly and the Wu-Tang Clan, Mr. Ansari, 26, has leaped into a film and television career: he appeared in the Judd Apatow movie Funny People as an annoyingly successful comedian named Randy (or, as the character prefers, Raaaaaaaandy!); and hes a star of the NBC sitcom Parks and Recreation, on which he plays the suave yet lazy government worker Tom Haverford. To his own astonishment, he has also become a friend of Kanye West, and once hung out in the rappers apartment (where they listened to Mr. Wests music).

title: Steep Job Losses Offer Hope for Fast Rebound
description: WILL labor markets in the United States remain weak for an extended period?

title: What Were Reading
description: On City Room, a tribute to Yonnah Schimmels knishery on its 100th birthday. People ask, Are your knishes fresh? said Ellen Anistratov, who owns the knishery with her father, Alex Wolfson. I say, Theyre a hundred years old. Also, Dale DeGroff has come up with a cocktail to celebrate Capt. Chesley B. Sullenberger III  The Sully  sort of a Manhattan with a float of Champagne.

title: Making Art Out of an Encounter
description: I first encountered Tino Sehgals work under ideal conditions: total ignorance. Happening to be in Berlin in 2006 at the time of the citys art biennial, I heard from an art-dealer friend that there was one exhibition not to miss. I wont tell you anything more, he said, as he walked me to the site and bid me farewell. I trod up a creaking staircase in a building from the turn of the last century and entered a decayed ballroom, its ornate moldings and gilt mirrors testifying to a more glorious past. Lying on the floor, a man and a woman, fully dressed, were embracing languidly. There was no one else in the room. My presence went unacknowledged. In a state of mounting confusion and embarrassment, I stayed until I could stand it no longer, and then I retreated down the staircase. Out on the street, I sighed with relief, because I once again knew where I was.

title: Part-Time Fulfillment
description: The past year brought about setbacks for many. For me, it signaled the end of my 25-year marriage, the loss of membership in the family medical plan and the necessity of re-entering the workplace at midlife after a long hiatus as a stay-at-home mom. The market crash gobbled up a big chunk of my modest retirement account, and the divorce litigation left me with a pile of bills.

title: Vigor Quest
description: NEARLY EVERY SUNDAY morning  Easter and Mothers Day included  John Bellizzi says goodbye to his wife, Francesca, grabs an equipment bag and slides into the front seat of his black BMW. He drives to a high-school soccer field about 10 miles from his home in the New York City suburb of Rye.

title: The Coast of Dystopia
description: I didnt move to California to become a Californian. I usually say that I came for a job; the truth is, I was young and in love and I followed a boy. That was 21 years ago, and much to my surprise, Im still here. The relationship fizzled, but I was seduced by the romance of the state. Id become a true believer in the California dream, right as it began to fall apart.

title: The Reader
description: Your latest book, The Professor, comes out on Tuesday, and Im not sure which is more surprising: the candid disclosures about your love life or the sparkling and witty prose, which you do not expect from a professor of literature at Stanford University. Why does academic writing tend to be so unreadable?  Paradoxically, academic writers are often inhibited when it comes to speaking directly, possibly because they were all little goody-goodies in junior high school, and theyre being massed together in university departments, and when you put all the smartest kids in the class together, theres a tremendous anxiety about whether one can live up to the seriousness of the enterprise.

title: The Reviewing Stand
description: Heres a challenge for students of expository writing: review a popular product on Amazon and aim to get your review chosen by readers as most helpful.

title: Smoke Screen
description: My son was dropped from our familys employee-sponsored health insurance shortly after graduating from college in May. While filling out the application for a new policy, he asked me how to answer a question about his marijuana use in the past year. I said, Honestly. He checked a box indicating he smoked very occasionally and was denied coverage. Now he is uninsured while countless pot-smoking liars have coverage. My husband thinks I gave our son foolish advice. Do you agree? M.H., MONTCLAIR, N.J.

title: Letters in Response to the 1.3.10 Issue
description: Whats a Bailed-Out Banker Worth?

title: Rescuers Race Clock in Haiti
description: Rescue efforts continued, but hope of finding more survivors of the earthquake alive faded as aid workers struggled to deliver relief supplies.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) Can gay rights boost economic prosperity?

title: Is the U.S. Doing Enough for Haiti?
description: With conditions in Haiti growing worse by the hour, the Obama administration has pledged $100 million and is sending 5,000 troops to help in relief efforts there. Should the U.S. be doing more? Does it have an obligation different from other nations? Should the U.S. take on a nation-building project in Haiti?

title: Europe Sends Aid and Pledges Money for Haiti
description: PARIS  The effort to aid Haitian earthquake victims is presenting Europe with the first test of its newly created foreign policy structure and prompting France to call on other nations to speed the forgiveness of the nations international debt.

title: Burgers, Loaded
description: All of the ketchup and mustard bottles at Coreys Catsup and Mustard are labeled Heinz. The hamburgers, though, are housemade, ground from beef every day, formed into slightly irregular, seven-ounce patties and cooked to order.

title: Turkish Medley, Amply Served
description: THE handful of Turkish restaurants in Connecticut seem to cluster in and around New Haven, so it was a surprise to see a billboard off Interstate 84 advertising Anatolia in Waterbury.

title: Can Main Street Win Business Plan Competitions?
description: Business plan competitions tend to emphasize technology.

title: A Pizza Tradition Put to a New Test
description: ONE of the shrines for pizza aficionados in Connecticut, Frank Pepe Pizzeria Napoletana, has had the audacity to open its fifth outpost smack in the middle of Central Park Avenue in Yonkers, where Rickys Clam House once stood. Central Av, as it is affectionately called by people who are particular about the tenderness of their mozzarella, is the source spring for Italian-Americans in Westchester, and the folks at Frank Pepe  the original owners grandchildren, to be exact  have taken a calculated risk in putting their thin-crusted, coal-fired pies right under the noses of a distinctly discerning audience.

title: Dual Agency Under Scrutiny
description: ITS a buyers market  everybody knows that, right? said Paul Howard, an agent for NJHomeBuyer.com in Cherry Hill. So how come so many buyers get frustrated when the seller seems to be holding more cards?

title: Comfort and Spice
description: Theres a stretch of Shrewsbury Avenue in Red Bank thats lined with small Mexican grocery stores. Thats where youll find La Chaparrita, where the shelves are stocked with staples like salsas and queso fresco. But customers are drawn as well by the fresh Mexican comfort food.

title: Fossil Fuel Use in 2034? Not Much Different.
description: A quarter century from now the United States reliance on fossil fuels will have declined only marginally, according to a projection from Black & Veatch, the engineering and energy consulting firm.

title: Wireless Companies Speed Up Texted Haiti Donations
description: Update | 3:45 p.m.  Adding information from Sprint.

title: Making History in a Brooklyn Neighborhood
description: WHEN Habitat for Humanity New York City consulted an architecture firm on its new site in the Ocean Hill section of Brownsville, Brooklyn, it received a response that switched on a light bulb. The firm, Dattner Architects, said that Habitat could proceed with its plan to build 12 town houses on the trash-strewn vacant lot, but that the site was actually capable of supporting many more units in apartment form  41, to be exact.

title: Schumacher Completes GP2 Test, Ready to Go for It
description: Michael Schumacher is feeling strong after his first real test on his comeback road to Formula One.

title: Wings for Super Sunday
description: On Super Bowl Sunday, Feb. 7, Peter Ambrosio, the owner of Taxis Grille in Huntington, expects to sell more than 500 dozen fried chicken wings. Thats roughly 1,000 pounds of takeout, just in time for the big game.

title: The River Floes
description: The Hudson River has frozen over as far south as Manhattan only three times in recorded history, according to I.N. Phelps Stokess six-volume classic Iconography of Manhattan Island. It hasnt happened since 1821. So this scene, captured by a reader, Harrison Hill, on Wednesday, looking south from the Chelsea waterfront to the skylines of Lower Manhattan and Jersey City, is about as close as we get these days. Still, its not too bad. Thank you, Mr. Hill.

title: The Problem of Corporatism
description: Chris Hayes has a great essay in The Nation that distills the free-floating left-wing anxiety about the Obama-era marriage of Big Business and Big Government, and tries to figure out what progressives ought to do about it. One answer he rejects is the possibility of a left-right alliance against crony capitalism:

title: An Oakland Police Sergeants View of the Drug Trade
description: For 10 years, Sgt. Bernard Ortiz specialized in drug enforcement, then in 2008 became a sergeant for an eight-man squad (problem-solving officers, in Oakland police department parlance) in the North Oakland area.

title: If Senators Bought Group Insurance
description: In virtually every industrialized country outside the United States, the contribution people make toward their health insurance is divorced from their age and health status. While this arrangement  known as community rating  is taken for granted abroad, it is still astoundingly controversial here in the United States.

title: Rich People Exercise More
description: Rich people are much more likely to exercise than their poorer brethren, according to new survey findings from Gallup.

title: Arenas Pleads Guilty to Gun Charge
description: WASHINGTON  Wizards point guard Gilbert Arenas pleaded guilty Friday afternoon to a felony charge of carrying a pistol without a license. Sentencing will be on March 26.

title: Schumacher Completes GP2 Test, Ready to Go for It
description: From our colleagues at Formula One:

title: President of Stevens Institute Agrees to Step Down
description: The embattled president of Stevens Institute of Technology, Harold J. Ravech, will step down in July, the college said Friday. And under terms of a settlement ending a lawsuit by the State of New Jersey that questioned his $1.1 million salary, the institute has accepted extensive governance changes that will stiffen oversight of its financial management.

title: A Brooklyn Apartment Sold Too Soon?
description: MY face betrayed me, disbelief slowly turning to distress as I stared silently at the Sunday real estate listings spread out on the kitchen table. It was a look my wife had seen too many times.

title: Lights! Speakers! Sound (in the Ceiling)!
description: Sonos popularized the idea of wirelessly sending music stored on your PC to satellite speakers around the house. Now Klipsch, the speaker manufacturer, has come up with a variation: Wirelessly sending music to light bulbs around the house.

title: Giuliani Stumps for Brown in Mass. Senate Race
description: BOSTON  In the shadow of the Old North Church where lanterns were held for Paul Revere, supporters of the Republican Senate candidate, Scott Brown, seized on the scenes revolutionary history, saying: The liberals are going.

title: Jonathan F. P. Rose
description: Mr. Rose, 58, is the founder and president of the Jonathan Rose Companies, which specializes in sustainable development. The company is involved in both nonprofit and for-profit projects and is one of the largest developers of affordable housing in New York City.

title: The Spirit of Port-au-Prince, Now Broken
description: Kesler Pierre grew up in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, attending services at the Port-au-Prince Cathedral. He saw Pope Jean Paul II near the cathedral during his 1983 visit. The cathedral is the tallest building in Port-au-Prince, he said on Friday in Brooklyn. You cant get lost in the city, because anywhere you are, you can see it.

title: Hands On With HPs Web-Connected Printer
description: HP made a splash last year with the introduction of its Photosmart Premium TouchSmart Web inkjet printer. The all-in-one device  it prints, copies, faxes, and scans  connects directly to the Web and wireless-enabled computers with built-in Wi-Fi. It is fronted by a very intuitive 4.3-inch touch-screen LCD for printer navigation and preview of photos.

title: Potential Strike Looming, Cleveland Musicians Make Their Case to an Audience
description: Members of the Cleveland Orchestra were onstage Thursday night for a performance of Strausss Don Juan, a violin concerto by Thomas Ads and Brahmss Second Symphony. It was their first night back with their music director, Franz Welser-Mst, since they had said a strike could take place as early as Monday. About 15 minutes before the concerts 8 p.m. start time, they left the stage, and a colleague announced that they would be passing through the aisles with leaflets, which is exactly what they did.

title: Democrats Forced to Yank Ad Over 9/11 Image
description: With the Massachusetts Senate race now in anybodys guess territory, the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee has gone up with another advertisement  but not without a little difficulty.

title: Power, Power Everywhere
description: Filmmakers know that five minutes  even though it doesnt sound lengthy  can be a long amount of screen time. And now users of YoGens new hand-cranked cellphone charger will discover that truism as well.

title: Winter in America (in Florence)
description: The arctic weather in Europe may be the simple answer, or perhaps its something deeper, but for some reason everybody at the Pitti Immagine Uomo trade fair in Florence, Italy, which closed today, was dressed like a mountaineer. On the runways and on the Renaissance streets, the default look comprised hiking boots, heavy felted, checked-wool puffed coats and scarves as wide as king-size bedspreads.Fashion rarely follows function or logic, but the fallout from the crumbling financial markets may also be responsible for this back-to-nature escapism. The Japanese have been forecasting this nature-bound, anti-urban trend for a few seasons and avant-garde Tokyo brands and boutiques have gone crazy for original plaid, snow boots and hunting gear of every kind, in the process re-energizing staid American mountain classics like Timberland, Pendleton, Woolrich, Filson, L.L. Bean and Red Wing. Last season at Pitti, Undercover showed a mix of tech and country styles that may have influenced the general mood.

title: Mural Spotting, the Oakland Mystery Game
description: Walk around Oakland and you see weathered murals on buildings and under freeway underpasses, overlooked remnants of a time when public art had a lot of support. Sometimes, I catch sight of a mural from a freeway, or even in the rear view mirror of my car as I drive in downtown Oakland.

title: Nelson Requests Removal of Nebraska Aid From Final Bill
description: Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, on Friday asked the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, to remove a special provision in the health care legislation that would have the federal government pay for all of Nebraskas costs of a proposed expansion of Medicaid, the federal-state insurance program for low-income Americans.

title: Australian Open Mens Field Is Wide Open
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Tennis officials here are fond of calling the Australian Open, which opens Monday, the Grand Slam of Asia/Pacific.

title: Being Orson Welles
description: Im curious to find out when youll be posting Christians interview, Christian McKays newly hired publicist e-mailed the Bagger a few days after we did the interview, the subtext being: please, run the interview! O.K., well bite. Mr. McKay drew uniformly great notices for his performance as Orson Welles in Me and Orson Welles, otherwise known as the indie vehicle in which Zac Efron didnt have bangs. A. O. Scott wrote that Mr. McKay, a British actor with a slender rsum and superhuman confidence, played the part with a brio and wit that puts most biopic mummery to shame.

title: Totally in His Element
description: SOME New Yorkers long to live in spanking new apartment buildings outfitted with sleekly designed lobbies and basement health clubs. To many other New Yorkers, nothing is as desirable as a prewar apartment, with its artfully arranged rooms and walls so thick that some latter-day residents have trouble getting wi-fi service.

title: Citadels Head of Investment Banking Leaves
description: Todd Kaplan, the head of investment banking at Citadel Investment Group, the giant hedge fund firm run by Kenneth C. Griffin, has resigned less than a year after joining the firm.

title: Chinese Gay Pageant Is Shut Down
description: BEIJING  The contestants were prepping backstage and the judges were settling in, but the first Mr. Gay China pageant was not meant to be. An hour before the show was set to begin on Friday night, eight police officers walked into the Lan Club and shut down the event, saying organizers lacked necessary permits.

title: Correction
description: In a column last week, I quoted Jonathan R. Cole, who praised the University of Chicago in his book The Great American University: Its Rise to Pre-eminence, Its Indispensable National Role, Why It Must be Protected. I failed to mention that Mr. Coles publisher, PublicAffairs Books, was founded by Peter Osnos, the chairman of the Chicago News Cooperative advisory board. Mr. Osnos had no role in the origin or handling of the column.

title: Protesters Win Right to March Outside Mayors House
description: A group of protesters who sued the city for the right to demonstrate outside of the Upper East Side town house of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg have won their case and will be permitted to hold their march, a lawyer representing the group said Friday.

title: For Financial Advice, Arriving at the Right Dosage
description: Most everyone needs financial advice. The big question is how much.

title: One of the Virgin Islands Welcomes First Resort
description: Private islands in the Caribbean dont come cheap. But the Scrub Island Resort, which is expected to open next month in the British Virgin Islands, promises all the privacy without the high price.

title: The Exercise
description: Here are the instructions for

title: Much Ado About a Beach Boy Cuda
description: The personal 1971 Plymouth Hemi Cuda of the Beach Boy singer Al Jardine could be the subject of an increased amount of notice when it crosses the auction block next week at the Barrett-Jackson event in Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: Prosecutors Near New Plea Deal in Galleon Case
description: Update | 5:56 p.m. Federal prosecutors on Friday said that they were near another plea agreement in the Galleon Group case, a disclosure made as the government asked for more time to file indictments against three of the original defendants in the matter.

title: More on Jon Gruber
description: Today Glenn Greenwald accused me of being a hypocrite for defending Jonathan Gruber, the health care economist who has become a target of some progressive opponents of the health care plan. He writes:

title: Obama on Aid to Haiti
description: President Obama pledges continued immediate and long-term support to Haiti. (NBC video)

title: Do You Pay For Financial Advice?
description: This weeks Your Money column discusses how much financial advice we need and when we should start paying for it.

title: Cutcliffe Will Stay at Duke
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  Dukes David Cutcliffe was apparently one of the targets of Tennessees search for a new football coach because Cutcliffe issued a statement Friday morning saying he was going to remain in Durham, N.C.

title: Testosterone to Fine-Tune an Aging Body
description: Can a regimen of exercise, vitamins, supplements and hormone shots slow down natures clock? Thats the question explored in The New York Times Magazine this week. The story begins with 51-year-old John Bellizzi of Rye, N.Y., a patient of Dr. Florence Comite, a Manhattan endocrinologist.

title: Classic Ad: 1954 Motorama
description: O.K., so its not an ad, really. But given the mostly sober proceedings at this years Detroit auto show, a look back at the bygone era of automotive glitz and glamor may be in order. And nothing exemplified pizazz during Detroits glory years quite like the General Motors Motorama, seen here in a 1954 promotional film.

title: Status of Sand Volleyball Upheld in N.C.A.A. Vote
description: Sand volleyball has secured its spot on the list of emerging sports for women after narrowly surviving a vote Friday by Division I institutions and athletic conferences at the N.C.A.A. Convention in Atlanta to strip the sport of its status.

title: Iran Warns Protesters Era of Mercy Is Over
description: SANA, Yemen  Irans national police chief issued a stark warning to the countrys opposition on Friday, saying that the era of mercy was over and that the authorities would begin cracking down more harshly not only on street protests but also on anyone who used cellphones and e-mail messages to publicize them.

title: Baroque Dexterity Applied to Dark French Passions
description: Like most countertenors, the French singer Philippe Jaroussky has specialized in the Baroque repertory, recording a number of impressive discs, including music by Vivaldi.

title: Should Tess Be Grounded?
description: Whats a fair punishment for a 15-year-old who drinks alcohol at a party and misses curfew by an hour?

title: Schumer Seeks to Keep Immigration Detention Site in Manhattan Open
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer is urging federal officials not to close immigration detention operations at the Varick Federal Detention Facility in Manhattan, saying that their decision to transfer its roughly 300 detainees to a county jail in New Jersey will represent a crushing blow to the due process rights of immigrants detained within the New York metropolitan area.

title: Dream On Dept. | The Other Golden Globes
description: The Golden Globes, which will be awarded on Sunday, certainly qualify as Must See TV. We cant wait to watch the endless parade of stars get up to the podium and thank the people who made it all possible for them: the directors, the producers, the agents, the plastic surgeons. Of course, there will be the usual camera pans to a smiling Jack Nicholson and a smirking Warren Beatty, insidery jokes by Tina Fey about the late-night wars, acceptance speeches by Meryl Streep and hopefully, plenty of heckling from the bleachers from the likes of Janice Dickinson and Bai Ling. Here are some of our favorite moments you might not see on your flat screen.Best Acceptance SpeechQuentin Tarantino thanking his first grade spelling teacher for inspiring Inglourious Basterds.

title: Taste. Smell. Ahhhh, Wisdom.
description: It starts with The Exercise. Become aware of where you are right now. Be aware of any expectations or concerns that may be present in the mind or heart. Now, let them go. Feel your feet on the ground, your clothes on your skin. Taste. Smell. Watch the breath as it enters and leaves the body. Now be aware of hearing. And so on.

title: Chairman Has a Gripe With the M.T.A., and a Desire to Fix It
