description: New Yorks bus, subway and rail network is inefficient, bloated and falling behind the worlds great transit systems.

title: Drug Industry Group Threatens to Withdraw Support
description: Update | 5:42 p.m.

title: Of Mutual Influence: The City and the 16th President
description: THINK Lincoln and New York and what first comes to mind might be the tunnel, the performing arts center, a hospital in the Bronx or a high school in Brooklyn.

title: The Gavel Falls on Tavern on the Green
description: Everybody was invited to a three-day auction at Tavern on the Green this week.

title: A Suburban Treasure, Left to Die
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y.

title: The Movies Coming on. No Barking.
description: Andrea Arden, 41, trains dogs for Animal Planets canine rags-to-riches makeover series, Underdog to Wonderdog, and for 15 years has run her own dog education/behavior modification business from three locations in Manhattan, including Animal Haven, a shelter on Centre Street. Separated from her husband, she lives in Red Hook, Brooklyn, with two Dobermans, two Savannah cats and her scruffy white terrier mix, Nora.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: HOMAGE is a new indoor skate spot opened by Michelle Sauer, 34, and Jose Portes, 36, a skateboarding couple whose skate shop, also named Homage, is a few blocks away, at 151 Smith Street. The shop is a big skater hangout and the couple offers lessons, but since it can be tough to find practice space in the winter, they opened this garage-like park at 615 Degraw Street, which has a suitable concrete floor and several wooden skateboard ramps wedged into it. The 2,500-square-foot space accommodates about 20 skaters; for now, it is open only to members who pay $100. Ms. Sauer, a former designer at Zoo York, the skateboard company, and at Burton, the snowboard company, said she and Mr. Portes planned to offer day-rate admission soon. Its hard for New Yorkers to skate in the winter, Mr. Portes said. So we wanted to set up a training facility because we want to see more pro skaters coming out of New York.

title: New American Attitude Applied to Old Favorites
description: IN a rollicking economy, the moderate prices, attentive service and solid food of BT Bistro, which opened in May, would probably ensure nightly crowds. Its location on Route 1, at the Clarion Hotel Palmer Inn, is an asset. So is the loyal clientele of the long-lived Ferry House in downtown Princeton, also owned by Bobby Trigg, who is the proprietor here.

title: Full Bottles to Light Pours: A Spot for Wine Lovers
description: ARRIQUE Kitchen and Wine Bar, which opened in Babylon Village in September, is a wine lovers dream. Fifty of the 150 wines on the list are available as half-bottles; 30 are sold by the glass in either three-ounce or six-ounce pours. And the restaurant will open any bottle on the list and sell it by the glass to a customer who commits to buying two glasses.

title: Chic in Review | Kate Moss Drops a Habit
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Audio: The Health-Tax Deal
description: Here are two questions  one economic, one political  about the deal between the White House and labor unions regarding the tax on health-cost health plans:

title: Globe Trotting to Iceland, Japan and Appalachia
description: Oneida

title: Famous Peacenik Joins the Army
description: The Baggers big-(clown) shoes-to-fill predecessor, David Carr, is buddies with Woody Harrelson, so much so that when we started talking to Mr. Harrelson at a lunch recently, he decided to text Mr. Carr mid-talk. (Im going to tell him Im talking to the new him, he said.) Not sucking up, but the new him thinks that Mr. Harrelson has a shot at some awards glory at the Golden Globes this weekend for his against-type performance in The Messenger as Capt. Tony Scott, a hard-driving, hard-living Army man charged with delivering news of fallen soldiers to their families. Mr. Harrelson, of course, is a famous peacenik, a hippie by his own admission, known equally for being pro-marijuana and antiwar.

title: Paulson and Friedman Called to Testify About A.I.G.
description: The list of those called to testify for a House inquiry into the American International Group and its payouts to its counterparties just gained a few more high-wattage witnesses.

title: Sunday Preview
description: K2, distant and mysterious, is perhaps the most feared and respected climbing peak in the world. Graham Bowley, who reports on business for The New York Times, journeys there to discover an icy world as perilous as it is beautiful.

title: Outsider Images in the Soviet Twilight
description: American visitors to Four Perspectives Through the Lens: Soviet Art Photography in the 1970s-1980s, an exhibition at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum, may be surprised to discover that photography was not officially considered art in the former Soviet Union. It was regarded as a documentary tool at the service of Communist Party propaganda.

title: Correction: No More Que Ser Ser: Give Day Her Due
description: An article last Sunday about the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences lack of recognition of Doris Day referred incorrectly to the academys recognition of Orson Welles. He did in fact win an Oscar in a specific category, for best screenplay (Citizen Kane) in 1941. It is not the case that, like Charlie Chaplin, he inexplicably never won the prize in competition. (Welles also received an honorary Oscar in 1970.)

title: Correction: Being Clooney: Not as Easy as It Looks
description: An article last Sunday about George Clooney misstated the profession of the character he played in Michael Clayton. He was a lawyer and former prosecutor; he was not a former police officer.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 944 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Friday:

title: Correction: Coming Out in Ireland: Stories Set to Song
description: An article on Dec. 27 about the play Silver Stars misstated the project on which Culture Ireland and the Irish Theater Institute collaborated for the Dublin Theater Festival, where the play had a run in September. They produced a showcase with the Dublin Theater Festival, they did not produce the entire festival.

title: Women, in All Their Glory
description: The Nassau County Museum of Art has its own building, lovely grounds and a pretty good collection, but like many suburban arts institutions, it struggles to find money for programming. One result is an exhibition like The Subject Is Women: Impressionism and Post-Impressionism, drawn largely from the collection of Arthur Levine, a vice president of the museums board, and his wife, Arlene Levine.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 15
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: A String of Successes in New London Music
description: New London

title: The Week Ahead: Jan. 17-23
description: Dance

title: Santo Domingo to Bedford, and Latin to Classical
description: LEONARD SLATKIN is a big jazz fan. But he was unprepared for what unfolded when, after performing as guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic at Lincoln Center one spring night in 1995, he decided to catch the pianist Michel Camilos show at the Blue Note in Greenwich Village.

title: Writer to Speak at a Tea on King Day
description: FOR the past 11 years, the Westchester Library System has celebrated Martin Luther Kings Birthday by holding the African-American Writers and Readers Literary Tea at Abigail Kirschs Tappan Hill in Tarrytown. Co-sponsored by the Westchester chapter of the Links, a service organization, the tea also ushers in Black History Month, during which African-American literature, performances, films and other events will be presented at the countys 38 member libraries.

title: Haitians Illegally in U.S. Given Protected Status
description: The Obama administration extended a special immigration status on Friday to Haitians living illegally in the United States that protects them from deportation for 18 months and allows them to work here.

title: On East 95th, Lodger Was Last of the Line
description: The landlord from his old building was on the phone.

title: Reliving the 60s, on Screen and Live
description: If life made sense, Simone Fortis name would be writ large, along with the other Judson Dance Theater artists who shattered conventional notions of performance in the 1960s. As it is, even those who are deeply invested in this history too seldom get a chance to see Ms. Fortis work from this period and hear her charming, astute contextualization for it.

title: Blaufrnkisch Reveals Itself
description: Just returned from a lunch with six Austrian producers of blaufrnkisch, and some of their wines were revelatory.

title: For Crew and Passengers of Flight 1549, Reunions and Reminiscences
description: Forty degrees 46 minutes 10.19 seconds north latitude, 74 degrees 16.69 seconds west longitude: Michael Leonard had been there before.

title: A New Look for the First Lady
description: After the family vacation in Hawaii, where a smooth, practical knot seemed to work, Michelle Obama has emerged with a new hairstyle. It looks shorter, rounder, more managed. One might be tempted to call the style an updated version of the classic Washington helmet. Mrs. Obama has tried a number of styles, their common theme a polished look that keeps the hair off her face. The style she wore around the Inaugural was somewhat longer and sportier, with bangs to one side. She did a glamorous version of that look for different events in April and May. Late in 2009, the bangs seemed to vanish.

title: Bill Clinton Rallies With Coakley
description: Updated: BOSTON  Former President Bill Clinton, along with a veritable Whos-who of Massachusetts Democrats rallied hundreds of supporters at a Boston hotel Friday afternoon, urging them to get out the vote amid signs that the race for the late Sen. Edward M. Kennedys seat is too close to call.

title: Winter Citrus Salad
description: Mark Bittman takes a bite out of scurvy with a salad of oranges and grapefruit with honey dressing.

title: The Gavel Falls on Tavern on the Green
description: From Glenn Collins at Diners Journal:

title: Quixotes of the Theater, Chasing Complete Works
description: Theatergoers had various reasons to attend the recent opening night of The Two Noble Kinsmen by a small New York company called the Guerrilla Shakespeare Project. Some were lured by the plays tale of two Theban soldiers. Others were friends of the cast or crew, or were there for the free Trader Joes sauvignon blanc.

title: Negotiators Break for the Weekend
description: White House and Congressional leaders working on a final version of far-reaching health care legislation have wrapped up their discussions  at least for the weekend  and officials will now wait for cost analysis on various proposals to bridge the final differences between the House and Senate version so of the bill.

title: Allowing Citrus to Add Sunshine
description: GOOD citrus can almost make you glad its winter. When its in season  thats now  its equal or superior to anything else you can buy in the plant kingdom. Any way you can devise to eat it, youre taking advantage of something at its peak. If this year is different because of Floridas bad weather, it only makes the good citrus that arrives more precious.

title: Another House Democrat Bows Out
description: Representative Vic Snyder of Arkansas announced Friday evening that he would not run for re-election in November, becoming the 11th House Democrat to bow out in the tough political environment.

title: How Long Have You Been at Your Job?
description: In China, its known as the iron rice bowl. In the United States, its the career job: the position you have for your entire working life, the job you never expect to lose or leave. But does it exist? Or rather, did it ever exist?

title: Duck Confit, and Hold the Fat
description: I HAD always been under the impression that making duck confit at home was a major undertaking, something along the lines of poaching a whole foie gras or deboning a pigs foot. It was on the list of things to cook in my lifetime, but not necessarily high on the page.

title: Battling Fears on Building Restrictions
description: Forty towns and villages out of the 111 incorporated communities on Long Island have adopted landmarking measures of varying strength to protect their historically and architecturally significant buildings and sites. Of the 40, 10 have enacted landmark laws that allow local governments to designate properties without owner consent, according to Alexandra Parsons Wolfe, director of the Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities.

title: A Bid to Preserve an Old Power Station
description: The Glenwood Power Station in Yonkers, with its twin smokestacks and majestic brick structure, is a familiar sight to riders of the Metro-North Railroad. But the station, constructed between 1904 and 1906 as part of railroad electrification, is hard to describe. It wasnt really built with a particular style in mind, said Erin Tobin, a regional director for the Preservation League of New York State. It has Romanesque Revival elements.

title: Hartford, a Shining Example
description: About 100 of Connecticuts 169 cities and towns have local historic districts or other neighborhood preservation protections, but Hartford is the only place where the ordinance is citywide. In Hartford, buildings listed on the state register of historic places come under the ordinances jurisdiction, and those structures can be demolished only if there is no feasible or prudent alternative. Its a shining example, said Helen Higgins, executive director of the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation. And its been hugely successful.

title: With a Tax, Restoring a Historic Fort
description: Fort Mott, in Pennsville, N.J., served as the main coastal defense for Philadelphia harbor during the Spanish-American War. Today, the fort, now a state park, has crumbling infrastructure and damaged walls, but not for long. Thanks to a business tax collected under a 2006 state constitutional amendment, a $1.65 million restoration project can begin.

title: A Recession, but Threats Persist
description: During the fiscal crisis of the 1970s, when big development projects in New York City were suspended, many New Yorkers decided to save their city by preserving it.

title: More Ways to Help Haiti
description: Heres an update on fund raising that restaurants and others in the food world are doing to help victims of the earthquake in Haiti.

title: From Bay State to Red State?
description: Strike One: The mission in Afghanistan was to go in because we believed that the Taliban was giving harbor to terrorists  Theyre gone. Theyre not there anymore.

title: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 15
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City. Subjects include passage of a medical marijuana bill, grief over lives lost in the Haitian earthquake, and the destruction of a shanty town on Long Island.

title: New Arrests in Japan Fund-Raising Scandal
description: TOKYO  Prosecutors arrested two former aides of a leading member of Japans ruling party on Friday, adding to a growing scandal over campaign finance that has dogged the new government.

title: Haitians Treated in Miami Hospitals
description: 23 patients  Haitian and American  have been admitted to the hospitals of the Jackson health system in South Florida. As of Friday afternoon, five have been discharged, seven are in critical condition, and the rest are stable. Two of the patients are children, one a 7-year-old boy, hospital administrators said. The injuries ranged from broken bones to head trauma.

title: No Longer Their Golden Ticket
description: THE first-year corporate lawyers of The Deep End, a series that has its premiere on ABC this week, inhabit an alternative legal universe, where advancement on the partner track seems measured by their perfect grooming and ability to model designer suits and trade flirtatious banter.

title: A Good Decade to Have a Drink
description: BY now, most of the reviews of the decade-that-just-was have been filed, and a consensus has emerged: If not the worst decade ever, as Time magazine put it, the 00s were awful.

title: Can Google Beat China?
description: Updated, Jan. 16, 9:40 a.m. |  Ross Anderson of Cambridge University joins the discussion. He says the growing complexity and volume of Web traffic will only make government censorship harder.

title: Elizabeth Edwards Teeters on Her Pedestal
description: YET another illusion has been shattered.

title: Progress Report of a Millennium Village
description: The following is the first in a series of reports from the Ethiopian village of Koraro, an important testing ground for the Millennium Village Project, an experiment in global development strategy spearheaded by economist Jeffrey Sachs. The reports, written by Jeff Marlow, a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, consider which parts of the project are working and which ones arent, and what can be learned from it to help billions of people escape extreme poverty.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Torn Between 2 Phones: Nexus One vs. iPhone
description: To switch or not to switch, that is the question. Googles announcement of its Nexus One smartphone happened over a week ago and Im still receiving lots of Tweets and e-mail from readers asking the same question: Should they give up their iPhone for the Nexus One?

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Beatles Video Game: Sales Not So Fab
description: Heres some news the Beatles were never used to hearing: they arent selling very well. According to a new report released by a market research company that tracks the video game industry, the heavily promoted (and widely lauded) game the Beatles: Rock Band has not performed as well as other popular music games, and the genre as a whole appears to be declining. The report, released on Thursday by NPD Group, said that over all the gaming industry had its best month ever in December, with more than $5.5 billion in sales of software, consoles and other hardware, and that the popular first-person shooter Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 had become the fourth-best-selling game of all time. But for games that involve the use of plastic guitars instead of guns, the picture wasnt as rosy. The Beatles: Rock Band, which allows players to tap buttons along to the music of the Fab Four, has sold 1.18 million copies in the United States and 1.7 million copies worldwide since its release in September. By comparison, the music game Rock Band 2 sold 1.7 million copies in its first four months of release in 2008, and Guitar Hero: World Tour sold 3.4 million copies in that time. Guitar Hero 5, a franchise sequel released in September, has sold 996,000 copies.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Modest Interest in Haiti Special
description: A prime-time special about the earthquake in Haiti was no match on Thursday for the usual fare of crime shows and medical dramas. According to Nielsens estimates, ABCs hourlong special, Earthquake Haiti: Race to Save a Country, drew 5.4 million viewers, finishing well behind Foxs Bones (10.7 million) and a CBS rerun of The Mentalist (9.6 million). CBS led the night over all with CSI (15.4 million) and a new episode of The Mentalist at 10 (15.3 million). ABC finished second, with Greys Anatomy (12.7 million) and Private Practice (11 million). Fox was third with Fringe (6.6 million), while NBC ranked fourth with back-to-back episodes of 30 Rock (5 million each).

title: Being Lady Gaga Can Wear You Out
description: The relentless life of Lady Gaga, below, filled with burdensome headpieces and nonstop costume changes and makeup jobs, has at last gotten to her. On Thursday night that chameleonlike pop singer (whose real name is Stefani Germanotta) canceled a show at Purdue University in West Lafayette, Ind., citing exhaustion, Billboard reported. On her Twitter account Lady Gaga wrote on Thursday night that she was feeling dizzy and having trouble breathing, and that paramedics later came and diagnosed exhaustion and dehydration. She said her show, which has many coordinated moving parts and mechanical elements, would be too dangerous to perform because, she wrote, she had passed out earlier. Billboard said the Indiana show would be rescheduled for Jan 26; Lady Gagas Monster Ball tour is scheduled to go to Atlantic City on Saturday and play four shows at Radio City Music Hall next week. The Associated Press reported that Lady Gaga performed on Friday on The Oprah Winfrey Show, showing no signs of illness.

title: Cleveland Musicians Make Case to Audience
description: Members of the Cleveland Orchestra were onstage on Thursday night for performances of Strausss Don Juan, a violin concerto by Thomas Ads and Brahmss Second Symphony. It was their first night back with their music director, Franz Welser-Mst, since Jan. 6, when they had said that a strike could take place as early as this Monday. About 15 minutes before the concerts 8 p.m. start time, they left the stage, and a colleague announced that they would be passing through the aisles with leaflets, which is exactly what they did. (Above, the keyboardist Joela Jones.) The leaflets made the performers case in a contract dispute with management, which wants them to take a salary cut this season, as staff members and executives have done. The musicians are calling for a freeze in pay at last years levels. After the leaflets were distributed, the players made their way back to their chairs, tuned up and started Don Juan.

title: Angels in America to Be Revived
description: The first New York revival of Angels in America, Tony Kushners landmark play about politics, AIDS and love, will begin preview performances at the Signature Theater Company on Sept. 14 and open in late October, with tickets priced at $20, Signatures leaders announced on Thursday afternoon. The two parts of Angels in America, titled Millennium Approaches and Perestroika, will alternate in repertory from the start of performances and will be directed by Michael Greif, above right with Mr. Kushner and a Tony Award nominee for the musicals Next to Normal, Grey Gardens and Rent. The casting process is currently under way. An Off Broadway nonprofit theater, Signature has long drawn critical praise for its productions devoted to a single playwright each season and for charging an unusually low price for tickets (largely because of a grant from Time Warner Inc.). Two more works by Mr. Kushner will be presented during Signatures 2010-11 season, its 20th. How long the initial run of Angels will last is not clear: Signature leaders did not give a time frame for the production, and it is almost certain to be extended if demand is strong. Subscriptions to the Kushner season will go on sale this spring, and individual tickets this summer.

title: Editor & Publisher Finds New Owner
description: Cue the punch lines: The owner of a publication called FishRap has resuscitated Editor & Publisher, the magazine devoted to covering the newspaper industry. But the new Editor & Publisher returned to life late on Thursday, two weeks after it shut down, without two of its stalwarts. The editor, Greg Mitchell, and Joe Strupp, perhaps its best-known reporter, were not retained by the new owner, Duncan McIntosh. Mark Fitzgerald, who has worked at the magazine for 26 years, was named the new editor. Nielsen Business Media announced last month that it would close Editor & Publisher at the end of 2009, prompting inquiries from several potential buyers. The sale to the Duncan McIntosh Company, for an undisclosed sum, was announced on Thursday. Mr. McIntosh said in an interview that he wanted to shift Editor & Publishers focus toward the business and technology of the industry, with less emphasis on what happens in newsrooms. His company, based in Irvine, Calif., publishes several magazines and Web sites about boating and fishing, including Boating World.

title: On Eve of Popes Visit to Synagogue, Some Ask if It Will Help
description: ROME  When Pope John Paul II visited Romes main synagogue in 1986, the first time a pope had ever entered a Jewish house of worship, it was a historic step forward in Catholic-Jewish relations. When Pope Benedict XVI visits the same synagogue on Sunday, the question is whether it will begin to repair the tensions that have developed between the two religions under his papacy.

title: Sun Eclipsed: Ring Round the Moon
description: The Moon did its job Friday. The annular solar eclipse was observed on the southern tip of India by Jay Pasachoff, the Williams astronomer and eclipse expert. Heres his dispatch to the Lab from Kanyakumari:

title: Sisters in Cinema
description: LOS ANGELES

title: In Capital, Health Crisis Overwhelms Rescue Effort
description: With uncounted thousands dead and many thousands more injured, the stricken city of Port-au-Prince is in a vast medical crisis.

title: Recasting Serbias Image, Starting With a Fresh Face
description: BELGRADE, Serbia

title: Envoys to Meet on Possible Sanctions Over Iran Nuclear Program
description: UNITED NATIONS  Senior diplomats from the five permanent members of the Security Council and from Germany are scheduled to meet in New York on Saturday to discuss imposing new sanctions on Iran, with the Western nations seeking tough measures while China appears to be stalling for time.

title: Strike Killed Hijacking Suspect, Pakistan Officials Say
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A militant of Palestinian origin who had been on the F.B.I.s most-wanted list was killed in an American airstrike, two Pakistani intelligence officials said Friday.

title: On Doubling Out of the Blue
description: If you play duplicate, at the end of a session check your scorecard and see how often the opponents went down two or more undoubled. If it happens a few times, you are not doubling for penalty often enough.

title: Political Turmoil Follows Barring of Hundreds From Iraq Ballot
description: BAGHDAD  A knot of young men stood Friday outside the Umm Al Qura Mosque, once a nest of insurgent fervor where a year of relative tranquillity has softened the jagged edges of nearby bullet holes. They were angry, frustrated and quick to punctuate their denunciations of a decision to bar scores of Sunni candidates from Iraqi elections in March with a single word: sharaiyya, Arabic for legitimacy.

title: Changes Made by a Single Stroke
description: Julian Casablancas seemed genuinely surprised that he was still a rock star when he brought his band to Terminal 5 on Thursday night, starting a two-night stand. A decade ago Mr. Casablancass band, the Strokes, spearheaded a New York City rock resurgence with concise, guitar-driven songs about alienation, glamor and strained romance. After three Strokes albums, the latest in 2006, the band members turned to solo projects, and Mr. Casablancas released his own album, Phrazes for the Young (Cult/RCA), in November.

title: Kenya: Decision to Deport Cleric Prompts Protests
description: Police officers in Nairobi on Friday clashed with rock-throwing mobs who were angry about the governments decision to deport a radical Islamist cleric. The police fired tear gas and unleashed attack dogs on hundreds of demonstrators. Witnesses said at least three people were killed. Kenyan officials recently arrested the Jamaican-born cleric, Abdullah al-Faisal, who has served jail time in Britain for inciting hatred, and are trying to deport him.

title: Japan: Navy Ends Mission in Support of Afghan War
description: The defense minister ordered Japans ships to return from the Indian Ocean on Friday, fulfilling a government pledge to end an eight-year refueling mission in support of the war in Afghanistan. Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama refused to renew the law authorizing the mission, ignoring requests from the Obama administration to continue it as a show of support. Military experts have said the Japanese withdrawal would not affect military operations in Afghanistan.

title: New Ships Idle, Waiting for Cargo to Fill Them
description: From Loch Striven in Scotland to the Strait of Malacca in Southeast Asia, more than a tenth of the vessels that transport the worlds manufactured goods in containers are idle. For most, orders to sail will not come for some time.

title: North Korea: Anger Over a Contingency Plan
description: North Korea denounced South Koreas reported contingency plan for the potential collapse of the Norths government, warning Friday that it would cut off all dialogue with the South and exclude it from all negotiations concerning the security of the Korean Peninsula. South Korean newspapers reported this week that the South recently revised the contingency plan in the belief that uncertain health of the Norths leader, Kim Jong-il, and the Norths deepening economic woes have made the country more unstable. The government has not confirmed the reports.

title: Russia: Lawmakers Ratify a European Courts Reforms
description: Parliament ratified a protocol on reforming the European Court of Human Rights on Friday. Russia has long accused the court of bias. With the measure passed, the court can now begin clearing a heavy backlog of cases, one-third of which are against Russia.

title: F.D.A. Concerned About Substance in Food Packaging
description: In a shift of position, the Food and Drug Administration is expressing concerns about possible health risks from bisphenol-A, or BPA, a widely used component of plastic bottles and food packaging that it declared safe in 2008.

title: Recipe: Old-Fashioned
description: Adapted from the Quarter Bar, Brooklyn

title: Jets Fans Crave Victory, but Despair Is Never Far
description: In most ways, it is hard to typify a Jets fan. There may have been a geographic alliance once, when the team practiced on Long Island and played at Shea Stadium; those lines blurred with the teams move to New Jersey.

title: Italy Presses Its Fight for a Statue at the Getty
description: PESARO, Italy  One summer day in 1964 a fishing trawler from Fano, a small seaside town a few miles south of this provincial capital on the Adriatic, unexpectedly dredged up a life-size bronze statue from the oceans depths. Most likely fashioned in ancient Greece and lost at sea after being looted by Romans, the sculpture is now a centerpiece of the Getty Villa, part of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles.

title: Jeffrey R. Fenster Picked for Workers Compensation Board Post
description: Ever since a law was passed more than two years ago to overhaul New Yorks troubled system for administering claims of hurt workers, the states Workers Compensation Board has vowed to introduce sweeping improvements. Among the longstanding criticisms of the board, which employs about 1,450 people throughout the state, has been its history of hiring senior administrators without relevant qualifications.

title: Decline in Shipping Business Puts Squeeze on Ports
description: Until mid-2008, the main worries for most port operators were congestion and a lack of infrastructure to cope with demand.

title: Jan. 15: Updates on Rescue and Recovery in Haiti
description: On Friday The Lede is continuing to supplement reporting by our colleagues in Haiti on the aftermath of Tuesdays earthquake by pointing to news and information on other Web sites. Readers are encouraged to share any first-hand accounts they receive from Haiti or see online by writing to us in the comments thread below.

title: Poetry for Times of Calamity and War
description: Before the New York Philharmonics concert on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall, Alan Gilbert, speaking on behalf of the musicians, dedicated the program to the victims of the earthquake in Haiti. As it happened, the scheduled works were movingly appropriate.

title: Crunch Time: Selling Tales of the Great Downturn
description: The new George Clooney film, Up in the Air, hit a nerve with its portrayal of an unmoored corporate executioner who makes his living by firing people. Now several writers and their publishers are hoping to catch the same wave with a cluster of forthcoming memoirs and novels that describe the fallout of losing a job, losing a house or losing an investment account.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Googles threat to leave China because of what the company called hacker assaults and efforts to limit free speech on the Web misidentified, in some copies, the organizational affiliation of Rebecca MacKinnon, an expert on the Chinese Internet. She is a fellow at the Open Society Institute, a New York-based democracy advocacy group; she is not with the Open Space Institute, a New York-based environmental group.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the earthquake that struck Haiti on Tuesday misspelled, at one point, the surname of a New York photographer who was in Port-au-Prince, the Haitian capital, and described what she called a scene of general mayhem. As noted elsewhere in the article, she is Tequila Minsky, not Minksy.

title: Hershey Moves Closer to Making Cadbury Bid
description: Hershey edged closer to a bid for Cadbury of Britain on Friday, people briefed on the matter told DealBook, just days before Kraft is set to disclose its final offer for the confectioner.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a federal judges ruling that the Food and Drug Administration could no longer block imports of electronic cigarettes from China paraphrased incorrectly from a statement released by Matthew L. Myers, president of the Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids, about the decision. Mr. Myers said the ruling opened a loophole in the F.D.A.s ability to regulate nontobacco products containing nicotine. He did not say it opened a loophole in the new federal law that gives the F.D.A. authority to regulate tobacco products.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Arts, Briefly column on Friday about the actor Santino Fontana, who has withdrawn from the Broadway revival of A View From the Bridge because of an injury suffered onstage, misidentified the director of the short-lived revival of Brighton Beach Memoirs in which Mr. Fontana appeared last fall. It was directed by David Cromer, not Gregory Mosher. (As the report noted, Mr. Mosher is the director of A View From the Bridge.)

title: Michael Kaufman, Times Reporter Who Roamed World, Is Dead at 71
description: Michael T. Kaufman, a former foreign correspondent, reporter and columnist for The New York Times who chronicled despotic regimes in Europe and Africa, the fall of Communism and the changing American scene for four decades, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 71.

title: Corrections
description: A Spare Times entry on Friday about a screening of an excerpt from the documentary AbUSed  The Postville Raid at Judson Memorial Church in Greenwich Village and a post-screening discussion misstated the suggested donation. It is $10, not $20.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Jan. 6 about the abstract artist Kenneth Noland omitted a former wife, Peggy Schiffer. (His wife, Paige Rense, survives him.)

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: MSNBC: New York Times Edition
description: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC provides updates on the humanitarian crisis in Haiti, reports on the tightening of the Massachusetts Senate race and speaks with Gretchen Morgenson about a proposed tax on big banks.

title: A400M Is Supported, but Money Is at Issue
description: Military officials from the countries signed up to buy the Airbus A400M transport plane reaffirmed their commitment to the much-delayed project on Friday but failed to reveal any additional financing.

title: Ruined Ports Hindering Delivery of Relief
description: MIAMI  The first cargo ship carrying aid for quake-damaged Haiti set sail for the northern port of Cap Hatien Friday evening, but most shipping companies that usually supply the country with goods are still unable to reach the desperate islanders because the main pier in Port-au-Prince has splintered and fallen into the ocean.

title: F.C.C. Orders Wireless Mike Modifications
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Broadway theaters, sports franchises and other public entertainment forums must change the radio frequency they use for their wireless microphones under an order issued Friday by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: A Place Where Diversity Extends to Sexuality
description: Huddled with aides last week in a room upstairs from his future district office, which the incumbent he defeated in the Democratic primary had yet to clear out, City Councilman Daniel Dromm ironed out the final details of his inauguration party.

title: OBrien and NBC Are Close to a Deal for His Departure
description: NBC and representatives of the networks disaffected Tonight Show host, Conan OBrien, continued negotiations Friday to settle his contract, but no outcome was expected Friday, according to one participant in the talks.

title: Lady BlahBlah
description: I have often accused Sarah Palin of having more fight than strategy in her. But I must concede that her decision to become a contributor to Fox News is a shrewd one. Touch, Barracuda.

title: Reuniting on the Hudson, but Smiling This Time
description: Forty degrees 46 minutes 10.19 seconds north latitude, 74 degrees 16.69 seconds west latitude: Michael Leonard had been there before.

title: Trusted Aides to Bloomberg Get Big Bonuses
description: Patricia E. Harris, Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs most trusted aide at City Hall, earned $451,000, including a $400,000 bonus, for less than two months of work on his re-election campaign, according to newly released documents. The records showed that Mr. Bloomberg showered his top aides with six-figure bonuses despite a narrower-than-expected re-election victory in November.

title: Dapper, Privileged and Unapologetic
description: In retrospect, it should have always been clear that the polarizing New York indie-rock band Vampire Weekend had a little bit of ska in its DNA. Later iterations of that genre, revived every decade or so, gave secondhand consumption a bad name, its manhandling of reggae signifiers the laziest and most regrettable sort of musical borrowing.

title: New Meaning to the Haitian in Haitian-American
description: Detective Claude Jean-Pierre has stumbled through the terrible hours and days after the earthquake in a daze every Haitian recognizes. He slept a few hours each night and could not concentrate on work. He called relatives and searched every corner of the Internet for information. He started a list of volunteers, of police officers in his Brooklyn precinct, to go to the nation and help.

title: 99.5 FM, Where the Board Meetings Make the Broadcasts Seem Tame
description: Comrades, comrades.

title: 11 Networks Plan a 2-Hour Telethon
description: Eleven broadcast and cable networks will show a two-hour telethon next Friday night to benefit the victims of the Haiti earthquake, MTV Networks announced on Friday.

title: At Sothebys, Tracing the Lives Behind the Letters
description: What is more moving: the meaning of important words or the trace left by their formulation, the sense of a precious document or the lines of ink that convey it? Does it matter, for example, that until next Saturday at Sothebys it is possible to look at the 1862 message in which Abraham Lincoln wrote to his dilatory Civil War general, George B. McClellan, urging him to take action? Or that we can read letters in which Benedict Arnold seems to be making a few too many excuses for himself during the Revolutionary War?

title: Narrow Senate Race Unnerves Democrats on Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  With their partys candidate struggling in Massachusetts in a race for what should be the safest of Senate seats, Congressional Democrats are growing increasingly unnerved about the political consequences of the health care overhaul even as their leadership closes in on a final agreement.

title: Scaling the Digital Wall in China
description: The Great Firewall of China is hardly impregnable.

title: State Looks at Doubling Cap on Charter Schools
description: New York legislators are poised to at least double the number of charter schools allowed in the state in an attempt to win as much as $700 million in federal education grants.

title: With Rent Increase, Dangerous Stress
description: Cleo Wilder rises every day at 4:30 a.m. and embarks on a brisk walk  a holdover, he said, from his two-year stint in the Army at the dawn of the Vietnam War.

title: Obama to Campaign for Senate Candidate in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON  In a last-ditch effort to avert a debacle for the Democrats, the White House announced that President Obama would campaign here on Sunday for Martha Coakley, the Democratic Senate candidate, amid growing signs that the race for Edward M. Kennedys Senate seat has become too close to call.

title: Pick for Top Digital Job in Europe Is Grilled
description: BERLIN  The nomination of Neelie Kroes, who was hard-nosed as Europes antitrust chief, to a new post as commissioner for the digital agenda was in doubt Friday after she was accused of being evasive during a testy appearance before a committee of the European Parliament.

title: For the Trapped, Rescue Is but the First Hurdle
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Herby Amels father dug through the collapsed college building first, pulling out a body so he could reach his son, trapped 20 feet into the pile. But when a rescue team from Miami arrived early Friday morning, Herbys left ankle remained pinned under a fallen beam.

title: Government Struggles to Exhume Itself
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  It did not take very long for Edwin Paraison, a member of Haitis cabinet, to take stock of his losses and deliver a thorough assessment of what remained of his government ministry.

title: Hershey Said to Be Closer to an Offer for Cadbury
description: Hershey edged closer to a bid for Cadbury of Britain on Friday, people briefed on the matter said. The move comes just days before Kraft is set to disclose its final offer for the confectioner.

title: N.B.A. Rookie Closes Inner Circle After Deadly Shot Is Fired
description: PHILADELPHIA  When Sacramento Kings guard Tyreke Evans was 7 years old, he hit the winning basket to beat his friend Dwayne Daviss team and remain unbeaten in a youth league. Davis was inconsolable, so Evanss oldest brother, James, visited his locker room and invited him to a nearby Chuck E. Cheese restaurant with the family.

title: Wizards Arenas Pleads Guilty to One Felony Gun Charge
description: WASHINGTON  Washington Wizards guard Gilbert Arenas pleaded guilty Friday to one count of carrying a pistol without a license in the District of Columbia.

title: Broadcast Coverage: Compassion and Self-Congratulation
description: One moment looters brandishing machetes trot through streets of Port-au-Prince lined with corpses, and soon after, Robin Roberts, a host of Good Morning America, kneels over a sleeping child, tenderly stroking her back.

title: Capmark Investments Files for Bankruptcy
description: Capmark Investments, a unit of the bankrupt commercial property lender Capmark Financial Group, filed for bankruptcy in a bid to sell its management contracts and interests in real estate equity funds. Capmark Investments listed assets and debt of at least $1 billion on a Chapter 11 petition on Friday in Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del. Its parent filed for bankruptcy last year amid falling property values and a drop in lending. The unit manages equity real estate and mortgage-related investments in the public and private markets, and had more than $1.7 billion under management as of Dec. 31, according to its Web site. Capmark Investments reached a deal on Thursday to sell the contracts and general partnership interest in its real estate equity funds to an unspecified third party, it said. The unit said it would seek bankruptcy court approval of the sale.

title: Agreement Expected in NBCs Talks With OBrien
description: NBC and representatives of the networks disaffected Tonight Show host, Conan OBrien, have continued negotiations to settle his contract, but no outcome was expected Friday, according to one participant in the talks.

title: A Gangland Bus Tour, With Lunch and a Waiver
description: LOS ANGELES  The tour organizer received assurances, he says, from four gangs that they would not harass the bus when it passed through their turf. Paying customers must sign releases warning of potential danger. And after careful consideration, it was decided not to have residents shoot water guns at the bus and sell I Got Shot in South Central T-shirts.

title: China, Where U.S. Internet Companies Often Fail
description: SHANGHAI  If Google pulls out of China because of frustration with government restrictions, it will not be the first time an American Internet giant has retreated from the country.

title: Saints Aim for the Strong Finish Theyve Talked About
description: NEW ORLEANS  The front of the black T-shirt shows the fleur-de-lis in gold with the words Our City, Our Home. On the back are the words Finish Strong.

title: 25 Down: Deer Stalkers
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Have you ever been stumped by a clue and asked someone for help, perhaps even by posting a comment here  and the moment you did, the answer came to you? I mention this because thats what happened to me with an answer in todays NW territory, where I was momentarily stumped. The minute I asked my wife, who was passing by, the light dawned.

title: Tennessee Hires Louisiana Techs Dooley as Coach
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  It was only a 35-minute introductory news conference, but it was also 35 minutes of a do-over. A year of brashness under Lane Kiffin was replaced with a more mature tone from Derek Dooley, who was introduced as Tennessees coach here Friday night.

title: In Health Talks, President Is Hands-Off No More
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has taken full control of the health care negotiations, casting himself for the first time in the role of mediator between the House and Senate during a 72-hour marathon of talks that have turned his White House into a de facto Congressional conference.

title: One Shining Moment for Pendergrass
description: Teddy Pendergrass, who died Wednesday, was an R&B superstar, but he also had a place in the hearts of many college basketball fans. For several years in the 1990s, it was the voice of Pendergrass that fans heard when CBS played One Shining Moment, the song that accompanies the highlight reel that traditionally ends its coverage of the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Men Who Once Bent Steel Are Now on Bended Knee
description: Tom Townsend pulled a quarter from his coat pocket. It was no ordinary quarter: He usually keeps it and another one just like it in a plastic case at home, and as he held the rusty-brown 1996 coin in his hand at a funeral home in Brooklyn on Thursday night, people gathered around and stared at it and touched it, tracing their fingers over its unnatural U-shaped curve.

title: Officer Is Convicted of Abusing Power in Seeking Sex
description: A New York City police officer who is accused of sexually assaulting several women was convicted Friday of telling an 18-year-old that he would destroy a summons he was issuing her in exchange for oral sex.

title: On the Street | Puffed
description: The inexpensive and lightweight puffy down coats that have been around for decades have taken sophisticated new shapes, often in licorice black and in fabrics that resemble cir.

title: Plan Would Allow SUNY and CUNY to Set Tuition
description: Gov. David A. Paterson proposed on Friday that the State University of New York and the City University of New York be allowed to set their own tuition rates, a plan that would end a longstanding policy under which tuition increases are determined by the State Legislature.

title: Lottery Numbers
Gender Testing Hangs Before the Games as a Muddled and Vexing Mess
description: At closed meetings in Miami on Sunday and Monday, medical specialists and representatives of the International Olympic Committee will tackle one of the most vexing questions in sports: What test should be used to determine whether an athlete competes as a man or a woman? Or should there be any official testing at all?

title: Excerpt: 'Spartacus: Blood and Sand'
description: The new Starz series updates the Spartacus legend.

title: Creams Offering Lighter Skin May Bring Risks
description: For years, Allison Ross rubbed in skin-lightening creams with names like Hyprogel and Fair & White. She said she wanted to even out and brighten the tone of her face, neck and hands. Mrs. Ross, 45, who lives in Brooklyn, also said that she used the lightening creams to be more accepted in society.

title: The Road West
description: When I drive from New York to California, as I did again last week, I always hope Im going to get a kind of backyard view of the present-day United States. But what I discover is that Im driving through the past. The road west is littered with the bones of old vehicles, taunting me in their rusted glory from just beyond the fence-line. Every echo of Route 66 is a reminder of a time when the highway was a trail of automotive woe, of engine failures and bad rubber, of drivers on bended knee in front of a jack.

title: Broad Minds Encourage Broad Laughter
description: Its often been said that stand-up comedy is the most subjective art form. Whats side-splitting to one person is seditious to the next. Yet while the evolving dynamics of the Bay Area entertainment scene have broadened traditional definitions of what constitutes comedy, some of the audience still takes a narrow view of whats funny and what isnt.

title: Swine Flu Deaths Reach 11,000
description: About 11,000 Americans have died of swine flu as of last month, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said. The agencys previous estimate  for deaths from April, when the virus was discovered, to mid-November  was about 10,000. Because the second wave peaked in late October, the number is unlikely to rise much unless there is a third wave later this winter. The estimate by the World Health Organization as of Jan. 3 was 12,799 deaths worldwide. The two numbers are not directly comparable because the W.H.O. counts only laboratory-confirmed deaths. Only a small fraction of all flu cases are tested by laboratories, especially in poor and middle-income countries, and many deaths that the flu causes are officially given other reasons, like pneumonia or heart failure.

title: Minaya Dials Back Mets Ire on Beltran
description: A day after the Mets sent an assistant to do verbal battle on the teams behalf, General Manager Omar Minaya was back in place Friday, trying to smooth over the strained relationship between the club and Carlos Beltran.

title: Raptors Bosh Likes Garden, Not the Glare
description: The first time Chris Bosh performed at Madison Square Garden, he played against Carmelo Anthony and Amare Stoudemire as a high school senior in the McDonalds All-American Game.

title: Bloggingheads: In Defense of 'Negro'
description: John McWhorter, left, of the Manhattan Institute and Glenn Loury of Brown University discuss the Harry Reid controversy.

title: The Fire and the Focus of the Ivy League
description: HANOVER, N.H.  Kathy Delaney-Smith, the coach of the Harvard womens basketball team, learned that she had breast cancer in December 1999, but she did not go public with the news until a month later. After a victory over Dartmouth, she let the news slip in a postgame interview.

title: Leno and OBrien Continue War of Words, More Coolly
description: The war of words between NBCs two late-night stars cooled a bit Friday night, but both Jay Leno and Conan OBrien offered a few jokes about their status at NBC and in recent press reports.

title: Pastors in Northwest Find Focus in Green
description: MILLWOOD, Wash.  State auditors told Millwood Community Presbyterian Church last summer to close its farmers market on the church parking lot or the lot could no longer be claimed as tax-exempt. Without hesitation, the church kept the market and paid the $700 in annual taxes.

title: Cadillac Plans
description: The agreement between the White House, Congressional leaders and labor unions over taxing high-priced health insurance policies is a reasonable solution to an issue that was threatening to derail health care reform. The agreement treats unionized workers far more favorably than nonunion workers, the price for the support of important Democratic constituencies. But it would preserve the taxs crucial role in slowing the rise in health care costs for decades to come.

title: Major Hasans Smooth Ascension
description: Pentagon officials are taking a sobering look at the career of Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, the Army psychiatrist who has been charged with murder in a shooting spree in November that left 13 people dead in Fort Hood, Tex. Investigators have found that Major Hasan moved smoothly up the ladder despite early signs of an erratic temperament and instances of questionable behavior, all obvious to his superiors.

title: Catching Up
description: At the start of 2008, all was going according to Marcia Bladens plans. She was earning enough as an administrative assistant at Time Warner to support her young son and, at night, was working on a masters degree in community health. In time, she was expecting to get a second masters, in clinical psychology, and open a rehabilitation center. She was not expecting to lose her job.

title: What to Do About Bankers Bonuses
description: To the Editor:

title: Smoking in Movies: How Does It Affect the Young?
description: To the Editor:

title: Medical Marijuana
description: To the Editor:

title: Did Haitis Poverty and Culture Worsen the Tragedy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Lend Me Your Ears
description: This just in from the Christian Broadcasting Network: The Rev. Pat Robertson did not say that the earthquake in Haiti was the result of Gods wrath at the Haitians for making a pact with the devil to get out from under French colonial rule.

title: Resolve Among the Ruins
description: In Haiti, the apocalypse wears the trappings of the norm. Its a place where heartbreak never seems to end.

title: My Nights With Eric
description: TO those of us who have seen all of Eric Rohmers films it is impossible not to remember when, where, with whom we saw each one. I even remember the second and third time I saw his films. My Night at Mauds, Claires Knee, Chloe in the Afternoon are grafted onto my life. Something happened between me and these films at the Thalia, at the Brattle, at the old Cinmathque, or at the old Olympia Theater on the Upper West Side. But I can no longer isolate what that something is. I dont even care to know what was exclusively Eric Rohmers and what was mine, what he was ever so cautious to convey and what I most likely misunderstood completely. The mix, as sometimes happens, becomes the work of art.

title: Hasib Sabbagh, Co-Founder of Middle East Builder, Is Dead at 90
description: Hasib Sabbagh, a founder of the Consolidated Contractors Company International, one of the largest construction companies in the Middle East, died on Jan. 12 in Cleveland. He was 90.

title: Geothermal Drilling Safeguards Imposed
description: The United States Energy Department, concerned about earthquake risk, will impose new safeguards on geothermal energy projects that drill deep into the Earths crust.

title: Raptors Remind Knicks What Boos Sound Like
description: In the Knicks recent surge, Madison Square Garden had been a security blanket. They won 8 of their last 10 home games before Fridays encounter with Toronto.

title: Correction
description: An article on Jan. 3 that evaluated President Obamas policies in the context of progressivism misspelled the surname of a historical political figure with whom Obama was compared. He was Robert La Follette, not La Follete.

title: Court to Rule on Right to Privacy for Referendum Petition Signers
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to decide whether the First Amendment requires that the names of people who sign ballot-initiative petitions be kept secret.

title: For Skating Favorites, Not All Is Lost After Two Tumbles
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  For Keauna McLaughlin, there were no tears Friday shortly after her dreadful performance at the United States Figure Skating Championships.

title: Grizzlies Youth Is Their Strong Suit
description: There is probably no evidence more striking of the talent gap between the Eastern and Western Conferences than the case of the Memphis Grizzlies, an emerging young team that seemingly cannot catch a break in the tougher West.

title: Feeling Strong, Miller Captures World Cup Race
description: WENGEN, Switzerland  Deep in thought over possible retirement last summer, Bode Miller was in a strikingly different place on Friday, back atop a World Cup podium after his first victory in nearly two years.

title: Ruth McBride Jordan, Subject of Sons Book Color of Water, Dies at 88
description: There were the quizzical looks, the dirty looks, the snide remarks and far worse when Ruth McBride Jordan walked down the street with a gaggle of her children in tow.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Five Points for Ovechkin as Caps Trounce Leafs
description: Only two games on Friday night, and sure enough one of them ended up at 1-0 or 2-0, as six other games this month have done. It does seem as if the N.H.L. is having another goal famine.

title: Shaking Off the Jitters, Abbott Finds His Footing
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  Lacing up his skates before competing in the U.S championships on Friday, Jeremy Abbott could not stop trembling.

title: Pants on the Ground
description: Video | A TV news report on the Pants on the Ground sensation. The ditty poking fun at droopy pants has become a viral hit since 63-year-old Larry Platt of Atlanta performed it on American Idol Wednesday night (next stop: The View):

title: Easing Up
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below:

title: 1975 Rewind: Drew Pearson Insists He Didnt Push Off
description: Known at the time as merely a bomb, Staubach entered a new term into the vernacular of football when he described how he pulled off the miraculous throw by saying, I closed my eyes and said a Hail Mary.   The Associated Press

title: Johnny Rockets Looking at Additional Concepts
description: Some marketers are cowed by a steep recession. Others see it as a chance to grow.

title: The Saturday Word: Dual Roles
description: Faced with natural disaster and political crises, the last week of President Obamas first year in office has hardly been a breather. This weekend he places himself at the center of the response to the earthquake in Haiti and the Massachusetts Senate race.

title: Coakley on Schilling: A Yankee Fan?
description: BOSTON  Could the fate of the health care bill, its passage or defeat, hinge on a sports gaffe?

title: Nora Gouge, Todd Moore
description: Nora Fitzgerald Gouge, a daughter of Joanne M. Gouge and Dr. Thomas Hamilton Gouge of New York, was married there Saturday to Todd William Moore, a son of Mary Ann Moore and John R. Moore of Somers, N.Y. The Rev. Timothy Lewis, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Epiphany.

title: Tamara Duricka and Evan Johnson
description: Tamara Jane Duricka and Evan Blake Johnson were married Saturday morning at the Los Angeles Temple Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints in California. Dr. James C. Brown, an elder in the church and the doctor who delivered the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Opportunity Knocks for Jazzs Gaines
description: Sundiata Gaines needed to do something to set himself apart at the end of his 10-day contract with the Utah Jazz. He did just that by hitting a game-winning 3-pointer, the first 3-pointer of his career, Thursday night against Cleveland.

title: Cari Engel, Mark Lapidus
description: Cari Allyn Engel, a daughter of Janet Engel and James Engel of Ramsey, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Mark Frederick Lapidus, a son of Kathryn Lapidus and Edward Lapidus of Bedford, N.Y. Rabbi Marvin Tokayer officiated at 583 Park Avenue, a catering space in Manhattan.

title: Margaret Bensfield, Edward Sullivan
description: Margaret Ashton Bensfield and Edward Matthew Sullivan were married Saturday at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in New York. The Rev. William P. Billow Jr., an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Debra Love, Jeffrey Katersky
description: Debra Beth Love and Jeffrey Michael Katersky were married Saturday evening at the Casa Marina Resort in Key West, Fla. Rabbi Shimon Dudai officiated.

title: Nina Schwartz, Matthew Pajak
description: Nina Anne Mittenthal Schwartz, the daughter of Sue Mittenthal of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Gil Schwartz of New York, was married Saturday evening to Matthew John Pajak, the son of Linda Pajak and Andrew Pajak of Gibsonia, Pa. Judge Alice Fisher Rubin of Civil Court in Brooklyn officiated at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York.

title: Officials Strain to Distribute Aid to Haiti as Violence Rises
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  As the focus on Saturday turned away from Haitians lost to those trying to survive, a sprawling assembly of international officials and aid workers struggled to fix a troubled relief effort after Tuesdays devastating earthquake.

title: Veronica Aguilar and Christopher Hornig
description: Veronica Marie Aguilar and Christopher Goddard Hornig were married Saturday at St. Austin Catholic Parish in Austin, Tex. The Rev. Steven A. Bell, a Roman Catholic priest and the churchs associate pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Candice Gidney, Jonathan Macy
description: Candice Beth Gidney and Jonathan Macy were married Saturday evening in Miami Beach. Rabbi Jonathan E. Berkun officiated at the Ritz-Carlton, South Beach, assisted by Cantor David Muchnick.

title: Ritu Asija and Rimmy Malhotra
description: Dr. Ritu Asija and Rahul R. Malhotra are to be married Sunday at the Hilton Papagayo Costa Rica Resort and Spa in Playa Arenilla. Einar Jos Villavicencio Lpez, a notary, is to officiate. Later in the day, the couple will have a Hindu ceremony led by Pandit Prabha Duneja.

title: Rachel Shafran, Daniel Steiner
description: Rachel Emma Shafran, a daughter of Robin B. Shafran and Charles M. Shafran of New York, is to be married Sunday to Daniel Walter Steiner, a son of Susan F. Steiner and Mark W. Steiner of Slingerlands, N.Y. Rabbi Robert N. Levine is to officiate at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York.

title: Allison Deutermann, Robert Dennis
description: Allison Kay Deutermann and Robert Thomas Dennis were married Saturday evening at the Gotham Loft, an event space in New York. Tulis McCall, an interfaith minister of the Universal Brotherhood Movement, officiated.

title: Cynthia Meyerand, James Shiftan
description: Cynthia Ann Meyerand and James Brand Shiftan were married Friday at Tulemar Beach in Manuel Antonio, Costa Rica. Dr. Roberto Yglesias Mora, a lawyer and notary, officiated, with his wife, Alice Michelle McCoy Garnier, also a lawyer and notary, taking part. Immediately afterward, the Rev. Paul Arndt, a Lutheran minister, led a religious ceremony.

title: Rachel Grand, Todd Spiegelman
description: Rachel Beth Grand, the daughter of Sherry M. Grand and William D. Grand of New York, is to be married Sunday evening to Todd Alan Spiegelman, a son of Harriet Spiegelman of Westbury, N.Y., and the late Steven Spiegelman. Rabbi Dr. David M. Posner is to officiate at Tribeca Rooftop in New York.

title: Alexandra Johnson, Matthew Cercone
description: Alexandra Jeanette Johnson and Matthew Sheldon Cercone were married Saturday at Grace Church in Brooklyn. The Rev. Stephen D. Muncie, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Julia Bloom, Andrew Weltman
description: Julia Ruth Bloom and Andrew David Weltman were married Saturday evening at the Ironhorse Country Club in West Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Joel L. Levine officiated.

title: Jessica Matsumoto and Jonathan Miller
description: Jessica Emi Matsumoto, a daughter of Carlene Sheryl Matsumoto and Jin Matsumoto of Cypress, Tex., was married Saturday evening in San Jose, Calif., to Jonathan Pett Miller, a son of Susan Sarill Miller and Leonard A. Miller of Potomac, Md. Rabbi Josh Berkenwald performed the ceremony at Congregation Sinai, which he leads.

title: A Truncated Term for the Democrats 60th Vote
description: WASHINGTON  Paul G. Kirk Jr. cannot be sure who will be succeeding him as the junior senator from Massachusetts or exactly when the transition will occur. But he can be certain that his time as a stand-in for the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy is running out.

title: Health issues in a Millennium Village
description: The following is the second in a series of reports from the Ethiopian village of Koraro, an important testing ground for the Millennium Village Project, an experiment in global development strategy spearheaded by economist Jeffrey Sachs. The reports, written by Jeff Marlow, a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, consider which parts of the project are working and which ones arent, and what can be learned from it to help billions of people escape extreme poverty.

title: China at Odds With Future in Internet Fight
description: BEIJING  At the elite Tsinghua University here, some students were joking Friday that they had better download all the Internet information they wanted now in case Google left the country.

title: Morgan Stanley Tries on a New Psyche
description: JAMES P. GORMAN, a 6-foot-2 Australian, recently took up boxing lessons, in keeping with some of the trappings of his Midtown Manhattan office. On one wall, opposite an inspirational poem by Rudyard Kipling (The Thousandth Man), hangs a photograph of Elvis Presley sparring with Muhammad Ali.

title: Kashmir Suicide Bomber Strikes Pakistani Soldiers
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A suicide bomber detonated his explosives on the Pakistani side of the Kashmir region on Saturday in a rare attack on the Pakistani military there.

title: Spurs Are Saving Duncan for the Playoffs
description: On Tuesday night, Tim Duncan poured in 25 points and added 13 rebounds, 4 blocks, 4 assists and 2 steals for San Antonio in a 105-85 victory over the visiting Los Angeles Lakers. It was just another solid game from one of the most consistent players in the league.

title: Palatopharyngoplasty Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Ive always thought that writing a puzzle is like solving a puzzle. The same problems are tackled, just from different directions. I mention this because Ms. Cox and Mr. Rathvon have added a challenge to the puzzle they solved in creating todays acrostic. Take a look at the A-to-Y answers. Did you notice anything about them, something they have in common?

title: A Presidential Triple Plea for Haiti Relief Fund
description: Former Presidents George W. Bush and Bill Clinton on Saturday began their new joint venture to raise money for the Haitian relief effort from corporations, foundations and ordinary Americans, as President Obama continued his efforts to ramp up the American response to the devastating earthquake.

title: Facing No. 1 and the Elements
description: Jon Jaques is a senior on the Cornell basketball team. As he did last season, Jon will be blogging for The Quad throughout this season. You can also follow him on Twitter. And for a sense of how the Cornell basketball team passes the time while on the road, check out this video:

title: Jan. 16: Updates on Rescue and Recovery in Haiti
description: On Saturday The Lede is continuing to supplement reporting by our colleagues in Haiti  including Marc Lacey, Damien Cave and Simon Romero  on the aftermath of Tuesdays earthquake by pointing to news and information on the Web. Readers are encouraged to share any first-hand accounts they receive from Haiti or see online by writing to us in the comments thread below.

title: Senate Candidates Storm the Bay State by Bus
description: BOSTON, Mass.  The candidates for the open United States Senate seat in Massachusetts are hopscotching the state via bus Saturday as the tight race to fill the late Senator Edward M. Kennedys seat heads into its final days.

title: Bagram Detainees Named by U.S.
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The American military released the names of 645 detainees held at the main detention center at Bagram Air Base, modifying its long-held position against publicizing detention information and taking a step toward making the system more open.

title: Quake Ignores Class Divisions of a Poor Land
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Marie Garmell Neptune, cradling one of her children and holding the hand of another, had lost everything. But as she boarded an American military cargo plane for Miami on Saturday with just the clothes on her back, she was one of the lucky ones.

title: Son Learns From His Father, but Puts Trust in Himself
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  All week, the Jets offensive coordinator, Brian Schottenheimer, tried to squash distractions, treat his next game like any other. He turned down a request to be interviewed for Buffalos head-coaching vacancy. He deflected praise for his deft handling of the rookie quarterback Mark Sanchez.

title: On Road to Super Bowl, Sprinkle Some Eye of Newt
description: Observe the angst of Jets fans. They are hopeful. They are fearful. More fearful than hopeful.

title: Massachusetts Race Tests Staying Power of Democrats
description: BOSTON  There may be no better place to measure the shifting fortunes of President Obama and the Democratic Party than in the race being fought here this weekend for the Senate seat that had been held by Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Crime Rises as Aid Awaits Distribution
description: While countries and relief agencies have showered aid on Haiti, little of it is reaching increasingly desperate Haitians. Across the city, there were reports of intensifying looting and violence.

title: NBCs Slide to Troubled Nightly Punch Line
description: At its height, NBC was the very model of what a television network should be. With iconic programming, enviable ratings and spectacular business success, the peacock network delivered plenty of laughs along the way with The Cosby Show, Seinfeld and Friends.

title: Storybook Season in Progress
description: IRVING, Tex.  Like many people from North Jersey, Miles Austin of the Dallas Cowboys sometimes wears a blue Yankees cap because he is a fan of the World Series champions.

title: In Show of Support, Clinton Goes to Haiti
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Bearing soap, bottled water and other much-needed supplies, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton flew into this ruined capital on Saturday and told the Haitian people that the United States will be here today, tomorrow and for the time ahead.

title: Twilight for Tomlinson, but Another Chance to Shine
description: SAN DIEGO  For all the talk about parade plans, whether Darrelle Revis can be cloned to cover Vincent Jackson and Antonio Gates, and how much weight Mark Sanchez can carry into his homecoming, the one sure-fire Hall of Famer who will step on the field Sunday when the Jets play the Chargers is not part of the conversation.

title: Buying Landmarks? Easy. Keeping Them? Maybe Not.
description: IT seemed a great idea at the time. In June 2007, Jerry I. Speyer and his son Rob bought six buildings in Chicago, making them one of the largest commercial landlords in the city.

title: Sponsor Takes the Next Step in Tennis
description: LAS VEGAS  Fernando Verdasco was straining against a leg-press machine as he raised 710 pounds, yet his strength and conditioning coach, Gil Reyes, was making the most noise. Reyes bellowed in two languages as Verdasco, a Spanish tennis star, raised the massive load 14 times before Reyes finally shouted at him to stop.

title: Credit Cards and Reluctant Regulators
description: ANYONE wondering how consumer rights might be faring in the Washington debate over financial regulatory reform has a lot to consider theses days.

title: New Cramping Rule Takes Aim at Gamesmanship
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  It was not an image the sport of tennis wanted broadcast to the world, a player screaming and writhing in pain on the court and unable to receive help of any kind.

title: Bronx Diner Owner Accused of Arson
description: The owner of a Bronx diner has been accused of hiring a man to set his establishment ablaze last month, causing a five-alarm fire that burned for five hours as it ripped through a commercial stretch of the Norwood neighborhood, the authorities said.

title: Gaining a Toehold for the E-Bike
description: TECHNOLOGY has eliminated many of lifes milder physical demands, like getting off the couch to change the channel, or going to the store to buy a book.

title: Chinese Site Criticizes Investor for Its Google Support
description: In an unusual move, the Alibaba Group of China on Saturday criticized Yahoo, one of its largest shareholders, for siding with Google after a cyber attack on that company.

title: The Iranian Exiles Eye
description: TORONTO, Canada  One day last June, on the quiet Tehran street where I lived, I noticed a man in a white Peugeot across the street looking at me, straight in the eye, as I started to drive out of my garage. There she is, he said, and he rushed to start his own car.

title: A Clear Coating, With Green Applications
description: IMAGINE how great it would be if, after dinner, you could stack the greasy dishes, pots, pans and utensils in the sink and let plain old water rinse away the grime  with no help from detergents, and little or no scrubbing. Bye-bye, dishpan hands.

title: Bernanke and the Beast
description: IS galloping inflation around the corner? Without doubt, the United States is exhibiting some of the classic precursors to out-of-control inflation. But a deeper look suggests that the story is not so simple.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Jan. 17
description: This Sundays lineup of officials focus the bulk of their conversations on the relief efforts in Haiti, and the health care negotiations on Capitol Hill take a distant second place.

title: OBrien Tops Letterman in Fridays Ratings
description: Conan OBrien scored a sweeping win in the ratings on Friday night, continuing what looks increasingly like a victory lap in finishing his run on the Tonight show.

title: Taking Away Directors Rubber Stamps
description: IT sounds like good work if you can get it, and thousands of people in corporate America do. On average, they attend 8 to 12 meetings annually. Although they are supposed to have fiduciary obligations, they often appear simply to warm their assigned seats, and to raise their hands when their leader calls for a vote. For that, they can receive as much as $640,000 a year.

title: Birds of a Feather Wear Bad Costumes Together
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  Memo to Evan Lysacek: Nobody ever won the Olympics dressed as a magpie.

title: Political Loyalty (or Lack of It) in the Tell-All Era
description: Late in the new book Game Change, a chronicle of the 2008 presidential campaign that has much of Washington cringing and the rest of the country gasping, comes a scene that may not match others for pure titillation but has an eerie, pitiable resonance all its own.

title: The Road to the Cure
description: AT 8 oclock most nights, my four siblings and I would gather around the TV. My dad was director of advertising for CBS in the early 1960s, and it was our family pastime to pick apart the ads on the different channels.

title: From the Archive: Haiti, Alive
description: There is a saying in Creole, the language of the streets here, that translates, Beyond the mountains, more mountains, Richard J. Meislin, a New York Times foreign correspondent, wrote from Port-au-Prince in 1982. It is both literally and figuratively the story of this country, where life is increasingly a daily contest between nearly insurmountable poverty and nearly unbreakable faith.

title: Concrete Solutions
description: Its obvious that many of the buildings that collapsed during the Haitian earthquake were poorly designed or constructed. In Haiti, because there is virtually no lumber for building, structures have been made of concrete blocks, often with inadequately reinforced concrete frames. But to suggest that the country simply be rebuilt to a technically higher standard is to take a shortsighted approach.

title: When Stress Flirts With Burnout
description: Q. You are a professional who is accustomed to stress, but all the uncertainty and anxiety in the workplace these days is putting you under more pressure than usual. You feel burned out  are you?

title: Two Belgians Qualify for Australian Open
description: The Belgians Xavier Malisse and Yanina Wickmayer made emphatic statements today at the Australian Open qualifying tournament, winning their way into the main draw after a winter of controversy surrounding their bans from professional tennis.

title: Haiti in Ink and Tears: A Literary Sampler
description: Today is a good day to remember that in Haiti, nobody ever really dies. The many thousands who've had the breath crushed out of their bodies in the earthquake, and the thousands more who will not physically survive the aftermath, will undergo instead a translation of state, according to the precepts of Haitian Vodou, some form of which is practiced by much of the population. Spirits of the Haitian dead  sa nou pa we yo, those we dont see  do not depart as in other religions but remain extremely close to the living, invisible but tangible, inhabiting a parallel universe on the other side of any mirror, beneath the surface of all water, just behind the veil that divides us from our dreams.

title: Eight Ways to Rebuild Haiti
description: When the immediate crisis passes, how can we ensure that Haiti becomes a functioning nation? Eight experts give their prescriptions.
