title: A Broadcaster Turned Replay Editor
description: The N.H.L.s video-review system has functioned well for 18 seasons. That is, until a defect in the system was exposed in the aftermath of a Penguins-Flyers game played on Jan. 7.

title: Charlie Cook responds
description: In comments, Charlie Cook responds to my post expressing puzzlement over what it would have meant, or what difference it would have made, if Obama had focused on the economy rather than turning to health care:

title: Squatters Rights
description: There are about a billion squatters in the world today, and over time many have transformed their once-squalid communities into normal urban neighborhoods. In the awful aftermath of the tremor that turned hundreds of thousands of Haitians into refugees in their own hometown, a few sensible squatter principles may hold out hope for the devastated residents of Port-au-Prince:

title: After SportsCenter Moment, Le Moyne Returns to Division II Reality
description: SYRACUSE  On Nov. 3, Le Moyne College pulled off perhaps the most stunning upset of the college basketball season. The Dolphins defeated the crosstown power Syracuse University in an exhibition game at the Carrier Dome, starting an unparalleled run of publicity.

title: Clouds Beginning to Lift for a Player From Benin
description: VILLANOVA, Pa.  Frank Tchuisi, a Villanova graduate assistant, received the phone call around midnight in San Juan, P.R.

title: Blip
description: Calculated Risk beat me to this: the economists at Goldman Sachs are now predicting 5.8 percent growth in the fourth quarter. But they also say that the headline number will be highly misleading: two-thirds of the growth will be an inventory bounce, with final demand growing only 2 percent. In short, it will be a blip.

title: Skip the Graft
description: Americas efforts to assist Haiti over the last 20 years were hobbled by bitter partisan division over Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the countrys elected, deposed and then reinstalled president. Unfortunately, as the American debate over policy toward Haiti subsided with Mr. Aristides final ouster in 2004, so did American interest.

title: A Presidential Triple Plea for Haiti Fund
description: WASHINGTON  Former Presidents George W. Bush and Bill Clinton began a new venture on Saturday to raise money for the Haitian relief effort from corporations, foundations and ordinary Americans, as President Obama pledged to ramp up the American response to the devastating earthquake.

title: Tebow to Appear in Super Bowl Ad for Focus on the Family
description: The former Florida quarterback Tim Tebow will appear with his mother in a 30-second Super Bowl ad for the Christian group Focus on the Family, which says the theme will be Celebrate Family, Celebrate Life.

title: Forget Gum. Walking and Using Phone Is Risky.
description: SAN FRANCISCO  On the day of the collision last month, visibility was good. The sidewalk was not under repair. As she walked, Tiffany Briggs, 25, was talking to her grandmother on her cellphone, lost in conversation.

title: Learn From Postwar Tokyo
description: The standard approach to residential redevelopment projects is to take ground zero as a starting point  even if it means creating it. This often translates into shifting people from substandard but incrementally developing environments into apartment blocks that cut them off from their social networks and livelihoods. These projects often become housing-centric and blind to the relationship between neighborhoods and economic development. They end up benefiting the construction industry much more than the population they are supposed to serve.

title: Structure? The Flatter, the Better
description: This interview with Cristbal Conde, president and C.E.O. of SunGard, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: A Recovery Built on Water
description: When Columbus landed on Hispaniola in 1492, he marveled at the islands luxuriant, towering forests. Today, on the Haitian side of the island, only 2 percent of the forest cover remains. During storms, water rushes off barren hillsides, causing deadly mudslides, clogging streams with soil and sewage and disappearing before it can replenish Haitis diminishing groundwater reserves.

title: For Safe Investors, This May Be a Challenging Year
description: MONEY market funds are paying investors next to nothing.

title: Easy Money
description: The United States has a vast bureaucracy to scrutinize how our government spends money abroad. While this kind of oversight is often necessary, there must be an exception made for crisis response in failed states. I base this on my experience after the Iraq invasion.

title: Sluggers and Bankers in the Strikeout Era
description: It seems fitting that in the same week that the mandarins of American finance were yanked to Capitol Hill to explain their roles in the global financial crisis, the baseball slugger Mark McGwire finally came clean about how he managed to crush so many monstrous home runs.

title: Final: Saints 45, Cardinals 14
description: Joe Lapointe was in New Orleans, and provided live analysis of Saturdays game between the Cardinals and the Saints, along with Andy Benoit, the founder of NFLTouchdown.com.

title: Guantnamo to the Rescue
description: Coinciding with the one-year anniversary of President Obamas unfulfilled pledge to close the American prison at Guantnamo Bay, the disaster in Haiti suggests a new mission for the United States naval base, one that might burnish Americas reputation in the world, if not redeem the base itself. Guantnamo is just 200 miles from Port-au-Prince, only 50 miles farther than Santo Domingo in the Dominican Republic, where American officials are staging earthquake recovery operations. Even as the United States works to close the prison, it should use the base for humanitarian intervention.

title: Haiti Quake Day 5: Tensions Rising
description: Tension and frustrations are mounting in Port-au-Prince as aid workers scramble to reach survivors in need of food, water and medical supplies.

title: Keep the Economy Underground
description: The underground economy in places like Haiti is often viewed as a criminal sector, made up of thugs and warlords, that sets back economic growth. But this is a one-sided portrait. Informal trading may be critical for Haitis recovery. Citizens in developing countries tend to find creative ways to make ends meet. The sharing of tools and workspaces, collective ownership of property, revolving credit associations and barter systems make up the backbone of the economy.

title: Pope Quiz: Is Every Pontiff a Saint?
description: When Pope Benedict XVI approved a decree last month that nudged nearer to sainthood his controversial wartime predecessor, Pius XII, he sparked another round of the sort of Jewish-Catholic disputations that have marked his papacy, and even cast doubt on whether his trip to Romes main synagogue, set for Sunday, would go on.

title: Where Baby Orwell Lived
description: The Bihar provincial government in India announced recently that it intended to restore George Orwells birthplace, in the town of Motihari, and open it as a museum. Doesnt hurt to be reminded that Orwell was a child of the Raj  as was Kipling, whose birthplace, in Mumbai, is already a museum  but its hard to imagine that the Orwell bungalow will become much of an attraction. Orwell spent a mere year there, his first, and Motihari, on the Nepalese border, is one of the remotest places in India.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: With World Watching, Rio Focuses on Security
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The police will invade 40 of the most violent slums in this city before the 2014 soccer World Cup being held in Brazil, with the goal of establishing a permanent policing presence in communities now controlled by well-armed drug gangs, Rio State officials say.

title: For Charities, Fewer and Smaller Gifts
description: As the outpouring of donations to Haiti has made clear, the charitable impulse is alive and well. But it was somewhat in abeyance in 2009, as the recession limited peoples ability to give and even caused some givers to become receivers.

title: Admission Doesnt Guarantee Entry
description: If one of Mark McGwires objectives for confessing his use of performance-enhancing drugs was to help his Hall of Fame candidacy, he may need to find another approach.

title: A Helping Hand for Haiti
description: This weekend, President Obama asked us to spearhead private-sector fund-raising efforts in the aftermath of the magnitude 7.0 earthquake that ravaged Haiti. We are pleased to answer his call.

title: Test for Chiles Coalition in Presidential Election
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Facing the prospect that Chile could swing to the right for the first time in two decades, Eduardo Frei took the stage in the working-class neighborhood of La Granja and pressed his leftist credentials one more time.

title: Olympic Fever Never Went Away
description: Scott Blackmun has had a case of what he calls five-ring fever since 1992, when he received his first legal assignment for the United States Olympic Committee. Now he is getting ready to begin what he considers his dream job as chief executive of the U.S.O.C. Blackmun, 52, had been the acting chief executive of the organization in 2000 and 2001. Then he went on to work as the chief operating officer for the Anschutz Entertainment Group, overseeing the development of the companys stadiums, theaters and arenas. He returns to the Olympic committee Jan. 26; the Vancouver Olympics begin Feb 12. And his three teenage children approve. KATIE THOMAS

title: Weld Joins Brown in Mass. Senate Rally
description: PLYMOUTH  State Senator Scott Brown started his day at a raucous rally with former Gov. William F. Weld, in front of the Quincy, Mass., library.

title: Iraqi Politicians Form New Secular Coalition
description: BAGHDAD  Prominent Iraqi politicians on Saturday announced the formation of what might emerge as the countrys most powerful secular coalition in parliamentary elections in March, a group that includes a vice president, a former prime minister and a leading Sunni lawmaker who was barred last week from taking part in the vote.

title: Letters: Critical Thinking in Business School
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: Hedge Fund Strategies, at Smaller Prices
description: An article last Sunday in the Mutual Funds Report, Part 2 of this section, about hedge fund strategies in mutual funds referred incorrectly to the hedge fund partnerships of Broadmark Asset Management. While the firm converted one such partnership into the Broadmark/Forward Tactical Growth mutual fund, it still has others.

title: J.F.K. Terminal Evacuated After Security Breach
description: A terminal at Kennedy International Airport was evacuated on Saturday afternoon after a passenger apparently used a restricted exit, a breach that delayed dozens of flights and threw the area into chaos as hundreds of people were rescreened, the authorities said.

title: Tennessee Tries to Give Its Fans a Reason to Believe
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  When someone pulls up in a car to take him to the store or to the movies or to go bowling, Bobby Maze, a senior guard on Tennessees basketball team, does not immediately jump in. First, he has to ask the big question.

title: Radio Show for Focus on the Family Founder
description: Dr. James Dobson, the founder of  Focus on the Family and an influential voice for Christian conservatives, is about to depart from the organization he created and is starting a radio program that will give him greater leeway to hold forth on politics.

title: Washington Border Area Is Bracing for Games
description: BELLINGHAM, Wash.  For nearly six years a group of as many as 150 government officials from dozens of security agencies have been meeting in Washington State every 90 days to discuss how to prepare for the 2010 Winter Olympics. Unlike security agencies gathering in Vancouver, the site of the Games next month, this groups focus has largely been on this side of the Canadian border.

title: An Odd Couple Defends Couples That Some (Oddly) Find Odd
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: In Latino Gardens, Vegetables, Good Health and Savings Flourish
description: SAN JOSE  At dawn, Maria Lupercio Alarcon wakens to the heady scent of onions and cilantro from her familys first garden, outside her bedroom window.

title: Figures Look at Families in Recession
description: Assessing the recessions impact on families, the Census Bureau said Friday that unemployment rates for couples with children under age 18 had doubled from 2007 to 2009.

title: For Antiterror Chief, a Rough Week Ahead as Hearings Begin
description: WASHINGTON  Not long after President Obama was inaugurated, Michael E. Leiter, the man in charge of the agency that is supposed to connect the dots to prevent terrorist attacks, took a stroll on the National Mall with a friend. The friend, a New Jersey doctor named Arthur Gross, mused aloud about what a new president feels when he learns of all the threats against the United States.

title: Forecasting a Winner? No, the Weather.
description: The forecast calls for a relatively cool Monday in Melbourne, with temperatures perhaps not making it out of the 60s. A breeze is expected, maybe even a little rain. Temperatures should trend upward from there over the next few days, but no drastic weather is on the near horizon.

title: Subtleties
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Its been a while since Cathy Allis (formerly Millhauser) has given us a Sunday puzzle, and its nice to have her back. Shes one of the funniest constructors around. Of the 50 puzzles in Will Shortzs Favorite Sunday Crosswords book, four of them are hers.

title: The Great Tea Party Rip-Off
description: Even given the low bar set by Americas bogus conversations about race, the short-lived Harry Reid fracas was a most peculiar nonevent. For all the hyperventilation in cable news land, this supposed racial brawl didnt seem to generate any controversy whatsoever in what is known as the real world.

title: Our Basic Human Pleasures: Food, Sex and Giving
description: Want to be happier in 2010? Then try this simple experiment, inspired by recent scholarship in psychology and neurology. Which person would you rather be:

title: Lonely Trek to Radicalism for Terror Suspect
description: KADUNA, Nigeria  Well before Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab disappeared into the rugged mountains of Yemen with an ominous goodbye to his father  warning him that this is the last time you are going to hear from me, according to top Nigerian officials  the tensions between the two pious men had already begun to show.

title: The Road to Radicalization
description: Behind Umar Farouk Abdulmutallabs journey from student to terrorism suspect was a struggle between an investment in this life and a longing for the next.

title: OBrien Talks Down to Final Details
description: With negotiations to settle Conan OBriens contract with NBC down to final details Saturday, attention shifted to others who will be affected by the breakup between the late-night star and the network.

title: Whats Our Sputnik?
description: Taipei, Taiwan

title: The Sources Stake in the News
description: WHEN The Times interviewed Michael Chertoff about airport security after the underwear bomber tried to blow up a passenger jet on Christmas Day, he said full-body scanners should be deployed at airports. Chertoff, the former secretary of homeland security, did not volunteer that he is a consultant to a company that makes such equipment, and though they spoke to him twice, reporters never asked if he had a financial stake in the matter.

title: Walking the Walk on School Reform
description: The American Federation of Teachers, the second-largest teachers union, has been working hard to distance itself from its competitor, the National Education Association, which tends to resist sensible reforms.

title: 3 Blackwater Guards Called Baghdad Shootings Unjustified
description: WASHINGTON  Three private security guards working for Blackwater Worldwide who witnessed a 2007 episode in Baghdad in which at least 17 Iraqi civilians were killed by other Blackwater guards told a federal grand jury that they believed the shootings were unjustified, according to newly unsealed court documents.

title: Whats in a Name? A Mountain of Controversy
description: The San Francisco lawyer who turned a few acres of vineyards into one of the countrys leading wine companies has always been known for thinking big. But his latest idea  to rename a Sonoma County mountain  is going over as smoothly as a bottle of turned Pinot.

title: A View That Took Millions of Years
description: When Doris Sloan, 79, is stuck in traffic on Highway 24 east of the Caldecott Tunnel, she takes the long view  the really long view. An adjunct professor of earth and planetary science at the University of California, Berkeley, Ms. Sloan, who lives in North Berkeley, wrote the field guide Geology of the San Francisco Bay Region. (Her words have been edited and condensed.)

title: Edward Schillebeeckx, Catholic Theologian, Dies at 95
description: The Rev. Edward Schillebeeckx, a prominent member of a wave of Roman Catholic theologians who helped reshape Catholicism during the Second Vatican Council and whose writings were later investigated for heresy, died on Dec. 23 in Nijmegen, the Netherlands. He was 95.

title: Newsom Is Eclipsed in Marriage Movement
description: Nearly six years after Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Francisco ignited a political and social firestorm by allowing same-sex couples to wed in his city, the issue of gay marriage remains at center stage, in the Bay Area and across the country.

title: New Yorks Street of Schemes
description: Over the past year, the New York Mayors Office of Special Enforcement has closed at least 64 of the storefront businesses that line the sidewalks of Canal Street from West Broadway to Lafayette Street, an area known as the Counterfeit Triangle. On one recent night, 10 buildings and 31 stalls were shut down, and a daisy chain of undercover and uniformed police officers filled an 18-wheeler with garbage bags holding $1 million worth of knockoff merchandise.

title: Thunder in the Dome as Saints Advance to N.F.C. Title Game
description: NEW ORLEANS  To motivate his Saints against the Arizona Cardinals on Saturday, New Orleans Coach Sean Payton gave them baseball bats marked with the words bring the wood.

title: 6 Major Powers Move Closer to Considering More Iran Sanctions
description: UNITED NATIONS  Six major powers agreed Saturday that the Iranian response to proposals to altering its nuclear development program had been inadequate and that it warranted consideration of further measures by the United Nations Security Council.

title: A Mountains Proposed Name Change and Other Highlights From Sundays Bay Area Report
description: Whats in a Name? | The lawyer, Jesse Jackson, 79, who owns the privately held Jackson Family Wines, wants to change the name of Black Mountain, a 3,128-foot-high peak a few miles east of Geyserville, to Alexander Mountain. Mr. Jacksons company is also seeking to create a new wine named Alexander Mountain, which, if approved, would permit the company to put a special label on the premium wine it makes from grapes grown at the base of the mountain. Area residents are not sympathetic, and a movement has formed against the change.

title: Dr. Thomas L. Petty, Researcher of Long-Term Oxygen Therapy, Is Dead at 76
description: When Dr. Thomas L. Petty started his research into severe chronic lung disease in the mid-1960s, oxygen therapy was generally administered in hospitals and typically for only a short time. Lung disease experts believed that providing oxygen to pulmonary patients for extended periods would cause a buildup of carbon dioxide in their bloodstreams, making them sicker.

title: Waylaid by Illness, Now Standing on Her Own
description: For Beatriz Hodge, the difference between a life in Puerto Rico and a life in New York was a trip to the zoo.

title: In Race for U.S. School Grants Is a Fear of Winning
description: As Illinois jockeys for position as a leader in education reform with a $500 million application for Race to the Top money, the states inability to pay current bills makes educators skeptical of Illinoiss capacity to take on such new initiatives.

title: Looting Flares Where Authority Breaks Down
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Along the capitals main commercial strip Saturday afternoon, dozens of armed men  some wielding machetes, others with sharpened pieces of wood  dodged from storefront to storefront, battering down doors and hauling away whatever they could carry: shoes, luggage, rolls of carpet.

title: The Death of a Playground Legend
description: Jon Scheyer was heating up the United Center on a cold Chicago night in early January, with 31 points and 6 assists in a no-sweat win over Iowa State. Now a senior at Duke, the spindly 6-foot-5 guard displayed the same deft shooting stroke and high-motor floor play that made him one of the most decorated prep players in Illinois when he was at Glenbrook North High School.

title: Corrections
description: The City Critic column in some editions last Sunday, about travel routes that will be affected the most by the Metropolitan Transportation Authoritys planned service cuts, misidentified the bus that the writer boarded in the Bronx, the beginning of one route, and misstated the route name of the bus she boarded in Queens that brought her to her destination, 26th Avenue. The Bronx bus is the Bx16, not the B16, and the Queens bus is the Q28; there is no B28 bus. The column also misstated the name of the Bronx cemetery that she passed on her travels. It is Woodlawn Cemetery, not Woodland.

title: Zenyatta to Compete This Year, Owner Says
description: Zenyatta, a front-runner with Rachel Alexandra for 2009 Horse of the Year, will come out of retirement and race in 2010, one of the horses co-owners, Jerry Moss, told the Santa Anita publicity department Saturday.

title: The Pulse: Forget the Scarf, but Think About the Frogs
description: As Chicagoans basked in last weeks relative warmth, they might have spared a thought for frogs. Above-freezing temperatures melt the citys roadside snowbanks, sending an annual average of 270,000 tons of road salt into the states waterways and giving flora and fauna a super-sized serving of NaCl.

title: The Pulse: Tillman Goes Free, but Others Still Wait
description: Michael Tillman, who has said he was a victim of police brutality, was freed from prison this week, but more than 20 black men who also say they were tortured into confessions by the Chicago police from 1973 to 1991 remain in prison, according to the Peoples Law Office.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the New Jersey Calendar in some editions last Sunday about a screening of Antichrist on Jan. 22 to 24, presented as part of the New Jersey Film Festival at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, misidentified the venue and Web site for the event and misstated the phone number for event information. The screening will be held in Room 105 of Voorhees Hall, not in the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum; both are at 71 Hamilton Street. The phone number is (732) 932-8482, and the Web site is njfilmfest.com.

title: Denney and Barrett Seize an Olympic Berth
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  Even before the music stopped during their long program at the United States nationals, Caydee Denney and Jeremy Barrett stood at center ice Saturday and fell into a long, hard embrace.

title: Corrections
description: The Quick Bite feature in some editions last Sunday, about Epsteins of Hartsdale, N.Y., misspelled the surname of a co-owner and misstated the delis phone number. The co-owner is Robert DeGroat, not DeGroaf, and the phone number is (914) 428-5320.

title: J.F.K. Terminal Evacuated
description: A terminal at Kennedy International Airport was evacuated on Saturday afternoon after a man apparently used a restricted doorway, a breach that delayed dozens of flights and threw the airport into disarray as hundreds of people were rescreened, the authorities said.

title: Corrections
description: A review in some editions last Sunday of Alices restaurant in Lake Hopatcong, N.J., with the chef David Drake, included an outdated reference to his namesake restaurant, David Drake, in Rahway, N.J. It closed on Jan. 6.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions last Sunday about Georgetown Universitys 72-69 victory over the University of Connecticut in mens basketball on Jan. 9 misidentified the Georgetown player who passed to Greg Monroe for the final basket of the game. It was Austin Freeman, not Chris Wright.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies last Sunday with an obituary about Freya von Moltke, a member of an anti-Nazi resistance group during World War II, misidentified the man shown. He was Field Marshal Helmuth von Moltke the Elder, the great-great-uncle of Mrs. Moltkes husband; he was not Count Helmuth James von Moltke, her husband and a leader of the resistance.

title: The Show Must Not Go On
description: Political theater and public scolding are good ways to draw attention to important issues and bad behavior, and Phil Angelides, chairman of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, made use of both last week. As he swore in four of the nations top bankers, it was impossible not to think of that famous scene with executives from the tobacco industry. During the questioning, he rebuked Lloyd Blankfein, head of Goldman Sachs, for his firms practice of selling mortgage-related securities and at the same time betting they would fall in value.

title: New Yorks Antique Divorce Law
description: Barring marriage by same-sex couples is not the only way that New York States policies on marriage are stuck in the past and inflict needless pain.

title: Will Restricting Salt Improve Health?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Cost of Prisons, in California and Texas
description: To the Editor:

title: The Safety of Ground Beef: Views From the Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: Trial by Ferry
description: There is nothing wrong with holding the trial of the man who has described himself as the mastermind of 9/11, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, in federal court in New York. But there is something wrong with spending upward of $200 million per year on security for a multiyear trial and disrupting the lives of people who have homes and jobs in Lower Manhattan, where the trial is to be held. Fortunately, there is a relatively easy solution to this problem: Governors Island.

title: Corrections
description: NEW YORK

title: On Los Angeles Bus Tour, an Insider View of Gang Life
description: LOS ANGELES  If nobody moves, nobody is going to get hurt, Alfred Lomas, tattoos scrawled along his arms and neck, announced from the front of the bus just before it departed. Just move all your money to the front.

title: Calipari Will Host Telethon to Raise Money for Haiti
description: A friend called Kentucky Coach John Calipari on Friday morning and told Calipari that he cried himself to sleep the night before because of the images from the tragedy in Haiti.

title: If It Feels Good, Do It  Give!
description: My Sunday column looks at something that has been written about for ages: that it is more blessed to give than to receive. Not always true, it seems, but often. And given the crisis in Haiti and so many other parts of the world (Im just preparing for a trip to one of the worst-off parts of the globe, so the issue is on my mind), there is a nice potential for an arrangement whereby we all benefit from a little more engagement.

title: Cornell Opens Defense of Ivy Title With Win Over Columbia
description: ITHACA, N.Y.  Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim said earlier in the week that he would seed the Cornell basketball team from a No. 4 to a No. 6 seed in this years N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: A Mess of a Primary to Inherit a Bigger Mess
description: Todd H. Stroger  the Cook County board president whose 2006 election may have matched last years election of President Hamid Karzai in Afghanistan as spectacle  may now belatedly pay the piper called democracy. Perhaps he should breathe a sigh of relief.

title: G.O.P. Sees Political Gain in Health Care
description: Even as Democrats nail down the final details of their health care bill, Republicans are devising ways to convert it into political capital.

title: End of the Line for Warner?
description: Kurt Warner, the Arizona quarterback, said he did not know if Saturdays 45-14 loss to New Orleans would be the last game in his career. He is 38 years old, has played 12 seasons and has had several concussions.

title: N.F.C. Divisional Playoffs: Saints Beat Cardinals
description: The Saints crushed the Cardinals, 45-14, Saturday in an N.F.C. divisional playoff game.

title: Players, and Fans, Turn Out for Haiti Relief Effort
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  More than 14,000 tennis fans swarmed onto the grounds of the Australian Open on Sunday afternoon here in an impromptu show of financial support for Haiti relief efforts  and the chance to see top players in an exhibition staged at the last-minute suggestion of Roger Federer.

title: Live Analysis: Final, Colts 20, Ravens 3
description: Judy Battista was in Indianapolis and John Woods was in Manhattan providing live analysis of Saturdays game between the Ravens and the Colts. Scroll down to track the progress of the game, as it happened. You also can follow Judy on Twitter.

title: Well-Rested Manning Leads Colts Past Ravens
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The Indianapolis Colts probably will not hold up Saturday nights game as a monument to avoiding rust during a playoff bye week, considering that Ed Reed improbably intercepted Peyton Manning twice on the same third-quarter drive. But after nearly a month at the center of the debate about whether teams should rest their starters in meaningless games  and whether their own history of shaky playoff performances suggested they made the wrong choice  the Colts provided the answer: this time, it worked for them.

title: Haiti Quake Day 5: Hunger Frays Nerves
description: Survivors show frustration and restraint at a locked supermarket, four days after a powerful earthquake devastated Port-au-Prince.

title: Mel Cuba Dies at 99; Saved 4 Drowning Orphans in Queens
description: The winds were whipping toward shore that summer day more than seven decades ago when 105 orphans from the Pride of Judea Home on Dumont Avenue in Brooklyn stepped off buses for what was supposed to be a gleeful romp at the beach in Rockaway, Queens.

title: The Poster as Propaganda
description: All across Europe, populist parties are growing by capitalizing on a very old-fashioned brand of propaganda art.

title: A Surprise Dinner Party for the First Lady
description: Michelle Obama turns 46 on Sunday, and the president took her out for a surprise birthday dinner Saturday night, according to a pool report.

title: McGwires Admission May Not Affect Hall of Fame Chances
description: Mark McGwires admission last week that he used performance-enhancing drugs did not improve his Hall of Fame candidacy, according to an informal poll by The Times. David Waldstein surveyed 35 Hall of Fame voters, and none who had bypassed McGwire said the confession would make a difference:

title: Vows: Rachel & Todd
description: Rachel Grand and Todd Spiegelman met on a blind date in 2005. They continued dating until they broke up when Rachel's ex-boyfriend showed up again. A year later, Rachel received an e-mail from Todd.

title: Israelis Blunder Sets Up a Surprising Finish
description: The biggest team event in chess is the biennial Olympiad, which was first held in 1924. At the last one, in Dresden, Germany, in 2008, teams from 146 nations competed.

title: A.F.C. Divisional Playoffs: Colts Beat Ravens
description: The Colts and a well-rested Peyton Manning beat the Baltimore Ravens, 20-3, in an A.F.C divisional round game.

title: Information on Haiti Is Getting Siloed
description: From Chris Csikszentmihalyi, Director of the M.I.T. Center for Future Civic Media: an important note to techies who are concerned with the situation in Haiti.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Sedin and Burrows Overshadow Crosby
description: Twelve games on Saturday, including a scare in the matinee game at Denver, where the Devils all-time leading scorer and 2009 Czech player of the year Patrik Elias was caught with his head down and knocked insensate. Fortunately, Elias seemed to be all right later, but he will undergo further examination back in New Jersey. Also, in Vancouver, Sidney Crosby came to town for only the second time in his N.H.L. career, just a few weeks after Alex Ovechkin made only his second trip to Vancouver as an N.H.L.er. Good thing that the Olympics will be held there. Home teams listed first:

title: Haiti Earthquake Multimedia
description: Videos, photographs and interactive features documenting the desperation in Haiti in the weeks after a powerful earthquake devastated the country on Jan. 12.

title: In Paris, a Night Devoted to Django
description: On Tuesday at 9 p.m., Paris will come alive with the sounds of Django.

title: Part 1: Answers on Fafsa and Financial Aid
description: For many high school seniors and their parents, this is the season for tackling the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, a notoriously cumbersome process that the government is attempting to streamline this year.

title: The Fuss Over Favre Was for a Day Like This
description: Those who followed the Fifth Down in the off-season (thanks, Mom) know we had our share of Brett Favre coverage.

title: Sure, Flying Is Less Fun, but Also Less Pricey
description: Once glamorous, air travel has turned into a slog of security rules, long waits and cramped limbs.

title: Jyoti Basu, Leader of Communists in India, Dies at 95
description: NEW DELHI  Jyoti Basu, a powerful leftist leader who dominated politics in the state of West Bengal for more than two decades and nearly became Indias first Communist prime minister, died in Calcutta on Sunday. He was 95.

title: 24 and Counting for American Men
description: This streak has to come to an end, right? You know the one. It started early last decade and has now surpassed the 20 mark.

title: Until Flo Ebbs, Progressive Will Capitalize on Her Popularity
description: It is always difficult to predict when an advertising character will catch on  or flop. Case in point, Flo, the chipper pitchwoman in a campaign for Progressive insurance who is portrayed by an actor and comedian named Stephanie Courtney.

title: Saturday Night Live Tries Some Late-Night Diplomacy
The Sunday Word: Bound for Boston
description: President Obama is traveling to Boston today in an effort to shore up Martha Coakleys bid for the Massachusetts Senate seat.

title: Jan. 17: Updates on Rescue and Recovery in Haiti
description: On Sunday The Lede is continuing to supplement reporting by our colleagues in Haiti -- see these recent articles by Simon Romero and Marc Lacey and by Ginger Thompson and Damien Cave -- on the aftermath of Tuesday's earthquake by pointing to news and information on the Web. Readers are encouraged to share any first-hand accounts they receive from Haiti or see online by writing to us in the comments thread below. Updates from previous days: Sat. | Fri. | Thurs. | Weds. and Tues.

title: Jan. 17: Updates on Rescue and Recovery in Haiti
description: On Sunday The Lede is continuing to supplement reporting by our colleagues in Haiti  see these recent articles by Simon Romero and Marc Lacey and by Ginger Thompson and Damien Cave  on the aftermath of Tuesdays earthquake by pointing to news and information on the Web. Readers are encouraged to share any first-hand accounts they receive from Haiti or see online by writing to us in the comments thread below. Updates from previous days: Sat. | Fri. | Thurs. | Weds. and Tues.

title: Karzai Closing In on Taliban Reconciliation Plan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan government will soon unveil a major new plan offering jobs, security, education and other social benefits to Taliban followers who defect, according to the spokesman for President Hamid Karzai.

title: Brown, Coakley, And the Outrage Gap
description: Wow. A video clip has surfaced from 2008 in which Scott Brown, the Republican candidate for Senate in Massachusetts, clearly suggested that President Obama may have been born out of wedlock.

title: Refugee Camp Swells With Injured (NBC)
description: NBC's Michelle Kosinski reports about a makeshift refugee camp in Haiti that for the most part is orderly and safe.

title: Responders Race to Treat Victims (NBC)
description: NBC's Dr. Nancy Snyderman reports on medical efforts in Haiti.

title: Gehry Withdraws From Museum of Tolerance Project in Jerusalem
description: Update | 3:35 p.m. The architect Frank Gehry has withdrawn from a project to design a Museum of Tolerance in Jerusalem, according to a report in Israels Haaretz newspaper last week. The building, which is being built by the Simon Wiesenthal Center, which opened the first Museum of Tolerance in Los Angles in 1993, has drawn criticism because it is being constructed on a site that was once part of a Muslim cemetery. However, other architects involved in the project say that Mr. Gehrys resignation was not related to protests over the site, but to financial issues. According to the architecture firm, Kolker, Kolker, Epstein Architects, part of the initial planning team, Mr. Gehry resigned after rejecting a request by the center to reduce the scope of the plan, the cost of which has been estimated at $250 million. Plans for the project were first announced at a groundbreaking ceremony in 2004 which included the former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Mr. Gehry and Arnold Schwarzenegger in Jerusalem.

title: Cast Announced for Come Fly Away
description: Audiences can now prepare for boarding: Come Fly Away has its crew. The new Broadway musical conceived, choreographed and directed by Twyla Tharp and based on the music of Frank Sinatra, has announced its cast. The show, about four couples who fall in and out of love at a nightclub, stars Matthew Dibble, Holley Farmer, Laura Mead, Charlie Neshyba-Hodges, Rika Okamoto, Karine Plantadit, Keith Roberts and John Selya, all of whom appeared in last falls production of the show, then called, Come Fly With Me, at Atlantas Alliance Theater and several of whom appeared in Ms. Tharps 2002 Broadway hit Movin Out (that one was based on the music of Billy Joel). The show, which has a cast of 15 dancers and an on-stage 19-piece big band, is to begin previews on March 1 and open on March 25 at the Marquis Theater..

title: Chaim Potok Papers go to Penn
description: The University of Pennsylvania is now home to the papers of the Jewish American author and rabbi Chaim Potok, the university announced Friday. Potok, the author of The Chosen, My Name is Asher Lev and other works about the struggle between religious and secular Jewish life, died in 2002 at age 73. An alumnus of the university, he bequeathed his papers to Penn, where he also taught. The collection includes writings, correspondence, lectures, sermons, article clippings and fan mail, including a letter from the Nobel Laureate and Holocaust survivor Elie Wiesel. The collection will be housed in the universitys rare book and manuscript library.

title: Hurt Locker Takes Home Top Award at Critics Choice
description: The awards season is off to a good start for Kathryn Bigelow. Her action-packed film, The Hurt Locker, about a bomb disposal unit in Baghdad, took home prizes for best picture and best director at the Critics Choice Awards on Friday, The Associated Press reported. Its wonderful to have this honor, Ms. Bigelow said at the ceremony, but the recognition should also go to the men and women who are in the field to this day. James Camerons Avatar and Quentin Tarantinos Inglourious Basterds won the most awards, with Mr. Tarantinos cast taking the prize for best ensemble and Christoph Walz winning for best supporting actor. Mr. Tarantino also won for best original screenplay. Avatar was named best action movie and also won for cinematography, editing, art direction, sound and visual effects. Jeff Bridges turn as a hard-drinking country singer in Crazy Heart earned him the best actor award while Meryl Streep and Sandra Bullock tied for the best actress honor for their respective work in Julie & Julia and The Blind Side and MoNique won the best supporting actress prize for her portrayal of an abusive mother in Precious. The winners are chosen by members of the Broadcast Film Critics Association.

title: The Foundry Theater
description: A look at some of the companys past productions.

title: Spielberg to Produce Ground Zero Documentary
description: Steven Spielberg is turning his eye to Ground Zero. The Oscar-winning director will be the executive producer of a documentary with the Science Channel about the reconstruction of the former World Trade Center site in lower Manhattan, Variety reported last week. Rebuilding Ground Zero will be broadcast in six parts in 2011. Filmed in 3D and high definition, the series will examine the different groups working to build the project, from the Port Authority of New York & New Jersey to the engineers, politicians and constructions crews. The series will also make use of time-lapse photography and other methods to chronicle the construction of One World Trade Center. The idea was initially conceived of by the architect Danny Foster and the director Jonathan Hock.

title: Final: Vikings 34, Cowboys 3
description: Pat Borzi is in Minneapolis and Paul Myerberg in New York providing live analysis of todays game between the Vikings and Cowboys. Use your refresh button to stay current with the updates.

title: Obama Takes to the Pulpit
description: President Obama told a black church in the nations capital today that the promise inherent in his election as the nations first African-American president has yet to be fully realized, acknowledging that partisan Washington politics continued to play a big role in governance.

title: Hurt Locker Takes Home Top Award at Critics Choice
description: Kathryn Bigelow and her film The Hurt Locker took home top prizes for best picture and best director at the Critics Choice Awards on Friday while James Camerons Avatar and Quentin Tarantinos Inglourious Basterds also were big winners. ArtsBeat has more on the awards, which also delivered a tie for best actress to Meryl Streep and Sandra Bullock.

title: Now Screening | Dolce & Gabbana
description: The fall 2010 collection from Dolce & Gabbana.

title: Haiti Quake Day 6: Steps Toward Normalcy
description: Damien Cave reports from Port-au-Prince on signs that some order is returning to the city as aid reaches survivors, many of whom sought solace at churches.

title: Hussein Aide Again Given a Sentence of Death
description: BAGHDAD  An Iraqi court sentenced a former aide to Saddam Hussein to death by hanging on Sunday for having ordered a poison gas attack on a Kurdish village in 1988.

title: Hansen and Watts Agree: Cold Weather, Warm Climate
description: As the ice that formed on the Hudson River during the recent cold snap begins to break up (see my video snapshot below), its perhaps a good time to close the case on unusual cold spells in an unusually warm world.

title: Another Injury Clouds U.S. Future
description: Update | 6:13 p.m.  Late Tuesday, Fulham officials said that, after an examination, it was determined that surgery would not be necessary on Clint Dempseys right knee. The club said that Dempsey sustained moderate damage to the posterior cruciate ligament, but should be available before the end of the English Premier League season in May and should be fit enough to play for the United States at the World Cup in South Africa in June.

title: Senator Enzi Says Bill Will Raise Costs
description: Continuing the conversation about why health care in America is so expensive, Senator Michael B. Enzi, Republican of Wyoming, explains his pessimism about the Democrats legislation emerging from Washington.

title: On Assignment: Where Is the Help?
description: Damon Winter has been in Port-au-Prince since Wednesday. James Estrin spoke with him at 12:30 p.m. Sunday by satellite phone. Viewers are cautioned that this slide show includes very disturbing images.

title: Avatar, Atop the Box Office, Nears $500 Million
description: James Camerons Avatar, neared the $500 million mark at the North American box office in just 32 days (it took Mr. Camerons Titanic 98 days to get there), as it earned the No. 1 spot for the fifth weekend in a row with $41.3 million in ticket sales.

title: Now Screening | Jil Sander
description: The fall 2010 collection from Jil Sander.

title: Australian Open Begins With Eye on Henin and Clijsters
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Like politics, all sports are local, and the passions of Australians have been on full display the past 72 hours. Virtually every television and car radio has been tuned to the cricket test between Australia and Pakistan under way in Hobart  between lunch and tea, of course. Horse racing has been off and running day and night, too, from one rugged coast to another.

title: Working Mothers in Germany
description: Katrin Bennhold looks at the lives of four working mothers in Germany and the difficulties they face managing careers and child care.

title: In Senate Race, Massachusetts Bucks a Political Stereotype
description: MARLBOROUGH, Mass.  Angela Grenham, 50, was raised a Massachusetts Democrat  We had the crucifix and the J.F.K. sign, she recalled  and voted for a Democrat for president as recently as 2000, when she supported Al Gore.

title: Pakistan Says Drone Strike Kills 15
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Missiles fired from American aircraft killed as many as 15 people in western Pakistan on Sunday, Pakistani security officials said, part of an increased campaign by the United States to use drones to kill militants.

title: Democrats Backup Health Plan: Ask House to Back Senate Bill
description: With the Massachusetts special election for United States Senate increasingly unpredictable, Democrats in Washington are contemplating an array of backup plans should a Republican upset on Tuesday deprive the Democrats of the crucial 60th vote that they need to pass far-reaching health care legislation.

title: Final: Jets 17, Chargers 14
description: Greg Bishop and William C. Rhoden are in San Diego and George Bretherton is in New York providing live analysis of todays game between the Jets and the Chargers. Use your refresh button to stay current with the updates.

title: Magic Tricks, Cupcakes and Footwear: Partying, Golden Globe-Style
description: Hows the Queen doing these days? Oliver Stone asked Helen Mirren at a party on Saturday afternoon. The Queens retired, Ms. Mirren replied. Mr. Stone hadnt kept up to date with Ms. Mirrens historical roles; shes currently playing Sonya Tolstoy in The Last Station, she reminded him at a brunch for Film Independents Spirit Awards nominees, one of the many parties the Bagger has popped in on this Golden Globes weekend, and the only one with decent food.

title: Obama Rallies Democrats in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON  President Obama swooped into Massachusetts on Sunday in an attempt to rescue the flailing candidacy of Martha Coakley, the Democratic Senate candidate in a special election on Tuesday that will determine whether the party will preserve its 60-vote majority in the United States Senate and keep alive its health care agenda.

title: Behind Defense and Favre, Vikings Beat Cowboys
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Minnesota Vikings defensive end Ray Edwards, a serviceable but rarely spectacular pass rusher, fell to the Metrodome FieldTurf late in the third quarter Sunday, grabbing his right knee. When Edwards limped off a few moments later, the crowd cheered as if Edwards were one of the Purple People Eaters from the 1960s and 70s.

title: Marriage and Mores in Rain-Soaked Hanoi
description: If you dont expect too much, everythings simple, declares Duyen (Do Thi Hai Yen), a radiant young Vietnamese bride in Bui Thac Chuyens moody, enigmatic film, Adrift. In the opening scene Duyen, still in her wedding gown, waits patiently by the nuptial bed as her new husband, Hai (Duy Khoa Nguyen), drinks himself into oblivion at a party on the floor below. When he is dragged upstairs unconscious, it is not an encouraging sign.

title: China Restores Text Messaging in Xinjiang
description: BEIJING  The Chinese government continued to ease a six-month-old blackout on communications in the northwest region of Xinjiang by restoring some text-messaging services on Sunday, the state news media said.

title: Conan Deal Is Imminent, Key Details All Worked Out
description: An announcement of a deal in the protracted negotiations between NBC and Conan OBrien could come as early as later tonight, representatives of both sides said Sunday.

title: Advanced Aesthetics: Creators and How to Stage Them
description: LONDON  Straight lines have never been part of the geometry of Alan Bennett, a writer known for his endearingly corkscrew approach to matters erudite. But with his Habit of Art, an amiable dodge of a play that imagines a late-life meeting between the poet W. H. Auden and the composer Benjamin Britten, he never seems to stop circling his subject. And you start to wonder if its because hes afraid of not getting it right.

title: 2010 Ford Taurus SHO
description: Ford's high-performance Taurus offers more excitement than any family sedan in recent memory.

title: Staying True to Novels Vigor
description: Inspired by reading Pushkins Eugene Onegin, the Indian writer Vikram Seth achieved an unlikely alchemy in his 1986 debut novel, The Golden Gate, detailing the intermingled intimacies of five contemporary San Franciscans in their 20s with stately rhymed sonnets. In creating an opera based on Mr. Seths novel, the composer Conrad Cummings has fashioned an equally improbable fusion: lithe melodic lines that flow and entwine in the manner of Monteverdi, peppered with musical references to Henry Mancini and the punk band Black Flag.

title: Bohemian Soul Mates in Obscurity
description: Patti Smith and Robert Mapplethorpe were both born in 1946, at a time when the iceman and the last of the horse-drawn wagons could still be seen on city streets. Ms. Smith points this out at the start of her tenderly evocative memoir, Just Kids, but there is even stronger evidence that this book dates back a long time.

title: Now Screening | Burberry Prorsum
description: The fall 2010 collection from Burberry Prorsum.

title: Professor Is a Label That Leans to the Left
description: The overwhelmingly liberal tilt of university professors has been explained by everything from outright bias to higher I.Q. scores. Now new research suggests that critics may have been asking the wrong question. Instead of looking at why most professors are liberal, they should ask why so many liberals  and so few conservatives  want to be professors.

title: Catchphrase
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Some solvers get frustrated when there are too many clues about sports or opera or 19th century French poetry or whatever their particular blind spot happens to be. Todays crossword is much simpler for television watchers. TV used to be the closest we had to a broadly shared cultural experience. Say the secret word and win $100. These days, you may not even have any friends who watch the tube. Times have changed.

title: Visitors From Vienna Bring Both the Pastoral and the Not-So-Pastoral
description: Programming symphonic concerts is too often done to formula, the lamest, nowadays, being overture, concerto, intermission, symphony. If anything more challenging can be slipped by the marketing department, it is tucked somewhere inside to avoid encouraging patrons to arrive late or leave early.

title: Design in Detroit
description: The focus was on smaller cars, global production and interactivity at the 2010 North American International Auto Show.

title: Local Stop: Yorkville
description: The neighborhood has changed since German and Hungarian immigrants dominated, but some local businesses retain a European imprint.

title: Its All in the Telling, a Step at a Time
description: How odd: Stories dominate this winters repertory from New York City Ballet. This company built its international reputation as the worlds foremost purveyor of plotless one-act dance works, with minimal costumes and without scenery. True, a number of narrative dramas have been integral to its popularity, notably George Balanchines 1949 production of Firebird and his 1954 one of The Nutcracker. Yet never has it presented so high a proportion of full-length narrative ballets as during the current November-to-February season: The Nutcracker, A Midsummer Nights Dream, Romeo + Juliet, The Sleeping Beauty and Swan Lake, each armed with a variety of costumes and dcors.

title: Matching Wits in Cyberspace
description: Every Wednesday morning at 11 Eastern time, two experts play online at bridgebase.com with juniors from around the world. Each junior plays two deals. On Dec. 30 I played against Benito Garozzo, who was the declarer in this deal.

title: From Tin Pan Alley to Springsteen With a Cock-Eyed Realist
Figure Skaters Campaign to Retake His Summit
description: One problem with Be Good Johnny Weir, a Sundance Channel documentary series about the efforts of Mr. Weir, the figure skater, to climb back to the top of the sport, is that it will be irrelevant by the time it has its premiere on Monday. The pivotal competition, the nationals, which the series will finally get to in March, was held over the weekend in Spokane, Wash. Anyone who cares enough about skating to watch this show will already know whether Mr. Weir did well enough to make the Olympic team, his goal.

title: New CDs
description: EELS End Times (E Works/Vagrant)

title: Cast Announced for Come Fly Away
description: Audiences can now prepare for boarding: Come Fly Away has its crew. The new Broadway musical conceived, choreographed and directed by Twyla Tharp and based on the music of Frank Sinatra, has announced its cast. The show, about four couples who fall in and out of love at a nightclub, stars Matthew Dibble, Holley Farmer, Laura Mead, Charlie Neshyba-Hodges, Rika Okamoto, Karine Plantadit, Keith Roberts and John Selya, all of whom appeared in last falls production of the show, then called Come Fly With Me, at the Alliance Theater in Atlanta and at least two of whom appeared in Ms. Tharps 2002 Broadway hit Movin Out (that one was based on songs by Billy Joel). The show is to begin previews on March 1 and open on March 25 at the Marquis Theater.

title: The Hurt Locker Wins 2 Critics Choice Awards
description: The awards season has begun well for Kathryn Bigelow. Her suspense-filled film The Hurt Locker, about a bomb disposal unit in Baghdad, took home prizes for best picture and best director at the Critics Choice Awards on Friday, The Associated Press reported. Its wonderful to have this honor, Ms. Bigelow said at the ceremony, but the recognition should also go to the men and women who are in the field to this day. Avatar and Quentin Tarantinos Inglourious Basterds won the most awards, with Mr. Tarantinos cast taking the prize for best ensemble and Christoph Waltz winning for best supporting actor. Mr. Tarantino also won for best original screenplay. Avatar was named best action movie and also won for cinematography, editing, art direction, sound and visual effects. Jeff Bridgess turn as a hard-drinking country singer in Crazy Heart earned him the best actor award, while Meryl Streep and Sandra Bullock tied for the best actress honor, Ms. Streep for her work in Julie & Julia and Ms. Bullock for The Blind Side, and MoNique won the best supporting actress prize for her portrayal of an abusive mother in Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire. The winners are chosen by members of the Broadcast Film Critics Association.

title: Strong Turnouts for the Navi and a Gypsy
description: James Camerons Avatar neared the $500 million mark at the North American box office in just 32 days (it took Mr. Camerons Titanic 98 days to get there), as it earned the No. 1 spot for the fifth weekend in a row with $41.3 million in ticket sales. The cumulative domestic total for Avatar, from 20th Century Fox, is $491.8 million, according to box office analysts, making it the No. 3 movie on the all-time domestic box office charts (not adjusting for inflation). Worldwide the film has taken in $1.6 billion, second only to Titanic, at $1.8 billion. The Denzel Washington action-adventure The Book of Eli (Warner Brothers) was second with a solid $31.6 million. The Lovely Bones (Paramount and DreamWorks) was third with about $17 million, a disappointing total for an expensive film from a major director (Peter Jackson), based on a best seller. The Lovely Bones will need to perform spectacularly to avoid becoming a box office disaster. Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (Fox) was fourth with about $11.5 million (for a new total of $193 million). Sherlock Holmes (Warner) was fifth with about $9.8 million ($180 million total). Also notable was a strong turnout for the Metropolitan Operas high-definition presentation of Carmen, starring Elina Garanca, right. Shown on 700 screens on Saturday, it sold about $3 million in tickets, a record for the Met movie series.

title: Papers of Chaim Potok to Go to Penn
description: The University of Pennsylvania is now home to the papers of the Jewish-American author and rabbi Chaim Potok, the university announced Friday. Potok, the author of The Chosen, My Name Is Asher Lev and other works about the struggle between religious and secular Jewish life, died in 2002 at age 73. An alumnus of the university, he bequeathed his papers to Penn, where he also taught.

title: Frank Gehry Withdraws From Museum Project
description: The architect Frank Gehry, below, has withdrawn from a project designing a Museum of Tolerance in Jerusalem, according to a report in the Israeli newspaper Haaretz last week. The project, being built by the Simon Wiesenthal Center, which opened the first Museum of Tolerance in Los Angeles in 1993, has drawn criticism because it is being constructed on a site that was once part of a Muslim cemetery. However, according to the architecture firm Kolker, Kolker, Epstein Architects, part of the initial planning team, Mr. Gehry resigned after rejecting a request by the center to reduce the scope of the plan, the cost of which has been estimated at $250 million.

title: Candidate Bans Worsen Iraqs Political Turmoil
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi officials have done little to clarify who, exactly, has been disqualified from running for Parliament in March because of ties to Saddam Husseins Baath Party. They did, however, make clear on Sunday that, contrary to Iraqi television news, the governments own spokesman was not among those declared a Baathist and therefore unfit for office.

title: For Many Start-Ups, a Spot on the Nasdaq Is No Longer the Goal
description: SEATTLE  Investors in technology start-ups have been trying to end the drought in initial public offerings of tech companies. But for entrepreneurs, has taking a company public lost its allure?

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 946 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Sunday:

title: Star Turns at Liberians War Crimes Trial
description: PARIS  Testimony in the case against the former warlord Charles G. Taylor sounded more like a Hollywood mystery than a war-crimes trial last week, with a cast of characters including Naomi Campbell and Mia Farrow and a plot involving plans to trade guns for a bag of diamonds.

title: The Bagger and the King of Insults
description: On Saturday night, at parties given by Paramount and Lionsgate here in Los Angeles, the Bagger encountered those fabled creatures, those unicorns of the awards season, the members of the Hollywood Foreign Press Association. For the most part, they lived up to their fanboy reputation, snapping photos with stars and acting giddy. The Paramount party, at the Chateau Marmont, attracted an even rarer breed  older Academy members, who dont usually brave the paparazzi. Don Rickles was there.

title: Israeli Defense Minister Visits Turkey to Mend Frayed Ties
description: ISTANBUL  Israels defense minister, Ehud Barak, traveled to Turkey on Sunday to try to smooth over recent tensions that have further frayed the traditionally strong ties between the two countries.

title: Pope Tries to Soothe Tensions With Jews
description: ROME  Pope Benedict XVI, in a visit to Romes main synagogue, sought to soothe tensions between Catholics and Jews on Sunday, though he and Jewish leaders aired one main point of contention: whether the church did enough against the Holocaust.

title: Rain on the Red Carpet
description: Update | 8:20 p.m. Umbrellas are the accessory of the evening outside the the Beverly Hilton Hotel as celebrities arrived for the 67th Golden Globe Awards. Fans gathered along the red carpet wrapped themselves in plastic ponchos and cheered as slightly soggy celebrities passed by.

title: A New York Volunteer Effort Will Soon Spread to 10 Cities
description: Since April, they have spruced up a dozen city blocks, helped give 164,000 flu vaccinations and installed 178,000 compact fluorescent bulbs in public housing. They are volunteers, part of an ambitious New York effort to tap unpaid workers as a permanent, strategic element in solving city problems.

title: Holiday: Martin Luther Kings Birthday
description: NEW YORK

title: Therapists Report Increase in Green Disputes
description: Gordon Fleming is, by his own account, an environmentally sensitive guy.

title: Renault Pledges to Keep a French Factory Busy
description: PARIS  Carlos Ghosn, the chief executive of Renault, sought to defuse an employment conflict with the French government, telling President Nicolas Sarkozy over the weekend that the automaker would split production of its new Clio model between France and Turkey, and would produce its new electric vehicle entirely in a plant near Paris.

title: As Shrinking Newsrooms Use Upstarts Content, Vetting Questions Arise
description: News comes from more and more outlets, about which readers know less and less.

title: Home Fires: A Guide and an Ally
description: Greetings again from the Sunshine State.

title: Hoping It Wont Be Needed, Democrats Ponder a Backup Plan on Health Care Bill
description: WASHINGTON  With the Massachusetts special election for United States Senate increasingly unpredictable, Democrats in Washington are contemplating a fall-back plan to advance far-reaching health care legislation, even if a Republican victory on Tuesday deprives Senate Democrats of the crucial 60th vote they need to overcome filibusters.

title: Companies Fight Endless War Against Computer Attacks
description: The recent computer attacks on the mighty Google left every corporate network in the world looking a little less safe.

title: OBrien Deal With NBC Said to Be Imminent
description: A settlement in the protracted negotiations between NBC and Conan OBrien to end the talk show hosts seven-month stint at The Tonight Show was said to be imminent on Sunday night, with all of the basic elements of the deal hammered out and both sides eager to be finished with it.

title: Presidential Election in Ukraine Goes to a Runoff
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Two of the chief combatants in the 2004 Orange Revolution, which brought to power a pro-Western government that has left the public increasingly disillusioned, battled in a presidential election on Sunday, but because neither received enough votes to win outright, they will face each other in a runoff.

title: In War Against the Internet, China Is Just a Skirmish
description: PARIS  In the beginning, there was one Internet, born from American research and embraced by academics around the world. It was in English and homogeneous, operating according to Western standards of openness.

title: Its Not Jay or Conan. Its Us.
description: The other night, my daughter and I watched Jay Leno, talking about him and his soon-to-be-canceled show. We took in Conan OBrien as well, dissecting the inside jokes and the implications of his walking away from The Tonight Show. As they did their thing, we talked about their performing styles, demographic appeal and remarkable hair.

title: Jets Advance to A.F.C. Title Game
description: SAN DIEGO  Minutes after the Jets cemented the most surprising upset of this N.F.L. season, before travel plans for the American Football Conference championship had been booked, linebacker Bart Scott stood defiant at his locker, mouth running, faster than ever.

title: United States Attorney Plans Drug-Terrorism Unit
description: The United States attorney in Manhattan is merging the two units in his office that prosecute terrorism and international narcotics cases, saying that he wants to focus more on extremist Islamic groups whose members he believes are increasingly turning to the drug trade to finance their activities.

title: Schumer, Citing Failures, Wants Airport Breaches Investigated
description: For the second time in two weeks, a New York-area airport went into lockdown after a security breach by someone who did not appear to be a terrorist.

title: Internet Politics From Both Sides Now
description: For a brief shining moment, late in the 2008 campaign, Democrats thought that they might own the Internet.

title: New Yorkers Ambitions Shock Few Back in Memphis
description: MEMPHIS  If you dont believe that Harold E. Ford Jr. is liberal enough to run for the United States Senate as a Democrat from New York, just ask Bob Capkovic.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: A First Visit to Tenniss Happy Slam
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  This is not only my maiden trip Down Under but my first experience in the rarefied air of Grand Slam tennis. Before Friday, all I knew of either were the Mad Max movies and memories of being stretched out on the family room floor as a kid watching Rod Laver, Margaret Court, John Newcombe and Evonne Goolagong.

title: A Rescue at U.N. Headquarters, as Others Wait and Hope
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, on Sunday made his first visit to Haiti since the earthquake that flattened much of the capital last week and plunged the international agencys already beleaguered mission here into crisis.

title: What Didnt Happen
description: Lately many people have been second-guessing the Obama administrations political strategy. The conventional wisdom seems to be that President Obama tried to do too much  in particular, that he should have put health care on one side and focused on the economy.

title: U.S. Mulls Role in Haiti After the Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas aggressive response to the deadly earthquake in Haiti has led to criticism from the far right that the United States is taking on too much, at a time when its foreign-policy plate is already full.

title: Shockey Still a Brash and Emotional Presence
description: NEW ORLEANS  Jeremy Shockey was a member of a Super Bowl championship team in the 2007 season as a tight end for the Giants. But it was hard for him to enjoy it because his season ended in Week 15 when he broke his left leg.

title: Embracing MoNique
description: The Bagger was disregarding protocol at the Golden Globes and wandering around the hallways near the press room backstage when we encountered MoNique, the newly minted best supporting actress winner for Precious, receiving a long, heartfelt hug from a woman. Seriously, this was like a three-minute embrace. Who was that?

title: Amid Rubble, Seeking a Refuge in Faith
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Five days after Haitis devastating earthquake, an evangelical pastor in a frayed polo shirt, his church crushed but his spirit vibrant, sounded a siren to summon the newly homeless residents of a tent city to an urgent Sunday prayer service.

title: In Hollywood, Grappling With Studios Lost Clout
description: LOS ANGELES  A proposed sale of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the most powerful and lucrative studio during the golden age of film, drew only meager offers last week, and now Hollywood must confront a troubling question: Are movie studios becoming a financial footnote?

title: Review of Jet Bomb Plot Shows More Missed Clues
description: This article is by  Eric Lipton, Eric Schmitt and Mark Mazzetti.

title: Why Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs Didnt Win
description: I think its a little bit of a challenge for people to award a film called Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs. Its just a little bit silly sounding  and the award goes to, Cloudy with a Chance of Dancing Horses in the Rain!  Phil Lord, a director of Cloudy, on why his film wouldnt win, on the red carpet of the Golden Globes.

title: Oscar Race Begins at Golden Globes
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  A rain-drenched Hollywood paused in its efforts to raise money for Haitian earthquake victims on Sunday long enough to focus on the Golden Globes, perhaps the most frivolous of the high-profile stops on the entertainment industrys awards trail. The big winner: James Camerons Avatar, which came away with awards for best dramatic picture and best director.

title: Rescues Beat Dimming Odds in Haiti but Fall Short of Need
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Despite dimming odds, rescue workers pulled more people alive from the rubble  including a 7-year-old girl who survived more than four days eating dried fruit rolls in the supermarket that collapsed around her  as water and emergency aid deliveries improved on Sunday, though not nearly enough to meet Haitis desperate need.

title: Minnesota Vikings at New Orleans Saints
description: Minnesota Vikings

title: While Offense Is Pondered, Colts Defense Takes Over
description: INDIANAPOLIS  In the Baltimore Ravens locker room, running back Ray Rice gave voice to the Indianapolis Colts peculiar image problem.

title: Right-Wing Businessman Wins Chiles Presidency
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Sebastin Piera, a billionaire businessman and former senator, broke the 20-year hold on power of a leftist coalition on Sunday, becoming the first right-wing president to be elected in Chile since the dictatorship ended in 1990.

title: Democrats Push to Salvage a Flailing Candidacy
description: BOSTON  President Obama came to Massachusetts on Sunday in hopes of rescuing the flailing candidacy of Martha Coakley, the Democratic candidate in an election on Tuesday that will determine whether the party preserves a 60-vote majority in the Senate needed to keep alive health care legislation and the rest of the presidents agenda.

title: Jets at Indianapolis Colts
description: Jets

title: Premium Cable Thumps the Networks
description: Some thoughts on the Golden Globes, television division:

title: Haitian New Yorkers Hold on to Their Hope
description: At SS. Joachim and Anne School on the eastern edge of Queens, a first grader has lost his father. A third grader is mourning an uncle. His father is still missing.

title: Wise Teenager, Unpromising Parents
description: The CW network, with its interchangeable casts and its New Mexico-size audiences (current population: around 2 million), is often dismissed as the kids table of prime time. Its not a bad place to sit, though: with Gossip Girl, The Vampire Diaries and Supernatural representing 30 percent of its nighttime schedule, CW has as high a percentage of purely enjoyable programming as any broadcast network.

title: Still Stung by Failure, Cubs Fans Convene to Refresh Faith
description: CHICAGO  The baseball writer Roger Kahn once wrote, You may glory in a team triumphant, but you fall in love with a team in defeat. By that axiom, the Cubs and their fans have one of sports most ardent love affairs, one that remains passionate despite a 101-year World Series title drought.

title: For 45,000 Americans in Haiti, the Quake Was a Nightmare Thats Not Ending
description: MIAMI  One was a 22-year-old volunteer from Washington State who was teaching youngsters with mental handicaps. Another was a Dallas woman who was fitting impoverished Haitians for eyeglasses. A third was a California landscape architect who had just arrived with three other men to work on a project to build playgrounds and athletic fields.

title: Wall St. Weighs a Challenge to a Proposed Tax
description: Wall Streets main lobbying arm has hired a top Supreme Court litigator to study a possible legal battle against a bank tax proposed by the Obama administration, on the theory that it would be unconstitutional, according to three industry officials briefed on the matter.

title: On Call for Acceptance Speech Advice
description: I hope she wins for our movie, Nora Ephron told the Bagger at some awards show or other in the last few weeks, on the subject of Meryl Streep competing with herself in the best actress  comedy category at the Globes. Ms. Ephron got her wish, when Ms. Streep won for Julie & Julia.

title: The Globes: Wet and Earnest
description: If you werent sort of half paying attention to the Jets-Chargers game as you finished off a nice Spanish red, you may have noticed that some of the red-carpet smiles were more forced than usual this year at the Golden Globe awards. Getting out of a limo while you haul a couple of pounds of damp couture silk behind you isnt exactly a blast. Heidi Klum, poured into a soupy Cavalli, actually seemed annoyed by the number of steps she had to negotiate  and she had Seal, her manly husband.

title: The Green Table
description: An effort in San Jose, Calif., is helping residents in city neighborhoods grow their own produce in their own backyards.

title: At the Cubs Convention, Hope Springs Eternal
description: Where does hope spring eternal? At a Hilton in downtown Chicago, site of the 25th annual Cubs Convention.

title: Dream for the Plaza Fades in a Not-So-Gilded Age
description: When an Israeli billionaire bought New Yorks storied Plaza Hotel for $675 million, he envisioned turning the plucky grande dame with the globally recognized name into mainly a luxury condo tower that would cater to the worlds wealthiest buyers and offer stores to satisfy their every desire.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 7 about Chinas efforts to lure back expatriate scholars and scientists referred incorrectly to the resum of Wang Xiaodong, a Howard Hughes Medical Institute investigator and a director of Beijings National Institute of Biological Sciences. Mr. Wang remains a full-time professor at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center in Dallas  he has not left. (He simultaneously serves as director of the Beijing institute.)

title: The One Way Older Actresses Have It Easier
description: In the press room, Meryl Streep said she thought she had it easy compared with younger actresses. When I was coming up, there was no such thing as the 24-7 news cycle, the blogosphere commenting on their weight endlessly, she said. That always happened but it happened in apartments and restaurants. You didnt hear everybodys opinion of you all the time.

title: In Recall, a Role Model Stumbles
description: The Harvard Business School teaches future executives the gold standard in brand crisis management. The model dictates that a company should communicate clearly with the public about a crisis, cooperate with government officials, swiftly begin its own investigation of a problem and, if necessary, quickly institute a product recall.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about logistical problems at Haitis Port-au-Prince airport that threatened to delay rescue workers and supplies from reaching earthquake victims misspelled, in some copies, the surname of the vice president of Haiti Shipping Lines, based in Miami, who commented on relief efforts at the port of Cap Haitien. He is Richard Dubin, not Dupin.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a contentious vote by the Beverly Hills, Calif., school board to dismiss students enrolled on out-of-district permits, using a board members estimate, misstated the number of students affected by the vote. It is 206, not roughly 400.

title: Alec Baldwin, Conspicuous by His Absence
description: Sunday nights best opportunity for NBC-bashing fizzled: Alec Baldwin, who won a third Golden Globe award for his portrayal of a power-mad NBC executive on 30 Rock, was absent. What was the previously scheduled charity event that kept him away from the stage? Inquiring minds will certainly have tracked it down by tomorrow. A quick look at alecbaldwin.com showed that the schedule of Mr. Baldwins public appearances there ended with Dec. 31.

title: Law to Curb Lobbying Sends It Underground
description: WASHINGTON  Ellen Miller, co-founder of the Sunlight Foundation, has spent years arguing for rules to force more disclosure of how lobbyists and private interests shape public policy. Until recently, she herself registered as a lobbyist, too, publicly reporting her role in the groups advocacy of even more reporting. Not anymore.

title: For Jets, Things Fall Right When Theyre Done Right
description: San Diego

title: Chucks Warm-Up Routine
description: I need to eat, I need to drink, and then I need to smoke.  Zachary Levi, of NBCs Chuck, filling his plate in the press dining room.

title: He Doesnt Miss Limelight, but Bush Is Back in It
description: WASHINGTON  For the first time in a year, he was roaming the halls of the West Wing, greeting ushers and Secret Service officers by name and being briefed in the Oval Office on the latest crisis. As former President George W. Bush strode into the Rose Garden with that same broad gait, his eyes searched for familiar faces.

title: At Genzyme, a Long View
description: Genzyme, a $14 billion biotechnology company, is getting a much-needed shake-up. Relational Investors, an investor in the company, is doing it by, at least for the moment, backing its management.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week included an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: In Church Visit, Obama Addresses Race, Struggle and Hope
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama told a church congregation here on Sunday that the promise inherent in his election as the nations first African-American president had yet to be fully realized, and he acknowledged the role partisan politics continues to play in Washington.

title: A.F.C. Divisional Playoffs: Jets Surprise Chargers
description: With two fourth-quarter touchdowns, the Jets surprised the Chargers and set up a return date with the Colts in Indianapolis for the A.F.C. title game.

title: For Ailing Health System, a Diagnosis but No Cure
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly everyone agrees that there is something sick about the American health care system, especially when it comes to the seemingly out-of-control rise in costs.

title: Avatar Grabs Some Oscar Momentum
