description: James Camerons Golden Globes victory for directing Avatar was a bit of a surprise, given that his ex-wife, Kathryn Bigelow, was a critical favorite, at least, for The Hurt Locker. And it bodes well for the films Oscar chances, if it can get past the Academys largest block of voters, actors, who have historically been against movies that hide their assets behind technology and green screens.

title: Digging Into Massachusetts Campaign, Democrats Might Find Midterm Strategy
description: The Massachusetts Senate race offers the clearest demonstration yet of Republican strengths in 2010  and of how beleaguered Democrats will try to fight back.

title: $2.22? Gosh, That Sounds Expensive
description: Researchers have known for 80 years about a symbolic connection between speech and size: back-of-the-mouth vowels like the o in two make people think of large sizes, whereas people associate front-of-the-mouth vowels like ee with diminutiveness. Marketers can use this effect to make consumers think a discount is bigger or smaller than it truly is, according to a study soon to be published in The Journal of Consumer Research by Keith Coulter of Clark University and Robin Coulter of the University of Connecticut.

title: Under Fire, Democrats Turn to Economic Populism
description: The Massachusetts Senate race offers the clearest demonstration yet of Republican strengths in 2010  and of how beleaguered Democrats will try to fight back.

title: Nets Seem Unlikely Threat to 1972-73 Sixers Loss Record
description: By his own accounting, Fred Carter has two claims to fame. He invented the fist bump. And he was the best player on the worst team in N.B.A. history. He will not readily surrender the titles.

title: Disaster Touches a Haitian Enclave, but Comfort Is Just as Close
description: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y.

title: With Momentum, Chargers Fall Hard
description: SAN DIEGO  The Chargers were rested and ready, they were playing the best football in the N.F.L., and they believed they had a coach who knew how to win in the playoffs.

title: Life-Changing Moments Where Land Meets Water
description: In both the best and the worst times of his life, Alejandro Vasquez found himself near the beach.

title: Spreading the Love
description: Last years Golden Globes television awards were incredibly concentrated: HBO 7, NBC 3, AMC 1. This year the Hollywood Foreign Press Association spread the love a little more: HBO still led, with four awards, but Showtime made a strong showing with three and AMC, CBS, Fox and NBC grabbed one each. Cable still dominated, though, by the same 8-3 ratio.

title: And the Winner Is  Avatar
description: The 67th annual Golden Globe Awards are taking place Sunday night at the Beverly Hilton Hotel. Check here for an updated list of winners throughout the night and share your thoughts about the ceremony in the comments.

title: Lottery Numbers
After Dubai
description: When it looked as if Dubai would go bust last month, making global financial markets swoon, its wealthy neighboring emirate stepped in and bailed it out with a $10 billion loan. Unfortunately Dubai isnt the only one teetering on the brink. Greece is also in trouble; so is Ireland. Others could follow. Unless the worlds richest nations come to the rescue of weakened states, the global financial crisis might sprout another leg and stop the nascent recovery in its tracks.

title: A Bagram Reckoning
description: We keep waiting  in vain  for the Obama administration to stop trying to block judicial scrutiny of some of the Bush administrations most outrageous policies on the detention of prisoners.

title: How Retirees Saved the Banks
description: If youre a retiree who relies on interest income, you know that the tap is running dry. In fact, many investors in certificates of deposits, savings accounts and money market accounts are losing money once taxes and inflation are subtracted from todays extremely low yields.

title: Politicians Watch Criminals Pack More Heat
description: The nations police chiefs are finding an alarming increase in criminals use of assault weapons  the high-powered battlefield rifles that used to be banned, back when the federal government showed greater concern for public safety. The 10-year ban expired in 2004, despite the vows of presidential nominees from both parties to fight for renewal. Congress hasnt mustered the guts to try, preferring to roll over for the gun lobby.

title: Expanding Medicaid in the Health Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Judging the Trial: Gay Marriage in California
description: To the Editor:

title: Israels Economic Leap
description: To the Editor:

title: The Gesture Revolution
description: To the Editor:

title: The Cape Wind Project
description: To the Editor:

title: Alternatives to Prisons
description: To the Editor:

title: Poverty in Russia
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqs Ban on Democracy
description: Washington

title: Mayor Faults Bill Doubling Charter Schools
description: A proposed law that would double the number of charter schools permitted in the state, but place significant new requirements and restrictions on them, drew criticism on Sunday from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who, under the law, would lose the authority to grant charters.

title: Fixture of Avenue A Faces the Threat of a Padlock
description: Opposite Tompkins Square Park, the usual sort of post-midnight gathering was taking place on a recent evening inside a cramped storefront with tile floors and a worn blue counter.

title: Hangover Jokes, by an Amateur
description: Im not good at writing jokes, Im not even that good at telling them, Justin Bartha, who played the straight man in The Hangover, which won for best comedy, said on the red carpet of the Golden Globes. I need people to write for me to be funny.

title: Coming Soon: More Sassy Leading Ladies?
description: Sandra Bullocks best actress victory for playing a take-charge Southerner in The Blind Side  and her nomination for The Proposal  is a triumph for a different kind of leading lady. Would we now see a slew of laurel-wreathed sassy, funny ladies?

title: Abbott Defends Skating Title With a Flourish
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  As Jeremy Abbotts long program came to a close Sunday, before his final spin was complete, the crowd at the United States Figure Skating Championships had leapt to its feet and was roaring.

title: Rachel Alexandra vs. Zenyatta Is Now Up to Voters
description: A race for superiority that has yet to be decided on the racetrack has now come down to the ballot box. Zenyatta and Rachel Alexandra are among the most accomplished horses ever to race: neither lost in 2009 and both achieved historic feats, but Eclipse Award voters had to choose between the two. The outcome still very much in doubt, the 2009 Horse of the Year will be announced Monday night in ceremonies at the Beverly Wilshire Hotel in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Instincts Take Over as Sanchez Finds Keller
description: SAN DIEGO  In the far corner of the Jets victorious locker room, Dustin Keller sat in front of his locker, leaned forward and considered his place in franchise history.

title: Looking Ahead
description: ECONOMIC DATA Reports include: housing starts and Producer Price Index for December (Wednesday); Conference Board index of leading economic indicators for December; the Philadelphia Feds manufacturing index for January(Thursday).

title: In Melbourne, Sharapovas Comeback Ends Quickly
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  They are the best tennis players in the world, yet they still get butterflies, and all Kim Clijsters, Andy Roddick, Justine Henin and Rafael Nadal had to do was watch Maria Sharapova slink out of Rod Laver Arena to know why.

title: Color and Design
Pay Rises for Leaders of Colleges, Survey Says
description: Many of the nations public universities eliminated courses and raised tuition last year, but the salaries and benefits of their presidents continued to rise, though at a slower rate than in years past, a new study has found.

title: Median Pay of Public University Presidents Rose to $436,000 Last Year
description: For those who may have wondered how the financial crunch at the nations public universities might be affecting the pay of the leaders of those institutions, The Chronicle of Higher Education provides some answers.

title: Honoring Dr. King
description: There are many places around the city paying tribute to Martin Luther King Jr. today. One of the highlights is sure to be at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where the boroughs president, Marty Markowitz, and Medgar Evers College of the City University of New York will host a public celebration in his honor. The festivities begin at 10:30 a.m. with the actor Danny Glover appearing as the keynote speaker and the New Life Tabernacle Mass Choir and the Human Orchestra providing musical performances. Stick around after the event at the opera house for a free screening of the documentary Soundtrack for a Revolution, which Mr. Glover produced. The movie explores the history of the civil rights movement through freedom songs and includes performances by John Legend, Joss Stone, Wyclef Jean, the Roots, Richie Havens and others. It begins at 1 p.m.

title: By One Estimate, Nets Wont Break N.B.A. Futility Record
description: Ryan Parker, a senior at the College of Charleston majoring in math and statistics, runs the Web site BasketballGeek.com.

title: The Multi-Tasker at the Met
description: Up or down? Its hard to know where to look for Plcido Domingo this week at the Met. When he is not in the pit conducting Verdis opera Stiffelio, he is onstage singing. Hell be easy to spot tonight when he performs Verdis Simon Boccanegra. As a young man, Mr. Domingo was a baritone, writes Anthony Tommasini. He built his top range through hard work, note by note, to become a tenor, a project that turned out extremely well. He has sung some 124 roles so far. Now, for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera, he performs his newest role, for baritone, the title role of Verdis Simon Boccanegra. For this back-to-the-future adventure, Mr. Domingo will have the support of James Levine in the pit, and a cast including the tenor Marcello Giordani and the soprano Adrianne Pieczonka. Though the plot of Simon Boccanegra is nearly impenetrable, in its revised version, which is offered here, the opera is rich with first-class Verdi music.

title: N.F.C. Divisional Playoffs: Vikings Pound Cowboys
description: Behind a swarming defense and four touchdown passes from Brett Favre, the Vikings pound Tony Romo and the Cowboys to advance to the N.F.C. title game.

title: Helping Haiti
description: Its no surprise that New Yorkers have come out in droves to contribute to the Haiti relief effort, and this week offers even more opportunities to help. City Winery will host a series of benefit concerts over a few days, beginning on Jan. 20 with Patti Smith and Yo La Tengo among the artists slated to perform, and tomorrow night Le Poisson Rouge is lending a hand, or space rather, with a concert featuring Groove Collective, DJ Logic, Bernie Worrell and Dr. Lonnie Smith. Tonight, the designers Narciso Rodriguez and Cynthia Rowley, as well as Chiara Clemente, Julia Restoin-Roitfeld, Mickey Boardman of Paper magazine and an array of other fashionable folks, will host a benefit at Thom Bar, beginning at 6 p.m. A $20 minimum donation will cover Skyy and Patron cocktails and music by the D.J. Belinda Becker, as well as snacks by Kittichai. All proceeds will go to benefit the American Red Cross/Haiti Relief and Development. If youre looking for other ways to contribute, just go here.

title: For Two Croats, Obstacles Are as Plentiful as Success
description: WENGEN, Switzerland  Five weeks after surgery on his right knee, Ivica Kostelic felt healthy enough to rip down two selective slalom runs and end up the winner here Sunday.

title: N.F.C. Championship Glance: Vikings vs. Saints
description: Minnesota Vikings (second seed) at New Orleans Saints (first seed)

title: George Leonard, Voice of 60s Counterculture, Dies at 86
description: George Leonard, a former journalist who foresaw the countercultural tides of the 1960s, then dived into them when he helped define the human potential movement at its de facto headquarters, the Esalen Institute, died on Jan. 6 at his home in Mill Valley, Calif. He was 86.

title: The Blue People May Soon See Oscar Gold
description: James Camerons Avatar  now jokingly rendered as I See Blue People instead of Dances With Smurfs  triumphed at the Golden Globes in a night when the biggest surprises came, perhaps, from the weather. Rain soaked the red carpet, which at least made it one of the few occasions when having an umbrella handler was not considered mere celebrity hubris. (The other being if youre Sophia Loren.)

title: Haiti Quake Day 6: Success and Failure
description: Simon Romero reports from Port-au-Prince on how a devastated country is fighting for stability.

title: St. Patrick Guard Dishes Out Assists and One-Liners
description: ELIZABETH, N.J.  Kevin Boyle Jr., whose wit is considerably quicker than his crossover, has been heckled on stages as large as Madison Square Garden and in front of national television cameras for suspected nepotism, but that was for basketball.

title: A Gentleman Enforcer Turns His Focus to Haiti
description: To go with the 1,126 penalty minutes he has accumulated, Georges Laraque has scored 53 goals in his 12-year N.H.L. career. But none were bigger than the one he scored Thursday, the night the Montreal Canadiens opened a fund-raising drive dedicated to earthquake recovery in Haiti.

title: Rangers Trounce Canadiens, 6-2
description: The Rangers scorers finally awoke at Madison Square Garden on Sunday night in a 6-2 victory, though it took a game against the Montreal Canadiens, who have the second-worst regulation record in the East, to rouse them from their offensive slumber.

title: A.F.C. Championship Glance: Jets vs. Colts
description: Jets (fifth seed) at Indianapolis Colts (first seed)

title: Golden Globe Winners
description: A look at the winners of the 2010 Golden Globe awards.

title: Even in Hollywood, Worlds Troubles Impinged
description: Ricky Gervais, true to form, went after NBC at the Golden Globes, mocking the networks Conan-Jay imbroglio with the words, Lets get on with it before NBC replaces me with Jay Leno. But the NBC-hazing actually started on the red carpet, with Julia Roberts telling Billy Bush during the pre-game show, NBC  you guys are in the toilet right now!

title: Haiti Quake Day 6: Faith and Healing
description: The decimated Catholic Church in Port-au-Prince offers hope while others offer what medical help they can.

title: Wall St. Weighs a Challenge to a Proposed Tax
description: Wall Streets main lobbying arm has hired a top Supreme Court litigator to study a possible legal battle against a bank tax proposed by the Obama administration, on the theory that it would be unconstitutional, according to three industry officials briefed on the matter, Eric Dash writes in The New York Times.

title: News Quiz | January 18, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: For Many Start-Ups, Nasdaq Not the Goal
description: Investors in technology start-ups have been trying to end the drought in initial public offerings of tech companies. But for entrepreneurs, has taking a company public lost its allure?

title: Kabul Attack Shows Resilience of Afghan Militants
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A team of militants launched a spectacular assault at the heart of the Afghan government on Monday, with two men detonating suicide bombs and the rest fighting to the death only 50 yards from the gates of the presidential palace.

title: The Difference Between Glitter and Gold for Johnny Weir
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  No American figure skater is more engaging than Johnny Weir or more acutely balanced on that thin edge between art and sport. He clearly wants to be a star. The question is, can he still be a champion?

title: China XD Begins New Year of I.P.O.s Modestly
description: China XD Electric, the countrys largest maker of electricity transmission and distribution equipment, set an unambitious pricing range in its I.P.O. to raise up to 10.27 billion renminbi ($1.5 billion), in the countrys first major offering this year, Reuters reported.

title: Wickmayer Wins Opener After Mighty Struggle
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  A rising star of womens tennis, Yanina Wickmayer of Belgium, fought the elements and a determined challenger, Alexandra Dulgheru of Romania, to win a three-set battle before a capacity crowd of about 6,000 spectators on the Margaret Court Arena. After a lengthy rain delay, Wickmayer prevailed, 1-6, 7-5, 10-8, to reach the second round. Had she lost, it would have represented a major setback, even though she was not seeded here because of an unresolved dispute over her availability for drug testing. The match was interrupted several times by a summer rain that stalled many of the tournments opening-day matches and eventually drove the two women off the court and into the locker room in midafternoon after more than three hours of play. Wickmayer is ranked 16th in the world and had defeated Dulgheru three times last year while climbing the ladder of womens tennis in the shadow of her Begian compatriots, Justine Henin and Kim Clijsters. But Dulgheru, a 20-year-old from Bucharest, fought tenanciously before yielding.

title: Hanwha Plans $2 Billion I.P.O. of Korea Insurance
description: Hanwha Group, the South Korean conglomerate, is planning to take its Korea Life Insurance unit public as early as in the current quarter, the parent group said Monday, in an I.P.O. worth an estimated $2 billion.

title: Election Monitors See Few Problems in Ukraine Vote
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Ukraine, where an election five years ago descended into mass protests over vote-rigging, carried out the first round of its presidential balloting far more competently and fairly on Sunday, election monitors said Monday.

title: From the Cruyff Turn to the Blanco Bunny Hop and More
description: It was the brightest flash of brilliant Orange. In a 1974 World Cup group match between the Netherlands and Sweden, Johan Cruyff picked the ball up on the edge of the box under pressure from a defender, feigned to cross, then pulled the ball back between his legs, leaving the Swedish fullback flailing like a drunken sea captain. And just like that, the Cruyff Turn was born.Since then, there have been other moves that have become synonymous with an individual player. At the World Cup in South Africa this year, we can hope to see some of the players performing their signature moves in action.

title: Stepanek Upset in Mens First Day
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Ten days ago, Radek Stepanek of the Czech Republic was battling toe-to-toe with Andy Roddick of the United States in the finals of the Brisbane International tournament. Stepanek, the defending champion, lost an epic encounter, 7-6 (2), 7-6 (7) and drew Roddicks praise as an indefatiguable opponent.

title: Man Who Shot Pope in 1981 Is Freed
description: ISTANBUL  Almost three decades after he shot and wounded Pope John Paul II, Mehmet Ali Agca walked free from prison on Monday, heading to a luxury hotel and proclaiming himself to be Christ eternal.

title: Workplace Lingo
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared the language they use at work words and phrases that are (all too) familiar to them, but of curiosity to outsiders.

title: Under the Stars, Shisha Smoke and Tasty Bites
description: Mumbais rooftop shisha lounges can be hard to find, but are worth seeking out. Even if smoking flavored tobacco from a hookah isnt your thing, these restaurants offer the rare chance to eat good north Indian food as its meant to be eaten  under the stars, sitting on cushions amid air tinged with mint and rose.

title: Jets Open Thread: The Formula Against the Colts
description: Next weeks A.F.C. championship game in Indianapolis will be one of the biggest games in Jets history.

title: Escaping the Capital as Help Is Arriving
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Wharf Jrmie on this citys edge was all chaos and destruction on Monday, with upturned shipping containers lying in the sea and pigs foraging on piles of refuse. But for a thousand or more seeking a ride on rickety boats away from the ruined capital, the wharf was a means to something hopeful: escape.

title: Germany Supports Tougher Iran Sanctions
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel said Monday that Germany would support much tougher sanctions against Iran in a bid to halt its nuclear ambitions.

title: Why Do Pet Stories Trump Haitian Disaster?
description: Todays idea: Why does a dog who understands Polish attract more readers on the BBCs Web site than the Haitian disaster? Because pet stories sit midway between a global civil society and a global horror show, a blogger says. And thats not such a bad thing.

title: Rex Ryans Postgame Speech in Locker Room
description: Do you suppose the Jets enjoy playing for this man?

title: Remembering the Little People: Accounting for Kids
description: Update | 10:14 a.m., February 16.

title: Analyzing Late Decisions by Rex Ryan and Norv Turner
description: Brian Burke of Advanced NFL Stats looked at the end-game calls by the coaches in Jets-Chargers.1) Norv Turners decision to go for the onside kick after San Diego closed the gap to 3 points with 2:14 left. (The Jets recovered.)2) Rex Ryans decision to go for it on fourth-and-one at the San Diego 29 with 1:09 remaining. (Thomas Jones converted the first down, sealing the game.)Excerpt:

title: View From San Diego: Were the Jets the Better Team?
description: Thats a question Nick Canepa of The Union-Tribune in San Diego asked in his column today.

title: Submit Your Funny Caption
description: Water Music | Tell us whats going on in the picture above (use the comment link below). Its the latest of the uncaptioned images were posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last weeks funniest captions are at right.

title: Assessing the Damage in Haiti
description: Maps showing the extent and magnitude of the destruction caused by the Jan. 12 earthquake that was centered near Port-au-Prince, Haiti.

title: Holiday Word
description: For the first time, a black president will observe the holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Ask John Burns: Islamic Radicalization
description: This week, John Burns, the chief foreign correspondent for The New York Times, will answer readers questions about Islamic radicalization. Mr. Burns was part of a team of Times reporters who worked on a profile of Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab published on Sunday tracing how this privileged young man embraced a violent vision of religion and is now accused of trying to ignite a bomb in an airplane over Detroit. How does it happen? How much is it personal, how much religious, how much the broader culture? Post a question below, and Mr. Burns will answer your questions later in the week.

title: Europes Growing Offshore Wind Capacity
description: Post corrected 01/19; 9:45 a.m.

title: Ask About New Yorks High Schools
description: This week, Clara Hemphill, whose book series New York Citys Best Schools is regarded as the bible for navigating school choices, responded to readers questions about the high school admissions process and the myriad choices in the city.

title: Popular Mechanics Wants to Fit Kids to a T
description: A Hearst magazine would like to revive the days when children dreamed that flying cars were just around the corner.

title: Were Vikings Classless in Adding Late Score?
description: The scene: The Vikings led, 27-3, with 1:55 left and with a fourth-and-3 from the Dallas 11. Instead of running up the middle or kicking a field goal, Brett Favre threw an 11-yard touchdown pass to Visanthe Shiancoe.

title: Cleveland Orchestra Goes on Strike
description: Update | 5:48 p.m.  After weeks of increasingly tense relations with management over contract negotiations, the musicians of the Cleveland Orchestra went on strike Monday.

title: Newbery and Caldecott Awards Announced
description: Rebecca Stead, author of When You Reach Me, a mystery and a novel of friendship set in New York City, won the John Newbery Medal for the most outstanding contribution to childrens literature on Monday. Ms. Stead was widely considered a favorite among librarians and bloggers who write about books for young people. The novel, which takes place in 1979 and chronicles an intimate neighborhood on the Upper West Side, tells the story of Miranda, a sixth-grader who must unravel clues about why her best friend, Sal, stopped talking to her. When You Reach Me has spent eight weeks on the New York Times Best Seller List for childrens chapter books. The award was conferred by the Association for Library Service to Children, a division of the American Library Association, at the library associations midwinter conference in Boston. The association also awarded the Randolph Caldecott Medal for the most distinguished American picture book for children to The Lion & The Mouse by Jerry Pinkney. Mr. Pinkneys book is a nearly wordless adaptation of Aesops fable about how the king of the animal kingdom is helped by one of its smallest creatures. For the first time this year, the Young Adult Library Services Association, also a division of the library association, awarded a prize for a nonfiction work to Charles and Emma: The Darwins Leap of Faith by Deborah Heiligman.

title: Jan. 18: Updates on the Crisis in Haiti
description: On Monday The Lede is continuing to supplement reporting by our colleagues in Haiti on the aftermath of Tuesdays earthquake by pointing to news and information on the Web. Readers are encouraged to share any first-hand accounts they receive from Haiti or see online in the comments thread below. See the home page of NYTimes.com for the latest news articles and multimedia features on the relief effort. Updates from previous days: Sun. | Sat. | Fri. | Thurs. | Weds. and Tues.

title: Motorsports Links: Sainz Wins Dakar Rally
description: Motorsports news from around the Web

title: Funding for Biofuels Research
description: The United States Department of Energy announced last week more than $80 million in financing from the economic stimulus package for a new national program dedicated to biofuels research.

title: Jets Crazy Ride With Kickers
description: Field-goal accuracy has been rising to such an extent that success has become almost monotonous. Nate Kaeding embodied the trend.

title: Wyclef Jean Responds to Questions About His Charity
description: Update | 4:25 p.m.  In a video message posted on YouTube, the musician Wyclef Jean defended himself against reports that he benefited personally from his Haitian relief charity, saying, Not only I denounce all of that, Im disgusted by that.

title: Bold Attacks Shake Kabul
description: In a spectacular assault at the heart of the Afghan government, two men detonated suicide bombs while other militants fought to the death near the presidential palace.

title: Sharapovas Expectations Collide With Reality
description: There was a Russian named Maria victorious on Day 1 of the Australian Open on Rod Laver Arena, but it wasnt Maria Sharapova. The lesser-known Russian Maria Kirilenko took out Sharapova in a battle of Marias, shocking the 2008 champion in three dramatic sets.

title: Screen Saver | The Film/Art Gallery
description: Matthew McCarthy, the owner of the Film/Art Gallery, began collecting film posters as a boy, but his private obsession turned public only a few years ago. And he has Audrey Hepburn to thank. As the story goes, he was visiting his linen-backer to restore some old Hepburn movie posters when the linen-backer asked if McCarthy knew Sean Hepburn Ferrer, the actresss son. He thought Sean might be interested in buying some of the posters, says McCarthy. And indeed, Ferrer bought a bunch of them. That was my first big sale. The introduction turned into a job for McCarthy as an archivist for the Hepburn foundation, and it prompted him to start his Web-based gallery, offering up some of his 3,000 vintage movie posters for sale. Hollywood and design insiders have quickly caught onto McCarthys astonishing collection of rare and foreign posters, many of them far more avant-garde than the standard-issue Hollywood versions. (Check out the Czech edition of Cool Hand Luke.) Besides continually adding to his collection, McCarthy (whose partner, Tyler Cassity, owns Hollywood Forever cemetery, where he hosts extremely popular movie nights in the summer) is planning a bricks-and-mortar gallery space to hold screenings and poster exhibitions based on particular stars, directors and genres.

title: Lady Gaga Puts Off More Shows
description: Fans of Lady Gaga were sufficiently baffled by the lyrics to her song Bad Romance; now theyre trying to understand how the singer was able to make a Friday appearance on The Oprah Winfrey Show while canceling or postponing several concert dates.

title: Now Screening | Roberto Cavalli
description: The fall 2010 collection from Roberto Cavalli.

title: Haiti Quake Day 7: Aid, by Sea
description: The Comfort, a United States naval hospital ship, is preparing to offer aid to Haitian patients.

title: Cap-and-Trade Proceeds for Residents?
description: A California family of four could receive more than $1,000 every year if a proposal floated by state officials is approved.

title: Answers From a Young Lawyer
description: On Monday, City Room published a video report about lawyers destined for the corporate track who were diverted into public service. The video featured Chris Reid, a Fordham Law School graduate who was originally recruited by Ropes & Gray to work in their patent litigation practice, then gave him the option of finding a public interest job in lieu of his first year. Mr. Reid ended up working with the Legal Aid Society in Brooklyn housing court, keeping families in their homes.

title: Reagan, Taxes, Jobs
description: Apropos of a point I made in todays column: there were two major tax changes in Reagans first term, which began in January 1981. ERTA, aka the Reagan tax cut, was signed in August 1981; TEFRA, which raised taxes, was signed in September 1982.

title: How Wyclef Jeans Haiti Charity Spent Its Money
description: The Smoking Gun reports that a charitable foundation established by Wyclef Jean, the Haitian-American musician, has spent hundreds of thousands of dollars over the years paying Mr. Jean himself, along with his business partner, for rent and various services. Mr. Jeans video response is now on YouTube.

title: Postmodern Warfare: Chvez Says PlayStation Will Teach You to Kill
description: Lets see Microsoft try to use these blurbs in their next Xbox campaign: the Sony PlayStation video game console has been criticized by President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela, not because he finds Assassins Creed II oddly unengaging or is growing impatient for the release of Final Fantasy XIII, but because he believes that it is poison and will lead children down a capitalist road to hell, Agence France-Presse reported. On his weekly radio and television show, Mr. Chvez said, Those games they call PlayStation are poison. Some games teach you to kill. He added that violent video games are sold by capitalist countries so they can later sell weapons, and they promote the need for cigarettes, drugs and alcohol so they can sell them, according to Agence France-Presse. In October, Venezuela passed a law making it illegal to sell violent video games, an offense punishable by up to five years in prison. Mr. Chvez has previously criticized Nintendo for promoting selfishness, individualism and violence, and that was before the company released New Super Mario Bros. Wii, which is, like, totally impossible.

title: Can We Make Chutzpah A Crime?
description: Because if we can, we can send a bunch of bankers to jail right away:

title: Trendspooning | Pine Nuts Return
description: When Momofuku Ko opened, friends, family and bloggers marveled over a certain foie gras dish that presentedthe main ingredient frozen, then grated. Although the mound of eraser-dust-like liver was compelling, what lay beneath was the real surprise: jagged chunks of pine-nut brittle.

title: Justices Better at Precedent Than Prescience
description: WASHINGTON

title: Video: Ten Minutes With Dan Pfeiffer
description: Let the questions begin.

title: Now Screening | Prada
description: The fall 2010 collection from Prada.

title: Monday Puzzle: The Golden Ratio Treasure
description: This week we have thrilling news. Roger and Penny, the protagonists of last weeks puzzle, found buried treasure. The way they figured out where it was has connections to at least three previous Monday puzzles. Are you ready for the adventure?

title: Paving Over Cambodia's Violent Past
description: With financing from several foreign governments and the Asian Development Bank, hundreds of miles of roads are being completed and many more hundreds are under construction in Cambodia.

title: A Porsche and Ferrari for Franchitti
description: PHOENIX  When I go to classic car events, I always pick the car Id most like to drive home. Turns out, Im not the only one. The IndyCar champion Dario Franchitti also plays that game, though his interests are in driving on the racetrack rather than on the roadways.

title: E-ttenuation
description: The destructive effect of technology on relationships.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Hawks Take Over the West, Caps Take Over the East
description: Four games on Sunday, and two of them gave the league new leaders in each conference. Home teams listed first:

title: A Boost for LED Lighting Development
description: As part of the governments aggressive push for more energy efficient lighting options, the Department of Energy announced Friday it had awarded more than $37 million in stimulus funds for research and development projects that will help advance the market for products that use light-emitting diodes, or LEDs.

title: Pants on the Ground': The Back Story
description: Update | 4:50 p.m. Petrarch had Laura; Dante had Beatrice; and Larry Platt saw some guy on the street and was inspired to write his hit song Pants on the Ground, he said on Monday. In an interview on the ABC morning program The View, Mr. Platt revealed how he came up with the song that has made him a minicelebrity ever since he performed it Wednesday night on American Idol.

title: The $250 Million Underdog Celebrates
description: The king of the world Sunday night was Tom Rothman, the co-chairman of Fox Filmed Entertainment, the studio behind Avatar. Weve had a very strong, diversified year, he said while fetching a seltzer and a soda for his kids at the bar of Craft. (Foxs other big recent hit was Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel.) He told us  in a mantra we heard all night  that James Camerons Avatar was the underdog film.

title: The Nifty 50 | Annie Baker, Playwright
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Apple to Show Off Its Latest Creation Next Week
description: Apple sent e-mail invitations to journalists Monday morning for a special event to be held next Wednesday in San Francisco. Come see our latest creation, the message says.

title: Risottos for Winter
description: When Im at a loss as to what to make for a dinner party, or what to do with a given vegetable, I invariably turn to risottos. They please everybody  kids and adults, vegetarians and meat-eaters, the gluten-sensitive and even vegans, if you forego the final addition of Parmesan.

title: Regimens: Questioning Benefit of Diabetes Test Strips
description: People with Type 2 diabetes are often advised to use blood-glucose test strips to monitor their blood sugar levels, but a Canadian analysis has found that routine self-monitoring is not cost-effective for many patients: the strips can cost almost a dollar each, and they prevent comparatively few complications of diabetes.

title: British File-Sharing Verdict: Not Guilty
description: A software engineer who was the first person in Britain to be prosecuted for illegal file-sharing has been found not guilty of conspiracy to defraud, BBC News reported. The engineer, Alan Ellis, ran the now-defunct file-sharing Web site OiNK.cd from an apartment in Middlesbrough, in northern England, from 2004 to 2007 until it was shut down in a police raid. Though the site did not require users to pay and instead asked for voluntary donations, prosecutors said that Mr. Ellis had $300,000 in a Paypal account and received $18,000 a month in donations. Mr. Ellis, 26, said in court that he had not intended to defraud the copyright holders of the songs downloaded through OiNK.cd, and that he had set up the Web site to further my skills. To better my skills for employability. The site, which did not host any songs itself, facilitated the illegal downloading of more than 21 million music files.

title: The Claim: If You Have a Seafood Allergy, Avoid CT Scans
description: THE FACTS Seafood allergies represent the most common form of food allergies in adults, affecting about 2 percent to 3 percent of Americans. But myths about the condition abound.

title: Now Screening | John Varvatos
description: The fall 2010 collection from John Varvatos.

title: On Assignment: Katrina Many Times Over
description: Michael Appletons photograph of 76-year-old Marie Carme Morency, receiving communion while lying injured in a wheel barrow near the collapsed Church of Sacr Coeur in Port-au-Prince, captured the Haitian peoples response to the overwhelming tragedy that surrounds them.

title: Why Alaska Isnt Free of Exxon Valdez Crude
description: Twenty years after the Exxon Valdez supertanker spilled nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil into Prince William Sound in southern Alaska, everything is pristine and natural again, right?

title: Narrowing an Eating Disorder
description: The year was 1988, and I was a college student on my junior year abroad, traveling aimlessly through the Middle East and Europe. My backpack was crammed with shorts and T-shirts, bathing suits and sarongs, my Walkman and Grateful Dead tapes. And oh, yes, a scale, buried deep beneath layers of socks. Having been a chubby adolescent  and having spent six summers at fat camp  I was terrified of gaining weight.

title: Jets Talk About the Power of Belief
description: SAN DIEGO  Early Monday at the airport, the family of Jets running back Thomas Jones sat at Gate 39 in Terminal 2. Mere hours had passed since the Jets stunned the San Diego Chargers and advanced to the American Football Conference championship game, extending their fairy-tale season for at least another week.

title: Even More Room at the Inn
description: Though it may seem counterintuitive at a time when many hotels around the country are having trouble filling their rooms, nearly 100 hotels are scheduled to open in major American cities this year.

title: Agency Combines Clients Stocks for a Mini-Mutual Fund
description: FORGET about the Standard & Poors 500-stock index or the Dow Jones industrial average. The latest gauge of Wall Street performance  at least on Madison Avenue  is the K.B.S.& P. Client Stock Index.

title: Children Dont Have Strokes? Just Ask Jared
description: My son Jared lay in a bed at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital, limp and pale, his 7-year-old body tethered to a tangle of tubes and monitor wires.

title: Luminous 3-D Jungle Is a Biologists Dream
description: When watching a Hollywood movie that has robed itself in the themes and paraphernalia of science, a scientist expects to feel anything from annoyance to infuriation at facts misconstrued or processes misrepresented. What a scientist does not expect is to enter into a state of ecstatic wonderment, to have the urge to leap up and shout: Yes! Thats exactly what its like!

title: When Built-In Antifreeze Beats a Winter Coat
description: In the bleak midwinter

title: Burbles and Gurgles
description: Q. I sometimes get a gurgling stomach, loud enough for the person next to me to hear it. It happens with dairy or soda, or even without. Whats going on? Should I worry?

title: Scientists Find a Shared Gene in Dogs With Compulsive Behavior
description: Scientists have linked a gene to compulsive behavior  in dogs.

title: Ancient Egypts Toxic Makeup Fought Infection, Researchers Say
description: The elaborate eye makeup worn by Queen Nefertiti and other ancient Egyptians was believed to have healing powers, conjuring up the protection of the Gods Horus and Ra and warding off illnesses.

title: The Platypus Is Cute but Far From Harmless
description: In The Nutmeg of Consolation by Patrick OBrian, the 14th in his series of maritime novels, the good Dr. Stephen Maturins unabashed joy at finally seeing a platypus in Australia is almost immediately tempered by the incapacitating pain he experiences when he is stung by poisonous spurs on the animals rear legs.

title: Genome Study Provides a Census of Early Humans
description: From the composition of just two human genomes, geneticists have computed the size of the human population 1.2 million years ago from which everyone in the world is descended.

title: Why Sharapova Lost to Kirilenko
description: Maria Kirilenko did not jump for joy or toss her racket skyward after winning her match with Maria Sharapova on the first day at the Australian Open. She even tried to quiet her more boisterous supporters as she walked to the net to shake hands with her taller, more celebrated opponent. Kirilenko looked as though she was already focusing on her next match, and this victory was not at all a surprise to her.

title: Now Reading | Cant Burn This
description: Who says literature cant be hot? The Fine Books Company of Rochester, Mich., is selling The Complete Science Fiction Asbestos Collection, a set of fireproofed, autographed first editions of Ray Bradburys Fahrenheit 451 and Stephen Kings Firestarter. The books are bound in a silvery, asbestos material, and going for the minor sum of $31,810. For those with money to burn, apparently.

title: Three Dominant Home Teams, and the Jets
description: Until the Jets crashed the party Sunday night, the N.F.L. playoffs had taken on the look of the bulked-up bullies kicking sand in the faces of weaklings. The dominance of the top-seeded teams  translation: of the home teams  should not have surprised anybody, though. Since 1990, home teams have a winning percentage of 73.8 in the divisional round of the playoffs, meaning that three-quarters of the time the top seeds advance to the conference championship round, according to the Elias Sports Bureau. And this year, there was a greater distance between the very best teams and those in the chase.

title: For 9/11 Team, Haiti Brings It All Back
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  A pile of rubble is a pile of rubble, whether it is Lower Manhattan or central Port-au-Prince. As a New York rescue team combed the wreckage of last weeks earthquake in search of long-shot survivors on Monday, some said one particular past disaster  the collapsed World Trade Center towers  was not far back in their minds.

title: Milan Fashion | Rooted Looks
description: MILAN  The buzzword for the mens shows here so far has been heritage  which is to say that designers are going back to their roots in order to entice still-weary customers with items that reflect the value of their houses rather than flash-in-the-pan status symbols. Dolce & Gabbana led the way with one of its strongest presentations in seasons, using Giuseppe Tornatores new film, Baara, as the starting point for a Sicilian-inspired collection highlighting Italian tailoring and distressed work wear. The Sunday-best suits looked especially sharp when contrasted with worn-out tank tops, frayed jeans and long johns tucked into worker boots. Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana are celebrating their 20th anniversary this year, and their attention is clearly in the right place.

title: Starting Over in Lexington: A Clarification
description: I have to admit, I was taken by surprise by some of the responses to my last post about the company we bought in Lexington, Ky. It seems a few people out there thought it was harsh of me to answer the questions from the shop floor by telling them it was up to them to figure out how to make this work. Some of the commenters said, You cant just abandon your employees.

title: Living With a Formerly Fatal Blood Cancer
description: In December 2005, a series of mysterious symptoms  night sweats, easy bruising, swollen ankles and breathlessness upon exertion  prompted Barry to see his doctor. Only six months earlier, a physical exam had found nothing abnormal. But now Barrys white blood cell count was through the roof.

title: Healing Physically, Yet Still Not Whole
description: Still haunted and chastened by the Puritan work ethic, our culture doesnt much believe in convalescing, in full recovery. No matter what happens in our lives  a grave illness, a wrenching divorce, a death in the family  the unspoken understanding is that we should want to rush back into the game. Like an old-time quarterback who has had one concussion too many, we are expected to stagger back onto the field no matter what.

title: A Little Too Close to the Battle in Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The man with the bulging shawl had only just exploded when the real battle got under way.

title: Dances, Proms and Other Party Night Tales
description: The Bagger has been known to party hop even when shes not on the clock, so after the Golden Globes on Sunday night, we hit nearly everything, though perhaps not in the proper order, despite using our fellow Oscar bloggers Twitter updates as a fun barometer.

title: When an Eating Disorder Has No Name
description: This week in Science Times, Abby Ellin discusses her own unusual eating pattern as a teenager.

title: A Child Suffers a Stroke
description: In todays Science Times youll read the surprising story of Jared, a 7-year-old boy who suffered a stroke. His father, Jonathan Dienst, writes:

title: Xbox Takes On Cable, Streaming TV Shows and Movies
description: Executives at Microsoft are fond of saying that its subscription gaming service, Xbox Live, should be thought of as a cable channel.

title: Education Grant Effort Faces Late Opposition
description: The Obama administrations main school improvement initiative has spurred education policy changes in states across the nation, but it is meeting with some last-minute resistance as the first deadline for applications arrives Tuesday.

title: For Gates Aides, No Fatigues at Work
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates has told his military aides not to wear combat fatigues to work at the Pentagon anymore, reversing a symbolic change of protocol ordered in the harrowing days after the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Further Reflections on a Golden I
description: Update | 2:57 p.m.  A number of readers raised concerns that the photo of Christina Hendricks at the Golden Globe Awards had been deliberately altered. The photo was slightly distorted inadvertently due to an error during routine processing. The photograph has been replaced.

title: Glassmaking Thrives Offshore, but Is Declining in U.S.
description: The majestic steel beams of a soaring office tower beginning to rise from the ruins of the World Trade Center are a tribute to American resilience, but also a marker in the decline of yet another industry. Not an inch of imported glass went into the two lost towers, built 40 years ago. The lower floors of the new one will soon be sheathed in Chinese glass.

title: Enriched by Record Ransom, Somali Pirates Free Tanker
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Somali pirates off the eastern coast of Africa released a Greek oil tanker and its 28-member crew on Monday after receiving what they said was a $5.5 million ransom, believed to be the largest sum paid to free a hijacked ship.

title: Managing Disasters With Small Steps
description: A week ago, Elizabeth Sheehan, the founder of Containers to Clinics, a nonprofit organization in Dover, Mass., was preparing to deploy the groups first medical clinic overseas. Made from two shipping containers, it was to be sent to the Dominican Republic, where it would begin to fulfill the groups long-term goal of building health care infrastructure in developing countries through networks of small container clinics in rural areas.

title: BMW 3 Series Latest to Get New Turbo Engine
description: BMWs 2011 335i coupe and convertible arrive this spring with a new engine, some minor cosmetic redo, new exterior colors and other tweaks.

description: In todays Cases column in Science Times, Dana Jennings writes about the difference between recuperating from an illness and the full recovery that often eludes people with cancer. He writes:

title: Desert Spider Discovery on Jordan-Israel Border
description: One benefit of the Israel-Jordan peace treaty, signed 15 years ago, was that it allowed for scientific cooperation and exchanges between the countries.

title: Party Central | Ts Golden Globes Party
description: WHO: T: The New York Times Style Magazine

title: The Semiotics of the Globes
description: Trying to corner Hollywoods rich and beautiful for interviews at an event like Sunday nights Golden Globes dinner is, by and large, a pointless exercise.

title: Texas Textbooks
description: Oh, boy. Paul Samuelson famously declared, I dont care who writes a nations laws  or crafts its advanced treatises  if I can write its economics textbooks. But guess whos going to be writing our textbooks?

title: How Do You Feel About Bordeaux?
description: My column this week is on inexpensive Bordeaux, costing $10 to $20 a bottle. Inexpensive Bordeaux might sound like an oxymoron, but in fact it accounts for the overwhelming percentage of the wine produced in the region. We just dont hear about it much.

title: Taking a Menu Forward to the 20th Century
description: American orchestras and their audiences have for years debated whether they should mainly be museums for the canonical repertory or evolving institutions that conserve that repertory but also push into the future. That debate came late to the Vienna Philharmonic, at least as it projects itself internationally, through tours and recordings: its conservatorship of the great works, particularly those of the Viennese Classical era, has always been the unchallenged heart of its mission.

title: The Morning Skate: A Rainy Night in the Garden
description: The Garden crowd arrived late, possibly delayed by the cold January rain or the warmth of watching the Jets N.F.L. playoff game on TV from San Diego. No matter. The Rangers arrived late, too.

title: Destructive creativity
description: I dont always agree with Naomi Klein, and I dont always disagree with David Frum, but Klein wins this one hands down: Frum worries that financial regulation might crush the creativity of the system, Klein counters that we could all do with them being a little less creative.

title: Scorecard | Dolce & Gabbana Wins!
description: Is it really fashion week again, already? Not to fear, as ever, Scorecard is here keeping tabs on all the critic talk so you dont have to. The opening day of the Milan mens-wear shows Saturday marked the big 2-0 for the Dolce & Gabbana duo and a centennial for Ermenegildo Zegna, so its no surprise that amid the birthday festivities designers were all about going back to their roots. Critics, meanwhile, were feeling this archive digging  so long as fashion flashbacks didnt land squarely in the Flashdance era.

title: Ankles Gain as Candidates for Joint Replacement
A New Joint Gains as a Candidate for Replacement
description: The bodies of many older Americans are practically bionic: more than 770,000 hip and knee replacements are performed each year in the United States.

title: Skepticism for Obamas Fiscal Policy
description: In a November 2008 Op-Ed article for The New York Times, the Nobel Prize-winning economist Joseph E. Stiglitz wrote that a huge stimulus package  as much as $1 trillion over two years  was needed to turn the Great Recession into a robust recovery and that new regulations were needed to change the destructive behavior of Wall Street that had brought about the fiscal calamities in the first place.

title: Which Super Bowl Matchup Do You Want to See?
description: It is never too early to speculate about Super Bowl matchups. That conversation starts long before the season even begins, sometimes as soon as the previous Super Bowl ends. But after divisional weekend, we are down to four teams to choose from, to dissect, to mix and match until the Super Bowl is set. Which matchup would you want to see? Which overdone story line would you dread hearing about for two weeks?

title: The Nifty 50 | Apiece Apart, Designers
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Critics' Picks: 'The Player'
description: A.O. Scott assesses Robert Altman's 1992 take on Hollywood film culture.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Isles Give DiPietro First Shutout in Nearly 2 Years
description: A couple of Martin Luther King Day matinees inaugurated Mondays slate of 10 games, and in each of those dayside contests a recently returned star came up big. Also, check out the Eastern Conference, where Buffalo joined Washington in displacing the Devils from the top spot, and the Western Conference, where San Jose romped to a first-place tie with Chicago. Home teams listed first:

title: Music, Impersonations and Insights From the Crowd
description: Brian Fallon, the frontman of the terrific New Jersey punk band the Gaslight Anthem, played a rare solo show at the Bowery Ballroom on Friday night, but he was not unaccompanied. His three band mates werent there, but in their stead he got soused singalongs and hecklers.

title: Secret Ingredients of Business Travel: Hot Sauce and Cash
description: IVE learned two things about business travel. Always carry hot sauce and have enough cash for some decent tips.

title: Obama to Deliver State of the Union Address Jan. 27
description: .Update | 6:49 p.m. President Obama will deliver his first State of the Union address on Jan. 27.

title: Pitti Uomo | Technical Concepts
description: FLORENCE, Italy  Here in at the fall/winter 2010 mens collections at Pitti Uomo it was hard to miss the continuing influence of vintage Americana on the sportswear being shown. However, theres a new technical edge infusing these traditional tweeds with elements of the worlds of mountaineering and climbing.A line simply called M based in Tokyo offered the perfect emblem of this rugged rough-and-ready sportswear, showing a photo of a shaggy model in a down vest embellished with Fair Isle-style detailing in the shadow of a snowy peak along with the slogan Challenge Mount Fuji  because its there. It offered the same graphic pattern in a heavy woolen short, an odd choice for a winter pant but one that consistently cropped up at the show. The trek-worthy gear also featured hooded plaid parkas with built-in backpacks.

title: Obama Breaks Ground With a Tweet
description: President Obama on Monday pushed the button on his first-ever tweet  a message about his visit to the headquarters of the American Red Cross to thank workers for their efforts in responding to the devastating earthquake in Haiti.

title: Critics Picks Video: The Player
description: In this weeks Critics Picks, A. O. Scott looks at The Player, Robert Altmans 1992 film, adapted by Michael Tolkin from his novel, about an ambitious Hollywood studio executive, played by Tim Robbins, who gets involved in a murder.

title: Sound of Ivy League Rock, With a World of Sources
description: Everything is natty and knowing in Vampire Weekends songs. They are marvelous, quick-fingered mechanisms of hooks and syncopations, riffs and references, both musical and verbal. They mesh bubblegum, Vivaldi, reggae, Zimbabwean chimurenga, new wave, soca and more. They cite Richard Serra, Cape Cod, the Khyber Pass, Aranciata, Contra Costa, Darjeeling tea, mansard roofs and diplomatic license plates.

title: Pelosi: Mass. Election Wont Stop Health Bill
description: With Democrats increasingly anxious about the special election in Massachusetts on Tuesday and what it will mean for their big health care legislation, the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, told reporters in California Monday that the legislation would move forward not matter what.

title: With New Films, CBS Charts Tough Middle Course
description: LOS ANGELES  CBS Films, the venerable television companys upstart movie studio, had a problem with its first film. The emotional peak of Extraordinary Measures, a medical drama set for release on Friday, was arriving too early.

title: A Rainy Globes Gets Ratings Boost
description: The rain at Sundays Golden Globes may have wreaked havoc on the hair-dos, but it did not wilt ratings. About 17 million people watched NBCs live telecast of the ceremony, according to Nielsen data, a fat 14 percent increase from the year before, when about 15 million watched. In the crucial advertising category of people age 18 to 49, the Globes perked up 10 percent  exactly what the network had predicted  going into the night.

title: Kraft and Cadbury Near a $19 Billion Deal
description: Update | 3:18 a.m. Kraft confirmed Tuesday morning that it was finalizing the terms for a friendly takeover of Cadbury of Britain.

title: Mass. Senate Rivals Cross Paths in Last Push
description: Back Story With The Timess Michael CooperClick Below to Listen

title: A Very New York Novel Wins Newbery Medal
description: With its complex structure, evocation of time travel and resonant 1970s New York setting, When You Reach Me, a novel of mystery and friendship, won the John Newbery Medal for the most outstanding contribution to childrens literature on Monday.

title: The Slugger and the Punching Bag
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  The playwright Will Power places an unlikely pair of contenders in the theatrical ring in the new play Fetch Clay, Make Man, which is having its premiere at the McCarter Theater Center here. In one corner we find Muhammad Ali, the world-renowned prize fighter and semiprofessional poet born Cassius Clay. Opposite him is Stepin Fetchit, the actor who made it big in Hollywood by performing a cruel comic stereotype of servility and laziness.

title: Now Scrutinizing | A Rounder Golden Globes
description: Maybe its just me, but I could have sworn that some of the ladies who showed up at the Golden Globes on Sunday had put on a little weight. Its almost criminal to name names, because the very actresses whose body-mass indexes have been the subject of endless tabloid speculation are the very ones now sporting sexier curves. You could definitely see the difference if you concentrated solely on the upper arms. Instead of a Barbie-doll circumference, there was suddenly, amazingly, a womanly roundness to their frames. More Marilyn than Twiggy, thats for sure.

title: Raucous Life Unveiled, in an Appeal to the Timid
description: There has to be some mistake. The title of the solo show is Wild Man, but the actor on the bare stage looks like somebodys eighth-grade math teacher.

title: Haiti Quake Day 7: A Mass Exodus
description: Thousands of earthquake refugees are fleeing to the countryside or trying to get on planes to leave the country entirely.

title: The Return of Northeastern Republicans?
description: While we await tomorrows outcome in Massachusetts, this early-January analysis from Steve Kornacki is worth pondering:

title: Not Guilty Verdict in File-Sharing Case
description: A software engineer who was the first person in Britain to be prosecuted for illegal file sharing has been found not guilty of conspiracy to defraud, BBC News reported. The engineer, Alan Ellis, ran the file-sharing Web site OiNK.cd, which is now defunct, from an apartment in Middlesbrough, in northern England, from 2004 to 2007 until it was shut down in a police raid. Though the site did not require users to pay and instead asked for voluntary donations, prosecutors said that Mr. Ellis had $300,000 in a Paypal account and received $18,000 a month in donations. Mr. Ellis, 26, said in court that he had not intended to defraud the copyright holders of the songs downloaded through OiNK.cd, and that he had set up the Web site to further my skills. To better my skills for employability. The site, which did not host any songs itself, facilitated the illegal downloading of more than 21 million music files.

title: President Chvez, the Nongameboy
description: Lets see Microsoft try to use these blurbs in its next Xbox campaign: the Sony PlayStation video game console has been criticized by President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela, not because he finds Assassins Creed II oddly unengaging but because he believes that PlayStation is poison and will lead children down a capitalist road to hell, Agence France-Presse reported. On his weekly radio and television show, Mr. Chvez said: Those games they call PlayStation are poison. Some games teach you to kill. He added that violent video games were sold by capitalist countries so that they could later sell weapons, and that they promote the need for cigarettes, drugs and alcohol so they can sell them, according to Agence France-Presse. In October Venezuela passed a law making it illegal to sell violent video games, an offense punishable by up to five years in prison. Mr. Chvez previously criticized Nintendo for promoting selfishness, individualism and violence.

title: Haitian Charity Questions Anger Wyclef Jean
description: In a video message posted on YouTube, the musician Wyclef Jean, below, defended himself against reports that he benefited personally from his Haitian relief charity, saying, Not only I denounce all of that, Im disgusted by that. Last week the Web site thesmokinggun.com posted a report that said that the Yle Haiti Foundation, the charity that Mr. Jean has promoted since the Haitian earthquake, has a lackluster history of accounting for its finances. The Smoking Gun, citing Internal Revenue Service records, said that the foundation had paid Mr. Jean and a business partner for rent, production services and Mr. Jeans appearance at a benefit concert, and filed taxes for the first time in August, despite having incorporated 12 years ago. A weary-looking Mr. Jean, who was born in Haiti and recently returned from a visit there, said in the video that he had always been committed to the people of that country. He is scheduled to be a host of Hope for Haiti, a benefit telethon that will be on many networks on Friday. In a news conference on Monday, Mr. Jean reiterated his defense of the foundation. Have we made mistakes before? he said. Yes. Did I ever use Yle money for personal benefits? Absolutely not. He added that the foundations books were open and transparent, and were given a clean bill of health by an external auditor every year since we started.

title: For the Heirs to Holmes, a Tangled Web
description: For a 123-year-old detective, Sherlock Holmes is a surprisingly reliable earner.

title: Pants on the Ground: The Back Story
description: Petrarch had Laura; Dante had Beatrice; and Larry Platt saw some guy on the street and was inspired to write his hit song Pants on the Ground, he said on Monday. In an interview on the ABC morning show The View, Mr. Platt revealed how he came up with the song that has made him a mini-celebrity ever since he performed it on Wednesday night on American Idol. After singing Pants on the Ground (and performing a dance routine, calisthenics and a split that didnt quite happen), Mr. Platt, 63, told the View hosts Sherri Shepherd and Elisabeth Hasselbeck that he had devised the song during a stroll. I was walking one day, said an out-of-breath Mr. Platt. I see a guy with a baby bottle in his mouth, pacifier, with his pants on the ground. Thats what gave me an inspiration. Mr. Platt, a longtime civil rights activist, was appearing on The View to celebrate Martin Luther Kings Birthday.

title: Globes Draw for NBC; N.F.L. Works for CBS
description: About 17 million people watched NBCs live telecast of the Golden Globe Awards, which were hosted by Ricky Gervais, above, on Sunday night. The number, from Nielsen data, is a 14 percent increase over the year before. In the advertising market of those aged 18 to 49, the Globes perked up 10 percent  exactly what the network had predicted. The Globes are trying to climb back from the devastating effect of a writers strike, which scuttled the show in 2008. About 20 million watched in 2007, while the shows high-water, mark came in 2004 with about 27 million viewers. NBC said the audience was its largest in the time period, excluding sports, in six years. Opposite the Globes and the eighth-season debut of Foxs 24, CBS appeared to lead Sunday nights ratings over all largely because of an overrun of its coverage of the National Football League playoff game between the New York Jets and the San Diego Chargers. CBS drew more than 30 million viewers for the final hour of the game, at 7, helping to raise audiences for the networks lineup that followed, including 60 Minutes at 8 (16.7 million), Cold Case at 9 (10.7 million) and a rerun of NCIS at 10 (9.6 million). NBC ranked second on the night, and Fox edged ABC for third.

title: Lady Gaga Cancels Several Shows
description: Fans of Lady Gaga were sufficiently baffled by the lyrics to her song Bad Romance; now theyre trying to understand how she was able to make a Friday appearance on The Oprah Winfrey Show while canceling or postponing several concert dates. On Thursday evening Lady Gaga canceled a show she was to perform at Purdue University in West Lafayette, Ind., writing on her Twitter account that she was feeling dizzy and having trouble breathing before the show and that she was later given a diagnosis of exhaustion and dehydration by paramedics. On Friday she taped an appearance on Ms. Winfreys show, where she discussed her upbringing, her personal life and her fans (and told the host, Theres Gandhi, and theres Oprah) and also performed her song Monster. But that was the only performance that Lady Gaga would give for the weekend. The Star-Ledger of Newark reported that she canceled a show scheduled for Saturday at the Borgata Hotel Casino and Spa in Atlantic City. The concert promoter Live Nation said on livenation.com that a Lady Gaga show scheduled for Sunday in Wallingford, Conn., was canceled, and the Mohegan Sun casino in Uncasville, Conn., said one planned for Monday was postponed. Lady Gaga is scheduled to begin a four-night stand at Radio City Music Hall in New York on Wednesday.

title: Group Hug | Renegade Convention
description: MILAN  The idea of rebels is always a powerful one in mens fashion, and its been making the rounds here this season. Bottega Venetas Tomas Maier brought flair and sophistication to his parade of Teddy Boys with tapered trousers, bright blazers, chunky creeper shoes and slick ducks tail hair. Roberto Cavallis renegades sported woven leather pants, destroyed jeans and metal mesh tops; at John Varvatos, rockers layered knit coats under and over double-breasted suits and long cardigan jackets. And at Emporio Armani, the nonconformist vibe came via snowboarding and acid-hued paraphernalia; not to mention, of course, the group of 30 models who closed the show wearing nothing but skimpy flesh-toned underwear and the Reebok EA7 sneakers developed by Emporio Armani and Reebok. Who worked out the nonconformist look best? You tell us.

title: From Deep in the Back Catalog, a Weber-Mahler Collaboration
description: Mahler, paradoxically, first attained recognition as a composer by completing Die Drei Pintos, a now obscure three-act comic opera by Carl Maria von Weber. The Bronx Opera presented that complete work this month in what was billed as its New York premiere.

title: Gilbert, Sullivan and Some Not-So-Helpful Ghosts
description: Just why Ruddigore, the 10th of the 14 operettas created by the peerless team of Gilbert and Sullivan, has failed to catch on over the years is hard to figure out. Introduced in 1887 in the wake of The Mikado, a runaway hit, Ruddigore was initially deemed a lesser work. Though its fortunes changed after a series of revisions, it is rarely encountered today.

title: Brazen Attack in Kabul
description: The Taliban coordinated a brazen rush-hour attack in downtown Kabul, sending a message to the government that they will bring the fight from the countryside to the city.

title: A Flash of Vulnerability, Yet Keeping Her Chin Up
description: Across 15 years or so, Beth Ortons music has come in various flavors, devised by different producers, sometimes lodged in fast-passing mini-movements.

title: What if Conan Said, Goodbye, NBC. Hello, Internet?
description: David Carrs media column this week looks at the state of affairs with late-night television. He argues that the ratings drama surrounding The Tonight Show has nothing to do with Conan OBrien or Jay Leno, but is instead a demonstration of the changing tide of consumer habits from television time slots to the Web.

title: Jerry Joness Decision: Keep Wade Phillips?
description: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com.

title: For Former Worlds Fair Ice Rink, Fragments of an Afterlife
description: When the Queens Museum of Arts expansion project is finished, sometime around 2012, the museum will have doubled in size, to 100,000 square feet. The existing buildings conjoined twin, the Worlds Fair ice rink, has already been demolished, and eventually, the museum will be airy and filled with light.

title: Will China Achieve Science Supremacy?
description: A recent Times article described how China is stepping up efforts to lure home the top Chinese scholars who live and work abroad. The nation is already second only to the United States in the volume of scientific papers published, and it has, as Thomas Friedman pointed out, more students in technical colleges and universities than any other country.

title: Get-out-the-vote Pitches in Massachusetts
description: LITTLETON, Mass.  Volunteers and campaign workers staffed phone banks for each of the candidates in the Senate race here, as they concentrated on energizing voters to get to the polls on Tuesday.

title: European Banks Take a Step Toward More Normal Lending
description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank and Swiss National Bank said Monday that they would end a program aimed at supplying Swiss currency to banks, in a further sign that the regions financial system is becoming more stable.

title: After Hearing in Pakistan, 5 Americans Allege Torture
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  The five American Muslim men from the Washington, D.C., area arrested last month in Pakistan on suspicion of plotting terrorist acts said at a court appearance on Monday that they were being tortured in custody.

title: Democrats May Seek to Push Health Bill Through House
description: WASHINGTON  The White House and Democratic Congressional leaders, scrambling for a backup plan to rescue their health care legislation if Republicans win the special election in Massachusetts on Tuesday, have begun laying the groundwork to ask House Democrats to approve the Senate version of the bill and send it directly to President Obama for his signature.

title: Hackers Said to Breach Gmail Accounts in China
description: BEIJING  Google e-mail accounts of at least two foreign journalists in Beijing have been compromised, a journalists advocacy group in China said on Monday, adding that hackers changed Gmail program settings so that all messages would be forwarded to unfamiliar addresses.

title: A Pacific Island Challenge to European Air Pollution
description: BRUSSELS  A Pacific island nation has challenged plans by the Czech Republic to refit a coal-fired power station, in an appeal that environmental advocates on Monday described as the first of its kind.

title: Modern-Day Pilgrims Find Interfaith Bond in Ancient Syrian Monastery
description: DEIR MAR MOUSA, Syria  As darkness falls over the vast Syrian desert and the first winter stars emerge, a trail of modern-day pilgrims is slowly climbing the stone steps of this remote cliff-top monastery.

title: Date for State of Union
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will deliver his first State of the Union address on Jan. 27.

title: Glen W. Bell Jr., Founder of Taco Bell, Dies at 86
description: Glen W. Bell Jr., whose idea in 1951 to sell crispy-shell tacos from the window of his hamburger stand became the foundation of Taco Bell, the restaurant chain that turned Mexican fare into fast food for millions of Americans, died at his home in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif. He was 86.

title: Edward H. Linde, Co-Founder of Boston Properties, Dies at 68
description: Edward H. Linde, a founder of one of the largest real estate investment trusts in the nation  and the behind-the-scenes partner of Mortimer B. Zuckerman  died on Sunday in Boston. He was 68 and lived in Weston, Mass.

title: An Antitrust Complaint for Google in Germany
description: PARIS  Google said on Monday that it faced antitrust complaints in Germany from newspaper and magazine publishers who want the company to pay for using article snippets in its Web news service and search results.

title: Leno Expects Resolution Tuesday
description: Jay Leno on his show Monday night addressed the issue between NBC, Mr. Leno and Conan OBrien and said we should have an answer tomorrow about whether he is going to return to the 11:35 p.m. time slot.

title: U.N. Panels Glacier Warning Is Criticized as Exaggerated
description: A much-publicized estimate from a United Nations panel about the rapid melting of Himalayan glaciers from climate change is coming under fire as a gross exaggeration.

title: Gunmen Attack a Charity in a Sunni Neighborhood of Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  Gunmen killed four or five people at the office of an Iraqi humanitarian group in a Sunni neighborhood in Baghdad at midday on Monday, and left a bomb for police responders, in a rare attack on a nongovernmental organization here.

title: Guatemala: No Damage in Quake
description: An earthquake centered just off the Pacific Coast rattled nerves and sent people into the streets Monday morning, but officials in Guatemala and El Salvador said there were no reports of damage or injuries. The epicenter of the magnitude 5.8 quake was 65 miles south southeast of Guatemala City, the United States Geological Survey said.

title: For Travelers in Danger, Someone to Swoop In
description: THERE is no place in the world where there are no business travelers, said Patrick Deroose, the manager of the corporate assistance division of the worldwide crisis response company International SOS.

title: Taliban Leaders Unlikely to Accept Offer, Gates Says
description: NEW DELHI  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Monday that there could be a surge of Taliban followers willing to reintegrate with the Afghan government of President Hamid Karzai, but that for now an Afghan government reconciliation with the Taliban leadership was unlikely.

title: Stephon Marburys Next Play: China
description: Stephon Marbury, whose N.B.A. career was distinguished as much by off-court distractions and feuds with coaches as by his playmaking ability, is taking his game far afield: he has joined the Shanxi Zhongyu Brave Dragons of the Chinese Basketball Association, according to the teams United States-based consultant.

title: At Yemen College, Scholarship and Jihadist Ideas
description: SANA, Yemen  The mosque at Al Eman University is larger than a football field, an immense warehouse with breeze-block walls, a tin roof and industrial lighting. On Fridays, more than 4,000 men come to pray, lining up along the marks on the figured green carpet, giving each enough room to prostrate himself toward Mecca.

title: The Bipartisan Panel: Did It Really Work?
description: WASHINGTON  The White House has joined some senators in a claim that upends an old saw. If there is no will among politicians to resolve budget problems, they argue, there is nonetheless a way  through a bipartisan commission.

title: The Rise and Fall of a Sunni in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  Saleh al-Mutlaq has never shied from controversy, sometimes relishing his plunge into the turbulence of Iraqi politics. But even Mr. Mutlaq, a disheveled former agronomist, seems taken aback at landing square center in a growing dispute that threatens to unleash turmoil ahead of Iraqs parliamentary elections in March.

title: Shades of Prejudice
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Swiss Banker Blows Whistle on Tax Evasion
description: From his home in the quiet village of Rorbas, outside Zurich, Rudolf M. Elmer is chipping away at the centuries-old traditions of Swiss banking secrecy.

title: As Haitians Flee, the Dead Go Uncounted
description: TITANYEN, Haiti  A few miles north of the busted-down buildings in Port-au-Prince, up a hillside where cows graze, an empty hole awaits the dead. Rectangular, 20 feet deep and wide, 100 feet long, it is one of the newest mass graves, but there are many more.

title: Marking King Day, From Oval Office to Soup Kitchen
description: WASHINGTON  The White House installed a rare signed copy of the Emancipation Proclamation in the Oval Office on Monday, just in time for President Obama to mark his first Martin Luther Kings Birthday in office.

title: U.N. Likely to Send More Security
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations Security Council is expected to agree on Tuesday to send an additional 3,500 soldiers and police officers to Haiti, a move requested by Secretary General Ban Ki-moon to protect the distribution of emergency supplies and to ensure public order if post-earthquake frustrations boil over.

title: Bloggingheads: Coakley's Woes
description: Chris Hayes, left, of The Nation and Tim Carney of The Washington Examiner assess the embattled Martha Coakley.

title: Kraft Is Said to Reach Deal for Cadbury
description: Kraft Foods has reached a tentative deal for a friendly takeover of Cadbury of Britain, agreeing in principle to pay about $19 billion in cash and stock for the confectioner, people briefed on the matter said on Monday.

title: Guatemala Protests Arrest of 3 in Florida Over Passports
description: The Guatemalan government has issued a public protest after three Guatemalans were arrested this month by immigration agents at a FedEx office in Florida, when one of the immigrants went to pick up a package containing his newly issued Guatemalan passport.

title: Aid Arrives but Few Are Lucky to Get It
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  When the aid helicopters descend on the Ptionville Club golf course, once a playground for the wealthy and now a sprawling city of makeshift tents, the residents hurry toward them. But to get there, they must climb a steep embankment to a landing zone on top of a hill where the 82nd Airborne Division distributes the food and water.

title: Bohemian Soul Mates
description: Just Kids, writes Janet Maslin, captures a moment when Patti Smith and Robert Mapplethorpe were young, inseparable, perfectly bohemian and completely unknown.
