The tenderly evocative memoir by Ms. Smith, the punk-rock queen, chronicles her early relationship with the photographer. Ms. Smith came across Mr. Mapplethorpe in a back bedroom of a Brooklyn apartment. He resembled a hippie shepherd, while she had been contemptuously described as looking like Draculas daughter, Ms. Maslin writes. They would go on to become roommates, soul mates, friends, lovers and muses. On Tuesday night, starting at 7 p.m., Ms. Smith will read about those bygone days at the Barnes & Noble at Union Square.

title: In Season
description: In 2007 the independent film Once, featuring the Irish musician Glen Hansard and the Czech pianist and songwriter Marketa Irglova, charmed audiences at the Sundance Film Festival. The pair, known as the Swell Season, went on to win an Academy Award for their duet from the film, Falling Slowly. The festival returns again this weekend, and another movie and soundtrack will surely emerge as the surprise hit, but before then go see the duo at Radio City Music Hall, where they will be performing songs from their follow-up album, Strict Joy, on Tuesday night.

title: The Next Stop on Our Tour ...
description: Continue traveling through the citys past with a visit to Downtown Pix: Mining the Fales Archives, 1961-1991. The exhibition reminds us what the arts scene in the East Village, SoHo and TriBeCa was like at the height of the AIDS epidemic, writes Martha Schwendener, before gentrification and before the downtown ethos and aesthetic were packaged into family viewing spectacles like Rent or those by Blue Man Group. The show at the Grey Art Gallery includes more than 300 photographs and offers a glimpse of the downtown of experimental art, music, film, theater and dance  often mashed up and delivered simultaneously.

title: Tyco to Acquire Broadview Security for $1.9 Billion
description: Tyco International will acquire Broadview Security for $1.9 billion in a deal that brings together two big North American names in residential and commercial security, the two companies said Monday.

title: Super Bowl III-Peat
description: Hollywood would call it a remake. When the Jets play the Colts in the American Football Conference championship game Sunday, the cast will be different but the dialogue and the story line arent that much different than before the Jets played the Colts in Super Bowl III.

title: A Deluge of Donations via Text Messages
description: A push by celebrities, athletes and the first lady encouraging text-message donations for earthquake relief in Haiti has contributed to a fund-raising bonanza for the American Red Cross, which a little over a year ago turned to Congress for a bailout.

title: Defiant Vow to Rebuild Amid Ruins and Bodies
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Alain Villard was stuck in traffic when the earthquake devastated both his T-shirt factory in the rough-and-tumble neighborhood of Carrefour and his elegant boutique hotel in the Ptionville suburb.

title: Big, in Banks, Is in the Eye of the Beholder
description: Can a bank be too big?

title: Homeless Haitians Told Not to Flee to U.S.
description: MIAMI  America has a message for the millions of Haitians left homeless and destitute by last weeks earthquake: Do not try to come to the United States.

title: Must There Be a Bottom Line?
description: Tomorrow, Jan. 19, marks the official publication of Barbara Herrnstein Smiths Natural Reflections: Human Cognition at the Nexus of Science and Religion. The title would seem to identify the book as an addition to the ever-growing body of studies that explore the relationships and tensions between religion and science, usually with the intent either of declaring one epistemologically or morally superior to the other, or of insisting (somewhat piously) that the two are compatible if we avoid extreme claims and counterclaims, or of triumphantly announcing that science is a form of faith, or of purporting to demonstrate that religion can be explained in naturalist terms as an expression of the instinct to survive and propagate.

title: Riding Wave of Disaffection, Brown Pushes for an Upset
description: Scott Brown, the Republican candidate for Senate, has run an aggressive, surprising campaign in Massachusetts, injecting fear into the Democratic machine over what was expected to be an easy victory.

title: American Airlines Raises Its Baggage Fees, Too
A Gun Charge, a Guilty Plea, a Contract at Risk
description: When Gilbert Arenas opted out of the final season of his contract two summers ago, the Washington Wizards made a decision that haunts them to this day. Even though Arenas had played in only 13 games and the Wizards had been eliminated in the first round of the playoffs for a third consecutive season, he was the face of the franchise. Retaining him became their priority.

title: Massachusetts Senate Candidates Push to Finish Line
description: BOSTON  With the weight of the political universe on their shoulders, the two candidates running for the Senate seat long held by Edward M. Kennedy embarked on a frenzied last day of campaigning on Monday, while outside groups on both sides of the health care debate flooded the state with money, advertisements and ground troops to try to influence the outcome.

title: Haiti Quake Day 7: U.N. Aid Efforts
description: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, requested that 3,500 more security officers be sent to Haiti to help ensure relief efforts can take place effectively.

title: After Career as Their Advocate, Coakley May Face Voters Wrath
description: Even during a fierce campaign for Senate, Martha Coakley speaks with quiet fervor, a serious woman who has been arguing issues since she was a standout on her Western Massachusetts high school debate team.

title: Zoe Wheeler Fulfills a Goal
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Todays puzzle is a debut. Thats somewhat unusual. We average a few debuts a month. Its a debut by a teenager. Thats rare. The teenage constructor is a young woman. Thats unique. I chat with Zoe Wheeler further down and its the most fun interview Ive ever done for Wordplay. But first, the puzzle.

title: Strike in Cleveland Points to Classical Music Woes
description: CLEVELAND  One of the first high-profile labor tussles of 2010 is brewing at the Cleveland Orchestra, and it points to troubled times for the nations elite classical musical ensembles amid the Great Recession.

title: Robinson Leads Knicks, and That Scares DAntoni
description: There are many stunning things Nate Robinson can do on a basketball court, but the idea that he is fast becoming the Knicks primary decision maker was enough to send a shudder through Coach Mike DAntoni.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about policy advocates who are choosing not to declare themselves as lobbyists, gave outdated information for Tom Daschle, the former Democratic leader in the Senate, who advises colleagues and private clients on health care policy and who also consults informally with the White House and former Senate colleagues. He recently joined the law and lobbying firm DLA Piper. He is no longer with Alston & Bird.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 26 about a thwarted bombing attempt aboard a Northwest Airlines flight from Amsterdam to Detroit on Christmas Day, citing information provided by federal officials, misstated the given name of the bombing suspect who was taken into custody. He is Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab, not Abdul Farouk Abdulmutallab. A picture caption on Wednesday repeated the error.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about Dr. James Dobson, an influential voice for Christian conservatives who is leaving Focus on the Family, which he founded 33 years ago, to start a radio program that will allow him more leeway to talk about politics, misstated Dr. Dobsons professional credentials. He is a psychologist, not a psychiatrist.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about President Obamas visit on Sunday to Massachusetts in support of the states Democratic senatorial candidate, Martha Coakley, misspelled, in some editions, the surname of the deputy director of Organizing for America, which is handling the get-out-the-vote effort for Ms. Coakley. He is Jeremy Bird, not Byrd.

title: Looking Fit, Roddick Sets Sights Deep in Draw
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  It was championship point of a grueling struggle last August in Washington, and neither Andy Roddick nor Juan Martin del Potro would give up.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Gilberto Sanchez, a Bronx man who posted a pirated copy of the movie X-Men Origins: Wolverine on a Web site before its release, described his contact with the Late Show With David Letterman incorrectly. It was Mr. Sanchez who contacted the show first; a representative called him back. CBS did not invite him to appear with the movies star, Hugh Jackman, on the show. The same error appeared in a subheading with the article.

title: For Edwards, Jets Epitomize Commitment to Winning
description: SAN DIEGO

title: Out of the Woods
description: It takes a strange frame of mind to believe that demolishing a wooded encampment of homeless immigrant men and evicting them onto the streets during one of the coldest weeks of winter can be an act of prudence and compassion. But that is how the town of Huntington, in Suffolk County on Long Island, describes it.

title: Researchers Find Study of Medical Marijuana Discouraged
description: Despite the Obama administrations tacit support of more liberal state medical marijuana laws, the federal government still discourages research into the medicinal uses of smoked marijuana. That may be one reason that  even though some patients swear by it  there is no good scientific evidence that legalizing marijuanas use provides any benefits over current therapies.

title: Denied a Chance for Honest Work
description: Among the leading causes of recidivism are employment policies in the private and public sectors that discriminate against former offenders and too often drive them back to jail. New York State first addressed this problem more than 30 years ago with laws protecting the employment rights of people with criminal convictions. But two investigations by Attorney General Andrew Cuomo suggest that some companies are finding ways around these laws.

title: Ms. Murkowskis Mischief
description: Senator Lisa Murkowskis home state of Alaska is ever so slowly melting away, courtesy of a warming planet. Yet few elected officials seem more determined than she to throw sand in the Obama administrations efforts to do something about climate change.

title: One Star for Ethics Reform
description: New York legislators proposed an ethics reform package last week that would definitely improve the miserable status quo in Albany. But the plan is not the full-fledged housecleaning necessary for a place that has gone too long without the slightest dusting of reform.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the Golden Globe Awards, where the AMC show Mad Men was named best dramatic television series, misstated, in some editions, the number of consecutive years it has won that honor. This was the third consecutive year, not the second.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: At a King Day Celebration, a Preview of a Gillibrand-Ford Primary
description: He sat in the front row. She was one row behind.

title: For Christie, an Inauguration on a Budget
description: He made his name by indicting New Jersey politicians.

title: School Plan for U.S. Aid Gets No Vote in Albany
description: An eleventh-hour push by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Gov. David A. Paterson to improve New York States chances to receive up to $700 million in federal education financing faltered on Monday after the State Legislature balked at the plan.

title: Blacks in Retreat
description: It has been easy for people to forget in the decades since we lost the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. that he was a passionate fighter for economic justice as well as civil rights. The two goals were as closely linked as the hydrogen and oxygen atoms in water.

title: The Pragmatic Leviathan
description: When I was in college, I was assigned Leviathan, by Thomas Hobbes. On the cover was an image from the first edition of the book, published in 1651. It shows the British nation as a large man. The people make up the muscles and flesh. Then at the top, there is the king, who is the head and the mind.

title: Reliving Horror in a Test for the Death Penalty
description: NEW HAVEN  More than two years later, the details still have the power to horrify.

title: Power Line Accident Prompts Evacuation and Subway Halt
description: Workers installing a gas line into a Brooklyn building accidentally struck a power line that feeds the subway on Monday, sparking electrical explosions that blew manhole covers into the air, disrupted subway service and rattled nerves in a pocket of Brooklyn Heights.

title: For Last Shot, the Biggest of Guns
description: TITLE Every Vote Matters

title: Emergency Brake Confuses Many on Subway
description: The emergency brake is a ubiquitous fixture of New York City subway cars, a cord that allows passengers to bring 400 tons of metal to a screeching halt.

title: A Message From the Kitchen
description: TITLE Rebuttal

title: Lottery Numbers
Rachel Alexandra Wins Horse of the Year
description: Unbeaten on the racetrack last year, Rachel Alexandra won again Monday night, defeating her rival Zenyatta to take horse racings top prize, the Eclipse Award for Horse of the Year.

title: Problems Mount at a Bronx Building Bought in a Bubble
description: It was in the community room on the ground floor of 1520 Sedgwick Avenue in the West Bronx that a young D.J. and his turntables helped to invent hip-hop, the music that spawned a global culture.

title: What Lessons Those Carrots Are Teaching
description: Remember New York Citys plan to reward students who excelled with cellphones? That plan fell by the wayside, not because so many people thought it was absurd  after all, cellphones are not allowed in New York City Schools  but because the projects guru, the Harvard economist Roland Fryer, decided to apply his energies elsewhere not long after the project began.

title: New Public Advocate Assails Bloombergs Performance on Homelessness
description: In his first policy announcement since taking office, Bill de Blasio, the citys new public advocate, will challenge Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs record on homelessness and call on him to intensify his efforts to address the problem.

title: The Stuff We Could Teach Jack Bauer
description: Not many New Yorkers dwell on this anymore, but the city has been on orange alert for years, suggesting that the terrorism risk is forever high. Somehow, weve managed to get by without help from Jack Bauer, the ne plus ultra of counterterrorism on Foxs long-running 24.

title: Call From Haiti Heartens Struggling Father
description: It was just before 3 p.m. on Saturday when the call came from his daughter, telling them she was alive.

title: Harold Faber, Longtime Reporter and Editor for The Times, Dies at 90
description: Harold Faber, a retired reporter and editor at The New York Times whose work for the paper ranged from war reporting in Korea, sustaining a grave injury while doing so, to covering the regions north of New York City, died Jan. 7 at his home in Salisbury, Conn. He was 90.

title: Following His Father Into the World of Fish
description: Leslie Barnes was not born in the Fulton Fish Market, but almost. As a sprat of 5, he accompanied his father on predawn forays to buy seafood for their restaurant, London Lennies on Woodhaven Boulevard in Rego Park, Queens, founded in 1959. Leonard, the father, a cockney sailor who parlayed four fish and chips stands in London into his stake in the colonies, is gone, so Leslie Barnes, 54, the father of four daughters, is the big fish now.

title: The Uses and Misuses of the Filibuster
description: To the Editor:

title: What Ails Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Change in Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: Millions of Marrow Donors
description: To the Editor:

title: The Fed and the Housing Bubble
description: To the Editor:

title: Sponsor Found to Replace Buick for Torrey Pines Event
description: The PGA Tour announced Monday that it had reached agreement with the Farmers Insurance Group of Companies, a Southern California-based insurance giant, to become the title sponsor of next weeks San Diego Open.

title: Amid Reports of a Deal, OBrien Jokes of a Gag Order
description: Update | 11:41 p.m.  Amid reports that the deal to settle Conan OBriens contract with NBC could include at least a temporary gag order on both him and NBC executives, the host, whose ratings have surged since his contretemps with the network, took the opportunity on Monday to play his situation for laughs  though he did not direct any of the jokes at Jay Leno, the man who will return as the Tonight show host in the deal expected to be finalized Tuesday.

title: Haiti Quake Day 7: N.Y. to Haiti
description: New York City police, fire and paramedic teams are working around the clock in Haiti.

title: U.S. Team Awaits Word on Dempseys Knee Injury
description: Barely two weeks after scoring a dazzling goal for his club team, Fulham, Clint Dempsey is playing a waiting game. His immediate future and the United States hopes at this summers World Cup in South Africa hinge on the words of doctors who are evaluating Dempseys right knee after he was injured Sunday in an English Premier League match at Blackburn Rovers.

title: In Cadbury-Kraft, 2 Winning Sides
description: It would have been astonishing if Kraft Foods hostile bid for Cadbury had gone to the bitter end. Like most contested takeover battles, this one looks to be edging toward a last-minute rapprochement. Cadbury will most likely squeeze more out of Kraft without an auction  an impressive feat.

title: Whos Up for Facing the Colts? Ellis Raises a Broken Hand
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Jets defensive end Shaun Ellis declared Monday that he would not let a silly little inconvenience like a broken left hand prevent him from playing in the American Football Conference championship game Sunday against Indianapolis. He has waited way too long for this chance.

title: More Men Marrying Wealthier Women
description: Beagy Zielinski is a German-born 28-year-old stylist who moved to New York to study fashion in 1995 and stayed. Just before Christmas, she broke up with her blue-collar boyfriend, who repaired Navy ships.

title: Israels Winter Athletes Come to U.S. Seeking Ice and Medals
description: HACKENSACK, N.J.  It almost never snows in Israel, and there is only one regulation ice rink in the entire country, in Metulla, on the Lebanese border, where temperatures regularly reach 100 degrees. During the 2006 war with Hezbollah, the rink had to be closed for security reasons and the roof was damaged from shelling. Even now, the ice is not entirely reliable, and there are not enough hours in the day to accommodate everyone who wants to use it: speedskaters, figure skaters, and hockey nuts who drive three hours from Jerusalem for Thursday night games.

title: Word of the Day | poseur
description: poseur \po-zr, po-zr\ noun

title: Snowboarder Davis Has Fractured Vertebrae
description: Danny Davis, an Olympic snowboarding hopeful, broke a bone in his lower back during an accident on an all-terrain vehicle on Sunday, putting an end to his season and sending another jolt through the United States halfpipe community.

title: Carl Smith, Country Music Hitmaker, Is Dead at 82
description: NASHVILLE  Carl Smith, the dapper singer who ranked among the most popular country hitmakers of the 1950s, died on Saturday at his home in Franklin, Tenn., just outside Nashville. He was 82.

title: News Quiz | January 19, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Dont Walk This Way
description: WHOM do you know who regularly uses a cellphone to talk or text while walking?

title: Swiss Banker Blows Whistle on Tax Evasion
description: From his home in the quiet village of Rorbas, outside Zurich, Rudolf M. Elmer is chipping away at the centuries-old traditions of Swiss banking secrecy.

title: Japan Airlines Files for Bankruptcy
description: Japan Airlines, the once-mighty flagship carrier and Asias biggest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection Tuesday, setting the stage for a state-led bailout that could bring sweeping changes to this busy corner of the global aviation market, Hiroko Tabuchi writes in The New York Times.

title: Cadbury-Kraft: A Win-Win Deal?
description: It would have been astonishing if Kraft Foods hostile bid for Cadbury had gone to the bitter end, Reuters Breakingviews says. Like most contested takeover battles, this one looks to be edging toward a last-minute rapprochement. Cadbury will most likely squeeze more out of Kraft without an auction  an impressive feat, the publication remarked before the two companies announcement Tuesday.

title: Swiss Re Gets $1.27 Billion in Deal With Buffett
description: The Swiss Reinsurance Company said on Monday that it had transferred part of its American life insurance business to Berkshire Hathaway, the conglomerate controlled by Warren E. Buffett, for 1.3 billion Swiss francs ($1.27 billion) to free up capital and invest it more profitably.

title: Another Snowboarder Injured
description: Danny Davis, an Olympic snowboarding hopeful, broke a bone in his lower back during an accident on an all-terrain vehicle Sunday, ending his season and sending another jolt through the United States halfpipe community. Davis, 21, is expected to recover, but not in time for next months Vancouver Olympics. Davis is one of the best friends of Kevin Pearce, who sustained a traumatic brain injury Dec. 31 while training in the halfpipe of Utahs Park City Mountain Resort.

title: If Big Funds Go Old-School, Profits May Follow
description: Giant private equity funds wont be back for a while, Reuters Breakingviews says. New research shows many investors have lost interest in multibillion-dollar funds. That will make it tougher for big buyout shops like Blackstone and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts to raise money in the amounts they have become accustomed to. Some may even have to relearn smaller-scale methods of investing.

title: Edward H. Linde, Zuckermans Partner, Dies at 68
description: Edward H. Linde, a founder of one of the largest real estate investment trusts in the nation  and the behind-the-scenes partner of Mortimer B. Zuckerman  died on Sunday in Boston, The New York Timess Dennis Hevesi reported. He was 68 and lived in Weston, Mass.

title: Europe Markets Rise Amid Rumors on Deals
description: European stock markets rose Monday as speculation of a pickup in corporate deal making kept investors interested on a day Wall Street was closed for the Martin Luther King public holiday and Greeces budgetary woes continued to weigh on the euro.

title: European Banks Take a Step Toward More Normal Lending
description: The European Central Bank and Swiss National Bank said Monday that they would end a program aimed at supplying Swiss currency to banks, in a further sign that the regions financial system is becoming more stable, The New York Timess Jack Ewing reported.

title: Agency Combines Clients Stocks for Mini-Mutual Fund
description: Forget about the Standard & Poors 500-stock index or the Dow Jones industrial average. The latest gauge of Wall Street performance  at least on Madison Avenue  is the K.B.S.& P. Client Stock Index, The New York Timess Stuart Elliott writes.

title: Does Who You Think You Are Influence What You Want to Do?
description: Do you have fixed ideas of what type of person becomes a nurse? A professor? A farmer, soldier or artist? Two sociologists have been studying the typecasting of professions by factors like gender and political ideology. What do you want to do? Do you think you are influenced by occupational typing?

title: Morgan Stanley Tries on a New Psyche
description: James P. Gorman, a 6-foot-2 Australian, recently took up boxing lessons, in keeping with some of the trappings of his Midtown Manhattan office. On one wall, opposite an inspirational poem by Rudyard Kipling (The Thousandth Man), hangs a photograph of Elvis Presley sparring with Muhammad Ali.

title: Capmark Unit Files for Chapter 11, and Signs Deal
description: Capmark Investments, a unit of the bankrupt commercial property lender Capmark Financial Group, filed for bankruptcy in a bid to sell its management contracts and interests in real estate equity funds.

title: After Skype Founders Return  an I.P.O.?
description: One night in 2007, employees at Skype Technologies decided to send a message to their corporate parent, eBay. They picked up the desk of Henry Gomez, an eBay senior executive and Skypes president, and moved it to a far corner of the companys London office, according to a former eBay manager.

title: Carpetbagger: Inside the Golden Globes
description: Melena Ryzik takes a look behind the curtain at the 2010 Golden Globe Awards.

title: Alibaba Criticizes Investor Yahoo for Google Support
description: In an unusual move, the Alibaba Group of China on Saturday criticized Yahoo, one of its largest shareholders, for siding with Google after a cyber attack on that company, The New York Timess David Barboza and Miguel Helft report.

title: Goldman and Morgan Stocks Closing the Gap
description: Goldman Sachs Group, whose record earnings in the first nine months of last year fueled public outrage, will probably hit a profit plateau in 2010, just as Morgan Stanley rebounds from its worst year ever, Bloomberg News reported.

title: BlackRock Acquires Helix Financial
description: BlackRock, the giant money manager, said Tuesday that it had acquired Helix Financial Group, a company based in Charlotte, N.C., that advises commercial real estate lenders.

title: Castle Harlan Buys Plastic Container Makers
description: The private equity firm Castle Harlan said on Monday that it was buying the plastic container maker Pretium Packaging and its rival, the PVC Container Corporation, in deals valued at a combined $200 million.

title: Travelport Takes $2 Billion I.P.O. to London
description: Travelport, the New York-based travel service company, introduced a $2 billion initial public offering on Tuesday to cut debt, in a sign that large share sales may be picking up, Reuters reported.

title: App Developer Shopkick Attracts $2.5 Million
description: Shopkick, which develops applications for mobile devices, has collected $2.5 million in a first round of venture capital, VentureBeat reported, citing a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Credit Suisse Seeks More Asian Hedge Fund Business
description: Credit Suisse will increase the headcount in its prime brokerage team in Asia by 15 percent to 20 percent in 2010 as it tries to win business from the increasing number of global hedge funds eager to set up a base in the region, a senior official at the Swiss bank said.

title: Iceslave Bill
description: Mordant nickname for the proposed $5 billion Icesave Bill  legislation that would commit Iceland to compensating the UK and the Netherlands for the banking failures of 2008.

title: Citi Hires Former Morgan Stanley Asia Chief
description: Citigroup said on Monday it appointed a Morgan Stanley executive, Alasdair Morrison, as an Asia senior adviser, a new role for the bank meant to support its expansion across the region.

title: Some Dubai World Creditors Said to Seek Loan Sale
description: Some creditors to Dubai World, which is currently restructuring $22 billion of debt, are seeking to offload loans to reduce their exposure to the Gulf emirates conglomerate, The Financial Times reported.

title: Guvera, a Music Site, Lands $20 Million
description: Guvera, an ad-supported music site, has landed $20 million in a fresh round of funding from AMMA Private Investment, an Australian consortium of private angel investors, Tech Crunch reported.

title: Cadbury Board Accepts $19.5 Billion Kraft Offer
description: After four months of pursuit, Kraft Foods announced the details Tuesday for a friendly takeover of Cadbury, whose board unanimously recommended the deal to its shareholders.

title: Berkshire Said to Consider Stock Split of B Shares
description: Admirers of Warren E. Buffett who find Berkshire Hathaways shares a little too rich for their blood may be in luck.

title: A.I.G. Said to Look at Other Ways to Repay Bonuses
description: American International Group is exploring several ways to repay $26 million of the $45 million in bonuses that executives at its financial products unit pledged to return last year, including a plan to cut 2010 bonuses but pay them out early, according to press reports.

title: Group Readies Bid for Three Canwest Newspapers
description: A group of bidders said on Monday that it was preparing to make an offer for three daily newspapers owned by the Canwest Global Communications Corporation.

title: N.Y. Pension Said to Seed Finisterre Fund
description: The New York State Common Retirement Fund, the third-largest pension plan in the country, has given Finisterre Capital a boost with a $250 million investment in the hedge funds new emerging markets fund, Bloomberg News said.

title: Spyker Says Its Still in Talks With G.M. Over Saab
description: Spyker Cars said on Monday it was still in talks to buy Swedish auto brand Saab from General Motors. Spyker, the Dutch luxury carmaker, gave no indication of when a deal might be clinched.

title: Posco Says Buffett Wants to Buy More Shares
description: Posco of South Korea said Tuesday that Warren E. Buffett, whose investment vehicle owns 4.5 percent of Posco, the worlds No. 4 steelmaker, had indicated he wanted to buy more stock, Reuters reported.

title: In Hollywood, Grappling With Studios Lost Clout
description: A proposed sale of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the most powerful and lucrative studio during the golden age of film, drew only meager offers last week, and now, Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes of The New York Times write, Hollywood must confront a troubling question: are movie studios becoming a financial footnote?

title: A Famed Parisian Kitchen Is Reborn
description: The Paris restaurant that helped cultivate the careers of names like Robuchon and Ripert has a new owner. Jamin (32, rue de Longchamp, 16th Arrondissement; 33-1-45-53-00-07; www.restaurant-jamin.com; Metro: Trocadro and Boissire), which had its heyday in the 1980s, is now being run by Alain Pras, who bought the restaurant space  as well as the name  last year, and reopened it in October.

title: Ultimate Jets Fan
description: The ultimate Jets fan might be the guy who was tossed out of the Chargers game on Sunday and who gained minor celebrity as the video shuttled around the Internet.

title: Goldman Said to Delay Release of Bonus Details
description: Goldman Sachs is likely to unveil details of multimillion dollar bonuses to staff next week, a person familiar with the matter told Reuters on Tuesday, a delay as the dispute over payouts heats up.

title: The Age of External Knowledge
description: Todays idea: Filtering, not remembering, is the most important mental skill in the digital age, an essay says. But this discipline will prove no mean feat, since mental focus must take place amid the unlimited distractions of the Internet.

title: BMW Sauber Signs Pedro de la Rosa
description: Interesting how BMW Sauber  and by the way, thats what the team still officially calls itself, despite BMW selling out  has decided to hire Pedro de la Rosa as its second driver. The team made the announcement Tuesday, and in the news release we learn that hell be 39 years old on Feb. 24.

title: Are Luxury Retailers Ready to Shop?
description: Are luxury retailers gearing up for a little deal-making now that their clientele are returning to the stores?

title: Preventing Haitis Next Crisis
description: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

title: Big, in Banks, Is in the Eye of the Beholder
description: Jamie Dimon, chief of JPMorgan Chase, may have strong arguments that banks should be able to grow as big as they want, but there is a swelling chorus of leaders in the United States and abroad who are more concerned about the risk that such huge banks present to the rest of the economy, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest column in The New York Times.

title: Now Screening | Gucci
description: The fall 2010 collection from Gucci.

title: Enjoying Revis for Years to Come
description: It would be almost football sacrilege to compare Darrelle Revis to Lawrence Taylor. No reason to do that. Taylor is in a separate category as a player who changed the game.

title: Part 2: Answers on Fafsa and Financial Aid
description: For many high school seniors and their parents, this is the season for tackling the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, a notoriously cumbersome process that the government is attempting to streamline this year.

title: Senate Returns, With Eye on Massachusetts
description: Congressional attention is fixated on Massachusetts as the Senate convenes Tuesday for the second session of the 111th Congress.

title: Williams Criticizes Size of U.S. Open Fine
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  There were no outbursts from Serena Williams here  at least on the court. She swiftly and, for the most part stoically, took apart her overmatched opponent, Urszula Radwanska, in straight sets. Afterwards, however, the womens defending Australian Open champion pointedly questioned the fine given to her for threatening to shove a ball down a line judges throat last summer at the United States Open.

title: Sampler: Butterflies, Wind Turbines and 911 Immunity
description: Californians Still Feel Things Are Worse | Californias famous optimism is endangered. For the third consecutive year, a majority of Californians feel worse off financially than they did a year ago, according to a Field Poll. Until last year, Californians went more than 40 years without letting more than one year pass during which they felt that their finances were worse than the previous year. This is a new era; California is usually bigger and better, said Mark DiCamillo, the Field Poll director. Its not just affecting a certain population but is affecting a broad base of people. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

title: What Were the Odds of This?
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below:

title: Rich Nations Call for Haiti Debt Relief
description: PARIS  Broadening the relief effort, the Paris Club of international creditors issued an appeal Tuesday for nations owed money by Haiti to cancel the debts to help reconstruction after the devastating earthquake a week ago.

title: Verizon and AT&T Cut Prices
description: For all of the analyst predictions that carriers will have to raise their data plan prices, at least voice plan prices are going in the other direction. Verizon and AT&T are lowering prices for their unlimited calling plans.

title: How to Send Money to Other Charities Using Text
description: AT&T has done a great job getting out the word that its customers can make a donation to Haiti earthquake relief via text message. Text the word Haiti to the number 90999 and a $10 donation is charged to your AT&T bill.

title: Q & A With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Barkley, Kansas City, Mo., acquired the business assets of Blacktop Creative, Kansas City, for undisclosed financial terms. The agency will be combined with the design group at Barkley and be renamed Barkley Blacktop. It will have 40 employees.

title: Dark Days for Jets Rivals in A.F.C. East
description: While savoring unexpected success, Jets fans would never take pleasure in the troubles of their division brethren. O.K., maybe they might:

title: Citigroup Reports a $1.6 Billion Loss for 2009
description: Update | 8:24 a.m. Even as it untangles itself from the federal government, Citigroup has shown few signs of a quick recovery. On Tuesday, the banking giant announced its second consecutive yearly loss, Eric Dash of The New York Times reports.

title: Pandit Is Running Out of Time to Clean Up Citigroup
description: It is make or break time for Vikram S. Pandit.

title: Today in Business Travel
description: For Travelers in Danger, Someone to Swoop InAfter the earthquake in Haiti, a service called International SOS jumped right into its mission to assist its clients in the area and evacuate them.

title: A Nuclear Critic Draws a Lesson from Frances Success
description: A new statistical analysis of an almost-secret topic  what it costs to build nuclear reactors in France  may have some lessons for a nuclear renaissance in the United States.

title: Jan. 19: Updates on the Crisis in Haiti
description: On Tuesday The Lede is continuing to supplement reporting by our colleagues in Haiti on the aftermath of last weeks earthquake by pointing to news and information on the Web. Readers are encouraged to share any first-hand accounts they receive from Haiti or see online in the comments thread below. See the home page of NYTimes.com for the latest news articles and multimedia features on the relief effort. Updates from previous days: Mon. | Sun. | Sat. | Fri. | Thurs. | Weds. and Tues.

title: Google Delays Release of Cellphones in China
description: BEIJING  Google said Tuesday that it and a Chinese cellphone service company had postponed the release this week of two mobile phones that would use Googles Android software.

title: Devastation in Haiti Stirs Memories of Ground Zero
description: A pile of rubble is a pile of rubble, whether it is Lower Manhattan or central Port-au-Prince. As a New York rescue team combed the wreckage of last weeks earthquake in Haiti in search of long-shot survivors on Monday, some said one particular past disaster  the collapsed World Trade Center towers  was not far back in their minds.

title: The Early Word: Bay State Ballot
description: Massachusetts voters will head to the polls to elect a senator on Tuesday, the end of a campaign more fascinating than almost anyone could have predicted. Heres a wrap of coverage thats out there Tuesday morning.

title: Politics From A to Z: Massachusetts
description: BOSTON  Its decision day in Massachusetts, where a special election is taking place to fill the seat of the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy. Neither Democrats nor Republicans would have predicted the contest between Martha M. Coakley and Scott P. Brown would have turned into such a remarkable race.

title: Drug Companies and a Pivotal Senate Race Help Lead the Markets Higher
description: The possibility that the dynamics of the health care debate could shift helped spur Wall Street higher on Tuesday, overshadowing concerns about the strength of banks and the American consumer.

title: Tentative Deal in Cleveland Orchestra Strike
description: The strike at the Cleveland Orchestra appears to be over. The players and management said on Tuesday morning that a tentative agreement had been reached after a marathon bargaining session that began at noon on Monday and ended shortly before 6:30 a.m. Tuesday. The agreement requires ratification by the musicians and the orchestras board, and that is expected today, giving the orchestra enough time to move forward with a scheduled trip to Miami for a series of concerts and educational events. It is due to leave on Thursday. No details were released, but the issues centered on pay: the players offered a freeze on salary this year and management asked for a 5 percent cut, to be restored next year, and a 2.5 percent raise the following year.

title: Digital Photo Frames Join the Social Scene
description: Over the past six months or so, digital photo frames have gotten connected and gone social. In addition to displaying photos from a memory card, a new breed of frames can connect to Facebook, Twitter, online-photo-sharing sites, and even RSS feeds.

title: Punishing Lawyers in Corporate Frauds
description: Peter J. Henning, a professor at Wayne State Law School, specializes in issues related to white-collar crime and follows them for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: Inside Out | The Layered Look
description: Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.

title: King, Young Fight Back to Lift American Hopes; Querrey Falls
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  In an up-and-down day for Americans, Vania King of Long Beach, Calif., was up and fighting mad.

title: China Curtails Run of Avatar as It Fills Theaters
description: BEIJING  Avatar, the Hollywood blockbuster that has proved wildly popular with Chinese moviegoers, will be pulled in the next few days from the majority of Chinese theaters where it is showing, Chinese media outlets reported Tuesday.

title: Awards Punditry Gone Awry
description: Now that Los Angeles has dried out, momentarily, and possibly sobered up, its time to take stock. The efforts that the Golden Globes producers made to get better ratings worked; the awards pundits were not so successful. Most, according to The Los Angeles Timess Gold Derby blog, got it wrong, or at least only half right.

title: Solar Power Advocates Hopeful for 2010
description: Between 500 and 600 megawatts of solar power will be built this year across the United States  about double the figure of last year  according to Larry Sherwood, who compiles and studies such data as a consultant to the Interstate Renewable Energy Council, a nonprofit industry group.

title: Milan: Inflation Man
description: After looking at images of Thom Brownes buoyant new collection for Moncler Gamme Bleu in the silty pre-dawn of New York, the thought came to me that if Moncler were to make a film of Mr. Brownes padded ski wear, the company should hire Wes Anderson and a small aircraft. Theres such a funny, bumptious quality about the clothesthe padded grays, the felon stripes, the great big snow bootsthat I imagine silly but hopeful men (Bill Murray, ideally) flinging themselves out of airplanes trailed by brightly colored chutes. Nicely done, Mr. Browne.

title: The Democrats Latest Health Cliffhanger
description: It is just shy of four weeks since the Senate adopted its big health care bill. And, oh, what a difference a month can make.

title: Europe Mulls Policy on Biodiversity
description: Despite disappointment at the outcome of the climate summit in Copenhagen, European Union regulators are seeking to keep up a reputation for environmental leadership by seeking to build a strong common position ahead of international negotiations  this time on global biodiversity rules.

title: Tuesday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Melanie Oudin Continues to Struggle
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Melanie Oudin had just blown four match points and her opponent, Alla Kudryavtseva, was gaining strength. She smacked the racket in her hand, blew air through her lips and tried to beat back the tears.

title: Can Immigrants Solve Our Health Care Problems?
description: Aaron Edlin is a law and economics professor at the University of California, Berkeley. Dana Goldman is a pharmacy and public policy professor and the director of the Leonard D. Schaeffer Center for Health Policy and Economics at the University of Southern California.

title: Modernizing Government: An Entrepreneurial Perspective
description: Last Thursday, President Obama invited executives from 49 of the nations leading companies to the White House to talk about how to make the government run more smoothly. Its exciting to see the leaders of some of the most innovative, cutting-edge, tech-savvy companies in the world gathered in the city where I had to fight tooth and nail just to get a BlackBerry, he said by way of welcome. There may be a little bit of a cultural clash here, but thats exactly why we want you here.

title: Crying Children Are the Worst
description: Monologue |  Monday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Last night, President Obama attended his daughter Malias school recital. Not to see her perform or anything. Just to see if any of the kids had a solution to health care. And they didnt.

title: An Updated Photo of Osama
description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Tonight Show With Conan OBrien on NBC: The U.S. State Department has released an updated photo of Osama bin Laden that shows what he might look like after aging a decade. And guess what? Somebody got fat!

title: A Building in Decline
description: A year after a private equity backed investor bought the Bronx apartment building, 1520 Sedgwick Avenue, tenants say housing code violations have piled up.

title: Blaming Old Computers
description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: The White House issued a statement today. Theyre blaming government inefficiencies  this is true  theyre blaming it on old computers. Apparently, all the computers keep crashing. And everyone knows the only crashing tolerated at the White House is during state dinners.

title: Heat Over Panels View of Asian Ice, Disasters
description: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, for two decades the most important guide for the global community to the causes and consequences of the phenomenon, is facing a series of challenge over its practices, both from within and without.

title: Robotic Women
description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: People are worried about NBC. Earlier today, President Obama announced that hes sending in 30,000 troops. Out to Burbank.

title: Cleveland Settles Orchestra Strike
description: The musicians of the Cleveland Orchestra and their management settled a strike on Tuesday that lasted little longer than a quick scherzo but made clear the tensions raised by difficult economic times across the orchestra world.

title: A Smaller, Less Powerful Version
description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: The heaviest snowfall in over 60 years is being reported in Beijing, China. To give you an idea of how bad it is, the army is now having to use snowplows to run over dissidents.

title: The Bittersweet History of Bike Clubs
description: Neither snow, nor sleet, nor bone-chilling cold can keep the members of New Yorks assorted recreational bicycle clubs from the swift  or, often, leisurely  completion of their appointed rides around and out of the city. The New York Cycle Club, the Five Borough Bicycle Club and Fast and Fab, a lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender bike club, are some of those that lead outings and other events year round. And while none of these was around at the turn of the last century, each traces its lineage back to the ubiquitous clubs that dominated the earliest years of cycling.

title: In Britain, Cadbury Takeover Raises Job Concerns
description: Britain did not take long to respond to the announcement Tuesday that Kraft had reached a friendly agreement to take over Cadbury for 11.9 billion ($19.4 billion).

title: War@WSJ: New Book Pulls Back Blankets on Murdochs Capture of The Journal
description: Get ready for another media parlor game, this one pivoting around War at The Wall Street Journal: Inside the Struggle to Control an American Business Empire. The book, by the former Journal media writer Sarah Ellison, is a scrupulously fair, careful account written from a close distance about how Rupert Murdoch came to own the crown jewel of American business journalism.

title: Video: Inside the Golden Globes
U.S. Troops Patrol Haiti, Filling a Void
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  American military helicopters landed on Tuesday at Haitis wrecked National Palace, and troops began rolling through the capitals battered streets, signs of the growing international relief operation here. But the troops presence underscored the rising complaints that the Haitian government had all but disappeared in the week since a huge earthquake struck.

title: Was Serena Williamss Punishment Fair?
description: Serena Williams, in first Grand Slam appearance since her outburst at last years United States Open, bristled when asked about the $92,000 fine she received for the outburst. Joe Drape writes that she pointedly questioned the fine given to her for threatening to shove a ball down a line judges throat last summer at the U.S. Open.

title: Text Messages in China to Be Scanned for Illegal Content
description: BEIJING  Expanding what the Chinese government calls a campaign against pornography, cellular companies in Beijing and Shanghai have been told to suspend text services to cellphone users who are found to have sent messages with illegal or unhealthy content, state-run media reported on Tuesday.

title: Behind Krafts Raise, a Glimmer of Bigger Savings
description: Update | 8:10 p.m. Cadbury finally agreed to sell itself to Kraft on Tuesday, after the American food giant raised its takeover offer to 11.9 billion ($19.5 billion)

title: Middle-Class Angst and San Franciscos Health Plan
description: In 2007, San Francisco began Healthy San Francisco (HSF), a health access plan (read: health services) for poor residents without insurance. Last winter, H.S.F. expanded to middle-class residents. Justine Sharrock, a writer who also happens to be the daughter of an anesthesiologist, signed up in 2009, when the upper limit on annual income was increased to $54,150 for a single person (and $110,250 for a family of four).

title: Now Screening | Versace
description: The fall 2010 collection from Versace.

title: Theater Talkback With Charles Isherwood
description: Charles Isherwood, theater critic for The New York Times, is taking readers questions about his recent articles and reviews, including an Arts & Leisure essay comparing South Pacific and Rock of Ages and his reviews of Lear, The Myopia, and Little Gem.

title: Boehner Hires Contract Architect to Promote G.O.P. Platform
description: With House Republicans planning to reprise the Contract With America that catapulted them into House control in 1994, Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the party leader, is bringing back an architect of the original contract as his chief of staff.

title: For Electric Bikes, Three Makes a Trend
description: Its a clich in certain corners of the news media that a reporter needs to note three examples to report a story about a trend. The rule of three is often cited more in derision than admiration, but it seems to hold a certain amount of water. (For example, here, here and here. See how that works?)

title: Spelling Check
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: Spelling Check
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: What Editors Do: Steven Lovelady
description: When civilians visit newsrooms, they are always amazed to see row after row of desks occupied by people who dont actually write stories. And the question arises: What do editors do?

title: Paterson Seeks Huge Cuts and $1 Billion in Taxes and Fees
description: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson proposed on Tuesday what would be the largest cut to school aid in more than two decades and nearly $1 billion in new or increased taxes and fees as he unveiled his budget, a plan that is likely to be the first chapter in a prolonged battle with the Legislature.

title: Facebook Fill-In
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first four paragraphs of this New York Region story by Susan Dominus headlined A Facebook Movement, Against Mom and Dad. Use your own words and phrases, or click read more to choose from a scrambled list of the words/phrases that were removed.

title: The Nifty 50 | Girl Talk, Musician
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: New Rule Would Bar Illegal Fishing Vessels From Ports
description: The United States is looking to shore up its abilities to bar vessels involved in illegal fishing from entering its ports.

title: Japan Stalls as Leaders Are Jolted by Old Guard
description: TOKYO  It had all the trappings of a typical political scandal in a nation that has seen all too many of them: stacks of cash from construction companies, shady land deals and late-night arrests of grim-faced political aides widely seen as fall guys for their powerful bosses.

title: Coachella Lineup Announced
description: Jay-Z, Muse and Gorillaz will headline the 11th annual Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival when that sprawling rock event gets under way on April 16 in Indio, Calif., planners announced on Tuesday, hoping to maintain the momentum from last year, when the festival drew its second-highest crowds despite the economic downturn.

title: On Assignment: Silence and Submission
description: Ron Haviv, who arrived in Haiti last week on assignment for People Magazine, has produced images of conflict and humanitarian crises worldwide for more than two decades. He is a co-founder of the photo agency VII and has published Blood and Honey: A Balkan War Journal (2000) and Afghanistan: The Road to Kabul (2002). He has received awards from World Press Photo, Pictures of the Year International and the Overseas Press Club. He was interviewed Monday by James Estrin.

title: Regimens: Tailor Medicine Levels to Size and Weight, Doctors Say
description: When pediatricians prescribe medicine for children, they take the childs size and weight into account and adjust the dose accordingly. But with few exceptions, medical practitioners take a one-size-fits-all approach when prescribing drugs to adults, whether the patient is petite or extra large.

title: Another Strike Vote Planned at British Airways
description: The Associated Press is reporting that the union representing the cabin crews at British Airways said Monday that it would hold a strike vote in a dispute over pay, job security and working conditions. The union, Unite, said it would continue to negotiate with the airline while the vote by 13,000 cabin crew members went ahead starting next week.

title: The Evolving I.P.O. Market, Circa 2010
description: What a difference a year makes.

title: TNR on WashPo: Inside the Messy Collapse of a Great Newspaper.
description: Gabriel Sherman writes a big heave in The New Republic suggesting that the next generation of leadership at The Washington Post has failed to address old problems and created a few new ones.

title: AARP Will Double Your Haiti Donation
description: The AARP is offering a dollar-for-dollar match on donations to its foundation, up to $500,000 in total contributions.

title: Generation XD
description: The youngest generation that has never known life without the Internet.[Generation X + D(igital)]

title: Travel Deals: American Airlines Flight Sale
description: If youre looking for a quick winter getaway, American Airlines is having two sales: one for flights within the United States and Canada, and another specifically for ski destinations. Both end this week.

title: Now Screening | Alexander McQueen
description: The fall 2010 collection from Alexander McQueen.

title: Philadelphia Sends Valentines, 12 Months a Year
description: Not so long ago, a certain brand of cream cheese was asking consumers, Isnt it silly not to use Philly? Substitute  visit for use, and you have the message being delivered by the next phase of a popular tourism campaign.

title: Obamas Haitian Dilemma
description: All of Washington is fixated on the Brown-Coakley race, but Tyler Cowen raises the possibility that the Haitian earthquake may cast a much longer shadow over Obamas administration than todays Bay State special election. Eventually, CNNs coverage will wind down, the outpouring of online contributions will diminish, and Haiti will join Afghanistan on the list of nearly-impossible foreign policy dilemmas  except that Obama didnt inherit this one from his predecessor, and Haiti lacks a War-on-Terror angle to keep Americans invested in its fate.

title: Votes of Confidence Curiously Follow N.F.L. Playoff Flops
description: Allow us to interrupt your N.F.L. divisional round playoff hangover, the period in which you are wondering why the Chargers felt the need to announce a contract extension for Coach Norv Turner in what feels like minutes after their latest playoff flop rather than just poking their fans with a sharp stick. Or perhaps you are stuck on Dallas owner Jerry Joness vote of confidence for the ever-popular Wade Phillips for crafting one more playoff win with the Cowboys than Bill Parcells.

title: Q&A: Crossing the Energy Divide
description: According to Robert Ayres and Edward Ayres, brothers and co-authors of the recently published book, Crossing the Energy Divide, the American economy uses energy with only 13 percent efficiency.

title: Yale Admissions Office Sets Its Pitch to Music (and Dance)
description: Many fans of Disneys High School Musical franchise are now old enough to apply to college, so it was probably inevitable that an admissions office would try to reach them by turning an otherwise staid group information session into a peppy music video.

title: Behavior: Too Much Sitting Shortens Lives, Study Suggests
description: A new study from Australia suggests that couch potatoes live shorter lives.

title: Australians Have Reason to Cheer
description: Day 2 at the Australian Open brought a homegrown celebration to Melbourne Park as Lleyton Hewitt, making his record-equaling 14th straight appearance at the tournament, led a charge of host-country players into the second round.

title: MetLife Nears a Deal for A.I.G.s Alico Unit
description: Update | 1:12 p.m. MetLife has emerged as the lead bidder for the American International Groups Alico life insurance unit, people briefed on the matter told DealBook, as A.I.G. seeks to sell off the unit to help repay its $182 billion in government aid.

title: Same-Sex Marriage Case, Day 6: Civil Unions
description: Update 5:46 p.m. Pacific Time | After the lunch recess, Charles J. Cooper continued working his way through a meticulously prepared black binder, to which he continually referred as he cross-examined Professor Lee Badgett on her research methods.

title: Obama Seeks $1.3 Billion More for Schools Initiative
description: With the fate of his health care overhaul hanging in the balance, and all eyes in Washington on the outcome of the special election in Massachusetts, President Obama sought to change the subject on Tuesday morning, albeit briefly, to education.

title: Against Emerson
description: William Major and Bryan Sinche, writing in The Chronicle of Higher Education, consider the vatic pronouncements of Ralph Waldo Emerson and conclude, This is the prose of a crazy person.

title: Schools With Many Homeless Students May Close
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: G.O.P. Senate Victory Stuns Democrats
description: BOSTON  Scott Brown, a little-known Republican state senator, rode an old pickup truck and a growing sense of unease among independent voters to an extraordinary upset Tuesday night when he was elected to fill the Senate seat that was long held by Edward M. Kennedy in the overwhelmingly Democratic state of Massachusetts.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) An economist who sees no way to stall rising health care costs: Baumols cost disease.

title: Featured Recipe: Squid With Chilies and Greens
description: In this recipe, essentially a stir-fry, the squid is held out till near the end of cooking so as not to overcook it. The pair of strong spices  jalapeos and garlic  are also cooked minimally, and the greens are seared just long enough to wilt. Yet with these powerful flavors the dish comes together around the sweet but distinctive mildness of the squid.

title: For Verdi, Masquerading as a Baritone
description: In 1959, when he was 18, Plcido Domingo auditioned for the National Opera in Mexico City as a baritone. The jury was impressed but told Mr. Domingo that he was really a tenor. Two years later he sang his first lead tenor role, Alfredo in Verdis Traviata in Monterrey. And so began one of the great tenor careers in opera history.

title: Babies at the Bar? A Deluge of Readers Weigh In
description: Parents in Park Slope, Brooklyn, can be a lightning rod for criticism, and this weekends Complaint Box about parents who bring their children to neighborhood bars attracted comments like a Bugaboo stroller at a baby shower.

title: Le Monde Appoints First Woman as Top Editor
description: PARIS  Le Monde, widely considered Frances newspaper of record, appointed a woman as executive editor on Monday, a first in its 65-year history.

title: Judge Upholds Indictment in Letterman Extortion Case
description: A Manhattan judge on Tuesday upheld the indictment of an Emmy Award-winning television producer accused of trying to extort $2 million from David Letterman.

title: Food for Thought | Copenhagens Coolest Dinner Theater
description: I love food, but I never actually wept over a meal until dessert at a former beer warehouse in Copenhagen last summer. I was at Madeleines Madteater  a kind of interactive dinner performance staged every few months in the neighborhood of Islands Brygge  eating nougat semifreddo while tightly wrapped together with a group of Danes in a stretchy white shroud, behind which waitstaff crept, caressing my back and pressing ghostlike faces through the fabric. There were lyrical strings and a dramatic chiaroscuro and a dancer undulating on the serving dais, and it was all gemtlichkeit, and ritual, and the sadness of endings, and  yes, I know this makes no sense. You had to be there. That is the point. Its art you experience with all five senses, the most satisfying performance in town. Madteater is precisely as its name translates: food theater.Unsurprisingly, Madeleines is named for Proust. The project, which started in 2006, is a collaboration between the chef Mette Sia Martinussen and the film production designer Nikolaj Danielsen, along with a board of directors that includes an anthropologist, a psychotherapist, a couple of artists and a neurology professor conducting research into the senses. But this is no gimmick; its still very much about the food. Martinussen has long occupied a prime spot in the Modern Scandinavian cooking scene. She co-owned the experimental restaurant Ester & Soja with Claus Meyer, the chef of Copenhagens beloved Noma. And in 2001 she and Danielsen opened a conceptual dining room called 1.th (First Floor to the Right), following it the next year with the experimental traveling restaurant MetteSias Sommerbus.

title: Erich Segal, Scholar and Author, Is Dead at 72
description: Erich Segal, a classics scholar who taught at Harvard, Yale, Princeton and Oxford but who was best known for creating two of the most enduring pop stories of the 1960s  he wrote the novel Love Story and was a co-writer of the screenplay for the Beatles movie Yellow Submarine  died on Sunday in London. He was 72.

title: Group Hug | Gucci, Versace, McQueen
description: MILAN  Yesterdays shows here continued to echo the emphasis that designers have placed on projecting authenticity. Guccis Frida Giannini went back to the houses classic signatures, with 70s-inflected suits and turtlenecks, updated loafers with a bumped sole and wool sweaters trimmed in suede. The idea was to make sure there was something special for every kind of guy  though the decadent otter blazer or Mongolian lamb evening jackets are definitely for the wild at heart.

title: Fearing Hackers Who Leave No Trace
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  The crown jewels of Google, Cisco Systems or any other technology company are the millions of lines of programming instructions, known as source code, that make its products run.

title: Erich Segal, Love Story Author, Dies at 72
description: Erich Segal, a Yale classics professor turned popular writer whose first novel, Love Story, became a staggering commercial success if not quite a critical one when it appeared in 1970, died on Sunday at his home in London. He was 72.

title: Should a 96-Year-Old Proposition 8 Supporter Lose a Public Post?
description: Update | 2:39 p.m. Pacific Time  Mayor Ron Dellums will pull from Tuesday nights City Council agenda the reappointment of Lorenzo Hoopes and three others to the board of the city-owned Paramount Theater. The mayor is expected to make a decision on Mr. Hoopess reappoinment in the next week, said Paul Rose, a spokesman with the mayors office. The community asked us to reconsider and thats what were going to do, Mr. Rose said.

title: Postcard From London: Pinter With a Broken Heart
description: LONDON  British book reviewers have gone all fluttery of late over Must You Go?, Lady Antonia Frasers perfumed love poem of a memoir about her late husband, Harold Pinter. This portrait of marriage, which begins, I first saw Harold across a crowded room, is said to reveal the softer sentiments of a man known for stark dramas of human inhumanity. But you neednt buy Ms. Frasers book to uncover a streak of gentleness in Pinters makeup; that side of him is touchingly in evidence in the new production of The Caretaker that opened on Monday night at Trafalgar Studios, with Jonathan Pryce as the fetid old tramp Davies.

title: Confucius Shoves Avatar Aside
description: Avatar may be racking up awards and nominations  the latest come from the Visual Effects Society, whose members gave it nods in categories like, Outstanding Animated Character in a Live Action Feature Motion Picture  it is not so popular with Chinese authorities. Sharon LaFraniere reports that the film, the most commercially successful of in history there, will be pulled from 2-D theaters to make room for a biopic about Confucius that stars Chow-Yun Fat. (Which, by the way, the Bagger would also pay to see.)

title: The Real Pigou
description: Every intro text in economics talks about market-based techniques for dealing with pollution, and refers to Pigouvian taxes  effluent charges  as the right way to go (cap and trade can be equivalent). And Id always assumed that Pigou himself wrote about pollution.

title: Haiti Quake Day 8: Haiti's First Lady
description: The Times's Marc Lacey spoke with Haiti's first lady, Elizabeth Prval, who said that the Haitian government was still in place despite many buildings having been destroyed.

title: Kate McGarrigle, Singer and Songwriter, Has Died
description: Kate McGarrigle, a Canadian singer and songwriter who, with her sister Anna, had a repertory of intimate songs about love and family in good times and bad, died of liver cancer on Monday. She was 63 and died at her home in Montreal, her brother-in-law, Dane Lanken, told The Associated Press.

title: Jean Tschumi Drawings Are Donated to MoMA
description: The architect Bernard Tschumi has donated 43 drawings by his father, the Swiss architect Jean Tschumi, to the Museum of Modern Art, the younger Mr. Tschumi is to announce on Wednesday.

title: A Blog About Dad
description: Recent increases in lifespan have neatly coincided with the rise of the Internet, so its little wonder that caregivers have taken to sharing their observations, frustrations and occasional exultation online. Like support groups that meet in church basements or community centers, personal Web sites and blogs can provide validation, empathy, practical counsel and a safe place to vent.

title: Plan B
description: It sounds as if House Democrats  or at least their leadership  are prepared to pass the Senate bill if, as expected, they lose todays special election.

title: Bernanke Wants an Audit of Feds Bailout of A.I.G.
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Ben S. Bernanke, asked federal auditors on Tuesday to review the central banks role in the much criticized rescue of the American International Group in 2008.

title: Iraqis on Iraq  Diyala and Kirkuk
description: With international attention shifting from Iraq to Afghanistan, we asked Iraqi journalists working for The New York Times to give a personal view of the areas where they live. Their names are withheld because of the continuing threat to their lives.

title: Dealer Sues Woman to Cancel Good Deal
description: Update | 1:11 p.m. A dispute about the price of a Chrysler Pacifica between Walser Chrysler, a Minnesota car dealer, and the buyer, Tammie Townsend, has been settled, Ms. Townsends attorney, David Knodell, said Monday.

title: Robert B. Parker, Mystery Writer, Has Died at 77
description: Update | 4:25 p.m. Robert B. Parker, the best-selling mystery writer who created Spenser, a tough, glib, Boston private detective who was the hero of nearly 40 novels, died on Monday at home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 77.

title: Essay: Prison Break
description: The main prison in Port-au-Prince emptied after the earthquake last week. Those inmates who werent killed were free to walk through the rubble, into the heart of the city. And an estimated 4,000 of them did just that.

title: Vancouver Rolls Out Art for Olympics
description: Vancouver will celebrate the body in sport, as well as art, during the 2010 Winter Olympics next month.

title: And Multiply That by Nine Lives Apiece
description: With the regularity of exploding manholes, cases of cat-hoarding crop up in the news. On Monday, workers from the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and the citys Animal Care and Control agency, summoned by a neighbors complaint, went to a one-bedroom apartment in East New York, Brooklyn, where two cats Kima Graham adopted five years ago had somehow managed to produce 33 more.

title: Wives Who Bring Home the Bacon
description: As my colleague Sam Roberts writes, the Pew Research Center today released a report on wives who outrank their husbands in both income and education.

title: Pre-Carnival Cruising | Rio Fashion Week
description: Jesus Luz might currently be Rios most famous export, but at last weeks Fashion Rio, it was clear that the Brazilian city has much more to offer than man candy. Infused with positive energy from the announcement of the 2016 Olympics, several designers sent out strong shows that demonstrated mastery of much more than the itsy-bitsy bikini.Rio is first and foremost a beach town, and many designers give laid-back style an haute bourgeois spin that appeals to the citys social elite. Take Victor Dzenk, who sent out flowing Grecian gowns of laser-cut silk chiffon to the strains of a spotlighted harpist deluged by a rain of confetti. The collection was the last word in camp, but the front rows ladies who lunch were eating it up.

title: Police Say Davis Crashed Into a Driveway Gate
description: The all-terrain vehicle accident that knocked the snowboarder Danny Davis out of his likely place on the United States Olympics team occurred at 3:30 a.m. Sunday. According to a report from the Summit County, Utah, sheriffs department, Davis was on a four-wheel vehicle that slammed into a closed gate at the end of a driveway. The report said that Davis was thrown from the vehicle and later found unconscious by friends, with injuries to his legs. Other news media reports said that Davis was not alone, but it was not clear who was driving.

title: Update on Massachusetts Senate Race
description: Adam Nagourney, The Times's chief political correspondent, assesses the race between the Democrat Martha Coakley and the Republican Scott Brown for the state's seat previously held by Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Bernanke Asks for Review of Feds A.I.G. Bailout
description: Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, on Tuesday asked the investigative arm of Congress to conduct a full review of the Feds publicly derided bailout of the insurance giant American International Group, The Associated Press reports.

title: Super Bowl XLIV and the Hall of Fame
description: Chase Stuart, a lawyer, Jets fan and statistical analyst, writes for the Pro-Football-Reference.com blog.

title: JAL Bankruptcy Filing Sets Off Reorganization and State-Led Bailout
description: TOKYO  Japan Airlines, the once-mighty flagship carrier and Asias biggest airline, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday, setting the stage for a state-led bailout that could bring sweeping changes to this corner of the global aviation market.

title: Citi Benefiting for Now From Homeowner Aid
description: The governments program to keep families in their homes also appears to be helping Citigroups bottom line  for the time being, that is.

title: Why You Can Get Written Confirmation From Comcast Now
description: Thanks to the efforts of Marc Pachtman, you can now more confidently ask for a written confirmation of agreements with Comcast cable customer service phone representatives.

title: Exploring Bordeauxs Other Side
description: IN a few months, Bordeaux will offer the first tastes of its highly touted 2009 vintage to members of the trade and wine writers. All concerned will debate which are the best bottles and no doubt lament the high prices they foresee for the top-classified wines.

title: Pairings: Chicken Baked With Lentils
description: Hardly show-offs, the Bordeaux wines priced less than $20 are workmanlike, perhaps a little brash, but they are fine to accompany a straightforward plate of food.

title: Tasting Report: Affordable Terroir
description: BEST VALUE

title: U.S. Ski Chief: We Still Aspire to Be Best in the World
description: For several years, the slogan of the United States ski team has been, Best in the World. At the 2006 Turin Olympics, this motivational motto was perceived by the international community as more of a battle cry and, rightly or wrongly, a rather haughty one at that. In a memorable scene following the 2006 Olympic mens giant slalom, after Austrias Benjamin Raich and Hermann Maier finished first and third, Maier mocked the American slogan.

title: Poe Toaster Is a No-Show
description: There are some secrets which do not permit themselves to be told, Edgar Allan Poe wrote in his 1845 short story The Man of the Crowd.

title: A Hard-Earned Victory for Youzhny
description: Margaret Court Arena was not packed with spectators, but the vocal, fiercely partisan crowd witnessed a gutsy and resourceful performance by the Russian Mikhail Youzhny. Down by two sets to love against the immensely talented Frenchman Richard Gasquet, Youzhny clawed his way back into the first-round match, winning back to back tie-breakers, forcing a fifth set despite cramping in his left quadriceps.

title: Teacher With Bible Divides Ohio Town
description: MOUNT VERNON, Ohio  Most people in this quiet all-American town describe themselves as devoutly Christian, but even here they are deeply divided over what should happen to John Freshwater.

title: A Robber in the Village Looks Improbably Familiar
description: A mini-crime wave in the boutiques and specialty shops of Greenwich Village has a face, and it looks an awful lot like William S. Burroughs.

title: Jury for the Future Generation Art Prize Announced
description: The Future Generation Art Prize, a new $100,000 award for artists under age 35 created by the Ukrainian billionaire and art collector Victor Pinchuk, has announced the members of the prizes jury, and many of the names are well-traveled ones on the international art circuit: Daniel Birnbaum, the director of the Stdelschule art academy in Frankfurt, Germany, and the director of the 2009 Venice Biennale; Robert Storr, the dean of the Yale University School of Art and the director of the Venice Biennale in 2007; Okwui Enwezor, the director of Documenta XI in 2002 and a highly sought-after curator and writer; and Ai Weiwei, probably Chinas most famous living artist.

title: White House Looks Again to Senator Snowe
description: The White House says it hasnt given up on getting Senator Olympia Snowe, Republican of Maine, to vote in favor of a health care overhaul.

title: The Morning Skate: The Auger-Burrows Controversy Spreads
description: With so many big hockey stories out there, its hard not to feel a thousand miles behind in covering them, but well try to play a bit of catch-up here. With luck, only one or two new ones will break today (oops), Mike Peca retired; oops, Chris Osgood gets the start tonight for the Wings; oops, Petr Sykora is on waivers, oops. Mario Lemieux discloses he retired as a player in 2006 due to an irregular heartbeat).

title: White House Promotes Rescue Video
description: The Obama White House has been running an aggressive public relations campaign out of Haiti, to spotlight the efforts of American troops and local search and rescue teams.

title: Update: OBrien Talks Held Up Over Staff Severance
description: With most of the television industry anticipating a formal announcement Tuesday of the widely expected exit of Conan OBrien from NBCs late-night lineup and the restoration of Jay Leno as host of the Tonight Show, the negotiations continued to be held up on one issue, according to representatives on both sides of the talks.

title: Pakistani Scientist Is Removed From Court as Trial Begins
description: A Pakistani neuroscientist who is accused of opening fire on American soldiers and F.B.I. agents while being detained in Afghanistan in July 2008 finally faced jurors in Lower Manhattan on Tuesday, after months of delays in her trial.

title: Blogging the Massachusetts Senate Race
description: Democrats Already Regrouping | 11:41 p.m.  Along with the hand-wringing by Democrats tonight in Washington, were told that there also was a fair bit of dialing. On the telephone, that is, as party leaders placed calls to some of the most vulnerable Democrats in the House and Senate.

title: Hoyer on Senate Bill: Better Than Nothing
description: The House majority leader, Representative Steny H. Hoyer, Democrat of Maryland, offered a backhanded endorsement of the Senate health care bill on Monday, saying it was better than nothing.

title: New Tenant Lifts a Manhattan Street
description: The sunken plaza at 182 East 86th Street had been abandoned for so long it had begun to spook neighbors.

title: Lesson on Limits of Eminent Domain at Columbia
description: In 2005, the United States Supreme Court upheld the right of officials in New London, Conn., to force the sale of private homes in a waterfront neighborhood to make way for a development project intended to improve the citys tax base. The decision caused an uproar around the country, spurring 43 states to pass legislation limiting, to one degree or another, the use of eminent domain.

title: Feng Shui in Austria
description: A six-bedroom three-and-a-half-bath contemporary near Salzburg is on the market for 890,000 euros ($1.3 million).

title: As Different as Night and Day
description: WHEN my two older daughters arrived home from college for winter break, they suddenly behaved in all the ways that I once believed would make me the happiest mother in the world.

title: $64.2 Billion Payday Seen for Wall Street
