description: New Yorks financial sector will pay $64.2 billion in bonuses this year, up from an estimated $57 billion in 2009, though this years amount would still be about $19 billion less than the amount paid out in 2008, the state budget division forecast on Tuesday in its revenue outlook.

title: Queens Man Is Accused in Plot to Kill Service Members
description: A federal prosecutor told a judge on Tuesday that a man who traveled to Pakistan in 2008 to attend a Qaeda training camp conspired to kill American service members in Afghanistan.

title: Is Obamas Liberalism The Problem?
description: The consensus on the left is a resounding no. According to Jonathan Chait, Matt Yglesias, E.J. Dionne, and many others, Obamas political difficulties are explained by a lousy economy, rather than a public backlash against liberalism. Like Ronald Reagan, who suffered a similar first-term swoon, the president is a prisoner of circumstance: His program is suddenly unpopular not because its too liberal and ambitious, but because the unemployment rate is around 10 percent and holding. In this climate, any agenda would be unpopular, and Obama would having exactly the same problems if hed governed as a cautious incrementalist rather than a would-be Lyndon Johnson.

title: Mauresmos Quiet Mark on Tennis
description: Eleven years ago Amelie Mauresmo burst on to the international tennis scene by upsetting three seeded players en route to the final of the Australian Open, where Martina Hingis ended her run. After her upset of Lindsay Davenport, Mauresmo came out as an openly gay woman at her news conference after the match. Her athleticism and long flowing strokes, especially her one-handed backhand, took the tennis world by storm. Her future looked limitless.

title: Q&A: Exploring the Kenai Peninsula
description: Q.

title: Pictures of the Day: Tuesday, Jan. 19
description: Comings and goings in Port-au-Prince. Coming: the 82nd Airborne, arriving by helicopter on the grounds of the ruined Presidential Palace. Going: thousands of citizens who have been living for a week with little or no food, water, shelter, power and waste removal. The latest post on Lens about the situation in Haiti, Damon Winters Essay: Prison Break, takes viewers inside the main prison in Port-au-Prince; now absent any prisoners.

title: Project Haiti: Holding a Teach-In
description: Overview | What are the effects of the earthquake in Haiti? What issues, problems and questions has the disaster caused and raised? How are students responding personally, and how can they help? In this lesson, students either participate in a personal response activity or engage in an in-depth teach-in project, researching topics related to the earthquake and presenting their findings to the community. They then develop proposals for a community service plan and choose one or more to implement.

title: Scorecard | Prada Wins!
description: Scorecard here, your handily reductive afternoon recap of all thats new in Milan mens fashion. Day 2 on the catwalks was still all about heritage dressing. At Gianfranco Ferr, Tommaso Aquilano and Roberto Rimondis latest take on the house codes failed to square the circle. Meanwhile, Miuccia Prada proved that sometimes to move forward you need to look back to the 70s  by way of your own witty ugly-chic aesthetic, that is.

title: Ad Industry Increases Efforts for Haiti
description: The response to the Haitian earthquake in the advertising community continues to gain momentum.

title: House Hunting in ... Austria
description: A SIX-BEDROOM THREE-AND-A-HALF-BATH CONTEMPORARY NEAR SALZBURG

title: Is All Fair in Love and Debt Collecting?
description: Ethics in business is generally black and white. Dont lie. Do the right thing. Treat people fairly. If you have a good moral compass, it usually does not require much thought to run an ethical business. Or to be an ethical person. There are, however, occasions that make you stop and think. Here is one of them:

title: Reading Apples Tea Leaves
description: Moments after Apple sent an invitation to journalists on Monday in advance of an event next week, the invitation itself came under the kind of intense scrutiny that was once seen only when a new photo emerged of the Kremlins leadership.

title: Where Does a Mothers Time Go?
description: Two articles published in the past few days explore how a mother spends her time. Neither one is relaxing reading.

title: A Barter for a Lease in Lebanon
description: Kamal Mouzawak and Rabih Kayrouz bartered for their vacation home in Batroun, about 25 miles northeast of Beirut.

title: Supreme Court Rules on Trial Conduct in Georgia
description: WASHINGTON  Unusual practices in Georgia trial courts, including off-color gifts to court personnel from jurors in a capital case, were the subjects of a pair of unsigned Supreme Court decisions on Tuesday.

title: City Hall to Start Shuffling Top Deputies
description: Moving to fulfill a promise made in his inaugural address, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Tuesday ordered that a top deputy in each city agency spend three weeks in another agency in an attempt to improve management habits.

title: Susan Boyle Shut Out of Brit Awards
description: The shortlist for the Brit Awards, Britains version of the Grammys, seems at least one name too short to many fans. Susan Boyle, whose rocket to fame began in April after her appearance on Britains Got Talent and whose first record just finished a six-week run at the top of the Billboard album chart, selling more than 3 million copies, was nowhere to be seen among the nominations, which include ones for Lady Gaga, Lily Allen and the newcomer Pixie Lott. The winner will be announced on Feb. 16 at a ceremony in London.

title: A Big Map That Shrank the World
description: WASHINGTON  When a map of overwhelming dimensions and detail is presented to the ruler of a land, the homage, surely, is a kind of deference. The map is partly meant to be an illustration of the rulers powers, the extent of his realm, the range of learning he commands.

title: Renovating for Rent, a Lebanese Retreat
description: It seemed they fell in love with the wrong house. In early 2004, Kamal Mouzawak, the founder of Beiruts twice-weekly farmers market Souk el Tayeb, and Rabih Kayrouz, a Lebanese fashion designer, were looking for a second home in the Lebanese countryside or perhaps the mountains, a place where they could escape their busy work lives and the bustle of Beirut. But it was a house in Batroun, a the seaside town about 25 miles northeast of Beirut, that swept them off their feet.

title: Ford to Take Leave From Merrill to Campaign
description: Harold Ford Jr., the Merrill Lynch vice chairman who is weighing a challenge to Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand, is taking a 30-day leave of absence from the Wall Street firm.

title: A Bitter Family Tradition of Low Expectations
description: Theres more than a little Death of a Salesman in Sean Cullens Safe Home, but Mr. Cullens forlorn characters could never dream of a career as grand as sales.

title: Tiny Steps Toward Basic Services
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Almost every wing of St.-Franois de Sales Hospital lies in ruins. But about 68 doctors and nurses have turned what is left into a triage center that performed at least 17 operations Tuesday.

title: Answers About Roth I.R.A. Conversions: Part 3
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks in which youll have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: The Youngest of the Capsouto Frres Dies
description: Albert Capsouto, the youngest of three brothers who in 1980 started Capsouto Frres, one of the first of the more high-end restaurants in TriBeCa, died today from a brain tumor that was discovered two months ago. He would have been 54 next Tuesday.

title: The Balkan Burger
description: Pljeskavica, the wide, thin patties that can be made with a mixture of beef, pork, veal and lamb, has arrived in New York.

title: David Sarkisyan, Champion of Moscow Architecture, Dies at 62
description: MOSCOW  David Sarkisyan, a former physiologist and film director who became famous as the director of the Shchusev State Museum of Architecture here and for his campaigns to preserve architectural monuments against rampant post-Soviet development, died on Jan. 7 in Munich, where he had been hospitalized. He was 62.

title: Accentuating Helen Mirren
description: For the Baggers nonexistent money, one of the juiciest races this season is for best actress. Meryl Streep (Julie & Julia) and Sandra Bullock (The Blind Side) both won at the Golden Globes, which recognize comedy and drama in separate categories, and tied at the Critics Choice Awards; the two, along with Carey Mulligan (An Education), Gabourey Sidibe (Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire) and Helen Mirren (The Last Station), are nominated for a Screen Actors Guild award.

title: App of the Week: Hop on a Suite of Free Voice Services
description: As iPhone users await an outcome in Apples decision to withhold Google Voice (and the subsequent F.C.C. inquiry), they dont have to go entirely without the features of Google Voice. Many are available through an app called Ribbit Mobile.

title: Security Ahead? Pack Patience
description: SINCE the Transportation Security Administration began tightening security in response to the Christmas Day bombing plot, travelers have faced increasingly rigorous screenings at airports. Theyve been forced to cope with extra bag checks, closer scrutiny of their identification, and full body pat-downs that include children as well as adults.

title: T. Boone Pickens Tweaks His Energy Plan
description: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas billionaire, got his first car, a 1942 Ford, in 1946. But in an interview today at The New York Times, he made it plain that the national romance with the automobile was beyond his reckoning. America is nuts about cars, he said. I dont quite understand this thing about horsepower. Cars are not a big deal to me, but they are a big deal to a lot of people.

title: Voices From the Race
description: The New York Times asked Boston-area voters their thoughts on the special election.

title: Evidence Found for Chinese Attack on Google
description: SAN FRANCISCO  An American computer security researcher has found what he says he believes is strong evidence of the digital fingerprints of Chinese authors in the software programs used in attacks against Google.

title: Dynamo Twosomes European Reception Is Mixed
description: Two Houston Dynamo midfielders looking for opportunities overseas received mixed news Tuesday. After Stuart Holden was told his services would not be needed at Bolton, fellow American Ricardo Clark was signed by Eintracht Frankfurt in the German Bundesliga.

title: Brit Awards Nominees
description: The shortlist for the Brit Awards, Britains equivalent of the Grammys, seems at least one name too short to many fans. Susan Boyle, above, who rocketed to fame last April after her appearance on Britains Got Talent and whose first record just finished a six-week run at the top of the Billboard album chart, selling more than three million copies, was nowhere to be seen among the nominees, who include Lady GaGa, Lily Allen, Taylor Swift, Jay-Z, Bruce Springsteen and the newcomer Pixie Lott. The winners will be announced on Feb. 16 at a ceremony in London.

title: Funny Night for CBS
description: CBSs Monday night comedy lineup finished on top of the ratings race, as usual, as Two and a Half Men at 9 and The Big Bang Theory at 9:30 delivered the evenings largest audiences. According to Nielsens estimates, 16.2 million viewers tuned into Men and 15 million watched Big Bang. In the 8 oclock hour, CBSs How I Met Your Mother and Accidentally on Purpose posted season highs with 10.5 million and 9.6 million viewers. Fox ranked second for the night with a two-hour installment of the new season of 24, which averaged 11 million viewers from 8 to 10, edging past The Bachelor on ABC in the same time period (10.6 million). ABC finished in third place for the night, with 9.4 million at 10 for Castle, which trailed CBSs CSI: Miami (13.2 million) in its time slot but outpaced The Jay Leno Show on NBC (4.6 million). NBC was a distant fourth, garnering 6.7 million for Chuck at 8 but just 3.9 million at 9 for Heroes.

title: $100,000 Art Prize
description: The Future Generation Art Prize, a new $100,000 award for artists younger than 35, created by the Ukrainian billionaire and art collector Victor Pinchuk, has announced the members of the prizes jury, and many of the names are well traveled on the international art circuit. They include Daniel Birnbaum, the director of the Stdelschule Art Academy in Frankfurt and the director of the 2009 Venice Biennale; Robert Storr, the dean of the Yale University School of Art and the director of the Venice Biennale two years before that; Okwui Enwezor, the director of Documenta XI in 2002 and a highly sought-after curator and writer; and Ai Weiwei, probably Chinas most famous living artist. The Victor Pinchuk Foundation, a nonprofit organization founded in 2006, also announced that it had begun to accept entries from artists, who can submit applications online at futuregenerationartprize.org through April 18. The prize will be awarded every two years, along with a more populist noncash side award, the Peoples Choice Prize, to be determined by a public online vote,  la American Idol.

title: Early Play at the Australian Open
description: The first round of the Australian Open was pretty true to form, reports Joe Drape from Melbourne. What can fans expect as the tournament progresses?

title: Big Plans for Coachella
description: Jay-Z, Muse and Gorillaz will headline the 11th annual Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival when that sprawling rock event gets under way on April 16 in Indio, Calif., planners announced on Tuesday. They are hoping to maintain the momentum from last year, when the festival drew its second-highest crowds, despite the economic downturn. The big news from the show is that it will serve as a stop on what seems to be shaping up as a sizable reunion tour for the long-lamented lo-fi band Pavement, which broke up a decade ago. Along with bands of the moment like Vampire Weekend, Dirty Projectors, Girls and Grizzly Bear, this years lineup includes some venerable names like Gil Scott-Heron, Grace Jones, Devo and Sly and the Family Stone, along with a few oddball entries like the filmmaker John Waters (maybe hell do his rendition of Mama, Im a Big Girl Now from Hairspray?) and D J Lance Rock, of the hipster childrens show Yo Gabba Gabba fame.

title: Is Poe to Be Toasted Nevermore?
description: There are some secrets which do not permit themselves to be told, Edgar Allan Poe wrote in his 1845 short story The Man of the Crowd. And since 1949 one such secret has attended Poes final resting place in Baltimore at the Westminster Hall and Burying Ground, where a black-clad figure has shown up annually early on the morning of Jan. 19, the authors birthday, to raise a Cognac toast to his grave and deposit three red roses, along with the remnants of the Cognac bottle. But the visitor  whose identity, or identities, has never been revealed, despite some claims to the contrary over the years  failed to show up this year for the first time, ending a strange crepuscular tradition and disappointing a crowd of more than 30 people who forfeited a good nights sleep to witness the visitation. I was very annoyed, Jeff Jerome, curator of the Edgar Allan Poe House, told The Baltimore Sun. Ive been doing this since 1977, and there was no indication he wasnt going to show up. Some conjectured that the Poe Toaster, as the visitor has come to be known, might have just had the flu or car trouble. But Mr. Jerome spoke with a Poe-ian air of finality. Last year was the bicentennial of Poes birthday, he said. And if it was going to end, he said, that would be the perfect time to end it.

title: MoMA to Receive Jean Tschumi Drawings
description: The architect Bernard Tschumi has donated 43 drawings by his father, the Swiss architect Jean Tschumi, to the Museum of Modern Art, the younger Mr. Tschumi is to announce on Wednesday. Jean Tschumi, who died in 1962 at 57, helped influence modern architecture and design in the mid-20th century and became an influential figure in architectural education and practice. The works on paper range from Mr. Tschumis early work while a student in Paris to his last project, the Nestl headquarters in Vevey, Switzerland. With this gift MoMA becomes the only institution outside of Europe to house a collection of drawings by Mr. Tschumi; the majority of his drawings are in the Archives of Modern Construction at the Lausanne Polytechnique, whose architecture school Mr. Tschumi founded in 1942, and in Basel in the collection of the pharmaceutical giant Novartis, formerly Sandoz, for which Mr. Tschumi built headquarters and laboratories in Switzerland and France. (Mr. Tschumis desk for the company director, above.) His notable works include the headquarters building of the World Heath Organization in Geneva. I think he was very ambitious and at the same time a little ironical about the pitfalls of fame, Bernard Tschumi said in a telephone interview from Paris on Tuesday. I think he would have been extremely pleased, but with a twinkle in his eye.
Olivia Judson is away this week.

title: Sex and the Digital City
description: Last week, reputable Web sites reported that semi-reputable Web sites had reported that Tiger Woods entered a Mississippi clinic for sex-addiction rehab. Meanwhile, South Carolinas legislature rebuked Gov. Mark Sanford for bringing disgrace and shame to the state via his extramarital affair with an Argentine journalist. And NBC aired a Law & Order episode apparently based on the alleged attempt to blackmail David Letterman over his staff liaisons.

title: Poet in Exile, Still Gripping His Memories
description: Late in A Room and a Half, a rich, heady fictionalized biography of the exiled Russian poet Joseph Brodsky, the middle-aged Brodsky ruefully reflects in a voice-over about how children are in a desperate hurry to leave the nest.

title: Now Screening | Dsquared
description: The fall 2010 collection from Dsquared.

title: Beekeeping in Koraro
description: The following is the third in a series of reports from the Ethiopian village of Koraro, an important testing ground for the Millennium Village Project, an experiment in global development strategy spearheaded by economist Jeffrey Sachs. The reports, written by Jeff Marlow, a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, consider which parts of the project are working and which ones arent, and what can be learned from it to help billions of people escape extreme poverty.

title: Christian-Muslim Mayhem in Nigeria Kills Dozens
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Armed with guns, machetes, torches, and bows and arrows, Christian and Muslim antagonists in central Nigerias religiously volatile city of Jos have been fighting for three days in sporadic clashes that have left dozens dead, witnesses and local news accounts said Tuesday.

title: Exec Rejoins Credit Suisse From Renaissance
description: Neil Harvey is leaving his position as deputy chief executive of the Renaissance Group to head up Credit Suisses effort to build its asset management business in Asia and other emerging markets. Mr. Harvey will be based in Hong Kong and report to Robert Shafir, chief executive of asset management, and Kai Nargolwala, chief executive of the Asia Pacific region.

title: Grass Fed | Working for Peanuts
description: If three is a trend, then peanuts are hot! Look! Theyre on the menu at brand-new Flatiron restaurant Rye House, boiled, right next to sweetbreads done Buffalo-style. Look! Theyre on the short menu of the weeks-old Baohaus, which is neither German nor arty, but instead a subterranean Asian eatery on the Lower East Side that slings steamed Taiwanese buns and boils up peanuts with a little rice vinegar in the brine. And theyre on the menu at that high church of hipness, the Breslin, the spawn of the Spotted Pig in the Ace Hotel, where April Bloomfield has married them to pork fat.

title: The Battle for a Senate Seat
description: Massachusetts voters came out in what became a surprisingly tight special election for the United States Senate.

title: What Were Reading
description: On The Moment, dinner as interactive performance art.

title: With One Word, Adding a Twist to a Prostitution Case
description: Slept through conjunction lessons in third grade? Well, heres a reason you might want to freshen up.

title: The Nifty 50 | Byrdie Bell, Actress
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Perspectives on Haiti's Earthquake
description: A collection of audio interviews, added to daily, with people directly involved in the aftermath of the earthquake.

title: Tavern Is in a Deeper Hole Than Was Thought
description: Now that the dust has settled from the auction last week of $3.5 million in items from the bankrupt Tavern on the Green, one thing is clearer. Tavern owes a lot more money than was realized.

title: Online, Its the Mouse That Runs the Museum
description: One morning last fall Judson Box woke up early to tend the horses at his farm near Leesburg, Fla. Before he could sit down to breakfast, however, his wife waved him over to the color TV that doubles as their home computer, thanks to an old WebTV setup. As Mr. Box leaned in closer to the grainy 17-inch screen, he started to make out the image of a fireman running through a tunnel.

title: Rubbernecking at the Capsule Trade Show
description: While Ts mens editors survey the pompadours (see Bottega Veneta) and hot pink camouflage (Hello, Prada!) on the runways in Milan, I will be making my rounds at the trade shows taking place in New York this week. First up: Capsule. Street fashion, new washes of denim, bold and bright sneakers along with reinterpreted brogues, the latest take on American workwear, etc. are all on display under two roofs (the Puck Building, 295 Lafayette Street, and Angel Orensanz Center, 172 Norfolk Street).

title: The Charge: Not So Much Cash 4 That Gold
description: The flashy ads have become a staple on late-night television, sometimes featuring figures like the late Ed McMahon or M.C. Hammer, trumpeting promises of quick dollars in exchange for bits of old gold jewelry.

title: Properties for $350,000
description: A condo in Memphis, a adobe in Cerrillos, N.M., and a house in Gloucester, Mass.

title: A Late Bloomer, Still Reveling in the Spotlight
description: Pop Star on Ice, David Barba and James Pelleritos swoony documentary about the figure-skating champion Johnny Weir, is one part hagiography and two parts psychotherapy. Together they showcase a talent both formidable and erratic, its bright and shining peaks sliding inexplicably into valleys of disaster.

title: Leave No Sin Untaxed
description: Gov. David A. Paterson got a bit freewheeling on Tuesday in his bid to close the states canyonesque budget gap, unveiling proposals to legalize ultimate fighting, let supermarkets sell wine and expand the hours of video slot-machine parlors.

title: What You Get for ... $350,000
description: MEMPHIS

title: After Atom Bombs Shock, the Real Horrors Began Unfolding
description: When Tsutomu Yamaguchi died two weeks ago, at 93, he was eulogized as a star-crossed rarity: a man who lived through two atomic blasts, at Hiroshima and then at Nagasaki. He was a man with very good luck, or very bad luck. Its hard to decide.

title: High-Wattage Guests for Conan OBriens Waning Days
description: With the close of his Tonight show tenure looming, Conan OBrien is bringing in a full roster of big names in what looks like his last week, including a doubleheaded A-list for his apparently last night: Tom Hanks and Will Ferrell.

title: Now Screening | Giorgio Armani
description: The fall 2010 collection from Giorgio Armani.

title: The Last Train From Hiroshima
description: Chapter 1: The Killing Star

title: At Milans Fall Shows, the Clothes Go Marching On
description: Milan

title: Taking Office, Christie Sees States Last Hope for Turnaround
description: TRENTON  Saying he would not squander New Jerseys last, best hope to reverse its decline, Christopher J. Christie took office on Tuesday as the states 55th governor, vowing to break through partisan gridlock to bring about lower taxes, economic resurgence and school choice.

title: Guinea Junta Picks Opponent as Premier on Path to Civilian Control
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Guineas military leaders appointed a veteran opposition figure as prime minister on Monday, a critical step in the transition to elections and civilian government later in the year, officials and news agencies reported.

title: R.B.C. Names New U.S. Investment Banking Head
description: Update | 7:38 p.m. The Royal Bank of Canada said on Tuesday that it has hired a new head of United States investment banking and other bankers as the firm seeks to bolster its American footprint.

title: New York Fed Defends Move in A.I.G. Bailout
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York defended itself on Tuesday against complaints that it had told the American International Group not to disclose critical bailout details in public filings, saying it had only suggested deleting a sentence about paying the insurers trading partners 100 cents on the dollar because it was not in fact precisely accurate.

title: Snack Time Never Ends
description: OF the many horrors that lurk in the e-mail in-box of a working parent  dental reminders, Facebook invitations involving some weird farm, thoughts from the boss  nothing quite rivals the snack request.

title: A Sign of Latin Americas Fading Polarization
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  The election of a billionaire from a right-wing party as Chiles president on Sunday appears to be less a signal of a regional move to the right than that of a pragmatic convergence of left and right agendas.

title: Medical Miracle Nears a Milepost
description: In the dozen years since brain surgery brought relief from debilitating epileptic seizures, Diane Van Deren has become one of the worlds top endurance runners. She regularly competes in long-distance tests of perseverance, 100 miles or more through wicked terrain and tortuous conditions. She won the 300-mile Yukon Arctic Ultra two years ago, pulling a sled through the depths of winter, and was the first woman to complete the 430-mile version last year.

title: How About a Snack?
description: With three children and a high-powered job in Los Angeles, Sheri Kaiserman is not easily unnerved. But she often feels done in by the doughnuts of others.

title: Tavern on the Green Is in a Deeper Hole
description: From Glenn Collins at Diners Journal:

title: Taxing Wall Street Down to Size
description: WHILE supply-side catechism insists that lower taxes are a growth tonic, the theory also argues that if you want less of something, tax it more. The economy desperately needs less of our bloated, unproductive and increasingly parasitic banking system. In this respect, the White House appears to have gone over to the supply side with its proposed tax on big banks, as it scores populist points against the banksters, too.

title: Return Our Investment
description: Chicago

title: In Europe, Steps to Cracking Down on Tax Evasion
description: European finance ministers said on Tuesday that they had made progress in plans to crack down on tax evasion. At the same time, the ministers delayed dealing with the most delicate issues related to exchanging details on individuals tax matters.

title: Economics of Haiti Aid Efforts
description: A roundup of some of the more provocative pieces from around the econoblogosphere that have been inspired by the Haiti relief efforts:

title: Yelps Divide Between Businesses and Reviewers
description: In the February issue of Inc. magazine, Max Chafkin writes about the sometimes bitter split between reviewers on Yelp and the businesses they critique.

title: Polanski Lawyers Say Prosecutors Misled Swiss
description: LOS ANGELES  In their latest filing with the Los Angeles Superior Court, lawyers for Roman Polanski on Tuesday said officials with the district attorneys office here had intentionally misled the Swiss government with a false record of Mr. Polanskis long-running sex case as a way to secure his extradition from that country illegally.

title: At Age 11, Balancing Olympic Ambition and Youth
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  At age 11, Polina Edmunds is young enough to carry a teddy bear for good luck, but old enough to be a veteran dreamer of an Olympic gold medal in figure skating.

title: When Fingers Would Fumble, Chefs Turn to Tweezers
description: EVERY so often, a tool will leap across professional borders and become standard in restaurant kitchens. The blowtorch, we now know, caramelizes as well as it solders. Today, the woodworkers Microplane rasp is far more likely to zest a lemon than shape a credenza.

title: MXco
description: 1491 Second Avenue (78th Street), Upper East Side; (212) 249-6080.

title: Xian Famous Foods
description: 88 East Broadway No. 106, (entrance on Forsyth Street), Chinatown; no phone; xianfoods.com.

title: Benefits
description: THE food and wine industry is helping to raise money for victims of the earthquake in Haiti.

title: The Balkan Burger Unites All Factions
description: AMERICANS might think themselves masters of the all-beef patty, and Germans may claim bragging rights for its point of origin. But there is no burger passion greater than the one for pljeskavica.

title: Schatzies Meat Market Heads West
description: Tony Schatz, a k a Schatzie, above, a fifth-generation New York butcher who had a meat market on the Upper East Side for 30 years, has moved it to the Upper West Side. The East Side store closed Jan. 9. The new market almost looks as if it has been a neighborhood fixture for years, not days (vintage cash register, old-fashioned white tiles).

title: Raising a Glass With the Monks
description: The architecture and history of monasteries and abbeys make them popular tourist sites. Equipped with A Taste of Heaven: A Guide to Food and Drink Made by Monks and Nuns, by Madeline Scherb, those tourists may head for the gift shops first, to stock up on the wines, spirits, beers, cheeses, condiments and sweets, often from centuries-old recipes, that are made at many monasteries.

title: Bitters From Germany, to Kick Up Your Cocktails
description: The new-guard bartenders who have driven a cocktail frenzy in the last decade depend on bitters. These potent alcohol-based elixirs, usually made with herbs, citrus peels and other aromatics, are used by the droplet in well-made drinks.

title: School Adds Weeding to Reading and Writing
description: THOSE who believe trends start on the West Coast and are perfected on the East Coast might add to their argument a garden planned for an elementary school in Brooklyn.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening This Week

title: A Grab for Keepsakes as the Gavel Falls
description: IT was an everything-must-go sale, and everything went.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Beer and Steak ...

title: Roman Holiday
description: My review this week is of Maialino, which the restaurateur Danny Meyer recently opened on the ground floor of the Gramercy Park Hotel. The concept is that of a Roman trattoria.

title: Maialino
description: MAIALINO is the restaurateur Danny Meyers latest venture, a Roman-style trattoria at the Gramercy Park Hotel. It is warm and familiar, comfortable, a trattoria in an imaginary Rome where everyone comes from Missouri and wants you above all else to have a nice time.

title: F.H.A. to Raise Standards for Mortgage Insurance
description: The Federal Housing Administration, which is supporting the housing market by insuring thousands of new mortgages every day, is expected to announce on Wednesday that it is tightening standards.

title: A.I.G. Unit May Be Sold to MetLife
description: MetLife, where Robert H. Benmosche made his mark as an insurance executive, has emerged as the lead bidder for a major subsidiary of the American International Group, where Mr. Benmosche is now chief executive.

title: Russia Seeks to Cleanse Its Palate of U.S. Chicken
description: MOSCOW  At the mere mention of American chicken at a central Moscow market, the poultry vendors pounce.

title: The Surgical Touch
description: At Alinea in Chicago, David Beran assembles the garnishes for a pork belly dish: black sea salt, cucumber, garlic chips, bananas with curry, lime, onion, coconut, cashews, pepper puree and a citrus marigold mix. (Video: Peter Thompson)

title: Dolphins Home Receives Its 7th Name Since 1987
description: The home of the Miami Dolphins has a new name  Sun Life Stadium  in time for the Super Bowl.

title: CIT Appoints Interim Chief Executive
description: The CIT Group, the small- to midmarket lender, said late Tuesday that it has appointed a director, Peter J. Tobin, as its interim chief executive as it looks for a permanent new leader.

title: NBC Haunted by Its Knockout Bid for the Games
description: The Winter Olympics start in 23 days, and NBC expects to lose $200 million on them.

title: Berra Calls em as He Sees em
description: LA QUINTA, Calif.  Yogi Berra, the host of the 2010 Bob Hope Classic, spent part of Tuesday squinting into television lights, smiling for cameras and shaking hands.

title: Centrist, and Yet Not Unified
description: So what should happen with health reform now?

title: Molina Rebuffs Mets to Re-Sign With Giants
description: The Mets spent much of the off-season trying to persuade Bengie Molina to become their starting catcher, and they were relatively confident they could entice him to accept a one-year deal with a vesting option for a second season.

title: Decision Day at the Polls in Massachusetts
description: There was little ambivalence or hesitation at polling places around Massachusetts on Tuesday as voters selected a senator to succeed the late Edward M. Kennedy. After more than a week of nonstop television commercials, automated phone calls and even a campaign appearance by President Obama, voters were well aware that there was more at stake in this race than the fate of a single Senate seat.

title: The Trials of Gavin Newsom
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Google Hopes to Retain Business Unit in China
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Few people say they think Googles Chinese-language search engine will survive the companys confrontation with China.

title: Arrests for a Revealing Dance Pit Flesh Against Faith
description: BANDUNG, Indonesia  Known during colonial times as the Paris of Java, this easygoing city remains famous in Indonesia for its universities, cuisine, fashion and night life. Residents of Jakarta, the capital less than three hours away by car, come here for weekend getaways and trips to the countless factory outlets.

title: After Attack, Afghans Question Motives or See Conspiracies
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Twenty-four hours after seven insurgents stormed a shopping center in downtown Kabul and immobilized the city, the shoemakers who ply their trade in front of the mall were back in business on Tuesday.

title: The N.F.L. Is Squeezing Discounters Over Apparel
description: Howard Faber has been selling official N.F.L. jerseys, hats and sweatshirts online for more than a decade. His business includes about $200,000 worth of all brands of apparel in a warehouse near Detroit. As with many online stores, Fabers modest profit targets allow him to offer steep discounts.

title: Ex-Convicts From U.S. Said to Join Yemen Radicals
description: WASHINGTON  Some American former convicts who converted to Islam in prison have moved to Yemen and a few may have joined extremist groups there, according to a new Senate report.

title: China to Scan Text Messages to Spot Unhealthy Content
description: BEIJING  As the Chinese government expands what it calls a campaign against pornography, cellular companies in Beijing and Shanghai have been told to suspend text services to cellphone users who are found to have sent messages with illegal or unhealthy content, state-run news media reported Tuesday.

title: Mariners Join Trend by Signing Hernandez to Long Deal
description: Baseball teams yearn for young ace pitchers because they are very productive for so little cost. Players need six years of service to reach free agency, and because their early years are often their best, young stars can be extraordinary bargains.

title: Insider Faces Sentencing in 07 Case
description: A former hedge fund manager named Mark E. Lenowitz has been secretly cooperating with an expanding federal investigation of insider trading on Wall Street for more than two years, in hopes of reducing his jail time.

title: 53 Haitian Orphans Are Airlifted to U.S.
description: MIAMI  A group of 53 Haitian orphans landed in Pittsburgh on Tuesday morning, the first wave to arrive after the United States loosened its policy on visa requirements to expedite Americans adoptions of parentless children living in the post-earthquake ruins.

title: A Plea for the Stricken in Haiti
description: To the Editor:

title: Senator Dodds Mortgage
description: To the Editor:

title: Listening to Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Port in Kenya
description: To the Editor:

title: Calhoun Takes Leave for Medical Reasons
description: University of Connecticut Coach Jim Calhoun took an indefinite medical leave of absence Tuesday, with the institution citing temporary medical issues. The university declined to specify Calhouns medical issues or offer a timetable for his return.

title: In Federers So-So Win, No Reply to Rivals Hope
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  He has been Roger the Great for so long that when Roger Federer turns in a merely mortal performance, as he did Tuesday in the first round of the Australian Open, people start to wonder: whats wrong?

title: Mara Cites a Lack of Progress in Talks
description: The Giants co-owner John Mara said Tuesday he was resigned to an uncapped season in 2010 and thought the union and owners might be moving further apart in talks toward a new labor agreement.

title: Russia: Ukraine to Get Ambassador
description: President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia said on Tuesday that he would send an ambassador to neighboring Ukraine now that it appeared that the next Ukrainian president would try to begin mending relations with Moscow. Mr. Medvedev recalled Russias ambassador last year to protest what he said were the anti-Russian policies of the current Ukrainian president, Viktor A. Yushchenko. On Sunday, Mr. Yushchenko lost his bid for re-election. The next Ukrainian president will be decided in a runoff on Feb. 7 between the opposition leader, Viktor F. Yanukovich, and Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko. Both support improving ties to Russia.

title: Huge Payoff for I.B.M. After a Shift
description: The corporate technology industry is scrambling for higher ground, moving up from hardware into services and mixing in some business software. The goal is steady revenue, higher profit and tighter bonds with customers  and the model is I.B.M., which reported its quarterly results on Tuesday, finishing off a record year of profits for the company.

title: Virginia Gunman Kills 8 and Shoots at the Police
description: A gunman shot and killed eight people before firing on law enforcement officers and hitting a police helicopter on Tuesday in a thickly wooded area of south-central Virginia, a state police official said.

title: Interviews Begin for Ex-Aides to Ensign
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department has begun interviewing former aides to Senator John Ensign, Republican of Nevada, as part of a criminal inquiry into accusations that he arranged lobbying work for a onetime senior aide in the fallout from an affair he had with the aides wife, people with knowledge of the case said Tuesday.

title: Marines Land in Villages on Edge of Life and Death
description: LOGNE, Haiti  The Marine helicopters began landing just before noon on Tuesday in a cow pasture here in this heavily damaged farming town about nine miles south of Port-au-Prince, kicking up strong winds and drawing crowds of the curious and hopeful.

title: PGA Announces New Fall Tournament
description: A day after its surprise announcement naming Farmers Insurance as the title sponsor for next weeks event in San Diego, the PGA Tour followed up on Tuesday with the announcement of a new fall tournament to complete the 2010 schedule. The McGladrey Classic, sponsored by the accounting, tax and consulting firm RSM McGladrey, will be played from Oct. 7 to 10 at the Seaside Course at Sea Island Resort in Georgia. The event, with $4 million in prize money, will also expand the roster of tour players involved in high-level tournament operations positions. Davis Love III, a Sea Island resident, is the tournament chairman.

title: Microsoft Puts a Time Limit on Bing Data
description: Bowing to pressure in Europe, Microsoft said Tuesday that it would comply with regulators and discard all data collected on users of its Bing search engine after six months.

title: Issues Stand Before Israel in Joining Elite Group
description: JERUSALEM  Israel, which has catapulted in the past two decades from a minor state-dominated economy to a market-driven technology hothouse, is in the final stages of accession to the exclusive club of advanced countries, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. But its secretive weapons trade, patent-bending drug industry and occupation of Arab lands are raising last-minute questions.

title: Aspirants
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  ETTA James shows up frequently in crosswords. Ive seen her live  shes a fine blues singer  but her grid popularity has at least as much to do with that convenient letter combination as her innate talent or even her popularity. When constructors toss coins into fountains, they wish for another Etta or ENYA to make it big in any field of endeavor, just so they can have more variety in their clues.

title: Zeus Approves of Norv Turners Onside Kick
description: Frank Frigo and Chuck Bower developed the Zeus computer program, which can simulate hundreds of thousands of N.F.L. outcomes in seconds. They examined Norv Turners controversial decision to try an onside kick late in Sundays loss to the Jets.

title: Republican Wins in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON  Scott Brown, a little-known Republican state senator, rode an old pickup truck and a growing sense of unease among independent voters to an extraordinary upset Tuesday night when he was elected to fill the Senate seat that was long held by Edward M. Kennedy in the overwhelmingly Democratic state of Massachusetts.

title: Just Another Massachusetts Miracle
description: Scott Brown, a little-known Republican state legislator, will be the next junior senator from Massachusetts, and the message for Democrats is: it wont much matter? Well, at least in terms of health care reform, writes Paul Waldman at the American Prospect, who sees two paths ahead:

title: Webb Urges a Halt to Senate Health Care Votes
description: Responding to the Republican victory in Massachusetts, Senator Jim Webb, Democrat of Virginia, is calling on Senate leaders to suspend any votes on the Democrats health care legislation until the winner in the special Senate election, Scott Brown, is sworn into office.

title: Is China an Enron? (Part 2)
description: Last week, I wrote a column suggesting that while some overheated Chinese markets, like real estate, may offer shorting opportunities, Id be wary of the argument that Chinas economy today is just one big short-inviting bubble,  la Dubai. Your honor, Id like to now revise and amend my remarks.

title: Obama Pressing for Protections Against Lenders
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Tuesday stepped into the middle of a fierce lobbying battle by reinforcing his support for an independent agency to protect consumers against lending abuses that contributed to the financial crisis. The presidents move also signaled a tougher line and a more direct role as Congress weighs an overhaul of banking regulation.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Stan Kroenke, whose portfolio of teams has made him a powerful figure in sports, described incorrectly the hit that scored Enos Slaughter in the eighth inning of Game 7 of the 1946 World Series, helping the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Boston Red Sox. The batter, Harry Walker, was credited with a double on the play, which has come to be known as Slaughters mad dash; it was not a single.

title: Budget Ballot Initiatives Debated in Colorado
description: DENVER  Overturning Colorados Taxpayer Bill of Rights, a strict constitutional budget-collar known by its acronym, Tabor, is not on either major partys official to-do list for the 2010 election cycle.

title: Republicans Seize on Massachusetts Upset
description: Senate Republicans moved quickly on Tuesday night to cast the election results in Massachusetts as a referendum on the Democrats health care legislation and to urge the Democrats to abandon the bill.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 8 about two bombings in Afghanistan, one in Paktia Province and the other in neighboring Khost Province, misstated the area of Pakistan with which Paktia shares a border. It borders on the Kurram Agency, not North Waziristan.

title: Kraft to Acquire Cadbury in Deal Worth $19 Billion
description: After months of fiercely resisting any deal, Cadbury agreed on Tuesday to an improved takeover offer from Kraft Foods, worth about $19 billion.

title: Top Deputies Trading Places at City Hall
description: Moving to fulfill a promise made in his inaugural address, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Tuesday ordered that a top deputy in each city agency spend three weeks in another agency in an attempt to improve management habits.

title: Corrections
Corrections
description: The Movie Box Office listing in the Most Wanted chart on Monday reversed the revenue totals for The Blind Side and Leap Year. Leap Year was in eighth place with a weekly take of $5.9 million and overall revenue of $17.5 million in its two weeks of release. The Blind Side was in ninth place with a weekly take of $5.6 million and overall revenue of $226.8 million in nine weeks of release.

title: A Leaner Budget for Lean Times
description: Gov. David Paterson of New York presented a lean budget on Tuesday that is a necessarily austere response to the states financial crisis. It is certain to make almost everybody unhappy.

title: Secrets of the Immigration Jails
description: Americans have long known that the government has been running secretive immigration prisons into which detainees have frequently disappeared, their grave illnesses and injuries untreated, their fates undisclosed until well after early and unnecessary deaths.

title: Policing Indecency
description: A few years ago, Cher, the entertainer, and Nicole Richie, the television personality, uttered brief expletives on separate music awards shows on Fox. The Federal Communications Commission ruled that the comments were indecent. A federal appeals court in New York is now considering the case. The court should rule that the F.C.C.s decision violates the First Amendment.

title: The Coal Ash Case
description: Just more than a year ago, one billion gallons of toxic coal sludge broke loose from a containment pond belonging to the Tennessee Valley Authority, burying hundreds of acres of Roane County in eastern Tennessee and threatening local water supplies and air quality. The Environmental Protection Agency immediately promised new national standards governing the disposal of coal ash to replace a patchwork of uneven  and in many cases weak  state regulations.

title: Corrections
Rangers Go From Punchless to Offensive Force
description: Less than a week removed from a 172-minute goalless drought, the Rangers are suddenly behaving like an offensive juggernaut, racking up an 8-2 victory over the Tampa Bay Lightning on Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Queens Man Is Accused in Plot to Kill U.S. Soldiers
description: A Queens College graduate who traveled to Pakistan in 2008 to attend a Qaeda training camp conspired to kill American service members in Afghanistan, a federal prosecutor said in court on Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about San Diegos departure from the N.F.L. playoffs on Sunday after it won its final 11 regular-season games described a key play incorrectly in some editions. Late in the third quarter, Chargers quarterback Philip Rivers threw a pass over the head of Vincent Jackson that was intercepted by the Jets; it did not sail over the head of Antonio Gates.

title: Corrections
description: Picture credits in the Escapes pages on Friday with an article about unusual crops that are being grown in Hawaii misstated the photographers given name. He is Marco Garcia, not Mario.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about a gene linked to compulsive behavior in dogs misspelled the surname of the actor who played Adrian Monk, the obsessive-compulsive detective in the television series Monk. He is Tony Shalhoub, not Shaloub.

title: Lawyers Use Humor to Plead Case
description: THE adage about encountering the scene of a car accident  you dont want to look, but cant look away  may also apply to commercials for lawyers who represent victims of those accidents.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on Friday, about faults, incorrectly described the location of Sichuan Province, the site of a 2008 earthquake. It is in southwestern China, not eastern China.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: A Year Later, Voters Send a Different Message
description: BOSTON  Special elections come and go. And the party that wins the White House one year ordinarily loses seats in the next Congressional election that comes along.

title: A Pocket of Work in an Area of Joblessness
description: The metal factory in East New York, Brooklyn, could be a picture on an old postcard, one that captures the faith in industry and soaring optimism of the 1950s, accidentally left behind in a neighborhood that now is New York Citys capital of unemployment.

title: Judge Upholds an Indictment in Letterman Extortion Case
description: A Manhattan judge on Tuesday upheld the indictment of an Emmy Award-winning television producer accused of trying to extort $2 million from David Letterman.

title: Advocacy Groups Clash Over Future of Health Bill
description: Liberal advocacy groups are insisting that Democrats must press forward with efforts to overhaul the nations health care system despite the election results in Massachusetts on Tuesday night, while conservative groups are arguing that Scott Browns victory is proof that the Democrats health care bill is flawed and should be scuttled.

title: Glacial Pace in Jury Selection for a Capital Murder Trial
description: NEW HAVEN  The first day of jury selection in the Cheshire triple murder case offered a taste of the intense emotions the case has brought to Connecticut, but ended without any jurors chosen in the capital murder trial.

title: City Agrees to Conduct a Study on the Risks of PCBs in Schools
description: New York City school officials have agreed to assess the environmental risks posed by PCBs in school buildings and to come up with a plan for cleanups and for reducing potential exposure, federal officials said Tuesday.

title: Outburst From Defendant in Afghan Shooting Trial
description: A Pakistani neuroscientist facing trial on charges that she tried to kill military officers and F.B.I. agents in Afghanistan erupted in a Manhattan courtroom and accused a witness of lying on Tuesday, as testimony began in her federal trial.

title: A Big Band in Sync With the City
description: It took a good three or four minutes for the musicians to sidle to their places, arms filled with instruments and charts. Five saxophones. Four trombones and four trumpets. An acoustic bass. Congas. Bongos. The minor percussion  maracas and the guiro. The piano. And then, front and center, the lead man, in a throne of cymbals and foot pedals and drums.

title: Wrangling in Albany Pushes States Request for School Aid to the Wire
description: ALBANY  Handing in its homework at almost the last minute, New York submitted an application to compete for $4 billion in federal education grants Tuesday, but without a charter school plan considered important to the bid.

title: A Robber in the Village Who Looks Improbably Familiar
description: A mini-crime wave among the boutiques and specialty shops of Greenwich Village has a face, and it looks an awful lot like William S. Burroughss.

title: OBrien Continues Ribbing NBC as Deal Stalls
description: With the announcement of his contract settlement apparently stalled for another day, Conan OBrien had one more opportunity to unleash some barbs toward NBC in his monologue Tuesday night. He even managed to dump on the network in Spanish.

title: Remaking His Life After Nearly Losing It in Colombia
description: The motorcycle pulled alongside Carlos Martins Renault during a drive in Cartagena, Colombia. It was Dec. 18, 2000. Mr. Martin did not notice the bike, or the two men riding it, until they opened fire.

title: George Jellinek, WQXR Opera Host, Dies at 90
description: George Jellinek, a former music director of the New York radio station WQXR and the host of a weekly program on opera singers and singing that ran on the station for 36 years, died on Saturday. He was 90 and lived in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Your Trip Is Ready for Its Close-Up
description: Last week, as I walked through B & H, the giant electronics store in Midtown Manhattan in search of a strap for my wifes camera, I made a quick stop in the video department to check on the Sanyo Xacti VPC-HD1010, the camera I bought a little over a year ago to record my Frugal Traveler adventures, like my family trip to Italy and several days of eating at Portlands street carts.

title: Scott Browns Victory Speech
description: The following is the prepared text of state Senator Scott Brown's remarks after winning the United States Senate race in Massachusetts, as provided by his campaign.

title: India: A U.S. Promise on Afghanistan
description: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates assured Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India on Tuesday that the United States would not precipitously leave Afghanistan. A senior American defense official, quoting Mr. Gates, said that the defense secretary told Mr. Singh that we intend to be in the region for a very long time. President Obama has promised to begin troop withdrawals by July 2011. Mr. Gates and Mr. Singh talked about expanded cooperation between the two countries on military technology and cybersecurity. They also discussed China, whose growing influence in the region has increasingly concerned Indias leaders. Mr. Gates is in India for a two-day visit.

title: Obama to Create Panel to Study Deficit
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama plans to create a bipartisan commission to make recommendations to Congress on ways to reduce the federal budget deficit under an agreement reached Tuesday night at the White House.

title: New Rules Set for H.M.O.s in California
description: LOS ANGELES  Patients in health maintenance organizations in California should see their waiting times for doctors appointments reduced and even their telephone calls to physicians answered promptly under sweeping new rules that, for the first time, establish time standards in medical services.

title: Carp DNA Is Found in Lake Michigan
description: CHICAGO  Genetic material from the Asian carp, a voracious invasive species long feared to be nearing the Great Lakes, has been identified for the first time at a harbor within Lake Michigan, near the Illinois-Indiana border, ecologists and federal officials said Tuesday.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Rangers and Sharks in Landslide Victories
description: Eight games on Tuesday night. The Rangers second straight goal deluge was probably the biggest story in the first part of the evening, and the Sharks second straight goal deluge was probably the biggest story in the second part. But that Sharks triumph also gave them first place over all in the N.H.L.

title: Patience Pays Off in Krafts Pursuit
description: Sometimes the wait can be worth it. Kraft Foods sweetened offer for Cadbury followed four months of drooling over the British chocolatier that must have seemed like four years for Irene Rosenfeld, Krafts chief executive. But the delay had its benefits. Though the company will have to raise more money to pay for the final deal, thats become easier and cheaper since Kraft made its bid.

title: American Idol 9 on 9: The Chicago Auditions
description: 12,000 contestants, 13 golden tickets: The Chicago auditions made for a ponderously dull night on American Idol. Despite Simon Cowells avowed distaste for country music, this episode featured the inimitable Shania Twain as a guest judge. The underwhelming lineup was perhaps payback. The two days of torture probably had Shania hopping the next plane back to La Tour-de-Peilz in Switzerland.

title: Phys Ed: Will Olympic Athletes Dope if They Know It Might Kill Them?
description: In November, a study appeared in The New England Journal of Medicine that should give pause to many athletic dopers and those who love them. The study examined the effects of Darbepoetin Alfa, one of a class of drugs commonly known as Epo that is used to stimulate the bodys production of red blood cells. In the experiment, more than 4,000 patients with diabetes, kidney disease and anemia were given either Epo or a placebo. The researchers were testing the impact of the drug when it was used as approved, at moderate doses in sick people. What they found, to their surprise, was that slightly more of the patients taking Epo suffered heart attacks than those in the placebo group, that nearly twice as many suffered a stroke and that the Epo groups self-reported quality of life, their subjective sense of fatigue and illness, was barely better than with placebo.

title: Showcase: Wearing Down
description: Weather, time and general wear and tear take their toll on every kind of material, and the street is as a good a place to notice this as anywhere else. The sole of a businessmans shoe in Lower Manhattan shows scuffs and the start of a hole. A close look at the sidewalk around Gramercy Park reveals the same thing is happening to bluestone as it is tread upon by millions of feet, decade after decade.

title: Democrats Wont Rush to Pass Senate Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Scott Browns decisive Senate victory in Massachusetts imperiled the fate of the Democratic health care overhaul in Tuesday as House Democrats indicated they would not quickly approve a Senate-passed health care measure and send it to President Obama.

title: If Your Kids Are Awake, Theyre Probably Online
description: The average young American now spends practically every waking minute  except for the time in school  using a smart phone, computer, television or other electronic device, according to a new study from the Kaiser Family Foundation.

title: Word of the Day | supine
description: supine \s-pin\ adjective

title: Credit Suisse Cuts Bonuses to Pay for British Tax
description: Credit Suisse says it will reduce its global bonus pool by 5 percent to pay for a new British tax on bonuses, but will cut deeper into the bonuses for its top managers in Britain.

title: You Saw What in Avatar? Pass Those Glasses!
description: If you thought that Avatar was just a high-tech movie about a big-hearted tough guy saving the beguiling natives of a distant moon, you might want to check the prescription on your 3-D glasses.

title: House Democrats Back Off Plan to Pass Senate Bill
description: House Democratic leaders appear to be backing away from a plan to ask their rank-and-file to approve the Senate version of major health care legislation and send the measure directly to President Obama for his signature.

title: When Not in Rome ...
description: Was New York City a better place when there were sad old men sitting at the bar in the lobby of the Gramercy alongside stooped former artists models, with smoke curling up toward the ceiling on exhalations of gin breath and despair? asks Sam Sifton. Probably not. But the era is worth recalling as you sit at Maialino, drinking prosecco or coffee and looking south toward Gramercy Park as cabs inch past. The latest venture from the restaurateur Danny Meyer is a Roman-style trattoria at the Gramercy Park Hotel, whose name is Italian for little pig. Pork is of course on the menu, but so is stracciatella, the Roman chicken soup with thick strands of egg; cold antipasti; and entrees including a moist and flavorful plate of swordfish with mushrooms and fennel fronds, and another of crisp deviled chicken with black pepper and pickled chilies. Enjoy them at a table or at the bar, long, wide and walnut, maybe the most cordial surface the designer, David Rockwell, has ever put into a restaurant. Or try the restaurants pice de rsistance, maialino al forno. The skin, blasted to crisp in a hot oven, is dusted in rosemary, cracked fennel, salt and pepper: an apparently unambitious preparation that tastes just great.

title: Opera Under the Stars
description: It doesnt have an orchestra pit, a stage or proper lighting, but that didnt deter the Gotham Chamber Operas artistic director Neal Goren from staging Haydns comedy Il Mondo Della Luna at the Hayden Planetariums dome at the American Museum of Natural History. Doing this opera at the planetarium is a perfect way to marry arts and science, said Mr. Goren in a recent article. The opera, about a strict father tricked by his daughters into believing that he has been transported to the moon, uses digital video projections provided by NASA, lasers and other spacey technologies to fuse music and stargazing. It runs through Jan. 28.

title: Never Say Goodbye
description: Remember spending hours strolling through the old Tower Records store in the East Village, scanning the aisles for the latest Lemon Heads album or a potential love interest? Those days are long gone  as, thankfully, is our penchant for 90s alternative rock  but for a few weeks you can revisit the feeling at the stores old location on Broadway and East 4th Street, where the nonprofit group No Longer Empty has opened a multimedia art installation called Never Can Say Goodbye. The exhibition, by Ted Riederer, re-creates the store with record bins, album covers, music posters and a performance stage as well as works by Meredyth Sparks, Siebren Versteeg, Ryan Brennan and other artists, which touch on the history of the store, the changes in the music industry brought on by the Internet and how technology has transformed the art form. The installation, which is free and will feature live performances, runs through Feb. 13.

title: Haiti Quake Day 8: A Proper Burial
description: Rob Harris joins a widow and her family on a pilgrimage to bury a loved one who died in last week's earthquake.

title: Lottery Numbers
In Europe, a Call to Follow Suit With Bank Tax
description: Swedens finance minister, Anders Borg, has called on his counterparts in Europe to follow President Obamas lead with a supertax on banks to recoup the costs of propping up the industry, Reuters reported.

title: Robert B. Parker, the Prolific Writer Who Created Spenser, Is Dead at 77
description: Robert B. Parker, the best-selling mystery writer who created Spenser, a tough, glib Boston private detective who was the hero of nearly 40 novels, died Monday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 77.

title: As U.S. G.D.P. Shrinks, Merger Rules Shift
description: American antitrust regulators have lowered the dollar value of mergers that must be reported to the government to $63.4 million from $65.2 million, the Federal Trade Commission said on Tuesday.

title: News Quiz | January 20, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Kate McGarrigle, Canadian Singer and Songwriter, Dies at 63
description: Kate McGarrigle, a Canadian singer who, with her sister Anna, captivated critics and fellow musicians with warm harmonies and a style that drew on both folk traditions and the personalized approach of 1970s singer-songwriters, died on Monday at her home in Montreal. She was 63.

title: Swimming With the Big Fish
description: WHOM do you know who has been scuba diving?

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Food Stuff last Wednesday about the extension of the Maine shrimp season this year misstated the last day of the harvest. It is May 29, not May 1.

title: Letterman on the Jets Powers of Belief
description: They say theres a fine line between confidence  and comedy. At least I think thats what they say.

title: Corrections
description: The Minimalist column last Wednesday, about the tri-tip cut of steak, misstated how many tri-tips can come from one animal. It is two, not one.

title: Corrections
description: A recipe with The Temporary Vegetarian last Wednesday for kimchi pancakes omitted the amount of cayenne that may be substituted for Korean red pepper powder. It is one-half tablespoon. A corrected recipe can be found at nytimes.com/dining.

title: What Exactly Happened When Gundlach Left?
description: Jeffrey Gundlach, the prominent bond fund investor who refers to himself as The Godfather, was storming around his office on Sept. 3, 2009, red-faced and fuming. He was anxious about his future at TCW Group, the Los Angeles firm where he had worked for almost 25 years, Reuters writes.

title: Obama Pressing for Protections Against Lenders
description: President Obama on Tuesday stepped into the middle of a fierce lobbying battle by reinforcing his support for an independent agency to protect consumers against lending abuses that contributed to the financial crisis. The presidents move also signaled a tougher line and a more direct role as Congress weighs an overhaul of banking regulation, The New York Timess Jackie Calmes and Sewell Chan write.

title: Patience Pays Off in Krafts Pursuit
description: Sometimes the wait can be worth it. Kraft Foods sweetened offer for Cadbury followed four months of drooling over the British chocolatier that must have seemed like four years for Irene Rosenfeld, Krafts chief executive.

title: Insider Faces Sentencing in 07 Case
description: Update | 8:33 a.m.  with postponement of sentencing.

title: South Korea Warns North on a First Nuclear Strike
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea would launch a pre-emptive conventional strike against the North if there were clear indications of an impending nuclear attack, the South Korean defense minister said Wednesday in Seoul, even as both countries were holding talks about improvements at their jointly operated industrial park.

title: French Banks Role in A.I.G. Payout Questioned
description: Undermining a report that French banks were behind the New York Federal Reserve Banks payouts on American International Group, Bloomberg News writes that French lenders took haircuts on a similar deal in the same period.

title: China Orders Some Banks to Rein in Loans
description: China has told some banks to limit lending and will restrict overall credit growth in the nation to 7.5 trillion renminbi ($1.1 trillion) this year, said the banking regulator, Liu Mingkang.

title: 8 Arrested in Firebombing of Malaysian Churches
description: BANGKOK  Eight men were arrested on Wednesday in Malaysia in connection with the firebombing of a Pentecostal church last month, one in a series of attacks that has targeted a dozen Christian churches, the police said.

title: Gates Warns of Militant Threat in South Asia
description: NEW DELHI  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates warned on Wednesday that the interconnected extremist groups on the Afghanistan-Pakistan border were working to destabilize the entire region and that a victory for one was a victory for all.

title: Ontario Teachers Pension Plan Buys Acorn Care
description: One of Canadas largest pension administrators, the Ontario Teachers Pension Plan, has agreed to buy a leading British provider of special needs education for an undisclosed sum, Reuters reported.

title: Stock Buybacks Back in Vogue in 2010?
description: Share buybacks by American corporations could be back in style this year, as an improving economy makes companies more willing to loosen their purse strings to fund transactions that could reward investors with a higher share price.

title: What Are the Most Amazing Things Youve Ever Seen in the Natural World?
description: A biologist writing in the Science Times talks about how Avatar, for her, recreated what is the heart of biology: the naked, heart-stopping wonder of really seeing the living world. When have you observed something in nature whether a beautiful place, fascinating animal, spectacular storm or anything else large or small  that inspired wonder in you?

title: Gacaca Courts
description: Open-air community trials in Rwanda, used to prosecute those accused of participating in the countrys 1994 genocide.[Gacaca derives from the Kinyarwanda word for grass or lawn.]

title: Air France-KLM Said to Eye Polish Airline
description: Air France-KLM, the French-Dutch air carrier, may be interested in taking over the troubled Polish airline LOT, the Polish newspaper Dziennik reported Wednesday without naming sources.

title: Takeovers  Do They Usually Do Harm?
description: Most takeovers end up doing more harm than good, The Daily Telegraph said in an editorial, because of the cuts that are necessary after a deal saddled the combined company with debt.

title: V.C.s Prescribe $8 Million for Orbis
description: Orbis Education, a developer of nursing-education software, has received $8 million in additional funding. Lightspeed Venture Partners led the Series B round of financing for the start-up, which is based in Indianapolis.

title: Atlas Brings Its European Ops Back to Boston
description: Atlas Venture, the technology-focused venture capital firm, is bringing its European operations back to Boston, in a move to re-focus its strategy.

title: Asia, not JAL, Is the Prize in Delta-American Fight
description: Japan Airlines isnt the real prize in the fight between Delta Air Lines and American Airlines to become partners with the troubled carrier, The Associated Pres writes. The American carriers are after JALs Asian routes and the premium passengers that come with them.

title: Paulson Said to Compete With Emerging Managers
description: John Paulson, the veteran hedge fund manager, will be vying with his former protege and other up-and-coming rivals for for investor money at an industry event next month, The New York Post reported, citing a private and confidential document.

title: Showcase: Same Time, Last Year
description: On Jan. 20, 2009, the best possible thing happened to Luke Sharrett, a photojournalism major from Western Kentucky University who was in Washington to witness the inauguration of President Obama.

title: U.S. Said to Score Premium from Banks on Warrants
description: The Treasury Department persuaded some big banks to pay more than market estimates to repurchase warrants issued to the government in the financial crisis, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing a draft Treasury report.

title: JPMorgan Said to Be in Exclusive Talks for Sempra
description: JPMorgan Chase has entered exclusive talks to buy the RBS Sempra commodities joint venture owned by Royal Bank of Scotland and Sempra Energy of the United States, people familiar with the matter told Reuters on Wednesday.

title: World Stocks Fall Amid Fears of China Bank Curbs
description: World markets dropped Wednesday, led by a near 3 percent tumble in Shanghais stock benchmark, as investors fretted about new curbs on the lavish bank lending that has driven Chinas economic revival.

title: Barclays May Face $27 Billion Deficit, Analysts Say
description: Facing a potential capital shortfall of 17 billion ($27.7 billion), Barclays may be forced to raise new funds from shareholders in order to avoid selling its stake in the money management firm BlackRock or canceling its recently reinstated dividend, Credit Suisse said Tuesday.

title: AMC Gobbles Up Providence-Backed Theater Chain
description: Movie studios may not be hot properties at the moment, but theater chains are apparently still attracting buyers.

title: Pandit Running Out of Time to Clean Up Citi
description: It is make or break time for Vikram S. Pandit.

title: Philippines Panel Clears Election Bid by Former President
description: MANILA  The Philippines election commission cleared the way Wednesday for Joseph Estrada, a former president, to run for the office a second time.

title: Goldman and Morgan Pay May Overshadow Results
description: Longtime rivals Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs  find themselves on different ends of the pay debate, as the surviving Wall Street titans prepare to disclose their fourth-quarter results, Reuters writes.

title: Analysts Expect 4th Quarter Loss for BofA
description: Bank of America likely will post another loss when it reports fourth-quarter earnings on Wednesday, as banks continue to grapple with their problems loans and a weak economy, Reuters reported.

title: Comparing 2009 Jets With 2000 Ravens
description: Luis DeLoureiro is building a better passer rating, among other statistical pursuits, at NFLStatAnalysis.net.  He also contributes at classactsports.com.

title: Hong Kongs Amazing Race
description: Hong Kong doesnt have much in the way of professional sports, but it takes its horse racing very seriously. The racing season runs from September through July (its too hot in the summer), so this is just about midseason. The next major meet, at the Sha Tin track, is the first leg of Hong Kongs Triple Crown on Jan. 31.

title: Deglobalization? Forget It
description: Todays idea: Reports of globalizations recession-choked demise have been greatly exaggerated, an article says. It is actually stepping up its game.

title: Attack of the Minimum-Wage Increase
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Hedge Funds Said to Bag $4.6 Billion in December
description: Total global hedge-fund assets grew by a hefty $4.6 billion in December, as the industry enjoyed its eighth straight month of capital growth, according to data released by Eurekahedge.

title: Quake Rattles Nerves in Hedge Fund Enclave
description: Hedge funds based in the Cayman Islands had at least their nerves rattled Tuesday, as a 5.8 magnitude earthquake hit the Caribbean hedge fund center. However, there were no reports of injury or damage, Reuters reported.

title: The More Things Change
description: AMMAN, Jordan  One quotation, four wars. Nearly a century after it was coined, versions of a saying attributed to T. E. Lawrence, the First World War British officer immortalized as Lawrence of Arabia, have become a common feature at American military bases in Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: U.S. Bancorp Reports Q4 Profit Doubled
description: U.S. Bancorp, one of the 10 largest United States banks, said fourth-quarter profit doubled, helped by a rise in fee income, Reuters reported.

title: Living With Music: A Playlist by Eric Puchner
description: Eric Puchner is the author of a story collection, Music Through the Floor. His first novel, Model Home, will be published next month.

title: Bombers Attempt Takes Center Stage on Capitol Hill
description: The failed Christmas Day attempt to blow up a Northwest Airlines jet will be in the spotlight on Capitol Hill beginning this morning, as top Obama administration officials will give their first public accounting to lawmakers about missed signals and intelligence lapses leading up to the attack.

title: State Street Reports Profit Nearly Doubles
description: State Street, one of the worlds biggest institutional investors, said on Wednesday that fourth-quarter net income nearly doubled, beating market expectations, as assets under management climbed and the company cut costs, Reuters reported.

title: Fitch Cuts Credit Ratings of Kraft and Cadbury
description: Kraft Foods and Cadbury saw their credit ratings cut to the lowest investment grade on Wednesday after Kraft won the backing of Cadburys board for its $19.6 billion takeover bid, Reuters reported.

title: Bank of America Posts Loss for 4th Quarter
description: Update | 7:25 a.m. Strapped consumers continue to rain on Wall Streets victory parade, but the deluge may be easing.

title: Sampler: School Gardens Are in the Spotlight; Gavin Newsom Is Not
description: Gavin Newsoms Next Career Move | In an interview with Maureen Dowd, Gavin Newsom jokes that his next career could be as the clerk of a wine store. He reviewed his political career and how the issue of same-sex marriage both put him into the national limelight but might have made it difficult for him to be seen as more than a single-issue candidate while running for governor in the past year. Daniel Weintraub, The Times Bay Area columnist, also commented on the mayors receding profile in Sundays report. The limelight has shifted several blocks away to a federal courthouse where the constitutionality of a state ban on same-sex marriage is being discussed. This is it. God bless. It was fun while it lasted, Mayor Newsom said of his career. Guys like me dont necessarily progress very far, which is fine. [The New York Times]

title: Alcon Directors Challenge Novartiss Takeover Bid
description: The independent directors of Alcon, the eye-care products maker, said on Wednesday that they are challenging Novartiss bid to acquire full control of the company, calling its offer grossly inadequate.

title: Bank of N.Y. Mellon Rises on Wealth Management
description: The Bank of New York Mellon said Tuesday that its fourth-quarter profit surged as asset and wealth management revenue offset lower interest income, The Associated Press reported.

title: Some Disappointing Earnings Send Markets Lower
description: A day after gliding to 15-month highs, Wall Street stocks had their steepest losses since mid-December on Wednesday as investors fretted over lackluster profits and a slowdown in global lending.

title: The Democrats Day After
description: We will be updating this discussion with additional commentary throughout the day. Scroll down to read Kathryn Jean Lopez, Donna Brazile, Dan Schnur, Glenn Greenwald, Theda Skocpol, Norman Ornstein and Julian Zelizer in the forum.

title: Morgan Stanleys Quarter Falls Below Forecast
description: Update | 9:21 a.m. Morgan Stanley said on Wednesday that it had net income of $617 million in the fourth quarter as it struggled to rebound from the financial crisis.

title: Man Surrenders in Virginia Killings
description: Just days before Christopher B.
