Speight surrendered to the police in connection with the killings of eight people in Appomattox County, Va., on Tuesday, co-workers said they had noticed that he had seemed sullen and on edge when he showed up for his job as a security guard at a small grocery store.

title: Jan. 20: Updates on the Crisis in Haiti
description: On Wedensday The Lede is continuing to supplement reporting by our colleagues in Haiti on the aftermath of last weeks earthquake by pointing to news and information on the Web. Readers are encouraged to share any first-hand accounts they receive from Haiti or see online in the comments thread below. See the home page of NYTimes.com for the latest news articles and multimedia features on the relief effort. For updates from previous days see: Jan. 19 | Jan. 18 | Jan. 17 | Jan. 16 | Jan. 15 | Jan. 14 | Jan. 12 and 13

title: Wild Edibles Settles With Workers Group Pushing Boycott
description: After filing for bankruptcy last July largely because of a boycott, Wild Edibles, one of New Yorks leading seafood purveyors, has reached a tentative $340,000 settlement with the workers group that persuaded more than 70 restaurants to boycott the company.

title: Nightmare in Haiti: Untreated Illness and Injury
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  A strong aftershock rattled Haiti once again on Wednesday, causing even more physical damage and further traumatizing the jittery population. But the authorities said the biggest dangers now facing survivors of last weeks major earthquake were untreated wounds and rising disease, not falling debris.

title: The Early Word: The Brown Effect
description: The effects of the stunning victory by Scott Brown are still settling in here in Washington  and in Massachusetts, with the Republicans win signifying an end to the Democratic supermajority in the Senate and having major implications for the midterm elections.

title: Wind Power Unreliable? Build More Turbines
description: One of the drawbacks to wind turbines is that while they may provide a lot of energy at times, they can never be counted on to provide energy in a pinch, a characteristic called capacity.

title: Better Late Than Never? A Welcome Gift for Conan OBrien
description: Theres been so much bad blood among the late-night hosts recently that its about time somebody did something nice for one of them. We turn the floor over to Norm Macdonald, who on Tuesday night finally brought Conan OBrien the gift basket hed been meaning to give the Tonight Show host since the summer.

title: Home Construction Down Sharply in December
description: Home construction slowed more than expected in December, the government said on Wednesday, as high unemployment made builders nervous about the demand for new homes. Still, there were signs that future construction might pick up, helped by the lure of a government tax credit.

title: From Struggling, Squabbling Albany, Bad News for Schools
description: Gov. David A. Paterson proposed on Tuesday what would be the largest cut to school aid in more than two decades and nearly $1 billion in new or increased taxes and fees as he unveiled his budget, a plan that is likely to be the first chapter in a prolonged battle with the Legislature.

title: In a Family Emergency, Nurse or Wife?
description: My husband, Arthur, fell the Sunday before Christmas. He was walking the dog and slipped on a patch of black ice about a block from our house. Luckily, someone with a cellphone walked by and called our home.

title: Morgan Stanleys Quarter Is Weak, Unlike Its Pay Pool
description: By almost any measure, 2009 was a lean year for Morgan Stanley  except when it came to pay.

title: Dreams of a Sundance Bidding War
description: The Bagger has not even packed away our Southern California finery, and now we have to get ready to swaddle ourselves in down for the Sundance Film Festival. (We know, youre crying for us.)

title: The Perfect Trail: A Few Clicks Away
description: Lets say you have a business trip to Knoxville, Tenn. coming up and youd like to do an easy hike  say about seven miles  in the Great Smoky Mountains, about 45 miles away. But youve never hiked south of the Mason-Dixon line. How does one find such a trail?

title: Supported by Brown, Massachusetts Reform Was a Model for Democrats in Washington
description: Senator-elect Scott Brown, Republican of Massachusetts, said in his victory speech that he is anxious to get to Washington and start his new job. But Mr. Brown, who owes his victory to independent voters, will quickly find himself at the center of a partisan typhoon over the fate of the major health care legislation.

title: Vietnam, Quelling Dissent, Gives 4 Democracy Advocates Jail Terms
description: BANGKOK  Four democracy advocates in Vietnam were convicted Wednesday in a closely watched trial of trying to overthrow the state, prosecuted as part of campaign against dissent that has led to dozens of arrests in recent months.

title: Dial P for Putdown
description: Video Classic | Satisfying consumer comeback on Seinfeld:

title: Hands-On | The Gropius Touch
description: When was the last time you looked at a piece of paper? Eight and a half by 11, unmarked, unblemished copy paper. That was the first task for the 20 students (and one architecture and design curator) at the Museum of Modern Arts Bauhaus Lab last week. The workshop was one of a series that are being held in conjunction with the exhibition Bauhaus 1919-1933: Workshops for Modernity, which closes on Jan. 25. Shout out your first thoughts, said Ati Gropius Johansen, the daughter of the pioneering Modernist architect and Bauhaus founding director Walter Gropius, who was teaching the Three-Dimensional Workshop. Five people immediately said, White.The students were arrayed around a flower-shaped table in the atrium of the museums education wing. Johansen had placed one sheet of paper in the center. What else? she asked. It has four sides. It has 90-degree angles. It is flat. This last response interested Johansen. She reclined gently on the table. How is it lying? If this were a person, what would you find yourself doing to it? Another student blurted out, It is like a baby. After 10 more minutes of discussion, Johansen sent the students off with the instruction to create the biggest change in the paper with the least action: one fold, one roll, one rip.

title: Three Experts, Three Views on Collector Car Trends
description: PHOENIX  Car collectors from around the world are either here in Arizonas Valley of the Sun (where its raining, with more precipitation forecast throughout the week), or they are tuned in via television, telephone or the Internet as some 3,000 vehicles of special interest and historic value are up for auction at a variety of venues.

title: The Times to Charge for Frequent Access to Its Web Site
description: Taking a step that has tempted and terrified much of the newspaper industry, The New York Times announced on Wednesday that it would charge some frequent readers for access to its Web site  news that drew ample reaction from media analysts and consumers, ranging from enthusiastic to withering.

title: Buffett Is No Fan of Kraft-Cadbury Deal
description: Earlier this month, Warren E. Buffett fired an unusual shot across Krafts bow: a public statement warning the American food giant not to overpay in its pursuit of Cadbury, and a threat to reject the companys plans to issue up to 370 million new shares as part of the deal.

title: Gas Drilling Techniques Under Fire  Again
description: Federal government oversight of hydraulic fracturing  a drilling technique that boosts natural gas extraction by blasting water, sand and chemicals underground at high pressure  is sorely lacking, putting drinking water supplies at risk, an environmental policy group claimed in a report released Tuesday.

title: G.O.P. Senate Victory Stuns Democrats
description: BOSTON  Scott Brown, a little-known Republican state senator, rode an old pickup truck and a growing sense of unease among independent voters to an extraordinary upset Tuesday night when he was elected to fill the Senate seat that was long held by Edward M. Kennedy in the overwhelmingly Democratic state of Massachusetts.

title: Wednesday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Brown: People Are Angry
description: In an interview with NBCs Today show Wednesday morning, Senator-elect Scott Brown was asked if his victory was a referendum on President Obama.

title: Answers About New York Citys High Schools
description: This week, Clara Hemphill, whose book series New York Citys Best Schools is regarded as the bible for navigating school choices, responded to readers questions about the high school admissions process and the myriad choices in the city.

title: The Times to Charge for Online Access
description: Richard Prez-Pea writes:

title: Fools On The Hill
description: So, will health care reform fail because a lazy candidate didnt bother campaigning and didnt know her Red Sox? (Yes, there were national factors at work, but Nate Silver makes it clear that a better candidate would have won easily). Its up to the House, which can and should just pass the Senate bill.

title: Massachusetts Upset
description: Teachers Note: In case youre talking about this news in class today, were publishing tomorrows 6 Qs early.

title: Officials Regret Curbs on Adding to Terror Watch List
description: WASHINGTON  Restrictions put into place last year that limit how people are added to terrorist watch lists unintentionally compromised the nations ability to prevent attacks, the Obama administrations top counterterrorism officials testified Wednesday.

title: Time For The Re-Set Button
description: Theres a scenario, believe it or not, in which Scott Browns stunning win last night could actually end up forestalling a massive G.O.P. sweep next November. It involves Barack Obama swallowing his pride, behaving like a President whos just been thumped, and making a very public show of internalizing the lessons of last night in Massachusetts. And it involves dismissing, immediately and with prejudice, the liberal fantasy that Rahm Emanuel should spend the next few weeks knocking heads together in the House, in the hopes of pushing the Senate bill through Congress.

title: A Note on Financial Reform
description: Whatever happens on health care  if House Democrats have any sense, theyll just pass the Senate bill, but thats a big if  financial reform is next up. But that leaves us with a question: what strategy should the Democrats follow?

title: Interviews for Joan, but Not for John
In Defense of Pants on the Ground
description: I think it was Samuel Johnson who said that when a man is tired of Pants on the Ground, he is tired of life.

title: Jobs Not Created
description: This CBO report on job creation leaves me a bit angry  not at CBO, but at SAOs (senior administration officials). Heres a chart showing CBO estimates of jobs per buck from various employment-creating policies.

title: Forest Carbon Offsets in the Ozarks
description: CE2 Carbon Capital, an investor in carbon emissions reduction projects, and Dogwood Carbon Solutions, an agency that helps private landowners gain access to the carbon credits market, announced last week that they have joined forces to develop carbon offsets on 300,000 acres of forest land in the Ozark mountain region of Missouri and Arkansas.

title: Speed Read for Wednesday, Jan. 20
description: Here are some highlights from Wednesdays editions of The New York Times:

title: Errors of Commission
description: I am not happy about plans to create an independent deficit-reduction commission. Ill have more to say later on, but right now let me just remind you about what happened with the last serious effort to do this kind of independent-commission stuff, the Greenspan commission on Social Security. It was a game of three-card monte:

title: People Robbing Banks
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: I just read President Obama plans to deliver his State of the Union address next Wednesday, Jan. 27. Until then, hes just at home going: Please everything get better by Wednesday. Please everything get better by Wednesday.

title: Appearing Before Homeland Security
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: You know up in Massachusetts, the big election, are you following whats going on up there? Ted Kennedys Senate seat is now up for grabs. The election is pretty close. I was thinking, you know, my money is on Jay Leno.

title: Understanding the A.I.G. Dispute
description: If you want to understand why Congress and the public remain focused and angry about the bailout of the American International Group, you must read the statement released Tuesday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The statement is a game defense of the New York Feds role in A.I.G.s disclosure of the Feds purchase of credit default swaps at approximately par value for a total of $61.9 billion. In fact, you can feel the frustration of the New York Fed in the statement as it strives to show just how transparent it is trying to be.

title: At Australian Open, Belgian Women May Face Off
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  They are working their way to each other, Kim Clijsters and Justine Henin, a pair of Belgian women who know each other well. Clijsters did not have to sweat much to keep their appointment in the quarterfinals. She dusted Tamarine Tanasugarn  6-3, 6-3  in the second round of the Australian Open here Wednesday.

title: The Shady Lady
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: Well, all the major airlines have raised their fees to check in baggage. In fact, its getting so expensive now to bring bags on board, even people who arent terrorists are stuffing things into their underpants.

title: Grammys Plan a 3-D Tribute to Michael Jackson
description: Michael Jacksons ability to provide audiences with technologically innovative, over-the-top spectacles has in no way been curtailed by his death. The coming Grammy Awards ceremony will include a special tribute to the King of Pop featuring a portion that will be broadcast in 3-D, the Recording Academy said on Wednesday.

title: Obamas Nominee for T.S.A. Withdraws
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas nominee to head the Transportation Security Administration, Erroll Southers, withdrew his name on Wednesday, saying that Republicans had politicized the appointment. The withdrawal was a setback for Mr. Obamas efforts to allay concerns about airline security after several highly publicized breaches.

title: Its on the Web: Concacaf U-20 Women
description: Concacaf, the regional confederation that includes the United States, bolsters its embrace of technology when it begins its Web coverage Wednesday afternoon of the regional U-20 qualifying tournament for the 2010 FIFA Under-20 Womens World Cup this summer in Germany (Bochum, Bielefeld, Augsburg and Dresden).

title: Big Oil Pursues Toreador Resources
description: Several big energy conglomerates are in initial discussions to buy or partner with the Toreador Resources Corporation, an independent oil and natural gas company that operates primarily in France, people briefed on the matter told DealBook.

title: When You Can Deduct the Cost of Your M.B.A.
description: Update: Weve posted additional information on M.B.A. tuition deductions here.

title: Joe Willie, and Passing the Jets From Father to Son
description: Ross Greenburg is president of HBO Sports.

title: Amazon Increases Royalty Rate for Books on Its Kindle E-Reader
description: In what appeared to be a clear bid to anticipate the release of the breathlessly awaited Apple tablet, Amazon announced Wednesday new royalty terms for authors or publishers who release e-books through its Kindles digital text platform, a direct publishing initiative.

title: Obama, White House Gauge Election Fallout
description: President Obama stepped before the cameras Wednesday morning to say he was cracking down on tax cheats. He left unanswered the biggest question in the capital today: What did he think of the decision by Massachusetts voters to send a Republican, Scott Brown, to the United States Senate?

title: Hong Kong Air Quality Stirs Passions
description: In an interview with Green Inc. last week, Eva Wong, a spokeswoman from Hong Kongs Environmental Protection Department, suggested that while air quality along the citys roads can be problematic, overall air quality in Hong Kong was generally good.

title: What Does the Vatican Newspaper Think of Avatar? Ask the Critic Who Wrote the Review
description: Among the many critics, commentators and advocates who have taken aim at James Camerons science-fiction blockbuster Avatar (and whose varying responses to this cinematic Rorschach test are discussed in this article by Dave Itzkoff) is Gaetano Vallini.

title: Part 3: Answers on the Fafsa and Financial Aid
description: For many high school seniors and their parents, this is the season for tackling the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, a notoriously cumbersome process that the government is attempting to streamline this year.

title: Rossi Begins Ferrari Test in Spain
description: Here we go again.

title: When It Isnt Just Clutter Anymore
description: She was a retired college professor, living alone in a New York apartment that had become unmanageable. When she called Bergfelds Estate Clearance Service for help, Kristin Bergfeld had trouble entering the apartment; the professor had to move objects out of the way simply to open her front door.

title: No Payoff for Woods as AT&T Ended Deal
description: When AT&T dropped Tiger Woods as its spokesman on New Years Eve, it did not pay him any of the millions of dollars it owed him, a company official confirmed. Nor did AT&T have to go to court to sever its ties to Woods.

title: Kiwis in Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The attack on the Central Bank in downtown Kabul this week revealed many things about Afghanistan. But one of the more surprising things it brought to light was that New Zealand is at war.

description: From our colleagues at Formula One:

title: Travel Deals: British Airways Sale to Europe
description: British Airways has a sale on flights to Europe, from 19 cities in the United States. The sale, which ends Jan. 28, is good for travel from Jan. 26 to March 28.

title: White House Party Crashers Take the 5th
description: Michaele and Tareq Salahi, the couple who sneaked into President Obamas first state dinner in November, declined to answer questions posed by lawmakers on Capitol Hill today.

title: Calm Returns to Torn Nigerian City; Toll Unclear
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The authorities in Jos gave a death toll sharply at odds with those of rights groups and local activists Wednesday, even as the central Nigerian city saw its first day of relative calm since Sunday, after three days of sectarian violence.

title: Group Hug | Dsquared, D&G, Giorgio Armani and Z Zegna
description: MILAN  The mens shows here ended with four radically different points of view. At Dsquared, Bill Kaulitz, the lead singer of the band Tokio Hotel, led a gang of bloodied, bare-chested hockey players  leaving some wondering whether the N.H.L. should consider a uniform of patent leather shorts, destroyed jeans with dangling chains and silver mesh tees. For D&G, the sport of choice was skiing, which provided a nifty excuse to layer the chunky knits, oversize parkas and furry hats that have been so prevalent. Giorgio Armani, on the other hand, kept his loose, fluid tailoring clean, though he did accessorize every look with bookish glasses and berets. And Z Zegna closed the week with snazzy suits with exposed seams, the better to reveal the quality and precision of the houses sartorial skills. Take a look at our slide show and tell us who you think capped off Milan best.

title: The Coach in the Machine
description: Sometime recently when we werent paying attention  perhaps we were distracted by Peyton Mannings presnap histrionics or by trying to keep an accurate count of Tiger Woodss mistresses  sports were completely taken over by coaches. This is not a good thing.

title: Dialing in a Plan: The Times Installs a Meter on Its Future
description: In announcing that it will adopt a metered model early in 2011, The New York Times managed to land with some authority, but not much impact. And perhaps that was by design.

title: A Reluctant Retailer Decides to Open Her Books
description: About five years ago, I began mentoring a creative and vibrant young woman named Meghan Chambers. Ms. Chambers, who was 23 at the time, had taken a chance by opening a retail shop in Springfield, Mo., called Staxx. She believed in the revitalization of the downtown area of the city and she was one of the first businesses to strike out there  something that earned her quite a bit of press and recognition.

title: Longevity at the Opera: The Domingo Phenomenon
description: Plcido Domingo, who holds the job of general director at both the Washington National Opera and the Los Angeles Opera, is at the Metropolitan Opera to conduct and sing. As Daniel J. Wakin reported recently, Mr. Domingo says he took the general director jobs with the thought of pursuing a second career after retiring from the stage. But his remarkably healthy and still-lustrous voice kept him in the performing game. I cannot betray the singer, he said. I wont sing one day more than I should, but also I wont sing one day less than I can.

title: Expanding Use of Wind Power Feasible, but May Be Costly
description: WASHINGTON  Wind could replace coal and natural gas for 20 to 30 percent of the electricity used in the eastern two-thirds of the United States by 2024, according to a study released Wednesday by the Energy Department.

title: A Q&A With Senator Cornyn on the G.O.P.s Pickup Prospects
description: BOSTON  Let the Republican recruiting season begin.

title: Attempting a Great Leap Sideways
description: It is among the countrys oldest and most established expressions of political ambition: a former member of the House of Representatives attempting to break into the Senate, that more exclusive upper chamber of Congress with the luxurious six-year terms and the all-you-can-eat media visibility.

title: Genuine Actress Flirts With Stardom
description: IF you were to choose one article of clothing to represent Laura Linney, it would have to be the little black dress. Simple, elegant, appropriate for any occasion. Add a white pilgrims bonnet and a long apron, and Ms. Linney is transformed into the nobly suffering Elizabeth Proctor in Arthur Millers Crucible. Dress it up with pearls, a slash of red lipstick and Manolos, and she is a high-strung Upper East Side wife in the 2007 film The Nanny Diaries. Include a scarf, a camera bag and a crutch, and she becomes Sarah Goodwin, the recuperating war photographer in Donald Marguliess new play Time Stands Still, opening on Broadway Thursday at the Manhattan Theater Clubs Samuel J. Friedman Theater.

title: What the Results in Massachusetts Mean
description: Gail Collins: David, sorry I was slow reaching out to you Tuesday night. Its very hard to write when one is crouched in a fetal position under the bed. Maybe if I remove the pillow from over my head

title: Arts Funding Is Hit Under Proposed New York State Budget
description: Cultural funding in New York State would suffer a $9.6 million cut under the 2010-11 budget proposed by Gov. David A. Paterson on Tuesday. A final version of the budget is due be enacted by April 1.

title: Shocking! | The Proto-TMZ
description: There are excerpts in Shocking True Story (Pantheon), a new history of the infamous and influential celebrity-scandal rag Confidential, that should strike you as straight out of a James Ellroy novel: the built-up glitz and the hard-boiled sleaze, to start, as well as something about the language  full of implication and insinuation, and as tart and pulpy as a blood orange. The author, Henry E. Scott, writes in the books acknowledgments that he was reading Ellroys L.A. Confidential when he became inspired to write about the magazine  which for five years in the 1950s incited paranoia in Hollywoods bedrooms and boardrooms with tightly sourced, stylized accounts of celebrity indiscretion. At the New York-based magazines height  which is to say just before its downfall at the hands of Tinseltown attorneys  it enjoyed a circulation of 9 million. Its pages laid the groundwork for the National Inquirer, E! and US Weekly; indeed, where once went Confidential, now goes TMZ.Not unlike an Ellroy novel, Shocking True Story sometimes delights in the macabre, particularly in the long passages it lifts from Confidentials pages. One article, from the magazines November 1954 issue, could almost describe a Jacques-Louis David painting from 150 years earlier: Police found her nude body in the bathroom of her San Francisco apartment. There was a grim touch of neatness, even comfort, in the way she had met death. After filling the tub with water, she had arranged a stack of pillows around the edge and drowned herself. The womans name was Dr. Jean S. Tatlock, and she was a communist. She killed herself in 1944, some six months after an overnight rendezvous with her former boyfriend, Dr. Robert Oppenheimer. This wasnt news by late 1954, but it did endear Confidentials charismatic, power-peddling owner, Robert Harrison, to J. Edgar Hoovers F.B.I. and the forces of McCarthyism, who at a public hearing earlier that year stripped Oppenheimer of his Atomic Energy Commission security clearance.

title: Coasting Into Spring
description: Wednesdays sweater weather notwithstanding, blizzards and ice may yet lie ahead, but take heart: the dead of winter is behind us. Statistically speaking, at least. Jan. 19 has the lowest average temperatures of the year in New York City  a low of 26 degrees and a high of 37, according to AccuWeather.com. The average high and low for Jan. 20 both leap upward by three-tenths of a degree.

title: Baldenfreude
description: A novel variety of Schadenfreude  pleasure felt at the misfortune of others  relating specifically to the discomfiture of those with little or no hair.

title: A New Comment System
description: From The New York Times:

title: Exciting Matches Have Late-Round Feel
description: On Night 3 of the Australian Open, two contests wowed fans and sent waves of warning through the mens and womens draws.

title: When to Report a Nanny to the Police
description: When my mother was about 3 she started telling her mother that she wanted to go to the restaurant with the tall chairs or the stand-up chairs, where her babysitter took her every afternoon. Eventually they figured out she meant the high stools at the neighborhood bar.

title: Perella Weinberg and Infinity to Form Transport Venture
description: Perella Weinberg Partners and Infinity Capital Partners said on Wednesday that the two investment firms would create a joint venture to pour up to $100 million into transportation assets.

title: Reactions Pour In to Times Announcement About Charging Online
description: In the wake of Wednesday mornings announcement that The Times will charge some readers for online access, starting early next year, reaction is pouring in from bloggers, media analysts and readers  and it is all over the map.

title: Bloomberg Highlights Strategy of Savings for City
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg focused on the incremental rather than the innovative in his annual State of the City address on Wednesday, pledging to avoid any new spending, to consolidate government operations and to take modest steps in helping small businesses and minority youths.

title: Vampire Weekends Contra Is No. 1
description: Lets hear it for blogs, cable-knit sweaters and Morningside Heights: Vampire Weekend, the band of Columbia University graduates that began its rise to indie-rock fame long before it had released any recordings, has reached No. 1 on the Billboard album chart with its second album, Contra (XL). Issued last week, Contra sold 124,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, giving it an easy victory over Susan Boyles I Dreamed a Dream (Syco Music/Columbia), at No. 2 with 77,000 sales, and Ke$has Animal (Kemosabe/RCA), which fell two spots to No. 3 with 67,000.

title: CrowdFlower Raises $5 Million to Boost Crowdsourcing
description: Jobs today are notoriously hard to come by. But thats only if you want to build cars. Or write for newspapers. Or sell mortgages.

title: Obsessions | Daves Killer Bread
description: When I hear the phrase organic bread, I think of a funky, hairy person in sandals toiling away proudly in a heated adobe hut someplace in, oh, say, Vermont. I usually dont think of a methamphetamine addict  does he even eat?  let alone a convict serving hard prison time. Which is why I was surprised to discover that one of the best commercially available organic breads  in my opinion  is manufactured by a convicted felon and former meth addict from Oregon named Dave Dahl.

title: Analysts Press New BofA Chief on His Plans
description: Brian T. Moynihan, the new chief executive of Bank of America, fielded a barrage of questions from analysts on Wednesday, all curious about his plans for the bank.

title: (500 Days) Director Swings to Spider-Man
description: If the next Spider-Man movie features an adorable nonlinear plot device, a musical number set to an underappreciated Hall & Oates song or a terrible final line that exhausts all your good will toward the film, now you know why. On Wednesday, Sony Pictures Entertainment announced that it had signed Marc Webb, the director of the hit romantic comedy (500) Days of Summer, to direct a fourth installment in its Spider-Man franchise, The Hollywood Reporter said.

title: Court Sides With Energy Department in Efficiency Dispute With LG Electronics
description: A United States district court has sided with the Energy Departments decision to strip the Energy Star label from about 40,000 refrigerator-freezers manufactured by LG Electronics.

title: Court Sets Unusual Special Session for Thursday
description: The Supreme Court announced at the close of arguments on Wednesday that it will hold a special session Thursday morning, presumably to issue decisions. Such special sessions are quite unusual, leading many to suspect that the court will release its long-awaited decision in Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission, a major campaign finance case.

title: Tallying Foreigners
description: Over the last half-century, Latin Americans have gone from representing under a tenth of the foreign-born population living in the United States to more than half of it.

title: A New Comment System for On the Ground
description: Hello On the Ground fans! This is Hilary, Nicks assistant, with a little bit of tech news:

title: Same-Sex Marriage Case, Day 7: Choice
description: The Bay Area blog has been reporting three times daily from the federal courthouse in San Francisco on the case of Perry v. Schwarzenegger. That case is challenging the constitutionality of Proposition 8, the ban on same-sex marriage approved by voters in 2008. Among the lawyers on the plaintiffs team are Theodore B. Olson, David Boies, Theodore J. Boutrous Jr., Christopher Dean Dusseault, Christine Van Aken, Danny Chu, Matthew D. McGill and Therese Stewart. The legal team for the defense includes Brian Raum, Charles J. Cooper, David Thompson, Andrew Pugno, James Campbell, Jordan Lorence, Nicole Moss, Howard C. Nielson Jr. and Peter A. Patterson.

title: James Patterson Inc.
description: Like most authors, James Patterson started out with one book, released in 1976, that he struggled to get published. It sold about 10,000 copies, a modest, if respectable, showing for a first novel. Last year, an estimated 14 million copies of his books in 38 different languages found their way onto beach blankets, airplanes and nightstands around the world. Patterson may lack the name recognition of a Stephen King, a John Grisham or a Dan Brown, but he outsells them all. Really, its not even close. (According to Nielsen BookScan, Grishams, Kings and Browns combined U.S. sales in recent years still dont match Pattersons.) This is partly because Patterson is so prolific: with the help of his stable of co-authors, he published nine original hardcover books in 2009 and will publish at least nine more in 2010.

title: Booted, but Not Suited
description: I CAN pull this off, I thought, coated in brown and admiring myself in one of the mirrors at the back of Daves New York.

title: Get the Blues
description: Avatar is many things to many people, as Dave Itzkoff reports on Wednesday, and it is many offensive things to many more people. The list of groups that James Camerons epic has angered includes:

title: The Great Unalignment
description: This time last winter, Democratic Washington was crackling with confident talk of a progressive re-awakening in the land and an enduring Congressional majority. Realignment was the word of the moment, as in the kind of demographic and ideological shift that shaped the nations politics for some 60 years after the election of Franklin Roosevelt. Now Democrats are trying to figure out how they lost what was presumed to be the safest Senate seat in the country  it belonged to Ted Kennedy for 46 years  and how to avoid hemorrhaging others. A year after George W. Bushs chopper swung away from the Capitol and disappeared from sight, voters seem to have put his presidency behind them; theyre no longer willing to blame Republicans alone for high unemployment and rising gas prices, for home foreclosures and tuition hikes. The crises that Bush bequeathed to Democrats have now officially become theirs, and the notion of a great liberal realignment seems as retro as Friendster. A string of Democratic lawmakers, largely from rural and contested states, the kind of places that were supposed to now be more hospitable to Democrats than they were before, recently decided to pursue other careers rather than risk being turned out by wrathful voters. Party leaders who had once hoped to expand their majorities in November are now showing signs of panic as they scramble to stave off the prospect of crippling losses.

title: Hes Got It Bad, or Baad, for His Art
description: ASK Melvin Van Peebles about his legacy, and you get a snort, a grimace, a wave of the hand, a game-show error buzz and a finely punctuated come on.

title: City Signals Intent to Put Fewer Teenagers in Jail
description: The Bloomberg administration plans to merge the citys Department of Juvenile Justice into its child welfare agency, signaling a more therapeutic approach toward delinquency that will send fewer of the citys troubled teenagers to jail.

title: No, They Probably Cant
description: Megan McArdle neatly distills the case for thinking that the knock heads, and pass health care now strategy is, in fact, a fantasy:

title: A Republican Steps Up to Senate Battle
description: ALBANY  Fresh off the upset victory of Republican contender Scott Brown in the Massachusetts Senate race, Bruce A. Blakeman, a Republican lawyer from New York City, arrived here on Wednesday to discuss his plans to run against Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand, the Democratic incumbent, this fall.

title: Blake Ousted in Five-Set Duel With del Potro
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Unseeded James Blake of Tampa, Fla., took the United States Open champion Juan Martn del Potro to the brink of elimination Wednesday night before yielding in a five-set thriller, 6-4, 6-7 (3), 5-7, 6-3, 10-8.

title: Commercial Focuses Attention on Issue Ads During the Super Bowl
description: Will television viewers take issue with issue advertising during a Super Bowl?

title: Wachtells Newest Hire: 90-Year-Old Morgenthau
description: Robert M. Morgenthau cant seem to quit practicing law.

title: Britain Tightens Antiterror Measures on Air Travel
description: LONDON  Acting on intelligence failures exposed by the attempted bombing of a Detroit-bound airliner on Dec. 25, Prime Minister Gordon Brown announced a major tightening of British aviation security measures on Wednesday, including the creation of a new no-fly list of terrorist suspects similar to one maintained by the United States.

title: A Renewed and Improved Henin
description: The luck of the draw was very unkind to Elena Dementieva, who fought for nearly three hours in her Australian Open loss to Justine Henin last night. The match could easily have been a Grand Slam semifinal, and the level of play by Henin, now starting what she calls her second career in tennis, astonished the capacity crowd at Rod Laver Arena. There was no sign that shes playing in only her second tournament since announcing her comeback. In fact, a case can be made that Henin 2.0 is an improved version of the former world No. 1.

title: Berkshire Holders Approve 50-to-1 Stock Split
description: Berkshire Hathaway said Wednesday that its shareholders had approved splitting the companys class B shares 50-for-1 as part of the companys $26.3 billion acquisition of Burlington Northern Santa Fe, the nations second-largest railroad.

title: What Kind of Weather Makes News?
description: Growing up in Chicago, I knew that a partly sunny forecast meant gray skies. And a partly cloudy forecast meant gray skies. The kind of wind that could turn your umbrella inside out was to be expected (just point the top toward the wind and move along).

title: Crunching the Numbers
description: As the Saturday deadline for turning in Oscar ballots looms, some voters are having a difficult time coming up with the 10 best picture nominees, reports Pete Hammond at The Los Angeles Times. I can barely find five movies to nominate; I have no idea what to do for 10, one member told him.

title: City Near Deal for New Coney Island Operator
description: Updated, 3:06 p.m.| It looks like Coney Island will not go without a whirling, clanging amusement park and a crop of new rides for the first time in more than a century as many had feared. The citys Economic Development Corporation is negotiating a lease with an amusement park operator, Zamperla USA, for six vacant acres in the heart of what has been the amusement district, between Surf Avenue and the ocean.

title: Vonn Reduces Helmet Design Choices to Three
description: The American Alpine skier Lindsey Vonn has reduced the choices for her Olympic helmet design to three finalists, which are now up for a vote on NBCOlympics.com.

title: Pets Find Relief at Airport
description: Dog parks are coming to an airport near you.

title: T. Boone Pickens Tweaks His Energy Plan
description: From our friends at the Wheels blog:

title: Sarah Palins Next Convention Speech
description: The news that Sarah Palin, the 2008 Republican vice presidential candidate, was hired to speak at the annual convention of the Wine and Spirits Wholesalers of America has drawn reactions ranging from puzzlement to consternation.

title: Morgan Stanleys New Chief Talks Risk (Again)
description: On Morgan Stanleys earnings conference call on Wednesday, new chief executive James P. Gorman reiterated his message of the moment: the bank has learned from its mistakes, especially when it comes to taking on too much risk.

title: Obama Aims at Tax-Evading Contractors
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, cracking down on tax cheats, said on Wednesday that the federal government would no longer award contracts to companies that did not pay their taxes, and called on Congress to pass legislation allowing the Internal Revenue Service to share information about businesses that owe back taxes.

title: Gang Brawl Inside Mexico Prison Leaves 23 Dead
description: MEXICO CITY  A prison riot between members of rival drug gangs broke out at an overcrowded state penitentiary in northern Mexico on Wednesday and authorities said 23 inmates were killed.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1) Clay Shirky argues that women are less likely to succeed in the workplace because they are bad at behaving like self-promoting narcissists, antisocial obsessives, or pompous blowhards, even a little bit, even temporarily, even when it would be in their best interests to do so.

title: Where Giants Dance and Crash in Japan
description: AT the edge of the balcony, a tiny woman was screaming. The elderly couple in the next row were jumping up and down. Below us, all around the ring at the Kokugikan, Japans national sumo stadium in Tokyo, a roaring crowd hurled seat cushions into the air. My husband and I looked at each other in amazement. After two weeks of travel among the intently well-behaved, rigorously unflappable Japanese, were we about to have a peek behind that decorous facade?

title: Obama: Seat Brown Before Moving Ahead on Health Care Bill
description: President Obama said today that Democratic leaders in Congress should not try to jam the health care bill through in the coming days, saying that lawmakers should wait to move forward on the legislation until Republican Senator-elect Scott Brown of Massachusetts is seated.

title: Laura Chapman Hruska, Co-Founder of Soho Press, Dies at 74
description: Laura Chapman Hruska, a founder and the editor in chief of Soho Press, an independent book publisher that specializes in literary fiction and exotic crime stories, died on Jan. 9 at her home in Manhattan. She was 74.

title: Scorecard | Gucci Wins!
description: We must be in the full swing of Milan fashion week because, as Scorecard knows, when it comes to Mondays shows critics werent afraid to let the barbs fly  yet somehow they never all quite seemed to agree. With rocker-chic faves Gucci and Versace going head to head, who came out ahead? Well give the win to Frida Giannini for her unexpected play of going back to Guccis pre-Ford-era heritage (theres that word again!), but tell us, do you agree?

title: JPMorgan Closes In on R.B.S. Sempra
description: JPMorgan Chase is the last bidder still in talks with Royal Bank of Scotland Group  to buy its commodity-trading joint venture, R.B.S. Sempra, in a deal that could be worth $4 billion, people briefed on the negotiations told DealBook on Wednesday.

title: Suit Charges Abuses by School Safety Officers
description: Five public school students and their parents are suing the city, claiming that school safety officers employed by the New York Police Department have wrongfully handcuffed, assaulted and arrested students.

title: New Mazda 5 Is First to Have Nagare Design
description: The doors to the Detroit auto show are still wide open to the public  it closes on Sunday  but the auto industry has moved on. The next major international auto show is in Geneva in early March, and several automakers have already begun to talk about their coming show vehicles. Mazda was among the first, revealing its newest design for the Mazda 5 minivan.

title: Conan Surges in the Ratings Among Young Viewers
description: Down to his final days  and perhaps hours  as an employee of NBC, Conan OBrien keeps pouring gas on the ratings fire he has been building since deciding not to accept a demotion in late night: Tuesday night, he once again routed his chief competitor, David Letterman of CBS, in early results measuring young audiences.

title: Defendant in Afghan Shooting Trial Vows No More Outbursts
description: A day after an outburst caused her to be removed from her own trial, a Pakistani neuroscientist accused of trying to kill government officials while detained in Afghanistan vowed to stay mum as testimony continued on Wednesday in federal court in Manhattan.

title: Behind the Scenes: A Doomed Classroom
description: When Peter Pereira arrived in the mountains above Carrefour, Haiti, he found the residents living without electricity, phone service or running water. And that was two months before the earthquake.

title: Haiti Quake Day 9: Hospital Ship Arrives
description: The U.S.N. Comfort, a United States naval hospital ship, treats its first earthquake patients in Haiti. For Haitian-American sailors it is a particularly meaningful duty.

title: Palin to Hit Campaign Trail for McCain, Other Republicans
description: Buoyed by Tuesdays election results in Massachusetts, former Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin will hit the campaign trail in the coming months for three Republicans seeking reelection this year.

title: A Career Crossroad for Johnny Damon
description: There was no real reason for Kenny Lofton to retire after the 2007 season. He was 40 years old, but he was still good. He had just played a full season and hit .290 with a .367 on-base percentage for Texas and Cleveland, helping the Indians come within a game of the World Series.

title: The Savory Take on Fruit Salad
description: The citrus salad that is the subject of this weeks Minimalist column began life as a dessert. But as I played around with it, I realized that I liked it more the sharper I made it, and that I had already done something similar in a dessert form. So  I went with the savory dish.

title: Rossi Happy With First Ferrari Test Day
description: Despite having to negotiate a wet track during the morning session, Valentino Rossi declared his first test day a success.

title: The Next Move for Democrats
description: Richard W. Stevenson, deputy Washington bureau chief for The New York Times, discusses the ramifications of Republican Scott Brown's victory over Democrat Martha Coakley for the Senate seat in Massachusetts.

title: Video Games | Loeffler Randalls Spring 2010 Look Book
description: Fashions forays in the digital realm have been as uneven as a pre-braces overbite, but thats not to say there havent been some noteworthy developments filling in the gaps. The SoHo-based label Loeffler Randall recently unveiled a slick Web site featuring shots by the photographer Jamie Isaia, and now the collaborative duo has followed up with a spring 2010 look book. Rather than go for the usual commercial shots, the designer Jessie Randall gave Isaia creative license to bring her vision to the project. The multimedia artist ran with the free rein  with the realist painter William-Adolphe Bouguereaus sense of motion and rosy tableaus in mind  by shooting the brands first video look book, making its debut above.

title: Lost in Translation
description: Bulgarians have something to celebrate today, as the countrys entry into the Oscar pool for foreign-language film, The World Is Big and Salvation Lurks Around the Corner, has advanced to another round. Eight other films made the shortlist, and as usual, there were some high-profile omissions. Those that made it include selections from Israel (Ajami), Kazakhstan (Kelin), the Netherlands (Winter in Wartime) and Peru (The Milk of Sorrow). The two most-well known films on these shores are Michael Hanekes The White Ribbon, the German entry, and A Prophet, (Un prophte) by Jacques Audiard from France. Both received rapturous reviews and the bulk of attention from other awards and critics groups.

title: Tavern on the Greens Last Sale, for Now
description: And now, welcome to Tavern on the Green: The Tag Sale.

title: A Durable Yet Vulnerable Eden in Amazonia
description: A new study has found that Yasun National Park in Ecuador, which sits atop major oil reserves, is home to the most diverse array of plants and animals in South America and possibly the planet. (One resident is the Ecuadorean poison frog, seen above transporting its tadpoles; image by Bejat McCracken).

title: Brown and His Daughters  a New Web Sensation
description: Scott Brown seemed to have a lot on his mind Tuesday night as he celebrated his upset win over Martha Coakley to become the next Senator from Massachusetts. Not only did he have a victory speech to make, he also seemed intent on marrying off his daughters.

title: Looking to Expand, but Fearing It, Too
description: THINKING CAPS TUTORING of Manhattan provides personalized study-skills coaching, subject-specific tutoring, enrichment programs and SAT preparation to about 300 middle and high school students annually. The business, which employs 30 tutors and part-time office help, had 2009 revenue of $500,000 to $600,000, says Alexandra Mayzler, who founded the company.

title: The War Between Apple and Google Has Just Begun
description: Update | 5:07 p.m. Added link to YouTubes start of its movie rental service.

title: Part of Munich Airport Closed After Security Scare
description: MUNICH  After an unidentified mans laptop set off alarms at Munichs international airport Wednesday indicating the possible presence of explosives, the traveler simply picked up the computer, walked into the crowded departure terminal and disappeared, touching off the fourth airport security scare in a month.

title: S.E.C. Seeks New Charges Against Rajaratnam
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission wants to expand its lawsuit in the widening Galleon Group insider-trading investigation by adding new charges against two defendants, Raj Rajaratnam, the hedge funds billionaire founder, and Anil Kumar, a former director of McKinsey & Company.

title: Natures Call: Drawing Inspiration From Avatar to Study and Create Organisms
description: Overview | Does seeing the unusual flora and fauna in the movie Avatar inspire a sense of wonder at the natural world? How might the film awaken interest in plant and animal life on Earth? In this lesson, students reflect on their experiences with nature, compare it to their impressions of the fictional Pandora and then use their observation and research skills skills to investigate awe-inspiring living things here on Earth. They then construct fantastical beings using features of the organisms they studied.

title: The Pitmen Painters Coming to Broadway
description: The acclaimed London production of The Pitmen Painters, about a group of British miners who become artists, will transfer to the Broadway house of the Manhattan Theater Club in September, the theater company announced on Wednesday.

title: Aid Urged for Groups Fighting Internet Censors
description: Five United States senators are publicly urging Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton to move faster to support organizations that are helping people in countries like Iran and China circumvent restrictions on Internet use.

title: Snack Time Never Ends
description: In the article Snack Time Never Ends, Jennifer Steinhauer writes about how snacking seems both mandatory and constant for American children. She writes, Apparently, we have collectively decided as a culture that it is impossible for children to take part in any activity without simultaneously shoving something into their pie holes.

title: Photo of the Week
description: A man walks through the Delaram district at sunset in southern Afghanistans Nimroz Province.

title: The Doctor Can See You Now
description: PLASTIC surgeons used to dispense advice primarily in private, face-to-face consultations, during which they would address a patients concerns and weigh the merits of surgery.

title: Should Surgeons Meet Patients Online?
description: IMAGINE the ease. Its 2 a.m. and you cant stop thinking about your saggy midsection. You log on to SurgeonHouseCall.com and create a free patient profile declaring your wish to get a tummy tuck. You fill out a brief medical history and include photographs of the problem area.

title: Roddick Shows a New Patience on Court
description: Andy Roddick dispatched the young Brazilian lefty Thomaz Bellucci in three workmanlike sets in the Hisense Arena in their second-round match. The match statistics tell a convincing story, that Roddick overwhelmed and outclassed Bellucci, winning 78 percent of points on his first serve and an incredible 75 percent of points on his second serve. He hit 11 aces and served no double-faults.

title: Seating Senator-elect Brown
description: BOSTON  Senator-elect Scott Brown plans to head to Washington Thursday, hoping to pave the way to be sworn in as soon as possible.

title: Trying to Make the Decision to Expand
description: We just published a small-business case study written by Adriana Gardella that reviews the expansion plans of Thinking Caps Tutoring, which offers personalized coaching, tutoring, and SAT preparation to about 300 students in public and private middle and high schools annually. Below are the analyses of several business owners with related experience:

title: Pictures of the Day: Wednesday, Jan. 20
description: Desperation and relief are the counterpoised themes from Haiti at the beginning of Wednesdsays show. Ruth Fremsons composition is the perfect visual expression of the term bottleneck. But Chris Hondros of Getty Images has captured what may be one of the first moments of unalloyed delight since last Tuesday.

title: From Lifes Assembly Line: Hits, Push-Button or Not
description: Tyne Daly isnt the first performer to reflect on the alarming way time seems to accelerate as the years pass. But her whip-smart, sophisticated new cabaret act, The Second Time Around, at Feinsteins at Loews Regency, explores the concept with wit and musical know-how along with an attitude of amused resignation. If modern life seems more and more like a science-fiction fantasy in which we are moving at what she calls warp speed, so be it; what other choice is there?

title: Answers About Roth I.R.A. Conversions: Part 4
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks in which you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: YouTube Takes a Small Step Into the Film Rental Market
description: SAN FRANCISCO  YouTube made its long-awaited entry on Wednesday into the business of online movie rentals. But do not expect to be able to stream to your PC the latest Hollywood blockbuster or even a flick from a studios dusty catalog of classics.

title: The Way We Ate: Too Old to Tiki?
description: In 1994, Ruth Reichl announced that New York had outgrown tiki bars. Her review of Gauguin, a French-Polynesian fusion palace that briefly occupied the basement of the Plaza Hotel, ended on the image of two exiting customers: a delighted child and her somber father. He was somber, perhaps, because he had had to foot the bill in a restaurant that paid rent to Donald Trump. More important, he was too old to believe in silly drinks and fake palms.

title: A New Comment System for By the Numbers
description: Hello By the Numbers readers! This is Hilary, Charless assistant, with some tech news:

title: Moon as Setting for Earthly Foibles
description: Haydn at the Hayden. The idea was terrific.

title: Bloomberg Cheers for Jets, and Quinn Wants a Recount
description: Sure, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg may have a little experience throwing out first pitches or tossing ticker-tape celebrations for triumphant championship teams. But maybe he should leave the cheerleading to Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker.

title: Comment of the Week
description: As disturbing as the graphic is, it is exceptionally well conceived. The minarets, as pointed out, resemble missiles, and I would argue that the message conveyed isnt that Sharia law is the next step, but that Switzerland will become a war zone. This is powerful propaganda and succeeds because of its fear-inspiring forms. Unfortunately tolerance, sweetness and reason tend to have far less dramatic images to promote them, and hence they lose in the battle for emotional resonance.

title: Megyn Kelly Gets Her Own Afternoon Program on Fox News
description: Megyn Kellys profile has risen a bit higher at the Fox News Channel.

title: Pushing Back: Jazz Notes Against the Current
description: The young pianist Aaron Diehl is putting his talent against the odds. What hes up to with his trio, which played at Smalls on Tuesday night, isnt new in the temporal sense or new in the art-movement sense, which is to say it isnt confrontational or puzzling.

title: What Were Reading
description: After filing for bankruptcy last July largely because of a boycott, Wild Edibles, one of New Yorks leading seafood sellers, has reached a tentative $340,000 settlement with the workers group that persuaded more than 30 restaurants to boycott the company.

title: Shopping With Enrico Bonetti and Dominic Kozerski
description: The New York-based designers sought out birdhouses and feeders that would appeal to birds and people alike.

title: Christie Channels His Inner Bruce
description: He was sworn in as the Boss of New Jersey state government Tuesday afternoon, so who could blame Christopher J. Christie   a devout fan of Bruce Springsteen, the states rock star laureate  from celebrating the occasion by taking the stage a few hours later at his inaugural party and belting out a few Springsteen songs?

title: Cheep Chic
description: BIRDHOUSES dont usually get as much attention from designers as human houses do, but theres no reason birds shouldnt have some style at home.

title: Children Speak for Same-Sex Marriage
description: LAST month, advocates and opponents of same-sex marriage packed the New Jersey State House in Trenton, supporters in blue, opponents in red. Near the end of the day, Kasey Nicholson-McFadden took the microphone. It doesnt bother me to tell kids my parents are gay, he said in a clear voice. It does bother me to say they arent married. It makes me feel that our family is less than their family.

title: Putting the Indie Back in Sundance
description: LOS ANGELES  Can Sundances new director redefine not just the festival but also the entire independent film industry?

title: Polling on Health Care  Divided and Unchanged
description: Despite yesterdays special election in Massachusetts and the ensuing assessments that the election was a referendum on health care reform, a spate of recent national polls signal that little has changed the publics mind over the last six months. Americans have remained divided over the health care legislation, without significant shifts.

title: Excerpt: 'The Deep End'
description: The ABC legal drama follows first-year attorneys and the bosses that torment them.

title: Obama Weighs Paring Goals for Health Bill
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama signaled on Wednesday that he might be willing to scale back his proposed health care overhaul to a version that could attract bipartisan support, as the White House and Congressional Democrats grappled with a political landscape transformed by the Republican victory in the Massachusetts Senate race.

title: In Shift, U.S. Lifts Visa Curbs on Professor
description: LONDON  Six years after using the Patriot Act to revoke the visa of a prominent Muslim academic, the United States State Department reversed itself and said Wednesday that it would no longer bar the scholar from entering the United States.

title: Mixing Bits From Columns A and B
description: When we complain that an artist is unoriginal, what do we mean? Some of the most original artists have not been among the greatest. Virgil, Shakespeare, Mozart, Balanchine were all heavily derivative.

title: A 3-D Tribute Planned for Jackson at Grammys
description: Michael Jacksons ability to provide audiences with technologically innovative, over-the-top spectacles has not been curtailed by his death. The coming Grammy Awards ceremony will include a special tribute to the King of Pop, featuring a portion that will be broadcast in 3-D, the Recording Academy said on Wednesday. Its not quite the return of Captain EO, the 3-D movie starring Jackson that was shown at Disney theme parks in the 1980s. But the Grammy Awards, which will be shown Jan. 31 on CBS, will honor Mr. Jackson with a performance that will show a short 3-D film, set to his Earth Song, that was originally being prepared for the This Is It tour he was rehearsing at the time of his death in June. The academy said that special 3-D glasses for this portion of the broadcast will be given out at Target stores (and of course to the audience members watching the Grammys at the Staples Center in Los Angeles). Other performers who will also participate in the tribute include Celine Dion and Smokey Robinson, above, as well as Jennifer Hudson, Carrie Underwood and Usher.

title: Vampire Weekends Contra Is No. 1 Album
description: Lets hear it for blogs, cable-knit sweaters and Morningside Heights: Vampire Weekend, above, the band of Columbia University graduates that began its rise to indie-rock fame long before it had released any recordings, has reached No. 1 on the Billboard album chart with its second album, Contra (XL). Issued last week, Contra sold 124,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, giving it an easy victory over Susan Boyles I Dreamed a Dream (Syco Music/Columbia), at No. 2 with 77,000 sales, and Ke$has Animal (Kemosabe/ RCA), which fell two spots to No. 3 with 67,000. Lady Gaga, who appeared on The Oprah Winfrey Show on Friday  and has also canceled several recent concerts because of exhaustion and dehydration  occupies two slots in this weeks Top 10: The Fame sold 64,000 to reach No. 4, and its companion mini-album, The Fame Monster, rose four spots to No. 6 with 36,000. (Both are released by Interscope.) With no other major new releases, the rest of the Top 10 is made up of familiar titles: Alicia Keyss Element of Freedom (J) is No. 5, Mary J. Bliges Stronger With Each Tear (Geffen) is No. 7, Taylor Swifts Fearless (Big Machine) is No. 8, the soundtrack to Alvin and the Chipmunks: the Squeakquel (Rhino) is No. 9, and the Black Eyed Peas E.N.D. (Interscope) is No. 10.

title: Those Daring Young Lawyers in Gray Flannel
description: The law relies on precedent, and so do legal dramas.

title: New York State Budget Would Cut Arts Funds
description: Cultural support in New York State would be cut $9.6 million under the 2010-11 budget proposed by Gov. David A. Paterson on Tuesday. A final version of the budget is due to be enacted by April 1. The governors proposal would cut funds to the New York State Council on the Arts by $6.5 million for its grant-making and by $600,000 for its administrative budget. In addition state support would be eliminated for the Egg performing arts center in Albany and begin to be phased out for the New York State Theater Institute in Troy. (There would also be a decrease of $400,000 from the 2009-10 budget because of the elimination of one-time funds for grants to arts and cultural organizations provided under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009.) Im deeply disappointed and distressed, said Norma P. Munn, the chairwoman of the New York City Arts Coalition, referring to the proposed reduction in arts council funds. Thats an extraordinary cut.

title: EBays Profit Rises Sharply, Aided by Sale of Skype
description: EBay earnings soared in the critical fourth quarter, fueled by growth in the PayPal business, the sale of Skype and success in luring more people to its shopping Web sites during the holiday season.

title: In Europe, the Arts Ask for Alms
description: BERLIN  Last week the shadow culture secretary for Britains Conservative Party, Jeremy Hunt, promised to introduce a U.S.-style culture of philanthropy if the Tories come to power in the coming election. Speaking before the State of the Arts conference in London, Mr. Hunt foresaw a golden age of tax breaks to encourage private donations and help cut back on government spending.

title: Health Care Bill May Be Scaled Back
description: With Democrats reeling from the Republican victory in the Massachusetts special Senate election, President Obama on Wednesday signaled that he might be willing to set aside his goal of achieving near-universal health coverage for all Americans in favor of a stripped-down measure with bipartisan support.

title: Showcase: Suddenly Long Ago
description: Asked to capture hope and change, 132 photographers in 79 countries answered in many ways. One chose to depict a man minutes after he was released from prison in Italy; another pointed her camera to a newborn baby in a Palestinian hospital.

title: As Usual, Idol Rules
description: An audition stop in Chicago turned up few Hollywood-bound candidates but yielded a typically large audience for American Idol on Tuesday night. That Fox reality show drew 26.1 million viewers, giving the network an easy win for the night and lifting a repeat of its new action series Human Target (9.2 million). CBS ranked second with a lineup of all repeats, including NCIS (14.1 million), NCIS: Los Angeles (12.3 million) and The Good Wife at 10 (9.6 million). NBC finished third with The Biggest Loser (9.9 million) followed by The Jay Leno Show (6.3 million), while ABC ranked a distant fourth. On Nickelodeon on Monday, a new installment of iCarly delivered a series record 11.2 million viewers at 8 p.m., beating all programming on network television in its time slot.

title: Icahn Wins in Bid for Las Vegas Resort
description: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn has made the winning bid to buy the bankrupt and unfinished Fontainebleau Las Vegas resort. According to court papers filed in Miami, the bankruptcy examiner in charge of running a court-supervised auction of the Fontainebleau said the only qualified bid received for the Fontainebleau was from Icahn Nevada Gaming Acquisition L.L.C., Reuters reports

title: (500 Days) Director Swings to spider-Man
description: If the next Spider-Man movie features an adorable nonlinear plot device, a musical number set to an underappreciated Hall & Oates song or a terrible final line that exhausts all your good will toward the film, now you know why. On Wednesday, Sony Pictures Entertainment announced that it had signed Marc Webb, above, the director of the hit romantic comedy (500) Days of Summer, to direct a fourth installment in its Spider-Man franchise, The Hollywood Reporter said. Last week news emerged that Sam Raimi, the director of the first three hit films about Spider-Man, and his star, Tobey Maguire, who plays the Marvel Comics hero and his alter ego, Peter Parker, were leaving the franchise over creative differences. Sony had said that it wanted to return the film series to the teenage roots of the Peter Parker character. In announcing that it had hired Mr. Webb, the studio said in a statement that it wanted a director who could capture the awe of being in Peters shoes so the audience could experience his sense of discovery while giving real heart to the emotion, anxiety and recklessness of that age. The new Spider-Man film is being planned for a 2012 release, but no stars or screenwriters have been announced.

title: Polanski Lawyers Say Prosecutors Misled Swiss
description: In their latest filing with the Los Angeles Superior Court, lawyers for Roman Polanski on Tuesday said officials with the district attorneys office had intentionally misled the Swiss government with a false record of Mr. Polanskis long-running sex case as a way to secure his extradition from that country. The claim is included in a brief for a planned Friday hearing on whether Mr. Polanski, who in 1978 fled the United States before sentencing on a conviction of having sex with a minor, should now be entitled to sentencing in absentia. Politics seems to be interfering with the just administration of the law, wrote Mr. Polanskis lawyers, Chad S. Hummel and Bart Dalton, in response to a district attorneys brief arguing that Mr. Polanski should have to appear before sentencing. This month the Los Angeles County district attorney, Steve Cooley, formed a committee to explore a run for California attorney general. Tuesdays filing did not specifically mention that possible run for state office, but it said the district attorneys insistence that Mr. Polanski return to the United States was a nakedly political approach to the case. Los Angeles prosecutors have long argued that Mr. Polanskis fugitive status deprived him of any right to challenge his treatment in California.

title: Food Production Made Palatable
description: Bobby Bognar seems willing to eat almost anything. But about once an episode on his new show, Food Tech, he encounters something even he is compelled to spit out.

title: Cuomo Files Suit to Shut Down Fund-Raisers
description: The telephone solicitor for the local Police Benevolent Association was polite at first, but when Toby Morse explained that she had decided not to give money this year, his tone shifted. He read aloud her address and wondered how sturdy her locks were. Over the following weeks, she received dozens of phone calls at all times of the day to press her for donations, including one from a man pretending to be a police officer.

title: I.B.M.s National Security Play
description: On the surface, I.B.M.s acquisition of the National Interest Security Company, a consulting firm, doesnt appear too noteworthy. No financial information was disclosed, and the news release is laden with technical jargon like predictive intelligence and enterprise architecture.

title: Mining Frail Aspirations in Rural China
description: The first feature from the young Chinese director Zhang Chi, The Shaft (Dixia de Tiankong) feels as though it were made by a very old soul. Tight and tender, this small family drama is so visually expressive that listening is always subordinate to looking.

title: Haiti Quake Day 9: Severe Aftershock
description: A strong aftershock struck near the Haitian capital on Wednesday morning.

title: Michelle Obama Tackles Childhood Obesity
description: On Wednesday, Michelle Obama asked the nations mayors to enlist in what she hopes will be her foremost project: an ambitious, wide-ranging effort to reduce childhood obesity.

title: Unions and Health Insurance
description: Last week, the Obama administration struck a deal with labor leaders to temporarily exempt union members from paying the excise tax on more generous health insurance plans. Why was this such a big deal?

title: App of the Week: Mimicking the Features of Google Voice
description: As iPhone users await Apples reconsideration of its decision to withhold Google Voice (and the subsequent F.C.C. inquiry), they do not have to go entirely without the features of Google Voice. Many are available through an app called Ribbit Mobile.

title: Wireless System Sends Bach or Bowie Into Your Light Bulbs
description: Klipsch, the speaker manufacturer, has come up with a twist on multiroom audio: wirelessly sending music to light bulbs around the house.

title: Earbuds That Dance or Not, and Have Artificial Intelligence
description: Technocel, an electronic accessories company, introduced what it calls the Ear Vibe, the first stereo headset that vibrates to the beat of your music at the Consumer Electronics Show. The $30 earbud-style headphones begin to move a bit when they encounter low-frequency notes. Its kind of a makeshift bass enhancement.

title: An Architect Pays Respects to a Dowager
description: BOSTON  More than a few eyebrows will likely be raised on Thursday when the Italian architect Renzo Piano unveils his design for the expansion of the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum here.

title: A Great but Costly Printer Is Now More Affordable
description: Hewlett-Packard made a splash last year with the introduction of its PhotoSmart Premium TouchSmart Web inkjet printer. The all-in-one device connects directly to the Web with built-in Wi-Fi. The TouchSmart Web also connects directly to the Internet to print photos, coupons, maps, event tickets and other images by using apps that are downloadable from H.P.s App Studio.

title: At 90, a Fresh Start for Morgenthau
description: So what does a recently retired 90-year-old do in a tough economy? Well, if youre a legendary former prosecutor with a Rolodex as extensive as the Bible and a passion for legal briefs, you do like Robert M. Morgenthau: join a big-time law firm.

title: Time to Cowboy Up
description: The polls had barely opened in Massachusetts on election day, a winter dawn that showed Democrats really were going to lose the seat of the lion Teddy Kennedy, when the stocks of big health care companies started to surge.

title: Now at Starbucks: A Rebound
description: SEATTLE  Young people wearing hoodies and chunky glasses are sipping microbrew beers and espressos, nibbling on cheese and baguettes made at a local bakery and listening to a guitarist strum and sing.

title: Chevy Volt Pricing: The War of the Asterisk
description: How much will the forthcoming Chevrolet Volt actually cost? Is it the low $30,000s? Or is it around $40,000? Call it the war of the asterisk. The growing confusion over the pricing of battery E.V.s and plug-in hybrids has to do with a $7,500 federal tax credit for purchasers of cars with battery packs of 16 kilowatt-hours or more. With high prices made unavoidable by expensive batteries, carmakers are sorely tempted to simply lower the price by the amount of the credit, then add an asterisk and fine print reading, Price includes a $7,500 federal tax credit.

title: An Obama Anniversary, Mostly Unheralded
description: Happy anniversary, Mr. President.

title: After Dempsey: A Look at the U.S. Depth Chart
description: Clint Dempseys knee injury proved not to be as severe as initially thought. But the prospect that the U.S. and Fulham midfielder would miss the the rest of the Premier League season and the World Cup revealed serious anxiety over the Americans attacking options for South Africa.

title: Foxwoods Owner Reaches New Debt Forbearance Pact
description: The Mashantucket Pequot Tribal Nation, which owns the Foxwoods Resort Casino in Ledyard, Conn., has reached a new agreement in principal with its senior lenders over a debt forbearance, with the deadline now pushed back to April.

title: Talk to The Times: Janet L. Robinson and Martin A. Nisenholtz
description: Senior executives of The New York Times Company will answer questions from readers on Thursday about the companys decision to charge for frequent use of NYTimes.com, which will take effect in 2011. (For more details, read the companys announcement and this article about it.)

title: Fish Tank: Hand-Held Warning
description: To the Editor:

title: Pierre Boulez: Revisiting the Revolution
description: To the editor:

title: Double Features: Two Shows? Try Four
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An earlier version of this article referred incorrectly to the National Rifle Association rating of Scott Brown, the winner of the special Senate election in Massachusetts. He had an A rating from the group, not an F rating.

title: Overweight on Air France
description: The touchy subject of how airlines should or should not treat obese passengers came up again today when Air France issued a new policy to refund heavier passengers the cost of a second seat, but instead found itself having to clarify the move.

title: Several Shades of Jazz, Some Infused With Metal
description: Myra Melfords Be Bread

title: Salazar Seeks Import Ban on Invasive Snakes
description: Reptile retailers, brace yourselves: the federal government wants to ban the import of some large and seemingly popular snakes.

title: Screen Language, Deciphered
description: Screen Language,

title: When Facing Eviction or Foreclosure, The Neediest Cases Fund Offers Hope
description: A New Yorker seeking shelter and warmth underneath cardboard boxes and ratty blankets along the city's wind-whipped streets is a typical image of homelessness  and the image that springs to mind for many people when they fall into a financial crisis. Below, the seven agencies supported by the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund explain how they are able to keep people in their homes or are able to provide more secure housing by pulling from the emergency reserve.

title: Trying to Stop Four Spades, With a Hint and Without
description: The most successful players at the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y., held Jan. 12 to 18, were R. Jay Becker of New York and Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J.

title: A View From Inside Coakleys Camp
description: Martha Coakleys campaign had originally planned on spending less money in the general election against Scott Brown than it had spent winning the Democratic primary, its chief strategist said in an interview today.

title: Newly Released Books
description: Women are front and center on this months list of new books, as authors and as characters. Tracy Chevalier (Girl With a Pearl Earring) tests whether fossil hunters are as appealing as Dutch painting, while Elizabeth Kostova has left vampire tales for the realm of art. Another female character is on the lam from her husband, a small man in many ways. But not to worry, Ozzy Osbourne is on hand to supply the testosterone.

title: Five Questions for Victor Garber
description: Victor Garber is tired of people telling him how closely he resembles Garry Essendine, the womanizing, petulant, vain, showy-rich actor he plays in the Roundabout Theater Companys Broadway revival of Noel Cowards comedy Present Laughter.

title: A Look Thats Bulletproof
description: JACK BAUER is in play again, and so is his hard-guy attire  sweaty T-shirt, leather jacket and that government agents staple: a bulletproof vest.

title: Taliban Overhaul Image to Win Allies
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Taliban have embarked on a sophisticated information war, using modern media tools as well as some old-fashioned ones, to soften their image and win favor with local Afghans as they try to counter the Americans new campaign to win Afghan hearts and minds.

title: Fall 2010 Mens Wear Collections
description: Photos from the Prada, Giorgio Armani, Dolce & Gabbana, Gucci, Verace and Ermenegildo Zegna shows.

title: Climate Change Bill Is in Doubt
description: As Democrats on Capitol Hill and the White House contemplated the fallout of the special election results in Massachusetts on Tuesday, proponents of major climate change legislation said they would persist in their efforts to win passage of a bill this year, despite a hostile political environment.

title: Trying to Paint the Deity by Numbers Against a Backdrop of Jewish Culture
description: In her latest novel Rebecca Newberger Goldstein envisions an intellectually sublime creature who is named Lucinda Mandelbaum, known as the Goddess of Game Theory and famed for something called the Mandelbaum Equilibrium, which is one of the non-Nash equilibria in zero-sum games. Lucinda is also a beauty and a triathalete, as long as were counting glamorous attributes. Ms. Goldstein would be on thin ice with an ber-woman like Lucinda if she herself were not a paragon in her own right.

title: Crunching the Numbers, Part 2
description: As we near Oscar nomination day on Feb. 2, the Bagger decided to get all Malcolm Gladwell and apply some behavioral economics to the campaign process. We spoke with Jehoshua Eliashberg, a Wharton professor of marketing and operations management who has studied the film business for 20 years. Hes also developed a sideline predicting a movies eventual box office based only on its script, with impressive accuracy.

title: Fashion Takes a Lie-Down
description: AS the new spring fashion advertisements begin circulating in earnest this month, you may be tempted to ask when it became O.K. for models to lie down on the job.

title: 36 Arguments for the Existence of God
description: The Argument from the Improbable Self

title: Robert B. Parkers Gentle Knight
