description: When Robert B. Parker died the other day  sitting at his desk, they say, working on a novel  his private eye alter ego died with him. And while we might pretend that Spenser is now among the immortal shades of other recently departed sleuths created by Ed McBain, Donald E. Westlake, and Tony Hillerman, the truth is that another hero has left town for good.

title: Buffett Assails Bank Tax and Praises Blankfein
description: Once again, its been Warren E. Buffett Day on cable TVs financial programs (and to some degree on DealBook as well).

title: He Wasnt The One Weve Been Waiting For
description: Health care reform  which is crucial for millions of Americans  hangs in the balance. Progressives are desperately in need of leadership; more specifically, House Democrats need to be told to pass the Senate bill, which isnt what they wanted but is vastly better than nothing. And what we get from the great progressive hope, the man who was offering hope and change, is this:

title: Read My Hips: These Are Jeans That Fit
description: THE big issues and tough questions are what concern us here in Style Land. Let other people fret about the recession, health care and the future of Conan OBriens pompadour. What troubles us is how the male consumers simplest decision somehow became the most difficult and fraught. Why, that is, are blue jeans, that most blameless and universal item of apparel, the one thing men always get wrong?

title: A Best Friend, Yes. Best Runner, Maybe Not.
description: A MANS friend is not always his best choice of a running partner. The same can be said of mans best friend.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 949 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: How Fast Is Your Web Connection?
description: When Andrew M. Odlyzko investigated why the Internet connection from his home in Minneapolis to his office just over two miles away was so sluggish, he found the answer: the data was taking a round trip to Denver.

title: U.N. Official Says Climate Deal Is at Risk
description: WASHINGTON  Just a month after world leaders fashioned a tentative and nonbinding agreement at the climate change summit meeting in Copenhagen, the deal already appears at risk of coming undone, the top United Nations climate official warned on Wednesday.

title: China Paints Google Issue as Not Political
description: This article was reported by Edward Wong, Jonathan Ansfield and Sharon LaFraniere, and written by Mr. Wong.

title: Packets Full of Miracles
description: HOW wrong can you go for $2.25? Thats the price of a packet of 20 tomato seeds from Baker Creek Heirloom Seeds. The variety Im considering is called Furry Yellow Hog, and the catalog copy suggests that it has citrus notes and a four oclock shadow, two traits I have never associated with a tomato.

title: The Cool Crowd
description: A look inside the a few of the homes of those who have chosen to forgo heat.

title: How an Inflammatory Term, Baathist, Bars Candidates in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Seven years after the United States-led invasion, and three years after the leader it overthrew was executed, a question in Iraq remains unanswered: Who is a Baathist?

title: Union Responds to Maras Comments
description: The N.F.L. players union fired back at team owners Wednesday, one day after the Giants co-owner John Mara said he was frustrated by the pace of labor negotiations and was resigned to a 2010 season without a salary cap, starting in March.

title: Still Jumping Strongly, Plushenko Makes a Comeback
description: TALLINN, Estonia  It certainly looked like the old Yevgeny Plushenko: from the hair (bowl cut on top, long in the back) to the ballet dancers flexibility to, above all, the jumps.

title: Accord Reached to Let Honduran President Depart
description: MEXICO CITY  The president-elect of Honduras agreed on Wednesday to grant safe passage to the Dominican Republic for ousted President Manuel Zelaya next week, in a deal designed to offer a graceful exit for the deposed leader.

title: China to Slow Lending to Fight Inflation
description: HONG KONG  Chinese authorities signaled Wednesday that bank lending would slow significantly this year, the latest in a series of moves intended to forestall inflation and stave off bubbles in the stock and property markets.

title: From Boston to D.C., Recapping the Day
description: Its been a dizzying day of blog posts, online and print articles, graphics and video, related to the election results in Massachusetts that resulted in the victory for Scott Brown, the Republican. From the Bay State to Capitol Hill, the developments have been incoming at a rapid pace.

title: Regret on Himalayan Glaciers Estimate
description: An international scientific panel overseen by the United Nations expressed regret on Wednesday for publishing an unsupported estimate of the speed at which Himalayan glaciers were melting. The estimate, included in a landmark 2007 report by the group, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, said that the glaciers in the Himalayas could disappear by 2035. The figure was culled from a dated magazine interview with an Indian glacier scientist who now denies that he used that number. Although there is abundant evidence that glaciers are retreating, scientists differ on the speed of that trend and which glaciers will be affected.

title: Guilty Plea in Sale of Products With Steroids
description: VMG Global, a sports nutrition company in California, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to selling products under the guise of dietary supplements that had been illegally spiked with steroids, according to court documents.

title: I.O.C. Panel Calls for Treatment in Sex Ambiguity Cases
description: A panel of medical experts convened by the International Olympic Committee recommended Wednesday that the issue of athletes whose sex seems ambiguous be treated as a medical concern and not one of fairness in competition.

title: White House: Obama Still Prefers a Major Overhaul
description: President Obama may have signaled some willingness to compromise on a scaled-back version of health care legislation, but the White House wants to be clear that the presidents first preference is to pass the sort of far-reaching legislation that lawmakers and the administration were negotiating before the Republican victory in Massachusetts upended everything.

title: Finding High Design on Sale
description: Mariette Himes Gomez, the New York decorator, will have a sale at her store, the Shop, below, on antiques and on new furniture and accessories designed by Ms. Gomez, from Jan. 27 to 31 (a chrome and glass coffee table, originally $7,900, will be $5,300); 504 East 74th Street (York Avenue), (212) 288-4971, theshopnyny.com.

title: Let the Good Times Roll
description: AvroKO, the design firm in NoLIta, has collaborated with Eben Freeman, a mixologist, to create a professional-grade version of that old entertaining workhorse, the bar cart. The look was inspired by vintage travel bar suitcases and airline galley carts from the 1950s and 60s, said Adam Farmerie, one of the designers. Mr. Freeman provided ergonomic insight on what is required for a fluid drink-making process. The result? A high-end mini bar that can be a stage for hosts to perform some fun cocktail theatrics, said William Harris, another designer.

title: Haitians and Hasidim Find Common Cause
description: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y.

title: Chilled by Choice
description: SERIOUS cold, Justen Ladda said, is when the sponge in the kitchen sink feels like wood or the toothpaste freezes or the refrigerator turns itself off, as it did one particularly frigid day last winter. Not that Mr. Ladda, a 56-year-old sculptor who has lived heat-free in his Lower East Side loft for three decades, is bothered by such extremes. Winter comes and goes, hell tell you blithely, adjusting his black wool scarf and watch cap. (Along with fingerless gloves, long underwear and felt slippers, they are part of Mr. Laddas at-home uniform when the mercury dips.)

title: Cohen Is Back on Ice After a Long Absence
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  The moment Sasha Cohen stepped onto the ice Wednesday for practice at the United States Figure Skating Championships, the cameras started clicking.

title: Local Stop: Tompkinsville
description: In Tompkinsville, Staten Island, its not just the streets that intersect. Cultures converge as well.

title: Uninvited White House Guests Take the Fifth at Hearing
description: WASHINGTON  Michaele and Tareq Salahi, the couple accused of sneaking into President Obamas first state dinner in November, declined to answer questions posed by lawmakers on Wednesday.

title: Zardari Re-emerges, but Effect on Pakistan Is Unclear
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  For the first time in months, President Asif Ali Zardari is doing what presidents normally do  giving rousing speeches, traveling around the country and asserting himself publicly as the countrys chief official.

title: If Your Password Is 123456, Just Make It HackMe
description: Back at the dawn of the Web, the most popular account password was 12345.

title: Clients Who Want It All, and Designers Who Love Them
description: BUNNY WILLIAMS and Bill Stubbs gave a talk to a room of designers as part of a lecture series at the Decoration & Design Building last week (sorry, like the swatches at Schumacher, which held the breakfast after, it was open to the trade only). And while the purported topic, according to Mr. Stubbs, a decorator based in Houston, was how to build a brand, the real subject was how to handle a difficult client.

title: Foreign Languages Fade in Class  Except Chinese
description: WASHINGTON  Thousands of public schools stopped teaching foreign languages in the last decade, according to a government-financed survey  dismal news for a nation that needs more linguists to conduct its global business and diplomacy.

title: Designers of an Ottoman
description: Mary Little and Peter Wheeler are known for their designs for contract furniture companies  their Pool collection for Brayton, for example, made quite a splash several years ago. But until now the two, who hail from Ireland and England, respectively, and work under the name Bius Studio, have not approached the consumer market, except through private commissions.

title: Architect, or Whatever
description: AT the Ballard Farmers Market in Seattle on a recent weekend, passers-by could be forgiven for thinking John Morefield was running for political office. Smiling, waving and calling out hellos to everyone who walked by his stand, he was the picture of friendliness. All he needed was campaign buttons and fliers.

title: Class, Please Take Your Seats
description: Furniture Masters is one of the design industrys best-kept secrets. The 62-year-old family business has provided custom upholstery services to a veritable Whos Who of designers for decades. Now the Long Island City company is opening its doors to those who want to learn the craft, offering a five-week workshop where students will be taught to upholster a club chair, provided by the company  from the preparation of springs and webbing and the cutting and sewing of a muslin pattern to covering the chair with fabric. The course will be taught by Rogelio Olguin, a master upholsterer with more than 25 years experience, and the finished chair is the students to keep. The class meets from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. on five consecutive Saturdays, beginning March 6; the cost is $1,800, which includes all materials except fabric. Information: furnish-d.com.

title: The Massachusetts Election
description: If anyone should have seen it coming in Massachusetts, it is President Obama  the long-shot candidate who rode to electoral victory on a wave of popular impatience and an ability to identify and address voters core anxieties.

title: Fisk Takes Aim at McGwire
description: Carlton Fisk gave voice Tuesday to something a lot of others Hall of Famers believe. No surprise, but theyre disgusted by the steroids era.

title: For Jets Sanchez, Its All About the Beard
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The maturation of Mark Sanchez is evident in his statistics, decisions and demeanor. The most obvious sign of growth, however, is on his face.

title: Tight-Lipped Colts Contrast Sharply With Blustery Jets
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Gary Brackett started out toeing the Indianapolis Colts company line. A month after they opened the playoff door to the Jets by pulling their starters with a 5-point lead in a Week 16 game, the Colts are confronted in the American Football Conference championship game with the monster they helped create. It is an irresistible story line to everyone but the Colts. Now they are channeling their inner New England Patriots, carefully crafting a compliment-a-thon for their opponent and tiptoeing around the obvious: the Jets probably would not have gotten close to playing this month if Curtis Painter had not entered the sports lexicon.

title: Obama Trying to Turn Around His Presidency
description: WASHINGTON  Chastened and bruised, President Obama on Wednesday began the daunting process of trying to turn around his presidency in a drastically altered political environment that will test his leadership, his instincts and his political dexterity as never before.

title: U.S. Envisions a Continuing Civilian Presence in Afghanistan and Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administrations ambitious civilian push in Pakistan and Afghanistan will keep thousands of Americans in those countries for years  rebuilding Afghan agriculture, rooting out corruption and using the local media to counter anti-American sentiment.

title: Tiling Minus the Trowel
description: Bondera TileMatSet is a new product that promises to simplify tiling by replacing mastic applied with a trowel with what amounts to double-stick tape. Im not particularly handy, so I wanted to try it.

title: Packing a Series of Pluses
description: Apparently, the people in positions of power at Palm werent completely pleased with the plethora of Ps in the appellations Palm Pre and Palm Pixi, the app phones Palm produced for Sprint. Palm has now expanded the parade of Ps with a pair of improved products: the Palm Pre Plus and Palm Pixi Plus.

title: Pictures Tell the Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Girls on Film
description: Barbara wears a fur coat, a Marilyn wig and a blank stare. Deborah leans against the rear window of a car, casually smoking and Beth just sets things on fire in a parking lot. Inspired by Alfred Hitchcock, David Lynch, Douglas Sirk and other masters of sexy darkness, the photographer Alex Prager specializes in cinematic images of women. Her latest portraits can be seen at Yancey Richardson Gallery, which is presenting Week-End, now through Feb. 20. The exhibition of new work by Ms. Prager is the third installment in her trilogy of staged female portraits set in the artists native city, Los Angeles. Ms. Prager examines female types with wigs, makeup, retro costumes and intriguing narratives lurking just outside the frame that make you want to look.

title: Laughing It Up
description: Wyatt Cenac is one of our favorite Daily Show correspondents; his recent visit to Las Vegas in search of a free buffet lunch and an apology from Harry Reid was a prime example of his smart brand of funny. Tonight he hosts Some Folks, a brand new comedy and music show at the 92nd Street Y in TriBeCa. The program kicks off with appearances by the comedians Colin Quinn, the former Weekend Update anchor and host of Tough Crowd, and Morgan Murphy, currently a writer for Late Night With Jimmy Fallon. The soul singer-songwriter and guitarist Bridget Barkan will perform.

title: Whats in Store?
description: It may not generate the level of buzz as the impending e-reader, or represent a major technological leap for that matter, but Apples foray into the role of presenter has certainly excited classical music fans. Earlier this month the Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes gave an elegant performance of Beethoven in the glass cathedral of commerce on 67th Street, according to Anthony Tommasini. Tonight two famous first cousins once removed, Ira and Philip Glass will be at the companys SoHo outpost beginning at 7 p.m. for the latest installment in the free performance series, iTunes Live. Wendy Sutter and the new ensemble, the Glass Chamber Players, will perform too.

title: Haitis Many Troubles Keep Bodies Uncounted
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Dr. Alix Lassegue, the physician who runs this citys largest hospital, including its morgue, has been trying to figure out how many people died after the earth buckled so violently last week.

title: Vows to Move Fast for Haitian Immigrants in U.S.
description: MIAMI  Clutching their passports and well-thumbed documents, hundreds of illegal Haitian immigrants crowded into a Roman Catholic church here on Wednesday to seek help in applying for a program that would allow them to stay and work legally in the United States for 18 months.

title: The Gadget Trap
description: To the Editor:

title: Restoring the Sheen to the Hope Classic
description: LA QUINTA, Calif.  The history of the Bob Hope Classic is not so much written as engraved, and time has rendered even larger the outsized characters who have peopled it. From the time Arnold Palmer shot 22-under-par to win the first event in 1960, the Hope has been on a 50-year run that, for the most part, has glittered like a clear night in the desert.

title: Both Parties Seek Ways to Channel Populist Ire
description: WASHINGTON  The remarkable Republican victory in Massachusetts demonstrated convincingly that the deep populist anger fueling the Tea Party movement has migrated from the political fringe to the mainstream, forcing both parties to confront how to channel a growing mood of public resentment to their own ends.

title: TV Coverage of Womens Short Program
description: The womens short program at the United States figure skating championships from Spokane will be seen live on Universal Sports, starting Thursday at 10:30 p.m., eastern, until 2:30 a.m. Friday. Sasha Cohen is expected to compete at about 1 a.m.

title: Leonhard May Lose His Helmet, but Not His Head
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Jets safety Jim Leonhard has a bright pink shiner under his left eye to match the bright pink smudge on the right thumb that he broke earlier this season. He also got kicked in the back of the head last Sunday when his helmet popped off as he pounced on a loose ball.

title: Conan OBrien, With Ratings Rising, Keeps Punching
description: As his settlement with NBC stalled for yet another day and his ratings grow every night, Conan OBrien kept firing jokes at NBC in his Tonight Show monologue Wednesday night.

title: Quiet Start to Trial in Police Brutality Case
description: A decade ago, during jury selection in the case of the police officers accused of torturing Abner Louima, thousands of people marched across the Brooklyn Bridge to protest abuses by the police.

title: Discipline Helped Carve Path to Senate
description: WASHINGTON  Scott Brown lives by what he calls Army values, instilled 30 years ago when he joined the Massachusetts National Guard. The most regimented person I know, his oldest daughter calls the Republican politician, who abhors disorder while sometimes inviting it with audacious pursuits  whether jumping into frigid lakes at 5 a.m. (for triathlon training) or into a seemingly quixotic Senate race.

title: Green Mold in the Fridge
description: The Thursday puzzle is in a special format that cannot be reproduced in Across Lite. Click here to see the puzzle as it appears in print.

title: Home Fires: In Balad, Smoke and Fire
description: Balad Air Base in northern Iraq was once nicknamed Mortaritaville by the soldiers and airmen who called it home. When I was there from 2007 to 2008, mortar attacks were so common and seemingly ineffective that the frequent interruptions were often a welcome break from the daily grind.

title: Teaching Americans What Haiti Needs: Money
description: Dont send shoes, send money. Dont send baby formula, send money. Dont send old coats, send money.

title: Republicans Oppose Obama Deficit Panel
description: WASHINGTON  Top Republicans on Wednesday were hostile toward President Obamas plan to create a bipartisan commission on cutting projected deficits, raising doubts about the prospects of a main piece of his budget strategy.

title: F.B.I. Charges Arms Sellers With Foreign Bribes
description: Sometimes the proposition was delivered in a quiet corner of the Mandarin Oriental Hotel in Miami. Sometimes the setting was the elegant Ritz-Carlton Hotel, a few blocks from the White House.

title: What Would It Feel Like to Hold a 10-Inch Apple Tablet?
description: The imminent Apple tablet announcement is purportedly just days away. For weeks, reports have been flowing from screen manufacturers that an Apple tablet computer could offer a 10-inch screen.

title: The Other Side of the Other Wizard
description: Gilbert Arenas has the fame and the lavish contract, the All-Star credentials and the clever nicknames. His puckish reputation is so well established that even a felony gun charge can be plausibly cast as a misguided practical joke.

title: Back on Duty, but Under a Cloud After a Death
description: A woman, pregnant and clearly in distress inside an Au Bon Pain store in Brooklyn, needed medical help. Two city medical workers, waiting in line, refused to provide it; the woman eventually died.

title: Big Benefits Are Seen From Eating Less Salt
description: In a report that may bolster public policy efforts to get Americans to reduce the amount of salt in their diets, scientists writing in The New England Journal of Medicine conclude that lowering the amount of salt people eat by even a small amount could reduce cases of heart disease, stroke and heart attacks as much as reductions in smoking, obesity and cholesterol levels.

title: Legislature Approves Ethics Bills, but Few Cheer
description: ALBANY  With 59 largely unenthusiastic ayes, the State Senate on Wednesday approved a package of bills meant to combat political corruption and require elected officials to disclose more about their outside financial interests.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the election of Scott Brown, a Republican, to fill the Senate seat from Massachusetts that was long held by Edward M. Kennedy, a Democrat, misstated the amount of time Mr. Brown will fill the seat until it is up for election again. Depending on how soon he is sworn in, Mr. Brown will serve almost three full years  not two. (The next election will be in November 2012, and the winner will be sworn in for a six-year term in early January 2013.)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the declining fortunes of the Plaza Hotel in New York misspelled the surname of a part owner of the Oak Room, one of the Plazas restaurants. He is Joey Allaham, not Alaham.

title: Banks See a Leveling Off in Bad Consumer Loans
description: Since the financial crisis hit, banks have chipped away at the mountain of mortgages and credit card debt looming over struggling Americans. At last, those efforts appear to be paying off, at least for the banks.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report by The Associated Press in the National Briefing column on Wednesday about the felling of New Englands oldest and largest elm tree, known as Herbie, misstated its location. It was in Yarmouth, Maine  not Yarmouth, Mass.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a reunion of the passengers and crew aboard the US Airways jet that crash-landed onto the Hudson River a year ago misstated the location of the crash and the event that occurred 90 seconds into the flight. The crash was at 40 degrees 46 minutes 10.19 seconds north latitude, and 74 degrees 16.69 seconds west longitude  not south latitude. It was the intake of geese by the planes engines that took place at the 90-second mark, not the crash itself.

title: As Cuomo Stays Silent on a Candidacy, the Pressure on Him Grows
description: ALBANY  Is it Hamlet on the Hudson, Part 2?

title: World Bank Sees Slowdown in Global Growth as Stimulus Wanes
description: WASHINGTON  The global economic recovery, already fragile in some regions, will probably slow later this year as the effects of stimulus spending by national governments wane, the World Bank said on Wednesday.

title: Alastair Martin, 94, Court Tennis Star and Modern Tennis Executive, Dies
description: Alastair B. Martin, who won a host of national championships playing the venerable game of court tennis, then helped forge the modern era of the Grand Slam-style game, died Jan. 12 at his home in Katonah, N.Y. He was 94.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Saturday about the mood among New York Jets fans as their team prepared for the division playoff game against the San Diego Chargers misstated the time between playoff appearances. It was three years ago  a 37-16 loss to the New England Patriots  not five years ago. (A playoff game five years ago marked the Jets last victory in the playoffs, a 20-17 win against the Chargers.)

title: F.B.I. Violated Rules in Obtaining Phone Records, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Bureau of Investigation improperly obtained calling records for more than 3,500 telephone accounts from 2003 to 2006 without following any legal procedures, according to a newly disclosed report by the Justice Departments inspector general.

title: Rare Session for Supreme Court
description: The Supreme Court will hold a special session on Thursday, presumably to issue decisions. Such special sessions are unusual, leading many to suspect that the court will release its long-awaited decision in Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission, a major campaign finance case. The court has already taken the rare step of hearing arguments in the case twice. For the second argument, the court asked the parties to offer their views on whether it should overrule a 1990 decision that upheld restrictions on corporate spending to support or oppose political candidates, and part of the 2003 decision that upheld the central provisions of the McCain-Feingold campaign finance law.

title: Republican Outlines Plan to Seek Gillibrands Senate Seat
description: ALBANY  Fresh off the upset victory of Scott Brown, the Republican contender in the Senate race in Massachusetts, Bruce A. Blakeman, a Republican lawyer from New York City, arrived here on Wednesday to discuss his plans to run against Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand, the Democratic incumbent, this fall.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a debate by the board of WBAI, New York Citys countercultural radio station, over whether to seat a new member, Lynne F. Stewart  the radical lawyer imprisoned for aiding terrorism  referred imprecisely to Danny Schechter, who said of WBAI: I wouldnt call it a collective. Id call it a collection. Although he has produced documentaries that were broadcast on WBAI, and has often appeared on air, he has never been on the staff of the station.

title: Fed Chief in New York Defends Main Office
description: The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York warned Wednesday against auditing the Federal Reserves interest-rate decisions and curbing its regulatory powers, as some in Congress have urged. It was his most detailed defense to date of the central banks conduct during the financial crisis.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 8 about Dubai Worlds negotiations with its creditors misidentified one of its foreign bondholders. It is Aurelius Capital Management in New York, not a company in Vienna with the same name. The Vienna firm pointed out the error in an e-mail message on Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Jail Protest by Immigrant Detainees Is Broken Up by Agents
description: Agents in riot gear from Immigration and Customs Enforcement tried to break up a hunger strike by detainees at the Varick Federal Detention Center in Lower Manhattan on Tuesday, three detainees at the center said Wednesday in telephone interviews.

title: A Percolating Candidacy
description: Conservatives quietly mobilized behind a state senator, Scott Brown, to fill the Senate seat left empty by the death of Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Ruling Backs Judge Who Rejected Post-5 P.M. Appeal
description: A Texas judge who refused to keep a courthouse open to receive a last-minute death penalty appeal did not engage in serious wrongdoing and should keep her job, according to a judge reviewing ethics complaints against her.

title: Banks Derivatives Activity Falls Under I.R.S. Scrutiny
description: Federal authorities are scrutinizing certain financial derivatives that may enable Wall Street banks to avoid collecting billions of dollars in withholding taxes on stock dividends.

title: Code Violations Found in Manhattan Schools
description: More than one third of Manhattans public school buildings have hazardous code violations, including many that have gone unresolved for years, threatening the safety of children and teachers, according to a report by the Manhattan borough presidents office.

title: Obama Picks Loretta E. Lynch for Brooklyn U.S. Attorney
description: The White House announced on Wednesday that President Obama would nominate Loretta E. Lynch as United States attorney for the Eastern District of New York, setting her up for a return to a post she held at the end of the Clinton administration.

title: Obama to Propose Limits on Risks Taken by Banks
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday will publicly propose giving bank regulators the power to limit the size of the nations largest banks and the scope of their risk-taking activities, an administration official said late Wednesday.

title: Apple Courts Publishers, While Kindle Adds Apps
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Its a formidable high-tech face-off: Amazon.com versus Apple for the hearts and minds of book publishers, authors and readers.

title: Amazon Cracks Open the Kindle
description: As Motoko Rich and I report in Wednesdays New York Times, Amazon.com is finally opening up the Kindle to developers. This has the potential to turn a popular single-purpose device into a more interesting and versatile gadget, limited only by the imagination of third-party programmers  and by what they can do with its monochrome e-ink screen.

title: Surviving the Camps but Struggling in Brooklyn
description: Ruth Usherenko keeps an improbably thick book on a table beside the couch in her living room. In it are roughly 58,000 names, all belonging to Jewish Berliners who perished during Hitlers regime.

title: Lottery Numbers
3 Weeks Into Retirement, Morgenthau Takes a Law Job
description: So what does a recently retired 90-year-old do in a tough economy? Well, if you are a legendary former prosecutor with a Rolodex as extensive as the Dead Sea Scrolls and a passion for legal briefs, you do as Robert M. Morgenthau did: join a big-time law firm.

title: Heightened Concern Over BPA
description: The Food and Drug Administration has raised its level of concern over the safety of bisphenol-A, or BPA, an industrial chemical found in baby bottles and the linings of canned goods and other consumer products. That is a welcome shift in attitude by an agency that seemed bent, during the Bush administration, on minimizing the potential for harm. But it sheds little light, for now, on how dangerous the chemical might be in the small amounts that leach out and are imbibed by infants and older people  or how rigorously it should be regulated.

title: Indian Tribes Await Their Due
description: After more than a century of obstruction and delays, still another deadline looms for a settlement that would compensate hundreds of thousands of American Indians for billions of dollars lost by a government that failed miserably to manage tribal lands that had been entrusted to it.

title: A Tern Around the World
description: We are all used to miniaturization in our daily lives  the steady shrinking of the electronic tools we use, like telephones and video screens. But what happens when miniaturization reaches the natural world?

title: The Messages in a Political Upset
description: To the Editor:

title: She Dies, and We Still Cry
description: To the Editor:

title: Growing Up Distracted
description: To the Editor:

title: High-Tech Dashboards
description: To the Editor:

title: Democratic Silver Linings
description: Poor Democrats, cheer up. Theres always a bright side.

title: Some Frank Talk About Haiti
description: On my blog, a woman named Mona pointed to Haitian corruption and declared: I wont send money because I know what will happen to it. Another reader attributed Haitis poverty to the low I.Q. of the 9 million people there, and added: It is all very sad and cannot be fixed.

title: Aftershocks
description: Port-au-Prince, Haiti

title: Tortures Loopholes
description: TOMORROW will be one year since President Obama signed an executive order outlawing torture, yet our debate about interrogation methods continues. Though the president deserves praise for improving matters, the changes were not as drastic as most Americans think, and elements of our interrogation policy continue to be both inhumane and counterproductive.

title: Snake Ban Proposed
description: Responding to concern over alien snakes in the Everglades, the Fish and Wildlife Service proposed to ban the import and interstate transport of Burmese pythons and eight other snake species. Interior Secretary Ken Salazar announced the move at Kennedy Airport in New York, the nations biggest entry point for wildlife imports. The proposal would add four species of python, four species of anaconda and the boa constrictor to a list of injurious species regulated by federal law, making their import and interstate transportation a misdemeanor.

title: Schwab Prices Its Offering at $19 a Share
description: Charles Schwab, the largest American online brokerage, said on Wednesday it priced an offering of more than 26 million of its shares at $19 a share, Reuters reported.

title: Path to the Senate
description: With his victory in Massachusetts, Scott P. Brown is the unlikely successor to Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the possibly fatal agent of President Obama's health care bill and the protagonist in one of the great political upsets in recent memory.

title: Why Bankers Tend to Hoard
description: The big gap between short- and long-term interest rates should mean fat lending profits for American banks. But some, like Wells Fargo, are wary of rising interest rates. Higher rates overall might encourage them to lend, but simultaneously could reduce their capacity to do so. Its a tricky problem.

title: Word of the Day |excerpt
description: excerpt \ek-srpt, eg-zrpt,\ noun and verb

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Another Brodeur Shutout, Another Sedin and Burrows Show
description: Only three games on Wednesday night, highlighted by the goaltending showdown in Newark. There Martin Brodeur of New Jersey and Team Canada, making his 27th straight start for the Devils, faced Tomas Vokoun of Florida and the Czech Republic. Home teams listed first:

title: China on Path to Become Second-Largest Economy
description: BEIJING  China said on Thursday that its economy rose by 10.7 percent in fourth quarter compared with a year ago, as the country continued to surge forward even as many other nations are still trying to punch through the global recession. That was up from a revised growth rate of 9.1 percent in the third quarter.

title: For Super Bowl XLIV Advertisers, Synergy Is the Name of the Game
description: FOR millions of football fans, the Super Bowl is the biggest social occasion of the year. That is becoming the case for Super Bowl advertisers, too, as they add a robust presence in social media like Facebook, Twitter and YouTube to their marketing lineups.

title: Exodus to Countryside Reverses Long Trend
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Arckela Dorvil carefully lifted his teenage sister from the road, practically holding his breath, trying desperately not to aggravate her wounded right side. He climbed into the back of a truck called Love Divine.

title: Marshall Nirenberg, Biologist Who Untangled Genetic Code, Dies at 82
description: Marshall W. Nirenberg, a biologist who deciphered the genetic code of life, earning a Nobel Prize for his achievement, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.

title: News Quiz | January 21, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Q.&A. on NYTimes.com
description: Q. Will access to NYTimes.com be free for subscribers to the print newspaper?

title: GenRe Settles With U.S. Over A.I.G. and Prudential
description: A unit of Warren E. Buffetts Berkshire Hathaway, General Re, has agreed to pay $92.2 million to settle accusations that it helped the American International Group and Prudential Financial manipulate financial statements, the federal government said Wednesday.

title: Corrections
description: The Fitness column last Thursday, about nutritional supplements for exercisers, overstated Dr. Teri M. McCambridges role at the American Academy of Pediatrics. She is the chairwoman of its council on sports medicine and fitness, not the chairwoman of the entire academy. The article also referred incorrectly to nitric oxide; although caffeine is often added to supplements that contain it, it is not a caffeine-based stimulant. And a picture caption with the article misidentified the exerciser who begins his morning workout by taking N.O.-Xplode. As the article correctly reported, he is Michael Deutsch  not Alex Feintuch, who is shown in the picture.

title: Corrections
description: The Letters column last Thursday misstated the surname of a reader who defended the value of physical therapy. She is Barbara Bell, not Ball.

title: Sinosteel Said to Seek I.P.O. Approval by June
description: Sinosteel, the Chinese state-owned metals trader, plans to file for an initial public offering of Chinese A-shares before March and get the required approvals by June, Huang Tianwen, the president of Sinosteel, was quoted as saying on Thursday, Reuters reported.

title: CrowdFlower Gets $5 Million for Crowdsourcing
description: From Brad Stone at Bits:

title: Why Massachusetts Voted Brown
description: Carolyn Ryan of The New York Times analyzes the different campaign styles of Scott Brown and Martha Coakley and how they may have determined the outcome of the Senate race in Massachusetts.

title: Why Bankers Tend to Hoard
description: The big gap between short- and long-term interest rates should mean fat lending profits for American banks. But some, like Wells Fargo, are wary of rising interest rates. Higher rates overall might encourage them to lend, but simultaneously could reduce their capacity to do so. Its a tricky problem, Reuters Breakingviews says.

title: Bloggingheads:  How Brown Won
description: Ezra Klein, left, of The Washington Post and David Weigel of The Washington Independent discuss Scott Brown's winning strategy.

title: Obama to Propose New Limits for Banks
description: President Obama on Thursday will publicly propose giving bank regulators the power to limit the size of the nations largest banks and the scope of their risk-taking activities, an administration official said late Wednesday.

title: Some Disappointing Earnings Send Markets Lower
description: A day after gliding to 15-month highs, Wall Street stocks had their steepest losses since mid-December on Wednesday as investors fretted over lackluster profits and a slowdown in global lending.

title: American Posts a Loss as Revenue Falls 7.4%
description: American Airlines ended 2009 with a loss and could start 2010 with a thud if the carrier loses its Asian partner, Japan Airlines, which filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday.

title: Annual Poll of Freshmen Shows Effect of Recession
description: The recession hit this years college freshmen hard, affecting how they chose a school as well as their ability to pay for it, according to an annual nationwide survey released Thursday.

title: Banks See a Leveling Off in Bad Consumer Loans
description: Since the financial crisis hit, banks have chipped away at the mountain of mortgages and credit card debt looming over struggling Americans. At last, those efforts appear to be paying off, at least for the banks, Andrew Martin writes in The New York Times.

title: Morgan Stanleys Quarter Is Weak, Unlike Pay Pool
description: By almost any measure, 2009 was a lean year for Morgan Stanley  except when it came to pay, Graham Bowley writes in The New York Times.

title: Banks Derivatives Activity Falls Under I.R.S. Scrutiny
description: Federal authorities are scrutinizing certain financial derivatives that may enable Wall Street banks to avoid collecting billions of dollars in withholding taxes on stock dividends.

title: Fed Chief in New York Defends Main Office
description: The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York warned Wednesday against auditing the Federal Reserves interest-rate decisions and curbing its regulatory powers, as some in Congress have urged. It was his most detailed defense to date of the central banks conduct during the financial crisis.

title: Questions for Cristine Cronin of NYCharities.org
description: For several years now, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has depended on nycharities.org to manage online donations. Cristine Cronin, the president and founder of NYCharities.org, answers a few questions about online giving and how it supports the Fund.

title: Baghdatis Hobbles Through Upset at the Australian Open
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  An irrepressible Marcos Baghdatis of Cyprus had just clawed his way back from two sets down to a 5-1 fifth-set lead when his legs began to cramp  again and again.

title: Blackstone Said to Apply For British Bank License
description: It seems the Blackstone Group, which counts leveraged buyouts, real-estate investment, hedge-fund management and financial advisory among its areas of expertise, is donning yet another hat: savings bank.

title: From Uno to Undici: Pizza Chain Files for Bankruptcy
description: Burdened by debt from a 2005 private equity takeover, the Uno pizzeria chains parent company filed for Chapter 11 protection Wednesday, with plans to give its lenders a controlling equity stake in exchange for debt.

title: American Idol 9 on 9: The Orlando Auditions
description: On Thursday night, an American Idol first, I believe: an on-screen arrest of a contestant. But is Idol still worth being arrested over? Or having  your old arrests dragged out into the sunlight? I mean, lets have some perspective: the guest judge Kristin Chenoweth couldnt even be bothered to stick around for Day 2 of the auditions in Orlando, Fla., though all she missed was a teenage felon.

title: Symetra Offering May Overshadow 5 Other I.P.O.s
description: The 2010 U.S. market for initial public offerings opens this week with a company connected to famed investor Warren E. Buffett getting most of the attention.

title: Lavish Worlds, and the Headwear to Match
description: When Lady Gaga finished her thumping, strobing, razzle-dazzle song-and-dance numbers at Radio City Music Hall on Wednesday night, she held her pose and kept the stage lights on, delighting her many camera-wielding fans. Her Monster Ball tour always provided something worth a snapshot: a sci-fi tableau, perhaps, or a skimpy, glittery costume. The more her image gets around, the better Lady Gaga does. Take my picture! she urged the audience, in her first of four sold-out shows at Radio City. I want to be a star.

title: Is It Issues, Ideology or Independence?
description: The election of Republican Scott Brown to succeed Ted Kennedy in the Senate has prompted soul-searching among Democrats and celebration among Republicans. But what else might it be about? What drives Americans election decisions?

title: Rosenfelds Gambit: Defying the Oracle
description: Irene Rosenfeld is clearly feeling lucky, Reuters Breakingviews says. Ms. Rosenfeld, the chief executive of Kraft Foods, raised her price to secure Cadburys agreement to a takeover. But in reducing the stock component, she also removed a chance of Warren E. Buffett voting against the deal, the publication notes.

title: U.S. Offers Pakistan Drones to Urge Cooperation
description: ISLAMABAD  The United States will provide a dozen unarmed aerial spy drones to Pakistan for the first time as part of an effort to encourage Pakistans cooperation in fighting Islamic militants on the Afghanistan border, American defense officials said Thursday. But Pakistani military leaders, rebuffing American pressure, said they planned no new offensives for at least six months.

title: Clean Filtration Gets $3.5 Million
description: Clean Filtration Technologies, maker of a self-cleaning filtration system for drinking and waste water, has pocketed $3.55 million of a targeted $7.2 million round of financing, VentureBeat reported.

title: Illegal Flower Donation
description: Flowers left outside Googles offices in Beijing as a protest against state censorship.

title: Infinium Capital Buys Fox River
description: Infinium Capital Management, the high-frequency futures trader, said in a joint statement late Wednesday that it would take over Fox River, a high-volume trader and specialist in equity options.

title: Loch Capital Hurt By Galleon Ties, Report Says
description: It seems that Loch Capital Management, a Boston-based hedge fund, may be the latest victim of the insider trading scandal surrounding the Galleon Group, Reuters reported.

title: Greece Mulls Bond Issue to Resolve Deficit
description: Greece is confident it can meet its financing needs as it grapples with a ballooning budget deficit and may issue bonds in yen and dollars this year to do so, top Greek officials declared Thursday, saying that the country could issue the bonds this year.

title: London Finance Jobs Market Picks Up, Survey Says
description: Hiring is set to rise in Londons financial sector this year, according a new jobs survey by the recruiting firm Morgan McKinley.

title: Its Not All About Tennis for the Williams Sisters
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Venus Williams caught the play Jersey Boys this week and was photographed holding a guitar with the cast doing her best Pete Townshend. She has played a little tennis here, too, but she really didnt have much to say about her performance.

title: At a Dutch Church, a Tale of Two Countries
description: The former church known as De Nieuwe Kerk has built a reputation over the last couple of decades with exhibitions tailored around specific countries, often thematically or historically linked back to the Netherlands. A show at the museum (Dam Square; 31-20-638-6909; nieuwekerk.nl), simply titled Oman, focuses on the history and culture of that Middle Eastern country.

title: In Nottingham, Theres a New Sheriff in Town
description: If Manager Billy Davies takes his club to the Premier League, Forest fans will do more than make him the sheriff of Nottingham by proclamation  he will be the new earl of Englands East Midlands.

title: Creditors to Sell Stake in Olympic Ski Sites
description: Creditors of Intrawest Holdings, which owns the Whistler ski resort where part of the Winter Olympics are set to take place next month, plan to put their stake in the company on the auction block in February.

title: Investors Watch Health Care in Wake of G.O.P. Win
description: Investors and distressed market advisers on Wednesday said the surprise Republican senate win in Massachusetts may present opportunities in health care bonds, hospitals and medical companies, Reuters reported.

title: Kraft Bond Investors Disagree With Buffett
description: Warren E. Buffett may have real doubts about Kraft Foods $19.3 billion takeover of Cadbury, but debt investors apparently dont.

title: Oracle Wins E.U. Approval for Acquisition of Sun
description: The European Commission said Thursday that it had approved the proposed $7.4 billion takeover of Sun Microsystems by Oracle, the U.S. software giant, because it would not significantly affect competition in the European Union, Matthew Saltmarsh writes in The New York Times.

title: Celebrity: How Sick Is That?
description: Todays idea: Modern society is an enabler of morbidly self-obsessed celebrities, an essay says, because people use them much as they use hypochondriacs  as foils for their own mortal fears.

title: China Said to Punish Banks for Overlending
description: China punished some banks, including Bank of China, for lending too much, after a surge in new loans this year increased inflationary pressures, sources said on Wednesday citing central bank figures, Reuters reported.

title: Super Bowl III Telecast Replayed Saturday
description: Passing along two e-mail messages I received:

title: Live Nation May Sell Concert Sites for Deal, Report Says
description: Live Nation is willing to sell some of its concert sites on favorable terms to a rival, Anschutz Entertainment Group, in exchange for dropping its opposition to Live Nations proposed merger with Ticketmaster, The New York Post reported.

title: An Antitrust Investigation of the Banks?
description: Simon Johnson is a professor at M.I.T.s Sloan School of Management and a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics.

title: Istithmar Chief Resigns, Amid Dubai Woes
description: Dubai World has shown the chief executive of Istithmar World the door, as the conglomerate struggles renegotiate its roughly $22 billion of debt load, Bloomberg News reported.

title: The Ford Logo That Almost Was
description: There are many interesting auto logo stories, including Cadillacs recent discarding of its heraldic ducks in favor of a new version of its shield and crest. And BMW recently cleared up the history of its logo, saying that its based on the Bavarian flag, not a spinning propeller.

title: Sampler: BART Airport Extension in Trouble and a Reward for a Missing Goat
description: BART Scrambles for Federal Funds | The Federal Transit Agency has threatened to give away $70 million in economic stimulus funds slated for the extension of BART to Oakland International Airport unless BART prepares an adequate analysis the projects impact on the poor and minorities in its path. BART officials hope to break ground on the 3.2-mile extension this summer. Critics have called the extension a ski lift to the airport for the elite. I think this is a problem of process, said James Fang, the president of BARTs board. We are confident we can beat back this last obstacle to the project. [The Oakland Tribune]

title: The S.E.C.s Whistle-Blower Problem
description: By now, its well known that the Securities and Exchange Commissions system of handling whistle-blowers is in dire need of fixing, as the fraud cases of Bernard L. Madoff and R. Allen Stanford have shown.

title: John Edwards Admits Paternity
description: John Edwards, who twice sought the Democratic presidential nomination, admitted in a statement on Thursday that he is the father of Frances Quinn Hunter, the 2-year-old daughter of his former mistress, Rielle Hunter.

title: Speed Read for Thursday, Jan. 21
description: Here are some highlights from Thursdays edition of The New York Times:

title: View From Indianapolis: Jets Beat a Freshman Team
description: The folks in Indianapolis may be tired of hearing how the Jets held their own against the Colts first unit in December. Bob Kravitz, The Indianapolis Star:

title: Goldman Reports $4.95 Billion 4th-Quarter Profit
description: Goldman Sachs said Thursday it earned $4.95 billion in the fourth quarter, rounding out a very strong year for the Wall Street bank in 2009, The New York Timess Graham Bowley reports.

title: Strong Year for Goldman, as It Trims Bonus Pool
description: No one was crowing about their big paychecks at Goldman Sachs headquarters in New York on Thursday. Despite a record 2009, the bank announced that it had set aside only $16.2 billion to reward its employees.

title: A Face-Off in Coal Country
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va.  Although a forum unfolding here today is nominally concerned with the Future of Energy, a very specific practice of energy resource extraction  and one prevalent in Appalachia  will hang heavy in the air: mountaintop removal coal mining.

title: Rex Ryan Uncut, Colts Week
description: First the Super Bowl, then Rex Ryan can take over The Tonight Show.

title: The Early Word: Browns in Town
description: Senator-elect Scott Brown Massachusetts , is in Washington on Thursday.

title: Two Medical Workers Speak Out
description: A woman, pregnant and clearly in distress inside an Au Bon Pain store in Brooklyn, needed medical help. Two city medical workers, waiting in line, refused to provide it; the woman eventually died.

title: The Underpants Gnomes Theory of Reform
description: Watching some liberal members of the House explain why they wont do whats necessary, and pass the Senate bill, I was wondering what they imagine will happen. Then the answer came to me: its the Underpants Gnomes business plan. In its original form this was:

title: Taking Sundance Back to Its Roots
description: The Bagger is making her way to Park City, Utah, on Thursday, just in time for what Brooks Barnes says may be the most important Sundance in years. The festival has a new director, John Cooper, whose self-imposed mandate is less commercial, more independent. Turning it to that direction, Mr. Barnes writes, may be a harbinger for independent cinema in general, which has seen its ranks shuffled now that many studios have shuttered or shrunk their boutique divisions.

title: See India by Luxury Train
description: Indias first cross-country luxury train the Maharajas Express will make its maiden journey from Mumbai to Delhi on March 6, stringing together subcontinental highlights from the iconic Taj Mahal to remote habitats of tigers.

title: Warren Buffetts Lost Vote
description: Kraft has deliberately structured its final offer to acquire Cadbury so that it wont need the approval of its shareholders. That act of shareholder disempowerment isnt sitting well with Warren E. Buffett.

title: Conan OBriens New Sidekick: The Bugatti Veyron Mouse
description: Last night, Conan OBrien introduced a new series of skits as he concludes his final week as host of The Tonight Show.

title: Conan OBrien and NBC to Part Ways
description: Say farewell to Conan OBrien.

title: Tsonga Keeps Dent on His Heels
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  In a strangely muted display of power versus stealth, 10th-seeded Jo-Wilfried Tsonga of France shut down the net-rushing game of Taylor Dent of Bradenton, Fla., in straight sets on Thursday night, 6-4, 6-3, 6-3.

title: Conan OBrien Finally Signs Off
description: Bill Carter reports:

title: Jets Win Probability vs. Colts: 28 Percent
description: (Brian Burke, a former Navy pilot who has taken up the less dangerous hobby of N.F.L. statistical analysis, operates Advanced NFL Stats, a blog about football, math and human behavior.)

title: The Developing Consensus
description: Thursday morning brought the release of the nominees for Britains Oscars, the BAFTAs, and the list reflected the growing consensus of this awards season, with one homegrown exception. Avatar, Up in the Air, The Hurt Locker and Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire all received nominations for best picture. The wild card was An Education, Lone Scherfigs film about a teenage girl in the England of the early 1960s being wooed by a man twice her age.

title: One Part of One Closing School Will Be Spared
description: Education officials said Wednesday that community pressure had persuaded them to change course on a small part of their decision to close 20 schools for poor performance next year, in the first such reversal since the closings were proposed.

title: The Nifty 50 | Teddy Cruz, Architect
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Police Explain Diversion of Flight to Philadelphia
description: Updated, 3:06 p.m. | A Philadelphia police spokesman, Lt. Frank Vanore, offered the following account of the confusion that ensued on US Airways Flight 3079 after a 17-year-old Orthodox Jew put on tefillin, the prayer garment made from a pair of small leather boxes containing scripture and connected by leather straps, shortly after takeoff:

title: Thursday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused articles appear in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Talk to The Times: Answers About Charging Online
description: Senior executives of The New York Times Company are answering questions from readers about the companys decision to charge for frequent use of NYTimes.com, which will take effect in 2011. (For more details, read the companys announcement and this article about it.)

title: Banksy Strikes at Sundance
description: On Wednesday the Web started to percolate with word that Banksy had hit Sundance. Yes, the graffiti art that popped up in Park City, Utah, over the last couple of days was courtesy of everyones favorite anonymous street artist. But here is what the movie bloggers failed to figure out: This time, the art was just a sideshow to a film directed by the reclusive Banksy, Exit Through the Gift Shop, a surprise addition to the Sundance Film Festival, which kicks off on Thursday.

title: Obamas Bank Proposal Helps Erase the Months Gains
description: Concerns over President Obamas plan to limit the activities of banks helped drag shares down on Thursday, erasing all the gains the stock market made in the first three weeks of 2010.

title: Jan. 21: Updates on the Crisis in Haiti
description: On Thursday The Lede is continuing to supplement reporting by our colleagues in Haiti on the aftermath of last weeks earthquake by pointing to news and information on the Web. Readers are encouraged to share any first-hand accounts they receive from Haiti or see online in the comments thread below. See the home page of NYTimes.com for the latest news articles and multimedia features on the relief effort. Previous Lede updates: Jan. 20 |Jan. 19 | Jan. 18 | Jan. 17 | Jan. 16 | Jan. 15 | Jan. 14 | Jan. 12 and 13

title: You May Now Resume Hassling the Hoff
description: After a highly contentious departure from the airwaves, a beloved personality has revealed the project in which hell make his long-awaited return to television. No, not Conan OBrien  David Hasselhoff. A&E said that it had ordered a new real-life docu-series (or as it is also known, a reality show) that will star Mr. Hasselhoff (or as he is also known, the Hoff) that will follow him as he raises two teenage daughters and attempts to help them find their places in the entertainment industry. Mr. Hasselhoff, the former Knight Rider and Baywatch star, said earlier this month that he was quitting his position as a judge of the NBC competition program Americas Got Talent, saying only that he was leaving to pursue his own series. The A&E show, which does not yet have a title, will take viewers on a shadowy flight with Mr. Hasselhoff and his daughters, Taylor-Ann, 19, a communications major at the University of Arizona, and Hayley, 17, a fashion model, who both aspire to be professional singers. Ten episodes have been ordered and are scheduled to be shown later this year.

title: An Antitrust Investigation of the Banks?
description: From Simon Johnson at Economix:

title: The Insider | Trevor Groth
description: The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here, Sundance Film Festivals Trevor Groth shares his essentials. The Utah native, who got his start at Sundance as an intern in 1991, became the director of programming last May. For the 2010 edition, which begins today and runs through Jan. 31, Groth and his team will present a roster of films that reflects a move back to the fests indie roots while at the same time showcasing works by filmmakers at the cutting edge of technology. He recently collaborated on a book, Take 100: The Future of Film: 100 New Directors, which will be published in May by Phaidon Press.

title: Mikey, Youre Not Alone
description: A week ago, I wrote about 8-year-old Michael Hicks, a Cub Scout who has the misfortune of sharing a name with someone on the governments terrorist watch list. That means that Mikey must jump through a few hoops to get a boarding pass and a seat assignment. The last time he flew, Mikey was aggressively frisked, his mother, Najlah Feanny Hicks, told me.

title: Grand Theft Autos New Weapon: The iPhone
description: If you have ever wanted to use your iPhone to murder someone, deal drugs or commit mayhem, your moment has arrived.

title: Ambush at Bardale
description: Omar Hammammi's face is finally uncovered in a 31-minute long video, released by the Shabaab. The instant jihadist classic  is a veritable homage to Omar.

title: Clinton Urges Global Response to Internet Attacks
description: WASHINGTON  Declaring that an attack on one nations computer networks can be an attack on all, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton issued a warning on Thursday that the United States would defend itself from cyberattacks, though she left unclear the means of response.

title: Banksy Strikes at Sundance
description: On Wednesday the Web started to percolate with word that Banksy had hit Sundance. Yes, the graffiti art that popped up in Park City, Utah, over the last couple of days was courtesy of everyones favorite anonymous street artist. But here is what the movie bloggers failed to figure out: This time, the art was just a sideshow to a film directed by the reclusive Banksy, Exit Through the Gift Shop, a surprise addition to the Sundance Film Festival, which kicks off on Thursday.

title: The Advantages of Incrementalism
description: To my suggestion that possibly, just possibly, voters are reacting negatively to ambitious liberal governance as well as to the unemployment rate, Jon Chait ripostes:

title: Billy Joels New Bobbers a Beaut
description: Hell for Leather on Wednesday showed off pictures of a terrific custom-built motorcycle that was headed to Brooklyn. Based on a Kawasaki W650, the bike was built by Deus Ex Machina, an Australian shop, and features a hardtail, a sprung seat, custom tank and peashooter pipes, among other mods.

title: Fibromyalgia, H.I.V. and Chronic Fatigue
Justices, 5-4, Reject Corporate Spending Limit
description: WASHINGTON  Overruling two important precedents about the First Amendment rights of corporations, a bitterly divided Supreme Court on Thursday ruled that the government may not ban political spending by corporations in candidate elections.

title: Rapidly Moving 39 Steps to Move off Broadway
description: Update | 1:04 p.m.  The revelation was hardly as suspenseful as an Alfred Hitchcock movie, but the producers of The 39 Steps announced on Thursday that their stage comedy, adapted from that 1935 film, will reopen off Broadway at New World Stages on March 25.

title: For College Freshmen, Ripple Effects From the Recession
description: They may not pay the tuition bills themselves, but college freshmen are clearly concerned about the recession, judging by an annual nationwide survey.

title: Send Us Your Lady Gaga Photos
description: Updated Jon Pareles writes that during the first of her four sold-out shows at Radio City on Wednesday, Lady Gaga urged the audience: Take my picture! I want to be a star. Were you at the show? Did you heed her request? Send us your photos, tell us about the show and well display some of the photos and your stories here.

title: The Concierge | Hors dOeuvres Duty
description: Christine Muhlke, T Magazines food editor and de facto concierge, is at your service. Have a dining or imbibing quandary for her? Leave your question in the comments section below.

title: A Lackluster Campaign
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: There was a huge Senate race in Massachusetts yesterday. Republican Scott Brown pulled off the upset. Now some Democrats are accusing their candidate, Martha Coakley, of running a lackluster campaign. They were especially confused by her campaign slogan, I guess we can?

title: Two Daughters Available
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on The Tonight Show With Conan OBrien on NBC: There was a big Senate race in Massachusetts yesterday. The winner, Scott brown, made a victory speech where he mentioned his two daughters were available. At least this explains his campaign slogan, Scott Brown, creepy for Massachusetts, creepy for America.

title: Hairs Gone Gray
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: It was a year ago today that the president moved into the White House. An since that time, his hairs gone gray, hes made some people mad at him, hes let down quite a lot of his supporters, which makes him perfect for his new job, host of The Tonight Show.

title: Answers About New Yorks High Schools, Part 2
description: Following is the second set of answers from Clara Hemphill, whose book series New York Citys Best Schools is regarded as the bible for navigating school choices.We are no longer accepting questions for this feature.

title: Easy Curries
description: A couple of years ago, at Jean Georges, my wife, Jackie, and I were served rack of lamb coated with crisp mint-scented panko crumbs. The sauce was basically the liquid part of a Thai curry, and it was just such a gas: it seemed to be a whole separate issue from the lamb, but the two things generated the most delicious, fun synergy, both on the tongue and up in the sinuses (my note on the dish says simply, Aroma).

title: One of Those Names
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: The Republicans elected a new senator from the State of Massachusetts. His name is Scott Brown. Thats one of those names they give you in the witness relocation program.

title: A Number of Explanations
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: Its hard to believe President Obama has now been in office for a year. And you know, its incredible. He took something that was in terrible, terrible shape, and he brought it back from the brink of disaster. The Republican Party.

title: Aid Groups Focus on Haitis Homeless
description: JACMEL, Haiti  Haiti has approved plans for more than a dozen sprawling tent cities in and around Port-au-Prince, the first step in an epic relocation effort that could reshape the country as up to one million people displaced by the earthquake find new places to live.

title: Return to Tomorrow: Old Sci-Fi Series From Star Trek Creator May Get New Life
description: Ron Howard and Brian Grazer are perhaps better known for projects about science-fact (say, Apollo 13) than science-fiction (though their adaptation of The Cat in the Hat was pretty trippy in a 2001 kind of way). But for their next project, the producing pair are boldly going where few have gone before: into the archives of the creator of Star Trek, Gene Roddenberry.

title: Offering Care for the Caregiver
description: The man was nearing 90, losing his sight and showing signs of early dementia. After examining his abdomen, I fumbled trying to help him get his shirt and pants back on. After an awkward few seconds, the patients middle-aged son sprang forward from his seat near the door and began working through the buttons, zipper and belt with a practiced deftness.

title: For Knicks Lee, a Grandfather, Mentor and Pal
description: David Lee used to go to the zoo with his grandfather. A lot of youngsters go to the zoo with their grandparents. This was a little different.

title: Who Takes Care of the Caregiver?
description: In todays Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline W. Chen writes about an aging patient with early dementia. But it was the mans middle-aged son who made the biggest impression. She writes:

title: Vain Glorious | Blow Outs to Benefit Haiti
description: With Vain Glorious, T Magazine breaks down the latest spas, salons and products for your aesthetic pleasure.

title: Political Fallout From the Supreme Court Ruling
description: Updated: Even before their Massachusetts victory this week, Republicans enjoyed a multitude of advantages in this years midterm elections. The Supreme Court has most likely just delivered one more: money.

title: Campaign Helps Prompt N.B.A. to Let Shannon Dunk
description: In December, I wrote about the grassroots campaign to get Lakers guard Shannon Brown in the All-Star slam dunk contest. Those efforts, which included YouTube videos, a barrage of Twitter activity, and a nifty catchphrase (Let Shannon Dunk!) with an eponymous website, paid off. On Monday, the league announced Browns selection for the contest, along with defending champion Nate Robinson of the Knicks and Gerald Wallace of the Bobcats. The fourth participant will be determined by a dunk-in contest between DeMar DeRozan of the Raptors and Eric Gordon of the Clippers, to be held at halftime of the Rookie-Sophomore game.

title: The Mighty Tumble in North Carolina
description: If you are feeling shaky today, it is understandable. Something is seriously out of whack. Apparently, a crease developed in the universe somewhere over North Carolina. The Duke and North Carolina mens basketball teams lost a game on the same night. Hasnt happened in 14 years. The jolt was so profound it even prompted John Edwards to stop lying about the child he fathered. We are awaiting confirmation that his hair also moved.

title: The Brinch
description: Suggested nickname for Simon Cowell.[British + Grinch]

title: Obamas Move to Limit Reckless Risks Has Skeptics
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama wants to cut down to size those too-big-to-fail banks. But his vow on Thursday to rewrite the rules of Wall Street left many questions unanswered, including the big one: Would this really prevent another financial crisis?

title: Interpublic Names New C.E.O. for Largest Unit
description: The long-running speculation over who would be named the next leader of the McCann Worldgroup, the biggest operating unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has ended. The answer: an executive from outside McCann but inside Interpublic.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1) One tally of the funds raised to support Haiti disaster relief: more than $350 million.

title: One-Legged Stools
description: As things fall apart on the health care front, one thing you keep hearing is the idea of doing reform in pieces  start with something popular, like banning discrimination on the basis of medical history, then do the hard stuff later.

title: Obama Moves to Limit Reckless Risks of Banks
description: Declaring that huge banks had nearly brought down the economy by taking huge, reckless risks in pursuit of profits, President Obama proposed legislation on Thursday to limit the scope and size of large financial institutions, The New York Timess Sewell Chan reports from Washington.

title: The New Bank Proposal
description: Heres the full text of the White Houses news release on its (new) bank proposal:

title: Part 4: Answers on the Fafsa and Financial Aid
description: For many high school seniors and their parents, this is the season for tackling the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, a notoriously cumbersome process that the government is attempting to streamline this year.

title: Leno to Return as Tonight Host on March 1
description: Choosing their words oh-so carefully, NBC and the comedian Conan OBrien issued a joint statement Thursday morning about a resolution of the issues surrounding OBriens contract to host The Tonight Show With Conan OBrien.'

title: Travel Deals: Hotel and Airfare Packages to Europe
description: Gate 1Travel.com, a tour company based outside Philadelphia, is offering several package deals to Europe through fall 2010.

title: Favorites Have Their Way in Second Round
description: In a tame day of tennis, the seeds came to rule in Melbourne, while former finalists found vastly different results in the second round of play.

title: Submit Questions for A.C. Milans Clarence Seedorf
description: The top of the Italian Serie A table looks familiar: Inter Milan leads the league with 46 points. But in second, trailing the four-time defending champion, is city rival A.C. Milan, with 40 points and a game in hand. The Rossoneri have reversed a problematic start to the season and enter 2010 with their sights set on a scudetto and the UEFA Champions League knockout round, where Milan will play Manchester United next month.

title: Arenas Contract Could Become Conundrum for N.B.A.
description: Earlier this month, I described the effect Gilbert Arenas suspension can have on the Wizards, the league, and Arenas himself. Since then, Arenas has pleaded guilty to a felony charge of carrying an unlicensed pistol. Sentencing is scheduled for March 26, and it is unlikely the league will act before then to change his current indefinite suspension.

title: What Should Children Learn About Race?
description: On a week that includes Martin Luther Kings Birthday and the inaugural anniversary of the first African-American president, Larissa Kosmos has questions.

title: Salary Talks Arent Verboten, Even in This Economy
description: As youve probably already heard, Wall Street executives are about to collect giant bonuses.

title: Theater Talkback: Charles Isherwood Answers Readers Questions
description: Charles Isherwood, a theater critic for The New York Times, answers readers questions about the state of New York theater, what makes a successful revival and the infamous flop Carrie.

title: More Naked, More Conflicted
description: On Jan. 3, the Book Review published Katie Roiphes cover essay on the aggressively virile sexual attitudes of the Great Male Novelists of the postwar period (Roth, Updike, Mailer, Bellow) contrasted with the mores of their more thoughtful, cuddly contemporary counterparts (Franzen, Chabon, Eggers, Wallace).
