description: Who would have thought an upset victory by a Republican in the Massachusetts Senate race would spur populist anger at the banks?

title: NBC Will Fill Tonight Slot With OBrien Repeats
description: NBC has solved one issue lingering after the departure of Conan OBrien on Friday: it will fill the week of Jan. 25 with repeats of earlier versions of Mr. OBriens show.

title: Dialing It Back at the Globes
description: Whether you thought Ricky Gervaiss performance as the host of the Golden Globe awards was too soft, too contemptuous or exactly right, he considers the show a success simply because he got through it. I was just so glad it was over so I could get drunk, Mr. Gervais said in an interview on Wednesday evening.

title: How Corporate Money Will Reshape Politics
description: We will be updating this discussion with additional commentary throughout the day. Scroll down to read Christopher Cotton, Heather K. Gerken, Eugene Volokh, Richard L. Hasen, Joel Gora, Michael Waldman and Fred Wertheimer in the forum.

title: Beyonc and Madonna Join Hope for Haiti Telethon
description: Beyonc and Madonna are among the more than 100 big names in music, film and television who will take part in Hope for Haiti Now: A Global Benefit for Earthquake Relief, a two-hour telethon on Friday night to be broadcast around the world on television and online.

title: On Tuesday, a Big Night for Fox News
description: The Fox News Channel was the big television winner on Tuesday night when the Republican Scott Brown won the Massachusetts Senate race.

title: Reactions to the Bank Proposal
description: Update | 2:50 p.m.

title: Million Dollar Quartet Scores Its Broadway Cast
description: Finding an Elvis Presley impersonator in New York probably isnt too much of a challenge; hiring convincing doubles for Johnny Cash, Jerry Lee Lewis and Carl Perkins is probably a few degrees of difficulty harder. But why bother when youve already got a cast that can do it, and has been doing it for more than a year?

title: The Art of Finishing Off an Opponent
description: Although we are just reaching the third round at the Australian Open, there has been no shortage of stirring five-set matches. Of the 96 matches played so far in the mens draw, 17 have gone to five sets. Remarkably, six of those matches involved a player coming back from being down, two sets to love. While Mikhail Youzhnys courageous win over Richard Gasquet, in which he overcame a 4-2 deficit in the final set while cramping, was noteworthy, some of these phenomenal comebacks have been lost in the noise and bustle of the first week.

title: Loyalties of Those Killed in Afghan Raid Remain Unclear
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A group of American and Afghan soldiers swooped into a village in a Taliban-heavy district early Thursday, fired their guns and came away. And in a scene repeated often here, one side cried murder and the other side claimed success.

title: Ford Dips Toe in Political Waters in Rockland
description: TAPPAN, N.Y. During the opening leg of a listening tour, New York Senate hopeful Harold E. Ford Jr. described the defeat of the Democrat Martha Coakley in the Massachusetts Senate race on Tuesday as a serious wake-up call to incumbents and called for the scaling back of Congressional health care legislation. At the same time, he urged his party to reclaim its place as the voice and conscience of the middle class.

title: Obama Bank Plan Overshadows Goldman Call
description: The earnings conference call at Goldman Sachs was dominated by President Obamas proposal to separate riskier proprietary trading from commercial banking, with analysts listening to the presidents announcement while the call was still going on.

title: All We Are Saying Is Give Pesce a Chance
description: There is a restaurant in Fort Collins, Colo., called Fish. It serves fish. Only fish. No meat or poultry. In Colorado. Crazy, huh? The only fish around Fort Collins are rainbow trout and cutthroat trout and brown trout and more trout, and a wayward salmon, perch or bass.

title: Johnson Discusses Losing Daughter
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  As Woody Johnson, the Jets owner, spoke at a conference table inside team headquarters Thursday, he tried to separate football wins and personal loss.

title: Robben W. Fleming, University President in Turbulent Times, Dies at 93
description: Robben W. Fleming, who as president of the University of Michigan in the late 1960s and 70s steered it through a turbulent era of student protests, using his labor negotiators skills to help defuse crises before they could turn violent, died Jan. 11 in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 93.

title: Right-Wing Flame War!
description: Charles Johnson has been writing a blog for almost as long as the word blog has existed. A bearish, gentle-voiced, ponytailed man who for three decades enjoyed a successful career as a jazz guitarist accompanying the likes of Al Jarreau and Stanley Clarke, Johnson has always had a geeks penchant for self-education, and in that spirit he cultivated a side interest, and ultimately an expertise, in writing computer code. His Web log, which he named Little Green Footballs (a private joke whose derivation he has always refused to divulge), was begun in February 2001 mostly as a way to share advice and information with fellow code jockeys  his approach was similar in outlook, if vastly larger in its reach, to the guiding spirit in the days of ham radio. His final post on Sept. 10, 2001, was titled Placement of Web Page Elements. It read, in its entirety: Heres a well-executed academic study of where users expect things to be on a typical Web page. It linked to, well, exactly what it said. The post attracted one comment, which read, in its entirety, Fantastic article.

title: Palm Pre Plus Magic
description: David Pogue looks at the Palm Pre Plus app phone.

title: Literary Pilgrimages: Exploring the Role of Place in Writers Lives and Work
description: Overview | How do places and experiences affect writers lives and works? Is where writer come from relevant to reading their work? In this lesson, students consider the power of place in their lives, research the life of a writer and develop travel brochures and annotated maps representing the significance of places in the writers life.

title: A Good Idea? The Amphibious Electric Car
description: Driving an electric car into a lake would seem, on the face of it, as fundamentally a bad idea as drowning a toaster in a bathtub.

title: Helping Bloomberg Help New Yorkers
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: The V Generation
description: Your new book, I Am an Emotional Creature, is a collection of 30-plus fictional monologues in which you assume the confiding, often plaintive, voices of teenage girls  from a Chinese factory worker to a sex slave in Africa to a schoolgirl in suburban America bemoaning her lack of purple Ugg boots. Why do you see yourself as a spokeswoman for teenage girls?  I dont feel like Im a spokesperson at all for girls. I just feel like, O.K., in the way that The Vagina Monologues was an attempt to communicate stories of women and their vaginas, this is an attempt to communicate the stories of girls on the planet right now.

title: James E. Cheek, Forceful University President, Dies at 77
description: James E. Cheek, who as president of the historically black Howard University in Washington led it through two decades of expansion amid periods of campus unrest and competition from predominantly white institutions, died on Jan. 8 in Greensboro, N.C. He was 77.

title: Pelosi: House Will Not Adopt Senate Bill
description: The House speaker, Nancy Pelosi of California, said on Thursday that Democrats remained committed to passing far-reaching health care legislation, but she said that the House would not simply adopt the Senate version of the bill and send it to President Obama in part because of problematic provisions that she said contributed to the Republican victory in the Massachusetts special election on Tuesday.

title: Rent Tour to Close
description: If there were only a song in Rent that noted the passage of time in excruciatingly precise detail, this might be the moment to cite it. On Thursday, press representatives for that musical said that its national tour will play its final performance on Feb. 7, making it the first time since it opened that Rent will not be performed on a Broadway or national stage. Rent, Jonathan Larsons rock-opera gloss on La Bohme, had its Off Broadway and Broadway openings in 1996 (after a workshop production in 1994), and went on to play 5,123 performances at the Nederlander Theater before closing in 2008. The national tour has played 373 performances in 39 cities, traveling 54,000 miles in the process. The final tour performances of Rent will take place Feb. 3 through 7 at the Community Center Theater in Sacramento, and will feature Adam Pascal, Anthony Rapp and Gwen Stewart, from the musicals original cast.

title: Speech Therapy
description: In 1966, William Labov, the father of sociolinguistics, discovered that many people with New York accents  the stock Noo Yawk kind  didnt like the way they talked. It was kind of sad. Labov found widespread linguistic self-hatred, he reported. People from New York and New Jersey described their own speech as distorted, sloppy and horrible. No wonder those great old accents came to be regarded as a class giveaway, to be thrown over in the name of assimilation, refinement and the acquisition of Newscaster English.

title: Obama and Pelosi Ignoring Publics Message, Boehner Says
description: The House Republican leader, John A. Boehner of Ohio, on Thursday said the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi of California, and President Obama were ignoring the message inherent in the Massachusetts election results, and that Democrats would pay a further price at the polls in November as a result.

title: Cold Case
description: I think Im going to faint, the tall, 35-year-old man said, grabbing the handrail of the stairs that led up from the beach. His brother turned back to see his older sibling collapse onto the sandy wooden planking.

description: Over at Economix, Catherine Rampell is gathering reactions from around the econoblogosphere to the Obama administrations (still somewhat hazy) bank proposal. Here is a sampling:

title: Switching Guardians
description: Our will stipulates that if my wife and I die, our daughter will be cared for by some longtime friends, who welcome the idea. Since making this plan we have learned that they feel different from us about money  they like living large  and we no longer want them to raise our daughter. Instead, we would like a nephew and his wife to do so. If we tell our friends, it will hurt them. If we dont, they may ultimately receive quite a shock. A note added to the new will would go down like a curse. Must we tell them now? J.D., NEW JERSEY

title: Jerilyn Ross, Advocate for the Anxious, Dies at 63
description: Jerilyn Ross, a therapist who helped hundreds of people overcome their worst anxieties and who became one of the countrys most visible and effective advocates for those with mental health problems, died on Jan. 7 in Washington. She was 63 and lived in Potomac, Md.

title: Steven Lovelady, Editor With a Deft Touch, Dies at 66

description: WASHINGTON  The federal government should require surveillance cameras in nearly all locomotives, to allow railroad managers to see if engineers are texting or talking on cellphones, sleeping or admitting unauthorized visitors, the National Transportation Safety Board recommended on Thursday.

title: Warming Expected to Cut Atlantic Hurricane Tally but Boost Threat
description: A new modeling study published in this weeks issue of Science projects a rise of about 30 percent in potential hurricane damage in the western Atlantic toward the end of the century as emissions of greenhouse gases rise. Although the overall number of storms in the region are expected to drop, the number of strong ones  those reaching Category 4 or 5 in the hurricane index  are expected to double from the number produced now, the study says. The projections are based on a midrange scenario for a rise in the heat-trapping emissions linked to global warming.

title: 36 Hours in Mexico City
description: POOR Mexico City. Just as it was luring back travelers with cool new hotels, a flourishing contemporary art scene and semi-endurable pollution levels, Mexicos escalating drug violence became front-page news. Then the capital became a swine flu epicenter. Suddenly, a run for the border didnt seem like such a smart idea. Ready for the truth? The time to visit this megacity  about 20 million people live in the metropolitan area  has rarely been better. Eager to attract people again, luxury hotels are offering specials that slash room rates by up to 65 percent. More restaurants, hotels and art galleries have sprung up in chic neighborhoods like Condesa and Roma. And Mexico City has probably never been this clean: even the street vendors now cart around big bottles of hand sanitizer.

title: Pleasures and Perils of Teaching Your Own Tot on the Slopes
description: RICHMOND, Vt.  It was five degrees on a Saturday morning at Cochrans Ski Area here last month, yet I was uncomfortably warm. Pools of sweat formed beneath my fleece zip-T, and my sunglasses fogged up against the clear blue, frigid sky. My quads burned. My forearms felt limp.

title: Can We Talk ... About That House in the Country?
description: NEW MILFORD, Conn.  A typical workweek is so frenetic for Joan Rivers  the comedian, Emmy Award-winning talk show host, jewelry designer, businesswoman, best-selling author, red carpet fashion roaster, reality TV star and plastic surgery zealot  that about the only time she sits is for hair and makeup. Occasionally she puts up her feet, but only for an eye lift or tummy tuck.

title: Metropolitan Museum Finds a Bald Man
description: The bust of a bald man with a deeply furrowed brow  a sculpture cast from tin alloy by the Austrian court sculptor Franz Xaver Messerschmidt  was acquired by the Metropolitan Museum of Art and approved by its board at a meeting last week. The sculpture, A Hypocrite and Slanderer, is the first by this artist to enter the museums collection and one of the few to be found in any American museum. (The Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, and the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles each have an example of his work.)

title: Time Change | Luxury Watches in Geneva
description: I took a brief leave of the catwalks to take in the annual SIHH luxury watch preview in Geneva. The packed hallways and buzzing booths were a welcome contrast to the quiet post-crisis scene a year ago. As usual there were the requisite one-upmanships between brands. Some innovations were astounding, others simply showy. There was an equally strong emphasis on heritage and brand DNA, with many companies focusing on line extensions, as theyre called, or simply slight updates of existing styles.Some industry leaders took a break from bloat and put their watches on strict, chronograph-free diets, Biggest Loser style. Piagets new Altiplano was recently named the world record holder for the watch with the thinnest automatic movement, as well as the thinnest automatic case. Rival Vacheron Constantins new Patrimony Traditionale 1968 was named the worlds thinnest manual winding watch. Finally, Baume & Mercier clocked in with its new Classima Executive, measuring only 4.4 millimeters thick, with a lean price of $1,490 for the quartz-movement watch. These three made strong, sleek statements that can hold their own against more complicated competitors.Cartier introduced the Montre Calibre, featuring a chunkier case and the first in-house-designed and in-house-produced automatic movement. A. Lange & Sohnes Zeitwerk Phantom was inspired by a dinner in the dark held in Berlin during the introduction of the original Zeitwerk. A UV-transparent coating allows the absorption of light by the numerals hidden beneath the face to glow in the dark. Audemars Piguet took cues from the car-racing world for its Royal Oak Offshore Grand Prix. The auto-inspired detailing and graphics, plus a dark forged carbon case and bright red anodized aluminum face, made for a racetrack-worthy watch. In one of the most innovative watches of the show, Montblanc introduced the Metamorphosis, a Transformer-style watch that has to be seen to be believed (and explained). This two-faced watch, the result of a collaboration between expert watchmakers, features two dials that separate to reveal two more hidden dials with chronograph functions.From the chic and seemingly simple to the innovative and complicated, this years SIHH confirmed that the vitality of the watch business depends on tradition as much as innovation.

title: Seaside Views, Sri Lankan Tastes
description: The seaside enclave of Tompkinsville sits on the north side of Staten Island, but, with a significant population of Sri Lankan immigrants, the neighborhood could easily be half a world away. To sample that nations cuisine or just enjoy the areas grand shoreline vistas, take the subway to South Ferry, hop on the ferry and, at St. George, take the Staten Island Railway one stop. Or opt for the scenic path: a casual 10-minute stroll along Bay Street.

It was the first such high-level trans-Atlantic meeting on the subject since the botched Dec. 25 bombing of an Amsterdam-to-Detroit flight by a passenger wearing explosives sewn into his underwear.

title: Pictures of the Day: Thursday, Jan. 21
description: A week later, the need and desperation persist in Port-au-Prince. Relief and security efforts (Slides 1 and 3) continued in the capital of Haiti, even as aid groups began shifting their focus to long-term challenges. In Washington, Senator-elect Scott Brown of Massachusetts visited his new workplace (Slide 7). Fresh from his amazing upset of the Democratic favorite, Mr. Brown was making more of a reconnaissance visit, since he cannot be formally sworn in until his victory over Attorney General Marcia Coakley is officially certified.

title: A Scaffold That People May Want to Walk Under
description: For decades, sidewalk sheds have been derided as urban eyesores. Their bolts have scratched and torn many a briefcase and shopping bag. They have been the bane, as well, of local businesses whose entrances  and signs  are blocked for months by all that wood and steel.

title: Exploring the Mysteries of Other Peoples Lives
description: Andr Tchins seductive drama The Girl on the Train opens with an extended traveling shot inside a tunnel. The camera appears to be perched at the front of the train, so that it looks as if were hurtling through the dark toward the nearing light, an apt description of what happens to the title character and, to an extent, the viewer. The film can be described as a character study or a fictionalized slice of terribly real life. Mostly, though, it is an inquiry into the mysteries of other people.

title: Barn Finds, Warts and All, at the Arizona Auctions
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  They are the Indiana Joneses, the automotive archaeologists who explore back corners and back forties, hoping to find the remains of a vehicle of value  or a barn find. Such cars are often captured in dramatic photography, rusting hulks amid, say, a field of wildflowers. And one author, Tom Cotter, has written a well-received series of books about barn-found vehicles and those who live for the hunt.

title: Going Back to the Well to Drink in the 70s
description: The maxim waste not, want not must be embroidered on a pillow somewhere in the director Murray Lerners home. In 1970 Mr. Lerner joined some 600,000 wet, chilled, increasingly cranky hippies on the Isle of Wight, off the southern coast of England, for a five-day outdoor concert. A quarter-century later Mr. Lerner released his best-known film about the event, Message to Love: The Isle of Wight Festival (1996), becoming a near Isle of Wight completist, with additional works on Miles Davis, the Who, Jimi Hendrix, Jethro Tull and Emerson, Lake & Palmer.

title: Gym. Tan. Laundry. Discuss.
description: Consider it an antipasto for Thursday nights season finale of MTVs reality series Jersey Shore. The John D. Calandra Italian American Institute at Queens College held a colloquium on guido culture on Thursday morning to discuss the uproar that has erupted over the shows depiction of the drinking, hot-tubbing, and brawling summer escapades of eight 20-somethings who proudly refer to themselves as guidos and guidettes.
