title: Ban Sought on Trade in Pythons and Kin
description: Even as the fight continues to keep Asian carp from spreading in the Great Lakes, the Obama administration is moving to stem the spread of another disruptive class of creature: Burmese pythons and other big constricting snakes that are efficient predators and, in many cases, appear to be thriving in Florida and possibly capable of doing so farther north.

title: The First Woman Through the Locker Room Door, 35 Years Ago
description: When the day finally came that she would break down a huge professional barrier, Robin Herman did not have much time to prepare. Herman, then a 23-year-old reporter for The New York Times, had been trying for a year to persuade N.H.L. teams to allow her and other women reporters access to athletes in the postgame locker room when, unexpectedly, the two coaches at the 1975 N.H.L. All-Star Game in Montreal said, yes, female reporters would be given the same access as men.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Rooting for Lovable Loser in a Furry Purple Suit
description: Pity poor Luciano, the sad-sack aspiring screenwriter played with twitchy, wild-eyed charm by Daniel Hendler in The Paranoids, a deadpan slacker comedy from Argentina. A childrens entertainer who dresses up in a furry purple suit to play a comic-book character at parties, Luciano is such a sloppy entertainer that he falls asleep on the job.

title: Naming Leaders, a Nonprofit News Outlet Takes Shape in San Francisco
description: A new nonprofit news organization in the San Francisco area began to take shape Thursday, with the announcement that it had hired a top administrator and top editor, and had reached an agreement to supply content to the Bay Area edition of The New York Times.

title: Air America Shuts Down and Will File for Chapter 7
description: From Brian Stelter at Media Decoder:

title: A New News Organizations Emerging Leadership
description: The Bay Area News Project unveiled its top business and editorial leaders Thursday. Lisa Frazier, a partner at McKinsey & Co., will be its chief executive and Jonathan Weber, the former editor of the technology and business magazine, The Industry Standard, will be the editor-in-chief.

title: Conservation as a Matter of Managing People
description: About three-quarters of the way through her new book, Rewilding the World, Caroline Fraser introduces us to Bhadai Tharu. A cheerful, round-faced 43-year-old man from Nepal, Mr. Tharu lost his left eye in 2003 when he was attacked by a tiger.

title: Rewilding the World
description: Introduction: The Predicta Moth

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Works & Process: The Art of Teaching: Participation and Perception
description: WORKS & PROCESS: THE ART OF TEACHING: PARTICIPATION AND PERCEPTION

title: Banksy at Sundance
description: On Wednesday the Web started to percolate with word that the artist Banksy had hit the Sundance Film Festival. Yes, the graffiti art that popped up in Park City, Utah, over the last couple of days was his handiwork. But this time the art was just a sideshow to a film directed by Banksy, Exit Through the Gift Shop, a surprise addition to the festival lineup, which kicked off on Thursday. Exit Through the Gift Shop, scheduled to have its premiere on Sunday night, is about an eccentric French shopkeeper and amateur filmmaker who was so obsessed with Banksy that he wanted to make a documentary about him. But the British-born Banksy turned the tables and made a film about the effort to film him.

title: 9/11 Attacks
description: Soon after the 9/11 hijackers struck, local reporters began calling Omar, then 17, for comment.

title: Footnote
description: Amy Winehouse, below, pleaded guilty to assaulting a theater manager at a Christmas pantomime show in central England, Reuters reported. She was given a two-year conditional discharge and ordered to pay about $140 in costs and about $160 in compensation to the manager, Richard Pound.

title: The 39 Steps Dashes Off Broadway
description: The producers of Alfred Hitchcocks The 39 Steps announced that their stage comedy, adapted from the 1935 film, would reopen off Broadway at New World Stages on March 25. The play, in which all the characters of The 39 Steps are juggled by four rapidly moving actors, has already been in three theaters over the course of its New York run. It originated at the American Airlines Theater in 2008, then moved to the Cort Theater and the Helen Hayes Theater, where it played for the last time on Jan. 10.

title: Try Shorts, Buddy
description: I walked into the locker room of my gym and nearly plowed into a mountain of flesh bending over a bench  naked. Not a pretty sight! He proceeded to walk to the mirror, still naked, and blew dry his hair from head to toe (if you know what I mean).

title: P.S. 1 and Moma Choose a Courtyard Architect
description: A Brooklyn architecture firm has won the annual competition to transform the courtyard of the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City, Queens, this summer. The firm, Solid Objectives  Idenburg Liu, came up with an interconnected system of poles and bungee cords that is constantly altered by human action and environmental factors like rain and wind. (Above, a computer rendering of a street view.) On discovery of its elasticity, visitors engage with the structure, to envision games, test its limits or just watch it gently dance, the architects proposal said. The competition, the 11th Young Architects Program, is run jointly by P.S. 1 and the Museum of Modern Art. The winning firms principals, Florian Idenburg and Jing Liu, said they opened their office just two years ago and were grateful for the competitions vote of confidence. This is the perfect form for a young firm to test new ideas, Ms. Liu said on Thursday. Its temporary and its an open pavilion, so theres not much prescribed program except for natural elements like shade and cooling.

title: The Americanization of Mental Illness
description: That the mind lives in the brain, the brain lives in the body and the body lives in a community is the key to understanding mental health in all cultural contexts. Ethan Watters makes several important, subtle points in The Americanization of Mental Illness but fails to acknowledge that globalization is systemic and not linear. While the infiltration of Western psychiatry into regions more culturally homogeneous than the U.S. may be harmful to some, non-Western concepts of the self are slowly integrating back into societies starving for a sense of coherent community. When it comes down to it, human beings are more like one another than different in their vulnerability to shifting forces larger than the self.

title: Million Dollar Quartet Names New York Cast
description: The principal foursome from the Chicago production of the musical Million Dollar Quartet will reprise their roles when it transfers to Broadway, the shows producers said on Thursday. The musical, about a 1956 session that brought together four of the biggest names in rock n roll, will star Eddie Clendening (as Elvis Presley), Lance Guest (Johnny Cash), Levi Kreis (Jerry Lee Lewis) and Rob Lyons (Carl Perkins), all making their Broadway debuts. Added to the cast are Hunter Foster (of Urinetown and Little Shop of Horrors), who will be playing the Sun Records producer Sam Phillips, and Elizabeth Stanley (Broadways Cry-Baby, Company) who will play Elviss girlfriend, Dyanne. With songs like Blue Suede Shoes, Great Balls of Fire, Folsom Prison Blues and Whole Lotta Shakin Goin On, it is to begin previews on March 13 at the Nederlander Theater and open on April 11.

title: The Pitmen Painters Heads to Broadway
description: The acclaimed London production of The Pitmen Painters, about a group of British miners who become artists, will transfer to the Broadway house of the Manhattan Theater Club in September, the theater company announced. The producer Bob Boyett had been aiming to mount the production on Broadway this spring but opted instead for an arrangement with the nonprofit Manhattan Theater Club to move the show to its 650-seat Samuel J. Friedman Theater. Mr. Boyett said the company had been courting him in a big way to do the show and that he had been unable to line up another Broadway house for a commercial run in time. Written by Lee Hall, who wrote the screenplay for the film Billy Elliot and the book and lyrics for the musical version now on Broadway, The Pitmen Painters had well-reviewed runs at Live Theater Newcastle and the National Theater in London, and it won the Evening Standard Award for best play in 2008. The original London cast, above, will perform in the Broadway production.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Checking In | The New Middle
description: Andaz Wall Street, Hyatts first New York boutique hotel, opened this week (with a Midtown location to follow this spring), and if Im reading the tea leaves about what this means for many of the nearly 50 hotels that will open in New York this year, one theme emerges: recession luxe. The Andaz property, part of an entirely new brand for Hyatt, is a far cry from last years extremes of old-school opulence and flophouse chic. In June, the unabashedly luxurious Pierre Hotel reopened, flaunting a $100 million renovation and posting room rates of the if you have to ask  variety. Then the Crosby Hotel opened, with each of the 86 rooms awash in bespoke fabric and art, and priced to match. Conversely, the aggressively gritty Ace and Jane Hotels, the latter featuring communal bathrooms, promised hipster cred on the cheap.

title: Seeing Is Disbelieving
description: Last week, after years of public curiosity about what was hidden behind Mark McGwires testimony to Congress in 2005, McGwire admitted he indeed had a secret. He conceded that his career was marked by intermittent steroid use, even during 1998, the year he broke Roger Maris single-season home run record. His historic run was unreal . . . literally.My brother was and is a supporter of the unreal  a huge fan of science fictions Godzilla. Thanks to him, when I was growing up I would catch an occasional episode of the TV show where Godzilla would take on Rodan (or some other nemesis) and they would end up in these knock-down, drag-out fights, reaping collateral damage all along the way. Once Godzilla went on his rampage, our eyes fixed on the TV, waiting to see which landmark would end up a pile of rubble. We loved it. And when the May 1998 release date of a remake of Godzilla approached, even with the baseball season in high gear I anticipated seeing it in a Philadelphia theater as soon as I could find some down time in between games.

title: Art in Review
description: MARKUS SCHINWALD

title: California to Subsidize Solar Water Heaters
description: California regulators on Thursday approved a $350 million program to subsidize the installation of solar water heaters to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

title: Spicing Dominican Bachata With Some Saltier R&B
description: Under normal circumstances, its easier to look after one woman than attend to 10,000 or so, but a concert by the bachata superstars Aventura isnt a normal circumstance.

title: National Endowment Grants to Urban Projects
description: Urban design projects that incorporate the arts will be awarded grants of up to $250,000 each from the National Endowment for the Arts, the chairman, Rocco Landesman, announced to the United States Conference of Mayors in Washington on Thursday. The Endowment expects to distribute up to 15 new grants starting at $25,000 to help finance emerging arts districts and design projects that enhance public spaces, like parks, libraries, memorials and pedestrian bridges. We want to make sure that citizens engage with the arts by having communities transform themselves through public spaces that have cultural activities," Mr. Landesman said in a speech. Interested cities need to submit their statement of interest by March 15. The guidelines and application materials are now available on the Endowments Web site, arts.gov.

title: A Bomb Squad for Wall Street
description: Gather round people, today we are going to discuss the highly opaque but hugely important topic of O.T.C. derivatives, or securities that derive their value from other securities and are traded between institutions over-the-counter, rather than on an exchange where they can be more closely regulated and monitored. Examples of such derivatives are an option to buy a stock in the future at a fixed price set today and credit-default swaps, a form of insurance against the future default of a bond.

title: Documentary of the Civil Rights Movement, Arranged and Composed for Gen Y
description: The documentary Soundtrack for a Revolution is essentially a condensed, lightly airbrushed, skillfully assembled history of the civil rights movement, with musical interludes. Its civil rights greatest hits: Montgomery, Selma, Birmingham; Eyes on the Prize, We Shall Not be Moved, We Shall Overcome. Its the kind of film that will have audiences clapping and singing along. And why not? The images and stories may be familiar, but its history worth retelling.

title: A Note on the Economy
description: Quite aside from everything else going on, the economic recovery isnt looking very good. Unemployment claims are stalled at a level that bodes ill for for the overall employment picture (dont count on falling unemployment until that number falls well below 400,000). And the 10-year bond rate, which is my personal index of the markets expectations about recovery, has been falling off again after rising for several weeks.

title: Food Stamp Materials Bound for Smithsonian
description: WASHINGTON  Like a $10 bill, it was printed by the Treasury, and it bore proud emblems of American democracy  an eagle, a portrait of Alexander Hamilton  alongside the words 10 Dollars. Unlike ordinary currency, though, it also bore a warning: Nontransferable except under conditions prescribed by the secretary of agriculture.

title: Beyonc and Madonna Join Telethon for Haiti
description: Beyonc and Madonna are among the more than 100 big names in music, film and television scheduled to take part in Hope for Haiti Now: A Global Benefit for Earthquake Relief, a two-hour telethon on Friday night to be broadcast around the world on television and online. The show, which in the United States will begin at 8 p.m. Eastern time on all the major networks and on cable channels, is to feature musical performances from multiple locations: Bruce Springsteen, Sting, Shakira and Wyclef Jean will play in New York, while in London Bono and the Edge of U2 will collaborate with Jay-Z and Rihanna, with Coldplay also slated to perform. The program in Los Angeles is to include performances by Stevie Wonder, Taylor Swift and Justin Timberlake and a collaboration among Keith Urban, Kid Rock and Sheryl Crow. Songs from the telethon will be for sale on iTunes for 99 cents beginning Saturday, will all proceeds going to a number of relief organizations.

title: Desperate Fathers Plea to a Detached Scientist
description: Extraordinary Measures, a movie about a medical breakthrough, is not especially eager to break new ground of its own. Directed with care and competence by Tom Vaughan (What Happens in Vegas), the film hews closely to familiar themes and patterns. One strand is a drama about a family in crisis, with parents facing the illness and possible death of two of their children, who suffer from a fatal genetic disorder. Another piece is a buddy picture, in which a mismatched pair of guys  one earnest and emotive (Brendan Fraser), the other gruff and solitary (Harrison Ford)  set off on an unlikely adventure, hoping to find a cure.

title: NBC Will Keep the Rights to Many of OBriens Comedy Bits
description: Whenever Conan OBrien comes back to television, his show is likely to look significantly different. NBC is claiming that it owns all the comedy bits that were created during Mr. OBriens run, first on the Late Night show and for the past seven months on Tonight.

title: 7 Indicted in Galleon Insider-Trading Case
description: Prosecutors unveiled grand jury indictments against seven people on Thursday in the growing insider-trading case involving the Galleon Group.

title: Changes at 1 Police Plaza
description: George A. Grasso, the Police Departments No. 2 official, is departing on Friday for a job as a criminal court judge. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly is poised to replace Mr. Grasso, the first deputy commissioner, with Rafael Pineiro, his longtime chief of personnel, said a person familiar with the moves.

title: Miniature Visions of Life, Faith and Purgatorys Gaping Maw
description: Some exhibitions are rare because they unite far-flung treasures seldom permitted to travel.

title: Toyota Issues a 2nd Recall
description: DETROIT  Toyota Motor issued its second large recall in two months on Thursday to fix a problem with accelerator pedals that can get stuck, causing vehicles to speed up unintentionally.

title: Take 5: Armenian Music and a Tribute to Michael Jackson, Latin Style
description: Wondering what to do this weekend? Weve got you covered:

title: City to Get Federal Aid to Fix or Close Weak Schools
description: Amid a national push to fix or close underperforming schools, New York State has placed 34 city schools on a list of low achieving schools and will provide federal funds to the city to either close or change them dramatically, the State Department of Education said Thursday.

title: Many Obstacles to Bipartisanship as Health Legislation Evolved
description: In hindsight, it should probably come as little surprise to Democrats that voters in Massachusetts, a state with near-universal access to health insurance, would not feel all that motivated to rescue President Obamas efforts to provide universal benefits nationwide.

title: Campaign Contribution Limits
description: The Supreme Court overruled two precedents on Thursday, proclaiming that companies and unions are not banned from political spending in candidate elections.

title: A Future Not So Distant, and Brighter
description: Despite swooning reviews and obsessive fans, Battlestar Galactica lasted just four seasons, signing off in March with a finale that drew a modest 2.4 million viewers. The potential audience for science fiction may be vast (just ask James Cameron), but apparently the audience for apocalyptic, claustrophobic, relentlessly grim science fiction, no matter how well made, is significantly smaller.

title: Downloading on the Slopes
description: About a dozen ski resorts have rolled out new iPhone Apps this winter. Most do the same thing  provide weather conditions, trail maps and lift ticket info  but some offer GPS locators, live Web cams and even Twitter-like feeds from the slopes.

title: Time to Start Over, Snowe Says
description: For months Democrats, including President Obama, courted Senator Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, hoping to win her vote for major health care legislation. And now that the legislation is stalled, following the Republican victory in the Massachusetts special election on Tuesday, Ms. Snowe said she tried to warn Democrats, including Mr. Obama, that they were pushing too hard too fast.

title: Its Raining Coyotes and Roosters Out There
description: What is up with the animals in this town? The last few days have brought the following reports:

title: Steinbeck Family Now Supports Google Book Plan
description: The family of the author John Steinbeck, which previously opposed the proposed Google Book settlement that would create a vast digital library of books, say that they now support it.

title: Two Country Slickers Looking for Gold
description: Television has already seen its share of shows about antiques, collectibles and the people who hunt for and sell them, but American Pickers, a new entry on History, brings some welcome spunk to the genre.

title: New York Citys Jobless Rate Hits 10.6%
description: In December, New York Citys unemployment rate reached 10.6 percent, its highest level in nearly 17 years, according to the states Labor Department. Last month was the first time since the recession began two years ago in which the citys unemployment rate was significantly higher than the nations. My colleague Patrick McGeehan has the story.

title: Answers About Roth I.R.A. Conversions: Part 5
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks in which you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Writing in the Dahl House, Part 1
description: I always liked stop-motion where the puppets had fur.

title: At a Haitian Restaurant in Brooklyn, Some Relief
description: At Kombit Bar and Restaurant in Brooklyn, the news from Haiti this week was bittersweet.

title: The 'Tonight Show' Changes Hands Again
description: The Conan OBrien chapter of The Tonight Show at NBC ended officially on Thursday. The Times's Bill Carter and Bruce Headlam discuss the late-night shuffle.

title: Capitol Hill Reacts Cautiously to Obama Bank Plan
description: Washington lawmakers reacted cautiously to the Obama administrations proposal on Thursday that would ban commercial banks from participating in proprietary trading and other risky investment strategies. Several senators whose offices were contacted by DealBook said they needed more time to study the plan and were not yet ready to declare their support or opposition.

title: Senators Want to Bar E.P.A. Greenhouse Gas Limits
description: WASHINGTON  In a direct challenge to the Environmental Protection Agencys authority, Senator Lisa Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, introduced a resolution on Thursday to prevent the agency from taking any action to regulate carbon dioxide and other climate-altering gases.

title: Its Still Mostly Sunny at Hartfield
description: There can be too much of a good thing, but a great thing can be remade over and over. Besides Pride and Prejudice, The Importance of Being Earnest and Star Trek, there is, of course, Emma.

title: Nonbelievers Must Wear Tutus
description: Woe to the grouchy sports hero who dares to tell children to stop believing in magic and give up their dreams. When Derek Thompson (Dwayne Johnson), a fading ice hockey star nicknamed Tooth Fairy for his habit of knocking out opponents teeth, scoffs at the young daughter of his girlfriend, Carly (Ashley Judd), for believing in the tooth fairy, the enchanted powers that be decide to teach him a lesson.

title: Past Decade Warmest on Record, NASA Data Shows
description: WASHINGTON  The decade ending in 2009 was the warmest on record, new surface temperature figures released Thursday by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration show.

title: Hair Seeks Would-Be Hippies
description: If Woodstock had been held in winter  and was much smaller and took place on a city street and was orderly and had venti Starbucks lattes  it might have resembled the scene outside the Public Theater in the East Village on Thursday morning.

title: Inside the List
description: GAME ON: Game Change, John Heilemann and Mark Halperins dishy account of the 2008 presidential campaign, enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 1. (Thank you, Harry Reid!) That puts them ahead of Barack Obama, whose book The Audacity of Hope, released at the start of his campaign, never made it higher than No. 2. Heilemann and Halperin describe how Obama blew his original deadline, pushing publication back a week, right into the path of John Grishams first nonfiction book, The Innocent Man. Grisham entered the list at No. 1, followed by Obama. Heilemann and Halperin describe what happened next: When Obama learned of the rankings, he was peevish, a little whiny. But I want to be No. 1, he complained. Elizabeth Gilbert no doubt feels his pain. Her book Committed drops to No. 2 in its second week on the list.

title: Red Bulls to Face Santos
description: The grand opening of Red Bull Arena will bring a storied Brazilian club, Santos, to Harrison, N.J., for an exhibition match on March 20. The Red Bulls of Major League Soccer, who are currently training in Spain, will open the league portion of their schedule at their new stadium against the Chicago Fire on March 27. The club said on Thursday that the match against Santos will be part of its season-ticket package at no additional cost.

title: Swedish Bank Fee Sets Example for America
description: When it comes to rescuing banks, the Swedes are earning a reputation as trendsetters. First they set a standard for recovering from disaster; now they want to export their idea for how to pay for it.

title: Out of Bankruptcy, Genetics Company Drops Drug Efforts
description: DeCode Genetics, the gene-hunting company in Iceland, said Thursday that it had emerged from bankruptcy and would continue its genetics research and its gene-based diagnostics as a private company. It will abandon its efforts to develop drugs from its discoveries.

title: G.M. Starts Revamp in Europe by Closing an Opel Plant
description: General Motors, taking the first step in overhauling its European operations, announced on Thursday that it would close its Opel plant in Antwerp, Belgium.

title: Preview: 'Caprica'
description: The new Syfy series is a prequel to "Battlestar Galactica."

title: Disaster Coverage Without Having to Roll Up the Sleeves
description: ABOUT the last thing on anyones mind since an earthquake turned Haiti into a scene from Dante was what people were wearing. The indelible images showed dazed survivors caked in dust, garments in tatters or altogether torn away.

title: Made in the U.S.A.: Carved, Hooked and Framed
description: Art and antiques fairs arent especially homey places. The exception is the American Antiques Show, at the Metropolitan Pavilion, which puts collectors and browsers at ease with quasi-domestic arrangements of antiques and folk art.

title: Paperback Row
description: FREEDOM FOR THE THOUGHT THAT WE HATE: A Biography of the First Amendment,  by Anthony Lewis (Basic, $15.95.) Many of the great advances in the quality  the decency  of American society were initiated by judges, Lewis writes in this account of how they prohibited the government from banning offensive speech and created the modern First Amendment. In this passionate if discursive essay, as Jeffrey Rosen called it in the Book Review, Lewis discusses a range of issues from sedition and obscenity to hate speech and secret wiretapping.

title: Editors Choice
description: GAME CHANGE: Obama and the Clintons, McCain and Palin, and the Race of a Lifetime,  by John Heilemann and Mark Halperin (Harper/HarperCollins, $27.99.) The inside story of the 2008 campaign, longer on vignettes and backstage gossip than on analysis.

title: Video: Talking About Tonight
description: The end of the Conan OBrien chapter of The Tonight Show was officially hammered out on Thursday. Bill Carter and Bruce Headlam of The New York Times discuss the late-night shuffle at NBC.

title: Geithner on the Bank Proposal
description: Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner is being interviewed on the PBS NewsHour tonight about the administrations new bank proposal, a k a the Volcker Rule, released today. Here are a couple of highlights from the interview, according to a transcript released by PBS. (Sorry, I cant find a link yet.)

title: John Burns Q. and A. on Islamic Radicalization
description: This week, John Burns, the chief foreign correspondent for The New York Times, is responding to readers comments and questions about Islamic radicalization.

title: Reimagining the Culprit in Versaces Murder
description: Outside a San Diego bar, the camera lingers suggestively on a sign announcing Cocktails. Inside, a 27-year-old gay hustler named Andrew Cunanan (Jonathon Trent) frets over his fading looks and softening six-pack.

title: The G.O.P.s Next Move on Health Care
description: The day after the Republican Senate victory in Massachusetts, President Obama  signaled a willingness to scale back on near-universal health coverage in favor of a stripped-down measure with bipartisan support. Top Republicans, however, did not sound conciliatory. When Mitch McConnell, the Senate Republican leader, was asked whether the health care bill was dead, he said: I sure hope so.

title: Census Figures Challenge Views of Race and Ethnicity
description: New census figures that provide a snapshot of Americas foreign-born population are challenging conventional views of immigration, race and ethnicity.

title: Paris: Craftiness
description: Running a tad late, or so I thought, for the Louis Vuitton show this afternoon, I arrived just as a car pulled up and a pair of ladies legs shimmied out followed by much fur. Kanye West and his girlfriend had arrived, each fur-clad, and as they made their way to the door a group of young women waiting with cameras seemed to react as if they had touched an electric current. I was far more interested in the tension in their faces, the little moans they made as they raced to get into positions to record his arrival, than Mr. West, though he had an eye-catching trio of rings on his fingers, two gold pyramids and something that resembled a small vessel.

title: The Dancer Had a Little Dog (It Followed Her to Lincoln Center)
description: Since there are ballets with lively roles for dancers playing dogs  notably Massines Boutique Fantasque, Ashtons Wedding Bouquet and Balanchines Midsummer Nights Dream  it may disappoint you to hear that nobody dances the role of the dog in Alexey Miroshnichenkos new ballet of Chekhovs story The Lady With the Little Dog, a production that had its premiere at New York City Ballet on Wednesday night. Though the cast includes eight men, some of whom perform distinctly doggy movements at the start, the program tells us they are Angels.

title: A Look at a Forbidden High School Romance
description: The writing is lazy at times, but convincing performances by Tye Olson and Kyle Clare in the central roles elevate David Oliverass Watercolors above run-of-the-mill gay cinema. This modest movie, with a side plot that looks unblinkingly at gay-bashing among high school students, deserves to attract crossover customers.

title: Agency Says Toyota Accelerator Problem is Serious Safety Issue
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration says balky accelerator pedals on an estimated 2.3 million Toyotas are a serious safety issue and the agency is pleased with the companys recall announced late Thursday.

title: Buffett Really Wants to Punish Failed Bankers
description: Given President Obamas new banking proposal, Liz Claman of Fox Business Network thought Thursday was a perfect day to talk to Warren E. Buffett  even though he had already given lengthy interviews the day before to Foxs rivals, CNBC and Bloomberg Television. But the billionaire financier started out by disappointing Ms. Claman, saying he needed to examine the proposal, and he brushed aside pleas to comment on specifics.

title: Just the Place to Find an Egyptian Sarcophagus
description: If you are in the market for a 14,000-pound, six-foot-tall urn carved from a block of pink Tennessee marble and encircled by a neo-Classical frieze of Indians hunting buffalo and engaging in intertribal warfare, hurry over to the 56th annual Winter Antiques Show before someone else snaps it up. Designed by the sculptor Paul Manship in 1914, this stunning object is on view at Gerald Peters, one of 75 art and antiques dealers gathered to dazzling effect under the capacious roof of the drill hall at the Park Avenue Armory.

title: Hard Work, Not Miracles, Ahead for City
description: Right after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg delivered his State of the City address last year, a miracle occurred. Thats what people instantly called the wondrous landing of US Airways Flight 1549 on the Hudson River  a miracle  though maybe, just maybe, the skill of the pilots, the design of their Airbus A320 and the swift response of New York rescue crews had something to do with everyone getting out alive.

title: Seagate Goes Direct
description: Some companies  most notably Dell  choose to go direct, others have directness thrust upon them.

title: Our Boredom, Ourselves
description: If you read a lot of book reviews, there are certain words that tend to crop up with comforting, or maybe its dismaying, regularity. Lyrical. Compelling. Moving. Intriguing. Absorbing. Frustrating. Uneven. Disappointing. But there is one word you seldom encounter: boring. It occurred a mere 19 times in the Book Review in 2009, and rarely as a direct description of the book under review.

title: Portrait of a Gay Childless Couple
description: In the breeding dramedy Misconceptions, a childless gay couple enters into a holy alliance with a fertile Christian wife. I suppose even a homophobic womb is better than none.

title: Drone Reportedly Killed Filipino in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A militant belonging to Abu Sayyaf, the Islamist separatist group fighting the government in the Philippines, was killed in a recent drone attack in Pakistans tribal areas, according to a Pakistani intelligence official and a local television report.

title: Still Life. Very.
description: I love the rationale for the museum heist three Edinburgh art lovers pull off in Ian Rankins coolly executed caper novel, DOORS OPEN (Reagan Arthur Books/Little, Brown, $24.99). Mike Mackenzie, a filthy rich but terminally bored software entrepreneur, convinces himself that he and his pals are performing a civic service by liberating some half-dozen paintings from the National Gallery warehouse where they currently languish. If you follow the logic of these self-entitled snobs  in an argument advanced by a distinguished but disgruntled scholar and quickly adopted by Mackenzie and a banker friend  it would be a mission of mercy to help some of those poor imprisoned paintings to escape by appropriating them and leaving forgeries in their place.

title: Legal Jostling Picks Up in Terra Firma-Citi Fight
description: The legal battle between the British private equity firm Terra Firma and Citigroup over the disastrous buyout of the EMI Group record company is picking up some steam.

title: Many Moves With Children in Tow, and Then a Fire
description: By the time Jeffrey and April Fish were 24 and 23, respectively, they were parents to five children under the age of 7. As if that was not overwhelming enough, they have waged a daily battle to stay solvent ever since.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: THE LISTENER  By Shira Nayman.  Scribner, $27.

title: An Athlete in Search of Redemption
description: Teenage martyrdom  the piety of it all. In To Save a Life, Jake (Randy Wayne) is a star high school basketball player; Amy (Deja Kreutzberg) is his cheerleader girlfriend; and Roger (Robert Bailey Jr.) is his childhood friend who years ago crippled himself protecting Jake from an approaching automobile. When Jakes popularity pushes Roger out of his life, Roger comes to school, brandishes a gun and shoots himself.

title: Air America, the Talk Radio Network, Will Go Off the Air
description: Air America, the long-suffering progressive talk radio network, abruptly shut down on Thursday, bowing to what it called a very difficult economic environment.

title: Citys Jobless Rate Rises to 10.6%, Exceeding Nations
description: The unemployment rate in New York City jumped in December to 10.6 percent, its highest level in nearly 17 years, as hotels, museums and builders eliminated jobs and hiring remained weak in most other businesses, the State Labor Department said Thursday.

title: OBriens Parting Shots (for Now)
description: Update | 10:32 p.m. Down to his last two shows on NBC, Conan OBrien kept the jokes about his situation  and relationship with the network  coming Thursday night. He even mixed in a little serious commentary.

title: Entrenched Monarchy Thwarts Aspirations for Modernity
description: CAIRO  In the heady days of the Dubai gold rush, when real estate sold and resold even before a shovel hit the ground, the ambitious emirate was hailed as the model of Middle Eastern modernity, a boomtown that built an effective, efficient and accessible form of government.

title: Fingers Still Pointing, NBC and OBrien Reach a Deal
description: The end of the Conan OBrien chapter of The Tonight Show was officially hammered out on Thursday with a lot of money  and some parting recriminations  being dished out.

title: Oracles Acquisition of Sun Wins Approval of Europeans
description: The European Commission said Thursday that it had approved Oracles $7.4 billion takeover of Sun Microsystems after concluding that it would not significantly affect competition in the European Union.

title: A Flight Is Diverted by a Prayer Seen as Ominous
description: The plane, a 50-seat regional aircraft that was less than a third full when it took off from La Guardia Airport, had been climbing through the early-morning sky for about 25 minutes. A 17-year-old passenger in a whitish sweater took out something he had carried onboard, and strapped it onto his wrist and his head.

title: Basking in Islands of Legalisms
description: The Cook Islands have a smaller population  about 20,000  than one apartment complex in Manhattan, and an economy with little to offer except tourism and pearl exports. The country contracts out its national defense to New Zealand, which is four hours away by plane.

title: Up Front: Hilary Mantel
description: Why are we so obsessed with understanding every detail of Anne Boleyns rise and fall, Hilary Mantel asks in her review of Alison Weirs Lady in the Tower this week. It is because her character has archetypal force. . . . She is the young fertile beauty who displaces the menopausal wife, Mantel writes. It is the human drama that engages us.

title: Monteverdi, 1610: Vespers to Usher in the Baroque
description: As Monteverdis magnificent 1610 Vespers gathers momentum in its inexorable march through a big anniversary year, it quickly becomes evident that comparisons, however odious, are inevitable. This vast canvas from the dawn of the Baroque  formally, the Vespro Della Beata Vergine (Vespers of the Blessed Virgin)  offers such a rich ground for competing scholarly views and conjecture that performances differ radically, one shedding light on another.

title: A Line Both Spirited and Firm
description: Agnolo Bronzinos was the hand to hire for a power portrait in mid-16th-century Florence. He could turn toddlers into potentates and make new-money Medicis look like decent people. His painting shaped late Mannerism, the profane, twisty, prosthetic style that erupted, like a repressed libido, between the humanist sanctities of the Renaissance and the smells and bells of the Counter-Reformation.

title: Inside Sundance
description: A look at some of the films appearing at the Sundance Film Festival

title: Who Declares War?
description: In Crisis and Command, his sweeping history of presidential prerogatives, John Yoo argues that national security crises inevitably ratchet up the power of the president at the expense of Congress. War acts on executive power as an accelerant, he writes, causing it to burn hotter, brighter and swifter. In Bomb Power, Garry Wills argues much the same thing, adding that the advent of atomic weapons has made this concentration of power in the White House even greater. The executive power increased decade by decade, he writes, reaching a new high in the 21st century  a continuous story of unidirectional increase. Where the two authors disagree is on whether this trend should be celebrated or denounced. Yoo finds increased executive power appealing and in accord with the Constitution. Wills finds it appalling and a constitutional travesty.

title: Sharing Soul Food, Fellowship and Faith
description: Lunching on greens and cornbread, the dignified church ladies huddled around a table at Marvins Soul Food restaurant on Cicero Avenue. They talked about corrupt politics, a wayward society and the truth of the Bible.

title: Good Times and Bad, Henin Has Kept Her Coach in View
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Justine Henin and Carlos Rodriguez have been together since she was 14. She was a wunderkind then, and he was her coach. Both have a bit of age on them now, but all you have to do is watch Henin search the grandstand for him after each hard-fought point to see not much has changed. They do not merely exchange glances; they mind-meld.

title: With Populist Stance, Obama Takes On Banks
description: WASHINGTON  The tougher approach to financial regulation that President Obama outlined on Thursday reflected a changed political climate, the rebound in big banks fortunes after their taxpayer bailout and a shift in power within the administration away from those who had been seen as most sympathetic to Wall Street.

title: New Chinese Speakers
description: Although thousands of American public schools have stopped offering foreign language instruction, one language is becoming more popular: Chinese.

title: If Bills Fail, a Quandary for Insurers
description: With the possible collapse of the Congressional health care effort, health insurers might seem to have reason to celebrate. The legislation threatened to remake much of their business, with the prospect of burdensome government regulation and less profit from selling coverage to individuals and small businesses.

title: Conference of Mayors Stresses Need for New Round of Stimulus Money
description: WASHINGTON  Saying that last years $787 billion economic stimulus plan has failed to ease urban unemployment, the nations mayors are asking the federal government for a second wave of stimulus money.

title: Nokia Fires Back at Google With Free GPS on 10 Phones
description: Nokia began giving away professional GPS navigation software on 10 of its smartphones on Thursday, matching a competitive move by Google. The move deals a blow to the leaders in the market for specialized navigation devices, Garmin and TomTom.

title: White House Eager to Project Image of Competence in Relief Efforts
description: WASHINGTON  At 5:52 p.m. on Jan. 12, President Obama was in the Oval Office when aides told him of the calamitous earthquake in Haiti. By 8:30, the president had ordered an aggressive relief effort. An hour and a half later, the deputy national security adviser convened an emergency meeting in the White House Situation Room.

title: For Israelis, Mixed Feelings on Aid Effort
description: JERUSALEM  The editorial cartoon in Thursdays mass-circulation Israeli newspaper Yediot Aharonot showed American soldiers digging among the ruins of Haiti. From within the rubble, a voice calls out, Would you mind checking to see if the Israelis are available?

title: After Benching, Rhodes No Longer Plays It Safe
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Kerry Rhodes, tight-lipped, walked slowly across the Jets locker room Thursday afternoon because he had an ice bag the size of a helmet attached to his right knee. Rhodes, a safety who has vindicated himself in the last month, was injured in practice.

title: Thriving Military Recruitment Program Blocked
description: A highly successful program by the armed forces to recruit skilled immigrants who live in this country temporarily has run into a roadblock, leaving thousands of potential recruits in limbo.

title: Cricket Team Snub Reeks of Politics to Pakistanis
description: NEW DELHI  India and Pakistan have fought three wars, claim hunks of each others territory and sit astride a deep religious and political divide.

title: Food Network and HGTV Back Aboard Cablevision
description: The Iron Chef is back in Cablevision households. The cable distributor said Thursday that it had signed a new deal with Scripps Networks, restoring two popular cable channels, the Food Network and HGTV, to the television lineups of about three million homes in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: European Title Is Only the Beginning for Plushenko and His Coach
description: TALLINN, Estonia  Aleksei Mishin, the Russian who has coached three mens Olympic figure skating champions, was beaming proprietarily Thursday night as Yevgeny Plushenko listened to the Russian anthem here with another gold medal around his neck.

title: Economy in Shock Struggles to Restart
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  The price of candles in the teeming La Saline market here has climbed 60 percent since last weeks earthquake. A box of matches is up 50 percent. A package of Perdue Chicken Franks has gone up 30 percent.

title: The Courts Blow to Democracy
description: With a single, disastrous 5-to-4 ruling, the Supreme Court has thrust politics back to the robber-baron era of the 19th century. Disingenuously waving the flag of the First Amendment, the courts conservative majority has paved the way for corporations to use their vast treasuries to overwhelm elections and intimidate elected officials into doing their bidding.

title: City Bids to Save Housing Imperiled by Investors
description: New York City has launched a new plan to rescue moderate-rent apartment buildings that were swept up by private equity firms during the financial boom, then left to deteriorate as they drifted toward foreclosure when the new owners were unable to repay their loans.

title: Eating for Haiti Relief
description: Theres still a lot you can do to contribute to the Haiti relief effort. Start with the telethon on Friday night, which will feature performances by just about every pop star on the planet, and on Sunday or Monday make plans to visit one of New Yorks top restaurants, which are participating in Dine Out for Haiti. The Modern, Fatty Crab, Babbo, ilili and the Waverly Inn are among those on a long list of restaurants that will donate up to 10 percent of sales to charities. Bring a big appetite, proceeds will be distributed to Action Against Hunger, Doctors Without Borders and Partners in Health.

title: After the Shore
description: Theres little doubt that the merits of MTVs Jersey Shore will be debated for months, nay years, to come. But now that the shows season has ended, lets take a break from the bickering and come together for a Jersey-themed dance party. On Saturday night Paul DelVecchio, a k a DJ Pauly D, will take over the Midtown bar Sutton Place to spin his special blend of house music from 11 p.m. to 1 a.m. Expect tans, blowouts and fist pumps. Shore attire is encouraged.

title: Say Ommm
description: As fashionistas know, the designer and yoga devotee Donna Karan infuses serenity in her clothes. Calm can also be found in her Balinese beanbag chairs, teak tables and at a workshop this Saturday at Donna Karans Urban Zen Center. From 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., Dr. James Gordon will lead a program titled Unstuck: Practical Steps Toward Clarity and Delight to help urbanites find balance in their busy city lives. Hell focus on techniques like mediation, guided imagery, movement, dance and nutrition, as well as experiments with drawing and dialogue. He hopes participants will leave with a new perspective on and appreciation of ourselves. Ommm.

title: Indictments Against 7 in Galleon Insider Case
description: Federal prosecutors on Thursday unveiled grand jury indictments against seven people in the wide-ranging insider-trading case involving the Galleon Group and numerous other hedge fund traders, lawyers and corporate executives.

title: Lobbyists Get Potent Weapon in Campaign Ruling
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court has handed lobbyists a new weapon. A lobbyist can now tell any elected official: if you vote wrong, my company, labor union or interest group will spend unlimited sums explicitly advertising against your re-election.

title: Vivid Testimony in Trial of Three Officers Accused in Subway Station Assault
description: In October 2008, from different vantage points, three members of the Dallas family watched the frenzied sequence of events that Michael Mineo says led to his abuse at the hands of police officers and that the officers say led to a mostly unexceptional arrest.

title: Governors I. Terror Trial? Unlikely but Under Study
description: At a news conference Thursday morning, Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said that the Police Department was studying the feasibility of staging the trial of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed on Governors Island instead of at the federal courthouse in Manhattan. But by evening, the possibility of such a change seemed highly unlikely, with Mr. Kelly saying in a televised interview that federal officials believed a change in venue would cause serious problems.

title: 2 Officers Suspended for Hitting Suspect
description: Two New York City police officers were suspended without pay after a video surfaced showing them striking a handcuffed man this month in the Bronx, officials said Thursday. The video was shot after a failed undercover drug operation during which two other officers were wounded when they were hit in a ricochet of shots fired at a charging pit bull.

title: Man Claims Terror Ties in Little Rock Shooting
description: MEMPHIS  A Tennessee man accused of killing a soldier outside a Little Rock, Ark., military recruiting station last year has asked a judge to change his plea to guilty, claiming for the first time that he is affiliated with a Yemen-based affiliate of Al Qaeda.

title: Before Dementia Assistance, Help With N.F.L. Application
description: FRANKLIN, Tenn.  The meaty right hand that once plowed footballs past oncoming linebackers cradled the pen as it negotiated the form. When it paused in confusion, another hand  all but a strangers  hovered in to assist.

title: A Good Place for Googles Cash
description: Cash, not China, is Googles biggest conundrum. More precisely, where should the search giant point its gusher of greenbacks? The online advertising market recovery and increasing efficiency pushed free cash flow up 44 percent, to $2.5 billion in the fourth quarter. Adding that to the companys $24 billion cash hoard doesnt make sense. But giving it to shareholders does.

title: Within Days, a Global Benefit Takes Shape
description: LOS ANGELES  Quicker than you can tie a red, blue and yellow ribbon  the symbol of concern for Haiti  celebrities rose to George Clooneys call for a telethon to aid that nations earthquake victims, to be shown Friday night on a hundred networks and myriad Web sites around the world.

title: Campaigns Walk the Invisible Tightrope
description: EVERY January, Madison Avenue gets into the betterment business, unleashing a flood of advertising that seeks to take advantage of the impulses among consumers at the start of a new year to improve themselves.

title: Wheres Johnny? Good Manners Take Hiatus
description: It was almost touching to see Conan OBrien look so tickled about his sudden rise in ratings. The departing host of The Tonight Show looked less surprised than gratified, as if he had at last won the mass audience he believes he deserves.

title: As Olympics Near, Theyre Ordering Snow
description: With seven years to prepare and a budget of about $2 billion, organizers have nearly everything in place for next months Winter Olympics in Vancouver.

title: Big Name in Flooring
description: And the three men I admire most:The Father, Son and the Holy Ghost,They caught the last train for the coastThe day the music died.

title: Weiss Has the Name and Pedigree to Boost Slovakia
description: Update | Friday, Jan. 22, 11:27 a.m. Vladimir Weiss has the name and pedigree to be a top European soccer player. The 20-year-old Slovakian wing has inherited his fathers and grandfathers sense for the game and brings his own talent to bear whenever he has the opportunity.

title: Honduras: Ousted President Agrees to Leave
description: The ousted Honduran president Manuel Zelaya has accepted a deal to go to the Dominican Republic next week when his four-year term ends, his top political adviser said Thursday. If all the conditions are met, then he will go, the adviser, Rasel Tom, said in a telephone interview from the Brazilian Embassy in Tegucigalpa, the Honduran capital, where Mr. Zelaya has taken refuge since September. In a statement, Mr. Zelaya called the deal a first step toward national reconciliation.

title: France: Parliament Weighs Ban on Veils in Public
description: Parliament is expected to pass a nonbinding resolution calling for a ban on facial veils in public, but any law will require significant further debate, legislators said Thursday. A parliamentary commission studying the so-called burqa ban is due to publish recommendations next Tuesday. President Nicolas Sarkozy, who has said that full facial veils have no place in France, is reluctant to support a law that could be both unenforceable and unconstitutional. Jean-Franois Cop, floor leader for Mr. Sarkozys party, told France Inter radio that the plan was for a resolution to explain and then a law to decide.

title: Lottery Numbers
Judge Says City Failed to Disclose Change in Rule on Police Video Recording
description: In a nearly four-decade-old case involving how the police investigate political groups, a federal judge ruled this week that New York City unnecessarily allowed a lawsuit to drag on for more than an extra year.

title: A New Search for Consensus on Health Care Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Even as Speaker Nancy Pelosi affirmed her commitment to pass far-reaching health care legislation this year, members of Congress and health policy experts began Thursday to deal with the reality that a smaller bill would have a better chance.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about criticisms and interpretations of the film Avatar misidentified the Christian entertainment Web site for which David Outten wrote a column about the movie. It is movieguide.org, not movieguide.com. And an accompanying picture of people in China watching the film carried an erroneous credit in some copies. It was taken by Agence France-Presse  Getty Images, not by Ng Huan Gan/Associated Press.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the presidential election results in Ukraine misspelled the surname of a voter who explained why she had supported Viktor F. Yanukovich, the opposition leader who won the most votes but not a majority. She is Irina Maltseva, not Matseva.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, some copies on Thursday omitted part of the answers for Wednesdays puzzle. The answers can be found at nytimes.com/crosswords.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about the mystery writer Robert B. Parker, using information from his publisher, referred incorrectly to his books dedications. Most of his books  not all  were dedicated to his wife, Joan.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: To Heal Haiti, Look to History, Not Nature
description: HAITI is everybodys cherished tragedy. Long before the great earthquake struck the country like a vengeful god, the outside world, and Americans especially, described, defined, marked Haiti most of all by its suffering. Epithets of misery clatter after its name like a ball and chain: Poorest country in the Western Hemisphere. One of the poorest on earth. For decades Haitis formidable immiseration has made it among outsiders an object of fascination, wonder and awe. Sometimes the pity that is attached to the land  and we see this increasingly in the news coverage this past week  attains a tone almost sacred, as if Haiti has taken its place as a kind of sacrificial victim among nations, nailed in its bloody suffering to the cross of unending destitution.

title: New G.O.P. Senator Having Fun on Capitol Hill
description: WASHINGTON  Senator-elect Scott Brown of Massachusetts visited his new workplace Thursday and seemed mighty pleased with his surroundings and colleagues.

title: In Parallel Worlds, Rex Ryan and Jim Caldwell Each Found Success
description: New Yorkers are not easily astounded.

title: Edwards Admits He Fathered Girl With Mistress
description: Former Senator John Edwards admitted on Thursday that he fathered a daughter with a campaign videographer with whom he had an extramarital affair during his presidential campaign.

title: On Defense, Colts Counterpunchers Are Now Sluggers
description: INDIANAPOLIS  When Tony Dungy was preparing to turn over the Indianapolis Colts to his assistant Jim Caldwell, they talked about nearly every facet of football, hoping for a seamless transition for one of the N.F.L.s most successful franchises. In the standings, that is exactly what happened. The Colts won their first 14 games under Caldwell and quarterback Peyton Manning dazzled, same as ever.

title: California Democrats Revive Universal Health Plan
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Democrats in California revived a bill on Thursday that would create a single-payer, universal health care system in the state.

title: Sunnis and Iraqs Election
description: We had hoped that the March 7 parliamentary elections would prove the growing maturity of Iraqs fragile democracy and set the country on a stable path as American combat troops get ready for this summers planned withdrawal. Instead, the process unfolding is disgracefully unfair and roiling dangerous sectarian tensions.

title: The Party of Nope
description: Here is the latest from the Grand Old Party: After years of eagerly enabling the Bush administrations deficit spending and record debt, Republicans in Congress are dusting off their budget hawk costumes and suddenly demanding fiscal responsibility for the nation. In this scenery-chewing role, they are not just denying their own profligate history, but they hardly seem to be serious. Take their reaction to President Obamas proposal for a bipartisan commission to tackle debt and budget threats.

title: Do the Right Thing
description: A message to House Democrats: This is your moment of truth. You can do the right thing and pass the Senate health care bill. Or you can look for an easy way out, make excuses and fail the test of history.

title: Politics in the Age of Distrust
description: In November 2008, William A. Galston and Elaine C. Kamarck wrote a report called Change You Can Believe In Needs a Government You Can Trust. Galston and Kamarck, who served in senior positions in the Clinton administration, threw up some warning flags for the incoming Obama administration.

title: A Bittersweet Trip Home for the Jets Keller
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Dustin Keller is not sure why he saved the voice mail message that his uncle left him on Tuesday. Maybe it was because of what he said, imploring Keller to give everything he had Sunday against the Indianapolis Colts in the American Football Conference championship game.

title: Sadness and Hope in Halfpipe Qualifying
description: PARK CITY, Utah  The six-week, five-event path to the Vancouver Games is an arduous one for snowboarding halfpipe riders trying to make the United States Olympic team. Now that the route has wended its way to its final weekend and its final two qualifying events, it contains a sad tinge of symbolism, too.

title: Wal-Mart Struggles to Expand in Chicago
description: In the room behind the City Council chambers during the Jan. 13 meeting, a high-ranking Wal-Mart official asked Mayor Richard M. Daley if he was committed to the companys plans to expand beyond its only store in Chicago.

title: Life in Two Worlds Influences a Photographers Art
description: If outsider status were the sole prerequisite for artistic success, Anna Shteynshleyger would be the most important artist of her time. As it is, she is not doing too badly: she is a rising star in the elite world of contemporary art photography.

title: Treasury Weighs Fixes to Foreclosures Program
description: The Obama administration plans next week to revamp its $75 billion program aimed at sparing homeowners from foreclosure, streamlining the documents required of borrowers seeking lowered payments, according to financial industry executives and others who have met in recent days with Treasury officials.

title: Cheers for McGwire, but Silence for Sosa
description: Sammy Sosa is still not welcome at Wrigley Field.

title: A Small Addition to Backyard Farms
description: Residents who have brought a bit of the rural life to Chicago with backyard beehives and chicken coops have lately turned their attention to another barnyard staple: goats.

title: A Fair of Curiosities
description: The American Antiques Show puts collectors and browsers at ease with quasi-domestic arrangements of antiques and folk art.

title: Renaissance Portraits
description: "The Drawings of Bronzino" at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is a scholarly tour de force. Holland Cotter reviews.

title: The Winter Antiques Show
description: At the Park Avenue Armory, 75 art and antiques dealers have gathered to dazzling effect.

title: Venture Capital Was Tight for Tech Start-Ups in 09
description: Venture capitalists, whose money provides fuel to technology start-ups, last year invested the lowest amount in such companies since 1997, according to a report from PricewaterhouseCoopers and the National Venture Capital Association released on Friday.

title: Solutions for Haiti
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pope and the Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article on Jan. 10 about the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences lack of recognition for Doris Day referred incorrectly to the Academys recognition of Orson Welles, and a correction in this space last Sunday, based on the article, also referred incorrectly to the Academys recognition of Charlie Chaplin. Welles did in fact win an Oscar for a specific category, for best screenplay for Citizen Kane (1941), and Chaplin won in a specific category, for best original dramatic score in Limelight. (The score written with Raymond Rasch and Larry Russell.) It is not the case that Welles and Chaplin inexplicably never won the prize in competition. (Welles received an honorary Oscar in 1971, and Chaplin received honorary Oscars in 1929 and 1972.)

title: Marriage Equality
description: To the Editor:

title: Obamas Political Challenge
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Deal With China
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Reform, After Massachusetts
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinese Christians Are the Focus of Same-Sex Marriage Case
description: Scores of evangelical Christians gathered this week for their regular Wednesday night prayer service at the River of Life Christian Churchs sprawling complex in Santa Clara, closing their eyes and opening their palms skyward as they rocked back and forth to soaring hymns.

title: Word of the Day | militate
description: militate \mi-l-tat\ verb

title: Detainees Will Still Be Held, but Not Tried, Official Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has decided to continue to imprison without trials nearly 50 detainees at the Guantnamo Bay military prison in Cuba because a high-level task force has concluded that they are too difficult to prosecute but too dangerous to release, an administration official said on Thursday.

title: Namath on the Jets-Colts
description: Dave Hutchinson of The Star Ledger caught up with Joe Namath on Wednesday:

title: Daniel J. Freed Dies at 82; Shaped Sentencing in U.S.
description: Daniel J. Freed, a Yale Law School professor who was a leading intellectual influence and commentator on how Americans convicted of crimes should be sentenced, died Sunday in Manhattan. He was 82 and lived in Guilford, Vt.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: No. 7 Roddick Tops Lpez and Advances to the Fourth Round
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Andy Roddick fired an ace on the first point of his Australian Open match Friday against Feliciano Lpez. It was an omen  but it took the seventh-ranked Roddick four sets and more than three hours to make it a reality, winning his third-round match, 6-7 (4), 6-4, 6-4, 7-6 (3).

title: Trains to Silicon Valley Get an Old-Fashioned Send-Off
description: The Bay Area might be the envy of the world for its technological prowess, but when it comes to the railroad that serves Silicon Valley, it all comes down to an unprepossessing piece of wood and a long stick.

title: Spare Times for Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Dances by Very Young Choreographers
description: DANCES BY VERY YOUNG CHOREOGRAPHERS

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Wednesday incorrectly stated the size of the coal ash spill in Roane County, Tenn., in December 2008. It was 1 billion gallons, not 1 billion tons.

title: Russian Pair Fuels Controversy With Aboriginal Dance
description: TALLINN, Estonia  Oksana Domnina and Maxim Shabalin of Russia are the reigning world ice dancing champions and favorites for the gold medal at next months Winter Olympics. But their original dance, performed to an aboriginal theme, is generating anger in the middle of the Australian summer, with the aboriginal elder Sol Bellear calling the dance very offensive.

title: Digital Muse for Beat Poet
description: Days before Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple, introduces his Next Big Thing (the consensus holds it will be a sleek tablet computer), I called up Gary Snyder, the Beat-era poet who writes about the American wilderness.

title: Booing at the Jets Pep Rally
description: Jeers at a pep rally somehow seemed fitting for hardboiled Jets fans on Thursday in Times Square.

title: A Wine World Provocateur Switches to Vegetables
description: The partys over for Naomi Brilliant. The social butterfly whose rock n roll events at Roshambo, her Sonoma winery, attracted droves of San Francisco hipsters  typically in silly costumes  is plowing under the vines she inherited from her grandfather to grow vegetables. Shes sold the last of her Roshambo wine.

title: Oracle President Admits Affair After Billboards Appear
description: Update | 9:20 a.m.  Adding credit to Gawker and the apparent motivation for the creation of the billboards.Update | 10:58 a.m. Correcting Charles Phillipss title.

title: Swine Flu Shots Catching on at Colleges
description: College students are beginning to get swine flu shots in growing numbers, according to a report by the American College Health Association. Flu activity stayed low at the 189 schools that answered the associations weekly survey, but 97 percent of schools now have some vaccine, which was not true in the fall, when the flu swept through many campuses. Although only about 9 percent of students had been vaccinated as of mid-January, on some campuses more than 25 percent had had shots.

title: Redesigning Themselves
description: WHO is the man in this picture?

title: News Quiz | January 22, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Man Is Stabbed to Death in His 46th St. Apartment
description: A 41-year-old man was found stabbed to death and covered in a pile of clothes in his Midtown apartment on Thursday, the police said.

title: Billboards Spur Oracle President to Admit Affair
description: Updated, 9:33 a.m. | The mystery of a Times Square billboard showing romantic photographs of the president of Oracle, Charles E. Phillips, alongside the words Charles & YaVaughnie and You are my soulmate forever! has been solved. In a statement Thursday, Mr. Phillips admitted to an extramarital affair.

title: Venture Capital Was Tight for Tech Start-Ups in 09
description: Venture capitalists, whose money provides fuel to technology start-ups, last year invested the lowest amount in such companies since 1997, according to a report from PricewaterhouseCoopers and the National Venture Capital Association released on Friday.

title: Gates Says Taliban Must Take Legitimate Afghan Role
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The United States recognizes that the Taliban are now part of the political fabric of Afghanistan, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said here on Friday, but the group must be prepared to play a legitimate role before it can reconcile with the Afghan government.

title: Visiting Congo
description: Im overnighting in Rwanda, heading overland to Congo right now. Its one of the most important and neglected humanitarian stories in the world, and I hope I can shine a light on it. If you have some issues youd like me to look into, let me know.

title: With Tougher Stance, Obama Takes On Banks
description: The tougher approach to financial regulation that President Obama outlined on Thursday reflected a changed political climate, the rebound in big banks fortunes after their taxpayer bailout and a shift in power within the administration away from those who had been seen as most sympathetic to Wall Street.

title: A Beat Poets Ode to a Macintosh, and Other Highlights From Fridays Bay Area Report
description: A Mac Is a Mac Is a Mac | Gary Snyder, the Beat-era poet and writer on wilderness whose path has crossed that of the personal-computer movement for decades, has written a never-published poem contemplating his Macintosh computer. Never published before now, that is. It appears in our pages as techies everywhere await Steven P. Jobs announcement next Wednesday of Apples latest brainchild.

title: Strong Year for Goldman, as It Trims Bonus Pool
description: No one was crowing about their big paychecks at Goldman Sachs headquarters in New York on Thursday. Despite a record 2009, the bank announced that it had set aside only $16.2 billion to reward its employees.

title: Busch Criticizes McGwire
description: If Mark McGwire thought all would be forgiven after he admitted taking steroids, he appears to have miscalculated. In recent days, Carlton Fisk, Jack Clark and Yogi Berra have taken shots at McGwire, who retired in 2001 and this month became a hitting coach for the St. Louis Cardinals, his old team.

title: Swedish Bank Fee Sets Example for America
description: When it comes to rescuing banks, the Swedes are earning a reputation as trendsetters. First they set a standard for recovering from disaster; now they want to export their idea for how to pay for it, Matthew Saltmarsh writes in The New York Times.

title: Obamas Bank Proposal Helps Erase the Months Gains
description: Concerns over President Obamas plan to limit the activities of banks helped drag shares down on Thursday, erasing all the gains the stock market made in the first three weeks of 2010.

title: Bidders Said to Line Up for Global Mart Assets
description: Standard Chartereds private equity unit, the Chinese conglomerate Fosun Group and three other bidders are vying to buy two Chinese retailers and other assets from the investment firm Global Mart, in a deal expected to fetch about 500 million yuan ($73 million), Reuters reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

title: If Health Care Bills Fail, a Quandary for Insurers
description: With the possible collapse of the Congressional health care effort, health insurers might seem to have reason to celebrate. The legislation threatened to remake much of their business, with the prospect of burdensome government regulation and less profit from selling coverage to individuals and small businesses.

title: Rusal Said to Raise $2.2 Billion in I.P.O.
description: Rusal, the worlds largest aluminum producer, raised 17.4 billion Hong Kong dollars ($2.2 billion) in the first initial public offering by a Russian company in Hong Kong, two people familiar with the sale told Bloomberg News.

title: How Much Time Do You Spend Consuming Media Every Day?
description: The answer for the average 8 to 18-year-old, according to an  article about a new study, is practically every waking minute  except for the time in school. Is this true about you? Are you using a phone, computer, television, mp3 player or other electronic device for the vast majority of your free time? If so, how do you think such heavy media use is affecting you?

title: Hopes Rest on Cohens Return to Competition
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  Desperate to restore a pulse to a flatlining sport, U.S. Figure Skating and NBC built their promotions for the national championships around the resuscitation of Sasha Cohen.

title: China Rebuffs Clinton on Internet Warning
description: BEIJING  The Chinese Foreign Ministry lashed out Friday against criticism of China in a speech on Internet censorship made by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, calling on the United States government to respect the truth and to stop using the so-called Internet freedom question to level baseless accusations.

title: Nagasu Is in the Lead, but She Isnt Ready to Exhale
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  The good Mirai Nagasu, the one that oozes talent and effervescence, skated at United States championships on Thursday. She cracked a saucy smile and used her eyes to flirt with the crowd. With an Olympic berth at stake and the pressure mounting, she looked like she was having fun.

title: Swofties
description: Dubious acronym for single women over fifty.

title: Exiting Bankruptcy, DeCode Lands in V.C. Hands
description: DeCode Genetics, the gene-hunting company in Iceland, said Thursday that it had emerged from bankruptcy and would continue its genetics research and its gene-based diagnostics as a private company. It will abandon its efforts to develop drugs from its discoveries.

title: Ex-Partners of Ernst & Young Sentenced to Prison
description: Two former partners of the accounting firm Ernst & Young each have been sentenced in New York to more than two years in prison after they were convicted of tax shelter charges, The Associated Press reported.

title: Drops in Dow May Hurt 6 I.P.O.s Set for Friday

But triple-digit stock drops this week could spook potential investors and even lead to a postponed coming out party for some, The Associated Press said.

title: Wall Street a Bright Spot Amid Grim Jobless Figures
description: The unemployment rate in New York City jumped in December to 10.6 percent, its highest level in nearly 17 years, as hotels, museums and builders eliminated jobs and hiring remained weak in most other businesses, the State Labor Department said Thursday.

title: Bank Plan Trips Financial Stocks in Europe
description: Financial stocks in Europe sagged Friday, following sharp losses in Asia, but broader stock indices held firm as investors balanced the conflicting prospect of tighter financial regulation with gradually improving growth rates.

title: Britains Conservatives Back Obamas Plan
description: British Conservative Party officials backed American plans to curb the banking sector on Friday but said they would not disadvantage Britains important financial services industry, Reuters reported.

title: Good Times and Bad, Henin Kept Her Coach in View
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Justine Henin and Carlos Rodriguez have been together since Henin was 14. She was a wunderkind then, and he was her coach. Both have a bit of age on them now, but all you have to do is watch Henin search the grandstand for him after each hard-fought point to see not much has changed.

description: Coca-Cola is considering buying a controlling stake in the Russian juice maker Nidan Soki from the London-based private equity group Lion Capital, sources familiar with the deal participants told Reuters.

title: Clijsters Knocked Out of Australian Open

She was on the court for 52 minutes, and Nadia Petrova, the 19th-seeded Russian, embarrassed her pretty much every second in a thorough 6-0, 6-1 banishment.

But mounting commercial loan losses and dwindling demand for items like jet engines raised some concerns among analysts, even though the company said it was on track for growth this year.

If approved, the school district would receive $15,000 a year from Clearwire, which sells a WiMax broadband service. The antenna spreads radio waves wider than Wi-Fi radio waves, something that concerns some parents. I dont want my kids used as an experiment, said John Johnson. [The Contra Costa Times]

description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Last week, John Isner, a 6-9 American with a monster serve, won his first singles title last week in Auckland, New Zealand. How monster?

Blankenship of Massey Energy, and an environmental lawyer, Robert Kennedy Jr., the University of Charlestons president, Ed Welch, expressed hope that he might nudge the two men beyond their talking points.

title: Writing in the Dahl House, Part 2
description: Fantastic Mr. Fox, Wes Andersons adaptation of the Roald Dahl childrens book, has garnered Mr. Anderson some of the most effusive praise of his already-lauded career, and made him a contender in the awards game. Though he is not exactly a veteran of the circuit, his debut, Bottle Rocket, did win an MTV award in 1996. (Its so badly made though, Mr. Anderson said. Its meant to look like popcorn and the carton just started to peel apart. Its not one that you can really keep forever on the mantelpiece.) The Bagger spoke to Mr. Anderson and his co-writer, Noah Baumbach, in Los Angeles. This is Part 2 of the conversation; Part 1 can be found here.

description: Updated, 1:36 p.m. | A newly configured slate of transit service cuts was unveiled on Friday by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, restoring overnight service to several crosstown bus routes through Central Park, and avoiding some previously announced cuts, like less-frequent trains at night.

title: The Choice
description: So, House Democrats have a choice: do they pass the Senate bill, or do they go back to the drawing board and spend several months cobbling together a plan thats worse in almost every dimension, generating thousands of stories about hapless Democrats  and almost surely find that Senate Republicans block the new plan, too.

title: Jan. 22: Updates on the Crisis in Haiti
description: On Friday The Lede is continuing to supplement reporting by our colleagues in Haiti on the aftermath of last weeks earthquake by pointing to news and information on the Web. Readers are encouraged to share any firsthand accounts they receive from Haiti or see online in the comments thread below. See the home page of NYTimes.com for the latest news articles and multimedia features on the relief effort.
