title: How Andy Roddick Won: Patience
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Andy Roddick looked refreshed. He had just turned back a determined challenger, Feliciano Lpez of Spain, in four sets. It was his sixth consecutive victory over Lopez, to whom he has not lost.

title: Every Waking Minute? Examining Personal Media Habits
description: Overview | What are the implications of a new study showing that kids use electronic devices virtually all the time? In this lesson, students take a close look at their own media use over time, identify any detrimental habits, then develop personal plans and put them into action. They then write and deliver persuasive speeches on the media and technology topic of their choice.

title: Tourists Return to an Ancient Crossroads in Syria
description: TO shouts of yella-yella  move along!  the driver of a donkey lugging a wagon overstuffed with pistachios parted the throngs of shoppers in Aleppos medieval souk. It was the middle of Ramadan, just hours before the iftar, the evening meal when Muslims break their daily fast, and the markets serpentine rows of squat stalls were filled with black-veiled women and keffiyeh-clad men, sniffing the handmade olive soaps and stocking up on spices.

title: Friday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appear in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: What Did Geithner Say?
description: Various news reports that Tim Geithner is privately opposed to the new Obama bank plan  which isnt that much of a surprise, but he should not be talking about it (if he is). What we do have is this PBS interview, in which he certainly isnt doing much to back the concept. The correct answer to In essence are you saying that big banks need to be broken up is Yes; add some qualifiers if necessary  were not talking about a sudden disruption, but about new rules of the game, but the eventual goal is smaller banks that arent engaged in inappropriate activities or something like that.

What are the best treatments and where do I find them? How will this affect the rest of my family?

title: The Moviegoer | No Sex Please, Theyre Married
description: Creation, which concerns Charles Darwins 20-year-long Hamlet moment over writing Origin of Species, is not what you commonly call a sexy story  even if 5-year-old viewers (both of them) will still say eeeewww: a barnacle is graphically dissected, a fox eats a rabbit (thus furthering the cause of movie foxes not named Megan; see Antichrist) and, in Darwins workshop, acid-washed birds are boiled down to their bones. For adults, however, the most disturbing event in this British production will be a rather Victorian sex scene between Darwin and his wife, Emma. Why? Because theyre played by the real-life couple Paul Bettany and Jennifer Connelly.Sure, we understand: the director, Jon Amiel, wanted to avail himself of the instant intimacy of a married twosome. But who wants to see that? Who wanted to see Alec Baldwin and Kim Basinger getting it on in The Getaway? Who wanted to cross the minefield that was Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman in Eyes Wide Shut? Who wanted to see Ed Harris and Amy Madigan (as the painter Jackson Pollock and heiress Peggy Guggenheim) coupling like wildebeests in Pollock? O.K., that was pretty funny. But married people in bed? You might as well watch a Don Johnson-Melanie Griffith festival.

description: The surge in viewership for Conan OBrien in his last week as hoist of The Tonight Show became a flood Thursday night, as young viewers flocked to his second-last performance on the program.

description: Q.

description: Paul E. Singer, the manager of the $16 billion hedge fund Elliott Associates, is never one to mince words. He recently shared his views  and criticisms  of the financial crisis and the Obama administrations efforts to reform Wall Street.

description: Four years ago, a representative of an established business plan competition, the ORNL Global Venture Challenge, phoned Tiffany Bussey, founding director of the Morehouse College Entrepreneurship Center. The representative was looking for minority students with business plans.

title: A Gainsbourg Moves Beyond Her Legacy
description: IT doesnt take long for IRM, the new album by the French singer and actress Charlotte Gainsbourg, to start sounding Gainsbourgian. The record opens with Masters Hands, a ballad full of tense guitar and banjo picking, clattering percussion and strings that dart and swoop.

description: In Ristretto, Oliver Strand, the curator of the Times Topics coffee page, explores the world of coffee gadgets, coffee beans and why its never been easier to get a perfect shot of espresso.

title: In the Worlds Tech Hub, an Expensive Old Ritual
description: Todays Barbary Coast column is about a primitive form of communication. No, not something from an ancient civilization. Its the system in place to identify the trains, tracks and departure times at the otherwise very modern Caltrain terminus at 4th and Townsend Streets in San Francisco.

title: Three Steps to Making Smart Haiti Donations
description: As soon as they heard about the earthquake, Haitians in Brooklyn started making their way to Savoir Faire, the record store in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, to pool what little information anyone had. And they also brought supplies to send back home  clothing, canned fruit, ramen, cases of bottled water. By early last week, the donations had been stacked into huge piles, and a plan had come into view: the store would lead a delegation of 25 people to Haiti, to rescue the children stranded at the Life for the World orphanage in the town of Source Matelas. Doctors, nurses and anyone else who wanted to come would each carry two large suitcases stuffed with food and medical supplies.

title: Weekend Competition: Erroneous Advice
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to be downright mean by proffering deliberately unhelpful advice for visitors from out of town.

title: Complaint Box | The E-Snub
description: NOT too long ago, a magazine in Manhattan invited me, by e-mail, to interview for a job. After meeting with me, the managing editor and the director of human resources asked me to take home the standard editing test and return it ASAP. I dutifully obliged.

title: Letter: Antarctica's Allure
description: To the editor: Great new, enticing picks in The 31 Places to Go in 2010 (Jan. 10) to whet the appetite for unusual travel. However, as a many-time traveler to Antarctica since the early 1980s, the statements suggesting that tourist travel has been only recent belie the facts. While 2010 may be a good year to go, ships complying with new standards at a later date will continue to make this continent the ultimate destination for those who have a love of unsurpassed natural beauty.

title: Corrections
description: The cover article on Jan. 10 about 31 Places to Go in 2010 misidentified the opposing sides in the civil war that plagued Sri Lanka for a quarter century. The war was between the Sinhalese-dominated government and a separatist Tamil group, not between the Sinhalese majority and the Tamil minority.

title: Spice Girls Plan a Musical Based on Their Songs
description: Watch out, Mamma Mia! The Spice Girls are cooking up a musical with an original story based on their hit songs, Reuters reports. The working title is Viva Forever, after the 1998 British No. 1 single by the five-member British band. The Viva Forever creators are the bands former manager Simon Fuller and Judy Craymer, who produced the worldwide hit musical Mamma Mia! which featured the songs of the Swedish band Abba, and later became a movie starring Meryl Streep. Mamma Mia! has made $2 billion in the past decade. The Spice Girls show could debut on the London stage in two or three years, Mr. Fuller and Ms. Craymer said. The Spice Girls  Melanie Chisholm (Sporty Spice or Mel C), Victoria Beckham (Posh Spice), Geri Halliwell (Ginger Spice); Emma Bunton (Baby Spice) and Melanie Brown (Scary Spice) became a cultural phenomenon after releasing their first single Wannabe in 1996. The group split up in 2000 but reunited for a tour in 2007.

title: Montreal Street Gets New Life
description: SOMETIMES, all it takes for a neighborhood to be transformed is some renovated footpaths.

title: Henin Stays on Track as Clijsters Falls
description: In an inexplicable fashion, Kim Clijsters crashed out of the Australian Open against the Russian Nadia Petrova, winning just one game on the way to a loss ESPN.coms Ravi Ubha called a savage beating.

description: Nearly four million car seats are being recalled because a restraining strap does not meet the safety standard set by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

description: ISTANBUL  More than 120 people suspected of ties to Al Qaeda, including some who were alleged to be senior members of the terrorist groups Turkish branch, were arrested in raids across the country on Friday morning, the semiofficial Anatolian news agency reported.

title: Local Vote Could Decide Japan Base Issue
description: TOKYO  Few Americans have ever heard of Yoshikazu Shimabukuro or Susumu Inamine, or even the tiny Okinawan city of Nago, where the two men are candidates in a heated race for mayor.

title: The Health Care System Without Change
description: Heres what has not changed about the health care system in America.

description: THE BASICS

title: Margaret Sylvester and Geoffrey Foster
description: Margaret Comer Sylvester and Geoffrey Worthing Foster were married Saturday by the Rev. Lawrence J. Madden at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington.

title: Kitty Kelley Takes On Oprah Winfrey
description: Oprah Winfrey is the latest subject for Kitty Kelley, known for her often unflattering, dishy and best-selling celebrity biographies. Crown Publishers announced this week that Ms. Kelleys 544-page, unauthorized Oprah: A Biography, will be released on April 13, The Associated Press reported. The first printing will be at least 500,000 copies. Ms. Kelley has written books about Frank Sinatra, Nancy Reagan and the Bush family. She conducted 850 interviews for the book and spent the last three years combing through Ms. Winfreys life, Ms. Kelley said, according to the A.P. She was, Ms. Kelley said, full of admiration for her accomplishments and fascinated by her complexity.

title: Anne Boleyn, Queen for a Day
description: The story of Anne Boleyn, second wife of Henry VIII, ended in May 1536, when the master executioner of Calais  sent for specially, and said to be an adept in his art  separated her clever head from her seductive body with one clean stroke of his sword. Historians are still puzzling over Annes downfall. Henry had fought for years to extricate himself from his first marriage and create a world where he and Anne could be husband and wife; to achieve it, he had split Christian Europe apart. How did he become so alienated from her that he wanted her dead? Had she really slept with her brother George? Who was the prime mover in alleging against her multiple acts of adultery, involving five men? Was it Henry himself, crediting some slander and lashing out in blind rage? Or his minister Thomas Cromwell, fighting for his own career? What part was played by the papist supporters of the Princess Mary, Henrys child by his first marriage? Were all these parties, for different reasons, acting together? And at what point was Annes doom sealed? Did her fortunes begin to falter in January 1536, when the kings first wife died and Anne miscarried a child? Or was she brought down over a few days, in an atmosphere of fulminating panic that infected the entire court?

title: On Liberias Shore, Catching a New Wave
description: WE were less than 30 minutes from our destination of Robertsport, home to Liberias nascent surfing scene, and gliding along what one local had accurately described as the best dirt road in the country, when my driver, Andrew, and I got into a loud and boisterous fight.

title: Swiss Ruling Jeopardizes Deal for UBS Clients Names
description: A Swiss court ruled Friday that Swiss authorities may not disclose the account details of a wealthy American who used UBSs private bank to evade American taxes.

title: Restaurant Review: The Lake Chalet Seafood Bar & Grill, in Oakland, Calif.
description: Every city needs a lake, and every lake needs a $22 million restaurant on its shores, where you can munch on tacos while a passing gondolier sings in Italian. Luckily, Oakland has figured this out, and residents can now unwind at the Lake Chalet there, where an inconsistent menu takes a back seat to the stunning surroundings.

title: Katherine Hess, Andrew Secunda
description: Katherine Kimble Hess and Andrew Morgan Secunda were married Saturday evening at Twenty Four Fifth, an event space in Manhattan. Amichai Lau-Lavie, the spiritual leader of Storahtelling, a Jewish organization, officiated.

title: Long March
description: The ad agency employees who form the collective narrative voice of Joshua Ferriss masterly debut, Then We Came to the End, are on intimate terms with the concept of branding. As branders, they undoubtedly would have advised their creator, in planning his second novel, to hew closely to the recipe that made his first novel such a critical and popular success, that made it read sort of like a highbrow novelization of The Office. With his second novel Ferris makes it clear that he has absolutely no intention, for the moment at least, of repeating himself or creating an authorial brand. In fact, its difficult to believe that The Unnamed and Then We Came to the End come from the same laptop.

title: Alison Shaffer, Samuel Ballen
description: Alison Jill Shaffer and Samuel David Ballen are to be married Sunday in an outdoor ceremony at the Seagate Beach Club in Delray Beach, Fla. Rabbi David Steinhardt is to perform the ceremony.

title: Storm Hits Russo & Steele Collector Car Auction
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  The Russo & Steele classic car auction was interrupted Thursday night by strong winds accompanying a wild storm that damaged cars and ripped away huge sections of the events tents and deposited them in the traffic lanes of the adjacent 101 freeway.

title: Mets Acquire Gary Matthews Jr. From Angels
description: Update | 3:11 p.m. Adds details.

title: The Producer
description: Heroes without flaws appear only in bad comics and worse books and movies. The giants who seize our attention and embody achievement at its most inspiring are often nearly as troublesome as they are noble, with defects and virtues that can stem from the same deep drives. Joseph Papp, the Brooklyn-born impresario who changed the face of the American theater by founding the New York Shakespeare Festival and the Public Theater, is unquestionably a hero of the complicated kind. His story is revisited in rich, rewarding detail in a fat new book, Free for All: Joe Papp, the Public, and the Greatest Theater Story Ever Told, written by Kenneth Turan and  whats this?  yes, Papp himself.

title: Danny Boyle to Direct Frankenstein on the London Stage
description: Now lets see. How many versions of Frankenstein will this make? Danny Boyle, the director of the Oscar-winning Slumdog Millionaire is to direct a stage adaptation of Frankenstein, based on the novel by Mary Shelley, The Guardian reports. Nicholas Hytner, the director of the National Theater in London, said that the British director will make his debut at the theater later this year. Mr. Hytner said that Mr. Boyle, who began his career at Londons Royal Court and the Royal Shakespeare Company, was returning to his first love after film distracted him for a while. (Mr. Boyle also directed Trainspotting.) Danny first talked about this eight years ago and it has taken him eight years, Mr. Hytner said of Mr. Boyles decision to direct the playwright Nick Dears new adaptation of Frankenstein. It will be a large-scale and theatrically and visually ambitious stage production, Mr. Hytner said

title: Anne Bracken, Patrick Gavin
description: Anne Margaret Grace Bracken and Patrick William Gavin were married Saturday evening in Washington. The Rev. Susan Moss, an Episcopal priest and an aunt of the bride, officiated at the National Museum of Women in the Arts.

title: Travel Deals: 40% Off in Turks and Caicos
description: The Seven Stars Resort in Turks and Caicos is offering 40 percent off as part of a winter special. With the discount, rooms start at $390 a night through March 31. A three-night minimum stay is required.

title: A Home for Hidden Treasures in London
description: WHEN it first opened in 1852, the stated mission of the Victoria and Albert Museum in London was to inspire designers, manufacturers and artists of the day. Now, with a brand-new set of galleries, the museum is hoping to inspire visitors by luring them back through the centuries.

title: Now Screening | Dries Van Noten
description: The fall 2010 collection from Dries Van Noten.

title: One Thing After Another
description: Not long ago, I walked in on a group of medical residents inserting a central line catheter into a patient in the intensive care unit. They were gowned and gloved, working quietly over the patients neck, exposed through a small hole in a sterile blue drape, where a thick needle was entering under the collarbone. I noticed they had neglected to drape the abdomen and legs, but at this point it didnt seem wise to interrupt the procedure, so I let it go. They had also apparently forgotten to don face shields and caps. I let that go, too. Like them, I wanted to get the procedure over with as quickly as possible before something bad happened.

title: The Mobs Turn Their Ire to Athletes
description: Memo to star athletes, former athletes, coaches: This is not the time to tick people off.

title: Room Service
description: You have to be a little crazy to read as much into Psycho as David Thomson does in The Moment of Psycho: How Alfred Hitchcock Taught America to Love Murder. Not that crazy people cant be charming and erudite, just as Anthony Perkinss Norman Bates is in that movie. But read this book in long stretches  sit, as it were, with Thomson in a room and listen to him expound  and you may start having that I gotta get out of here feeling.

title: Troy Story
description: Neither the early life of Priam, the elderly king of Troy, nor his miserable and bloody fate are direct concerns of the Iliad. The Homeric epic opens in medias res, already in the 10th year of the Trojan War, and it draws toward its suspenseful close with one of the most brilliant and counterintuitive episodes in all of ancient literature, Priams stupendously dangerous journey to the heart of the Greek camp to ransom the corpse of his son Hector from the Trojans implacable enemy, Achilles.

title: Group Hug | Day 1 at the Paris Mens Shows
description: The Paris shows were off to a good start with Louis Vuitton, where the mens studio director, Paul Helbers, got things going with a Vienna-inspired parade of somber flecked coats and jackets, convertible boots with zippers and beautiful bags with abstract hand-painting by the artist Christian Schoeller. Helbers said that he had looked at artists like Egon Schiele and Gustav Klimt for inspiration; he also commissioned a soundtrack featuring a Kafka reading, and even changed the show-space configuration: instead of a normal runway, models walked in a mazelike setup to allow for greater proximity to the audience. It was a smart move. From the leather anoraks and blazers to the new clog-inspired short boots and the contrasting fabric insets on jackets and coats, this was a collection that needed to be seen up close.

title: Kimberly Essency, Antonino Pillari
description: Kimberly Brooke Essency, the daughter of Barbara L. Essency and C. Keith Essency of Austin, Tex., was married in Manhattan Saturday to Antonino Pillari, a son of Maria Pillari and Francesco Pillari of Astoria, Queens. The Rev. Anthony Schueller performed the ceremony at St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church, where he is pastor.

title: Capitalist Chameleon
description: What is the nature of capitalism? For Joseph Schumpeter, the Austrian-born economist whose writings have acquired a special relevance in the past year or two, this most modern of economic systems incessantly revolutionizes the economic structure from within, incessantly destroying the old one, incessantly creating a new one. Capitalism, Schumpeter proclaimed, cannot stand still; it is a system driven by waves of entrepreneurial innovation, or what he memorably described as a perennial gale of creative destruction.

title: Adjustments Likely in Hudson River Cleanup
description: Judging from some draft evaluations prepared by the Environmental Protection Agency and General Electric, the plan for dredging the Hudson River for PCBs faces some likely adjustments.

title: The Buying Begins at Sundance
description: This is an auspicious beginning: hours before the opening film at the Sundance Film Festival, the first deal has already been made. Variety reports that Waiting for Superman, a documentary about the crisis in public education, was picked up by Paramount for its (much-streamlined) boutique Paramount Vantage division. The film comes from Davis Guggenheim and Lesley Chilcott, the director-producer team behind An Inconvenient Truth, which made an Oscar-winning moneymaker out of another unsexy topic  the environment.

title: The Shopping Cure
description: The Egyptian Islamist theoretician Sayyid Qutb believed the West  in particular the United States  posed an existential threat to Islam. He feared that globalization, spearheaded by the American colossus, might eventually destroy Islam by tempting pious Muslims with freewheeling capitalism, the separation of religion from government and the unleashing of decadent animalistic desires. Qutb, in word and in deed, took up the sword against Gamal Abdel Nassers secular government. Nasser hanged him in 1966, but Qutbs ideas transformed the world by inspiring Osama bin Ladens Qaeda theology.

title: Carolina Bolado and Nathan Hale
description: Carolina Ivette Bolado and Nathan Hale were married Saturday at St. Raymond Catholic Church in Miami. Msgr. Toms M. Marn performed the ceremony.

title: Putting a Price on a Miracle
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: The Year That Was
description: Europes geopolitical map, just 20 years after the breach of the Berlin Wall, looks like a foregone conclusion today  the natural upshot of Communisms demise and the spread of liberal democracy. The Central Europeans are snugly in the European Union; NATO presides over a largely peaceful continent; and though spats between the West and an authoritarian Russia occasionally flare, this is surely understandable given all the givens.

title: Alma Mater
description: To the Editor:

title: Bernankes Bid for a Second Term at the Fed Hits Resistance
description: The Obama administration struggled on Friday to secure confirmation of Ben S. Bernanke to a second term as chairman of the Federal Reserve, underscoring the political upheaval as both parties tried to find their footing amid a powerful wave of populism.

title: Alma Mahler
description: To the Editor:

title: Zero Tolerance
description: To the Editor:

title: First Tweet From Space
description: On Friday Timothy Creamer, an Astronaut on board the International Space Station (I.S.S.), sent the first live tweet from space. It was one small tweet for man, one giant tweet for mankind.

title: Fresh Powder Meets Fine Dining at Cortina dAmpezzo
description: CONSIDERING the elegant bottle of sangiovese he was about to pour, the waiters ragged stocking cap and well-worn black sweater might have been casual to the point of gauche. The diners werent exactly in black tie either, with many dressed in stretchy sportswear and poofy coveralls. But the dishes were without flaw: an unusual beet ravioli, startlingly rich and sweet, and a creamy bowl of polenta that was cheesy and velvety.

title: When N.F.L. Ruled Airwaves With Blackouts
description: In the dark days of silly, anti-fan blackouts, Jets fans had to travel at least 75 miles outside the New York City market to watch their team beat the Oakland Raiders in the 1968 American Football League championship game.

title: This Article Is Not Yet Rated
description: ALONG with buckets of money  more than $1.6 billion so far, worldwide  and a couple of Golden Globes, James Camerons Avatar has collected a smattering of controversy. Some of the hue and cry has involved matters of political allegory and theological implication, as pundits have divined that this globally popular blockbuster may represent a veiled ideological attack on America, capitalism, humanity, monotheism or all of the above. But the fiercest attack on Avatar has focused on what may seem, compared to such lofty matters, like a minor detail. Of all the corny lines and ready-made catchphrases in Mr. Camerons script, perhaps none has turned out to be so provocative as one uttered by Grace Augustine, the scientist played by Sigourney Weaver: Wheres my damn cigarette?

title: Another View: Putting Clients First by Going Private
description: William W. Sprague, chief executive of the privately held investment bank Madison Williams and a former Kidder Peabody and Smith Barney banker, says a return to a private partnership culture may be the best medicine for unrepentant Wall Street professionals.

title: Carrie Geller and Jeremy Schein
description: Carrie Lyn Geller, the daughter of Merryl R. Zuber of Houston and Marc S. Geller of Houston, was married there Saturday evening to Jeremy Simon Schein, the son of Carla Salomon Schein and Dr. Jonah W. Schein of New York. Rabbi Jack Segal officiated at the Omni Houston Hotel and Rabbi Roy Walter took part.

title: Mini Countryman Further Expands the Once-Niche Brand
description: Call it the Mini maxi.

title: Jessica Myers, Bradley Spiegel
description: Jessica Celia Myers, a daughter of Beth B. Myers and Steven E. Myers of Kings Point, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Bradley Craig Spiegel, the son of Deanne R. Spiegel, also of Sands Point and the late Edward Spiegel. Rabbi Robert S. Widom officiated at the Pierre in New York, with Cantor Elliot Levine taking part.

title: Stacey Lutzker, Adam Mayer
description: Stacey Melissa Lutzker, a daughter of Jill Lutzker and Elliot H. Lutzker of New York, was married Saturday evening to Adam Jay Mayer, a son of Helen Mayer and Dr. Eugene Mayer of Huntingdon Valley, Pa. Rabbi Michael S. Friedman officiated at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York.

title: Its Not Supposed to Work Like This
description: LIKE a lot of boomers, Allan Goldstein, 60, has mixed feelings about the online world he inhabits. As a college teacher  hes the assistant director of the writing program at the Polytechnic Institute of New York University  he works with young people and feels pressure to keep current. He uses an electronic blackboard system to post his syllabus, class assignments and grades online, but he doesnt trust it. There are glitches, he said. The schools system has crashed a few times. They want us to use it, but I back everything up on paper.

title: Florida by Subway
description: KATHERINE WAI CHAN and Jimmy Louie, who started dating as college students in Ohio in the late 1990s, began their life together in distinctly unprepossessing quarters.

title: 2010: The Year of the Renter?
description: SCORES of stalled construction projects can be found scattered around New York City, but one category of building that doesnt seem to have been sidetracked by the recession is the luxury apartment rental.

title: Graphic Best-Seller Lists:  A Series Inspired by Christopher Robin, but Not for Kids
description: Tom Taylor has a problem. He is the inspiration for Tommy Taylor, a world-renowned boy-wizard character concocted by his father, an author. The pressure of being linked to such a beloved icon is crushing. Theres also an added complication: Tommys fictional world is seeping into the real one. And thats just the beginning of The Unwritten, a new series written by Mike Carey and illustrated by Peter Gross, whose first collected edition lands at No. 8 on our softcover list this week.

title: Dana Kaplan and  Zachary Davidson
description: Dana Margot Kaplan and Zachary Sean Davidson were married Saturday evening at Stage Six at Steiner Studios at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Rabbi Joseph Potasnik officiated.

title: Serpico on Serpico
description: HARLEMVILLE, N.Y.  He looked like some sort of fur trapper, this bearded man walking through the snowy woods here in upstate New York. But then, Frank Serpico has always been known for his disguises.

title: The First Blogs With Bite of 2010
description: My friend Mike Licht starts off the year with toasters, pho and candy bar wrappers. See the list here.

title: Policy Experts Urge House to Pass Senate Bill
description: Forty-seven health policy experts sent a letter (PDF) Friday to the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, and the chairmen of three crucial House committees urging the House to adopt the Senates health care legislation.

title: Frank Wants to Replace Fannie and Freddie
description: Representative Barney Frank said Friday that the House Financial Services Committee, which he leads, would push to replace Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, seized by regulators almost 17 months ago, with a different model for mortgage financing.

title: A Different Howl for a Revamped Sundance
description: The revamped Sundance Film Festival  slogan: Reborn. Rebellion. Rebirth. Rebel. Renewed. Rebooted  got under way on Thursday night, and some changes were already evident. At the opening news conference, Robert Redford, the founder and guiding light, dissed a regular attendee: Paris Hilton doesnt have anything to do with anything, he said, as Roger Ebert reported.

title: Chair of Goldman Hedge Group Said to Retire
description: The chairman of Goldman Sachss quantitative hedge fund group, whose funds run off of complex computer trading algorithms, plans to step down at the end of the month, Bloomberg News reported Friday, citing unnamed sources.

title: David C. Walentas
description: Mr. Walentas, 71, is the founder and principal of the Two Trees Management Company, which has developed and managed more than four million square feet of commercial and residential real estate, mostly in New York City. Mr. Walentas is also credited with establishing the Dumbo neighborhood in Brooklyn.

title: Corporations Are Not People
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: The Supreme Court today ruled in a five votes to four decision that corporations can now spend as much as they want on political campaigns. In other words, if Exxon or Dow wants to support a candidate, they can give him or her as much money as they want. I cant see that having any negative repercussions, can you?

title: Great American Speeches
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Well, today officially marks the beginning of President Obamas second year in office. He has three years left, but NBC offered him $45 million to leave altogether. So, well see what happens.

title: Free Checking Could Go the Way of Free Toasters
description: Free checking began as a privilege. Once it spread, customers felt entitled. Eventually, it became a commodity, as most banks felt they needed to offer it. Soon, people took it for granted.

title: A Separation Agreement
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Tonight Show With Conan OBrien on NBC: NBC and I have finally reached a separation agreement. Id like to apologize to the guests that were scheduled for next week. President Barack Obama, the pope, the queen of England, and our good friend, Elvis Presley, was stopping by.

title: Mapping Future Growth
description: IF every acre of unprotected open space on Long Island were developed with single-family homes, the landscape could hold another 90,000 homes. On the other hand, if erected as town houses, garden apartments and apartment buildings, the same 90,000 units could be built in downtown areas, utilizing about half of the 8,300 acres  or 13 square miles  of available parking lots, vacant land or open space on the Island.

title: Book Review Podcast: Atul Gawande
description: This week: Atul Gawande discusses his new book, The Checklist Manifesto; Charles Isherwood, a theater critic for The New York Times, remembers the great Joseph Papp; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: At Bonus Time, Less Appetite for Toys
description: WITH all eyes on banks and their bonus pools, there is the question of what happens to the bonus money the bankers receive this year. Will they return to flashy spending or invest it more conservatively?

title: Which Is More Hard to Believe?
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: Anybody here from Massachusetts? You got a new senator, congratulations. Do you know anything about this guy? His name is Scott Brown. Isnt that the guy Elvis played in Clambake?

title: The Betting on Bernanke
description: Update | 5:23 p.m.

title: New Guidelines Could Make Co-op Renovations Tougher
description: IF they had a theme song, the new co-op renovation guidelines from the New York City Bar Association might be set to the rock anthem Were Not Gonna Take It.

title: A Guide to the New Good Faith Estimate
description: Anyone who has shopped for a mortgage knows how confusing the process can be  loans come with different sets of fees, interest rates and closing costs, all of which must be untangled before you can figure out whos offering the best deal. But comparison shopping may get a little easier.

title: The Delicate Balance of Power
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: Well, in political news, the big upset. A Republican was elected to the U.S. Senate in Massachusetts, filling a seat once held by Ted Kennedy. So, this could tip the delicate balance of power in the U.S. Senate from the completely incompetent back to the morally corrupt.

title: A Second Act for Trump Condo
description: JERSEY CITY

title: In Ohio, Obama Vows to Keep Fighting on Health Care
description: ELYRIA, Ohio  Conceding his health care overhaul had run into a little bit of a buzz saw, President Obama vowed on Friday to keep fighting for legislation that will hold the insurance industry accountable and to bring more stability and security to folks who are in our health care system.

title: Luxury Retirement Community Planned in Westchester
description: ROUND-THE-CLOCK NURSING? Youve got it. Alzheimers support? Ditto. Cocktail lounge and valet parking? But of course.

title: Obstacles to Recovery in Haiti May Prove Daunting Beyond Other Disasters
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  The relief effort in Haiti could end up being the most difficult, faith-testing recovery from a modern disaster, perhaps even exceeding that from the 2004 Asian tsunami, according to United Nation officials and aid groups with experience in large-scale catastrophes.

title: So Paulo Fashion Week | Hits Below the Equator
description: So Paulo fashion week is still coming into its own, but it certainly gives good show. From a slew of supermodels to unmarked after-parties, the cool quotient held its own against the more traditional fashion capitals. This seasons model check saw Lara Stone walking for Forum Tufi Duek, Brazils prodigal son Jesus Luz doing an awkward catwalk turn for Ellus, Alessandra Ambrosio filling in for Gisele at Colcci, Isabeli Fontana opening for Alexandre Herchcovitch and Chanel Iman at Rosa Cha.

title: Choking Game No Mystery to Children, Oregon Study Finds
description: One in three eighth graders in Oregon has heard of the dangerous choking game, and more than 1 in 20 have taken part, according to one of the first statewide surveillance efforts to gauge the popularity of this risky pastime.

title: Comment by China Adds to Mystery of Missing Lawyer
description: BEIJING  The Chinese government made its first official comments on Thursday about a prominent human rights advocate who disappeared nearly a year ago, but its remarks left his fate shrouded in mystery.

title: Swiss Court Rules UBS Cannot Release Clients Data
description: A client of the Swiss banking giant UBS has won an appeal to prevent her account information from being handed over to authorities in Washington as part of a tax evasion investigation, Reuters reported.

title: A New Take on Refinancing
description: SEARCHING for home mortgage rates online often means submitting information to a Web site, then withstanding a flurry of calls and e-mail messages from brokers and lenders trying to sell a loan.

title: Risottos for a Midwinter Nights Meal
description: In this weeks Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman turns to risottos, the creamy Italian rice and grain dishes that offer warmth and comfort on these cold winter nights.

title: Attracted to Walkable New York
description: IT was Manhattans street life that appealed most to John Southern and Polly Crongeyer, residents of Pensacola, Fla. Last year the couple, who are both retired, were thinking about redesigning our lifestyle a little bit, Mr. Southern said.

title: Fireman Ed Sits Out a Big One
description: All the earth  or at least those living in a frenzied parallel universe known as Jets fandom  might view the 6-foot-1, 235-pound retired New York City fireman as a talisman for regaining lost Super Bowl glory, a raging, one-man booster club for a once-storied football franchise on the verge of toppling doubt.

title: Veterans Like Sharper Found a Fit With the Saints
description: NEW ORLEANS  The deal was struck during a business meal late last winter at Emerils.

title: Oil Estimates in Venezuela Doubled
description: Venezuela has long been known to hold some of the worlds biggest deposits of oil sands  thick bituminous resources that require substantial investments and refining methods to develop.

title: How Players Recover After a Match
description: With both the temperatures and the intensity ratcheting up as we round the bend into the second week at the Australian Open, recovery after a match starts to have a bigger effect on performance. Both Justine Henin and Kim Clijsters looked a step slow and not in top form in their second-round matches. And on the mens side, Markos Baghdatis and Mikhail Youzhny each endured painful cramps at the end of their recent five-set wins.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) Americas best companies to work for, according to Fortune Magazine.

title: Dark Times for Harley-Davidsons Bottom Line
description: Harley-Davidson reported its 2009 earnings on Friday, and they were bad  worse than Wall Street analysts had been expecting. In fact, 2009 was the worst year for the Milwaukee-based motorcycle maker since 1993.

title: The Cost of Autism
description: In todays Patient Money column, Walecia Konrad focuses on the financial impact autism has on families. She writes:

title: Would You Pay for a Checking Account?
description: In this weeks Your Money column, I explain why the free checking account may be an endangered species.

title: A Static View in a Changing Neighborhood
description: THE view from the Brooklyn Heights Promenade, a five-block walkway that has overlooked New York Harbor from its perch at neighborhoods edge since 1950, is almost the same as it was 60 years ago. The Lower Manhattan skyline rises up, seeming close enough to touch, against a backdrop of clouds; tugboats push barges to and fro; cars and trucks race underneath on the cantilevered Brooklyn-Queens Expressway.

title: Teacher Q | Whats Working Well in Your Classroom This Year?
description: In many schools the semester is winding down, so we thought this week wed ask a question that might help you reflect on the last five months and inspire you for the next five.

title: Howl: Allen Ginsberg and His Times Are Brought To Life
description: There was a mad night in 1955 when Allen Ginsberg read his poem Howl for the first time at the Six Gallery, a former auto-body shop on Fillmore street in San Francisco.

title: Geithnerdaemmerung?
description: One surprise consequences of the debacle in Massachusetts is that Democrats are suddenly turning on the architects of the financial rescue. Bernankes reappointment doesnt look so certain; Geithner and Summers are apparently on the outs.

title: The Nifty 50 | Stephen Dorff, Actor
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Moving House
description: CHAPPAQUA

title: Going Really Indie, With His Own Cash
description: INSIDE the Bay Ridge Manor catering hall in Brooklyn recently, preparations were under way for yet another rites-of-passage weekend: bar mitzvahs, weddings, sweet 16s. But in an upstairs office resembling a military headquarters a different kind of promise was being fulfilled: White Irish Drinkers!, a young woman said, answering the phone. No, it wasnt an A.A. meeting. It was a movie.

title: Davis Undergoes Second Surgery
description: The injured snowboarder Danny Davis had surgery for the second time since his all-terrain vehicle crash, this one on Thursday to repair a broken pelvic bone, his agent said in a statement.

title: Footage of Subway Robberies
description: A video clip of a robbery on December 25, 2009 and footage of the suspect leaving the subway.

title: Watching 'Serpico' With Serpico
description: Forty years after getting shot in a drug bust and testifying against police corruption, retired Detective Frank Serpico is still trying to heal.

title: Inside Joan Rivers's Home
description: Ms. Rivers calls her 5,000-square-foot home a "Connecticut country manor."

title: Get Ready for a New Tax
description: Income taxes alone wont be enough to fill the nations budget hole, according to a new study.

title: Urban Bush Women, Moving Through a Defiant Past
description: Anniversaries are opportunities for pomp, circumstance and celebration. There was some of that on Wednesday night at Dance Theater Workshop, when the Urban Bush Women, led by its founder, Jawole Willa Jo Zollar, kicked off its 25th-anniversary season with Zollar: Uncensored. Alvin Ailey American Dance Theaters artistic director, Judith Jamison, gave a postshow toast; audience members were pulled up onstage for an impromptu dance party.

title: Ransom
description: The sea has many voices. The voice this man is listening for is the voice of his mother. He lifts his head, turns his face to the chill air that moves in across the gulf, and tastes its sharp salt on his lip. The sea surface bellies and glistens, a lustrous silver-blue-a membrane stretched to a fine transparency where once, for nine changes of the moon, he had hung curled in a dream of pre-existence and was rocked and comforted. He hunkers down now on the shelving pebbles at its edge, bunches his cloak between his thighs. Chin down, shoulders hunched, attentive.

title: Debt Burden Now Rests More on U.S. Shoulders
description: THE United States government borrowed more money than ever before in 2009, but its largest lender  China  sharply reduced the amount it was willing to lend.

title: Jackson Estate Opposes Allowance for Singers Father
description: Attorneys for Michael Jacksons estate have filed papers opposing an effort by Joe Jackson, the singers father, to receive a monthly allowance, The Associated Press reported. Attorneys for the estate administrators, John Branca and John McClain, filed papers to deny Mr. Jacksons request for more than $15,000 a month from his sons estate. The attorneys noted that the singer did not name his father as a beneficiary in his will and trust and that Joe Jackson failed to show that his son supported him while he was alive. When he filed for the monthly stipend in November, Mr. Jackson said he needed his sons financial help to survive.

title: Part 5: Answers on the Fafsa and Financial Aid
description: For many high school seniors and their parents, this is the season for tackling the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, a notoriously cumbersome process that the government is trying to streamline this year.
Introduction: Creating Post-Cold War Europe: 1989 and the Architecture of Order

title: Forces of Fortune
description: Chapter 1: The Power of Commerce

title: Loretta Lynn and Norah Jones to Play Lilith Fair
description: Loretta Lynn has been added to the 2010 lineup of the Lilith Fair, the music tour of female performers. Ms. Lynn, Cat Power, Kate Nash, Norah Jones and Lissie were among the artists announced by the festival producers this week. The festival also added San Diego, Phoenix and Austin to the tour. I have never done shows with just other girl singers, Ms. Lynn said in a statement. When I first started out, they said girl singers couldnt sell records or concert tickets. Weve come a long way since then and were gonna have a big time out there!

title: Betting on Bernanke
description: From Catherine Rampell at Economix:

title: Sundance in a Nutshell
description: The buzzy shorts premieres on Sundances opening night Thursday included Im Here, a feature about robot love by Spike Jonze  financed by Absolut  and a documentary by Rory Kennedy, The Fence, about the inadequate structure separating the United States-Mexico border.

title: The Lady in the Tower
description: Chapter 1: Occurrences That Presaged Evil

title: Candles for the Dead Bathe a Church in Light
description: As the church filled up, a woman repeated the Hail Mary in French, over and over.

title: Candles for the Dead Bathe a Church in Light
description: As the church filled up, a woman repeated the Hail Mary in French, over and over.

title: Yearning for Glass-Steagall on Capitol Hill
description: President Obamas plan to rein in big banks and their ability to make risky bets may seem to hark back to the days when commercial banking and investment banking were separated by the Depression-era Glass-Steagall Act. But the so-called Volcker Rule, as Mr. Obamas proposal is known, does not go as far as Glass-Steagall in that it would allow commercial banks to retain some investment banking activities, like underwriting securities and trading on behalf of clients.

title: Woman and Two Girls Fatally Stabbed in Brooklyn
description: A 24-year-old man in Brooklyn fatally stabbed his female companion and her two young daughters, then phoned his father in the Bronx to tell what he had done, the authorities said.

title: Weekend Links
description: David Frum proposes an alternative path to campaign-finance reform.

title: Book Review Podcast: Atul Gawande
description: This week: Atul Gawande discusses his new book, The Checklist Manifesto; Charles Isherwood, a theater critic for The New York Times, remembers Joseph Papp; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Ski Resorts Exaggerate Snow, Economists Say
description: Ever wonder why that foot of fresh powder that a ski resort brags about feels more like five inches when you actually get there? Well, a pair of Dartmouth economists may have found the answer.

title: Gay Identity Refracted in Multiple Voices
description: WHAT did gay liberation do for gay cinema? To begin to tackle this question, one has to survey the shadowy history of on-screen homosexuality, consider the elusive notion of a gay sensibility and  as with all minority-group debates  weigh the conflicting ideological positions on difference and assimilation. But while there may be no easy answer, the coincidental appearance this week of two gay-theme events in New York repertory houses provides a window into the evolution of gay cinema, both in the shadow of liberation politics and far beyond it.

title: Cavaliers Winning and Hurting
description: The Cavaliers could revel after their victory Thursday night as they completed a regular-season sweep over the Los Angeles Lakers, but their point guard corps is running thin.

title: Koglin Hams in Grand Central Is Closing
description: For almost 10 years Koglin German Royal Hams has sold a staggering variety of hams, cured meats, sausages (25 different kinds of bratwurst) and imported goodies from marzipan to mustard at its stand at the Grand Central Market in Grand Central Terminal. But next Friday, the stand will shutter for good and Armin Koglin, the owner, will move to the Philippines.

title: Equilibrium in Groove, and a Touch of Hip-Hop
description: Its standard practice in jazz circles to refer to Fly as a different sort of saxophone trio. Thats a fair characterization, inasmuch as the band  Mark Turner on tenor and soprano saxophones, Larry Grenadier on bass, and Jeff Ballard on drums  upholds a keenly colloquial rapport, rejecting the post-bop heroic ideal. But the inspired stubbornness of that stance almost demands some kind of further distinction. Why not call it a bass trio, or a drum trio? Why not eliminate the frame of reference altogether?

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Smoking in Movies, Laura Linney, Melvin Van Peebles and More
description: Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

title: Helped to Heal by a Strangers Truth
description: I DRESSED as if preparing for a first date. I picked out a blue cotton sweater with an appliqu bird perched on the right shoulder. Pearl earrings, lip gloss, a touch of mascara. Jeans to balance out the makeup and the appliqu bird. I wanted to look as if Id tried, but not too hard.

title: Word Is Out: 30 Years Later
description: With the re-release of the documentary "Word Is Out," Mariposa Film Group looks back at the making of the film.

title: Solow Gets a Delay
description: Jamie Solow has at least one more week of freedom.

title: A Fathers Quest to Cure His Children
description: The new movie Extraordinary Measures, opening around the country this weekend, focuses on a fathers quest to find a treatment for Pompe disease, a rare and often fatal disorder that disables the heart and muscles. While the movie takes some liberties on the real life events and people it depicts, its based on the true story of entrepreneur John Crowley, as chronicled in the book The Cure by Wall Street Journal reporter Geeta Anand.

title: A Prophet Takes the Lead in French Oscar Race
description: Jacques Audiards Un Prophte (A Prophet), which won the Grand Jury Prize at last years Cannes Film Festival, received 13 nominations on Friday for the Csar award, the French version of the Oscars, including ones for best film, best director and best actor for Tahar Rahim.

title: Vikings Receiver Willing to Do Whatever It Takes
description: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  Behind the end zones at the University of South Carolina, red tip hedges grow against the stands at Williams-Brice Stadium, perilously close to the field of play. Whenever a Gamecocks receiver pulls up short of the hedges while pursuing a pass, Coach Steve Spurrier evokes the name of Sidney Rice, the one player who never did.

title: Historical Society to Open a Childrens Museum
description: When thinking of ways to spend a rainy Saturday afternoon, studying history is not high on the list for most families. Now, in a bid to make history more vivid, alluring and accessible for the Wii generation, an interactive museum within a museum, focusing on the lives of young New Yorkers, will open in November 2011 on the lower level of the New-York Historical Society, museum officials said.

title: Same-Sex Marriage Case, Day 9: Research
description: The Bay Area blog has been reporting daily from the federal courthouse in San Francisco on the case of Perry v. Schwarzenegger. That case is challenging the constitutionality of Proposition 8, the ban on same-sex marriage approved by voters in 2008. Among the lawyers on the plaintiffs team are Theodore B. Olson, David Boies, Theodore J. Boutrous Jr., Christopher Dean Dusseault, Christine Van Aken, Danny Chu, Matthew D. McGill and Therese Stewart. The legal team for the defense includes Brian Raum, Charles J. Cooper, David Thompson, Andrew Pugno, James Campbell, Jordan Lorence, Nicole Moss, Howard C. Nielson Jr. and Peter A. Patterson.

title: Scorecard | Louis Vuitton Wins!
description: Bievenue  Paris! After the first day of mens-wear shows, critics have already dropped that favored heritage buzzword. As Scorecard can tell you, concept reigns here in the City of Light, so better make sure your theme explores dualistic tension and depth. (Bonus points awarded for making references to Austrian symbolism, modernist lit, and/or the postmodern, preferably all at once.)

title: Stover Avoids the Kicking Blues
description: Field-goal kicking wasnt so great during the regular season  kickers converted just 81.3 percent, way off from last years 84.5 percent, the highest in N.F.L. history. But it has been a disaster in the postseason, where kickers have made just 57.8 percent of their attempts, including Shayne Graham and Nate Kaeding, who are a combined 0-5 against the Jets.

title: Progressive Radio Hosts Say Air America Closing Wont Affect Them
description: The hosts of several progressive talk shows hastened to remind fans on Friday that although the brand-name network Air America had abruptly folded, their shows were still on the air.

title: Insight Into Obama's Financial Plan
description: John Harwood of CNBC and The New York Times spoke with Representative Chris Van Hollen, Democrat of Maryland and chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, on President Obama's approach to financial reform.

title: Called Far and Wide to Touch Minds
description: Cornel West, 56, has many roles: Princeton professor, philosopher, fiery orator, civil rights activist, classical violinist and actor (in two Matrix movies). On weekends, Dr. West travels the country delivering lectures, being, in his own words, a bluesman in the life of the mind, a jazzman in the world of ideas, forever on the move.

title: Brooklyn Hts. Montessori to Close Its Little Room
description: Brooklyn Heights Montessori School will close the Little Room, a well-known preschool for children with special needs, in August after failing to secure a new sponsor for the program during a yearlong search.

title: The Broads Give More for Their Namesake Museum in Michigan
description: Museums in Los Angeles arent the only ones receiving gifts from Eli Broad. Mr. Broad, the billionaire philanthropist and Michigan State alumnus, and his wife Edythe Broad, have donated an additional $2 million to the construction of an art museum that bears their names on the Michigan State campus in East Lansing. The gift, announced by university officials earlier this week, brings the total gift from the couple to $28 million: $7 million earmarked for acquisitions, exhibitions and operations and $21 million for construction of the Eli and Edythe Broad Art Museum, designed by Zaha Hadid, the Pritzker-award winning architect.

title: Pair of Military Vehicles Are the Heroes at Barrett-Jackson
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  As I walked past row after row of vehicles during the collector car auctions here this week, I was struck by a display that drew a large crowd. Some people were walking away with tears in their eyes.

title: As Colts Rested, Jets Awoke
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.

title: Pictures of the Day: Friday, Jan. 22
description: Time and again, it comes down to this: individual faces seem to convey the impact of mass trauma far more resonantly than broader views of destruction and devastation. Several such faces already stand out in the coverage of the earthquake in Haiti. And today, Ruth Fremson added to that poignant gallery with her portrait of Jean Marseille (Slide 4), waiting at the University Hospital of Haiti to be transferred to a hospital ship because his injuries are so significant. Mr. Marseilles gaze at the camera  his gravity unimpeached by the strip of tape across his forhead with the word, Ship  cannot be ignored and will not soon be forgotten.

title: In Rossellinis War Movies, the Naturalism Survives
description: IN the immediate aftermath of World War II, Roberto Rossellini made three films that helped to lay the foundations of modern cinema: Rome Open City (1945), Paisan (1946) and Germany Year Zero (1948). Its almost impossible to underestimate the importance of these movies, both for the impact that their startling realism had on the audiences and filmmakers of the time and for the influence they continue to exert on directors.

title: Poll: Americans Support Aspects of Health Care Legislation
description: In the latest poll from the Kaiser Family Foundation, Americans are evenly divided over the health reform proposals being discussed in Congress, a finding echoed in other recent national polls.

title: Chief of Hollywood Trade Group to Step Down
description: LOS ANGELES  Dan Glickman, the chairman and chief executive of the Motion Picture Association of America, said on Friday that he was resigning his post at the Hollywood trade association as of April 1, to become president of Refugees International.

title: Miserable in Michigan
description: Sixteen states and the District of Columbia had double-digit unemployment rates in December, according to a new government report, with Michigans jobless percentage still in the top spot.

title: No News Is Good News at the New York Motorcycle Show
description: Expectations werent exactly high going into the 2010 New York Cycle World International Motorcycle Show. After a year of plummeting American sales, manufacturers were not in a position to showcase flashy new products or fancy exhibits. Most of the presentations at the media preview on Friday focused on products that had been revealed elsewhere. It was a distinct change from the 2009 show, when the industry had a previous-year sales boost to crow about and there were new models and concept bikes on display.

title: The Shiba Inu Puppy Cam: Reassuring Squeaks in Uncertain Times
description: [To see the PuppyCam, whose sounds were permeating the entire site, please go to Read Below]

title: Sundances Queen of Documentaries
description: Perhaps no one has more at stake at the Sundance Film Festival this year than Diane Weyermann. Then again, few people have as much skin in the game.

title: Leno to Appear on Oprah Winfrey on Thursday
description: Conan OBrien may be going under the radar for a while after signing off on The Tonight Show on Friday night, but the man making his way back into the host chair on that show, Jay Leno, will be highly visible in the coming months.

title: Boat Carrying 124 Refugees Lands on Corsica
description: PARIS  A boatload of 124 refugees, many of them apparently Kurds from Syria, was discovered Friday morning on a beach in southern Corsica, the local police said. It was the first time that illegal immigrants were able to land on the island, a part of France, and they were put there sometime Thursday night or even before, presumably by smugglers, the police said.

title: The Nifty 50 | Kat Dennings, Actress
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Supplier Accused of Bribes for U.N. Contracts
description: Last year, according to people briefed on the case, a Florida businessman went undercover to play the part of a corrupt sales executive in a foreign bribery sting that led to nearly two dozen arrests and 16 indictments announced earlier this week.

title: The Lowdown on the Pour Over
description: Cappuccinos at  Bluebird Coffee Shop didnt do the trick for Oliver (Shaky) Strand. He needed more.

title: MSNBC: New York Times Edition
description: John Harwood of CNBC and The New York Times hosts the MSNBC and New York Times special edition. (Video: MSNBC)

title: Howard Marks Is Worried About the Recovery
description: In his latest chairmans letter, Howard S. Marks of Oaktree Capital Management explains why he is worried about the prospects for economic recovery.

title: For Sale: Plane Salvaged From Hudson (Hero Not Included)
description: Care to buy a plane?

title: Glass-Steagall vs. the Volcker Rule
description: For the second time in less than 80 years, the nations commercial banks are being told to stick to their knitting. Their knitting is taking deposits, handling checking accounts, lending money and managing the nations payment system. Twice now, they have ventured beyond these standard activities, gotten into trouble and almost brought down the financial system.

title: One Man Embodying 3 of His Artistic Mentors
description: There have been many superlative dancers who have been far from their own best choreographers. (Rudolf Nureyev surely tops the list.)

title: John Burns Q. and A. on Islamic Radicalization
description: This week, John Burns, the chief foreign correspondent for The New York Times, has been reviewing and responding to readers comments and questions on Islamic radicalization. On Thursday, Mr. Burns posted this essay on the topic; below are a few comments from At War readers that we thought were worth highlighting and Mr. Burnss response.

title: Sunday Preview
description: Frozen pizzas and chili bowls? Not at Cortina dAmpezzo, a fashionable ski resort in the Dolomites of northern Italy, which is prized for its fine dining as much as its fresh snow. Evan Rail skis his way from mountain hut to mountain hut, sampling the regions Tryrolean goulash, house-made spaghetti and steaming polenta.

title: Chic in Review | Thats Sir Marc Jacobs to You
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: More Colleges Report Increases in Applications
description: Freshman applications to Princeton are up 19 percent this year, Bloomberg.com reports.

title: Jamaica High May Close, but Memories Will Live On
description: INSIDE the high-ceilinged vestibule of the Georgian Revival showplace that is Jamaica High School, a red sign reads, Eighty percent of success is just showing up. Alas, the schools average attendance rate this year is 79 percent.

title: With Help From Friends, Fruit Vendor Is Free
description: Around 3 in the morning on Thursday, Trisha Alam awoke to a shocking but joyous sight. Her father, Nurul Alam, a Bangladeshi fruit vendor who worked on the Upper East Side and whose plight The New York Times chronicled last month, had returned to their home in Parkchester in the Bronx after around three months detention at the Hudson County Correctional Center in Kearney, N.J.

title: The Dangers of YouTube
description: With the news that Sundance and the nearby, concurrent festival Slamdance will share content with online and non-traditional platforms like YouTube and Microsofts Xbox 360, Variety examines whether these short-term deals could hurt filmmakers looking for distribution. With every angle needed to make a profit, the availability of a movie for rent before a film is sold could dissuade some dealmakers from offering a more lucrative deal, considering one of their distribution platforms has already been eliminated from the mix, Marc Graser writes.

title: Serving the Community, Satisfying the Palate
description: JULIE CARRIN, the director of catering and culinary services at the Kitchen @ Billings Forge, is having a tart-crust crisis.

title: Where Alsace Meets Belgium
description: MOULES ET FRITES has been packed ever since it opened in Syosset in mid-November. Its owned by the Reststar Hospitality Group, which counts Bistro Cassis in Huntington, Bistro Citron in Roslyn and Brasserie Cassis in Plainview among its many holdings.

title: Wine Appreciation, Made Easier
description: KELLY TOBIN, a 35-year-old stockbroker from Hoboken, learned that the old rule of white wine with fish and red with meat no longer applies.

title: Cameras Swarm Rajaratnam at Restaurant
description: In a rare moment away from the courthouse, Raj Rajaratnam, the Galleon Groups founder and accused mastermind of a multimillion-dollar insider trading ring, was caught on camera by Bloomberg News leaving Tao restaurant in Manhattan on Friday.

title: Biden to Meet Iraq Leaders Amid Candidate Dispute
description: BAGHDAD  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. arrived Friday in a visit that underlined an enduring reality of Iraq under the Obama administration: As the United States prepares to withdraw, an Iraqi political system tailored to crisis and brinkmanship has repeatedly necessitated United States intervention to propel the political process forward.

title: Bonus Tops $8 Million for Chief at Morgan
description: A few days after Morgan Stanley reported its first loss in its 74-year history, the bank announced on Friday that its chief executive, James P. Gorman, would receive $8.11 million in deferred stock as part of his bonus for 2009.

title: Carole Stimpfle, Gregg Savarese
description: Carole Anne Stimpfle, a daughter of Eileen Stimpfle and John B. Stimpfle of Northvale, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Gregg Adam Savarese, the son of Louis A. Savarese, of Randolph, N.J., and the late Ilene W. Savarese. Msgr. Frank Del Prete performed the ceremony at SS. Peter and Paul Church in Hoboken, N.J., with Rabbi Ari Fridkis taking part.

title: Obama Vows to Keep Fighting for Health Care Overhaul
description: Update | 6:00 p.m.

title: Bonus for Morgan Stanley Chief Tops $8 Million
description: A few days after Morgan Stanley reported its first loss in its 74-year history, the bank announced late Friday afternoon that its chief executive, James P. Gorman, would receive $8.11 million in deferred stock as part of his bonus for 2009, The New York Timess Graham Bowley reports.

title: State of Shock
description: People on Wall Street are in a state of shock today. It shows in the stock market, which is down 5 percent in three days.

title: Capsized
description: The State of Maine, its often said, is a state of mind, a state sometimes inscrutable to relative newcomers like my husband, Marty, and me. So we were not surprised to be the only boaters heading out from the dock near Damariscotta on a gorgeous Saturday morning last November. We launched onto calm seas, so confident of the weather that we didnt bother to check the forecast or pack our safety gear  the extra paddles, whistles, radio and flares. But half a mile from shore, we learned why no one else was out. The wind blew up, as did the chop. Our boats got skittish. Martys Red Sox cap blew off, and I begged him not to circle back for it. He assured me that we had seen much worse, that we would be fine. It was the response I had come to expect from him.

title: Tastes of Japan, in Many Flavors
description: JAPANESE restaurants have become so popular that even small towns may have several to choose from. Ardsley is especially endowed, with three within a half mile, each with a distinct style.

title: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 22
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City. Subjects include a metals factory in Brooklyn, prayers for earthquake survivors in Haiti, and a new job for Robert M. Morgenthau.

title: For Lady Gaga, Every Concert Is a Drama
description: In her stunningly gruesome extravaganza at Radio City Music Hall, Lady Gaga scowls more than she smiles, muses about dying and appears on vast video screens vomiting, being slapped and generally being abused. Fame is killing me, she says. Death becomes her.

title: The Keypad Solution
description: There is a long and noble history of trying to change the English languages notoriously illogical system of spelling. The fact that through, rough, dough, plough, hiccough and trough all end with -ough, yet none of them sound the same as any of the others, is the sort of thing that has been vexing poets and learners of English for quite some time. Proponents of fixing this wayward orthography have included some of the most prominent names in American history. Benjamin Franklin suggested changing the alphabet, and Andrew Carnegie provided money for people to study the problem. President Theodore Roosevelt issued an edict in 1906 that gave the Government Printing Office a list of 300 words with new spellings: problem cases like artisan, kissed and woe were to be changed to artizan, kist and wo. Roosevelt was largely ignored by the G.P.O., and the matter was soon dropped. Although this issue has been extensively studied and argued over by these and other eminent thinkers, there has been an almost complete lack of success in effecting any substantial progress.

title: Just Walk Away
description: Roger Lowenstein triggers a provocative idea. If enough underwater homeowners threaten to walk away from their mortgages at the same time, the banks would have no choice but to renegotiate terms, potentially lowering everyones principal. What we need is a community organizer. Isnt that what President Obama used to do?

title: Russian Oligarchs Long Road to a Hong Kong I.P.O.
description: MOSCOW  Oleg V. Deripaska, the Russian oligarch, was so deeply in debt at the onset of the financial crisis that Russian and Western banks could have bankrupted his company, the sprawling aluminum giant Rusal, within months.

title: The Reading Life: Parsing the Poetry Best-Seller List
description: The words poetry and best seller dont appear often in the same sentence. But if you want to get a handle on what verse Americans are reading right now, heres the place to go  the Poetry Foundations contemporary poetry best-seller list.Scanning the most recent Poetry Foundation list, for the week ending Jan. 3, 2010, one thing is pretty clear: its Mary Olivers world, we only live in it. Ms. Oliver, who writes earnest poems about nature, has no fewer than five books in the Top 10. (Shes been knocked out of the No. 1 position this time, however, by Wendell Berrys book Leavings.)

title: Obama, With Defiant Tone, Vows to Push Agenda
description: ELYRIA, Ohio  President Obama, striking a no-retreat, no-surrender posture in the wake of his partys humiliating defeat in the Massachusetts Senate race this week, vowed Friday to press on with his expansive domestic agenda  including a health care overhaul and tough new restrictions on banks  even if it meant he had to take my lumps from political critics.

title: On This Road, Watch Your Step
description: THE killer road beckons benignly in the winter sunshine. The name remains the same, Hempstead Turnpike, but any charm it once had is gone, along with its tolls.

title: Third and Atlantic Avenues Have Most Fatalities
description: From 2006 to 2008, the deadliest roads for pedestrians in the city were Third Avenue in Manhattan and Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn, which each had nine fatalities, according to data from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: In Westchester, Areas Not Conducive to Walking
description: There were 27 pedestrian fatalities in Westchester County from 2006 to 2008, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. They were not concentrated in any one area, and no road had more than three deaths.

title: U.S. 1 and U.S. 5 Have Most Deaths in the State
description: From 2006 to 2008, 94 pedestrians were killed in Connecticut. Fourteen of those deaths were along U.S. 1 and U.S. 5, which traverse the state, according to data from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Burlington County Road Has States Most Deaths
description: In New Jersey, 451 pedestrians were struck and killed by vehicles from 2006 to 2008. With nine fatalities during those three years, U.S. 130 (Burlington Pike), in Burlington County, an 83-mile stretch whose southern portion is in Philadelphias suburbs, had more pedestrian deaths than any other road in the state.

title: Other Deadly Stretches on Long Island
description: Hempstead Turnpikes sibling to the southeast, the stretch of Sunrise Highway (Route 27) in Suffolk County, ranked second in the region in pedestrian fatalities from 2006 to 2008, according to data from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. There were 11 deaths on the road during that period.

title: Sony Adds GPS and SD Card Support
description: Sony unwrapped two new Cyber-shot cameras that pack cool features like built-in GPS, automatic high dynamic range (HDR) image capture, and a new wireless file transfer technology. They also can record full HD 1080p video in the AVCHD format, a first for Sony.

title: Confusion in the Haitian Countryside
description: Outside Port-au-Prince, major obstacles still stand in the way of getting food, water and shelter to those affected by the earthquake.

title: Samsung Compact Camera Adds GPS
description: Its officially a trend, and a great one at that. Point-and-shoot cameras are gaining built-in GPS capabilities that are very useful to peripatetic photographers who want to geo-tag their images.

title: An Age When Love Needs a Safety Net
description: Sometimes, love is not all you need. In fact, it can be downright dangerous. Love abounds in the family depicted in Darci Picoults new play, Lils 90th; but the Eldridges are in big, big trouble anyway.

title: Polanski Denied Sentencing in Absentia
description: LOS ANGELES  A state court judge here rejected the director Roman Polanskis request to be sentenced while he remains under arrest in Switzerland, setting the stage for a renewed legal battle over his extradition to face sentencing on a 32-year-old sex charge.

title: On Stage, Feeling More at Home Away
description: To find an audience outside Connecticut, Brian Dolzani has written alternative rock songs with themes that most anybody can relate to  like the romance of Summer and the everyday ennui of Water. But he doesnt necessarily relish playing them for the home-state crowd.

title: A Helmet for Obama
description: The House Judiciary Committee has devoted two hearings to the subject of football head injuries. The Senate will soon consider a bill to raise awareness of the seriousness of sports concussions. As the issue climbs the political ladder, its fair to wonder if President Obama will chime in on the subject.

title: Letting Postcards Tell Niagara Falls Story
description: Once a favorite of newlyweds, Niagara Falls has thrived for decades as a general tourist destination and, more recently, as the setting for several casinos. In the spring and summer months, the New York Power Authority even turns up the water flow to please the crowds.

title: Seedorf Responds: 10 Answers From Milans No. 10
description: Clarence Seedorf, the A.C. Milan midfielder, participates in a monthly exchange with New York Times readers. On Friday, two days before his team will take on Inter Milan in the seasons second derby at the San Siro, he answered questions about Milan, how clubs can better manage their business affairs and the World Cup. Previous discussions can be found here.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 22
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: In Unions, Government Workers Surpass Private-Sector Workers
description: Many people, when they hear the phrase union worker, probably imagine someone who works on an assembly line. But such blue-collar jobs are probably no longer representative of the typical union man or woman.

title: From a Dutch Painter, Works With Much to Say
description: As the Hudson Valley has celebrated the 400th anniversary of its discovery by Henry Hudson in a Dutch expedition, art exhibitions focusing on contemporary Dutch culture have been especially rich. Fendry Ekel  The Witness, a show of a dozen works in its final week at the Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art, is among them.

title: The Quilt as Canvas
description: MORRIS TOWNSHIP

title: In Suburban Houses, Roots of Modernism
description: Levittown, the mass-produced suburb built in Nassau County after World War II, is often the first thing that comes to mind when the subject is Long Island architecture. Fair enough; it was the archetype for such communities throughout the country. But what is less well known is that Long Island provided fertile ground for early Modernism in American architecture. Many of the most prominent Modern architects designed homes here, including Frank Lloyd Wright, Philip Johnson and Marcel Breuer. A remarkable exhibition at the Heckscher Museum of Art seeks to document their achievements.

title: Filmmaker Seeks to Temper the Message of An Inconvenient Truth
description: LOS ANGELES  At the Sundance Film Festival four years ago, the global-warming debate took center stage with the premiere of an alarming work, the director Davis Guggenheims documentary An Inconvenient Truth.

title: Oakland Prospect Retires to Join Priesthood
description: Grant Desme hit 31 home runs and stole 40 bases in Class A last season, and as an encore, he was named most valuable player of the Arizona Fall League. The Oakland Athletics had plans to invite Desme, a 23-year-old outfielder, to spring training next month.

title: Paris Mens: Small Epiphanies
description: The high points of the day were Rick Owens and Comme des Garcons. Many times an Owens show feels like a journey of self-realization: the American who brought his dark, singular aesthetic to Paris and seemingly discovered it there. His latest collection flowed like a skillful narrative. The opening looks were tailored, monochromatic and spare, with cropped pants and a shoulder line that looked as straight and strong as an industrial beam.

title: Projecting a New Laptop
description: In addition to touch screens and tablets  all the rage this month  throw in the miniature projector as part of the new wave of features destined for the laptop.

title: Dcor: Far East Chic. Diners: Pure Manhattan.
description: A brief bankerish stroll from the New York Stock Exchange, this seven-month-old Asian-accented French restaurant, at 40 Broad Street, seems to have been created for purposes of wealth redistribution  that is to say, to separate its upscale clients from their disposable income by way of a $69 three-course dinner and a highly curated, high-altitude wine list. The dcor is Far East chic (silk walls, ornamental calligraphy brushes), but the diners are pure Manhattan: equities traders, corporate lawyers and, last week, an Iranian-born wine connoisseur who turned up with her cousin and Connecticut-bred companion.

title: A Big-Picture Look at Google, Microsoft, Apple and Yahoo
description: On Wednesday, I wrote about a battle looming between Apple and Google as discussions take place over the possibility of Apple making Microsofts Bing the default search engine on the iPhone.

title: A Celebrated Scout Camp on Staten Island Is in Jeopardy
description: IN the wooded heart of Staten Island lies a rugged spread of land, crowned by a rustic lake, that has provided camping grounds for Boy Scouts and Cub Scouts from the New York area for 60 years.

title: Bush Senior: Hutchison for Governor
description: Former President George H.W. Bush officially endorsed Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas, in her gubernatorial primary against sitting Gov. Rick Perry.

title: Cartoons, Tennis and Traffic Lights
description: Training for the Open

title: Diner Serves Apocalypse, Easy on the Destruction
description: In Legion the world ends not with a bang but with a short stack.
