description: At 2:29 p.m. on Jan. 12, Juan Macias, 19, a sophomore at San Francisco State University, sat in a cafe near the engineering firm where he works part time as an office assistant, staring at a laptop computer screen.

title: Q. and A. With Thomas Jones
description: In his 10th N.F.L. season, at an age when most running backs have started, or finished, a sharp decline, Thomas Jones posted career numbers with the Jets. This follows his usual unusual pattern. Drafted seventh over all by Arizona in 2000, Jones has played for four teams and reached the Super Bowl with Chicago in the 2006 season. Yet he was voted to his first Pro Bowl last season and he gained a career-high 1,402 rushing yards this season. But there is more to the 31-year-old Jones. He is the Jets unquestioned leader and pregame speaker. He runs a music production company, Outta Pocket Entertainment. And he enjoys watching old television sitcoms.

title: Serena and Sam: Two Who Know How to Serve
description: Its not as rare as a solar eclipse, but its getting there. O.K., thats an exaggeration. But what should unfold in the fourth-round match between Serena Williams and Samantha Stosur is something you dont see often nowadays: a match between two women who havent been afflicted with the yips when they step up to the baseline to serve.

title: Villanovas Reynolds Is Happy to Be Back
description: Although Notre Dames Luke Harangody was picked as the preseason Big East player of the year, Villanovas Scottie Reynolds is certainly making a case during the regular season.

title: More Than 150,000 Have Been Buried, Haiti Says
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Haitis government provided a preliminary assessment of the earthquakes body count on Saturday, putting it at more than 150,000, and declared that the search for survivors trapped in the rubble would soon be coming to an end.

title: My So-Called Wife
description: Pasadena, Calif.

title: Nonfiction Filmmakers Still Tell Rich Stories
description: The Bay Area has long been known as a center for documentary filmmaking. Many local documentarians have won or been nominated for Academy Awards, including Sam Green (The Weather Underground) and Robert Epstein (The Times of Harvey Milk). The area is home to the Independent Television Service, a major financer of documentary films, as well as some of the most respected film schools in the country.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions last Sunday about Secretary of State Hillary Clintons trip to Haiti on Saturday misspelled the surname of a Haitian doctor with who lives in the United States and who traveled with Mrs. Clinton. He is Herby Derenoncourt, not Derononcourt.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the presidential election in Chile misstated the year when Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former dictator of Chile, was arrested in Britain on a Spanish warrant that alleged he had committed crimes against humanity. It was 1998, not 1988.

title: Students Class Struggles and Other Highlights From Sundays Bay Area Pages
description: Class Struggles | Because of state budget cuts, Californias state university system, which enrolls 433,000 students, is overwhelmed. Educational opportunities cost more and are harder to grasp and even harder to hold onto than ever before, with truncated offerings, furloughed professors and overcrowded classrooms.

title: Are the Huskies on the Rebound?
description: Is UConn gearing up for a second-half run?

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about St. Pauls School in Garden City, N.Y., a historic building that the village is considering tearing down, referred incorrectly to a vote on its fate. Forty-five percent  not a majority  of residents voted for demolition, with the remainder voting to either mothball the building or convert it into apartments.

title: Deadly Truck Explosion Closes the L.I.E. 10 Hours
description: A fuel tanker flipped on the Long Island Expressway on Saturday morning, resulting in an explosion that killed the driver, melted the roadway and caused major delays for travelers in both directions.

title: Man Arrested in Vermont in Fatal Stabbing of Event Planner
description: A suspect in the fatal stabbing this week of a security industry event planner has been captured in Vermont after New York City detectives tracked him there, partly by tracing his use of the victims credit cards, the authorities said.

title: 3 Are Stabbed, One Fatally, Outside Times Square Club
description: Three men were stabbed, one fatally, in a swirl of violence outside a popular nightclub in Times Square early Saturday morning, the authorities said.

title: Bankers Sense of Entitlement
description: We suspect most Americans would be baffled to realize that bankers see themselves as victims of the Obama administrations financial policies. But there you go.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions last Sunday about landmarking measures on Long Island misstated the ethnic origins of Rafael Guastavino, the architect of a house, now for sale, on an unprotected site in Bay Shore. He was Spanish, not Italian.

title: Hidden Danger
description: Radiation accidents like those that injured Scott Jerome-Parks and Alexandra Jn-Charles don't have to be made public under New York state law, leaving many unaware of treatment risks.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 32 this weekend about the writer James Patterson refers incorrectly to his share of the publishing market. Since 2006, Mr. Patterson has written one out of every 17 hardcover novels  not hardcover books  bought in the United States.

title: The Legacy of Baker Street
description: Eventually, time will have its way with Sherlock Holmes, and he will pass fully into the public domain. In America, that bow to posterity will come sometime in 2023. Until then, Holmes is privately owned, and the subject of an uncongenial dispute among the descendants of Arthur Conan Doyle over who controls the rights to his venerable detective, whose last adventure appeared in print in 1927. The details of the squabble over the estate are less important than the lesson to be drawn from it.

title: Pairs Win Shows Depth of U.S. Dancing Lineup
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  Even before they were 10 years old, Meryl Davis and Charlie White had dreamed of this.

title: White House Is Confident Bernanke Will Be Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON  After a full-scale mobilization, White House officials expressed confidence on Saturday that they had contained a populist uprising among Democratic senators that had threatened President Obamas nomination of Ben S. Bernanke to a second term as the Federal Reserve chairman.

title: Bob Noorda Is Dead at 82; Designer Took Modernism Underground
description: Bob Noorda, an internationally known graphic designer who helped introduce a Modernist look to advertising posters, corporate logos and, in the 1960s, the entire New York City subway system, died on Jan. 11 in Milan, his adopted city. He was 82.

title: Jack T. Litman, Lawyer for Preppy Killer and Others, Is Dead at 66
description: Jack T. Litman, a lawyer known for his cerebral, cool and aggressive defense of notorious murder defendants and his uncanny ability to persuade juries to sympathize with crimes of passion over four decades, died at a Manhattan hospital on Saturday morning. He was 66.

title: Two Lives on the Road to Independence, One Step at a Time
description: In daily articles from November to January, the Neediest Cases charitable campaign provides a window into the lives of the people it serves. Sometimes the money provided by the fund can offer minor but vital assistance; sometimes it can do little more than lessen the pain of a daily struggle.

title: UConns Second-Half Blitz Topples Texas
description: STORRS, Conn.  Texas guard Avery Bradley arrived for a 6 a.m. workout last summer, expecting to see only his teammates. But there, among the still-groggy group, was the would-be senior forward Kevin Durant, who had left the program two years earlier to become the second overall pick in the 2007 N.B.A. draft.

title: Terrorist Threats, Intelligence Flaws
description: To the Editor:

title: The Last Holdout on No-Fault Divorce Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: An American Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: Evaluating Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Adventures in Old Age
description: To the Editor:

title: Between God and a Hard Place
description: Boston

title: When Radiation Treatment Turns Deadly
description: In todays New York Times, Walt Bogdanich reports on the devastating consequences of medical mistakes related to radiation treatment. He tells the story of several patients who believed they were undergoing lifesaving treatment but instead were hit with lethal doses of radiation. He writes:

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about renaming a mountain in Sonoma County referred incorrectly to plans by a winemaker to change the name of Black Mountain, an area outside of Geyserville, to Alexander Mountain. The winemaker, Jesse Jackson, wants to use the name for a new wine appellation  not for a new wine. (An Alexander Mountain wine already exists.)

title: Giving Away Half a House
description: My Sunday column is about the Salwen family of Atlanta, and how they sold their house and used half the money to fund poverty-fighting projects in Ghana. To me, the most striking thing about their story and book was how the project empowered not only the Ghanaians but also the Salwens. And I see that all the time: Somebody reluctantly takes on some good cause, thinking that its the right thing to do even if theyre way too busy, and then the cause turns out not to be a sacrifice but the best thing theyve done.

title: The Power of Storytelling: A Look at Three Bay Area Documentaries
description: The Bay Area has long been known as a center for documentary filmmaking. In her latest column, Chloe Veltman says that while the success of locally produced documentaries can be attributed to education, funding and community, it ultimately comes down to storytelling.

title: More Than Academics at Morton Alternative
description: A gritty industrial patch of a blue-collar Chicago suburb seems an unlikely setting for the pioneering curriculum at Morton Alternative High School. The program, which combines intensive psychotherapy with conventional studies to help gang members and emotionally troubled teenagers finish school, has reported promising results and has attracted the notice of educators nationwide.

title: Looking Sharp, Hewitt Now Turns His Focus Toward Federer
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  There is not a more visceral competitor in all of tennis than Australias Lleyton Hewitt. He roars come on after hard-fought points, aims Popeye-styled muscle-flexes to the crowd and snarls and stamps as he scrambles about the court. No matter if you love or hate him, you hear him and feel him.

title: The Pulse: Emanuels Influence Expands to Puppet World
description: How many strings can Rahm Emanuel pull at once? This is not a trick question.

title: The Fiscal Fear Factor Is Increasing by the Day
description: In the genteel environs of the Commercial Club of Chicago, a bastion of the business establishment since 1877, the luncheon declaration was a jarring call to arms.

title: The Pulse: Proposed Bill Would Shield People Reporting Overdoses
description: As a former heroin user, Kathleen Kane-Willis said she remembered being afraid when she called 911 to report a drug overdose because she thought she might be arrested. Now a drug policy researcher at Roosevelt University, Ms. Kane-Willis is pushing to resurrect legislation that would help shield callers from prosecution when they seek medical attention for themselves or someone else who has overdosed.

title: The Pulse: Prix Fixe Dinners at Chicago Restaurants
description: These are fine times for penny-pinching gourmands. The Chicago Convention and Tourism Bureaus Chicago Restaurant Week, which features three-course lunches for $22 and dinners for $32 at over 160 of the citys leading restaurants, runs from Feb. 19 to 28.

title: Movie and Book Explore Link Between Board and Bedroom
description: Can chess be erotic? Yes, according to the movie Joueuse, which was released last month in France and Germany.

title: Player Ratings: U.S. vs. Honduras
description: It was the first game of the year for two teams off to South Africa for the World Cup. Bob Bradleys U.S. team can be generously called experimental  the majority of the European-based American players were not available Saturday because it was not an official FIFA international game day.

title: White and Clark Riders to Beat in Vancouver
description: PARK CITY, Utah  The snowboarders Shaun White and Kelly Clark finished the United States Olympic qualifying season Saturday by winning for the fourth time in five events, emphatically sending them to the Winter Games in Vancouver as the halfpipe riders to beat.

title: Lottery Numbers
Correction
description: Because of an editing error, the In the Region article in Westchester and Connecticut copies last Sunday, about the state of the housing market in Connecticut, referred incorrectly to 14 sales in New Canaan in 2008. That was the number for the fourth quarter, not all of 2008.

title: In New Hampshire, an Angry Tide Swells
description: MILFORD, N.H.  George Brown, 50, the owner of Arthurs barber shop on the Oval in this picturesque New England town, said he breathed a sigh of relief whenScott Brown was elected to the Senate last week in neighboring Massachusetts.

title: Murray Rolls; Nadal Awaits in Quarterfinal
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  John Isners big serve was not big enough to dispatch Andy Murray from the Australian Open. Murray, the scrambling Scotsman, employed crosscourt forehands and drop shots in their match Sunday to run Isner, the 6-foot-9 American, out of his comfort zone.

title: Simulating Danger
description: The Pentagon is trying to harness the high-tech wizardry of the entertainment industry to train its forces.

title: Bringing Buildings to Life
description: Chilly perfection is traded for humanity in Iwan Baans architectural photographs.

title: Flatt Outskates Nagasu for Title
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  On a night when figure skating fans had waited for the performance of Sasha Cohen, the skating star of old who was trying to make her third Olympic team, they ended up seeing two younger skaters sparkle even brighter.

title: Bobcats Showing Signs of Life
description: Quick, which is the hottest team in the N.B.A.? It is not the Lakers or the Celtics or the Cavaliers or any of the usual suspects.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Habs and Flyers Move Up, Isles and Bruins Fall Out
description: Hockey Night in Canada opened its telecast on Saturday with a tribute to the great Canadian novelist, musician and essayist Paul Quarrington, who died on Thursday.

title: Afghanistan to Delay Parliament Vote
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Independent Election Commission will announce on Sunday a postponement of the parliamentary elections to Sept. 18, according to a Western diplomat involved in the election process.

title: N.F.C. Title Game: Welcome to Thunder Dome
description: No city wants this like New Orleans. Its all we talk about. Think about. Dream about. Sunday will be a beautiful day in the city of New Orleans. I will wake up find the second line parade that heads straight to the Superdome.. and enjoy the dreamlike atmosphere. Itll be a great game! From a reader named New Orleanian in the comments section

title: Car Owners Survey Storm Damage at Auction Site
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  The storm-damaged site of the Russo & Steele classic car auction reopened Saturday to concerned car owners and auction officials.

title: Vows: Dana & Zachary
description: Dana Kaplan and Zachary Davidson met on a blind date. They soon discovered that they were both practical jokers and fell in love. They were joking throughout the relationship, including the proposal.

title: Gamboa Retains Belt; Lopez Wins a Title
description: In the first of two featherweight title fights at Madison Square Garden, Yuriorkis Gamboa (17-0, 15 knockouts) kept his W.B.A. title, stopping Rogers Mtagwa at 2 minutes 35 seconds of the second round. Juan Manuel Lopez (28-0, 25 knockouts) won the World Boxing Organization featherweight title by knocking out Steven Luevano with a right hook 44 seconds into the seventh round. Also at the Garden, John Duddy (28-1) knocked out Juan Astorga (14-4-1) just 1:55 into their middleweight fight.

title: Brooklyns Foreman to Face Cotto at Garden
description: Yuri Foreman, the 154-pound World Boxing Association champion, will make his first title defense against Miguel Cotto on June 12 at Madison Square Garden, the promoter Bob Arum said. It will be Cottos first fight since his loss to Manny Pacquiao. Foreman (28-0, 8 knockouts) is from Brooklyn and has a large New York City following, as does the Puerto Rican Cotto (34-2, 27 knockouts).

title: Afghanistan Postpones Parliamentary Election by 4 Months
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Independent Election Commission said Sunday that it would delay Afghanistans parliamentary election by four months, from May until September, citing a lack of money, logistical challenges and the continuing violence in the country.

title: Murray Defeats Isner in Straight Sets
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  John Isners big serve was not big enough to dispatch Andy Murray from the Australian Open. Murray, the scrambling Scotsman, employed crosscourt forehands and drop shots in their match on Sunday to run Isner, the 6-foot-9 American, out of his comfort zone.

title: Cabaret Culture Stays Sexy in Berlin
description: Berlin will always be synonymous with the artistic diversity and decadence of the Weimar Republic. But aside from the occasional revivals of The Three Penny Opera, cabaret culture in the city is largely a thing of the past. Perhaps the most insistent exception is the Kleine Nachtrevue (Little Night Revue), an erotic nightclub in the Schneberg district that balances the risqu with the classy.

title: Jets Memories: Sneaking Into Shea in 1968
description: Weve received a lot of good stories from Jets fans. David From Long Island shares this one:

title: Bankers Face a Harsh Spotlight in Davos
description: Its that time of the year again. The World Economic Forum is preparing for its annual enclave in Davos, with several of the worlds top leaders  political, economic and otherwise  flying in to discuss weighty matters by day and schmooze by night.

title: Late Night TV Channels Ken Burns
description: Video | Leno vs. OBrien as a PBS documentary:

title: Paris Mens: Trekking
description: Like a number of shows this weekend, Alfred Dunhill suggested travel and adventure. Heres the packing list, so to speak, for the first look in the collection (designed by Kim Jones):

title: Skatings Scoring Has Little Love for Artistry
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  As Mirai Nagasu completed her stirring free skate Saturday night, the crowd at Spokane Arena leapt to its feet in raucous applause. A hail of toy animals rained onto the ice. Clearly, most in attendance thought that Nagasu had won the United States Figure Skating Championships.

title: Henin, Back on the Court, Is as Fierce as Ever
description: MELBOURNE, Australia - Her legs are sore, and shes had the three most taxing matches of any woman - or for that matter man  here at Melbourne Park. But even after nearly two years away from competitive tennis, Justine Henin hasnt lost an ounce of ferocity or mental toughness. In only her second tournament back, she had a date in the quarterfinals after a three-set victory over 20-year-old fellow Belgian Yanina Wickmayer, 7-6, 1-6, 6-3.

title: Roddick Finally Turns Back Gonzalez
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Andy Roddick was down 2 sets to 1 to Fernando Gonzalez, and he had blown four set points before finally taking the match to a fifth set. As he sat in his chair to catch his breath between sets, he growled, mostly to himself, Im not going anywhere.

title: Sunday Word: Economy Week
description: Congress and the White House are gearing up for an economy-focused week.

title: Famous Russian Comedian
description: Monologue |  Friday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: We all love celebrity birthdays. You know whose birthday it is today? Yakov Smirnoff. Famous Russian comedian, 59 years old, and he celebrated. Spent the entire day waving to Sarah Palin.

title: Last of 7 Parts: Answers on the Fafsa and Financial Aid
description: For many high school seniors and their parents, this is the season for tackling the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, a notoriously cumbersome process that the government is trying to streamline this year.

title: Mayor-Elect in Okinawan City Opposes U.S. Base
description: TOKYO  A candidate who opposes the relocation of an American air base on Okinawa won a crucial mayoral election on Sunday, raising pressure on Japans prime minister to move the base off the island, a move opposed by the United States.

title: Laura Linney on Stage
description: A look at some of the actress's performances in New York.

title: Rated OMG!
description: Looking at the method and the madness to film ratings.

title: Raf Simons: School for High Fashion
description: Waiting in line backstage after Raf Simonss show last night, one guest murmured to another, That was great.

title: McCain Nudges Obama Toward His Partys Health Plans
description: In the wake of a political setback for national health care legislation, Senator John McCain, the losing candidate in the last presidential election, advised his victorious 2008 adversary on Sunday that the way to get meaningful changes passed is to start from the beginning by meeting with Republicans.

title: Robert A. Mosbacher, 82, Ex-Commerce Chief, Dies
description: Robert A. Mosbacher, a native New Yorker whose swashbuckling career as a wildcatter in the oil fields of Texas and Louisiana paralleled and often intersected with that of President George H. W. Bush, whom he served as a fund-raiser, confidant, political adviser and secretary of commerce from 1989 to 1992, died at a Houston hospital on Sunday. He was 82 and lived in Houston.

title: As Haitis Focus Turns to Shelter, Families Press Search for Missing
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  As officials focused Sunday on the Herculean task of this nations physical recovery  clearing the wreckage and setting up housing for the hundreds of thousands left homeless by an earthquake  desperate relatives of those still missing pleaded with the authorities not to give up the search.

title: A View From Brooklyn of Tragedy Most Classic
description: Whats extraordinary about Gregory Moshers beautifully observed production of A View From the Bridge is how ordinary most of it feels. Very little in this revival of Arthur Millers kitchen-sink drama with knives, which opened Sunday night at the Cort Theater, calls loudly for our consideration. Voices are often kept to a just audible murmur, and the Hollywood sheen of the shows big-name stars, Liev Schreiber and Scarlett Johansson, has been dimmed to a matte finish.

title: Now Screening | John Galliano
description: The fall 2010 collection from John Galliano.

title: A.F.C. Championship Final: Colts 30, Jets 17
description: Greg Bishop, Ben Shpigel and William C. Rhoden are in Indianapolis providing live analysis of todays A.F.C. championship game between the Jets and the Colts. Use your refresh button to stay current with the updates.

title: Now Screening | Dunhill
description: The fall 2010 collection from Dunhill.

title: Ballot Stuffing
description: When Celtics guard Ray Allen suggested recently that some of the power of All-Star voting should be taken away from the fans, he may have been thinking about situations like Allen Iverson, the 76ers guard, being selected as a starter for the Eastern Conference.

title: Bankers: Ready to Spend, but Not to Boast
description: Last year, investment bankers and their spouses kept their wallets shut during bonus season, first, out of panic, and later, fearing mobs with torches would descend upon their gated estates.

title: The Phantom Policy Conflict
description: The idea that Obama made a mistake by focusing on health care instead of the economy seems to be catching on on the left as well as on the right. But my question remains: what are we talking about, specifically?

title: 2010 Subaru Outback
description: The new Outback offers more room and a burlier exterior.

title: Cars to Watch
description: These five cars will likely be highlights of the auctions at Scottsdale.

title: 2010 Subaru Legacy
description: The new Legacy gets a chic, assertive design and offers more room for passengers.

title: Now Screening | Raf Simons
description: The fall 2010 collection from Raf Simons.

title: Kitchen Sink Cadillac
description: This Cadillac was loaded with conveniences to serve the on-the-go potentate with a hearty appetite.

title: A Rift at the Fed Over the Bailout of A.I.G.
description: New documents submitted to Congressional investigators examining the 2008 rescue of the American International Group show that officials at the Federal Reserve were deeply divided over the structure of the bailout and its long-term implications, The New York Timess Louise Story and Gretchen Morgenson write.

title: Netanyahu Says Some Settlements to Stay in Israel
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said Sunday that several Jewish settlement blocs in the West Bank would always remain part of Israel, a comment that upset the Palestinians even as the Obama administrations Middle East envoy was trying to coax them back into peace talks.

title: Difference of One Heart Leads to Lots of Points
description: The Sunday Swiss Teams at the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y., on Jan. 17 was won by Ljudmila Kamenova of Stony Brook, N.Y.; Alex Perlin of Metuchen, N.J.; William Ehlers of Jersey City; and Jiang Gu of Mountain Lakes, N.J.

title: Know Your Feds
description: Im hearing a lot from people who want Paul Volcker as Fed chair. (Consider the joke about exemplifying too big to fail as having been made). There really is nobody with his stature (literally, as it happens) and moral authority. And hes a powerful advocate of financial reform.

title: Exclusive!!! Gossip Has a History!
description: No one speaks of the good weve done, the magazine mogul Robert Harrison complained. Perhaps he was referring to Confidential magazines occasional public-service article about the dangers of cigarette smoking or air travel. But in 1957 readers could be pardoned for overlooking Mr. Harrisons good deeds; he was much better known for the innuendo mongering that had turned Confidential into Americas most dangerous publication and created its legacy. Ask John Edwards whether the magazines tactics are still operative today.

title: Navigating Between Abandon and Control
description: New York is internationally celebrated for ballet and modern dance. But I find it remarkable that of the five live performances I watched last week  which included ballet and modern dance, ranging from 1950s works to premieres  by far the freshest dancing, and much of the most enthralling choreography, came from a group from Maryland specializing in the Kuchipudi style of India.

title: Championing the Music of Neglected Traditionalists
description: The battles within contemporary music during the middle decades of the 20th century are long forgotten. Young composers today couldnt care less that way back when, the new-music scene was divided into warring camps, with the complex modernists on one side and those who maintained at least loose connections to tonal procedures on the other.

title: U.N. Seeks to Drop Some Taliban From Terror List
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The leader of the United Nations mission here called on Afghan officials to seek the removal of at least some senior Taliban leaders from the United Nations list of terrorists, as a first step toward opening direct negotiations with the insurgent group.

title: Connecting Purcell With George Crumb
description: In the program note for her recital of songs by Henry Purcell and George Crumb at Zankel Hall on Wednesday evening, the soprano Christine Schfer wrote that for me theres no such thing as early music or new music. In her view, knowing each side of the repertory makes you hear the other differently.

title: Woman Collides With a Picasso
description: On Friday afternoon a woman taking an adult education class at the Metropolitan Museum of Art accidentally lost her balance and fell into The Actor, a rare Rose Period Picasso, tearing the canvas about six inches along its lower right-hand corner.

title: At Festival in India, Books Are the Buzz
description: JAIPUR, India  A crowd, some members sitting on the floor, listened attentively last week as the author Amit Chaudhuri described the influence of writers from Ireland and the American South on his work.

title: Liberal Radio, Even Without Air America
description: In a week of bad news for liberal causes, the announcement that Air America, the left-wing talk-radio network, was abruptly closing was greeted this way by Markos Moulitsas, founder of the Daily Kos political blog, when he asked on Twitter, Air America was still really on the air?

title: Pie, Then Confession: Madoff Case as Legal Thriller
description: Damages is Law & Order as rendered by Marcel Duchamp. The series rips a scandal from the headlines, then fragments it so artfully that it takes an entire season to see the whole picture.

title: G.O.P. Seeks to Widen Field of Play in Fall Elections
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans are luring new candidates into House and Senate races, and the number of seats up for grabs in November appears to be growing, setting up a midterm election likely to be harder fought than anyone anticipated before the partys big victory in Massachusetts last week.

title: Freezing Motion in a Festival of Dance Films
description: Our television screens keep taking us to scenes of devastation in Haiti. So it is uncanny to realize that the choreographer Ralph Lemon, in planning his i get lost Platform series, had already (in December or earlier) booked for Tuesday a screening of the (silent) unedited films taken in Haiti by Maya Deren between 1947 and 1954. Here is another Haiti: in particular, the Haiti of Vodoun rites and their scenes of religious possession.

title: Homeless Need Tents in Haiti
description: Haitian and international officials issued an urgent call for help putting roofs over the heads of the estimated hundreds of thousands of people left without shelter by the quake.

title: Lost: The Dharma Initiative
description: The research project began in 1970.

title: Very British, Somewhat Borat and a Lot of Nerve
description: The British comedian Marc Wootton employs much the same techniques as Sacha Baron Cohen but steers in the direction of situation comedy rather than anarchic farce. While he doesnt often inspire the helpless laughter that Borat or Da Ali G Show provoke, his quieter, more slowly building situations can have their own devastating payoffs.

title: New CDs
description: LADY ANTEBELLUM  Need You Now (Capitol Nashville)

title: 22 Across: Wrigley Field
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Before we get to the Monday puzzle, I have a response from Al Jaffee (the genius behind Mads fold-in) to yesterdays crossword:

title: N.F.C. Championship Final: Saints 31, Vikings 28 (Overtime)
description: Thayer Evans and Joe Lapointe were in New Orleans providing live analysis of the N.F.C. championship game Sunday between the Vikings and the Saints.

title: Hope for Haiti Takes in $57 Million
description: The George Clooney-led telethon Hope for Haiti Now: A Global Benefit for Earthquake Relief, raised more than $57 million in 24 hours, according to a statement from the producers. That preliminary total did not include donations from corporations or large private donations. A recording of the event, which featured performances by Madonna, Bruce Springsteen and Stevie Wonder, among others, was the No. 1 iTunes album in 18 countries on Saturday. ... Another musical benefit for Haiti is in the works, this one led by the pianist Lang Lang, a Unicef Goodwill Ambassador, and the conductor Christoph Eschenbach. They announced plans for a concert at Carnegie Hall on March 21 to benefit Unicef and its effort to help children who survived the earthquake. The Schleswig-Holstein Festival Orchestra, made up of musicians under the age of 27, will provide accompaniment.

title: Avatar Rules for a Sixth Weekend
description: The cerulean-skinned warriors of Avatar (20th Century Fox) were No. 1 at the North American box office for an astonishing sixth weekend in a row, selling about $36 million in tickets for a new domestic total of $552.8 million. Fueled by particularly strong sales at higher-priced 3-D and Imax locations, Avatar now ranks as No. 2 on the all-time domestic box-office charts, behind only Titanic. (The rankings do not account for inflation.) Sonys inexpensive Legion, a supernatural thriller, was second this weekend with about $18.2 million, according to Hollywood.com, which tracks ticket sales. The Book of Eli (Alcon Entertainment via Warner Brothers) was third with about $17 million (and a new total of $62 million). Terrible reviews may have hurt The Tooth Fairy, a Fox comedy starring Dwayne Johnson. It opened in fourth place with about $14.5 million. The Lovely Bones (Paramount) was fifth with about $8.8 million ($31.6 million total). As expected, the fledgling CBS Films had a tough time with its Extraordinary Measures, a modestly budgeted medical drama starring Harrison Ford and Brendan Fraser that opened in seventh place with about $7 million.

title: Woman Collides With a Picasso
description: On Friday afternoon a woman taking an adult education class at the Metropolitan Museum of Art accidentally lost her balance and fell into The Actor, right, a rare Rose Period Picasso, tearing the canvas about six inches along its lower right-hand corner. Immediately after the accident the painting was taken to the Mets conservation studio so experts could assess the damage, museum officials said. A statement released by the Met on Sunday afternoon said, The damage did not occur in the focal point of the composition and the curatorial and conservation staffs fully expect that the repair  which will take place in the coming weeks  will be unobtrusive. The canvas  about 6  feet by 4 feet  was hanging on the wall of a second-floor gallery with other early Picassos. The museum declined to identify the woman, but said she was not injured. Picasso created the painting, which depicts an itinerant acrobat theatrically posed, during the winter of 1904-5. Museum officials said they expected the repair to be completed in time for Picasso in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, an exhibition of some 250 works from its collection opening on April 27.

title: Penn and Pattinson May Join the Circus
description: Sean Penn, below, and Robert Pattinson, bottom, may be joining Reese Witherspoon in a Fox 2000 film adaptation of Sara Gruens best-selling novel Water for Elephants, Variety reported. Francis Lawrence (I Am Legend) will direct that Depression-era story, to be adapted by Richard LaGravenese (The Fisher King), in which a veterinary student drops out of school and takes a job with a traveling circus. Ms. Witherspoon plays the equestrian Marlena, who is married to an animal trainer, most likely to be played by Mr. Penn, according to Variety, though contracts have not been finalized for Mr. Penn or Mr. Pattinson. Production is expected to begin in June.

title: In the Wings
description: SoHo Rep in TriBeCa has announced a second extension of Lear, the playwright Young Jean Lees riff on mortality and family using the Shakespeare tragedy as a jumping-off point. It will now run through Feb. 14. ... The Living Theater in Lower Manhattan has announced an extension of its production of Red Noir, written by the poet Anne Waldman and adapted and directed by Judith Malina. Performances will run through Feb. 27, with a pay what you can policy on Wednesdays and Thursdays. ... The 52nd Street Project, a childrens theater company and arts education resource center in Midtown, will cut the ribbon on its new home and theater on Tenth Avenue on Feb. 8. The comedian Lewis Black and the actresses Edie Falco and Mary Testa, among others, will take part in the festivities, which are to include an open house with activities, music and food from the neighborhood. The new building, in the Archstone Clinton development, includes a 150-seat theater, rehearsal rooms, offices, a lounge and tutoring space.

title: Familiar Wins at SAG Awards
description: The Screen Actors Guild Awards were in large part a rerun of the Golden Globes, with Jeff Bridges, Sandra Bullock, MoNique and Christoph Waltz claiming the top film honors at the ceremony in Los Angeles on Saturday night, according to the guilds Web site, sag.org. They joined Kevin Bacon, Alec Baldwin, Drew Barrymore, Michael C. Hall and Julianna Margulies, who reprised their Globes wins in the television categories. The one departure of the evening was the award for actress in a comedy series, which went to Tina Fey for NBCs 30 Rock, beating out Toni Collette who won the Golden Globe, as well as last years Emmy, for her performance in Showtimes United States of Tara. Ensemble awards went to the casts of Glee and Mad Men for television and Inglourious Basterds for film. The guilds highest honor, the Life Achievement Award, was presented to Betty White.

title: Colts Put End to Jets Surprising Run
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The Jets trudged toward their locker room in silence as confetti swirled behind them on the field. The N.F.L.s most talkative team had finally been muted, muzzled by quarterback Peyton Manning and the explosive hometown Colts in the American Football Conference championship game.

title: National Book Critics Announce Finalists
description: Some familiar names and past winners were mixed in with newcomers on the list of the National Book Critics Circle Award finalists announced Saturday at the Housing Works Bookstore Cafe in New York. The awards, given annually by the critics group, will be handed out on March 11. The fiction finalists included Hilary Mantels Wolf Hall, which won the Man Booker Prize last year, and two National Book Award finalists, Bonnie Jo Campbells American Salvage and Jayne Anne Phillipss Lark and Termite. The other finalists in the fiction category were Michelle Huneven for Blame and Marlon James for The Book of Night Women. Finalists were also announced for autobiography, biography, criticism, nonfiction and poetry. Notable names among those nominees included Mary Karr, Edmund White, Tracy Kidder and Louise Glck. The Ivan Sandrof Lifetime Achievement Award will be given to Joyce Carol Oates.

title: Oscar Clues From the SAG Awards
description: On Saturday night, as the Screen Actors Guild awards were being doled out in Los Angeles, the Bagger was still Sundancing it up, going to screenings that involved seeing Kristen Stewart nearly naked and partying with the dudes from Cyrus, Jonah Hill and John C. Reilly. So we hope to be forgiven for skipping the SAGs, which followed much the same rhythm as the Golden Globes. Jeff Bridges, Christoph Waltz, MoNique and Sandra Bullock all picked up statuettes, making them near-locks for the Oscar nominations, to be announced next week. Ms. Bullock in particular is riding a wave of awards-show buzz that wouldve surprised red carpet-watchers a year ago. The Bagger hasnt heard much talk about industry types loving The Blind Side, the film Ms. Bullock won for, but its performance at the box office ($234 million and counting) surely has won hearts and minds.

title: More on N.Y. Feds Actions on A.I.G. Details
description: As a House oversight committee prepares for a Wednesday hearing over the governments handling of the American International Groups bailout  an event that will feature testimony from Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner  more documents are emerging about efforts to keep details of that rescue confidential.

title: Democrats, Get Down to Business
description: SCOTT BROWNS victory last week in the Massachusetts Senate race, following the Republican gubernatorial triumphs in New Jersey and Virginia, marked the third time in three months that the Democratic Party has lost the support and trust of independent voters.

title: Mavericks Deal the Knicks Their Worst Home Defeat
description: By the time the fourth quarter was ticking away, the Knicks-Dallas Mavericks game looked a bit like one of those old Harlem Globetrotters-Washington Generals games, with unconscious outside shots, uncanny inside flings, thunderous dunks and little resistance to the spectacular or the routine.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,365 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 953 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Sunday:

title: Alpha Wives: The Trend and the Truth
description: Why are more American men marrying women who make more money than they do? Maybe it is the simple fact that more higher-earning women are available. And social norms have changed, with the benefits of such unions supposedly winning out over the perceived blow to the male ego.

title: Bill Gates, Sundance Celebrity
description: Forget Paris Hilton. It was Bill Gates who created a stir at one Sundance screening on Saturday.

title: Retirees at the Mercy of the Bankers
description: To the Editor:

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Flyers-Penguins . . . Again?!
description: Dj vu  that strange feeling we sometimes get that weve lived through something before, that what is happening now has already happened. Dj vu  that strange feeling we sometimes get that weve lived through something before, that what is happening now has already happened.

title: Buried Finds a Savior
description: Update | 10:45 a.m. Amid the cold and crowds of Park City, distributors are showing interest in several movies, including the Ryan-Reynolds-Trapped-In-A-Coffin film Buried and the Ben-Affleck-Trapped-In-An-Unemployment-Office movie The Company Men. On Sunday, the producers of Buried chose Lionsgate, according to Variety, representing the first major acquisition of the festival. The price tag: about $3.5 million.

title: Op-Ed: Advanced Pressure
description: The filmmaker Vicki Abeles features the stories of students and teachers of Advanced Placement classes and the pressures they face in our achievement-obsessed culture.

title: Corporate Antagonism Goes Public
description: When Time Warner Cable was tussling over fees with the News Corporation, it did something that would have been unthinkable in the backrooms where deals were once struck: it hired a political consultant to mount a public campaign against its own client.

title: Court Ruling Invites a Boom in Political Ads
description: Among those closely watching the Supreme Court ruling last week that loosened restrictions on corporate campaign spending were local television stations, which now hope for a windfall.

title: For Transgender People, Name Is a Message
description: Katherine used to be Miguel. Olin had a girls name. And in October, Robert Ira Schnur, 70, became Roberta Iris Schnur, a Manhattan retiree with magenta lipstick and, she noted the other day, chipped silver nail polish.

title: Wal-Mart Tells Employees It Will Cut 11,200 Jobs
description: Wal-Mart Stores, the nations largest retailer, is cutting about 11,200 jobs at its Sams Club warehouses, the company told its employees in a memo on Sunday.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Jaguars Dont Live Here Anymore
description: EARLIER this month, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service announced it would designate critical habitat for the endangered jaguar in the United States and take the first steps toward mandating a jaguar recovery plan. This is a policy reversal and, on the surface, it may appear to be a victory for the conservation community and for jaguars, the largest wild cats in the Western Hemisphere.

title: Campaign Trail | Annie Leibovitz for Louis Vuitton
description: When we think of the face of Louis Vuitton, glamazons like Madonna and Lara Stone spring to mind  not the photographer Annie Leibovitz. But the newest installment of the labels core values campaign features a shot of Leibovitz with her longtime friend Mikhail Baryshnikov.

title: Christmas Bombing Try Is Hailed by bin Laden
description: WASHINGTON  Osama bin Laden, the leader of Al Qaeda, spoke publicly for the first time about the botched Christmas Day airliner bombing, praising the attempt  but not explicitly taking responsibility for it  in an audiotape broadcast Sunday that was aimed personally at President Obama.

title: A Playland for Apps in a Tablet World
description: Apples move to open up the iPhone to outside programmers in 2008 started a software-writing frenzy. Giant companies and bedroom tinkerers alike rushed to get their applications into the App Store and onto the phones 3.5-inch touch screen.

title: General Puts Up a Fight in Sri Lankas Election
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka  When President Mahinda Rajapaksa announced late last year that he would move the presidential election up by two years and seek a fresh mandate from Sri Lankas war-weary electorate, he seemed like a shoo-in.

title: OBrien Undone by His Media-Hopping Fans
description: Conan OBrien made a triumphant exit from NBC Friday night, accompanied by one of the most impressive outpourings of support by younger viewers that any late-night host had ever seen  and Mr. OBrien was effusive in his thanks for their backing.

title: Still Preparing, Cuomo Courts Black Support
description: ALBANY  As New Yorks political world waits for Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo to make official his run for governor, Mr. Cuomo has been quietly but methodically working to defuse an issue that helped unravel his last quest for the job.

title: Independent Group to Look at Ways to Reduce Debt
description: WASHINGTON  Just as President Obama and Congressional Democrats are trying to create a bipartisan commission on reducing the debt, some well-known former elected officials and veterans of past administrations are announcing their own task force on Monday, underscoring the mounting concern over the nations fiscal future.

title: The Bernanke Conundrum
description: A Republican won in Massachusetts  and suddenly its not clear whether the Senate will confirm Ben Bernanke for a second term as Federal Reserve chairman. Thats not as strange as it sounds: Washington has suddenly noticed public rage over economic policies that bailed out big banks but failed to create jobs. And Mr. Bernanke has become a symbol of those policies.

title: Insurer Steps Up Fight to Control Health Care Cost
description: A front in the national health care battle has opened in New York City, where a major hospital chain and one of the nations largest insurance companies are locked in a struggle over control of treatment and costs that could have broad ramifications for millions of people with private health insurance.

title: Ex-Opera Performer Still Singing, and Volunteering
description: Inside Rayford Dudleys sunny 45th-floor apartment in the Manhattan Plaza, the view is breathtaking. Mr. Dudley, a retired opera singer, is one of the original residents of the place, a 1970s-era Mitchell-Lama complex on 43rd Street and Ninth Avenue.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Web Filters Cause Name Change for a Magazine
description: OTTAWA  In 1920 when the Hudsons Bay Company began publishing a magazine for its 250th anniversary, The Beaver: A Journal of Progress probably seemed to be a good title. The company, which controlled much of the landmass that is now Western and Northern Canada, owed much of its early fortune to the trade in beaver pelts.

title: Transfer Wes Johnson Finds Paradise at Syracuse
description: SYRACUSE  There is a simple reason Syracuses Jim Boeheim has taken just five transfers in his 34 seasons as head coach.

title: In Haiti, Many Amputees Have No Place to Go
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  In a tent serving as an acute-care ward on the grounds of this citys biggest hospital, Jocelin Franois was sitting up in bed when a nurse went by, barking at him in French. Mr. Franois, whose left leg was amputated nearly to his knee after the earthquake on Jan. 12, threw out his arms and fell back on the mattress.

title: Hungry for New Content, Google Tries to Grow Its Own in Africa
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.

title: Looking Ahead
description: ECONOMIC DATA Reports will include existing-home sales for December (Monday); the Case-Shiller home price index for November and the Conference Boards consumer confidence index for January (Tuesday); new-home sales for December (Wednesday); durable goods orders for December (Thursday); and fourth-quarter gross domestic product and the Reuters/University of Michigan consumer confidence index for January (Friday).

title: Pakistans Rebuff Over New Offensives Rankles U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  The Pakistani Armys announcement last week that it planned no new offensive against militants for as long as a year has deeply frustrated senior American military officers, and chipped away at one of the cornerstones of President Obamas strategy to reverse the Talibans gains in Afghanistan and Pakistan.

title: In Drug War, Tribe Feels Invaded by Both Sides
description: SELLS, Ariz.  An eerie hush settles in at sundown on the Tohono Oodham Nation, which straddles 75 miles of border with Mexico.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 13 about a report from a special state committee expected to recommend that the New York Senate vote on two resolutions sanctioning Senator Hiram Monserrate, who was convicted of misdemeanor assault on his companion, misspelled the surname of a spokesman for the Senate Democratic leader, John Sampson, who said Mr. Sampson would not comment on the report. The spokesman is Austin Shafran, not Shafrin.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Jan. 10 about Freya von Moltke, a member of an anti-Nazi resistance group during World War II, misstated the name of the university from which she earned a doctorate in law in 1935. At the time, it was the University of Berlin, not Humboldt University. (It became Humboldt in 1949.)

title: Corrections
description: NEW YORK

title: Rivalries as Keen as on the Field
description: THERE is nothing like the big matchups at the Super Bowl as powerhouse players go head to head. For Madison Avenue, those fascinating face-offs have nothing to do with football; they pit marketers against one another in competitive categories like automobiles, credit cards, fast food and online services.

title: Accounts, People & Miscellany
description: Accounts

title: A Quest to End Spending Rules for Campaigns
description: WASHINGTON  James Bopp Jr. likes to begin speeches by reading the First Amendment. He calls opponents, including President Obama, socialists. He runs a national law practice out of a small office in Terre Haute, Ind., because he prefers the citys conservative culture.

title: Sanchezs Graduation Day Leaves Him Wanting More
description: INDIANAPOLIS  His eyes weary, his body bruised, his lips pursed, Mark Sanchez walked through the Jets locker room Sunday night carrying a red toiletry kit. He was on his way to cleanse himself of a disappointing loss, a 30-17 defeat to the Indianapolis Colts in the American Football Conference championship game, but he had another task in mind, too. When he returned, the beard he had spent the previous five weeks cultivating was gone.

title: Conjuring Up the Latest Buzz, Without a Word
description: This Wednesday, Steven P. Jobs will step to the stage at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco and unveil a shiny new machine that may or may not change the world.

title: Possible Second Life for Stalled Xanadu Project? Consider Trip to Jersey Shore
description: Theres a new governor, Christopher J. Christie, who took office on Tuesday, but otherwise the news from New Jersey last week had that familiar ring.

title: An Unofficial Candidate, on the Trail
description: BUFFALO  Harold E. Ford Jr. does not so much enter a restaurant as attack it. His eyes dart around the room as he figures out where to start. He systematically introduces himself to everyone: the waiters, the busboys, and then, the diners.

title: Trial in Real Estate Brokers Killing May Turn on Aides Recanted Confession
description: She sat before a bland white cinderblock wall, her posture and face in constant motion, revealing little on the videotape except a series of random facial gestures and movements.

title: Defending Police Officers Who Are in Legal Trouble
description: Fresh out of the Navy, John D. Patten walked into his congressmans office unannounced; he walked out with a job as an aide. He did the same a few years later, after graduating from law school, selling Frank Hogan, then the Manhattan district attorney, on the story of his working-class Irish upbringing and noting the many times that Mr. Hogan had been discussed at the Patten family dinner table.

title: New Rule Allows Use of Partial DNA Matches
description: ALBANY  New York has become the latest of a handful of jurisdictions to permit a controversial use of DNA evidence that gives law enforcement authorities a sophisticated means to track down criminals.

title: Close Call for Haitian in an Immigration Web
description: A day after being released from federal custody in Pennsylvania, a Haitian immigrant whose detention in December touched off protests told supporters at a Manhattan church on Sunday that he was so close to being deported this month that friends were waiting for him at the airport in Port-au-Prince.

title: Lottery Numbers
Next News From Haiti: Pulling Out
description: The CNN anchor Anderson Cooper knows the 24-hour news cycle as well as anyone, and last week, he lamented that the survivors of the Haiti earthquake would soon fall victim to that reality.

title: After 10 Years, Federal Money for Technology in Education
description: More than a decade ago, Lawrence K. Grossman, former president of both NBC News and PBS, and Newton N. Minow, the former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, were asked by several foundations to explore how nonprofits like schools, libraries and museums could tap into emerging digital technologies.

title: After Senate Race, Some Say Barrier for Women in Massachusetts Still Stands
description: BOSTON  The defeat of Martha Coakley in last weeks special election to fill the Senate seat that was long held by Edward M. Kennedy has reignited the debate over whether there is a glass ceiling for women in Massachusetts politics.

title: In a Companys Hometown, the Emptiness Echoes
description: DAYTON, Ohio

title: Legal Sites Plan Revamps as Rivals Undercut Price
description: Westlaw and LexisNexis, the dominant services in the market for computerized legal research, will undergo sweeping changes in a bid to make it easier and faster for lawyers to find the documents they need.

title: Newsday Employees Reject Contract With Pay Cuts
description: Following the lead of their national union president, employees at Newsday on Sunday overwhelmingly rejected a contract with pay cuts and other concessions. The vote by members of Local 406 of the Graphic Communications Conference of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters was 473 to 10 against the proposed pact.

title: Still Waiting at the T.S.A.
description: Wanted: a smart, honest, tough-minded administrator to head up the Transportation Security Administration  before the country faces another terrorist threat.

title: Citibank in 2011, Hypothetically
description: Suppose it is 2011 and the so-called Volcker Act has recently become law, sharply curtailing banks riskier activities, like hedge funds and proprietary trading, and separating those activities from consumer businesses and retail deposits. Citigroups recently arrived chief executive, Bob Steel, formerly of Wachovia, is dismantling the group to comply with the law. A memo to the banks staff announces that Tim Geithner has been hired as head of the banks strategy and investor relations. Oddly, this imaginary situation is not such a stretch.

title: Luck Trumps Death
description: A Marine lance corporal stepped on a bomb big enough to destroy a pickup truck or kill several men, but it didnt explode.

title: A.F.C. Championship: Colts Bring Jets Down to Earth
description: Peyton Manning rallied Indianapolis to victory and into the Super Bowl.

title: Volatility and Politics Are Feeding Fears of a Market Correction
description: Brace yourself for another wild ride on Wall Street.

title: Notes of Optimism for Jets in the Aftermath of Defeat
description: INDIANAPOLIS

title: At Sundance, New Routes to Finding an Audience
description: PARK CITY, Utah  The starkest picture to emerge from the opening days of this years Sundance Film Festival may be of an independent film business forced to stretch in untested directions because its old distribution model no longer works.

title: On Street Tracing Haitis Pain, Survival Goes On
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Avenue Poupelard in the center of this devastated city pulses with life and reeks of death almost two weeks after the earthquake.

title: For Top Economic Aides, a Shaky Week in Office
description: At a moment of financial peril in 1999, Time magazines cover featured a Federal Reserve chairman and Treasury secretary under the headline: The Committee to Save the World.

title: Guild Awards Snub Avatar
description: LOS ANGELES  The Oscar race turned into a free-for-all over the weekend, as the Producers Guild of America gave its top prize on Sunday to The Hurt Locker while the Screen Actors Guild gave its top movie award to the ensemble cast of Inglourious Basterds.

title: Producers Scramble the Oscar Race
description: At the Hollywood Palladium on Sunday, the Producers Guild of America gave its top movie honors to the producers of The Hurt Locker  turning the Oscar race into a mad scramble. Just a day earlier, the Screen Actors Guild gave its highest movie honor to the acting ensemble behind Inglourious Basterds. A week earlier, the Golden Globe for best dramatic motion picture went to Avatar.

title: For Top Economic Aides, a Shaky Week in Office
description: At a moment of financial peril in 1999, Time magazines cover featured a Federal Reserve chairman and Treasury secretary under the headline: The Committee to Save the World.

title: Ethiopian Airliner Crashes Near Beirut
description: An Ethiopian Airlines plane crashed into the Mediterranean Sea on Monday morning shortly after it took off from Beirut International Airport in stormy weather. Officials said that 82 passengers and 8 crew members were on board.

title: Did Officials Bungle the End Game for Vikings?
description: Thirty-four years after the Vikings were knocked off the road to the Super Bowl on a controversial non-call against the Dallas Cowboys (see the Fifth Down post last week), Minnesota was denied again in part because of controversial and late officiating decisions.

title: Restarting Financial Reform
description: In calling for new limits on the size and activities of big banks, President Obama has given the effort to enact serious financial regulatory reform something it lacked: a rational starting point.

title: In From the Cold?
description: Killing Taliban fighters wont be enough. If there is any hope of defeating the insurgency, Afghanistans government will have to persuade a large number of militants to put down their weapons.

title: Big Food
description: As huge corporations merge and get even huger, we find ourselves yearning for some old-fashioned competition, and maybe a little diversity.

title: Praise for Plcido Domingo
description: To the Editor:

title: Banning Baathists in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: The Glass Industry, Domestic and Foreign
description: To the Editor:

title: Italys African Heroes
description: Naples, Italy

title: Obama to Offer Aid for Families in State of the Union Address
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will propose in his State of the Union address a package of modest initiatives intended to help middle-class families, including tax credits for child care, caps on some student loan payments and a requirement that companies let workers save automatically for retirement, senior administration officials said Sunday.

title: Saints and Vikings Fans Share an East Village Bar
description: Of all the gritty Manhattan taverns that exiled disciples of the New Orleans Saints would choose to make their own, why did they have to pick the very same East Village watering hole where displaced Minnesota Vikings fans had already staked a claim?

title: In Clicks on Ads, the Sound of Fraud
description: In 2009, when an online ad was clicked by a computer in Vietnam, the odds were nearly even that the click was fraudulent. Web sites practice so-called click fraud by running Internet ads, soliciting clicks, receiving payments from advertisers for the clicks, and then kicking some money back to the clickers. Much of the clicking is done by botnets, enormous networks of personal computers that are harnessed and controlled using viruses.

title: Too Big to Reform
description: Weve been here before.

title: Nadal, Defending Champion, Shrugs Off the Whispers
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Rafael Nadal has been reminded daily that he has not beaten a top-10 player in his last 11 such matchups, a fallow period stretching back to May. Juan Martn del Potro, Novak Djokovic and Nikolay Davydenko have all had his number.

title: Analysis: How Roddick Escaped Gonzalez
description: Fernando Gonzalez was feeling it. Winners were flying off his racket, and his serving was pinpoint precise and tough to read. Ahead by two sets to one and serving to force a fourth-set tie-breaker against Andy Roddick, Gonzalez looked poised to upset the higher-ranked American. Having lost the coach Larry Stefanki, who jilted Gonzalez to work with Roddick, a sweet victory was within reach.

title: N.F.C. Championship: Saints Outlast Vikings
description: New Orleans took advantage of Minnesota's mistakes and won in overtime.

title: Inevitably, Manning Solves Ryans Complex Defense
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Peyton Manning dug into his film archives last week. Grinding, he said, was his word of the week and one of the golden oldies the ultimate studier bore into was a Colts-Ravens playoff game from 2007.

title: Surviving Twice, Saints Reach Super Bowl
description: NEW ORLEANS  The owner of the Saints, Tom Benson, danced back and forth, from one foot to the other, a little soft-shoe shuffle as he left the artificial turf of the Superdome.

title: Showcase: Long Soviet Shadows
description: Jenishs home in Kyrgyzstan is underground, near pipes that deliver hot water to the city overhead. The photographer William Daniels portrayed him tossing back a glass of vodka, as starkly lit as a figure by Caravaggio. The realities faced by a day laborer could not be plainer than in this picture (Slide 5). And its grim atmosphere sets the mood for Mr. Danielss depiction of contemporary Kyrgyzstan, a destitute former Soviet republic in central Asia.

title: Super Bowl at First Glance
description: For the first time since 1993, the two No. 1 seeds advanced to the Super Bowl. The Saints and the Colts each started 13-0, and its fitting that the seasons most dominant teams made it to Miami, where Indianapolis won the Super Bowl three seasons ago. The Colts defense suddenly looks like the 1985 Bears compared with the defense New Orleans played against Minnesota. Expect still more offense in the Super Bowl, with the two best quarterbacks this season, Peyton Manning and Drew Brees, taking center stage. But the Saints had better tighten up their protection of Brees, or Colts end Dwight Freeney will run wild.

title: Sites to Refuel Electric Cars Gain a Big Dose of Funds
description: Better Place, the closely watched start-up that hopes to create vast networks of charge spots to power electric cars, is set to receive a vote of confidence on Monday, in the form of $350 million in new venture capital.

title: U.S. Women Lack Established Star in Figure Skating
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  Minutes after being named to the United States Olympic team late Saturday, more than two hours after the United States Figure Skating Championships had ended, the teenagers Rachael Flatt and Mirai Nagasu bubbled over with joy.

title: The U.S. Womens Hockey Team Is Not as Battle-Tested as It Intended
description: MINNEAPOLIS  In putting together a schedule leading to the Olympics, the United States womens hockey team hoped to intersperse a dozen or so games against Minnesota boys high school teams within its usual lineup of international and collegiate opponents. USA Hockey officials and Coach Mark Johnson thought that boys prep teams best replicated the speed of Team Canada, its rival for Olympic gold. And the states rich prep hockey tradition offered a bounty of potential opponents within easy drive of the teams home base in Blaine.

title: Stuyvesant Town Returned to Creditors
description: The owners of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, the iconic middle-class housing complexes overlooking the East River in Manhattan, have decided to turn over the properties to creditors, officials said Monday morning.

title: N.Y. Housing Complex Is Turned Over to Creditors
description: The owners of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, the iconic middle-class housing complexes overlooking the East River in Manhattan, have decided to turn over the properties to creditors, officials said Monday morning.

title: A Bitter Contest
description: The re-election campaign of President Mahinda Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka, conqueror of the Tamil Tiger rebels, is encountering surprisingly strong opposition.

title: Australian Boarder Awaits Her Moment
description: GAYLORD, Mich.  It is not hard to find the Australian snowboarding star Torah Bright against the stark white canvas of a superpipe.

title: Word of the Day | subliminal
description: subliminal \()s-bli-m-nl\ adjective

title: Exciting Game, Unsatisfying Ending: New Formula for Overtime Needed
description: (Brian Burke, a former Navy pilot who has taken up the less dangerous hobby of N.F.L. statistical analysis, operates Advanced NFL Stats, a blog about football, math and human behavior.)

title: Devastation and Survival Along Avenue Poupelard
description: A survey of the damage and survivors along a quarter-mile stretch of Avenue Poupelard in the heart of Port-au-Prince.

title: Venus Williams Finds Rhythm and Reaches Quarterfinals
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Venus Williams spotted Francesca Schiavone a set on Monday before settling into a rhythm and advancing to the quarterfinals of the Australian Open, 3-6, 6-2, 6-1.

title: News Quiz | January 25, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Bruised and Beaten, Favre Is Again Unsure of Future
description: NEW ORLEANS  For once, Brett Favre looked his age after the Minnesota Vikings loss Sunday in the National Football Conference championship game.

title: Demons, Yarns & Tales
description: Images of tapestries on display at the James Cohan Gallery.

title: Purple Postseason Pain
description: The Minnesota Vikings are 0-4 in the Super Bowl and have also had their share of heartbreak in National Football Conference championship games.

title: Using Their Powers For Good
description: WHO organized a celebrity telethon for Haiti that aired over the weekend? WHO went on stage pretending to be nobody?

title: Primaries to Watch in the 2010 Congressional Elections
description: Key primaries for Democrats and Republicans going into this years midterm elections.

title: Bankers Face a Harsh Spotlight in Davos
description: Bankers are trickling back to Davos, but they will not be strutting quite the way they used to.

title: Volatility and Politics Spark Fears of Market Correction
description: Brace yourself for another wild ride on Wall Street.

title: For Richer or for  Not Quite as Rich
description: Every era needs an emblematic tycoon, and for the age of the Great Recession, you couldnt do better than Peter M. Brant, The New York Timess David Segal writes.

title: What Could You Live Without?
description: Times columnist Nicholas D. Kristof asks readers this question in his latest column, telling the story of an Atlanta family who, wanting to do something about inequity in the world, sold their luxurious family home and donated half the proceeds to charity. What would you be willing to give up to help others? Why?

title: Bank of China Mulls Hong Kong Offering
description: Bank of China, planning a 40 billion yuan ($5.9 billion) convertible bond sale on the mainland, told analysts it may raise additional capital by selling new shares in Hong Kong, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Shots Fired at Oslo Home of Kurdish Cleric
description: OSLO  A man was wounded when several shots were fired early Monday morning into the Oslo residence of Mullah Krekar, a Kurdish cleric who helped found the militant Islamist group Ansar al-Islam in Iraqi Kurdistan in 2001 while he held refugee status in Norway.

title: China First Heavy Among List of Shanghai I.P.O.s
description: China First Heavy Industries, a maker of heavy machinery, said Friday that it would hold an initial public offering in Shanghai in the coming week, aiming to raise at least 8.4 billion renminbi.

title: Ethiopian Airliner Crashes Near Beirut
description: An Ethiopian Airlines plane crashed into the Mediterranean Sea on Monday morning shortly after it took off in stormy weather from the airport in Beirut, Lebanon.

title: Goldmans Woes Good for Options Investors?
description: Options investors could benefit from federal government criticism of Goldman Sachs  if they use a specific strategy, according to Barrons.

title: After 10 Years, U.S. Money for Tech in Education
description: More than a decade ago, Lawrence K. Grossman, former president of NBC News and PBS, and Newton N. Minow, the former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, were asked by several foundations to explore how nonprofits like schools, libraries and museums could tap into emerging digital technologies.

title: An Animated Discussion
description: The cartoonist Garry Trudeau will help us try to get a handle on the ongoing wars in Afghanistan and Iraq tonight at the  92nd Street Y. The "Doonesbury" creator will be part of a round-table discussion with David Stanford, who with Mr. Trudeau, publishes Trudeau's Sandbox, a blog by Iraq soldiers and veterans, as well as the photographer David Levinthal. The discussion, which will be moderated by Time magazine editor and writer Roger Rosenblatt, will examine the conflicts as they are seen through cartoons, blogs, photography and traditional journalism.

title: Can I Interest You in a Sarcophagus?
description: "If you are in the market for a 14,000-pound, 6-foot-tall urn carved from a block of pink Tennessee marble and encircled by a neo-Classical frieze of Indians hunting buffalo and engaging in intertribal warfare, hurry over to the 56th-annual Winter Antiques Show," writes Ken Johnson, "before someone else snaps it up." The object is on view at Gerald Peters, one of 75 art and antiques dealers gathered to "dazzling effect" under the "capacious roof" of the drill hall at the Park Avenue Armory on view daily through Jan. 31. Go to marvel at items like a complete Egyptian sarcophagus, Tiffany lamps, Cubist flappers, and others displayed in booths that are constructed to resemble tony antique shops and even a room in an 18th-century Bostonian home. The show covers a "practically encyclopedic range of art, decorative objects, furniture, tribal arts and crafts," with "dealers in ancient art, medieval suits of armor, Art Nouveau, American folk art and Modernist design." The cutoff for the newest material is 1969. The oldest objects date back thousands of years.

title: Dance Culture
description: The choreographer Mark Morris is well acquainted with dance forms from other cultures. Tonight you can start to catch up with him by paying a visit to India by way of the Dance on Camera Festival. The annual festival, with films from around the world through Feb. 2, opens tonight at the Mark Morris Dance Center in Brooklyn. On the bill is the premiere of "Nrityagram: For the Love of Dance," a documentary by Nan Melville about a gurukul, or dance village, near Bangalore where students live and dance in close proximity with their master guru. Before the documentary will be a screening of "Bahudha," part of a series of duets using the Kathak style of Indian classical dance. The colorful short shows two dancers performing before projected images of themselves. Stick around after the film when Mr. Morris and Ms. Melville will participate in a Q. and A.

title: For Obama Economic Aides, a Tough Week Looms
description: From John Harwood at The Caucus:

title: Citibank in 2011, Hypothetically
description: Suppose it is 2011 and the so-called Volcker Act has recently become law, sharply curtailing banks riskier activities, like hedge funds and proprietary trading, and separating those activities from consumer businesses and retail deposits.

title: Robert A. Mosbacher, 82, Ex-Commerce Chief, Dies
description: Robert A. Mosbacher, a native New Yorker whose career as a wildcatter in the oil fields of Texas and Louisiana paralleled and often intersected with that of President George H. W. Bush, whom he served as a fund-raiser, confidant, political adviser and secretary of commerce from 1989 to 1992, died at a Houston hospital on Sunday. He was 82 and lived in Houston.

title: More Tainted Dairy Products Are Found in Chinese Stores
description: BEIJING  Health officials in southern China have swept frozen confections and other dairy products from stores after discovering they contained melamine, the industrial compound at the center of a tainted-food scandal that rocked Chinas dairy industry in 2008, news reports said Monday.

title: Better Place to Refuel With $350 Million
description: Better Place, the closely watched start-up that hopes to create vast networks of charge spots to power electric cars, is set to receive a vote of confidence on Monday, in the form of $350 million in new venture capital.

title: Longest Super Bowl Droughts
description: Tales of woe by Jets fans can be overdone. Since the 1998 season, the team has been to two A.F.C. title games and to the playoffs six times over all. But in one respect, the gloom is justified.

title: Two Achieve a First for China in the Quarterfinals
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Folks here had hoped Australia Day, a commemoration of a historic settlement, might come one day early and be celebrated with a couple of major upsets in a sport this country cherishes. So what if Roger Federer and Serena Williams are the worlds most fabulous tennis players? Lleyton Hewitt, the native son, is a two-time Grand Slam winner and former No. 1; Samantha Stosur, another top Australian, is ranked No. 13 and climbing.

title: KDDI Pays $4 Billion for Libertys Stake in Japanese Cable Company
description: Liberty Global, the United States-based communications company controlled by John Malone, said Monday that it would sell its stake in Jupiter Telecommunications of Japan to KDDI Corporation, a Japanese wireless operator, for $4 billion.

title: In Negotiations, Corporate Antagonism Goes Public
description: When Time Warner Cable was tussling over fees with the News Corporation, it did something that would have been unthinkable in the backrooms where deals were once struck: it hired a political consultant to mount a public campaign against its own client.

title: Google Founders to Sell Shares, But Keep Control
description: From Miguel Helft at Bits:

title: Resetting the Moral Compass
description: It was great to see President Obama renew his focus on financial reform last week, even if it looked like an attempt to distract voters from his partys stunning loss of the Senate election in Massachusetts, The New York Timess Gretchen Morgenson writes in her latest Fair Game column.

title: Ask About New Yorks Response to Haitis Earthquake
description: This week, Elsie St. Louis-Accilien, the executive director of Haitian-Americans United for Progress, will responded to readers questions about New Yorks response to the relief effort in Haiti following the devastating earthquake, how the Haitian community is coping, how to get involved and other questions.

title: Colts Favored in Las Vegas
description: Oddsmakers, not impressed with the Saints, installed the Colts as 4.5-point favorites in the Super Bowl. The initial odds ranged from 4 points to 5.5 points.

title: Russian Oligarchs Long Road to Hong Kong I.P.O.
description: Oleg V. Deripaska, the Russian oligarch, was so deeply in debt at the onset of the financial crisis that Russian and Western banks could have bankrupted his company, the sprawling aluminum giant Rusal, within months.

title: Private Equity Funds Move to Bankroll Builders
description: Take a risk. Put some money on the line. See what happens.

title: Garcon Takes Haiti Onto the Field
description: The previous weekend, the Colts Pierre Garcon probably had the biggest play of the game, chasing down the Ravens Ed Reed and punching the ball out of his hands. Yesterday, Garcon had 11 catches for 151 yards and a touchdown against the Jets. He lifted the Colts, then he carried the flag for Haiti.

title: Passion and Death Meet at Madrid Exhibition
description: Through Sunday, visitors to Madrid can ogle the dreamy soccer star David Beckham between the sheets in a 2004 Sam Taylor-Wood video  just one of the pieces included in the exhibition Lagrimas de Eros (Tears of Eros), on view jointly at the Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza (Paseo del Prado 8; 34-91-369-0151; www.museothyssen.org) and the Fundacin Caja Madrid (Plaza San Martin 1; 34-90-224-6810; www.fundacioncajamadrid.org). Across a survey of 119 works spanning centuries, the exhibition looks at the links between eroticism and the death instinct.

title: Ferrero Officially Bows Out on Cadbury
description: Ferrero has ruled out a rival bid for Cadbury, clearing the way for Kraft Foods to complete its 11.7 billion ($18.9 billion) proposed takeover of the British confectioner, Reuters reported.

title: Now Screening | Lanvin
description: The fall 2010 collection from Lanvin.
