title: Chess, Poker and the Mind
description: Todays idea: The advances of computer chess have failed to illuminate the workings of the mind, writes Garry Kasparov. Time for programmers to master a bigger challenge: poker.

title: (B)advice
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared the bad advice they would offer to visitors from out of town.

title: Blackstone Takes a Look at Banking Market, Chief Says
description: The Blackstone Group is examining the possibility of entering the British banking market, the private equity giants chieftain, Stephen Schwarzman, told Reuters on Sunday.

title: BioScrip Snaps Up Critical Homecare for $343 Million
description: BioScrip, a pharmaceutical services firm, said it had agreed to acquire Critical Homecare Solutions, a provider of home infusion and home health agency services, for $343.2 million in cash and stock.

title: Swiss Have Yet to Hand Over UBS Client Data
description: Switzerland has not yet handed over data on clients of UBS to American authorities as part of a probe into possible tax evasion among wealthy bank customers, a government spokesman said, Reuters reported.

title: Citigroup Resumes Operations in Haiti
description: Citigroup said on Sunday it had resumed operations in Haiti, but has relocated operations after a massive earthquake on Jan. 12 damaged its main building and killed five employees.

title: A.I.G.s Airline Leasing Chief Is Said to Be Leaving
description: Steven Udvar-Hazy, the chief executive of International Lease Finance Corporation, the airline leasing company of the American International Group, is expected to leave as soon as this week, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

title: Family Leave: Right or Privilege?
description: Edvard Munch, The Sick Child, 1896.

title: To Get NBC, Comcast Still Has Persuading to Do
description: Before Comcast can transform the entertainment business by taking control of NBC Universal, it must convince Washington that the plan wont hurt rivals and consumers. And the promises the cable company has made so far dont impress opponents who want federal regulators to attach strict conditions to the deal, The Associated Press writes.

title: Mercedes GP Launches Car  and Schumacher
description: The Mercedes Grand Prix team today launched its new car in Stuttgart at the Mercedes-Benz Museum with the two drivers, Nico Rosberg and Michael Schumacher. This is one weird moment, really seeing Schumacher involved in a team car launch and wearing the team colors  if silver is a color, and Im color blind anyway, so who knows. The car is said to have green on it too?!

title: Senate Plans Vote on Deficit Panel
description: The Senate will this week test whether President Obamas new backing for a Congressionally created commission to tackle the deficit can put the proposal over the top.

description: The N.F.C. title game was a CliffsNotes version of Brett Favres career.Every one of his major attributes was on display.

title: Goldman Said to Cap Pay of London Partners
description: Goldman Sachs Group, the most profitable securities firm in Wall Street history, will cap the salary and bonuses of its London partners at 1 million ($1.6 million) because of public anger about the size of investment bankers pay, a person familiar with the situation told Bloomberg News.

title: Spyker Shares Surge Again on Saab Hopes
description: Shares in the small, loss-making Dutch luxury carmaker Spyker Cars surged again Monday on hopes the companys owners would reach a deal to buy Saab from General Motors that could also bolster Spykers prospects.

title: European Union to Investigate Rio Tinto-BHP Billiton Deal
description: European Union regulators said a plan by the worlds No. 2 and No. 3 iron ore miners, Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton, to combine some operations could damage competition.

title: Bain Grabs a Piece of Pizza in Japan
description: Bain Capital, the American private equity firm, said Monday it would acquire the Japan franchisee of Dominos Pizza because it saw opportunities in the countrys niche pizza delivery market, Reuters said.

title: A Thank You From the Friends and Family of Sultan Munadi
description: The colleagues and friends of Sultan Munadi, who was slain during a rescue operation in Afghanistan, would like to thank readers for the many generous donations they made to help his family. Sultans family is extraordinarily grateful to them as well.

description: Some attendees at the World Economic Forum will try to be a lot less prominent this year, as bankers face a populist backlash and the prospects of tighter regulation.

title: With Profit Down 82% for Quarter, Ericsson Plans More Job Cuts
description: Ericsson, the worlds biggest maker of mobile-phone networking equipment, said on Monday its fourth-quarter profit fell 82 percent last year and that it planned to cut 1,500 jobs this year, mostly in Sweden, after eliminating 5,000 last year.

title: Vikings Explain How They Lost the Game
description: I felt they didnt win the game, but rather we lost it.  Adrian Peterson, Vikings running back

description: Britains Financial Services Secretary, Paul Myners, called for an independent review of the investment banking industry to re-examine the greed is good culture that he said had spread through society.

description: The American International Group has grounded most of its executives, save for its chief executive, the insurer disclosed in a regulatory filing.

title: The Early Word: Moving On

description: Wow. Harold Fords op-ed in todays Times has to set some kind of new standard for cluelessness.

description: With tough economic times many students are choosing less expensive trade or training schools over traditional colleges.

title: Issues Versus People
description: Scott Sumner argues that we should be debating the substance of monetary policy, rather than whether Ben Bernanke should be reappointed. I wish it were that simple.

description: Last week, the government doled out more than $80 million in stimulus money for biofuels research, much of which will be focused on algae research.

title: China Issues Sharp Rebuke to U.S. Calls for an Investigation on Google Attacks
description: BEIJING  China delivered a bristling response on Monday to the United States demand that it investigate recent attacks on American computers from Chinese soil, saying that any suggestion that it conducted or condoned the hackers intrusions was groundless and aims to denigrate China.

title: Throwing In the Towel at Stuyvesant Town
description: A group led by Tishman Speyer Properties has decided to give up the sprawling Peter Cooper Village and Stuyvesant Town apartment complex in Manhattan to its creditors in the collapse of one of the most high-profile deals of the real estate boom. The decision comes after the venture between Tishman and BlackRock Inc. defaulted on the $4.4 billion debt used to help finance the deal.

title: The New Corporate Threat: Going Public
description: In Mondays paper, Stephanie Clifford writes:

title: Looking for Clarity Under the Volcker Rule
description: Just how President Obamas proposed banking restrictions would affect the large banks bottom lines remains somewhat unclear at this point. If broadly defined, banks could be forced to divest major portions of their business, while if narrowly defined, the banks could largely continue business as usual.

title: Admitting Misconduct While Avoiding Charges
description: Peter J. Henning, a professor at Wayne State Law School, specializes in issues related to white-collar crime and follows them for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: The Nifty 50 | Jeanne Gang, Architect
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

description: Motorsports news from around the Web

title: As Idaho Utility Pushes Efficiency, Critics Seek More Renewables
description: As I write in Sundays Times, Idaho Power  the main electric utility in Idaho  has taken aggressive strides to promote energy-saving measures.

title: Serenas Thunder Down Under
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  The Serena Williams and Samantha Stosur match promised to be a servers showdown. Both were thought to pack cannons and all were looking for some thunder for Down Under. They brought it, but Williams outgunned the Aussie.

title: Baghdad Blasts Shatter Sense of Security in Capital
description: BAGHDAD  In a coordinated attack as devastating as it was ruthlessly efficient, three bombs unleashed minutes apart on Monday wrecked landmark Baghdad hotels catering to foreigners, wilting a tattered sense of security and underscoring the uncertainty of the political landscape weeks before parliamentary elections.

title: Counting a Nation
description: The background and purpose of the census, conducted every 10 years since 1790.

title: Leaving No Stone Unturned
description: For every 1 percent of people who dont return their census forms, the government spends $85 million tracking them down.

title: Looking for a Leg Up in a Bad Economy
description: On the 10th floor of an office building in the West Village, situated a few doors down from a video store advertising blowout prices and a huge selection, and a gourmet deli that offers two eggs and a coffee for $3, students of various ages, occupational backgrounds and ambitions are in class, training to be medical assistants, chefs and hotel managers.

title: The Politics of the Count
description: The independence of the Census Bureau and skeptical critics. This time around, Mr. Groves says, Acorn is not a partner.

title: A Question of Race
description: Putting Negro on the census form was not intended to offend, Mr. Groves says, but to capture how some people refer to themselves.

title: Medtronic to Buy Stent Maker Invatec
description: Medtronic said Monday that it would pay up to $500 million for Invatec, a company that makes medical devices to treat cardiovascular disease, The Associated Press reports.

title: A True Story, Except When Its Not
description: Bansky, of course, was nowhere to be found at the Sundance premiere of his new movie, Exit Through the Gift Shop. Or rather, the anonymous British street artist may have been in the capacity crowd on Sunday night, but who wouldve known? Morgan Spurlock, perhaps, whos a fan and a collector  and a connoisseur of the stunt documentary. Exit Through the Gift Shop was a late addition to the Sundance schedule but caused a stir when Banksy graffiti pieces began popping up in Park City; people have been brushing aside the snow to photograph them all week long.

title: Hussein Aide Chemical Ali Executed in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Ali Hassan al-Majid, a symbol of the former government of Saddam Hussein, who ordered a poison gas attack on a Kurdish village in northern Iraq, was executed on Monday.

title: Whitacre Said to Become G.M.s Permanent Chief
description: Update | 12:57 p.m.  General Motors on Monday said it was ending its search for a chief executive, instead electing to have its chairman and interim chief, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., take the job permanently. Mr. Whitacre, 68, did not say how long he anticipated continuing to run the automaker, except that it would be an adequate amount of time to get done what we need to get done.

title: Now Screening | Dior Homme
description: The fall 2010 collection from Dior Homme.

title: The Food Program in a Koraro School
description: The following is the fifth in a series of reports from the Ethiopian village of Koraro, an important testing ground for the Millennium Village Project, an experiment in global development strategy spearheaded by economist Jeffrey Sachs. The reports, written by Jeff Marlow, a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, consider which parts of the project are working and which ones arent, and what can be learned from it to help billions of people escape extreme poverty.

title: Bidens Son Will Not Run for Delawares Open Senate Seat
description: Updated In more bad political news for Congressional Democrats, Beau Biden, the vice presidents son and the partys top choice for a Senate candidacy in Delaware, announced to his backers this morning that he would not seek the Senate seat vacated by his father, Joseph R. Biden Jr., last year.

title: A Plan to Honor an Adversary Ruffles Legal Feathers
description: It has been almost a year since Robert M. Morgenthau announced the end of his 35-year reign as the Manhattan district attorney. Ever since, he has been showered with accolades, receiving awards from organizations like the Vera Institute of Justice and the New York County Lawyers Association.

title: Aloha (and a Confession) From Hawaii!
description: It has been 19 days since I left New York City and my business behind to enjoy my wedding and celebrate on my honeymoon. Brad and I will be heading back home in three days, at which point I will get back into the swing of things, this time as a very happily married chief executive.

title: Video: Ten Minutes With Census Director Robert Groves
description: Robert Groves, director of the United States Census Bureau, is this weeks guest on Ten Minutes, the new video series on The Caucus.

title: To Attract Shoppers, G.M. to Pay Debt to U.S.
description: DETROIT  Like Lee Iacocca at Chrysler, Edward E. Whitacre Jr. thinks the best way to lure consumers back to a bailed-out automaker is to pay back the loans from American taxpayers.

title: Existing-Home Sales Drop More Than Forecast
description: Home sales plunged more than expected in December, raising fresh questions about whether the housing market can function without ample government assistance.

title: Large High Schools in the City Are Taking Hard Falls
description: The boos cascaded over the auditorium as a city education official read out the case against Christopher Columbus High School, one of the last remaining large high schools in the Bronx.

title: When Did Conan OBrien Become Norma Rae?
description: Conan OBriens reign at The Tonight Show is now all over but the shouting (and the ratings counting). And while some industry observers are wondering if a small sliver of young viewers might have allowed Mr. OBrien to keep his job at the program (and avoided the feud that Alessandra Stanley called an explosion of incivility that burns through late-night bonhomie), one prominent critic is wondering why we care about NBCs late-night woes at all.

title: Monday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused articles appear in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Nancy Kerrigans Brother Charged With Assaulting Their Father, Boston.com Reports
description: Boston.com is reporting that the brother of the former United States figure skating star Nancy Kerrigan will be charged with assaulting their father, who later died.

title: Adopting a Child From Haiti
description: The scenes of heartbreak in Haiti have led a number of you to want to do more, much more, for the hundreds of thousands of children estimated to have been orphaned by the earthquake. In the past two weeks, I have received a number of e-mail messages like this one from Chavi Cohen, who writes:

title: Falling Eggs, Losing Teams and Fancy Baby Food
description: If the rainy, warm and windy weather seems a less-than-ideal way to start the week, consider an alternative offered by the gods  or rather, some condo dwellers  in one Brooklyn dog park: falling eggs.

title: Now Auctioning | The Ultimate Fornasetti
description: Think custom car and youre usually thinking about artists like Ed Big Daddy Roth or Von Dutch. The name Fornasetti does not come to mind. But a couple of weeks ago, a curious item (#300382940551) popped up on eBay: a burgundy Mercedes-Benz 280TE station wagon of a vaguely 1980s vintage tricked out with an architectural-frieze pattern credited to the legendary Milan atelier known for its whimsical umbrella stands, butterfly-sprinkled tray tables and decorative plates emblazoned with the enigmatic face of a 19th-century woman. The bidding starts at $9,000  significantly less than, say, a vintage Fornasetti room divider.

title: G.M. and Spyker Still in Talks Over Saab
description: Spyker Cars, the Dutch maker of luxury cars, is still in talks with General Motors to buy its ailing Saab brand, but no deal has been reached, spokesmen for both sides said Monday.

title: A Bargain Lunch, and Dancing Bears, Too
description: Nothing can keep a great showman down.

title: Negro Designation Stays on Census Form
description: When Senator Harry Reid apologized to President Obama earlier this month for uttering the phrase Negro dialect, the moment touched off considerable discussion over the use of the word. Mr. Obama called it an unfortunate remark. And Mr. Reid said he deeply regretted using such a poor choice of words.

title: How Much Exactly for a Famous Meter Maid?
description: Update | 11:45 a.m.  Did Conan OBrien really save his most costly joke  at NBCs expense  for last?

title: Pressure Cooking: Fast, Healthy Eating
description: (Paula Crossfield, the managing editor of Civil Eats, e-mailed me recently about how much she likes her new pressure cooker. I asked her to write about it, and she did. MB)

title: In Health Debate, a Struggle to Balance State and Federal Roles
description: Are you are a Minnesotan first, or an American? Do you worry about protecting and defending Vermont, or the United States? Is it O.K. for the economy to thrive in North Dakota, but wither in Michigan?

title: Uncertainty Tinges the Jets High Hopes
description: INDIANAPOLIS  As devastated as Rex Ryan felt Sunday night, he had already started to look forward. The Colts were celebrating their 30-17 victory over the Jets in the American Football Conference championship game, but Ryan was detailing the talent in his locker room.

title: Celebrating Half a Century of Loud, Soothing Pops
description: Bubble Wrap game courtesy of www.virtual-bubblewrap.com.

title: Travel Deals: Discounted Theater Tickets in New York and London
description: One option for finding cheap theater tickets in New York City is the TKTS booth. Another is On the House, a two-for-one program offered by NYC & Company, the citys tourism organization. While TKTS offers discounted tickets to Broadway and Off Broadway shows, On the House is aimed at more than 20 Off Broadway productions throughout Manhattan, including The Fantasticks ($75), Fuerza Bruta ($75), Stomp ($72.50) and The Gazillion Bubble Show ($41.50).

title: The Claim: Coughing Can Blunt the Pain of a Doctors Needle
description: THE FACTS Sometimes there are no words that can comfort a patient who fears an injection or the drawing of blood. But there may be one cheap and easy way to ease the needles sting.

title: Haiti: Stolen Tents
description: In Port-au-Prince, tents which had been sent as relief for homeless Haitians, were subsequently stolen, leaving some without shelter.

title: Obamas Measures for Middle Class
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama vowed on Monday to reverse the overall erosion in middle class security as he stepped up his efforts to reconnect with Americans suffering from a weak economy and high unemployment.

title: Jesus Rifles
description: Rifles with sights that are inscribed with Biblical references.

title: Now Screening | Paul Smith
description: The fall 2010 collection from Paul Smith.

title: Wind Wreaks Some Havoc
description: Updated, 5:58 p.m.| Gusting winds and related meteorological phenomena blew debris off a downtown skyscraper, toppled trees onto train tracks and threw airline schedules into chaos Monday. At least one person was injured, when bricks fell from a building in the Bronx.

title: International Rift Grows Over Financial Reform
description: Its clearer than ever now that when it comes to financial reform, the United States and Britain are separated by more than the Atlantic.

title: A Bill Worth Saving?
description: Since my column today draws on Jonathan Rauchs Governments End to critique the Democrats attempt at a comprehensive health care bill, its only fair to note that Rauch himself thinks the legislation is worth saving. His argument is worth reading in full, but this is his crucial point in favor of the bill:

title: Some National Universities Look Locally for Students
description: Until the past few decades, universities like Harvard, Yale and Stanford relied heavily in their admissions process on a feeder network of headmasters, guidance counselors and principals at nearby prep schools and high schools, to say nothing of their alumni. But for a number of reasons  not least the desire to diversify their classes  these institutions and others began combing the nation in earnest in the 1960s and 1970s to assemble their freshman classes.

title: Jersey Shore Party Becomes a Dangerous Situation
description: The MTV reality series Jersey Shore isnt broadcasting any more new episodes, and yet it still finds ways to trouble its home state. On Friday night, a party at a New Jersey nightclub where the Jersey Shore cast members were scheduled to appear drew an unexpectedly large crowd, resulting in fights among clubgoers hoping to catch a glimpse of Snooki or the Situation, and forcing the police to temporarily close down the street. The Star-Ledger of Newark reported that the 501 Lounge in Montclair, N.J., hosted a Jersey Shore event on Friday night that drew an estimated 2,000 fans to the 800-person capacity club. They had crowds much larger than they could control, David Sabagh, the police chief of Montclair, told The Star-Ledger. They had 600 upstairs, 200 to 300 downstairs and 400 outside. He added: There were fights inside and fights outside. Mr. Sabagh said four people were arrested on charges of disorderly conduct and drunken driving. On Thursday night, the season finale of Jersey Shore was watched by 4.8 million people.

title: Those Who Made a Difference
description: So, its Saints-Colts.

title: Advancing the Flywheel for Energy Storage and Grid Regulation
description: Beacon Power has begun construction in Stephentown, N.Y., near Albany, on a plant that stores energy in flywheels  essentially rotating wheels or cylinders whose inertia is used to store power or deliver it quickly.

title: Retromobile: A Little Bit of Everything
description: PARIS  Retromobile may be Europes best old car show. Housed in a hall here at the Porte de Versailles, Retromobile officially celebrates the bicentennial of Peugeot and urban transportation. But the eclectic nature of the exhibits means theres a little bit of everything spread around the immense pavilion.

title: Answers About Roth I.R.A. Conversions: Part 6
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks in which you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Paraguay Striker Shot in Head in Mexico City Bar
description: Update | 5:05 p.m. Paraguay and Club America striker Salvador Cabaas was shot in the head Monday in the bathroom of a Mexico City bar and was in serious but stable condition after surgery.

title: Of Fate and Fumbles
description: It has not been a good year for Obama, or for the progressive agenda. But why? Ignore all the pontificating about how Obama needed to focus differently, seek bipartisanship with people who have no interest in making a deal, etc.. The primary factor in Obamas troubles is, simply, the continuing weakness of the job market.

title: In Defense of Bernanke
A New Fight Over Ethics in Albany
description: ALBANY  Not everyone thinks lawyers who also happen to be legislators should get a free pass from disclosing the names of the clients contributing to their legal income.

title: Agreement on Effort to Help Haiti Rebuild
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Concerned about corruption and wobbly Haitian leadership, international donors agreed Monday during a meeting in Montreal on a 10-year rebuilding effort for earthquake-damaged Haiti, one that would create an even better capital city and that the government said would cost $3 billion.

title: Avatar Makes Its Mark on Chinas Geography
description: China, it can be safely said, has a complicated relationship with Avatar. Last week it was reported that the 2-D version of the science-fiction epic, directed by James Cameron, was being pulled from many Chinese theaters; now a mountain there is being renamed for a peak seen in the film. In a ceremony on Monday, the Southern Sky Column in Zhangjiajie City, in Chinas Hunan province, was formally renamed the Avatar Hallelujah Mountain, Reuters reported, citing the local governments official Web site. The name change seemed to be an effort to stir up the interest of Chinese tourists, who have helped Avatar sell more than $100 million in tickets, breaking box office records in the country. Travel companies have already begun offering tours that emphasize the regions resemblance to Pandora, the lush alien moon depicted in the film. On its site, the municipal government wrote: Pandora is far but Zhangjiajie is near. Welcome to Zhangjiajie to see Avatars Hallelujah Mountains and discover the real world of Pandora.

title: After 34 Years, a Plainspoken Justice Gets Louder
description: WASHINGTON

title: Private Equity Deals Leveled Out Last Quarter
description: The number and value of private-equity deals in Europe leveled off in the fourth quarter, after showing constant growth throughout last year, according to a new report released by Candover.

title: Obamas Speech on Helping the Middle Class
description: Following is a text of President Obama's and Vice President Joseph R. Biden, Jr.'s remarks on Monday when they addressed an Obama administration task force aimed at helping the middle class, as released by the White House:

title: Ant Colony
description: On Saturday, the Invisible Dog, a burgeoning new art center in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, opened its doors for large installation by the French conceptual artist Xavier Roux. An enormous ant built of steel and nylon balloons, with a porkpie hat suspended above its head, The Ant refers to the childrens poem by the Surrealist artist Robert Desnos. The poems refrain is well known in France: An 18-meter ant/With a hat on its head/That doesnt exist, that doesnt exist! The rhyming whimsy, however, conceals a dark history: Desnos was a resistance fighter, and the 18-meter ant refers to the 18-meter train cars used by the Nazis for transport.

title: Same-Sex Marriage Case, Day 10: Domino Effect
description: The Bay Area blog has been reporting daily from the federal courthouse in San Francisco on the case of Perry v. Schwarzenegger. That case is challenging the constitutionality of Proposition 8, the ban on same-sex marriage approved by voters in 2008. Among the lawyers on the plaintiffs team are Theodore B. Olson, David Boies, Theodore J. Boutrous Jr., Christopher Dean Dusseault, Christine Van Aken, Danny Chu, Matthew D. McGill and Therese Stewart. The legal team for the defense includes Brian Raum, Charles J. Cooper, David Thompson, Andrew Pugno, James Campbell, Jordan Lorence, Nicole Moss, Howard C. Nielson Jr. and Peter A. Patterson.

title: More Senators Take Sides on Bernanke Reconfirmation
description: Update | 4:20 p.m.  Senator Dianne Feinstein, a Democrat from California, also said Monday that she supported Ben S. Bernankes reconfirmation as Federal Reserve chairman.

title: UBS Names Executives to Run Fixed-Income Unit
description: From Julia Werdigier, a DealBook colleague:

title: The Pacifica Geological Drama: Man, With Equipment vs. Nature, With Power
description: At the Chit-Chat Cafe in Pacifica, tables were rearranged Sunday so that cafe patrons could watch boulders being unloaded from trucks. People drove to this coastal town 15 miles south of San Francisco for the big show, the effort to shore up the cliff supporting three apartment buildings, according to an article by Carolyn Jones in The San Francisco Chronicle.

title: Saving Lives on the U.S.N.S. Comfort
description: The U.S. Navy struggles to get earthquake victims to the Comfort, a hospital ship, so they can be treated.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1) United Van Lines recently released its annual migration report, based on where its customers moved to. For the second year in a row, the District of Columbia was the top destination for moving Americans. On the other end of the spectrum, Michigan had the highest percent of outbound moves, for the fourth consecutive year.

title: The Media Equation: Applecadabra!
description: In Mondays Media Equation column, David Carr writes:

title: Patersons Budget Could Cripple City, Bloomberg Says
description: ALBANY  With New York Citys fiscal health in the balance, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg traveled to Albany on Monday to ask the Legislatures help in stopping some of Gov. David A. Patersons proposed budget cuts, saying they were unfair, could cripple the city and would force him to layoff thousands of police officers and firefighters.

title: Meeting an Unmet Need
In Game Change, Wall St. Makes a Few Cameos
description: You need only watch the cable talk shows or read the political press to realize that Game Change, the fly-on-the-wall political tome from John Heileman and Mark Halperin, is the book of the moment. Its hard not to talk to a politico and not hear gossip about the back story of the 2008 presidential race, from ill-worded remarks from Senator Harry Reid to the slow implosion of Senator John McCains presidential campaign.

title: Monday Puzzle: Stashing Llamas
description: After an adventure finding buried treasure last week, we return to the mountains in this weeks puzzle. Weve had a mountain puzzle about the one-L lama (whos a priest). Heres one about the two-L llama (whos a beast).

title: Delhi to Ditch Coal for Natural Gas
description: The city of Delhi, India, has announced that it will shut down all of its coal-fired power plants and switch to natural gas, according to an article in The Hindustan Times.

title: Bill Gates, Party Animal
description: As Brooks Barnes noted on Sunday, one of the unlikeliest must-see celebrities at Sundance has been Bill Gates. Mr. Gates was in town promoting a documentary, Waiting for Superman, about the educational system, which Paramount Vantage bought even before the festival started. As Mr. Barnes also notes, Viacom, Paramounts corporate parent, recently agreed to team with the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation to promote education improvement; as part of the agreement, the foundation pays third parties that create such content for Viacom.

title: OBrien Not Laughing All the Way to NBCs Bank
description: Just to be totally clear  and regardless of what any bandleaders for any other NBC late-night shows might say  a publicist for Conan OBrien said on Monday that none of the skits and stunts that Mr. OBrien ran during his final week at the host of The Tonight Show broke NBCs budget or cost more than what was normally spent on the show.

title: The Morning Skate: Isles See Green, Laraque Sees Red and No One Sees Canucks
description: In breaking news Monday morning, the Quebec Major Junior League has suspended the Devils draft choice Patrice Cormier for the remainder of the season. Playing for Rouyn-Noranda Huskies on Jan. 17, Cormier elbowed Quebec Remparts Mikael Tam in the head, sending Tam sprawling to the ice and convulsing (video). Here are stories on the suspension from CBC.ca and TSN.ca.

title: New Hotel Brand Wants to Become a Grand Elysian
description: To prove that successful brands can be born in hard times, marketing historians point to examples like Fortune magazine and Snickers candy bars, both brought out in 1930; Diet Coke, introduced in 1982; and the iPod, which came out in October 2001.

title: Hedge Funds Sue Porsche for Billion Lost on VW
description: A group of hedge funds filed a lawsuit on Monday against Porsche SE and two former executives, accusing the German sports car company of lying and illegally manipulating shares of Volkswagen A.G., thus costing the funds more than $1 billion in trading losses.

title: Q & A with Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: Paris Couture: Diors Many Icons
description: Most of the day-to-day, minute-by-minute events in the fashion world are so random and implausible that nothing really surprises. Outside the Dior haute couture show, held in the house, where the pale gray walls are lined with portraits of the famous and (mostly) departed, a throng of photographers and onlookers waited behind steel barricades. It was a chilly gray day. I was greeted like a country mouse by the security man at the entrance. He pulled at the corner of my invitation to see if there was a seat assignment, and then waved me in. On the stairs to the salons, I saw more camera people and then roses galore. The displays were abundant and colorful enough, surrounded by puddles of fabric, to be camp. I said hello to one or two people from the house and then found my seat.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: American Family Insurance, Madison, Wis., selected the Chicago office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of WPP, to handle its creative account, which had been handled by Element 79 Partners, Chicago, part of the Omnicom Group. Spending was estimated at $30 million to $35 million.

title: That Figures: Understanding Numbers in News Reports
description: Overview | What can understanding the magnitude of numbers tell us about what is happening in the world around us? Why is it important to comprehend numbers in the news? In this lesson, students develop the skill of understanding numbers in news stories by examining a story that interests them, developing a meaningful context and visually representing the numbers.

title: Generations of Admirers Play Their Respects
description: Tuli Kupferberg, a leader of the Fugs, was 41 when that Lower East Side band started in 1964. He had a Depression-era New York catarrhal croak, and cheerful paranoia. He wasnt cute, and was a chanter, not a singer. Two other band members, Ed Sanders and Ken Weaver, carried the melodies. Mr. Kupferberg was both ultracynical and ultraidealistic. Aside from all the other liberation going on in a Fugs record  sexual, poetic, drug-related, political  there was the amazing fact of this rabbinical monotone finding its use in a rock band.

title: An All-Brahms Program, Careful and Calculated, but Not Cautious
description: Among the most memorable recitals at the Boston Early Music Festival last spring was a Beethoven program by the cellist Pieter Wispelwey and the fortepianist Kristian Bezuidenhout, in which Mr. Wispelwey played on a period cello and made the familiar sonatas and variations sound zesty and fresh. He did much the same for Brahms in a Sunday afternoon recital at Alice Tully Hall, this time using a modern cello, with Paolo Giacometti as his pianist.

title: G.O.P. Lawmakers Reject Obamas Latest Tax-Break Plans
description: The senior Republican on the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee, Representative Dave Camp of Michigan, issued a statement today rejecting President Obamas plans to help middle class Americans with additional tax breaks for retirement savings, education and child care, which are expected to be outlined in Wednesday evenings State of the Union speech.

title: Music in Review
description: LE POME HARMONIQUE

title: Berkeley to Vote on Letter to Iran on 3 Hikers Behalf
description: It has been 179 days since three graduates of the University of California, Berkeley, were arrested and charged with illegally crossing the Iranian border during a hiking trip last summer. Friends and family of Shane Bauer, Sarah Shourd and Joshua Fattal, as well as the Kurdish government, say the border crossing was unintentional, a case of unfamiliar terrain. But the Iranian government has accused the three hikers of espionage, and said they will be tried.

title: Blueberries Pack a Nutritional Wallop
description: Blueberries are the king of fruits when it comes to micronutrients. They may not have the vitamin C of oranges and grapefruit, or the potassium found in bananas. But blueberries do have an abundance of phytonutrients, whose strong antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties, some scientists believe, may help protect against heart disease, colon cancer and other maladies.

title: Iran Opposition Leaders Drop Demand for New Election
description: CAIRO  Two of Irans opposition leaders, Mohammed Khatami and Mehdi Karroubi, appear to have dropped their demand for a new presidential election, saying that while they still believe the vote in June was fraudulent, they accept Mahmoud Ahmadinejad as the head of state, according to Iranian news services.

title: Chief of Jaguar Land Rover Leaves
description: Just as Ed Whitacre removes the interim tag from his chief executive position at General Motors, Tata Motors announces that David Smith, the top man at Jaguar Land Rover, is stepping down.

title: An Ill Father, a Life-or-Death Decision
description: I am utterly spent by the time my father lands in the emergency room, shortly after 1 a.m. on a cold January night.

title: Abusing Not Only Children, but Also Science
description: Given the vested interests lurking all over the current medical landscape, it is no wonder that the scientific method is so often mauled a little in transit. Cases of data ignored or manipulated to serve an agenda are like muggings in a bad neighborhood: you hear about them all the time, but in fact relatively few are ever openly examined.

title: Another Awards Show Looks Across the Ocean
description: Are irreverent British comedians the new hosts with the most? Seems so. After Ricky Gervais took the posh out of the Golden Globes, Eddie Izzard  known his cross-dressing and, increasingly, for his mainstream actor gigs  will do the same for the Spirit Awards, the producers announced on Monday.

title: China to Move Against Local Lobbyists
description: BEIJING  Addressing a facet of political life all too familiar to Americans, Chinas government is reported to have ordered the closure of thousands of regional liaison offices  in essence, lobbying firms  that local governments and companies operate in Beijing to curry favor with high officials.

title: Seeking a Place at Airports
description: Virgin America has managed to survive skyrocketing oil prices and an economic crisis since it started in mid-2007 and even hopes to achieve an operating profit this year.

title: Slime Mold Proves to Be a Brainy Blob
description: Lets hear it for slime molds.

title: Patient Safety: Conversation to Curriculum
description: Two summers ago, as bright-eyed third-year medical students, we rushed into clinics and operating rooms, eager to apply our textbook knowledge at last to the daily practice of working with patients.

title: Cheap Seats: Off Broadway Twofers
description: For the second year, On the House, a program of NYC & Co., the citys tourist board, is offering a two-for-one ticket deal for 25 Off Broadway shows.

title: 2 More Senators Support Bernanke
description: From Sewell Chan at Economix:

title: Trial of Woman Accused of Killing Real Estate Agent Begins
description: A lawyer for the woman accused of killing Linda Stein, a former real estate agent and punk-rock manager whose clients included the Ramones, conceded on Monday that his client was guilty, but not of murder.

title: Cheap Seats: Day-of-Show Discounts at Lincoln Center
description: Starting Wednesday at noon, Lincoln Center will offer discounted day-of-show tickets at its box office.

title: The Details of Obamas Middle-Class Plan
description: In his State of the Union address on Wednesday, President Obama  is expected to propose a package of modest initiatives intended to help middle-class families squeezed between sending their children to college and caring for elderly parents. Here are some of the proposals that are expected, according to a news release and fact sheet the White House released Monday.

title: Justice Dept. Clears Ticketmaster Deal
description: Ending a yearlong investigation, the Justice Department on Monday announced its conditions for accepting a proposed merger between Ticketmaster Entertainment and Live Nation, a deal that could significantly remake the live entertainment business by combining touring, management and ticketing into one company.

title: Dietary Dilemma
description: Q. Since vitamin D is a fat-soluble vitamin, is the supplement I take with my low-fat breakfast being absorbed? I eat half a grapefruit, shredded wheat with banana, nonfat yogurt and nonfat milk.

title: Dont Schmear Me, Ford Warns
description: ALBANY  Its a smear campaign, New York-style.

title: Group Hug | Fall Trends From Paris
description: The Paris mens-wear shows just ended, and several key fall 2010 trends are already clear. I know  whos thinking about next fall when were all freezing and pining for spring? Still, its always good to be prepared, and you can always check your closet to try and get a jump-start on what everyone will be doing next winter. For example, you could tuck your pants into boots  pretty much every designer has shown a version of long johns tucked into rugged explorer footwear. Or, see if you already have a floor-grazing coat, like the ones at Dior Homme, or a cape like John Gallianos. Go through our slide show of the key looks from this past weekend, and let us know what trends you think will actually stick.

title: Referees Are Gunning for Tall Guys, Study Asserts
description: The German defender Philipp Lahm, a diminutive 5 foot 7, is often described as skillful, heady and tenacious. A veritable frantic smurf on the back line for his national team (63 caps) and club team, Bayern Munich (more than 120 games since 2005), who often encounters taller and stronger opponents.

title: Fresh Off a Massachusetts Victory, G.O.P. Aims at Illinois
description: CHICAGO  Republicans in Illinois hold no statewide offices, are minorities in both chambers of the State Legislature and struggle some years to recruit viable candidates even at the top of the ballot.

title: U.S. Clears Ticketmaster Deal With Conditions
description: The Justice Department approved the merger of Live Nation and Ticketmaster Entertainment on Monday, but it imposed several conditions on the deal that Assistant Attorney General Christine Varney said would have the effect of lowering ticket prices.

title: Tea Party Convention Loses Another Sponsor
description: Another participating organization has pulled out of the National Tea Party convention in Nashville next month, adding to the sense of unraveling around an event that was billed as the coming together of the grassroots movement that shot up across the country starting a year ago.

title: Telling Time With Spices
description: A friend who wants to remain anonymous writes (and I love this):

title: A Deadly Quake in a Seismic Hot Zone
description: To scientists who study seismic hazards in the Caribbean, there was no surprise in the magnitude 7 earthquake that devastated the Haitian capital, Port-au-Prince, two weeks ago.

title: In Labor, a Snack or a Sip?
description: Maternity wards have long forbidden women in labor to eat or drink. Even when labor goes on and on, the bill of fare is usually limited to ice chips.

title: Parasites: Tropical Diseases Are Common in Arctic Dwellers, a Survey Finds
description: The kind of worm and protozoan infections that are often called neglected tropical diseases are also common among aboriginal peoples living in the Arctic, according to a recent survey.

title: Hedge Funds Sue Porsche Over VW Stock Deals
description: From our colleagues at DealBook:

title: Man Testifies on Police Acts in Subway
description: In court, Michael Mineo told the story of his troubled young life, reciting the wrongs he had committed against others, and those he said had been visited upon him.

title: Wide Fallout in Failed Deal for Stuyvesant Town
description: In the beginning, investors and lenders could not get enough of the record-breaking $5.4 billion deal to buy the largest apartment complexes in Manhattan: Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village.

title: Breaking Down Nadal vs. Murray
description: Uncle Toni is a master at lowering expectations for his nephew Raphael Nadal, the six-time Grand Slam winner and defending champion at the Australian Open. Despite winning seven of nine times against his quarterfinal opponent Andy Murray, Uncle Toni sounds suspiciously like a campaign manager trying to make his candidate the underdog.

title: When House Prices Rise, Sales Fall
description: The December sales numbers for existing home sales show disappointing sales, and higher prices. That reverses previous trends.

title: In the Mail: Fielding Messages for Serpico
description: In response to my profile on Sunday of Frank Serpico, I received roughly 100 e-mail messages from readers. There were, of course, dozens from fans of the film Serpico who appreciated an update, and from people in publishing looking to get in touch with Mr. Serpico. But there were some unusual ones in the bunch.

title: A Mixed Report on American Health
description: There is some good news in the numbers released last month by the National Center for Health Statistics on the health of Americans in the first half of 2009. But there is ample bad news, too, and a third of us are not feeling very well: the percentage of people who reported having excellent or very good health declined to 66.6 percent in the 2009 period, from 69.1 percent in 1998.

title: Critics' Picks: Network
description: A. O. Scott looks at Sidney Lumet's 1976 satire.

title: Going Into Labor? Its O.K. to Snack
description: For years, women enduring lengthy labors have been prohibited from eating or drinking, and typically they are only given ice chips to sustain them. But a new look at the research suggests the practice may be outdated. Todays Science Times reports:

title: Obama Couldnt Make Jury Duty
description: Update | 4:39 p.m.  The circuit court in Cook County, Illinois, lists seven reasons why you may be excused from jury duty, such as being on active duty in the military, living in a nursing home and serving as the primary caretaker of another person. Maybe it needs to list an eighth: Youre running the country.

title: Ticketmaster and Live Nation Win Approval To Merge
description: After months of scrutiny, the Justice Department announced on Monday that it had approved a merger of Ticketmaster Entertainment and Live Nation, creating a giant new company that could reshape almost every aspect of the live entertainment business.

title: No. 1 vs. No. 1: Its Rarer Than You Think
description: The New Orleans Saints probably didnt feel much like a No. 1 seed Monday, considering they barely escaped with a victory against a Vikings team that exposed plenty of weaknesses. Still, when the Saints and the Colts meet in Miami Gardens, Fla., in two weeks, the Super Bowl will feature the two most dominant regular-season teams, and the top seeds in each conference.

title: Stirring Storytelling and Amorous Rapture
description: Ask any serious vocal enthusiast to provide a list of the finest singers currently working, and the chances are good that Bernarda Fink, an Argentine mezzo-soprano, will figure in. Here in New York, where Ms. Fink has appeared infrequently, her renown stems primarily from her performances on CD, including opera recordings conducted by Ren Jacobs and highly desirable recital discs on the Harmonia Mundi label.

title: Shared (Not Divided) Parenting
description: Its a continuing conversation within households, and here on Motherlode, about how to make parenting feel less lopsided and more equal. A couple who spends a lot of time talking about this subject  first as a goal in their own life, and then as authors of the book Equally Shared Parenting: Rewriting the Rules for a New Generation of Parents  are Marc and Amy Vachon. I wrote about their book here a few weeks ago, and in the comments, many of you questioned whether parenting should be equal if the resulted would be constant weighing, measuring, dissecting and bickering about how to divide their time.

title: Exercise: In Women, Training for a Sharper Mind
description: Older women who did an hour or two of strength training exercises each week had improved cognitive function a year later, scoring higher on tests of the brain processes responsible for planning and executing tasks, a new study has found.

title: A Better Brain After Weight Lifting
description: New research shows that older women who lift weights build more than muscle. Weight lifting also appears to lead to better brain health. In todays Science Times, Roni Rabin writes:

title: Princeton Raises Tuition and Fees 3.3%
description: Princeton is raising undergraduate tuition, room and board and some fees 3.3 percent, the university announced on Monday. In its press release, Princeton called it one of the lowest percentage increases in undergraduate tuition and fees since 1966 and said that the trustees had also endorsed a 9.6 percent increase in the financial aid budget.

title: After Smoking and Fats, Focus Turns to Salt
description: In decades past, when companies wanted to test-market a product meant to enhance health and well-being, they often tried it first in California  where people were reputed to be the most health-conscious in the country. But now companies might be wise to consider field-testing their wares in New York City.

title: Building Better Hydrogels With Mix of Clay and Water
description: If youre like most people, you probably dont think much about hydrogels. Even when you encounter them  those Jell-O cubes in the school cafeteria, say, or the Sea Foam Salad you had at Grandmas  you probably dont give them a second thought.

title: Rangers Sale Ends Months of Wrangling
description: The sale of the Texas Rangers baseball team ends months of wrangling between the Hicks Sports Group, headed by the former private equity maven Thomas O. Hicks, and the teams debt holders, made up of various investors including hedge funds and wealthy individuals.

title: Answers About Salt and Health
description: In todays Personal Health column, Jane Brody explores the science behind New York City Mayor Michael Bloombergs efforts to curb sodium intake. She writes:

title: Surrender That Submarine
description: Trevor Cook has been accused of securities fraud in civil cases filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. No court has ruled on the claims, but civil cases can lead only to fines and injunctions, not to prison terms.

title: Play, Then Eat: Shift May Bring Gains at School
description: Can something as simple as the timing of recess make a difference in a childs health and behavior?

title: Pictures of the Day: Monday, Jan. 25
description: Two other catastrophes, both documented in dramatic photographs, displaced Haiti as the lead subject of Pictures of the Day for the first time since the earthquake. (This, of course, is exactly the concern of advocates for Haitian victims; that the story of their suffering will quickly fade from global consciousness.) In Baghdad, a coordinated bombing attack killed 36 people in and around the Ishtar Sheraton, the Babylon Hotel and the Hamra Hotel. Ayman Oghanna was among the photographers on the scene and produced one of the many unsettling pictures of the immediate aftermath (Slide 2). And in Beirut, an Ethiopian Airlines plane with at least 90 people aboard crashed into the Mediterranean shortly after takeoff.

title: A Less-Than-Serious Suicide
description: To be or not to be, that is the punch line.

title: Physicists Dreams and Worries in Era of the Big Collider
description: A few dozen scientists got together in Los Angeles for the weekend recently to talk about their craziest hopes and dreams for the universe.

title: Black Babies, Boys Less Likely to Be Adopted
description: Both straight and gay adoptive parents are likely to exhibit racial and sex-based biases when applying to adopt a child, a new study finds.

title: The Tyranny Of Markets
description: Gah. I hate, hate, hate it when people say that we have to do something, not on its merits, but because otherwise we would damage market confidence. Nobody really knows how the markets will react; the right thing, always, is to pursue policies that look right on the substance.

title: When Impulse Control Goes Awry
description: The title of Robert Stones new collection of stories, Fun With Problems, is clearly meant to be read in an ironic sort of way. Mr. Stones characters do not have fun. They may get high, get drunk or get loaded, but they are almost always lost, disaffected and desperate. They may visit exotic parts of the world and go on all sorts of wild adventures, but in doing so, they are always courting danger or falling prey to bad faith, bad karma and bad vibes. Even scuba diving or bungee jumping becomes for them existential confrontation with mortality, raising primal questions about courage and angst, life and death, God or his absence.

title: Now Booking | Caribbean Queens
description: Despite a still tricky, if rebounding, real-estate market, several luxury hotel brands are throwing caution to the tradewinds with splashy new Caribbean resorts. After a long delay, the Viceroy Anguilla finally made its debut last month, joining the sleepy little islands outsize collection of high-end hotels. (The Moorish-inspired Cap Juluca still reigns supreme, while the much-touted developments of Temenos and Rendezvous Bay have stalled.) At this latest Viceroy, situated on Mead and Barnes Bays, Kelly Wearstler has created ultradecadent penthouses suites, cabana-lined infinity pools and multiple lounges, among them the Half Shell, carved out of the side of a cliff.In the Turks and Caicos, where construction seems to continue unabated on Grace Bay Beach (for better or worse), the new Veranda Resort, managed by the company that owns the chic Grace Bay Club, begins accepting guests Feb. 1. It might siphon off some of the jet set whove been holing up at the nearby Gansevoort Hotel, but probably just a little  the chainlets third outpost after New York and Miami has been going strong since last spring.

title: Match of Hate, Renewed
description: With the taste of World Cup defeat still lingering, Egypt will have a chance to face down its archrival Algeria  again  when the teams play in the African Cup of Nations semifinal Thursday in Benguela, Angola. The two North African teams played two fiercely contested matches late last year to determine the final spot in the 2010 World Cup in South Africa. The meetings were marred by violence and controversy.

title: Engineers Plot the Future of a Hobbled Mars Rover
description: PASADENA, Calif.  As they have on many days during the past six years, about 10 engineers at the NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory gathered in a conference room here last Tuesday to plan the schedule of the Mars rover Spirit.

title: Keeping Options Open, Novelist Tows Museum on Road to Dream
description: SEBASTOPOL, Calif.  As the rakish, love-struck, sex-obsessed teen hero of the 1993 cult novel Youth in Revolt, Nick Twisp encounters all manner of obstacles, including dysfunctional parents, jealous rivals, the Berkeley police and, of course, acne.

title: Ruling Could Mean Lower Rents for 300,000 Tenants
description: To most renters in New York City, it sounds like a modest, even enviable, rent increase: pay an additional $45 if your monthly rent happened to be less than $1,000 and you had been living in the same apartment for more than six years.

title: The Upfront Is Looking Up
description: One sign that the television networks were suffering as a result of the economy was decisions by several to cut back or eliminate their annual presentations of coming fall shows to advertisers during several days in May known as the upfront week.

title: Obama Greets the Lakers
description: If youre going to talk trash with the Los Angeles Lakers, it helps to be president. Harder for the other guy to talk back.

title: For Citigroups Pandit, Soul Food or Sushi, Please
description: Some critics of finance may assume that all Wall Street executives enjoy are the finest and most expensive of meals. Nothing less than the power-lunch extravaganzas at the Four Seasons or San Pietro will do.

title: Timing the Sale of Your Business
description: A recent report published by BizBuySell  one of the Internets largest marketplaces for buying or selling a small business  confirmed a hunch Ive had for several months, namely that small business deals seemed to pick up during the latter part of 2009. While many business owners have put their exit plans on hold until the economy recovers, others are not only hanging on but enjoying growth and have a bright outlook for 2010.

title: A New Way to Look for Diseases Genetic Roots
description: The hunt for the genetic roots of common diseases has hit a blank wall.

title: Welcome! Now Go Home
description: MY husband likes a dinner party as much as the next person. Until 9 p.m.

title: Dreams of a Teenage Loser
description: If you buy the old rumors that Disney animators sometimes slipped pornographic images into their artwork, then you can probably also readily imagine that writers of Disney teenage comedies like Jonas and Wizards of Waverly Place sit around after hours, knock back a few and concoct raunchy versions of their standard scripts.

title: Laptop Sales Help Apple Top Forecasts
description: Apple said Monday that it earned $3.38 billion in its most recent quarter, handily beating Wall Streets optimistic expectations with record sales of Macs and iPhones.

title: Cutting a Deal With the Taliban
description: In separate interviews published on Monday, both Gen. Stanley McChrystal, the top American commander in Afghanistan, and his boss, Gen. David Petraeus, suggested that peace talks with the Taliban may be on the horizon.

title: The Nifty 50 | Joseph Altuzarra, Designer
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Mixing Extroverts and Introverts of the 18th Century
description: Europa Galante, the superb period-instrument ensemble led by the violinist Fabio Biondi, explored two distinct sides of the 18th-century orchestral repertory at Zankel Hall on Thursday evening. The first half of the program was devoted to the extroverted music of Telemann. After intermission Mr. Biondi and company set their sights on Italy by way of four strikingly different composers: Giovanni Battista Sammartini, Pietro Nardini, Arcangelo Corelli and Pietro Antonio Locatelli.

title: A Tale of E-Silence Ignites a War of Words
description: After interviewing for job at a New York magazine and completing the requisite editing test, Neal Hirshfeld waited and waited for a response from human resources. When Mr. Hirshfelds patience expired, he decided to have his revenge by accepting an offer that he never received, calling the companys human resources department to tell them that he would report to duty on Monday morning. When he let the human resources director in on the joke, he didnt let her down easy.

title: Opposites in Style, Equals in Stature
description: Great musical theater does not always take place in the precincts around Times Square, as I was forcefully reminded last week. In a span of three days I caught two of the most memorable musical theater performances Ive seen so far this season. Neither was part of a Broadway show.

title: Corporate Backing for Research? Get Over It
description: I find myself in the unfamiliar position of defending Al Gore and his fellow Nobel laureate, Rajendra K. Pachauri.

title: Solid Renderings of Strauss and Other Stalwarts
description: In Grossmchtige Prinzessin from Strausss Ariadne auf Naxos, Zerbinetta takes a Sex and the City approach to heartbreak, coquettishly insinuating that the despairing Ariadne needs a rebound fling. On Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, the stellar soprano Diana Damrau flirted her way through the treacherous vocal terrain of Zerbinettas showpiece aria, vividly accompanied by James Levine and the Met Orchestra.

title: Brains Behind Beetlejuice to Head Cannes Jury
description: The filmmaker who turned Michael Keaton into an undead bio-exorcist and Johnny Depp into an emotionally stunted chocolatier has just taken another step toward legitimacy. On Tuesday the Cannes Film Festival is to announce that it has named Tim Burton, director of Beetlejuice and Charlie and the Chocolate Factory (and many more phantasmagoric blockbusters), to serve as the jury president for its coming festival. In a statement the Cannes festival president, Gilles Jacob, called Mr. Burton a magician of visual delights who turns the screen into a faerie wonder. He adding, We hope his sweet madness and gothic humor will pervade the Croisette in Cannes. Mr. Burton, whose work is currently featured in a retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art, said in a statement, After spending my early life watching triple features and 48-hour horror movie marathons, Im finally ready for this. The 63rd Cannes Film Festival is to run from May 12 to 23, and film selections are expected to be announced in mid-April.

title: Avatar Makes Mark On Chinas Geography
description: China, it can be safely said, has a complicated relationship with Avatar. Last week it was reported that the 2-D version of this science-fiction epic, directed by James Cameron, was being pulled from many Chinese theaters. Now a mountain there is being renamed for a peak seen in the film. In a ceremony on Monday the Southern Sky Column in Zhangjiajie City, in Hunan province, was formally renamed the Avatar Hallelujah Mountains, Reuters reported, citing the local governments Web site (www.zjj.gov.cn/website/). The name change seemed to be an effort to stir the interest of Chinese tourists, who have helped Avatar sell more than $100 million in tickets, breaking box-office records in the country. Travel companies have already begun offering tours that emphasize the regions resemblance to Pandora, the lush alien moon depicted in Avatar. On its site, the municipal government wrote: Pandora is far but Zhangjiajie is near. Welcome to Zhangjiajie to see Avatars Hallelujah Mountains and discover the real world of Pandora.

title: Buried Finds Savior
description: On Sunday at the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah, Lionsgate paid an estimated $3.5 million for Buried, a Spanish thriller starring Ryan Reynolds as a civil contractor in Iraq who awakens to find himself buried alive in a wooden coffin. His captors have given him nothing but a lighter and a cellphone, which he must use to meet their ransom demand before he suffocates. Tagline: 170,000 square miles of desert. 90 minutes of oxygen. Buried, sold by United Talent Agency, was a hot item for buyers going into the festival for several reasons. Genre films typically dont have much downside  they are cheap to make and comparatively easy to market. And if that marketing is executed properly they can become phenomena with young audiences. (See: Paranormal Activity.) Although he has yet to show he can anchor a movie, Mr. Reynolds is a budding heavyweight. Warner Brothers recently hired him to play the lead in Green Lantern, a megapicture planned for summer 2011.

title: Economists Reactions to Bernanke Renomination
description: Economists left, right and center have weighed in on Ben S. Bernankes nomination to serve a second term as Federal Reserve chairman. Here are a few of their reactions:Im with Abraham Lincoln: dont swap horses in the middle of the stream.  James Hamilton, University of California, San Diego

title: OBrien Not Laughing All the Way to NBCs Bank
description: Just to be totally clear, a publicist for Conan OBrien, above, said on Monday that none of the skits and stunts that Mr. OBrien ran during his final week as the host of The Tonight Show broke NBCs budget or cost more than what was normally spent on the show. In a telephone interview, Leslee Dart, Mr. OBriens publicist, said the comedy sketches all fell within the shows normal prop and music budget guidelines. For example, for a skit in which Mr. OBrien appeared to bring the Kentucky Derby-winning horse Mine That Bird onstage while showing Super Bowl footage on a television screen, Ms. Dart said, the horse was a standard rental and the Super Bowl footage wasnt from the N.F.L. For a segment in which Mr. OBrien showed off an expensive Bugatti Veyron automobile while playing the Rolling Stones song Satisfaction, Ms. Dart said, The Bugatti was loaned to the show for free, and the music clearances were no different than the show gets for other pop tunes all the time. ?uestlove, the bandleader on NBCs Late Night With Jimmy Fallon, had written on Twitter that it cost The Tonight Show $500,000 to play the Beatles song Lovely Rita when Tom Hanks appeared on the show on Friday. But a representative for Sony/ATV Music Publishing, which handles the Beatles catalog, said that it cost the show only a nominal fee.

title: Jersey Shore Party a Dangerous Situation
description: The MTV reality series Jersey Shore isnt broadcasting any more new episodes, but it still finds ways to trouble its home state. On Friday night a party at a nightclub in Montclair, N.J., where the Jersey Shore cast members were scheduled to appear, drew an unexpectedly large crowd, resulting in fights among clubgoers hoping to catch a glimpse of Snooki or the Situation and forcing the police to close the adjacent street temporarily. The Star-Ledger of Newark reported that the event at the nightclub, the 501 Lounge, drew an estimated 2,000 fans to the 800-person-capacity club. They had crowds much larger than they could control, David P. Sabagh, the Montclair police chief , told The Star-Ledger. They had 600 upstairs, 200 to 300 downstairs and 400 outside. He added, There were fights inside and fights outside. Chief Sabagh said that four people had been arrested on charges of disorderly conduct and drunken driving. On Thursday night the season finale of Jersey Shore was watched by 4.8 million people.

title: Football Conquers All
description: Foxs National Football League playoff coverage dominated Sunday night prime-time ratings as more than 50 million viewers tuned in to watch the National Football Conference championship game, according to Nielsens preliminary estimates. Although final ratings for the live broadcast were not available on Monday, overnight numbers for the New Orleans Saints overtime victory over the Minnesota Vikings showed an impressive 27.6 rating for Fox, or more than a quarter of American households. By comparison, CBS and ABC, which finished in a virtual tie for second place, struggled to top 8 million viewers for a single program. ABC averaged 7.8 million viewers for Extreme Makeover: Home Edition from 8 to 10, while a rerun of Desperate Housewives at 10 drew 4.2 million. CBS earned 7 million at 7 for a special 60 Minutes tribute to that newsmagazines former executive producer Don Hewitt. CBS broadcast crime show repeats from 8 to 11, including CSI: NY (5.4 million), Cold Case (6.1 million) and CSI: Miami (7.2 million). NBC ranked fourth for the night with Dateline from 7 to 9 (4 million), followed by coverage of the United States Figure Skating Championships (3.6 million).

title: Hybrid Boards Rethink the Curve
description: ALTHOUGH snowboarders have a reputation for trying ever-more-dazzling tricks, snowboard technology has changed only incrementally until recently. For decades, almost all boards had a camber, or curve: if you looked at the board from the side, it was convex, rising to an arc in the middle and then pointing up again at the tips.

title: Made in Americana | Red, White, Blue  and Black
description: In the collaboration-crazed world of mens wear, the hookup of Steven Alan and Michael Williams was only a matter of time. And geography. Every morning, Williams  who, as the man behind the blog A Continuous Lean, is pretty much the charismatic leader of the cult of Americana  makes the trek from his apartment in the Financial District to his office in SoHo. The designer and retailer Alan, meanwhile, commutes in the opposite direction to his office in TriBeCa. I would walk north and he would walk south, Williams says. The more that I saw him, the more we talked. The result of those discussions, two shirts ($168 each) that arrive today at Williamss newish A.C.L. & co. online shop, is both predictable and a little surprising.

title: Robot Love
description: Spike Jonze, objectively speaking one of the coolest dudes around, is mild-mannered and polite almost to the point of awkwardness. (We mean that in a nice way.) Mr. Jonze created a stir when he was at Sundance for a few days showing a 30-minute short, Im Here, which he made with money from Absolut. Its a robot love story with more human than computer-generated effects: square-headed Sheldon (Andrew Garfield) falls for sleek Francesca (Sienna Guillory), whos quirky and fun but prone to losing body parts.

title: Lawmakers Take Aim at Tanning Beds
description: Beneath Brittany Lietz Cicalas porcelain skin and flowing blond hair are blemishes from nearly three dozen surgeries to remove cancerous moles, including an eight-inch scar across her back. The 2006 Miss Maryland title-holder, Ms. Cicala, 24, blamed an obsession with tanning beds for triggering the cancer.

title: Does 401(k) Advice Help Boost Returns?
description: Investors who receive employer-provided help investing in their 401(k)s have better returns than those who go it alone, according to a recent study. That provides some support for the Obama administrations expected proposal, which would make unbiased investment advice available to workers who participate in these types of plans.

title: Twitter Could Become the Unemployeds Best Friend
description: Update | 5:06 p.m.  Adding clearer quote from Mr. Barton at end.

title: Critics Picks Video: Network
description: This week, A. O. Scott gets mad as hell with Sidney Lumets 1976 film Network, a satirical look at the inner workings of the corporate media. While the television landscape has changed in myriad and fundamental ways since Network was released, Mr. Scott argues that the films essential insights about the nature of mass communication in modern society are as fresh as ever. Please share your thoughts about the film  its relevance and resonance  with a comment below.

title: Scorecard | Rick Owens Wins!
description: Did Scorecard speak too soon? It seems house codes (i.e., heritage) were a point for discussion in the analysis of Fridays shows, where Rick Owens scored major points for his luxe take on his own futoro-goth thing. Meanwhile, back at the Gothic cathedral of Givenchy, general consensus among the fashion cardinals was that Riccardo Tiscis novitiates werent quite Catholic.

title: Treating a Disorder (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Stroke Risk in Children (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Accidental Music Lesson
description: In a way, this is a tale of two cities.

title: CT Scans and Iodine (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Elation of Discovery? (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: To a Tapestrys Warp and Weft, Add Vision and Craft
description: It is always instructive when artists translate their work from one form into another, especially if the end result is the mad, magical, labor-intensive domain of tapestry. While astoundingly flexible and able to represent the finest details, the warp and weft of the loom have a regularizing effect. Their physical consistency creates a level playing field but also deadens some designs while enhancing others. So we learn new things about an artists sensibility and how well it travels.

title: Turning Trash Piles Into a Bird-Watchers Paradise
description: Do you see what I see? Seth Wollney asked.

title: Explanation Offered for Error in U.N. Climate Report
description: BRUSSELS  Faulty communication allowed an unsubstantiated estimate ofthe melting rate of Himalayan glaciers to make it into the landmark 2007 report by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a senior scientist and panel official said Monday.

title: Questions Over Fixing Torn Picasso
description: Since 1952 The Actor, a rare Rose Period Picasso, has hung prominently at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, along with other examples of early paintings by this Spanish master. But on Monday it could be found in a new, temporary home, the Mets conservation laboratory, where experts there are trying to determine the best course of action for this 105-year-old paintings brand-new feature: an irregular, six-inch tear running vertically along the lower right-hand corner.

title: Trailer for 'The Park'
description: The trailer for "The Park," a sumptuous new original series from T.

title: A Walk in The Park
description: The Park, a sumptuous new original series from T  yep, we have those, see our T Takes  debuts next Monday. Directed by Poppy de Villeneuve and set within the majestic bounds of Central Park, the five-episode series stars Macaulay Culkin, Qorianka Kilcher, and the vaunted stage actress Mary Beth Peil, who plays Chris Noths mother on The Good Wife.

title: Too Much Power
description: My former Times colleague Susan Antilla has a fun column today on the scare tactics being used by the Chamber of Commerce and others to defeat the presidents proposal for a Consumer Financial Protection Agency.

title: Whos Conflicted Now?
description: Have we gone too far in worrying about conflicts of interest, as I argue in my Findings column?

title: A Factory Sputters Back to Life in Haiti
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  In a city still overwhelmed by rubble and desperate for food and money, a small miracle of commerce took place on Monday: a garment factory reopened.

title: Judge Allows S.E.C. to Add Galleon Case Charges
description: A federal judge ruled Monday evening that the Securities and Exchange Commission could add new charges against Raj Rajaratnam and others involved in the broadening insider trading case surrounding the Galleon Group.

title: Pentagon Asks Senate Panel to Wait on Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: The Obama administration has asked the Senate Armed Services Committee to delay hearings on the fate of the militarys controversial dont ask, dont tell policy, because the president expects to discuss it in Wednesdays address to Congress, the committee chairman said today.

title: Turning Trash Piles Into a Bird-Watchers Paradise
description: Do you see what I see? Seth Wollney asked.

title: Obama Says Hed Rather Be a Really Good One-Term President
description: With his poll numbers in retreat and his agenda under fire, President Obama said in a television interview today that he would not sacrifice his ambitious goals simply to win a second term in the White House.

title: Halloween With Omar
description: Omar Hammami celebrates Halloween in 1992 in Alabama.

title: Economics Rap Battle
description: John Papola and Russ Roberts have finally released their much-anticipated (by me, anyway) music video of a rap battle between those two economic gangstas, John Maynard Keynes and Friedrich Hayek. Considering Professor Roberts blogs at a site called Cafe Hayek, you can sorta guess where his sympathies lie. But its a fun video no matter where you fall in this epic rivalry.

title: The Ozone Hole Is Mending. Now for the But.
description: That the hole in Earths ozone layer is slowly mending is considered a big victory for environmental policy makers. But in a new report, scientists say there is a downside: its repair may contribute to global warming.

title: Omar Plays in Snow
description: Omar Hammami rarely saw snow in Alabama.

title: Bill Gates Defends Google, Then Pans It
description: Bill Gates dropped by The New York Times on Monday to discuss his full-time job as head of the Gates Foundation, the worlds largest philanthropy, especially its work in global health and development.

title: Stitching the Narrative of a Revolution
description: BEIJING  It was the height of the Cultural Revolution, but in the heart of Chinas capital, in range of the prying eyes of foreign embassies, young Beijingers had embraced the tenets of capitalism.

title: A Leading Role for Women in Keeping the Home Fires Burning
description: BASED on the bond between men and their barbecue grills, you might think an affinity for flame would translate indoors to the fireplace. But in a recent campaign for its manufactured logs, Duraflame has made women the center of attention.

title: Out of Tragedy, Questions About God
description: To the Editor:

title: Danger Ahead: Pedestrian With Cellphone
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping Guests Happy, Down to the Last Detail
description: Nicholas A. Sciammarella, 25, works as a front desk agent at the Four Seasons in Midtown, where rates go all the way to $35,000 per night for a penthouse suite. A native of Kings Park on Long Island, Mr. Sciammarella has been tending to guests at the Four Seasons since June 2007.

title: In His Bags, Spoils of a War and Stories of Heroism
description: SEVERAL years ago, I started a foundation called Monuments Men. Its dedicated to some unknown heroes who made a huge difference in World War II. These are the museum directors, curators, librarians, architects and others who risked their lives to save art that was being destroyed or confiscated by the Nazis.

title: Kerrigan Brother Charged in Assault
description: WOBURN, Mass.  The brother of the former Olympic figure skater Nancy Kerrigan was charged Monday with assaulting their 70-year-old father, who died after being found unconscious by the police.

title: A Wine Report from Home
description: Had some great wines in the last few days, and rather than consign them to the loneliness of my computer notes, I thought Id share a few of them.

title: E-Mail Saves Time, but Being There Says More
description: EMOTICONS are intended to represent a facial expression and to convey the sort of emotion that plain text does not, it says in the Websters online entry about those typographical symbols that turn up in e-mail messages.

title: Tens of Millions Watch Haiti Telethon
description: The television ratings are in for last weeks Haiti telethon, and the results reiterate that the earthquake devastation in that country has dominated the publics consciousness in the United States.

title: Poetic Justice in a Trial Offshore
description: In 1988, President Ronald Reagan and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the soon-to-be-former Soviet Union met for a couple of hours on Governors Island. Clearly, protecting the two most powerful  and perhaps most threatened  leaders in the world on that spot of land in Upper New York Bay did not present an insurmountable problem.

title: Fighting Starvation, Haitians Share Portions
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Maxi Extralien, a twig-thin 10-year-old in a SpongeBob pajama top, ate only a single bean from the heavy plate of food he received recently from a Haitian civic group. He had to make it last.

title: CBS Strains to Give Show a Head Start
description: LAS VEGAS  CBS had to barter, literally, with television stations to secure time slots for its new syndicated show starring Nancy Grace, the tenacious former prosecutor.

title: Obama to Seek Spending Freeze to Trim Deficits
