description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will call for a three-year freeze in spending on many domestic programs, and for increases no greater than inflation after that, an initiative intended to signal his seriousness about cutting the budget deficit, administration officials said Monday.

title: Super Bowl Story Lines That You May Hear About
description: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com.

title: Caught in the Middle
description: An Indian reservation along Arizona's border with Mexico has seen an increase in drug smuggling and stepped-up monitoring by federal agents.

title: N.F.C. Title Game Draws Most Viewers Since 1982
description: The New Orleans Saints overtime win over the Minnesota Vikings on Fox was seen by an average of 57.9 million viewers Sunday  the most for an N.F.L. conference championship game since 1982, when 68.7 million watched San Francisco defeat Dallas on Joe Montanas fabled fourth-quarter pass to Dwight Clark.

title: Still Needed: A Sheriff of Finance
description: We need a global sheriff.

title: Clock Ticks for Nepal to Settle Its Future
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  For anyone living in a country where reforming health care is regarded as an insurmountable challenge, consider the political calendar in the struggling Himalayan republic of Nepal. By May 28, or roughly four months off, the entire country must be reorganized.

title: Ruling Could Mean Lower Rents for 300,000
description: To most renters in New York City, it sounds like a modest, even enviable, rent increase: Pay an additional $45 if your monthly rent happened to be less than $1,000 and you had been living in the same apartment for more than six years.

title: Ryans Gospel of Green Softens Sting of Defeat
description: Florham Park, N.J.

title: What to Watch: Henin vs. Petrova
description: Its hard to top Justine Henins return to tennis after a 20-month hiatus, but the resurgence of Nadia Petrova is another compelling storyline in this years Australian Open. The two are now playing in the quarterfinals, having survived a section of the draw that included Elena Dementieva, Kim Clijsters, and Svetlana Kuznetsova.

title: Apple's Upcoming Announcement
description: Bruce Headlam and Stephanie Clifford of The Times discuss Apple's upcoming announcement about its tablet computer and media companies' excitement for the device.

title: In Digital Combat, U.S. Finds No Easy Deterrent
description: This article was reported by John Markoff, David E. Sanger and Thom Shanker, and written by Mr. Sanger.

title: Bloggingheads: Liberal Disarray
description: Joan Walsh, left, of Salon and Joe Klein of Time debate the Democrats' troubles.

title: Argentine Banking Dispute Goes to Congress
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The showdown between President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner and the nations central bank president will shift to Congress on Tuesday, as lawmakers take up the fight over tapping the banks reserves to pay the countrys debts.

title: Serious About His Studies and Helping Out at Home
description: For a while, kitchen table conversations in Emilio Loras household were tense.

title: Gainsbourg Convergence
description: It can be hard to get past the pedigree when considering Charlotte Gainsbourg, writes Jodi Rosen. But the daughter of the Gallic pop great and provocateur Serge Gainsbourg and Jane Birkin, the English actress and vocalist, is an artist to be reckoned with in her own right. She recently released an album, IRM, produced and largely written by Beck, and the stylish star, who took home the best actress award last year at Cannes for her role in Lars von Triers controversial Antichrist, is also the subject of a film retrospective at the French Institute Alliance Franaise. Today, catch a screening of Happily Ever After, which features Ms. Gainsbourg and her husband Yvan Attal in what Stephen Holden wrote is a breezy, skin-deep sex comedy.

title: But Will There Be a Bat?
description: In his new book, I Am Ozzy, the reality television star and former Black Sabbath frontman Ozzy Osbourne offers what might be, according to Amy Virshup, the most honest disclaimer ever from a memoirist: Other peoples memories of the stuff in this book might not be the same as mine. I aint gonna argue with em. Over the past 40 years Ive been loaded on booze, coke, acid, Quaaludes, glue, cough mixture, heroin, Rohypnol, Klonopin, Vicodin, and too many other heavy-duty substances to list in this footnote. On more than a few occasions I was on all of those at the same time. Tonight, head to Borders at Columbus Circle, where the author will sign books and shed some light on how he kept track of his journey from working-class kid from Aston to animal-biting rock star.

title: A Florentine Master Arrives at the Met
description: At his peak, in the 1550s, Bronzino was the most influential painter in Florence, writes Holland Cotter. Why, given his fame, this artist has had to wait some 500 years for a museum solo is a puzzle. But finally that solo, called The Drawings of Bronzino, has arrived at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Go to discover this artist, the son of a butcher who inspired Henry James and was thoroughly embedded in Florentine high culture, with its weave of European urbanity and Tuscan particularity. The show, which encompasses all but two of the 61 works on paper currently attributed to the artist, is a scholarly tour de force.

title: With Apple Tablet, Print Media Hope for a Payday
description: SAN FRANCISCO  With the widely anticipated introduction of a tablet computer at an event here on Wednesday morning, Apple may be giving the media industry a kind of time machine  a chance to undo mistakes of the past.

title: Officers Honored in Kabul Amid Grief and Criticism
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghans may have been battered by decades of war, forced to flee several times over, but they are not shy.

title: Tea Party Disputes Take Toll on Convention
description: A Tea Party convention billed as the coming together of the grass-roots groups that began sprouting up around the country a year ago is unraveling as sponsors and participants pull out to protest its expense and express concerns about profiteering.

title: An Investigator Presses to Uncover Bailout Abuse
description: Neil M. Barofsky is not a household name like some special investigators of the past  Kenneth Starr during the Clinton administration or Archibald Cox in the Watergate years.

title: Questions Linger as Nadal Falls to Murray
description: Note: Post updated after the match.

title: U.S. Envoys Cables Show Worries on Afghan Plans
description: WASHINGTON  The United States ambassador in Kabul warned his superiors here in November that President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan is not an adequate strategic partner and continues to shun responsibility for any sovereign burden, according to a classified cable that offers a much bleaker accounting of the risks of sending additional American troops to Afghanistan than was previously known.

title: A Legal Puzzle: Can a Baby Have Three Biological Parents?
description: Scientists have created baby monkeys with a father and two mothers. Their goal was to eliminate birth defects, but increasing the number of biological parents beyond two could add a futuristic twist to an area where the law already is a mess: the question of who, in this age of artificial insemination and surrogacy, should be considered the legal parents of a baby.

title: Science and Religion, Lives and Rocks
description: My account of Barbara Herrnstein Smiths new book, Natural Reflections: Human Cognition at the Nexus of Science and Religion, provoked many lengthy and serious comments in which a number of important issues were raised. The editors and I have invited Professor Smith to respond:

title: Girls Rescue From Haiti Expands Family by Two
description: ROCA, Neb.  Dieunette babbles a constant stream of baby talk and flashes big expressive eyes, but she has trouble sleeping and is fussy from fighting a tapeworm. Bettania is a quiet explorer, spending her days walking from room to room, running her hands over the grand piano, flicking light switches on and off, staring at the billiards table and fireplace, all the while silent but clearly in fascination.

title: Obamas Credibility Gap
description: Who is Barack Obama?

title: Pernell Roberts, Star of TVs Bonanza, Dies at 81
description: Pernell Roberts, the outspoken actor who played Adam Cartwright, the thoughtful eldest son on televisions seminal western series Bonanza and who was the last surviving member of the shows original family, died Sunday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 81.

title: Lottery Numbers
Trial Begins for Woman Accused of Killing Linda Stein
description: A lawyer for the woman accused of killing Linda Stein, a former real estate agent and punk-rock manager whose clients included the Ramones, conceded on Monday that his client was guilty  but not of murder.

title: Bernanke Is Gaining Supporters
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve committee that sets the nations monetary policy will begin its first meeting of 2010 on Tuesday with a critical question hanging in the air: how the Feds chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, will emerge from the bruising fight over his nomination to a second four-year term.

title: The Populist Addiction
description: Politics, some believe, is the organization of hatreds. The people who try to divide society on the basis of ethnicity we call racists. The people who try to divide it on the basis of religion we call sectarians. The people who try to divide it on the basis of social class we call either populists or elitists.

title: Wizard Gets Probation in Dispute With Arenas
description: Washington Wizards guard Javaris Crittenton will serve a year of probation after pleading guilty to misdemeanor gun possession, a charge arising out of his Dec. 21 locker-room confrontation with Gilbert Arenas.

title: Mayor Objects, Politely, to Proposed Budget Cuts
description: ALBANY  It was not the kind of sentiment that lawmakers were used to hearing. Not from Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs mouth.

title: 13 Down: Summer in Montreal
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  No, todays theme is not NEW TIERS over PAR, although that runs down the center of the puzzle. Paula Gamache has something much nicer going on. Her theme consists of five entries, each containing two words that can follow the word KEEP. I know because I can KEEP COUNT and KEEP TRACK. I also know how to KEEP QUIET, but I wont just yet.

title: Guatemala: Authorities Cannot Find Former President Sought by U.S.
description: American prosecutors have charged a former Guatemalan president, Alfonso Portillo, with money laundering and requested his extradition, but the Guatemalan authorities say he has slipped out of their hands. The indictment, which was unsealed in New York on Monday, alleges that Mr. Portillo, left, embezzled $3.9 million from the Defense Ministry and stole at least $1.5 million in donations from the government of Taiwan intended to buy books for school libraries. Acting on an extradition warrant from the United States, Guatemalan police officers and soldiers searched his ranch and three other properties over the weekend but could not find the former president.

title: Outbursts and Ejections in Afghan Shooting Trial
description: From the beginning, disruptions have plagued the trial of Aafia Siddiqui, a Pakistani scientist accused of trying to shoot United States Army officers while detained in Afghanistan in 2008. And Monday was hardly an exception.

title: Bankers Return to Davos With a Bit Less Swagger
description: Bankers are trickling back to Davos, but they will not be strutting quite the way they used to.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about President Obamas planned State of the Union proposals intended to help middle-class families described incorrectly nonrefundable tax credits, like the expanded child care credit Mr. Obama is expected to propose for families earning less than $85,000. Nonrefundable credits are those that do not result in cash payments for people who pay no income tax. They reduce the tax liability, and therefore may increase the refund, of households that do pay taxes.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the housing crisis in Haiti caused by the Jan. 12 earthquake misspelled, in some copies, the middle name of a quake victim in the city of Jacmel. She is Charles Mary Ren, not Charles Marie Ren.

title: Medtronic Heart Device Is Approved
description: Federal regulators have approved Medtronics minimally invasive heart valve, the first replacement valve that can be implanted via a catheter rather than open-heart surgery.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a debate in Massachusetts, following Martha Coakleys loss in last weeks Senate race, over whether a glass ceiling exists there for women in politics, misstated, in some copies, the number of women that Massachusetts has sent to the United States House of Representatives through the years. There have been four, not three.

title: In Stuyvesant Town, Shock, Apprehension and a Stirring of Hope
description: By their own admission, it is a long shot. But for the tenants of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, the news that Tishman Speyer Properties had relinquished ownership of their sprawling plain-Jane apartment complex on the East Side of Manhattan revived an old dream:

title: Zimbabwe: Prosecution Faces a Setback in the Trial of a Mugabe Adversary
description: In a major blow to the prosecutions case against Roy Bennett, a senator and treasurer of the Movement for Democratic Change who is an adversary of President Robert Mugabe, a judge ruled Monday that a confession from the main witness against him, Peter Michael Hitschmann, could not be used as it was obtained under pressure. Mr. Hitschmann said state agents burned his buttocks with cigarettes to force him to implicate Mr. Bennett, now facing terrorism charges.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a reports finding that more than one-third of Manhattans public school buildings have hazardous code violations referred incorrectly to the School of the Future on East 22nd Street, which has 10 open violations. It is a traditional public school, not a charter school.

title: Britain: Leaders Work on Ulster Discord
description: Prime Minister Gordon Brown and his Irish counterpart, Brian Cowen, flew to Belfast on Monday in a bid to defuse a political crisis that has threatened the collapse of Northern Irelands power-sharing government. The two leaders intervened after months of increasingly bitter discord over the transfer of police and justice powers to Belfast from London. Talks between the principal partners in the Belfast government  the mostly Protestant Democratic Unionist Party and the mostly Catholic Sinn Fein  broke down last week.

title: Charles Mathias, Former U.S. Senator, Dies at 87
description: Charles McC. Mathias, a former United States senator from Maryland who as a liberal Republican clashed with the Nixon and Reagan administrations and who was called the conscience of the Senate by its Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield, died Monday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 87.

title: Russia: Mayor Vows to Stop Gay Parade
description: Moscows mayor, Yuri M. Luzhkov, an outspoken opponent of gay rights groups, vowed Monday to again prevent a gay parade in the city. Mr. Luzhkov referred to gay parades as satanic, the Interfax news agency reported. Members of gay groups have tried to march in Moscow in recent years, only to be detained or dispersed. We havent permitted such a parade and we wont permit it in the future, said Mr. Luzhkov, above. Its high time that we stop propagating nonsense discussions about human rights, and bring to bear on them the full force and justice of the law. Gay rights groups said they would press ahead with plans for a parade in May.

title: The Hidden Dangers of Helmand Province, Part I
description: They now operate a web of outposts and patrol bases that dot the farmland and the steppe of Helmand Province, and they patrol regularly around and between them. Their sustained presence in many districts, along with the decrease in vegetation that followed fall harvests and the onset of cold Afghan weather, has left Taliban fighters with less ability to hide in a gunfight. Winter has brought a decrease in small-arms attacks.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a colloquium at the John D. Calandra Italian American Institute of Queens College on the MTV reality show Jersey Shore misstated the contribution of the playwright Mario Fratti to the Broadway musical Nine. Mr. Fratti, who took part in a question and answer session, is credited with the adaptation from the Italian version he wrote; Arthur Kopit, not Mr. Fratti, wrote the musicals book.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about plans by the New-York Historical Society to open a childrens history museum next year in the societys renovated building misstated part of the title of Louise Mirrer, a top society official. She is president and chief executive, not president and chief economic officer.

title: Oil Company Near Settling Over Contract in Kurdistan
description: OSLO  A Norwegian oil producer announced Monday that it would probably have to pay from $12 million to $144 million in an approaching arbitration settlement with parties identified in legal documents and local media reports as the former American diplomat Peter W. Galbraith and a Yemeni businessman.

title: Colleges Market Easy, No-Fee Sell to Applicants
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Over the last few years, the tiny College of Saint Rose in Albany has seen applications increase at least 25 percent annually, minority admissions rise and its standing in the U.S. News and World Report rankings climb more than 20 rungs.

title: With Waived Fees and Express Processing, College Applications Emulate Credit Card Companies
description: If youve ever received an unsolicited college application that looked like a brightly colored credit card solicitation  the kind that may have promised waived application fees and expedited processing  you might be interested in an article of mine just published on The Timess Web site.

title: Corrections
description: A television review and a headline on Friday about Caprica, on the Syfy channel, misstated the time frame of that series and its predecessor, Battlestar Galactica. The events take place in the distant past, not the future, and the colonizers of the planet Caprica are ancestors of present-day humans, not their descendants.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about Irwin Dambrot, the former City College basketball star, omitted a survivor. In addition to his sons, Stuart and Jonathan; his brother, Sidney; and three grandchildren, Mr. Dambrot is survived by a daughter, Donna.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Gambling on Matches Makes Tennis Tours Uneasy
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Nikolay Davydenko has won 14 straight matches against some of the best players in the world, including two against Roger Federer, whom he will meet Wednesday in the Australian Open quarterfinals. In the past week, Davydenko has come out of what had been an inscrutable shell as well, proclaiming that his rivals are scared of him and that he would rather have his millions in prize money than fame.

title: Bloomberg to Hire Ex-Clinton Strategist
description: Howard Wolfson, a national Democratic political strategist and the chief architect of Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential bid, is quitting his job as a campaign consultant to join the administration of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg as a senior adviser, according to three people told of his plans.

title: Supporters of Gay Marriage Ban Start Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO  After two weeks of testimony by witnesses seeking to overturn Proposition 8, Californias ban on same-sex marriage, the defense began its case on Monday, with a lengthy overview of the recent political gains by gay men and lesbians in the state and beyond.

title: British Airways Is Training Employees as Fill-Ins if Attendants Strike
description: LONDON  British Airways passengers could have their meals served by baggage handlers or pilots if its flight attendants strike.

title: The Heyday of Jamaica High: Nostalgia and Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: Mixed Martial Arts
description: To the Editor:

title: Dont Give Up Now
description: It would be a terrible mistake for Democrats to abandon comprehensive health care reform just because voters in the Massachusetts Senate race last week decided that they liked the Republican, Scott Brown, more than the Democrat, Martha Coakley.

title: New York Could Use the $700 Million
description: Because of a disagreement over charter schools, legislative leaders in Albany are in danger  once again  of letting hundreds of millions of federal dollars slip through their fingers.

title: A Payroll Tax Break for Jobs
description: Washington

title: Stampede Toward Democracy
description: Washington

title: Bidens Son Will Not Run for Fathers Senate Seat
description: WASHINGTON  Joseph R. Biden III, a son of the vice president, announced Monday that he would not seek the Delaware Senate seat vacated by his father last year, giving Republicans a good chance of taking over the Democratic slot.

title: Sanchez Raises His Game, and His Expectations
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Perched in a cubbyhole inside Jets quarterback Mark Sanchezs locker Monday was a yellow toy football with Super Bowl XLIV scrawled on one side. Sanchez explained that the football had been passed among the Jets  a team thing, he said.

title: Energy Grants Seek Reliable Source for Diagnostic Aid
description: WASHINGTON  Amid a global shortage of a radioactive isotope used to diagnose cancer, heart disease and kidney problems, the Energy Department on Monday moved to develop two radically different sources for the material.

title: Neediest  | A New Start
description: The Community Service Society (C.S.S.) was able to draw three month's back rent from The Neediest Cases Fund for the Lora family. This assistance allowed Emilio Lora, 19, to stay in school.

title: Retirement Discussion Begins Anew for Favre
description: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  On a white folding table in the Minnesota Vikings locker room lay the trappings of leisure: a stack of magazines, scattered dominoes and three compact disc jewel cases. One of the CDs, by the jazz artist Melody Gardot, may be the epitaph of Brett Favres one season with the Vikings, if he finally retires: My One and Only Thrill.

title: Decision Looms on Advancing Health Care Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Seeking to avert the collapse of major health care legislation, the White House and Democratic leaders in Congress face a crucial decision about whether to use a procedural maneuver that would allow them to advance the bill despite the loss of their 60-vote majority in the Senate.

title: G.M. to Build Its Own Electric Motors for Hybrids
description: General Motors on Tuesday will announce plans to build its own electric drive motors for future hybrid and electric vehicles, making it the first major United States automaker to claim in-house design, engineering and manufacturing of this important technology.

title: Southern Christian Leadership Conference Picketed by Members
description: ATLANTA  Several dozen members of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, the civil rights group founded by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., gathered here from across the South on Monday to demand the resignations of two board members accused of financial and ethical violations.

title: Showcase: Cultural Tapestry, Under Wraps
description: Pablo Delano set out in 2007 to compile a portrait of the varied ethnic groups of Honduras. He traveled to villages and cities, weaving a tapestry of multiple cultures, rather than producing tourist-pleasing shots of Mayan natives, frozen in time.

title: Its Time to Agree on Higher Rates
description: A new Great Depression has been avoided. Gargantuan efforts from governments and monetary authorities have limited the damage of the credit crisis to a bad recession. But the worlds political and business leaders cant spend too much time on the ski slopes at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, this week. Its time for them to build a consensus for higher interest rates.

title: Wind Power Grows 39% for the Year
description: Despite a crippling recession and tight credit markets, the American wind power industry grew at a blistering pace in 2009, adding 39 percent more capacity. The country is close to the point where 2 percent of its electricity will come from wind turbines.

title: Families Struggle to Afford Food, Survey Finds
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly one in five Americans said they lacked the money to buy the food they needed at some point in the last year, according to a survey co-sponsored by the Gallup organization and released Tuesday by an anti-hunger group.

title: Bobby Bragan, Ex-Baseball Manager and Executive, Dies at 92
description: Bobby Bragan, a National League shortstop and catcher in the 1940s who became a protg of Branch Rickey, went on to manage three major league teams and served as a baseball executive, died Thursday at his home in Fort Worth. He was 92.

title: Court Refuses Noriega Case and Disposes of Another
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday refused to block the extradition to France of Manuel Antonio Noriega, the deposed Panamanian dictator. The court also disposed of what could have been a major case on testimony from crime lab analysts with an unsigned one-sentence opinion sending the case back to the lower courts.

title: Mets Start Comeback From Run of Injuries
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Pelting rain chased several Mets from the practice field Monday, but the storm should not necessarily be taken as an omen for the coming season. The few players who participated in the light workout appeared to have escaped without injury, so maybe the Mets fortunes are changing.

title: Nets Could Face $7.5 Million Fine if They Move to Newark
description: New Jerseys new governor, Christopher J. Christie, wants the Nets to pay a $7.5 million penalty if the team breaks its lease at the Izod Center and moves to the Prudential Center in Newark next season.

title: Anisimov Ends His Slump, but Rangers Cant Halt Theirs
description: Counting Monday nights 4-2 loss to the Pittsburgh Penguins at Madison Square Garden, the Rangers have accumulated 17 goals in the eight games since Jan. 12. Even that total is misleading, because they have been shut out four times.

title: Benefits Eligibility Extended
description: At least 4,300 veterans from Iraq and Afghanistan who left the military because of post-traumatic stress disorder are eligible to have their cases reviewed to see if they were improperly denied benefits, a nonprofit veterans group said. The group, National Veterans Legal Services Program, said the law required service members who had been separated from the military at least in part because of post-traumatic stress must receive disability ratings of at least 50 percent to receive benefits. At least 4,300 such veterans received ratings of less than 50 percent, according to a review by the Pentagon. In response to a lawsuit by the legal services program, a federal court last month ordered that those veterans be informed that they can ask to have their cases reviewed. Those with ratings of 30 percent or higher will become eligible for benefits, said Bart Stichman, co-executive director of the veterans group. Applications are at ptsdlawsuit.com.

title: Princeton Tuition Tops Inflation
description: Princeton University announced it would charge 3.3 percent more for undergraduate tuition, room, board and some fees in the next school year, an increase that exceeds inflation. The resulting charge, $48,580, up from $47,020 this year, is not the total price students will pay. Other fees will be set in July. The total cost for the current year is $50,620, which includes books and supplies.

title: After Celebration, Saints Face Reality and the Colts
description: METAIRIE, La.  The raucous party for the New Orleans Saints lasted until the wee hours of Monday morning in the French Quarter.

title: Word of the Day | indomitable
description: indomitable \in-d-m-t-bl\ adjective

title: New Coach Gives Red Bulls Hope
description: It may be early in a new season and for a new staff, but the Red Bulls best player, striker Juan Pablo Angel, is, well, bullish.

title: DealBooks Guide to Davos: The Annotated Map
description: View Annotated Guide to Davos in a larger map

title: News Quiz | January 26, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Still Needed: A Sheriff of Finance
description: Crises have cascaded from subprime mortgages to the financial sector to the wider economy over the last two years, but the world seems no closer to addressing the problems that caused it, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest column in The New York Times.

title: A More Sober Davos for 2010?
description: Bloomberg News Preparations are underway at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

title: Defining the Allure of Davos
description: The World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, is now such a pervasive element of modern culture, for good and bad, that its presence is almost taken for granted.

title: Convio Gives I.P.O. Another Try
description: Convio, a venture capital-backed provider of software and services that help nonprofit organizations raise money, is again planning an initial public offering, according to a regulatory filing Monday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Japans High Debt Prompts Credit Rating Warning
description: One of the leading credit ratings agencies on Tuesday changed its outlook for Japan to negative, heralding a possible future downgrade of the worlds second-largest  but heavily indebted  economy, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

title: Wall St. Ends Higher, but Concerns Persist
description: Wall Street shares closed higher on Monday as investors tried to look beyond the blistering losses of the previous week.

title: An Investigator Presses to Uncover Bailout Abuse
description: Neil M. Barofsky is not a household name like some special investigators of the past  Kenneth Starr during the Clinton administration or Archibald Cox in the Watergate years.

title: Genii Withdraws From Bidding for Saab
description: Genii Capital, the investment company, has withdrawn from the bidding for General Motors Saab unit, leaving Spyker Cars as the sole remaining bidder to rescue the ailing Swedish auto brand, Reuters reported.

title: A Battered Roddick and a Hobbled Nadal Are Out
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  What had been a very good week of tennis here for Andy Roddick  raising the hopes of his faithful fans that a second Grand Slam was in reach  ended abruptly when 14th-seeded Marin Cilic beat him in a back-and-forth five-set match, 7-6 (4), 6-4, 3-6, 2-6, 6-3.

title: Krugman: The Bernanke Conundrum
description: A Republican won in Massachusetts  and suddenly its not clear whether the Senate will confirm Ben Bernanke for a second term as Federal Reserve chairman, Paul Krugman writes in The New York Times.

title: Tamil Vote Could Be Key in Sri Lanka
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka  As voters streamed to the polls on Tuesday in Sri Lankas first election since the defeat of the Tamil Tiger insurgency, the Tamil vote emerged as the bloc that could decide the winner.

title: Roddicks Chances Dashed as He Battles Shoulder Injury
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  What had been a very good week of tennis here for Andy Roddick  raising the hopes of his faithful fans that a second Grand Slam was in reach  ended abruptly when the 14-seeded Marin Cilic downed him in a back and forth five-set match, 7-6 (7-4), 6-4, 3-6, 2-6, 6-3.

title: Layoff Lit
description: Literature suited to leaner economic times.

title: Goldman Shown Most Aggressive With A.I.G.
description: Goldman Sachs was the most aggressive bank counterparty to American International Group before its bailout, demanding more collateral while assigning lower values to real estate assets backed by the insurer, documents obtained by lawmakers show, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Are Small Schools More Effective Than Large Schools?
description: Dozens of large, low-performing schools are being closed in New York City. In many cases, they are being shut down and replaced with several smaller schools. How large is your school, and does its size seem to be related to how effective it is at educating students?

title: Fund Might Prove New Hurdle for Rangers Deal
description: Just when it looked like the months of wrangling over the sale of the Texas Rangers baseball team might be over, an unhappy hedge fund could throw a new wrench into the deal, the Sports Business Journal reported.

title: European Commission Approves Libertys Deal for Unitymedia
description: The European Commission has approved Liberty Globals acquisition of Germanys second-largest cable television operator for $5.2 billion.

title: Davos in the Media: Whither the Forum in 2010?
description: A new raft of uncertainties face the financial industry as its chieftains head to Davos, Switzerland, this year for the annual World Economic Forum. Last year, survival was at the top of the list. But at the 2010 event, a host of proposed regulatory reforms looms large over the banking industry.

title: Fallout Is Wide in Failed Deal for Stuyvesant Town
description: In the beginning, investors and lenders could not get enough of the record-breaking $5.4 billion deal to buy the largest apartment complexes in Manhattan: Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village.

title: Alcon Shareholders Push Novartis on Bid
description: Novartiss bid to buy out minority shareholders in the eyecare company Alcon does not fairly value their holdings, one of the largest investors in Alcon said.

title: Blair Signs Speaking Deal With Lansdowne
description: The British media was buzzing Monday with the news that the former British prime minister, Tony Blair, was set to reap hundreds of thousands of pounds through a speaking contract with Lansdowne Partners, the British hedge fund that made millions in bets against the lender Northern Rock.

title: To Attract Shoppers, G.M. to Pay Debt to U.S.
description: Like Lee Iacocca at Chrysler, Edward E. Whitacre Jr. thinks the best way to lure consumers back to a bailed-out automaker is to pay back the loans from American taxpayers.

title: Latest Bombings Add New Layer of Anxiety and Suspicion in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  The sounds echoed Tuesday through Investigations Square, mundane in their familiarity and poignant in their anguish. Glass shattered by a suicide bombing sounded like tinny chimes as vendors swept their sidewalks. Condolences in Arabic were murmured in the numbed aftermath of chaos. Down the street, dominoes clacked as Ali Hassan played on a table, perched before a store shorn of its facade.

title: Bernanke Is Gaining Supporters
description: The Federal Reserve committee that sets the nations monetary policy will begin its first meeting of 2010 on Tuesday with a critical question hanging in the air: how the Feds chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, will emerge from the bruising fight over his nomination to a second four-year term.

title: 50 Years of Bubble Wrap
description: Bubble Wrap game courtesy of www.virtual-bubblewrap.com.Go to related blog post

title: T-Mobile Needs Orange Deal to Compete, Exec Says
description: T-Mobile needs to merge with Orange in Britain or the two groups will struggle to compete with the biggest operators, the top executive of T-Mobiles British arm said Tuesday, as he set out his argument to regulators.

title: Wind Power Grew 39 Percent Last Year
description: Despite a crippling recession and tight credit markets, the American wind power industry grew at a rapid pace in 2009, adding 39 percent more capacity. The country is close to the point where 2 percent of its electricity will come from wind turbines.

title: Soros Leads Round for ExteNet
description: ExteNet Systems, a maker of network gear for wireless carriers, said that it had received $128 million in new financing, in a round led by Soros Fund Management, the firm founded by the billionaire investor George Soros, and SBA Communications.

title: Government Bans Texting By Truck and Bus Drivers
description: The Department of Transportation plans to announce new rules Tuesday that will prohibit interstate commercial truckers and bus drivers from sending text messages while they are operating moving vehicles.

title: Liberal Groups Urge Congress to Revive Public Option
description: To save their big health care legislation, the White House and Democratic leaders in Congress are considering a hardball procedural maneuver known as budget reconciliation to adopt a health measure, despite losing their 60-seat super majority in the Senate.

title: London Pubs Go Far Beyond Beer
description: Despite Englands long-standing affection for lager, the economic downtown is increasingly causing pubs to shut down. All over East London, bars are competing for attention in ways that go well beyond drink specials  from drawing classes to clothing sales.

title: Is Racy FriendFinder I.P.O. Too Hot to Handle?
description: Sex may sell, but investors may not be ready for an initial public offering this hardcore.

title: Chinese Banks Said to Rein in Loans
description: Chinese banks have begun restricting new loans, responding to a push by regulators to contain credit after a surge in lending in the first half of this month, sources told Bloomberg News.

title: Buffett Takes Stake in Munich Re
description: Warren E. Buffett has built a $1 billion stake in the reinsurer Munich Re, as the billionaire investor continues to add to his holdings in the reinsurance sector.

title: Rethinking African-American
description: Todays idea: American-born blacks shouldnt call themselves African-American because now there are many more people in the United States who were actually born in Africa, a black linguist and commentator says.

title: Face-Veil Issue in France Shifts to Parliament for Debate
description: PARIS  A fractured panel of French legislators on Tuesday endorsed the idea of a ban on full facial veils in government offices, public hospitals and mass transit, but  Parliament remains deeply divided over the effectiveness and constitutionality of such a law.

title: King Says Britain Needs More Robust Bank System
description: Britain needs a safer and more robust banking system, the governor of the bank of England said Tuesday, telling British lawmakers that President Obamas plans for an drastic overhaul of the banking sector were part of a much needed debate on how to fix the industry.

title: Different Strokes for Different Tennis Folks on Twitter
description: When Andy Roddick issued an apology on Wednesday for his on-court behavior after a verbal tussle with the chair umpire in his second-round match at the Australian Open, he didnt do so through a press agent or an interview with a news media outlet, instead, he did so on Twitter.

title: A New,  Improved State of the Union?
description: Presidential State of the Union addresses are often mocked for their laundry lists of new initiatives, but most of them are anticipated for some particular reason. President Obamas second speech to a joint session of Congress is going to be scrutinized in light of last weeks stunning Republican victory in Massachusetts.

title: Will the Volcker Rule Do Anything?
Adobe Prices $1.5 Billion in Debt
description: Adobe Systems, the company best known for its Adobe Reader and Photoshop software, said Monday it priced $1.5 billion in new notes, and that most of the proceeds would go to repaying its existing debt.

title: Shiseido Makes Tender Offer for Bare Escentuals
description: Shiseido, the Japanese cosmetics maker, said Monday it had started a tender offer to buy all outstanding shares of Bare Escentuals, in its effort to acquire the company for $1.7 billion, The Associated Press reported.

title: Jose Maria Lopez Confirmed at USF1
description: As reported here last week, Jose Maria Lopez, an Argentine driver, will race for USF1. The announcement was made by the President of Argentina, Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner, in the Casa Rosada, or Government House, in Buenos Aires.

title: Germany to Add Troops to Afghan War
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany promised Tuesday to send up to 850 more soldiers to Afghanistan, a compromise between the pleas of the United States and other allies for a larger commitment of forces and the political realities of a deeply unpopular war at home.

title: Sampler: Boosting Graduation Rates and a Call for Trees to Feed Elephants
description: Making Sure More Students Get Degrees | On Wednesday, California State Universitys trustees will discuss a plan to boost graduation rates at its 23 campuses. The national graduate rate for a four-year university is 53 percent for entering classes who were freshmen in the fall of 2001, according to USA Today. The overall goal is an eight percent increase in the systems six-year graduation rate by 2016, the chancellors office said. Those campuses already in the top quartile of national graduation rates are to increase their rates by six percent. For freshmen beginning in 2002, the East Bay campus had a 44 percent graduation rate. In San Jose, it was 41 percent and in San Francisco it was 44 percent. [California Watch]

description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: Ed Thigpen, Jazz Drummer, Dies at 79
description: Ed Thigpen, a drummer whose tasteful and understated style made him a favorite accompanist of some of the best-known performers in jazz, died on Jan. 13 in Copenhagen, where he had lived since 1972. He was 79.

title: Using Soccer to Supplant Kerosene Use?
description: In many developing countries, heavy reliance on kerosene lamps has led to myriad health problems. The World Bank, for example, estimates that breathing the fumes created from burning kerosene indoors equals the harmful effects of smoking two packs of cigarettes a day.

title: British Airways Is Training Employees as Fill-Ins if Attendants Strike
description: As cabin crews vote on whether to begin a strike, the airline has started training employee volunteers to take their place if the union decides to walk out. Read the full story.

title: Speed Read For Tuesday, Jan. 26
description: Highlights from todays media coverage:

title: Verizon Posts Loss, Citing Charge Related to Layoffs
description: Verizon reported a fourth-quarter loss of $653 million on Tuesday, mostly because of costs related to layoffs, despite a 10 percent increase in revenue.

title: Bloomberg Uses His Nice Self in Albany
description: It was not the kind of sentiment that lawmakers were used to hearing. Not from Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs mouth.

title: Obama Liquidates Himself

title: With Chinas Rise Comes Conflict With West
description: Chinas rise will be on prominent display in Davos this week, with the biggest Chinese delegation in the World Economic Forums history, Katrin Bennhold writes in the International Herald Tribune.

title: Travolta Flies More Scientologists to Haiti
description: After flying a jet filled with relief supplies, doctors and Scientologist healers to Haiti, John Travolta told reporters at the airport in Port-au-Prince, We have the ability to actually help make a difference in the situation in Haiti, and I just cant see not using this plane to help.

title: Rex Ryan, Jets vs. Giants, and P.S.L.s
description: Giants fans and Jets fans dont have a history of animosity  a rivalry, yes, but nothing like Yankees vs. Mets or Rangers vs. Islanders. My sense from fielding reader comments on the Fifth Down is that a fair number of Giants fans supported the Jets during the playoffs, many were neutral, and a smaller percentage rooted against the Jets.

title: Home Prices Up Slightly in November
description: The recovery in the housing market is still alive, barely.

title: Roll Up: The Beatles Meet the Wu-Tang Clan in Magical Mystery Chambers
description: Even among music fans whose tastes are omnivorous enough to include the Beatles and the Wu-Tang Clan, most people would not necessarily want to listen to both bands at the same time. Most people are not Tom Caruana, a 28-year-old music teacher and producer from Brighton, England, who spent about two months stitching together Beatles and Wu-Tang samples to create Enter the Magical Mystery Chambers, a mashup album that unites the Fab Four and the fearsome hip-hop collective.

title: Shares End Lower After a Day of Wandering
description: Stocks erased gains in the sessions final hour as concerns that the Federal Reserve may signal more plans to unwind stimulus measures overshadowed higher-than-estimated earnings and consumer confidence.

title: Bomber Strikes Near U.S. Base in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A Taliban suicide bomber wounded eight American soldiers in Kabul on Tuesday afternoon, in what appeared to be an attack on their convoy during the evening rush just outside the gates of a United States military base, Camp Phoenix. At least eight civilians were wounded as well, but there were no confirmed reports of fatalities.

title: How to Make a More Efficient Light Bulb? Make it Dimmer
description: A few years ago California regulators, concerned about energy efficiency in the state, created new rules mandating a 5 percent reduction in the wattage levels for incandescent bulbs.Experts advised the California regulators that manufacturers could meet the standard in a variety of ways without losses in bulb brightness  by filling the bulbs with different types of gas, for example, or using more advanced filament designs.

title: Upper West Side Soweto
description: This week Contra, the excellent second album by the indie alternative-rock band Vampire Weekend, debuted at No. 1 atop the Billboard Top 200 Album charts. Somehow this heady stew of African-inflected alt-rock managed to top two of the best-selling artists of the last few months: the late-blooming juggernaut Susan Boyle and the confectionery rapper Ke$ha.

title: Today in Business Travel
description: Seeking a Place at AirportsMany new airlines struggle to get access to runway slots and terminal gates at some of the nations biggest and busiest airports.

title: As Markets Rose, Plainfield Was Left Behind
description: Money is finally flowing back into hedge funds, after a year of big investor redemptions. But not all firms have been able to lure investors back in with ease.

title: Borders C.E.O. Resigns
description: Borders Group, the bookstore chain, announced Tuesday morning that Ron Marshall had resigned as chief executive to take a job at another retail chain. Michael J. Edwards, chief merchandising officer, has been named interim chief executive.

title: Sanitation Worker Is Killed in Queens
description: Updated, 4:50 p.m. | A tractor-trailer struck the rear of a sanitation truck in Astoria, Queens, on Tuesday morning, killing a sanitation worker, the police said.

title: Still Very Traditional
description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: John McCains wife and her daughter, Meghan, have posed for pictures endorsing gay marriage here in California, although Senator McCain  well, hes still very traditional. He believes marriage should be between an older man and a really hot-looking younger woman.

title: Tuesday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Dalai Lamas Envoys to Resume Talks With China
description: BEIJING  Envoys of the Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of the Tibetans, arrived in China on Tuesday to resume a long-running series of negotiations over Tibet that have so far been fruitless.

title: Play, Then Eat: Shift May Bring Gains at School
description: Can something as simple as the timing of recess make a difference in a childs health and behavior?

title: White House Plans Civil Rights Concert in February
description: Bob Dylan, Jennifer Hudson and Smokey Robinson are among the artists who will participate in the White Houses first music event of 2010, the White House said on Tuesday in a news release. The concert, called In Performance at the White House: A Celebration of Music From the Civil Rights Movement, will be on Feb. 10 in the State Dining Room, and is timed to celebrate Black History Month. Other performers on the bill include Natalie Cole, John Legend, John Mellencamp, Seal, the Blind Boys of Alabama, and the Howard University Choir. It will be hosted by Morgan Freeman and Queen Latifah, and will feature songs associated with the civil rights movement as well as readings from famous civil rights speeches. The concert is the latest event in the White House music series started last year by Michelle Obama, and will be broadcast on public television and streamed live online at whitehouse.gov.

title: Biofuel Companies Attack Algae Study
description: Post corrected, 10:20 a.m.; 1/28/2010

title: Now Serving | Not Another Lisbon Cod Piece
description: In Lisbon, not ordering cod is no longer seen as suspiciously odd, since this luminous city, one of the rare Old World capitals to have escaped the soul-sloughing ugliness of postwar American urbanism and Bauhaus gone boffo (Le Corbusier never got much of a look-in here), is going gourmand.

title: Jacobs Pillow Festival Announces 2010 Lineup
description: Dance artists from around the world will converge in the bucolic Berkshires of Massachusetts for the 78th annual Jacobs Pillow festival this summer. This years festival, which runs from June 19 through Aug. 29, will showcase more than 50 companies from nine countries and four continents. Highlights include three world premieres from the young choreographers Kyle Abraham, Monica Bill Barnes, and Camille A. Brown as well as the United States debut of the Goteborg Ballet of Sweden. The ballerina Nina Ananiashvili will help open the season at a gala event on June 19 with a performance of The Dying Swan. That program will also include a world premiere by Karole Armitage. Dance Theater of Harlem, Shantala Shivalingappa, Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, Trey McIntyre Project and Hubbard Street Dance Chicago are among the companies and artists also slated to appear throughout the season. In addition to performances, the festival also includes talks with the artists, film showings, exhibits and over 75 dance classes for the community.

title: Government Bans Texting by Truck and Bus Drivers

title: Candidate Not Allowed to Vote in Sri Lanka
description: Last Updated | 4:55 p.m. Millions of Sri Lankans cast votes on Tuesday in a presidential election, but the leading opposition candidate, a retired general who crushed a separatist movement last year, was not one of them.

title: Baby, Its Cold Outside for Mini Es
description: Oh the weather outside is frightful, and my Mini E electric car is  dying? Thats the problem some Northeastern drivers of the leased battery vehicles are having as the mercury dips. And at least one ended up on the business end of a tow hook.

title: Murray Raises His Game to a New Level
description: Rafael Nadal, the defending Australian Open champion, retired midway through the third set in his quarterfinal match against Andy Murray. Already down by two sets to love, Nadal injured his knee in the second game of the third set while running wide for a forehand. But Nadals injury obscures the real story of the match, the brilliant all-court play of Murray. He had an answer for Nadals best tennis, playing with a stunning blend of power, masterly defense and deft volleying.

title: Marriage and Women Over 40
description: In the mid-1980s, a now infamous Newsweek article declared that a single, college-educated 40-year-old woman was more likely to die in a terrorist attack than ever walk down the aisle. The claim, repeated in movies and sitcoms, convinced generations of women that if they werent married by 40, it probably wasnt going to happen.

title: Football Fill-In
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first four paragraphs of this article about the upcoming Super Bowl, No. 1 vs. No. 1: Its Rarer Than You Think. Use your own words and phrases, or click read more to choose from a scrambled list of the words/phrases that were removed.

title: Pro-Wall Street Democrat Takes On a House Veteran
description: Shes young, she just moved into the district and she is taking on an established and popular House Democrat in a primary bid she concedes is a huge gamble. Shes also a hedge fund lawyer, and proud of it.

title: Google Voice Comes to iPhone, Palm Pre
description: The spat that erupted last summer among Google, Apple and AT&T over Google Voice remains unresolved, which means the app for the popular call routing and calling service from Google is still not available on the iPhone.

title: Sitting Down to Be Counted
description: At midnight Tuesday, I spread out a copy of Mondays newspaper on the still-damp sidewalk where West 13th Street meets Avenue of the Americas. I sat down, curled my knees into my chest, and played homeless.

title: An Underdog Who Isnt Daunted by a New Try for the Senate
description: The long shot ate breakfast with his mother. She asked for campaign buttons for her friends. He handed her a dozen. She got worried. That many? Werent they expensive? Calm down, Mom, he said, theyre cheap.

title: Selling Dolphins to the Academy
description: The Bagger is nearing the end of her Sundance sojourn and still hasnt quite figured out how to schedule her time. On Monday night, at the fairly exclusive Creative Coalition dinner, we only got as far as the speechifying and the appetizer before we had to run off to a screening. (We know: youre crying for us, again.) And in the meantime, there were plenty of Twitter reports about all the fun we were missing, namely at the premiere of Lisa Cholodenkos The Kids Are All Right, which drew buyers and press galore, and wound up with some of the best buzz of the festival.

title: Rivalries in Iraq Keep G.I.s in the Field
description: MOSUL, Iraq  A string of checkpoints has appeared on the roads that spoke out from this volatile city, guarded by hundreds of American soldiers working with Arab and Kurdish troops.

title: A Parents Intuition
description: Does a parent know when something is wrong with their child? It would be comforting to believe that, no? I have had my share of times when I awoke with a start, and went to check on a sleeping boy, only to find him whimpering with fever or tangled in a blanket. And there have been times when I anticipated the ring of the phone (or the buzz of a text), saying they needed my help.

title: Condoleezza Rice Reveals Details of First Memoir
description: Readers who await Condoleezza Rices reflections on her years in the White House of George W. Bush will have to wait for memoir No. 2: on Tuesday, Ms. Rice, the former secretary of state and national security adviser, and her publisher, the Crown Publishing Group, said that the first release in a two-book deal signed by Ms. Rice last February would discuss her growing up against the backdrop of the civil rights movement. In a news release Crown said that the book, called Extraordinary, Ordinary People, would chronicle Ms. Rices childhood in Birmingham, Ala., from the seemingly placid 1950s, when Birmingham blacks lived in a segregated parallel universe, through the shockingly violent 60s when Rice saw girlhood friends lose their lives to the bloodshed. The book would also emphasize Ms. Rices role models, including her parents, John and Angelena.

title: Gobsmacked in Midtown and Williamsburg
description: Restaurant (two) week(s)  that biannual ritual during which, for about the price of two Martinis ($24.07), one can lunch at some of the citys most stylish establishments (or for $35, eat dinner)  began Monday.

title: Leaving the Nest, but How Far to Go?
description: Last weekend, Nicole was so sick with a cold and a fever that we canceled our weekend plans to head upstate New York to look at colleges (on the agenda were Skidmore, Hamilton, Colgate and Cornell). When our decision was final, I immediately took out my largest stockpot and prepared a vat of homemade chicken soup (my mothers recipe, of course)  the medicine my kids count on most when they are sick. With anything.

title: White House Music Series Will Honor Civil Rights Movement
description: On our sib-blog, ArtsBeat, David Itzkoff, one of The Timess culture reporters, takes a look at the latest concert in the White House music series. The concert, called In Performance at the White House: A Celebration of Music from the Civil Rights Movement, will take place on Feb. 11 in the State Dining Room, and is timed to celebrate Black History Month. Read more on ArtsBeat.

title: China Leads Better-Than-Expected Global Recovery
description: WASHINGTON  The global recovery has been more vigorous than expected, led by 10 percent growth in China, the International Monetary Fund said Tuesday. But the recovery in developed economies will be weak by historical standards, with continued high unemployment, and will probably slow next year, the fund said.

title: The Prison Conditions for the Three Hikers
description: With the city of Berkeley set to decide Tuesday evening whether to send a letter to the Iranian government asking for the release of three graduates of the University of California, Berkeley, new details are emerging about the circumstances of their imprisonment  some of it in solitary confinement  in Irans Evin prison.

title: Sidewalk Reading
description: I took a new route to work this morning: instead of my usual walk down 42nd Street and through Bryant Park, I shifted one block south  and discovered a whole new world. Like what, you say? Well, I found a new favorite place for hot chocolate (Lily OBriens, on West 40th Street), but thats not why Im writing: Do other New Yorkers know about the Library Walk on East 41st Street? Its a series of brass plaques set into the sidewalk as you approach the main library, each decorated with a literary quotation and a related artwork. For instance, an image of sunlight streaming through the reading rooms windows appears on one plaque along with this quotation, from Alfred Kazins New York Jew:

title: Strange Bedfellows Seek Generous Distributor
description: So while everybody who was anybody at Sundance was still buzzing about Lisa Cholodenkos The Kids Are All Right,  If anything happens to the people in this room, there goes the independent film world, the festivals director, John Cooper, said during his introduction  the Bagger was en route to the premiere of another big screening, our hometown favorite The Extra Man.

title: Hyundai Drives for Super Bowl Superiority
description: The automotive bowl to be played inside the Super Bowl on Feb. 7 looks to be a competitive one, as six car brands will vie for viewer attention and consideration. One marque, Hyundai, is shaping up as perhaps the brand to beat.

title: Pence Wont Run for Senate in Indiana
description: Representative Mike Pence, the No. 3 Republican in the House, will run for re-election this year rather than challenge Senator Evan Bayh, the Indiana Democrat.

title: Congresss Team: Deal for Merger Included Saints
description: The Saints advance to the Super Bowl has been a lesson in patience. New Orleans has hosted the Super Bowl nine times, but the Saints have never played in one since entering the N.F.L. in 1967. Carol Channing made it to the Super Bowl twice, as a halftime entertainer, each time at Tulane Stadium, the first home of the Saints.

title: Schooling the Aging Brain
description: What if older people who volunteered to work in elementary schools, in a program that bolstered educational progress for children, could at the same time reduce their own risk of cognitive decline? Talk about a win-win.

title: Favre Inspires Puzzlement and Pity
description: With the parties in Indianapolis and New Orleans winding down, with fans in New York and Minneapolis canceling their orders for the six-foot sandwich two weeks hence, and Saints tailback Reggie Bush spending Monday wearing his two-hours-of-sleep sunglasses, the only place still whooping it up might have been Favre-loving, Favre-hating Green Bay.

title: Gimme! Gimme! Gimme! (An Abba Museum)
description: To our minds, an Abba theme park should be an experience thats so ridiculously fun youre ashamed to tell your friends you actually enjoy it. The organizers behind Abbaworld, a new museum/theme park dedicated to the lives and work of that best-selling Swedish pop quartet, have something a little more reverential in mind: The Associated Press reported that Abbaworld, scheduled to open in London on Wednesday, will offer 25 rooms and more than 30,000 square feet of Abba-related fare, chronicling the ascent of Bjorn Ulvaeus, Anna-Frid Lyngstad, Benny Andersson and Agnetha Faltskog from their teenage years to the present day. Amid the displays of silk, satin and spandex costumes, visitors are also promised re-creations of the bands recording studio and the seaside cabin where Mr. Ulvaeus and Mr. Andersson composed many of the bands hits; an exhibition that allows aspiring performers to sing and dance alongside an animated version of the band; and an audio guide recorded by Stellan Skarsgard, the Swedish actor who starred in the film version of Mamma Mia! Magnus Danielsson, the president of Touring Exhibitions, the company behind the museum, told The A.P. that the guiding principle behind its design was,How do we give the visitor a big hug in each room? He added that he was a big Abba fan growing up, but switched to hard rock when he changed schools.

title: Holiday Inn to Use Humans as Bed Warmers
description: File this travel tip under creepy. According to an article from Reuters, Holiday Inn will offer a trial human bed-warming service at three British hotels this month.

title: President Plans Own Panel on the Debt
description: WASHINGTON  Advocates of more aggressive steps to address the national debt failed Tuesday in their effort to create a bipartisan commission to press for tax increases and spending cuts, but President Obama now plans to establish a similar panel by executive order in his State of the Union address on Wednesday.

description: January has been a tumultuous month for the New York City school system, but no moment is likely to be more contentious than Tuesday night, when a panel will decide the fate of 19 schools scheduled for closing.

title: When the Insurer Says No More
description: Though it may be the only way forward for President Obamas top domestic priority, it is not clear that House Democrats can be induced to pass the Senate health care legislation. Though the House and Senate bills are alike in many ways, there are Senate provisions that many House Democrats simply cant swallow, according to the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi  provisions that might fuel voter outrage of the sort so vividly on on display in Massachusetts.

title: G.M. Strikes Deal to Sell Saab to Spyker

title: Tapping Methane at Lake Kivu in Africa
description: Beneath the surface of Africas 1,500-foot deep Lake Kivu, which borders Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of Congo, large deposits of methane and carbon dioxide have long intrigued researchers  and energy developers.

title: Correction
description: An earlier version of this article misstated the number of publishers that have created mockups of their magazines for tablet computers. At least three - Hearst, Cond Nast and Time - not two, have created the mockups.

title: Dungeons & Dragons Prison Ban Upheld
description: Prisons can restrict the rights of inmates to nerd out, a federal appeals court has found.

title: A Tale Of Two SOTUs
description: In 1982 Ronald Reagan gave his first State of the Union address. His approval rating was about the same as Barack Obamas now. His economic track record was considerably worse: instead of presiding over the end of a recession, he had presided over the beginning of one, and the economy was in free fall. Nonetheless, Reagan mounted an unapologetic defense of his economic ideology, combined with a harsh critique of his precedecessors.

title: Target Stops Selling Farmed Salmon
description: The retail chain Target announced on Tuesday that its food stores will stop selling farmed salmon.

description: From his privileged  and lofty  perch in the Australian Open semifinals, Marin Cilic of Croatia has already looked back on his past and learned.

title: Juvenile Offenders Shackled Illegally, Judge Rules

description: The Internal Revenue Service said on Tuesday that it would require large corporations to reveal basic information about their tax transactions, a surprise move intended to root out questionable or illegal tax shelters.

title: The Nifty Fifty | Rye Rye, Musician
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Latest Italian Food Fraud Charge Involves Mozzarella
description: Italys agriculture minister said he had disbanded the consortium of producers which guarantees buffalo mozzarella quality after routine inspections had shown that even mozzarella produced by Luigi Chianese, the consortiums president, had been watered down with cows milk, The Times of London reports.

title: The Morning Skate: Will Hockey Heed the Message of Cormiers Ban?
description: If the suspension of Patrice Cormier for the balance of the Q.M.J.H.L. season by the league commissioner Gilles Courteau is supposed to send a message to players in all three Canadian major junior leagues that head shots must stop, the columnist Wayne Scanlan of the Ottawa Citizen, for one, is highly skeptical.

title: Emotions Run High in Police Assault Case
description: As court got under way Tuesday morning, a defense lawyer, Stuart London, greeted Michael Mineo, who is testifying that he was sodomized by a police officer who was arresting him.

title: Deficit Projection Fuels Blame Game
description: The Congressional Budget Office on Tuesday projected a federal deficit of $1.35 trillion this year, prompting top Democratic budget-makers in Congress to lash out  at the Bush administration.

title: But How Big Is the Garage?
description: PHOENIX  So you raised your hand a few more times than you anticipated during the Arizona classic car auction week and youre going home with more cars than your garage can hold. Maybe its time to move.

title: Revisiting the Value of Vinny Testaverde
description: Vinny Testaverde should be a Hall of Famer?

title: OConnor Mildly Criticizes Courts Campaign Finance Decision
description: Retired Justice Sandra Day OConnor offered some thoughts this morning about whats been going on here at the Supreme Court.

title: Same-Sex Marriage Case, Day 11: Churches
description: The Bay Area blog has been reporting daily from the federal courthouse in San Francisco on the case of Perry v. Schwarzenegger. That case is challenging the constitutionality of Proposition 8, the ban on same-sex marriage approved by voters in 2008. Among the lawyers on the plaintiffs team are Theodore B. Olson, David Boies, Theodore J. Boutrous Jr., Christopher Dean Dusseault, Christine Van Aken, Danny Chu, Matthew D. McGill and Therese Stewart. The legal team for the defense includes Brian Raum, Charles J. Cooper, David Thompson, Andrew Pugno, James Campbell, Jordan Lorence, Nicole Moss, Howard C. Nielson Jr. and Peter A. Patterson.

title: A Terrible Game, but Not a Reason to Panic
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  It has been a while since anyone in the Knicks hierarchy felt compelled to issue a broad proclamation of utter disdain. Circumstances pushed Donnie Walsh over the edge Monday afternoon.

title: Sri Lankans Vote in Contentious Election
description: As voters streamed to the polls in Sri Lankas first election since the defeat of the Tamil Tiger insurgency, the Tamil vote was considered important to the outcome.

title: The Next Bills Bar and Burger Will Be Huge
description: Stephen Hanson plans to make the Bills Bar and Burger opening this spring in Rockefeller Center the largest independent burger restaurant in the country. He and his team at B.R. Guest Restaurants have reconfigured the floor plan for the two-story space, formerly Tuscan Square, so that it will have room for 563 seats instead of 330.

title: Banks to Pitch the Wonders of Overdraft
description: Starting in July, banks wont let you overdraw your checking account unless you raise your hand and give them explicit permission. So unless you opt in, you wont be able to spend more than you have in the bank when using your debit card to make a one-time purchase at a store or withdraw more than your balance from an A.T.M. machine.

title: Sundance 2010 | The Big Bing
description: How do you get to Sundance? Perseverance, perspiration and, if possible, private jets: on Sunday Bill Pullman and Jessica Alba blew in from the left coast on a tiny aircraft to attend the premiere of Michael Winterbottoms The Killer Inside Me, which was certainly one way of skirting the weather problems that kept many so many grounded in cities like Los Angeles and Phoenix. As a result, people have for days been trickling in to American cinemas annual indie bacchanal, and when they finally got here, they found more snow in Park City, Utah, than during any Sundance in years  a constant, muted downfall that didnt let up until Sunday but that certainly didnt stop the hordes of stockingless young women clad in miniskirts and stilettos from swarming into the mush-and-ice covered downtown. Mardi Gras beads were strewn all over Main Street on Sunday morning, which was probably a metaphor for something. But the fact that so much of the festival has nothing to do with movies is a pretty straightforward statement about what Sundance has become  namely, a brand to be readily exploited by whoever wants to set up shop and give away medicated lip gloss. Still, there are pearls among the swine.

title: Rare Spirits Borne on Vodkas Back
description: UKIAH, Calif.

title: Holden Signs Short-Term Contract With Bolton
description: Stuart Holden was eager to explore opportunities overseas. When I spoke to him in December, he said that he was exploring options in Europe but wanted to make sure he found the right fit.

title: Humor for Haiti?
description: The last thing anyone would associate with the earthquake in Haiti is humor and it remains an open question whether a line will be crossed at a benefit for disaster relief efforts on Wednesday night at the comedy club Carolines on Broadway.

title: NBCs Gaspin Talks About Emotion of Late-Night Changes
description: Jeff Gaspin, the chairman of NBC Universal Television Entertainment, said Tuesday that he underestimated the level of emotion that the networks late-night changes provoked.

title: Police Cameras at Protest Draw Protest
description: Updated, 6:12 p.m. | They fought for the right to protest in front of the mayors house and nearly beat City Hall.

title: Parliament Awaits Burqa Ban Report
description: A French parliament report called for a ban on the full Islamic veil in schools, hospitals, public transport and government offices.

title: Now Boarding: The Greatest Train Movies
description: Forget about the Golden Globes and never mind the Oscars  the years most important film honors have been compiled, at least from the perspective of people who know that the St. Louis Car Co. built 400 model R17 train cars between 1955 and 1956.

title: Lincoln and Bayh Vow to Oppose Budget Reconciliation
description: In a sign of how hard it is for Democrats to regroup on major health care legislation, two centrist Democratic senators said on Tuesday that they would oppose efforts to muscle through a bill using a procedural tactic called budget reconciliation.

title: Students See a Creek and Imagine a Bridge for VW
description: In Germany, Volkswagen is known for innovative architecture. Audostadt, its theme park in Wolfsburg, has more than a dozen sleek buildings, including a pair of circular glass silos for new cars.

title: Mrs. Obama Promises Aid Increase for Military Families
description: Michelle Obama announced today that President Obamas 2011 budget will propose $8.8 billion in funding for programs to support military families  a 3 percent increase at a time when Mr. Obama is calling for a freeze in spending on many non-defense domestic programs.

title: Specter Feels Squeeze From New Friends and Old
description: DOYLESTOWN, Pa.  It seems either a cruel or fitting twist. Senator Arlen Specter left the Republican Party last year and became a Democrat to save his political career. Now, at 79, he suddenly finds that the party he switched into may not provide a safe haven.

title: Correction: 36 Hours Tucson
description: The 36 Hours column on Jan. 3 about Tucson misstated the location of a shopping center, the Plaza Palomino. It is north of downtown, not in downtown.

title: Is This the Right Room for an Argument?
description: Michael Palin asked that question nearly 40 years ago on Monty Pythons Flying Circus, and its as germane as ever in considering the merits and drawbacks to blogging, and particularly the comment strings following posts.

title: Ford Is Taking Explorer to Land of Lincoln
description: The Ford Explorer, that one-time king of sport utility vehicles, is being downsized and transferred.

title: Attending Super Bowl Roused Boozer to Help Jets Win One
description: How will the Jets respond to Sundays lopsided loss to Indianapolis in the American Football Conference championship game?

title: Shipping Luggage Can Be Cheaper Than Checking
description: As airlines continue to raise fees for checking baggage, passengers are turning to shipping services.

title: Star Fishing | Celebrities at Sea
description: A peek at some of this winters bold-face Caribbean beach bunnies.

title: China Raises Bank Reserve Rules, Starting Stock Sell-Off
description: BEIJING  Asian markets sagged Tuesday amid concerns that China was reining in credit and might raise interest rates to curb rising inflation.

title: Los Angeles Marijuana Sellers Limited
description: LOS ANGELES  The City Council approved an ordinance on Tuesday that would shutter the majority of the nearly 1,000 medical marijuana dispensaries in Los Angeles and make the use of marijuana in the remaining outlets illegal.

title: Sheets and Nady Find Homes; Damon Is Still Out There
description: An opening day starting outfielder for the 2009 Yankees finally signed a free agent contract on Tuesday. But no, it wasnt Johnny Damon. It was Xavier Nady, who is now a Chicago Cub. Nady agreed to a one-year deal worth $3.3 million.

title: Editors Choice
description: CRISIS AND COMMAND: The History of Executive Power From George Washington to George W. Bush,  by John Yoo (Kaplan, $29.95.) The former Bush administration lawyer finds appeal in a presidency whose power is typically expanded in a time of war.

title: On the Issues: Predicting and Responding to the State of the Union Address
description: Post-Speech Update | January 28  Have your students respond to the State of the Union address through our Student Opinion question, or use these additional Times resources to examine the speech and the reaction to it.

title: Gaming the Luggage System
description: ON a recent Delta flight from Westchester County, in New York, to Columbus, Ohio, Gregg Hamilton, a retired real estate agent, was determined not to pay to check his bag. But he didnt want to deal with the usual carry-on kerfuffle either: bolting toward the gate to be among the first to board, racing up and down the aisle to find a spot for his bag and trying to create space in the already-jammed overhead bins. Instead he, and a handful of others, avoided that mess entirely by taking advantage of an apparent loophole in the system: the gate check.

title: Talk of a Bridge Extension on Broadway
description: Amid strong reviews from critics on Monday and $500,000 in ticket sales that same day, the Broadway revival of A View From the Bridge is now awash in Rialto chatter about a possible extension beyond its April 4 closing date, after which its theater, the Cort, is scheduled to go to the revival of August Wilsons Fences.

title: F. Murray Abraham: Action Hero
description: The real drama was offstage at Monday nights rehearsal reading of Much Ado About Nothing at the Classic Stage Company, after a member of the audience rose and wandered in the direction of the actors dressing rooms while the performers were working on the piece.

title: For Night Riders, Finding Peace on Sleepy Streets
description: There are days  sometimes ten a month  when Steve Vaccaro finds himself in the saddle well past midnight. A lawyer in Midtown, Mr. Vaccaro, 44, commutes by bike to and from his Upper East Side apartment, even when work keeps him in the office until early the next morning.

title: Paperback Row
description: EVERYTHING RAVAGED, EVERYTHING BURNED,  by Wells Tower (Picador, $14.) The protagonists of these nine polished and distinctive stories, as our reviewer, Edmund White, called them, are men who are older, battered, no longer successful. (In the story Retreat, they are sad, paunchy hordes . . . nightly pacing carpeted apartments from Spokane to Chattanooga.) White praised Towers remarkable style: his grasp of psychology, crisp dialogue and supple syntax, and his dark, surrealistic vision of American life.

title: Google Voice Is Back on the iPhone, Mostly
description: Google Voice (formerly GrandCentral) has always been beyond awesome. Imagine: You pick out a new phone number. Anytime your friends call that number, all your phones ring at once: cell, home, work. One number to rule them all. People dont have to chase you down anymore. (I left a message for you on your cellIll try you at home)

title: Canadians Give Generously to Haiti
description: Updated | Wednesday While almost 90 million Americans tuned in to a celebrity telethon for Haiti on Friday, and donated more than $61 million, about 6 million Canadians watched one of two similar telethons broadcast the same night and donated nearly $20 million.

title: The Nifty 50 | Gary Carrion-Murayari, Curator
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: A Preview of the Houses A.I.G. Hearing
description: Ahead of a House committee hearing on Wednesday, more details are emerging about the governments bailout of the American International Group in 2008 and why its trading partners were paid in full.

title: Hoyer Tries a Yogi Berra Take on Jobs
description: With populist outrage apparently pulsing across the land, many Democrats, including President Obama, have acknowledged a need to focus more directly on reducing unemployment and creating new jobs.

title: 'Time Stands Still'
