description: In this excerpt from Donald Margulies's play, Sarah (Laura Linney), a photojournalist wounded while on assignment, talks about her photographs with Mandy (Alicia Silverstone). (Video courtesy of Manhattan Theater Club)

title: New Castle Exec to Plead Guilty in Galleon Case
description: Prosecutors in the insider-trading case centered on the Galleon Group told a federal judge on Tuesday that Mark Kurland had waived an indictment, an indication he intends to plead guilty in the case.

title: Of Slovenly Beards and Smudged Eyeliner
description: There is Oscar bait and there is indie bait. The former skews to sweeping big picture dramas and grand performances; the latter, to intimate, loose slice-of-life stuff (and comedy). Whether the filmmakers intend it or not, its inevitable to find patterns as you race from screening to screening at Sundance. Over at Vanity Fair, Julian Sancton has put together a list of common festival tropes, including dead pets, car accidents and slovenly beards indicating despair.

title: In Defense of Leno
description: Like everyone else, I think Conan OBrien is funnier and more talented than Jay Leno. Like everyone else, I was on OBriens side in his public war with NBC. But that being said, I think Michelle Cottle gets it exactly right in her defense of Leno this week:

title: Cheap Seats: 20at20
description: If you find yourself with no plans one night over the next two weeks and an extra $20 in your pocket, you can see an Off Broadway show for less than the cost of a movie ticket and a large popcorn.

title: Both Sides Making an Issue of Issue Ad on Super Bowl
description: CBS is feeling more heat  from both sides  on its decision to accept a commercial from the evangelical organization Focus on the Family that will run during Super Bowl XLIV on Feb. 7.

title: Four Years After Unlikely Gold, Snowboarder Frieden Retires
description: Switzerlands Tanja Frieden, a gold medalist and the answer to a nifty Olympic trivia question, retired from snowboardcross three weeks before the Vancouver Games.

title: McCaskill on Edwards: Hes Disgusting
description: The McGraw Show on KTRS Radio

title: Youthful Reality, MTV-style
description: MTV and VH1 have a formula: VH1 gets the C-list celebrities; MTV gets the anonymous teenagers and 20-somethings who aspire to be C-list celebrities.

title: Scorecard | Lanvin Wins!
description: Scorecard knows were in the midst of couture week, so the fashion flock has moved on to the frothy and feminine  yet theyve crossed back over to the guys side to file their final reviews from the weekends mens-wear shows, so heres one final one for the gents. At Margiela, where the namesake designer has left his Maison, the rocker-chic vibe failed to impress, while over at Lanvin, Alber Elbaz and Lucas Ossendrijvers not-completely-heteronormative romantic masculinity had the critics going boy crazy.

title: 4 Arrested in Phone Tampering at Landrieu Office
description: NEW ORLEANS  Federal officials charged four men on Tuesday with plotting to tamper with the telephone system in the New Orleans office of Senator Mary Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana. One of the men was a conservative activist who gained fame last year by secretly recording members of the community group Acorn giving him advice on how to set up a brothel.

title: Medical Marijuana Supporters Wonder if Time Has Come
description: New Jersey added a new herb to its state garden last Tuesday when Gov. Jon S. Corzine signed the New Jersey Compassionate Use Medical Marijuana Act on his last day in office.

title: Fox News Tops Cable Ratings
description: The upset Senate victory by a Republican in Massachusetts lifted the Fox News Channel last week to its highest levels in more than a year.

title: Pictures of the Day: Tuesday, Jan. 26
description: Ozier Muhammad of The Times, whose photograph of food recipients in the Cit Soleil district of Port-au-Prince opens Pictures of the Day, has chronicled Harlem for 30 years. His unflinching and affectionate portrait of that community was first published on Lens in May 2009 as Ozier Muhammads Harlem.

title: A Love of Gospel Music, a Wish to Spread It Around
description: Patty Griffins new gospel-infused album, Downtown Church, celebrates what she calls the largely untapped soul of American music. But it also honors one part of a holy trinity of musicians for Ms. Griffin, a singer and songwriter who is more at home in the world of crossing genres than crossing Jordan.

title: Cedar Fairs Mystery: An Investors Game Plan
description: A mystery has arisen around the $2.4 billion acquisition of the amusement park operator Cedar Fair by Apollo Management.

title: Correction: When Hollywood Learned to Talk, Sing and Dance
description: The DVD column on Jan. 17, about the transition from silent movies to talkies, misidentified the composers who wrote songs for the 1927 Broadway musical Rio Rita, which Warner Brothers released as a movie in 1929. The songs were written by Harry Tierney and Joseph McCarthy  not by E. Y. Harburg and Harold Arlen, who wrote some of the music for the 1942 version of the film.

title: Police Find Weapons After N.J. Arrest
description: Police in Branchburg, N.J., found a cache of high-powered weapons and a map of an American military base on Tuesday in the hotel room of a man they has arrested early in the morning for acting suspiciously at a convenience store.

title: Correction: Genuine Actress Flirts With Stardom
description: An article last Sunday about the actress Laura Linney misidentified the state where she attended boarding school. She attended Northfield Mount Hermon in western Massachusetts, not in upstate New York. The article also misidentified the school that Ms. Linney attended with the actress Jeanne Tripplehorn. They attended Juilliard together, not Brown. (Ms. Linney attended Brown.)

title: Correction: Born the Same Year; Similarities End There
description: An article last Sunday that contrasted the careers of the composers Frdric Chopin and Robert Schumann misidentified the key in which Chopin wrote a ballade that he eventually dedicated to Schumann. It was his Ballade in F major  not Ballade in F minor, a piece he wrote years later.

title: King, the Everyman; King, the Moral Leader
description: On a stormy April night in 1968, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. delivered a speech at the Mason Temple in Memphis. He had seen the Promised Land, he said, though admitted, I may not get there with you. Still, he assured his listeners: Im happy tonight. Im not worried about anything. Im not fearing any man.

title: Awards Already Known, Winners Present a Show
description: Christine Ebersole, described as the Meryl Streep of cabaret, was named outstanding cabaret vocalist in a major engagement at the New York Nightlife Awards on Monday evening at Town Hall. Accompanied on piano by John Oddo, the winsome, curly-headed Broadway star, who opens a new show at the Caf Carlyle next week, sang a bright, skys-the-limit The Music That Makes Me Dance, from Funny Girl.

title: Comment of the Week
description: No matter how objective you purport to make the rating criteria, there will inevitably be arbitrary and capricious interpretation that is incomprehensible to anyone outside the locked room where the censors made their decision.

title: Life, Death and Family in Footes Texas
description: Nobody in Harrison, Tex., needs to ask for whom the bell tolls. Not, at least, in 1918, the year that gives the title to the opening work in the reverberant final installment of Horton Footes Orphans Home Cycle at the Peter Norton Space on West 42nd Street.

title: Biden Holds Out Little Hope for Jobs Rate to Ease Quickly
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. predicted today that the economy would begin adding jobs by spring, but he held out little hope of pushing unemployment back down anytime soon to where it was in the middle of last year.

title: Lines and Tempers as Haitians Queue for Cash
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Thousands of Haitians lined up at money transfer offices here on Tuesday, crowding windows and arguing with the police as they waited as long as 10 hours to collect small cash infusions wired from relatives abroad.

title: Wrestling With Nature
description: The title story of T. Coraghessan Boyles new collection, Wild Child, is a fictional retelling of the life of Victor, the Wild Boy of Aveyron, born to a peasant family in revolutionary France under an unhappy star. His early hindrances include muteness, a lax mind and an unsympathetic stepmother, who, when Victor is 5 years old, leads him to the forest and slits his throat. Still, it was enough, Boyle writes in one of this storys wealth of haunting moments. His blood drew steam from the leaves and he lay there in a shrunken, skeletal nest, night coming down and the woman already receding into the trees.

title: Cold Snap Hits the Forest of Arden: Lovebirds Are Shivering
description: The deep freeze enveloping New York and much of the rest of the country over the past month apparently extended all the way to Shakespeares Forest of Arden. Biting cold at times threatens to smother the biting wit in Sam Mendess tough-minded, wintry new production of As You Like It, which opened on Tuesday night at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, as the first show in the Bridge Projects second season.

title: Q&A: A Saturday in Beirut
description: Q.

title: In the Bronx, Waiting for Jobs That Never Came
description: The Bronx leads the city in unemployment  which may explain why among some jobless men it led them to be led on.

title: Dont Look Back | Downtown Pix at the Grey Art Gallery
description: It was with trepidation that I visited Downtown Pix, the Grey Art Gallerys show of photographs drawn mostly from the Downtown Collection at New York Universitys Fales Library, an archive documenting the creative ferment below 14th Street from 1975 to the present. This past year was, after all, the one in which I finally moved uptown, after having pledged allegiance for most of my adult life to the cultural crucible of Lower Manhattan. From my current perch, in exile on the Upper East Side, how would the stomping grounds of my youth appear to me?

title: Coffins Emblem Defies Certainty
description: When the remains of hundreds of colonial-era Africans were uncovered during a building excavation in Lower Manhattan in 1991, one coffin in particular stood out. Nailed into its wooden lid were iron tacks, 51 of which formed an enigmatic, heart-shaped design.

title: Drinkability Lands in the Drink as Bud Light Changes Plays for Super Bowl
description: Dont look for Bud Light commercials during Super Bowl XLIV on Feb. 7 to be centered on drinkability, an attribute that the beer brand has spent more than a year promoting.

title: White House Plans Civil Rights Concert
description: Bob Dylan; Jennifer Hudson, near right; and Smokey Robinson, far right, are among the artists who will participate in the White Houses first music event of 2010, according to a news release on Tuesday. The concert, In Performance at the White House: A Celebration of Music From the Civil Rights Movement, will be held on Feb. 11 in the State Dining Room, and is timed to celebrate Black History Month. Other performers on the bill include Natalie Cole, John Legend, John Mellencamp, Seal, the Blind Boys of Alabama and the Howard University Choir. It will be hosted by Morgan Freeman and Queen Latifah. The concert is the latest event in a music series started last year by Michelle Obama, and will be broadcast on public television and streamed live online at whitehouse.gov.

title: A Revival Is Seeking a Few Good Stars
description: The Broadway producer Ken Davenport and the director David Esbjornson are on the hunt for a star actor to play the lead in a planned revival of Aaron Sorkins breakthrough play, A Few Good Men, which they are aiming for Broadway next season. With an increasingly high premium put on casting stars for Broadway revivals to help sell tickets, an executive involved in the casting process said on Tuesday that Mr. Davenport (Oleanna, 13) and Mr. Esbjornson (The Goat, or Who Is Sylvia?) had begun scouting star talent for the role of Lt. Daniel Kaffee, a Navy lawyer who investigates a murder at the Guantnamo Bay Naval Base in Cuba. Tom Hulce played the part in the original 1989 production  and was nominated for a Tony Award for best actor  and Tom Cruise played Kaffee in the 1992 film. This would be the first revival of the play since it closed at the Music Box Theater on Jan. 26, 1991.

title: A To-Do at Much Ado
description: The real drama was offstage at Monday nights rehearsal reading of Much Ado About Nothing at the Classic Stage Company, after an audience member rose and wandered toward the actors dressing rooms while the performers were working on the piece. According to executives involved with Classic Stage Company, an Off Broadway house in the East Village, the actor F. Murray Abraham, who was in the audience, noticed the man slipping out. Mr. Abraham, above, got up and spoke to the house manager, and the two of them went backstage and found the man hiding under a table in a dressing room. The house manager shouted that a robbery was under way, while Mr. Abraham and the man scuffled, with the intruder punching Mr. Abraham. Cast members ran backstage as the intruder fled; in the aftermath, company members discovered that a bag belonging to the actress Martha Plimpton  who was participating in the reading  was missing, as well as the wallet of another actress. The police were soon on the scene and are investigating. Mr. Abraham did not require medical attention, only a bag of ice.

title: Fox Continues Its Winning Streak
description: One night after Fox drew a record 57.9 million viewers for its N.F.L. playoff coverage, the largest audience for a conference championship in 28 years, House and 24 lifted that network to No. 1 in Mondays primetime ratings as well. According to Nielsens estimates, 14.2 million viewers tuned in to Fox at 8 p.m. for House, making it the nights top-rated show. At 9, 24 drew a more modest 10.7 million, enough to ensure Foxs overall lead, but fewer than CBSs comedy reruns in the hour, Two and a Half Men (12.1 million) and The Big Bang Theory (11.5 million). Foxs 24 also trailed the second half of ABCs reality show The Bachelor, which earned 11.1 million viewers from 8 to 10. ABC finished the runner-up, garnering 10.5 million at 10 for Castle, which outperformed CBSs repeat of CSI: Miami (9.6 million) in the same time slot. CBS ranked third for the night, followed by NBC with its lineup of Chuck at 8 (6.9 million), Heroes at 9 (4.3 million) and The Jay Leno Show at 10 (4.3 million).

title: Jacobs Pillow Festival Announces 2010 Lineup
description: Dance artists from around the world will converge in the bucolic Berkshires of Massachusetts for the 78th annual Jacobs Pillow festival this summer. This years festival, which runs from June 19 through Aug. 29, will showcase more than 50 companies from nine countries. Highlights include three world premieres from the young choreographers Kyle Abraham, Monica Bill Barnes and Camille A. Brown, as well as the American debut of the Goteborg Ballet of Sweden. The ballerina Nina Ananiashvili will help open the season at a gala event on June 19 with a performance of The Dying Swan. The gala will also include a world premiere by Karole Armitage. Dance Theater of Harlem, Shantala Shivalingappa, Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, Trey McIntyre Project and Hubbard Street Dance Chicago are among the companies and artists also scheduled to appear throughout the festival.

title: Rice Reveals Details of First Memoir
description: Readers who await Condoleezza Rices reflections on her years in the White House of George W. Bush will have to wait for memoir No. 2: on Tuesday Ms. Rice, left, the former secretary of state and national security adviser, and her publisher, the Crown Publishing Group, said in a statement that the first release in a two-book deal signed by Ms. Rice last February would discuss her childhood in Birmingham, Ala., in the 1950s and 60s against the backdrop of the civil rights movement. The book would also emphasize Ms. Rices role models, including her parents, John and Angelena. In a statement Ms. Rice said: After I left Washington it seemed important to write about how my very special parents, my extended family and so many mentors shaped me for the challenges that lay ahead. I decided that was the story I wanted to tell first.

title: A Crime Novelist Takes on St. Peter
description: The author Walter Mosley specializes in his own kind of flawed Everyman: easy to underestimate, easy to overlook, like the title character from his allegorical 2008 novel, The Tempest Tales. But a new spotlight will fall on Tempest Landry and the other characters from the book as they wrestle with big questions about perceptions of good and evil in Mr. Mosleys first play, The Fall of Heaven, which opens on Thursday at the Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park.

title: He Doth Surpass Himself: Avatar Outperforms Titanic
description: LOS ANGELES  James Camerons science-fiction epic Avatar has passed his Titanic to become historys highest-grossing film, with a sizable boost from higher-priced tickets for 3-D and Imax showings.

title: Sure-Fire Shorting
description: Heres a virtually foolproof way to make money in the stock market.

title: Tablet Mania! Tablet Mania?
description: Personal Technology editor Sam Grobart talks to people in Times Square about the possibility of an Apple tablet.

title: Democrats Put Lower Priority on Health Bill
description: WASHINGTON  With no clear path forward on major health care legislation, Democratic leaders in Congress effectively slammed the brakes on President Obamas top domestic priority on Tuesday, saying they no longer felt pressure to move quickly on a health bill after eight months of setting deadlines and missing them.

title: Should You Shop Around for Title Insurance?
description: Update: New Mexico passed a law last year that allows title companies to compete on price, said Morris J. Chavez, superintendent of Insurance for New Mexico. The superintendent now sets a maximum insurance rate and allows competition under that rate. Before the law went into effect in July, the superintendent set a single rate for all title insurers. Superintendent Chavez said that two title insurance companies are inquiring about the process to offer lower rates.

title: British Central Banker Favors Splitting Big Banks
description: LONDON  Mervyn A. King, the governor of the Bank of England, is an owlish, self-effacing man who, in contrast to his more outspoken peers in Frankfurt and Washington, strikes a public posture that borders on the demure.

title: An Abandoned Milk Depot Becomes a Home
description: When Ken Taylor and Julia Manheim bought an old milk depot in London, the structure had been abandoned on and off for around 30 years.

title: U.S. to Join Talks on Helping Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen  A month after the failed airplane bomb plot that put this countrys problem with Al Qaeda in the international spotlight, the United States and 20 other countries are gathering for a conference on Wednesday in London to discuss ways to address Yemens growing instability.

title: From Dairy Depot to Industrial Chic
description: LONDON  In the late 1990s, when Ken Taylor cycled past an abandoned, asbestos-ridden milk depot just off the high street in the rundown area of Peckham, he saw an opportunity. Over a decade later and after investing around 517,000 pounds ($840,000) in the derelict structure, Mr. Taylor, a freelance architect and founder of the firm Quay 2c, and Julia Manheim, an artist, were showing local school children around their colorful and luminous home for a hands-on lesson in architecture.

title: A Moorish Castle in Grenada
description: A six-bedroom six-and-a-half-bath waterfront castle about 15 minutes from St. George is on the market for $4 million.

title: S.E.C. Cites 2 Funds for Short-Sale Violations
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced on Tuesday two enforcement actions against hedge funds that had profited by shorting stocks just before they bought shares of the same stock in a public offering. The agency said they were the first enforcement actions since a rule against abusive short-selling was strengthened.

title: House Hunting in ... Grenada
description: A SIX-BEDROOM SIX-AND-A-HALF-BATH WATERFRONT CASTLE

title: In Paris, Two Family Affaires
description: Paris

title: When Chocolate and Chakras Collide
description: I DONT condemn/I dont convert.

title: Properties for $250,000
description: Homes in Asheville, N.C., Milton, N.H., and in San Diego.

title: M.T.A. Is Struggling to Complete Security Upgrades
description: After the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority pledged to enact state-of-the-art security measures throughout the New York City transit system, widely considered a potential target for terrorism.

title: One Death in Baghdad
description: Yasser was killed on Monday.

title: What You Get for ... $250,000
description: ASHEVILLE, N.C.

title: Some Teams Start Shedding Salary
description: With the Feb. 18 trade deadline now less than a month away, teams are beginning to make moves toward achieving their goals. Only a few teams are looking to load up on talent in preparation for this years playoffs  many of the remaining teams are already looking to the future. Some of these teams are trying to shed salary to increase the amount they can offer an A-List free agent this summer. Others are making moves motivated entirely by financial considerations.

title: S.E.C. Cites 2 Funds for Shorting Violations
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced Tuesday enforcement actions against two California hedge funds that had profited by shorting stocks just before they purchased shares of the same stocks in public offerings, The New York Timess Floyd Norris reports. The agency said they were the first enforcement actions since a rule against abusive short-selling was strengthened.

title: Chinese Legal Experts Propose Ban on Eating Cats and Dogs
description: A group of Chinese legal experts has proposed that the government  ban the eating of cats and dogs, according to The Guardian.

title: Fantasy Intrudes on Costume Design Race
description: The Costume Designers Guild, which announced its nominees on Tuesday, breaks down its awards into three categories  fantasy, period, and contemporary. (Dont you wish your job could be broken down that way? Oh, Ive got a meeting up on fantasy today. Wheres my cape?)

title: Bipartisan Group of Senators Bands Together on Terrorism Trials
description: The fallout from the Democratic loss in Massachusetts is being felt in big ways on Capitol Hill, evidenced this week by, for example, the Obama administrations proposed federal spending freeze. But its also showing itself in more nuanced fashion as Democrats reposition themselves in the changing political environment.

title: Toyota Halts Sales of 8 Models in U.S. for Pedal Flaw
description: Toyota Motor, still struggling to resolve a problem with accelerator pedals, said Tuesday that it would temporarily stop building and selling eight models, including the popular Camry and Corolla sedans, in the North American market.

title: A Singer Who Stopped His Showing Off
description: Offstage Bill Withers, the eternal hero of karaoke baritones, exhibits the same gift for aphorism and general soulfulness that informed hit songs like Lean on Me and Aint No Sunshine. This makes much of the biographical documentary Still Bill pleasant and even moving. Looking out the window of a car, pondering his place in the culture, Mr. Withers says: I think Im kind of like pennies. You have em in your pocket but you dont remember theyre there.

title: NASA to Review Human Spaceflight
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is preparing for a major evaluation of its human spaceflight program, even as many who will conduct the survey have yet to be informed of the agencys revised mission.

title: The Quarrel Over Bernanke
description: Updated, 6:10 p.m. | The Senate voted on Thursday to give Ben Bernanke a second term as chairman of the Federal Reserve.

title: Reviving Phoenix Through Art
description: BOARDED-UP buildings and empty lots in the shadow of office towers hardly seemed a promising foundation for an arts district in rapidly growing Phoenix. But once-neglected and dangerous Roosevelt Row, on the north side of downtown, turned out to be an irresistible lure for artists looking for cheap spaces in which to live and work. Galleries, restaurants and a farmers market soon followed.

title: One Noodle at a Time in Tokyo
description: NOT far from Waseda University in Tokyo, around the corner from a 7-Eleven, down a tidy alley, lies a ramen shop that doesnt look like a ramen shop. In fact, Ganko, as its called, doesnt look like anything at all. Theres no sign, no windows, only a raggedy black tarp set like a tent against a tiled wall, with a white animal bone dangling from a chain to signal (somehow) what lies within.

title: A Long Road to World-Class Fly Fishing in New Zealand
description: IN Gore, a town of 12,500 on the South Island of New Zealand, street signs proclaim that the visitor has arrived in the world capital of brown trout. To reinforce the point, town officials have erected a huge sculpture of the fish in a grassy park halfway between the towns bustling main business street and the Mataura River, a world-famous brown trout stream a quarter-mile away.

title: In Paris, Art Fills the Void
description: ON the Rue de Rivoli, one building stands out amid the busy boutiques and department stores. Inside a colorful interior, the place buzzes with shoppers and tourists  and young people covered in paint.

title: Big Gorilla or Underdog?
description: This is the ultimate underdog story, the Fox co-chairman Tom Rothman said Tuesday. He was talking about Avatar knocking off Titanic as the highest-grossing movie in history (not adjusting for inflation), with $1.86 billion in worldwide ticket sales, after just over five weeks in theaters.

title: Roll Over, Elvis. Meet Indie Memphis.
description: ITS hard to shake Elvis in Memphis. His pompadoured, crooning visage peers out from all corners, from jukeboxes to diner counters. But the King was nowhere to be found at Electrocity, a semi-legal warehouse party that was recently held in an unheated garage in the citys energetic Midtown neighborhood.

title: 36 Hours in Buenos Aires
description: CONTEMPORARY Argentine history is a roller coaster of financial booms and cracks, set to gripping political soap operas. But through all the highs and lows, one thing has remained constant: Buenos Airess graceful elegance and cosmopolitan cool. This attractive city continues to draw food lovers, design buffs and party people with its riotous night life, fashion-forward styling and a favorable exchange rate. Even with the uncertain economy, the creative energy and enterprising spirit of Porteos, as residents are called, prevail  just look to the growing ranks of art spaces, boutiques, restaurants and hotels.

title: Guarding an Ethnic Fault Line in Iraq
description: American soldiers are working together with Arab and Kurdish troops at a series of new checkpoints.

title: Egypt Also Tries to Restrict Veils
description: As French legislators wrestle with the thorny idea of banning full facial veils in government offices, public hospitals and aboard public trains and buses, it may comfort them to know that the issue is also causing headaches for officials in Egypt, where a partial ban on the niqab  which covers a womans entire face except for her eyes  was overturned last week by a court in Cairo.

title: Small Specialties, Savory and Sweet
description: Pichet Ongs talent flowered with Asian-style desserts at Spice Market. But at Village Tart he oversees more familiar temptations, both savory and sweet, including little bacon-topped pizzas, flaky quiches, Parmesan breadsticks, jewel-like glazed tartlets, cookies and cakes to eat at a counter or to take away. A dining room will be in full swing on Feb. 1. Mr. Ong, above left, is the consulting baker; Janina Amezcua, above right, the executive chef.

title: North Korea Keeps Hiding, and Fascinating
description: Computers are rare in North Korea, and the Internet, for most of its citizens, is little more than a whispered rumor. Its probable, in fact, that only one person surfs the Web in North Korea without someone monitoring every click: Kim Jong-il, that authoritarian regimes supreme leader.

title: Nothing to Envy
description: Chapter 1

title: The Cleanest Race
description: Preface

title: Excerpt: 'The Inbetweeners'
description: The new BBC America comedy follows four British teens.

title: Hammami in Bin Laden Tape
description: Omar Hammami is seen training fighters inside Somalia.

title: Le Caprice
description: IN London, the restaurant called Le Caprice holds a place somewhere between our Michaels, the news media hub on East 55th Street, and the Sardis of old in the theater district. It is not so much a restaurant as a club.

title: Lost: Jacob and the Man in Black
description: The two mystical figures appear to have been engaged in an epic battle on the island for centuries.

title: No Rush on Health Care Overhaul, Democrats Say
description: With no clear path forward on major health care legislation, Democratic leaders in Congress effectively slammed the brakes on President Obamas top domestic priority on Tuesday, saying that they no longer felt pressure to move quickly on a health bill after eight months of setting deadlines and missing them.

title: The Afghan Leaders Hat, Always More Than Just Headgear, Is Losing Its Cachet
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  It once attracted the admiration of trendsetters in the West, the jests of comedians at home and abroad, and the somewhat impotent ire of animal rights advocates.

title: The New Old Way to Tote Your Beer
description: BY midafternoon on a recent Saturday, Bierkraft, the beer emporium and grocery on Fifth Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn, was half-filled with customers, many of them parents with babies or toddlers in tow. They were browsing the more than 1,000 varieties of bottled beer or surveying the listing of selections available on the 13 taps and 3 cask lines. Some carried a good-sized satchel.

title: Paulson Distances Himself From A.I.G. Payments
description: Former Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. has a very direct message for the House committee investigating the bailout of the American International Group: Dont blame me for paying about 100 cents on the dollar to A.I.G.s trading partners to unwind tens of billions of dollars in credit default swaps.

title: Szechuan Chalet
description: IF the corner slice joint had brought in a pizzaiolo and brick oven from Naples, it wouldnt have been as surprising as hearing that the Sichuan place on Second Avenue and 73rd Street was actually good.

title: Tingling East Side Tongues
description: The $25 and Under review this week is of Szechuan Chalet on the Upper East Side. Thats never been a neighborhood noted for its authentic Asian cuisine. Previous tenants in the restaurants space had served the usual mild, gummy dishes that all too often passes for Sichuan cooking. But like a few other places in New York, Szechuan Chalet presents some real Sichuan flavor. Have you been there? Have you been to Sichuan? Do you have a favorite Sichuan restaurant or even a favorite neighborhood Chinese restaurant?

title: Chicken Tonight
description: To the Editor:

title: Not the Usual (but Original) Drink
description: One sip and you might think this dark, potent, aromatic drink was an Italian digestive. But Root is an American original. Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction, a Philadelphia collective of craftsmen and artists, resuscitated an early American recipe for alcoholic root tea. Root tea was eventually tamed as nonalcoholic root beer by Charles Hires of Philadelphia.

title: Restaurants Reboot at Reality-Show Speed
description: LAST Saturday afternoon at the Cooper Square Hotel on the Bowery, some 60 staffers sat down for a marathon tasting orchestrated by the chef Scott Conant, who will soon open a new restaurant called Faustina there. Amid the aroma of fresh paint, the whine of a circular saw, and the sight of artisans applying silver gilt to various surfaces, Faustinas waiters and dishwashers sampled olive-oil-poached sardines, veal porterhouse steaks and tajarin pasta with tomato and sea urchin (which Mr. Conant described as sex in a bowl).

title: Unchained: Replicating Restaurant Dishes at Home
description: IM not a regular consumer of fast food, but Ive always liked the idea behind the Eat This, Not That series by the editor of Mens Health, David Zinczenko. These books give menu guidance to the angels and devils perched on the shoulders of the millions of Americans who eat at chain restaurants. For example, at Arbys, they recommend you eat the evil-sounding Bacon Cheddar Roastburger, a roast beef sandwich with 440 calories, 18 grams of fat and 1,427 milligrams of sodium and not the more benign-sounding Ultimate BLT Market Fresh Sandwich with 779 calories, 45 grams of fat and 1,571 milligrams sodium.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening This Week

title: Dining Calendar
description: Roll Out the Barrel

title: The Way We Eat
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lift to Any Can
description: This blue whale can opener (which also comes in black) is not only winsome, but is also a clever and effective tool. The best part is that there are no dangerous sharp edges left on the can or the lid.

title: The Hidden People of North Korea
description: Working for Oneself

title: M.T.A. Short on Security System Cash
description: After the attack of Sept. 11, 2001, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority pledged to enact state-of-the-art security measures throughout the New York City transit system, widely considered a potential target for terrorism.

title: Resignation of the Chief at Borders Adds to Unease About Book Sales
description: Adding to anxiety among publishers about the health of the book market, the Borders Group announced on Tuesday that Ron Marshall had resigned as chief executive just a year after he took the helm of the countrys second-largest bookstore chain.

title: All Eyes on the State of the Union Address
description: What will President Obama say about health care?

title: Baking Swiss Treats Amid Acid Debate
description: WANGEN BEI OLTEN, Switzerland  Bertram Deckers second-floor office in Nestls big food plant here looks out over the towns only minaret, a wooden turret topped with a gilt star and crescent.

title: G.M. Enters Agreement to Sell Saab to Spyker
description: Saab, the Swedish automaker that seemed destined for the junkyard a month ago after its owner, General Motors, said it could not find a buyer, won a new lease on life Tuesday when G.M. agreed to sell Saab to a tiny Dutch maker of high-end sports cars.

title: Lost: Desmond Meets Faraday
description: The meeting in 1996 between the characters confirmed for Faraday the possibility of time travel.

title: Gillibrand Lashes Out at Remarks From Ford
description: Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand sharply objected Tuesday to Harold E. Ford Jr.s characterization of her as a parakeet and accused him of engaging in a fraudulent campaign for her Senate seat.

title: Fine Points
description: To the Editor:

title: Have You Ever Been Had in Clubland?
description: My restaurant review this week is of Le Caprice, a sleek, dark and deco British import that opened in the Pierre hotel in the fall. Its the first American outpost for the tycoon Richard Caring, who has been amassing a portfolio of British clubs and restaurants since around 2005. The restaurant is O.K.  the technical term is fair.

title: Growth in British Economy Suggests End to Recession
description: Britain finally reported positive growth in the final three months of 2009, government data showed Tuesday, after six straight quarters of contraction. The data could signal an end to the recession in Britain.

title: Honduras: Court Clears Military Officers of Charges
description: The Supreme Court cleared six high-ranking military officers on Tuesday of charges of abuse of power in last summers coup. The six, including the armed forces chief of staff, Gen. Romeo Vsquez Velsquez, were accused of illegally expelling President Manuel Zelaya from the country. A court had ordered the military to detain Mr. Zelaya, and the Supreme Court ruled Tuesday that the commanders had not acted with malice and that they had Mr. Zelaya flown to Costa Rica to avoid violence. Mr. Zelayas term ends Wednesday, when he is expected to leave Honduras for the Dominican Republic.

title: Guatemala: Ex-President Arrested on U.S. Warrant
description: The authorities arrested former President Alfonso Portillo on Tuesday on an extradition warrant from the United States, ending his four days on the run. On Monday, federal prosecutors in New York unsealed an indictment charging that Mr. Portillo embezzled tens of millions of dollars during his presidency and laundered at least $6.5 million through American banks. Attorney General Amlcar Velsquez said Mr. Portillo was captured in the beach resort of Punta de Palma, near the border with Belize.

title: Courts as Battlefields in Climate Fights
description: Tiny Kivalina, Alaska, does not have a hotel, a restaurant or a movie theater. But it has a very big lawsuit that might affect the way the nation deals with climate change.

title: With Sun, Oracle Aims at Giants
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Oracle, having spent the last nine months fighting rivals and regulators in order to own Sun Microsystems, has pushed itself into the middle of the scrum of technology heavyweights all jostling for the same corporate customers.

title: When a Grecian Urn Takes a Step Onto the Cosmic Banana Peel
description: One afternoon not too long ago, a truck arrived on Park Avenue, delivering a batch of Impressionist paintings from a familys home in the Hamptons to their apartment in Manhattan. With some but not all of the art unpacked, the lady and man of the house went out for the evening, leaving instructions for their maid to finish up and get rid of the boxes.

title: Offer to Take Over Ailing Hospital Stirs Outcry
description: One of New York Citys largest hospital systems has made an offer to take over the financially struggling St. Vincents Hospital in Greenwich Village, provoking opposition from elected officials who fear the loss of critical medical services, especially emergency care, for tens of thousands of patients who could be sent elsewhere.

title: U.S. Wrestling With Olive Branch for Taliban
description: WASHINGTON  As the Obama administration pours 30,000 additional troops into Afghanistan, it has begun grappling with the next great dilemma of this long war: whether to reconcile with the men who sheltered Osama bin Laden and who still have close ties to Al Qaeda.

title: A Long Farewell to Merce Cunningham
description: It starts in Columbus, Ohio, and ends in Manhattan, on New Years Eve 2011. The Merce Cunningham Dance Company on Wednesday will announce its final tour, meant to give the world a last chance to view the works created by its founder, as performed by the men and women he trained. The modern-dance tour begins on Feb. 12 and wends its way through 35 cities before a final performance at the Park Avenue Armory. Cunningham, who died on July 26, had approved the tour as part of a plan to wind down the companys activities and preserve his legacy. The company will disband afterward. The tour will take it across the United States, to Montreal and then to France, England, Germany and Spain. Eighteen works will be performed, including seven pieces that have long been out of the repertory, the company said. The final New York performances will cost $10 a ticket, according to Cunninghams wishes.

title: A Long Farewell to Merce Cunningham
description: It starts in Columbus, Ohio, and ends in Manhattan, on New Years Eve 2011. The Merce Cunningham Dance Company on Wednesday will announce its final tour, meant to give the world a last chance to view the works created by its founder, as performed by the men and women he trained. The modern-dance tour begins on Feb. 12 and wends its way through 35 cities before a final performance at the Park Avenue Armory. Cunningham, who died on July 26, had approved the tour as part of a plan to wind down the companys activities and preserve his legacy. The company will disband afterward. The tour will take it across the United States, to Montreal and then to France, England, Germany and Spain. Eighteen works will be performed, including seven pieces that have long been out of the repertory, the company said. The final New York performances will cost $10 a ticket, according to Cunninghams wishes.

title: Studies Link Rare Ailment to Pain Pumps
description: When the first cases popped up in orthopedic journals, they read like medical mysteries. Surgeons around the country reported that several active young patients had suddenly developed chondrolysis, a relatively rare ailment in which joint cartilage dies, leaving bone to grind on bone.

title: Mets Are Hoping Perez Will Continue to Follow Santanas Lead
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Johan Santana and Oliver Perez were in the waiting room together at the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan early last September, two left-handed starters taking their turns on the operating table rather than in the rotation.

title: Athletics Roll the Dice and Add Sheets, a Four-Time All-Star, for a Year
description: There will never be a 2009 line on Ben Sheetss career record. A four-time All-Star in his first eight seasons, Sheets spent the season recovering from a torn flexor tendon in his elbow. He never signed a contract.

title: Two at Fed Had Doubts Over Payout by A.I.G.
description: Weeks after rescuing the American International Group with an $85 billion taxpayer loan in late 2008, Federal Reserve Board officials rejected a proposal that would have forced the insurers trading partners to return $30 billion in cash that they had received from A.I.G. in the preceding months.

title: Haitis Children Adrift in World of Chaos
description: CROIX DES BOUQUETS, Haiti  Not long after 14-year-old Daphne Joseph escaped her collapsed house on the day of the earthquake, she boarded a crowded jitney with her uncle and crawled in traffic toward the capital, where her single mother sold beauty products in the Tte Boeuf marketplace. Mama, she said she repeated to herself. Mama, Im coming.

title: After Long Decline, Teenage Pregnancy Rate Rises
description: After more than a decade of declining teenage pregnancy, the pregnancy rate among girls ages 15 to 19 increased 3 percent from 2005 to 2006  a turnaround likely to intensify the debate over federal financing for abstinence-only sex education.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 957 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Ailing Banks Favor Salaries Over Shareholders
description: Finding the winners on Wall Street is usually as simple as looking at pay. Rarely are bankers who lose money paid as generously as those who make it.

title: Coachs Career Risk Keeps Paying Off at St. Johns
description: At 26, Kim Barnes Arico, now the womens basketball coach at St. Johns, faced a career choice.

title: In Speech, Obama to Admit Missteps in First Year
description: WASHINGTON  For all the questions circulating in Democratic quarters as President Obama tries to weather the worst storm of his administration, perhaps none is as succinct as this: Are the missteps at the White House rooted in message or substance?

title: A Cascade of Injuries Tests Nadals Strength
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Last year on the same court, Rafael Nadal was on top of the tennis world, seemingly invincible. He was ranked No. 1 and had won his first Australian Open in a dazzling five-set, four-hour victory over Roger Federer, arguably the greatest player in the world. The match was so wrenching that the usually unflappable Federer broke down in tears. It was Nadal who graciously offered a consoling hug.

title: Salvation (for Newspapers) Is at Hand
description: Last week the debut of my online column for The New York Times (that is, this column) came on the same day that The Times announced its plan to start charging for content. Coincidence?

title: 1,500 Workers in L.I. Diocese Will Receive Buyout Offers
description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre plans to offer buyouts to 1,500 of its 6,000 employees next month as part of a cost-cutting plan to save its schools and parishes amid stagnant revenue and rising demand for charitable services, church officials said Tuesday.

title: Hostile Grilling and Angry Witness Mark Officers Trial in Abuse Case
description: Stuart London, a defense lawyer, wasted little time on pleasantries as he greeted Michael Mineo on the witness stand just after 10 a.m. Tuesday.

title: AllianceBernstein Takes Aim at Novartis Over Alcon
description: AllianceBernstein, the big money manager, isnt usually known for making major public statements. But when it comes to Novartiss proposed takeover of the shares in Alcon it doesnt already own, the gloves are apparently off.

title: Radiation Safety Falls Behind
description: As medical radiation technology advances, a patchwork of regulations does not always protect patients from radiation injury.

title: Martha Stewart Will Shift Show to Hallmark Channel
description: LOS ANGELES  Martha Stewart, the homemaker extraordinaire, announced Tuesday that she would move her daytime television show to the Hallmark Channel cable network beginning in September, where it will open a two-and-a-half hour block of original Martha-related programming each day.

title: Rambis, a ChampionWith the Lakers, Was Briefly a Knick
description: The image resonates instantly with anyone who watched the N.B.A. in the 1980s. The blond, surfer-dude hair, parted in the middle and curling toward the shoulders. The long torso and the calf-high tube socks. The glasses. Of course, the glasses.

title: Lawmakers Hunt for Ways to Rekindle Hiring
description: Legislators are showing renewed interest in proposals for a government subsidy to encourage new hiring. President Obama last month endorsed the idea of a tax incentive for companies that add jobs, and many will be listening for more details in his State of the Union speech Wednesday night.

title: 49 Down: Sword Handle
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Early on, this puzzle seemed as if it was going to be fairly straightforward  phrases composed of anagrams. Weve even seen TEXAS TAXES before. But then it took a nice turn. Each of the the four theme entries involves a state in America. Its like a road trip in search of anagrams, starting in Texas, trekking over to Florida, then up to New York and on to Maine.

title: Judge Bars Youth Prisons From Routine Shackling
description: ALBANY  The agency that runs the states juvenile prison system routinely violates the law by shackling youthful offenders when taking them to court even when the youth poses no obvious threat, a state judge ruled on Tuesday.

title: A Little i to Teach About Online Privacy
description: A LITTLE blue symbol is carrying big implications.

title: Facing Lean Times, but Together Again, in a New Home for the Holiday
description: In accordance with the old Julian calendar, the Russian Orthodox Church celebrates Christmas on Jan. 7. So on Christmas Eve, about three weeks ago, the reunited Shevchenko family  who immigrated from Ukraine to Albany in 2007  had reason to celebrate the relief and security of a new, clean and bedbug-free apartment in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn.

title: Lottery Numbers
Its Midterm Week for Vandy and B.Y.U.
description: Wednesdays top games should prove strong tests for a couple of ranked teams.

title: State of the Union, in Dutch
description: Americans tend to think of the State of the Union as our singular event. But while it is a special night, its not unique. In fact, leaders around the world deliver a yearly address in which they step onto the podium to score points, lay out agendas and offer up a flourish or two. So how does American rhetoric measure up? Read the following excerpts (taken from official transcripts and translations of speeches given in the last few months), listen to the president tonight and then decide.

title: Witnesses Are Gathered Against Chief of Galleon
description: Prosecutors in the widening insider-trading investigation involving the Galleon Group are working to secure new witnesses who could testify against Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire founder of Galleon, and others charged in the case.

title: Chief of Davos Security Dead in Apparent Suicide
description: The Associated Press Markus Reinhardt, the police official in charge of security at the World Economic Forum, was found dead on Tuesday in what authorities have described as a suicide.

title: An Eclectic Bill
description: Jimmy Fallon, The Walkmen, Sondre Lerche, Eugene Mirman, The Wrens, Ted Leo and Pat Kiernan of NY 1. No, it's not some weird only-in-New-York fantasy team, but the partial lineup for "Strength Through Unity," a benefit for the victims of the Haiti earthquake at the Bell House tonight. Also on the eclectic bill will be Michael Showalter, Here We Go Magic, AC Newman of the New Pornographers and Rhett Miller of Old 97s, plus Nicole Atkins as a Seekers cover band, New York State Senator Diane Savino and many more. Go grab an Asian Dog, available all night for $2, and listen to the sets as well as the guest D.J.'s, including Au Revoir Simone, and a special two-hour edition of keyboard karaoke hosted by Joe McGinty and Sara Schaffer. Things get cooking at 6 p.m.

title: All the Worlds a Stage
description: Sam Mendes's new take on Shakespeare's "As You Like It" suits the season. The "tough-minded, wintry" production, which opened Tuesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Harvey Theater, is the first show in the Bridge Project's second season. "Mr. Mendes's arrestingly somber staging of Shakespeare's pastoral comedy firmly favors adversity over sweetness," writes Charles Isherwood. "For all the spirited comedy of 'As You Like It,' true love arrives only after strenuous study and emotional hardship." Thankfully, comic relief does come in the form of the vagabond philosopher Jaques, played with "sly and subtle wit by the terrific British actor Stephen Dillane." Christian Camargo, Michelle Beck and Juliet Rylance also star in the play, which "makes clear that the human heart is fickle, easily deceived, sometimes perfidious. The mettle of love must be tried and tested, and tried again, before its sweet felicities can be safely indulged."

title: Whats for Dinner?
description: Knowing there's a good, dependable Chinese restaurant just around the corner can alleviate some of the stress that comes with living in New York. (They should do a test and prove it.) So there's good news for those who live on the Upper East Side or at least willing to hop on a subway and visit. At Szechuan Chalet "there are pleasures to be had," writes Nick Fox. Like Sichuan pork dumplings with roasted red oil, braised flounder fillets perfectly cooked with napa cabbage in chili oil sauce and razor clams with scallion pesto, which has its own attention-getting device: The dish comes arranged in the shape of a peacock, "the bird carved from daikon and its comb made from a carrot. The clams fan out behind it, enrobed in a sauce of scallions, chilies and Sichuan peppercorns. Disneyesque but delicious." Go for these dishes and the ox tongue and tripe with roasted chili and peanut vinaigrette, the "thoughtful service," and a visit from Wei Lu, the chef and an owner who checks on the dining room to make sure everything is alright.

title: In Two Games, Knicks See Both Sides of a Rout
description: For the second time this week, the Knicks took part in a historic rout Tuesday at Madison Square Garden. The experience was considerably more enjoyable this time.

title: Capitals Show Young Islanders What to Strive For
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Tuesday nights game at Nassau Coliseum was likely to be one-sided from the start, and that is indeed what it was, a 7-2 victory for a Washington Capitals team establishing itself in first place in the Eastern Conference over an Islanders team striving to stay on the playoff bubble.

title: Vote on Bernanke Confirmation Is Scheduled for Thursday
description: WASHINGTON  Ben S. Bernankes prospects for confirmation to a second term as chairman of the Federal Reserve advanced on Tuesday as the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, scheduled a crucial vote in the process for Thursday.

title: Amid Budget Worries, Mayor Finds Jobs for Campaign Staff
description: Even as he warns that the city may have to lay off thousands of workers, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has found city jobs for 15 members of his re-election campaign, many of whom are earning six-figure salaries, records and interviews show.

title: Rule Bans Texting for Truckers and Bus Drivers
description: The Transportation Department announced a new rule Tuesday that prohibits interstate commercial truckers and bus drivers from sending text messages while they are operating moving vehicles.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the implications of a hackers theft of software code from a technology company misstated the role that VeriSign iDefense played in investigating the recent online attacks on Google. While VeriSign assisted several other companies that were also attacked, it did not help Google.

title: Lindsey Vonn and Bode Miller Named to U.S. Alpine Team
description: The United States ski team Tuesday announced the 22 Alpine racers who would compete in the 2010 Vancouver Olympics, and although there were no surprises, it did affirm that Bode Miller, barring injury in the next few weeks, would return for his fourth Games.

title: Venus Is Out, but Serena Perseveres
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  There will be no Williams sisters showdown in the semifinals of the Australian Open. Li Na made sure of that Wednesday by stunning sixth-seeded Venus Williams, 2-6, 7-6 (4), 7-5, in a grinding, error-filled marathon that should have been over after two sets. Li now joins her compatriot Zheng Jie in the semifinals, the first time two Chinese players have advanced that far in a Grand Slam.

title: Ruth P. Smith, Abortion-Rights Pioneer, Dies at 102
description: Ruth Proskauer Smith, a longtime reproductive rights advocate who helped found what is now Naral Pro-Choice America, died Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 102.

title: As Technology Surges, Radiation Safeguards Lag
description: In New Jersey, 36 cancer patients at a veterans hospital in East Orange were overradiated  and 20 more received substandard treatment  by a medical team that lacked experience in using a machine that generated high-powered beams of radiation. The mistakes, which have not been publicly reported, continued for months because the hospital had no system in place to catch the errors.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Monday about an election on the Japanese island of Okinawa won by an opponent of the American military base there misidentified, in some copies, the jurisdiction where the winner will serve as mayor. As the article noted, the winner, Susumu Inamine, is the mayor-elect of Nago, a small city on Okinawa that the United States hopes will be the new home for the base, currently situated on a more crowded part of the island; he is not the mayor-elect of Okinawa. (Okinawa has a governor, not a mayor.)

title: Emerging Economies Gain a Voice at Davos
description: At the World Economic Forum this year, it will be hard to miss the rise of emerging countries  and it wont just be because of the Bollywood tunes at the nightclubs.

title: Corrections
Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about concerns on the part of some Tea Party groups around the country over the cost of a Tea Party convention scheduled for early next month in Nashville paraphrased incorrectly from an e-mail message from Sherry Phillips, a founder of the convention organizer, Tea Party Nation. Ms. Phillips wrote that Tea Party Nation is not a nonprofit. She did not say it is a nonprofit group.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Monday about Jean Montrevil, a Haitian New Yorker fighting a deportation order who was released from federal custody over the weekend, misstated the location of the Varick detention jail, the site of three demonstrations by Mr. Montrevils supporters. It is in Greenwich Village, not TriBeCa.

title: Q&A With Ben Nemtin From The Buried Life': Four Guys and a Bucket List
description: What do you want to do before you die? Thats the question that Dave Lingwood, Ben Nemtin and Duncan and Jonnie Penn, four friends from Victoria, British Columbia, asked themselves back in 2006. Full of ambition, they were feeling trapped by the odd jobs they were doing (Ben was a representative for a beer company, the Penns were working in the oil fields of northern Canada), and so they did what any ambitious young person would do: they wrote up a list of their top 100 desires (No. 8: ride a bull; No. 45: sleep in a haunted house), acquired an RV and a video camera and hit the road in search of low-budget adventure.

title: A Downtown Becomes Full of Life Again
description: Most companies have shelved expansion plans until the economy recovers  but not the Devon Energy Corporation, one of the countrys biggest independent energy companies.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about President Obamas support for a new agency to protect consumers against lending abuses misstated a provision of a House bill on financial regulation that would establish a consumer financial protection agency. The measure, passed last month, exempts smaller community banks and credit unions from independent annual examinations of their lending practices; it does not exempt them from regulatory authority of the agency altogether. (Annual exams for smaller community banks and credit unions are typically done by their primary regulators.)

title: They Check the Medical Equipment, but Who Is Checking Up on Them?
description: In the eyes of those who hired him, Norman Fenton was a model medical physicist  diligently protecting patients from the hazards of too much medical radiation or too little.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about seismic hazards in the Caribbean referred incorrectly to the Septentrional fault, where some experts had thought an earthquake might first occur on the island of Hispaniola. A long segment in the Dominican Republic, not the entire fault, has gone without a quake for 800 years.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a recent scientific conference in California that focused on issues facing physics misstated the academic affiliation of Aaron Pierce, who was a participant. Dr. Pierce is an assistant professor at the University of Michigan; he is not with the California Institute of Technology.

title: Without Treaty, Pollution-Fighting Firms Set Course
description: Whats next for climate change?

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Liberty Seeks Bigger Stake in Live Nation
description: Liberty Media is looking to more than double its stake in Live Nation Entertainment, the new company formed by the merger of concert promoter Live Nation and Ticketmaster, The Associated Press reports.

title: Opposite of Bold
description: In and of themselves, the economic initiatives announced this week by the Obama administration are not objectionable.

title: The Taliban Would Applaud
description: It is easy to see that a womans human rights are violated when a government requires her to wrap her body and face in an all-concealing veil, as the Taliban used to do when it ran Afghanistan. It should be just as easy to see the violation when a French parliamentary panel recommends, as it did this week, barring women who wear such veils  the burqa and the niqab  from using public services, including schools, hospitals and public transportation. (Muslim head scarves have been banned from public school classrooms since 2004.)

title: Radiation Therapys Harmful Side
description: Radiation treatments have helped save the lives of countless cancer patients, but when medical personnel get sloppy and manufacturers fail to provide technical safeguards the results can be devastating. Two tragic cases at hospitals in New York City illustrate the dangers, and a look at cases elsewhere reinforces the feeling that much more needs to be done to protect patients.

title: A Responsible Man
description: The news that Charles Mac Mathias had died at 87 of Parkinsons disease aroused fond memories of a slightly round and rumpled man who drove a battered blue station wagon to his Senate office and sometimes brought his black Labrador retriever with him.

title: State of the Union, and of the President
description: To the Editor:

title: Helping Haitian Children
description: To the Editor:

title: 9/11 Terror Trials
description: To the Editor:

title: A Film Portrayal of Lula, My Dad
description: To the Editor:

title: Bringing Sexy Back
description: WASHINGTON

title: Adults Only, Please
description: Maybe its just me, but Ive found the last few weeks in American politics particularly unnerving. Our economy is still very fragile, yet you would never know that by the way the political class is acting. Were like a patient that just got out of intensive care and is sitting up in bed for the first time when, suddenly, all the doctors and nurses at bedside start bickering. One of them throws a stethoscope across the room; someone else threatens to unplug all the monitors unless the hospital bills are paid by noon; and all the while the patient is thinking: Are you people crazy? I am just starting to recover. Do you realize how easily I could relapse? Arent there any adults here?

title: Case Studies: When Medical Radiation Goes Awry
description: Americans today receive far more medical radiation than ever before. But patients often know little about the harm that can result when safety rules are violated and ever more powerful and technologically complex machines go awry.

title: Judge Rules for Ratings Agencies in Suit Over Lehman Securities
description: In a victory for ratings agencies, a federal judge on Tuesday dismissed claims against Moodys Investors Service and McGraw-Hills Standard & Poors in litigation over nearly $100 billion of Lehman Brothers mortgage-backed securities.

title: Lost: Jacob is Murdered
description: Ben is persuaded to kill Jacob by the reincarnated Locke, who is revealed to be the man in black, Jacob's longtime opponent.

title: Lost: The Incident
description: Juliet Burke detonates a nuclear warhead in order to erase the castaways' history on the island.

title: Lost: Dharma Massacre
description: The Others, aided by Benjamin Linus, wiped out the Dharma colony and took over its settlement.

title: Immobile and Aging, Rover to Study Mars From One Spot
description: The Martian rover Spirit will rove no more.

title: Boos and Personal Attacks as City Panel Prepares to Vote on School Closings
description: In a contentious meeting that drew more than eight hours of public testimony, a city board voted early Wednesday morning to close 19 schools for poor performance, despite the protests from hundreds of observers who repeatedly drowned out the meeting with cheers, shouts and boos.

title: Advocates of Climate Bill Scale Down Their Goals
description: WASHINGTON  As they watch President Obamas ambitious health care plan crumble, the advocates of a comprehensive bill to combat global warming are turning their sights to a more modest package of climate and energy measures that they believe has a better chance of clearing Congress this year.

title: A.I.G.s Big Debt to U.S. Taxpayers
description: The role of the Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, in the $180 billion bailout of the American International Group will be under scrutiny in Washington on Wednesday when Representative Edolphus Towns, Democrat of New York, convenes a hearing of the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform. Whatever the outcome, A.I.G. still owes American taxpayers $124 billion. The company is making progress on asset sales. But to repay its rescuers in full, it still needs a charmed future.

title: Former Justice OConnor Sees Ill in Election Finance Ruling
description: WASHINGTON Justice Sandra Day OConnor did not sound happy on Tuesday about the Supreme Courts big campaign finance decision last week. It repudiated a major part of a ruling Justice OConnor helped write before her retirement from the court in 2006, and it complicated her recent efforts to do away with judicial elections.

title: Showcase: Mikes Mark
description: For now, if the name Mike is conjured on the Upper East Side, chances are that the incumbent mayor will come to most New Yorkers minds. (Here he is last November on East 81st Street, after voting in the mayoral election.)

title: Still Worried
description: If something happens once, that teaches people that it could happen again. One result is that fears can linger.

title: Phys Ed: How Exercising Keeps Your Cells Young
description: Recently, scientists in Germany gathered several groups of men and women to look at their cells life spans. Some of them were young and sedentary, others middle-aged and sedentary. Two other groups were, to put it mildly, active. The first of these consisted of professional runners in their 20s, most of them on the national track-and-field team, training about 45 miles per week. The last were serious, middle-aged longtime runners, with an average age of 51 and a typical training regimen of 50 miles per week, putting those young 45-mile-per-week sluggards to shame.

title: Iceland Leads Environmental Index as U.S. Falls
description: A new ranking of the worlds nations by environmental performance puts some of the globes largest economies far down the list, with the United States sinking to 61st and China to 121st.

title: Boston College Looks to Make a Mark
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass.  Reggie Jackson knows the reality of being a Boston College basketball player.

title: President of Sri Lanka Is Re-elected by Wide Edge
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka  Mahinda Rajapaksa, Sri Lankas president, was re-elected by a wide margin, election officials here said Wednesday, defeating the newly retired army general who had tried to lay claim to Mr. Rajapaksas biggest political victory, the defeat of the Tamil Tiger insurgency.

title: Word of the Day | finite
description: finite \fi-nit\ adjective

title: Oregon Voters Approve Tax Increase
description: Two ballot measures that would raise taxes on businesses and higher-income residents in Oregon appeared headed for approval late Tuesday.

title: Lawrence Garfinkel Dies at 88; Fought Smoking
description: Lawrence Garfinkel, an epidemiologist with the American Cancer Society who helped design landmark studies that linked smoking to lung cancer, died Thursday in Seattle. He was 88.

title: Footage From the Michael Mineo Case
description: Prosecutors say Mr. Mineo was sodomized by a police officer in a Brooklyn subway station in October 2008. Subway surveillance cameras show Mr. Mineo confronted by police and, later, walking with the help of friends.

title: Looking for Cause of the Pain
description: A relatively rare ailment has ended dozens of budding athletic careers.

title: Woman Fatally Stabbed in Queens
description: A 46-year-old woman was stabbed to death on Tuesday night after a dispute inside a Queens building, the police said.

title: One in Five Report Hunger
description: Nearly one in five Americans said they lacked the money to buy food at some point in the last year, according to a survey co-sponsored by the Gallup organization and released by an anti-hunger group. The numbers soared at the start of the current recession, but dipped in 2009 despite the continuing rise in unemployment. The anti-hunger group, the Food Research and Action Center, attributed that trend to falling food prices, rising enrollment for food stamps and an increase in the amount of the food stamp benefit. More than 38 million Americans  one in eight now receive food stamps, a record high.

title: Inquiry Into Congressmans Finances Ends
description: Federal officials have ended their investigation of the finances of Representative Alan B. Mollohan, Democrat of West Virginia, said a spokesman for United States Attorney Channing Phillips. Mr. Mollohan was the subject of an investigation into whether he profited from federal money he got for organizations in his district.

title: Koreas Exchange Fire at Sea, Adding to Tension
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea fired dozens of artillery shells on Wednesday from its shoreline into waters near its disputed western sea border with South Korea, and the South Korean military returned warning shots from smaller weapons, according to South Korean military officials and fishermen on a border island.

title: Oregon: Voters Approve Tax Increases
description: Two ballot measures that would raise taxes on businesses and higher-income residents appeared headed for approval. The tax increases, which would raise about $727 million largely for public education and social services, were approved by the Legislature, but later put to a public referendum after opponents gathered signatures in a petition campaign. One measure raises income taxes on individuals who earn more than $125,000 and on couples who earn more than $250,000, the other raises taxes and fees on most businesses.

title: California: Threat to Bart Expansion
description: A plan to expand the San Francisco Bay Areas commuter rail system is in jeopardy of losing $70 million in stimulus money after the Federal Transit Administration found that the rail agency had not considered the views of minority and low-income residents near the construction zone of a proposed $440 million project to connect the existing Bay Area Rapid Transit lines to the Oakland airport. Opponents of the project say that it would largely bypass minority residents and that the money could be spent on cheaper, more accessible ground transportation. A BART spokesman said the agency was confident it could resolve the problems by a March 5 deadline.

title: Footage From the Michael Mineo Case
description: Prosecutors say Mr. Mineo was sodomized by a police officer in a Brooklyn subway station in October 2008.

title: News Quiz | January 27, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Television Debut
description: Less than a year after Omar had landed in Somalia - he made his public debut with the Shabaab in a television interview broadcast on Al Jazeera.

title: Corrections
description: A recipe last Wednesday for kajmak, with an article about Balkan burgers, gave an incorrect equivalent measurement for the four ounces of butter that is creamed together with cream cheese, ricotta and sour cream. The four ounces equals one stick, not half a stick. A corrected recipe is at nytimes.com/dining.

title: Spring 2010 Couture Collections
description: Images from the Christian Dior, Givenchy, Armani Priv, Jean Paul Gaultier, Alexis Mabille, Thimster and Chanel shows.

title: Ailing Banks Favor Salaries Over Shareholders
description: Finding the winners on Wall Street is usually as simple as looking at pay. Rarely are bankers who lose money paid as generously as those who make it.

title: Two at Fed Had Doubts Over Payout by A.I.G.
description: Weeks after rescuing the American International Group with an $85 billion taxpayer loan in late 2008, Federal Reserve Board officials rejected a proposal that would have forced the insurers trading partners to return $30 billion in cash that they had received from A.I.G. in the preceding months.

title: A.I.G.s Big Debt to U.S. Taxpayers
description: The role of the Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, in the $180 billion bailout of the American International Group will be under scrutiny in Washington on Wednesday when Representative Edolphus Towns, Democrat of New York, convenes a hearing of the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform.

title: British Central Banker Favors Splitting Big Banks
description: Mervyn A. King, the governor of the Bank of England, is an owlish, self-effacing man who, in contrast to his more outspoken peers in Frankfurt and Washington, strikes a public posture that borders on the demure.

title: Play First, Eat Later
description: WHO has found that kids seem to respond better to having recess before lunch?

title: What Are the Hot Fashion Trends at Your School Right Now?
description: The Times Fashion and Style section covers everything from critter hats  seen on the streets of New York to haute couture shown on the runways of Paris. What are people in your school wearing this year? How much do you think trends influence what you wear?

title: American Idol: The Los Angeles Auditions
description: Forget an intro. All that needs to be said is this: Katy Perry is welcome to write a guest blog on American Idol any time she so desires. In a grim week of auditions in which a guy in a newsboy hat covering Maroon 5 was the high point, Ms. Perry was transcendent. Shes got plenty of promise as a music critic (ahem) should the singing thing not work out.

title: With Sun, Oracle Aims at Giants
description: Oracle, having spent the last nine months fighting rivals and regulators in order to own Sun Microsystems, has pushed itself into the middle of the scrum of technology heavyweights all jostling for the same corporate customers, Ashlee Vance reports in The New York Times.

title: Yitai Coal Said to Plan $1 Billion I.P.O.
description: Inner Mongolia Yitai Coal, the Chinese coal mining company, aims to raise about $1 billion from a Hong Kong initial public offering in the second to third quarter of 2010, a source close to the deal told Reuters on Wednesday.

title: K.K.R. Set to Buy British Pet Retailer
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the private equity firm, is to buy Pets at Home in a deal that valued the British retailer at 955 million ($1.5 billion), including debt, one person familiar with the matter told Reuters.

title: Citizen Journalism Site Pockets $3 Million
description: AllVoices, a citizen journalism site, has nabbed $3 million in a funding round led by VantagePoint Venture Partners, TechCrunch reported.

title: Valero Said to Seek Sale of Refineries
description: Valero Energy, the top independent American refiner, is working to sell its remaining plants on the East Coast and in the Caribbean, The Wall Street Journal said.

title: Rusal Shares Slide in Hong Kong Debut
description: Shares in Rusal, the Russian aluminum giant, fell 9 percent in their landmark trading debut in Hong Kong on Wednesday, weighed down by a broad market slump that has seen many of the worlds leading stock indexes fall below where they began the year, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

title: Problem Loans Plague Banks in Austria
description: The Austrian banking regulator said Tuesday that it expected massive write-offs this year by the countrys banks as they recognized more bad loans in Eastern Europe, Judy Dempsey reports in The New York Times.

title: Davos in the Media: Forecasts and Sanitizing Gel
description: It seems the attendees of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, just cant help themselves when it comes to making predictions.

title: Dorseys Square Assembles Roster of Angels
description: Jack Dorsey, the co-founder and chairman of Twitter, has rounded up an impressive list of angel investors for his latest venture, an on-the-go credit card payment platform called Square.

title: Borders Chief Resigns After 1 Year
description: The Borders Group, which counts hedge fund Pershing Square Capital Management as its largest investor, announced on Tuesday that Ron Marshall had resigned as chief executive just a year after he took the helm of the countrys second-largest bookstore chain, adding to anxiety among publishers about the health of the book market.

title: Terreno Realty Said to Pull I.P.O.
description: Terreno Realty has shelved its initial public offering due to market conditions,The Associated Press reported, citing a person familiar with the offering on Tuesday.

title: Tullow Launches 1 Billion Share Sale
description: Tullow Oil, the London-based oil explorer, offered to sell 80.4 million shares on Wednesday, equivalent to 10 percent of its outstanding stock, to raise funds to pay for development of assets in Uganda.

title: Shares End Lower After a Day of Wandering
description: Stocks erased gains in the sessions final hour as concerns that the Federal Reserve may signal more plans to unwind stimulus measures overshadowed higher-than-estimated earnings and consumer confidence.

title: Live From Davos; Geithner Takes the Stand
description: Greetings from Davos, Switzerland, where the World Economic Forums annual meeting is just getting under way. We have a team of reporters here on the ground (Im writing this from a BlackBerry at the Steigenberger Belvedere Hotel, a central hub of activity) and will be bringing you all the news and behind-the-scenes happenings throughout the week.

title: Congresss Team: Deal for Merger Included Saints
description: The Saints advance to the Super Bowl has been a lesson in patience. New Orleans has hosted the Super Bowl nine times, but the Saints have never played in one since entering the N.F.L. in 1967. Carol Channing made it to the Super Bowl twice, as a halftime entertainer, each time at Tulane Stadium, the first home of the Saints.

title: Vote on Bernanke Set for Thursday
description: Ben S. Bernankes prospects for confirmation to a second term as chairman of the Federal Reserve advanced on Tuesday as the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, scheduled a crucial vote in the process for Thursday.

title: Whos Afraid of Malones Live Nation Move?
description: News that John C. Malone is seeking a 35 percent stake in the company to be formed by the freshly approved merger of Ticketmaster and Live Nation, has The New York Post pitying Live Nation Entertainments chief executive, Michael Rapino.

title: The Pain in Spain Falls Mainly on the Gains
description: Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, Spains second-biggest lender, said fourth-quarter profit slumped 94 percent as it wrote down the value of its United States business and set aside more money for bad loans, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Apples iPad Tablet
description: After months of anticipation, Apple unveiled its tablet device that features a multi-touch screen, Wi-Fi, 3G and the ability to run iPhone apps.

title: Litigation Funds Turn to U.K. Market
