description: A review of civil litigation in Britain that seeks to overhaul the legal culture is attracting a rush of funds that finance lawsuits in return for a cut of payouts, Reuters reported.

title: The Global Politics of Massachusetts
description: At a private dinner Tuesday night among a group of C.E.O.s, politicians, lobbyists, journalists and bankers from around the world, one topic seemed to take center stage: Massachusetts.

title: I.R.S. Moves to Uncover Corporate Shelters
description: The Internal Revenue Service said on Tuesday that it would require large corporations to reveal basic information about their tax transactions, a surprise move intended to root out questionable or illegal tax shelters, The New York Timess Lynnley Browning reported.

title: Berkshire to Join S.&P. 500, and Its Shares Soar
description: Standard & Poors said it would add Warren E. Buffetts Berkshire Hathaway to its flagship S&P 500 stock index, as the company prepares to acquire a company already on the list, the railroad operator Burlington Northern Santa Fe.

title: Schools Supporters Fear They Werent Heard
description: When state lawmakers voted last summer to renew Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs control over New York City schools, they included a compromise devised to respond to complaints that the public had little opportunity for meaningful input.

title: City Banker Said to Be Set for Virgin Money Helm
description: Richard Bransons Virgin Money is reportedly set to appoint the banker Brian Pitman as chairman, as the bank appears ready for some dealmaking.

title: Share Your Favorite Moment From the 2009 Jets Season
description: Readers have been generous about sharing their long-ago Jets memories:a) Recalling Joe Willie, and the bond passed from father to sonb) Sneaking into Shea in 1968c) Driving 100 miles out of town to watch the blacked-out A.F.L. title game.

title: Saunas to Warm Up Wintertime Berlin
description: Berlin in winter is typically dark, gray, cold and ill tempered, and this season has been no exception. But insiders know a surefire way to combat the seasons grimness: getting hot, sweaty and naked in a sauna.

title: The Curse Of The Supermajority
description: Heres how democracy works: political parties that make an effective appeal to voters get the right to govern and implement new policies.

title: British Hedge Funds Unlikely to Sue Porsche
description: British hedge funds are unlikely to follow their American brethren in suing Porsche, because they are striving to reach a compromise in Europe over tough new rules for the industry, Reuters reported, citing industry sources.

title: Same As He Ever Was
description: These days quite a few people are frustrated with President Obamas failure to challenge conservative ideology. The spending freeze  about which the best thing you can say in its favor is that its a transparently cynical PR stunt  has, for many, been the final straw: rhetorically, its a complete concession to Reaganism.

title: Pro-Wall St. Democrat Takes On House Veteran
description: Shes young, she just moved into the district and she is taking on an established and popular House Democrat in a primary bid she concedes is a huge gamble. Shes also a hedge fund lawyer, and proud of it.

title: Third World as Retirement Home
description: Todays idea: Because of uneven global population trends, old people in the future might be encouraged to move from aging rich countries to high-fertility developing nations with the medical and other workers to support their needs.

title: Chinas Line: Trains, Soy Milk and a Dollar Peg
description: Senior government officials making the long trip to the Alpine venue of the annual World Economic Forum tend to fly in from Zurich by helicopter  that is, those who can still afford it do.

title: Whos Afraid of the Big Bad Deficit?
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Should Childrens Books Be Rated?
description: The novelist and blogger Tony Buchsbaum thinks they should.

title: Monkeys, Candy and Cognitive Dissonance
description: Do humans and even monkeys tend to rationalize their choices? Or have researchers for decades been rationalizing their own work because of a mathematical flaw in the experiments that led to the theory of cognitive dissonance? Today weve got two new offerings in this debate, but first let me give you some background.

title: Geithner Denies Role in Limiting A.I.G. Disclosures
description: Update | 10:19 a.m. The House hearing has begun and The New York Timess Mary Williams Walsh is providing continuing coverage.

title: The Early Word: Big Night
description: All eyes are on President Obama, as he prepares to deliver his first-ever State of the Union address tonight at 9 p.m. Eastern.

title: In Line at the Courthouse, an Everyday Scene of Drama and Duty
description: The line begins forming outside the Bronx County Hall of Justice before 9 a.m., stretching a full block down East 161st Street. Within half an hour it bends around the corner of Morris Avenue, until 11 a.m., when the flood slows to a trickle.

title: Housekeeping: New Comment System
description: Later today, a new and improved comment system will be unleashed on Schotts Vocab.

title: Shillers List: How to Diagnose the Next Bubble
description: Asset-price bubbles have been the cause of most of the recent economic downturns, including the most recent one. But how do you know when a bubble is forming? If central bankers, regulators and investors knew the answer to the question, they might be able to avoid them.

title: Barclays Diamond Takes a Swipe at Obama Plan
description: Robert E. Diamond Jr., president of Barclays, said the Obama bank regulation plan failed to address the real problems facing the industry.

title: Toyotas Woes in America Raise Concern in Japan
description: TOKYO  As Toyotas problems mounted in North America with the announcement of a halt to sales and manufacturing of the bulk of its cars, commentators in Japan fretted Wednesday that the automakers problems could seriously hurt the reputation of the rest of Japans manufacturing sector.

title: Politics From A to Z: State of the Union
description: President Obama will deliver his first State of the Union address tonight. The speech, which comes at a challenging moment of his presidency, will help frame the midterm election year ahead.

title: Sampler: More Cuts for City Schools and Another Amazing Gerhart
description: San Francisco Schools Face Further Cuts  | With the schools budget likely to face a $113 million gap between its programs and its financial resources, the superintendent, Carlos Garcia, plans to eliminate 100 teachers, put employees across the system on furlough and sharply trim summer school and teacher training programs. There are things in here that go against my beliefs, Mr. Garcia said, calling the planned cuts horrible and deplorable. The teachers union said its consent would be needed for some of the cuts. [The San Francisco Chronicle, The Associated Press]

title: Geopolitics: A Swiss Afghanistan and Russian NATO
description: Abdullah Abdullah, the former foreign minister of Afghanistan, called for his home country to be turned into a neutral country like Switzerland.

title: Circumstance and Tradition Shape State of the Union Speeches
description: When President Obama enters the House chamber on Wednesday night to deliver his first official State of the Union address, it will be a moment of great challenge and opportunity. Under fire and on the defensive, Mr. Obama will get to speak past the punditocracy directly to the American people as he seeks to reframe his presidency.

title: Samsung Life I.P.O Could Settle Long Dispute
description: With the stock market in Seoul rebounding strongly from the global economic downturn, South Korean companies could raise as much as $11 billion this year by selling their shares to the public for the first time, including Samsung Life Insurance, the biggest insurer in the country, Choe Sang-Hun reports in The New York Times.

title: After 8 Hours of Protests, Panel Votes to Close Schools
description: In a contentious meeting that drew more than eight hours of public testimony, a city board voted around 3:30 Wednesday morning to close 19 schools for poor performance, despite protests from hundreds of observers who repeatedly drowned out the meeting with cheers, shouts and boos.

title: Turning the Focus to Fiscal Restraint
description: The announcement of a limited spending freeze is likely to be a centerpiece of President Obama's State of the Union address, but the question is whether the news can foster real bipartisan support.

title: Questioning the Purity of Organic Cotton
description: A battle is brewing over identifying clothing as being made of organic cotton when it contains strains of genetically modified cotton seed.

title: The Jihadist Next Door
description: ON A WARM, cloudy day in the fall of 1999, the town of Daphne, Ala., stirred to life. The high-school band came pounding down Main Street, past the post office and the library and Christ the King Church. Trumpeters in gold-tasseled coats tipped their horns to the sky, heralding the arrival of teenage demigods. The star quarterback and his teammates came first in the parade, followed by the homecoming queen and her court. Behind them, on a float bearing leaders of the student government, a giddy mop-haired kid tossed candy to the crowd.

title: Speed Read for Wednesday, Jan. 27       (Or as its now known, Apple Tablet Day)
description: Highlights from todays media coverage:

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Coyotes Doan Ignites Inspiring Rally
description: Eight games on Tuesday night, highlighted by the Phoenix Coyotes, who continue to surprise during a season that most thought theyd be playing in Hamilton or barely surviving by scraping together pennies. Home teams listed first:

title: NATO and Kazakhstan Reach Transit Pact for Afghanistan
description: MOSCOW  NATO and Kazakhstan completed an agreement Wednesday that will permit NATO allies to ship cargo through Kazakh territory to Afghanistan, providing an important alternative to vulnerable routes elsewhere.

title: Electric Trucks Before Electric Cars?
description: WASHINGTON  The biggest thing at the Washington Auto Show  quite literally  is a 22,000-pound electric truck. Two, actually. They have been built by Smith Electric Vehicles, an established British brand. The American company, a licensee based in Kansas City, Mo., began deliveries in December.

title: Avatar, Painted With the Palette of Pocahontas
description: Avatar may now be the highest-grossing movie of all time (with assists from inflation and the higher costs of 3-D and Imax screenings) but that hasnt stopped moviegoers from pondering the cinematic pedigree of that James Cameron blockbuster  particularly the many plot details that Avatar seems to share with the 1995 Disney film Pocahontas.

title: Style Map | St. Barts
description: The social epicenter of the Caribbean, St. Barts is where Diddy, Gisele and mega-yacht captains come together to shop at Louis Vuitton, eat moules frites at La Marine and dance on the tables at Le Ti. This season the French island is heating up again: hotels have been redone (like the Carl Gustaf), new kitchens set up and shops stocked with fresh goods. Heres where tastemakers on holiday get their style fix.

title: What Readers Want to Hear Tonight
description: Updated: After the White House disclosed some of the tax-break initiatives aimed at the middle class that President Obama plans to outline in his address to Congress tonight, readers offered their views on what they hoped to hear from the president in his State of the Union address.

title: Uncle Who Vouched for Terror Suspect Arrested
description: In the days after he emerged in September as a suspect in what federal prosecutors called a Qaeda terror plot, much about the life of Najibullah Zazi became the subject of intense interest.

title: Fundamentalists and the Atheists Who Love Them
description: As a general rule, I try to avoid writing about both Pat Robertson and Richard Dawkins. (The attention only encourages them). But Dawkins defense of Robertson, against the milquetoast Christians who rushed to disavow the televangelists suggestion that the Haitian earthquake victims were being singled out for divine punishment, offers an interesting illustration of militant atheisms symbiotic relationship with religious fundamentalism. Heres the new atheist:

title: Never Too Early to Start 2013 Campaign
description: The 2009 mayors race was so, well, last year. Bring on 2013!

title: As Nations Meet, Clinton Urges Yemen to Prove Itself Worthy of Aid
description: LONDON  Senior officials from the United States and 19 other countries gathered here on Wednesday to declare themselves friends of Yemen. But Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton administered a dose of tough love, saying Yemen, an impoverished Arab nation, must earn increased foreign aid by rooting out corruption, settling internal strife and protecting the rights of girls and young women.

title: Why the Payroll Tax Break Wont Create Jobs
description: I just read a proposal from Senators Charles Schumer and Orrin Hatch in The New York Times that is meant to give private companies incentive to hire people who have been out of work for 60 days.

title: Economists Hip-Hop Showdown
description: Video | Yo, its John Maynard Keynes vs. F.A. Hayek in a rap video put together by an economist and video producer to explain the markets-vs.-government conflict within the dismal science (details here and here). The supply of time this consumes may exceed your demand to watch it:

title: Schumachers Optimism
description: The German newspaper, Bild, has reported that Michael Schumacher is not only thinking about staying in Formula One for the duration of his three-year contract with Mercedes, but also beyond that.

title: Tyranny of the Majorities
description: If we learned anything about Barack Obama during the now-distant campaign of 2008, it was that he was a man who valued stoicism and self-possession in himself and others. And so it was significant, in an understated way, to hear Obamas press secretary describe him, on the day of the election in Massachusetts to fill Ted Kennedys former Senate seat, as surprised and frustrated by the collapse of the Democratic candidate, Martha Coakley, and then to hear Obamas closest aides heaping scorn on her campaign. You could see how this latest defeat might have registered on Obama like a horse hoof to the abdomen, shaking him from his prized equanimity and plunging his White House into a spate of uncharacteristic self-doubt. On a personal level, Obama had to feel that he had somehow failed one of his mentors, allowing not only Kennedys seat to slip away but quite possibly his dream of national health care too. Politically, the Massachusetts election seems likely to presage worse days ahead, suggesting, as an unending parade of commentators have now pointed out, that Obama and his governing party could face a calamitous November.

title: Drawing Fire, Geithner Backs Rescue of A.I.G.
description: WASHINGTON  Timothy F. Geithner, the Treasury secretary, defended the bailout of the American International Group again on Wednesday to a group of representatives who would not buy his explanations.

title: Storing Energy as Ice?
description: The Southern California Public Power Authority   a coalition of several public power agencies  and a seven-year-old Colorado company called Ice Energy have signed a contract to deploy rooftop units that use electricity at night, when demand is low, to make ice.

title: The Outsider
description: As you make the rounds of television talk shows to promote your new book, Freefall: America, Free Markets and the Sinking of the World Economy, many of us are wondering why you arent talking to the members of the Obama administration instead. Were you offered a job by the president?  No. There was no natural position for me within the usual structure of government.

title: What to Watch (If Youre Not Watching the State of the Union)
description: If youre an upstanding citizen with a compelling interest in American democracy, you probably should watch President Obamas State of the Union address on Wednesday night. (Spoiler alert! Hes going to accept responsibility for missteps.)

title: Wednesday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Crash Blossoms
description: Elizabeth Barrett Browning once gave the poetry of her husband, Robert, a harsh assessment, criticizing his habit of excessively paring down his syntax with opaque results. You sometimes make a dust, a dark dust, she wrote him, by sweeping away your little words.

title: Get Your Non-Apple News
description: If youre not interested in the exorbitant amount of Apple news flowing through the Internet today, heres a short list of five non-Apple related stories. Youll be happy to know that theres lots of interesting news going on outside the Apple ecosystem today, including Twitters new Local Trends feature, a new privacy push for online ads, and AT&T starting a new service to compete with Yelp.com.

title: Live Blogging the iPad Product Announcement
description: Over and Out

title: A Couple of Updates, from Deworming to Sudan
description: Im always dazzled by the way readers respond to some columns. Shortly before Christmas I wrote a column listing various organizations doing good work in development, and I included a paragraph about Deworm the World. I received this update from the group:

title: Satellite Feed
description: If youre thinking of using feral cats as rat-chasing barn cats, consider this word of caution: A solid white cat is going to reflect moonlight, and then its going to be like a coyote magnet.

title: Hot Ticket: A Lunch With Soros
description: George Soros pushed for climate change action at the 2010 World Economic Forum.

title: Poet Chosen Over Toibin in Literary Prize Shocker
description: It was supposed to be the literary prize that Colm Toibin was going to win in a walk  the one for which his novel Brooklyn was named the runaway favorite by one British newspaper, for which one British bookmaker gave 6-to-4 odds in the authors favor and another declared it dead even. Instead, Mr. Toibin has gone home a runner-up in the Costa book of the year competition, having lost to a poet. The Guardian reported that Christopher Reid was named the winner of the Costa award for his collection A Scattering, about his wife, Lucinda Gane, who died in 2005. Mr. Reid became only the fourth poet to win the prestigious British literary award &#8212 and its prize of about $48,000  following Douglas Dunn, Ted Hughes and Seamus Heaney (who was the most recent poet to claim victory, in 1999). Josephine Hart, one of the prizes 11 jurors, told The Guardian, It is a devastating piece of work and all of us on the jury felt it was a book we would wish everybody to read. In addition to Brooklyn, other finalists for the award included Patrick Nesss childrens book The Ask and the Answer; Raphael Selbournes first novel, Beauty; and Graham Farmelos biography of the quantum physicist Paul Dirac, The Strangest Man.

title: The Crisis? Its Just Like Traffic, Really
description: Lord Levene of British insurer Lloyds (left) and George Soros.

title: Belichicks Advice for Super Bowls Winning Coach
description: After the Patriots were eliminated by the Ravens earlier this month, Bill Belichick conducted a curt news conference  even for him.

title: Open the Marriage, Close the Door
description: My husband and I practice polyamory, a k a ethical nonmonogamy. We are open about this to friends but are unsure what to disclose to others. Our housekeeper might have seen me in bed with my boyfriend. Must I explain? When I travel for business, I sometimes take my boyfriend. Must I fill in a co-worker I see only occasionally? I dont want to hide my affection for my boyfriend or make anyone uncomfortable. NAME WITHHELD, SAN FRANCISCO

title: The Shortest Speech in History
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: Tomorrow night, President Obama will give his State of the Union address. The White House says the speech will focus on American jobs. So, I guess hes going to talk a lot about India.

title: 2009 Traffic Deaths Were Lowest in a Century
description: Deaths in traffic accidents in New York City fell to an all-time low last year - a record that city officials said dates to 1910, when deaths by streetcar and carriage-horse were commonplace.

title: Impossible Hamster, Big Coal, Climate Concerns
Nobodys Perfect in College Hoops
description: Kentucky, the last of the unbeatens, lost to South Carolina, 68-62, in mens basketball on Tuesday night.

title: Is There an Ecological Unconscious?
description: About eight years ago, Glenn Albrecht began receiving frantic calls from residents of the Upper Hunter Valley, a 6,000-square-mile region in southeastern Australia. For generations the Upper Hunter was known as the Tuscany of the South  an oasis of alfalfa fields, dairy farms and lush English-style shires on a notoriously hot, parched continent. The calls were like desperate pleas, Albrecht, a philosopher and professor of sustainability at Murdoch University in Perth, recalled in June. They said: Can you help us? Weve tried everyone else. Is there anything you can do about this?

title: Jean-Georgess Fried Rice
description: This weeks Minimalist column is Jean-Georges Vongerichtens simple, mildly unusual, but utterly fantastic fried rice with ginger, leeks and a fried egg.

title: The Orphans Home Cycle
description: Images from all three parts of Horton Footes work at the Signature Theater.

title: Travel Deals: 33% Off Hilton Weekend Stays
description: Hilton Hotels is offering up to 33 percent off Friday through Sunday stays for most of the year at more than 520 hotels and resorts worldwide. The deal, which is good for weekend stays through Dec. 26, must be booked by Jan. 31 at Hilton.com/January.

title: Quote Unquote | Need a Lift?
description: Jimmy Choo tells the Buckinghamshire Advertiser about his surprising personal shoe choice. Who knew that the shoe designer and Tom Cruise had so much in common?

title: The Dog Who Hates Me
description: It was the movie Hotel for Dogs that sealed the deal. My kids had been asking for a dog for years, promising to take care of it, arguing how our family wouldnt be complete until we had one. But after we rented that movie, in which humans cant really find happiness without a canine pal, our kids became inconsolable in their dogless sorrow. Moaning, wailing  youd have thought they severed an artery. Fine, well get a dog. Yay, Dad!

title: What Would You Like Obama to Say?
description: What should President Obama say tonight about health care?

title: For Microsoft Executive, Ireland Is a Beautiful Place for a Data Center
description: Companies and governments keen to cut their energy bills and burnish their green credentials are thinking carefully about the climate of countries where they locate data centers  the vast hubs of computer servers that have become vital to everything from policing to banking and global communications.

title: Inspired by Ratatouille
description: Tilda Swinton, the avant-garde actress who won an Oscar for her performance in Michael Clayton, trekked to Utah from her home in Scotland this week to celebrate the Sundance premiere of her new film I Am Love. It has become a familiar routine: Just about every festival that matters wants to shower attention on the picture.

title: Ozawa and James Taylor to Headline Carnegie Season
description: Carnegie Hall, famed for the classical music luminaries on its stage, will give the singer-songwriter James Taylor pride of place next season. At the other end of the musical spectrum, the violinist Christian Tetzlaff will also be featured.

title: Carnegie Hall Announces Its 2010-11 Schedule
description: Carnegie Hall announced its plans for next season on Wednesday. The headlines: There will be a Perspectives series led by the singer-songwriter James Taylor and the violinist Christian Tetzlaff, along with a festival dedicated to Japan run by Seiji Ozawa. Valery Gergiev will conduct the Mariinsky Orchestra in most of the Mahler symphony cycle (the remainder of the symphonies will take place at Lincoln Center, with the London Symphony Orchestra).

title: Should You Walk Away From Your Mortgage?
description: The New York Times has run a couple of articles, including this one, in recent weeks about whether it makes sense to walk away from a mortgage that is bigger than the house is now worth. In a recent paper cited in an article on Sunday, a University of Arizona law professor, Brent White, explained that the vast majority of underwater homeowners continued to make mortgage payments even if it might make more financial sense for them to strategically default and walk away.

title: New York Pops Takes a Chance on Abba
description: The great 2010 Abba-thon continues: following the news that the best-selling Swedish pop quartet will be honored with its own museum in London, the New York Pops said on Thursday that it is planning an entire concert of Abba music to kick off its 2010-11 season. In a news release, the New York Pops said that it will open its coming season on Oct. 15 at Carnegie Hall with The Music of Abba, featuring Rajaton, the Finnish vocal ensemble, performing hits like Dancing Queen, Mamma Mia and Take a Chance on Me. Other events on the Pops schedule include an 80th birthday celebration for Stephen Sondheim on Nov. 19; a holiday concert with Brian Stokes Mitchell on Dec. 10 and 11; a performance of El Ritmo de la Vida, a new work of Latin music by Doc Severinsen, the former Tonight Show band leader, on Jan. 28, 2011; and a concert honoring the 50th anniversary of Judy Garlands Carnegie Hall debut, featuring Ashley Brown, Heather Headley and Karen Olivo, on March 11, 2011. The Pops performances will be conducted by its musical director, Steven Reineke.

title: NATO Contractor Is Sentenced to Death in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  An Australian security contractor working for an American company has been sentenced to death by an Afghan court for murdering a colleague and then trying to cover up the crime by staging a Taliban ambush.

title: Rohatyn Returns to Lazard as Special Adviser
description: Felix Rohatyn, one of the gray eminences of the deal-making world, is returning to Lazard, the firm that he helped build into one of the major players in mergers and acquisitions.

title: Under Fire, Geithner Defends A.I.G. Bailout
description: Update | 1:45 p.m. In heated questioning that at times took on the air of a cross-examination, Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner on Wednesday defended his role and the governments actions in bailing out the American International Group, saying Washington did what was necessary to prevent a second Great Depression, The New York Timess Mary Williams Walsh and Sewell Chan report from Washington.

title: Richard Wrights Estate Calls Google Book Settlement Grievously Flawed
description: In a last-minute statement (pdf) before a deadline to opt out of the Google Book Settlement, which would lead to the creation of a vast digital library, the estate of Richard Wright, author of Native Son and Black Boy, described the settlement as grievously flawed.

description: Starting today, the Comments portion of the Consults blog will get a makeover. Consistent with many of the other New York Times blogs, readers will be able to recommend comments. You will also be able to sort comments in a variety of ways: newest first, oldest first, reader recommendations, and editors selections.

title: Kurland Will Not Cooperate in Galleon Case
description: Mark Kurland, a former senior executive of New Castle Funds charged with insider trading in the Galleon Group case, has decided not to cooperate with investigators despite his expected guilty plea on Wednesday, people close to the case said.

title: Web Site of M.I.T. Tops List of Most Visited
description: With so many high school students leaving the family minivan in the garage and visiting colleges virtually, it was probably inevitable that some entity would try to count which university Web site gets the highest traffic.

title: Brainstorming for the Common Good
description: Organizers of the World Economic Forum tried on Wednesday to harness the wisdom of crowds for new insights into todays pressing global problems. But while it was a heck of a crowd  an elite group of academics, executives and at least one royal (Crown Prince Haakon of Norway)  it wasnt clear how much was learned.

title: Now Skating for (Insert Country)
description: TALLINN, Estonia  She is a 20-year-old from Richmond, Va. He is 24 and from Whitby, Ontario. Together, they compete for Greece as a professional pairs figure skating team.

title: Trending Topics Go Local: Regents Anyone?
description: For some time now, Twitter users have been able to track the services most frequent #hashtags and keywords as a way of gauging global trends, sharing jokes and forcing up the names of their favorite things.

title: Stage Is Set for Semifinals
description: Roger Federer will play his record 23rd consecutive Grand Slam semifinal against Jo-Wilfried Tsonga after Federer survived a confident Nikolay Davydenko and Tsonga outlasted Novak Djokovic on Wednesday.

title: Hope for Haiti Now Leads Album Sales
description: Hope for Haiti Now, the download-only album of performances from the Haiti benefit telethon on Friday night, is No. 1 on this weeks Billboard chart, outselling Susan Boyle, Lady Gaga and other hits by a wide margin despite being on sale for only part of the week. After going on sale through iTunes shortly before the show began on Friday, the album (released by MTV Networks, and for sale also through Amazon, Napster and Rhapsody) sold 171,000 copies in the United States through Sunday, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It is the first digital-only release to reach No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, and proceeds will benefit relief organizations.

title: Problems With Food Distribution in Haiti
description: Last Updated at 6:06 p.m. Two weeks after the devastating earthquake that left much of Haiti in ruins, food distribution to desperate Haitians remains limited and often chaotic.

title: Burned Out? So Are Your Kids
description: Parents who complain of feeling burned out at work are more likely to have kids who are burned out at school.

title: Obama to Reaffirm Commitment to an Overhaul
description: In a conference call today with Congressional staff, the White House communications director, Dan Pfeiffer, said that President Obama would reiterate his commitment to a comprehensive overhaul of the nations health care system in his State of the Union address on Wednesday night.

title: The New Indie Film Arms Race
description: It was barely a week ago that the Bagger parachuted into Sundance, ready to gorge on movies and parties. Mission accomplished! Though only a few films have sold since then (most notably Buried), and a few more have drawn the kind of attention that suggests distribution is imminent, there has been another kind of contest at play: At nearly every post-screening Q.&A. and interview, filmmakers have mentioned how long (or short) their shoot was. Its a badge of honor in the indie film world to get a movie in the can in 24 or 26 days, an indication of how economically (fiscally and timewise) you work. By that metric, Howl, the artsy feature about Allen Ginsberg, was a winner: it was shot in 14 days.

title: Berlin Fashion Week | Party Like Its 1929
description: Germany is still stuck in a financial slump, but judging from the nonstop revelry that took place at Mercedes-Benz Berlin Fashion Week, for the countrys tastemakers, life is a cabaret. Hugo Boss got the party started on Thursday at the Hamburger Bahnhof museum, with a post-show soiree following its Boss Black runway presentation. Guests, including celebrities like Hillary Swank and Matt Dillon, filed behind the stage and into a massive tent with an L.E.D.-lit dance floor and high-tech digital projections, not to mention four full bars, servers circling with magnums of Champagne and  get this  an open invitation to smoke. Try getting that kind of treatment in New York these days, where austerity is the new black. Compared to the party, which left many guests nursing massive hangovers at the next days shows, the collection was tame, working a high-end sexy secretary angle for women and a nerd-bird banker vibe for Mad Men-loving male clientele.

title: Same-Sex Marriage Case, Day 12: The End (for Now)
description: The Bay Area blog has been reporting daily from the federal courthouse in San Francisco on the case of Perry v. Schwarzenegger. That case is challenging the constitutionality of Proposition 8, the ban on same-sex marriage approved by voters in 2008. Among the lawyers on the plaintiffs team are Theodore B. Olson, David Boies, Theodore J. Boutrous Jr., Christopher Dean Dusseault, Christine Van Aken, Danny Chu, Matthew D. McGill and Therese Stewart. The legal team for the defense includes Brian Raum, Charles J. Cooper, David Thompson, Andrew Pugno, James Campbell, Jordan Lorence, Nicole Moss, Howard C. Nielson Jr. and Peter A. Patterson.

title: Two Pitchers Eyed by Mets Go Elsewhere
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets options of pitchers to fill out their rotation are shrinking rapidly. On Tuesday, Jon Garland agreed to a deal with the San Diego Padres, and Ben Sheets went to the Oakland Athletics. The Mets were interested in each player.

title: Digital Help for Haiti
description: People around the world have been yearning for meaningful ways to help the people of Haiti  and up to now, most have felt powerless to do much more than open their wallets.

title: Obama Will Endorse Paygo Law
description: President Obama is calling for a so-called paygo law  as in, pay as you go  that would require Congress to offset the cost of new tax cuts or spending on entitlement programs, like Medicare, with tax increases or spending cuts to avoid adding to the deficit, according to his press office.

title: Ministry of Matchmaking
description: Nickname for South Koreas health ministry  based on its unusual efforts to curb the countrys falling birth rate.

description: Louis Auchincloss, a Wall Street lawyer from a prominent old New York family who became a durable and prolific chronicler of Manhattans old-money elite, died on Tuesday night in Manhattan. He was 92.

description: Fiscal restraint will be one of President Obamas key messages tonight. The major planks are expected to include a three-year freeze on spending on some domestic programs as well as plans to establish a debt commission. In a new video, Jackie Calmes takes a look at the presidents shift to the center and at whether the spending freeze can attract bipartisan support.

title: Feeling Unsettled at a Feel-Good Show
description: I KNOW there is nothing a white person can say to a black person about race which is not both incorrect and offensive, James Spaders hard-driving lawyer says in the new David Mamet play, Race. I know that. Race is the most incendiary topic in our history. And the moment it comes out, you cannot close the lid on that box. That may change. But not for a long long while.

description: Update | 2:40 p.m.  Added link to Apples iPad video.

title: Salazar and Oil Group Trade Barbs
description: The war of words between the Obama administration and the oil industry continues.

title: Passing the Baton at the Opera Orchestra of New York
description: Eve Queler, the founder and longtime music director of the Opera Orchestra of New York, who has seen the institution through recent financial struggles, is preparing to step down from her post. The orchestra said in a news release that it had appointed Alberto Veronesi, the Italian conductor, to serve as its full-time music director starting with its 2011-12 season. Ms. Queler, who established the orchestra in 1971 to present concerts by established opera performers and emerging talents  including Rene Fleming, Deborah Voigt and Jos Carreras  will share the baton with Mr. Veronesi for the orchestras 40th anniversary season in 2010-11. During that time he will serve as music director designate and conduct an opera-in-concert performance. The next season, Ms. Queler will become conductor laureate, and Mr. Veronesi will begin a five-year term. Mr. Veronesi is the music director of the Puccini Festival at Torre del Lago and the Orchestra Sinfonica Siciliana, as well as the artistic director of the Filarmonica del Teatro Comunale di Bologna. He will retain these positions during his time with the Opera Orchestra.

title: A Note to Readers About Comments
description: Starting with this post, Laugh Lines is using a new commenting system.

title: The Sap Flows in Brooklyn. How Sweet it Is.
description: If you believe maple syrup can only be made in Vermont or upstate New York, think again. This time of year, the citys sugar maples are ripe for tapping. One three-story-high specimen in a backyard in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, yielded syrup old-fashioned and mellow. Read the full story by Ava Chin, the Urban Forager, on The Local.

title: Bernanke Responds to A.I.G. Questions
description: While Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner came under fire on Capitol Hill for the bailout of the American International Group, Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserves chairman, offered his defense in writing on Wednesday.

title: Leno Tells Winfrey He Hasnt Talked to OBrien
description: In his first interview after the upheaval in NBCs late-night schedule, Jay Leno told Oprah Winfrey that he had not yet talked over the situation with the man he is replacing at 11:35 each weeknight, Conan OBrien.

title: Louis Auchincloss, Chronicler of the Upper Crust, Is Dead at 92
description: Louis Auchincloss, a Wall Street lawyer from a prominent New York family who became a widely read author of dozens of books that plumbed the world of Manhattans old-money elite, died Tuesday night in Manhattan. He was 92.
