description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Jewelry Store Worker Killed in Upper East Side Robbery
description: Updated, 3:02 p.m. | A 71-year-old worker at a jewelry store on the Upper East Side was shot and killed in a brazen daytime robbery on Wednesday, the police said.

title: The Democrats Dark Valley
description: Anyone inclined to pin all the blame for last Tuesdays Senate outcome on poor hapless Martha Coakley should check out the numbers John Judis has compiled here, which compare Senate polling data to Barack Obamas approval ratings in Ohio, Pennsylvania, Missouri and Colorado. In each case, the trend is clear: As the presidents ratings drop, the Democratic Senate candidates number execute a nosedive as well, and the G.O.P. candidate pulls ahead. None of the plunges are as steep as the one that Coakley took, and none of these states are as solidly Democratic as Massachusetts. But I suspect that in the long run, shell look less and less like the worst Senate candidate since Alan Keyes, and more and more like the victim of a national climate that was beyond any individual Democrats control.

title: Passing Strange Collaborators Prepare a Concert
description: Stew and Heidi Rodewald, the rock artists who created the musical Passing Strange, are headed to St. Anns Warehouse in Brooklyn for a week next month to present the world premiere of a new multimedia concert tracking their journey from dive clubs to Broadway.

title: Construction Company Indicted in Kickback Scheme
description: A construction management company was indicted Wednesday on charges that it stole nearly $7 million from five condominium and office projects in Manhattan and elsewhere as part of a scheme involving fake invoices and kickbacks from electrical and other subcontractors.

title: State of the Union: An Advance Look
description: The Times' Jeff Zeleny takes an advance look at President Obama's first State of the Union speech.

title: What Obama Should Say Tonight
description: David Brooks: Gail, Im hoping to nudge you to release your secret plan to revive the Obama presidency. I know youve been keeping it in your desk drawer, under the explanation for why God allows evil to exist in the world and how consciousness emerges from the brain, and I was hoping if I asked real nice you might share it with me.

title: Questions for Lula Washington, Who Helped Avatar Move
description: Until recently the Los Angeles-based choreographer Lula Washington did not use e-mail. Actually, she resisted most forms of technology. Her dance company had a Web site; Ms.Washington just hadnt visited it. So its somehat interesting that a few years ago she found herself working with one of the most technologically innovative directors in Hollywood.

title: Haitians Scramble for Aid
description: France24 reports on desperate Haitians trying to get some aid food in the Cit Soleil district of Port-au-Prince.

title: Saab 9-5 and 9-4X: Promising, but Enough to Sustain Spyker?
description: If there ever was a feel-good story in the auto industry, this would be it: Spyker agrees to salvage Saab from the scrap heap. And it will cost the Dutch sports car maker only $74 million in cash and $326 million in preferred shares of the new company.

title: Against Wishes, Dawson Will Enter Hall as an Expo
description: Gary Carter is no longer the lone Montreal Expo in Cooperstown.

title: For Toyota Dealers, a Day of Patience and Preparation
description: Toyota dealers across the country faced a cacophony of messages on Wednesday: calls from panicky customers wondering whether their cars needed repair, pages of marching orders faxed from corporate headquarters, e-mail messages from salesmen asking if paychecks would be trimmed.

title: Fairey Said to Face Criminal Inquiry in Obama Photo Case
description: A criminal investigation is pending against the artist Shepard Fairey in connection with his use of an Associated Press photograph of Barack Obama, Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of the Southern District of New York revealed in a hearing on Tuesday, a lawyer involved in the case said on Wednesday.

title: Perils of the Parenting Playground
description: Every moment as a parent can feel filled with import  we have to say the right thing, make the right choice, set the right example. We are, after all, our childrens guides and teachers. Any small moment could be the one that launches or inspires them; together those moments will set the direction of their lives.

title: Anger at Exec Pay Trumps Politeness at Davos
description: A Welsh labor leader broke the World Economic Forums normally polite tone of debate on Wednesday to deliver a blast of populist sentiment on the issue of executive pay.

title: Reserve Management to Give Last Cash to Investors
description: Reserve Management, whose $60 billion Primary Fund money-market mutual fund collapsed shortly after the fall of Lehman Brothers, will return nearly all the remaining cash it has to investors.

title: Live Web Coverage of Obamas Speech
description: President Obama will deliver the State of the Union address at 9 p.m. Eastern, but the coverage and the conversation of the speech will begin long before  and linger long after  on The New York Times Web site and in the paper tomorrow.

title: A Day Before Vote on Bernanke, Fed Leaves Rates Alone
description: WASHINGTON The Federal Reserve decided not to rock the boat on Wednesday.

title: With Its Tablet, Apple Blurs Line Between Devices
description: SAN FRANCISCO  After months of feverish speculation, Steven P. Jobs introduced Wednesday what Apple hopes will be the coolest device on the planet: a slender tablet computer called the iPad.

title: Iraq Insurgency Group Says It Bombed Baghdad Hotels
description: BAGHDAD  An insurgent group known as the Islamic State of Iraq claimed responsibility Wednesday for this weeks bombings in Baghdad that wrecked three landmark hotels catering to foreigners and warned of more strikes.

title: Trade Center Site Developer Set Back
description: An arbitration panel has ruled against the developer Larry Silverstein on a series of critical issues involving the construction of three office towers at ground zero, including his request for free rent and, potentially, billions of dollars in damages from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the 16-acre site.

title: John and Elizabeth Edwards Are Separated
description: John and Elizabeth Edwards, whose marriage received outsized attention during the last two Democratic presidential campaigns, have legally separated, according to two people close to the family.

title: Book Review: Original Letters From India by Eliza Fay
description: Eliza Fay (1756-1816) was an actual Englishwoman, even if she was also, in the words of E. M. Forster, quite a work of art. Only a woman as confident in mind and body as Mrs. Fay could have survived the perilous adventures in foreign lands she relates here with such sang froid. As Simon Winchester writes in his introduction to this latest edition of her correspondence, she was someone for whom the words imperturbable, indomitable, and redoubtable might have been coined.

title: In Austria, a Chalet for the Night
description: STANDING 3,346 feet above sea level on a steep mountain slope overlooking the village of Bruck, Austria, I found it was easy to feel a little breathless. As the morning fog lifted, the jagged peaks of the Hohe Tauern mountain range  including the mighty Grossglockner, Austrias highest mountain at 12,460 feet  slowly emerged. Ah, these hills are very much alive.

title: At Davos, Sarkozy Calls for Global Finance Rules
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  France wants to use its presidency of the Group of 20 next year to create a new international monetary system, President Nicolas Sarkozy said on Wednesday, adding that he believed the dollar should no longer be the primary reserve currency in the global economy.

title: Bloomberg Wants Terror Trial Moved
description: For the first time, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has spoken out against plans to stage the trial of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, accused mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks, at the federal courthouse in Lower Manhattan, joining a growing chorus of people who believe the epic trial will be too disruptive and expensive for the city.

title: Hotel Review: W Hoboken in Hoboken, N.J.
description: THE BASICS

title: Donating Credit Card Points to Help Haiti
description: Credit card networks have already waived fees for certain donations aimed at helping Haiti. Now, many are also making it possible for you to redeem your rewards points to make donations to aid Haiti.

title: Louisiana Wins Fight for Hospital
description: Ending one of the longest-running disputes left by Hurricane Katrina, a federal arbitration panel ruled Wednesday that Louisiana would receive $474.8 million  nearly all it had requested  to pay for the replacement of Charity Hospital in New Orleans, which has been closed since the storm.

title: Why Companies Dont Open the Books
description: Ive noticed that some of my recent posts have stirred up skepticism in the comments section. Im not surprised that several of the comments have raised questions about whether open-book management can work in this company or that industry. Ive run into plenty of folks over the years who couldnt wait to tell me why open-book simply cant work at their company.

title: Honduras Swears In New President, as Ousted One Leaves
description: MEXICO CITY  The deposed former Honduran president, Manuel Zelaya, packed his guitar and flew into exile Wednesday as the country inaugurated a new president, who promised to try to repair the rifts left by months of political turmoil.

title: The Kids Benefit From Bidding War
description: A trace of the Sundance Film Festival of old, at least on the deal-making front, returned on Tuesday when a bidding war broke out for the comedy The Kids Are All Right. Focus Features was close to emerging victorious on Wednesday morning with a bid of just under $5 million, although people with knowledge of the matter said a deal was still incomplete. A Focus spokeswoman declined to comment.

title: Iran Continues Focus on Outside Provocateurs, Now Blaming Germany
description: CAIRO  Iranian officials continued to cast blame for the nations recent political crisis on foreign interference on Wednesday, focusing their ire for the first time on Germany, one of the countrys closest trading partners, with an accusation that its diplomats and intelligence agents helped organize protests at the end of December.

title: Case Study | White Dogs Day
description: Case Study is a bimonthly posting on all things alcoholic by Toby Cecchini, Ts spirits columnist.

title: James Taylors Carnegie Hall Plans
description: Carnegie Hall is entrusting a certain portion of its prestige to James Taylor, the singer-songwriter-guitarist with folk, blues and pop roots. It announced Wednesday that next season he would lead a Perspectives series, a high-profile element of its programming. At a news conference at Carnegie, Mr. Taylor said he was aware of the responsibility. Its something you rise to, he said.

title: Albany Grocery Powered by a Fuel Cell
description: Post corrected, 5:55 p.m., 1/27/2010

title: Answers About New Yorks Response to Haitis Earthquake
description: Following is the first set of responses from Elsie St. Louis-Accilien, the executive director of Haitian-Americans United for Progress.

title: Forget Jenny Craig. Hit the Drive-Thru.
description: CAN eating fast food help you lose weight?

title: Volunteer Rate Barely Budged in 2009
description: Despite the deluge of layoffs, volunteer rates in the United States barely budged in 2009, according to a new report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Samurai Shopper | Post-Traumatic Tress Disorder
description: Every time I get a haircut I need new hair products. I dont know what it is: weird science, astrology, diabolical plots, but whatever products work for a while just up and die once Im snipped and styled.

title: Brooklyn Sweetness
description: On the Local blog, getting a jump on the maple syrup season in Brooklyn. Two gallons of sap from a neighbors tree renders a cup of syrup and makes an apartment smell like candy.

title: Obamas Themes: Rescue, Rebuild, Restore
description: The State of the Union address is less than six hours away, and President Obama and his aides are still putting final touches on the speech, but the White House has provided a set of talking points to Capitol Hill that outlines the central themes he intends to touch upon.

title: Northern Ireland Talks Near Collapse
description: LONDON  Talks aimed at preventing the collapse of the power-sharing government in Northern Ireland appeared to be on the brink of failure on Wednesday when the British and Irish prime ministers withdrew after three days of talks and flew back to their respective capitals.

title: Lowdown on Getting High: The Risks of the Choking Game and Legal Substance Abuse
description: Overview | What is the choking game? What dangers and long-term consequences are associated with it and with other ways that teenagers get high aside from using illegal drugs? In this lesson, students reflect on high-risk, readily available, often legal ways teenagers achieve a high, using stories, facts and statistics to make connections and learn the risks and dangers associated with these activities. Then they go further by making skits or public service announcements to warn classmates or younger students about these dangers.

title: Photo of the Week
description: A tourist rides his horse around the Apoyo Lagoon, in Nicaragua.

title: Catholic Bishops Urge Congress Not to Abandon Overhaul
description: Theology can make for confusing politics, especially in partisan Washington.

title: More Executives Warn on Too-Tough Regulations
description: Global business leaders warned Western governments on Wednesday that a populist crackdown on the financial industry could crimp a fragile recovery from the worst recession since the 1930s.

title: House Panels Other Punching Bag Is Goldman
description: Along with taking swipes at Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner, House committee members investigating the governments bailout of the American International Group vented their anger on Wednesday at the insurers largest trading partner, Goldman Sachs, which was paid $12.9 billion to unwind derivative contracts without being forced to make concessions.

title: Officer Testifies He Saw No Abuse of Mineo
description: A police officer who helped arrest Michael Mineo testified on Wednesday morning that he never saw any of his colleagues pull down Mr. Mineos pants or jab a baton into Mr. Mineos buttocks as they arrested him in a Brooklyn subway station in October 2008.

title: Coca-Colas Super Bowl Ad Plans Include Social Media
description: Coca-Cola is telling Pepsi-Cola that when it comes to Super Bowl advertising, you can walk and chew gum at the same time.

title: Hobbled by Illness, Mike Sutton Perseveres at Tennessee Tech
description: COOKEVILLE, Tenn.  Mike Sutton, the Tennessee Tech mens basketball coach, could not grip a pen for a year, so he could not draw plays. The three months he spent on a ventilator robbed him of a loud voice, so it was difficult for him to command players. His legs were weak from nerve damage, so he could not stalk the referees on the sideline.

title: Amid Earthquakes Ruins, Signs of Revival in Haiti
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  This devastated capital showed increasing signs of stirring back to life on Wednesday as Haitians restarted factory assembly lines, visited their barbers, sought replacement cellphones and even picked up their dry cleaning.

title: The Nifty 50 | Jason Blum, Producer
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: A Banjo Head for Haiti
description: Pete Seeger, the tireless folk troubadour and environmental advocate, isnt among the pop artists featured on the Hope for Haiti Now fund-raising CD. He is, however, lending his voice  and his beloved banjo  to the cause.

title: Drive-Thru Dieting
description: The words weight loss and fast food arent often used in the same sentence, but that may be changing soon. Taco Bell is promoting its new Drive-Thru Diet after a 27-year-old Pensacola, Fla., woman claimed to lose weight on a diet of fast-food tacos. And chains from Dunkin Donuts to Kentucky Fried Chicken are now touting lower-calorie fare.

title: Koraro: The Sustainability Factor
description: The following is the sixth and final post in a series of reports from the Ethiopian village of Koraro, an important testing ground for the Millennium Village Project, an experiment in global development strategy spearheaded by economist Jeffrey Sachs. The reports, written by Jeff Marlow, a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, consider which parts of the project are working and which ones arent, and what can be learned from it to help billions of people escape extreme poverty.

title: Arrest in Killing of Queens Job-Agency Owner
description: Updated, 6:22 p.m. | A Queens man has been arrested in the stabbing death of a woman who ran an employment agency from which he had sought help finding a job, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said on Wednesday. Another woman was also arrested, charged with helping the killer dispose of the murder weapon.

title: The Apple iPad: First Impressions
description: Today Apple finally unveiled its tablet computer, the iPad. Thus concludes Phase 1 of the standard Apple new-category roll-out: months of feverish speculation and hype online, without any official indication by Apple that the product even exists.

title: An Unlikely Haven for Rock n Roll Entrepreneurs
description: LITITZ, Pa.  This small town in Pennsylvania Dutch country, in the midst of cornfields and dairy farms, would seem an unlikely home for a warehouse filled with the detritus of rock concerts past and future  a large section of the stage for the next Black Eyed Peas tour, the sets for an Elton John concert and gigantic lips from the Rolling Stones.

title: Word of the Moment | Brocavore
description: brok vr (n.) | A dude involved in the local food movement and restaurant scene. Typically identified by his fixed-gear bicycle, tattoos, facial hair and fondness for craft beer (preferably Sixpoint) in a jar and early Pavement. Commonly seen at Robertas, Prime Meats, the Bell House.

title: New Search for the Truth in A Lie
description: SAM SHEPARD already had Buried Child, True West and other plays about dysfunctional families to his credit in 1985, when he directed the premiere of his ensemble drama A Lie of the Mind, which depicts two families torn by violence and resentments. Starring Harvey Keitel, Geraldine Page, Amanda Plummer and Aidan Quinn, the production ran off Broadway for six months and won the Drama Desk Award for best play, among other honors.

title: David Pogues First Look at the Apple iPad
description: David Pogue, the personal technology columnist for The New York Times, got his hands on the new Apple iPad for a few minutes. He didnt have a chance to do a full review, but here are a few of his impressions:

title: For Disaster-Struck Haitians, Arrival in U.S. Does Not Mean an End to Problems
description: MIAMI  Marie Violande Guerrier-Cavalier arrived in Florida from Haiti on Jan. 16, with little more than her feverish infant son, Marcley, his tiny legs in casts because of a birth defect. She left her husband and four other children behind, living in the yard outside their broken house.

title: The Blogosphere Reacts to the Apple iPad
description: The iPad made its debut today in San Francisco. Although technology writers seemed excited about the device, there are also some concerns about the iPads limitations, including lack of camera, no SD card support, no Adobe Flash support and the lack of multitasking with applications.

title: Send In the Toads
description: For the record, the dudes from Animal Collective, the Brooklyn hipsterimental band, are very excited to see Cane Toads: The Conquest in 3-D. But the documentary, Sundances first 3-D feature, conflicted with the Tuesday night premiere for their film, ODDSAC, a sort of extended psychedelic video. So they consoled themselves by D.J.ing at their own afterparty, at the Star Bar, on what was perhaps Sundances most stoner-friendly evening.

title: Pictures of the Day: Wednesday, Jan. 27
description: It is an unusual day that a celebration leads this slide show, but supporters of President Mahinda Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka had reason to rejoice after he was re-elected by a wide margin. Lynsey Addario  whom Lens readers may recall as having been injured in Pakistan and then winning a MacArthur Foundation genius award  was in Colombo, shooting for The Times. Tyler Hicks, in Afghanistan, transmitted a picture of a card game at Combat Outpost Geronimo that Rembrandt might have painted (Slide 4). And Richard Drew of The Associated Press found an appealingly different angle on the clich Wall Street Reacts photo from the floor of the Stock Exchange (Slide 8). Note the text of the crawling titles on the television screen.

title: Quest for Joy and Wonder Before Time Runs Out
description: The cues for tenderness and uplift are all over Live for the Moment: the choked-back tears, the crowds of applauding family and friends, the corny speeches, the constant reiterations (essential for this sort of reality show) of how amazing the whole experience has been. Those of us who find it slightly depressing and more than a little creepy are probably outside the target audience to begin with.

title: Oracle to Live the Life Quixotic With Sun Products
description: As I laid out in an article Wednesday, Oracle expects that through its acquisition of Sun Microsystems, it has a way to sell a full spectrum of hardware and software to business customers.

title: The Screwtape Letters to Return to New York
description: The Screwtape Letters, a play adapted from the C.S. Lewis novel about humanity and Christianity from the viewpoint of devils, will return to New York this spring after a national tour that drew large audiences and good reviews from critics.

title: The Alabama Jihadist
description: How did a popular kid from a small town in Alabama wound up connected to Al Qaeda?

title: Federal Rules Dictated That Toyota Halt Sale of Recalled Vehicles
description: Toyota had no choice but to stop selling eight different models while it works out a way to fix what the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has called a dangerous accelerator pedal issue.

title: Simple Ritualistic Dances, Profound Spiritual Context
description: The latest addition to Ralph Lemons i get lost, part of Danspace Projects continuing Platform series, wasnt an actual dance performance but a panel discussion and film documenting Haitian voodoo dances from the middle of the last century. The Haitian Footage: Maya Deren Unedited, shown at Anthology Film Archives on Tuesday night, featured film from Derens study of dances and rituals captured during visits to Haiti, from 1947 to 1954.

title: Kurland Pleads Guilty in Galleon Insider Case
description: Mark Kurland, a former senior executive of New Castle Funds who was accused of insider trading in the Galleon Group case, pleaded guilty to two counts of securities fraud on Wednesday afternoon.

title: Remembering George Perle, With Humor
description: George Perle could seem a model of compositional sobriety: a composer of complex but poetic works, influenced by serialism but not wedded to its techniques or accents, and a theorist who wrote with clarity and passion about thorny aspects of contemporary style.

title: What to Watch: Federer vs. Tsonga
description: The last time Roger Federer failed to make the semifinals of a Grand Slam, President Obama was an obscure state senator from Illinois. Gustavo Kuerten beat Federer in the third round of the French Open in May 2004, but since then, Federer has been a model of consistency. His 15 Grand Slam titles may receive more notice, but a case can be made that reaching 23 consecutive semifinals in tennis major championships is the more difficult record to break.

title: One Object of Desire, Delivered
description: An audition can be a serious psychodrama, as any actor will tell you  probably at length, over a six pack of Pabst Blue Ribbon or a couple of dirty martinis. But the teeter-tottering test of wills that takes place in Venus in Fur, a tasty new comedy-drama by David Ives at the Classic Stage Company, makes even the most fraught encounter between a domineering director and a sensitive performer seem like a play date in the sandbox. Actors may be pleased to hear that in this 90 minutes of good, kinky fun, the upper hand does not necessarily belong to the usual suspect.

title: Swiss Back Away From Deal to Give Names of Rich UBS Clients to U.S.
description: The Swiss government on Wednesday backed off an agreement with the United States that required it to hand over the names of wealthy American clients of the Swiss bank UBS who were suspected of tax evasion.

title: From Mexico, a Soaring and Resilient Free Spirit
description: With her high, clear voice and insouciant phrasing, the Mexican songwriter Natalia Lafourcade sounds like a very wise child: affectionate, sly, sophisticated and resilient. Ms. Lafourcade performed solo at S.O.B.s on Tuesday night, playing guitar or piano and stripping away the multifarious arrangements  sometimes orchestral, sometimes electronic, sometimes rock  of her songs, concentrating on her 2009 album, Hu Hu Hu (Sony BMG Mexico). But she kept the musics whimsical grace.

title: The One-Sided Relationship of ONeal and James
description: When the Cleveland Cavaliers acquired Shaquille ONeal in the off-season, the decision was met with mixed reviews. On the plus side, ONeal is still a very effective player thanks to his size and skill. Unfortunately, he does his thing by crowding the paint, an area in Cleveland normally reserved for LeBron James. Has ONeal had a positive or a negative impact on the superstar through the first half of the season? I turned to the statistics to find out.

title: As Hong Kongs Political System Stalls, So Does Its Democracy Movement
description: HONG KONG  The political system in Hong Kong is increasingly paralyzed, and street protests are growing more confrontational as public dissatisfaction on economic issues and a lack of democracy is rising. At the same time, the pro-democracy movement here has splintered, weakening its ability to press for changes.

title: Craig Joins Skadden, Arps
description: Gregory B. Craig, the former White House counsel, has landed back at one of the nations premier law firms just a few weeks after leaving the West Wing.

title: Stern Issues Suspensions to Deter Use of Guns
description: N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern issued two lengthy suspensions Wednesday and one solemn warning about players carrying firearms.

title: Warm and Fuzzy Department | Jim Drains Wearable Art
description: The artist Jim Drain has gained recognition for his vivid, abstract textile sculptures, whose soft, almost cuddly aspect renders them all the more strange and startling. Recently turning an eye toward fashion, and backed by the Greene Naftali gallery, Drain created a collection of limited-edition sweaters, just 29 in all, available now at Opening Ceremony. Their bright colors and pixellated patterns  a series of connected hearts, streaming data and brain waves, a wall of bricks kicked in by a midair ninja  have caught the eye of shoppers like Bjork. T reached Drain, 34, in Miami, where he lives and works.

title: From Neoliberal Paradise to Paradigm of Serpents
description: The neoclassical model of economics failed a lot earlier than in the current crisis, at least according to Richard Thaler, a professor of behavioral economics at the University of Chicago. Lets go back to Adam Smith, Mr. Thaler suggested on a high-profile panel on Rebuilding Economics. No, actually, lets go back to Adam.

title: War Rooms Set Up for Speech, Using Web Tools
description: You can tell its the age of social media, text messaging, and the swift moving news cycle.

title: Knowledge Is Good. But Is Technology?
description: The timing was simply too delicious to pass without comment.

title: When Mommies Are Bullies
description: Have you ever been bullied online?

title: Catch Me if You Can
description: Grouper has been a fixture of South Carolina eating for what seems like centuries, but right now its harder to source than Iranian caviar.

title: Triggerfish With Pistou and Garden Vegetables
description: 4 cups water

title: Sterns Statement on Suspensions of Wizards
description: N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern has suspended Washington Wizards teammates Gilbert Arenas and Javaris Crittenton for the rest of the season for bringing unloaded handguns into the locker room and displaying them during a Dec. 21 dispute.

title: Tour dEurope
description: Need more exercise than a seven-day biking trip along the rolling hills of Tuscany? Tour dAfrique, an outfitter based in Toronto, is offering a 42-day, nine-country, 1,925-mile bike marathon across Europe

title: YoGen Uses Elbow Grease to Recharge Devices
description: The $40 YoGen, from Easy Energy, is one of a crop of cellphone chargers made to provide emergency power when a wall outlet is not available. The YoGen is smaller than a pack of cards. To charge a device (the YoGen is compatible with a variety of portable items, including iPods and digital cameras), you pull on a nylon self-retracting string, as if you were trying to start an outboard motor.

title: Too Cool for School | Tavi Grows Up
description: Dearly beloved, I have gathered you in this intimate venue of the Internet to bid farewell to the Old Tavi. The shy, awkward preteen I first encountered almost two years ago has, as of yesterdays sighting at the Paris couture shows, officially gone to the great beyond.When we first met, she was a pocket-size child with Moms-choice eyeglasses and a tiny helium voice who wore Converse sneakers and a thrifted skirt. When I saw a picture of her in Paris yesterday, I gasped. Newly dyed ice-blue locks, giant sunglasses (indoors, of course) and shocking red lips set in a No pictures right now, please pout. She is a confident and poised young woman, who now gets gifted couture hats by Stephen Jones (which received this oddly controversial wearing the day before) and sits front row at Chanel (no big deal). Tavi 2.0 has arrived. And she is major. Farewell, little suburban girl. You will be remembered fondly in the Blogspot archives.

title: Madden as the New Game Film
description: An article in the February issue of Wired says that the Madden NFL video game has given todays football players a major edge over their predecessors by vastly increasing their knowledge of complex football concepts at earlier ages.

title: Heavy Lies the Head of the Head of State
description: Theres a certain campy pleasure in bad special effects. Think of Godzilla, or pretty much any episode of Star Trek, ever.

title: From Sundances Snow to Oscars Stage
description: As Sundance nears its final stretch and the Oscar nominations loom, the Bagger is hearing more and more about the Apple iPad.

title: Charles Anthony Sings
description: The opera singer as the Emperor in Giacomo Puccini's "Turandot," followed by a brief interview with Patricia Racette. Conductor: Andris Nelsons. Video courtesy the Metropolitan Opera.

title: New Music Director for Opera Orchestra
description: Eve Queler, the founder and longtime music director of the Opera Orchestra of New York, who has seen the institution through recent financial struggles, is preparing to step down. The orchestra said in a news release that it had appointed Alberto Veronesi, the Italian conductor, as music director starting with its 2011-12 season. Ms. Queler, who established the orchestra in 1971 to present concerts by established opera performers and emerging talents  including Rene Fleming, Deborah Voigt and Jos Carreras  will share the baton with Mr. Veronesi for the orchestras 40th anniversary season in 2010-11. During that time he will serve as music director-designate and conduct an opera-in-concert performance. The next season, Ms. Queler will become conductor laureate, and Mr. Veronesi will begin a five-year term.

title: Passing Strange Team Ready With New Show
description: Stew and Heidi Rodewald, the rock artists who created the musical Passing Strange, are headed to St. Anns Warehouse in Brooklyn for a week next month to star in the world premiere of a new multimedia concert tracking their journey from dive clubs to Broadway. The concert, Making It, will run Feb. 17 to 22 at St. Anns and be conducted by Stew, with a cycle of new songs and set and video design by Jim Findlay and Jeff Sugg. St. Anns commissioned the piece as a vehicle to explore the relationships of Stew and Ms. Rodewald to work, success and self-perception as critically acclaimed collaborators. For Passing Strange, Stew won the 2008 Tony Award for best book of a musical.

title: Hope for Haiti Now Leads Album Sales
description: Hope for Haiti Now, the download-only album of performances from the Haiti benefit telethon last Friday night, is No. 1 on this weeks Billboard chart, widely outselling Susan Boyle, Lady Gaga and other hitmakers despite being on sale for only part of the week. After going on sale through iTunes shortly before the show began on Friday, the album (released by MTV Networks, and for sale also through Amazon, Napster and Rhapsody) sold 171,000 copies in the United States through Sunday, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It is the first digital-only release to reach No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, and proceeds will benefit relief organizations. Ms. Boyles I Dreamed a Dream (Syco Music/Columbia) is at No. 2 with 86,000 sales, followed by Lady Gagas The Fame (Interscope) with 62,000, and Spoons Transference (Merge) at No. 4 with 53,000. The album 2010 Grammy Nominees (Grammy Recordings/EMI), a 20-track compilation with Beyonc, the Black Eyed Peas, Taylor Swift and other nominees, reached No. 5 in its first week out, with 49,000 sales. Last weeks No. 1, Vampire Weekends Contra (XL), dropped to No. 6 with 43,000.

title: New York Pops Takes Chance on Abba
description: The great 2010 Abba-thon continues: following the news of a museum in London honoring that best-selling Swedish pop quartet, the New York Pops said on Wednesday that it was planning a concert of Abba music to kick off its 2010-11 season. On Oct. 15 at Carnegie Hall, the Pops will present The Music of Abba, with Rajaton, the Finnish vocal ensemble, performing hits like Dancing Queen, Mamma Mia and Take a Chance on Me. Other events on the Pops schedule include an 80th-birthday celebration for Stephen Sondheim on Nov. 19; a holiday concert with Brian Stokes Mitchell on Dec. 10 and 11; a performance of El Ritmo de la Vida, a new work of Latin music by Doc Severinsen, the former Tonight Show band leader, on Jan. 28, 2011; and a concert honoring the 50th anniversary of Judy Garlands Carnegie Hall debut.

title: NCIS Challenges Idol
description: American Idol led Fox to a ratings victory on Tuesday but by a surprisingly narrow margin. According to Nielsens estimates, Idol had the nights largest audience with 24.2 million viewers, about four million more than the one for CBSs NCIS (20.1 million) at 8. CBS led both the 9 and 10 p.m. hours with NCIS: Los Angeles (17.2 million) and a repeat of The Good Wife (10.3 million). NBC was third on the night with The Biggest Loser (9.7 million) and The Jay Leno Show (6.3 million), while ABC finished fourth with Scrubs (3.3 million) and Better Off Ted (2.5 million).

title: Artist Is Facing Criminal Probe Over His Use of Obama Photo
description: A judge revealed in a hearing on Tuesday that a criminal investigation was pending against the artist Shepard Fairey in connection with his use of an Associated Press photograph of Barack Obama, a lawyer involved in the case said on Wednesday. At the hearing the judge,  Alvin K. Hellerstein of the Southern District of New York, denied a motion by Mr. Fairey to delay a deposition in a civil case while the criminal investigation was pending. In a letter obtained by The New York Times, a lawyer for Mr. Fairey also referred to a criminal investigation; also, The Associated Press said it had received a grand jury subpoena in the case. The letter requested that Tuesdays hearing be sealed, based on the fact that the motion relates to a grand jury investigation by the U.S. Attorneys office. The letter, signed by Meir Feder of the firm Jones Day, added that an open hearing on these issues would risk compromising the confidential nature of the criminal investigation. That motion was also denied. The legal dispute hinges on whether Mr. Fairey had the right to use an A.P. photo of Mr. Obama for his Hope poster. In October Mr. Fairey, at right with his poster, admitted that he had lied in court papers about using a different photograph of Mr. Obama, and that he had created false documents to cover the discrepancy.

title: The Keeper of Moscows Architectural Conscience
description: No one who visited the office of David Sarkisyan, the outspoken director of the Shchusev State Museum of Architecture in Moscow, soon forgot the experience. Wedged behind an ornate desk cluttered with Soviet-era souvenirs, architectural tchotchkes and ashtrays, he was constantly fulminating against the decrepit state of that citys landmarks, enthusing about a drawing he had discovered buried somewhere in the museums archives, making introductions among the architects, historians and socialites who constantly wandered in and out, or pleading over the phone with the few journalists and government officials he felt he could trust.

title: Bridging the Gap: The Campaign for a Bike Lane on the Bay Bridge Western Span
description: Its one of the most frustrating few miles in the Bay Area for bicyclists: The Bay Bridge.

title: Journals New York Edition Faces a Delay
description: Technical snags threaten to delay Rupert Murdochs plan to create a metropolitan edition of The Wall Street Journal and go head-to-head locally with The New York Times, according to several people briefed on the matter. To keep to its schedule, the project needs outside help  help that could come from, of all places, The Times.

title: High-Zoom Camera Provides Something for Every Traveler
description: Those who travel frequently will find a lot to like in the new high-zoom Samsung HZ35W. The camera can tag photos with the exact location (longitude and latitude coordinates) where shots were taken. It can also display the name of the city, state and country on its screen, and a mapping feature enables you to view the photos locations on a map without having to upload the images to the Internet or photo-editing software.

title: Picture This: One Frame to View All Your Photos
description: Media Street has created a service called LifeGoRound that serves as a content portal for its eMotion Social Connect digital frame, an 8-inch Wi-Fi-enabled display priced at $149. The LifeGoRound Web site enables you to view photos stored at sharing sites like Flickr, Picasa, Photobucket and Wal-Mart.

title: App of the Week: Got Any Art Exhibits Around Here?
description: If coffee shops, malls and the gym have lost their indoor-leisure charm, Artnear, an app for the iPhone and BlackBerry, offers an alternative.

title: Pizza Chain Comes Off the Sidelines for Super Bowl
description: Papa Johns International, which will advertise for the first time during a Super Bowl game, plans to run a commercial that may not look to many viewers like one.

title: Three Choreographers, Bound by Their Way With a Ballet Twist
description: WASHINGTON  The acronym of Ashton-Ratmansky-Tharp spells ART, and the Ashton-Ratmansky-Tharp program at the Kennedy Center here, with which American Ballet Theater began its new year, proves a lavish display of the art of ballet itself. Vocabulary, style, poetry, invention: if youd never seen ballet before, you could learn much about its capacity from these three alone.

title: Despite Assurances, Met Finds Artworks Arent Restored Overnight
description: After a museumgoers trip and fall opened a rip in a century-old Picasso painting last week at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, officials there assured the public that  nightmarish as accidents are at a place entrusted with protecting priceless art  conservators would be able to fix the work quickly, in time for a major Picasso show in April.

title: Yelp Gets a Five-Star Review from Elevation Partners
description: Yelp, the popular Web site for reviews of local businesses, has a new investor: Elevation Partners, a private equity firm that has committed up to $100 million to the company.

title: Jeff Daniels to Return to God of Carnage
description: The producers of God of Carnage showed a playful touch this afternoon, announcing that Jeff Daniels  who appeared in the original cast last year  would return to the Broadway run in March, but this time in the role first played by James Gandolfini, and that the Charlies Angels star Lucy Liu would barrel her way into the fray as well.

title: How Much Grass Must Be in Organic Milk?
description: President Obama has a lot on his plate, but hes about to get more from activists who want cows to be required to eat more grass before the milk they produce can get the federal organic shield.

title: Three Reasons Why the iPad WONT Kill Amazons Kindle
description: It may be suddenly fashionable to say so, but the new Apple iPad tablet wont kill the Kindle from Amazon. Here are three reasons. My colleague, Nick Bilton, has weighed in on this topic from the opposite side. Please add your thoughts in the comments section below.

title: For Hmong Hunters, a Guiding Voice in Their New Home
description: SACRAMENTO  Along the barren airwaves of AM radio in Northern California, somewhere between gospel music and traffic updates, Yia Yang can be heard telling his devoted listeners to always be aware of their gun muzzles.

title: Lobbying and Risky Lending
description: A paper finds that the banks that lobbied most on mortgage lending and securitization issues also happened to engage in riskier lending strategies. Coincidence?

title: Woozy, Moody Pop Played at a Resting Pulse Rate
description: The Patti Smith tangle atop Victoria Legrands head was quaking something fierce on Tuesday night while all around her stillness was the move. Otherwise the most energy emanated from flickering neon lights trapped inside trees of white fur and occasionally the small bursts of life from her Beach House band mate, Alex Scally, or the touring drummer, Dan Franz.

title: After Arrest, Provocateurs Tactics Questioned
description: NEW ORLEANS  Shortly after news broke of his arrest on charges of trying to tamper with the telephones in Senator Mary L. Landrieus district office here, James OKeefe III posted a brief statement on Twitter: I am a journalist, it read. The truth shall set me free.

title: Schumann and Chopin: Another Thing in Common
description: To the Editor:

title: Laura Linney: The Reader
description: To the Editor:

title: From the Lunch Line to the Front Line
description: Wednesday morning, 77 newly minted emergency medical technicians joined the New York Fire Department in a graduation ceremony at the Fire Academy on Randalls Island.

title: Political Posters: A Precedent?
description: To the Editor:

title: Nelson Planned to Insist on Tighter Abortion Restrictions
description: As negotiations on major health care legislation went down to the wire last month, Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, won a lot of attention as the 60th member of the Democratic caucus to commit to voting for the bill.

title: Cond Nast and Time Inc. Cheer iPad; Others Have Doubts
description: No tablet-ready magazines were unveiled at Apples event on Wednesday, but Sarah Chubb, president of Cond Nast Digital, said that did not concern her.

title: For Gamers, the iPhone Is a Player
description: Quick, name the fastest-growing video game platform. Wii? PlayStation? DS?

title: Connecting a PSP to a Mac
description: Connecting

title: Bright Lights, Green Living
description: Hours before dawn Wednesday, a half dozen college students and professors arrived in Times Square, across from the TKTS booth, to begin setting up a small but chic abode called Lumenhaus.

title: In Paris, Tempted by History
description: Paris

title: After 10 Years, Age-Bias Suit Ends in Changed Hollywood
description: LOS ANGELES  People here rarely bother to hide the way that Hollywood covets youth. Film and television stars regularly brag about their latest plastic surgery procedures, and even the people who toil behind the cameras have been known to lie about their age to secure work.

title: The Web Way to Learn a Language
description: The young woman seated next to us at the sushi bar exuded a vaguely exotic air; her looks and style, we thought, made it likely that she was not American born.

title: iCountry News
description: The maestro has spoken. The all-powerful Oz has come and gone. Behold: after a buildup so big it makes the State of the Union speech look like a rebranding of Grape Nuts, Steve Jobs has descended from the mountain with a tablet. The written word is safe  for now  with him.

title: Its Old Timers Day at Shepards Arena
description: Even as they face their twilight years, those Shepard boys are still tearing down the house. Ever since he sent a demented young man hurtling through a wall in La Turista in the mid-1960s, Sam Shepard has been the go-to American playwright for onstage demolition. Rest assured that in his Ages of the Moon, the two-character sigh of a play that opened Wednesday night at the Linda Gross Theater in Chelsea, there will be destruction of property.

title: G.O.P. Chief Opposes Ideology Tests for Candidates
description: HONOLULU  The chairman of the Republican National Committee on Wednesday denounced a proposed resolution that would require Republican candidates to adhere to a checklist of conservative positions in order to receive party support, warning that it could undercut his party as it seeks to rebuild and win back control of Congress.

title: After 57 Years at the Met, a Tenors Swan Song
description: Would a Caruso by another name be as memorable?

title: BlackRocks Big Deal Gives Huge Boost to Profits
description: Completing the biggest deal of its history has been kind to BlackRock, the giant money manager.

title: The iPad: A Media Machine That Opens Up a New Front
description: Can you create a whole new category merely by changing one little letter? Will the iPad be a bigger game-changer than the iPod, and perhaps have a similarly transformative effect on media providers?

title: Apple's iPad Tablet
description: John Markoff and Jenna Wortham of The Times discuss Apple's latest announcement: the iPad tablet.

title: Judge Rejects Former Garden Executives Lawsuit Over YES Network
description: A federal judge in Manhattan rejected on Tuesday all claims made by a former president of Madison Square Garden that he gave George Steinbrenner, the Yankees principal owner, the idea for the YES Network.

title: What the New York Fed Bought in A.I.G.s Bailout
description: One more secret of the American International Groups bailout became public on Wednesday: a list of the tens of billions of dollars in toxic assets that the Federal Reserve Bank of New York bought for 100 cents on the dollar from A.I.G.s trading partners.

title: What to Do If Your Car Accelerates Uncontrollably
description: As Toyota deals with a recall and a sales moratorium on eight of its American models, readers may be wondering what action they should take if they find themselves in a car that accelerates out of control. Some drivers have tried to turn off the ignition, but found that their steering wheels locked up, creating another hazard. And other drivers have been unable to figure out how to turn off cars with push-button ignitions.

title: In an Online Matchup, a Younger Player Surprises a Veteran
description: When Benito Garozzo and I played online with juniors on Dec. 30 at bridgebase.com, Garozzos first partner, Jan Novotny from the Czech Republic, made a great play on the diagramed deal.

title: The Lost Books of the Odyssey
description: Chapter 1: A Sad Revelation

title: Odysseus Engages in Spin, Heroically
description: In one of the chapters in Zachary Masons dazzling debut novel, Odysseus  the wily warrior and canny voyager from Homers epic poem  emerges as the creator of his own legend. Hes a war-weary soldier who leaves the battlefield and finds refuge outside Troy, posing as an itinerant bard, a poet who begins by singing the classics and later takes to telling the story of Odysseus of the Greeks, cleverest of men, whose ruses had been the death of so many.

title: Parsing the State of the State of the Union
description: When presidents deliver their State of the Union address, they love to report that the state of our union is strong, or some variation on that old trope. So what does a president say when the state of the union is palpably not so strong?

title: Web Resources for the State of the Union Speech
description: President Obama will deliver the State of the Union address at 9 p.m. Eastern. NYTimes.com will provide several ways to watch, read and react tonight.

title: Acers e-Book Reader Due in Summer
description: Acer Inc., no slouch when it comes to competing in the personal computer space, plans to enter the electronic-book reader arena later this year, as well as to offer a version of Googles Chrome operating system on a netbook before the end of 2010.

title: Panasonic Adds GPS to Its Slim Super-Zoom
description: Panasonic has upgraded its popular super-zoom compact ZS line to include built-in GPS capabilities and has added a tougher follow-up to its rugged TS1 snap-shooter.

title: Dont Ask, Dont Tell: Dont Keep
description: Besides Afghanistan and Iraq, there is perhaps no military policy that raises as much controversy within the public domain as Dont Ask, Dont Tell.

title: Rapid Growth Has Its Perils, Toyota Learns
description: DETROIT  Toyota executives set an ambitious goal in 2002 to own 15 percent of the global auto industry by 2010, meaning it would surpass General Motors as the worlds largest carmaker. To get there, it would have to grow by 50 percent. It would have to build new plants in the United States, China, and elsewhere in Asia, and introduce dozens of new models.

title: App of the Week: An Artful Answer to Cabin Fever
description: Its that time of the year when cabin fever makes you desperate to get out of the house, but the weather still makes a casual stroll more unpleasant than staying in.

title: Demo of the Apple iPad
description: A quick look at Apple's new tablet device, the iPad

title: Pentax Focuses on High Design, Low Cost
description: Pentax has announced a trio of new snap-shooters that focus on design and affordability. For the first time, the camera maker offers an entry-level model that squeaks in a nickel below $100.

title: Is the iPad the Final Nail in the GPS Coffin?
description: If the GPS Industry was worried that its dash-top navigation devices were being replaced by mobile phones with turn-by-turn software, wait until they get a look at the new Apple iPad.

title: Study Offers an Insight Into Dinosaur Colors
description: What color were dinosaurs? Well, at least one of them had a feathered mohawk tail in a subdued palette of chestnut and white stripes.

title: S.E.C. Adds Climate Risk to Disclosure List
description: WASHINGTON  The Securities and Exchange Commission said on Wednesday for the first time that public companies should warn investors of any serious risks that global warming might pose to their businesses.

title: Three Reasons Why the iPad WILL Kill Amazons Kindle
description: My colleague Brad Stone just blogged about why he thinks Apples iPad wont kill the Kindle from Amazon.com.

title: Excerpts From the Address
description: Following are excerpts from President Obama's first State of the Union address, as released by the White House:

title: The Verdict: Our Union Is Strong
description: The answer is in: President Obama is sticking to the traditional assertion that the union is strong  but with the caveat that times are tough.

title: Live Blogging the Presidents Address
description: A Memorable, Unusual Moment | 10:38 p.m.  David Kirkpatrick notes a rare moment of confrontation. As Mr. Obama criticized the recent ruling on campaign finance, Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. appeared to correct him.(The justices reaction is captured on YouTube.)

title: The State of Obama
description: In the wake of the Massachusetts results, there was a lot of chatter among conservative pundits about whether Barack Obama was even capable of executing a strong pivot to the center. Jay Cost was uncertain, Jim Geraghty was skeptical  and Jonathan Last, provocatively, argued that Obama was as likely to prove as stubborn about course corrections as George W. Bush.

title: Waxman Requests Information on White House Deals
description: The Obama administrations health care proposals are taking fire from all sides. A powerful House Democrat on Wednesday lent some support to a Republican effort to press the White House for documents and details about any deals it made with drug companies, hospitals, labor unions and other interest groups during its behind-the-scenes negotiations over the proposed health care overhaul.

title: Obama to Party: Dont Run for the Hills
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama vowed Wednesday night not to give up on his ambitious legislative agenda, using his first State of the Union address to chastise Republicans for working in lock-step against him and to warn Democrats to stiffen their political spines.

title: Google Adds More Social to Search
description: Google is trying to make users search results more social, adding new features to its search page and integrating relevant links from people you know and connect with online. Google hopes to improve your search results with this information.

title: As Devices Pull More Data, Patience May Be Required
description: Could Apples new iPad end up being too much of a good thing?

title: Monitoring Twitters iPad Commentary
description: The New York Times Research Labs created a real-time look at Twitter mentions related to the Apple announcement on Wednesday. At its peak, iPad-related messages were coming through Twitter at an average of 2,200 a minute, and maintained steadily at around 1,500 a minute hours after the briefing ended.

title: Sending Breast Milk to Haiti
description: What to do for Haiti? Many of us are sending money. And some of us are sending breast milk.

title: Proposition 8 Trial Pauses, but Not for Ruling
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Testimony concluded Wednesday in the first stage of the federal trial over the fate of Proposition 8, Californias voter-approved ban on same-sex marriage, as lawyers on both sides continued to argue their case to the news media.

title: Lost: Oceanic 6 Rescued
description: Six survivors of Oceanic 615 were rescued in 2005. They lied about what had happened to them.

title: Lost: Crash of Oceanic 615
description: The crash of Oceanic 615 on the island began "Lost."

title: A Bachelors Effort to Understand Love
description: IT was on the island of Saipan, in a remote part of the Pacific Rim, that John Bowe, then a 42-year-old writer researching a book on modern-day slavery, fell madly in love for the first time in his adult life.

title: Guilty Plea by Trader in Fraud Case
description: Mark Kurland, a former senior executive at a hedge fund based in New York who was accused of insider trading in the Galleon Group case, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to two counts of securities fraud.

title: Voters in Oregon Approve Tax Increases
description: Amid recession, high unemployment and tight household budgets, voters in Oregon have agreed to raise taxes on people with higher incomes, to pay for public education and social services.

title: A Video Demonstration of the iPad
description: Brad Stone, who covered the introduction of the Apple iPad on Wednesday, got his hands on the device for a few minutes of play. The video shows just how fast the apps open.

title: Governors Spending Plan Draws Criticism in California
description: SACRAMENTO  The State Legislatures independent analyst has panned a proposal by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger to require the state to spend more money on higher education than on prisons.

title: Zelda Rubinstein, Clairvoyant in Poltergeist, Dies at 76
description: Zelda Rubinstein, a 4-foot-3-inch character actress best known for playing the indomitable ghost-purging psychic in Poltergeist, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. She was 76 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Rule of Thumbs: Koreans Reign in Texting World
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Ha Mok-min is feeling like a gunslinger these days. At the English-language cram school she attends during the winter break, students jealous of her international bragging rights line up to duel with her.

title: Howard Zinn, Historian, Dies at 87
description: Howard Zinn, historian and shipyard worker, civil rights activist and World War II bombardier, and author of A Peoples History of the United States, a best seller that inspired a generation of high school and college students to rethink American history, died Wednesday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 87 and lived in Auburndale, Mass.

title: House Could Pass a Revised Senate Bill, Pelosi Says
description: Update | 9:54 p.m.

title: Carmakers Pounce on Toyota Owners
description: DETROIT  For years, General Motors has been on the defensive, steadily losing sales to Toyota. Now it finally sees a chance to turn the tables. On Wednesday, G.M. began offering discounts and no-interest financing specifically to Toyota owners.

title: Meanwhile, Back at the Madoff Ponzi Scheme
description: With all the fuss in Congress over the American International Groups bailout, it would be easy to overlook another debacle from the darkest days of the financial crisis: Bernard L. Madoffs vast Ponzi scheme. But there was news on that front as well on Wednesday.

title: Make Tracks Like an Olympian
description: DOWNHILL skiing may get all the glory, but when it comes to authenticity, Andrew Newell says, nothing compares to cross-country.

title: The Mets Play Hard to Get, This Time With Smoltz
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  John Smoltz, who turns 43 in May and would like to extend his Hall of Fame career, has received 2010 contract offers from several teams, his agent, Lonnie Cooper, said Wednesday. The Mets, however, are not among those clubs, Cooper added, even though they have expressed some interest in Smoltz, a pitcher who often stymied them as a member of the Atlanta Braves.

title: When Moths Make a Home in Yours
description: MOTHS that thrive on wardrobes full of cashmere, wool, fur and other fabrics made from animal hair are a bane to many people. But there are plenty of ways to protect your clothes without resorting to mothballs.

title: Republicans Fault Obama on Transparency
description: Not even two hours before President Obama was to arrive at the Capitol to give his State of the Union speech, House Republicans were not letting up the pressure one bit. In a letter to the president, they accused him of carrying out secretive negotiations on health care legislation (PDF) and urged him to renounce any further backroom deals.

title: Mickelson Speaks Briefly on Woods
description: SAN DIEGO  Dressed in a black polo shirt and cap, and white slacks, Phil Mickelson was as unequivocal as his outfit on the subject that has brought together the worlds of golf and gossip. He was not here to talk about Tiger Woods.

title: The Republican Response to the State of the Union
description: Following are the prepared remarks that Republican Gov. Robert F. McDonnell of Virginia is expected to say after President Obama delivers his State of the Union address, as released by the governor's office:

title: He Knows How to Work a Room
description: THE woman wearing the brown tweed jacket and the canary diamond was politely frustrated. She had been quizzing Jeffrey Bilhuber about his book, Defining Luxury, a $65 doorstop from Rizzoli, and couldnt get the answer she was after. How would you like me to use your book? she asked for the fifth or sixth time.

title: Freestylers Are Uptight About Keeping Clothes Loose
description: ASPEN, Colo.  When peer pressure and mocking do not work, the fashion police monitoring ski cross and snowboard cross at the Winter X Games can resort to more hands-on measures: pinching the fabric on an athletes pants between boot and midthigh should produce at least eight centimeters of play  roughly the length of a credit card. If not, well, the rules are not fixed. But there is the possibility of not being invited back to ESPNs action sports extravaganza, which begins here Thursday on Buttermilk Mountain.

title: John Edwards and Wife Have Separated, Friends Say
description: WASHINGTON  John and Elizabeth Edwards, whose marriage received outsize attention in the last two Democratic presidential campaigns, have legally separated, according to two people close to the family.

title: A Run to Twilight at the Millrose Games
description: Willie Gault and Tim Dwight have known the thrill of running with the football in the Super Bowl. On Friday, they will recapture the art of bursting out of the blocks as sprinters in the Millrose Games.

title: The iPads Name Makes Some Women Cringe
description: When Apple announced the name of its tablet computer today  the iPad  my mind immediately went to the feminine hygiene aisle of the drugstore. It turns out I wasnt alone.

title: Recycling as Nature Does It
description: The Green River Stone Company, which for the last several years has been selling the prehistoric fossils that the firm mines from its own quarry to make kitchen tiles, countertops and backsplashes, recently teamed with John Strauss, a furniture maker, to create a line of one-of-a-kind tables. The custom pieces, which vary in price according to the stone, are available as a 24-inch-square side table (about $5,350, below) and as an 18-by-52-inch cocktail table (about $5,100). Mr. Strauss, above, trained in New York with the furniture maker Gabriel Giuntini, whose clients included Mark Hampton. He spoke from his home in Ohio.

title: Artistic Look, Artistic Location
description: A new furniture and design showroom has opened amid the galleries of West Chelsea. Its the brainchild of three veteran designers: David Khouri and Roberto Guzman of Comma, and Christiaan Bunce, formerly of Girth Design. We wanted a gallery vibe, not a 200 Lexington vibe, said Mr. Khouri, explaining the location on 25th Street.

title: Books on iPad Offer Publishers a Pricing Edge
description: With a few notable exceptions, the print world welcomed Apples new iPad on Wednesday, eager to tap into the 125 million customers who already have iTunes accounts and are predisposed to buying more content from Apple.

title: Made for One Another
description: Like the Russian nesting dolls that tuck inside one another, Offi Nester Stacking Boxes  which can be used as bookcases, stools or tables  fit snugly together. (Eric Pfeiffer, the product designer in Oakland, Calif., who created them, said he got the idea from his 10-year-old daughter, Keegan, who has a set of the dolls.) The boxes, which are made by Offi, a company in Corning, N.Y., range in size from 9 inches square and 10 inches deep to 15 inches square and 14 inches deep; when all four are stacked, the combined height is 46 inches, but they ship nested together, in a single compact box.

title: Obama to Warn of Consequences of Inaction on Health Care
description: In excerpts of his State of the Union speech released this evening, Mr. Obama paints a grim picture of the nations economic challenges and the dire state of health care costs.

title: Begone, Carbon Footprint!
description: Method, the cleaning products company known for its clever slogan (people against dirty) and stylish packaging, is introducing a laundry detergent. It comes in a small lightweight bottle with a pump for one-handed dispensing and is highly concentrated, so 10 ounces of liquid will wash 25 loads. (By comparison, 10 ounces of the detergent Method has been selling for several years cleans only 10 loads.)

title: Paris Couture: Roses, Clouds, Spice
description: I dont think anyone would bother to argue that Chanel was the best show of the spring haute couture collections, in a class by itself. Those ethereal cloud colorspale pink, blue and violet, a sudden vinegary yellow. Those subtle wool boucle dresses and jackets at the beginning with the seams magically erased by flat, random stitches. Karl Lagerfeld said he had been thinking for awhile about how to do a seamless dress and only recently found a method that satisfied him. He said he thought this collection might be his most interesting in terms of technique. It took me 54 collections to get there, he said.

title: Flowers, Vases and Places to Set Them
description: Flora 2000, an online florist, is offering 10 percent off arrangements by David Beahm during February, when the code NYT100 is entered at checkout (Mari, above, normally about $165, will be $148); (212) 655-3075 or flora2000.com.

title: Text: Obamas State of the Union Address
description: Following is the transcript of President Obama's State of the Union address, delivered Jan. 27, 2010, as released by the White House:

title: Living With the Chill
description: To the Editor:

title: Not for the Nesting Bird
description: To the Editor:

title: Best Sellers and Bombs, and What Stores Hope Will Lure You Back
description: IT should come as no surprise to anyone that 2009 wasnt a stellar year for retailers specializing in home furnishings  or in just about anything else. According to the Census Bureaus most recent monthly retail trade report, sales at furniture and home furnishings stores were down 11.9 percent last year from 2008.

title: Afghan Tribe, Vowing to Fight Taliban, to Get U.S. Aid in Return
description: JALALABAD, Afghanistan  The leaders of one of the largest Pashtun tribes in a Taliban stronghold said Wednesday that they had agreed to support the American-backed government, battle insurgents and burn down the home of any Afghan who harbored Taliban guerrillas.

title: Radiation Levels Cloud Vermont Reactors Fate
description: Levels of radioactive tritium have risen rapidly in recent weeks in the groundwater surrounding Vermonts sole nuclear power plant, leading both longtime supporters and foes of the reactor to question whether it will be allowed to keep operating.

title: United Nations: New Top Envoy in Afghanistan Named
description: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon on Wednesday appointed Staffan de Mistura, a Swedish diplomat who has been with the United Nations for nearly 40 years, to be his top envoy in Afghanistan. Mr. de Mistura will take over March 1 from Kai Eide, a Norwegian whose tenure included a public spat over electoral fraud with his deputy, Peter Galbraith, an American, that ended with Mr. Galbraiths being recalled. Mr. de Mistura, formerly Mr. Bans chief envoy to Iraq, is currently the deputy executive director of the World Food Program.

title: Israel: Man Hits Judge With Tossed Shoe
description: Chief Justice Dorit Beinisch was mildly hurt on Wednesday when a man entered the Supreme Court while a hearing was in session, took a seat and threw his shoes at her face, breaking her glasses and knocking her off her chair. The man, a 52-year-old Israeli Jew who was disgruntled with the legal system over a family court decision four years ago and has a violent history, was arrested. Chief Justice Beinisch, left, was taken to a doctor and returned later to work.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a National Aeronautics and Space Administration report on warmer temperatures in the past decade misidentified the agency that oversees the National Climatic Data Center, and a correction in this space on Wednesday reversed two words in that agencys name in some editions. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (not Atmospheric and Oceanic) has jurisdiction over the data center; NASA does not manage it.

title: Malaysia: Pig Heads Are Left at Mosques
description: Worshipers at two mosques found the severed heads of pigs when they arrived for morning prayers on Wednesday, according to the police. Pigs are considered unclean by Muslims. The incident followed vandalism and arson at 11 Christian churches this month and appeared to be part of a continuing dispute over the use of the word Allah by Christians to designate God in the Malay-language Bible.

title: Russia and Belarus Sign Oil Supply Agreement
description: Russia and Belarus reached an oil supply agreement in Moscow on Wednesday, ending the threat of disruptions in European deliveries that arose when a previous deal lapsed at the end of last year. Russia announced that the two sides had signed documents that covered the sale of Russian oil to Belarus and the piping of Russian oil through Belarus for other European customers.

title: Bankruptcy Judge Approves Bonus Payments for Tribune Executives
description: A bankruptcy judge on Wednesday approved a $45.6 million incentive program for top executives and managers of the Tribune Company, overruling objections by a union and the bankruptcy trustee that the payout was too high and unwarranted.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Jan. 15 about charges that a former United Nations official, Scott Ritter, engaged in online sexual exchanges with a minor misstated Mr. Ritters role with the United Nations Special Commission from 1991 until 1998, when he resigned. He was a chief weapons inspector on several missions in Iraq during that time; he was not the chief weapons inspector on every mission.

title: A Reminder of Precedents in Subsidizing Newspapers
description: American newspapers have relied on government subsidies since Washingtons day, but that support has dropped sharply in the last four decades, according to a report to be released Thursday by the University of Southern California.

title: Bloomberg Balks at 9/11 Trial, Dealing Blow to White House
description: The Obama administration on Wednesday lost its most prominent backer of the plan to try the self-described mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks in Lower Manhattan when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said the trial should not be held in New York City.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about the cross-examination of Michael Mineo, the complainant in a police brutality trial in Brooklyn, misidentified the defense lawyer who asked Mr. Mineo to stand as if he were handcuffed. He is Richard Murray, not John D. Patten.

title: Corrections
description: The Hempstead Journal article in some editions on Saturday, about bittersweet feelings among Jets fans from Long Island, where the team used to practice, misspelled the surname of a basketball player from Long Island whose team, the Nets, left the Island for New Jersey. He is Julius Erving, not Irving. The article also misstated the number of years since the Jets last appeared in an American Football Conference championship game. It was 11 years ago, not 20.

title: Hundreds Arrested in Drug Raids
description: A total of 476 people were arrested last week by immigration agents, who said those detained were members of international drug-trafficking gangs. The arrests took place in coordinated operations in 83 cities in what Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials called the largest antinarcotics operation ever undertaken by the immigration agency. Among those detained were 151 American citizens. The biggest roundup was near Charlotte, N.C., where 49 were arrested.

title: Corrections
description: A headline with an article in some copies on Tuesday about quarterly profits at the cellphone equipment maker Ericsson misstated the period during which profit fell 82 percent. As the article noted, that drop was for the fourth quarter, not for the full year.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Personal Tech pages last Thursday about Web connection speeds misstated the surname of the chief executive of Ookla, which created a ping test to measure the delays in an online connection. He is Mike Apgar, not Apcar.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Jan. 20 with a film review of A Room and a Half, a fictionalized biography of the poet Joseph Brodsky, misidentified an image from an animated scene in the movie. It showed St. Marks Basilica in Venice, not part of the city of St. Petersburg, Russia.

title: Its Farewell to Damon After Yanks Sign Winn
description: For weeks, the Yankees insisted that they were down to their last $2 million in shaping their 2010 roster. That did not stop the perception that they would ultimately bring back Johnny Damon. Their decision Wednesday will change that.

title: Bloggingheads: Bipartisan Health Bill?
description: Matthew Yglesias, left, of the Center for American Progress and Reihan Salam of The Daily Beast debate whether a bipartisan health care bill was ever possible.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday with an article about the Jaipur Literature Festival in India misspelled the surname of an author shown at the festival. He is Chetan Bhagat, not Chagat.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Critics Choice column on Monday about new CDs, including Boca Negra by the Chicago Underground Duo, misstated the surname of a singer-songwriter with whom a member of the Duo, Chad Taylor, has toured. He is Sam Beam, not Bean.

title: Soros Endorses Obamas Plan on Banks
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  The billionaire investor George Soros said on Wednesday that he supported President Obamas proposal to limit the size of banks. But he warned that it was too early to put such a plan in place and that it did not go far enough.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Wednesday about the New York Nightlife Awards show, at Town Hall, misstated the year the awards began. It was 2003, not 1983.

title: Corrections

title: Dressing for Success on Valentine's Day
description: NOTHING is actually known about the Christian martyr who was buried near Rome on Feb. 14. There were a number of different St. Valentines; even Pope Gelasius had no idea who the guy was when he established a feast in his name in the fifth century. Historians assume that he did so as a means of whitewashing the pagan holiday Lupercalia, an ancient Roman tradition of worshiping the goat lord Pan (known as Faunus in Roman cosmology), to rid the city of evil spirits and restore fertility. A dog and a goat were usually sacrificed; salt cakes were burned by vestal virgins.

title: Yankees Move On Without Damon

But the officer, Noel Jugraj, said he did hear Mr. Mineo yell, You all violated me, and heard his partner, Officer Alex Cruz, respond, You liked it, you liked it.

description: A winter mood has settled on Democrats, though they rule the federal government with a majority that leaders of other eras would find enviable. Their blood is molasses. They needed a jolt on Wednesday night, a rallying cry.

The presidents tone was mild compared to the animation in some other parts of the speech, and I thought he looked momentarily awkward. But maybe I was just projecting.

Rather than looking at his recent collections as representative of one of the worlds most influential designers in midcareer, the fashion world was faced with the realization that his oeuvre is now complete.

description: He took office a year ago promising to change Washington. On Wednesday, President Obama tried to convince viewers that Washington hasnt changed him.

title: Shopping for Love
description: If the movie Atonement had been rated NC-17, writes Cintra Wilson, Keira Knightley might have been ravished in the library wearing a silk blindfold and leather wrist cuffs from Kiki de Montparnasse, and it still wouldnt have looked too Cinemax. With Valentines Day just around the corner, now might just be the perfect time to pay a visit to the high-end lingerie store for similar cinematic inspiration or your own classy set of cuffs. The stores atmosphere has the effect of making its superbly made (and astronomically priced) fetish accouterments look respectable. If bondage, however well-heeled, is still not your thing try Agent Provocateur, only a few of blocks away from Kiki de Montparnasse, but considerably closer to the old 42nd Street in spirit. The vibe is more user-friendly for embarrassed guys shopping alone and packs of teenage girls; the lights are brighter, the music is dumber, louder and younger. Many items fall into a black and pink, rockabilly hot-rod style. It is, in essence, a vamped-up version of Victorias Secret by way of Johnny Rockets, the retro diner chain. Either way, remember that Valentines Day was originally a time to ritually exorcise evil spirits and restore ones city to health and fertility, so do your civic duty.

title: The Place to Be
description: "The extravagantly dynamic pianist Hiromi Uehara has a new album, 'Place to Be,' that showcases her talent in a solo context," writes Nate Chinen. With her hip bob, the Japanese keyboardist-composer has become something of a phenomenon in the jazz world  she is on the cover of JazzTimes in February and Keyboard magazine this month. "A forceful presence on any stage," she appears at the Highline Ballroom tonight for two shows at 8 and 10:30 p.m.

title: Accessible Films
description: "Mary & Max," the Australian stop-motion animated feature film by Adam Elliot, about the pen-pal relationship between a young girl and a man with Asperger's syndrome opens the second annual RealAbilities: NY Disabilities Film Festival tonight. The festival, which runs through Feb. 2 and is presented by the JCC in Manhattan, showcases films that "celebrate lives, stories and artistic expressions of people with disabilities." Nine films will be shown in 12 venues across the city, including Andrew Bujalski's "Beeswax," "Henry O!," about a blind baseball commentator, and "Zig Zag Love," which stars Robert Carlyle from "The Full Monty" as an overprotective dad of a girl with cerebral palsy. This is one of the most accessible festivals in the region, with ASL interpretation, live audio description, captions and Braille materials all available.

They will go up against the 6-9 Al-Farouq Aminu (16.9 points, 11.4 rebounds) and Chas McFarland (7.3, 7.7), a 7-footer.
