title: Showtime
description: He had us before he said hello. It was, in part, the look. Blue suit, but not the usual blue  subtler; red rep tie, white shirt, a skin color cosmetics and sun could never deliver, and, for much of the time, a big smile. It was the rock-star look in full Technicolor. Everyone else seemed to be in black and white. He dominated the screen and he did it with an ease that stopped just short of entitlement, an ease that said, in Chevy Chase fashion, Im the president and youre not.

title: A Loss of Faith in Afghanistan
description: Tonight, President Obama presented a compelling defense of his strategy to disrupt, dismantle, and defeat Al Qaeda in Afghanistan. Following my deployment to the northeastern region of the country in 2006-2007, I arrived at many of the same conclusions as he has over recent months. I believed that the faltering mission required a revamped approach, more troops, and more resources. Dealing with the dysfunctions of the U.S.-led effort, serving in an overstretched unit and suffering casualties in my platoon prompted my initial diagnosis. However, time, distance, and perspective from my experience have forced me to reconsider this assessment.President Obamas goals are sound. Training Afghan security forces, rewarding good governance, reducing corruption, supporting the rights of all Afghans, and strengthening the international coalition are vital to the fight against Al Qaeda. However, a fatal flaw plagues the counterinsurgency strategy adopted by the president: the more the U.S. and its allies deepen their involvement and commitment in Afghanistan, the more they undercut the Afghan sense of ownership, accountability and sustainability that will determine the long-term fate of the mission. Simply put, his strategy is directly at odds with his goals.

title: Health Care Gives Way
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama drew sustained laughter from Congress, especially Democrats, on Wednesday when he declared in his State of the Union speech that by now it should be fairly obvious that I didnt take on health care because it was good politics.

But 2009 offered powerful and, at times, bruising lessons for a new president struggling to fulfill the seismic promise of his election.

Japans new prime minister, Yukio Hatoyama, is refusing, so far, to commit to the agreement, and the Obama administration is being less than patient. Before any serious damage is done to this important alliance, both countries must work harder to find a compromise.

Men and women in uniform must have a fair opportunity to vote, but allowing online voting in its current state could open elections up to vote theft and other mischief.

title: John Baldessari | Everything but the Kitchen Sink
description: In 1971 John Baldessari made a print of a text-based artwork that has become legend. It said, I will not make any more boring art, and the pioneering California conceptualist has been as good as his word. Baldessaris deadpan videos, paintings, photographs and assemblages, which he adapts from existing imagery, provoke laughter, puzzlement and admiration, often all at once. As both teacher and artist, he has inspired several generations of younger artists subscribing to his belief that anything goes in art and everything in the world can be fodder for making it. He ramps up his photographic works  photomontages juxtaposing multiple framed images drawn from television, advertising or film  by masking telltale noses, ears or eyes with floating, brightly colored dots. Museums and collectors have invested in his unique products for a very pretty penny. Now comes a complete compendium of his more affordable limited-edition works, of which a new book, John Baldessari: A Catalogue Raisonne of Prints and Multiples, 1971-2007, is one.

title: Now Showing | Thats Coal

Its a little romance with the muck, the designer says of the anthracite chunks, which he buys 14 tons at a time from a mine in Pennsylvania and stores in the backyard of his upstate New York house. The coals earthiness appeals to Zivic, but the irony of his situation doesnt escape him. The same stuff my neighbors are burning for heat, Ralph is selling for thousands of dollars, he says, referring to Ralph Pucci, the owner of Ralph Pucci International, the company that is known for its fashion mannequins and its furniture by cutting-edge designers.

title: Chinas Avatar Mountains Come Crashing Back to Earth
description: If youd like to plan a visit to the Hallelujah Mountains on your next vacation, your best option is to see Avatar for the seventh time. A Chinese city is backing away from reports that it renamed one of its mountains for those floating peaks from the James Cameron film, amid complaints that the city was caving in to Western cultural influences. On Monday, the government Web site of Zhangjiajie City in Hunan province said that it had changed the name of its Southern Sky Column to Avatar Hallelujah Mountains; the change was apparently an attempt to capitalize on the success of Avatar, which has earned more than $100 million in China. But according to Reuters, a report in the state-run Xinhua news agency said that the decision was unpopular with city residents, who accused officials of being money-oriented and blindly worshiping Western culture. A local tourism official told Xinhua: We only added a way to call the mountain. The previous name is not abolished. China is historically wary of the effects of Western culture, and recently pulled the 2-D version of Avatar from many movie theaters, despite the films popularity there.

title: On Weather Stations and Climate Trends
description: Theres been an ongoing attack on the credibility of federal climate monitoring efforts that has been partly inspired by Anthony Watts. In 2007, Mr. Watts, a former TV weather forecaster, began recruiting legions of volunteers across the United States to inspect the thousands of weather stations  some in peoples back yards or in parking lots  that have for generations produced the raw data feeding into federal and independent efforts to track climate trends. The result was SurfaceStations.org. Its rogues gallery of photos of particularly suspect weather stations has been credited by many meteorologists and climatologists as a wake-up call for the need for better monitoring (an issue that affects many other realms, from monitoring acid rain to tracking flood risks):

title: American Idiot Gets Its Broadway Cast, and a Grammy Night Kickoff

John Gallagher Jr., Michael Esper, Mary Faber, Rebecca Naomi Jones, Tony Vincent and Christina Sajous will all reprise their roles in the musicals Broadway transfer, which begins previews on March 24 at the St. James Theater and opens on April 20. Theyll be joined by Stark Sands, a Tony Award nominee for Journeys End, who has been cast as Tunny, and will also perform the song 21 Guns with Green Day on the Grammy Awards, which will be on CBS. The American Idiot musical, adapted from the bands best-selling album, is directed by Michael Mayer and features orchestration by Tom Kitt and choreography by Steven Hoggett.

title: Molto Triennale | A New Design Museum
description: The scene Tuesday afternoon at the TriBeCa offices of the Italian television network RAI International was, perhaps not surprisingly, a little like RAIs distinctive brand of programming: leisurely, charming, chatty, full of attractive personalities and, for English speakers anyway, slightly baffling. But not necessarily in a bad way. The event was billed as a send-off for Roy Lichtenstein, Meditations on Art, an exhibition of more than 100 works by the late Pop artist opening that day at the Triennale museum in Milan. But the 50 or so men and women milling around a red-carpeted 25th-floor meeting room sipping Pellegrino and speaking fluent Italish were there for what proved to be bigger news: the official announcement that the Triennale  the impressive 87-year-old design-focused institution  will open a New York satellite exhibition space, Triennale NYC, this spring.A live closed-circuit TV hookup with the Triennale in Milan  think giant projection-screen Skype  yielded a series of disconnections, pixelated greetings back and forth across the Atlantic (saluti a tutti!) and halting moments of unclear protocol, but the crowd took it all in with breezy bella figura. On the screen, there was the Triennale president Davide Rampello at the museum in Milan, and in the room an array of Italian-culture panjandrums, including the Italian Consul General Francesco Maria Tal, the RAI director Massimo Magliaro and Roberto Bobo Manzoni, a veteran Milanese businessman who has been guiding the Triennales effort to scope out potential new locations,  la the Guggenheim, around the world. Manzoni said that a visit to MoMA in December 2008 gave him the flash of inspiration that allowed him to follow a dream: to open Triennale NYC across West 53rd Street in what was the home of the Museum of Arts and Design (formerly the American Craft Museum) from 1986 until 2008, when it moved to new quarters in the remade 2 Columbus Circle.

title: The Doctors Are Real, but Not the Patient
description: In the latest Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline Chen writes about the challenges doctors face in working as a team, and how even experienced doctors can fumble when they work together for the first time.

title: A New Grasp of Complexities in Washington, and of Blame
description: Last month, Mary Haas, a 62-year-old retiree in Wisconsin, told pollsters that she disapproved of President Obamas handling of the economy. While his State of the Union address did not change that opinion, Ms. Haas did say Thursday that she now appreciated his frustrations about dealing with Congress, particularly on health care.

title: What to Watch: Henin vs. Williams
description: The fierce rivalry between Serena Williams and Justine Henin resumes on Saturday night in the Australian Open singles final. Although this is their 14th meeting,(Williams leads, 7 to 6) it will be their first meeting in a Grand Slam final. Williams is seeking her fifth Australian title and 12th major championship, while Henin looks to add her second Australian Open championship and her eighth Grand Slam title.

title: Looking for the Perfect Artichoke
description: Here I am at the Giant Artichoke, a restaurant and farmstand in Castroville, California, near Monterey. Its the self-proclaimed artichoke capital of the world. Indeed, the Salinas Valley is covered in artichokes and other mild-weather crops, including grapes.

title: White House v. the Supreme Court
description: The White House is trying to back up President Obamas side after a rare moment of dispute with Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. was captured on camera during last nights State of the Union.

title: Shave Every Day. Shower Every Two Months.
description: Patrols are a constant for the Marine infantry in Afghan outposts. The Marine Corps believes that little keeps a unit as safe, as effective or as informed as having a constant  and constantly changing  presence moving over the ground.

title: The End of an Era?
description: Update | 3:39 p.m. As the indie Mecca of Sundance closes up shop for the year, industry watchers and movie fans are paying their respects to the onetime indie powerhouse Miramax, which shut its offices in New York and Los Angeles on Thursday.

title: Venturing Out on a Handymans Errand
description: Let us say, for arguments sake, that you are a New Yorker with a very large Chia Pet collection and a wife who has finally grown impatient with your habit. It is now time to organize them on a shelf  problem is, you dont have a shelf. So you choose the manly option  build one  and head off not only to buy the tools you need but also to engage, along the way, in a variety of other roll-up-your-sleeves pursuits.

title: How The Catcher in the Rye Eluded One Editor
description: In an interview with George Plimpton in The Paris Review in 2000, Robert Giroux recalled how he won and lost the opportunity to publish The Catcher in the Rye while he was an editor at Harcourt, Brace & Co. Here is how Mr. Giroux, the Farrar, Straus and Giroux chairman who died in 2008, described his first meeting with J. D. Salinger:

title: Farewell, J. D. Salinger
description: A lot of authors seem frozen in time, stuck forever at the age they were when they first entered the publics consciousness. That was even truer of J. D. Salinger than most  because he stopped publishing after 1965, because he fiercely guarded his privacy, because he remained so closely identified with the perpetual adolescent Holden Caulfield and the arrested adolescent Seymour Glass  and so the news of Salingers death today was almost less shocking than the fact that he was 91 years old when he died.

title: Accelerator Pedal Supplier in Toyotas Recall Has Many Customers
description: The CTS Corporation, the Indiana-based automotive supplier that makes the gas-pedal assembly at the center of Toyotas stop sale order and recall announcements this week, also produces assemblies for other manufacturers, including Honda and Ford.

title: Senate Votes Along Party Lines to Raise Debt Limit
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate voted on Thursday to raise the nations debt limit to $14.3 trillion, a $1.9 trillion increase that would allow the government to keep borrowing to cover operations beyond the November election and into early next year.

title: The Nifty 50 | Melanie Oudin
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Giant Steps: The Survival of a Great Jazz Pianist
description: Influential artists sometimes click in the public consciousness only after the rise of the movements they have influenced. A school of creative work emerges  seemingly spontaneously, its origins obscure at first. Then, with attention to the artists in that school comes recognition of their influences, their antecedents and their mentors. After Pollock, de Kooning and their peers in postwar American art established Abstract Expressionism, the precursory importance of prewar iconoclasts like Kandinsky became clear. After the Ramones, the Sex Pistols and the Clash blurted forth punk rock in the 1970s, a rude vision became apparent in the noise of 60s garage bands like the Seeds.

title: Gettin a Glow On in Mercers Savannah
description: Savannah, Ga.

title: A Forecast for VMwares Shopping Spree
description: VMware, a maker of business software, has been on an expansionary kick ever since it went public in 2007, acquiring companies to help it dominate the world of virtual computing. Recent purchases like SpringSource and Zimbra have enabled VMware expand its reach, but it may need to acquire even more companies to make the most of its recent purchases, according to a new report from the 451 Group, a technology investment research firm.

title: Creators of Lost Say the GPS Unit Is Plugged In
description: LOS ANGELES

title: In Hunt for Gold, Ski Jumper Will be First
description: The first medal of the Vancouver Games will be awarded to a man. The normal hill individual ski jump will be decided on Feb. 13, the second day of the Olympics at Whistler Olympic Park.

title: Q&A: Heading to Lima, Buenos Aires and Rio
description: Q.

title: Sanchez, the Franchise and a Few Comparisons for the Jets
description: Luis DeLoureiro is building a better passer rating, among other statistical pursuits, at NFLStatAnalysis.net.  He also contributes at classactsports.com.

title: Now Wearing | The Beach Boys
description: While you can always count on the spring mens shows for beach fashion, this season more designers than usual seemed to be taking cues from movies like Nick Nolte and Jacqueline Bissets The Deep. Here is a roundup of clothes inspired by a dive into the big blue  or just cocktails by the pool.

title: Correction: 36 Hours in Whistler
description: The 36 Hours column on Jan. 17 about Whistler, British Columbia, referred imprecisely to some nonstop flights between New York and Vancouver. Under a code-share arrangement, Continental sells tickets for flights to Vancouver operated by Air Canada, not by Continental. (Continental does offer nonstop service between the two cities in the summer.)

title: Bernanke Confirmed for 2nd Term as Fed Chair
description: Update | 4:26 p.m. The Senate voted 70 to 30 on Thursday afternoon to confirm Ben S. Bernanke as chairman of the Federal Reserve for another four years, Sewell Chan of The New York Times reports from Washington. The confirmation came minutes after senators voted 77 to 23 to end a debate in which critics excoriated the central banks handling of the financial crisis.

title: Holding Their Noses on Capitol Hill
description: Something stinks in Congress.

title: Letter: Sri Lanka
description: To the Editor: Regarding "The 31 Places to Go in 2010" (Jan. 10): I am surprised you included Sri Lanka as one of the 31 places to visit. It appears your newspaper seems to have forgotten the innumerable human rights violations committed by successive Sri Lankan governments, the worst being by the present regime. Journalists have disappeared; people with independent views were abducted and whereabouts not known; massacre of the Tamils by the army in May 2009; no press freedom and no law and order.

title: Letter: Vatican Tours
description: To the Editor: Adam Nagourney's article on private Vatican tours "Alone (or Almost) With Michelangelo in Vatican City" (Jan. 17) provided readers with the names of several companies offering after-hours tours of the Vatican Museums and the Sistine Chapel. Another option exists for those who prefer to see Italy as part of an escorted group. The tour operator Tauck now includes private Vatican visits on seven guided itineraries. The cost of the visit is built into each tour or cruise price.

title: Borders Group Lays Off 10% of Corporate Staff
description: The Borders Group, the countrys second-largest bookstore chain, has laid off 124 corporate employees, about 10 percent of its corporate staff.

title: The Rise of Developing Countries, Continued
description: You know the world is changing when a high-powered crowd turns up to hear economic advice from the prime minister of Vietnam. That was the case at the World Economic Forum on Thursday, when several dozen Davos participants attended a luncheon session on rebuilding economic growth.

title: Bloomberg Unveils a Grim Budget
description: Declaring that the citys finances were between a rock and a hard place, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled a $63.6 billion budget proposal Thursday that would eliminate 20 fire companies, increase the cost of truck parking on Manhattan streets by 25 percent and close four swimming pools and a center for the homeless.

title: Plans for Fast-Charging Stations Raise Concerns Among California Utilities
description: Think, the Norwegian electric automaker, announced a deal this week with a California company, AeroVironment, a maker of electric vehicle charging stations, to introduce fast-charging stations that can charge its battery-powered City car to 80 percent capacity in as little as 15 minutes.

title: Help for Hoarding
description: The volume of comments from readers trying to cope with elders who hoard everything from newspapers to yogurt containers to cats  and from readers struggling with their own hoarding tendencies  has come as something of a surprise to me.

title: Doctors Killer Puts Abortion on the Stand
description: WICHITA, Kan.  Scott Roeder, the man charged with murder in the shooting of George R. Tiller, one of the few doctors in the country to perform late-term abortions, took the witness stand in his own defense on Thursday, and said that, yes, he did it.

title: Flash Sales From Kayak
description: Starting today Kayak, the travel search engine, is offering special hotel deals for a limited time every Thursday.

title: The Politician
description: Friends and staffers who had to deal with Elizabeth Edwards's suspicions and saw signs of his infidelity tried not to think about the issue. I believe that David Kirby and I avoided having a frank conversation about the senator and Rielle because if we said out loud what we were thinking, we might have to deal with it directly. Also, we were powerless to do much about it.

title: Obamas Remarks on Going to College and Going for Broke
description: At our sib-blog, The Choice, Jacques Steinberg mines the import behind the segment of President Obamas State of the Union address that dealt with student loans.

title: The Catcher in the Rye Bread
description: Leave it to the dining critic to find a food angle on the death of J.D. Salinger. Sam Sifton led us to This Sandwich Has No Mayonnaise, a story in the October 1945 Esquire that has nothing to do with sandwiches or mayo. Its about a soldier waiting to go to a dance and thinking of his brother, Holden Caulfield, who is missing in action.

title: Winners and Losers in Bloombergs Budget Plan
description: The biggest loser in the mayors 2011 budget: the citys libraries.

title: Defendant in Afghan Shooting Trial Takes Stand
description: For most of her nearly two-week trial, Aafia Siddiqui has not been shy about expressing her opinions.

title: Join the Club! Supporting Independent Reading With Book Groups
description: Overview | What are the benefits and drawbacks of reading both independently and as part of a group, like a class, book club or online network? In this lesson, students consider the value of private and collective reading experiences and then form book clubs around titles they pitch to each other. They respond to the texts as they read and execute a final project. Ideas for concurrent and culminating activities are provided.

title: Looking for Lost Clues? Watch These Episodes
description: With 95 episodes of Lost already broadcast, it would be all but impossible to review the entire series before the premiere of the final season on Tuesday. But there are shortcuts. Carlton Cuse and Damon Lindelof, executive producers of the series, provided a list of the episodes that they think are the most crucial for newcomers who want to prepare for the final season and for longtime viewers who want to refresh their memories about key plot points and characters. Total viewing time? About six hours. Episodes are available free on ABC.com and Hulu.com and for sale or rent on iTunes, Netflix and on DVD.

title: Six Mississippis and Counting
description: Princeton Junction, N.J.

title: London Underground | At Home With Vintage Design
description: Elias Redstone is the senior curator at The Architecture Foundation, London.

title: Bribing Children to Sleep
description: Tired much? Rachel Aydt was, for more than five years. That was how long it took to get her son to sleep in his own bed.

title: Haitian Law Enforcement Returns
description: The Haitian police are back on patrol in Port-au-Prince.

title: The Dutiful and the Mind-Boggling
description: Andrew Youngs hero was an inspiring Southern orator and a paragon of Christian virtue. He was a pillar of his community. Then he was photographed in compromising circumstances, outed as an adulterer and beset by a scandal that destroyed his career. They caught me, Andrew, the Rev. Bob Young confessed to his heartbroken teenage son.

title: Hesher Finds a Partner
description: Heres how the film festival pendulum works: Hesher, which stars the (500) Days of Summer Sundance sweetheart Joseph Gordon-Levitt as a non-sweetie, long-haired-loner-weirdo, got great buzz at the outset of the festival but withering reviews when it actually had its premiere. But the movie, from the first-time writer-director Spencer Susser, struck a chord with fanboys (I feel like I just had my brain thrown in a blender, splattered with hot sauce and nails, was one Twitter review). I flat out loved HESHER, wrote Quint at Aint It Cool News. For tone and sheer ballsy entertainment this one is going to be hard to top during my Park City adventure.

title: Pictures of the Day: Thursday, Jan. 28
description: Jorge Silva of Reuters, who took the picture of the boy in Slide 5, crossed into Haiti from the Dominican Republic 36 hours after the earthquake. Every day that passed we realized the dimension of the destruction was even greater, he wrote. Every time I explored what was behind a wall, in a garden or a plaza, inside a field hospital or in the ruins of a house, there would be more children who urgently needed food and medicine. Mr. Silvas work has appeared here once before, on Sept. 25. It was also a picture of a young boy. But this fellow was on the beach at Margarita Island, off the coast of Venezuela; a place and a time that now must seem very distant to Mr. Silva.

title: Curse of Spree: Knicks Lee Left Off All-Star Roster
description: David Lee has failed to make the N.B.A. All-Star team, extending the Knicks drought to nine years and raising the question of whether mystical forces are at work. Call it the curse of Sprewell.

title: Two Also-Rans of the Great Skyscraper Race
description: THE new Burj Khalifa in Dubai, at 160 stories and 2,717 feet high, makes the 102-story Empire State Building into a pipsqueak, and indeed the urge to build the tallest structure in the world is an infectious one. Within that aspirational tradition John A. Larkin bears the mantle of two attempts. He proposed the boxy 110-story Larkin Tower in 1926, and reprised it in 1952 with a plan for the World Trade Building  132 stories, 2,000 feet high.

title: After the Putti, the Baby Calamari
description: WHO doesnt have childhood memories of field trips to the museum? After a morning of being guided through the paintings and sculptures of the great masters, everyone would head for the basement cafeteria, where you would stand in line, plastic trays in hand, waiting to be treated to a lunch of rubbery chicken and gooey tapioca pudding. Those days are gone, or at least numbered. Increasingly museums are moving away from the middle-school approach to feeding visitors, with its emphasis on a lowest-common-denominator menu, in favor of stylish restaurants that offer fine dining to go with the fine art.

title: Despite Changes, Many Still Oppose Google Books Deal
description: UPDATE 8 P.M. January 28 Removing reference to Arlo Guthries support for the settlement. He filed a brief in opposition.

title: Answers About New Yorks Response to Haitis Earthquake, Part 2
description: Following is the second and final set of responses from Elsie St. Louis-Accilien, the executive director of Haitian-Americans United for Progress.

title: Scott Roeder Trial
description: The Times's Monica Davey discusses the trial of Scott Roeder, who is accused of killing George R. Tiller, a Kansas abortion doctor.

title: Now Viewing | Supermodels by Timothy Greenfield-Sanders
description: In the art and fashion worlds, many a project begins with a fabulous party. In the case of Supermodels of the 70s and 80s, the photographer Timothy Greenfield-Sanderss new exhibition at Steven Kasher Gallery in Chelsea, it was a party thrown by the hairstylist Harry King. The room was full of all these fabulous women, the photographer says, and it seemed an obvious opportunity.

title: Jobs and Youthful Optimism
description: Gallup just released its latest poll numbers on the percentage of Americans who say now is a good time to find a quality job. For the last few months, less than a tenth of Americans answered in the affirmative.

title: Movie Misquotations
description: As Fred Shapiro rightly notes, the title of Woody Allens film Play It Again, Sam is not an accurate quotation from the motion picture Casablanca. But it is possible to read that title as something other than a misquotation. The hero of Allens film, Allan Felix, is obsessed with the figure of Humphrey Bogart  especially with his character, Rick, from Casablanca  and imagines himself re-enacting Ricks heroic gesture at the climax of the film. Play it again, Sam is, whether intentionally or not, a doubly witty trope: suggesting both the action in the mind of Felix, replaying the role of Rick, and the action of Woody Allen himself, in creating a film that involves a parody of a theme from Casablanca. This very compression makes it easy to miss the implications of that title. If Woody Allen did not intend these implications, then he was lucky to hit on so brilliant a misquotation.

title: Obamas War Over Terror
description: Peter Bakers reference to President Bushs prediction that if a Democrat won the election, he or she would be like Dwight Eisenhower to his Harry Truman, shows Bushs ignorance of history. Truman was ostracized and deemed politically ineffective because he went against public opinion and limited the Korean War with MacArthurs firing. He in effect introduced us to the outside-the-box concept of limited war, which led to the concept of dtente. What Bush did was make a pre-emptive attack on a tyrannical government for no known legitimate reason. Trumans cause was justified by subsequent history, whereas Bushs actions will have us scratching our heads 20 years hence. Bristol, Conn.

title: Vigor Quest
description: I propose a type of research that was not cited in Tom Dunkels article  probably because it doesnt exist: a comparison study. The research I suggest would entail a group of participants on the Cenegenics program and comparable participants who are strongly motivated to engage in a program of weight training and aerobic exercise, combined with a highly nutritious diet and widely accepted supplements like vitamin D and fish oil.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Jan. 17 about the use of hormones to forestall the aging process misspelled the third word in the name of one of them. It is human chorionic gonadotropin, not gondatropin.

title: 'Reconciliation' Top Priority for Karzai
description: France24 reports from the international conference on Afghanistan held in London.

title: The Four Basic Elements of Dining (and Umami, too)
description: If someone likes a restaurant, just enjoys being in that space, say no more, the game has been won. Thats a chef talking, a highly acclaimed young New York City gastro-turk.

title: Bernanke Confirmed for Second Term
description: In a victory for President Obama, Ben S. Bernanke has been confirmed for a second term as head of the Federal Reserve. The Senate voted 70-30 on Thursday to leave Mr. Bernanke at the helm of the central bank for another four years. The confirmation came minutes after senators voted, 77-23, to end a debate in which critics excoriated the central banks handling of the financial crisis.

title: The Coast of Dystopia
description: Thank you for Peggy Orensteins truly sad but wonderfully written piece on the death of Californias educational dream. This state seems to have been working long and hard to destroy its schools, first with the irrational Proposition 13 capping property taxes and thus stripping the elementary and secondary schools of their most logical source of funding and now moving on to damage the centers of higher education with a perpetually deadlocked Legislature that can no longer manage to put Band-Aids on the wounds it keeps producing. They often say that trends begin in California and spread to the rest of the country. Lets not forget, it was California that foisted Ronald Reagan on the country, propelling the ideology that now prevails: every man for himself.

title: J.D. Salinger and The Catcher in the Rye
description: When J.D. Salinger died in 2010, Charles McGrath wrote his Times obituary. In it, he describes the initial reaction to Catcher and how reading it used to be a rite of passage:

title: In TV Interviews, Giuliani Misstatements Go Unchallenged
description: For the second time in under a month, the former presidential candidate Rudy Giuliani is coming under criticism for his misstatements in television interviews.

title: Tampering at Landrieu Office Called a Stunt
description: NEW ORLEANS  The lawyer for one of the four men arrested Monday on charges of interfering with the phones in Senator Mary L. Landrieus office in New Orleans said the episode was a prank based on what conservative activists have said was a problem getting through to the senators office during the health care debates.

title: Less Water Vapor May Slow Warming Trends
description: A decrease in water vapor concentrations in parts of the middle atmosphere has contributed to a slowing of Earths warming, researchers are reporting. The finding, they said, offers part of the explanation for a string of years with relatively stable global surface temperatures.

title: A Big Audience for State of the Union
description: President Obamas first State of the Union address was one of the longest in recent years, and it was also one of the most watched.

title: Now Showing | Elliott Erwitt for Puerto Rico
description: Fifty years ago, when the 26-year-old photographer Elliott Erwitt shot an advertising campaign for Puerto Rico, the island still held a sense of the exotic for American travelers. Nowadays, Old San Juan has a Marshalls discount store on one of its main plazas, and the island struggles to differentiate itself from other spots in the Caribbean  that is, as a place to hole up in a pool-side cabana between trips to the beach and the breakfast buffet. Which is why Puerto Rico tourism officials have commissioned Erwitt to reprise his 1950s shoot with a new portfolio of images intended to recapture some of the islands cultural allure (you can read about the campaign in Stuart Elliotts advertising column). Its yet more evidence  in addition to the recently revived grand-dame hotels and retro cocktails and velvety old-world passenger trains  that nostalgia is a powerful force in the travel world just now. Heres a look at Erwitts photographs, then and now, the difference at times being poignantly hard to discern.

title: Mona Lisa She Is Not, but Coveted Nonetheless
description: The portrait of a woman made famous because it is not by Leonardo da Vinci sold at Sothebys on Thursday for $1.5 million. That price, which included the auction houses fees, was triple the high estimate of $500,000.

title: Conan OBriens Final Week Turned Out to Be His Biggest
description: In an indication of just how big a national event Conan OBriens farewell turned out to be, the official national ratings released Thursday confirmed that the late-night star had his biggest week among young viewers in his seven-month run as host of The Tonight Show.

title: Avatar Mountains Come Back to Earth
description: If youd like to plan a visit to the Hallelujah Mountains for your next vacation, your best bet is to see Avatar for the seventh time. A Chinese city is backing away from reports that it renamed one of its mountains for those floating peaks from the James Cameron film, amid complaints that the city was caving in to Western cultural influences. On Monday the government of Zhangjiajie City in the Hunan province said it had changed the name of the nearby Southern Sky Column to Avatar Hallelujah Mountains; the change was apparently an attempt to capitalize on the success of Avatar, which has earned more than $100 million in China. But according to Reuters the state-run Xinhua news agency reported that the decision was unpopular with city residents, who accused officials of being money-oriented and blindly worshiping Western culture. A local tourism official told Xinhua: We only added a way to call the mountain. The previous name is not abolished. China is historically wary of the effects of Western culture, and recently pulled the 2-D version of Avatar from many movie theaters.

title: Art in Review
description: JOHN MCLAUGHLIN

title: Smaller Season for Los Angeles Opera
description: As it predicted, the Los Angeles Opera has announced a downsized season of six productions for 2010-11  one or two fewer than usual  because of financial troubles. They are Il Postino by Daniel Catn, a world premiere; Le Nozze di Figaro; Lohengrin; Rigoletto; Il Turco in Italia; and The Turn of the Screw. The tenor Ben Heppner, above, will take the title role in Lohengrin, with Dolora Zajick singing her first Ortrud. George Gagnidze, who sang Scarpia in the Metropolitan Operas controversial production of Tosca this season, will star in Rigoletto. Plcido Domingo, the companys general director, will appear as the poet Pablo Neruda in Il Postino and will conduct performances of Le Nozze.

title: Skiers Buy Vacation Homes as Prices Fall
description: DENVER

title: Dont Jump in the Lake
description: WHO Mark Hulst, 48, a business owner

title: A Window Into the Turbulence of 16th-Century Rome
description: Early in the 16th century Rome and Florence were locked in a heated rivalry. Florence had the Medicis, or what was left of them; Rome was in ruins  it had been sacked in 1527  but it had the papacy, and with it the promise of rebuilding. The best artists were frequently caught in between.

title: Jaw-Breaking Boston Detective Unravels His Daughters Murder
description: The last time we saw Mel Gibson in a leading role, he was throwing cold water on alien invaders in M. Night Shyamalans Signs. Now after a hiatus spent burnishing his reputation as the worlds pre-eminent director of ultraviolent dead-language epics, he tries a return to movie-star form in Edge of Darkness, in which he plays a grieving dad trying to solve and avenge the death of his daughter.

title: American Idiot Gets Its Broadway Cast
description: The Broadway cast of the musical American Idiot will look largely familiar to anyone who saw the show in its Berkeley Repertory Theater incarnation, but newcomers can get an introduction to the performers at the Grammy Awards broadcast on Sunday night on CBS. John Gallagher Jr., Michael Esper, Mary Faber, Rebecca Naomi Jones, Tony Vincent and Christina Sajous will all reprise their roles in the Broadway transfer of the musical, which begins previews on March 24 at the St. James Theater and opens on April 20. They will be joined by Stark Sands, a Tony Award nominee for Journeys End. The cast will perform the song 21 Guns with the band Green Day on the Grammy Awards. The musical, adapted from the bands best-selling album American Idiot, is directed by Michael Mayer and features orchestration by Tom Kitt and choreography by Steven Hoggett.

title: Composers Who Made the Center Hold
description: The Focus! festival at the Juilliard School is examining the generation of composers who created a mainstream American style in the 25 years after World War II. Mainstream, here, means traditional: in a program note Joel Sachs, the festivals director, broadly describes the composers he has in mind as those who wrote pieces called Symphony and still used Italian tempo markings. They were not avant-gardists, experimentalists or innovators but musicians determined to uphold European formal traditions, though in an updated harmonic language and with an American accent.

title: Bachmann and Blackburn Bail on Tea Party
description: Even before the Tea Partys $549-a-head convention next week, some of the movements biggest champions are partied out.

title: Jeff Daniels to Return to God of Carnage
description: The producers of God of Carnage have announced that Jeff Daniels, top right, who appeared in the original cast last year, would return to the Broadway run in March, but this time in the role first played by James Gandolfini. Lucy Liu, bottom right, who starred in Charlies Angels and other films, will join the fray as well. Along with Mr. Daniels and Ms. Liu, who will be making her Broadway debut, will be Janet McTeer (Mary Stuart), reprising the part she played in the London production of Carnage, and Dylan Baker. Hope Davis and Marcia Gay Harden, who won a Tony Award in June for her role in the play, were the original wives of the two husbands in the four-member cast. The current second cast, featuring Christine Lahti, Annie Potts, Jimmy Smits and Ken Stott, is performing through Feb. 28. Mr. Daniels was said to have had so much fun the first time around that he was eager to return to the show, a comedy about two couples who fight over an altercation between their sons. The third cast will take over the show on March 2; no exit date has been announced. Tickets are on sale through June. God of Carnage, by Yasmina Reza, also won Tonys last year for best play and best director for Matthew Warchus.

title: Howard Zinn, Historian, Is Dead at 87
description: Howard Zinn, historian and shipyard worker, civil rights activist and World War II bombardier, and author of A Peoples History of the United States, a best seller that inspired a generation of high school and college students to rethink American history, died Wednesday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 87 and lived in Auburndale, Mass.

title: Theater Listings: Jan. 29  Feb. 4
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

title: Because Its There Is the Least of Their Reasons
description: As you watch Philipp Stlzls gripping survival drama, North Face, it is impossible not to put yourself in the boots of the mountaineers clinging to a sheer, icy rock face during a blizzard that threatens to send them into oblivion. The sight of the exhausted climbers fighting to stay alive after failing to reach the summit of the Eiger, a 13,000-foot peak in the Swiss Alps, is transfixing in the way that well-told life-and-death adventure tales inevitably are. It is the films more mundane elements  an awkward, under-nourished love story and half-baked politics  that are problematic.

title: Lou Reed and Sting Do Oldies
description: Experiments in Dissonance: That wasnt the title of the program of popular standards produced by Hal Willner for Lincoln Centers American Songbook series at the Allen Room on Wednesday evening. But it would have been a more accurate description of the concert somewhat misleadingly called Hal Willners I Gotta Right to Sing the Blues? Music and Readings from A Fine Romance: Jewish Songwriters, American Songs. (Note the question mark in the title.)

title: Taking a Walk Through J. D. Salingers New York
description: Hey, listen. You know those ducks in that lagoon right near Central Park South? That little lake? By any chance, do you happen to know where they go, the ducks, when it gets all frozen over?

title: In the Packaging of Loans, a Bust With Precedent
description: Real estate securitization was one of the great innovations in finance in the last quarter-century. In an unprecedented way, it allowed vast sums of money to go into the real estate market from people who traditionally did not take part in it.

title: Magic, Sparkle and Happily-Ever-Afters Galore
description: Storybook ballets are full of conventional magic: benevolent fairies and malevolent spells and princely kisses to rescue whichever princess happens to need rescuing.

title: The Iniesta Generation
description: Soccer players are reputed to do it for 90 minutes and some fans of Barcelona, inspired by their favorite team, did it  and did it  and did it.

title: Dont Smirk, Sundances Roots Do Show
description: PARK CITY, Utah  The spin was hotter and the vibe somewhat warmer at the 26th annual Sundance Film Festival here, while the movies were much the same, with good and bad entries promising much and sometimes delivering. Each year the festival, which ends Sunday, takes over this ski town in northern Utah, flooding the snowy, icy streets with some 40,000 attendees. This year, though, it also has a new director in John Cooper, a low-key, long-time Sundancer who took over from another veteran, Geoffrey Gilmore.

title: A Sugar Hill Town House
description: Paul Kogan and his wife, Deborah Copaken Kogan, live with their children in a century-old gray limestone town house in Sugar Hill in Harlem.

title: Whats Really Fair in Love and War?
description: Sarah Goodwin, the complicated woman at the heart of Time Stands Still, seems to thrive on conflict, at least professionally. A photojournalist who covers wars and global strife, she keeps chaos at arms length by trapping it in the camera lens, exerting a fierce control over moments of horror by fixing them in time.

title: Day 2, Non-Apple News
description: Its Day 2 of Apple-mania, and technology writers everywhere are weighing in on the pros and cons of the iPad. But what else is happening online?

title: Andrew Youngs Mind-Boggling Memoir
description: Janet Maslin calls The Politician, the much-anticipated memoir by Andrew Young, the one-time aide to former presidential candidate John Edwards, a mind-boggling book about the sheer freakiness of Mr. Edwardss hubris, ambition and dishonesty.

title: A Kinetic Innovator, Plumbing the Surreal
description: The camera has been recording dance and choreography, some of it custom-made for the screen, since the earliest cinematic days of Georges Mlis. Like Mlis, a great many modern directors connect dance to fantasy, dreams, magical tours, alternative states.

title: Now Playing: The Three Bears
description: Once upon a time there were three little brown bears. They lived on Baranof Island in Alaska. One day, their mother wandered too close to people, and she was killed. The orphans were rescued by the Alaskan government and taken to a shelter called Fortress of the Bear. From there, the bears took a plane to New York. They arrived at the Bronx Zoo in time to play in the Christmastime snow you see above.

title: A Global War on Terror
description: Of all the slights that have stoked the outrage of vocal supporters of Israel, the one that prompted a makeshift protest in downtown Manhattan on Thursday is undoubtedly the smallest.

title: Ming-Yi Chuang and Alan Smith
description: MING-YI CHUANG was a bank examiner, not an actress, but she met her future husband while starring in a four-minute film about breaking up  with a kumquat.

title: Huynh Closes One Door and Opens Another
description: Is Michael Huynh finding too much on his plate, or is he just changing plates?

title: Restaurant Umami
description: On our small-business blog Youre the Boss, Bruce Buschel, who brought you The 100 Things Restaurant Staffers Should Never Do, has a round-table discussion about what matters most in a restaurant  food? ambience? service? price? the wine? How about umami.

title: Treasury Streamlines Its Mortgage Program
description: Borrowers seeking to improve their mortgages through a government program will soon find the paperwork a little less cumbersome.

title: News So New It Just Has to Start Early
description: Its 5:57 p.m. Do you know why the 6 oclock news is already on?

title: Just Cut the Painting in Half
description: To help decorate our younger daughters new apartment, my husband and I offered any item in our basement. She took a painting. A few days later, she phoned to say that she had researched the artist, and his work averages $11,000 at auction.

title: Battling an Image and Reality, Berlusconi Takes on the Mafia (Real and Fictional)
description: ROME  It seemed a spirited defense of his nations reputation: calling organized crime groups a terrible pathology, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi on Thursday criticized movies and television shows that fictionalized the Mafia for giving Italy a negative image abroad.

title: Goel Leaves Intel Amid Galleon Charges
description: Rajiv Goel, an Intel employee charged in connection with the huge Galleon Group insider trading case, has left the company, an Intel spokesman told DealBook on Thursday.

title: Wednesdays Ratings
description: While President Obama commanded the largest network television audiences in prime time on Wednesday for his first State of the Union address, Foxs American Idol dominated the 8 p.m. hour with 24.7 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. No other network came close to matching Fox in the 8 p.m. time slot, although both CBS and ABC broadcast comedy reruns, and NBC offered a repeat of Mercy (4.2 million). Meanwhile a precise accounting of the presidents audience was not immediately available on Thursday, but preliminary overnight estimates show the speech probably attracted a smaller audience than the presidents first address to a joint session of Congress in February of last year. That speech drew 52.4 million viewers, while Wednesdays speech, which began at 9 p.m. and lasted until 10:20, appeared to have garnered an audience more similar in size to President Obamas prime-time address in December about the American strategy in Afghanistan, which drew 40.8 million viewers. Final ratings were expected to be released late in the day on Thursday.

title: After Ratings Decline, Ugly Betty Is Canceled
description: Ugly Betty, the ABC series that won a Golden Globe award for best comedy in its first season on the air in 2006-7 but whose audience has fallen by half over its four seasons, to about five million currently, will end its prime-time run this spring, the network and the shows producers said. ABC said it will broadcast eight more original episodes, including a series finale. An adaptation of a popular Spanish-language soap opera, Betty La Fea, about an unattractive but cheerful secretary at a fashion magazine, Ugly Betty was imported to the United States by Reveille Productions and featured America Ferrera, left, as Betty, a role for which she won a Golden Globe and an Emmy for acting in her first season. The initial buzz around the show was strong even before the series premiere, but convoluted story lines alienated some viewers. This season ABC moved the series to Friday nights, where ratings fell dramatically, before shifting the program to 10 p.m. Wednesdays after the cancellation of Eastwick.

title: Onetime Idol Prospect Finds His Inner Rebel
description: Sometime in 2007 Jason Castro accidentally stumbled through a door that led to the auditions for American Idol and decided to just stick around. At least thats how it seemed throughout that shows seventh season, from his first appearance right up until he placed fourth. He had about one-tenth the intensity of the next-most-lethargic contestant, appeared anxious when it came to speaking and was only beginning to test the boundaries of his voice.

title: Grammys Weight Is Now Measured in Face Time
description: THE award or the performance? The recognition or the spectacle? Those are perennial questions for the Grammy Awards, which will be bestowed for the 52nd time on Sunday at the Staples Center in Los Angeles, and broadcast live on CBS at 8 p.m. Eastern Time.

title: Universal Orlando Conjures Up a Harry Potter Spot in the Super Bowl
description: Marketing professors say that a good use of commercial time bought during a Super Bowl is to promote a new product, service or attraction. The folks at the Universal Orlando Resort in Orlando, Fla., must be reading their textbooks.

title: Film Series and Movie Listings
description: FILM SERIES

title: Artists Rights Act Applies in Dispute, Court Rules
description: A federal appeals court has decided that a lower court erred in 2007 when it ruled in favor of the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art in a bitter dispute between the museum and the artist Christoph Bchel over an immense, unfinished installation.

title: AT&T and Apple Allow Cheap VoIP Calls on 3G
description: In all of the hullabaloo over it the iPad, a long-awaited change to the iPhone got lost in the shuffle: Apple has taken the wraps off VoIP calls over the 3G network. That could mean a potentially huge savings on domestic and foreign calls.

title: Shining a Light on a Forgotten Poet
description: Mary Webb, a British novelist, deprecated herself despite having published six books and dozens of poems set in her native Shropshire. Known in the 1920s for her evocative descriptions of the countryside and racy plots involving abortion, patricide and premarital sex, she nonetheless called herself wholly un-gifted and sometimes felt whelmed in remorse & terror over her perceived literary mistakes.

title: Hes Older and a Cuckold, but He Has Tough Friends
description: 44 Inch Chest can be described as six guys sitting around in barely furnished rooms, talking. Actually, one of the six says nothing at all: he sits quietly in the chair to which hes tied, bruised and bloody and shaking and wondering if  or maybe just when  the other five will kill him.

title: Wall St. Tries to Put a Price on Volcker Rule
description: President Obama is pushing hard for stricter financial regulation, promising in his first State of the Union address that he would not sign a bill that does not meet the test of real reform. This has left Wall Street wondering how much Mr. Obamas regulatory proposal, known as the Volcker Rule, will cut into its profits.

title: Europe on the Upper East Side
description: The Upper East Side gallery scene can often seem a bit staid, but it has its mercurial side. For one thing, the art in its contemporary galleries frequently pushes the envelope. For another, its many semiprivate dealers occasionally mount shows en masse, whether by plan or coincidence, that amount to collective mood swings. Sometimes Asian art is ascendant, or 19th- and early-20th-century American art. Right now the neighborhood has broken out in exhibitions of European drawings.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Readers Respond to J.D. Salingers Death
description: The ArtsBeat commenter MB of Chicago plucked out a memorable line from The Catcher in the Rye to memorialize its author:

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Mumblecore Auteurs Get Ready for Their Close-Up
description: Let this be a lesson to budding filmmakers everywhere: if you make low-budget, scruffy comedies with a distinct point of view long enough, you will eventually attract  other people who like low-budget scruffy comedies with a distinct point of view. At least thats what happened to the Duplass brothers, Jay and Mark, the Austin, Tex.-based auteurs of the mumblecore genre (The Puffy Chair and Baghead). They hit Sundance this year with their first mainstream film, Cyrus, developed for and distributed by Fox Searchlight. The feature, their first to crack 90 minutes (only because our credits are like five minutes long, Jay said) was largely improvised; it stars John C. Reilly and Marisa Tomei as a couple whose relationship is threatened by her adult son, Jonah Hill, in the title role. The Bagger liked it and so did many others at Sundance; it won unofficial best-of polls  and even had some watchers talking Oscars  pretty heady stuff for a couple of dudes who made their Sundance entre with what they called their $3 movie and cast their parents in the follow-up. The Bagger spoke with them in the plasticized courtyard of a hotel in Park City.

title: Poor Insurance Adjuster Has a Devil of a Problem
description: There is one joke in the first-time filmmaker Hue Rhodess pretentious indie road comedy, Saint John of Las Vegas, that plays off its inspiration, Dantes Inferno, with witty ingenuity. The image of a sinner burning eternally in hell becomes a carnival performer, Smitty (John Cho), known as the Flame Lord, who after a technical malfunction finds himself trapped in his protective suit that bursts into flames every 20 seconds. Approached by John Alighieri (Steve Buscemi), a ratty-looking insurance-claims adjuster investigating a possible fraud, Smitty pleads for a cigarette.

title: Coins and a Fountain That Make a Magic Mess
description: It goes without saying that we root for Beth (Kristen Bell) and Nick (Josh Duhamel), the appealing would-be couple at the center of When in Rome, to find bliss together. And it goes without saying that they will. This is a romantic comedy, after all, and no genre is more reliable in its outcome. But if that foreordained result  in this case an Italian wedding at the end to echo the one where Nick and Beth met cute at the beginning  is going to be satisfying, there need to be obstacles along the way. Nothing too serious or painful, of course, but an inkling of trouble sufficient to convince us that the happy ending has been properly earned.

title: Wired Kids, Negligent Parents?
description: Young Americans from the ages of 8 to 18 spend more than seven and a half hours a day on average using a smart phone, computer, television or other electronic device. On top of that, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation  study released last week detailing these habits, many children are electronic multitaskers  surfing the Web, for example, while listening to music or watching TV.

title: Loss Forecast at Motorola; Shares Drop
description: The stock of Motorola, the mobile phone maker, fell after the company forecast a surprise first-quarter loss, signaling that new handsets were failing to increase sales.

title: Of Teen Angst and an Authors Alienation
description: What really knocked readers out about The Catcher in the Rye was the wonderfully immediate voice that J. D. Salinger fashioned for Holden Caulfield  a voice that enabled him to channel an alienated 16-year-olds thoughts and anxieties and frustrations, a voice that skeptically appraised the world and denounced its phonies and hypocrites and bores.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Emanuel: Democrats Not Dropping Health Care
description: Some observers have wondered whether Democrats are quietly planning to abandon President Obamas sweeping health care overhaul. But Mr. Obamas chief of staff, Rahm Emanuel, insists that is not the case.

title: Tale of a Terrorist
description: A Palestinian terrorist and an Israeli outcast lock fates in For My Father, a wartime romance about people more at odds with their own cultures than with each others.

title: Swedish Banks Diverge on Bonus Question
description: Swedens top banks are going their separate ways on the question of employee bonuses.

title: A Race for Identity
description: Do you feel black? a counselor asks Avery Klein-Cloud in the documentary Off and Running, voicing the question that hovers subliminally over every scene. Avery, an African-American teenager, is clear. I dont know what that means, she says, though the film has already suggested that the answer is no.

title: Obama Plan Privatizes Astronaut Launchings
description: President Obama will end NASAs return mission to the moon and turn to private companies to launch astronauts into space when he unveils his budget request to Congress next week, an administration official said Thursday.

title: The Catcher in the Rye in 1960: Permission Slip Required
description: I first read J.D. Salingers Catcher in the Rye in the summer of 1960, when I was 12. I heard about it from an older boy who was an unerring guide to books that were racy. So I went to my local library, in Brighton, Mass., asked for Catcher, and was told that I would need a note of permission from my parents. The librarian glared at me as she said this. My mother, who was not a big reader herself, wrote a note saying I should be allowed to read whatever I wanted, which now seems one of her greatest gifts to me. That little piece of paper got me into the other, grownup side of the library, where I found a lot of books that opened my eyes and, I suppose, led me eventually to become a writer myself. I have since read better books than Catcher but few that made a more lasting impression. I still recall reading the first paragraph and thinking to myself, You can really do that?

title: Spain, Greece and Latvia Affirm Their Commitment to the Euro
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Leaders from three of Europes most economically troubled countries said on Thursday that the financial crisis had only solidified their commitment to the euro, and they pledged to make budget cuts and other changes required for membership.

title: Baggage Fee Not Taxable, I.R.S. Says
description: Airline baggage fees are not taxable, the Internal Revenue Service said, a victory for carriers trying to protect a growing revenue stream.

title: While Confident Health Care Will Pass This Year, Democrats Still Search for a Plan
description: WASHINGTON  Democratic leaders in Congress voiced resolute optimism on Thursday that they would adopt major health care legislation this year, and they said that doing so was a crucial element of President Obamas broader agenda to create jobs, revive the economy and reduce federal budget deficits.

title: Preschools Add Brush-and-Spit to Day
description: HAVERHILL, Mass.  The twelve 4-year-olds sat in a corner, small hands clasping toothbrushes. Isaac and Aaron brandished them like swords, stabbing each other in the side. Jacky rubbed his into the carpet. Abigail squirmed, and Chayleece jumped up and down.

title: Using Humor in a Campaign Supporting Disabled People
description: A NATIONAL effort to encourage businesses to employ workers with disabilities is not your fathers hire the handicapped campaign.

title: Tea With Chachaji
description: TEA WITH CHACHAJI

title: Speed Thrills in Contest for Vonns Helmet
description: The American alpine racer Lindsey Vonn held a public contest to design the helmet she will wear at the Vancouver Games, and she announced Thursday that the winning entry belonged to Laddie Lee Whitworth, a 60-year-old retired machinist from Pocatello, Idaho.

title: Womens League Shutters Popular Los Angeles Team
description: Womens Professional Soccer has decided to shut down the Los Angeles Sol, its most popular team, after failing to find a buyer for the club.

title: Bright, a Halfpipe Medal Contender, Sustains Another Concussion
description: Torah Bright of Australia, a strong contender for a medal in snowboard halfpipe at the Olympics next month in Vancouver, pulled out of the Winter X Games on Thursday after sustaining her second concussion in three days.

title: Vonn Plots Her Final Training for Vancouver
description: There is one remaining series of World Cup races before the Vancouver Games  this weekend in St. Moritz, Switzerland  and after that, Lindsey Vonn said Thursday, she will be resting and training.

title: Has Ford Earned Its Share Price?
description: Is Fords auto business worth $52 billion? With the companys stock trading at over $11 a share, thats the value investors appear to be putting on it. Sure, the company is performing nicely compared to its Detroit rivals, Chrysler and General Motors. But to justify its valuation, Ford needs to prove its rebound has staying power.

title: Amazons Holiday Sales Buoyed Profit
description: Amazon.com reported fourth-quarter profit and sales that beat analysts estimates as shoppers took advantage of holiday discounts and free shipping.

title: How to Regain Control of an Accelerating Vehicle
description: As Toyota deals with a recall and a sales moratorium on eight of its American models, drivers may be wondering what action they should take if they find themselves in a car that accelerates out of control.

title: Israel Signals Tougher Line on West Bank Protests
description: NILIN, West Bank  For more than a year, this village has been a focus of weekly protests against the Israeli security barrier, which cuts through its lands. Now, the village appears to be at the center of an intensifying Israeli arrest campaign.

title: From Reeds to the River, a Village From Iraqs Past
description: HALAICHIYA, Iraq  The phrase has a poetry that the land lacks. Behind the sun, its residents say in Arabic, and it means that this forlorn locale, at the headwaters of the channel that joins the Tigris and Euphrates, is flung as far as any other town in Iraq.

title: Promises and Perks to Try to Lure Cubs From Arizona
description: With spring training approaching, the annual tussle between the Grapefruit and Cactus Leagues has returned, only with a twist.

title: Mudslides Trap Tourists Near Peru Ruins
description: Five days after mudslides crippled roads and rail access near the Machu Picchu ruins in the mountains of southern Peru, more than 1,000 people had been evacuated by helicopter, but hundreds more remained stranded and faced food and water shortages.

title: Brazil: High Blood Pressure Sidelines President
description: President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, left, suffered an attack of high blood pressure and canceled his trip to Davos, Switzerland, for the Global Economic Forum, where he was to have accepted the Global Statesman award. Mr. da Silva, 64, fell ill Wednesday while on the presidential plane in Recife and was taken to a hospital, said Cleber Ferreira, the presidents private doctor. He said that the attack had been caused by stress and fatigue, adding that the presidents blood pressure was absolutely normal and that he did not have a hypertension problem.

title: South Korea: North Fires Into Disputed Waters Again
description: For a second straight day, North Korea fired shells into waters near the disputed western sea border with South Korea, asserting its territorial claims in the most volatile section of the inter-Korean frontier. After lobbing dozens of shells on Wednesday, North Korean shore guns roared again Thursday in what the North called a routine military exercise, said a spokesman at the Joint Chiefs of Staff of the South Korean military. The border was drawn by the United Nations at the end of the Korean War but never accepted by the North.

title: Bursting Pride in Super Bowl Team Replenishes a City
description: NEW ORLEANS  The threshold for excessive celebration here is high.

title: Medicine for Musicians
description: The players of the Houston Symphony were not the only virtuosos from their city holding forth at Carnegie Hall on Thursday. While the orchestra rehearsed in the main auditorium for its evening concert, doctors from the Methodist Center for Performing Arts Medicine of the Methodist Hospital in Houston were participating in a daylong symposium on the management of medical problems among musicians specifically and performing artists more generally. Sponsored by the center in collaboration with the Center for the Performing Artist at New York-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center, the conference was timed to coincide with the orchestras big night.

title: Battling for Health Coverage as Cancer Spreads
description: Rashidam Shakirova moved from Atlanta to New York in 2008 so she could earn more as a home health-care aide  $9 an hour instead of $7. But she now believes that her new job indirectly took a drastic toll on her health.

title: Reelabilities Film Festival
description: Mainstream movies with disabled characters follow a well-worn path that begins with an obstacle  be it a hardened heart (Rain Man), the inability to read (The Miracle Worker) or merely life itself (Forrest Gump)  and ends with the barrier surmounted and audience members reaching for their Kleenex.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: An Authors Prose
description: A sampler of J. D. Salingers prose.

title: Latest Legal Battle Leaves Americas Cup Showdown in Doubt
description: They have been dueling without boats and without salt water in their faces for nearly three years. Instead of the customary helmsmen and bowmen, the combatants in the 33rd Americas Cup have been the lawyers and public-relations specialists pushing the opposing agendas of the team owners Larry Ellison of BMW Oracle Racing and Alinghis Ernesto Bertarelli, who said this week that he would forfeit the Cup if he lost his latest court battle.

title: Experts Say a Rewrite of Nations Main Education Law Will Be Hard This Year
description: In his State of the Union address, President Obama held out the hope of overhauling the main law outlining the federal role in public schools, a sprawling 45-year-old statute that dates to the Johnson administration.

title: Seeking Fans in 2 States, Despite a Record of 4-40
description: As they sauntered around the Brooklyn Hospital Center, the two pro basketball players seemed like the stars they once were, larger-than-life figures who drew the gaze and praise of nearly everyone they passed. Awed children shook their hands; adults awkwardly asked for autographs.

title: Bank Tax Is Knotty Issue for New Yorks Senators
description: President Obamas proposal to impose new taxes on large banks is testing the ties New Yorks United States senators have with Wall Street, a pillar of the states economy and a major source of their campaign dollars.

title: Possible Teacher Layoffs Would Have Big Impact
description: For more than three decades, New York City schools have soldiered on through turmoil, politics, recessions, budget crises and a changing cast of mayors and chancellors. But since 1976, the system has never carried out significant layoffs of teachers.

title: Firm Brings Gene Tests to Masses
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif.  The new movie Extraordinary Measures is based on the true story of a father who starts a company to develop a treatment for the rare genetic disease threatening to kill two of his children before they turn 10.

title: Real Estate Interests Help Cuomo Gain a Big Edge in Cash
description: As Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo readies his candidacy for governor, one industry is helping him amass a huge fund-raising advantage: real estate.

title: Landlord Faces Lawsuit for Harassment
description: State Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced Thursday that he intends to sue a major New York landlord that he says harassed hundreds of tenants in rent-regulated apartments in Queens and Manhattan in a systematic effort to force their departure to create vacancies for higher-paying tenants.

title: Chinese Leader Offers a Glimpse of the Future
description: DAVOS, SWITZERLAND  China gave the world a glimpse of the next generation of Chinese leaders on Thursday when Li Keqiang, widely expected to be the next prime minister, vowed that his country would act swiftly to shift from an over-reliance on exports toward greater domestic consumption.

title: Inmates Stock Is Rising in Albany District Fight
description: ALBANY  As state lawmakers prepare to redraw the boundaries of Congressional and state legislative districts, one segment of the population is quickly becoming a coveted constituency: prisoners.

title: Health Bill Stalled, Obama Juggles an Altered Agenda
description: WASHINGTON  The White House on Thursday signaled the outlines of its strategy for breaking the partisan logjam holding up President Obamas agenda, saying Democrats would move quickly to underline their commitment to fixing the broken economy and to build an election-year case against Republicans if they do not cooperate.

title: Suspicious Backpack Leads to Courthouse Evacuation
description: To the woman who found a knapsack outside the federal courthouse in Brooklyn on Thursday, taking it to the courthouses lost and found office might have seemed like a simple act of courtesy.

title: Like the Crisis of the 70s, but Angrier
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced his new budget plan on Thursday, ushering in what is sure to be a period of unity among New Yorks many disparate groups. No doubt, they will all agree on a single course of action to get the city through its fiscal distress: Cut some other guys program, but dont ask me to make a sacrifice.

title: Supreme Court Gets a Rare Rebuke, in Front of a Nation
description: WASHINGTON  It is not unusual for presidents to disagree publicly with Supreme Court decisions. But they tend to do so at news conferences and in written statements, not to the justices faces.

title: New Panel Will Study Disposal of Waste
description: WASHINGTON  The Energy Department plans to announce on Friday the formation of a blue ribbon commission to study the disposal of nuclear waste.

title: Henin and Williams Know Life Beyond Tennis
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Serena Williams and Justine Henin have seen plenty of each other over the years  they have played 13 matches, with Williams holding a 7-6 edge. But when they take the court here in the womens final of the Australian Open on Saturday night, they will do so with a newfound respect and appreciation of each other.

title: In Disaster, Tensions Ease Between an Islands Rivals
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Like almost anyone from Hispaniola, the island uncomfortably shared by Haiti and the Dominican Republic, Paloma Rivera is acutely aware that the two nations distrust each other, complain about each other and cite grievances about each other going back well over a century.

title: Intense Seeker of Powerful Elegance
description: IF a single word can be used to characterize the British artist and movie director Steve McQueen, it is probably particular. Curators often invoke it when describing the way he insists on presenting his enigmatic, carefully wrought films and videos: with every detail of the installation precisely specified, down not just to the dimensions of the screen and the viewing space, but also to the finish on the surrounding floors and walls.

title: 19th-Century Concept, With a Few Upgrades
description: PAT METHENY, the jazz guitarist, has lately spent an inordinate amount of time thinking about robots. Actually, thats putting it mildly: he has been downright obsessed with robots, and with getting them to do his bidding. I havent slept more than four hours a night for six months now, he said one day last fall at a makeshift rehearsal space in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, the former home of a Byzantine Catholic church.

title: Pop Against the Grain, With Sounds of the 70s
description: THEY grow up so fast now. It seems like only last summer that the Jonas Brothers  Nick, Joe and Kevin  were cementing their hold on the teenage hive mind.

title: Are Those Love Songs? On a Yeasayer Album?
description: YEASAYER is braced for a backlash. People could turn on us at any moment, said a smiling Anand Wilder, 27. Hes one of the three songwriters, singers and multi-instrumentalists in the Brooklyn band Yeasayer, along with Chris Keating, 28, and Ira Wolf Tuton, 30.

title: Untouched by War, in Iraq
description: The village of Halaichiya has the distinction of never having seen an American, much less a soldier.

title: Administration Considers Moving Site of 9/11 Trial
description: WASHINGTON  Facing mounting pressure from New York politicians concerned about costs and security, the Obama administration on Thursday began considering moving the trial of the chief organizer of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks out of Manhattan, administration officials said.

title: Republicans Compromise on Ideological Test
description: HONOLULU  A potentially divisive dispute over a Republican National Committee purity resolution that would require candidates to commit to a series of conservative positions  or face a cut-off of party funds  has apparently been averted.

title: For Apple, iPad Said More Than Intended
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple has generated a lot of chatter with its new iPad tablet. But it may not be quite the conversation it wanted.

title: Haiti Recovers Slowly
description: Haiti's devastated capital, Port-au-Prince, showed increasing signs of life as a motley assortment of enterprises reopened.

title: The Next Time
description: Three years ago, after Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. led the Supreme Court to the brink of overturning a few precedents but then blinked, a frustrated Justice Antonin Scalia accused the chief justice of faux judicial restraint.

title: Cloud Over the Capitol
description: Something stinks in the Capitol, literally. Senate Democrats had to move their weekly caucus lunch on Tuesday from the ornate Mansfield Room to a room in the new Congressional Visitor Center because the stench, mostly on the second floor of the Senate, was so bad. Accusations about the fish entre in the Republican luncheon were quickly dismissed. So was a rumor that workers renovating Senator Edward M. Kennedys old hideaway office cut through a sewer line and never cleaned up. The smell persists, and the air is rife with theories of its source.

title: Brooklyn Beats
description: Rain Machine is a side project of Kyp Malone from TV on the Radio, and it leaves no question as to exactly where Mr. Malones main band gets its churn and melancholy, writes Jon Caramanica. Mr. Malone will be at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Saturday, with Anti-Pop Consortium, for Sounds Like Brooklyn. The music festival, in its fourth year, features an eclectic mix from the neighborhood  one that seems to have a knack for churning out really great bands. Head to BAM tonight for a totally different pairing when Les Savy Fav headlines a show that also includes the Vivian Girls, whose wistfully melodic no-fi dream-pop will probably be the haziest sound ever featured in the Academys Howard Gilman Opera House. The festival continues next weekend, Feb. 4-6, with shows all around the borough, featuring Dred Scott Trio, The Sweet Divines, The Antlers, Rose Parade and more.

title: Soups On
description: Roasted winter squash and carrot bisque from 21 Club or Jean-Claudes lobster bisque from Chez Josephine: Could there be more perfect meals for a cold winter day? You can choose either one  or both  at the NYC Restaurant Week Truck, which will be parked on Broadway between 50th and 51st today. In honor of restaurant week, the city is offering soups from 24 of the citys restaurants, including Le Cirque, Blue Water Grill, Tribeca Grill, Delmonicos Steakhouse and many more. The soups cost $6 and come with bread from Tom Cat Bakery. Even better, $1 from every NYC Restaurant Week Truck purchase will go to The Haiti Relief Fund at the Mayors Fund to Advance New York City. The truck is on the move through Feb. 5, so check the Web site for times and locations.

title: Coney Country
description: Despite many attempts to revive Coney Island, for most New Yorkers the former resort still conjures images that are more likely to resemble a Diane Arbus photograph than a charming Victorian postcard. But Save Coney Island, the volunteer nonprofit organization, hopes to change that. This Saturday, the group, which is working to restore Coney Island to an amusement destination, is hosting Gone Country for Coney, a Country Jamboree at Galapagos Art Space in Dumbo. The all-day benefit event, which begins at 3 p.m. and runs through 9:30 p.m., features performances by rock, country and blue-grass groups, including Citigrass, Piataland, the 2009 fiddle champion Rob Hecht, Central Valley Wildfire and Animal Pharm. The program will also feature dance performances by the Prospect Cowgirls and plenty of BBQ and raffle prizes, not to mention an after-concert burlesque.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a new effort by the United States and other countries to help stabilize Yemen, which is threatened by poverty, insurgency and Al Qaeda militants, misstated the year that Edmund J. Hull, a former United States ambassador to Yemen, first traveled to that countrys more dangerous areas in an earlier American effort to foster aid projects. It was 2002, not 2003.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the devastation of Haitis National Palace in the Jan. 12 earthquake misspelled the surname of a structural engineer from California who was helping Haitian officials plan the safest route into crumpled parts of the building to retrieve sensitive documents. He is Kit Miyamoto, not Miramoto.
