title: Europe Weighs Possibility of Debt Default in Greece
description: European leaders are quietly considering whether to come to the aid of their troubled neighbor Greece amid fears that the nation might default on its debts and unleash another round of financial crisis.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the lost cachet of the karakul hat, the Afghanistan headgear made famous by President Hamid Karzai, misidentified, in some editions, the nationality of the fashion designer Tom Ford, who once called Mr. Karzai the chicest man on the planet. Mr. Ford is American, not British.

title: A World Cup Dream Revives Indias Womens Team
description: GOA, India  When the Indian womens national team takes the field against Sri Lanka on Friday in the South Asian Games, it will be its first soccer match in two years.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday with the TV Watch column, about President Obamas State of the Union address, misidentified, in some editions, two people shown watching the speech at a Los Angeles cultural center. They are Chez Nwanyanwu and Juliet Lawrence, not Wajenda and Ivory Chambesi.

title: Mets and Smoltz Still Talking
description: Discussions between the Mets and John Smoltz continue apace, and Mets front office officials had more internal discussions Thursday about adding the veteran right-hander.

title: Trial of Three Officers Looks at Internal Inquiry
description: The focus of the police brutality trial unfolding in a Brooklyn courtroom shifted Thursday from the disputed events of Oct. 15, 2008, when prosecutors say that a 24-year-old body piercer was abused by an officer in a subway station, to aspects of the investigation that followed.

title: Shudders Follow a Killing on Madison Avenue
description: The yellow crime-scene tape stretched from the elegant iron railing outside the century-old Florian Papp antique furniture shop, past the R. S. Durant jewelry store next door and down the sidewalk to the edge of the doorway of F. M. Allen, a luxury safari and sportswear shop. It stopped short of Pat Areias, a small, upscale belt and buckle shop where the display window was already decorated with red hearts for Valentines Day and a two-inch-wide alligator belt cost $720.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a listing in the New Jersey Calendar in some editions on Sunday about a performance by the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra this Sunday at the Mayo Center for the Performing Arts in Morristown misstated the phone number for tickets. It is (800) 255-3476.

title: Neuroscientist Denies Trying to Kill Americans
description: For just over a week, a Pakistani neuroscientist being tried on charges of trying to kill American soldiers and F.B.I. agents in Afghanistan has been kicked out of the courtroom nearly every time she has spoken, her angry outbursts judged a disruption.

title: Lottery Numbers
Corrections
description: A picture caption with an article in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about a competition to design a pedestrian bridge at Volkswagens new plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., reversed the identifications of two Auburn University students who helped develop the winning proposal. Dylan Cook was second from right and Tyler Maloney was at far right.

title: 47 Across: It Merged With Tanganyika in 1964
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Do you drink coffee while solving your puzzle? Or maybe a Diet Coke to wash down some HOHOS? A bit of food or drink can come in handy for a puzzle like todays. It keeps one busy while mulling and musing and meandering among the clues to find something of help.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of credits on Monday with a television review of Damages, on FX, omitted a production company and erroneously included another. Besides Sony Pictures Television and FX Productions, KZK Productions should have been credited, but not No Hands Productions.

title: Jets Sanchez Considering Surgery on Knee
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  General Manager Mike Tannenbaums decision to trade up and choose Mark Sanchez at No. 5 in last Aprils draft served as a launching point for the Jets rise to the American Football Conference title game. Now, after visiting with the orthopedic surgeon Dr. James Andrews, Sanchez is deciding whether to have an operation on his left knee, which he originally hurt in August 2008.

title: Corrections
description: An art column on Jan. 15 about the Museum of Fine Arts and the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston referred incorrectly to the size of the Egyptian collection at the Museum of Fine Arts. The museum says it has the largest collection of Egyptian Old Kingdom art outside of Cairo, not the largest collection of all Egyptian art outside that city.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about the astrophysicist Andrew Lange, whose measurements of light left over from the Big Bang helped explain the shape and nature of the universe, misstated the given name of Dr. Langes father. It is Alfred, not Albert.

title: Obama Sets Ambitious Export Goal
description: WASHINGTON  In promising Wednesday night to double the United States export growth over the next five years, President Obama set an ambitious goal for American trade policy that, he said, could create two million jobs.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Building Haitis Economy, One Mango at a Time
description: IN an astonishing outpouring of generosity, nearly half of American households have donated money to help Haiti recover from the recent earthquake. The United States government and other governments around the world, for their part, have sent thousands of relief workers and have pledged $1 billion so far. But Haitians need something more fundamental than relief from the present situation; they need jobs that they can count on for years ahead. For this, the private business sector is essential. Luckily, business leaders are meeting now in Davos, Switzerland, and Haiti is prominent on their agenda.

title: Nokia Profit Rises on Smartphone Sales and Cost-Cutting
description: Nokia, the worlds largest maker of mobile phones, said on Thursday that its profit rose 60 percent in the fourth quarter as cost-cutting measures and an increasing share of the smartphone market helped offset a decline in revenue.

title: At Florida Stop, Obama Announces Rail Investment
description: TAMPA, Fla.  President Obama sought to rekindle the fire of his presidential campaign on Thursday as he left behind his political challenges in Washington and began a series of trips around the nation to show that his administration is striving to rebuild the economy and accelerate sluggish job growth.

title: Bloggingheads: Tea Partiers' Paranoia
description: Michelle Goldberg of The American Prospect and Matt Welch of Reason debate the mindset of the Tea Party movement.

title: S.E.C. Settles Stockman Lawsuit
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said it had reached a tentative settlement of a civil lawsuit against David A. Stockman, a former budget director in the Reagan administration. The agency said in the suit that he and other executives of the bankrupt auto-parts maker Collins & Aikman of Southfield, Mich., had misled investors.

title: In Sweden, Banks Differ on Paying Bonuses
description: Swedens top banks are going their separate ways on the question of employee bonuses.

title: Walking in Holden's Footsteps
description: A tour of New York spots in The Catcher in the Rye.

title: Raptors Pile On to Knicks Anguish
description: David Lee is playing like an All-Star but was denied the honor presumably because his team does not win enough. On Thursday, Lee played like an All-Star, while battling an actual All-Star, and the Knicks lost again, which seemed to prove the point.

title: Vibrant Flavors, Served When the City Sleeps
description: Out by the cold expanse of Ocean Beach is not where youd expect to find good food at 2 a.m.

title: Many Successful Gay Marriages Share an Open Secret
description: When Rio and Ray married in 2008, the Bay Area women omitted two words from their wedding vows: fidelity and monogamy.

title: North Korea: Second American in Custody
description: North Korea acknowledged that it had detained an American for illegally crossing into its territory from China, the second United States citizen to be held as the Norths dispute with Washington over its nuclear weapons program continues. The American entered North Korea on Monday and was under interrogation, the Norths state-run news agency, K.C.N.A., said. The other American being held is believed to be Robert Park, a Christian missionary from Arizona.

title: In Santa Clara, Uneven Fight Over a New Stadium for the 49ers
description: As Santa Clara ponders whether to play ball with the San Francisco 49ers and the National Football League, the money, glamour and traditional political power line up on the pro-stadium side. The stop-the-stadium campaign will run on e-mail, shoe leather and indignation about rich owners and athletes.

title: Ending Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: Toward the end of his State of the Union address Wednesday night, President Obama said something that untold numbers of Americans who suffer discrimination had wanted to hear for more than 16 years. He promised to work to repeal the law that bans gay members of the military from living their lives openly.

title: Theyre Right to Be Galled
description: In his budget proposal this week, Mayor Michael Bloomberg had chilling news for New York Citys 300,000 workers. With a $4.9 billion deficit projected for the coming year, he said, the city will have to renegotiate benefits and cut its work force. That was a hard but necessary truth, and Mr. Bloomberg must now steel himself for months of wrestling with the citys powerful unions.

title: Lilly and Evelyn
description: On Jan. 29, 2009, in the East Room of the White House, President Obama signed his first bill into law, the Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act. It overturned a notorious 5-to-4 Supreme Court decision from 2007 that had denied Ms. Ledbetter restitution for years in which her employer, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, had paid her less than her male colleagues.

title: J.D. Salinger
description: The last, long stage of J. D. Salingers life  the unpublishing of himself  is now over. It began, more or less, when he moved to Cornish, N.H., in 1953, two years after The Catcher in the Rye came out. And it ended with his death this week at the age of 91.

title: Thoughts on the State of the Union
description: To the Editor:

title: Disagreeing About Fields
description: The shortage of athletic fields in many Bay Area communities affects the number of children who can play Saturday soccer and has led to nasty turf wars.

title: A View From Kabul: The Election and the Police
description: To the Editor:

title: FedEx and the Immigrants: What Guatemala Says
description: To the Editor:

title: Columbia and the Eminent Domain Lawsuit
description: To the Editor:

title: March of the Peacocks
description: Last week, the Center for American Progress, a think tank with close ties to the Obama administration, published an acerbic essay about the difference between true deficit hawks and showy deficit peacocks. You can identify deficit peacocks, readers were told, by the way they pretend that our budget problems can be solved with gimmicks like a temporary freeze in nondefense discretionary spending.

title: The Perot Option
description: There is a specter haunting America: the specter of a saner, updated version of Ross Perot. He is lurking out there, ready to ride the free-floating anger and distrust of Washington. He is out there now in one of his homes or private jets, getting madder by the day. He is large of ego, full of money and cranky in mien.

title: Out of Auschwitz
description: Paris

title: Its Not Hockey, Its Bandy
description: ROSEVILLE, Minn.  On a recent 10-degree night in this Twin Cities suburb, two mens teams skated and stick-handled and zeroed in on goal.

title: Assessor Candidate Benefits From Property Tax Lawyers
description: By day, Joseph Berrios is the longest-serving member of the three-man board that holds the power to cut the property tax bill for any parcel in Cook County. By night, Mr. Berrios is a master fund-raiser, bringing in about $3 million in political contributions over the last decade from the same lawyers who ask him and the board to give tax breaks to their clients.

title: A Display of Old Masters
description: Master Drawings New York, an annual weeklong constellation of exhibitions, offers a wealth of extraordinary talents.

title: At Leo High, a Gathering and a Mission
description: A breath-draining climb up three flights of stairs is required to reach the basketball court at Leo High School, but the reward is a trip back through time. Peach baskets would fit the dcor of the tiny gym better than the glass backboards that hang there.

title: Results of Study on Cellphone Use Surprise Researchers
description: Laws banning cellphone use while driving apparently havent reduced crashes, according to a study released on Friday that compared the number of total crashes before the ban with the number after. The study found virtually no difference in the numbers, a finding that had the researchers scratching their heads.

title: Freestyle Skier Is Betting On Making 2014 Olympic Alpine Team
description: ASPEN, Colo.  Jon Olsson figures he will spend close to $500,000 in an attempt to win a $6,000 bet. But when it comes to the calculus of quashing skiing stereotypes, saving face, and breaking down barriers, Olsson, one of the worlds most accomplished freestyle skiers, still figures he will somehow come out ahead.

title: Still Arguing His Case, Even After All These Years
description: Time stopped in drab Cook County Eviction Court last week as the lawyer George N. Leighton smoothly argued for the Illinois International Port District in a marathon dispute involving a 1965 lease and whether a slip for big ships on the Calumet River was properly dredged.

title: Word of the Day | vantage
description: vantage \van-tij\ noun

title: Snow Stockpiles Are Said to Be Enough
description: OTTAWA  Emergency snow stockpiles at the resort hosting freestyle skiing and snowboarding for the Winter Olympics in Vancouver are more than ample to cover any further thaw, the organizing committee said Thursday.

title: Attention Commuters: Stop to Enjoy the Tiles
description: The citys latest effort to liven the drudgery of commuting as part of its Arts in Transit program was unveiled at the Belmont C.T.A. station on Thursday.

title: The Pulse: Ultimo Will Close After Four Decades
description: Ultimo, a symbol of European haute couture in Chicago, is closing its doors on Saturday after 40 years.

title: No Woods, but Plenty of Good Scores at Torrey Pines
description: SAN DIEGO  As a bright orange sun crept toward the western horizon on Thursday, the face of the cliffs of La Jolla took on a reddish hue, as though embarrassed by the sheer beauty that annually reflects off Torrey Pines Golf Course this time of year.

title: Murder Suspect Caught on Camera
description: From an outdoor security camera, video of a man the police believe to be the killer of an employee at an Upper East Side jewelry store.

title: Santa Claras Stadium Fight and Highlights From Fridays Bay Area Report
description: Notes From the South Bay Scrimmage | As the San Francisco 49ers continue their courtship with the City of Santa Clara and the voters among its 117,000 residents, the council and the mayor who favor paying for a stadium to attract the football team are riding on a glossy publicity campaign, complete with the likeness of the soccer star Brandi Chastain. Meanwhile, the opponents are running on shoe leather. A local election, most likely on June 8, will determine whether the city puts up $114 million to help the 49ers leave Candlestick Park in San Francisco and play in Silicon Valley beginning in 2014.

title: The Rules of the Road in Open Relationships
description: My column this week looks at the prevalence of open relationships in the gay community. A new study from San Francisco State University estimates that half of the gay male couples in the Bay Area have this arrangement.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Blackhawks Pip Sharks in Clash of Western Titans
description: Seven games on Thursday night, and the big one was the last one, Chicago at San Jose, for the league lead. A 60-minute win on this night would put the Hawks atop the N.H.L.; anything less would leave the Sharks on top. But first, the other games. Home teams listed first:

title: In Packaging of Loans, a Bust With a Pedigree
description: Real estate securitization was one of the great innovations in finance in the last quarter-century. In an unprecedented way, it allowed vast sums of money to go into the real estate market from people who traditionally did not take part in it. But the people making the loans did not need to worry if they would be repaid, and in the end the entire edifice collapsed.

title: Art-astrophes
description: WHO painted the painting shown here, which was damaged when a wrecking ball came through the wall of the house where it was hanging and shot a perfect hole through the canvas?

title: News Quiz | January 29, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: New York Mellon Said to Eye PNCs Global Unit
description: Bank of New York Mellon is in talks to buy PNC Financial Services Groups global investment-servicing unit for as much as $2.5 billion to add hedge-fund and mutual-fund clients, a person familiar with the matter told Bloomberg News.

title: BHP Buys Potash Producer in Canada
description: BHP Billiton, the global mining giant, said Thursday it had agreed to acquire Canadian potash explorer Athabasca Potash for 341 million Canadian dollars ($323 million) in cash, expanding its asset base in the potash-rich Canadian province of Saskatchewan.

title: Barclays Seeks Dismissal of Lehmans Lawsuit
description: When is a secret $5 billion windfall profit not a secret or a windfall?

title: China Manufacturer Prices I.P.O. to Raise $1.7 Billion
description: China First Heavy Industries has set the price range for its Shanghai initial public offering at 5 to 5.80 renminbi, which could raise 11.6 billion renminbi ($1.7 billion) in Chinas biggest I.P.O. this year, Reuters reported.

title: From Finance to Fine Skis: A Bankers Trajectory
description: Benedikt Germanier, while still a senior currency strategist at UBS, decided that he had become just another battery hen on a trading floor where money was everything that counted. So he ditched his bonus and banker life in the United States to make skis, Bloomberg News writes.

title: What Are Your Favorite Books and Authors?
description: In his obituary of J.D. Salinger, Charles McGrath writes, Reading Catcher used to be an essential rite of passage, almost as important as getting your learners permit. What are the books and authors that have been essential for you, whether you read them as a child or recently?

title: U.S. U-20 Women Qualify
description: Goals by Kristie Mewis and Teresa Noyola gave the United States womens under-20 national team a 2-1 win over Costa Rica in Guatemala City in a semifinal game of regional qualifying for the world championships this summer in Germany. The victory means the United States has qualified for the FIFA U-20 Womens World Cup, regardless of the outcome of the Concacaf championship game.

title: Delphis Asia Business Bought by Autoliv
description: Autoliv, the global seatbelt and airbag maker, said Thursday that it had agreed to buy the Asian auto safety business of United States auto parts maker Delphi for an undisclosed sum, Reuters reported.

title: New Trial Sought for French Ex-Premier
description: PARIS  French prosecutors will appeal the judgment clearing former Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin of complicity in an effort to tarnish his rival, the French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, the Paris state prosecutor announced on Friday.

title: SouthGobi Shares Take a Dive on First Day
description: SouthGobi Energy Resources, the Canadian-listed coal miner, saw its shares fall about 11 percent on their Hong Kong debut, hurt by the stocks overly high valuation and poor timing, Reuters reported.

title: Citing 9/11, Blair Defends Legacy at Iraq Inquiry
description: LONDON  Almost seven years after he ordered British troops to join the American-led invasion of Iraq, former Prime Minister Tony Blair mounted an unwavering defense of his actions on Friday, saying he would take the same steps again to counter what he depicted as a threat from Saddam Hussein that had assumed far greater dimensions after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Developed Market Funds Suffer Redemptions
description: Investor concerns about tightening lending conditions in China and deteriorating finances in Greece and Japan led them to pull cash out of developed market equity funds and invest in debt funds in the week ended Jan. 27, fund tracker EPFR Global said late on Thursday.

title: Allianz Executive Dampens Swiss Life Rumors
description: Investors hoping that Swiss Life would be gobbled up by Allianz may be disappointed to hear that the German insurer isnt on the hunt for any big deals.

title: Judge Denies WaMu Request for Deal Documents
description: A Delaware bankruptcy judge on Thursday denied Washington Mutuals request to force government regulators and others to turn over documents related to the 2008 collapse of Washington Mutual Bank, The Associated Press reported.

title: Worried Bankers Reach Out From the Sidelines
description: Chief executives of the worlds biggest banks, including Bank of America and Deutsche Bank, met with policymakers in Davos on Thursday afternoon, concerned that their interests and opinions about financial regulation are going unheard.

title: Information Curtain
description: Hillary Clintons Churchillian description of Internet censorship.

title: Lee A. Archer, Ace Tuskegee Airman and V.C., Dies
description: Retired Air Force Lt. Colonel Lee A. Archer, a Tuskegee Airman considered to be the only black ace pilot who also broke racial barriers as an executive at a major U.S. company and founder of a venture capital firm, died Wednesday in New York City. He was 90.

title: Davos in the Media: Bank Reform and Resistance
description: There were three hot topics buzzing around the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Thursday: banking reform, banking reform and more banking reform.

title: Bank Tax Is Knotty Issue for New York Senators
description: President Obamas proposal to impose new taxes on large banks is testing the ties that New Yorks United States senators have with Wall Street, a pillar of the states economy and a major source of their campaign dollars, The New York Timess Raymond Hernandez writes.

title: Lackluster Economic News Pushes Market Lower
description: Wall Street was hit with a string of disappointments on Thursday: a weaker-than-expected unemployment picture, a tepid recovery in manufacturing and skepticism about technology companies, including concerns about Apples tablet device.

title: S.E.C. Settles Stockman Lawsuit
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said it had reached a tentative settlement of a civil lawsuit against David A. Stockman, a former budget director in the Reagan administration and a private equity investor. Terms of the tentative settlement were not disclosed.

title: Inexpensive Gene Tests for Parents-to-Be
description: The new movie Extraordinary Measures is based on the true story of a father who starts a company to develop a treatment for a rare genetic disease threatening to kill two of his children before they turn 10.

title: Gates Foundation to Double Spending on Vaccines
description: Endorsing vaccines as the worlds most cost-effective public health measure, Bill and Melinda Gates said Friday that their foundation would more than double its spending on them over the next decade, to at least $10 billion.

title: Favre and a Battering by Fate
description: Larry Canale is a columnist at Tuff Stuffs Sports Collectors Monthly and editor in chief of the monthly newsletter Antiques Roadshow Insider (insert your own joke about Brett Favre being an antique).

title: Global Leaders Struggle With Bank Regulation
description: The conversation among business and government leaders at the World Economic Forum no longer revolves around whether to regulate the banking industry more sharply, but rather how to do so.

title: Speed Read For Friday, Jan. 29
description: Highlights from Fridays media coverage in The New York Times:

title: For Relaxation in Mumbai, Try a Massage
description: In this often overwhelming city, weary dwellers have a robust selection of affordable massage and reflexology outposts to choose from, depending on their privacy standards and the body part in need of a knead.

title: Marx, God and Faith in the Markets
description: The Bible is revolutionary, declared a certain Mr. Marx.

title: Biogen Confirms Icahns Bid for 3 Board Seats
description: Biogen Idec confirmed on Thursday it has received notice from Carl C. Icahn that he intends to nominate three people to its board as he seeks to expand his influence at one of the worlds biggest biotech companies.

title: Chinese Leader Offers a Glimpse of the Future
description: China gave the world a glimpse of the next generation of Chinese leaders on Thursday when Li Keqiang, widely expected to be the next prime minister, vowed that his country would act swiftly to shift from an over-reliance on exports toward greater domestic consumption.

title: An Evening on Camerons Pandora
description: James Cameron, director of Avatar, clearly struck a chord with some of the depressed bankers and gloomy businessmen in Davos when he told them at an exclusive evening session about his blockbuster film that his aim was to put a global audience into a lucid dream state.

title: Champions Spar as McLaren Mercedes Launches MP4-25
description: Well now, that was fun. I did not go to England for the McLaren launch, but I felt like I was there  as did plenty of the readers of this blog, Im sure. The McLaren launch just finished a few seconds ago, and the whole thing was visible online over a nearly perfect Internet connection. I thought I was watching television.

title: Long Tail Becomes Longer Tale
description: Todays idea: Welcome to the long tail of manufacturing. If the past 10 years have been about discovering post-institutional social models on the Web, then the next 10 years will be about applying them to the real world, writes Chris Anderson.

title: Looking for Women in Wall Streets Top Ranks
description: When Sallie Krawcheck was hired six months ago as president of global wealth and investment management at Bank of America, she was besieged with e-mail messages from current and former Wall Street women celebrating her return to the fray.

title: Federer, Making Quick Work of Tsonga, Will Face Murray in Final
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  So much for all the pretournament talk about how Roger Federer was distracted, aging and vulnerable at the Australian Open, and how 8 to 10 players were ready to knock him from his throne. After filleting Jo-Wilfried Tsonga of France in straight sets, now there is only one: Andy Murray, the scrambling Scotsman.

title: Cuomo to Sue Vantage Properties for Harassment
description: New York State Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo said he intended to sue a major landlord that he accuses of harassing hundreds of tenants in rent-regulated apartments in Queens and Manhattan in a systematic effort to force their departure to create vacancies for higher-paying tenants, The New York Timess Charles V. Bagli reported.

title: No Such Thing as Simple Health Reform
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

title: Former BofA Chief Gives Moynihan High Marks
description: Hugh McColl Jr., who built Bank of America into the behemoth it is today, apparently feels really good about the banks new chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan.

title: Switzerland Tries to Lure British Financiers
description: It seems that Switzerland is making full-court press to persuade British-based investment bankers and hedge fund managers to pack their suitcases and head for a low-tax enclave.

title: Burkle Said to Offer to Take Control of Barneys
description: Ronald Burkle has offered to invest at least $50 million in Barneys New York in order to take control of the luxury department store operator, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the situation.

title: Seeing Through the Apple (and Avatar) Hyperbole
description: There are a few similarities between Wednesdays Apple announcement and the blockbuster movie Avatar. They both cost many millions of dollars and took many years to produce. They both required vast amounts of technology to build, and of course they will both make hundreds of millions of dollars for their respective companies. But they will also share another category: too much hype before their launch, and a result that comes across as intriguing and entertaining, yet sadly anticlimactic.

title: JPMorgan Said to Plan Global Corporate Bank Unit
description: JPMorgan Chase is launching a worldwide business aimed at selling loans and commercial banking services to multinational corporations, the Financial Times reported.

title: After Stuyvesant Default  TrumpTown?
description: Will the sprawling Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village Manhattan apartment complex one day be known as TrumpTown?

title: Sampler: Palo Alto to Plant Trees and San Jose to Consider Tree Maintenance Tax
description: BART to Avoid Fare Increases, for Now | On Thursday, BART directors said they would not raise fares or cut service to help close a $25.2 million shortfall in the current budget. Although the transportation agency said it would cut 74 positions, 55 of those are vacant, 12 employees can transfer to another job and the number to be laid off can be reduced further if there is more turnover. BART will also rely on $19.2 million in stimulus and other funds to help close the gap. Proposals, like imposing a surcharge of 10 or 25 cents for rides through the Transbay Tube, were bypassed for now. We believe those charges would have a negative impact on our already soft ridership, said Carter Mau, BARTs executive manager for planning and budgets. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

title: As Bonuses Shrink, Goldman Said to Offer Loans
description: After The Wall Street Journal reported that banks were doling out other financial perks to their employees to ease the toll taken by the slimmer bonuses, Gawker got busy investigating Goldman Sachss lending practices.

title: Black Named as JPMorgan Vice Chairman
description: Steven D. Black, the executive chairman of JPMorgan Chases investment bank, was named a vice chairman of the firm on Thursday, as part of a plan to give more responsibility to the investment banking head, James E. Staley.

title: So Hows Holden Caulfield Holding Up?
description: Right-thinking ArtsBeat readers can agree that J.D. Salinger was no phony. The Timess chief book critic, Michiko Kakutani, writes in an appraisal that the author, who died Wednesday at 91, had unerring radar for the feelings of teenage angst and vulnerability and anger, and that The Catcher in the Rye, published in 1951, remains one of the books that adolescents first fall in love with  a book that intimately articulates what it is to be young and sensitive and precociously existential.

title: Shares Fall for the Day, the Month and the Year
description: For those on Wall Street who believe in omens, crystal balls or just plain historical precedent, Friday was not a day to rejoice.

title: Overcoming the Ugly Factor in Building-Integrated Solar Design
description: The idea of integrating solar power with building materials has been an attractive concept for decades, but one of the biggest challenges, according to Anna Dyson, director of the Center for Architecture Science and Ecology, or CASE, has been aesthetics.

title: Live From Davos, Day 3: The Bankers Meet
description: Good morning from Davos, where the topic of the day isnt anything that happened during the official panels of the World Economic Forum.

title: He Will Be Missed
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. To allow others to recommend your jokes, please send them one per comment:

title: The Early Word: Business in Baltimore
description: Two days after calling for more cooperation between Democrats and Republicans, President Obama heads to Baltimore for a discussion with House Republicans at their retreat.

title: U.S. Economy Grew at Vigorous Pace in Last Quarter
description: The United States economy grew at its fastest pace in more than six years at the end of 2009, even as businesses resisted hiring and continued to do more with less.

title: Snake Charmer | Chrissie Morris, Cobbler
description: The London-based shoe wizard Chrissie Morris had a lot on her mind when she designed this multifunctional stiletto of rock python, stingray and suede. Inspired by the cagelike structure inside a Gothic church cupola, the shoe has a detachable suede ankle strap (not shown) so you can wear it  get this  three different ways. Its not exactly cheap ($1,390 at kirnazabete.com), but this kind of ingenuity is oh so New Economy.

title: Real Estate Is Top Giver to Cuomo Campaign
description: As Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo readies his candidacy for governor, one industry is helping him amass a huge fund-raising advantage: real estate.

title: Jimmy Kimmel Teaches Jay Leno the Meaning of Sucker Punch
description: The momentary disappearance of Conan OBrien from the airwaves brought peace to the late-night landscape for, oh, about four days. On Thursday night, the surviving combatants were reapplying their war paint as the ABC host Jimmy Kimmel used his monologue to rebut Jay Leno, who said that Mr. Kimmel had sucker-punched him in an earlier interview on Mr. Lenos show. And by rebut, we mean pound him mercilessly.

title: Danica Patrick Announces 12-Race Nascar Schedule
description: Danica Patrick said Thursday that she planned to compete this year in at least 12 races on the Nascar Nationwide Series, the second highest level in the sport. Officials at the racetracks where she expects to compete promptly stomped on their marketing accelerators to sell tickets.

title: Bin Laden Adds Climate Change to List of Grievances Against U.S.
description: Osama bin Laden, the leader of Al Qaeda, blamed the United States and developed countries for not halting climate change and said that the global economy should immediately abandon its reliance on the American dollar, according to an audiotape released Friday by the broadcaster Al Jazeera.

title: The Blip Cometh
description: As expected, a big GDP number (pdf), signifying nothing much. Its an inventory blip: topline growth at 5.7 percent, but only 2.2 of that is final demand.

title: Sexing Up Ukrainian Politics
description: The annual lunch hosted by Ukrainian powerbroker and philanthropist Viktor Pinchuk in Davos has often been a bellwether for the tangled politics of the huge country of 46 million sandwiched between Russia and Europe.

title: Private Equity Is Bullish on Clean Energy
description: With strong interest from corporations eyeing the clean energy sector, 2010 could turn out to be a good time for private equity and venture capital firms to pursue investments.

title: Complaint Box | Ubiquitous Pets
description: This weeks Complaint Box features two views on dogs in public, from Barbara Rosenblatt and Erica Manfred.

title: Massachusetts Sets Ambitious Energy Standards
description: Massachusetts state officials on Friday announced new energy efficiency standards for utilities that aim to be the most ambitious in the nation.

title: Breakfast at Melbourne, More or Less
description: The womens and mens finals of the Australian Open will be shown live this weekend when many people in the United States will be asleep. But each match will then be shown on tape several times.

title: 'The Planets'
description: An excerpt from the HD visual presentation, produced  by the filmmaker Duncan Copp, featuring Gustav Holst's score. Courtesy of the Houston Symphony.

title: Migraines Force Sufferers to Do Their Homework
description: MIGRAINES may be right up there with root canals and childbirth as one of lifes more painful experiences. But unlike childbirth or dental surgery  the pain of which can be dulled with standard medications  migraines are notoriously tricky to treat.

title: Graphic Books Best-Seller List
description: Are comic books the new lease on life for television series that have ended their runs? There certainly seem to be more adventures in store for characters created by Joss Whedon. Hes already been involved in the comic-book version of Season 8 of Buffy the Vampire Slayer, which is published by Dark Horse. (There are even plans to reunite her with  spoiler alert!  Angel). This week, another of Mr. Whedons television creations enters our softcover list at No. 3. Serenity: Better Days continues the journey of the space-faring crew from the 2002 television series Firefly. The show was canceled early in its first season, but its characters returned in the 2005 film Serenity and as a comic book, Serenity: Those Left Behind.

title: Liberals and Incrementalism
description: This Mark Schmitt piece on the tug-of-war within liberalism dovetails with some of the themes Ive been exploring lately. He writes:

title: Another View: The Revenge of the Luddites?
description: Michael Pagano, a finance professor at Villanova, argues that the Volcker Rule resembles another attempt to turn back progress  namely, the Luddite movement of nearly 200 years ago.

title: Bain Capital Invests $12 Million in Edgar Online
description: Bain Capital said Friday that it has invested $12 million in Edgar Online, a publicly traded data services company that helps businesses prepare regulatory filings in a new format that will be mandatory by 2012.

title: Keeping a Watchful Eye Over Davos
description: Andrew Ross Sorkin/The New York Times

title: The Spectacle of West Bank Protests
description:
With a stalled peace process, Israeli soldiers and Palestinian protesters clash violently each Friday. 
The skirmishes are a combination of desperate activism and staged theater.

title: Vance Starts Greasing the Rusted Wheels of Change
description: He strolled into the mostly empty room on Wednesday, jolly as can be. He looked the part of a public figure, with his black suit, navy blue tie stamped with small ducks, and tortoiseshell glasses.

title: Google vs. China: Considering Threats to Internet Freedom
description: Overview | What threats exist to Internet freedom, and how can people and democratic governments combat them? In this lesson, students imagine how they might communicate, and evade censors, if they were antigovernment activists. They then look more closely at the issues involved in the dispute between Google and China and develop ideas for how Google or the United States government should respond. Finally, they do independent research to learn more about the types of information that the Chinese government has sought to block online.

title: Friday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Inside the List
description: I AM PATTI: Just Kids, the new memoir by Patti Smith, enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 7  not bad for a singer who had precisely one hit single, Because the Night, which reached No. 13 on the pop charts in 1978. It may also be a rare moment of punk poetic justice in a book market that tends to be friendlier to the likes of Tori Spelling and Kathy Griffin than to defiantly un-Botoxed middle-aged rockers. And then theres poor Ozzy Osbourne, marooned at No. 26 on the extended list with I Am Ozzy. In an epilogue called Patient Notes, the now drug-free sexagenarian confesses hed still like to have a No. 1 album in America but is realistic about what will be on his headstone: I aint under any illusions. If I close my eyes, I can already see it: Ozzy Osbourne, born, 1948. Died, whenever. He bit the head off a bat.

title: Performers Plan More Charity Projects For Haiti
description: Entertainment personalities are continuing their efforts to raise awareness and money for the earthquake relief effort in Haiti. On Thursday, BET Networks said that it would hold a benefit concert and celebrity telethon for Haitian charity organizations, to be presented on several cable channels on the night of Feb. 5. The event, to be called SOS Saving Ourselves  Help For Haiti, will take place at the AmericanAirlines Arena in Miami and will be hosted by Queen Latifah;, Sean Combs, known as Diddy; and Pharrell Williams. It is to be shown from 8 to 10 p.m. Eastern time on BET, MTV, VH1 and the Centric channel, with proceeds going to charity organizations like Yle Haiti, CARE, Project Medishare and Childrens Safe Drinking Water. A full lineup of artists for the concert has not been announced, but Wyclef Jean, the Haitian-born musician and founder of Yle Haiti, is expected to perform at the event.

title: Law Has Little Effect on Early Release for Inmates
description: COXSACKIE, N.Y.  With his swollen legs and a throaty rasp that whistles like a kettle through his broken teeth, Eddie Jones is an unlikely man to make history.

title: Musical Planets, and Real Ones
description: Like an aliens scarred cranium, an orange Mars rose slowly above the stage of Carnegie Hall. Later, Venus hung suspended, an alabaster orb in the darkness. Strips of Jupiters surface of swirling colors looked like canvases of abstract art. Moons made guest appearances.

title: Tony Blair on Iraq: No Regrets
description: Update | 1:09 p.m.  No Regrets.

title: Weekend Competition: Malapropisms
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to submit malapropisms either those they have overheard or those of which they are guilty.

title: How Times Have Changed (or Not) for Deals
description: The financial markets are returning to measurable health and consequently private equity firms are now doing deals more frequently, even those particularly hurt. Apollo Management, scarred by the Huntsman/Hexion acquisition, has a pending acquisition of Cedar Fair, and TPG, which posted a $1.35 billion loss after its investment in Washington Mutual, is acquiring IMS Health. About a week ago, Lone Star Funds agreed to acquire Lodgian in a deal valued at $270 million.

title: Republicans Ready to Spar With Obama
description: BALTIMORE  Its the rumble in Baltimore as House Republicans take on President Obama today.

title: McDonalds Goes Local
description: Pete Confalone, an old friend and a faithful correspondent who lives in Miami, sends this hilarious clip from the Huffington Post. Italy has arranged with McDonalds to use local produce and traditional flavors on a couple of burgers. This is along the lines of making a Mickey Ds burger with (sugary sweet) barbecue sauce to somehow regionalize it  but is it better (i.e., artichoke puree is good stuff) or worse (i.e. it puts a friendlier face on fast food)? More amusing than monstrous, I suppose, but your comments?

title: Winds or High Water, the Sales Must Go On
description: Phoenix

title: Obama Offers a More Generous Tax Credit for Hiring
description: This morning, as President Obama visits a small business in Baltimore to unveil a temporary tax credit to encourage the hiring of new employees, The Agenda would like to fill you in on the details. The initiative, which would require Congresss assent, is more generous than earlier versions that have floated around Washington, and its tailored more specifically for small businesses.

title: Art of the Road Trip | Mark Dions Souvenirs
description: In the catalog for the artist Mark Dions project Travels of William Bartram  Reconsidered, now on view at the Tanya Bonakdar Gallery, Dion is quoted as saying, I like things  not pictures or facsimiles of things. This is a little like Michael Bloomberg saying he likes being mayor: inarguably true, and more than a bit of an understatement.

title: Notable Sales at the Auctions
description: IN a preview of the Arizona vintage car auctions in last weeks Automobiles section, five cars of special note (among the 2,500 on the block) were profiled. Here are the results of those sales, including buyers premium, followed by the presale estimates:

title: What Constitutes a Board Vacancy
description: Q.

title: When Apartments Make You Sick
description: Q.

title: Slurping Through Tokyo
description: Back in 1993, when I was a sophomore in college, I came across a movie that changed my life: Tampopo, the charming tale of a truck driver who comes to the aid of a young, beleaguered widow whos struggling to raise a childand run a ramen shop. The movie, directed by the late Juzo Itami, is all about foodabout the intricacies of making ramen and eating ramen, about slurping noodles, about the ways that what we eat and how we eat make us who we are.

title: Co-op Buyer Looks for a Bridge
description: Q.

title: Packed With Guilty Pleasures
description: BETHLEHEM, N.H.

title: The Night Belongs to Us
description: Apart from a certain shared apprehension of immortality  complacent in one case, but endearingly gingerly in the other  the skinny 28-year-old on the cover of Patti Smiths seismic 1975 album, Horses, doesnt look much at all like Picassos portrait of Gertrude Stein. But because the shutterbug was Robert Mapplethorpe, who was soon to become fairly legendary himself, that exquisite photograph of Smith on the brink of fame is as close as New Yorks 1970s avant-garde ever came to a comparable twofer. The mythmaking bonus is that the latter-day duo were much more genuinely kindred spirits.

title: Bad Choices
description: A Robert Stone character is often in a position to do harm or good, and his inclination is often to choose harm. This harm is as frequently to the protagonist himself as it is to others  the characters in Stones new collection, Fun With Problems, are, like many in contemporary fiction, dangerous mostly to themselves. But what distinguishes Stones men and women is that they realize it. They are conscious of their bad decisions, which prevents them from resembling that more ordinary fictional bungler, the still-waters-run-deep guy hatched by Hemingway and subsequently adopted by an unending stream of male American story writers.

title: The Question of Quality
description: A LONGTIME Land Rover strength is its off-road ability, but a serious weakness is its reliability, according to two leading research organizations, Consumer Reports and J. D. Power & Associates.

title: Pen and Brush Town House Sale Looks Likely
description: Pen and Brush, a nonprofit space in Greenwich Village for public exhibitions and performances and earlier a private club where women gathered for teas and dinner, has found a buyer for its historic town house on East 10th Street, its executive director, Janice Sands, confirmed on Friday.

title: A Tenement Transformed Tells the Lives of Its Squatters
description: When Andrew Castrucci moved into a tenement on East 3rd Street in 1986, he arrived not with a real estate agent and a new set of keys but with two accomplices who stood watch as he used a 10-pound sledgehammer to smash through cinder blocks filling a rear door to the derelict building.

title: Faithless Love
description: The photos lying on her lovers desk depicted a young, naked, pregnant woman photographing herself, legs apart, in front of a mirror. In his notebook, also lying open (or was it closed?), beside the photos, was an entry about Blandine  not the pregnant woman, another one  where he wrote of his great desire for her. Shes so beautiful! Thus Catherine Millets hellacious ordeal began with not one but two women, naked, fertile, beautiful and, of course, younger. When she confronted her partner, Jacques Henric, on the phone with her discovery of the two women, he generously promised, when he returned from a trip, to tell me all about the affairs he had had with five or six women. Alas, the hollandaise has already thickened. And so Millet is catapulted down the rabbit hole of jealousy, from which there is little chance of return  and never to innocence.

title: From Spyker to Saab, a Quest for Miracles
description: THE top executives at most car companies can rattle off the names of their models. Victor R. Muller can tell you the names of his customers.

title: Shifting Gears
description: Are you the kind of person who instinctively hates the fact that foreign companies are investing billions of dollars in some of Americas most depressed regions, creating millions of well-paying jobs and acting as an engine of growth and prosperity? Me neither.

title: What Were Reading
description: Shipments of California wine fell last year for the first time in 16 years, The Los Angeles Times reports. Consumption of wine is up 2.1% nationally, but industry analyst Jon Fredrikson told the audience at the annual Unified Wine & Grape Symposium on Wednesday that the American public was snubbing tonier bottles from the Golden State and instead opting for cheaper bulk wine imports from overseas winemakers. And in Australia, imports are up and the value of Australian wine sales are down.

title: Travel Deals: Valentines Day Getaways
description: Several hotels and tour companies are offering sweetheart deals, some lasting the entire month of February.

title: Prove It
description: Imagine, if you can, a novel that imbues pot roast, green beans and scalloped potatoes with Gnostic import  not just evoking the aroma of Sundays past, with their old orderliness, aloof from all disruption, as in Marilynne Robinsons last novel, Home, but embodying specific doctrinal precepts and divine mysteries. Reason recoils. Yet, in the philosopher-novelist Rebecca Newberger Goldsteins latest work of fiction, 36 Arguments for the Existence of God, the rotund and orotund Jonas Elijah Klapper, the Extreme Distinguished Professor of Faith, Literature and Values at Frankfurter University (think of Brandeis), proposes the traditional Jewish Sabbath meal of cholent (bean and potato stew) and kugel (pudding) to his overawed grad student, Cass Seltzer, as a worthy dissertation topic. And hes not kidding. All of the dishes have kabbalist significance, he tells Seltzer. The tzaddikim, or righteous ones, proclaimed that there are profound matters enfolded in the kugel.

title: The Way We Learn
description: In the four rigorously reasonable essays in The Marketplace of Ideas, Louis Menand takes up four questions about American higher education: Why is it so hard to institute a general education curriculum? Why did the humanities disciplines undergo a crisis of legitimation? Why has interdisciplinarity become a magic word? And why do professors all tend to have the same politics?

title: Its a Family Affair: Sly Stone Sues Manager
description: Sly Stone has filed a lawsuit against his longtime manager, Jerry Goldstein, saying that Mr. Goldstein defrauded him of tens of millions of dollars in royalties for more than 20 years, and that he registered a trademark for the name Sly and the Family Stone without permission. In the suit, filed on Thursday in Los Angeles County Superior Court, Sly Stone (whose real name is Sylvester Stewart) and another former manager, Ken Roberts, request an accounting of royalties and unspecified financial damages that their lawyers estimate at $20 million to $30 million. (The musician previously told his side of the story in this 2008 profile in Vanity Fair.)

title: Haitian Lawmakers Seek to Delay Elections
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Lawmakers in the lower house of Haitis Parliament plan to ask President Ren Prval to postpone upcoming elections and instead extend their terms of office by two years, United Nations officials said on Friday.

title: Glory Days
description: By all rights, sidemen should be the ones with the best stories in rock n roll. Lead singers, burdened by the requisite narcissism and constant media presence, seem unlikely to open up and reveal much. The other band members are the ones with front-row seats for the madness and less public image to preserve.

title: The Nifty 50 | Matt Bomer, Actor
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Tom, Dick and Carlin
description: Two new books center on the collision between comedy and the old establishment. Last Words, a posthumous autobiography from George Carlin, is a jazzy, inward-looking piece of work. Its strength lies in its documentation of how this great comedian made the trip from a happy-to-be-here entertainer of the 1960s to the salt-in-the-wound philosopher-comic of the 1970s and beyond. Dangerously Funny: The Uncensored Story of The Smothers Brothers Comedy Hour,  by the veteran television critic David Bianculli, is a straightforward chronicle that charts the rise and fall of a charming double act cut down in its prime by annoyed CBS executives.

title: Smileys People
description: Twenty years ago, the subject of this vast and fascinating book did not, officially speaking, exist at all. The Security Service, better known as MI5, is the domestic arm of British intelligence. While its sister organization, MI6, supplies the British government with foreign intelligence, MI5 is responsible for counterintelligence, countersubversion, counterterrorism and security within the United Kingdom.

title: With Recall Expanding, Toyota Gives an Apology
description: DETROIT  The president of Toyota issued his first apology Friday as his troubled automaker expanded its recall to include Europe and it rushed to complete its strategy to modify or replace millions of accelerator pedals.

title: Honda Recalls 141,000 Fits in U.S. for Window Issue
description: Honda said it was recalling about 141,000 20078 Honda Fits in the United States because of a fire hazard involving the power-window switch.

title: Finding the Right Migraine Treatment
description: While watching my daughters volleyball practice from the sidelines recently, I struck up a conversation with another mom who looked, quite frankly, awful. Migraine, she explained, wincing as she spoke.

title: Race to the Top, but Not to the Web
description: After scores of states applied for a competitive education grant known as Race to the Top last week, the vast majority of states posted their applications online for all to see.

title: Postcolonial Everyman
description: Chinua Achebe has a real knack for titles. With its simple assertion that Things Fall Apart, Achebes now classic 1958 novel took Yeatss horrified imaginings of Christian Europes apocalyptic end and made them resonate within the space of precolonial black Africa. Now, some 50 years later, Achebe has given this volume of autobiographical essays its own Pandoras box of a title. Deceptively disarming, The Education of a British-Protected Child belies the complexity of what he calls the strongly multiethnic, multilingual, multireligious, somewhat chaotic situation he was born into as a colonial subject whose first passport described him as a British Protected Person. As the 16 essays in this collection reveal, the education Achebe and his fellow Nigerians received from their exploitative and racist self-proclaimed protectors would not be a model of perfection. Indeed.

title: California Officials Would Not Regulate Electric Car Charging Firms
description: California officials have indicated they are not inclined to regulate electric car infrastructure companies that plan to sell electricity to drivers through networks of charging stations.

title: Abortion Foe Found Guilty in Doctors Killing
description: WICHITA, Kan.  In the end, it took jurors 37 minutes on Friday to convict Scott Roeder, an abortion opponent, of first-degree murder in the death of George R. Tiller, one of the few doctors in the country to perform late-term abortions.

title: Clinton Warns China on Iran Sanctions
description: PARIS  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton warned China on Friday that it would face economic insecurity and diplomatic isolation if it did not sign on to tough new sanctions against Iran for its nuclear program, seeking to raise the pressure on Beijing to fall in line with an American-led campaign.

title: Canadas Supreme Court Says Inmates Rights Were Violated at Guantnamo
description: OTTAWA  The Supreme Court of Canada ruled Friday that Canadian agents violated the rights of the only Canadian citizen held at the Guantnamo Bay detention center when they interrogated him there. But the ruling, the second concerning the mans politically sensitive case, does not order the government to demand his return to Canada, as he has long requested.

title: Aprs le Dluge
description: Paris may be known as the City of Light, but the City of Water would be just as apt. Since its origins as an island outpost in the middle of the Seine, the city owes some of its greatest advantages  its trading routes, military security and fertile farmland  to its riverside position. That placement has also, however, long made Paris vulnerable to flooding. The citys Roman name, Lutetia, is said to derive from the Latin word for mud (lutum), and one of its oldest neighborhoods, the Marais, was originally just that: a marsh. In 814, an unnamed author remarked that when God wants to punish the people of Paris by water, he sends such a flood and overflows the river Seine. Divine retribution or not, the deluge is an age-old Parisian problem and accounts for its otherwise improbable-sounding motto: Fluctuat nec Mergitur (She is tossed about by the waves but does not sink).

title: Cast Away
description: Who remembers the last survivors of Muslim Spain, whom Spaniards contemptuously called Moriscos (little Moors)? Impressive research on them has appeared in the last 30 years, yet until now, none of it has escaped beyond the walls of the academic ghetto. Matthew Carrs well-balanced and comprehensive book brings the story of their tragic fate to a wider public.

title: Checking It Twice
description: To the Editor:

title: Dear Author: Never Mind
description: To the Editor:

title: Dinner and a Reading
description: To the Editor:

title: Criticism and the Critic
description: To the Editor:

title: Weighting Wallace
description: To the Editor:

title: Marines Invest in Local Afghan Projects
description: BOGRABAD, Afghanistan  Abdul Salam, an elder in this impoverished Afghan village, rose to meet the approaching Marines and Navy corpsman. Behind him, his mosque had a new concrete floor and two windows. Last month, before the Marines paid him to refurbish it, the mosque was windowless and had a dirt floor.

title: The Rap on Happiness
description: Smart people often talk trash about happiness, and worse than trash about books on happiness, and they have been doing so for centuries  just as long as other people have been pursuing happiness and writing books about it. The fashion is to bemoan happiness studies and positive psychology as being the work not of the Devil (the Devil is kind of cool), but of morons. No mockery in this world ever sounds to me so hollow as that of being told to cultivate happiness, Charlotte Bront wrote in 1853. What does such advice mean? Happiness is not a potato, to be planted in mould and tilled with manure.

title: U.N. Mission Head in Afghanistan Met With Taliban Envoys
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Members of the Taliban leadership met with a United Nations official earlier this month to discuss the possibility of entering into face-to-face peace talks with the Afghan government, American and United Nations officials said Friday.

title: Tax Tips for the Unemployed and Financially Distressed
description: If youve lost your job, or suffered a big drop in income, you may have a significantly different tax situation from previous years.

title: Up Front: Wells Tower
description: In his review of T. Coraghessan Boyles new story collection, Wild Child, Wells Tower points out that Boyle has long had an affinity for the natural world.

title: Davos Diary on CNBC: Washington on Everyones Minds
description: We cant stress this enough: Washington is the dominant topic at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, this year. Between the panels and at the parties, political and business leaders from around the world keep asking whether or not the Obama administration can pull off its ambitious initiatives.

title: Indianas Buyer Announces Retirement
description: Representative Steve Buyer, a veteran Indiana Republican, announced today that he would not seek re-election this year.

title: Tokyo Quest: Ramen 101
description: The Frugal Traveler, Matt Gross, gives a quick course on the Ramen Mania culture in Tokyo. There is an art to ordering well and eating well.

title: Talking About a Revolution (for a Digital Age)
description: IT is time to blow the whole thing up. In September 1960, when those words were lobbed at the world by a New York-centric, off-Hollywood circle of malcontents called the New American Cinema Group, there was no mistaking their radical urgency. Given the cold war times  one of the first large ban-the-bomb rallies had been held in Madison Square Garden some months earlier  this call to annihilation might have seemed tasteless. But for this group, whose numbers included the film critic, later filmmaker Jonas Mekas and the not-yet-director Peter Bogdanovich, the time for a free American cinema, one rooted in personal vision and liberated from censorship and the distribution and exhibition strangleholds, was now.

title: BlackRock Hires Former Goldman Banker
description: BlackRock said Friday that it had hired a former Goldman Sachs banker, Kendrick R. Wilson, to be a vice chairman and help support the firms client relations as the firm solidifies its position as one of the worlds largest asset managers. Mr. Wilsons large Rolodex could help BlackRocks win new clients as well as help it gain a louder voice in Washington.

title: Bair Offers Guarded Praise for Trading Curb Limits
description: Sheila Bair, the head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said on Friday that proposed proprietary trading limits are very positive, but said they would not have necessarily reined in risk-taking at the institutions that required huge bailouts.

title: The Financial Side to Paternity Leave
description: Our colleagues over at the Motherlode blog note that the British government has just approved a paid paternity leave system that allows men to stay home for up to three months, under certain circumstances, to take care of a newly arrived child.

title: Memories of Salinger, From Blog to Blog
description: The death of J. D. Salinger, whose life remained private in a way few celebrities could imagine possible for today (Tiger Woods en tte), left many blogging in the blanks of his life or else reliving those few moments, literary or otherwise, they spent with the man.

title: Teacher Q | What Are Your Favorite and Least Favorite Books to Teach?
description: I taught The Scarlet Letter eight times in my classroom career, and got to the point where I could reel off whole passages by memory.

title: Another Push for Wine Sales in Groceries
description: Its a new year, and a new New York State budget proposal, but its the same old deficit. So once again, Gov. David A. Paterson has proposed allowing New York groceries to sell wine as a means of raising revenue through license fees.

title: Results of Study on Cellphone Use Surprise Researchers
description: Over on our sister blog, Wheels, Cheryl Jensen writes that laws banning cellphone use while driving have not resulted in a reduction in car crashes. The study was conducted by the Highway Loss Data Institute.

title: Why J. D. Salinger Never Wanted a Catcher in the Rye Movie
description: Its been the dream of many a producer  and perhaps the nightmare of many a faithful reader  that J. D. Salingers novel The Catcher in the Rye might someday be translated to another medium. In a report for The Associated Press, Hillel Italie writes that Mr. Salinger considered a stage version of the novel in which he himself would play its teenage protagonist, Holden Caulfield. That (mercifully) never happened; nor did offers for film adaptations from Billy Wilder, Elia Kazan, Steven Spielberg and Harvey Weinstein, all of which the author summarily turned down.

title: Q. & A. With Reggie Miller
description: Reggie Miller did not hit every big shot of his 18-year N.BA. career against the Knicks, but sometimes it felt that way. Miller, who is remembered as one of the great clutch performers of his generation, is the star of an ESPN documentary, Winning Time: Reggie Miller vs. the New York Knicks. The film, which will be broadcast on March 14, highlights the Knicks-Pacers rivalry and focuses on Millers legendary performance in the 1995 playoffs. In Game 1 of that series, Miller scored 8 points in 18.7 seconds to break the Knicks hearts and give Indiana a come-from-behind victory at Madison Square Garden. Whether it was feuding courtside with Spike Lee or butting heads with Knicks like John Starks, Miller was at the center of the rivalry.

title: The Importance of Being Ernie
description: Cops love him. So do schoolchildren, and their parents, and nice old ladies, and waiters in Greek diners, and charity bigwigs, and late-night comedians.

title: On Water Vapor and Warming
Activist Offers Justification for Tampering in Senate Office
description: NEW ORLEANS  After nearly a week of silence since his arrest on Monday on charges of interfering with the phones in Senator Mary L. Landrieus New Orleans office, James OKeefe III, the conservative advocate, said Friday that he was trying to determine whether Ms. Landrieu was avoiding constituent complaints.

title: One of Our Older Monuments
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: How many of you watched President Obamas State of the Ruin, uh, State of the Union address?

title: Blueberries Morning, Noon and Night
description: Frozen blueberries are one of the foods I wrote about in The 11 Best Foods You Arent Eating. These nutrient-rich fruits are available year-round and dont spoil, and blueberries have been associated with better memory in animal studies.

title: Leaving Nebraska for Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Laura al-Asadi has found her heaven in a cold and dusty apartment in Baghdads Red Zone. Mrs. Asadi, a 49-year-old from Lincoln, Neb., has married an Iraqi and moved to Iraqs violence-ridden capital.

title: Salinger and the Estate Tax
description: Most people seeing the J.D. Salinger obituary on Friday are probably remembering when they read Catcher in the Rye. Richard A. Behrendt, a lawyer and estate planner at Robert W. Baird & Company, is a self-confessed tax geek, with a different perspective. He sends along the following:

title: One Conflict, Many Views, No Actors
description: TEL AVIV

title: The University of California to Play the Waiting-List Game
description: For the first time in its history, the University of California is expected to institute waiting lists for incoming applicants, possibly starting this spring. More than 1,000 applicants may be affected.

title: Oscars Try to Navigate Through Babel
description: THERE was a time when the Academy Award for best foreign-language film reflected the state of world cinema: Fellini films won back-to-back Oscars in the mid 1950s, as did Bergman films in the early 60s. But the category has come to suggest a peculiar gulf between Academy opinion and the tastes of critics and audiences alike.

title: We Made It Ourselves | Marcie Blaine Chocolates
description: In her column, We Made It Ourselves, Charlotte Druckman writes about restaurants and small businesses with interesting house-made treats.

title: He Looked Something Like This
description: This is not to diminish the seriousness of the fact that a man was recently murdered in a jewelry store holdup, but the sketch that the police released Wednesday got us wondering: how is this going to help anyone catch the killer?

title: Helping the Sax Find a Classical Home
description: THE saxophone, invented by the Belgian-born instrument maker Adolphe Sax around 1840, has seldom achieved prominence in the classical instrumentarium. Master orchestrators like Strauss, Ravel and Rachmaninoff have used it for coloristic purposes, and a number of composers have featured it as a solo instrument. But its chamber repertory is sorely limited, as Matt Levy found when, as a student at the University of Michigan 25 years ago, he started the Prism Quartet, a classical saxophone ensemble.

title: Dr. Louisa Stark on the Science Prize
description: Two Web sites created at the University of Utah's Genetic Science Learning Center were honored with the Science Prize for Online Resources in Education. (Science/AAAS)

title: The Gossip Guy Doesnt Miss a Beat
description: Village Voice columnist Michael Musto makes his nightly rounds with shoe leather, not Twitter.

title: Believe It or Not, Existing-Home Sales Were Up in 09
description: WHEN prices fall far enough, buyers will appear.

title: Digging Through the Sundance Hype
description: Manhola Dargis delivers an almost final word on Sundance, slicing through the hype and history to find that its all still pretty worthwhile.

title: Super Bowl Wager Provokes Art-Museum Trash Talk
description: Its not only mayors and inveterate gamblers who place bets on the Super Bowl  art museums do, too. The Times-Picayune reported that the New Orleans Museum of Art and the Indianapolis Museum of Art have placed a friendly wager on the outcome of the big game on Feb. 7: if the New Orleans Saints win, the Indianapolis museum will send The Fifth Plague of Egypt  that is, the landscape from its collection painted by J.M.W. Turner in 1800  to the New Orleans museum, which gets to show it for three months. If the Indianapolis Colts prevail, the New Orleans institution will send the painting Ideal View of Tivoli, a 1644 work by Claude Lorrain, to Indianapolis for three months. The Times-Picayune said the bet was instigated by Tyler Green, who writes the Modern Art Notes blog for artsjournal.com, and who helped egg on some tongue-in-cheek trash talk between the museums directors. When E. John Bullard, the New Orleans museum director, offered to wager a valuable Renoir, his Indianapolis counterpart, Maxwell Anderson, dismissed it as a sentimental blancmange. Mr. Bullard replied: I am amused that Renoir is too sweet for Indianapolis. Does this mean that those Indiana corn farmers have simpler tastes?

title: Hello, New York: Avant-Garde Eastern Europe
description: IN Poland during the late 1960s and early 70s acquiring American hit records and similar artifacts of Western culture was virtually impossible. But where there is a demand, a solution is sure to arise. A desire for bubble-gum pop in Krakow led to kiosks dealing in sound postcards: cheap, disposable records consisting of a grooved plastic laminate affixed to a colorful paper card suitable for mailing.

title: Must See: A Saving Berth at Sea
Alone on a Path Shared by Many
description: PORTRAIT of me, 2005: New Yorker, writer, age 31. I had a new boyfriend, an agent excited about my novel and a new college teaching job. I was finally approaching happiness, even if I had taken the scenic route. I should have been running victory laps.

title: Taliban Bombers Attack Afghan Provincial Capital
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Once again Taliban insurgents staged a surprise attack on official targets, using a squad of heavily armed suicide bombers, and again they failed to achieve their declared goals.

title: The Salinger Playlist
description: The blog Classics Rock! has reposted its list of songs referring to the works of J. D. Salinger.

title: Israel Defends Its Inquiry Into Gaza War
description: JERUSALEM  Israel sent a letter to the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, on Friday, defending the credibility of its internal military investigation into the Israeli Armys conduct during last winters Gaza war.

title: Now Showing | Americans in Paris
description: Unlike their fashion brethren, young American furniture and product designers get little respect or attention in their native land, let alone in the sophisticated capitals of Europe. But now, in a surprising turn of events, they are being celebrated in Paris, the apogee of chic.On Jan. 21, Triode, a Left Bank gallery, opened Americans in Paris, a show that features the work of over a dozen budding United States-based talents including Harry Allen, Mathilde Alessandra, Chris Ferebee, KleinReid, Paul Loebach, Jason Miller, Jeff Miller, Moorhead & Moorhead, John Pomp, Josh Owen, Jonah Takagi and Ali Tayar.

title: A Recuperated Swan Takes Flight
description: THE words swan and lake mean a lot of things to a lot of ballerinas, but for Sara Mearns, the words have a special significance. They put her on the map of the New York City Ballet.

title: Weir Says He Will Wear Fake Fur at Olympics
description: Yielding to pressure from animal rights groups, Johnny Weir, the three-time national figure skating champion, said he would tweak the costume he had planned to wear in his long program at the Olympics, replacing the outfits white fox fur with white faux fur.

title: S O S! Fewer Acronyms ASAP!
description: POTUS delivered his SOTU, with SCOTUS sitting right there in front of him.

title: The Numbers, Like Them or Not
description: Sodium content in some favorite New York restaurant dishes.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) Tweets per minute from different cities around the world.

title: Genetics Web Sites Win Online Award
description: Two Web sites created at the University of Utah were awarded the Science Prize for Online Resources in Education for "providing an excellent source of new material while educating a hugely diverse audience of users."

title: Summers Turns Up the Heat on Banks
description: Agence France Presse Lawrence H. Summers, left, with Charlie Rose at the World Economic Forum. Mr. Summers maintained the pressure on banks to accept greater regulation.

title: City Critic | Salt in the City
description: Ariel Kaminer visits a popular New York restaurant to get the lowdown on how chefs really cook with salt.

title: Juniors Watch: Robson Reaches Another Final
description: Laura Robson, who played on Britains Hopman Cup team with Andy Murray to start the 2010 season, has replicated his success at the Australian Open by reaching Saturdays girls singles championship final. The Australian-born left-hander, a finalist in Melbourne last year, may not be seeded, but she is the favorite when she takes the court against No. 6-seeded Karolina Pliskova of the Czech Republic.

title: Giving Serial Killings Serial Treatment
description: ITS getting dead murky, isnt it? says a detective in the Red Riding crime trilogy, a voyage into the decaying heart of Northern England in the 1970s and 80s. This adaptation of three novels of the four-book series by the Yorkshire-born writer David Peace is an ambitious endeavor: it is shot by three directors, shares characters (though the protagonists shift) and mingles invention and fact. Like David Finchers 2007 serial-killer drama Zodiac, the Red Riding films are more about capturing an era than solving a mystery.

title: The Shining
description: Glistening fabrics gave the spring couture collections in Paris an extra quality of mystery. What were some of those glassy, textured, iridescent fabrics at Giorgio Armani? They were certainly otherworldly and made for an absorbing, different Armani Priv show. In addition to gorgeous silk satins, Karl Lagerfeld at Chanel used stockings with shimmer, embroidery that looked like melted nuggets of silver, and custom-made rocker boots in silver leather with rococo heals.

title: Seattle Symphony Agrees on a Contract
description: The Seattle Symphonys musicians and management have agreed on a contract after contentious negotiations that included a strike authorization. The agreement, which was announced on Thursday and still has to be ratified by both sides, includes a 5 percent pay cut through August with a complete restoration of the cut by early 2011 and a 1.5 percent raise at the beginning of the 2011-2012 season. The players also agreed to donate $2,010 each, or $168,840, back to the orchestra. The symphonys minimum wage is $78,750, not including the reduction, although most musicians earn more than that. The concessions by the players are in line with moves at many orchestras around the country during the recession.

title: Fact Check: Obama and House Republicans
description: Update | 3:50 p.m.  Part two of this post is here.

title: The Morning Skate: Campbells Complaint, Malhotras Goal and Kanes Antics
description: N.H.L. Vice President Colin Campbell is not especially pleased with two prominent Canadian politicians, federal Finance Minister Jim Flaherty and Member of Parliament Ken Dryden, two men with hockey backgrounds who, as noted here yesterday, called for the league to take more of a leading role on the matter of checks to the head.

title: Another View: The Challenges of Time for Start-Ups
description: Cameron Lester and Mike Kwatinetz of Azure Capital Partners examine why start-up companies need to be time-efficient as well as capital-efficient.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Giardini'
description: The artist Steve McQueen discusses a scene from Giardini, a 30-minute film about the Venice Biennale's festival grounds in winter.

title: On the Plate, a Pinch or a Pound?
description: Ever since Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced his salt reduction initiative this month, people on all sides of the issue have developed a case of high blood pressure. Some scientists have gone on as though that white powdery substance were the most dangerous biological weapon on the planet. Meanwhile, some chefs and diners have responded as though the city were stationing armed police officers in kitchens and bodegas lest anyone make a move for the Doritos.

title: Will Super Bowl Spot Become a Horse of a Different Color?
description: The maker of Budweiser beer is having second thoughts about a decision to run commercials during Super Bowl XLIV that would not feature the brands familiar Clydesdales.

title: Book Review Podcast: Patti Smith and Rebecca Newberger Goldstein
description: This week: the music legend Patti Smith discusses her memoir, Just Kids; Rebecca Newberger Goldstein talks about her new novel, 36 Arguments for the Existence of God; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Georgetown Big Mans Loyalties Endure
description: WASHINGTON  Norma Monroe returned from her shift at a New Orleans post office around 11 p.m. on Aug. 27, 2005, two days before Hurricane Katrina made landfall in Louisiana.

title: Daniel R. Tishman
