description: Mr. Tishman, 54, is the chairman and chief executive of the Tishman Construction Corporation and vice chairman of Tishman Hotel & Realty.

title: Book Review Podcast: Patti Smith and Rebecca Newberger Goldstein
description: This week: the music legend Patti Smith discusses her memoir, Just Kids; Rebecca Newberger Goldstein talks about her new novel, 36 Arguments for the Existence of God; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Couture Warriors
description: Heres a look at another idea from the spring couture: garments with exceptional three-dimensional texture. Jean Paul Gaultier, right, used feathers, crisp fan pleating and basketweave details. Among his most dynamic looks were a cream day suit with a lattice jacket, and a stiff, semi-transparent skirt scattered with feathers and shown with a corseted white shirt/jacket.

title: C-Span to Replay Obamas Q&A With G.O.P.
description: Reacting to a wave of interest in President Obamas televised dialogue with Congressional Republicans, C-Span said it would replay the session in prime time tonight.

title: The Reading Life: Jeff Bridges and Crazy Heart': Channeling Donald Barthelme?
description: Jeff Bridges has deservedly earned some of the best reviews of his career for his role as Bad Blake, a washed-up country singer, in the movie Crazy Heart. In interviews, Mr. Bridges has said he based the look and feel of the character on his friend Kris Kristofferson, among other musicians.

title: Islamic Insurgents Attack Troops in the Somali Capital
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Islamic insurgents who control much of rural Somalia launched an early-morning attack on international peacekeepers and government soldiers in this battered capital on Friday, trading fire for hours in a street battle.

title: Between a Castle and a Cottage
description: WESTPORT

title: Dont Become Happier Than Your Wife
description: If you are happier than your wife, you may be at greater risk of divorce.

title: Chic in Review | George Clooney for President
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: The Unloved Annuity Gets a Hug From Obama
description: Annuities: The official retirement vehicle of the Obama administration.

title: Damsels in Distress, Bozos in Heat
description: THE television landscape is a universe of opposites. The Travel network (get up and go someplace!) is the opposite of HSN (sit on your couch and buy stuff!). Syfy (fantastical things that havent happened yet) is the opposite of History (moderately interesting things that have already happened). The Golf Channel (sedentary activity watched by sedentary old duffers) is the opposite of Nick Jr. (frenetic activity watched by frenetic young children).

title: Shout Out Loud About Your Annuity
description: In my latest Your Money column, I discuss the Obama administrations push to get more people to put some of their retirement money into simple annuities or other products that can provide a regular income stream for the rest of their lives.

title: At Tavern on the Green, Everything Must (and Does) Go
description: Frenzied bargain hunters who descended on the Tavern on the Green tag sale on Friday hardly entertained hopes of landing the $180,000 leaded-glass ceiling, as it was long gone. And they knew the $75,000 stained-glass peacock was but a memory.

title: Hamas Official Murdered in Dubai Hotel
description: SANA, Yemen  The Palestinian militant group Hamas said Friday that one of its senior officials was murdered in a Dubai hotel room last week. Hamas accused Israel of the killing and vowed to retaliate.

title: No More Crushes; This Is Serious
description: CLAIRE DANES wouldnt mind a contemporary role for a change, if that can be arranged. Last year she played an ambitious careerist in the 1930s theater in Me and Orson Welles, now shes an autistic animal scientist in the 1960s in the biopic Temple Grandin. So shed like something in the here and now  maybe where she gets to wear heels on occasion, even show a little leg.

title: The Verdict: Change and Chinese Food
description: DIM SUM is so commonplace around Civic Center, the swath of downtown Manhattan that encompasses City Hall, police headquarters and the courts, that it might almost be considered the official food. Passers-through on lunch break from jury duty have no doubt eaten their share in the Chinese restaurants lining Baxter Street.

title: Prediction Mania as Nomination Day Approaches
description: Its T-4 days until the Oscar nominations are announced; the Bagger will be there to deliver some bleary-eyed analysis in person. In the meantime, awards watchers are weighing in on

title: C-Span Wants More of Obama-Republican Q and A
description: Reacting to a wave of interest in President Obamas televised dialogue with Congressional Republicans, C-Span said it would replay the session in prime time tonight.

title: Girls vs. Boys
description: What do the programs on Spike and Lifetime tell us about the sexes?

title: Living in Civic Center
description: The Civic Center neighborhood has its heart at City Hall Park; its perimeter hugs the edges of Chinatown, TriBeCa and the financial district.

title: Becoming a Stage Mother
description: We talk about helicopter parenting as though this generation invented it whole cloth. True, weve perfected it  spurred by a changing world where being a parent is harder and is layered with more guilt. But overly involved parents (and those who wondered where the lines were) have been with us for generations.

title: Lillie Mear, Charles Howard
description: Lillie Nesbitt Mear and Charles Taylor Howard were married Saturday at the Georgian Suite, an event space in New York. The Rev. Dr. Katherine Kurs, a member of the religious studies faculty at the New School, officiated.

title: Margaret Cannella and Ronald Brown
description: Margaret Mary Cannella and Ronald Alan Brown were married Saturday at the Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Thomas J. Mullelly, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Fact Check 2: Obama and House Republicans
description: In his extraordinary question-and-answer exchange with House Republicans, President Obama fielded a query from Representative Jason Chaffetz, a freshman from Utah, who asserted that Mr. Obama and Democrats had shut Republicans out of the health care debate and that the president had broken a campaign promise to let C-Span show health care negotiations on live television.

title: Builders Reassess the Market
description: THE number of new-housing permits issued statewide in 2009 did not even reach 12,000. The last year the tally was that low: 1945, when New Jersey was still mostly cow and corn country.

title: New Teams Connect Dots of Terror Plots
description: WASHINGTON  The nations main counterterrorism center is creating new teams of specialists to pursue clues of emerging terrorist plots as part of a rapid buildup that will sharply increase its analyst corps, perhaps by hundreds of people over the next year, intelligence officials said Friday.

title: Emily Colahan, Craig Cerone Jr.
description: Emily Sullivan Colahan, a daughter of Jane Hawkins Colahan and Peter D. Colahan of Rye, N.Y., was married Saturday to Craig Lewis Cerone Jr., a son of Jane M. Cerone and Mr. Cerone Sr. of Ridgefield, Conn. The Rev. Susan McKnight performed the ceremony at the Warren United Church in Warren, Vt.

title: Gila Weinstein, John Houten
description: Dr. Gila R. Weinstein and Dr. John K. Houten are to be married Sunday evening at the Razag Ballroom in Brooklyn. Rabbi Yeshosua Balkany is to officiate.

title: Boses New System Is a Truck Seat
description: Tell a seasoned trucker who drives a heavy-duty rig day in and day out that the Bose Corporation has made a product especially for him, and hed probably guess that its a new sound system or perhaps a fancy pair of noise canceling headphones to wipe out road noise.

title: The Nifty 50 | Paul Loebach, Furniture Designer
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: A Nightclub to Call Home
description: THE name Ohm may conjure ideas of meditative tranquillity for some. But developers of one of Manhattans latest rental apartment buildings have another Ohm in mind  one that has more to do with a high-wattage lifestyle.

title: Driving the Carp That Roared
description: OPEN the Spyker C8 Ailerons scissor doors, slide into a form-fitting leather bucket seat and turn the key to start your test drive.

title: Michelle Ko, Tony Wong
description: Michelle Chi-Hsun Ko and Tony Wong were married Friday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau in New York. Blanca Martinez of the City Clerks office officiated.

title: I.P.O. Market Begins to Regain Its Luster
description: The I.P.O. pipeline in the United States is filling up as companies once afraid of braving the capital markets are now lining up to for initial public offerings. A fair number of these companies, especially in the financial industry, are looking to spin off businesses at lucrative prices.

title: Carbon Market Could Grow 33% This Year
description: The global carbon market is expected to total $170 billion this year, a 33 percent jump from 2009, driven mostly by higher prices in Europe and a growth in the nascent carbon market in the United States, according to a new report from Point Carbon, a market analysis firm.

title: Wooed, and Finally Won Over
description: THE seven years that Karen Dahl and Brian Reich spent in Cambridge, Mass., were formative ones. They married there, bought a home, and had a son, Henry. Though Ms. Dahl longed to return to New York, where both had lived after meeting as workers in Al Gores 2000 presidential campaign, her husband had no interest in doing so.

title: Pictures of the Day: Friday, Jan. 29
description: Not yet 30 years old, Muhammed Basem Muheisen of The Associated Press is among the more prolific photojournalists out there. He was a member of the team that won the Pulitzer Prize in 2005 for breaking news photography, for a stunning series of photographs of bloody yearlong combat inside Iraqi cities. In recent months, his work has been featured 18 times in Pictures of the Day; second only to his A.P. colleague, Altaf Qadri, in appearances by non-Times photographers. (Mr. Muheisens latest, Slide 10, shows a family very much on the move in Rawalpindi, Pakistan.)

title: Consumer Reports Withdraws Recommendations on 8 Toyota Models
description: Just when it appeared life couldnt get any worse for Toyota, the influential Consumer Reports magazine says it is withdrawing its Recommended label from eight Toyota models being recalled because the accelerator may stick.

title: Property Seizure for Atlantic Yards Is Delayed
description: The states planned seizure of property in Brooklyn to make way for the $4.9 billion Atlantic Yards project was delayed on Friday when a judge declined to rule immediately on the states request for final approval.

title: Chart: Diplo Presents
description: The artist Andrew Kuo charts every track on Diplo Presents: Free Gucci (Best of the Cold War Mixtapes) a compilation of mixtape series tracks by the Atlanta rapper Gucci Mane, remixed by the likes of Flying Lotus, Salem, Zomby and Diplo himself. Gucci Manes latest studio album, The State vs. Radric Davis, came out late last year.

title: At Tavern on Green, Everything Must (and Does) Go
description: From Glenn Collins at Diners Journal:

title: Obama, House Republicans Debate Their Divisions
description: Updated, 4:30 p.m. BALTIMORE  President Obama and the Congressional Republicans who have opposed him engaged in a lively and robust public debate this afternoon over health care, the economy and who was more to blame for the toxic atmosphere clouding the nations politics.

title: The Weinsteins Snap Up Blue Valentine
description: News from the Weinstein Company that is not doom or gloom!

title: F.H.A. Lending Standards Tightened
description: SINCE lenders started tightening underwriting standards in 2008, many people have flocked to mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration, which serves borrowers who have poor credit and little money for down payments.

title: Warming Up to Modern
description: HUNTINGTON

title: Buying a Condo: Now vs. Later
description: AS the residential real estate market in New York City continues to emerge from its deep freeze, sales at new condominium developments are starting to pick up.

title: Sundance 2010 | Coming Out of the Cold
description: Karmically speaking, we have to guess that the Sundance Film Festival is in pretty good shape. The Dalai Lama sent a message of peace, which was broadcast during the Music 4 Peace Initiative press conference, an event attended by Dr. Arun Gandhi, the Def Jam founder Russell Simmons and the civil rights leader Dr. Benjamin Chavis, Jr. (Music 4 Peace also sponsored an appearance by Pras, the Haitian former member of the Fugees, who performed for Haitian Relief.) Less divinely, but only slightly, Robert Redford came down from the mountain last night to sit in on a panel with the author Naomi Klein and the director Michael Winterbottom, who together made The Shock Doctrine, a documentary about Milton Friedman, the Chicago School of Economics, third-world corporate oppression and how countries like Haiti get that way. Great stuff. And if the connections with American independent cinema seem a bit, shall we say, loose, well thats all part of the Great Wheel of Life in Park City, Utah.But its hardly a big mystery. When people whisper about the dirty little secret of Sundance (the jaded will say, Uh, which one?), theyre usually talking about something else: that the documentaries are better than the features? (Yawn.) That the festival is as much about stars as anywhere else? (No kidding.) That when a film is introduced by someone who says, It went through the Sundance lab  but thats not why its here, you know thats exactly why its here? Old news. How about the fact that the festivals Volunteer Appreciation Day was celebrated Wednesday with the same enthusiasm that prison inmates would celebrate Corrections Officer Day? Tell us something we dont know.

title: Bronx Man, Already Jailed, Convicted of Manslaughter
description: Quindel Francis, a 21-year-old Bronx man who spent the last five years in jail on charges of murdering a classmate, was convicted of manslaughter on Friday, bringing an end to a legal saga that had stretched through two mistrials.

title: A Timeline of the Lost Universe
description: Because Lost, which began its final season, can get awfully confusing, we've arranged some major events of the shows first five seasons in chronological order.

title: A Prewar Home, to Say the Least
description: WITH a spinning wheel in the attic, flintlock rifles on the walls, foot warmers at the hearth and a horse-drawn sleigh in the barn, Annette and Stuart Mont are well-equipped for 18th-century colonial farm life.

title: Masculinity in a Spray Can
description: ONE bathroom in Stefanie Mullens home in a suburb of San Diego is stocked with enough products to line an aisle in a drugstore:

title: Dangerously Funny
description: Introduction

title: Now Performing | Gelitin in the Flesh
description: Blindfolded and dressed somewhere between princess drag and locker-room sweats, the four-man Austrian art collective Gelitin began a weeklong residency at Greene Naftali Gallery in Chelsea last night, working in a makeshift plywood arena before a dense crowd of oglers. Assisted by up to seven guest artists each day, with a performance by the art band XXX Macarena scheduled for Saturday at 7:30 p.m., Gelitin is building a completely mad, totemic sculpture made of fabric, rubber, glue, spools of thread, Styrofoam and whatnot, which they will be the last to see.

title: Oscar Ads Still There for the Buying
description: Another reason that the Academy moved to 10 best-picture nominees this year was to boost TV ratings, but if the sale of commercial time is any indication, it may not pay off. Ad Age reports that the price of commercials during the Oscar telecast is essentially the same as it was in 2009, between $1.3 million and $1.5 million for a 30-second spot. Last years Oscar telecast cost advertisers around $1.4 million for a 30-second ad, down significantly from 2008, when a 30-second spot commanded as much as $1.82 million, Brian Steinberg writes. (For comparison, a Super Bowl spot will cost up to $3 million this year, though its advertisers are also grappling with the economy.)

title: Defend the Realm
description: Introduction: The Origins of the Secret Service Bureau

title: MGMs Search for a Buyer Is Extended
description: MGM has gained additional concessions from its lenders to allow it to continue to seek a buyer. The studio, crumbling under the weight of almost $4 billion in debt, can now skip interest payments until March 31. This is the second time MGM has asked to skip payments. Initially, lenders had agreed to let the studio bypass September, October and November. Then it sought and won an extension until Jan. 31.

title: Crash Course
description: Chapter 1: Where the Weak Are Killed and Eaten

title: The Selling of the American Economy
description: Chapter 1

title: Visual Learning: The Lend Me a Tenor Poster
description: When the Quaker Oats company decided its namesake logo  the behatted fellow who has been the face of its oat products since 1877  was too heavy and pasty-faced for todays health-conscious consumer, the company hired the illustrator Robert Rodriguez to give their man a makeover.

title: The Diarist of a Scene That Never Gets Old
description: PERHAPS it is the pumpkin-colored sweater he wears, a choice better suited to an eccentric uncle than a New York gossip columnist. Or maybe it is the way his round glasses compete with his arched eyebrows and rubbery grin. But one way or another, Michael Musto  who has chronicled the lives of drag queens, club kids, and an array of freaks and celebrities for The Village Voice for 25 years  still turns heads.

title: Sunday Preview
description: In Tokyo, ramen is more than a bowl of brothy noodles  it is an everypersons staple that inspires passion among Japanese and foreigners alike. Matt Gross, who writes the Frugal Traveler column, slurps his way through the citys ramen joints in search of the perfect bowl.

title: Couture Scorecard | Chanel Wins!
description: Repurposed pajamas, Janus-faced models and anti-Bolshevik iconography, oh my! Spring/summer 2010 couture collections werent your grandmothers couture. Well, not quite. After John Gallianos beautiful elegy in duchesse satin at the house of Dior on Monday, the heat was on to see who would be the new standard-bearer of (real-world-relevant) French chic in the post-Lacroixian era. As ever, Scorecard exhaustively records the critics votes. The verdict? In his 54th couture collection for a little house on the rue Cambon, Karl Lagerfeld sealed the deal for a new New Look  seamlessly. Are you surprised?

title: When Phones Are Just Too Smart
description: IF Caroline Cuas iPhone looked anything like her closet, where she keeps her dozens of pairs of shoes, she would have screen after screen of applications.

title: Jobless Turn to Family for Help
description: WARRENTON, Ore.  After Jean Ley lost her job as a mental health counselor in June 2008, she quickly realized how limited her options were. She had little savings. Unemployment benefits were not going to be enough to pay her bills. She was at risk of losing her home here on the Oregon coast.

title: Beef Bowl Economics
description: TOKYO  The broiled meat is tender and the rice is silky-smooth. But as Japans economic recovery falters, beef bowls have come to symbolize one of its most pressing woes: deflation.

title: Still Coolly in Control of Her Life and Songs
description: As Suzanne Vega took the stage of the Allen Room on Thursday evening, it seemed almost unimaginable that 25 years have passed since she released her first album. Reed slim and showing few signs of age, Ms. Vega cuts almost exactly the same figure at 50  that of a poised, slightly diffident, slightly aloof bohemian waif exuding an innate regality  that she did at 25.

title: Calling All Cabbies: Remove Device From Ear. Now.
description: The citys latest attempt to separate cab drivers from their cellphones began with a crackdown on Friday.

title: Buying Begins at Sundance, but Gingerly
description: LOS ANGELES  The acquisition market at the Sundance Film Festival is showing signs of life again, but both buyers and sellers say the game has changed  and likely for the better for the future of independent cinema.

title: Locals Mostly, for Now
description: THE Lower East Side has become a destination for those from other boroughs, other towns and other nations who seek a few hours of Manhattan life. On a recent Saturday night, on Rivington Street between Essex and Ludlow, it was easy to find people from Queens, Brooklyn, Staten Island, England and Germany. It was harder to find a local resident.

title: When Hippos Are Muses for Choreographers
description: Its strange to think that film animation (though its definitions and dates of origin vary) is now in its second century: it still seems a young art form. Something in its nature seems to prompt brightness of energy and rhythm. Though several of the latest experiments in it may be both fanciful and forgettable, they dont seem markedly decadent or mannerist.

title: Gates Foundation to Double Spending on Vaccines
description: Endorsing vaccines as the worlds most cost-effective public health measure, Bill and Melinda Gates said Friday that their foundation would more than double its spending on them over the next decade, to at least $10 billion.

title: Weir and Animal Rights Group Continue Feud
description: Friends of Animals, the international animal rights group based in Connecticut, is not happy with the figure skater Johnny Weir  again. And this time its not because he wears fur.

title: MGMs Search for a Buyer Is Extended
description: From Brooks Barnes at Media Decoder:

title: Panoramas: Views From Haiti
description: Scenes of life in Haiti as it recovers from January's devastating earthquake.

title: Abandon All Poetry, but Enter Hell With an Attitude
description: Theres a new edition of Dantes Inferno thats recently begun appearing in bookstores. Same words. Different cover. Its got a big picture of a muscular fellow in a spiky crown and an overline that says, The literary classic that inspired the epic video game.

title: Correction: Where the Gizmos Fizzled and the Gin Fizzed
description: The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about a building on West 56th Street in Manhattan that was passed over for landmark designation, described incorrectly the electrical treatment used by Dr. William J. Morton, the first resident of the building, to treat a patient for scarlet fever in 1893. The doctor sat the patient on a chair insulated from the ground by glass balls and applied thousands of volts to the chair and then modified the electric fields by waving a grounded rod around her head and body. He did not pass thousands of volts of electrical current around her body.

title: A Woman With Questions, Trying to Tell a Story
description: Julie Bours Why Now? begins with a narrative and ends with a dance. The question in the title, though its meaning remains somewhat vague, refers to a woman who is on the brink of a life-altering change.

title: Correction: 2010: The Year of the Renter?
description: An article last Sunday about new rental units coming online this year in New York City misstated the role Rose Associates has with two buildings in Brooklyn, 184 Kent Street and 34 Berry Street. It is marketing the buildings, not managing them. The article also misstated the title Robert Scaglion holds at the company. He is the senior managing director of residential marketing, not the managing director.

title: Scallop Gumbo
description: Mark Bittman prepares a version of New Orleans-style gumbo with scallops, peppers and a homemade roux.

title: No Oxymoron: A Lighter Gumbo
description: GUMBO, the Southern stew, is like many regional dishes: there are nearly as many interpretations as there are cooks. Most include the common Louisiana trinity of vegetables: green peppers, celery and onion.

title: Walls Can Talk
description: AS the saying goes, there are eight million stories in the naked city. But sometimes whats more telling is all that those souls leave behind. The remnants of humanity live on in the simple flourishes, banal trappings, shadows cast and layers of paint that decorate the citys walls.

title: On Assignment: Deeper Into the Depths
description: Ozier Muhammad is one of the Times staff photographers covering the aftermath of the earthquake in Haiti. His was the memorable picture of desperate people at a food distribution site that ran at the top of the front page on Wednesday. (He was also among earliest contributors to Lens, with his narrated slide show, Ozier Muhammads Harlem.) On Tuesday evening, Mr. Muhammad spoke by telephone with James Estrin. The interview has been condensed somewhat and edited for clarity.

title: Avatar Faces Traffic Jam at 3-D Screens
description: LOS ANGELES  Will it soon be time for 20th Century Foxs Avatar to surrender the 3-D stage? Walt Disney Studios certainly thinks so.

title: Inhabiting a Piece of Art: Its Not Always So Pretty
description: Heartfelt, thought-provoking and at times hilariously funny, the 2008 documentary film Koolhaas Houselife made Ila Beka and Louise Lemoine cult figures in the European architecture world. A look at the difficulties of living with an architectural masterpiece  one that was designed by Rem Koolhaas for Ms. Lemoines paraplegic father  it touched a nerve with those who have always been suspicious of the gap between the idealism of many architects and the realities of everyday life.

title: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 29
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City. Subjects include a church service for Haiti earthquake victims, a 57-year veteran of the Metropolitan Opera, and a robbery and murder on Madison Avenue.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 29
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: U.S. Approval of Taiwan Arms Sales Angers China
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has approved an arms sales package to Taiwan worth more than $6 billion, a move that has enraged China and may complicate President Obamas effort to enlist Beijings cooperation on Iran.

title: Chinas Zeal for Avatar Crowds Out Confucius
description: BEIJING  A Hollywood vision of the future is testing the Chinese governments preference for a piece of the countrys past.

title: The Symphony as a Vessel to Visit Other Worlds
description: The British composer Gustav Holst was an astrology buff when he composed his most famous work, The Planets, in 1914-16. His portraits of the planets were inspired by their mythological names and astrological associations. The Earth is not included because the suite is about what the seven other planets (Pluto had not yet been discovered) meant to earthlings. What the planets might actually be like was not the point.

title: The Many Permutations of Parents
description: Its tempting to say that watching A Family Is a Family Is a Family: A Rosie ODonnell Celebration is like drowning in a vat of syrup. But you could never actually drown in a vat of this program. Because its too shallow.

title: Sharing the Spotlight
description: JUSTIN TRANTER, the leggy, bleached-blond singer of Semi Precious Weapons, ended his bands set this month at Radio City Music Hall by turning a frenzied cartwheel and shouting the name of an old friend from the New York party scene, a girl who opened for his glam-rock group years ago. I say Lady, you say Gaga! he yelled. Lady! he screamed. Gaga! shrieked 6,000 or so tweens in platinum wigs, men in sequined vests and other, less fabulous, civilians.

title: Its a Family Affair: Sly Stone Sues Manager
description: Sly Stone, below, has filed a lawsuit against his longtime manager, Jerry Goldstein, saying that Mr. Goldstein defrauded him of tens of millions of dollars in royalties for more than 20 years and that he registered a trademark for the name Sly and the Family Stone without permission. In the suit, filed on Thursday in Los Angeles County Superior Court, Sly Stone (whose real name is Sylvester Stewart) and another former manager, Ken Roberts, request an accounting of royalties and unspecified financial damages that their lawyers estimate at $20 million to $30 million. On Thursday, Jay M. Coggan, Mr. Goldsteins lawyer, said that the case was without merit, and that the accusations had been made before. He said Sly Stone and his bandmates had given written approval for the trademark, and added: Mr. Stewart would like to rewrite history. He would like to get everything back even though he owes money.

title: Seattle Symphony Agrees on Contract
description: The Seattle Symphonys musicians and management have agreed on a contract after contentious negotiations that included a strike authorization. The agreement, which was announced on Thursday and requires ratification by both sides, includes a 5 percent pay cut through August with a restoration of the cut by early 2011 and a 1.5 percent raise at the beginning of the 2011-12 season. The players also agreed to donate $2,010 each, or $168,840, back to the orchestra. The symphonys minimum wage is $78,750, not including the reduction, although most of the musicians earn more than that. The concessions by the players are in line with moves at many orchestras around the country in the recession.

title: Whats a Super Bowl Without a Wager and Some Art Trash Talk?
description: Its not only mayors and inveterate gamblers who place bets on the Super Bowl  art museums do, too. The Times-Picayune of New Orleans reported that the New Orleans Museum of Art and the Indianapolis Museum of Art have placed a friendly wager on the outcome of the big game on Feb. 7: if the New Orleans Saints win, the Indianapolis museum will send The Fifth Plague of Egypt  that is, the landscape from its collection painted by J.M.W. Turner in 1800  to the New Orleans museum, which gets to hang it for three months. If the Indianapolis Colts prevail, the New Orleans institution will send the painting Ideal View of Tivoli, a 1644 work by Claude Lorrain, to Indianapolis for three months. The Times-Picayune said the bet was instigated by Tyler Green, who writes the Modern Art Notes blog for artsjournal.com, and who helped egg on some tongue-in-cheek trash talk between the museums directors. When E. John Bullard, the New Orleans museum director, offered to wager a valuable Renoir, his Indianapolis counterpart, Maxwell Anderson, dismissed it as a sentimental blancmange. Mr. Bullard replied: I am amused that Renoir is too sweet for Indianapolis. Does this mean that those Indiana corn farmers have simpler tastes?

title: Healthy Night for Bones
description: With CBS, ABC, and NBC showing mostly reruns, Fox won a rare Thursday night ratings victory. At 8 p.m., Foxs Bones (with Emily Deschanel and David Boreanaz, above) earned the nights largest audience with 12.4 million viewers according to Nielsens estimates, outperforming the ABC legal drama The Deep End (6 million) and CBSs special Live for the Moment (4.7 million). At 9 p.m., Foxs Fringe delivered a season-best 8.9 million viewers, finishing just behind a rerun of CSI (9.1 million) on CBS. CBS ranked second for the night, and ABC was third with reruns of Greys Anatomy (5.3 million) and Private Practice (4.3 million), while NBC ranked fourth with repeats of its comedy lineup.

title: Performers Plan More Efforts for Haiti
description: Entertainment personalities are continuing their efforts to raise awareness and money for the earthquake relief effort in Haiti. On Thursday, BET Networks said that it would hold a benefit concert and celebrity telethon for charity organizations to be presented on several cable channels next Friday night. The event, SOS Saving Ourselves  Help for Haiti, will take place at the American Airlines Arena in Miami and will be hosted by Queen Latifah, right; Sean Combs, known as Diddy; and Pharrell Williams. It is to be shown from 8 to 10 p.m. Eastern time on BET, MTV, VH1 and the Centric channel, with proceeds going to organizations including Yle Haiti, CARE, Project Medishare and Childrens Safe Drinking Water. A full lineup of artists for the concert has not been announced, but Wyclef Jean, the Haitian-born musician and founder of Yle Haiti, is expected to perform. Billboard reported that Simon Cowell, the American Idol host and music impresario, was planning a Feb. 7 digital release for an all-star charity recording of the R.E.M. song Everybody Hurts. Among the performers are Mariah Carey, Rod Stewart, Miley Cyrus, Michael Bubl, Jon Bon Jovi, James Blunt and Leona Lewis. Proceeds are to go to the Helping Haiti fund of Britains Sun newspaper and the Disasters Emergency Committee. A CD release was planned for Feb. 8.

title: Obama Photos at Schomburg Center
description: The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture will mark Black History Month with two major new exhibitions: one features photographs of President Obamas first year in the White House; the other showcases watercolors by Jerry Pinkney that depict people and events in African-American history from colonial times to the Voting Rights Act of 1965. On view together under the theme of 365 Days: 390 Years in the Making, the two exhibitions will be on display Feb. 5 through April 18. President Barack Obama: The First Year, features 77 photographs by Pete Souza, the chief White House photographer for Mr. Obama. African-American Journey to Freedom, brings together 35 watercolors by Mr. Pinkney, an award-winning artist and illustrator.

title: Pen and Brush Group Finds a Buyer
description: Pen and Brush, a nonprofit space in Greenwich Village for public exhibitions and performances, has found a buyer for its historic town house on East 10th Street, its executive director, Janice Sands, said on Friday. The sale has yet to be completed, Ms. Sands said. The buyer, Heirloom Trust, offered $13 million; the asking price was $13.5 million. On Wednesday, members of Pen and Brush voted to approve the sale. The organization determined that the 1848 building, its home of more than 80 years, was no longer suited to its mission and that repairs would be too costly. It has found new space on East 22nd Street, between Broadway and Park Avenue South. Ms. Sands said the new site, on which Pen and Brush is still in negotiations, offers about three times the current exhibition space.

title: Sri Lankan Police Raid Defeated Opposition Candidates Office
description: Sri Lankas quarter-century-long civil war may have ended, but there is no peace between the two rivals in Tuesdays presidential contest. Police raided opposition candidate Sarath Fonsekas campaign headquarters on Friday, seizing computer equipment and arresting 15 members of his staff.

title: The Evolving Vision of a Belgian Auteur
description: CHANTAL AKERMAN IN THE SEVENTIES

title: A Whirligig of Jazz, Generating Electricity
description: Hiromi Uehara, the pint-size piano dynamo who performs under her first name, has a penchant for brisk bedazzlement and hyper-articulated drama. That much has been true since she appeared on the radar six or seven years ago at the helm of a neon-lighted fusion band. Lately it has been just as true in drier, leaner settings.

title: Asking the Whole County to Embrace a War Story
description: THOUSANDS of Westchester residents will be reading aloud  from the same story  as the countys third Big Read gets under way on Feb. 6.

title: G.O.P. Waters Down Purity Test for Its Candidates
description: HONOLULU The Republican National Committee today approved a watered-down resolution designed to deal with a demand by conservative committee members that Republican candidates agree to support a list of conservative positions as a condition of receiving financial support from the party.

title: Type-A-Plus Students Chafe at Grade Deflation
description: When Princeton University set out six years ago to corral galloping grade inflation by putting a lid on As, many in academia lauded it for taking a stand on a national problem and predicted that others would follow.

title: Democrats Eye Insurers Antitrust Exemption
description: If Democrats break down their major health care legislation into components that could be approved separately, the first bill up for consideration could be a proposal to end the exemption from federal antitrust laws that insurers have enjoyed since 1945.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: SEWARD PARK is a huge residential co-op with a huge car problem. Street parking is almost nonexistent, and although the complex has 400 parking spots at Clinton and Grand Streets, there are roughly 500 people on the waiting list. So officials at the co-op arranged with Hertz to keep two cars on hand for hourly rentals through Connect by Hertz. Last week, a gray Prius and a cute red Smart Car took their designated spots in a driveway on Clinton Street. Residents register and pay online for the cars, which can be used for a quick errand or a weekend trip for about $10 an hour, including gas and limited mileage. Seward Park residents get a slight discount, but the cars are available to the public, said Michael Tumminia, president of the co-ops board. Its a fantastic way for our people to own a car without owning a car, Mr. Tumminia said.

title: Hear That? Its the Silent City
description: Frdric Fekkai, 51, knew he wanted to be a sculptor when he was a boy in Aix-en-Provence. He just never imagined that hair would be his medium. A session with Mr. Fekkais shears in his Fifth Avenue salon costs $750; today, he mostly oversees his various salons and his line of hair and body products. On Sundays he retreats to his Upper East Side duplex or his farm in Millbrook, N.Y., with his wife, Shirin von Wulffen, 35, and their 10-month-old daughter, Cecilia. Mr. Fekkais son from a previous marriage, Alexandre, 15, visits on breaks from boarding school.

title: Catholics Reel as a Diocese Whittles Its Parishes
description: DEPTFORD TOWNSHIP, N.J.

title: Americas Economy Expanded.  Did Yours?
description: The United States economy grew at its fastest pace in over six years at the end of 2009, announces The Timess Catherine Rampell, Gross domestic product expanded at an annual rate of 5.7 percent in the fourth quarter, after growing at an annualized rate of 2.2 percent in the previous quarter  the strong growth in the fourth quarter capped a year of the biggest contraction since 1946, when the country was still cooling off from World War II.

title: The City, From Wartime Grit to Modern Soullessness
description: THE most famous images of World War II-era New York capture the celebrations in Times Square at the conflicts end. But what was the city like during the war itself? Lorraine B. Diehl, who has written books about Pennsylvania Station and the Horn & Hardart Automat, now weighs in with an answer in Over Here: New York City During World War II (Smithsonian Books, $26.99).

title: The Week Ahead: Jan. 31  Feb. 6
description: Dance

title: Pat Metheny in Performance
description: Pat Metheny and the Orchestrion perform an excerpt from the album, "Expansion."

title: Double Dipping Helps Resolve Her Indecision
description: THE test of a dip is what happens when the chips and crudits run out.

title: Italian With a Zeal for the Elemental
description: GO for the tasting menu, a friend told me. And try not to sit by the door.

title: The Nuclear Option Is Yours
description: Some of the Buffalo wings at Atomic Wings in Jersey City are fiery hot, as you might expect, but others are sticky sweet. Theres a wide spectrum of spice at this franchise of the New York City chain, which also serves chicken fingers, nachos, wraps and burgers, among other items.

title: Pete Seeger Halts Banjo Head Auction
description: Where have all the bidders gone?

title: Reaching Holden Caulfields Grandchildren
description: Reading J.D. Salingers The Catcher in the Rye was a rite of passage for generations of teenagers who saw in Holden Caulfield, the high school truant, an enemy of adult phoniness and hypocrisy. The novel, as Charles McGrath wrote in Mr. Salingers obituary, attained cult status in mid-20th century America for its portrayal of adolescence and its fierce if alienated sense of morality and distrust of the adult world.

title: Creative Cuisine and a Copper Dcor
description: CU29 has been brightening the South Shore dining scene since it opened in Sayville in mid-November. Its name combines the symbol for copper (CU) on the periodic table of elements with its atomic number (29). It is a reference to semiconductors; copper is widely used in their manufacture, and the restaurants owner, Manny Lakios, works in a related business.

title: Crepes, Savory or Sweet
description: At the six-month-old Tasty Crepes in the Country Glen Center in Carle Place, you place your order at the counter. Then you can watch the cooks ladle and swirl the batter on one of six flat round griddles. The crepe is flipped, filled and folded in minutes.

title: Obama Outlines Plan to Increase Employment
description: WASHINGTON  In proposing a one-year, $33 billion tax credit for small businesses, the Obama administration is simultaneously seeking to stimulate hiring by reducing payroll taxes and to turn its attention to a constituency that has historically been associated with Republicans.

title: Spaghettis Place in the Neighborhood
description: NELLOS LA CANTINA in Milford is an old-style, Italian-American family restaurant. The kitchen whips up the usual suspects  sauted broccoli rabe, veal alla francese, lasagna, baked ziti, spaghetti with meatballs  in portions that are abundant, tasty and affordable.

title: Making Dessert the First, or Perhaps Only, Course
description: A sign behind the counter at the Black Forest Bakery and Cafe has just one word on it: Indulge. Given the tempting treats showcased there, it would be hard not to.

title: In Tough Times, Interesting Opportunities for Diners
description: The buildings that line the upper village stretch of Old Post Road South in Croton-on-Hudson are pretty dark at night. The delis, liquor store and offices typically are not open once the daylight disappears. But one evening a month, the street comes to life.

title: Slow and Steady at Sundance
description: Manohla Dargis covered the artistry of Sundance and now Brooks Barnes takes a look at the business side. He reports in The New York Times that deals are trickling out of the festival, which officially ends this weekend, though not at the same pace that they once were.

title: Gambling on an Even Trump Split, and Winning
description: There are two unusual features to the diagramed deal, one of which will not be apparent.

title: Louis R. Harlan, Historian of Booker T. Washington, Dies at 87
description: Louis R. Harlan, whose definitive two-volume biography of Booker T. Washington convincingly embraced its subjects daunting complexities and ambiguities and won both the Bancroft Prize and the Pulitzer Prize, died on Jan. 22 in Lexington, Va. He was 87.

title: Rise Seen in Deaths From Pneumonia and Flu
description: Deaths from pneumonia and influenza across the country rose sharply in the weekly flu report released Friday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, but a spokesman for the agency called it merely a blip were checking out.

title: Sesame Street: 1 2 3 Count With Me
description: Ernie teaches Humphrey to count at The Furry Arms hotel. (Excerpt)

title: Two Charged in Deaths of Immigrants at Sea
description: LOS ANGELES  Two Mexican men have been indicted on federal charges arising from the deaths of two people who drowned this month when a boat overloaded with migrants capsized off the San Diego coast, the first known fatalities in a recent spate of maritime smuggling.

title: Aldrich Celebrates Five Exhibits at Once
description: UPON entering the Leir Atrium at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum, visitors will find themselves surrounded by images from inside an enormous human eye. The eye belongs to Jo Yarrington, an artist based in Norwalk and New York City who created the installation, which she calls Ocular Visions, using floor-to-ceiling color transparencies of photographs taken of the inside of her eye with sophisticated optometric equipment. Video animation of Ms. Yarringtons eye captured by similar equipment is being projected in the Aldrichs camera obscura.

title: Opening Doors With New and Old
description: THE dancer and choreographer Nai-Ni Chen tossed around terms like movement vocabulary at a recent rehearsal in Harlem for her companys coming performances at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark. And it was easy getting her to talk about the importance of educating audiences through modern works as notable for their boldness as their beauty. But ultimately, Ms. Chen wants the performances of her troupe, the Nai-Ni Chen Dance Company, founded in Fort Lee in 1988, to be accessible.

title: Not Just About Quilts, but About a Post-Plantation Society
description: Gees Bend is not just about homemade quilts so beautiful that they ended up on the walls of the Whitney Museum of American Art. And it is not just about the poor, culturally isolated black women who made them.

title: Tesla Motors Plans Public Offering to Raise $100 Million
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Tesla Motors, the electric car company in Silicon Valley, said on Friday that it had filed plans to sell shares to the public.

title: Singing Songs for Young Brains
description: The childrens musician Roger Day has nothing against school vacations. They are, in fact, what will allow some students to attend his concerts at six Long Island libraries Feb. 16 to 19, when many schools will be closed for winter recess.

title: U.S. Government Plans to Reduce Its Energy Use
description: WASHINGTON  The federal government will take steps to cut its energy use and reduce its heat-trapping emissions by 28 percent by 2020, compared with 2008 levels, the White House announced on Friday.

title: China Moves to Protect Owners of Homes Set to Be Razed
description: BEIJING  Moving to address a major source of social strife, the Chinese government says it plans to toughen regulations significantly to protect and compensate homeowners whose dwellings are singled out for demolition and redevelopment.

title: China Insists That Its Steps on Climate Be Voluntary
description: BEIJING  As a Sunday target date approaches for countries to submit to the United Nations their plans for fighting climate change, China is banding together with other major developing nations to stress that only the wealthier countries need to make internationally binding commitments.

title: New Rules Promise Better Mental Health Coverage
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration issued new rules on Friday that promise to improve insurance coverage of mental health care for more than 140 million people insured through their jobs.

title: Secret Videos Aired in Jersey City Corruption Trial
description: NEWARK  To understand the irrepressible oiliness of Solomon Dwek, one need only know this: as a young religious school student, he once paid his math teacher a $50 bribe for a passing grade.

title: For Haitians in the U.S. Illegally, Some Help
description: Two years ago, at age 17, Stephanie Germain arrived in New York from Haiti, overstayed her tourist visa and slipped into the parallel universe of the illegal immigrant. While she managed to learn English, graduate from high school and enroll in Queensborough Community College, her immigration status ensured that she would have to live largely out of the governments view.

title: Mark Bartkiewicz and Scott De Angioletti
description: Mark Bartkiewicz and Scott De Angioletti were joined in a civil union on Friday at the Hudson County Administration Building in Jersey City. Judge Barry P. Sarkisian, a superior court judge of the State of New Jersey, officiated.

title: Cardinals Warner Quits After 12 Unlikely Years
description: Kurt Warner took a job stocking grocery store shelves in Iowa after his first rejection from the National Football League, just one of the stops on Warners unorthodox path to stardom. There was no stint at a top college or selection in a high draft round. Instead, Warner wound through the backwaters of the Arena Football League and the now-defunct N.F.L. Europe.

title: U.S. Drops Plan for a 9/11 Trial in New York City
description: The Obama administration on Friday gave up on its plan to try the Sept. 11 plotters in Lower Manhattan, bowing to almost unanimous pressure from New York officials and business leaders to move the terrorism trial elsewhere.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: An Attempt to Revive the Lost Art of Apology
description: IM sorry that my column hasnt appeared for several weeks (I was on book leave). Im sorry if you missed reading it. And Im sorry if you didnt notice.

title: Obama Acts to Ease Way to Construct Reactors
description: The Obama administration moved vigorously on two fronts Friday to promote nuclear power, proposing a tripling of federal loan guarantees for new projects and appointing a high-level commission to study what to do with nuclear waste.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 958 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Friday:

title: Final Family Night Before a Father Is Locked Up
description: Steven Rondos pulled into his driveway in Ridgewood, N.J., ahead of his family on Thursday, with a busy night and an early morning ahead:

title: Michigan: Shrine Circus Loses Home
description: The state said it would not rent a building on the recently shuttered Michigan State Fair grounds for March performances of the 103-year-old Detroit Shrine Circus. The decision is likely to mean the end of the circus, the nations oldest Shrine circus, which had been held at the Michigan State Fair coliseum since 1925. It lost that venue last fall when Michigan decided it could no longer afford to operate the 160-year-old fair, also the oldest continuously operating state fair in the nation.

title: What to Watch: Federer vs. Murray
description: When Rafael Nadal withdrew from Wimbledon last summer, the tennis world wondered who would emerge as Roger Federers competition for major titles while Nadal healed his ailing knees. Andy Roddick came achingly close in his epic five-set loss to Federer at Wimbledon. At the United States Open, Juan Martin del Potro twice came back from a set down to take the title from Federer, proving that the worlds best tennis player wasnt invincible. On Sunday in the mens final at the Australian Open, Federer will take on another challenger in Andy Murray, the shrewd and talented Scot.

title: In Casinos, New York Faces Uncertain Returns
description: Gov. David A. Paterson announced Friday that he had selected a casino operator for the Aqueduct racetrack in Queens. It would be the ninth racetrack casino to open in the state since 2001.

title: In Davos, Bankers Look for Closer Bond With Policy Makers
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  As a fresh snowfall melted slowly outside the Davos Congress Center, officials and bankers made plans to try to thaw their relationship.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: May a Thousand Job Tax Credit Proposals Bloom
description: President Obama today filled in the details of his proposed job creation tax credit.

title: As Citys Charter Schools Expand, State Remains Deadlocked on Future Growth
description: Next year will be the biggest year of growth yet for New Yorks charter schools, with 29 due to open in New York City alone. But Seth Andrew, the founder of Democracy Prep, a successful charter middle school in Harlem, is already starting to turn his focus to another state. The political environment in New York, he fears, is shifting.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Barclays Seeks Dismissal of Lehman Estate Suit
description: Barclays Capital asked a federal judge on Friday to dismiss a lawsuit contending that it improperly reaped a $5 billion windfall when it bought Lehman Brothers core banking operations during the 2008 financial crisis.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Sondra Goldschein and David Stern
description: Sondra Goldschein and David Stern were married Saturday evening at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, N.Y. Rabbi Michael A. White officiated.

title: Jessica Manzi, Tim Driscoll
description: Jessica Angela Manzi and Tim Driscoll were married Saturday at the Casa Marina Resort in Key West, Fla. Carmen J. Rodriguez, a Florida notary public, officiated.

title: Salingers Last Known Manhattan Home
description: It is a beige, 19-story building on the corner of Second Avenue. It was designed by Emery Roth and is considered one of the first luxury high-rises on the Upper East Side.

title: An Ordinary Man: Both His Wives Say So
description: Bigamy is a game being played strictly for laughs in the jovial production of the British farce Run for Your Wife, by Ray Cooney, now at the John W. Engeman Theater in Northport.

title: Judge, Im Telling You, the Car Was Grandmas
description: Traffic court.

title: Robyn Weinstein and Matt Goldich
description: Robyn Weinstein and Matt Goldich were married Saturday evening in Wilmington, Del. Rabbi Josh Snyder officiated at the Hotel du Pont.

title: Former Skating Champion Wins a Big Olympic Tuneup
description: Mao Asada, the former world champion figure skater who struggled last season, has gotten her grove back  and just in time for the Vancouver Olympics.

title: Russia: Test Flight of New Fighter Is Called a Success
description: The Russian military conducted the first successful flight of its new fifth-generation stealth fighter jet on Friday, Russian media reported. The Sukhoi T-50 prototype, the first completely new fighter built by Russia since the fall of the Soviet Union, took off from a base in the Far Eastern city of Komsomolsk-on-Amur and flew a 47-minute test run. The test, which was broadcast on Russian television, comes amid a series of failures of weapons systems that has shaken confidence in the nations military. Russian officials hope the new fighter will one day challenge the United States Air Forces F-22 Raptor, which first flew in 1997.

title: Emily Scharfman, David Menchel
description: Emily Bette Scharfman and David Menchel are to be married Sunday in Lawrence, N.Y. Rabbi Jordan D. Rosenberg will perform the ceremony at Temple Israel of Lawrence.

title: Off Script, Obama and the G.O.P. Vent Politely
description: BALTIMORE  President Obama denied he was a Bolshevik, the Republicans denied they were obstructionists and both sides denied they were to blame for the toxic atmosphere clouding the nations political leadership.

title: Ruling Could Halt Nuclear Project
description: A Texas judges ruling on Friday in a dispute over a proposed nuclear project may make it easier for one partner to withdraw, casting further doubt on whether the reactors will be built.

title: An Olympic Qualifier, but Not in Israels Eyes
description: Israel has its first Olympic qualifier in womens figure skating  but the countrys Olympic officials will not let her compete at the Vancouver Games.

title: Seeking to Give Children a Home of Their Own
description: Ten years ago, Veronica Hibbert found herself suddenly alone, raising four children and trying to maintain the familys home in the Baychester section of the Bronx, all on the small salary of a patient-care assistant at a local hospital. Her husband of 18 years had left, and child-support payments were not forthcoming.

title: Deep in Debt, Spain Cuts Spending by $70 Billion
description: MADRID  The Spanish government outlined far-reaching spending cuts on Friday to bring its sizable budget deficit under control, amid forecasts that the country would remain mired in recession for another year.

title: To California, Moon Junk Is State Treasure
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In one small step for preservation and one giant leap of logic, the official historical commission of California voted Friday to protect two small urine collection devices, four space-sickness bags and dozens of other pieces of detritus, all currently residing nearly a quarter of a million miles from the state.

title: Daughter of the Victim Testifies at a Murder Trial
description: After spending days battling her emotions in a courtroom gallery, Samantha Wells took center stage on Friday in the trial of the woman accused of murdering Mrs. Wellss mother, Linda Stein.

title: Archbishop of Canterbury Challenges Wall Street on Its Home Turf
description: For three days this week, the 104th archbishop of Canterbury told economists, theologians and others attending a Wall Street conference that the fat cats of the world were not necessarily bad people, just victims of a terrible misunderstanding.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 1 about a court decision to dismiss the indictment of former Blackwater security guards over a shooting in Baghdad in 2007 that left 17 Iraqis dead misstated, in some copies, the number of guards affected. It was five, not four. (The error was repeated in an article on Jan. 8 about the arrest of two other former guards for the company on murder charges from a shooting in Afghanistan last May.)

title: Giving Birth in Haiti
description: Haitians must wait in line to give birth in a tent in the wake of the earthquake that hit the country more than two weeks ago.

title: Portrait of Reality, as Told by Vick
description: Beginning on Tuesday, Black Entertainment Television will broadcast the first of a 10-part series featuring Michael Vick. The series is called Michael Vick Project.

title: From Marines, a Softer Approach
description: Marines have been financing local projects in an effort to build loyalty among the population.

title: Giving Life in a Land Overflowing With Pain
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Biology and the earthquake dictated that Roseline Antoine would give birth at 9:42 a.m. Thursday to a healthy baby girl who has no home but the street. The same irrevocable forces left Delva Venite naked a few feet away, in pain, waiting nearly a day for doctors to deal with the stillborn son inside her.

title: Black Priest Shares Past, Enlightening White Town
description: ASH GROVE, Mo.  When he moved back home here 12 years ago, the Rev. Moses Berry wanted to settle down to small-town life with his wife and two children. He did not intend to become a one-man racial reconciliation committee.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Jan. 12 about the effects of Europes prolonged cold weather misstated the initials of Frances state-owned rail operator, and a correction in this space on Jan. 20 misstated the operators full name. The operator is known as S.N.C.F., not S.C.N.F. And the initials stand for Socit Nationale des Chemins de Fer Franais  not for Socit national chemins de fer France.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Friday about the growing opposition among New York politicians to holding the trial of the accused Sept. 11 conspirators in Lower Manhattan misstated the political affiliation of Representative Peter T. King of New York, who on Wednesday introduced legislation to block civilian trials for the suspected plotters. He is a Republican, not a Democrat.

title: U.S. Suspends Haitian Airlift in Cost Dispute
description: MIAMI  The United States has suspended its medical evacuations of critically injured Haitian earthquake victims until a dispute over who will pay for their care is settled, military officials said Friday.

title: Corrections
description: The Reuters Breakingviews column on Thursday, about the lessons to carmakers in Toyotas recent problems, misstated Toyotas market status relative to that of General Motors. While Toyota is the top seller of vehicles globally, it is not the leader in the United States. G.M. remains No. 1 in the American market.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column on Jan. 22, about a changing approach in campaigns for self-improvement products, misidentified the company running a campaign for Nicorette gum. It is GlaxoSmithKline, not Johnson & Johnson. (Johnson & Johnson owns Nicorette, but licenses it to GlaxoSmithKline for sale in the United States market.)

title: Coaching Baseball Rookies for the Limelight
description: LEESBURG, Va.  Many of the 104 teenagers and young men who gathered at a resort here this month will soon be very rich, and some may be larger than life: household names, tabloid celebrities, possibly even worldwide brands.

title: 47 Down: Judging Point at a Dog Show
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  By definition, a clue is something that helps one arrive at a solution. In a Monday puzzle, a clue does just that. By the time we reach Saturday, however, the clues have been bathed in ambiguity. Erudition plays a bigger role, red herrings are strewn about and meanings are uncertain.

title: A Favorite Saint
description: NEW ORLEANS  The young woman behind the counter at Huevos, a Mid-City spot, took Tom Dempseys breakfast order Thursday morning and said, Could I get a first name?

title: Dogs Life (and Death) Is a Poignant Tale
description: Two grizzled denizens of the 84-unit apartment building at 115 West 86th Street died last weekend, Harry on Friday evening, and his compatriot Bix on Saturday. They were virtual centenarians. Both were wildly popular, highly visible and on a one-name basis with their piece of the Upper West Side: Harry for a debonair self-assurance reminiscent of Cary Grant, Bix for his diplomatic skills and soulful eyes.

title: Lottery Numbers
Prepping Players Through Comedy
description: During professional baseballs annual Rookie Career Development Program, actors performed skits illustrating various situations rookies might find themselves in. This one, written and acted by members of the Second City comedy troupe, takes place in a club back home, with three of the old gang:

title: Corrections
description: An essay on Tuesday about caring for a terminally ill parent gave an incorrect side effect for lithium, a drug given for bipolar disorder. Lithium was not responsible for the liver damage found in the writers father because the drug is filtered and excreted by the kidneys.

title: On the Street | Mad Plaid
description: This winter the optimists are holding their own with their bright, freshly colored lumberjack looks, although the traditional Paul Bunyan checks are still a force to be reckoned with.

title: Corrections
description: The Phys Ed column on Page 17 this weekend, about the ability of exercise to slow some aspects of aging, misidentifies the German city that is home to Saarland University Clinic, which has conducted studies on the life spans of human cells. It is Homburg, not Hamburg.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Jan. 20 about George Jellinek, the former music director of the New York radio station WQXR, misstated his age at the time he left his native Hungary. He was 19, not 18.

title: Obama Addresses House Republicans
description: A Q. and A. with the president was without precedent.

title: Corrections
description: EDITORS NOTE

title: Japans Elder Statesman Is Silent No Longer
description: TOKYO

title: Searching for Some Light Amid the Heat
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama squared off with House Republicans in a question-and-answer session on Friday, perhaps no issue was more contentious than health care. Among Mr. Obamas boldest assertions was that Democrats had put forward a mostly centrist plan and that Republicans attacked it as some Bolshevik plot.

title: Phil Mickelson Accused of Cheating at Torrey Pines
description: SAN DIEGO  A published report Friday, in which the PGA player Scott McCarron accused Phil Mickelson of cheating by using a square-grooved wedge, evoked the image of the Frankenstein monster rising from a musty tomb to lumber across the emerald fairways at Torrey Pines Golf Course.

title: G.O.P. Adopts Purity Pledge After Revisions
description: HONOLULU  The Republican National Committee on Friday approved a watered-down resolution designed to deal with a demand by conservative committee members that candidates agree to support a list of conservative positions as a condition of receiving financial support from the party.

title: City Schools May Get Fewer As
description: Months after handing out As and Bs to 97 percent of New York City elementary schools, education officials plan to change their methods for grading the citys public schools, making it harder to receive high marks.

title: Lawsuit Takes Aim at Trespassing Arrests in New York Public Housing
description: The relationship between the New York police and public housing residents has long been uneasy, but according to a lawsuit filed against the city and its housing authority this week, it is growing far worse, with many innocent people, including residents, ending up arrested on trespass charges that were later dismissed.

title: Multiple Meditations on the Duet
description: How precisely the human body can move, and yet how varied and ambiguous its meanings. A shoulder tucked forward under a chin, a palm planed and tilted just so, a raised foot rotating in minute degrees from a planted heel: we see everything and understand so little.

title: Riding on the the Main Line of Jazz
description: The trumpeter Jeremy Pelt has spent most of the last decade as a young exemplar, traveling the postbop continuum on his own steam, at his own pace. As a bandleader he has plunged headlong into funk and dipped a toe in chamber orchestration, but the larger theme of his output seeks a footing on the bedrock of jazz convention. Hes still finding good terrain to explore there, as he proved at Jazz Standard on Thursday night.

title: Showcase of Shot-Put Power Takes on a Main-Event Flair
description: Christian Cantwell, a 29-year-old shot-putter from Missouri with a scrub-brush goatee and the girth and temperament of a defensive tackle, ambled through a service corridor at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, dwarfing every sprinter, hurdler, vaulter and miler in his way.

title: Robert Joffe, Noted Lawyer, Dies at 66
description: Robert D. Joffe, a leading New York lawyer and partner at Cravath, Swaine & Moore who played a critical role in Time Inc.s $14 billion merger with Warner Communications, died in Manhattan on Thursday. He was 66.

title: Damon Remains Open to Possible Return to Yanks
description: The Yankees have been as emphatic as possible that Johnny Damon has ended his four-year run with the team. But as long as Damon remains unsigned, he continues to leave open the possibility that he could again be a Yankee.

title: Amazon Pulls Macmillan Books Over E-Book Price Disagreement
description: Update | 7:01 p.m. Amazon relents and is selling Macmillan books again.

title: Bits: Amazon Pulls Macmillan Books from Its Site
description: Amazon has pulled books published by Macmillan from its site in a disagreement between the online retailer and the publisher over the price of e-books. For the moment, Macmillan books are available on Amazon only when bought through third parties. Macmillan, like other publishers, has been wrangling with Amazon over the retailers insistence that all e-books for its Kindle device be priced at $9.99. Many publishers want to charge more, or at least have more control over prices for individual books. The dispute hit a new level this week when Apple introduced its new iPad device, which will have an iBooks application through which publishers will have more control over e-book prices. The full story is here.

title: As Big Ten Studies Expansion, Others Brace for Ripple Effects
description: When the Big Ten Conference announced last month that it was considering expansion, the college sports world began a high-stakes game of musical chairs that will be influenced by athletic performance, academic standing, geography and money. Several universities have begun to circle hopefully, lobbying, eyeing a potential seat in new conference alignments, wanting desperately to avoid being left out of the big-money alliances once the music stops.

title: Bloggingheads: The Unchanged Tone
description: Joshua Cohen, left, of Stanford University and Glenn Loury of Brown University debate President Obama's pledge to change Washington.

title: Murray Is One Left to Test Federer
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  So much for all the pretournament talk about how Roger Federer was distracted, aging and vulnerable at the Australian Open, and how 8 to 10 players were ready to knock him from his throne. After Federer filleted Jo-Wilfried Tsonga of France in straight sets, now there is only one: Andy Murray, the scrambling Scotsman.

title: Iran, After the Deadline
description: Iran has again proved to be a master at playing for time. Six months after a new diplomatic overture from Washington and its partners, Tehran has shown no interest in resolving the dispute over its nuclear program. It is time for President Obama and other leaders to ratchet up the pressure with tougher sanctions.

title: The Insurer vs. the Hospitals
description: A bitter dispute between one of the nations largest health insurers and a consortium of New York City hospitals illustrates the difficulties of controlling the ever-rising costs of medical care and insurance premiums. In this case, the insurer appears to be acting responsibly, if a bit heavy-handedly.

title: A Troubling Uptick
description: One of President Obamas worthier first-year achievements was to redirect federal sex-education financing from an abstinence-only approach to broader, more-effective programs that provide information to young people about contraceptives, pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases.

title: Hanging a For Sale Sign Over the Judiciary
description: As I read over last weeks aggressively wrong 5-to-4 Supreme Court decision greatly escalating the power of corporate and union money in elections, my thoughts turned to former Justice Sandra Day OConnor.

title: France Considers a Ban on the Burqa
description: To the Editor:

title: Heart-Rending Stories: The Children of Haiti
description: To the Editor:

title: J. D. Salinger: The Brilliance and the Silence
description: To the Editor:

title: Revising the Government of New York City
description: To the Editor:

title: Reforming Juvenile Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Benefits of a Soda Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Inconvenient Truth
description: Back last November. ... Wow, that seems like a long time ago. Health care was passing. Jay Leno was popular. Dinosaurs roamed the earth.

title: A Radical Treasure
description: I had lunch with Howard Zinn just a few weeks ago, and Ive seldom had more fun while talking about so many matters that were unreservedly unpleasant: the sorry state of government and politics in the U.S., the tragic futility of our escalation in Afghanistan, the plight of working people in an economy rigged to benefit the rich and powerful.

title: Lost in Translation
description: President Obamas State of the Union address soared  right over a familiar cliff.

title: The Pre-Postmodernist
description: Birmingham, England

title: Mets Add Josh Fogg
description: The Mets added the journeyman pitcher Josh Fogg, although it is not clear if he will be on the team when the season begins. Fogg, 33, has been with four teams in his major league career, mostly as a starter, although he pitched almost exclusively in relief for Colorado in 2009, compiling an 0-2 record with a 3.74 earned run average. The Mets also announced that they signed Fernando Tatis to a one-year deal. Tatis, 35, hit .282 for the Mets last season in a part-time role.

title: The Places They Go When Banks Say No
description: IN the glory days of the digital photo frame business, when his products were still a novelty and shoppers were flush with cash, getting a bank loan to manufacture them was a cinch, Michael Levy says.

title: Amazon Removes Macmillan Books
description: Amazon.com has pulled books from Macmillan, one of the largest publishers in the United States, in a dispute over the pricing on e-books on the site.

title: Wizards and Nets in One Unenchanted Evening
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  A photograph of Gilbert Arenas adorned the tickets that were distributed for Friday nights game between the Wizards and the Nets, an eerie reminder of an ugly incident that has stained the N.B.A.s reputation.

title: Nike Ads Loaded Image Hits Raw Spot for the N.B.A.
description: Just days after suspending Gilbert Arenas and Javaris Crittenton for the season for bringing pistols into the Washington Wizards locker room, the N.B.A. is facing the handgun issue again because of Nike.

title: Northern Ireland Power-Sharing Talks Go On
description: HILLSBOROUGH, Northern Ireland (Reuters)  Rival parties in Northern Ireland cast aside a Friday deadline set by the British and Irish prime ministers, negotiating into Saturday in an effort to avoid the collapse of their power-sharing government.

title: Full of Tricks, White Dazzles in the Superpipe
description: ASPEN, Colo.  With a run that included one trick that only a handful of riders can perform, and another that only he can perform, Shaun White won his third consecutive gold medal Friday in the Winter X Games superpipe.

title: For Suns Frye, a Big Improvement From Long Range
description: In his first four seasons, Channing Frye hit 20 career 3-pointers. This season, Frye has hit 114 and through Thursday was second in the league to the Knicks Danilo Gallinari (118) in 3-pointers made.

title: Families, Lost and Found
description: Agencies around the country are trying to get children out of foster care by uniting them with lost relatives.

title: Jane Jarvis, Player of Jazz and Mets Music, Dies at 94
description: Jane Jarvis, who brought a jazz sensibility to unlikely places as an organist for the New York Mets and a programmer for Muzak, died on Monday at the Lillian Booth Actors Home in Englewood, N.J. She was 94.

title: What Will the Jets Off-Season Bring?
description: On Thursday, four days after a stinging end to the Jets season in the A.F.C. championship game, General Manager Mike Tannenbaum held a news conference and gave some insight into the months ahead. With the possibility of an uncapped 2010 season, the off-season promises to be unpredictable. This time, though, the decisions by Tannenbaum and Rex Ryan will be given every benefit of the doubt.

title: Where Theres No Smoke, Altria Hopes Theres Fire
description: FOR years, Altria, home to Philip Morris and its popular Marlboro cigarette brand, was a corporate pariah blamed for the deaths of millions of people and sued for hundreds of billions of dollars by attorneys general in every state. After eventually acknowledging, like others in its industry, that cigarette smoking was, indeed, addictive and caused disease, Altria went a step further. It broke from the Big Tobacco pack and began supporting legislation that would ultimately put the company under the regulatory thumb of the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Back to School, as an Adjunct
description: IN this time of job insecurity, the question may have occurred to you: Should you consider part-time teaching as a way to improve your finances and expand your career opportunities?

title: Woman, 39, Is Killed in Hit and Run on Upper West Side
description: A 39-year-old woman was killed Friday night in a hit-and-run accident on the Upper West Side, the police said.

title: NBC Universal and Sony Television Reach Deal for Nate Berkus Show
description: After several sessions of all-night negotiations, NBC Universal and Sony Television concluded a deal late Friday night that will establish a home base of television stations for a new syndicated weekday show starring Nate Berkus, a design expert who rose to prominence as a regular guest on Oprah Winfreys talk show.

title: Are You a C.E.O. of Something?
description: This interview with Mark Pincus, founder and chief executive of Zynga, a provider of online social games, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Soldier, Broker and C.E.O.
description: I grew up in the Little Italy area of Hartford, in my grandparents four-family home. Im the oldest of six brothers.

title: When a Portfolio Is Red or Blue
description: YOURE likely to feel more confident about the economy when your political party is in power. Thats no surprise. But a new study has found that your feelings probably affect the way you invest your stock portfolio.

title: Classic Ad: Toyota Celica
description: Since theres probably not a whole lot of jumping for joy at Toyota these days, this weeks classic ad looks back to happier times for the company: namely the 1980s, when its reputation for quality and dependability  and its loyal customer base  was still being built. Toyotas signature ad campaign of the era was probably its long-running Oh What a Feeling series of commercials, each of which culminated with a satisfied Toyota customer leaping ecstatically into the air.

title: Editors Note
description: The Critical Shopper column on Jan. 14, about Lily et Cie in Los Angeles, referred to a dog as omnipresent at the store. That information was outdated and erroneous; according to the owner, the dog, a Lhasa apso named Trouble, died some time ago. The reference to the dog was based on earlier published accounts of the store and its owner. It should not have been included in the column without being verified.

title: The Spirit of Giving
description: Donors describe their reasons for giving to The Neediest Cases Fund campaign.

title: Shirley Bell Cole, the Voice of Little Orphan Annie, Dies at 89
